headline: A Bollywood Plot Thickened With Every Ingredient
text: A pumped-up example of the Bollywood school of More Is More, “Rowdy Rathore,” starring Akshay Kumar, has a little of everything, all executed in an exaggerated, playful style by the film’s director, Prabhudheva. There are fights, colorful songs and dances (the stick-in-your-head, drum-driven tunes are by Sajid and Wajid Ali), comedy, romance, a superstar item girl (Kareena Kapoor, who appears in one song) and a plot worthy of the old days of Hindi cinema.

headline: The Elusive Art of Moving Bodies Through Space
text: Is any art more elusive than choreography? What are the secret laws that make a structurally disparate work cohere as a stage world and a seemingly unified one fall apart? We ask a ballet to succeed in impossibly many ways: as body language and sociology; in its organization of time and space; in terms of movement-by-movement, narrativelike sense; and as an artist’s view of human energy. No wonder so few choreographers have won universal admiration.

headline: Outposts of the Empire
text: BERLIN

headline: Soho House Is Taking the Party Global
text: WHEN the London-based members-only social club Soho House opened a branch in New York’s meatpacking district almost a decade ago, it seemed to confer a sense of exclusivity and festivity to a neighborhood that was radically reinventing itself. Raucous parties were held at the rooftop pool, where an invitation to lunch made one feel puffed out with self-importance; Harvey Weinstein showed films privately in the screening room; attractive women tottered toward the entrance in Jimmy Choo shoes.

headline: Video: Green Garlic Basics
text: This week’s video and column are all about green garlic, the tender, immature stalks that are in season now for a few more weeks. In the video I show how to clean and slice it. In the column I give a recipe for green garlic salsa verde to serve with seared pork.

headline: Johan de Nysschen, Audi of America President, Resigns From Post
text: On a day when Audi of America announced record-setting sales for a 17th consecutive month, Johan de Nysschen, an architect of that success and the president of the division for more than seven years, announced his resignation.

headline: Andy Samberg Confirms He’s Leaving ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: In one of his last appearances on the season finale of “Saturday Night Live,” a rapping Andy Samberg traded a rhyme with Chris Parnell that seemed loaded with underlying meaning: “On these New York streets I hone my fake rap penmanship / That’s how it began, and that’s how I’m-a finish it.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Piracy Negotiations and Apple’s Smart Move
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: Jobs Report Makes Federal Reserve More Likely to Act
text: WASHINGTON — The odds surely increased Friday that the Federal Reserve will ride again to the rescue of the faltering economic recovery, making borrowing a little cheaper for a little longer, as it has done repeatedly over the last four years.

headline: Jobs Remarks: A Comparison
text: With the May jobs report dominating headlines on Friday, Mitt Romney and President Obama tried to spin the numbers to fit into their campaign messages.

headline: Rielle Hunter to Publish a Memoir This Month
text: Only one day after former Senator John Edwards escaped conviction in federal court on six corruption charges, Rielle Hunter announced some news of her own: she has written a memoir.

headline: Rangel Attacks Process That Led to His Censure
text: As questions of ethics shadow Representative Charles B. Rangel in what has become a challenging bid for re-election, he is pushing for an examination of the House proceedings that led to his censure.

headline: Authentic Taste of Italy, Exported by 2 Brothers
text: THE owners didn’t attend culinary school, and I’ve never seen the word artisanal on their menu. Still, if I were choosing where to have lunch in northern New Jersey, I’d choose Queen Margherita Trattoria, in Nutley.

headline: After a Day of Bad Economic News, an Invitation From Anna Wintour
text: Friday was a day of grim economic news — a jobs report that put an exclamation point on the financial struggles of average Americans.

headline: Reviewing the Ferrari FF
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews the 2012 Ferrari FF, the all-wheel-drive shooting brake intended for the Ferrari driver with groceries and passengers to haul.

headline: Interactive Comparison of Obama and Romney on the Jobs Report
text: With the May jobs report dominating the headlines on Friday, Mitt Romney and President Obama tried to spin the numbers to fit with their campaign messages. Mr. Romney went on an interview on CNBC, and Mr. Obama delivered a speech at a factory in Golden Valley, Minn.

text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,979 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Old Hands at Italian Add a Tex-Mex Outpost
text: CASUAL Tex-Mex restaurants are ubiquitous on Long Island, but the lively cantina Del Fuego, which opened in St. James in November, stands out from the pack. It has a pedigree: the restaurant is owned by Joseph, Jim and Leo DeNicola, three brothers who also own Ruvo West in Greenlawn, Ruvo East in Port Jefferson and La Tavola in Sayville.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Botswana’s Olympic Hope
text: Botswana sprinter Amantle Montsho trains in Senegal, thousands of miles from home, in hopes of capturing her country’s first Olympic medal.

headline: California: Tribe Wins Ruling Against Gold Mining
text: A federal appeals court ruled Friday that the Forest Service’s policies permitting gold mining in rivers in national forests violated the Endangered Species Act. The 7-to-4 decision, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, came in a lawsuit filed in 2004 by the Karuk Tribe of Northern California. The tribe had argued that some types of mining on the Klamath River, including suction dredging and motorized sluicing, posed risks to coho salmon, a federally protected species. Coho are important to the tribe for cultural, religious and subsistence reasons. The Forest Service had argued that the Mining Act of 1872 prevailed over the Endangered Species Act.

headline: Colorado: Immigrant Group’s Financing Is Replaced
text: A coalition of advocacy groups announced Friday that it had raised enough money to make up for financing that the Roman Catholic Church is cutting off to Compañeros, which provides services for immigrants in southwestern Colorado. The Catholic Campaign for Human Development ended about $30,000 in annual financing to Compañeros because it had joined a coalition that supported same-sex marriage. The Catholic Campaign, an arm of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops that is devoted to reducing poverty, has stopped financing groups that run astray of Catholic positions. Nicole Mosher, executive director of Compañeros, said a fund-raising campaign had netted more than $60,000. The Gill Foundation, which supports gay rights legislation, matched donations raised by several immigrant, religious and gay advocacy groups.

headline: At a Spirited Hangout, Gallic Insouciance
text: IF you can visualize New Canaan’s downtown Main Street as a Parisian boulevard, then calling the new restaurant there “Boulevard 18 Bistro and Wine Bar” isn’t too much of a stretch.

headline: How to Make Renewable Energy Competitive
text: STANFORD, Calif.

headline: Beyond the Basics in Puerto Rican Fare
text: WESTCHESTER COUNTY is experiencing something of a Latin awakening. There have long been little corner eateries offering no-frills but often tasty food that catered mainly to the county’s Spanish-speaking population. But recently, more sophisticated, upscale restaurants have been popping up, taking the Caribbean and Latin American fare in the area to a new culinary level.

headline: Following Up on the Martin-Diaz Spat
text: DETROIT — Joe Torre managed Russell Martin for three seasons with the Los Angeles Dodgers. But his phone call to Martin, the Yankees’ catcher, on Thursday was not to say hello or ask about his Carolina blue sneakers.

headline: Edwards Jurors Open Up in Morning TV Interviews
text: Three jurors in the federal corruption trial of former Senator John Edwards said on Friday that they believed Mr. Edwards was guilty of at least one of the campaign-finance charges against him but that the government had failed to prove its case.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Immigration Reform
text: IN the noisy American debate over immigration reform, something important seems to have escaped notice: time, and common-sense decisions by Mexican migrants, have brought us nearly everything immigration reform was supposed to achieve.

headline: Mr. Edwards and the Shrimp
text: John Edwards: Sort of not guilty. The Justice Department must now decide whether to retry him in another lengthy case during which we could relive his degrading affair, his awful marriage and his wife’s fatal illness, and watch his daughter and elderly parents loyally and miserably accompany him to court.

headline: Giants’ Umenyiora Agrees to Deal
text: Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora avoided a second straight off-season of contract controversy by agreeing to a restructured deal Friday, the team announced.

headline: Israel: Soldier and Militant Killed
text: An Israeli soldier and a Palestinian militant were killed in an exchange of fire early Friday after the militant breached the fence along the Gaza-Israel border. Israeli forces fired warning shots from the ground and the air, and then carried out an airstrike in Gaza against a squad that had fired a rocket at Israeli soldiers, according to military officials. A Gaza medical official said that four Palestinians were wounded in the airstrike.

headline: An Absentee Landlord of an Absentee Vacation Property
text: “Now I can spot a scam a mile away,” a woman named Lisa said. She then shared her story — with the condition that her last name and the name of her employer be withheld — so that others could spot one, too. Lisa lives in Portland, Ore. In March, while planning a work trip to Manhattan, she came across a beauty of a deal on Craigslist in the increasingly competitive field of apartments for vacation rental: a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment at 98 Mercer Street, a cobblestone block of SoHo. Cost: $100 a night.

headline: The Evolution of a Movement, Preserved in Glass
text: MILLVILLE, N.J.

headline: The Mortgage Fraud Fraud
text: I got an e-mail the other day from Richard Engle telling me that his son Charlie would be getting out of prison this month. I was happy to hear it.

headline: Pakistan: Doctor’s Conviction Appealed
text: Lawyers for Shakil Afridi, the Pakistani doctor who helped the C.I.A. find Osama bin Laden, lodged an appeal on Friday to overturn his conviction. On May 23, tribal authorities sentenced Dr. Afridi to 33 years in prison and fined him $3,500, although the conviction related to charges of aiding the militant group Lashkar-i-Islam, rather than ties to the C.I.A. The appeal document said that the charges were “false, concocted and without foundation” because Dr. Afridi had no links with Lashkar-i-Islam, and that he had not received a fair trial under the legal framework that applies in Pakistan’s tribal belt. It said Dr. Afridi was kidnapped by Lashkar-i-Islam in 2008 and forced to pay a ransom of $10,600 to win his freedom.

headline: The Human Form, Unleashed
text: RYE, N.Y.

headline: California Cuts Threaten the Status of Universities
text: LOS ANGELES — Class sizes have increased, courses have been cut and tuition has been raised — repeatedly. Fewer colleges are offering summer classes. Administrators rely increasingly on higher tuition from out-of-staters. And there are signs it could get worse: If a tax increase proposed by Gov. Jerry Brown is not approved this year, officials say they will be forced to consider draconian cuts like eliminating entire schools or programs.

headline: Poets, Off the Page and Under the Sky
text: THE poet Tony Hoagland had been hearing about the Sunken Garden Poetry Festival for eight or nine years before finally getting the chance to perform there last year.

headline: How Slow Can It Go?
text: There are two unavoidable conclusions from the May jobs report: The slow economy is getting slower, and there is no help on the way.

headline: ‘Our Servants Do Pretty Much as They Please’
text: Touring the United States for the London Times, the war correspondent William Howard Russell reached New Orleans late in May 1861 to find a city ablaze. Confederate flags flew from the public buildings and private homes. Soldiers paraded through the streets in smart columns of dash and pomp. Gentlemen at the St. Charles Hotel pored over the latest papers for news of the dawning war. The police were rounding up suspected abolitionists, and every night mysterious fires flared up around the city – set, it was rumored, by the slaves.

headline: Cuomo’s $4 Billion Plan for Project in Queens Falls Apart
text: A $4 billion plan announced by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to create the country’s largest convention center and a casino in Queens has fallen apart, the governor acknowledged on Friday.

headline: For Children, a Summer to Shine Onstage
text: YOUNGSTERS who thrill to the roar of the crowd at the school play — even if their parents are doing much of the roaring — need not pack away their passion for the summer. Long Island theaters and day camps offer a variety of options during the school break for drama-oriented children, whether they are novices or already dreaming of future residuals.

headline: A Jury Draws a Line
text: Rodney Gurley faced a mandatory minimum sentence of 10 years in federal prison for possession of 28 or more grams of crack cocaine with an intent to distribute it because he had previously been convicted of a felony.

headline: When in Rome, Speak Up for Reality
text: The nation’s Roman Catholic nuns are pushing back against the Vatican’s unjustified attack on their fidelity. The president and the executive director of the Leadership Conference of Women Religious, which represents about 80 percent of the nation’s 57,000 nuns, intend to go to Rome and fully rebut the accusations that the group has “serious doctrinal problems” and a tendency toward “radical feminist themes.”

headline: Dick Beals, Actor Who Gave a Voice to Gumby and Speedy, Is Dead at 85
text: Few people know the name Dick Beals, but millions may remember his liltingly boyish voice as Speedy Alka-Seltzer proclaiming, “Plop-plop, fizz-fizz, oh, what a relief it is!”

headline: Looking at Bloomberg’s Soda Ban Through a Doughnut Hole
text: “Hey, let me have one of those suckers.”

headline: Set, and Left, Adrift
text: Around the world, some 42.5 million vulnerable people were forcibly out of their homes and on the move in 2011, according to the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

headline: A Different Angle on Building in New York
text: SAMUEL C. FLORMAN’S memoir of life in the construction trade opens with a bang. He recalls overhearing an argument between a contractor working on a six-story apartment building in the Bronx and a city inspector threatening to shut down the job because of a missing permit. Mr. Florman writes: “Suddenly the shouting stopped, and very quietly the inspector said, ‘O.K.’ Pause. ‘It’ll cost you a hundred bucks.’ ”

headline: Darkness in the Sunshine State
text: Florida ought to know better. And must do better, particularly on the issue of voting and discrimination.

headline: Thunder Slow Parker and Find New Life
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — His first name comes from a South African dialect and means “the one who brings joy,” but three minutes into Game 3 of the Western Conference finals, Thabo Sefolosha had brought enough pain upon the San Antonio Spurs to reset the series’s momentum.

headline: Baptists Reprimand Policy Leader for Comments
text: The Southern Baptist Convention on Friday reprimanded Richard Land, the chief of its policy branch, for making racially provocative remarks about the Trayvon Martin killing and announced the cancellation of his weekly radio program on public affairs.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 1, 2012

headline: Scrutiny for Connecticut House Speaker
text: HARTFORD (AP) — A federal investigation into the campaign finances of the Connecticut House speaker will not prevent him from running for Congress or force him to step down as speaker, his new campaign manager said Friday.

headline: Slowdown in Growth Could Reshape Fight for Presidency
text: WASHINGTON — The weak employment report on Friday held the potential to reshape the presidential campaign, members of both parties said, lifting Mitt Romney’s efforts to make the race all about President Obama’s handling of the economy and making it harder for Democrats to break through in their efforts to define Mr. Romney on their terms.

headline: Soda Industry Maps Strategy to Defeat Bloomberg Plan to Ban Super-Size Drinks
text: For years, the nation’s powerful soda industry has known it faced a formidable opponent in Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Pouring It On
text: AS Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg promoted his plan to ban large sugary drinks from many New York City outlets, Twitter struggled gamely to find humor in its collective horror.

headline: Panetta Outlines New Weaponry for Pacific
text: SINGAPORE — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta, seeking to persuade a skeptical audience of Asian officials here on Saturday that the United States is committed to enhancing its military presence in the region despite coming budget constraints, unveiled the most detailed inventory to date of planned new weapons for the region.

headline: Woods Closes In on Lead at the Memorial, Despite Sniffles and Hiccups
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — The white towel that Tiger Woods clutched throughout the second round of the Memorial Tournament on Friday was not a symbol of surrender. The cottonwood trees at Muirfield Village Golf Club triggered Woods’s allergies and turned his towel into a giant handkerchief. His game, meantime, remained hale.

headline: In Harlem, an Unlikely Garden
text: Li Tingpang, 78, grew tired of the planned activities in his senior residence in Harlem, so he found a neglected lot near the Harlem River Drive and began tilling a garden.

headline: Sabbatini’s Beat Is Good So Far
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Because of bad weather in the morning, Rory Sabbatini didn’t start his second round at the Memorial until well after 3 p.m. To pass the time, he watched a documentary about the reggae star Bob Marley. Playing in overcast, windy conditions, Sabbatini scored so well he could be forgiven for whistling “The Sun Is Shining” from Marley’s song list.

headline: Mr. Li’s Guerrilla Garden
text: LI TINGBANG, a 78-year-old Chinese immigrant who grew up on a farm outside Canton, now known as Guangzhou, was always a restless type. So three years ago, bored with the dance and mah-jongg classes given in the senior residence where he lives in Harlem, he decided he needed a garden.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Faint Praise
text: Ashley Parker reports on Mitt Romney’s strategy of calling President Obama a “nice guy” while attacking his record.

headline: Until an Ancestral Graveyard Is Found, No Time to Rest
text: “Halt! Advance and give the countersign!”

headline: Critics From Base See Romney Pulling Punches on ‘Nice Guy’ Obama
text: To hear Mitt Romney tell it, President Obama has slowed the economic recovery, apologized for America abroad, taken his cues from the social democrats of Europe and wasted hundreds of millions in stimulus dollars on companies like Solyndra.

headline: A Straight Shot it’s Not
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Mmm … fresh and crunchy. Just the thing for a Saturday.

headline: Beltran’s One Wish Ignores That Strikeout
text: The talent gap is obvious. We know we cannot throw 95 miles an hour, or make the pivot on a double play with a runner bearing down, or square up a jackknifing curveball with a season on the line. We imagine what it feels like to be an elite athlete, but we cannot know.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in May
text: How the auto industry, automakers and the most popular cars and trucks fared in May.

headline: Santana, Pushing Past Pitch Count, Throws Mets’ First No-Hitter
text: What stood between the Mets and the first no-hitter in their 51-season history was a matter of inches, Carlos Beltran and one deceiving baseball. Johan Santana was supposed to have a pitch count, but his left shoulder was not supposed to be this healthy, and for how well he danced with fate all night, it would not have mattered how many pitches he threw.

headline: A Military Regimen: Bring the Pain
text: ON Monday, inside a warehouse turned gymnasium on an empty street in Gowanus, Brooklyn, a group of well-educated, accomplished New Yorkers chose to start their holiday with one of the most punishing workouts on earth.

headline: New Rules for Money Transfers, but Few Limits
text: From her job at a packaging factory in Chicago, Patricia Gonzalez cobbles together $70 a month to send to her mother in Guadalajara, Mexico, leaving her less money for groceries. In Boardman, Ore., Raul Esparza, a migrant farmworker, works as many hours as he can to send $50 a week to his children in Mexico City.

headline: Turkish Pianist Is Accused of Insulting Islam
text: ISTANBUL — A court here on Friday charged Fazil Say, a classical and jazz pianist with an international career, with insulting Islamic values in Twitter messages, the latest in a series of legal actions against Turkish artists, writers and intellectuals for statements they have made about religion and Turkish national identity.

headline: Devils Filled Defensive Gap With Zidlicky, and a Hole in His Résumé, Too
text: NEWARK — Marek Zidlicky, the defenseman who seemed to make the Devils complete, says he is finally planning to move into his own place after living for two weeks with Patrik Elias, a fellow Czech, and then in a hotel for almost three months.

headline: Johan Santana Throws the Mets’ First No-Hitter. Discuss.
text: Johan Santana threw the first no-hitter in Mets history on Friday night, testing the limits of fate, his pitch count and his surgically repaired shoulder to beat the Cardinals, 8-0. On a night when fans at Citi Field were forced to look back to a quintessentially Mets moment, Santana sent them home with an unforgettable one. Now that it’s over, share your thoughts, your fears as his pitch count rose, and your reaction in the comments.

headline: In Mets’ 51st Year, Finally, Their First No-Hitter
text: For 8,019 games, across 51 seasons, it had never happened for the Mets. Not at the Polo Grounds, not at Shea Stadium, not at Citi Field, not on the road. Not for Ryan or Seaver, not for Koosman or Matlack, not for Gooden or Cone, not for Leiter or Glavine. No Mets pitcher had ever thrown a no-hitter. Not until Friday.

headline: Corrections: June 2
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: From Long Shot to G.O.P.’s Best Bet in Nebraska’s Senate Race
text: LINCOLN, Neb. — Sometimes, she got her colleagues in the Nebraska Legislature to side with her by making assurances: “We’ll get the people to help you get your bill through.”

headline: A Chiropractor for the Four-Legged Set
text: At quarter to 11 on Friday morning, only two hours after galloping around the Belmont Park oval, I’ll Have Another yawned contentedly in his stall. He licked his lips. He looked as if he could not be happier.

headline: Judge Blocks City Plan for New Class of Livery Cabs
text: A State Supreme Court justice on Friday blocked the Bloomberg administration’s plan to create a new class of livery cabs, a setback in the city’s effort to expand street hail service beyond Manhattan.

headline: Race to Win, but No Doughnuts
text: Ramon A. Dominguez is in an elite class of horse whisperers: his gift for guiding thoroughbreds across the finish line brought him the Eclipse Award for Outstanding Jockey in 2010 and again in 2011, when his mounts earned almost $20 million, tops in the nation. He won the 2011 Breeders’ Cup Juvenile aboard Hansen, the Pegasus-like stallion that was also his 2012 Kentucky Derby mount; but his horse for the June 9 Belmont Stakes was withdrawn. Tall for his trade at 5-foot-6, Mr. Dominguez, 35, who was born in Venezuela, lives in Floral Park, N.Y., with his wife, Sharon; their sons, Alex, 7, and Matthew, 5; and their dog, Lucy. He also owns a 14-acre horse farm near Elkton, Md. Sunday is a race day, but afterward, he indulges in a normal Sunday dinner. Monday and Tuesday are off days, with no weigh-ins.

headline: Drug Helps Defense System Fight Cancer
text: CHICAGO — One of the great frustrations for researchers in the war on cancer is that the body’s own defense system does not do a better job fighting the disease. Tumors, it turns out, have a molecular shield that repels attacks from the immune system.

headline: Rape Case, in Public, Cites Abuse by Armed Groups in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Lal Bibi is an 18-year-old rape victim who has taken a step rarely seen in Afghanistan: she has spoken out publicly against her tormentors, local militiamen, including several who have been identified as members of the American-trained Afghan Local Police.

headline: Search for Illegal Voters May Violate Federal Safeguards, U.S. Tells Florida
text: MIAMI — The Justice Department has asked Florida to stop searching for and purging the names of possible ineligible voters, saying that the state appears to be in violation of federal voter protection laws.

headline: Orlando Woolridge, N.B.A. Star and W.N.B.A. Coach, Dies at 52
text: Orlando Woolridge, who electrified crowds with his freewheeling play — dashing upcourt, lobbing alley-oop passes and slamming dunks — through 13 N.B.A. seasons, died on Thursday in Mansfield, La. He was 52.

headline: Way Beyond Bake Sales: The $1 Million PTA
text: EACH fall, parents at the Anderson School, a highly regarded K-8 on the Upper West Side for gifted and talented students, receive letters from the PTA emblazoned with the school’s elegant “A” logo. Though Anderson indulges in the usual trappings of public-school fund-raising — bake sales, book fairs, auctions — this letter is blunter: It urges parents to simply write a check. And it suggests an amount: This school year, it was $1,300.

headline: Goals Keep Coming for the Kings’ Kopitar, Accompanied by New Attention
text: NEWARK — When Anze Kopitar went forehand-backhand-forehand on Devils goalie Martin Brodeur to end Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals in overtime on Wednesday, fans across North America and Europe finally got a glimpse of what Kings fans have seen for the last six years: Kopitar, a rock star, scoring a spectacular goal.

headline: Wisconsin Tops Itself in Big-Money Race
text: The last governor’s race in Wisconsin, in 2010, broke spending records for such campaigns in the state, with more than $37 million expended by the candidates and outside groups. Two years later, in a recall election set for Tuesday, the candidates — Gov. Scott Walker and Mayor Tom Barrett of Milwaukee — are the same, but the money has ballooned to an estimated $60 million.

headline: Granderson’s Slam Ends Skid and Breaks Open the Game
text: DETROIT — Maybe the Yankees have been doing this wrong all along. Rain washed out batting practice on the field for both teams at Comerica Park on Friday, when the Yankees took a major stride toward reversing their baffling, two-month-long ineffectiveness with the bases loaded.

headline: Gay or Stupid? One’s Still an Insult
text: Not too long ago, Lee Stern, a music educator, was accompanying his 11-year-old nephew in an elevator in his Chelsea apartment building. Mr. Stern is gay, and so is his brother, who adopted the boy with his partner and lives down the hall.

headline: Dubious Call Saves Mets’ No-Hitter
text: Perhaps, over time, the memory will fade. But for the immediate future it will be impossible to talk about Johan Santana ending the Mets’ no-hitter drought without also mentioning the call — and the umpire — who helped make it happen. In the sixth inning, St. Louis outfielder Carlos Beltran ripped a ball down the third-base line. Adrian Johnson, the third-base umpire, quickly threw up his arms and signaled that the ball was foul.

headline: On Twitter, God Is Greater Than Glitter
text: While prominent celebrities like Lady Gaga or Justin Bieber have millions of Twitter followers, religious leaders show much higher levels of engagement.

headline: Things Fall Apart II
text: LONDON — We said it last week. And now things have gotten worse. The latest data from the United States and Europe to India and China show dangerous signs of a slowing global economy. Meanwhile, Paul Krugman laments, Britain is obsessed with counterproductive austerity.

headline: Celtics Jump Out to Big Early Lead, and This Time They Don’t Let Up
text: BOSTON — The foul was hard and sudden, and it left Kevin Garnett flat on his back, his lanky frame spread across a broad expanse of green-toned hardwood. He flipped over, put his knuckles to the floor and pressed hard for eight push-ups, the din at the TD Garden growing louder with each one.

headline: How Do You Shoo the Neighborhood Kids Out of the Yard?
text: This week’s quandary came from a message J. sent via Facebook: How, she asked, can we keep the children in our great, family-friendly neighborhood from hanging out with us in our yard — all the time?

headline: Mets’ Voices Make the Call
text: A no-hitter like Johan Santana’s Friday night is, in the modern world, a viral event. Shortly after seeing messages on Twitter saying that Santana was on his way to making Mets history, a friend called to say, “Watch the top of the ninth.” In the past, that suggestion amounted to a tease. Tom Seaver lost three no-hitters in the ninth inning.

headline: In Land of Gas Drilling, Battle for Water That Doesn’t Reek or Fizz
text: PAVILLION, Wyo. — It has been more than four decades since the first well was drilled in the natural gas field beneath this stretch of slow rolling alfalfa and sugar beet farms. But for some who live here, in the shadows of the Wind River Mountains, the drilling rigs have brought more than jobs and industry.

headline: Helping to Rewrite Record Book and the Tone of a Web Site
text: The curse is history — so is the Web site.

headline: Untangling a Rape Case in Crown Heights
text: THERE were mornings when the women at Mama’s Senegalese hair salon received an unusual guest: a 13-year-old Jewish girl from the neighborhood’s Chabad Lubavitch community. She had an unusual request: to change clothes in the bathroom.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: The First Magic Moment at Citi Field
text: One of the first no-hitters I can ever remember hearing about was thrown by an Oakland A’s rookie named Mike Warren in September 1983. Within two years, Warren was finished as a major leaguer, with a career record of 9-13 and an earned run average of 5.06.

headline: Christian Leaders Are Powerhouses on Twitter
text: Why are some tweets more popular than others?

headline: The Mets’ First No-Hitter
text: Johan Santana’s memorable night against the Cardinals provided the first no-hitter in 8,020 Mets games over 51 seasons.

headline: Deciphering the Hidden Rules That Tempt China’s Officials
text: Increasingly, some Chinese officials are saying: It’s O.K. to be a little bit corrupt, when others are so much more corrupt than you.The unusual self-defense by some public servants – corruption is unequivocally a crime in China – is featuring more and more in Chinese media reports, sparking wide debate in a country where the prime minister says corruption is so bad it could one day “terminate” Communist Party rule (see this report by Bloomberg Business News.)

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Indian cricket team captain Mahendra Singh Dhoni will visit the Baramulla district in north Kashmir on Sunday to cheer for a match in the Kashmir Premier League, or KPL, Kashmir’s own version of the Indian Premier League cricket tournament. The initiative was started by the Indian Army last year to promote cricket among youngsters in the conflict-ridden valley (Hindustan Times).

headline: Catastrophic Credibility
text: A little while ago Ben Bernanke responded to suggestions that the Fed needed to do more — in particular, that it should raise the inflation target — by insisting that this would undermine the institution’s “hard-won credibility”. May I say that what recent events in Europe, and to some extent in the US, really suggest is that central banks have too much credibility? Or more accurately, their credibility as inflation-haters is very clear, while their willingness to tolerate even as much inflation as they say they want, let alone take some risks with inflation to rescue the real economy, is very much in doubt.

headline: Mumbai Showcases Gay and Transgender Films
text: A frustrated petitioner arguing her own case before the judge blasts the state for its atrocities and double standards. As the audience in the courtroom erupts into a roar and loud applause, so does the audience sitting in one of the theaters at Cinemax, a popular multiplex in Andheri, Mumbai’s entertainment district.

headline: My Head Talks Tomorrow
text: On ABC’s This Week with George Stephanopoulos, from New York. I assume it will go something like this:

headline: New Turmoil in Egypt Greets Mixed Verdict for Mubarak
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Saturday sentenced former President Hosni Mubarak to life in prison as an accomplice in the killing of unarmed demonstrators during the protests that ended his nearly 30-year rule.

headline: The Weekend Word: Game Changer
text: Today’s Times

headline: Aid Workers Who Were Held in Cave Are Rescued From Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four aid workers, including two women, who were abducted May 22 were freed early Saturday in a NATO rescue operation in northern Afghanistan, according to a NATO spokesman and a Swiss-based aid organization, Medair.

headline: Real-life Hunger Games in America
text: LONDON — Back in The New York Times newsroom on a recent trip to New York, I came across some children’s literature. The slim pamphlets, in bright colors and featuring beloved cartoon characters, were about subjects like teeth brushing and healthy eating, and I immediately thought I had to pick them up for my kids.

headline: A Giddy Catcher Retraces a Special Night
text: Josh Thole almost did not get to run to the mound and hug Johan Santana on Friday night, his first night back from the disabled list since May 7, when he sustained a concussion. Never mind how difficult it was for the battery mates Santana and Thole to keep the St. Louis Cardinals guessing and hitless all night, it almost did not happen: Manager Terry Collins had nearly persuaded Thole to play one more minor league rehab game.

headline: Florida Versus Spain
text: Mainly as a note to myself: What was once Peter Kenen’s big insight about optimum currency areas is now a commonplace: They’re much more likely to be workable if you have fiscal federalism, so that there are large automatic transfers to depressed regions. Now, I often compare Spain with Florida: both had huge housing bubbles followed by busts. Florida, however, has its retirement and much of its health care paid for from Washington. So how big are the transfers?

headline: Egyptians React After Former President Is Sentenced
text: Ousted Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak was sentenced to life in prison on charges of complicity in the deaths of some of the nearly 850 protesters who lost their lives in the uprising that swept him from power last year.

headline: An Aggressive Play in Left Field Preserves a Gem
text: The hero watched the end of the game from the trainer’s table.

headline: In the Galápagos Islands, A Bigger Center for Divers
text: The Galápagos Islands, on the wish-list of many scuba divers, will get a new dive center this summer that is bigger than any other on the archipelago.

headline: A 4-Year-Old Filly Is Safe, and Sound
text: This is the face of horse slaughter. She’s a 4-year-old thoroughbred filly, a New York-bred. She was born on a beautiful farm in Westchester County. Her life on that farm would have been textbook perfect, it’s an outstanding facility, with a staff experienced in raising top-flight racehorses. Eventually, she was in training at Finger Lakes Race Track in Farmington, N.Y., but she never made a start. At the end of last year’s race meet, her owner asked her trainer to find her a home.

headline: Hosni Mubarak Sentenced to Life Term
text: David Kirkpatrick of The New York Times reports on the verdict finding Hosni Mubarak, the former Egyptian president, guilty of failing to stop the killing of demonstrators in last year’s uprising.

headline: The Standouts and the Washouts Among No. 1 Draft Picks
text: By the middle of spring training, Astros General Manager Jeff Luhnow had scouted all of the top contenders for the No. 1 overall pick in this week’s draft. There is no obvious choice, he said, which makes it tougher for Houston to find the kind of player it seeks.

headline: It’s Not Billions, but It Can Help Rescue an Artist
text: WHERE’S my bailout?

headline: Harboring Dreams of a Winner, Then Loving a Loser Anyway
text: The 1962 Mets — a team filled with colorful characters, including Casey Stengel, Choo Choo Coleman and Marv Throneberry, that lost 120 games in its inaugural season — inspired entire books. Writers like Jimmy Breslin took joy in the Mets’ misery, casting them as lovable losers.

headline: At Last, Taster’s Choice in a Paris Wine Bar
text: PARIS — Paris may be the capital of the greatest wine-producing country, but in one way it sometimes falls short. It’s not always easy to find a place to sample high-quality wines by the glass here. If tasting is your thing, you’re often better off going straight to the French wine regions. Or to Italy.

headline: Evelyn Hofer’s New York
text: Evelyn Hofer’s photo assignments took her around the globe. But her biggest challenge was right in New York, her adopted home since the 1940s.

headline: Variety: A Kinky Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — When you have curly hair, finding a hair stylist who can do those curls justice is a challenge.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Weak Economy Points to Obama’s Constraints
text: WASHINGTON — The bleak jobs report on Friday predictably had heads snapping toward the White House, looking to President Obama to do something. Yet his proposed remedies only underscore how much the president, just five months before he faces voters, is at the mercy of actors in Europe, China and Congress whose political interests often conflict with his own.

headline: Lepchenko Continues Surprising Run to Round of 16
text: PARIS — The longer Varvara Lepchenko held on against Francesca Schiavone, the more Lepchenko implored herself to fight. That last word is something of a mantra for Lepchenko, a tidy way to explain an untidy narrative, the simplest way to summarize her life.

headline: Challenges Remain for the September 11 Memorial Museum
text: While much of the World Trade Center Memorial Plaza has already opened to the public, the memorial museum, which lies 70 feet below ground at bedrock, has been delayed because of arguments over financing. Here are some of the expected features when the museum opens. That date is still not set.

headline: At Museum on 9/11, Talking Through an Identity Crisis
text: It seemed self-evident at the time: A museum devoted to documenting the events of Sept. 11, 2001, would have to include photographs of the hijackers who turned four passenger jets into missiles. Then two and a half years ago, plans to use the pictures were made public.

headline: When History Sneaks Up on You
text: My children are not Mets fans. They had no idea what a no-hitter is. They had never heard of Johan Santana. They may not know the difference between Mr. Met and the Kool-Aid Man.

headline: It Was a Magical Night, With a Cherry on Top
text: The Mets have always been about surprise, good surprise.

headline: Santana’s Milestone Is Celebrated in His Homeland
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Even President Hugo Chávez was excited about Johan Santana’s no-hitter for the Mets on Friday night. Chávez is the No. 1 fan in this baseball-loving country, and shortly after Santana, a native Venezuelan, no-hit the St. Louis Cardinals, Chávez posted on Twitter: “Giant Johan, compatriot! What pride! Viva Venezuela! Our words of congratulations, Golden Lefty!”

headline: In a Lebanese City, Fighting Over Syria Conflict Is Deadly
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Sectarian tensions between supporters and opponents of the Syrian government reignited street fighting in the northern Lebanese port city of Tripoli on Saturday, with local news media reports saying at least 7 people were killed and 30 were wounded.

headline: Fearing Harm to Myanmar Ties, Thailand Limits Visiting Opposition Leader
text: MAE LA, Thailand — Amid growing concerns here that the six-day visit of Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, might damage relations with Myanmar’s government, Thai officials tried to rein her in on Saturday at a refugee camp on the Thai border.

headline: Construction Frozen in a Fight Over Financing
text: For more than six months, work on the National September 11 Memorial Museum has been at a virtual standstill because of a multimillion-dollar dispute between the foundation creating it and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is responsible for the construction.

headline: Warren Fends Off Party Challenger in Massachusetts Race
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — In a display of political muscle, Elizabeth Warren overwhelmingly won the state Democratic Party’s endorsement on Saturday for the United States Senate seat held by Scott P. Brown, a Republican. With the size of her victory, she avoided a party primary in September.

headline: Pakistan Acquits Four Men in Times Square Bomb Plot
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani court on Saturday acquitted four men accused of assisting Faisal Shahzad, the Taliban-trained militant who tried to explode a car bomb in Times Square two years ago, a lawyer and several relatives said.

headline: Quakes Deal Irreparable Blow to an Italian Region’s Cultural Heritage
text: MIRANDOLA, Italy — With every new quiver here, something crumbles or new cracks appear. “It’s like receiving a daily list of war casualties,” said Carla Di Francesco, the supervisor for cultural heritage in this part of northern Italy. The second of two major earthquakes last month “compounded the emergency, and we had to start monitoring everything from scratch.”

headline: Court Rivals May Someday Vie on Distant Field
text: On May 30, 1984, Liverpool beat A.S. Roma in a penalty shootout at the Stadio Olimpico in Rome to capture the European Cup, the precursor to soccer’s prestigious Champions League. At the time, Kevin Garnett was an 8-year-old in South Carolina and LeBron James had not been born. But when the same two soccer clubs meet July 28 at Fenway Park as part of their United States summer tours, James and Garnett are likely to be there as minority owners, James for Liverpool and Garnett for Roma.

headline: Winning Entry in ‘What is a Flame’ Contest
text: I recently wrote about the “Flame Challenge,” a contest organized by the Center for Communicating Science at Stony Brook University. In the competition, more than 800 contestants sought to answer — in everything from poetry to animation — the question, “What is a flame?”

headline: Plan to Tax Soda Gets a Mixed Reception
text: RICHMOND, Calif. — The California good life — the one of endless varieties of lettuce and tasting rooms nestled in vineyards — does not extend to Richmond’s Iron Triangle, a neighborhood named for the railroad tracks that delineate its borders and historically one of the neediest communities in the Bay Area.

headline: Gun Violence Wave Challenges Seattle’s Notion of Security
text: SEATTLE — The worst surge of gun violence in years, culminating last week in six deaths over the course of an otherwise unremarkable Wednesday morning-into-afternoon, has deeply stressed this city, where many neighborhoods normally feel as safe as living rooms.

headline: Purses Are a Sore Point for Players at Majors
text: PARIS — Donald Young lost in the first round of the French Open and pocketed 18,000 euros, or about $22,300.

headline: Yes, You’re Smart, but What About Your Topspin?
text: This interview with  Mike Sheehan, chief executive of the ad agency Hill Holliday, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Lawsuit Shakes Foundation of a Man’s World of Tech
text: Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Influential Women in Silicon Valley
text: Starting tech companies in 2012 is still a male game, and financing them even more so. But there are powerful exceptions to the rule.

headline: Islamist Rebels Impose Harsh Rule in Northern Mali
text: Rebels who captured Timbuktu have imposed hard-edged Islamic laws, prompting many residents to flee what had been a tolerant city.

headline: The Curtain Opens on 401(k) Fees
text: IF recent stock market gyrations have taken a bite out of your 401(k), get ready for more discomfort. You’re about to learn how much you’re paying just to maintain that account.

headline: How Do Kenyan 10K Runners Get to London? Through Raindrops in Oregon
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Where better to hold the men’s 10,000-meter Kenyan Olympic trials than ... here?

headline: In Timbuktu, Harsh Change Under Islamists
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Isolated for centuries by the harsh desert that surrounds it, Timbuktu now finds itself even more cut off from the rest of the world.

headline: Privacy, Please: This Is Only for the Two of Us
text: SOME friends were gushing recently about a new mobile application called Pair, intended for people in a relationship.

headline: Social Media Goes Antisocial
text: Jenna Wortham, a technology reporter, introduces new applications that have the potential to offer the private experience missing from Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 3
text: Several news shows this Sunday will focus on the potential fallout on the presidential race of Friday’s employment report, which showed that the economy added 69,000 jobs in May, the fewest in a year. Representatives from President Obama’s re-election committee will make the rounds to argue that the latest report was just a hiccup in the president’s plan to fix the economy, while officials in the Republican Party will say that it is time to see what a Romney administration can do.

headline: A Geneticist’s Research Turns Personal
text: HUMAN genome sequencing is already helping researchers find new treatments for illness. Now an unusual case study suggests that the benefits of sequencing may be enhanced in combination with detailed blood tests.

headline: Work Materials Catch Fire at 1 World Trade Center Site
text: Firefighters scrambled to contain a small fire that was discovered on Saturday after it had apparently smoldered overnight amid construction debris and plywood on the 89th floor of 1 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, the authorities said.

headline: After the Crowds Leave the Track, Who Keeps You Company?
text: When I wrote my first short story, I used my cat Moses as a muse. I created a world where he was a wise old tabby barn cat wearing a leather collar with a brass nameplate who interacted with everyone at the track and bettered their lives. Imagine my surprise when I walked past Security Gate 5 at Churchill Downs the week before this year’s Kentucky Derby and was greeted by Bill, an old tabby cat wearing the same exact collar. I stopped to return his affection and the security guards proudly told me that he “ran Churchill Downs, and in his day, probably fathered most of the kittens around.”

headline: American Industry as War Hero
text: ARTHUR HERMAN has set out to right an injustice: the loss, down history’s memory hole, of the epic achievements of American business in helping the United States and its allies win World War II.

headline: Finally Passing Test of Time
text: FORT SMITH, Ark. — The former United States Open winner stood on the practice range holding a driver like the one he saw in Fred Couples’s bag during this year’s Masters. He hit a shot as straight as a crow flies, watched it roll toward a flag 250 yards away and muttered, “I almost whiffed that one.”

headline: In Occupied Tibetan Monastery, a Reason for Fiery Deaths
text: DHARAMSALA, India — One young Tibetan monk walked down a street kicking Chinese military vehicles, then left a suicide note condemning an official ban on a religious ceremony. Another smiled often, and preferred to talk about Buddhism rather than politics. A third man, a former monk, liked herding animals with nomads.

headline: U.S. Stock Market Still Looks the Best of a Bad Lot
text: EUROPE’S worsening debt crisis and the sharper-than-expected slowdown in China have weighed down stocks since the start of April. Yet some market strategists say that so long as these overseas fears don’t morph into another global panic, they could serve another purpose: to remind investors that the domestic stock market may be the best choice among a tough set of options.

headline: Repairing Roads Can End All Kinds of Gridlock
text: DEMOCRATS and Republicans share less common ground than at any point in living memory, and they are especially divided about our still-ailing economy. When Democrats propose additional economic stimulus, Republicans call for more cuts in government spending and regulation. And even though the effects of the Great Recession are still with us, political gridlock seems set to continue.

headline: Fighting Sign Pollution in Florida With Robocalls
text: In Florida, they are as much a part of the landscape as palm trees and oceanfront hotels: plastic signs cluttering roadsides with messages like “We Buy Houses!” “Junk Cars!” and “Avoid Foreclosure!”

headline: League Worries About Officiating
text: This season, N.H.L. general managers, coaches and commentators have said that on-ice officials are allowing obstruction to creep back into the game, negating rules installed after the 2004-5 lockout that succeeded in opening up play.

headline: The Fading of the Euro
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Kind of Victory?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spencer Tunick
text: Spencer Tunick is an artist and photographer whose medium is naked people. He has created more than 75 site-specific installations arranging dozens, hundreds and even thousands of nude volunteers whose individual forms seem to meld into a singular, sculptural whole.

headline: Salt, We Misjudged You
text: Oakland, Calif.

headline: Li Steadies Game and Defeats McHale
text: PARIS — Christina McHale roared out of the gate on Saturday to take the first set against seventh-seeded Li Na of China but ran out of steam under steady counterattack, losing by 3-6, 6-2, 6-1, in the third round of the French Open.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Public Service for Lawyers
text: Readers debate a 50-hour pro bono requirement in New York.

headline: Mutually Assured Cyberdestruction?
text: Washington

headline: 10 Tasks to Jettison
text: A sampling of routine screening tests and medical procedures that research has suggested are unnecessary.

headline: Let’s (Not) Get Physicals
text: FOR decades, scientific research has shown that annual physical exams — and many of the screening tests that routinely accompany them — are in many ways pointless or (worse) dangerous, because they can lead to unneeded procedures. The last few years have produced a steady stream of new evidence against the utility of popular tests:

headline: At the Top of the Lists
text: The high schooler Byron Buxton has more upside, but Stanford’s Mark Appel is the presumed No. 1 pick.

headline: Wall Street and the Average Reader
text: UNTIL May 18, the Facebook story seemed to ride an ever-higher wave of media attention.

headline: Weather Threatens to Accelerate Wildfire in New Mexico
text: Since early May, it has scorched more land than there is in New York City’s five boroughs, sending billows of smoke from the canyons of southwestern New Mexico across the border to Arizona.

headline: In Hollywood, Theories of Infinite Dimensions
text: South Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Pumping Gas in Toledo
text: Seattle

headline: Out of Tragedy, a Good Life
text: Washington

headline: I Did Everything but the Fun Stuff
text: I HAD a job once.

headline: I Taught Shakespeare in Botswana
text: Budleigh Salterton, England

headline: My Brilliant Career
text: As college graduates leave their campuses behind this spring — for beach weeks and internships and entry-level jobs — it’s worth remembering that careers aren’t built in a straight line, and that sometimes the oddest jobs are the ones that matter most.

headline: U.S.-Pakistan Freeze Chokes Fallback Route in Afghanistan
text: SALANG PASS, Afghanistan — Nowhere is the impact of Pakistan’s ban on NATO truck traffic more visible than here at the top of the Hindu Kush, on one of the only alternative overland routes for supply convoys to reach Kabul and the rest of the country.

headline: Stain of Scandal Again Taints Italian Soccer
text: Soccer in Italy is not unlike driving. Laws are treated merely as suggestions.

headline: The Good Guys and Bad Guys That I’ve Been: Paul Williams on ‘Paul Williams Still Alive’
text: You’d think the life of Paul Williams would provide more than enough material for a documentary: he’s the vintage-1970s songwriter whose work includes “We’ve Only Just Begun,” “Evergreen” (which won him an Academy Award) and “Rainbow Connection” (which didn’t).  He’s a star of cult films like “Phantom of the Paradise” and “Smokey and the Bandit.” And after badly derailing his career with drug and alcohol abuse, he is now proudly 22 years sober.

headline: Death, Sex and Vampires
text: “ABRAHAM LINCOLN WAS A WOMAN!” In 2002, a cover story in The Weekly World News reported that a cache of Mathew Brady daguerreotypes of “Babe-raham Lincoln” had been found in the basement of the White House, and hidden among the president’s effects at the Smithsonian was a telltale box of sanitary napkins. Lincoln, it was disclosed, had married a man (“Take a look at a photo of Mary Todd Lincoln and you’ll be convinced”) and given birth to six children. All this, however, is ho-hum compared with the revelations in the coming film “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter,” in which our 16th president is, basically, Buffy in a stovepipe hat.

headline: What’s at Stake in the Belmont
text: The horse racing industry should be deeply shamed that extraordinary security measures had to be ordered to guard horses in next Saturday’s Belmont Stakes from the doping abuses engulfing thoroughbred racing. The horses will be kept in an isolated barn with visitors limited, feed and hay bales checked for drugs, and veterinarians and trainers under daily watch to ensure there is no manipulation of food or medication.

headline: Where the Trough Is Overflowing
text: Every five years or so, Congress promises a new, improved farm bill that will end unnecessary subsidies to big farmers, enhance the environment and actually do something to help small farmers and small towns. But what it usually does is find ways of disguising the old inequities, sending taxpayers dollars to wealthy farmers, accelerating the expansion of industrial farming, inflating land prices and further depopulating rural America.

headline: In Defense of Marriage
text: The federal appeals court ruling last week that struck down part of the Defense of Marriage Act did not say whether same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry, but the decision sets the stage for what will almost certainly be a Supreme Court showdown over the unfair treatment of gay people and their families.

headline: Treating You Better for Less
text: There is some good news about the overly costly, underperforming American health care system. A growing number of hospitals, doctors, employers and health insurers are finding ways to reduce the cost of delivering medical care while maintaining or improving quality. If enough providers adopt their already proven techniques, this grass-roots movement could transform the entire system in ways that will benefit all Americans.

headline: G.(reen)O.P.?
text: MITT ROMNEY certainly has his weaknesses as a candidate, but his biggest challenge in attracting independent swing voters will be overcoming a well-earned reputation for saying whatever the Republican base wants to hear. Having watched him in the primaries, you have to wonder whether there is any issue in which he would turn to the far-right in his party and say: “I’m sorry. You have this wrong. Here’s the hard truth. ...”

headline: Starving Its Own Children
text: IN THE NUBA MOUNTAINS, Sudan

headline: New Plan Yields Glimmer of Hope for Ramshackle Los Angeles Coliseum
text: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum has provided the stage for some of this city’s proudest moments: it hosted the 1932 and 1984 Summer Olympics; it is where John F. Kennedy accepted the Democratic presidential nomination; and it is where Nelson Mandela called for the end to apartheid in 1990, just a few months after his release from prison.

headline: Imagining a Romney Recovery
text: EARLIER this year, well before the latest round of job numbers made the current recovery look even more sickly, the Obama campaign released a chart putting the bravest possible face on its economic record.

headline: Trimming a Fat City
text: WHILE Michelle Obama focused on carrots, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg brandished a stick. It’s what we deserve. Cry all you want about a nanny state, but as a city and a nation we’ve gorged and guzzled past the point where a gentle nudge toward roughage suffices. We need a weight watcher willing to mete out some stricter discipline.

headline: Dreaming of a Superhero
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Italy’s Seppi Is Making His Move Up the Ranks
text: PARIS — As Andreas Seppi continued to climb the ATP Tour men’s singles rankings this spring, his path continued to cross with that of Novak Djokovic, the tour’s No. 1-ranked player.

headline: Tourist and a Cab Driver Killed in Crash Near Kennedy Airport
text: A Utah woman was killed, and her 11-year-old grandson was seriously injured, when a yellow taxicab carrying them from John F. Kennedy International Airport to Manhattan crashed on a rain-slicked section of highway in Queens early Saturday morning, the police said.

headline: The Insights of Elders
text: MY father inspired me. He attended the University of California, Berkeley, for some years in the 1950s, then drove a truck before being drafted into the Army. His military experience motivated him to go back and finish college and become a doctor.

headline: Cancer on the Brain
text: I got a call from a friend last year. He had prostate cancer and wanted some help thinking through what to do. He had gone to his doctors for the details about his physical condition. He was calling me for help dealing with the other condition he knew he was facing — excessive fear of this dreaded disease that sometimes does more harm than good, what some have called “cancer phobia.” [1]

headline: Determining the Champion: The Rules Keep Changing
text: What is the best way to select a world champion? The World Chess Federation keeps changing its mind.

headline: Carbon Paper? What’s That?
text: Not long ago, I was disgraced by a package of carbon paper. More precisely, I was disgraced by a visit to my local stationer’s, where I tried to buy a package of carbon paper. (I needed to transfer a drawing from surface A to surface B, and it seemed to me, then as now, that carbon paper has endured all these years for expressly that purpose.)

headline: Answers to the Carbon Paper Exam
text: I. Define these words and phrases:

headline: Balancing a Vacation and a Busy Office
text: Q.  You’d like to take some vacation time this summer, but you have a heavy workload and are worried about falling behind. Should you take time off anyway?

headline: Debating the Wisdom and Foolhardiness of the Hit-and-Run
text: Whatever happened to the hit-and-run? Players ran wild on the bases in the 1980s and early 1990s before baseball was overtaken by sluggers bashing home runs.

headline: Dallas Has Its Own Indie Film Scene, and a Festival
text: For a generation of young Texans eager to write and direct their own movies, the message has long been the same: head to Austin, that promised land of “Slacker” and South by Southwest and the ever-expanding Alamo Drafthouse franchise. With its high-profile residents — among them Richard Linklater, Robert Rodriguez and Terrence Malick — its myriad film festivals and the University of Texas film program, it is a city known for its worshipful devotion to a certain brand of independent-spirited cinema.

headline: Every Vote Is Valuable, but How Much Is Too Much?
text: In his failed bid for the 33rd Congressional District, Dr. David Alameel, a dental center mogul, spent more than $2.6 million — almost all of which came from his own pocket. But his investment did not translate to the ballot box. He received 2,064 votes for an average of $1,276.78 spent per vote received.

headline: Unlikely Hockey Hot Spot: Redondo Beach
text: REDONDO BEACH, Calif. — Flagpoles bearing the standards of Canada and Quebec stake a claim to a small parcel in the midst of beachgoers.

headline: A House of Strangers Calls for a Shrewd Leader
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Crosses Are Gone, but Campus Clash Lives On
text: Last fall, Sissy Bradford, an adjunct instructor who taught criminology at Texas A&M University-San Antonio, questioned why crosses were being placed near the public university’s entrance. Last month, she was informed that the university would not offer her any courses to teach in the fall semester. Ms. Bradford insists there is a connection, but university officials deny any link.

headline: Earl Shorris, 75, Dies; Fought Poverty With Knowledge
text: Earl Shorris, a social critic and author whose interviews with prison inmates for a book inspired him to start a now nationally recognized educational program that introduces the poor and the unschooled to Plato, Kant and Tolstoy, died on May 27 in New York. He was 75.

headline: Pain Pills Add Cost and Delays to Job Injuries
text: Workplace insurers are accustomed to making billions of dollars in payments each year, with the biggest sums going to employees hurt in major accidents, like those mangled by machines or crushed in building collapses.

headline: For Venerable New Zealand Star, Titles and Battles Keep Coming
text: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — The joke making the rounds after Leinster won the Heineken Cup was that Brad Thorn was going to join the soccer club Chelsea because he wanted to add the Premier League and Champions League trophies to his pool room.

headline: Myth-Labeled
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — WARNING: It wouldn’t be fair to super-constructor Patrick Berry to keep comparing all of his puzzles to his stunning suite that ran last October during the “Cross” Words Contest, so we’re not going to do that. At least we’re going to try not to. That’s what happens, though, when you are such an exceptionally talented artist: the bar is set so high that it’s difficult to exceed it every time.

headline: Moving On Sooner, Butler Is Scrambling
text: INDIANAPOLIS (AP) — It is a warm spring afternoon in Indianapolis, and the Butler basketball coaches are already going full throttle.

headline: What's the Best Way to Break Society's Bad Habits?
text: Is it the government’s role to change people’s behavior and make them live healthier lives? And if so, what’s the most effective way to do it?

headline: Major Players in the European Debt Crisis
text: A grouping of the key figures who chart the course of Europe’s economy, including national, European and international leaders.

headline: Reader Comments on my Nuba Mountains Column
text: My Sunday column was a particularly heartbreaking one to report. It’s from the Nuba Mountains of Sudan, where the government is trying to bomb and starve the Nuba people into submission. Please read the column, post your comments, and spread the word. This has been going on for a year now, and it continues in part because there has been so little attention, so little outrage.

headline: In Economic Deluge, a World That Can’t Bail Together
text: Less than four years ago, with the world’s financial system in danger of collapsing, major countries managed to come together on a coordinated course that averted a global depression.

headline: Drawing Top Athletes Into the Fight Game
text: Michael King, 64, knows something about heavyweights — television heavyweights. He spent most of his career in charge of King World Productions, which distributed “Wheel of Fortune,” “Jeopardy!” and “The Oprah Winfrey Show.”

headline: Oil Output Soars as Iraq Retools, Easing Shaky Markets
text: BAGHDAD — Despite sectarian bombings and political gridlock, Iraq’s crude oil production is soaring, providing a singular bright spot for the nation’s future and relief for global oil markets as the West tightens sanctions on Iranian exports.

headline: Not Yet in High School, but Able to Receive College Scholarship Offers
text: ATLANTA — There is no way Mo Lewis could have anticipated the inevitable father-son chat coming this soon.

headline: Durably Dominant American View: Humans are a Recent Divine Creation
text: A fresh poll by the Gallup Organization shows that since 1982 there has been hardly a flicker in the dominance of the American view that God created humans in essentially modern form within the last 10,000 years:

headline: Day After No-Hitter, Dickey Puts Up More Zeros
text: R. A. Dickey saw the ninth inning of Johan Santana’s no-hitter with a towel wrapped around his head, because he could not bring himself to watch what was unfolding. The ninth inning was too much, Dickey said, so he focused on Santana and his reactions, wanting the no-hitter so badly for both Santana and the city of New York.

headline: Top Choices Can No Longer Break the Bank
text: Bryce Harper and Stephen Strasburg, teammates on the Washington Nationals, were baseball’s closest equivalents to the hype-inducing draft picks of the N.B.A. and N.F.L., and they used that hype to demand lucrative major league contracts.

headline: Yankee Recalls the Catch That Saved a No-Hitter
text: DETROIT — Dewayne Wise rarely gets to play for the Yankees these days. But in the aftermath of Johan Santana’s no-hitter for the Mets on Friday night, Wise’s face and glove kept showing up on ESPN’s “SportsCenter” replay Saturday morning.

headline: In Bosh’s Absence, Heat Face an Inside Problem
text: BOSTON — One of the tedious but necessary questions that Miami Coach Erik Spoelstra fields before each game is listing the inactive players for that night’s contest. Recently, he has listed Chris Bosh and someone else not nearly as important.

headline: Candidates Have College, Spicy Chicken and ‘Star Trek’ in Common
text: WASHINGTON — Points of unity: Mitt Romney and President Obama both like process-driven decisions, iPads, ABC’s “Modern Family” and chicken.

headline: Devils Follow Example of Their Coaches’ Success
text: NEWARK — If there was one thing the Devils were sure about as they went into Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night, it was the pedigree of the coaches behind their bench.

headline: Mets Manager’s Agonizing Did Not End With Santana’s Final Out
text: Casting shadows upon the afterglow of Johan Santana’s no-hitter were concerns about the effect the effort may have on his surgically repaired left shoulder.

headline: For Nadal, a Stroll to a Victory; for His Next Opponent, a Marathon
text: PARIS — There was no need for Rafael Nadal to scrawl an apology in the clay at Roland Garros on Saturday.

headline: The Wars of Carl Schurz
text: In the early months of 1862, Carl Schurz took leave of his post as ambassador to Spain to make a daring step he had been contemplating for months: he wanted a commission in the Army. In a face-to-face meeting with Abraham Lincoln in March, the 33-year-old German immigrant explained that he found the luxurious life of a diplomat “intolerable” while his adopted nation “was fighting for its life.” Lincoln acquiesced, though not without pointing out that Schurz was giving up prestige, comfort, and a “large salary” for a position that paid “little” and would bring “plenty of work,” “discomfort,” and “danger.”

headline: Chavez, the Venezuelan President, Sends Congratulatory Wishes to Santana
text: Among the people who reached out to congratulate Johan Santana, the Venezuelan left-hander who had just thrown a the first no-hitter in Mets history Friday night, was Hugo Chavez, the Venezuelan president who is a huge baseball fan.

headline: In Between Cigarette Breaks, Player Seeking First Win Takes Lead at Memorial
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — As soon as Spencer Levin struck the putt, he started walking, a sure sign he had misread the line. Levin played his first six holes on Saturday in four under par to take the third-round lead at the Memorial Tournament. But as his par putt rolled toward the hole on the par-3 eighth, Levin was certain he was staring at his second straight bogey. He believed it right up until the ball caught the edge of the hole, rimmed around and, much to his disbelief, dropped.

headline: For Olympic Contenders, the Prefontaine Serves as a Tuneup and as a Barometer
text: EUGENE, Ore. — It’s called the Prefontaine Classic, or “the Pre,” but for many Olympic hopefuls, “Pre” doubled as shorthand for preview of their competition leading into the United States track trials, which will take place here at the end of the month.

headline: For a Cardinals Pitcher, It’s Also a Night of Firsts
text: Sam Freeman warmed up the way he always had, taking his time. He has always been a creature of habit, he said Saturday, the day after he made his major league debut with the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: A Met Who Came Close, Seaver Praises Santana
text: Tom Seaver, the Mets’ greatest pitcher, said he was unaware that Johan Santana had pitched the team’s first no-hitter Friday night against the St. Louis Cardinals until he went for his morning run the next day.

headline: Gunman Kills One and Injures Seven at Toronto Mall
text: OTTAWA — One man was killed and seven other people were injured after a gunman opened fire in a crowded food court Saturday evening in downtown Toronto’s largest shopping mall, the police said.

headline: Corrections: June 3
text: NEW YORK

headline: Behind Flurry by Durant, Thunder Even Series
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The stage was set for a grand finale, and as Kevin Durant delivered a dunk and awaited a trip to the free-throw line, he sought out Serge Ibaka and Kendrick Perkins and tapped each of the big men on the chest.

headline: Instant Replay: Kings Win Again
text: NEWARK — For the Los Angeles Kings, this season’s playoffs are looking more and more like a coronation, a regal procession to the Stanley Cup.

headline: Ferrying a Drug Into a Cancer Cell
text: Investigators released preliminary results from a clinical trial of T-DM1, a drug that targets and kills a type of cell that appears in some breast cancers.

headline: Interrupting Prostate Cancer Treatment Could Shorten Life, Study Finds
text: CHICAGO — Taking periodic breaks from a commonly used treatment for prostate cancer could shorten men’s lives, researchers reported here on Saturday.

headline: In Study, Drug Delays Worsening of Breast Cancer, With Fewer Side Effects
text: CHICAGO — A drug that delivers a powerful poison to tumors without some of the side effects of traditional treatments can delay the worsening of breast cancer and also appears to substantially prolong lives, according to results of a study presented here Saturday.

headline: Tigers Top Yankees’ Rally With One of Their Own in Bottom of Ninth
text: DETROIT — Anyone watching a baseball game at which someone in a Darth Vader costume throws out the first pitch, which happened before the Yankees played the Detroit Tigers here Saturday night, should not be surprised when more strange things unfold later on.
