headline: ‘How Horrible Wars Can Be’
text: HONG KONG — “Too hot!” she was screaming. “Too hot!”

headline: Another Good Night for Brodeur, but Only a Great One Would Do
text: NEWARK — Martin Brodeur tried planting his stick on the ice to stop Jeff Carter’s shot from the high slot, but Brodeur made his move a split-second too late. The Los Angeles Kings then swarmed Carter to celebrate as Brodeur skated off the ice, another good night undone.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Open magazine takes a look at Pakistan’s “newly liberated” media and reports that it is taking on India bashers.

headline: Kings’ Doughty Rises to Potential, at Just the Right Time
text: NEWARK — The best defenseman on the top pairing on the hottest team in the N.H.L. logged the most ice time in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night, just as he did in the series opener. Drew Doughty of the Kings tallied Los Angeles’s first goal, and he gazed helplessly from five feet away when the Devils tied the score. He delivered several crushing hits, and he committed what could have been a critical penalty in the waning minutes of regulation.

headline: David Wright’s Contract Non-Situation
text: David Wright repeated on Saturday that he did not wish to negotiate a new contract during the season.

headline: Vikram Gandhi’s Documentary ‘Kumaré’
text: “In his early 20s Vikram Gandhi, a fledgling Indian-American filmmaker from New Jersey, decided to make a documentary about the yoga industry in the United States, focusing on its offshoot, the guru,”Kathryn Shattuck  writes in The New York Times.

headline: A ‘Quietly Mesmerizing’ Novel Set in the Himalayas
text: “Late in this quietly mesmerizing novel, set in a Himalayan hill town in the north of India,” Andrea Thompson writes  in The Sunday Book Review section of The New York Times, Anuradha Roy “describes the crystalline beauty of the peaks in winter, viewed long after the haze of the summer months and the fog of the monsoon, held in secret for those who choose to brave the cold.”

headline: Common Goals Demand a United Front
text: It has been more than a year since I published my first, and last, book, “Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy.” The entire experience has been life-altering, including managing the Web site that provided daily updates on Barbaro; researching the book, which included a two-year stint working for the trainer Steve Asmussen; writing the book; and selling it.

headline: Russia’s Stance on Syria Poses a Challenge for E.U.
text: BRUSSELS — European Union-Russia summit meetings haven’t changed much since the last time Vladimir V. Putin was president, which was five years ago. Then, as now, there were talks about energy and the economic and investment climate in Russia. Sore spots: visa rules and Russian bans on imports of certain European farm products.
Update below

headline: Assad Condemns Houla Massacre, Blaming Terrorists
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad denied Sunday that the Syrian government played a role in the massacre in the village of Houla, using his first speech in five months to reiterate his line that foreigners were fomenting the violence in Syria.

headline: At the Spoleto Festival USA, Chamber Music Continues to Fly Under the Radar
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The big classical music draws at the Spoleto Festival USA are usually the operas: this year, Philip Glass’s “Kepler” and Guo Wenjing’s “Feng Yi Ting” (which will make its way to the Lincoln Center Festival next month). But if comparatively few festivalgoers travel to Charleston specifically for the chamber music concerts, they have been a popular and consistent part of this 35-year-old festival’s personality from the start.

headline: Ashley Biden and Howard Krein
text: Ashley Blazer Biden, the daughter of Jill Jacobs Biden and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., was married Saturday evening to Dr. Howard David Krein, a son of Bunny Lipner Krein and Stanley Krein of Cherry Hill, N.J. The Rev. David F. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Joseph on the Brandywine Church in Greenville, Del., with Rabbi Joseph Forman assisting.

headline: Britain Celebrates Queen’s 60-Year Reign
text: LONDON — Braving a day of bone-chilling, rain-dampened weather, a crowd estimated by the police at more than a million people lined the banks of the Thames on Sunday to acclaim Queen Elizabeth II as she marked 60 years on the throne with a royal river pageant of a kind last seen 350 years ago.

headline: Playing Too Well for Your Own Good
Swimming in Sync At a London Hotel
text: Women with a case of Olympic fever can try to ease it with a dip in the pool at The Berkeley hotel in London, where synchronized swimming classes are being offered this summer.

headline: Charlotte Decker and Gabriel Morgan
text: Charlotte Wanita Decker and Gabriel Adam Morgan were married Saturday afternoon at Blackberry Farm, a resort in Walland, Tenn. The Rev. Celeste A. Schroeder, a minister of the Light of Christ Community Church, officiated.

headline: A Sport That Inspires a Sharp Wit
text: For all the eloquent and evocative writing there has been about golf, some of the best contributions to the lore, appreciation and understanding of the game have been spoken. There have been funny and perceptive things uttered about other sports, but there just seem to be more memorable quotations about golf. Here are a few of my favorites.

headline: Katherine Hynes and Thomas Scott
text: Katherine Vance Hynes, a daughter of Anne Marie and James Hynes of Riverside, Conn., was married Saturday in Greenwich, Conn., to Thomas Everett Scott, a son of Darby A. Scott and Daniel T. Scott of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Ciprian Bejan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel in the Convent of the Sacred Heart school, from which the bride graduated.

headline: Alison Butterfass and John Zagat
text: Alison Lauren Butterfass, a daughter of Susan Morris Butterfass and Stephen Eliot Butterfass of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Dr. John Alexander Zagat, a son of Nina Zagat and Tim Zagat of New York, are to be married Sunday in New York. Cantor Steve Sher is to officiate at the Water Club.

headline: Xbox Gives Microsoft a Head Start in the Battle for Every Screen
text: Given the relentless battles by tech companies to win new smartphone users, you would think that the tiny screen is the only one that matters.

headline: Thames Flotilla Highlight of Diamond Jubilee Celebrations
text: Tens of thousands gathered in London to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II’s diamond jubilee with an extravagant river pageant.

headline: Lawsuit Shakes Man’s World of Tech
text: Are the men who invented the Internet trapped in the past even as they create the future? That’s the debate that has sprung up here since Ellen Pao, a junior partner in her early 40s at the distinguished venture capital firm of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, filed a sexual discrimination lawsuit against the company and her colleagues there, reports David Streitfeld in Sunday’s New York Times. Although the accusations have yet to be heard in court, even some of Ms. Pao’s critics concede that she is exposing an uncomfortable truth about Silicon Valley: starting tech companies in 2012 is still a male game, and so is funding them.

headline: Adjustable Drivers Fix Some Problems While Posing Others
text: With the market flooded with adjustable drivers, I wondered if these new tools were affecting golf instruction. Are people no longer asking their pros to fix their driver swings because all their problems are fixable by opening or closing the face with a click of a wrench or by moving some weights in the club head?

headline: Cooler Weather Brings Trouble for Top Players at French Open
text: PARIS — The weather changed at the French Open, and the top of the tennis pyramid shook.

headline: Euro Zone Is Lurching to a Crossroad
text: LONDON — As Spain’s economic crisis deepens and uncertainty swirls over Greece’s future in the euro zone, the guardians of the increasingly fragile European monetary union are near a moment of truth: can they muster the will and resources to keep the euro zone from breaking apart?

headline: Warming Arctic Tundra Producing Pop-Up Forests
text: Even as insect infestations and other factors accompanying warming have led to the “browning” of some stretches of boreal forest between temperate regions and the Arctic tundra, the tundra appears to be greening in a big way, various studies have shown. The newest such work, focused on scrubby windswept regions along Russia’s northwest Arctic coast, has found a particularly noteworthy shift is under way.

headline: Obeying Judge’s Order, Zimmerman Turns Himself In and Is Back in a Florida Jail
text: MIAMI — Six weeks after being released from jail on bond, George Zimmerman, who is facing second-degree murder charges in the death of Trayvon Martin, is back behind bars.

headline: In the Disability, Stress the Ability
text: “Push Girls,” a reality show about five attractive women in wheelchairs, is likely to engender a number of reactions in viewers, not all of them helpful to the cause of illuminating the lives of people with disabilities. From the premiere, showing Monday night on the Sundance Channel, it’s not entirely clear which of those reactions the series’s creators are going for. But the intent seems to be good, and if they can find the elusive line between voyeuristic and didactic, the show could become something of a milestone for a lot of people who have felt invisible for a long time.

headline: A Fairy-Tale Weekend for ‘Snow White and the Huntsman’
text: Kristen Stewart, some gnarly dwarfs and a bloody fairy tale prevailed, as “Snow White and the Huntsman” led the weekend box-office results at North American theaters with about $56.3 million in ticket sales for Universal Pictures. It was an impressive feat, because the film opened without a 3-D version and the accompanying higher-priced tickets, though it took some technology to squeeze the likes of Bob Hoskins and Ray Winstone into their diminutive roles.

headline: A $1 Cigarette Tax Starts a $47 Million Brawl in California
text: LOS ANGELES — California has some of the toughest antismoking laws in the country — it is illegal, in some places, to smoke in your own apartment — and boasts the second-lowest per capita smoking rate in the 50 states. But for all the disdain toward smoking, it has been 14 years since California raised its cigarette tax, a tribute to the power of the tobacco industry here and the waning of this state’s antitobacco dominance.

headline: Velazquez Teams With Union Rags for Impressive Work
text: ELKTON, Md. — John Velazquez made the journey from New York to Fair Hill Training Center in Maryland on Sunday morning to ride Union Rags for the first time. Union Rags was scheduled to put in his final work, ahead of Saturday’s Belmont Stakes. Things could not have gone more perfectly.

headline: Feel the Fraudulence
text: Apparently I said something harsh but true this morning.

headline: A Daddy for ‘Annie’
text: The Broadway-bound “Annie” has found its Daddy. The Australian opera and musical-theater singer Anthony Warlow will make his Broadway debut as the billionaire industrialist Daddy Warbucks in the coming revival of the 1977 musical, the show’s producers announced on Sunday. Mr. Warlow will star opposite the previously announced cast members Katie Finneran as Miss Hannigan and Lilla Crawford as Annie.

headline: Granderson Calls for More Accountability for Umpires
text: DETROIT — Yankees center fielder Curtis Granderson used Saturday night’s ejections of the hitting coach Kevin Long and Manager Joe Girardi by the plate umpire Bob Davidson to call for greater accountability for umpires.

headline: The Level of Government Spending
text: A quick note on what has happened to the level of government spending since the economic crisis began.

headline: Philip Glass, at Spoleto USA as Speaker and Spectator, Also Performs
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Philip Glass was not at the first performances of “Kepler,” his opera about the German mathematician and astronomer that opened here at the Spoleto Festival USA on May 26. But he flew in for the closing performance of the run, on Saturday. And while he was in town, he sat for an hourlong public interview and an impromptu performance at the Dock Street Theater on Saturday afternoon, as part of the festival’s “Music in Time” series.

headline: Forces of Nature and Ecstasy
text: Since the conductor and composer Julian Wachner became the director of music and arts at Trinity Wall Street in September 2010 he has pursued at least two distinct agendas. He has increased the amount of contemporary music performed by the church’s admirable Trinity Choir, bolstering that move by inaugurating a new instrumental ensemble, Novus NY. He has also taken steps to make the choir more visible outside its native habitat of Lower Manhattan, like mounting one of its cherished annual performances of Handel’s “Messiah” at Alice Tully Hall last year.

headline: A Line Dance Charged With Meaning
text: The dabke is a line dance of the Levant. At weddings in Jordan, Lebanon and Syria, people link up arm to shoulder or hand in hand and stomp out rhythms and patterns. Israelis, so often at odds with their neighbors, also have a version. Dances are easier to share than territory.

headline: Tunes From ‘Screwy Bally-Hooey’ Warner Brothers
text: Attention all ye would-be hosts, writers and performers aspiring to the venerable 92nd Street Y series Lyrics & Lyricists. The season finale, “It’s Magic: Nine Decades of Songs From Warner Brothers,” is a master class on how to escape the pitfalls of stuffy nostalgic reverence and make show business history crackle. Solemnity is the enemy, enthusiasm the key and insider’s gossip the secret ingredient. A sample: Kissing Ronald Reagan, Alexis Smith once confided to Rex Reed, the show’s host and writer, was like licking an elbow. There’s a lot more where that came from.

headline: A Sly Take on Creativity
text: When you’re sitting before Rebecca Patek, you must be patient. “Um,” she said at the start of her performance, “Real Eyes,” at the Chocolate Factory on Thursday night. “Hi. Um. I’m Rebecca. Um.”

headline: ‘Carmina Burana’ Specialists From Spain Enliven a Favorite
text: The veteran Spanish conductor Rafael Frühbeck de Burgos gave the New York Philharmonic audience everything it had come to Avery Fisher Hall for on Thursday evening, and more. (The concert was the first in a subscription series that ended on Saturday.)

headline: Yawns to Laughs: Audiences Shape a Play
text: During rehearsals for his new Off Broadway play, “Storefront Church,” John Patrick Shanley rewrote the final scene 20 times before he was satisfied. But it wasn’t until the production’s first preview, on May 16, that he discovered other scenes needed revising too. The evidence came from audiences — the sort of patrons who pay to attend Off Broadway shows early on and have more power than they may realize to shape new plays, even one by a Pulitzer Prize winner like Mr. Shanley (“Doubt”).

headline: With Eye on Qualifying, Michael Bradley Is Eager to Get Back to Work
text: With the United States national team set to take on Canada Sunday night at Toronto’s BMO Field, midfielder Michael Bradley is anxious to get back onto the field after Wednesday’s 4-1 loss to Brazil.

headline: Japan Arrests Fugitive Wanted in 1995 Gas Attack
text: TOKYO — The police on Sunday arrested one of the two remaining fugitive suspects from the doomsday cult behind the 1995 nerve-gas attack on the Tokyo subway, Japanese media reported.

headline: Out of Dark, Onto Field
text: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt — Bob Bradley stood at attention as a full military band played the anthem of his adoptive country. In front of him, Egypt’s national soccer team, which he began managing about nine months ago, was lined up on the field at the 80,000-capacity Borg el Arab military stadium, the players singing proudly.

headline: A Jail Guard’s Tale of His Journey to Inmate
text: Gary Heyward stood on 125th Street in Harlem, not far from the Apollo Theater, wearing a jumpsuit that was half blue and half orange.

headline: I.S.S. Backs Two Starboard Nominees for AOL Board
text: Institutional Shareholder Services has recommended that AOL investors vote for two of three board candidates named by Starboard Value, an activist hedge fund.

headline: Contemporary Movement With a Foot (or a Leg) in Earlier Times
text: Contemporary dance in America is often described as experimental. One unfortunate result of such lazy contextualizing, often, is to obscure that these artists, however progressive-minded, are working within and influenced by very distinct movement traditions. Twenty-first-century choreographers aren’t breaking new ground, at least not in the old sense of the avant-garde — and that isn’t a bad thing.

headline: Yankees Solve Verlander, Ending Trip on High Note
text: DETROIT — Seventeen seasons of playing for the Yankees have conditioned Derek Jeter to expect scenes like this, and to make fun of them.

headline: Loneliness of 7-Eleven for Indian Immigrant
text: Dhiraj, the Indian immigrant father in Mayank Keshaviah’s unsatisfying play “Rangoon,” a Pan Asian Repertory production, is like a Tiger Dad mixed with a Jewish mother. He loves to guilt-trip his children and has such high expectations for them that when his son brings home an excellent report card, he still gets scolded: “An A minus is not an A.”

headline: William Hanley, Playwright and TV Writer, Dies at 80
text: William Hanley, who received critical acclaim as a Broadway and Off Broadway playwright in the 1960s and who later won Emmys for television scripts, died on May 25 at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 80.

headline: Philosophy’s Western Bias
text: There is much talk in academic philosophy about the need to open up the discipline to so-called non-Western traditions and perspectives, both through changes to the curriculum and also within the demographics of philosophy departments themselves. These two aspects are seen as connected: it is thought that greater representation of non-Western philosophy will help to bring about greater diversity among the women and men who make up the philosophical community.

headline: Stick Episodes Aside, Kings Feeling Comfortable With 2-0 Series Lead
text: The feeling now is that the Kings will win the Stanley Cup, and that only the details (number of games, parade route) need to be worked out. Whether or not that bears out, the team’s second consecutive 2-1 overtime victory against the Devils — after a circular tour of the Devils’ zone by Jeff Carter that was as mesmerizing as Anze Kopitar’s breakaway in Game 1 — lifted a weight off of the organization that had been lingering for 19 years.

headline: Richard Dawson, Host Who Kissed on ‘Family Feud’, Dies at 79
text: Richard Dawson, the British-born actor and comedian who played a larcenous prisoner of war on the comedy “Hogan’s Heroes” and became a star as the dapper and gregarious host of the game show “Family Feud,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: Winning Start for Bradley’s Egypt, but Challenges Are Many
text: Bob Bradley on Friday coached his first World Cup qualifier since being hired as Egypt’s manager last year, but he did so in an empty stadium — a consequence of the violence that plagued the country in general and soccer games in particular in the wake of the overthrow of the former president Hosni Mubarak. James Montague was in Alexandria for the game, reporting on the hardships, the sadness, the challenges and the pride Bradley feels as he tries to lead the Pharoahs back to their customary place atop African soccer.

headline: Metalheads of All Alloys, Swirling Into the Night
text: TAMPA, Fla. — At the end of a loud, slow and steadying set on Saturday night by the doom-metal band Saint Vitus, its singer Scott Weinrich, known as Wino, methodically distributed Pabst Blue Ribbon tall boys to members of the audience and sang an old song, “Born Too Late,” over big riffs, a restful tempo and a minor key. It was music with little anxiety.

headline: Orbiting the Grid
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Welcome back for another week of solving!

headline: Talent Agency Adds Brand Strategy Unit
text: A TALENT agency whose clients bear names that are like brands in Hollywood — among them, Johnny Depp, Channing Tatum, Judd Apatow and Jennifer Lopez — is getting more deeply into the brand-building business.

headline: When Defending Earth Cost 25 Cents
text: LACONIA, N.H. — You insert a token. With a joystick and a button you blast away at robots, spaceships and meteors advancing from all sides. Eventually your last man dies. Game over.

headline: An Actor Finds a Role Too Real
text: Paris on the brink. World War II looming. A place of culinary, erotic, conversational, sartorial and so many other pleasures. A place of elegance and discretion. The aromas of “a thousand years of rain dripping on stone,” of “rough black tobacco and garlic and drains.” And now, the smell of fear too.

headline: Lifting Off to Copland and Stucky
text: Clara Longstreth, the music director of the estimable New Amsterdam Singers, has a knack for putting together engaging programs with a thematic hook. But as she notes on the chorus’s Web site, a “theme is only good if every piece is a winner, not included just because it serves a theme.”

headline: Tribute to Composer Revered for Her Iconoclastic Ways
text: Darmstadt Institute, an annual new-music festival founded in 2008 by the New York composers Nick Hallett and Zach Layton, has become one of the city’s most reliable sources for concerts as entertaining as they are edifying. Equally important, the series is a crowbar meant to pry open a rigid canon and admit outliers whose work, however obscure, has proved significant and durable.

headline: Playing the Blues While Inside Prison Walls
text: Filmed at the Louisiana State Penitentiary, “Music From the Big House,” Bruce McDonald’s loosely built documentary, yields the cognitive dissonance of being entertained by performers convicted of rape, murder and other offenses. The Canadian blues singer Rita Chiarelli acts as our ambassador to a realm of life sentences and strained redemption as she and the inmates put on a concert within this notorious prison known as Angola, formerly the site of a slave plantation.

headline: New Tabloid by Murdoch Losing Sales
text: LONDON — Rupert Murdoch has endured a litany of blows in the unending phone-hacking scandal at his British tabloids. But one setback isn’t happening in Parliament, but on Britain’s newsstands.

headline: Reisinger Knockout Teams in New York City
text: The 52-board final of the Reisinger Knockout Teams took place on Thursday and Friday evenings at the Manhattan Bridge Club. After three low-scoring quarters Margie Gwozdzinsky, Ira Herman, Pietro Campanile, Brian Glubok, Allen Kahn and Jeffrey Rothstein led by 21 international match points.

headline: Pregame: Canada vs. U.S.
text: The United and Canada share a long soccer history that dates to 1925, the first official international, won by Canada in Montreal, 1-0, on June 27. The American team has a 13-8-9 overall record against Canada and is riding a 14-game unbeaten streak (8-0-6) since losing by 2-0 in Vancouver, British Columbia on April 2, 1985.

headline: Valentino to Create Ballet Costumes
text: The Italian designer Valentino Garavani will create costumes for three works by the New York City Ballet, to be performed for one night at its annual fall gala, the company is to announce on Monday. The gala, to be held at Lincoln Center on Sept. 20, will feature a new ballet set to selections from Tchaikovsky’s “Eugene Onegin” and a performance of George Balanchine’s “Rubies” as a tribute to the signature use of red by the designer simply known as Valentino, above. “There is so much beauty in the ballet, the grace, the fluidity,” Valentino said in a news release. He said he was honored to have City Ballet “celebrate my work in this way, and I am very passionate about the design of these very special costumes.” Benefit-priced tickets for the gala are available at (212) 870-5585. Tickets to the performance only go on sale Aug. 6 through (212) 496-0600 or nycballet.com.

headline: Carly Simon to Share Her Life Story in Book
text: Carly Simon is joining the pack of musicians who have gone from writing and performing for the stage to telling all in memoirs. Random House announced on Sunday that it would publish Ms. Simon’s autobiography — the story of her childhood, “the discovery of her life-altering stammer, her meteoric rise and unparalleled career in music, and her loves, including her marriage to James Taylor.” Ms. Simon, above, a daughter of Richard L. Simon, a founder of Simon & Schuster, said she had an early awareness of the publishing industry, writing in a diary even as a child. “After years of keeping journals and writing lyrics for my tunes, I have developed a strong interest in seeing how my life might just string together in a longer form,” she said in a statement. “I know I’ll be looking for a strong chorus, like a repeating dream or theme.” Ms. Simon told Reuters in a recent interview that she was busy writing her book and planned to finish it by year’s end. Susan Kamil, the publisher of Random House, said in an e-mail that Ms. Simon’s “prose on the page is powerful, evocative, narrative driven, and the stories she tells are riveting.” Random House has not announced a publication date.

headline: A New Publisher for Richard Dawkins
text: Richard Dawkins, the evolutionary biologist, has moved to a new publisher for his next book, the story of his intellectual evolution and his work as an atheist. Ecco, an imprint of HarperCollins, said on Sunday that it had acquired the North American rights to Mr. Dawkins’s book, which is not yet titled. Daniel Halpern, the publisher of Ecco, said in a statement: “We couldn’t be more excited to be working with a thinker and writer as profound and influential as Richard Dawkins. It is truly an honor to have him at Ecco.” An Ecco spokesman said the book was tentatively scheduled for release in the fall of 2014.

headline: Newspapers Cut Days From Publishing Week
text: The news waits for no one. But newspapers might start asking readers to — at least for print copies.

headline: Bike-Sharing Comes to New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Kafka Behind the Plate

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be reported this week will include: factory orders for April (Monday); the Institute for Supply Management service index for May (Tuesday); revised first-quarter productivity and the Federal Reserve’s beige book (Wednesday); consumer credit for April and weekly unemployment claims (Thursday); and the trade deficit and wholesale trade inventories for April (Friday).

headline: Scion Rock Fest
text: Scenes from the music festival in Tampa, Fla.

headline: Champion of Gay Rights to Leave New York State Senate
text: State Senator Thomas K. Duane, who first burst onto the political scene two decades ago, when he disclosed during a successful bid for City Council that he was H.I.V. positive, and later made his mark as the first openly gay member of the Senate, has decided not to seek re-election.

headline: Why We Fear Mormons
text: Provo, Utah

headline: Expert Issues a Cyberwar Warning
text: MOSCOW — When Eugene Kaspersky, the founder of Europe’s largest antivirus company, discovered the Flame virus that is afflicting computers in Iran and the Middle East, he recognized it as a technologically sophisticated virus that only a government could create.

headline: Mining for Influence in Montana
text: Helena, Mont.

headline: Brash Chef and Big Bet for CNN
text: Michael K. Williams played Omar Little, the righteous stickup man in “The Wire,” and now plays Chalky White, the bootlegger on “Boardwalk Empire,” so he is a big deal in the Brooklyn housing projects where he grew up. Standing in Gloria’s 3, a Trinidadian restaurant in nearby Crown Heights last Thursday, he said he had fun running around his old neighborhood. But he added that it was the man he was with who created most of the fuss.

headline: June Brings Harbingers for the Fall
text: To understand what is happening in a presidential campaign, it is sometimes important to look elsewhere.

headline: Asleep at the Laptop
text: THE alarm bells sound regularly: cybergeddon; the next Pearl Harbor; one of the greatest existential threats facing the United States. With increasing frequency, these are the grave terms officials invoke about the menace of cybercrime — and they’re not understating the threat.

headline: Hints of a Rift Between Myanmar’s Political Reformers
text: MAE SOT, Thailand — The first trip abroad in more than two decades by Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, appears to have strained her crucial relationship with President U Thein Sein, who is leading the country’s transformation from military dictatorship to embryonic democracy.

headline: In Lists of Best High Schools, Numbers Don’t Tell the Whole Story
text: This is the time of year when the lists of best high schools in the United States are published. For anxious consumers, the number of lists can be daunting, whether national in scope (U.S. News & World Report; The Washington Post; Newsweek and The Daily Beast) or local (Boston magazine; New Jersey Monthly; The Chicago Sun-Times).

headline: Stephens Stays Close, but Comes Up Short Against Stosur
text: PARIS — Sloane Stephens of the United States surrendered a first-set lead and could not recover in a tightly contested loss, 7-5, 6-4, to Sam Stosur of Australia on Sunday at the French Open.

headline: A Star, and Maybe a Future One
text: PARIS

headline: 100 Days of Madness as the ‘King of Fruits’ Is Celebrated Again
text: MUMBAI, India — Inside his tiny office near the entrance of Crawford Market, Arvind Morde is a bit harried. It is mango season, after all. His telephone rings. A client wants to ship a box of mangoes to Germany, a gift for the Indian-born conductor Zubin Mehta. Another caller wants to send a box to Switzerland; still another, to Singapore.

headline: With Fanfare, Ashanti People From Ghana Install Their New York Chief
text: The elders had poured libations, the holy men had delivered invocations, and all had sworn allegiance to the Ashanti kingdom. A battery of percussionists, glistening with sweat, started pounding out waves of rhythm that brought hundreds of guests, draped in elaborate kente cloth, to their feet.

headline: This Republican Economy
text: What should be done about the economy? Republicans claim to have the answer: slash spending and cut taxes. What they hope voters won’t notice is that that’s precisely the policy we’ve been following the past couple of years. Never mind the Democrat in the White House; for all practical purposes, this is already the economic policy of Republican dreams.

headline: Some Lawmakers Look for Way Out as Defense Cuts Near
text: SUMTER, S.C. — Senator Lindsey Graham rode last week like Paul Revere from South Carolina’s wooded upstate to its gracious Lowcountry to its sweltering midsection, offering a bureaucratic rallying cry for his military-heavy state — the defense cuts are coming.

headline: A Dream Fades Under Paris Clouds
text: PARIS — It had been a heady week at Roland Garros for Treat Huey of Charlottesville, Va., but his French Open ended Sunday in a straight-set loss in a third-round doubles match.

headline: For Bronx Private School, All the City’s a Classroom in an Experiential Course
text: On a drizzly Tuesday morning, Shiloh Shabazz, a wiry and excitable 71-year-old, was talking about sleeping on subways, on and under park benches, and generally about being an addict and a nomad. “Crack was big. Base was big,” he said of the time when he was using drugs. The shelters, he said, were rough.

headline: Playmaker and Cup Winner Has Helped Fuel Kings
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — Understanding Justin Williams’s value to the Los Angeles Kings during the Stanley Cup playoffs involves a simple comparison.

headline: JPMorgan Was Warned About Lax Risk Controls
text: A small group of shareholder advocates delivered an urgent message to top executives at JPMorgan Chase more than a year ago: the bank’s risk controls needed to be improved.

headline: The Tension of Teaching Journalism in China
text: Can you teach journalism without free speech?

headline: Political Clashes and Vow of Appeal in Verdict on Mubarak and Aides
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military-led government said Sunday that it would appeal the weak verdicts delivered by a court on Saturday against former President Hosni Mubarak, his sons and top security officials of his government — verdicts that have intensified the polarization gripping Egypt two weeks before the runoff to decide Egypt’s first competitive presidential race.

headline: Whose Welfare?
text: Every week the campaign dollars pile up, by the tens of millions, by the hundreds of millions, to a level never before seen in American political life. Outside groups now say they plan to spend $1 billion on behalf of Republicans in the November election, which will probably be twice the level raised by groups supporting Democrats. Even the slush-funders of the Watergate era would have been slack-jawed at the number of seven- and eight-figure checks pouring into groups with names like Crossroads and Americans for Prosperity.

headline: Red Flags Were Raised on Client Cash, MF Global Inquiry Is Told
text: Federal investigators are conducting a final round of interviews with former MF Global employees, as they weigh whether to file criminal charges against some senior executives and grant another one immunity from prosecution.

headline: Women in Combat
text: More than 130 American women in military service have died in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. More than 800 women have been wounded. Women make up almost 15 percent of the 1.4 million Americans on active military status and many are regularly engaged in combat activities as part of their service.

headline: Woods, at His Best, Matches One of the Greats
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — There are “safe house” signs scattered around Muirfield Village Golf Club, residences of refuge for the golfers during weather delays. The course built by Jack Nicklaus, the Memorial Tournament host, has long been a shelter for Tiger Woods.

headline: A Start on the Dream
text: President Obama has been an overachiever on immigration enforcement, far outpacing his predecessor, George W. Bush, in swiftly racking up a million deportations. But on the other crucial part of reform — getting undocumented immigrants right with the law — Mr. Obama talks a lot but has done far too little.

headline: Fox Plans Special Trailers to Let Film’s 3-D Effects Shine
text: LOS ANGELES — The 3-D filmmaking in Ang Lee’s forthcoming “Life of Pi” is so remarkable in the eyes of 20th Century Fox that the studio has decided a typical trailer just won’t do.

headline: Hollywood Agent’s Estate Sale Displays Star Power
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s the little things that draw your notice, especially when it comes to celebrity estate sales.

headline: For Mets Fan, First a Field Trip, Then the Charges
text: When Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth’s home run record in 1974, two fans took to the field to celebrate and run alongside the new record-holder. Two years later, Chris Chambliss had to fight off the hordes of fans that overran Yankee Stadium after he hit the game-winning home run, earning the Yankees the American League pennant.

headline: The M.T.A. and Fairness
text: New York’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority closed an unfortunate chapter in its history last week when it settled a discrimination lawsuit brought by the United States Justice Department in 2004 over the agency’s treatment of Sikh and Muslim employees in the wake of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Treatment for Penis Curvature Sees Results
text: It can be painful and embarrassing for men: a disease that causes a curvature of the penis that makes intercourse difficult or impossible.

headline: Bank Case Gets Tribunal at Behest of Karzai
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Twenty-one criminal indictments in the huge Kabul Bank fraud case have been sent to a special tribunal at the urging of President Hamid Karzai, including that of the bank’s chairman and chief executive, Afghan officials said this weekend.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 3, 2012

headline: Adolfo Calero, Contra Leader in Nicaragua, Is Dead at 80
text: MEXICO CITY — Adolfo Calero, a leader of the American-backed contra rebels who fought Nicaragua’s revolutionary Sandinista government and eventually achieved its ouster through democratic elections, died on Saturday in Managua. He was 80.

headline: LeRoy Ellis, a Star Big Man at St. John’s, Dies at 72
text: LeRoy Ellis, a star center at St. John’s University who went on to a long N.B.A. career and played for the 1971-72 Los Angeles Lakers championship team that won a record 33 straight games, died on Saturday in Scappoose, Ore., a suburb of Portland. He was 72.

headline: As Vatican Manages Crisis, Book Details Infighting
text: VATICAN CITY — In an undisclosed location here, the Vatican authorities are busy questioning Paolo Gabriele, the pope’s butler, and others in a widening leaks scandal that has made the seat of the Roman Catholic Church appear to be a hornet’s nest of back-stabbing and gossip.

headline: Contentious Hire Puts Spotlight on Black Coaches
text: For more than two decades, Fitzgerald Hill has fought to have minority and African-American head football coaches hired at predominantly white colleges and universities. In his new book, “Crackback: How College Football Blindsides the Hopes of Black Coaches,” written with the veteran journalist Mark Purdy, Hill, a former head coach at San Jose State, tells about those efforts. He uses “crackback” as a metaphor to describe what often happens to black candidates seeking head coaching jobs at predominantly white universities.

headline: Corrections: June 4
text: NEW YORK

headline: Nonpartisan Primaries Face Test in California
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — When new redistricting maps changed the boundaries of this Congressional district to give Democrats a slight edge for the first time in decades, party loyalists were elated.

headline: Brooklyn Shore, 5:58 P.M.
text: A barge carrying the shuttle Enterprise traveling along the shore of Brooklyn.

headline: Yankees Upset by Slow Response of Tigers’ Security
text: DETROIT — The scene unfolded with comical slowness. And the Yankees were not happy about it.

headline: Merrill Losses Were Withheld Before Bank of America Deal
text: Days before Bank of America shareholders approved the bank’s $50 billion purchase of Merrill Lynch in December 2008, top bank executives were advised that losses at the investment firm would most likely hammer the combined companies’ earnings in the years to come. But shareholders were not told about the looming losses, which would prompt a second taxpayer bailout of $20 billion, leaving them instead to rely on rosier projections from the bank that the deal would make money relatively soon after it was completed.

headline: Intrigue in Karzai Family as an Afghan Era Closes
text: WASHINGTON — With the end in sight for Hamid Karzai’s days in office as Afghanistan’s president, members of his family are trying to protect their status, weighing how to hold on to power while secretly fighting among themselves for control of the fortune they have amassed in the last decade.

headline: Ibaka Is ‘Maybe a Surprise to You,’ but Not to Him or the Thunder
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The ball kept finding Serge Ibaka, thrown his way simply because he was open. Crisp, trustful passes dictated by the rhythm of the game and delivered with the knowledge that he would embrace the faith.

headline: Drama Desk Awards
text: The romantic Broadway musical “Once” was expected to receive four Drama Desk Awards at a ceremony on Sunday night honoring theater work on Broadway and Off Broadway. “Once,” already the recipient of numerous awards this season to go along with its 11 Tony nominations, was to take home trophies for outstanding musical, director, lyrics and orchestrations. The Broadway revival of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman” won three awards for outstanding play revival, director and lighting design. “Nice Work If You Can Get It” won for featured actor (Michael McGrath) and actress (Judy Kaye) in a musical, along with outstanding book. The Broadway comedy “One Man, Two Guvnors” won for outstanding music in a play, actor (James Corden) and featured actor (Tom Edden). “Tribes” was named outstanding play, and “Follies” outstanding musical revival. A full list of winners is at dramadeskawards.com.

headline: A Food Truck Takes Paris
text: Jordan Feilders just opened Cantine California, one of the first food trucks in Paris to offer upscale versions of American food.

headline: Are Single-Sex Groups Better for Preventing Dating Violence?
text: With the current national conversation about the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act focusing on adults, the notion of dating violence among teenagers seems an afterthought. But despite years of prevention efforts aimed at high school and college students, statistics around intimate violence and older adolescents are stubbornly grim. As I wrote in today’s story, programs are now skewing even younger: the latest drafts of the act make grants eligible to provide services and education to children as young as 11.

headline: A Warning to Teenagers Before They Start Dating
text: BOISE, Idaho — After studies emerged more than a decade ago showing that the highest rates of physical and sexual assault happen to women ages 16 to 24, programs to prevent abusive relationships have concentrated on high school and college students.

headline: Food Trucks in Paris? U.S. Cuisine Finds Open Minds, and Mouths
text: PARIS — An artisanal taco truck has come to Paris. The Cantine California started parking here in April, the latest in a recent American culinary invasion that includes chefs at top restaurants; trendy menu items like cheesecake, bagels and bloody Marys; and notions like chalking the names of farmers on the walls of restaurants.

headline: Start Strong Idaho: 2012 Writing Contest Winners
text: Winning submissions to the 2012 “Love’s What’s Real” writing contest on healthy teen relationships.

headline: New Questions for U.S. on Eve of World Cup Qualifying
text: TORONTO — After a 4-1 loss to Brazil on Wednesday, the United States national team continued to struggle and was held to a scoreless tie by a determined Canada team on Sunday night at BMO Field.

headline: Player Ratings: Canada (0) vs. U.S. (0)

headline: Bank of America Shareholder Suit
text: Days before shareholders voted on Bank of America’s 2008 purchase of Merrill Lynch, top executives were told the investment firm’s losses would most likely hammer future earnings.

headline: Champion Gymnast’s Knee Problems Derail Comeback Attempt
text: Shawn Johnson, the Olympic gold medalist who once was considered so talented and perky that she was called the next Mary Lou Retton, has abandoned her attempt at a comeback for this summer’s London Games, announcing Sunday that she is retiring from competitive gymnastics.

headline: With Boos and Solyndra, Romney Plays Offense
text: At Mitt Romney’s Boston headquarters, there was pure glee.

headline: Recall Battle in Wisconsin May Snarl Obama Camp
text: DE PERE, Wis. — President Obama holds multiple paths to re-election, with a handful of battleground states being able to slip away without leading to his defeat. But each possible outcome on his campaign map has always shared a common trait: winning Wisconsin.

headline: A New Ashanti Chief
text: A new chief is named for a local Ashanti group

headline: Cuomo Seeks Cut in Frisk Arrests
text: Wading into the debate over stop-and-frisk police tactics, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to ask legislators on Monday for a change in New York State law that would drastically reduce the number of people who could be arrested for marijuana possession as a result of police stops.

headline: Veteran Agent Saw Promise in I’ll Have Another’s Jockey
text: There are the martinis and the daily trips to the gym. The morning chops-busting sessions among race trackers in a halo of sunshine beneath the San Gabriel Mountains at Santa Anita Park help, too. At 85, Ivan Puhich neither knows nor cares what keeps him if not exactly young, at least vigorous.

headline: Harlem Shooting Kills One Man, Injures 3 Others
text: A 25-year-old man was killed and three others were injured on Sunday afternoon in a shooting at a basketball court in Harlem, the authorities said.

headline: Connecticut House Speaker Denies Knowledge of Scheme to Kill a Bill
text: MERIDEN, Conn. (AP) — Christopher G. Donovan, the speaker of the Connecticut House and a candidate for Congress, strongly denied on Sunday evening that he had any knowledge of what the federal authorities say was a scheme to kill a piece of legislation.

headline: Germany Resists Proposals to Aid Spain’s Banks
text: PARIS — European Union and French officials squared off against Germany on Monday over how best to help Spain’s ailing banks, drawing lines in the debate over the latest challenge to the euro zone.

headline: With Play of Late, Great Is Only Good for the Mets
text: Only after the spoils of the Mets’ weekend could the finest performance of Jon Niese’s season be assessed with almost mild commendation. On Friday, Johan Santana entered Mets lore when he threw the first no-hitter in franchise history. On Saturday, R. A. Dickey followed with a shutout. So when Niese took the mound Sunday, it was unlikely he could match his peers.

headline: Slathering on Sunscreen, Early and Often
text: This is a plea to all children and teenagers, their parents and teachers, and the doctors who treat them: Please take sun exposure more seriously.

headline: Paul Rudd and Michael Shannon Set for ‘Grace’ on Broadway
text: Paul Rudd and Michael Shannon are set to return to the stage this fall for the Broadway premiere of Craig Wright’s “Grace,” a darkly comedic play about a young couple who move to Florida to open a chain of gospel hotels that feature sanctuaries and baptismal pools. The producers are to announce on Monday that Mr. Shannon will play the disgruntled neighbor and cynic to Mr. Rudd’s religious optimist.

headline: Word of the Day | limber
text: limber •\ˈlim-bər\• adjective and verb

headline: Hello, Heterogeneity
text: Between 1948, when American National Election Studies first surveyed the electorate, and 1970, the percentage of voters who were white didn’t change much, ranging from 89 to 91 percent.

headline: A Drug for Advanced Melanoma Is Found to Prolong Patients’ Lives
text: CHICAGO — A new type of drug prolonged the lives of patients with advanced melanoma in a clinical trial, potentially adding to a growing number of therapies for a disease that was once nearly untreatable.

headline: Trailing in the Finals, but Remaining Ahead of the Game
text: The last time the Devils won the Stanley Cup, in 2003, they held the victory parade not on Broadway but in the Meadowlands parking lot. This greatly amused some of my superior New York friends. Why not the Pulaski Skyway? one of them suggested. But at least we had a parade. How long has it been since a New York hockey team enjoyed one?

headline: Celtics Even Series as James Takes a Seat
text: BOSTON — In a most pivotal moment of a pivotal evening, LeBron James was sitting, arms outstretched, palms up, eyes wide, mouth agape, a portrait of bewilderment and distress.

headline: A Look at New York City, From 1940 to Today
text: The New York Times has compared statistics and photographs from five neighborhoods, one in each borough of New York City, to show how they have changed from 1940 to today.

headline: From Morrisania to Williamsburg, How the City Has Changed in 70 Years
text: “New York is a city of contrasts,” the analysis began. “An amazing, infinite, inspiring, shocking, beautiful, ugly, old, new city of seven million plus.” Seven decades later, it still is. The same adjectives apply, but the city is even bigger: The population has grown to a record 8.3 million.

headline: As Mango Season Peaks, Mango Jingoism Runs Rampant
text: “Mangoes are objects of envy, love and rivalry as well as a new status symbol for India’s new rich,” Jim Yardley writes in The New York Times. “Mangoes have even been tools of diplomacy. The allure is foremost about the taste but also about anticipation and uncertainty: Mango season in the region lasts only about 100 days, traditionally from late March through June; is vulnerable to weather; and usually brings some sort of mango crisis, real or imagined.”

headline: Lips, Teeth and the U.S. Navy

headline: Devils Putting Best Spin on Being Down, and Away

headline: How I Fire People
text: Jay Goltz, like any normal person, hates firing people. The commenters on his post about firing brought up a wide range of subjects, but one issue that wasn’t addressed is the actual mechanics of firing. I don’t have wide experience with this, but over the last 26 years, I have had to fire five workers for breaking the rules, and I also laid off 11 people one day in 2008. If you are a boss, the day will arrive when you have to fire someone.

headline: Lindsay Lohan’s New Wave
text: In “First Point,” his new short film, the artist Richard Phillips combines two of his current obsessions: surfing and Lindsay Lohan. Phillips has worked with the actress and tabloid goddess before, on a 90-second video for Neville Wakefield’s “Commercial Break,” which had a very brief run during the 54th Venice Biennale. And his studio is lined with several larger-than-life paintings of Lohan that came directly out of that particular project. But don’t call Lohan his muse. Lohan, Phillips insists, is his collaborator as much as anyone in the stellar cast of people who worked on the film, including the legendary surf filmmaker Taylor Steele; the professional surfer Kassia Meador, who performs mesmerizingly as Lohan’s body double; the editor Jay Rabinowitz; and Thomas Bangalter, one half of the electro duo Daft Punk, who composed the ominously swelling score. As the trailer implies, “First Point” is at once a surf film and a film noir, an exploration of the California dream and the Hollywood nightmare, worlds that Lohan doesn’t have to pretend to straddle on screen. But no doubt the question on everyone’s lips when “First Point” has its premiere next week at Art Unlimited, the curated section of the Art Basel fair, will be: “Is it art?” And that is just fine by Phillips. “It’s just like in my paintings,” he says. “Because of the actor and the popular culture dimensions of the project, it will give people — especially people in the art world — a real sense of instability with regard to my intentions. Is it a film? Is it an art video? It refuses to announce itself as either.”

headline: Starz Announces Final Season of ‘Spartacus’

headline: How Big Data Gets Real
text: The business of Big Data, which involves collecting large amounts of data and then searching it for patterns and new revelations, is the result of cheap storage, abundant sensors and new software. It has become a multibillion-dollar industry in less than a decade. Growing at speed like that, it is easy to miss how much remains to do before the industry has proven standards. Until then, lots of customers are probably wasting much of their money.

headline: Timeless by Design
text: At the Italian Cultural Institute of New York, “Timelessness,” a tiny, tantalizing exhibition of works by the designers Lella and Massimo Vignelli, opens today and runs through July 15. It’s a one-room show that features a cross-shaped arrangement of vitrines — their bases painted red to match the color of the room’s carpeting — which display some of the Vignellis’ product designs from the 1950s to the present and which amply illustrate the couple’s devotion to the idea that designers should produce things of lasting value. “We despise the culture of obsolescence, the culture of waste, the cult of the ephemeral,” they wrote in their book “The Vignelli Canon,” which you can download from the firm’s Web site.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Adam & Eve, London, an independent agency opened in 2008, was acquired by DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which will merge the agency with DDB United Kingdom, London, to create Adam & Eve/DDB. Financial terms were not disclosed; the Web site of the British trade publication Campaign estimated the cost of the deal at $92.5 million. James Murphy, a founder of Adam & Eve, becomes chief executive at Adam & Eve/DDB, and Stephen Woodford, chief executive at DDB United Kingdom, becomes chairman at Adam & Eve/DDB. The deal echoed one in 1989 when DDB bought Boase Massimi Pollitt, an independent London agency opened in 1968, and merged it with the DDB London office to form BMP DDB; that name lasted until 2004.
