text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On Sunday afternoon, a few hours before the beginning of Hot 97 Summer Jam 2012, Peter Rosenberg — one of Hot 97’s morning hosts — was speaking on a small stage in the parking lot of MetLife Stadium here, faulting what was going to happen on the big stage inside the stadium that night.

headline: After a Slip, Markets End Near Where They Started
text: Stocks reversed losses and closed nearly unchanged on Monday as analysts saw value in issues in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, which on average were at their lowest level relative to their earnings in six months.

headline: Can a Product be Carcinogen-Free?
text: Want to avoid applying known carcinogens to your skin and hair?A new line of body-care products from Canada, called Attitude, aims to take the guesswork out of shopping for shampoo, lotion, soap and other products, with packaging that explicitly and rather boldly declares “Carcinogen Free.”

headline: TimesCast | June 4, 2012
text: Egypt's elections face new fraud accusations. | Young Thais flee rice farms for urban jobs.

headline: How Kanepi Can Use Her Power Against Rus
text: Kaia Kanepi faces Arantxa Rus for a spot in the quarterfinals of the French Open and a showdown against Maria Sharapova. The imposing Estonian upset former world number one Caroline Wozniacki by blending patience with her powerful attacking style in a way that baffled the consistent, counterpunching style of the young Dane.

headline: The Shut-Up Gun
text: 6/7/12 | Updated with editors’ note about a similar interview elsewhere.

headline: Vatican Scolds Nun for Book on Sexuality
text: The Vatican’s doctrinal office on Monday denounced an American nun who taught Christian ethics at Yale Divinity School for a book that attempted to present a theological rationale for same-sex relationships, masturbation and remarriage after divorce.

headline: Times Readers Recommend Their Favorite Religious Fiction
text: Times staffers and contributors recently shared some of their favorite novels with religious themes, and we put the call out on Twitter for readers to play along using the tag #religiousfiction. Below is a selection from the many responses we received. Special mention goes to Gregory Wolfe, who came up with 16 thoughtful recommendations (by my count), two of which are below.

headline: Settling Afghan Disputes, Where Custom Holds Sway
text: From the Chinook helicopter, I saw villages dotting valleys and hugging small brown streams. Every house in Shah Wali Kot district was constructed of mud, until more modern structures emerged on the approach to Kandahar Airfield. Rugged hills and steep passes divided villages. The challenge to Afghanistan’s stability appeared self-evident: How can the state project justice where it can’t reach?

headline: Ads Seek to Light a Match Under Would-Be Volunteers
text: The next time a cop asks, “O.K., buddy, where’s the fire?” the answer ought to be, according to a new campaign, “Why, within me, officer.”

headline: A Couple Who Gave Brownstones New Life
text: You may not have heard of Everett and Evelyn Ortner, but if you have picked yourself up in the past few decades and moved out to western Brooklyn, you may have them, in part, to thank. The Ortners were early and vigorous promoters of the borough as a historic site worth preserving and a collection of neighborhoods worth nurturing, while most Manhattanites still considered it an unacceptable place even to go for dinner.

headline: Your Questions About the Wisconsin Recall
text: Do you have questions about Tuesday’s recall election in Wisconsin? Are you wondering how it could affect the general election in November? Curious about the money raised and spent? Want to know more about Gov. Scott Walker or his Democratic opponent, Mayor Tom Barrett of Milwaukee? Post a comment below or on our Facebook page, or tweet @thecaucus using the hashtag #asknyt. The Times’s Monica Davey and Jeff Zeleny will be answering readers’ questions here on Tuesday and some of your questions may be answered in Tuesday’s special edition of TimesCast.

headline: From a Familiar Stranger, a Poem Written on the Stars
text: I went for a walk the other night. Someone said it was supposed to rain, but the skies looked clear to me. I headed up Eighth Avenue, crossed over at 23rd Street and at 10th Avenue saw a stairwell going up and took it. I was on the High Line. That much I’d expected. What I had not anticipated was how crowded it would be, like being stuck on a moving sidewalk at an airport. But the night was too nice to begrudge anyone anything, particularly a chance to experience beauty.

headline: Behind the Story: Wil S. Hylton on Craig Venter and God, Craig Venter and DNA Graffiti and Craig Venter and Piles of Cash
text: Wil S. Hylton, a contributing writer for the magazine, profiled the scientist Craig Venter for this week’s Innovation issue. He last wrote for the magazine about the state of U.S. biodefense preparations.

headline: Conservatives Attack Romney’s Choice to Lead Transition
text: Mitt Romney’s choice of Michael O. Leavitt as his transition chief has spurred loud opposition from some conservatives over Mr. Leavitt’s support of a crucial part of President Obama’s health care plan.

headline: Gay Rights Groups to Join Others in Condemning Stop-and-Frisk
text: National gay rights advocates plan to join other civil rights leaders on Tuesday in calling on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to end the Police Department’s current stop-and-frisk policy, which they argue constitutes harassment of young black and Latino men.

headline: ‘Ignore the Rankings’ and Other Advice From the College Life Fair
text: Last week, The New York Times held its first-ever College Life Fair. The one-day event, which was free to attendees, was held at Navy Pier in Chicago and served as a meeting ground for thousands of high school students and hundreds of colleges and universities, large and small, public and private, domestic and international.

headline: Obama Surprises Conference Call on Pay Equity
text: WASHINGTON – The White House conference call to promote the Paycheck Fairness Act began as so many of those calls do in Washington – with hold Muzak followed by the warning that the conversation would be one-way – no questions could be asked during a presentation of the White House’s legislative agenda.

headline: Mets’ Young to Bring Rehab Full-Circle in First Start
text: Chris Young has not pitched in the major leagues since May 2011. His start for the Mets on Tuesday in Washington will mark the completion of a lengthy recovery from career-threatening surgery, a process with which the team is all too familiar.

headline: Microsoft to Expand Offerings on Xbox Live
text: LOS ANGELES – On the eve of the annual E3 video game convention here, Microsoft announced on Monday that it intended to double the amount and scope of media content offered over the next year through the company’s Xbox Live online service. While games were the initial focus of Xbox Live, the recent addition of video from partners including Major League Baseball, Netflix and HBO has helped reposition the service and Microsoft’s Xbox 360 console as a hub for entertainment beyond video games.

headline: More Jolts as Li Loses and Sharapova Labors
text: PARIS — Behind the microphone, Li Na sighed. She had no answers, only questions, like the reporters who packed around her, who wondered about the weather and whether she had prepared properly for this French Open.

headline: After a Decade of Planning, LeMay Museum Opens
text: On June 2 the LeMay museum opened its newly built home in Tacoma, Wash.

headline: Double Rainbow in New York City
text: A rare double rainbow filled the sky over the city on Sunday, June 3, 2012.

headline: In Gupta Case, Motive Matters
text: As the prosecution of Rajat Gupta moves into what looks to be its final week, the crucial question for the jury is coming into focus: Why would a wealthy, well-respected business leader reveal confidential corporate information to a hedge fund trader like Raj Rajaratnam?

headline: The Sun on Sunday
text: The Sun began publishing on Sunday, taking the place of The News of the World, which was closed amid the phone-hacking scandal. I

headline: Nan Goldin Given Lifetime Achievement Award
text: The MacDowell Colony, the prestigious artists’ retreat in New Hampshire, has awarded the photographer Nan Goldin its Edwin MacDowell Medal for lifetime achievement in the arts.

headline: Video: Double Rainbow All the Way (From Bronx to Brooklyn)
text: The Times reporter Alan Schwarz snapped the neat video above of Sunday’s double rainbow shortly before 6 p.m. from a 22nd-floor balcony on East 90th Street. From the Bronx at one end to Brooklyn on the other, it’s all in there. No orgiastic voice-over, but it sure is beautiful. Enjoy.

headline: Is this New York’s Smallest Museum?
text: Residents of TriBeCa can be forgiven for overlooking the neighborhood’s newest museum, which is built into an abandoned freight elevator and accessible only down a dark alleyway. Simply called Museum, this tiny room officially opened on Cortlandt Alley late last month after a ribbon-cutting ceremony presided over by one Rudolph W. Guliani, a celebrity impostor of the former mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. “We wanted a real politician,” said Josh Safdie, one of Museum’s founders, who contacted several local officials before hiring Guliani, a fairly convincing look-alike. “To us, this is about introducing a new institution to the city.”

headline: Andrew Huxley, Nobel-Winning Physiologist, Dies at 94
text: Sir Andrew Huxley, a British scientist from an illustrious family whose boyhood mechanical skills led to a career in physiology — “the mechanical engineering of living things,” he called it — and a Nobel Prize for explaining the electrical basis of bodily movement, died on Wednesday. He was 94.

headline: The Many Masks of Richard Dawson
text: When Richard Dawson first turned up as host of “Family Feud” in 1976, some people might well have done a double-take. “What is this?” they might have asked. “An actor disguised as a game show host?”

headline: MTV Music Awards Red Carpet
text: Red carpet highlights from the MTV Movie Awards 2012.

headline: The Making of Green Gold
text: The key to Buddhapesto, the ambrosial green mixture created in Cornwallville, N.Y., is the humble food processor.

headline: Hedge Funds of the Living Dead
text: Jay Eisenhofer and Matthew P. Morris are partners with the shareholder rights law firm Grant & Eisenhofer.

headline: Jared Harris of ‘Mad Men’ Discusses Sunday’s Episode
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sunday’s episode of “Mad Men” that are especially sad if you like nice British people.

headline: Survival in the Nest
text: Q. How do seed-eating birds keep their chicks hydrated? And how can chicks in birdhouses survive high temperatures?

headline: More Protests Loom in Egypt, Targeting Candidacy of Mubarak’s Prime Minister
text: CAIRO — The presidential candidate of the Muslim Brotherhood and two popular rivals eliminated before the runoff called on Monday for further street protests until Egypt’s current military rulers enforce legislation disqualifying the other remaining candidate, former President Hosni Mubarak’s last prime minister, Ahmed Shafik.

headline: Just a Minute: In Britain, The Sun’s Success Hasn’t Shifted to Sunday
text: Amy Chozick discusses the challenges facing a new edition of The Sun, the anchor of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspapers. Four months ago it started publishing on Sunday, taking the place of the weekly News of the World, which was shut as the phone-hacking scandal expanded.

headline: In Performance
text: A selection of Tony Award nominees, including Josh Young from “Jesus Christ Superstar,” perform songs and scenes from this year’s shows.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: May 27-June 02
text: Moments from the campaign trail this week, including Memorial Day services and reactions to employment numbers.

headline: By Sound and Touch, Producing Pesto Bliss
text: CORNWALLVILLE, N.Y.

headline: Justices Refuse to Hear Ex-Governor’s Appeal
text: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear the appeals of former Gov. Don E. Siegelman of Alabama and the man convicted of bribing him, a case which has tested the murky limits of when a campaign donation can be considered corrupt.

headline: The Science Times Podcast
text: High-rises made of wood; tennis for the blind; and the culture of cancer screening.

headline: Photo Replay: June 4
text: Preparations continued for the Olympics and the Paralympics throughout the world, and the French Open tennis tournament continued in Paris.

headline: Commencement 2012: ‘18 Years in Rap’ and Some Teaching Ideas
text: “The Last 18 Years in Rap,” a celebration for 2012 graduates from Flocabulary.

headline: House Member’s Aide Who Wrote About Tossing Acid at Women Quits
text: WASHINGTON — A top campaign adviser to Representative Nan Hayworth, a New York Republican facing a potentially tough bid for a second term, resigned on Monday because of a comment he made urging people to “hurl some acid” at Democratic female lawmakers with whom he differed.

headline: Your Tech Questions, Answered: Part 2
text: In this batch of questions, I answer questions about scheduling e-mail messages, setting up a Wi-Fi network with multiple access points, how to archive iTunes music files, uninstalling virus-protection software and how to download YouTube videos. You can find my answers to the first batch of questions here.

headline: No, Those Aren’t Tribbles
text: To introduce Sunday’s Innovation Issue, Hugo Lindgren filmed an editor’s video note, in which he expressed dismay that he hadn’t learned of “smart fur,” which provides some of the health benefits of petting a live animal, in time to save himself the trouble of being covered in bunnies.

headline: People With Individual Health Plans Would Save Out-of-Pocket Under Reform, Study Finds
text: 6:18 p.m. Updated / To make clear that the anticipated savings are for out-of-pocket medical costs.

headline: Euro 2012: Germany Has Changed. England Take Note.
text: On June 9, Germany will begin play in this year’s European Championships with an opening match against Portugal. The competition will be the 14th continental championship and the 11th consecutive time Germany has qualified. Yet most German fans will approach the tournament with one foot firmly in the past as they bitterly remember a similar situation 12 years ago, and how far the team has come.

headline: Just One Look | Burberry Prorsum
text: The standouts at today’s Burberry prespring collection presentation were the paper-bag pants for her (high and cinched at the waist with a rolled leg) and the outerwear for him (bombers and trenches in luscious, new fabrications with handsome proportions and fit). What the men and woman shared were prints, tiny foulards on everything from shirts to shorts and silk scarves, that gave each look a bit of a pajama feel. And the seersucker; quite relaxed for the tightly tailored Britons at Burberry. Here, the star pant as part of a striped cotton seersucker suit relaxes with a graphic tee and a wedge heel. On him, a printed tie and the season’s signature neck scarf is styled with a waterproofed-silk trench coat.

headline: Thai Youth Seek a Fortune Away From the Farm
text: BAAN KHLONG KHOO, Thailand — During 18 years living across the road from rice paddies, Malinee Khammon has never planted a single seedling. The daughter of farmers who is in her last year of high school, she has become adept at deflecting increasingly desperate pleas from her parents for help on the farm.

headline: Thailand’s Fading Farmers
text: Young people are avoiding working in Thailand’s rice farms, threatening the country’s status as the world’s biggest rice exporter.

headline: Nervous Europeans Snap Up London Property
text: LONDON — Britain may be in recession, but business is booming for Rupert des Forges, a real estate agent in one of London’s most expensive neighborhoods.

headline: Leukemia, 1899
text: Leukemia, a malignant cancer of the blood, was named in 1847 by Dr. Rudolf Virchow, a German politician whose wide-ranging interests led him to significant discoveries in cell biology, pathology and anthropology. Although Dr. Virchow’s name appeared often in The New York Times, mostly in the late 19th century, his discovery of leukemia was not mentioned until Feb. 22, 1970, in an article by Dr. Lawrence K. Altman.

headline: Apothéke Bar Dispute Heads for Trial
text: The interminable trademark battle over the haute Manhattan cocktail haunt Apothéke can at last go to trial this summer, to resolve whether Albert Trummer (right), the celebrity mixologist — or his former business partner, Heather Tierney — owns the name of the lucrative bar, which has the potential to become a worldwide brand.

headline: Creative Digital-Ad Agency in New York Is Being Acquired
text: Pod1, an advertising agency in New York that specializes in creative digital services, with a focus on clients in e-commerce, is being acquired.

headline: Cheap vs. Expensive Drugs
text: There are many, many reasons why health care spending has become such a huge national burden, including overtesting, the aging and weight gain of the populace, poor communication among health care professionals and deficient information about what treatments are most effective.

headline: MoMA Names New Chief Curator of Photography
text: The Museum of Modern Art has appointed Quentin Bajac, chief curator of photography at the Pompidou Center in Paris, to be its next chief curator of photography, it announced today. He succeeds Peter Galassi, who retired from that job in 2011 after 30-years at MoMA.

headline: TimesCast | Egyptian Election Fraud
text: June 4, 2012 - Egypt's elections face new fraud accusations.

headline: In Winning Definition of ‘Flame,’ Jargon Melts Away
text: Ben Ames, winner of a contest to explain a flame in terms that an 11-year-old could understand, was flummoxed when asked what he would say to someone who asked him what a flame was.

headline: Really? Always Shave the Patient Before Surgery
text: THE FACTS

headline: Corcoran Gallery May Relocate After 115 Years
text: Struggling with continuing deficits and a change in leadership in recent years, the Corcoran Gallery of Art may be looking to leave its imposing Beaux-Arts building at 17th Street and New York Avenue NW in Washington, according to the Washington City Paper.

headline: Fever in Pregnancy Tied to Autism Risk
text: Running a fever during pregnancy is associated with a risk of autism spectrum disorders and developmental delays in the offspring, a new study reports.

headline: Zinc: Supplements for Babies Being Treated With Antibiotics Appear to Save Lives
text: Giving zinc to newborns being treated with antibiotics for serious infections appears to save lives, according to a new study done in India.

headline: Waddling Into the Sunset
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.

headline: E.C.B. Under Pressure to Ride to the Euro's Rescue
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank must decide Wednesday whether to stand on principle and insist that political leaders take their turn at dealing with the euro zone’s banking and debt crisis, or bend to market forces and once again ride to the rescue.

headline: L.A. P.O.V. | Brian Williams, Walter Cronkite and ‘Girls’
text: There were blue skies over the National Mall, and it was packed with jubilant George Washington University grads in caps and gowns and a bevy of appropriately dressed parents sitting on folding chairs on the lawn. So sunny, we moved our chairs under the shade of a tree. My husband, my children and I had flown to Washington, D.C., from Los Angeles as my son Ethan Harari is a proud member of the G.W. graduating class.

headline: New Obama Video Seeks to Combat Negative Perceptions
text: After a challenging week capped by a lackluster jobs report, the Obama campaign released a new Web video Monday that aimed to reassure supporters and asked them not to “lose focus” on the campaign’s “grass-roots organizing efforts.”

headline: U.S. Open Cup: Harrisburg vs. Red Bulls
text: The Red Bulls can see the road ahead to the semifinals of the 99th Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup … and it is composed of two more games on the road.

headline: Starbucks Makes $100 Million Bet on Baked Goods
text: As Frapuccinos give way to Blueberry muffins, Starbucks is increasing its bet on baked goods.

headline: Marion O. Sandler, 81, Banker and Philanthropist, Dies
text: Marion O. Sandler, who with her husband transformed a two-office bank into one of the biggest savings and loan firms in the country, Golden West Financial, only to be accused of contributing to the financial crisis when they sold it to Wachovia in 2006, died on Friday at her home in San Francisco. She was 81.

headline: Flowers’ Cells Lay Out a Sticky Carpet for Bees
text: Scientists have long known that the petals of most flowering plants have cone-shaped cells that are not found anywhere else on the plants.

headline: New Epilepsy Tactic: Fight Inflammation
text: In November 2008, when he was just 6, William Moller had his first epileptic seizure, during a reading class at school. For about 20 seconds, he simply froze in place, as if someone had pressed a pause button. He could not respond to his teacher.

headline: Tree of Life Project Aims for Every Twig and Leaf
text: In 1837, Charles Darwin opened a notebook and drew a simple tree with a few branches. Each branch, which he labeled with a letter, represented a species. In that doodle, he captured his newfound realization that species were related, having evolved from a common ancestor. Across the top of the page he wrote, “I think.”

headline: Upon Further (DVR) Review, ‘Modern Family’ Challenges ‘Idol’
text: Fox’s “American Idol” may still hold its claim as the No. 1 live program on television, but once DVR viewers are included in the ratings there can be only one true champion: ABC’s “Modern Family.”

headline: Wisconsin Voters in the Political Spotlight
text: FORT ATKINSON, Wis. – On the eve of Wisconsin’s recall election, many voters here are getting a flash of déjà vu.

headline: More Than Attention Must Be Paid: ‘Salesman’ Sets Record Ticket Price
text: The Broadway revival of “Death of a Salesman” has set a record of $499 for the highest ticket price ever charged by a Broadway musical or play, slightly more than the previous record price of $480 that the 2001 musical “The Producers” charged.

headline: Israeli Leader Pledges Hard Line on Migrants
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised to step up efforts to deter, detain and deport illegal migrants to Israel, as tensions mount over an influx of asylum seekers from Africa. His pledge came a day before an early morning fire, apparently set by arsonists, ravaged an apartment occupied by about 10 Eritrean migrants on Monday. Four people were injured.

headline: Prince Philip Hospitalized in London
text: LONDON — A day after spending several hours in the biting cold atop a royal barge on the Thames, Prince Philip, the 90-year-old husband of Queen Elizabeth II, was taken to a hospital on Monday suffering from what a Buckingham Palace spokesman described as a bladder infection.

headline: For Charleston and Spoleto, It’s Clean Up, Paint Up, Fix Up Time Once Again
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.— When the Spoleto Festival USA opened shop here in 1977, its performing spaces were a motley combination of revived old theaters, modern auditoriums and outdoor arenas. To some extent, that’s how it still is, but in recent years the festival, the city of Charleston and private groups interested in upgrading Charleston’s performing facilities, have been reconfiguring some of the main theaters. Spoleto, the theory goes, is here to stay; its halls might as well be up to date. And renovating them can only encourage the city’s artistic life between festivals as well.

headline: The Trouble With ‘Doctor Knows Best’
text: Doctors were told last month that we should stop doing so many screenings for prostate cancer with the prostate-specific antigen test. We learned that sigmoidoscopy is a cheaper, easier and effective alternative to colonoscopy for colon cancer screening. And a study I led turned up strong evidence that routine lung cancer screenings are justified only for people at high risk because of heavy smoking in the past.

headline: Just One Look | Zero + Maria Cornejo
text: “It’s about creating desire rather than treating a season as whatever it’s supposed to be,” said Maria Cornejo at her NoLIta studio earlier today. She was talking about her resort collection, which will deliver to stores in November and stay there for almost four months, through the holidays and into the new year. “It’s about transition now, and livening up what you already have in your winter wardrobe,” she said. “Not everyone goes to the beach.” Pointing to looks like this one — a draping viscose and wool skirt paired with a clean, black V-neck tank — Cornejo made references to cities like New York and Berlin (where one could quickly make use any of the collection’s leather pieces, too), and suggested Art Basel in Miami as a perfect place to wear the complete range, from swimwear to evening wear and every “dorky sort of look with a white shirt buttoned up” in between.

headline: Sandusky Trial Begins Tuesday
text: After months of pretrial maneuvering, jury selection will begin Tuesday in the trial of Penn State’s former defensive coordinator Jerry Sandusky, who is accused of sexually abusing at least 10 boys over a 15-year period.

headline: Summer Jam
text: Images of some of the performances at this year’s Hot 97 Summer Jam.

headline: A Unique Slice-and-Dice Strategy for Chewing
text: A New Zealand lizardlike reptile called the tuatara eats like no other animal, researchers report in a new study: By sliding its lower jaw forward and backward, it can slice its food like a steak knife.

headline: Administrator Fined for Taking 75 Theme Park Tickets Given to School
text: Last June, a middle school on Staten Island received 370 free tickets from Six Flags Great Adventure — a boon that many grade-schoolers would consider priceless.

headline: Attacking Amazon, Authors Group Urges Opposition to E-Book Settlement
text: The Authors Guild on Monday urged its 8,500 members to protest the Department of Justice’s proposed settlement with three publishers, a proposal that clears the way for Amazon to lower prices on e-books.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Scott Dixon Is Flawless in Flawed Return of IndyCar to Detroit
text: Volatility at the Chevrolet Detroit Belle Isle Grand Prix was caused not so much by weather, although it rained, and not by drivers, although tempers flared, but by asphalt, epoxy and the ravages of time.

headline: Making a Cake at 30,000 Feet
A Storm’s Aftermath, Lost in the City
text: Some choreographers can take or leave set designs, but Brian Brooks is engrossed by their structural possibilities. Leading off the Gotham Dance Festival, a fairly middling two-week showcase at the Joyce Theater that features five programs and many more choreographers, the Brian Brooks Moving Company unveils “Big City.” The company’s New York premiere on Wednesday juxtaposed the cold glint of aluminum with the warmth of dancers’ bodies.

headline: Poll Shows Polarization Limited to Parties
text: Americans of different races are no more polarized in their political views than they were 25 years ago. Men and women are no more polarized either. The same goes for people of different education levels, different income groups and different levels of religiosity.

headline: Cardinals Spoil Sweep, but Not Mets’ Mood
text: As he stood in front of his locker late Monday afternoon, Dillon Gee good-naturedly accepted that the brilliance of the Mets’ starting pitching over the weekend had made the very competent effort he had just produced look sort of mediocre.

headline: Wobbles and Jumbles, but Also Magic
text: The mixed bill presented during the Gotham Dance Festival at the Joyce Theater this past weekend was a kind of three for two. The program was organized around the work of two freelance choreographers, Peter Quanz and Jodie Gates, but three companies performed.

headline: Grass? At Garros? Catch It While You Can
text: PARIS — On the far edge of the grounds at Roland Garros — past Court 12, Court 14, Court 16 and Court 18, beyond a security guard wearing a dark suit and an earpiece and a frown, and up a flight of stairs — there are two courts that seem entirely out of place.

headline: Free Wi-Fi, but Speed Costs
text: As airlines try to persuade passengers to pay for Internet access at cruising altitudes, more airports and hotels are offering it free on the ground.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tough Viruses and Facebook Addiction
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. See more here.

headline: Your Tech Questions Answered, Part 3
text: In this batch of questions, I answer questions about setting up wireless audio, remotely accessing a parent’s computer, choosing a streaming-video option, stabilizing a Wi-Fi connection and picking a good computer for a schoolkid. (You can also read my answers to the first and second batch of questions.)

headline: The 5 Best David Milch-isms from GQ’s TV Round Table Featuring Matthew Weiner, Vince Gilligan and David Milch
text: From a recent discussion of television featuring the reliably provocative, endlessly interesting and only occasionally inscrutable David Milch:

headline: Mystery of Big Data’s Parallel Universe Brings Fear, and a Thrill
text: Not long ago, a woman in Tacoma, Wash., received a suggestion from Facebook that she “friend” another woman. She didn’t know the other woman, but she followed through, as many of us have, innocently laying our cookie-crumb trails through cyberspace, only to get a surprise.

headline: Amazon Buys Avalon Books, Publisher in Romance and Mysteries
text: Amazon.com has expanded its publishing reach again by acquiring Avalon Books, a small, 62-year-old publisher that specializes in romance and mysteries.

headline: Building With Engineered Timber
text: A residential tower in London is one of the tallest timber buildings in the world.

headline: The Call of the West: ‘Longmire’ Draws a Crowd to A&E
text: Cowboys are riding again on television — at least on cable.

headline: Kings May Add Gagne to Lineup for Game 3
text: LOS ANGELES — Left winger Simon Gagne was expected to return to the Kings’ lineup Monday from a concussion that has sidelined him since Dec. 26.

headline: Up-and-Coming Composers Secure a Valuable Friend
text: Most young composers can probably persuade a competent soloist or small ensemble to try out a short work, but chances to collaborate with a professional orchestra on a symphonic piece are scarce.

headline: Recalling the Sounds Of a Life Steeped in Woe
text: On June 2, 1937, Louis Vierne gave his 1,750th organ recital at the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris, where he had been the principal organist since 1900.

headline: Late Polls Find Walker Is Still Favored
text: Two polls released over the weekend suggest that Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican, remains the clear favorite to win Tuesday’s recall election.

headline: Goldman Sachs Cuts a Little Deeper
text: It isn’t getting better out there.

headline: R.I.P. Zune
text: Microsoft is sending Zune to the pasture where Microsoft brands go to die. It’s the end of the road for a name that once symbolized Microsoft’s grand plans to curb Apple’s entertainment ambitions.

headline: Emissions Fell Under Cap and Trade Program, Report Says
text: The cap and trade system known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative announced on Monday that carbon dioxide emissions from power plants in the nine participating states on the East Coast fell by an average of 23 percent during the first three years of the program.

headline: Preserving Species
text: To the Editor:

headline: Beauty, Height and Success
text: Much has been written about the extent to which beautiful and tall people succeed in life. But what happens when everybody is beautiful (more or less), or everyone grows taller?

headline: A Canopy as Social Cathedral
text: One of the best new works of architecture in New York isn’t a flashy skyscraper or museum but a fairly modest structure, an angular glass canopy over an obscure but busy pedestrian street called North End Way, in the shadow of One World Trade Center no less.

headline: Sweet Irony
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Young Dreamer, With Eyes Wide Open
text: Barack Obama’s life, says his latest biographer, David Maraniss, was to an astonishing extent “the product of randomness.” His mother, Stanley Ann Dunham, the only child of a couple from Kansas, met his father, Barack Hussein Obama, a student from Kenya, in an elementary Russian language class at the University of Hawaii, and the young Barry Obama would grow up in Hawaii and Indonesia, taking an odd, zigzagging and totally improbable road to the White House. And yet, Mr. Maraniss makes clear, despite the bewildering role that chance played in Mr. Obama’s story, he has been very much the author of his own life — an outsider, who, in the very American tradition of literary heroes like Gatsby, “raised himself” and forged an identity through a series of self-conscious and deliberate choices.

headline: Reproductive Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: All the World On a Stage In America
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Spoleto Festival USA justifiably prides itself on variety, but its greatest strength is in its presentations of contemporary work. The festival’s staging of Philip Glass’s opera “Kepler,” which closed on Saturday evening, was dramatically nearly static because Mr. Glass and his librettist, Martina Winkel, wrote it that way, but it explored the relationship between science and religion in compelling, sometimes provocative ways.

headline: Abortion in Turkey
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Boy Who Lived, Casting a Humorous Spell
text: With all the Harry Potter books and movies done, and no new material to pore over, where can a devoted Muggle get a fix? You could fly to Florida, to the Universal Studios Orlando theme park. Or over to Britain, where tours of the films’ sets, at Leavesden Studios outside London, have begun. Online, there’s always J. K. Rowling’s Pottermore Web site.

headline: Another Solstice in an Endless Summer
text: THE BEACH BOYS

headline: Teaching the Men a Lesson
text: Monteverdi’s “Ballo Delle Ingrate” (“Dance of the Ungrateful Women”) offers an objectionable prefeminist moral: women should submit to male desire or face eternal damnation. The pasticcio version by Musica Nuova ends with a satirical twist. After being threatened with exile to a convent, the female protagonist voluntarily becomes a nun to escape her suitor.

headline: A City’s Better Days
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Apocalyptic Road Trip, With Three Worriers and One Optimist
text: Alex Escalante doesn’t shy away from political work. This experimental choreographer took on immigration issues in “Clandestino” and propaganda in “The 25th Frame.” In “Charlie,” his new 40-minute solo, he investigates issues surrounding the environment with the help of four characters — Charlie, Alex, Linda and Todd — who consider humanity’s destructive and regenerative nature. Mr. Escalante plays them all.

headline: Overly Aggressive Care (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Very Expensive Nap (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is It Time to Rewrite the Constitution?
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Amazon’s Warehouses, Cooler Times
text: One of the most-talked about technology articles last year was a lengthy investigative effort by The Allentown, Pa., Morning Call documenting how Amazon warehouse workers were collapsing from the heat.

headline: Turkey Presses Case Against Israeli Officers in Raid
text: ISTANBUL — An effort by the Turkish authorities to prosecute four former Israeli military commanders over a raid on a Turkish ship moved forward on Monday when an Istanbul court ordered that Israel be formally notified of the charges.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Nigeria, Spain, Iraq and Lebanon.

headline: Hugo Lindgren Answers ‘Anything’
text: Last Friday, Hugo Lindgren, editor of The Times Magazine, participated in the second-ever official New York Times chat to be hosted on Reddit. After the success of Paul Krugman’s “IAmA,” the first such chat, Lindgren invited Redditors to ask him about anything — even his office full of bunnies. (These chats are sometimes referred to as an AMA, shorthand for the invitation to “Ask Me Anything.”)

headline: ‘Lilly’ Awards Given to Arianda, Paulus, Hall  and More
text: An organization that honors women working in the theater will present the third annual Lilly Awards on Monday evening to nine recipients, including the 2012 Tony-nominated actresses Cristin Milioti (“Once”) and Nina Arianda (“Venus in Fur”) and director Diane Paulus (“The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess”).

headline: Airlines Weighing Fee for Oversize Carry-Ons
text: HERE’S something that the big airlines really wish we wouldn’t discuss right now, with planes flying full, fares rising, fuel prices stabilizing and customers generally resigned to the air travel system:

headline: In Texas, a Debate Over a Debate in Spanish
text: Debate challenges are nothing new to Texas politics. But in the race between Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst and the Houston lawyer Ted Cruz for the state’s open United States Senate seat, Texans have come to expect the unexpected.

headline: The City Council Speaker Weighs in on the School Discipline Code
text: As the city tries to decrease its student suspension rate with a revised discipline code, Christine Quinn, the city council speaker, urges the Department of Education to consider even more measures to keep students in school.

headline: Devils’ History of Success and Financial Disputes Repeats
text: The Devils have not paid nearly $80 million owed to their banks to build Prudential Center.

headline: Hot 97 Says No Refunds for Summer Jam Show
text: Hot 97 has decided not to refund ticketholders to its Summer Jam held on Sunday even though Nicki Minaj, one of the biggest stars on the bill, pulled out of the concert at the last moment when a D.J. mocked her most recent single.

headline: Learning From Celestial Beauty
text: Haleakala, Hawaii

headline: Ad Watch: Obama Ad Focuses on Jobs in Romney Era
text: President Obama’s campaign notched up their assault on Monday on Mitt Romney’s record as governor of Massachusetts, putting $10 million behind a tough new commercial that claims Mr. Romney had “one of the worst economic records in the country.” The ad will air in nine battleground states: Colorado, Florida, Iowa, North Carolina, New Hampshire, Nevada, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

headline: White Tee Swagger in Harlem
text: Ariel Weekes discusses how his personal style has been influenced by Harlem.

headline: Live and Online, a Game Show Developed for the Internet Age
text: FOR decades, advertisers were as closely associated with game shows as slick hosts eager to give away prizes. Now, an airline known for nontraditional approaches to advertising is sponsoring a game show with a couple of contemporary twists: It will be played live, and online.

headline: Messier Praises Gaborik, the Rangers’ Run and the Kings’ Playoff Success
text: LOS ANGELES — Mark Messier called Marian Gaborik “10 times the hockey player he was when he came to the New York Rangers three years ago.”

headline: Commissioner’s Power to Punish Saints in Bounty Scandal Is Affirmed
text: The lengthy battle between the N.F.L. and the players’ association over discipline for players said to be involved in the New Orleans Saints’ bounty scandal inched forward Monday when an arbitrator affirmed Commissioner Roger Goodell’s authority to punish the players.

headline: Egyptian-American Activist Returns to Cairo to Stand Trial for Democracy Promotion
text: Updated, Tuesday, 11:48 a.m. Three months after United States diplomats in Cairo brokered a deal to allow 11 Americans to leave Egypt without standing trial for promoting democracy without a license, an Egyptian-American also charged in the case was detained as he returned to the country to proclaim his innocence.

headline: Leaving Cuba to Pursue a Dream in United States
text: Manuel Huerta was 6 and living in Havana when he first dreamed of being an Olympian, after practicing alongside the Cuban national swim team six blocks from his home.

headline: Do Cyberattacks on Iran Make Us Vulnerable?
text: By pursuing cyberattacks against Iran, is the United States protecting itself or risking far greater danger?

headline: An Upset in Michigan House Race Even Before Voters Go to the Polls
text: Just a few weeks ago, the campaign for Thaddeus McCotter’s seat in Congress didn’t look as though it would be much of a contest.

headline: Dashed Hopes in Queens as Convention Plan Falters
text: Ozone Park, a spare, working-class neighborhood in southwestern Queens, has long had a reputation as a place people pass through to get somewhere else. Most visitors are heading to or coming from Kennedy International Airport. Recently, hopes were raised of continuing to transform this neglected area into a destination in its own right by building a convention center and casino: a $4 billion project that promised the area money, jobs and a more central spot in New York’s tourist literature.

headline: A Guilty Plea to Giving Aid to Al Qaeda Since 2007
text: A former Brooklyn resident pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Monday to providing material support to Al Qaeda.

headline: A Threat to Bristol Bay
text: The possibility that a giant gold-and-copper mine might someday be built near the headwaters that feed Bristol Bay in Alaska, one of the richest salmon fisheries in the world, is cause for alarm. A new report from the Environmental Protection Agency reinforces those fears.

headline: Armed Group Briefly Seizes Tripoli Airport
text: Members of an armed militia briefly shut down Tripoli’s international airport on Monday, swarming the runway and exchanging fire with other armed groups in the latest affront to Libya’s weak interim authorities.

headline: Asthma by the Numbers
text: Federal health officials recently issued a gloomy report noting that the percentage of Americans suffering from asthma reached a record high of 8.4 percent in 2010, up from 7.3 percent in 2001. An estimated 25.7 million people had asthma in 2010, including 18.7 million adults and seven million children below the age of 18. It is a frightening disease in which sufferers struggle to breathe. In severe attacks, victims can die.

headline: Why the Queen Matters
text: London

headline: Blankfein Takes the Stand in an Insider Trading Case
text: For someone who has not practiced law in 30 years, Lloyd C. Blankfein has been spending quite of bit of time in the courtroom.

headline: Pedro Borbon, Helped Reds Win 2 Titles, Dies at 65
text: CINCINNATI (AP) — Pedro Borbon, a relief pitcher who helped the Cincinnati Reds win back-to-back World Series titles in the 1970s, died on Monday at his home in Pharr, Tex. He was 65.

headline: Anthony Says He’ll Do His Part to Help Rebuild Knicks
text: Carmelo Anthony has had a few weeks to process the Knicks’ first-round postseason elimination at the hands of the Miami Heat. On Monday afternoon, he made a public appearance on behalf of USA Basketball and watched fans shoot free throws on a makeshift court adjacent to the Flatiron Building in Manhattan. Conditions were not optimal for the shooters, with an unseasonably low temperature, periodic gusts of wind, and cars whizzing by in the background.

headline: Clinton Takes a Hard Jab at Romney
text: Former President Bill Clinton, days after lauding Mitt Romney for a “sterling business career” as a private investor, said on Monday that, as president, Mr. Romney “would be, in my opinion, calamitous for our country and the world.”

headline: No Crime, Real Punishment
text: New York State decriminalized the possession of small amounts of marijuana in the late 1970s. But last year, in New York City, 50,000 people — the majority of them, young African-American or Hispanic men — were still arrested for possession because of overzealous policing and a weakness in the law.

headline: Preview of Tuesday’s Quarterfinal Matches
text: A look at the two women’s and two men’s singles matches at the French Open on Tuesday. Players seeds are in parentheses.

headline: Canadian Fugitive Is Arrested in Germany
text: BERLIN — A 29-year-old Canadian wanted in a bizarre and grisly killing in Montreal was arrested in Berlin on Monday, after eluding Canadian and European authorities for days.

headline: Solar Panel Payments Set Off a Fairness Debate
text: In California’s sun-scorched Central Valley, the monthly electric bill can easily top $200. But that’s just about what George Burman spent on electricity for all of last year.

headline: The Harm in Free Speech
text: Jeremy Waldron’s new book, “The Harm in Hate Speech,” might well be called “The Harm in Free Speech”; for Waldron, a professor of law and political theory at New York University and Oxford, argues that the expansive First Amendment we now possess allows the flourishing of harms a well-ordered society ought not permit.

headline: Canada: Suspect Arrested in Mall Shooting
text: The Toronto police on Monday arrested a man and charged him with first-degree murder and six counts of attempted murder in connection with a shooting that set off a panic in a downtown Toronto shopping mall on Saturday evening. At a news conference, Detective Sgt. Brian Borg said that it appeared that the attack was a gang-related shooting and that the accused man, Christopher Husbands, 23, killed his intended target, Ahmed Hassan, 24. The six people who were wounded by the stray gunfire in the mall’s food court were bystanders. One, a 13-year-old boy who was visiting Toronto with his mother and sister, was in fair condition on Monday after surgery to repair a bullet wound in his head.

headline: Astros Defy Expectations With the Top Overall Pick
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — With a move to the American League planned for next season, the Houston Astros faced the choice of a safe college pitcher or a high schooler loaded with potential. But the team chose neither, selecting Carlos Correa, a shortstop from Puerto Rico, with the first pick in the 2012 first year player draft.

headline: Some Questions to Ask Mr. Dimon
text: Jamie Dimon’s trip to Capitol Hill next week to explain his bank’s multibillion-dollar trading debacle could quickly devolve into Washington Gotcha Theater.

headline: To Watch Venus Journey Across the Sun, a City Filled With Vantage Points
text: Shortly after 6 p.m. on Tuesday, a small black dot will begin moving across the face of the Sun, an event that is turning New York City — not usually an epicenter of astronomy — into an interplanetary kind of town, with astronomy buffs and telescope jockeys in parks, on street corners and along piers. The rare astronomical event, known as the transit of Venus, comes in pairs about once every century, with the previous one occurring in 2004. The next one will not take place until 2117, making the event on Tuesday truly a last-chance opportunity.

headline: Gambling Group Gave $2 Million to a Cuomo Ally
text: A group closely allied with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo received $2 million from gambling interests last December as he developed a proposal to expand casino gambling in New York.

headline: Police vs. Prosecutor in ’94 Brooklyn Kidnapping Case Against a Rabbi
text: Charles J. Hynes, having once embraced silence on the question of his vigor in prosecuting sex abuse in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community, cannot stop talking now.

headline: Ohio State Gets $483 Million Bid for Parking Lease
text: As state universities try to fill in gaps left by shrinking government support, Ohio State University is taking steps to open a new financial frontier with its parking lots. University officials say that a private bidder has offered $483 million in a lump sum for a lease to operate university parking facilities for 50 years.

headline: Industries That Rely on Foreign Sales
text: Industries that rely on foreign sales

headline: Europe’s Fade Becomes Drag on Sales for U.S. Companies
text: As the European crisis intensifies, a growing number of companies in the United States are warning investors that sales in the region are slowing and could get much worse.

headline: Millions Spent on Wisconsin Recall Election
text: Democratic and labor groups have been major players in the race, but Gov. Scott Walker has spent the most money, partly as a result of a state law that exempted him from contribution limits until the recall election was formally announced in March.

headline: Frenzied Campaigning on Eve of Wisconsin Vote
text: MILWAUKEE — Gov. Scott Walker and his opponent, Mayor Tom Barrett of Milwaukee, raced through a final, frenzied day of campaigning on Monday, stopping in seemingly every region of the state as Wisconsin braced for an Election Day unlike any it has seen before.

headline: Heat Feel Bosh’s Absence in Conference Finals
text: Before LeBron James’s foul-out, before Dwyane Wade’s 3-point clang at the buzzer, before the Boston Celtics rose from the near-dead and before the Miami Heat had lost control of the Eastern Conference finals, Erik Spoelstra tried to sell the world on the value of Christopher Wesson Bosh.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 4, 2012

headline: Revelations by the Dads of Teenagers
text: One of the most memorable scenes in the television series “Louie” last year was when the title character rocked out to a song by the Who while his daughters looked at him blankly from the back seat of a car. What the vignette dramatized so elegantly was the idea that not only were your parents young once, but also that the people they were then didn’t completely disappear.

headline: Strong Advocates of Margarine
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Say what you want about puns (all together now: “They’re the lowest form of humor…”), but I get a kick out of them. Why not get a giggle out of a puzzle, especially early in the week?

headline: Germany Is Open to Pooling Debt, With Conditions
text: BERLIN — Pressed by a banking crisis and turmoil in the markets, Germany has indicated that it is prepared to accept a grand bargain that would provide greater support for its most indebted euro zone partners in exchange for more centralized control over government spending in Europe.

headline: The Untold Future of American Politics
text: The demographic future of the United States is clear. Sometime around 2050 today’s racial and ethnic minorities will likely become a majority. Understanding that change is one of the keys to understanding the future of American politics, but not in the way that most people believe. The conventional view is that in the decades to come the growing minority population and its strong ties to the Democratic Party will be a boon to Democrats and a blight for Republicans.

headline: The Class of 2012
text: College graduation is supposed to be a giant step on the way to a prosperous future. But the weak labor market means that graduates lucky enough to find good jobs will face reduced starting salaries, while many others will struggle to find work or have to settle for lower-level and lower-paid positions that do not require college degrees.

headline: The Enigma Beside Edwards
text: By the end of John Edwards’s trial, we’d all heard more than we ever wanted to about the sad characters in this sordid melodrama: the politician himself, whose ego trumps Trump’s; his onetime aide, who mistook “Single White Female” for an instruction manual; the New Age mistress, who complained when a love nest lacked the proper feng shui. Regrettably, she has a memoir due out soon. Proper feng shui dictates its placement in the remainder bin.

headline: Ratings Don’t Match Intensity of Cup Finals
text: LOS ANGELES — The four previous Stanley Cup finals were compelling on the ice, all involving cities with deep hockey traditions and all providing the N.H.L. with a boost in television ratings.

headline: The Debt Indulgence
text: Every generation has an incentive to borrow money from the future to spend on itself. But, until ours, no generation of Americans has done it to the same extent. Why?

headline: Turning Our Backs on Unions
text: “The Great Divergence” by Timothy Noah is a book about income inequality, and if you’re thinking, “Do we really need another book about income inequality?” the answer is yes. We need this one.

headline: O’Neill to Speak About Violations on ‘Costas Tonight’
text: Excerpts from an exclusive interview with I’ll Have Another’s trainer, Doug O’Neill, by Bob Costas on “Costas Tonight,” which will air after Monday night’s Stanley Cup Game 3 on NBC Sports Network.

headline: New San Francisco Tech Boom Brings Jobs but Also Worries
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When Twitter moves into its new headquarters in downtown San Francisco this month, it will occupy three floors of an 11-story 1937 Art Deco building that has sat shuttered for five years. Outside, its blue bird logo will replace the former main tenant’s sign, whose analog clocks remain frozen at 9:18, 4:33 and other times past.

headline: Theory of Negativity Leaves Mets Unfazed in Hunt for First
text: Expectations frame every season, and the most captivating teams often seem to spring from nowhere. Suddenly, every game is relevant again, the unlikely pennant race a reward to fans for years of pain. After a certain point, the journey of the overachiever is bound to be successful, however it ends.

headline: Using Undictionaried Words
text: There are lots of ways that writers use dictionaries, from the expected (checking spelling) to the unconventional (bibliomancy) to the ill advised (starting an article with some variation of the hackneyed “As my trusty desk dictionary tells me, term X is defined as …”). But perhaps the primary use of dictionaries by writers is as a malapropism preventer, in order to avoid what should be called the “Princess Bride” problem: “You keep using that word. I do not think it means what you think it means.”

headline: Fast High School Shortstop Taken by Mets in First Round
text: Gavin Cecchini, a Met for less than five minutes, had already been declared David Wright’s best friend.

headline: Hostility Between Muslims and German Nationalists Rattles a Former Capital
text: BONN, Germany — The people who live in the trim row houses with well-tended gardens that line the streets of this spa town along the Rhine like to boast of their city’s tolerance, which dates to its time as the capital of West Germany and home to dozens of foreign embassies.

headline: Corrections: June 5
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Top Education Official Tells New York to Keep Up Reforms
text: Arne Duncan, the United States secretary of education, urged New York grant makers to support reforms in curriculum, testing and teacher evaluations so that the state -- and the country -- can catch up to the rest of the world.

headline: Clinton Supports Obama at New York Fund-Raisers
text: Days after lauding Mitt Romney for a “sterling business career” as a private investor, former President Bill Clinton said on Monday that as president, Mr. Romney “would be in my opinion calamitous for our country and the world.”

headline: Elite Military Forces Are Denied in Bid for Expansion
text: WASHINGTON — In late April, the military’s Special Operations Command presented the State Department and Congress with an urgent request for new authority to train and equip security forces in places like Yemen and Kenya.

headline: Fashion Awards, on Speed Dial
text: Marc Jacobs may not have been a winner at the Council of Fashion Designers of America’s annual awards show on Monday night, but his dress was the star. Seth Meyers, the evening’s host, turned Mr. Jacobs’s black lace number — the Comme des Garcon shirt dress he wore at the recent Costume Institute party, over white boxers — into comic material. Later in the show, Mr. Meyers appeared in the dress, remarking, “This has such good ventilation.” He also joked that he had consumed 11 drinks since his opening monologue.

headline: The Landowners’ Lease
text: The oil and gas boom has arrived in the Upper Ohio River Valley, and landowners wise to concerns of “fracking” are learning how to get the most from their mineral leases.

headline: Controversy after German Soccer Team Visits Auschwitz
text: A prominent leader in Germany’s Jewish community has criticized a visit by members of the German national soccer team to the site of the former Auschwitz concentration camp.

headline: Lindsay Lohan in "First Point"
text: Poparazzi continue to haunt Lindsay Lohan, day and night, in this new film by Richard Phillips and Taylor Steele.

headline: Pausing Between Shots, Just to Regroup
text: DUBLIN, Ohio

headline: Microsoft Tries to Make Windows Updates Flame Retardant
text: Like archaeologists on a dig, security researchers continue to unearth some interesting — some terrifying — facts about Flame, the virus aimed at computers in the Middle East.

headline: New Value for Land in Rural Ohio
text: CALDWELL, Ohio — The energy boom has swept into the rural counties of the upper Ohio River Valley, producing a torrent of investment in mineral leasing that is jolting the economies of small towns and swelling the bank accounts of some working-class families.

headline: As the Kings Chase a Sweep, the Devils Try to Survive
text: LOS ANGELES — Those regal dynasties — the Canadiens, the Oilers, the Islanders — seemed to play close to perfect Stanley Cup hockey. This year’s Los Angeles Kings have toppled records in dominating fashion like those teams of long ago.

headline: Democrats Grab a Chance to Speak With One Voice
text: WASHINGTON — If there was any doubt that the White House strongly supports legislation to make it easier for women to sue over unequal pay, clarity was provided on Monday by President Obama himself. He jumped on a routine conference call with reporters to push the measure, known as the Paycheck Fairness Act, saying, “I don’t have to tell you how much this matters to families across the country.”

headline: City Launching Online Applications for Housing Lotteries
text: The process of applying to live in a city-financed affordable housing development is about to enter the 21st century.

headline: Penalty Kills Keep Kings in Control
text: LOS ANGELES — Defense in hockey means more than punishing hits, acrobatic saves and blocked shots.

headline: Doing Anything This Saturday?
text: Jack Kerouac once said that no one, not the biggest drinker, fighter or lover, could find the center of Saturday night in America. But Kerouac never had a Saturday like this to work with.

headline: Blacking Out 180,000 Candles
text: HONG KONG — News of the record turnout for a candlelight vigil in Hong Kong on Monday night was above-the-fold news in every English-language paper in the city on Tuesday morning. The mass-circulation tabloid The Standard carried a banner photo over the headline, “Sea of Candles.”

headline: Word of the Day | conciliatory
text: conciliatory •\kən-ˈsil-yə-ˌtȯr-e, -ˈsi-le-ə-\• adjective

headline: Promoting Nutrition, Disney to Restrict Junk-Food Ads
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company, in an effort to address concerns about entertainment’s role in childhood obesity, announced on Tuesday that all products advertised on its child-focused television channels, radio stations and Web sites must comply with a strict new set of nutritional standards.

headline: Deal Reached on Student Loans
text: College and university presidents representing more than one million students will meet with White House officials on Tuesday to announce an agreement to provide incoming students a “shopping sheet” of easy-to-understand terms for financial aid packages, beginning in the 2013-14 school year. The participants promised to clearly detail a student’s net cost after grants and scholarships are taken into account, and estimate the monthly payments a student would have to make after graduation to repay any federal loans.

headline: Focus on State’s Jobs in Romney Era
text: President Obama’s campaign ratcheted up its assault on Mitt Romney’s record as governor of Massachusetts on Monday, putting $10 million behind a tough new commercial that claims Mr. Romney had “one of the worst economic records in the country.” The advertisement will be broadcast in nine battleground states.

headline: Tibet: Negotiators Resign
text: Two senior envoys of the Dalai Lama who negotiated with China in nine rounds of talks have resigned, according to the Tibetan government-in-exile in India. The envoys, Lodi Gyari and Kelsang Gyaltsen, said in a statement that they were resigning because of the “deteriorating situation inside Tibet,” which, since 2009, has prompted 38 Tibetans to set themselves on fire. The envoys expressed disappointment over China’s rejection of a plan for “genuine autonomy” for Tibet put forward by the Dalai Lama in 2008, and they said current circumstances made substantive dialogue difficult. The last round of talks took place in 2010. The Tibetan exile government said a task force on talks would meet again in December, after China announces its new leadership in the fall, with the aim of renewing negotiations.

headline: El Salvador: Canadian Lawsuit Over Mine Allowed to Proceed
text: A Canadian company’s lawsuit against El Salvador for blocking a gold mine can proceed under the country’s investment law but not under the provisions of the Central America Free Trade Agreement, a World Bank panel ruled Friday. In a case closely watched by environmentalists and the mining industry, the panel, the International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes, will make a binding decision on whether El Salvador unfairly failed to license the mine proposed by the Pacific Rim Mining Corporation or had the sovereign right to reject it after the company already made investments. Environmentalists had hoped the panel would reject the case outright and slow the spread of mining in Central America.

headline: A Conversation with: Director Karan Gour
text: “Kshay (Corrode),” written and directed by Karan Gour, is a black-and-white independent feature based on a character’s single-minded obsession with an unfinished statue of the Hindu goddess Lakshmi. The film examines the idea of obsession through the Arvind and Chhaya, a middle-class Indian couple struggling to make ends meet when Chhaya becomes drawn to the statue.

headline: Syria: Heavy Clashes Reported
text: A Syrian activist group reported that at least 80 soldiers were killed over the weekend in clashes with rebels, which would be one of the largest losses for government forces since the uprising began in March 2011. The report, by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, could not be independently confirmed. The group also told Reuters that rebels had overrun army checkpoints in the northern town of Ariha, and a photo, right, released by activists was said to show damaged army tanks in the town. The reports cast further doubt on the viability of a truce plan arranged by Kofi Annan, an envoy of the United Nations and the Arab League. He plans to brief the United Nations Security Council this week and will also meet with Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has said President Bashar al-Assad of Syria must resign as part of any solution to the conflict.

headline: Randy Paar, Talk-Show Host’s Daughter and Guest, Dies at 63
text: Randy Paar, who is remembered by many 1950s and ’60s television viewers as the cute, precocious girl whom her father, the late-night talk-show host Jack Paar, introduced to a national audience in his monologues and home movies, died on Saturday after falling off a platform at Grand Central Terminal. A successful lawyer in Manhattan, she was 63.

headline: Thunder Take Lead as Their Young Stars Best the Spurs’ Veteran Ones
text: SAN ANTONIO — They finished the regular season with the best record in the N.B.A. They won 20 straight games, including the first 10 of the playoffs. They dazzled opponents with selflessness and precision. Just days ago, with a 2-0 lead in the Western Conference finals, a return to the N.B.A. finals appeared on the horizon for Tim Duncan and the Spurs.

headline: U.S. General in South Korea to Be Replaced After Spy Report
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The Pentagon announced the replacement of the commander of United States Special Operations in South Korea after a news media report quoted him as saying that American and South Korean troops had been parachuting into North Korea on spy missions, a statement denied by Washington and the government in Seoul.

headline: News Quiz | June 5, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Pre-Euro Reading List: Greek Hopes, Irish Smiles, English Aches, French Fear
text: There’s harmony in the Ireland camp. Backbiting in England. Drama in Italy. And not a small amount of controversy in Poland and Ukraine before the European Championships open in those two countries beginning Friday.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 5, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Brash Chef and Big Bet for CNN.”

headline: Service for the Blind: A New Sport for the Visually Impaired
text: Go to related article »

headline: Queen Elizabeth’s Jubilee Concludes With Expressions of Mutual Appreciation
text: LONDON — Saying she was touched and humbled by “countless kindnesses” shown to her, Queen Elizabeth II wound up a spectacular and closely scripted four-day celebration of her 60 years as monarch on Tuesday, seeming buoyed by an outpouring of support that is likely to cement her family’s place in British society for years to come.

headline: Soho House Expansion Plans Include Mumbai
text: Soho House, the London-based members only club, is expanding to Mumbai, among other locations, Nicole LaPorte writes in The New York Times.Soho House’s chief executive, Nick Jones, who founded the club in 1995, currently oversees 10 Soho Houses (six in Britain, three in the United States and one in Berlin).

headline: Can Mom-and-Pop Shops Survive Extreme Gentrification?
text: When I was about 6, my dad and I were sitting near Wall Street when I asked him why so many men were wearing suits and ties. It was the 1970s, and we lived in Greenwich Village, a place where you could see men wearing almost anything except a suit and tie. My dad, a theater actor, told me that the people on Wall Street cared about money, and as a result, they had to dress formally. I even remember feeling bad for these poor chumps.

headline: Photographers on Trial Outside Court
text: I can’t think of a time I felt worse for my brother photojournalist than covering the John Edwards trial.

headline: What Advice Would You Give to Somebody Who Just Started Dating?
text: The most recent government report on high school students involved in abusive relationships found that nearly one in 10 has been physically hurt by a boyfriend or girlfriend. Programs to teach teenagers about relationships are proliferating, but questions about their effectiveness and reach remain. What advice have you received about relationships? What advice do you wish you had received? What would you encourage a younger friend to keep in mind before dating?

headline: Putin Arrives in China, Seeking Stronger Ties
text: BEIJING — The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, arrived in China on Tuesday for meetings aimed at strengthening a partnership between the two countries and offsetting the influence of the United States.

headline: Pakistan Says It Tested Nuclear-Capable Missile
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s military said it successfully test-fired a nuclear-capable cruise missile on Tuesday, continuing a pattern of what analysts say is a regional arms buildup with a focus on India.

headline: White T-Shirts Are Fashion and Function in Harlem Street Style
text: This week, we visit the home of the Apollo Theater, the Studio Museum and the shopping strip, 125th Street. We saw Ariel Weekes strolling up Lenox Avenue, at 121st Street, in Harlem wearing a white T-shirt, blue jeans and red sneakers. With a red, sharpened No. 2 pencil tucked behind his ear, Mr. Weekes spoke of his love for James Baldwin, a Harlem native, and for the style and functionality of white T-shirts, a staple for many of Harlem’s native sons.

headline: The Rail Bookshelf: ‘Affirmed’
text: In all my enduring years as a sportswriter and presently a full-time author, I’ve never come across a more compelling subject than the book I wrote about Affirmed, the last Triple Crown winner. Symbolically, it was my 25th tome. With the approaching Belmont on June 9 there is a prodigious feeling among the railbirds that the 34-year-old drought will be ended by a horse with the melodious moniker of “I’ll Have Another.”

headline: Getting Nowhere on Varick Street
text: Dear Diary: I was trying to get into the Holland Tunnel in the late afternoon during rush hour and was stuck on Varick Street, inching toward the entrance, when an attractive woman in her early 20s knocked on my passenger window. I was startled, but she seemed very interested in speaking to me, so I opened my car window, curious about what she might have in mind.

headline: The Chancellor Pays Tribute to a Spelling Bee Finalist
text: Arvind Mahankali, a seventh grader at Junior High School 74 in Queens, has placed third in the National Spelling Bee two years in a row. On Monday, Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott visited his school to congratulate him.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Old People Really Do Have a Different Smell
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: A Tech Boom in San Francisco’s Urban Core
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Norimitsu Onishi reports on how tech start-ups are moving into San Francisco’s urban core, transforming a neighborhood that has defied development for decades. Among those making the move is Twitter, which next month will take over three floors of an 11-story 1937 Art Deco building that has sat shuttered for five years. Zynga, Yelp and other social media start-ups also have offices within the city. Meanwhile, workers at the big Silicon Valley companies, like Google and Apple, are becoming attracted to San Francisco’s urban charms, choosing to live in the city while commuting to the valley.

headline: In ‘Game of Thrones,’ You Win or You Buy: HBO Offers $30,000 Iron Throne Replicas
text: One way to obtain the Iron Throne, the ceremonial seat of power in HBO’s “Game of Thrones” that has been made from the swords of hundreds of surrendered lords, is to defeat your rivals in battle and unite the Seven Kingdoms at the cost of thousands of lives and countless treasure. Or if you’re squeamish about the sight of blood and entrails but still have some extra treasure to spare, you could simply buy one for $30,000.

headline: Chessmate
text: LONDON — It was Game 8 of the World Chess Championship, and the four-time winner and defending champion, 42-year-old Viswanathan Anand of India, playing white, was a game down to the Israeli Boris Gelfand, 43. Gelfand, perhaps buoyed by his success in Game 7, had chosen an unexpectedly sharp line against Anand, who is renowned for his ability to calculate quickly on the board.

headline: Independence Days
text: JERUSALEM — The Knesset member Lia Shemtov seems puzzled. Why would anyone oppose her bill proposing a commonsensical fix to an oddity in Israel’s holiday calendar? “Am I missing something?” the Ukrainian-born Israeli told me by phone on Thursday.

headline: At City Hall, Not Seeing Moderation in All Things
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would have done well to follow his own advice about food and apply it to policing: everything in moderation.

headline: Thomas H. Lee Takes Stake in Party City in $2.69 Billion Deal
text: It’s a private equity party.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Disney’s Health Push, and Eerie Numbers in China
text: At a Washington news conference with the first lady, Michelle Obama, the Walt Disney Company on Tuesday plans to announce new nutritional standards for advertisers on its many child-focused outlets, including the Saturday morning cartoons on the ABC stations it owns. The standards would disqualify a wide range of candy, sugared cereal and fast food from advertising, Brooks Barnes writes. Also, Disney will reduce the amount of sodium by 25 percent in the children’s meals served at its theme parks, and create public service announcements to promote exercise and healthy eating.

headline: The Kings Rule
text: When a season reaches its final series of the playoffs, with two teams having clawed themselves into position for their sport’s ultimate prize, it’s natural to hunker down and expect something epic. There are going to be ebbs and flows, big gaffes and jaw-dropping feats, swings of momentum that take fans from one extreme to the other. When it’s over, the winning team will celebrate in exhaustion and relief, having taken the opponent’s best shot and persevering.

headline: Your Tech Questions, Answered: Part 4
text: In this batch of questions, I answer questions about unlocking an iPhone; using a projector and laptop for all your video needs; the most cost-effective way to connect your computer to your stereo system; forwarding text messages for storage purposes; and using your own wireless router in a hotel room. (You can also read my answers to the first, second and third batch of questions.)

headline: For ‘Godfather of Indian Advertising,’ A Mocking Tribute

headline: From Balloon Dogs to Puppets, Jeff Koons Teaches an Art Class
text: It's Visual Arts Appreciation Week in city schools. The artist Jeff Koons stopped by a classroom to talk animal sculptures with second graders.

headline: Rally and Open Letter Signal Pushback to a Less-Than-Daily Times-Picayune
text: On Monday a rally was held and an open letter was issued from people in New Orleans who believe that Advance Publications’ decision to reduce the publishing schedule of The Times-Picayune to three days a week would damage the civic and cultural life of the city.

headline: Just One Look | Reed Krakoff
text: For prespring (otherwise known as resort), Reed Krakoff presented 31 looks, all of which expressed great reservation and elegance, but with a flirty subtext. Pieces that elongated the body — monochromatic dresses and lean, slit-up-the-side skirts — sent the strongest message about this season’s silhouette: flattery was everything. As in previous collections, Krakoff stuck to a palette of neutrals. Cream and sand colors came accented with hits of coral, orange and bright blue, reminders that minimalism need not be colorless. Here, an example of how effective a bold/barely-there color combination can be.

headline: Cisco’s Strategic Box
text: Cisco just announced a product that it hopes will give it something it needs just as bad as revenue: relevance in two of the hottest trends in tech, the mobile Internet and software-defined networking, or S.D.N.

headline: On Our Radar: Melting Tropical Glaciers
text: Scientists rush to map the tropical glaciers in the Rwenzori Mountains, which are expected to disappear in a decade or two from Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. [The Guardian]

headline: Walker Survives Wisconsin Recall Vote
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — Gov. Scott Walker, whose decision to cut collective bargaining rights for most public workers set off a firestorm in a state usually known for its political civility, easily held on to his job on Tuesday, becoming the first governor in the country to survive a recall election and dealing a painful blow to Democrats and labor unions.

headline: There’s No Need to Fear That Garter Snake
text: “Venom” is not a word to use lightly. It is richly suggestive, conjuring thoughts of poisonous snakes like copperheads, water moccasins and rattlesnakes. So perhaps it is not surprising that my reference to eastern garter snakes as “mildly venomous” in a Spring Time post a few weeks ago troubled some readers.

headline: The Darker Thrills of Ecotourism
text: For many people, ecotourism evokes a picnic in Muir Woods in California, perhaps, or counting endangered sea turtles on a Costa Rican beach or spending the night in a tree house with gibbons in Laos. Andrew Blackwell, a Brooklyn-based author and journalist, sees it differently. His idea of an interesting trip is less about beauty than environmental devastation.

headline: Your Wisconsin Recall Questions Answered

Have a question you don’t see answered here? You can post a question here or on our Facebook page, or send a message via Twitter @thecaucus using the hashtag #asknyt. And be sure to tune back in later on Tuesday night for our live coverage and analysis of the election results.

headline: How Can Facebook Safely Add Under-13s?
text: For the past few weeks, there have been rumors that Facebook is considering expanding its reach to include children under 13. With The Wall Street Journal reporting yesterday that Facebook is actively testing options to create a safe, child-friendly space on the site, those rumors can be officially considered to have reached some sort of critical mass: unnamed sources good enough for The Journal have effectively confirmed them.

headline: Kohr Principles

headline: Share Your Summer Reading List

The Learning Network, The Times’s teaching and learning blog, invites you to use the hashtag #summerreading to share recommendations, photos of your stack of beach books, or more general thoughts on why summer seems to be the season for reading. The best responses will be posted on the blog.

headline: The Galvanized Yankee
text: It is unlikely that Henry Stanley knew, upon joining an Illinois artillery unit on June 4, 1862, that his action validated a central Darwinian principle — namely, that it is not necessarily the biggest and strongest that survive, but the most adaptable.
