headline: Broadway Gives Its Regards, to the Tune of $11.2 Billion, to New York
text: The Broadway industry helped generate $11.2 billion in spending by New York City tourists, theater owners and producers during the 2010-11 theater season, a 9 percent increase over the dollar amount in a comparable economic impact study two years earlier, according to the Broadway League trade association of producers.

headline: For More of Midtown, Traffic Relief May Be a Mouse Click Away
text: Updated 4:43 p.m. | A high-tech program introduced last year to help reduce traffic congestion in Midtown Manhattan will be more than doubled in size after initial results indicated that travel speeds had been improved by 10 percent, city transportation officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Now Playing | ‘Fifty Years of the CFDA’
text: Last night the Council of Fashion Designers of America (CFDA) Fashion Awards took place at Lincoln Center’s Alice Tully Hall in New York. There, industry members gathered to commemorate the organization’s 50th anniversary, to recognize the year’s most exciting contributions to fashion design and journalism, and to celebrate the lifetime achievements of some of the business’s biggest creative influences. Kicking off the evening’s ceremony was this short film, “50 Years of the CFDA,” directed by Zoe Cassavetes and inspired by Richard Avedon’s 1969 portraits of Andy Warhol and members of the Factory. “I think it came out as half film, half art collage,” noted Cassavetes about the project. Of her subjects she said: “I was pretty blown away by the talent that came through the studio during those two days [we were shooting]. It was interesting to see which designers are inspired by others and why. It’s not just about the clothes they make … it’s about the universe they create.” Below is a list of this year’s award winners and honorees:

headline: How Jellio Is Solving Its Manufacturing Problems
text: Last week, we published a case study about Jellio, a company that makes whimsical home furnishings that are hard to manufacture. Demand for Jellio’s products, which include its top-selling Gummi Bear candy-inspired GummiLights, was strong. But to build the business, the owner, Mario Marsicano, knew he had to increase production while reducing costs.

headline: At Made in NY Awards, Kickstarter Shares Honors With Streep and De Niro
text: The media production company @radical.media and Kickstarter, the crowd-sourced financing Web site, were among the companies and people honored Monday night by the City of New York for their achievements in “making it” in New York, literally and idiomatically.

headline: Abortion Qualms on Morning-After Pill May Be Unfounded
text: Labels inside every box of morning-after pills, drugs widely used to prevent pregnancy after sex, say they may work by blocking fertilized eggs from implanting in a woman’s uterus. Respected medical authorities, including the National Institutes of Health and the Mayo Clinic, have said the same thing on their Web sites.

headline: Drug’s Nickname May Have Aided Politicization
text: Scientists say that one reason emergency contraceptives have become so politicized is that their nickname, “morning-after pills,” has given rise to misconceptions about how the drugs help prevent pregnancy after sex.

headline: Cloaking the Aboriginal Past
text: She is backstage at the Sydney Opera House. She is going to perform. A young woman, a photographer, takes her picture. She wears a cloak made from possum pelts stitched together, each individual square adorned with images that contain countless sacred stories.

headline: If Fish Liked Nightclubs
text: TWO tyros in Wall Street livery walk into a bar; can’t decide what to drink. “Champagne?” one hazards. The other shrugs. Nevertheless, a bottle is summoned. There is no toast, nothing to celebrate — yet. The women are just starting to eddy.

headline: How Federer Survived del Potro
text: PARIS — Roger Federer of Switzerland reversed a slide toward defeat in a tense match and turned the tables on Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina, 3-6, 6-7 (4), 6-2, 6-0, 6-3 in a French Open quarterfinal before nearly 10,000 spectators at Roland Garros.

headline: In El Barrio, a New Bookstore Is Counting on Its Community
text: It seems to make little business sense. Not when Amazon’s dominance continues to threaten brick-and-mortar storefronts. And not when the economy has already claimed many small businesses.

headline: Death Penalty Death Watch: Mississippi
text: There is really only one rationale for the death penalty: Vengeance. Supporters of capital punishment talk about deterrence, but there’s scant evidence that the threat of dying at the hands of the state actually reduces violent crime. On the contrary, as Princeton’s Peter Singer wrote in October, “murder rates in Europe and other Western industrialized nations are lower, often much lower, than those in the US. In the US itself, the 16 states that have abolished the death penalty generally have lower murder rates than those that retain it.”

headline: How Same-Sex Couples Can Find Financial Advisers
text: And though a recent federal appeals court ruling has provided some hope to gays and lesbians that their unions could potentially be recognized by the federal government, nothing has changed just yet.  That means that same-sex couples, including those who live in states that recognize their unions, should take extra care when setting up their financial life with a partner or spouse.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Reader's Question
text: The national political correspondent Jeff Zeleny answers a reader's question regarding the Wisconsin recall election: "If the Democrats win, can the Republicans then do their own recall?"

headline: Farming on the Campus Quad
text: Picture the archetypal college campus: venerable Gothic stone buildings, maple leaves aflame in autumn colors and students lounging with books on a wide, open lawn.

headline: Meet Blanca, Roberta’s Sister
text: The new restaurant Blanca, opened by the team behind Roberta’s in Bushwick, is the sleek counterpart to Roberta’s cluttered charm.

headline: Drone Strike Killed No. 2 in Al Qaeda, U.S. Officials Say
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Central Intelligence Agency drone strike in Pakistan’s tribal belt killed Al Qaeda’s deputy leader, Abu Yahya al-Libi, American officials said on Tuesday, dealing another blow to the group in a lawless area that has long been considered the global headquarters of international terrorism but the importance of which may now be slipping.

headline: Going Nuts for Smoothies
text: When I make a smoothie I like to make a meal out of it, or at least make something substantial enough to get me through my morning swim. But I don’t like to bulk up my smoothies with protein powders or brewer’s yeast, supplements I used to add when I was first a vegetarian years ago and we didn’t know much about how to get protein and certain B vitamins from plant sources. Now protein powders, the stuff of many an athlete’s blended drink, seem too processed to me. And I don’t like to add anything that doesn’t improve the taste of a blended drink, which rules out brewer’s yeast.

headline: A Sleek Surprise Around Back of Roberta’s
text: THE team behind Roberta’s, the pizzeria and do-it-yourself lifestyle cooperative on Moore Street in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn, has quietly opened a new restaurant, Blanca. Carlo Mirarchi, who runs the kitchen at Roberta’s and owns it and Blanca with Chris Parachini and Brandon Hoy, is the chef. The new restaurant seats 12.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Wisconsin Recall

headline: Carrot and Papaya Smoothie With Hazelnuts and Pistachios
text: The carrot and the nuts contribute great texture and substance to this smoothie, and the coconut ice cubes add great flavor.

headline: Just One Look | Marc Jacobs
text: The fun-house silhouettes, prints and fabrics in Marc Jacobs’s resort collection came inspired by Cindy Sherman’s clown series: tinsel tweeds, sequin stripes, primary colors and polka dots covered many of the curious puppet-doll dresses and suits. The shoes — clunky sandals with big candy ball stones and awkward, cartoon-character loafers — looked a little too big on the models. Make no mistake, though. Jacobs wasn’t just clowning around. He knows his customers and knows that their eyes will have adjusted to ballooning skirts and funny fitting jackets (see fall) by the time resort hits stores. Jacobs also knows very well how to design commercial successes and sprinkle them between his experiments. These calf-length shifts, their fronts covered with glossy sequin florals and topped with jesters’ bows at the neck, like so, will wow and wear effortlessly.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Adds Power and a Pair of Letters to SLS AMG for 2013
text: Though they are not typically shopped against German track-day specials, the 2012 Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 and 2013 Ford Shelby GT500 are plumbing supercar depths of horsepower and performance, arguably diminishing a car like Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG, which landed like a Teutonic hammer in 2010.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Wisconsin Recall

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Issue Moves Closer to Justices
text: The likelihood that the Supreme Court will weigh in on same-sex marriage in the coming year grew markedly on Tuesday when a federal appeals court rejected a request to review its own recent ruling throwing out a voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage in California.

headline: Clear Channel and Taylor Swift’s Label Agree to Reinvent Royalty System

headline: The Best Tweets From the #CFDA Awards
text: A roundup of tweets from the annual fashion awards ceremony, held on Monday night.

headline: Debra Winger to Make Her Broadway Debut in David Mamet’s ‘Anarchist’
text: After a film career that has included “Terms of Endearment,” “Urban Cowboy” and “An Officer and a Gentleman,” it was only a matter of time before someone swept Debra Winger off her feet and carried her over the threshold of Broadway, and the man who’s going to do it (sans naval uniform) is David Mamet. The producers of Mr. Mamet’s coming play, “The Anarchist,” said on Tuesday that Ms. Winger would make her Broadway debut in the production, which is scheduled to begin performances in November.

headline: Kia Recalls 73,000 Rio Models for Air-Bag Malfunction Hazard
text: Kia announced it would recall almost 73,000 of its Rio models from the 2006-8 model years because a passenger air bag could malfunction and deploy when a small child was seated in the front passenger seat.

headline: Meg Whitman’s Defining Moment, Still Undefined
text: LAS VEGAS — Meg Whitman spoke Tuesday morning to 10,000 customers and partners at an event in the gambling capital. It was her biggest public performance as the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. In a sense it was her defining moment: after the turmoil of the last couple of years, she tried to define what H.P. is and does, and why the company still matters.

headline: Rounding Up Apple Conference Chatter, From Maps to TV Apps
text: Apple’s Worldwide Developers Conference, an annual event where the company has typically unveiled new iPhones, will start on Monday. And as usual, the Web is noisy with chatter about what’s to come.

headline: How Steep Are the Odds of a 3-0 Comeback? Very
text: With Los Angeles taking a 3-0 lead over the Devils in the Stanley Cup finals, television types have repeatedly mentioned that only one N.H.L. team has come from down three-games-to-none to win a Stanley Cup finals: the 1942 Toronto Maple Leafs, who erased the Red Wings’ 3-0 lead to win the Cup. But what happened to all the other teams that fell behind 3-0?

headline: Through a Courtyard, Ambitious Pork
text: There is more than one way to put some pig in a sandwich. Ralf Kuettel (right), the chef and owner of Trestle on Tenth, channels Northern Europe instead of Tennessee or Italy in the sandwich he’ll be serving at his new shop, Rocket Pig, using seasonings like juniper, mustard and bay leaves to flavor hunks of pork neck and shoulder, which he brines, then smokes and roasts. The compact shop, which opens next week, is behind the restaurant, reachable through a rusted gate and a charming little brick courtyard. There are counters for eating, as well as access to the restaurant’s garden. Raw oysters, cheeses, cured meats, potato chips, cookies, brownies and wine and beer round out the menu. Other items, like salads, soups and sausages, may be added in coming months. Everything, except for the alcoholic beverages, can be packed to go. And with the High Line entrance a block away, why not?

headline: The Best Summer Olympics Movies (With a Few Asterisks)
text: The Summer Olympics always brings two weeks of incredible stories of joy, triumph and heartbreak, mostly involving fit, attractive young people. So it should be a great subject for films, right?

headline: From a TV Chef, Bottoms Up in Baking Pans
text: The latest addition to the line of cookware and serving pieces from Curtis Stone, the chef and television personality, is a trio of baking pans that combine heavy-duty steel with silicone liners. The cake, loaf and muffin pans have built-in silicone bottoms that can be popped up, making it easier to release their contents. Mr. Stone said he developed many of the cookware items sold under his name after filming the reality series “Take Home Chef,” in which he randomly finds people in a supermarket and goes to their homes to help them cook a meal. “I got real insight into what people go through in the kitchen and how inadequate their equipment often is,” he said. “My products are not just endorsements. I hope I’m solving problems.”

headline: A Latino Basic Goes Vegetarian
text: Young women embarking on a new artisanal food venture has become a familiar story. Susana Columna and Gloribell Tavera, both of whom lost their jobs in television, now make sofrito, a base for Latino dishes that is as essential as roux in New Orleans or mirepoix in France. (Soffrito is the Italian version.) Though sofrito is often made with pork or pork fat, Chulita’s Famous Sofrito, produced in Long Island City, Queens, is vegetarian. Unlike a mass-market sofrito, it has no added starches, thickeners or other additives. There are two varieties: a verde, with bell peppers, garlic, lemon juice, vinegar and herbs; and a spiced one that is ruddy, dense and less moist, with similar ingredients as well as a good dose of paprika and cumin. Use them to get that bean and pork stew, chicken casserole or paella going; they can also serve as salsa, garnish or embellishment for a bowl of soup.

headline: Neta
text: Inside the spartan sushi bar founded by two head chefs from Masa and Bar Masa.

headline: A Rebuke for Saudi Morals Officer Who Chastised Woman Wearing Nail Polish
text: The head of Saudi Arabia’s morals police criticized one of his officers this week for getting into a public confrontation with a young woman over her nail polish at a mall in Riyadh. The incident, which took place last month, gained global attention because the woman refused the officer’s command to leave the mall for violating the kingdom’s standards of female modesty and recorded the standoff on her phone.

headline: Tighter Banking Ties Are Proposed in Europe
text: FRANKFURT — Under growing international and financial market pressure to fix the region’s bank problems, European officials took a step on Tuesday toward surrendering a cherished national prerogative by proposing to knit banking systems together more closely.

headline: Scuderi Sees Hope for His Once Beloved Islanders
text: Kings defenseman Rob Scuderi is one game away from having his name engraved on the Stanley Cup for a second time. But he can still remember when that was first a dream, growing up as an Islanders fan on Long Island during the team’s heyday.

headline: Critique of Obama Jobs Record Puts Romney in a Bind
text: If there’s one thing Mitt Romney cannot stand, it’s when President Obama blames the economic situation he inherited from former president George W. Bush for the country’s current gloomy challenges.

headline: Nicki Minaj Faces Off With the Hot 97 D.J.’s
text: Nicki Minaj, the Queens rapper, called into Hot 97 on Monday night to explain her decision to pull out of the radio station’s concert the previous day and became embroiled in a heated debate with DJ Funkmaster Flex.

headline: Big Government, Small Families
text: Last week I had the pleasure of joining the Washington Post’s E.J. Dionne on “The Diane Rehm Show” for a discussion of his engaging new book, “Our Divided Political Heart,” which is both a meditation on the individualistic and communitarian strands in American political thought and history, and (as you might expect, given the author) a lament that the contemporary Republican Party has tilted the contemporary balance dangerously toward a radical individualism. My main criticism of his thesis (also perhaps predictably) was to question Dionne’s tendency to equate “community” with “government,” given the way expansions of state power tend to crowd out more personal and/or voluntary forms of common life (civic, religious, familial), replacing human-scale interactions with bureaucratic process and leaving society more atomized than before. To which he responded that while this can happen, it doesn’t have to happen: Government can strengthen local communities as well as weaken them, partner with private groups as well pre-empt them, and fill in the gaps left by purely voluntary effort as well as take those efforts’ place. Conceding that reality, I nonetheless tried to press Dionne a bit more on whether given where we are now, with a large-scale and costly welfare state having become a permanent feature of our national life even as more local and personal forms of community have attenuated, the conservative-communitarian suspicion of state power might not be more relevant than the liberal-communitarian view of the state as an instrument of social solidarity.

headline: Djokovic and Federer Survive to Set Up French Open Semifinal Clash
text: PARIS — In a roundabout sense, Novak Djokovic has the French to thank for helping to make him the armor-plated champion he has become. Djokovic credits leading Serbia’s Davis Cup team to an emotional victory over France in the 2010 final for launching him into the tennis stratosphere, for giving him the confidence to move mountains named Nadal and Federer, for helping him stare down Grand Slam inconveniences like match points.

headline: Gleaming Sushi That Fills the Eye
text: EVEN by the spartan standards of sushi bars, the interior of Neta, on West Eighth Street, is defiantly plain. The walls are covered in a nubby material that makes them look like bulletin boards in a corporate cafeteria. They’re even dotted with pushpin-size holes, as if somebody had taken down the Man With a Van fliers just before unlocking the doors at 5 p.m.

headline: Some New Sounds End a Season
text: The Orchestra of the League of Composers began its season-finale concert on Monday evening at the Miller Theater of Columbia University with a reminder of its storied legacy of promoting new music: Aaron Copland’s gentle Prelude for Chamber Orchestra, derived from his youthful Symphony for Organ and Orchestra. Then it got to the real new music that audiences have come to expect from this ensemble, formed in 2009, including a world premiere, an American premiere and a New York premiere.

headline: Diller Donates $30 Million to Fund for Hollywood Retirees
text: LOS ANGELES — Barry Diller, the chairman of IAC/InterActive Corp, is contributing $30 million to Hollywood’s Motion Picture and Television Fund, the fund said on Tuesday.

headline: Senate Republicans Again Block Pay Equity Bill
text: WASHINGTON — A bill that would pave the way for women to more easily litigate their way to pay equality failed to clear a procedural hurdle in the Senate on Tuesday as Republicans united against the measure for the second time in two years.

headline: Obama’s Fate May Depend on Europe
text: The recent downshift in the economy has dealt a powerful blow to President Obama’s chances of re-election in November. But perhaps most worrying for the president is just how little sway he retains over where the economy goes from here.

headline: Census Data Finds Who Votes, and Who Doesn’t
text: The Census Bureau on Tuesday released data showing who tends to vote in the United States, going far deeper than any polls can in studying voter behavior.

headline: Links While Driving Through Pocatello
text: If you want to get a firm grasp on the farm bill, check out this wonderful resource.

headline: Is Android Having a Bad Year?
text: For some time now, Google‘s Android system has been No. 1 worldwide and in the United States in terms of smartphone market share. But recent statistics suggest that the almighty robot has been losing steam in this country.

headline: Sticking Points | Box Play for Kids
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: ‘Color Jam’ in Chicago
text: Jessica Stockholder’s art installation transforms the intersection of State and Adams Streets.

headline: Minds Eclipsed by Peculiar Disorders
text: More restraint in the presentation would have been nice, but there’s no denying that the cases detailed in “Broken Minds,” a new series on Discovery Fit & Health, are unsettling reminders of how precarious our mental health can be.

headline: At a Busy Intersection, Going Beyond Red, Yellow and Green
text: CHICAGO — In 2009 the multimedia artist Jessica Stockholder used brightly colored plywood platforms and metal bleachers to turn a section of Madison Square Park in New York into a kind of abstract painting, “Flooded Chambers Maid.” Children instantly appropriated it as a playground, and adults used it as an informal seating area.

headline: Imagining a Smaller Drink for a Big, Thirsty City
text: AT a sunny street fair Sunday on the Lower East Side, students from the Ivy Smart Learning Center worked a tiny lemonade stand, jostling to be the one to add the lemon slices and pour the sugar. For the first time, New York City children were participating in Lemonade Day, a nationwide event sponsored by a Houston-based nonprofit group to encourage entrepreneurship among American children.

headline: MF Global and the Risks Looming in the Repo Market
text: MF Global employees are the ones responsible for the risky trades that propelled the company toward its demise. But those crippling bets were only possible because MF Global was able to borrow voraciously in a debt market that also played a big role in the collapses of Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns.

headline: Animated Simulation of Bronx Bus Crash
text: The National Transportation Safety Board released this video along with its findings on the 2011 crash.

headline: Google Issues New Warning for State-Sponsored Attacks
text: Starting Tuesday, look out for an unusual warning atop your Gmail inbox, Google home page or Chrome browser. It will not mince words: “Warning: We believe state-sponsored attackers may be attempting to compromise your account or computer.”

headline: Court Grants Partial Access to Records of Anti-Communist Inquiry
text: A woman who has been seeking historical records about an anti-Communist investigation mounted decades ago by New York City’s Education Department won a small victory on Tuesday from the state’s highest court.

headline: Jack Y. Jaffa
text: Mr. Jaffa, 37, is the president and founder of Jack Jaffa & Associates, a consulting firm based in Brooklyn that specializes in helping clients deal with building violations and tax abatements.

headline: Three Dishes at Neta
text: Neta, which opened this spring in Greenwich Village, is a sushi bar where the sushi itself may not be the main attraction. What makes the restaurant stand out is, above all, the selection of small dishes, both hot and cold. This week before my review was published, I spoke on the phone with Nick Kim, the restaurant’s co-chef along with Jimmy Lau, to learn about three of those dishes.

headline: Myanmar Article Hints at Strains Between Top Figures
text: BANGKOK — A state-run newspaper in Myanmar published an analysis on Tuesday expressing concerns that the “hard-won trust” between President Thein Sein and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel laureate and opposition leader, could “vanish.”

headline: Orlando’s One-Upmanship Continues in Tourism Claims
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may want to put a limit on how many tourists Orlando can claim to be drawing.

headline: The CFDA Awards Morph Into a Comedy Fest
text: IF you look at the annual awards night at the Council of Fashion Designers of America as a stand-up comedy contest, which it generally resembles only in the sense that it seems to demand heckling, then Seth Meyers has nothing on John Waters.

headline: Remembering a Jazzman Who Overcame Heroin and Prison
text: Stark shadows. Empty streets. A lone figure clutching a horn. The conventions for depicting a hard-boiled jazz hero have been firmly established for decades, in fiction and in film. The implicit toll of the music, according to this code — a clutch of obsession, leading to one or another form of ruination — would register as hollow cliché were it not for the exception that proves the rule. Somebody like Frank Morgan.

headline: Photo Replay: June 5
text: A view of the day in sports included the French Open and lead-up to the start of Euro 2012 soccer.

headline: Michael Lewis Gives Some Graduation Advice Worth Remembering
text: A few weeks ago, we listed some of the commencement speakers heard by our staff members at their college graduations. If there was a common thread binding the roster together, it wasn’t tied to the speakers themselves but the forgetfulness of those who listened to them. Many just couldn’t remember much about what was said, just who spoke. (Guilty as charged.)

headline: Fannie Mae Names Its Top Lawyer as Chief
text: Fannie Mae, the government-backed mortgage finance giant, on Tuesday chose Timothy J. Mayopoulos, who was ousted in a shake-up at Bank of America at the height of the financial crisis, to be its next chief executive.

headline: Disney Limits Junk-Food Ads
text: Finally, an entity powerful enough to challenge food manufacturing conglomerates takes affirmative action against advertising food to children that we don’t, as a society, actually want them to eat. The Food and Drug Administration? No, not them. The Federal Communications Commission? Not them, either.

headline: Chamber Players’ Variations in the Key of John Cage
text: Random lines from “The Big Lebowski” kept coming up at the Knights’ performance piece at the Stone on Sunday evening. At one point, reading off a card, one of the players said, in effect, “You guys aren’t privy to all the new stuff,” though the language was definitely coarser.

headline: Kevin Durant’s Defense Is Still on the Rise
text: The summit is in sight for Kevin Durant. After years of sharpening his jaw-dropping offensive game, the N.B.A.’s premier up-and-comer has officially begun his defensive ascent. The distance remaining — and the slope of the climb to two-way dominance — may be daunting yet, but Durant seems capable of finishing what he has begun, and following the path to defensive excellence and basketball completion.

headline: Resort Report | 3.1 Phillip Lim
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
text: Photos from the West Bank, Ukraine, Faroe Islands and Afghanistan.

headline: How to Run a High-Tech High School
text: Apps for taking attendance and scheduling tutoring? That's what goes on at the Academy for Careers in Television and Film in Queens. Columbia journalism students looked at "life in an automated school" and also tracked some students as they participated in an internship program in film and television.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Fairness and Taxes
text: To the Editor:

headline: I.S.S. Sides With Vector in Fight Over Technicolor
text: In the battle to take a big stake in Technicolor, Vector Capital received a prominent supporter in Institutional Shareholder Services.

headline: Darfur War Crimes Prosecutor Urges Tougher Action Against Sudan President
text: The outgoing prosecutor at the International Criminal Court, frustrated over his inability to enforce arrest warrants for the Sudanese president and three others accused of war crimes in the Darfur conflict, recommended to the Security Council on Tuesday that it take more severe action against the defendants, including possibly seizing them inside Sudan for trial in The Hague.

headline: Gay Marriage Inches Towards the Supreme Court
text: For the second week in a row, there is major news on gay rights. Last Thursday, the First Circuit ruled against the Defense of Marriage Act, which prohibits granting federal benefits to same-sex couples. Today, the Ninth Circuit declined to review an earlier decision by a three-judge panel against Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage in California.

headline: Savoring Movers Over the Moves
text: If you are a balletomane, caring more about dancers than choreography, then the casting of John Cranko’s three-act ballet “Onegin” (1965) brings excitements. When I first watched it, in 1978, the Stuttgart Ballet fielded four casts in three days, including two of Cranko’s original cast (Marcia Haydée as Tatiana, Egon Madsen as Lensky); I applauded them all eagerly. In the 1980s, when Natalia Makarova danced Tatiana with the English National Ballet, I thought her more riveting and varied than any previous interpreter. When Lynn Seymour later stepped into the same role, her intensity and naturalism proved yet more astonishing.

headline: Gowns for Belles of the Ball at the Victoria and Albert Museum
text: The Queen’s Diamond Jubilee may be over but the Victoria and  Albert Museum allows visitors to prolong the spirit of celebration and pageantry by focusing on a garment that encapsulates a sense of occasion: the ballgown.

headline: In Nigeria, Stunned Residents Recount Plane Crash
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — A pair of women’s high heels protruding from a charred tan suitcase, a muddied toiletries kit, a change of underwear: rescue workers grimly ferried these possessions of Dana Air Flight 9J 992’s passengers from the airliner’s wreckage here on Tuesday, even as colleagues searched for and found bodies.

headline: Covert Wars, Waged Virally
text: Is the United States at war with Iran? If David Sanger’s account in his new book, “Confront and Conceal,” on President Obama’s foreign policy, is to be believed — and I find it very believable — we certainly are.

headline: In Texas, Romney Raises Money and Attacks Obama
text: FORT WORTH, Tex. — Mitt Romney headed to Texas on Tuesday, making his way across the state for back-to-back days of fund-raisers. But before he started, he laid out his fundamental campaign message to voters at an office systems warehouse here, arguing that the economy had stalled under President Obama, and that Mr. Obama did not deserve credit for any improvements that might occur between now and November.

headline: Live Updates of Wisconsin Recall Election
text: MILWAUKEE — Sixteen months after Wisconsin erupted into one of the fiercest political wars in residents’ memories, voters began streaming into polling places on Tuesday to decide whether to remove Gov. Scott Walker, the Republican whose decision to cut collective bargaining rights for most public workers set off the fight.

headline: Clinton Suggests Extending Tax Cuts Temporarily
text: 9:03 p.m. | Updated  Former President Bill Clinton, voicing a new “antiausterity” line opposed by both parties, suggested Tuesday that all expiring tax cuts be extended temporarily and that short-term budget cutting be put off until the country emerges from what he called a recession.

headline: As Google Bets on Mobile Office, Microsoft Waits
text: If Microsoft couldn’t find compelling enough reasons to release its Office applications for the iPad, Google just gave it one.

headline: Ruling Delayed on Adding Cancer to 9/11 Fund Illnesses
text: An eagerly awaited federal ruling on whether to include cancer among the illnesses that will be treated and result in compensation using money set aside by Congress for victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center has been delayed by several days, federal officials said Tuesday.

headline: Live Streaming Video of Venus Transit
text: Starting at 6:03 p.m. Eastern, weather permitting, skywatchers around the world can begin looking for Venus to start crossing the face of the sun, a rare event that won’t come around again for 105 years.

headline: Sweden 1912: Way Before Stubhub
text: One hundred years ago the Summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Jail on Yelp and Google Cars
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. See more here.

headline: Lukas Receives Stitches After Being Struck by Horse
text: The Hall of Fame trainer D. Wayne Lukas, who will saddle Optimizer in Saturday’s Belmont Stakes, was taken to Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, N.Y., on Tuesday afternoon after one of his horses reared up and struck him in his head.

headline: Symbolism and Struggle in a Contest of Dreams
text: SAN DIEGO — In the new musical “Hands on a Hardbody,” dreams die a sudden death, with the buckling of knees, a hand gone numb or a descent into hallucination. This Broadway-bound show, making its premiere at the La Jolla Playhouse here, sings sincerely and with a rough-edged humor of the dusty margins of American life, where people live paycheck to paycheck if they are lucky enough to have a job, and chase a chancy illusion of sudden salvation if they are not.

headline: Your Tech Questions Answered, Part 5
text: In this batch, I answer questions about turning an old PC into a server of sorts; getting an HD signal through an antenna; contract-free mobile Wi-Fi; a remote control for cord-cutters; and connecting an iPhone to a projector. You can also read my answers to the first, second, third and fourth batch of questions.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: College Board Cancels Summer SAT for Select Students, Calling It ‘Inappropriate’
text: The College Board has canceled plans to offer the SAT exam to gifted students enrolled in a $4,500 summer program, a spokeswoman announced on Tuesday.

headline: Anchors Get Giddy Around The Crown
text: God save us from the queen.

headline: CPR by Disco
text: The American Heart Association kicked off a new CPR campaign in New York City, teaching a chest compression-only method to the beat of the Bee Gees’ ”Staying Alive.”

headline: An Idolatrous Echo Across Networks
text: The setup: Four celebrities sit on revolving chairs in front of a live studio audience and listen to blind auditions. If they like what they hear, they swivel around to take a look.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Herring Check In

headline: Samsung Backs Open Source, Joining Linux Foundation
text: Samsung on Tuesday said it was becoming a platinum member of the Linux Foundation, giving $500,000 to the nonprofit in support of the Linux system and the open-source projects related to it. The membership status gives Samsung a seat on the foundation’s board, allowing it to have more of a say in how Linux is developed.

headline: A New Wedding App for the Modern Bride
text: Gone are the days of sending multiple e-mails to your bridal party, calling family members with updates on wedding events, or sending mass texts to guests with directions to venues. Appy Couple, a new wedding app, can replace the traditional wedding planning methods, like building your own Web site, with an app for the tech-savvy, fast-moving and multitasking bride. You can stay in touch with your guests and organize events from your iPhones, iPads and Androids.

headline: New Ad Attacks Obama on Federal Debt
text: Crossroads GPS, a conservative advocacy group founded by Karl Rove and other top Republicans, released a new advertisement on Tuesday that hammers President Obama’s handling of the budget and the national debt. The advertisement is the third piece of a $25 million campaign that is running in 10 swing states. Crossroads said it is putting $7 million into the commercial, which uses a ticking clock to drive home the point that the country is piling on more debt every second.

headline: A Lifesaving Lesson With a ’70s Bee Gees Beat
text: It might have been some strange daytime disco event or it might have been a red-carpet movie premiere. It was hard to tell on Tuesday afternoon in Bryant Park.

headline: Barbara Walters Apologizes for Helping Aide to Assad of Syria
text: In the months after her exclusive interview last year with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, Barbara Walters tried to intercede to get a television position for a former aide of his, who Ms. Walters acknowledged helped arrange the interview.

headline: Boehner Aides in Talks With Justice Dept. on Gun-Running Inquiry
text: 11:39 p.m. | Updated As Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. prepares to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday, Justice Department officials praised the House Republican leadership – including Speaker John Boehner – for opening negotiations with the Justice Department about resolving a dispute over subpoenaed information related to the botched gun-trafficking investigation dubbed Operation Fast and Furious.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Antigay-Shirt Ban Illegal, Group Says
text: HARTFORD (AP) — The American Civil Liberties Union of Connecticut claimed on Tuesday that a high school violated a student’s rights to free expression by asking him to remove a T-shirt with an antigay message.

headline: College Student Debt
text: To the Editor:

headline: Luxury in a Tomb-Size Hotel Room
text: For many years the standard complaint about hotel rooms in New York was, “They’re expensive but they’re small,” often uttered with a “What are you going to do about it?” shrug.

headline: Emergency Law Broadens Canada’s Sympathy for Quebec Protests
text: MONTREAL — Until recently, the daily student protests that have clogged the streets of Montreal since late February did little to win public support for their cause.

headline: Ada María Isasi-Díaz, Dissident Catholic Theologian, Dies at 69
text: Ada María Isasi-Díaz would have become a Roman Catholic priest, she told friends, if not for the church’s ban on ordaining women. Instead, she became a dissident theologian who spoke for those she considered the neglected spiritual core of the church’s membership: Hispanic women like herself.

headline: School Health Centers
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Ohio River City Comes Back to Its Shoreline
text: CINCINNATI — The shoreline of this Ohio River city, which in the 19th century hummed with 30 steamboat visits a day but faded in the 20th as pollution and industrial disinvestment pushed people and businesses inland, is emerging again as a hub of civic and economic vitality.

headline: The D.S.M. Gets Addiction Right
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Unit to Halt Urinary Implants
text: Johnson & Johnson’s Ethicon division will stop selling four types of mesh implants used to treat urinary incontinence, the company announced in a letter to judges overseeing two large groups of lawsuits filed by women who claim the devices caused serious injury.

headline: Judge Says He Was Struck by a Police Officer in Queens
text: Thomas D. Raffaele, a 69-year-old justice of the New York State Supreme Court, encountered a chaotic scene while walking down a Queens street with a friend: Two uniformed police officers stood over a shirtless man lying facedown on the pavement. The man’s hands were cuffed behind his back and he was screaming. A crowd jeered at the officers.

headline: LinkedIn’s Leaky Mobile App Has Access to Your Meeting Notes
text: LinkedIn mobile app subscribers may be surprised to learn that the calendar entries on their iPhones or iPads— which may include details about meeting locations, participants, dial-in information, passwords and sensitive meeting notes — are transmitted back to LinkedIn’s servers without their knowledge.

headline: Wisconsin Exit Poll Highlights
text: 10:03 p.m. | Updated The Times’s polling unit is parsing the exit polls in Wisconsin, looking for clues about the electorate and suggestions of what the recall results might portend for November. This post will be updated as we crunch more numbers.

headline: Woods Set for Major. Just Not That Woods. Or That Major.
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — When the name Woods moves up leader boards, rapt attention always follows. This week, a Woods most golf fans don’t know — Cheyenne — hopes to make her presence felt after accepting a sponsor’s exemption into the Wegmans L.P.G.A. Championship.

headline: Governors’ Races Can Be a Contrary Indicator for Presidential Elections
text: The results of the recall election in Wisconsin on Tuesday night may tell us something about the future of the labor movement and the salience of collective bargaining rights as an issue to swing voters. A win by Gov. Scott Walker, who is ahead in the polls, might make other Republican governors who have sought to pare collective bargaining, like John Kasich of Ohio, breathe a little easier when they come up for election again.

headline: Senate Will Investigate National Security Leaks About Terrorism ‘Kill List’
text: The Senate will investigate recent national security leaks to the news media in the wake of articles in The New York Times about a “kill list” for terrorists and the use of cyberweapons against Iran, a Senate official said on Tuesday.

headline: Evolution’s Sweet Tooth
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: After Loss, JPMorgan Regulators in Spotlight
text: WASHINGTON — JPMorgan Chase’s regulators will be in the spotlight here on Wednesday, when they testify before Congress on the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading blunder and its implications for the future of Wall Street regulation.

headline: Matsui Back at Yankee Stadium, This Time as a Ray
text: Hideki Matsui was unemployed on opening day and seemingly undesired throughout baseball, but on Tuesday the former Yankees stalwart started in right field and batted in the cleanup spot when the Tampa Bay Rays opened a three-game series against the Yankees in the Bronx.

headline: Mets’ Relief Corps Is Short-Handed
text: WASHINGTON — There was some shuffling amid the Mets pitching ranks on Tuesday, including one development that will leave the team shorthanded for its three-game series here this week.

headline: Iran and Azerbaijan, Already Wary Neighbors, Find Even Less to Agree On
text: BILASUVAR, Azerbaijan — The perennially tense relationship between Azerbaijan and Iran, wary neighbors on the Caspian Sea, has deteriorated in recent weeks amid deep unease in Tehran over expanding military cooperation between Azerbaijan and Israel.

headline: Nepal, on the Brink of Collapse
text: Katmandu, Nepal

headline: What the Locusts Ate
text: One of the most troubling features of today’s global economic crisis is the lack of political leadership anywhere. No one has the courage to tell their people the truth. And the truth, alas, is that four of the pillars of today’s global economy — Europe, America, China and the Arab world — have, each in their own way, squandered huge dividends they enjoyed in recent decades, and now they have to dig out of their respective holes with fewer resources, less time and, almost certainly, more pain. There is no easy way out. But, as confronting these hard truths becomes unavoidable, I think we’re likely to see some wild, angry and destabilizing politics that could make the economic recovery even more difficult. Deep holes and weak leaders are a bad combination.

headline: Altering a Law the Police Use Prolifically
text: On Tuesday afternoon, a 51-year-old black man was led into Manhattan Criminal Court to be arraigned on a charge that he broke a law that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has enforced with more vigor than any other: the possession of less than an ounce of pot.

headline: Voters Cast Ballots in Historic Recall Election
text: Wisconsin residents streamed into polling places on Tuesday to decide whether to remove Gov. Scott Walker, the Republican whose decision to cut collective bargaining rights for most public workers set off a fierce political fight.

headline: Cost of Prekindergarten Special Education Is Soaring
text: New York City is paying private contractors more than $1 billion this year to operate a little-known special education program for 3- and 4-year-olds, nearly double the amount it paid six years ago.

headline: A Concert Mogul Is Betting on Electronic Dance Music
text: The man who corporatized the concert industry is back, and he wants to dance.

headline: Disney Takes On Obesity
text: The Walt Disney Company deserves applause for its plan to impose strict standards on food advertising aimed at young children on Disney-owned television channels, radio stations and Web sites. The standards, based on federal guidelines, should eliminate junk-food ads on children’s programs and could set an example for other companies and advertisers to follow.

headline: Office Cleaner’s Killer Gets 25 Years to Life
text: A judge on Tuesday sentenced a man to 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a woman who was bound, gagged and stuffed into the air duct of the Lower Manhattan building where she cleaned offices.

headline: North Carolina, Meet Citizens United
text: The North Carolina Judicial Coalition is a new tax-exempt organization, known as a super PAC, supported by wealthy conservative Republicans who are determined to make this year’s race for a seat on the North Carolina Supreme Court ideological and expensive.

headline: Up Off Mat, Celtics Going for Knockout Against Heat
text: MIAMI — If this is indeed its last stand, if the Boston Celtics’ proud core of seasoned stars is heading inevitably toward a sorrowful farewell, those players will not part ways without one more rich playoff memory and perhaps, as surprising as it would seem, one more run at a title.

headline: What Is Food?
text: If you believe government has no role in helping people — including encouraging us to act in our own best interests by doing things like not smoking, wearing seat belts and getting exercise — you’re probably no fan of New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg. The mayor, who has already banned smoking in bars and transfats from restaurant food,  has created more bike lanes in his administration than all other administrations combined and forced the posting of calorie counts in fast food restaurants, added to his sins by proposing to ban the sale of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) over one pint (16 ounces) in a variety of venues.

headline: Airtime Adds to a Growing Choice of Video Chat Services
text: When Americans first started exploring the online world en masse in the early 1990s, many of them headed for AOL’s chat rooms to connect with other curious strangers.

headline: Veterans Pension Program Is Being Abused, Report Says
text: A yearlong investigation into a federal pension program for low-income veterans has concluded that weak oversight and unclear rules have made the system ripe for abuse, including by financial planners and lawyers who help well-off retirees qualify for benefits by transferring or hiding assets.

headline: Group Forms to Urge Strict Oversight of Wall Street
text: Efforts to increase and improve regulation of Wall Street have bogged down, according to Sheila C. Bair, the former chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. On Wednesday, she will announce a new group, the Systemic Risk Council, that will monitor and encourage regulatory reform.

text: FRAGRANCE counters could soon be catching another case of Bieber Fever as they begin selling a second celebrity scent from the young singer Justin Bieber.

text: When Andrew Cuomo was running for governor of New York in 2010, he printed eight books describing his priorities. Many were excellent ideas, including campaign finance reform, ethics reform, balancing the budget, ending pay-to-play, getting government to work. Nowhere in those books was there a word about casinos.

text: Under pressure from regulators last summer to increase its capital cushion, MF Global moved some of its risky European debt holdings to an unregulated entity in an effort to avoid having to raise extra money, according to a new report.

headline: What Makes Shrek Shriek
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — At the time of this writing, I have come down with a flu that, if it had a name, would probably be along the lines of “Cyborg Death Flu.” I will spare you the details, but I’m just letting you know that this one will be short so I can crawl back to bed and whimper for my Mommy. Please feel free to discuss the puzzle amongst yourselves; I will just ask you all to please keep it clean and civil while I am recuperating.

headline: Complaints Flying Before Councilman’s Retrial

text: By the time Wendell B. Walters, a former top official at a New York City agency that builds affordable housing, pleaded guilty to accepting bribes in March, he was known to be cooperating with the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors.

headline: Red Knots in Danger
text: The East Coast red knot population has plummeted, and wildlife biologists in New Jersey worry that without stronger protections, they could vanish altogether. But that depends on the crabs.

headline: A Bird, a Crab and a Shared Fight to Survive
text: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J. — Like clockwork, the red knots arrive every spring, descending on the beaches of Delaware Bay to feast for a few weeks on horseshoe crab eggs and, in the process, double their body weight. The knots are delicate, robin-size shorebirds named for their salmon coloration and renowned for their marathon migration — more than 9,000 miles each way, from the southern tip of South America to the Canadian Arctic.

headline: William Lee Miller, Scholar on Abraham Lincoln, Is Dead at 86
text: William Lee Miller, a historian and ethicist whose work examined the rocky landscape where religion, morality and American political leadership meet, died on May 27 in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: A Glimmer?
text: There is a plenty of blame to be shared for why peace talks between the Israelis and Palestinians are going nowhere. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s insistence on expanding Israeli settlements in the West Bank and Jerusalem are a big part of the problem. There may be some glimmer of hope in Mr. Netanyahu’s decision to support an Israeli Supreme Court order to close an illegal neighborhood, known as Ulpana, in the West Bank settlement of Beit El.

headline: When to Punish, and When to Rehabilitate
text: When minors commit violent crimes, should they be treated differently from adults? Is prison effective as a punishment or a deterrent for juveniles?

text: MOSCOW — Russia’s lower and upper houses of Parliament approved a draft law on Wednesday imposing steep fines on people who organize or take part in unsanctioned meetings, apparently in an attempt to bring down the curtain on the large antigovernment street protests that began six months ago.

headline: Herb Reed, an Original Platter, Dies at 83
text: Herb Reed, an original member of the Platters, one of the first pop groups to break the color barrier in the 1950s, and the last surviving member who sang on the group’s  crossover hits like “Only You,” “The Great Pretender” and a soaring street-corner version of “Smoke Gets in Your Eyes,” died on Monday in Boston. He was 83.

headline: Barbara Walters Admits She Aided Assad’s Press Adviser
text: Last Updated | Monday | June 11, 9:53 a.m. As my colleague Bill Carter reports, Barbara Walters said on Tuesday that she tried to help one of President Bashar al-Assad’s press advisers get an internship at CNN and a place at Columbia University after the young woman facilitated Ms. Walters’s interview with Mr. Assad in December.

headline: Is Pleasure a Sin?

headline: Egypt’s Military Council Sets Deadline for Charter
text: CAIRO — Ten days before the runoff to decide Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, the country’s ruling military council gave political party leaders 48 hours to agree on a 100-member assembly to write a new, permanent constitution, state news media reported. If they fail to comply, the reports said, the generals will issue their own new interim charter setting ground rules for the assembly.

headline: Pettitte Showing No Signs of Fatigue or Age
text: It is not that Yankees Manager Joe Girardi defies conservatism when determining how long he uses 39-year-old Andy Pettitte, and Girardi’s preference is actually preservation. But Girardi’s willingness to stretch Pettitte deep into games during Pettitte’s return to the Yankees after a 19-month hiatus is the byproduct of the veteran’s prowess, the injuries to the Yankees’ bullpen and the amount of rest that Pettitte accrues between starts.

headline: Canada: More Body Parts Turn Up
text: Police officers in Vancouver, British Columbia, said two parcels, one apparently containing a human hand and the other a human foot, arrived at two schools in the city on Tuesday. They said they had contacted the Montreal police to see if the packages were related to the killing of Jun Lin, a Chinese student. On Monday, the police in Berlin arrested a suspect in the killing, Luka Rocco Magnotta, who left Montreal for Europe over a week ago. Mr. Magnotta has agreed not to contest his extradition to Canada. Parcels containing another hand and foot were sent to the offices of two Canadian political parties last week. Montreal police said earlier on Tuesday that the victim’s head as well as a foot and a hand were still missing.

headline: Eduard Khil, Unlikely YouTube Sensation, Dies at 77
text: MOSCOW — Eduard Khil, a Brezhnev-era balladeer who experienced an improbable and unwitting YouTube comeback as “Mr. Trololo,” tra-la-lah-ing his way through a song whose lyrics about the American prairie were eliminated because of fears of Soviet censorship, died on Monday in St. Petersburg, Russia. He was 77.

headline: Audits for 3 Georgia Schools Tied to Turkish Movement
text: A group of three publicly financed charter schools in Georgia run by followers of Fethullah Gulen, a prominent Turkish imam, have come under scrutiny after they defaulted on bonds and an audit found that the schools improperly granted hundreds of thousands of dollars in contracts to businesses and groups, many of them with ties to the Gulen movement.

headline: Mysterious Buddhist Retreat in the Desert Ends in a Grisly Death
text: BOWIE, Ariz. — The rescuers had rappelled from a helicopter, swaying in the brisk April winds as they bore down on a cave 7,000 feet up in a rugged desert mountain on the edge of this rural hamlet. There had been a call for help. Inside, they found a jug with about an inch of water, browned by floating leaves and twigs. They found a woman, Christie McNally, thirsty and delirious. And they found her husband, Ian Thorson, dead.

headline: Since a Hard Slide, a Sharp Rise for the Rays
text: The Tampa Bay Rays announced themselves, violently and with purpose, in the ninth inning of an exhibition game against the Yankees in March 2008. The franchise was still an annual loser when Tampa Bay’s Elliot Johnson barreled into catcher Francisco Cervelli at spring training. In so doing, he broke Cervelli’s wrist and broke down the doors of the American League East.

headline: House Bill Takes a Scythe to Spending
text: WASHINGTON — Financial regulators would lose hundreds of millions of dollars needed to implement the new Wall Street regulatory law. The Internal Revenue Service’s budget would not be increased, with a prohibition on cash transfers to implement the health care law. President Obama’s energy-efficiency and renewable energy efforts would be gutted, along with international climate change programs. And regulations to force new efficiency standards in federal buildings would be blocked.

headline: Nuns, Rebuked by Rome, Plan Road Trip to Spotlight Social Issues

headline: For Mosquitoes, Rain Isn’t a Flight Hazard
text: A single raindrop can weigh 50 times as much as a mosquito. So how can the insects fly through a downpour and come out alive?

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. grew up, in Sweet Auburn,  Atlanta, are among the 11 important sites at risk of damage or destruction cited by the National Trust for Historic Preservation in its annual list, to be unveiled on Wednesday.

headline: Moderation as the Sweet Spot for Exercise
text: For people who exercise but fret that they really should be working out more, new studies may be soothing. The amount of exercise needed to improve health and longevity, this new science shows, is modest, and more is not necessarily better.

headline: More Young Americans Out of High School Are Also Out of Work
text: For this generation of young people, the future looks bleak. Only one in six is working full time. Three out of five live with their parents or other relatives. A large majority — 73 percent — think they need more education to find a successful career, but only half of those say they will definitely enroll in the next few years.

headline: Average Prison Stay Grew 36 Percent in Two Decades
text: For petty offenders and violent criminals alike, the length of a prison stay increased by more than a third over the past two decades, a period of time in which the prison population doubled, according to a report by the Pew Center on the States. Inmates released from prison in 2009 spent an average of 2.9 years — or 36 percent — longer behind bars than offenders released in 1990, the report found. The additional time cost taxpayers more than $10 billion. In Florida, the average time served rose by 166 percent; in New York, 2 percent. Eight states showed decreases in the length of prison terms, according to the report, which analyzed data from the federal government’s National Corrections Reporting Program. Adam Gelb, director of the center’s Public Safety Performance Project, noted that the variation among states followed no evident regional pattern, reinforcing the idea that “state policy choices, often driven by particular crimes or circumstances in that state, drive the size and cost of the prison population, rather than data and research about what’s most effective in reducing crime.”

headline: Louisiana: Two Scientists Surrender E-Mail to BP
text: Two prominent scientists involved in estimating the flow rate from a ruptured oil well during BP’s 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have surrendered more than 3,000 of their private e-mails to the company in response to a subpoena by the United States District Court in New Orleans. BP sought the e-mails from the scientists, Chris Reddy and Richard Camilli of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, to help prepare its defense in a lawsuit brought by the federal government. In an op-ed article in The Boston Globe, the scientists said they had given the company more than 50,000 pages of documents and data before the company also demanded the e-mails. They said they worried that BP would use the e-mails to falsely cast doubt on their conclusions. “Our concern is not simply invasion of privacy, but the erosion of the scientific deliberative process,” the scientists wrote. BP said the subpoena was “in no way an attack on science.”

headline: College Board Drops Plans for Summer SAT
text: Just days after word that the College Board would offer an unusual summertime SAT to students enrolled in a preparatory course conducted by the National Society for the Gifted & Talented, the plan has been dropped. Critics complained that the Aug. 3 test was unfair, because only students enrolled in the $4,500 course, held on the Amherst College campus, could take it. The next general SAT test date is in October. The College Board initially said the August test was a pilot for summer testing. But on Tuesday, it said that because the SAT was “created to democratize access to education,” any summer pilot would have to be “better aligned with our mission.”

headline: For Sutter, Call Out of Blue Put Him Behind Bench
text: LOS ANGELES — While Devils Coach Peter DeBoer answered questions about how he could fix his team, Kings Coach Darryl Sutter recalled the day in December when General Manager Dean Lombardi called to tell him he was hiring him to take over the club.

headline: Mets Fritter Away Game and Chance to Be in First

headline: Finding a Way to Score Is Still Elusive for the Devils

headline: Union Talks Are Continuing as Belmont Stakes Nears

headline: Saavn, Online Jukebox of Indian Music, Attracts Millions
text: Pandora and Spotify are hugely popular online services that stream music from around the world for free, but for Indian songs, the biggest jukebox is at Saavn (South Asian Audio Visual Network), which hit 10 million users this month.

headline: No Recall
text: For disappointed Democrats, seduced by early exit polls into a vain hope that the union-busting Wisconsin governor Scott Walker might actually be recalled from office late last night, the good news is that some of their pre-election spin still holds up. Yesterday’s recall vote is not necessarily a bellwether for the general election, not necessarily a sign that Mitt Romney can win a slew of purple states, not necessarily proof that the country is ready to throw in with Walker’s fellow Wisconsinite Paul Ryan on issues of spending and taxation.

headline: News Quiz | June 6, 2012

headline: Meet Aparna, Mumbai’s Teenage Sex Educator

headline: Red Bulls Knocked Out of U.S. Open Cup

headline: Evangelist for Al Qaeda Said to Be Killed
text: HONG KONG — In the world of violent global jihad, Abu Yahya al-Libi was an evangelist, a philosopher and a social media rock star. He was even being mentioned as a likely candidate to take over as the head of Al Qaeda.

headline: Nepal, on the Brink of Collapse
text: For more than two decades, Nepal, a resource-rich, impoverished country wedged between China and India, has teetered between paralysis and upheaval Seyom Brown and Vanda Felbab-Brown write in The New York Times. The latest crisis brought on by the dissolution of the legislature after it missed the fourth deadline to write a constitution for the democratic republic, “risks turning it into a failed state,” they write.

headline: Afghanistan Faces Deadliest Day for Civilians This Year in Multiple Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Violence took the lives of at least two dozen Afghan civilians and possibly many more on Wednesday, making it the deadliest day for Afghan civilians so far this year. The day included a complex suicide attack in Kandahar City and a NATO airstrike that Afghan officials and residents said had killed women and children in eastern Afghanistan.

headline: A Historic Photo Archive Re-emerges at the New York Public Library
text: Roy Stryker, founder of the Farm Security Administration’s photography project, was determined to compile a visual encyclopedia of the United States in the 1930s and ’40s and preserve it for future generations.

headline: What Is Your Opinion About the Morning-After Pill?
text: Scientific evidence shows that morning-after pills delay ovulation but do not prevent fertilized eggs from implanting in the womb, contrary to statements on their packaging. Anti-abortion groups point to the statements as evidence that the pills terminate a fertilized egg, which they consider a person. What are your thoughts on the morning-after pill, and, perhaps, abortion in general? Does this recent evidence affect your opinion, and if so, how?

headline: Amid Reports of New Massacre, Nations Press Syria
text: Syrian opposition activists reported a mass killing of villagers by pro-government militiamen and security forces on Wednesday — if verified, the fourth massacre in less than two weeks — threatening to inject a new surge of angry momentum into the growing international effort to isolate President Bashar al-Assad and remove him from power.

headline: FR-S: The Selling of a Different Sort of Scion
text: On Monday, Toyota announced that its Scion subsidiary had begun sales of the 2013 FR-S sports car. The 2,800-pound rear-drive coupe, with its 200-horsepower two-liter boxer four-cylinder engine and exhaustively refined chassis, represents a departure for a brand known primarily for odd-box machines aimed at young buyers lured to dealerships by no-haggle pricing and a hefty dose of lifestyle marketing.

headline: Obama Heads West for Dollars and Thanks From Gay Supporters

headline: Prep-School Predators
text: From the elevated platform of the No. 1 train’s last stop at 242nd Street, you can just about see the lush 18-acre campus of the Horace Mann School. The walk from the station is short, but it traverses worlds. Leaving the cluttered din of Broadway, you enter the leafy splendor of Fieldston, an enclave of mansions and flowering trees that feels more like a wealthy Westchester suburb than the Bronx. Head up the steep hill, turn left, then walk a bit farther, past the headmaster’s house. From the stone wall that runs along Tibbett Avenue, you can see practically the whole school: Pforzheimer Hall, Mullady Hall, the auditorium, the gymnasium and, right in the center, the manicured green expanse of the baseball field, home of the Lions, pride of the school.

headline: The Microinsurance Revolution
text: Six years ago David Patient felt his immune system slipping. He had been H.I.V.-positive for a long time, but now he made two decisions: He started on antiretroviral medicines to protect himself, and he began trying to buy life insurance to provide for his partner.

headline: Whitman’s Simple Vision: Hewlett-Packard Has Work to Do
text: LAS VEGAS — Meg Whitman has a clear vision of Hewlett-Packard making radically new consumer products. She sees it selling cloud computing technologies that she hopes will attract fast-growing start-ups to the venerable brand. She wants to transform its printing and services businesses. Much of the promise is on show at a big show for corporate clients in Las Vegas this week.
