headline: Mubarak May Be Returned to Hospital as Health Slips
text: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak’s health has deteriorated so sharply since he was first taken to prison five days ago that the authorities are close to a decision to return him to a hospital outside the penal system, security officials and the state news agency said on Wednesday.

headline: Wednesday Reading: The Quest for a  Frugal Scandinavian Summer
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: Whither Hewlett-Packard
text: Meg Whitman, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has spent much of this week trying to persuade customers as well as employees that she can straighten out the company and make it grow again. Quentin Hardy of The New York Times interviewed her Tuesday to learn what she is thinking.

headline: Live Blogging the French Open
text: After the chaos of simultaneous five-set comebacks Tuesday at the French Open, the remaining four quarterfinals from the bottom halves of the singles draws have a lot to measure up to Wednesday.

headline: Boardwalk Surprises
text: Dear Diary: I often walk on the Long Beach boardwalk. This week two odd things occurred.

headline: Wisconsin Democrats Claim Victory in State Senate
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — After being soundly defeated in their fight to recall Gov. Scott Walker from office, Democrats in Wisconsin on Wednesday were claiming a smaller victory — control, at least for now, of the State Senate.

headline: Spending for a Special Education Program Is Investigated
text: The city is paying contractors more than $1 billion this year for a special education that serves 25,000 3- and 4-year-olds  with physical, learning, developmental and other disabilities, nearly double the amount it paid six years ago. Audits into some of the contractors by the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, have already led to a felony guilty plea by one Brooklyn contractor, and officials said more arrests were expected.

headline: Back to You: Aaron Sorkin Returns to Television With ‘The Newsroom’
text: LOS ANGELES — A new one comes every few years, like a presidential election or the Olympic Games: an Aaron Sorkin television series set in a high-pressure work environment. “The Newsroom,” which will have its HBO debut on June 24, is the latest show from Mr. Sorkin, the Academy and Emmy Award-winning screenwriter, and his first in nearly six years. It chronicles the behind-the-scenes drama (and comedy) at a fictional cable-news program, hosted by an anchor (played by Jeff Daniels) who has recently returned from a very public “mad as hell” moment of unraveling.

headline: Students and Others Rally Before Discipline Code Hearing
text: The city is considering changes to the student discipline code to reduce students to suspensions. But at a demonstration, others said the changes did not go far enough.

headline: Wisconsin
text: The best lack all conviction, while the worst are filled with a passionate intensity. Obviously I’m not happy with the result; not just out of political sympathies, but because all the recent political trends have been rewarding the side that caused the very crisis from which it is now benefiting, not to mention politicians who have been wrong about everything since the crisis hit.

headline: Today’s India Recalls the Reign of Victoria
text: “As Britain celebrates six decades of Elizabeth II as monarch, it is the reign of another queen that contemporary India resembles,” Manu Joseph writes in The International Herald Tribune.

headline: Social Secretaries Dish on White House Dinners and More
text: Six current and former members of one of the world’s most secretive sororities — the office of the White House social secretary — regaled an audience in Washington on Tuesday night with stories about President Obama, Queen Elizabeth II and White House guests who pilfer golden eagle place card holders from state dinners.

headline: Doing Their Best to Destroy Europe
text: Martin Wolf is shrill (and rightly so):

headline: Think of the Children
text: Every time I hear some smug pundit or politician saying that we can’t spend to create jobs because that would be laying too much of a burden on our children, I get angry — because of reports like this:

headline: Stocks Jump After Central Bank Officials’ Remarks
text: Stocks surged on Wednesday as remarks from a Federal Reserve official stirred stimulus hopes and after stocks in Europe rose when the European Central Bank kept the door open to making a future cut to its benchmark interest rate.

headline: Corning Museum to Get New Wing
text: The Corning Museum of Glass in upstate New York will create a new north wing with a design by the architect firm Thomas Phifer and Partners that was unveiled on Wednesday. The 100,000-square-foot expansion includes new galleries for the museum’s contemporary glass collection and a large space for glassblowing demonstrations and glass design sessions.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Warren Buffett Likes Newspapers, and Barbara Walters Apologizes
text: Taylor Swift and her record label may be reversing decades of music economics with a new deal struck with Clear Channel, the nation’s largest radio operator, writes Ben Sisario. The deal would give the label and performer royalties for traditional radio play — something the music business has long fought for and never received. In return, the label agreed to accept a cut for online radio play (which does award royalties to performers and labels), giving Clear Channel at least some measure of predictability in online payments. Online play is a tiny part of Clear Channel’s business but the company saw an opportunity to preemptively control costs.

headline: Ristretto | I Know What You Did Last Summer
text: It’s iced coffee season, which in New York means hitting the cold brew.

headline: Tip of the Week: Translations on the Go
text: If you want to brush up your language skills for a European vacation or just take the slower pace of summer to learn something, the free Google Translate mobile app can be a useful tutor. The app, recently updated to match the Ice Cream Sandwich edition of the Android operating system, translates phrases spoken aloud in 17 languages and can translate typed text between 64 languages.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Observer: Why are moms, even after pregnancy, denied the pleasures of a good stiff drink? — Patrick Farrell

headline: Assessing a Case Against MF Global Executives
text: Much as the mythical Icarus plunged to his death after he flew too close to the sun, the trustee’s report on the demise of MF Global shows how the firm pushed the permissible uses of customer money to the edge until the firm collapsed. The question is whether prosecutors can build a criminal case or whether management stayed close enough to the line to avoid being charged.

headline: On Our Radar: Actors Spar Over Oil Spill Venture
text: Lawyers for the actors Kevin Costner and Stephen Baldwin face off in court over Mr. Baldwin’s assertion that Mr. Costner cheated him out of his share of a multimillion-dollar deal to sell oil cleanup devices to BP in 2010. [Reuters]

headline: Because of Katie, Children With Severe Disabilities Can Live at Home
text: Katie Beckett died last month at age 34. Most Americans don’t know who she is. But as a parent of a child with disabilities, her name is as familiar as my own child’s. Because of the legislation that bears her name, hundreds of thousands of children, including my own, are able to be at home with their families instead of being institutionalized.

headline: Mosquitoes and Raindrops
text: High-speed videography is used to show how mosquitoes are able to fly in the rain.

headline: AppSmart Extra: Someone to Watch Over Me
text: In a recent column, I reviewed apps that help parents keep track of their children — younger children in particular.

headline: Battered Man Group Shares Get a Boost
text: Shares of the Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund company, surged in London trading on Wednesday after Citigroup analysts recommended the stock.

headline: The Last Leg of a Space Shuttle’s Journey to Manhattan
text: Updated, 4:05 p.m. | First, the space shuttle Enterprise came by air. Then, on Wednesday, it arrived again — this time by sea.

headline: Ray Bradbury, Who Brought Mars to Earth With a Lyrical Mastery, Dies at 91
text: Ray Bradbury, a master of science fiction whose imaginative and lyrical evocations of the future reflected both the optimism and the anxieties of his own postwar America, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Two HTC One Phones, Both Pleasing
text: HTC seems to have taken a page out of the Samsung playbook, with the release of its One Series phones: the One S and the One V.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: June 7
text: For father’s day, ties updated for hip dads, from Park & Bond; new dresses, in time for summer; and Pendleton prints on beach towels.

headline: Early Theater of Shakespeare Is Unearthed in London
text: The tomb of William Shakespeare in Stratford-on-Avon may warn the inquisitive (and the morbid) not “to digg the dust encloased heare,” but archaeologists who delved into the dirt in London have found what they say is a momentous site from that playwright’s career: the theater where Shakespeare plays, including “Romeo and Juliet” and possibly “Henry V,” were originally performed.

headline: Chairman Mao, in Their Own Hand
text: BEIJING — The past few days have brought some encouragement for observers of grassroots political mobilization in China. As June 4, the 23rd anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident rolled around, the sheer variety of words and phrases that online censors have had to block is a heartening indicator of how hard Chinese netizens are pushing for political justice. (The microblogging platform Weibo even removed the candle icon, a common expression of mourning, from its selection of emoticons.)

headline: Poland’s Diverse Euro 2012 Team Endures Criticism, Aims High
text: “My heart is Polish too,” said Damien Perquis, in French. “Sure, I don’t speak, but I’m a Polish guy too.”

headline: Money Tips for Globe-Trotters
text: CREDIT cards and A.T.M.’s may have eased the challenge of spending and exchanging money on a trip abroad, but that doesn’t mean we don’t occasionally find ourselves in a foreign country, fuming in front of machines that have just rejected our plastic cards. Fortunately, American banks have recently begun issuing credit cards that are more widely accepted around the world. Here are some tips on managing your cards and cash based on my recent trip to Japan and Hong Kong.

headline: Is Sunscreen Flammable?
text: News that a Massachusetts man suffered severe burns while using a backyard grill — just after applying sunscreen spray — has raised new fears about sunscreen products. But dermatologists and burn experts called it a freak occurrence caused not by the sunscreen itself, but by the fact that the man was using an aerosol spray near an open flame.

headline: The World Out There
text: Some of us are more susceptible than others, but it’s not uncommon for picture book illustrations to give almost anyone — grown-ups even more perhaps than children — the goose bumps. And no one’s better at eliciting them than Raúl Colón (“Good-Bye, Havana! Hola, New York!,” “Angela and the Baby Jesus”). In “Don’t Forget, God Bless Our Troops,” his haunting image of a faded soldier standing outside an autumn window, as imagined by the daughter who awaits him at home, is nearly soaked in melancholy. “Daddy’s not here,” she thinks, “as she watches a red leaf drift past the window and out of sight.”

headline: Business Day Live | June 6, 2012
text: How video chat could transform social media. | What happens if Greece runs out of money. | For American youth, bleak job prospects.

headline: British Mining Firm Sues Indonesia for Asset Seizure
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When David F. Quinlivan visits Indonesia, he carries stacks of documents and a well-worn map of a mining concession in East Kalimantan province marked with a dizzying array of timelines and arrows. They are his weapons in a two-year battle with Indonesia’s judicial system.

headline: Summers’s Comment Adds to Confusion Over Extending Tax Cuts
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: Comparing Colleges by What New Graduates Are Doing
text: Every year, many colleges survey their imminent or new graduates about their plans for work or graduate school, and their starting salaries.

headline: Estonian Rhapsody
text: Since Estonia has suddenly become the poster child for austerity defenders — they’re on the euro and they’re booming! — I thought it might be useful to have a picture of what we’re talking about. Here’s real GDP, from Eurostat:

headline: Do the Heat Have Heart?
text: Such is the state of the LeBron James-fixated N.B.A. that now everything — in the Eastern Conference at least — appears to revolve around the axis of the Miami Heat. Whatever happens in any game, it becomes some sort of a reflection on the Heat and their drive for the mythical seven championships. Granted, this is much easier to do when they're in the Eastern Conference finals, so even when the Celtics stage a gritty, for-the-ages victory in Game 5, it was, of course, more about what the Heat did not do. And what the Heat are not. Perhaps what the Heat had for breakfast.

headline: Britain’s Prince Philip Said to Have ‘Improved Considerably’ After Infection
text: LONDON — Britain’s royal household said on Wednesday that Prince Philip, the husband of Queen Elizabeth II, had “improved considerably” since he was hospitalized on Monday with a bladder infection, but that he was likely to remain in the hospital for several more days.

headline: Excerpt: 'Sons of the Prophet'
text: A scene from Stephen Karam's play at the Laura Pels Theater. (Video courtesy of the Roundabout Theater Company.)

headline: Just One Look | Ohne Titel
text: At Ohne Titel yesterday morning, the designers Alexa Adams and Flora Gill showed a collection that seeks to flatter, above all else: the soft, dropped shoulder seams on knits show off pretty collarbones; the roomier skirts, like the one shown here, feature lines on the diagonal, which draw the eye in and against the outward curve of the hips. The color palette, which the designers called “acidic,” include muted mint (on a winning crocodile print cotton sweater with a matching skirt) and coral (the star of a color-blocked shirtdress). The message, which seems to be as much about lines and minimalism as accenting the best parts of a women’s body, is crystal clear.

headline: True Ventures Raises $205 Million Fund
text: While Facebook’s sagging stock price may have chilled investors’ appetite for rising technology start-ups, some venture capital firms continue to collect new money.

headline: A Celebrity’s Drive for the Olympics: ‘Elmo’s O.K.!’
text: Of all the big-name athletes vying for a spot in the London Olympics, perhaps none is bigger than Elmo. He’s got a loyal, young fan base that any N.B.A. player would covet, a Facebook page supporting his quest, and hopefully fireproof fur for his spin in the torch relay.

headline: No Surprise: I’ll Have Another Is Morning-Line Favorite for Belmont
text: The Triple Crown hopeful I’ll Have Another drew Post 11 and was installed as the morning-line favorite when post positions were drawn Wednesday morning at Belmont Park for the 144th running of the Belmont Stakes. Replays of the draw can be seen on MSG Plus at 2:30 p.m., 6:30 p.m. and 10:00 p.m. Twelve horses are entered for Saturday’s Grade I, $1 million race. Belmont coverage begins at 4:30 p.m. Eastern on NBC; post time is set for 6:40 p.m.

headline: Looking at Recall Vote as Drawing Lines for Fall
text: WASHINGTON — As a laboratory of democracy, the battle to recall Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin had all of the messy pieces: a clash of armies on the ground, the influence of a vast amount of money and the broader context of an improving but still sagging economy.

headline: Morning  Walkabout — 6/6: Orlando vs. New York, and International Yarn Bombing Day
text: Who’s No. 1 in Tourism? New York and Orlando were each claiming the crown as the country’s top tourist destination in 2011. But Orlando has released figures showing that it had 55 million visitors last year, while New York had 50.6 million. Still, New York’s tourism agency says that people don’t visit Orlando, they visit three different counties. We’re calling this one a draw. (The New York Times)

headline: Image of the Day: June 6
text: The Venus transit as visible from Agra, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: What Three Exhibitions Taught Us About the U.S. National Team
text: The United States national team coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, said he was going to treat the current stretch of exhibition and World Cup qualifying matches as a five-game tournament, bringing a sense of urgency and focus to his team in the process.

headline: Cricket to Offer a No-Contract iPhone
text: I am a fan of prepaid plans, and now that Cricket Wireless is offering the iPhone on what it calls a no-contract prepaid monthly plan, it would seem exactly the kind of thing I’d jump at.

headline: Lending Club Reaps $15 Million From Kleiner Perkins
text: Lending Club is proving to be a mini-reunion of sorts for former Morgan Stanley executives.

headline: Out of School And Nowhere to Work
text: A high school diploma offers little help to young people looking for work in today’s economy. Jonathan Bowles of Center for an Urban Future studies the situation in New York City.

headline: Video Chat and Social Media
text: June 6, 2012 - Can video chat services like the new Airtime transform social media?

headline: Greece Rapidly Runs Out of Money
text: June 6, 2012 - Officials in Greece said that despite the latest bailout, the government faces a shortfall of 1.7 billion euros.

headline: In an Upset, Rubin Defeats Broady in Junior Boys Match
text: PARIS — Unseeded Noah Rubin of the United States surprised third-seeded Liam Broady of Britain, 6-2, 6-3, to reach the quarterfinals of the French Open junior boys championship.

headline: The Get | Morton & Hudson’s Tropez Tote
text: The unbleached canvas beach tote with contrast trim is an icon of summer style, a simple yet effective object that designers mess with at their peril. One who’s taken it on and come out ahead is Sydney Weinger of Morton & Hudson, whose linen-lined Tropez tote takes the utilitarian nature of the original and Gallicizes it (hence the reference to the French resort). Diagonal pleats in the canvas give the Tropez texture; leather trim in blue, moss or neon yellow provides a tiny splash of color; and the attached change purse has a practical life beyond towel-and-sunscreen duty. In short, a bag for all summers.

headline: An Archive of Depression-Era Images Re-emerges
text: The Farm Security Administration’s project to photograph life in Depression-era America yielded a national image archive of incomparable depth and breadth. Most of the images — 175,000 negatives and 1,600 color transparencies — are housed in the Library of Congress. But 41,000 prints were sent in the 1930s and ’40s to the New York Public Library, where they languished largely forgotten and uncataloged.

headline: Pelosi to Boehner: Don’t Leave Town
text: It is a classic move made by the minority party – when things are going badly in a negotiation, tell those who lead not to leave Washington.

headline: Over-Interpreting Wisconsin
text: Yesterday I said we shouldn’t over-interpret the gubernatorial recall election in Wisconsin. If they won, pro-recall forces would be wrong to assume that public sector pensions (and other benefits) are sacrosanct. Scott Walker supporters would be wrong to assume that Wisconsinites necessarily support an anti-union agenda – or more broadly his reckless slashing of government spending.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Chicago’
text: This Poetry Pairing, our last one until September, matches Carl Sandburg’s 1914 classic “Chicago” with a 2012 New York Times article  about the sprawling freight traffic jams in that city today.

headline: 15-Year-Old Drowns Off Staten Island
text: A 15-year-old boy drowned off the north shore of Staten Island in the Kill Van Kull on Tuesday, the authorities said. The boy, Vaughan Mitchell, jumped into the water with some friends off the end of Jersey Street in the New Brighton neighborhood around 5 p.m. and could not swim, the Fire Department said. It took police divers and a fire boat an hour to find him. Vaughan was pronounced dead at Richmond University Medical Center.

headline: Comparing Notes on Excess Inventory (and Other Small-Business Problems)
text: During the last meeting of the She Owns It business group we introduced Deirdre Lord, an owner of The Megawatt Hour, and Beth Shaw, who owns YogaFit. Ms. Lord talked about a marketing opportunity that her company was scrambling to maximize, and Ms. Shaw shared her desire to get out of the apparel business and focus on education, her company’s core competency. Ideally, she would like to license the apparel side of her business. We also caught up with the other members of the group.

headline: Audie Awards Celebrate Great Voices, Not Famous Faces
text: The audiobook industry honored its best at the 17th annual Audie Awards gala on Tuesday night at the New-York Historical Society. Winners like Tina Fey, William Shatner and Jane Fonda weren’t there, but the stars of the audiobook world — narrators like Katherine Kellgren (seven nominations), Simon Vance and Dion Graham (four each) — were greeted with loud applause.

headline: Kenneth Cole’s Board Approves Management Buyout
text: Kenneth Cole Productions is ready to put Kenneth Cole solely in charge of Kenneth Cole.

headline: Regulator Concedes Oversight Lapse in JPMorgan Loss
text: 8:56 p.m. | Updated

headline: Gambling Group Lobbied for Convention Center at Cuomo Fund-Raiser
text: ALBANY — After Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s State of State speech in January, the political world wondered where he got the idea for a huge, Malaysian-financed convention center.

headline: Just One Look | Michael Kors
text: Michael Kors opened three stores in Istanbul recently, and it’s there that he went for inspiration for resort. Coats as look changers, legginess (“women are really going for shorts,” Kors said during the presentation) and opulence through fabric (gold ikat shantung, lacquered python, fox fur and cashmere) were the collection’s key points. Most looks were shown with embellished flat sandals — “What makes it resort?” Kors asked the editors in attendance; “what’s on your feet,” he asserted — and small bags decorated with gemstones (“built-in jewelry”). Here, a most elegant panne velvet shift captures the group’s glamorous and easy attitude best.

headline: Happy Hour at Ugg
text: Around 5 p.m. on Tuesday, inside the expanded Ugg store on Madison Avenue and 58th Street, preparations were underway to introduce what the company, well known for its shearling footwear, was describing as its first freestanding store for men. Actually, it’s attached to the two-year-old women’s store, but there’s a separate entrance.

headline: Recall of the Wild
text: Gail Collins: David I’m really sad about the results from Wisconsin. I can’t find a silver lining. You and I totally disagree about what this vote means, and my analysis is much more depressing.

headline: HBO Says No, for Now, to Fans Who Want a Web-Only Option
text: HBO doesn’t want your money, Web-only television viewers.

headline: Suspect Sought in Queens Sex Attacks and Robberies
text: A young man is wanted in connection with the recent sexual assaults and robberies of several women at knifepoint on the usually safe streets of Forest Hills, Queens, the police said.

headline: Smoothly, Sharapova Reaches the Semifinals
text: PARIS — For years, Maria Sharapova struggled on the red clay at the French Open, as if the court itself were a red light screaming at her to stand still. The alternative sometimes proved more embarrassing, at least initially. She ran so awkwardly, so rigidly, that she once compared her ungraceful movements here to that of a cow on ice.

headline: U.S. Open Cup: Cal F.C. Hits the Wall
text: The dream of Cal F.C. is over.

headline: Crop Insurance Proposal Could Cost U.S. Billions
text: WASHINGTON — At the same time that high crop prices are prompting farmers to expand into millions of acres of land once considered unsuitable for farming, Congress is considering expanding a federal insurance program that reimburses farmers for most losses or drops in prices.

headline: For Ukraine Striker, Ending Is Also a Beginning
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The end is near, so much so that Andriy Shevchenko cannot precisely remember the distant beginning of his brilliant soccer career. He is said to have begun kicking a ball before he could walk.

headline: Pete Cosey, Guitarist With Miles Davis, Dies at 68
text: Pete Cosey, a guitarist who played on many blues and R&B records in the 1960s but who became best known for his work in Miles Davis’s electric band of 1973-75, contributing a sound drenched in distortion and punctuated by the wah-wah pedal, died on May 30 in Chicago. He was 68.

headline: Former E.P.A. Official Pulls Out of House Hearing
text: A former Environmental Protection Agency official who stepped down this spring over controversial remarks he had made about punishing major polluters has sidestepped a grilling that he was expected to face on Wednesday at a House subcommittee hearing.

headline: Grant on the Edge
text: In early June 1862, a few days after Union forces captured the vital rail lines at Corinth, Miss., William Tecumseh Sherman sat chatting with Henry W. Halleck, his superior and commander of the victorious Yankee army. With elaborate casualness, Halleck mentioned that Ulysses S. Grant, another of his subordinates, was departing the next morning for 30 days’ leave.

headline: Sheryl Crow Says Brain Tumor Has Affected Her Memory
text: Sheryl Crow, the singer and songwriter who has survived breast cancer, disclosed this week that she has a benign brain tumor that has affected her memory.   Ms. Crow, 50, mentioned her condition in offhand comments to an audience at a recent concert and her publicist later confirmed that she has a meningioma, a tumor common in middle-aged women that grows in thin layers of tissue around the brain and spinal cord, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Nasdaq Sets Aside $40 Million to Settle Facebook Claims
text: 9:28 p.m. | Updated The Nasdaq OMX Group is taking its first step to quell investor anger over the flawed debut of Facebook shares last month — pledging $40 million to cover broker losses — but some customers and competitors quickly raised objections.

headline: Sitting on the Other Side of the Desk
text: Teachers training teachers is a common practice at Urban Assembly, a public school in the South Bronx. Teachers almost always complete tasks such as lesson planning and curriculum development collaboratively and under the guidance of “team leaders,” typically more experienced teachers who have previously taught the class they are team leading. A Columbia journalism student sits in.

headline: TimesCast Tech: New Xbox Services
text: Napster’s founders introduce their latest venture. | Tumblr’s founder shares his inspiration and mistakes. | Jenna Wortham checks out TaskRabbit, Pocketbooth and Uber.

headline: Companies Try to Create Room on Radio Spectrum
text: Cellphone carriers like AT&T and Verizon say they are worried about running out of the radio spectrum that carries wireless calls and data, and they want the government to give them more chunks of it. But a number of companies are developing technology that could change the whole spectrum game by using radio frequencies more efficiently.

headline: In Zenyatta’s Transition, a Life Lesson
text: I don’t even remember the drive from Louisville to Lexington. I do remember getting up before sunrise to watch the morning workouts at Churchill Downs. It was there I received a message asking if I was available to come to Lane’s End to visit Zenyatta and her colt. The next thing I knew, I was sitting in their reception area crying. When the Lane’s End bloodstock assistant Sarah Campion came in, she took one look at me, patted my arm and said knowingly: “I know; it’s always very emotional to see Zenyatta.” I stumbled on my reply and fled to the bathroom to repair myself.

headline: Tsonga Played It Safe, and Paid a Price
text: When Jo-Wilfried Tsonga watches a replay of his gripping match with Novak Djokovic he will wince at his lack of aggressive play on his four match points in the fourth set. In much the same way he thwarted Roger Federer in the 2010 United States  Open semifinals, when he faced double match point at 4-5, 15-40 in the fifth set, Djokovic attacked. Like Federer, who twice chipped backhand returns on second serves, Tsonga elected to play it safe rather than hit out.

headline: Are We Nearing a Planetary Boundary?
text: The earth could be nearing a point at which sweeping environmental changes, possibly including mass extinctions, would undermine human welfare, 22 prominent biologists and ecologists warned on Wednesday.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Speaking With Tumblr’s Founder
text: David Karp, Tumblr’s founder, shares his inspiration and mistakes on the inaugural episode of The Times’s weekly technology show. Also, Sam Grobart talks with Yusuf Mehdi, the chief marketing officer for Microsoft’s Interactive Entertainment Business; Napster’s founders introduce their latest venture; and Jenna Wortham checks out TaskRabbit, Pocketbooth and Uber.

headline: FX Orders New Comedy Series ‘Legit’
text: It may be the network of spooky houses, lawmen with bad attitudes and bikers with even badder attitudes, but FX also wants to be known as the cable channel that makes you laugh: on Wednesday it added to its roster of scripted comedy series, saying it had picked up a new show called “Legit,” starring the Australian comedian Jim Jefferies. In “Legit,” Mr. Jefferies,  who created the series with Peter O’Fallon, plays a comedian named Jim who hopes “to become legitimate in life,” according to a release. The series also stars Dan Bakkedahl (of “The Daily Show”) as Jim’s best friend, Steve, and D.J. Qualls (“Hustle & Flow”) as Steve’s brother, Billy. FX is already the home of the comedy series “Louie,” about the life of the comedian Louis C. K., as well as “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” and “Wilfred.” Later this month the channel will introduce the comedy series “Anger Management,” starring Charlie Sheen, and “Brand X,” a late-night series hosted by Russell Brand.

headline: Reviving Elvis, Just Like Tupac
text: The special effects company that brought Tupac Shakur back to life in the form of a ghostly image on stage at the Coachella music festival says it has plans for a similar project with images of Elvis Presley, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The company, Digital Domain Media Group, has said it has entered a deal with Core Media Group to produce images of Presley for a range of entertainment projects on film, television and at live events. Core Media owns the rights to Presley’s image.

headline: Clothes Encounters | The Deste Fashion Collection at Barneys
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: LinkedIn Was Breached. Now What Do You Do?
text: Security researchers have confirmed that a file containing 6.5 million encoded LinkedIn passwords has been posted to a Russian hacker site. LinkedIn has yet to confirm the breach, but it took to its Twitter account Wednesday to tell users it was investigating the matter.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Castle Is Open to Tours
text: The next season of “Downton Abbey” won’t be broadcast until January for American audiences, but fans of the show can visit the filming location long before then.

headline: German Lawmakers Spar Over Child Care Subsidy
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cabinet approved a bill on Wednesday to provide parents of toddlers with an allowance for keeping their children out of state-run day care, a move that critics say would derail recent efforts to encourage German women to return to work after starting a family.

headline: Plays Well With Others: Video Game System Transcends Solitude
text: LOS ANGELES — Six years ago, while much of the video game industry continued to obsess over explosion-addled young men in basements, Nintendo had the gumption to move in a different direction with the introduction of the Wii. It was built around a vision of families having fun together in living rooms.

headline: Beholding Nadal’s Empire of Clay
text: PARIS — Only one man has beaten Rafael Nadal at the French Open, and he is too ill to play here this year.

headline: I’ll Have Another to Start From Post No. 11
text: The post position draw for Saturday’s Belmont Stakes featured some good-natured posturing at Belmont Park on Wednesday, when I’ll Have Another was installed as the 4-5 morning-line favorite in his bid for the Triple Crown.

headline: In Europe, a ‘Shareholder Spring’ Leads to a Push to Curb Ad Executives’ Pay
text: PARIS — Maurice Lévy, one of the world’s most powerful advertising executives, issued a public call last year for higher taxes on the wealthy, saying it was only fair that they should make a greater contribution to reducing national budget deficits.

headline: Scouting Report
text: EVENTS

headline: Hyundai Prices Veloster Turbo at $22,725
text: Notwithstanding its gray matte paint finish that so enthralled attendees at the 2012 Detroit auto show, the 2013 Hyundai Veloster Turbo is a known quantity. Specifically, $22,725.

headline: Confessions of a Science Fiction Addict
text: Ray Bradbury, who died today at 91, introduced many young readers to science fiction.

headline: Netanyahu Ministers Reject Move to Legalize Some Settler Homes
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel seemed headed for a showdown with hard-core Jewish settlers on Wednesday, after his ministers followed his instructions to vote against a draft bill that would have retroactively legalized illegally built settler homes in the West Bank.

headline: G.O.P. Senators Oppose Cuomo’s Marijuana Plan
text: ALBANY — The Republican majority in the State Senate is not satisfied with a proposal by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to decriminalize the open possession of small amounts of marijuana and will not pass it in its current form, the chamber’s top lawmaker said Wednesday.

headline: Off to Camp, but First ... a Wax?
text: LOTS of tweens and teenagers are gearing up for sleep-away camp, making sure they have stocked up on a season’s worth of bathing suits, sunblock and bug spray.

headline: How Long Can You Hold Your Breath?
text: In describing Noomi Rapace’s underwater cover shoot recently, we wrote that the actor “was able to stay submerged for what seemed like minutes at a time.” And it did seem like that — so much so that our original words didn’t even include that “what seemed like.” But then a copy editor here, who obviously has no use for mermaids, raised a skeptical eyebrow at the claim that Rapace held her breath for minutes. So we added the qualifier.

headline: Google Schools Apple on Maps
text: Google wants Apple, and the rest of us, to know just how expensive and hard it is to make good maps.

headline: Nadal’s Latest Weapon: A Backhand Down the Line
text: Rafael Nadal speaks frequently about finding “solutions.” He continues to evolve, adapt, and improve his game, anticipating how his opponents will play him and adding new shots to keep them off balance. On Wednesday in his match against Nicolas Almagro, Nadal knew that Almagro would try to dominate play by ripping his heavy topspin forehand deep into Nadal’s backhand. If Almagro could make the match about his strength against Nadal’s weaker side, he would have his best chance at upsetting Nadal.

headline: Finding Security Among the SPFs
text: EACH summer brings new and supposedly improved sunscreens, but this year’s really are quite different. With a set of the coming Food and Drug Administration regulations in mind, manufacturers have tweaked formulas and labels, and have even discontinued products, to comply. Words like “waterproof” and “sunblock,” which could give a false sense of protection, will be banned. Originally scheduled for this month, these requirements won’t take effect until December, but most new products already abide by them. Here are some possibilities for the sunny days ahead.

headline: Gupta Trial Judge Reprimands Law Student Spectator
text: Judge Jed S. Rakoff asked a law student attending the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta to stop sending him letters about the case.

headline: Two Profound Slumps, With Some Parallels
text: Batting practice for the Class AAA Charlotte Knights had just finished on a steamy, hot afternoon in Fort Mill, S.C., when Conor Jackson emerged from the Knights Stadium clubhouse and took a seat in the dugout. It has been seven years since Jackson, 30, once a fixture in the Arizona Diamondbacks lineup, was a regular in the minor leagues.

headline: Auction House Fights Seizure of Cambodian Statue
text: Sotheby’s filed papers on Tuesday urging a federal judge to dismiss efforts by prosecutors to repatriate a 10th-century statue to Cambodia, contending that there is no proof that the sculpture had been stolen from its homeland.

headline: The People’s Choice: An All-in-One, Mobile Utility Meter
text: The people have spoken, choosing VELObill as their favorite app among the 50-plus entries in the Energy Department’s Apps for Energy contest.

headline: The Urge to Punish
text: I’ve been hearing various attempts to explain the ECB’s utterly bizarre refusal to cut interest rates despite soaring unemployment, sliding inflation, and on top of all that the special problems of a monetary union that probably can’t survive unless overall demand is strong. The most popular story seems to be that the ECB wants to “hold politicians’ feet to the fire”, letting them know that they won’t get relief unless they do what’s necessary (whatever that is).

headline: As Twitter Matures, a New Bird Emerges
text: When a start-up grows up, it often signals its maturation by hiring a new chief financial officer or filing a prospectus. For Twitter, growing up means a new logo.

headline: From The Lively Morgue: Republican National Convention, Chicago, 1952
text: July 4, 1952: Chicago. As part of its coverage of the Republican National Convention, The Times ran a full program and a chart showing the positions that delegates would occupy on the convention floor. Read more on The Lively Morgue.

headline: In Hakalau, a Modern Success Story
text: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

headline: After Flooding Stops, Hard Drive Costs Continue to Rise
text: A report issued by I.H.S. iSuppli, the research firm, found that last year’s extensive flooding in Thailand, where many hard drive components are made, will have a continued impact on the cost of computer drives into 2014.

headline: Boys Being Boys, With Beer and Guns
text: As you watch “The Bad Guys,” an absorbing one-act comedy-drama by Alena Smith at the McGinn/Cazale Theater, your opinion of just which characters should be classified as miscreants may shift from scene to scene. The cocky investment banker would seem a natural candidate, right? Hedge funds! Cue the booing and hissing. But then his loyalty to a childhood friend whose life has unraveled earns some sympathy. The drug dealer who freely admits to selling to kids certainly appears to qualify, at least until the moving speech in which he reveals that his illicit trade is the only bulwark between his extended family and abject poverty.

headline: Just One Look | Suno
text: This resort season, the Suno designers Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty expanded their collection to a total of 27 looks. They also showed a sportier Suno: silk racer-back tank dresses (in their signature mixed digital prints), techy Lucite windbreakers in colors like highlighter pink and lavender, and Suno-emblazoned graphic baseball tees. If you look closely at these boyishly boxy trousers and varsity jacket, you’ll see that the print is a basketball court.

headline: Nokia Adds to Its Low-End Lineup of Phones
text: BERLIN — As Nokia waits for its high-end business to grow, it made another move to shore up its bread-and-butter market.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Rapture, Blister, Burn’
text: A scene from Gina Gionfriddo’s new play.

headline: Dating Profiles of High-Tech, High-Worth Bachelors
text: From Pete Cashmore of Mashable to Jack Dorsey of Twitter, these young, bright, wildly overcompensated hyper-achievers are currently unattached.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Homosexuality and the First Amendment
text: Bryan Fischer of the American Family Association said on his radio show yesterday that we have to choose between homosexuality and the First Amendment.

headline: Bachelorville’s Big Fish
text: WHEN Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook married his longtime girlfriend, Priscilla Chan, recently, one of the world’s youngest billionaires was off the market.

headline: Anna Teresa Callen, Cookbook Author, Dies
text: Anna Teresa Callen, an influential cookbook author who began her career as a cooking teacher in New York City, died on Sunday in a hospital in Lanciano, in Central Italy. She was 86, and died during surgery for cancer, said Nick Malgieri, the director of baking programs at the Institute of Culinary Education.

headline: Limit Soda for Kids’ Sake
text: For some people, the central knock on Mayor Bloomberg is his eagerness to institute a “nanny state,” the most recent example of which is his administration’s attempt (opposed by nearly two-thirds of Americans) to ban large servings of sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs). In this scenario a nanny is unquestionably a bad thing: an excessive and patronizing intrusion, something to be feared and reviled.

headline: At Best Buy, Lumia Is Selling O.K. but More Slowly Than Android
text: Nokia and AT&T have aggressively promoted the new Lumia 900 smartphone with a big marketing campaign, but at Best Buy, Lumia sales still pale in comparison to the hottest Android phones, a company executive says.

headline: The Lessons of Pineapplegate
text: The writer, who broke the story of the pineapple and the hare test question, believes that the state and federal education bureaucracy is becoming inextricably tangled with for-profit testing companies and thus deeply compromised. "Their testing obsession is undermining our schools, not only in this city, but nationally,'' she writes.

headline: Should Ike Davis Be Sent Down?
text: Ike Davis was expected to be the Mets’ cleanup hitter this season. Instead, he has struggled from Game 1 and is now hitting  .160, the lowest average of any regular position player in baseball, entering Wednesday’s games.

headline: Teachers: Arne Duncan Wants to Hear From You
text: The education secretary is on Twitter, asking teachers:  What is one positive lesson you learned from another teacher this year? #teachtalk

headline: Giving Your Bangs a Name
text: Like jeans and shoes, bangs are hardly one size fits all. Herein, a fringe glossary to help you convey to your stylist what you want (or don’t):

headline: College Admissions Books for Your Summer Reading Pleasure
text: In collaboration with our sister blog, The Learning Network, The Choice will join a Twitter celebration of summer reading on Thursday, using the hashtag #summerreading.

headline: Breaking It Down: Djokovic vs. Tsonga
text: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga had finally arrived at one of the most important moments in his career – his first match point three hours and eleven minutes into his French Open quarter final battle with world number one Novak Djokovic in Paris on Tuesday.

headline: Baring Shoulders and Knees, Students Protest a Dress Code
text: The first hint of the looming rebellion came from the lips of Hao Yang, 17, as he practiced ballroom dancing outside Stuyvesant High School on Wednesday morning, the first licks of sunlight casting a long shadow that made a perfect dance partner on the wall behind him.

headline: A Dark Tale of Tokyo That Only Gets Darker
text: The title of Richard Lloyd Parry’s true-crime book “People Who Eat Darkness,” is creepy, especially now that zombies are in the news. Its sleek cover, which features a blurry sketch of a serial rapist and murderer, is creepier still. I read “People Who Eat Darkness” over the course of two days and always placed it face down in the kitchen, lest a glimpse of it unnerve the children and animals in the house.

headline: Scene City: A Milestone for Gordon Parks
text: Karl Lagerfeld, Anna Wintour and Annie Leibovitz toast the photographer’s vision.

headline: A Call for More Clarity on Net Access in Europe
text: BERLIN — In Europe, the debate over unrestricted Internet access — so-called net neutrality — has shifted to a core question: How much should the European Union intervene when mobile Internet service providers restrict Web access?

headline: Memories of a Master of the Lens
text: TWELVE years ago, in an interview with The New York Times for an article that was part of the newspaper’s “How Race Is Lived in America” series, Gloria Vanderbilt described how she first met the photojournalist Gordon Parks, with whom she would have a longtime romantic relationship.

headline: News Roundup: Panetta Defends Drone Strikes in Pakistan; Courts India
text: Gardiner Harris reports in The New York Times’ India Ink blog that Leon E. Panetta, the United States defense secretary, does not think drone strikes, like the one on Monday that killed Abu Yahya al-Libi, the Qaeda deputy leader, violate Pakistan’s sovereignty. They instead protect both Pakistan and the United States, he said on Wednesday in New Delhi.

headline: YouTube Will Stream Olympic Coverage to 64 Countries
text: YouTube will stream 2,200 hours of live Olympic coverage free to 64 countries and territories in Asia and Africa at youtube.com/olympic during the Summer Games in London, which start July 27.

headline: For Celtics, Not Practicing Seems to Be Working
text: BOSTON — One of the many responsibilities for Jeff Twiss, the Celtics’ media relations director, is updating reporters each day on the team’s practice times. In this postseason it has pretty much been a robo call: the Boston Celtics will not practice today.

headline: Could Obama Have Made a Difference in Wisconsin?
text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y7v8f8jBrW8

headline: Bangs Are Back as a Popular Hairstyle
text: Celebrities like Rooney Mara and Jessica Biel have been sporting bangs, a trend that is making a comeback.

headline: The Forehead Is the New Canvas
text: AT the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Gala last month, Ginnifer Goodwin showed off bangs as short as the mowed grass in Yankee Stadium. Jessica Biel had fringe so thick and long, she looked like one of the Beatles. And Marion Cotillard had a tuft on her forehead seemingly styled by a weed whacker. As if those bangs weren’t sufficiently extreme, days later at the Chanel cruise show in Versailles, the stylist Sam McKnight gave the models fringe in pastel hues typically reserved for Easter eggs.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Prospectus Humor and 3rd World Start-ups
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Goodbye, MobileMe. Hello, Jimdo.
text: If this is Thursday, Apple must be revamping its online services again.

headline: When Teasing Is Loving, and When It’s Not
text: “I was only teasing.” Those are words that roll around our house a lot. From brother to sister, sister to brother, and occasionally, from parent to child, or even (less often, but occasionally) from my husband to me. We are a family that teases.

headline: Sara Errani’s Best Year Ever
text: PARIS — Sara Errani of Italy is playing the tournament of her dreams.

headline: Jill Lepore Talks About Life, Death and the Stages in Between
text: In “The Mansion of Happiness: A History of Life and Death” (Knopf), Jill Lepore examines the ways in which we’ve historically defined where life begins, where it ends and how it should be conducted while it lasts. In a recent interview via e-mail, Ms. Lepore discussed why death is a less contentious subject than conception, why the word “parenthood” had to be invented and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Giants Extend Coughlin’s Contract to Reward a Two-Time Champion
text: Once the Giants won the Super Bowl in February for the second time in Tom Coughlin’s coaching tenure, the question of his latest contract extension became a matter of when instead of if. The Giants answered Wednesday, announcing that Coughlin’s contract, which was set to expire after the coming season, had been extended through 2014.

headline: Just One Look | Boy by Band of Outsiders
text: “I just bought a 1930s-style house, and it actually looks a lot like this collection,” said Scott Sternberg, the designer behind Band of Outsiders. The L.A.-based collection featured many California design influences (thanks to LACMA’s recent interiors show): Bauhaus-inspired architecture and primary colors translated into classic captain blazers and striped kerchief dresses and anoraks (above), for example. In addition, Sternberg points out: “We experimented with evening wear last season, and it went over really well.” He has even taken a liking to jumpsuits. “So we’re going to keep at it.”

headline: Don’t Think College Is Worth It? Ask People Who Haven’t Gone
text: Last month the Heldrich Center for Workforce Development released data showing that college graduates generally do not regret going to college, despite lots of criticism of the value of higher education. Today the center released a new report focusing on the depressing state of America’s recent high school graduates, who seem to agree about the importance of further education.

headline: LinkedIn Tweaks Calendar Feature to Stop Taking Meeting Notes
text: On Tuesday, Bits reported that LinkedIn’s mobile application for the iPhone and iPad contained an opt-in feature that transported sensitive information from users’ calendars — including meeting notes, dial-in information, passwords and participants’ contact information — back to its servers, without users’ knowledge. Security researchers noted that the practice could prove problematic in cases where people inserted sensitive information, like confidential financial data or strategic plans, for instance, into those meeting notes.

headline: The Choir, the Clarinet and the Adrienne Rich Part
text: In the section of David Eagleman’s work of fiction “Sum: Forty Tales From the Afterlives” called “Egalitaire,” a mature female God is imagined mulling the difficulties of arbitrating morality.

headline: Ray Bradbury Dies at 91
text: The author of “Fahrenheit 451” brought science fiction to the literary mainstream.

headline: Homes for $460,000
text: Properties in Kansas, Oregon and Massachusetts.

headline: What You Get for ... $460,000
text: KANSAS CITY, KAN.

headline: Dates and Hours Announced for the Next New York Run of  ‘The Clock’
text: In April Lincoln Center announced that Christian Marclay’s much-loved “The Clock’’ — a 24-hour montage of clips from movies and television that depict particular minutes in the day, synchronized with the moment they are shown — is coming to Lincoln Center’s David Rubenstein Atrium, on Broadway between 62nd and 63rd Streets, where it will be shown free.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Italy and Elsewhere
text: Pictures from Italy, Bahrain, Afghanistan and Gaza.

headline: Happy IPv6 Day! But What the Heck Is IPv6?
text: Several technology companies on Wednesday celebrated World IPv6 Day, a historic moment when many big tech companies and Internet providers began switching to a new system for getting on the Web. Most of us will never even have to think about this.

headline: In Buenos Aires, a triplex with an industrial heritage
text: A three-bedroom triplex in the Puerto Madero neighborhood is for sale for $980,000.

headline: House Hunting in ... Argentina
text: A TRIPLEX IN A FORMER GRAIN SILO IN BUENOS AIRES

headline: Bill Fontana’s ‘Acoustical Visions’
text: This work in “International Orange,” a FOR-SITE Foundation exhibition in San Francisco, uses the Golden Gate Bridge as a musical instrument, with real-time views under the roadway expansion joints.

headline: Some Final Thoughts on a Booming Industry
text: Having covered the boom and bust of the e-commerce industry, and then the boom and bust of the mortgage industry, I’m exiting the mobile apps beat before I see death and destruction again.

headline: Balanchine’s Nocturnal Dream, Tailor Made for June
text: George Balanchine’s two-act ballet “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” turns 50 this year. To return to it at New York City Ballet on Tuesday night was to find it fascinatingly different from the ballet I remembered. And I realize now, after many viewings over the years, that it has added up each time to a different whole. This time it was funnier than in its last revival here: the sound of children in the audience gurgling with laughter in Act I was delicious.

headline: Just One Look | Organic by John Patrick
text: “I kept thinking about the word ‘throwback’ and realized I don’t want to throw anything back,” said the designer John Patrick of Organic, whose resort collection was inspired by Edit DeAk and Walter Robinson’s 1970s zine Art-Rite. “I’m not watching Nick at Nite anymore. This is fresh.” To get fresh, Patrick showed color-pops of cobalt blue, recycled polyester slip dresses and skirts, classic daisy embroidered tunics in voluminous proportions and — wait for it — men’s wear. Monochromatic nylon uniforms were designed for everyone. “Designing men’s definitely made everything a bit more ambiguous for both,” said Patrick, pointing out this all-white sports-set shown with Roger Vivier kitten heels. “Not David Bowie ambiguous but pristine, healthy and active.”

headline: National Black Theater Clears Financial Hurdles
text: The National Black Theater, a cultural fixture in Harlem that was in danger of losing its home, has resolved a series of financial disputes that had endangered its future.

headline: The Message From Wisconsin
text: When Gov. Scott Walker moved to strip Wisconsin public employees of their collective-bargaining rights last year, a few weeks after taking office, it was clear that he wasn’t doing it to save the state money. If that had been the case, he would have accepted the unions’ agreement to pay far more in health care and pension costs. His real goal was political: to break the unions by demonizing their “bosses,” ending their ability even to collect dues and removing them as a source of money and energy for Democrats.

headline: At Belmont Park, a Clinic’s Doctor Gets Track Workers Back on Their Feet
text: As a general practitioner with a practice in Nassau County, Dr. Fredric Cogan was familiar with the usual flus, fevers and fractures his patients dealt with.

headline: Ray Bradbury Wants to Pass on a Message From Jules Verne
text: The story begins with Ray Bradbury, stepping out of a time machine. From the misty distance emerges a man in a dark suit. It is Jules Verne, who has been dead for 50 years to the day. The conversation between one master of science fiction and another starts with the practical.

headline: A Singer With Many Influences but a Soul That’s Hers Alone
text: The story of the recent British soul revival is the story of ghosts. Artists like Adele and Amy Winehouse succeeded as much because of the memories they conjured with their reference points as because of their talent. They had the familiarity of yesteryear on their sides. And given that they summoned styles dating back to Motown girl groups and Dusty Springfield, they had a lot of peoples’ yesteryears in their arsenal.

headline: Indisputably ‘Out of Service’
text: There is no doubt that this bathroom stall cannot be used.

headline: Stephen Tyrone Williams
text: STEPHEN TYRONE WILLIAMS has accumulated some impressive regional theater credits, including Cory Maxson in “Fences” at Seattle Rep and Syracuse Stage, and Simon in “Ruined” at the Geffen Playhouse and the Intiman Theater. But this University of Alabama graduate (Class of 2004), born and raised in Tuscaloosa, has been seen somewhat less onstage in New York.

headline: A Comedian Retraces His Life Through 16 Homes
text: Adam Carolla, the comedian and radio personality, “grew up in a string of semi-bad places,” he said, in the San Fernando Valley in California. He spent his 20s working construction jobs and living in more shoddy homes, including a North Hollywood ranch house that had what he described as “half-bedrooms,” the bedroom equivalent of half-baths.

headline: Think of It as a Big Portable Teakettle
text: When you live in the city but long for the country, you might go for a drive or, if circumstances allow, buy a getaway property.

headline: When the Shade Moves, Just Follow
text: Perfectionist furniture arrangers will breathe easy with Dala, new outdoor seating and tables by Stephen Burks for Dedon. The pieces, which include a lounge chair (from about $2,400) and side table (from about $600), are portable and casual, with strap handles that allow them to be dragged to shady spots under tree canopies or sunny patches near the pool. The very shape of this collection is easygoing. “Everything is round and circular,” Mr. Burks said, “so there’s no particular orientation to how you should sit.”

headline: It’s a (Very) Small World
text: Emre Ozberk, 38, is a Turkish architect who works for a large firm but has developed an interest in the tiny.

headline: Taking Its Design Eye Outside
text: In the five years since it was started, Remodelista.com has established itself as a sourcebook for home renovation and furnishings. Its appeal lies in its balance of highbrow minimal taste (a portfolio of patterned Scandinavian blankets) and sensible advice (how to spray-paint Ikea pendant lamps).

headline: Save on Cookware, Beds and Lights
text: Broadway Panhandler is taking up to 70 percent off many pieces of brand-name cookware, through Sunday (the All-Clad D5 brushed stainless 1.5-quart saucepan with lid, shown, usually $190, is about $115); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I’m renovating my kitchen, and considering adding a wine refrigerator. Would that be good for the resale value of my home?

headline: Beer Glasses

headline: Shopping for Beer Glasses
text: “Form, beauty, function, ritual: all of these things go into making a great beer glass,” said Garrett Oliver, a Brooklyn Brewery brewmaster.

headline: A Would-Be Christo’s Hard Lesson
text: IT is not often a furniture designer makes the evening news. Takeshi Miyakawa, 50, a Japanese-born, Brooklyn-dwelling maker of delicate pieces that are both conceptual and functional, may be one of the first to do so.

headline: Photo Replay: June 6
text: A view of the day in sports included the French Open and preparation for the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Finding Flavor in the Weeds
text: I know I’m not the only one who had chickweed growing like a deeply rooted carpet all over my vegetable garden this spring. And have you ever seen such huge leaves of dock this early in the season?

text: The new NBC medical drama begins Thursday night.

headline: The Candidate Next Door

headline: From Garden Weeds, Unexpected Meals
text: Rather than fighting the weeds in her garden, Tama Matsuoka Wong learned to embrace them and incorporate them into meals.

headline: After an Accident, a Doctor’s Lingering Presence
text: Watching the first two episodes of “Saving Hope,” a new medical drama that begins Thursday night on NBC, I wondered: If I didn’t already know that it was a summer-filler Canadian import, would I have been able to tell?

headline: Graffiti as Art in Rice Mill Lofts
text: The building, once home to one of the largest rice processors in North America, has kept the graffiti left over from its derelict days.

headline: CT Scans Increase Children’s Cancer Risk, Study Finds
text: CT scans in children can cause small but significant increases in the risk of leukemia and brain cancer, a new study finds.

headline: Where the Walls Do Talk
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Mayer Keeps Top Spot on Album Chart
text: John Mayer’s “Born and Raised” (Columbia) topped the Billboard album chart for a second week, but that was not a huge accomplishment since sales were anemic all around. Mr. Mayer needed to sell only 65,000 copies to hold on to the top slot, the smallest number for a No. 1 album since February 2011 when Nicki Minaj’s “Pink Friday” was on top after selling only 45,000. Album sales are down 3 percent since January compared to the same period last year. Adele’s “21” (XL/Columbia) remained at No. 2, and Regina Spektor’s “What We Saw From the Cheap Seats” (Sire/Warner Brothers) entered the chart at No. 3 with 42,000 copies sold. One Direction’s “Up All Night” (Syco/Columbia) was just behind at No. 4 with 41,000 in sales, and Edward Sharp and the Magnetic Zeros made their debut at No. 5 with “Here,” (Community Music) which sold 35,000 copies.

headline: Why Facebook Should Build a Phone
text: Last week I reported about Facebook assembling a team of experienced engineers with the hopes of building a Facebook smartphone.

headline: Expo’s Hope: Personal Touch to Sell Books
text: Last year at BookExpo America, the publishing industry’s annual trade convention, the unknown author Amor Towles arrived to pitch his first book, “Rules of Civility,” to the throngs.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Choice'
text: The new dating show, beginning on Fox on Thursday, is similar to "The Voice" on NBC.

headline: Looking for Love, or Something, Sight Unseen
text: When Fox picked up a new dating show called “The Choice,” featuring celebrity contestants in swivel chairs who choose potential dates sight unseen, its motives were clear: to belittle the NBC singing competition “The Voice” by blatantly copying it. In this case imitation is the sincerest form of mockery.

headline: Fortunately, George Washington Had a Better Crew
text: Robert Sullivan, the author perhaps best known for his 2004 book on rats in New York City, wanted to promote his new book on the landscape of the Revolutionary War by plunging potential buyers into the world of historical Manhattan.

headline: Women’s Team Trial for the World Mind Sports Games
text: The 96-board final of the women’s team trial for the second World Mind Sports Games ended late on Tuesday evening in Schaumburg, Ill. The winner became the United States team, heading to Lille, France, in August.

headline: The Technology in Our Lives, and How to Make It Work Better
text: Technology is supposed to make our lives easier. Sadly, that is not always the way it works. Sometimes, technology’s promise of an easier, more productive life is lost behind layers of jargon, settings and hardware adjustments.

headline: New York Hospitals Look to Combine, Forming a Giant
text: Two of New York City’s biggest hospital systems reached agreement on Wednesday to pursue a merger that would shake up the way medical care is delivered, especially in Manhattan, where hospitals compete to serve some of the wealthiest neighborhoods in the world.

headline: Ethics Case Against Congresswoman to Resume
text: WASHINGTON — Leaders of the House Ethics Committee said Wednesday that they would move ahead with a long-delayed inquiry into allegations of impropriety by Representative Maxine Waters after concluding that committee missteps had not denied Ms. Waters a fair hearing in the case.

headline: After the Recall Vote in Wisconsin
text: To the Editor:

headline: Romney and Obama to Appear on Country Music Award Show
text: President Obama and Mitt Romney will share a stage Wednesday night – in a manner of speaking — when they perform in a comedy sketch for the CMT Music Awards.

headline: Misuse of City Cellphone Costs Worker Her Job
text: She spent almost a decade working for the city agency that specializes in telecommunication technology, yet it was a flagrant violation of the city’s cellphone policy that brought about her resignation.

headline: Icon, Builder of Custom 4x4s, Kicks Up Dust After Perceived Snub by Hot Wheels
text: If, as the essayist Charles Caleb Colton wrote, imitation is the sincerest of flattery, there is a whole lot of sincerity going on around the release of a Hot Wheels car. At issue, however, is who is imitating whom.

headline: Defense Chief Shrugs Off Objections to Drones
text: NEW DELHI — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta brushed aside concerns on Wednesday that drone strikes against leaders of Al Qaeda in Pakistan violate that country’s sovereignty.

headline: That Was Fast: Criminals Exploit LinkedIn Breach For Phishing Attacks
text: After hackers posted millions of encoded LinkedIn passwords to a Russian hacker site on Wednesday, criminals used news of the breach to trick unsuspecting users into downloading malware that can be used to extract financial gain.

headline: Bay and Beato Return in Latest Roster Shuffle

headline: Campaign to Boycott Egypt’s Presidential Election Gains Momentum

headline: A Little Optimism at the Federal Reserve
text: WASHINGTON — Three members of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee indicated in separate speeches Wednesday that recent economic data, while troubling, does not yet justify an expansion of the Fed’s economic aid campaign.

headline: Romney Touts a Book, but Reads It Selectively
