headline: Detention Provision Is Blocked
text: WASHINGTON — The government may not rely on a disputed law enacted last year to hold people in indefinite military detention on suspicion that they “substantially supported” Al Qaeda or its allies — at least if they had no connection to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, a federal judge said on Wednesday.

headline: A ‘Mad Men’ Debut for a Behind-the-Scenes Player
text: TURN, a Silicon Valley company, works with advertisers to target digital ads by determining likely demographic attributes — but not actual identities — of consumers as they land on Web pages. Its software instantly calculates whether to display ads likely to be relevant to computer and mobile device users, like a diaper ad to mothers.

headline: Prosecutors Try to Prove Incentive for Insider Tips
text: At the end of 2007, Rajat K. Gupta had an investment in a Galleon Group fund worth $16.4 million. Less than a year later, his stake in the fund was wiped out.

headline: I’ll Have Another’s Long Ride
text: It is in years like this one, with a Triple Crown on the line, that the Belmont Stakes truly lives up to its august nickname, the Test of the Champion. In more than a century of American horse racing, only 11 horses have passed this singular exam to earn their place among the sport’s immortals.

headline: U.S. Aides in Israel Give Assurances About Iran
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and his senior advisers have said little publicly about Iran since the resumption of negotiations over its nuclear program in April, preferring to let the diplomats hash out the issues in the hope that tensions with Tehran can be managed, at least until the election in November.

headline: Prize or Prejudice
text: BRITAIN’S prestigious Orange Prize, awarded exclusively for fiction by women writing in English without regard to nationality, has just now completed its 17th year. And while the prize is lauded for its international reach and has never been disparaged for choosing to bar translated work, once again the annual clamor erupts: how can such a circumscribed honor be deemed legitimate? Why only women?

headline: The Age of Unsatisfying Wars
text: Washington

headline: U.S. Attacks, Online and From the Air, Fuel Secrecy Debate
text: WASHINGTON — In recent years, the United States has pioneered the use of two innovative weapons, drones and cyberattacks, that by many accounts have devastated Al Qaeda and set back Iran’s nuclear effort.

headline: California’s Nonpartisan Primary Shows Independents to Be in Short Supply
text: LOS ANGELES — For those who hoped that an open, nonpartisan primary in California would bring in a new wave of independent candidates and voters, Tuesday’s primary might have felt like a splash of cold water. Turnout remained stubbornly low, and the vast majority of candidates who advanced to the fall election were registered Republicans and Democrats.

headline: Talk of Higher Office Swirls Around Wisconsin Governor in the Spotlight
text: WAUKESHA, Wis. — Two years ago, Gov. Scott Walker was a county executive, little known outside the Milwaukee area. By Tuesday night, after surviving a bitterly fought recall election, he was taking congratulatory calls from some of the top names in Republican politics, including Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate; Al Cardenas, chairman of the American Conservative Union; and Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia, who leads the Republican Governors Association.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 6, 2012

headline: Finding Hockey in Siberia, or in This Case, NBC Sports Network
text: The World Series, Super Bowl and N.B.A. finals are all televised on traditional broadcast networks.

headline: Opponents of Gay Marriage Face Tougher Test in Washington State
text: OLYMPIA, Wash. — Evenly matched ballot fights over same-sex marriage have been about as rare in American politics as transits of Venus. Opponents have won by a knockout in state after state, with voters consistently preferring to define matrimony as a compact only for heterosexuals.

headline: After Cabinet Officials, Next on the Docket for Pakistan’s Chief Justice Is His Son
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The gleaming, marble Supreme Court building in Pakistan’s capital has been the stage for several high-intensity dramas this year, as senior judges have called politicians, government officials and even military commanders to account. But the proceedings on Wednesday saw the court move in an entirely new direction, when the chief justice summoned his own son to answer corruption allegations.

headline: Model for Success Shows Its Faults
text: MIAMI

headline: Things I Saw — No. 14
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Europe’s Woes Give Democrats a New Line of Attack
text: WASHINGTON — In American politics, being European is bad again. But these days, President Obama and the Democrats, not the Republicans, are holding up their allies across the Atlantic as the poster children for bad policies.

headline: If Only Our Leaders Had Mariam’s Guts
text: IN THE NUBA MOUNTAINS, Sudan

headline: Bill Pushes for Increase in Wages
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. tried to give new vitality to the issue of the federal minimum wage on Wednesday, coming at the debate with a fresh angle: that raising it might encourage Americans to spend more and, thus, help stimulate the nation’s struggling economy.

headline: A Stay of Execution
text: Doing what law and justice required, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio on Tuesday granted a two-week reprieve to Abdul Awkal, who had been scheduled to be executed Wednesday morning. Mr. Awkal, who was convicted of killing his estranged wife and brother-in-law in 1992, has a long history of severe mental illness and has been found mentally incompetent by three courts in the past 20 years.

headline: Spain Holds a Trump Card in Bank Bailout Negotiations
text: BERLIN — The bargaining has begun over a deal to rescue Spain’s ailing banks, confronting Europe with urgent choices about whether to try to enforce onerous bailout terms on Madrid as the crisis spreads to the region’s largest economies.

headline: College’s True Cost
text: The Obama administration is rightly pressing colleges to bring clarity to the often misleading and unintelligible financial aid letters that many send out to newly admitted students. The White House’s announcement that 10 colleges and state university systems have agreed to create user-friendly financial aid letters is encouraging, but more will obviously need to be done.

headline: Unions, at Center of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Suffer a New Setback in Its Outcome
text: Labor unions led the failed effort to recall Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, and their defeat in Tuesday’s election was a significant setback to organized labor’s political clout in both symbolic and tangible ways.

headline: Mosquito Coast
text: A warm winter and wet spring. Fading memories of the last frost, whenever that was. The sun rising early and setting late, throwing shadows over steaming pavement puddles, murky birdbaths, brimming gutters and stagnant storm drains.

headline: Two in Dispute Over Control of Archie Comic Company Reach Settlement
text: The embattled co-chief executives of Archie Comic Publications, the company in Mamaroneck, N.Y., that publishes Archie and other comics titles, settled their long-simmering dispute for control of the family-run company on Wednesday, though some shareholders indicated that they will seek a change in leadership.

headline: France Brings Pension Age Down for Some
text: PARIS — France intends to lower the legal retirement age from 62 to 60 for a small class of workers, the government announced Wednesday, maintaining a campaign pledge by the newly elected president, the Socialist François Hollande, and partly undoing a major change by his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy.

headline: Is Fiction Changing, for Better or Worse?
text: Is “summer reading” now just “reading”? Have novels become more entertaining, and less of a cultural touchstone or a political voice?

headline: DNA Blueprint for Fetus Built Using Tests of Parents
text: For the first time, researchers have determined virtually the entire genome of a fetus using only a blood sample from the pregnant woman and a saliva specimen from the father.

headline: In a Moment of Levity, Obama and Romney Poke Fun at Politics
text: With the presidential campaign turning personal and rancorous, especially after the flashpoints of a disappointing jobs report and the Wisconsin recall fight, there have been few moments of harmony between President Obama and Mitt Romney.

headline: Selected Poems by Natasha Trethewey
text: Poems by Natasha Trethewey, the newly named poet laureate.

headline: New Laureate Looks Deep Into Memory
text: The Library of Congress is to announce Thursday that the next poet laureate is Natasha Trethewey, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of three collections and a professor of creative writing at Emory University in Atlanta. Ms. Trethewey, 46, was born in Gulfport, Miss., and is the first Southerner to hold the post since Robert Penn Warren, the original laureate, and the first African-American since Rita Dove in 1993.

headline: Rules Are Made to be Broken
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — We all know the poem memorized in our youth to help us with one of the oddities of the English language, and today Joe Krozel offers us a cute puzzle that reminds us that even rules of spelling can be broken.

headline: First Lady Keeps Career, but Choice Stirs Unease
text: PARIS — The companion of the new French president has finally found a role for herself, but her choice is getting mixed reviews.

headline: Judge Is Said to Identify Officer Accused of Hitting Him
text: Queens prosecutors and a police internal affairs unit that investigates brutality complaints are trying to determine whether a police officer accused of hitting a State Supreme Court justice in the throat and assaulting a handcuffed man committed a crime, officials briefed on the case said on Wednesday.

headline: Woman Who Died at Bosh’s Home Identified
text: The Miami Beach police released the identity of the massage therapist who collapsed at the home of Miami Heat player Chris Bosh on Monday afternoon and died late that night at an area hospital. She was Chautele Mia Cooksey, 41, who managed Channels of Light Life Center in Miami. The cause of Cooksey’s death has not been determined. Foul play is not suspected.

headline: Deportations Continue Despite U.S. Review of Backlog
text: After seven months of an ambitious review by the Obama administration of all deportations before the nation’s immigration courts, very few of them have been halted, disappointing immigrants President Obama hopes to court for his re-election bid.

headline: Iran Threatens Delays in Nuclear Talks
text: Iran raised the possibility on Wednesday of delaying or canceling the resumption of nuclear talks with the big powers, scheduled in less than two weeks, because of what it called dithering by the other side in holding preliminary meetings aimed at ensuring some success.

headline: Student, 17, Is Shot in Brighton Beach
text: Four suspects were arrested and charged after a 17-year-old high school student was shot in the back on Wednesday near his Brooklyn school when he apparently tried to thwart a group of armed men trying to rob another student, the police said.

headline: Judge Rejects Move to Delay Chesapeake’s Annual Meeting
text: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) — A federal judge denied a shareholder request to postpone the annual meeting of Chesapeake Energy on Wednesday, clearing the way for the large natural gas producer to convene the shareholder’s meeting on Friday as planned.

headline: After Bumpy Stretch, Stable Start for Nova
text: After blowing a four-run lead against the Los Angeles Angels, after his fourth ungainly start in a row, a stretch in which he had a 6.47 earned run average, Ivan Nova pointed the finger at himself. “I’m not pitching good,” he said then.

headline: What Will You and Your Children Read This Summer?
text: June 7 is the beginning of the official summer reading season, at least as far as Motherlode, The Learning Network, The Choice blog and Room for Debate are concerned. We’re all posting and discussing our summer reading plans. Room for Debate is hosting a discussion on how fiction is changing: is all reading now “summer reading”? The Choice has “College Admissions Books for Your Reading Pleasure.” And all day, we’ll be posting tweets and retweets with the hashtag #summerreading. (Twitter handles @KJDellAntonia, @NYTMotherlode, @kschulten,  @NYTimesLearning, @roomfordebate and @nytimescollege).

headline: Mets Are Sloppy Once Again, but Lethargy Dooms Them
text: WASHINGTON — Manager Terry Collins was not compelled to speak to his players after the Mets’ cringe-inducing, error-strewn loss here on Tuesday night. There had been worse games, he reasoned, and his players always seemed to bounce back, anyway.

headline: Tracing Kings’ Run Toward Cup to a Scrappy Team of a Different Kind
text: LOS ANGELES — For Bob Wall, the first captain of the Los Angeles Kings, watching his hockey descendants play for the Stanley Cup on Wednesday night compounds the personal significance that June 6 has had for 48 years.

headline: Most Regions Experienced Modest Growth
text: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserve’s 12 districts, according to survey results released by the Fed on Wednesday. The survey is based on information collected on or before May 25.

headline: Democrats’ Comments Spark Tax Cut Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans pounced Wednesday on disputed comments from Bill Clinton and a former senior Obama economic adviser, claiming that the Republican push to extend all of the Bush-era tax cuts beyond the 2012 expiration date has support at the highest levels of the Democratic Party.

headline: Tseng Follows Sorenstam as She Pursues Another Major
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Yani Tseng, the top-ranked female golfer in the world and the defending champion at this week’s L.P.G.A. Championship, acknowledges that she is motivated by chasing L.P.G.A. records. She also says that the voice she still hears in her head is that of the Hall of Famer Annika Sorenstam.

headline: Up From the Depths of Pulp and Into the Mainstream
text: Martians, robots, dinosaurs, mummies, ghosts, time machines, rocket ships, carnival magicians, alarming doppelgängers who forecast murder and doom — the sort of sensational subjects that fascinate children are the stuff of Ray Bradbury’s fiction. Over a 70-year career, he used his fecund storytelling talents to fashion tales that have captivated legions of young people and inspired a host of imitators. His work informed the imagination of writers and filmmakers like Stephen King, Steven Spielberg and James Cameron, and helped transport science fiction out of the pulp magazine ghetto and into the mainstream.

headline: San Diego and San Jose Lead Way in Pension Cuts
text: While the eyes of the nation focused on Wisconsin, where Gov. Scott Walker brushed back a recall attempt by critics of his move to strip most public-sector unions of their collective bargaining rights, a pair of less noticed local elections Tuesday in California could have more immediate ramifications for struggling state and local governments and for organized labor.

headline: A Space Shuttle’s Final Voyage
text: The space shuttle Enterprise made its way up the Hudson to its new home at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum.

headline: No Hollywood Ending: Devils Avoid a Sweep
text: LOS ANGELES — Zach Parise, the Devils’ captain, found a glimmer of hope in a conversation with his father before Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Florida Defends Search for Ineligible Voters
text: MIAMI — Saying the state would not stop trying to scrub the rolls of ineligible voters, Florida’s election chief told the Department of Justice on Wednesday that Florida was not violating any laws.

headline: Seeking to Clear Roadblocks to Loan Repayment
text: With the default rate steadily rising among the nation’s 36 million student loan borrowers, President Obama is seeking to ease the repayment process by streamlining enrollment in the income-based repayment program, which helps low-income borrowers by capping monthly payments at 15 percent of their discretionary income, and 10 percent in 2014. Fewer than 700,000 borrowers are enrolled in the program, in part because registration is complicated. But beginning Sept. 30, Education Secretary Arne Duncan said Wednesday, most borrowers will be able to electronically import data directly from the Internal Revenue Service onto their application, letting them complete the application at one sitting, without going through their loan servicer. Mr. Duncan said the new process could avert “a significant percentage of defaults.”

headline: Canada: Police Link Body Parts to Murder Victim in Montreal
text: The police said Wednesday that they were confident that a hand and a foot mailed to two schools in Vancouver, British Columbia, came from a man who was killed and dismembered in Montreal. The police in Montreal said the packages were mailed from that city, and other factors indicated that they were some of the remains of Lin Jun, a Chinese student. Luka Rocco Magnotta, a Montreal resident, is in a Berlin jail awaiting extradition to Canada on several charges, including first-degree murder.

headline: China: Foreigners Barred in Tibet
text: Several travel agencies in China said Wednesday that foreigners were banned from traveling to the Tibet Autonomous Region, the Chinese name for central Tibet, for at least June. The agencies said they had been told of the ban recently. One agency said the ban was expected to last until September, while another said there was a chance the ban could be lifted by July. In late May, two Tibetans set themselves on fire in front of the Jokhang, the holiest temple of Tibetan Buddhism, in the center of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, to protest Chinese rule. One man died. Those self-immolations were among at least 38 that have taken place in Tibetan regions since 2009. Foreigners were barred from Tibet from late February to early April, a period that coincided with the anniversary of large protests against Chinese rule.

headline: Eugene Ferkauf, 91, Dies; Restyled Retail
text: Eugene Ferkauf, the founder of the E. J. Korvette chain of discount department stores, whose 1950s strategy of low prices, quick turnover and high volume helped shape today’s retail landscape, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: A Tour of Foursquare’s Redesigned App
text: Foursquare, the mobile app that lets people share their whereabouts with friends, has a brand-new look. On Thursday the company released an overhauled version of its application, built entirely from scratch. It is designed to turn the company’s rich trove of data and location information into a handy guide that can be used to navigate a familiar or foreign city.

headline: Rather Than Share Your Location, Foursquare Wants to Suggest One
text: Two years ago, Foursquare was the star of the New York start-up scene. Celebrities and major brands embraced its mobile app, and companies like Facebook and Yahoo were eager to buy it.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: An Ugly Rash
text: The Challenge: A woman develops a fever and an itchy, bright red rash on her torso and face while camping in Vermont. Can you figure out what’s making her sick?

headline: Thunder Headed to N.B.A. Finals After Knocking Out Spurs
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — If this was the last stand of the San Antonio Spurs, it was a valiant one, befitting a team from the Alamo city. But across as tense and furious a night of 48 basketball minutes as we have seen this N.B.A. playoff season, the Spurs’ aging legs failed to match the intensity of their resolve.

headline: Chinese Companies on an Overseas Shopping Spree
text: HONG KONG — Chinese companies went on an overseas shopping spree in the first three months of the year, with the value of outbound deals rising 118 percent, to $21.4 billion, from the period a year earlier, a study released on Thursday showed.

headline: Rosa Guy, 89, Author of Forthright Novels for Young People, Dies
text: Rosa Guy, a Caribbean-born writer known for her unflinchingly direct novels for young people about black life in urban America, died on Sunday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Not Afraid to Talk About Race
text: Hey, I heard that: “Oh, no, the black columnist is writing about race, again.”

headline: The Kings Let Their Chance Slip Away
text: LOS ANGELES — Excitement and anticipation permeated the atmosphere around Staples Center on Wednesday before Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals. The Los Angeles Kings needed one more victory to win the first Stanley Cup in their 45-year history.

headline: Putting Chinese Students to the Test
text: HONG KONG — They’ve been at it for years now, cramming for China’s annual college-entrance exam, some of them hooked up to oxygen canisters and intravenous drips of amino acids during late-night and weekend study marathons. Their parents hire special tutors, force the kids into educational boot camps in the summer and promise lavish gifts of cash and cars for good results. Housekeepers and nannies with college degrees come at a huge premium. Some girls take contraceptives or get hormone injections to make sure they won’t be distracted by getting their period during the exam.

headline: Can India ‘Fix’ Afghanistan?
text: As the United States winds down its military engagement in Afghanistan, optimism is growing about the role India can play to stabilize and develop the country.

headline: 12 Potential Stars for Euro 2012
text: A glance at the odds provided by European bookmakers for who will be named player of the tournament at Euro 2012 offers something of an insight into who fans are likely to be lauding when the event ends in Kiev on July 1. Cristiano Ronaldo, Franck Ribéry, Mesut Özil, Robin Van Persie, Wayne Rooney, Xavi. They are the elite of the elite, and they’re all listed.

headline: News Quiz | June 7, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Celebratory Air at Obama Event for Gay Rights Supporters
text: LOS ANGELES – Nearly a month after President Obama announced his support for same-sex marriage, on Wednesday night he got a rousing reception and at least $2.5 million at a gala of gay rights supporters and a private, celebrity-studded dinner afterward.

headline: Panetta Visits Afghanistan Amid Mounting Violence
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta arrived in Afghanistan on Thursday after the deadliest day for civilians this year, caused in part by a NATO airstrike the day before in which Afghan officials say 18 women and children were killed.

headline: Survey Finds Gloomy Attitudes Toward Retirement
text: PARIS — People in the United States and Europe are increasingly pessimistic about their financial prospects for retirement, as cash-strapped governments face pressure to cut social programs and raise retirement ages, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

headline: Syrians Bar U.N. Monitors From a Massacre Inquiry
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The Syrian conflict escalated to a dangerous new level on Thursday when government troops and their civilian supporters blocked unarmed United Nations monitors from investigating a massacre of farm families, prompting sharp denunciations of Damascus from diplomats who have struggled vainly to find a workable, consensus solution to the crisis.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 7, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “One Week on a Mississippi Steamboat Cruise.”

text: WHO was Ray Bradbury?WHO are some of the authors whose works Mr. Bradbury read instead of going to college?

headline: Photos to Provoke a Conversation on Race
text: In a society where many people don’t feel comfortable talking about race, Hank Willis Thomas insists on making art about race.

headline: Will There Be a Meaningful Volcker Rule?
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Do You Have a Job?
text: For many young people in America, steady work is far from guaranteed. A new study shows that only one of six high school graduates is now employed full time, and although 73 percent think they will need more education, only half say they will enroll. Are you now employed? What jobs have you had in the past? Do you think you could find work after high school, if you choose not to attend college?

headline: Pakistan’s Chief Justice Removes Himself From Panel Investigating His Son
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Amid accusations of conflict of interest, Pakistan’s chief justice announced on Thursday that he was removing himself from a panel investigating corruption accusations against his son and announced the formation of a two-member bench to look into the claims.

headline: The Drone-Happy President
text: Coming on the heels of a much-discussed article detailing the United States’ extensive drone program, the strike that killed Al Qaeda’s deputy leader, Abu Yahya al-Libi — and about 15 other people — in Pakistan on Monday is reinforcing long-standing concerns.

headline: Blogging a Day Devoted to Summer Reading
text: Updated |  June 11

headline: Counting by Murders
text: MONTREAL — One hundred fifty-five thousand seven hundred and eighty-eight. That, according to new research by the Venezuelan criminologist Fermín Mármol García, is the number of murders committed in Venezuela since 1999.

headline: Insanely Delicious Recipes From Simon Hopkinson
text: There are chefs who cook for notoriety, or for their own gratification, and there are those who cook for the pleasure of others. Those of the second type certainly cook to make a living, but they’re motivated to guarantee that their customers have real pleasure, as opposed to demonstrating their own brilliance. Simon Hopkinson is a first-rate pleaser, a chef who was never after recognition but one who wanted to produce terrific food his customers would love. He’s best known as the founding chef of Bibendum, the London restaurant started by Terence Conran in 1987 and recognized as one of the restaurants that marked the end of that city’s postwar cooking slump.

headline: A Drinker’s Guide to Dublin
text: I’m often told that I should visit a city unknown to me, branch out a bit, widen my horizons and all that. Instead, I return to Dublin as often as possible. Its familiarity is a comfort, but the city holds enough surprises to remind me that there’s always some corner I haven’t explored, a pub I haven’t tried.

headline: How Do You Live Knowing You Might Have an Alzheimer’s Gene?
text: It seemed as if it would be a perfectly ordinary occasion, that hot August day in 1959. Three generations of a large Oklahoma family gathered at a studio in nearby Perryton, Tex., to have a photo taken of the elders, 14 siblings ranging in age from 29 to 52. Afterward, everyone went to a nearby park for a picnic.

headline: The Design of ‘Prometheus’
text: A look at designs for the film with commentary from the production designer Arthur Max.

headline: Bank of England Maintains Interest Rate and Stimulus Program
text: LONDON — The Bank of England decided on Thursday to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low as the British economy struggles to recover amid the government’s austerity program and troubles in the euro zone.

headline: Romney Raises More Than Obama in May
text: 1:09 a.m. | Updated  The revised version of this post is available here.

headline: When Coughlin Turned Down the Giants
text: Tom Coughlin’s contract extension was expected. (It’s also to be expected that some fans will call for him to be fired if he goes 6-10 next season.)

headline: Stone Links: Robot Right and Wrong
text: Driverless cars may be just around the corner, but who do we blame if they cause an accident? An article in the Economist argues that the proliferation of robots, now in heavy use by the military and increasingly by civilians, demands that we reconsider long-held concepts of agency and autonomy in order to develop a “machine ethics.” Sorting out this new landscape may well involve asking the kind of questions experimental philosophy is currently asking about everyday moral intuitions. And at the very least, ethicists and engineers will have to get used to the idea of working closely together. The article also suggests it will be necessary “to determine whether the designer, the programmer, the manufacturer or the operator is at fault” if something goes wrong. But if responsibility can ultimately be assigned to a human being, its unclear why we would need to scrap the good old fashioned moral system we already have in place. If we can’t blame the robots, why bother developing a system in which they’re accountable?

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Goldman Sachs Expected to Name Fewer Partners  |  As Goldman Sachs shrinks, its elite inner circle will also be getting smaller. The Wall Street firm is expected to name fewer than 100 new partners this fall, one of the smallest classes in recent years, according to people briefed on the matter but not authorized to speak on the record.

headline: New Poll: The Supreme Court and the Health Care Law
text: More than two-thirds of Americans hope the Supreme Court will overturn some or all of the 2010 health care law, according to a new poll conducted by The New York Times and CBS News. Just 24 percent said they hoped the court “would keep the entire health care law in place.”

headline: New Jersey Is Sued Over Cap-and-Trade Reversal
text: Since Gov. Chris Christie pulled New Jersey out of the multistate carbon trading system known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative last year, supporters of the program have been clamoring for a reversal of the decision.

headline: The Long, Hot, Dry Wait
text: “For others to know India and her people, they have to know the monsoon,” the Indian novelist Khushwant Singh told The New York Times in 1978. “The monsoon is the most memorable experience of our lives.”

headline: Italian Police Detain Suspect in Fatal School Bombing
text: ROME — Investigators in the southern Puglia region said on Thursday that they had detained a suspect in a school bombing that killed one student and injured five at a Brindisi school three weeks ago.

headline: China Cuts Lending Rate as Its Economic Growth Slows
text: HONG KONG — Faced with a sharply slowing economy, weak exports and faltering investment, China’s central bank unexpectedly announced Thursday that it would cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point.

headline: Once More Unto the Galactic Void
text: If you grew up in the 1970s, you may have a dim memory of “Chariots of the Gods,” an international best seller by Erich von Däniken full of dubious speculation about extraterrestrial influences on ancient earthling civilizations. The book, a kind of space age “Da Vinci Code,” inspired a goofy German documentary and, if memory serves, some earnest, anxious debates among sixth-grade protogeeks who shall remain nameless.

headline: No Nomination, but Paul Predicts Strong Contingent at G.O.P. Convention
text: Representative Ron Paul may be the most libertarian of the Republicans who ran in the 2012 primaries, but he is encouraging his supporters with delegate estimates that veer toward liberal.

headline: Live Blogging the French Open
text: Thanks to some odd scheduling, Thursday is the first day of the 2012 French Open on which only one court will be used for singles. And what a day it should be.

headline: Two Carriers to Combine Mobile Forces in Britain
text: BERLIN — Telefónica and Vodafone said on Thursday that they planned to combine their wireless phone grids in Britain and jointly build a superfast network to keep pace with the market leader, Everything Everywhere, a joint venture of T-Mobile and France Télécom.

headline: Can Iran Play a Part in Syria Solution?
text: LONDON — As Western leaders on Thursday denounced the latest reported massacre in Syria, moves were afoot to bring Iran into international efforts toward a peaceful resolution of the conflict.

headline: No School: What Are Your Children Doing Today?
text: There is no school today because of Brooklyn-Queens Day, but some parents are out marching and protesting what they call an over-emphasis on testing.

headline: That’s News to Him: Aaron Sorkin on ‘The Newsroom’ and His Steve Jobs Screenplay
text: LOS ANGELES — When we last left Aaron Sorkin, he was discussing the creation of his coming HBO series, “The Newsroom.” In these final excerpts from that conversation, in his office at the studio here, Mr. Sorkin (who is the subject of an article this week) talks about balancing the writing of the new show with film projects like “The Social Network,” as well as future assignments like a musical about Houdini (written with Stephen Schwartz, the composer of “Wicked” and “Pippin”) and a screenplay about Steve Jobs, adapted from Walter Isaacson’s best-selling biography about that Apple co-founder.

headline: The English Are Waiting for a Triple Crown Winner, Too
text: Though American racing fans have been waiting for a Triple Crown since 1978, the English have them beat. No horse has won the English Triple Crown for colts since 1970.

headline: For a Broadway Producer, a Time to be Acknowledged
text: Sitting at his usual table in the Cafe Edison, a Broadway hangout on 47th Street known to its regulars as the Polish Tea Room, Emanuel Azenberg had assorted feelings about the honor he would soon receive.

headline: Message in a Tennis Ball
text: Dear Diary: It was so lovely on a Sunday afternoon to literally stumble upon a reminder of childhood as it was before every New York 10-year-old had a cellphone and Facebook became the default method of communication.

headline: Thursday Reading: College Admissions Books for Summer Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Ray Bradbury’s Long Shadow, and a First Lady’s Journalism
text: Ray Bradbury, who conjured up life on Mars, virtual reality and, perhaps most shockingly, a world without books, died on Tuesday at age 91. His was a prolific professional writing career – that produced novels, short stories, a screenplay and plays — that spanned 70 years, Gerald Jonas writes. The impulse began in childhood, he wrote in an autobiographical essay for The New Yorker. “It was one frenzy after one elation after one enthusiasm after one hysteria after another,” he wrote, noting, “You rarely have such fevers later in life that fill your entire day with emotion.”

headline: Do You Expect Europe’s Problems to Affect Your Business?
text: This week The Times reported that an increasing number of American companies are warning that sales in Europe are slowing — and that the situation could get much worse. “Prospects for the European economy darkened in recent days,” Nathaniel Popper wrote, “as surveys showed that manufacturing across the euro zone contracted in May and the unemployment rate climbed to a record 11 percent.”

headline: At a House Hearing, a Focus on Argentine Bonds
text: The House Financial Services Subcommittee on Capital Markets is scheduled to hold a hearing later on Thursday on what it has titled “The Need to Protect Investors From the Government.”

headline: Daily Report: Squeezing More Data Into Spectrum
text: Cellphone carriers like AT&T and Verizon say they are worried about running out of the radio spectrum that carries wireless calls and data, and they want the government to give them more chunks of it. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Thursday’s New York Times, a number of companies are developing technology that could change the whole spectrum game by using radio frequencies more efficiently.

headline: Another Week for Mayer at Top of Charts
text: John Mayer’s “Born and Raised” (Columbia) topped the Billboard album chart for a second week, but that was not a huge accomplishment, since sales were anemic all around. Mr. Mayer needed to sell only 65,000 copies to hold onto the top slot, the smallest number for a No. 1 album since Feb. 2011, when Nicki Minaj’s “Pink Friday” was on top after selling only 45,000. Overall, album sales are down 3 percent since January compared to the same period last year.

headline: Dramatic Rush From the Beat of Delicate Hearts
text: ONE of the happier stories of the Broadway season, to be capped on Sunday night with the annual presentation of the Tony Awards, was the wealth of fine new plays. There’s a story behind that story: the continuing importance of Off Broadway as the cultivating ground for America’s best dramatists. All four of this year’s nominees for best play — “Clybourne Park,” “Other Desert Cities,” “Peter and the Starcatcher” and “Venus in Fur” — were first produced Off Broadway.

headline: Seeing Things | Arcana’s Next Chapter
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Bernanke Offers No Clear Sign of New Action
text: WASHINGTON — Lackluster jobs data and storm clouds on the economic horizon have not yet convinced Federal Reserve officials that growth is slowing, nor that they should respond, the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Thursday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Smithsonian: To Mark Twain, San Francisco was all about bushels of tiny, coppery Olympia oysters at the Occidental Hotel. The delicate, slow-growing oysters (Ostrea conchaphilia) vanished long ago from polluted Bay Area waters but have been brought back from near extinction, and cultivated as a labor of love in Puget Sound. — Glenn Collins

headline: For Safety, Ballet Between Human and Killer Whale Loses Some Intimacy
text: MIAMI — The electrifying in-water duet between trainer and killer whales at SeaWorld will never be quite the same after a judge ruled recently that animal trainers must be better protected from the fearsome mammals during performances.

headline: Fast-Paced Thieves Reinvent the Wheel Crime
text: It was before dawn on Monday when a New Rochelle patrol officer spotted a car carrying two men suspected in a series of thefts in the area. He flicked on his lights. The suspects sped off, beginning a chase that ended in the Bronx, when their car slammed into a bank of parked cars, killing one of the men and injuring the other.

headline: How Do You Like Bill Clinton in Your Corner?
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama seeks re-election, he has one advantage that Bill Clinton did not have as president in 1996: a popular Democratic predecessor to vouch for him — Mr. Clinton. The former president had only Jimmy Carter, who remained a political pariah.

headline: Premier League Managers: Euro 2012, and More
text: Managers in England’s Premier League say that Spain, the defending world champion, will successfully defend its European championships title in Poland and Ukraine, with 73 percent of respondents picking La Roja to win again.

headline: Business Day Live | June 7, 2012
text: Nasdaq tries to quell anger over bungled Facebook I.P.O. | I.B.M. makes deal with New York City to increase solar energy usage. | Cutting pensions in California.

headline: New Buyers for Venerable London Power Station
text: LONDON — SP Setia and Sime Darby, two Malaysian property investment concerns, agreed on Thursday to buy London’s Battersea Power Station out of bankruptcy for $618 million, and plan to turn it into apartment buildings.

headline: Best Buy Chairman Leaving Early
text: Management upheaval continued at Best Buy, as its founder, Richard Schulze, said Thursday he would leave the board earlier than expected.

headline: Making Sense of Morgan Stanley’s Derivatives Moves
text: As regulators and lawmakers take a closer look at derivatives, Morgan Stanley is trying to figure out what to do with $50 trillion of such financial instruments.

headline: Low Interest Rates Crimp Retirement Plans, Survey Finds
text: Rising pessimism about the course of the economy, along with low interest rates and increasing health care costs, are squeezing Americans’ retirement plans, a new survey finds.

headline: Business Day Live: Anger Over Facebook Claims
text: Nasdaq tries to quell anger over Facebook’s flawed initial public offering. I.B.M. makes a deal with New York City to increase solar energy usage. Cutting pensions in California.

headline: Thunder and Reign
text: In the end, it all looked so logical, preordained even. The Thunder winning the N.B.A.'s Western Conference felt like a coronation, a changing of the guard that could not have been more official if the Spurs had passed them a baton. This was the way it was supposed to be when this loopy, lockout-delayed season started, the Thunder coming of age, the talented young team finally working its way to the top.

headline: Beatles Museum in Hamburg is Kaput
text: And in the end, the profits you take are a function of the sales you make. But without enough paying visitors, a German museum dedicated to the memorabilia of the Beatles and situated on the Hamburg street where the band played some of its earliest shows is planning to close at the end of the month, The Guardian reported.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Finding My Cancer Style
text: One year ago, almost to the day, I asked my hairdresser to cut off 16 inches of my hair. It was a pre-emptive strike. A few days later I would be admitted to the oncology unit at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan to undergo chemotherapy to treat leukemia. Everyone knows that chemo takes your hair. I wanted to take control of what I could before the poison did its damage. But I left the hair salon in tears, my braids in a plastic bag.

headline: Resort Report | Lanvin
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Southfork Revisited
text: A new version of “Dallas,” the long-running series that redefined the parameters of prime-time melodrama, will have its premiere on TNT on June 13.

headline: Not a Dream: More ‘Dallas,’ Aging Intact
text: LINDA GRAY will slap you across the face if you ask nicely.

headline: Jobs Tracker Holds Steady
text: This week’s economic data have brought few surprises, and The New York Times weekly jobs tracker shows no change: Moody’s Analytics forecasts average monthly job growth of 157,000 in the six months leading up to Election Day.

headline: Imagine a Pollution Monitor That Checks Your Vital Signs
text: A bus just passed by. I think I have a headache.

headline: All Hail ‘Heidi’: Beyond Feminism but Still a Dream
text: THE day after my new play, “Rapture, Blister, Burn,” began previews Off Broadway I received a Facebook message from Wendy Wasserstein’s former assistant, a fellow playwright named Jenny Lyn Bader. Jenny had been in our first audience and wanted to tell me how much she had enjoyed the play. She said she wished Wendy were here to see me “taking up where ‘The Heidi Chronicles’ left off.”

headline: After Elimination, Spurs Tip Their Hats to the Thunder
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The hug came as the clock struck zero and the roars and streamers inside the Chesapeake Energy Arena cascaded from the rafters. A week after they appeared invincible, time had run out on the San Antonio Spurs, and as Tim Duncan embraced Kevin Durant near midcourt, the Thunder’s future had officially begun.

headline: A Heart Quandary
text: What does it feel like when the defibrillator implanted in your chest detects a sudden change in heartbeat, an arrhythmia, and delivers a high-voltage shock to return the heart to a normal pace?

headline: Book Report: ‘A Great Aridness’
text: Ari Phillips, who’s pursuing a master’s degree in global policy studies and journalism at the University of Texas, Austin, sent this fine Dot Earth Book Report after reading “A Great Aridness” in preparation for a two-month reporting trip this summer exploring energy use and climate change in the Southwest. You can read more about his project here and follow him on Twitter @re_ari.

headline: Police Make 9 Arrests at March Supporting Protests in Quebec
text: Updated, 5:02 p.m. | The police arrested 9 people in Manhattan on Wednesday night after a crowd of about 300 set out from Washington Square Park, declaring their support for students in Quebec, who have been on strike since February to protest tuition increases.

headline: Bear Stearns Investors Settle Claims for $275 Million
text: A group of Bear Stearns shareholders who claimed to have been hurt by the investment bank’s deteriorating health agreed on Wednesday to settle its claims for $275 million, four years after the firm was sold to JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Barnes & Noble Argues Book Settlement ‘Punishes Consumers’
text: Barnes & Noble has added to the chorus of objections to the Justice Department’s proposed settlement with several major book publishers, releasing a statement on Thursday calling the settlement damaging to the industry.

headline: In Audi E-tron Program, Pure Electrics Surrender Some Charge to Plug-in Hybrids
text: Reports circulated this week saying that Audi planned to jettison certain vehicles in its E-tron electric-vehicle program because of high development costs and low projected demand, particularly in Europe. The automaker, however, offers an alternative scenario: It couldn’t cancel the cars because their production plans never existed.

headline: Head of Institute of International Finance to Step Down
text: Charles Dallara, the managing director of the Institute of International Finance, announced on Thursday that he was stepping down.

headline: Morning Walkabout – 6/7:  Delta’s Chief, Unfiltered, and Training With Cosmonauts
text: Delta C.E.O. Sits Down for a Chat The chief executive of Delta Airlines advocates a national airline policy that wouldn’t increase regulation but would “let free markets work” and justifies passing some of the cost of transporting luggage onto its travelers, among other things, in a National Public Radio interview. (NPR)

headline: John Irving: By the Book
text: What book is on your night stand now?

headline: Nasdaq Plan Comes Under Fire at Industry Conference
text: Nasdaq’s plan to compensate investors for the flawed debut of Facebook’s shares was called “illegal” and “shameless” at an industry conference held in New York on Thursday.

headline: Good Golly, Miss Molly
text: I’m in Austin for this:

headline: Former Card Counter’s New Start-Up Helps Measure Productivity
text: In Silicon Valley, there’s a theory called the “10x engineer,” which holds that the best engineer at a company is 10 times more productive than the average engineer.

headline: Krueger Advances to Junior Semifinal
text: PARIS – Eighth-seeded Mitchell Krueger of Aledo, Tex., population 1,726, defeated Max de Vroome of the Netherlands, 6-2, 6-1, to gain the semifinal round of the French Open junior boys championship on Thursday.

headline: Business Day Live | Nasdaq Settlement
text: June 7, 2012 — Nasdaq tries to quell anger over bungled Facebook I.P.O.

headline: ‘Frankenstein’ Comes Alive in the App Store
text: An iPad app by Inkle Studios and Profile Books based on Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” drew some rave reviews for its sophisticated choose-your-own-adventure approach when it was released in April. Now a second ambitious interactive take on the classic monster novel has jolted to life in Apple’s App Store, courtesy of the New York Public Library.

headline: ‘Frankenstein’ Comes Alive in the App Store
text: An iPad app by Inkle Studios and Profile Books based on Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” drew some rave reviews for its sophisticated choose-your-own-adventure approach when it was released in April. Now a second ambitious interactive take on the classic monster novel has jolted to life in Apple’s App Store, courtesy of the New York Public Library.

headline: Ballistic in the Baltics
text: I’m hearing from various sources that my rather mild-mannered post on Estonia has generated a vitriolic response from the nation’s president. I’m not going to try to track the thing down.

headline: Image of the Day: June 7
text: A shareholder waits to attend Reliance Industries’ annual general meeting in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Still Too Raw to Eat Meat
text: One evening, as I sprawled on our sofa reading a book, I heard my husband rummaging through the kitchen cabinets. There was a clang as he removed a skillet from the pile of pans, nested together like children’s stacking toys. This was unusual. Since he’d gotten sick a few months earlier, I was the one who cooked. Puttering around our small kitchen and preparing meals comforted me; it was the one small routine that remained consistent when everything else was falling apart.

headline: The Martian Eco-Chronicles
text: So, we’ll go no more a roving So late into the night,Though the heart be still as loving, And the moon be still as bright.

headline: Just One Look | Thakoon
text: The designer Thakoon Panichugal talked about two things at his resort presentation: cake frosting and the recent Fred Wilson show at the Pace Gallery in New York. What he showed were pretty jacquard dresses with acidic pastel stripes, a number of leather and silk mash-ups, a series of longer, more fluid floral pieces (jumpsuit included) and this look: a Caribbean blue dress with an elastic waist, deep V and sporty, perforated sleeves. (In black it was quite edgy and architectural.)

headline: The Untraditional Origins of a New Southern Comfort Ad
text: At first glance, there would seem to be little in common between Southern Comfort liqueur and Dannon Oikos Greek yogurt. But Southern Comfort is joining Dannon Oikos in running commercials created through a crowd-sourcing initiative rather than by a traditional advertising agency.

headline: Lovely Flies, and Flies in Love
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week’s image.

headline: Charter Schools Prepare for a New Regime at City Hall
text: Supporters of charter schools rallied at City Hall Wednesday with a message for those who want to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has been a supporter of charter schools. “Mayoral candidates, we are here and we vote,” Kathleen Kernizan, the mother of two students in the Uncommon Schools chain, boomed. “Do not ignore us.”

headline: Tickets Available for Maurice Sendak Memorial
text: A limited number of tickets to a memorial service next week for Maurice Sendak are being made available to the public. The service will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, June 12, in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. People interested in tickets can send an e-mail to Sendakmemorial@gmail.com. There is a limit of two per request, and those seeking tickets will be notified by e-mail.

headline: Video: Nasdaq’s Facebook Fallout
text: The Nasdaq OMX Group plans to set aside up to $40 million to settle disputes with investors over issues caused by technical problems in Facebook’s initial public offering, but the action has not made everyone happy. Michael J. de la Merced and Catherine Rampell discuss.

headline: Election Forecast: Obama Begins With Tenuous Advantage
text: The first look at the 2012 FiveThirtyEight presidential forecast has Barack Obama as a very slight favorite to win re-election. But his advantage equates to only a two-point lead in the national popular vote, and the edge could easily swing to Mitt Romney on the basis of further bad economic news.

headline: Pfizer Confirms Spinoff of Animal Health Unit
text: Shares in Pfizer were up slightly on Thursday after the drug maker made the entirely unsurprising announcement that it planned to take its animal health unit public rather than sell it to a potential buyer.

headline: Pep Boys Affirms It Is Not on the Block
text: Pep Boys, which last week ended a proposed $1 billion sale to the private equity firm Gores Group, is not looking to pursue another deal any time soon.

headline: Far-Right Politician in Greece Slaps Rival on TV
text: ATHENS — Politics has been a rough-and-tumble affair here this year, but mostly in a metaphorical sense until Thursday, when a male legislator from an ultraright political party attacked two rival legislators on a live television talk show, both of them women, throwing water in the face of one and slapping the other in the face repeatedly.

headline: Breaking It Down: Murray vs. Ferrer
text: When you step on court to play a tennis match, you don’t play one match – you actually play two.

headline: Scion FR-S and Subaru BRZ Are Recalled for Error in Owner’s Manuals
text: 4:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: A New ‘Vanya’ for the Living Room
text: It began with a bottle of mescal, a hillside in Utah and a copy of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya.” The impromptu reading among a small group of friends ended some hours later, the theater director Sam Gold recalled recently, with “me in tears and my head cradled on Annie’s lap.”

headline: Lively Morgue Tumblr numbers 61 to 70
text: Lively Morgue Tumblr numbers 61 to 70

headline: Summer Styles | Minding the Gap
text: A look at who’s staying cool and looking cooler this season.

headline: The Ins and Outs of the Doctor’s Day
text: The inpatient wards and the outpatient clinic are part of the same hospital where I work, but they are like different planets.

headline: App Smart Extra: What Apple and Google Get Right
text: In my valedictory App Smart column this week, I offer a few parting thoughts about improvements I’d like to see from the mobile apps industry.

headline: A Painting Only You Can See
text: Four years before he died, the Austrian novelist and playwright Thomas Bernhard wrote one of his funniest works, “Old Masters,” a bitter comic tale of a musicologist named Reger who has spent every other day for 30 years visiting the same room at the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, planting himself on the same settee and looking at the same portrait, “The White-Bearded Man,” by Tintoretto.

headline: Senate Advances Farm Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday voted to advance a farm bill that will set the nation’s nutrition and agriculture policy for the next five years.

headline: So Sue Them
text: Florida’s governor, Rick Scott, is itching for a fight with the Justice Department. As The Miami Herald reported on Wednesday, he’s refusing a federal demand to stop purging his state’s voter rolls. His office sent a defiant letter that, as the Herald put it, “all but dares the Justice Department to sue Florida.”

headline: Japan Society Names New Gallery Director
text: At an annual dinner on Thursday night the Japan Society will formally announce that Miwako Tezuka, the associate curator at the Asia Society, has been named the new director of the organization’s gallery, making her its first Japanese chief. The current director, Joe Earle, is retiring in September. “I am honored to join Japan Society and to work with its dedicated staff to create exciting exhibitions and related programming that stir the imaginations of the New York audience and people the world over,” Dr. Tezuka said in a statement. Motoatsu Sakurai, the president of the society, said, “Miwako is a well-regarded curator, who has an intimate knowledge of the New York art scene and a broad perspective of Japanese art in the global sphere.” The nonprofit Japan Society was set up to encourage mutual understanding between the United States and Japan, and its gallery has been mounting exhibitions since 1971.

headline: Lauryn Hill Charged With Tax Evasion
text: Federal prosecutors have charged the singer and actress Lauryn Hill with failing to file income tax returns for three years during which she earned more than $1.6 million.  Prosecutors in New Jersey said in a court document that Ms. Hill, an eight-time Grammy Award winner, did not file tax returns in 2005, 2006, and 2007, even though she owns and operates four corporations, tours as a musician and earns royalties from recordings and films she has made.  She is scheduled to appear before a magistrate in federal court in Newark on June 29 to answer the charges.

headline: TimesCast | U.N. Observers Blocked
text: United Nations observers say that they were prevented from entering the site of another reported massacre in Syria, and that government forces shot at them.

headline: Out of War, a Symphony
text: War, with its many horrors and heroes, has been a powerful muse to composers from Beethoven to Copland to Glass. Now comes a trio of American artists who hope to create a major classical composition about war, based on the experiences of American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Moving From Square One on Nuclear Waste
text: The idea that the proposed Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository in Nevada is dead has not gone down well in Congress, where some Republicans are trying to allocate new money to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission so it can revive its evaluation of the site’s suitability. But at a Senate subcommittee hearing on Thursday, some supporters of the civilian power industry said it was time to move on.

headline: Experienced Hand Points to the Finals
text: Oklahoma City

headline: A Small Raptor at Home in the Big City
text: A male American kestrel soared high above Amsterdam Avenue on a recent Friday afternoon, clutching a smaller bird in its talons.

headline: Jeff Biegel Plays Beethoven
text: Jeffrey Biegel, a concert pianist, performs Beethoven’s “Choral Fantasy.”

headline: Townsend and Bouchard Advance in Doubles
text: PARIS – Top-seeded Taylor Townsend of Stockbridge, Ga., and Eugenie Bouchard of Canada gained a semifinal berth in the French Open junior girls’ doubles championship with a 6-0, 6-3 victory over Ioana Loredana Rosca of Romania and Camilla Rosatello of Italy.

headline: CHI 2012 Conference Q&A With Joseph Konstan
text: Eight weeks after the annual South by Southwest Interactive conference, Austin again became a hub for creative technologists. The CHI 2012 conference is an annual gathering for researchers who focus on human-computer interaction (HCI). CHI 2012 is produced by ACM, the Association for Computing Machinery, a professional society for computing researchers.

headline: Playwrights’ Collective to Disband After Production of Ruhl Work
text: 13P, a New York City collective of 13 writers who teamed to produce one play by each member, will mount its final show in July before disbanding after nearly nine years, the organization announced on Thursday. The last production will be a chamber music adaptation by the playwright Sarah Ruhl and the composer Todd Almond of Ms. Ruhl’s 2001 farce, “Melancholy Play,” which will be performed July 18-27 at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn. The director will be Davis McCallum (“February House”), and the actors will be David Greenspan, Erik Lochtefeld, April Matthis, Sarah Tolan-Mee, and Amy Warren.

headline: Just One Look | Donna Karan
text: “Inspired by the elements, designed for the city,” Donna Karan is dressing women for parties with resort. At the presentation earlier this week, formal, celebration-ready cocktail dresses dominated the collection’s 43 looks, many of which came decorated with large pieces of quartz, crystal or jet (as pins on jackets and swinging as earrings). Here, a slimmer silhouette (long and lean is in this season) offers a new kind of tuxedo dressing.

headline: Would You Want To Read Your Fetus’s DNA?
text: It’s now possible, although still financially impractical, to sequence the DNA of a baby from nothing but a blood sample from the pregnant woman and a saliva sample from the father. The New York Times reporter Andrew Pollack reported that genome scientists from the University of Washington say they “took advantage of new high-speed DNA sequencing and some statistical and computational acrobatics to deduce the DNA sequence of the fetus with about 98 percent accuracy.” For now, it’s expensive ($20,000 to $50,000) and still inaccurate, but:

headline: Boston Mayor Loves His Celtics, Especially K.J. and Hondo
text: Lots of people are climbing on the Boston Celtics’ bandwagon these days, what with their 3-2 lead over the Miami Heat in the Eastern Conference finals. The mayor of Boston, Thomas Menino, would like to be one of them. Just as soon as he can figure out who plays for the team.

headline: Syrian Activists Post Videos Said to Show Latest Massacre
text: As my colleagues Rick Gladstone and Alan Cowell report, United Nations monitors in Syria said they were prevented Thursday from verifying reports of a mass killing the day before in a village in central Hama Province.

headline: Hurd Sells Oracle’s Cloud in the Oracle Style
text: Oracle entered the cloud computing business in a big way on Wednesday and did so in its typical fashion — with an overpowering host of hardware and software, plus bluster, misdirection and trash talking. The technology, while more of a work in progress than Oracle wants to say, appears solid.

headline: Lively Morgue Tumblr numbers 71 to 80
text: Lively Morgue Tumblr numbers 71 to 80

headline: Bonnaroo: Let the Tie-Dyed Whimsy Begin
text: NASHVILLE — I see late nights ahead. I’m headed to the 11th annual Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., where 700 acres of former farmland sprout considerably more than 100 bands, dozens of comedians and 80,000 people to hear them over the next four days.

headline: Bryans Reach Doubles Final
text: PARIS – Shootout is the word that best describes high-stakes doubles in international tennis. Americans Mike and Bob Bryan are the shootout kings, bouncing, darting and pulling the trigger on winning shots.

headline: The CW Is the First to Finish ‘Upfront’ Sales
text: CW has become the first of the five big English-language broadcast television networks to complete the bulk of its advertising sales ahead of the 2012-13 season in what is known as the upfront market.

headline: Ask About the Greek Elections
text: Greeks will return to the polls on Sunday, June 17, amid growing doubts about the euro’s viability in its current form, worries that Greece won’t be able pay its bills next month, and rising speculation about how the country would go about leaving the euro and starting to print its own currency.

headline: Belmont's Bugler
text: Sam Grossman, the official bugler for the New York Racing Association playing the flourish that announces each race.

headline: Slanting Towards Partisanship
text: Over on the Politico Web site, the media columnist Dylan Byers had an important post earlier this week about how different cable news operations covered the Wisconsin returns. It underscored, beautifully, the partisan slants of these operations. And, in doing so, it reflected what I believe is a broader problem—and a growing one—with the way too much news is served and consumed these days.

headline: TimesCast Politics: An Election Forecast
text: New election model from the FiveThirtyEight blog | Portrait of a Latino voter | Visiting Mitt Romney’s neighborhood in California.

headline: At Gupta’s Insider Trial, a Star Goldman Witness and Charts
text: 8:13 p.m. | Updated

headline: Columbia Accepts Assad Aide Who Was Helped by Barbara Walters
text: The young aide to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria who received an endorsement from the longtime television correspondent Barbara Walters was accepted into a prestigious graduate program at Columbia University, the university said on Thursday.

headline: How Did Errani Win? Smart Adjustments
text: Sara Errani continued her string of upsets at the French Open as she toppled Samantha Stosur in a match that featured huge momentum swings, shrewd tactical adjustments, and a tricky, swirling wind on Court Phillippe Chatrier. While Stosur’s game plan was to use her big kick serve and top-spin forehand to dominate her service games, Errani had to make two key adjustments to negate Stosur’s big game.

headline: Thakoon
text: Resort 2013

headline: Deep River Cleanup
text: The business strategist Carol Roth evaluates an illustrative pitch for a technology start-up.

headline: Boehner Aide Shifts to Planning for Lame-Duck Session
text: Barry Jackson, chief of staff to Speaker John A. Boehner, has left his post to take on the task of managing the epic lame-duck session anticipated at the end of the year. His new title: senior counselor for long-term planning.

headline: Madrid Leans on Its Troubled Banks to Buy Its Bonds
text: LONDON — While the Spanish government was able to sell all the bonds it wanted to on Thursday, it mostly sold to the usual buyers: Spain’s increasingly fragile banks.

headline: Elizabeth Taylor Never Visited This Italian Cliff
text: Parts of Jess Walter’s mosaic novel “Beautiful Ruins” take place in a remote Italian coastal town in 1962. Other pieces can be found in present-day Hollywood. Still others are scattered in Edinburgh; Seattle; and Florence, Italy, not to mention Portland, Ore.; Truckee, Calif.; and Sandpoint, Idaho. “Beautiful Ruins” also includes wittily wrought excerpts from its various characters’ writings, among them a novel, a memoir, a play and a movie pitch. The screenplay idea is about the Donner party (“Donner!”). It might just be the worst screenplay idea Hollywood has ever known.

headline: Errani and Sharapova Advance to Final
text: PARIS — Born 10 days apart and once boarders at the same Florida tennis factory, Maria Sharapova and Sara Errani will play each other for the first time as professionals in the French Open final on Saturday.

headline: Rick Perry, Back on Stage
text: FORT WORTH, Tex. – More than four months after withdrawing from the Republican presidential race, Gov. Rick Perry addressed thousands of conservative Texans on Thursday here at the state Republican Party convention, poking fun at his own gaffe-filled campaign and throwing his support behind his onetime rival Mitt Romney.

headline: Know That Venue: The Aquatics Centre
text: Aquatics Centre

headline: Just One Look | Proenza Schouler
text: When the Proenza Schouler designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez ask themselves, which they often do, “How would our girl wear this?” 9 out of 10 times the answer is, “with jeans.” Proenza Schouler will open its first store this July on Madison Avenue, designed by the architect David Adjaye, who also did the showroom and offices. Resort finds McCollough and Hernandez not with their heads in the clouds on some fantasy surfing safari but thinking on their feet. In other words: “How are we going to keep our store filled?” The answer: wearable pieces steeped in the DNA of the brand, including tweeds (like the coat pictured here), tie-dyes, lace and, yes, an entire range of denim pieces “their girl” will definitely want to snatch up.

headline: The Man With the Lips That Call Race Fans to Life
text: If you have watched horse racing at Aqueduct, Belmont or Saratoga racetracks in the past 20 years, chances are good that you have heard Sam Grossman playing the flourish announcing each race on his three-foot-long trumpet.

headline: Thoughts on Water From Young New Yorkers
text: New York City has announced the latest winners of an annual competition in which students reflect on water through art and poetry.

headline: Multiple Facebook Accounts for Suspect in Canadian Killing Case
text: OTTAWA — The Internet — and particularly, Facebook — is playing a critical role as the police in Montreal build their case against Luka Rocco Magnotta, who is accused of killing Jun Lin, a Chinese student, and then dismembering his body and mailing parts to the offices of political parties here.

headline: Bringing Table Tennis to the Schools
text: Supporters gathered Wednesday night to raise funds to bring table tennis to more middle and high schools in the city.

headline: Meet the New Ethicist: Chuck Klosterman
text: Following a murderer’s row of guest Ethicists — Betsey Stevenson, Andrew Light, Cheryl Strayed and the poet laureate Philip Levine — a new full-time Ethicist starts this Sunday. He is Chuck Klosterman, who may be familiar to you for any number of reasons. He wrote for our magazine in years past, including this memorable 2002 profile of Billy Joel, and more recently, he was instrumental in the start of ESPN’s Grantland, Bill Simmons’s excellent sports journalism Web site (the magazine profiled Simmons last year). Chuck’s eighth book, “I Wear the Black Hat,” will be published next year. Now living in Brooklyn, he is from Wyndmere, N.D. Like other longtime Klosterman fans, I first heard of him when his first book, “Fargo Rock City,” was published to immediate acclaim in 2001.

headline: Halfhearted Half Brother
text: My father recently died. His daughter from his first marriage (which ended several years before his marriage to my mother) has made efforts to stay in touch with me since his death. I have never had a direct relationship with my half sister. She has had a difficult life, missing out on many of the advantages my sister and I enjoyed. I want to be sympathetic to her struggles, but though I’ve tried, I’ve never felt an attachment to her. She has been an intermittent presence and not always a pleasant one. Is it ethical to decide not to carry on this relationship? Or does someone else’s desire for connection, which perhaps comes out of a strong wish to be part of a family, outweigh my personal preference? J.G., NEW JERSEY

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Twitter Knows When You Sleep, and More
text: Twitter knows when you nap. At least its engineers think they have a pretty good idea when you nap, because those are the few times when you’re not pouring your heart out in 140-character bursts.

headline: Fed Wants U.S. Banks to Adhere to Stiffer International Rules
text: The Federal Reserve proposed on Thursday that the country’s banks adopt a broad package of international regulations aimed at making the global financial system more resilient to shocks.

headline: Theater Talkback: Numbers That Stopped the Show on Tony Night
text: The Tony Awards have promised us more live performances than ever this year, with even musicals that were shown little affection in the nominations, like “Godspell” and “Ghost,” getting their moment before the television audience. (The television audience that isn’t watching the finale of “Mad Men,” that is.) The long-since-shuttered “Hairspray” is reportedly being resurrected via cruise ship, so seasick-prone viewers should remember to take their Dramamine.

headline: Mitt Romney, His Money and Identity Politics
text: Earlier today, Joe Scarborough railed against a Times spread on Mitt Romney’s $12 million house in La Jolla, Calif. His particular gripe was that we didn’t give comparable coverage to John Kerry’s personal wealth in 2004. “Did The New York Times ever dispatch reporters to John Kerry’s homes, because John Kerry is worth a lot more money, obviously, than Mitt Romney?” Actually, we did. Here’s one. Here’s another. And another.

headline: Campaign Aims to Restore Weather-Abused ‘Lightning Field’
text: Walter De Maria’s magical “Lightning Field,” in the remote desert of western New Mexico, is showing its age. Years of rough weather have damaged the work, which was commissioned by the Dia Foundation and completed in 1977.

headline: Dickey Extends His Scoreless Streak
text: WASHINGTON — R. A. Dickey chaperoned the Mets to a 3-1 victory over the Washington Nationals on Thursday afternoon, solidifying the notion that his season of steady effectiveness was flowering into a full-blown renaissance.

headline: Loving Flowers and Vines to Abstraction
text: In 1970 the Metropolitan Museum curator Henry Geldzahler mounted a big survey of three decades of New York art. It included two rooms of work by Ellsworth Kelly: one of abstract painting and sculpture, and another given over entirely to drawings of plants. It was the first time Mr. Kelly had shown any of these drawings, which he had been making since his first big artistic breakthrough in late-1940s Paris.

headline: A Bridge’s Golden Years
text: WHEN it opened on May 27, 1937, the Golden Gate Bridge was an engineering and economic marvel linking California’s northern counties with the rest of the state. But within a few years it was something more: a universally recognized symbol, the romantic embodiment of the City by the Bay.

headline: Romney Says a Deceptive Obama Has Had His Chance
text: ST. LOUIS — When a candidate sets out the Teleprompters, it is a sign he will skip his usual stump speech and reach for more gravitas.

headline: As Al Qaeda Loses a Leader, Its Power Shifts From Pakistan
text: The death this week of Al Qaeda’s deputy leader, Abu Yahya al-Libi, is likely to accelerate a shift in power from the group’s dwindling leadership in Pakistan to its increasingly autonomous franchises, particularly the branch in Yemen, whose focus on attacking American interests is sure to continue, according to United States counterterrorism officials.

headline: Racial Gap in Life Expectancy at All-Time Low
text: The gap in life expectancy between whites and blacks in America has narrowed, reaching the lowest point ever recorded, a new study shows.

headline: Crooning and Swinging in a Night of Reinvention
text: “Sweet & Low Down: How Popular Standards Became Jazz Classics,” the Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at the Allen Room on Wednesday evening, was a botched opportunity. The notion of exploring how popular standards have been torn apart and reinvented by artists like Miles Davis, Gil Evans, John Coltrane or Betty Carter, who used them as platforms for expanding the song form, is exciting enough to deserve an entire series of concerts.

headline: Excerpt: 'Medieval Play'
text: A scene from Kenneth Lonergan's new play at Signature Theater.

headline: Guiding the Orchestra With His Violin and His Baton
text: During intermission at the New York Philharmonic concert on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, I ran into a friend from college and asked how she had enjoyed the first half.

headline: Parents and Students Say 'Enough' to More Testing
text: At a rally that resembled a street carnival, complete with scarecrows and blowing bubbles, students and their parents said they would sit out the field tests being conducted by Pearson, the company that writes the state standardized tests.

headline: Peter Gleick Reinstated at Pacific Institute
text: The water and climate expert Peter Gleick, a scientist who masqueraded as a board member of a conservative organization to gain access to its confidential financial information, has been reinstated as president of the Pacific Institute, the environmentally minded think tank that he founded.

headline: United States Offers Rewards in Hunt for Somali Militants
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United States government announced on Thursday $33 million in rewards for information on the location of top terrorist suspects in Somalia in an effort to get residents there to turn in leaders of the Shabab militant Islamist group.

headline: Learning to Play the Cards She Is Dealt
text: “WILL he have a normal family?” Andrea asked.

headline: Boston Redefines Its Offense Through Ball Control
text: The Boston Celtics haven’t merely veered off script in the Eastern Conference finals, they’ve set its pages ablaze and scattered the ashes on South Beach. What looked to be a brief formality of a series has turned out to be anything but; not only have the mighty Miami Heat tumbled into a legitimate crisis, but the Celtics -– once a team far too lopsided to be considered a serious title contender -– have somehow created a stable, efficient offense out of thin air.

headline: Be Slow to Cast the First Stone
text: When my husband lost his job, I fired our once-a-week cleaning woman to streamline expenses. Since then, I’ve noticed that several pieces of expensive, irreplaceable jewelry belonging to my parents are missing. This woman continues to work for my neighbor, and I am tempted to cross the street and confront her. But I worry that I may be making a mistake, and the jewelry is hiding in an attic trunk or basement. Any suggestions?Barbara, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

headline: IDC Says Nokia Shipped 2.2 Million Lumia Phones Last Quarter
text: 6:44 p.m. | Updated  Adding clarification that the Lumia 900 began shipping last quarter.

headline: When It’s Time for the Neighborhood Children to Go Home
text: Just say it.

headline: Nicoletta, a Lower-Crust Option from Michael White
text: The chef Michael White’s attachment to Wisconsin pizza goes back to his childhood. He said his first restaurant job was at a pizzeria in his hometown, Beloit, Wis., when he was 16. But his father, Gerry White, who is in New York this week from Beloit, said he recalled that his son, who is now 40, hung around the place when he was maybe just 6.

headline: Just One Look | Belstaff
text: Is Belstaff the next Burberry? That seems to be the driving ambition at the English company whose heritage rests on the shoulders of a single piece of outerwear, the Trialmaster racing jacket. But the designer Martin Cooper (who happens to be a Burberry alum) has already gone a considerable distance with the brand in a short time. Using the crosshatch pattern on the original jacket’s hardware as a leitmotif, Cooper turned out a resort collection full of clever riffs on the Trialmaster — as a snappy linen jacket, say, or a fitted dress — that will get fashion motors running without any trouble at all.

headline: Among the Autograph Hounds at BEA
text: Thursday, the last day of BookExpo America, the publishing industry’s annual convention, is a relatively light day for author appearances, but the autograph area this morning still looked like a LaGuardia departure lounge during a blizzard. More than half of those in the long, snaking line to meet Kristin Cashore, the author of “Bitterblue,” were seated on the floor, biding their time.

headline: Real Government Spending Per Capita
text: A followup, for the purposes of a project I’m working on, on this post about falling government spending recently. Here are two figures, both in natural logs: overall real government spending per capita, and state and local real government spending per capita, this time in levels rather than changes.

headline: A Parisian Journalist’s Ruthless Liaisons
text: Georges Duroy, the coldblooded social climber who seduces his way to the top of Gallic society in Guy de Maupassant’s 1885 novel, “Bel Ami,” is one of the nastiest pieces of work in French literature. But Robert Pattinson, who plays Georges in the novel’s latest English-language adaptation, seems stuck in the land of “Twilight.” Lowering your gaze and flashing a vampirish glare is not acting, it’s making faces.
