text: Resort 2013

headline: A Spin Around Osaka, Japan
text: After snacking on fried octopus balls, go shopping and wind up floating high above the city.

headline: 36 Hours in Osaka, Japan
text: OSAKA’S concrete canyons and elevated freeways will never win the city any urban beauty contests. But when the ethos of a place is kuidaore — the concept of eating oneself bankrupt — aesthetics don’t much matter. Fittingly, Japan’s third-largest city has no shortage of fine-dining establishments (the city now boasts 108 total Michelin stars, including five three-star restaurants); but the convivial, freewheeling local food culture can just as easily be tapped into at the inexpensive food stalls that line the recently renovated banks of the Dotonbori canal. And when the belly-busting glut becomes too much, Osaka’s top-notch museums and urban parks provide welcome, necessary respite.

headline: A Complex Budget Picture Feeds Reliance on Parent Donations
text: The budgets for each public school that arrive each spring, dictating the degree of austerity for the following year, are almost never seen by parents. They are not pretty, most principals would agree, and they have grown increasingly complicated in the last few years.  Yet parents, as well as their children, soon feel the consequences, as schools turn to the families for everything from donations of toilet paper and hand sanitizers to money, which can total thousands of dollars, to fill gaps in staffing.

headline: When Youthful Training Gets a Payoff Moment
text: At the School of American Ballet Workshop Performances on Tuesday evening the sight of young dancers eating up the stage made a strong case for ballet as the province of their age. Still, the annual performances aren’t only about spotlighting the next generation of talent; they also allow audiences to see repertory with new eyes. At the school, affiliated with New York City Ballet, performances of Balanchine works usually come with a little extra snap and crackle.

headline: Civic Lessons, Public Invited
text: If you’ve been living out of town for the last year — perhaps on a different planet — you might need some back story before heading down to see “Common Ground,” an exhibition of outdoor sculpture and performance by 10 international artists in City Hall Park.

headline: ‘Washington Doesn’t Get Us’
text: If you’re among the Americans who find it hard to understand Arizona, or the connection between patriotism and high-powered weaponry, watch this political ad — and prepare to still be baffled. It’s for Ron Gould, a Republican running for Congress in Arizona’s 4th District. It seems to argue for homegrown border militias and the abolition of Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: A Place of Her Own, No Strings Attached
text: SINCE her graduation from Rutgers University in 2000, Claudia Beqaj has lived in Manhattan, first sharing apartments with roommates and then sub-subletting from a friend.

headline: Digitized Offering Plans Catch On With Developers
text: NEW YORK STATE has postponed a requirement that developers make their offering plans available in a digitized format to prospective buyers, but many developers are making them available anyway.

headline: Thieves of Light, Built by Barbarians
text: LATER this summer, 1 World Trade Center will top out at 1,776 feet. New York will again be proud to have the tallest building in the United States, a new landmark in the race for height. But is that really such a good thing? From the nativity of the skyscraper in the 1860s through its early adulthood in the 1900s, this kind of “progress” was more often denounced than embraced.

headline: Adulthood Calling, to Faraway Minds and Lost Ambition
text: Abe (Jordan Gelber) is a tubby underachiever in his 30s who lives with his parents, sleeping in a bedroom full of action figures, movie posters and other emblems of interminable childhood. In other words he is, in the context of recent American cinema, not unusual. But “Dark Horse” is a Todd Solondz movie, which means, among other things, that Abe is neither a sweet Apatovian schlub nor a stoner saint like the title character in Mark and Jay Duplass’s “Jeff, Who Lives at Home.” He is, instead, an emblem of loneliness and failure, whose cocoon of self-delusion and misplaced vanity is carefully dismantled by the sharp, remorseless tweezers of Mr. Solondz’s sensibility.

headline: Singing Wholesome Lyrics, Depending on Your Ears
text: Lewdness in song is where you find it. And if you’re looking for dirt, it’s everywhere. I can recall being a seventh grader in a church choir surrounded by tittering children embarrassed at having to sing the word “bosom” in a popular hymn. In her new cabaret show, “Into the Garden,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, the radiant Maude Maggart focuses on Michael W. Balfe’s Victorian parlor song “Come Into the Garden, Maud,” based on a poem by Alfred Lord Tennyson.

headline: Beethoven’s Heroic Style in a Tumultuous Sonata

headline: Weeding Out ‘Fake Farmers’
text: THOSE selling freshly laid eggs, organic herbs, Christmas trees, or any other homegrown products in New Jersey may soon have to redouble their efforts if they want to protect the drastically reduced property taxes they pay by using their land for farming.

text: AFTER a long recessionary torpor, an incentive program intended to help communities create affordable housing appears to be on the verge of revival.

headline: Art, Life and Death, Inexplicably Intertwined
text: At a certain point in David Gordon’s “Beginning of the End of the ...” it seems that the dance-theater work will go on forever, repeating its series of interlocking elements in endless permutations: life chasing art chasing life.

headline: The Latest Vibe Moved to Brooklyn
text: For artists New York City has always had unaffordable neighborhoods. Now it has an unaffordable borough, Manhattan. There, in the past, blue-collar areas like Greenwich Village, SoHo and the Lower East Side offered cheap living for the no-collar day-jobbers that most artists were and still are. Rents were such that they could make their work upstairs and show it downstairs.

headline: Using a Dollhouse to Reconstruct a Murder, 77 Years Later
text: Cynthia von Buhler figured the simplest way to make sense of a Depression-era murder that intrigued her was to reconstruct the crime scene.

headline: Just One Look | Calvin Klein
text: Always looking to architecture for inspiration, Calvin Klein’s Francisco Costa chose California modernism, and specifically the Eames house in Los Angeles’s Pacific Palisades, for resort. The contrast between the house’s rigid exterior and softer, more comfortable interior spoke to the designer who, too, balances similar strictness with sumptuousness in his collections. Silhouettes were all very ’70s — tunics and jackets with belts slung low around the hips and modern caftans over cropped pants. The shoes were clomping flat platforms. “It feels sort of groovy,” Costa said of the clothes, with their flowy, relaxed fits and long-over-short proportions. Case in point: this technical viscose dress worn over a black bandeau with pleated pants and a patent version of the platform.

headline: That Tony Pool: Few Sure Bets
text: THE new Broadway musicals “Newsies” and “Once” won’t run the table at the Tony Awards on Sunday the way “The Book of Mormon” did last year or “Billy Elliot” did in 2009, when those hits were runaway favorites in multiple categories. But the 2012 awards ceremony, the biggest night of honors for the Broadway industry, offers something even more fun than singing missionaries and pint-size ballerinas: competition.

headline: What’s Next for Some Tony Nominees
text: You don’t need to be a gossip hound to know how Andrew Garfield will follow up his Tony-nominated role as Biff in the recent Broadway revival of “Death of a Salesman.” As the star of “The Amazing Spider-Man,” the much-promoted movie reboot opening on July 3, he will probably be seen by more people in one day than in his entire, just-completed Broadway run.

headline: Apple Buddies Up With Cheaper Wireless Partners for iPhone
text: Sprint said on Thursday that the iPhone would become available this month on Virgin Mobile USA, its service for prepaid plans, where customers pay for the service as they use it. The cost will be considerably less than the fees  contract customers pay monthly to use an iPhone — once you get past the upfront price of the phone itself.

headline: Accounting Backfired at MF Global
text: Back when I was studying accounting at Columbia University’s business school, the professor had a handy way to determine whether it made sense for a company to recognize revenue: Had it completed the hard task in its business?

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: Stop motion videos are always cool, especially when they’re about shopping. Refinery 29 offers 44 seconds of eye candy (above).

headline: To Singers, Ad Sounds Too Familiar
text: Fans of the band Beach House became excited last month when a new advertisement for Volkswagen was broadcast in Britain. The spot tells the story of a father raising his daughter and featured what sounded like a new song by the Baltimore duo.

headline: Tied by Gender, but Not Much Else
text: Would it seem odd not to mention that all five major exhibitions at the New Museum now are solos by female artists? The museum’s promotional material does not make a point of it, nor are the shows related by some umbrella theme, feminist or otherwise. Unless you are a gender-ratio scorekeeper, it would seem to be irrelevant that the artists in question — Ellen Altfest, Phyllida Barlow, Tacita Dean, Nathalie Djurberg and Klara Liden — are women. They are all variously celebrated artists first. And yet, in ways that are not necessarily obvious, and if only because of the all-female lineup, questions of gender come to the fore.

headline: Approval Rating for Justices Hits Just 44% in New Poll

headline: She’s Almost 30 and Starting Over

As her 30th birthday approaches, Lola (Greta Gerwig), a graduate student living in New York, is dumped by her fiancé, Luke (Joel Kinnaman). The shock waves of this catastrophe reverberate through the rest of the movie, directed by Daryl Wein from a script he wrote with Zoe Lister-Jones.

Eisenhower later this month, a Web site about Washington, dcist.com, reported on Thursday.

headline: Take It From Grandma, Everything Is Groovy
text: To a crowded pantheon of stage and screen matriarchs that includes Mother Courage, Mama Rose and Mommie Dearest, add the name Mama Woodstock, or more precisely, Grandma Woodstock, in the person of Jane Fonda. That isn’t the nickname of her character, Grace, in the comedy “Peace, Love & Misunderstanding,” but it might as well be.

headline: Waters and Supporters Urge Ethics Panel to Share Report
text: Representative Maxine Waters and 68 other House Democrats called on the ethics committee Thursday to release its internal report on its handling of an investigation into possible improprieties by Ms. Waters.

headline: California Dreaming, Ululation And Jazz
text: On Wednesday at the Joyce Theater the Gotham Dance Festival offered New York something that its dance audiences (and critics) rarely see: signs of life from the Los Angeles dance scene.

headline: Martin Puryear: ‘New Sculpture’
text: McKee Gallery

headline: John Heliker: ‘A Tribute’
text: Davis & Langdale Company

headline: Looking for Themselves in Fading Dreams From the Past and Present
text: An indie comedy as endearing as “Safety Not Guaranteed” can seem as deceptively easy to toss off as a foolproof recipe for chocolate chip cookies. Measure, stir, bake and presto, you have instant melt-in-your-mouth goodies.

headline: Tokyo Gas Attack Arrest Reawakens National Trauma
text: SAGAMIHARA, Japan — For two years, the woman who called herself Chizuko Sakurai lived with her boyfriend in a rundown old barn on the far western edge of Tokyo’s sprawl, where tracts of identical suburban homes fade into farms and mountains. She drew little attention, wearing drably colored clothes and no makeup. Neighbors said she avoided eye contact and kept to herself.

headline: Points North
text: Willa Cather once wrote that “a creative writer can do his best only with what lies within the range and character of his deepest sympathies.” By that measure, and any other, Richard Ford is doing his very best in his extraordinary new novel, “Canada,” his first book since “The Lay of the Land” six years ago. Here, Ford is clearly writing within the range and character of his deepest sympathies — in this case, from the point of view of an abandoned 15-year-old boy — and he’s doing it with a level of linguistic mastery that is rivaled by few, if any, in American letters today.

headline: At Another Job Fair, Hope This Will Be the One
text: Linda Baker walked from employer to employer at a job fair in Brooklyn on Thursday, inquiring about opportunities. Ever since being laid off from her construction job three years ago, Ms. Baker, who is in her 40s, has been constantly searching for some kind of work.

headline: A Bit of Dance, a Touch of Heat
text: PEOPLE have been talking about the supposed body-transforming powers of Tracy Anderson for several years. She’s the trainer who has traveled with Madonna, established her roots in Los Angeles and runs a studio there that has become a mainstay for stars like Jennifer Lopez, Gwyneth Paltrow and Courteney Cox. Word spread so quickly about her workouts that Ms. Anderson herself became a celebrity.

headline: ‘Common Ground’
text: Photos from the exhibition of outdoor sculpture and performance in City Hall Park.

headline: Spare Times for June 8-14
text: Around Town

headline: Brooklyn Philharmonic and Yasiin Bey in Bedford-Stuyvesant
text: It’s been quite a year for the Brooklyn Philharmonic. More or less in the space of a single season, a troubled organization has made something of a turnaround, thanks largely to its energetic artistic director, Alan Pierson, who was hired in 2011 and has set about restoring the orchestra to a status worthy of its home borough’s cultural cachet.

headline: Street-to-Street Art
text: A look at the Bushwick art scene.

headline: They’re Running Away With the Circus
text: The humor is similar, but the scale is bigger, faster and brighter in “Madagascar 3: Europe’s Most Wanted,” this summer’s installment in DreamWorks Animation’s billion-dollar-grossing franchise. The images, styled after Miroslav Sasek’s illustrations, still charm, and the movies’ returning directors, Eric Darnell and Tom McGrath, keep their machine humming. A third director, Conrad Vernon, has joined them, perhaps to accommodate the heightened pyrotechnics.

headline: Wait, the Bus Is Leaving Without Him
text: “Double Trouble” is an action-comedy that stars Jaycee Chan, the son of Jackie Chan, in the type of role his father perfected, and for that alone it has some curiosity value. But that value, it turns out, isn’t worth the price of admission.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 8, 2012
text: The New York Times film critics on “Prometheus,” “Dark Horse,” and “Lola Versus.”

headline: Obama Criticizes Republicans Over Student Loan Rates
text: LAS VEGAS — After a day of fund-raisers in California, President Obama on Thursday traveled again to swing-state Nevada for the one event of his two-day Western trip that was designated as an official appearance, as opposed to a campaign stop. But it again illustrated that everything is political in an election year.

headline: For Incoming International Students, a College Checklist for June
text: In March, The Choice introduced a series called Counselor’s Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track as they go through the admissions process.

headline: Once a Criminal, Hard to Turn Back
text: A moralizing message sits awkwardly atop a crime story in “For the Love of Money,” a film that can’t quite capitalize on the big names it has in relatively small roles.

headline: At Graduation, Ohio High School Seniors Remember Fellow Students Killed in Shooting
text: Thomas M. Lane III, the 17-year-old accused of fatally shooting three students and wounding two others in the cafeteria at Chardon High School in Ohio last February, is scheduled to be arraigned Friday on charges of aggravated murder and attempted aggravated murder.

headline: Exploding Ephemera
text: “Lay on Ground, Light Fuse, Retire Quickly” and “Do Not Hold in Hand After Lighting” are the recurring warnings on 3,000 vintage firecracker packages for sale on June 22 and 23.

headline: ’70s Troubadour , From Prime Time to Vegas
text: Paul Williams, a singer-songwriter behind 1970s classics like “Rainy Days and Mondays,” “Evergreen” and the “Muppet Movie” anthem, “The Rainbow Connection,” was a kind of Zelig on ’70s prime-time television as well, guest-starring on seemingly everything: “Circus of the Stars,” “Police Woman,” countless “Tonight” shows. Short and bespectacled, he was an unlikely celebrity, but his romance with drugs and alcohol was all too common. After embracing sobriety he largely dropped out of the public eye to rebuild his life and counsel other substance abusers.

headline: Spoiling History at Belmont
text: In 2008, Da’Tara, ridden by Alan Garcia, pulled off a huge upset at the Belmont Stakes, preventing Big Brown and jockey Kent Desormeaux from winning the Triple Crown.

headline: Italy: Man Arrested in School Bombing
text: Investigators in the southern Puglia region said Thursday that they had detained a suspect in a bombing that killed one student and wounded five at a Brindisi school three weeks ago. After hours of interrogation that started on Wednesday, officials said, a 68-year-old fuel vendor from the area was arrested on suspicion of attempted multiple homicides with the intent of terrorism. The authorities later identified the man as Giovanni Vantaggiato. Because the school was dedicated to Francesca Morvillo, who was killed with her husband, Giovanni Falcone, a prosecutor, by a Mafia bomb 20 years ago, investigators had initially investigated links to organized crime. The prosecutor Cataldo Motta said the suspect had admitted to having “economic problems,” but could not explain how that might have prompted him to carry out what Mr. Motta called a terrorist act. “He did not explain, he did not give justifications,” he said.

headline: Pakistan: Judge Quits His Son’s Case
text: Amid accusations of conflict of interest, Pakistan’s chief justice, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, removed himself from a panel investigating corruption accusations against his son and announced the formation of a two-member bench to look into the claims. The day before, the son, Arsalan Chaudhry, testified before his father that rumors that he had accepted bribes worth $3 million to $4 million from a powerful and well-connected real estate developer were untrue. Justice Chaudhry had insisted he could rule fairly in the case, but he stepped aside after mounting criticism that he was hurting the court’s credibility.

headline: After Juneteenth Project Stalls, a Replacement Emerges
text: The Tejano Monument, unveiled in March on the Texas Capitol’s south lawn, stands to honor the state’s early Spanish and Mexican settlers. But for some Texans, it is a reminder of the failed Juneteenth monument project, approved two years before the Tejano Monument.

headline: House Acts to Repeal Medical-Device Tax
text: WASHINGTON — In another assault on President Obama’s health care law, the House passed a bill on Thursday to repeal a new tax on medical devices.

headline: Middle East: Sentence for Former Adviser to Arafat
text: A Palestinian Authority anticorruption court sentenced Yasir Arafat’s former financial adviser to 15 years in prison with hard labor and a $15 million fine, according to the official Palestinian news agency, Wafa. The adviser, Muhammad Rashid, was convicted in absentia of embezzlement of public funds and money laundering from the period when he ran the Palestine Investment Fund. Mr. Rashid has denied wrongdoing in the past. He left the Palestinian territories after Mr. Arafat’s death in 2004, and his current location is unknown. His was the highest profile corruption case to have been dealt with to date by the court in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

headline: A Troubled Silence
text: THE revelation this week of alleged widespread child abuse at the elite Horace Mann School in New York City, most of it occurring during the 1970s and ’80s, is only the most recent instance of men coming forward, many years after the fact, with horrific stories of sexual molesting from their childhood.

headline: Bad News for the Badlands
text: I HAVE good news and bad news from the Badlands of North Dakota, one of our loveliest and most fragile wildernesses. And even the good news is mostly bad: The National Trust for Historic Preservation announced on Wednesday that Theodore Roosevelt’s Elkhorn ranch beside the Little Missouri River, an exquisitely peaceful meadow revered as the cradle of conservation, is one of America’s 11 most endangered historic places.

headline: Hardware at All Hours
text: Nuthouse Hardware, in Kips Bay, is a basement and three floors of nuts, bolts, housewares, do-it-yourself supplies and building materials, with the added bonus of being open all night.

headline: 24 Hours of Nuts and Bolts
text: IT was shortly before midnight on a recent Saturday in Kips Bay, and Third Avenue was teeming with 20-somethings in stilettos and hair gel, ready for a night out.

headline: Italy’s Take on Baseball for the Blind Fosters ‘Sense of Freedom’
text: BOLOGNA, Italy — When Eugenio Brivio first started coaching blind baseball players in 2002, getting across one basic tenet had him stumped.

headline: Can a Politician Win Without Wall Street?
text: How can candidates raise enough money to get elected, without becoming beholden to the rich?

headline: Toughened Up, St. John’s Makes Run in N.C.A.A. Tournament
text: There were times when Jeremy Baltz second-guessed why he chose to play baseball at St. John’s.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: After Setback, Cuomo Weighs New Option for Convention-Casino Complex in City
text: ALBANY — Now that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has abandoned his dream of building the nation’s largest convention center at the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens, he is handling multiple offers from the gambling industry to develop a combination casino and convention center at other sites around New York City.

headline: Portuguese Just Shrug and Go On in the Face of Cuts and Job Losses
text: LISBON — Behind the cheery yellow edifice that is this country’s Finance Ministry, where the news is not so cheery these days, Joaquim Marçalo’s waterfront grill is open for business, any business at all, seven days a week.

headline: Timeline: Islamists in Algeria
text: A history of the Islamic resistance in Algeria, from its roots as a local insurgency to its merger with Al Qaeda.

headline: In Chinese Murder Mystery, Take 2 for Big Scene
text: CHONGQING, China — In the chill of late January, around the time Chinese were celebrating the Lunar New Year, the police chief of this foggy southwestern metropolis pressed Bo Xilai, the ambitious Communist Party official who ruled the area, with evidence that Mr. Bo’s wife had been involved in a murder.

headline: Donations to Key Cuomo Ally Show a Rift Among Unions
text: Backed with millions of dollars in contributions from business, the Committee to Save New York has been Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s most important ally in his battles with public-sector unions over government spending, pensions and teacher accountability.

headline: A Failure of Discretion
text: When the director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, John Morton, said in a June 2011 memo that his agency would focus on deporting convicted criminals and repeat immigration violators rather than noncriminals who pose no threat, he raised hopes of restoring balance to a broken system. He told agents and prosecutors to use “all appropriate discretion” with immigrants who lack criminal records, have deep family ties to this country and are pursuing “legitimate civil-rights complaints.”

headline: In Istanbul, a Showcase for International Artists
text: For 40 years, the Istanbul Music Festival has brought performers from around the globe to evocative settings in Turkey’s cultural capital, and this year is no exception.

headline: Bonnaroo: Wild Girls in Control
text: Bonnaroo got under way on Thursday with wild girls working two varieties of smoldering and letting loose on two tent stages: one with the staccato digital attack of hip-hop; the other with the drones and smears of primitivist rock.

headline: European Championship Favorites Will Be Tested
text: Here is a look at five favorites in the European Championships, which begin Friday and will be played in Poland and Ukraine.

headline: Egyptian Judge Speaks Against Islamist Victory Before Presidential Runoff
text: CAIRO — The president of the association of Egyptian judges said Thursday that they were abandoning their neutrality toward the coming presidential runoff in an effort to guard against an Islamist monopoly of power.

headline: Once-Reticent Investors Join Shareholder Revolts
text: Every spring, corporate chieftains and their boards squash uprisings from a familiar batch of pugnacious investors, a ritual that shields many companies from major change.

headline: In Patz Case, a Confession on an Image of the Child
text: As investigators questioned a one-time bodega worker, Pedro Hernandez, last month about the disappearance of Etan Patz, they showed him a picture of the child.

headline: Miracles in the Clouds
text: Let us now praise famous monuments to quirky genius. The Golden Gate Bridge and the Space Needle are basking in birthdays this year. The bridge is 75, the needle is 50.

headline: She Waited 40 Years to Marry, Then When Her Wife Died, the Tax Bill Came
text: In her apartment just north of Washington Square Park, Edith Windsor ran down a few pieces of simple arithmetic on Wednesday afternoon to explain why she had gone to the trouble of suing the government in what surely are the late seasons of her life.

headline: Arizona Tries to Keep Reins Tight as It Starts Regulating Medical Marijuana
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Soon after health officials announced they would dole out Arizona’s first licenses for medical marijuana dispensaries, Ryan Hurley, co-chairman of the medical marijuana practice at the Rose Law Group here, noticed a common trait among some of the people most eager to enlist his services: They were already in the business in other states.

headline: As Grain Piles Up, India’s Poor Still Go Hungry
text: RANWAN, India — In this north Indian village, workers recently dismantled stacks of burned and mildewed rice while flies swarmed nearby over spoiled wheat. Local residents said the rice crop had been sitting along the side of a highway for several years and was now being sent to a distillery to be turned into liquor.

headline: Antigua, Tiny U.S. Foe With Big Aspirations
text: BRADENTON, Fla. — On the banks of a lake at the IMG Academies here, two members of the Antigua and Barbuda national soccer team were arguing over whose turn it was to hold the fishing rod.

headline: Son’s Cigarette Caused Fatal Fire in Putnam County, Police Say
text: CARMEL, N.Y. (AP) — A man’s flicked cigarette ash probably caused the house fire in this Putnam County town last month that killed his parents and two sisters, the police said Thursday.

headline: Egypt Struggles Toward a President
text: Last month’s first round of presidential voting in Egypt produced two flawed, polarizing candidates: Ahmed Shafik, former President Hosni Mubarak’s last prime minister; and Mohamed Morsi, a functionary of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Barry Unsworth, Writer of Historical Fiction, Dies at 81
text: Barry Unsworth, considered one of the foremost historical novelists in English, who was known for rich, densely textured fiction that conjured lost worlds — those of the Trojan War, medieval Europe and the Napoleonic age, among many others — died on June 4 in Perugia, Italy. He was 81 and had lived in the Umbria region of Italy for many years.

headline: Common Sense on Marijuana
text: Dean Skelos, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, shows a serious lack of good sense in opposing Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s plan to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana in public view. Mr. Skelos’s flippant remark — that the proposal would allow people to “walk around with 10 joints in each ear” — trivializes a serious problem and misrepresents a sound proposal that has broad support from law enforcement.

headline: Behind Belmont Long Shot, a Quirky and Bold Trainer
text: “Dood!” cried the former jockey Jerry Bailey, shaking the hand of Doodnauth Shivmangal.

headline: ‘You’re Likable Enough, Mitt.’
text: Recent political commentary contrasts Mitt Romney’s negative personal image with President Obama’s positive one. Polls report that Obama is more “likable” than Romney, and that his “favorable to unfavorable” ratio is more positive. Other things being equal, it is no doubt better for a candidate to be liked than disliked, but when other things are not equal, historical data suggest that a candidate’s likability is a relatively minor factor in deciding modern presidential elections.

headline: Battling Tight Fairways, Three Tie for L.P.G.A. Lead
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Three players were tied for the lead of the Wegmans L.P.G.A. Championship on Thursday while seven others were one stroke behind.

headline: The Moral Diet
text: In the 1970s, the gift shop at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was an informal affair. It was staffed by about 300 mostly elderly volunteers, and there were cash drawers instead of registers. The problem was that of the shop’s $400,000 in annual revenue, somebody was stealing $150,000.

headline: Ex-Pitcher’s Video Game Company Goes Bankrupt
text: The video game studio run by the retired baseball star Curt Schilling filed for bankruptcy on Thursday, while Rhode Island and federal officials began investigating the operations of the company, which was buoyed by financial support from the state.

headline: Reagan Was a Keynesian
text: There’s no question that America’s recovery from the financial crisis has been disappointing. In fact, I’ve been arguing that the era since 2007 is best viewed as a “depression,” an extended period of economic weakness and high unemployment that, like the Great Depression of the 1930s, persists despite episodes during which the economy grows. And Republicans are, of course, trying — with considerable success — to turn this dismal state of affairs to their political advantage.

headline: The Bills to Nowhere
text: This is now the pattern of business in the House of Representatives: Spend most of the time passing bills designed not to become law but to satisfy the ideological desires of conservative voters. And block laws that actually need to get passed.

headline: Who Should Teach Our Children?
text: As at most colleges, our semester at Notre Dame ends with student evaluations of their teachers. Each time I wonder what the students — and their parents — make of this exercise. “Wait,” I imagine them saying, “we’ve just paid you tens of thousands of dollars in tuition to take courses at your school, and now you’re asking us to tell you if the teachers you hired are any good? If you didn’t already know that they’re first class, you had no right taking our money.”

headline: A Car Shop Promises: Just the Work You Need
text: A NEW commercial for Jiffy Lube, the oil-change chain, opens on a quiet road, where a mechanic working underneath a car at a repair shop spots a woman driving by in an S.U.V.

headline: Another Official Resigns in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — The government of the nation’s capital was in turmoil this week after the chairman of the City Council, Kwame R. Brown, was charged with bank fraud and violating campaign finance rules, a high-profile move by prosecutors that expands a growing circle of defendants in federal investigations.

headline: Man Linked to Saudi Prince Draws 10-Year Term for Rape
text: A member of the traveling entourage of a Saudi prince was sentenced on Thursday to 10 years in prison for the rape of a 26-year-old woman who fell asleep in his room at the Plaza Hotel after a night of barhopping.

headline: Prosecutors in Seabrook Case Can’t Use Just His Last Name
text: At the June 19 retrial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, federal prosecutors may seek to characterize the defendant as a liar or a cheater, as they had in the first trial. What they cannot do, however, is simply refer to him by only his last name.

headline: Molded for Success on Clay Courts
text: PARIS — That Rafael Nadal is not simply great on clay, but historically great on clay, perhaps the best ever on clay, is not an unfamiliar notion. The pertinent question is: What is it about Nadal that makes him dominant on all surfaces but nearly unbeatable on this one?

headline: A West Bank Curfew, but What’s for Dinner?
text: Even the most meticulously prepared cook cannot be expected to cope with all kitchen disasters. A fully stocked spice rack, an ample larder and even a closet full of pickled staples will not necessarily suffice when a curfew keeps you housebound for more than a week with a family to feed.

headline: Queens Thief Didn’t Count on Missionaries
text: The thief who snatched a taupe, buckle-covered bag from a young woman with a glossy black ponytail and designer sunglasses on Thursday afternoon in Queens might have thought it would be an easy crime.

headline: School Rings
text: Administrivial Fun Puzzle Event Alert! The Napa Library Foundation is sponsoring a day of puzzle events — including a crossword tournament — on Saturday, June 30. After a morning session of kid-friendly puzzles and games, and a free afternoon screening of the movie “WORDPLAY”, three-time A.C.P.T. champion Dan Feyer hosts the tournament at the Napa City County Public Library. The tournament will feature three unpublished New York Times puzzles as well as an exclusive Napa-themed crossword created especially for the event. Between the preliminary rounds and the championship round, puzzle experts will lead a Q&A and discussion of crossword solving and construction. Scheduled to appear: Tyler Hinman, Andrea Carla Michaels, Jeremy Horwitz, and moderator Dan Feyer. Visit the Napa Library Foundation website for more information!

headline: Ex-Aide to Senator Pleads Guilty in Scheme That Snared Only Him
text: WASHINGTON — Douglas Hampton came to the Capitol from Nevada six years ago on the coattails of his best friend, Senator John Ensign, to serve as Mr. Ensign’s senior political aide.

headline: Magician Arrested in Series of Brooklyn Bank Robberies
text: A self-described magician and escapist who once set a record for eating a household light bulb in fewer than 34 seconds was arrested and charged with committing a string of Brooklyn bank robberies, the police said Thursday.

headline: The Hundred Years’ War Certainly Did Drag On
text: Bloated, gaseous, archly self-conscious and on occasion truly funny, Kenneth Lonergan’s “Medieval Play” is like a vintage “Saturday Night Live” sketch that won’t die. Imagine a skit from, say, the mid-1970s, in which John Belushi and Chevy Chase portray violent, inept knights clunking around in cumbersome armor and talking about looting and plundering in goofy pseudo-chivalric speech.

headline: No Eviction After Renter Didn’t Pay for 9 Years
text: The state’s highest court ruled on Thursday that a Brooklyn loft tenant who has not paid rent since 2003 could not be evicted because the landlord had not brought the building up to residential standards.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 7, 2012

headline: 3 Men Are Found Dead in BMW Near Columbia U.
text: Three men were found dead on Thursday inside a car parked near the campus of Columbia University after an apparent shooting, the authorities said.

headline: Nadal’s Clay Supremacy
text: Since 2005, Rafael Nadal has dominated on clay, compiling a 221-9 match record and a 34-4 mark in clay court finals

headline: A Rookie, a Mustache and Comeback Visions
text: NEWARK — Adam Henrique, the 22-year-old rookie center who seems to score a big goal whenever the Devils need one, was asked again Thursday about his decision Tuesday to turn his playoff goatee into a playoff mustache. He said he just wanted to lighten the mood.

headline: Obstacles Mar Quest for Arab Dictators’ Assets
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Soon after the revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi began in Libya last year, foreign banks and governments began freezing billions of dollars in assets held by his family and government, just as they had frozen accounts of the toppled governments in Tunisia and Egypt.

headline: Pressing for Leak Inquiry by a Special Counsel
text: WASHINGTON — Calls for a special counsel to investigate leaks of classified information by Obama administration officials gathered momentum on Thursday after the Justice Department’s national security division partly recused itself from the inquiry, apparently because of the possibility that the department might have been a source of some of the disclosures.

headline: Triple Crown or Not? Picking the Belmont Stakes
text: Who will win the Belmont? A half-dozen New York Times staffers offer their thoughts, led by Joe Drape, who writes about racing and would love to see a Triple Crown winner. But he’s not holding his breath.

headline: Bite-Size Previews of Five Euro 2012 Contenders
text: Rob Hughes of The International Herald Tribune has been previewing the tournament all week. In case you’ve missed any of his columns, and with only hours to go before the tournament kicks off, here are slimmed-down versions of five teams to watch:

headline: A Church, and Its Faithful, Both Lost
text: An image, at once arresting and overly symbolic, sums up what’s good and bad about “Corpo Celeste,” the writer-director Alice Rohrwacher’s feature debut: Blindfolded almost-teenagers grope their way around a spartan church sanctuary in Reggio Calabria, Italy.

headline: Teixeira Gets Diagnosis for Persistent Cough
text: Mark Teixeira’s mysterious, lingering cough finally has an identifiable reason. Teixeira visited an ear, nose and throat specialist in New York on Thursday and was found to have nerve damage in one of his vocal cords.

headline: Ex-Catcher Girardi Delivers a Message to Martin
text: After a day off in Detroit, spent ruminating over recent trends with his pitching staff, Manager Joe Girardi called catcher Russell Martin into his office at Comerica Park last Saturday for a short meeting before Martin went behind the plate.

headline: The Only Thing Missing Is a Swamp Monster
text: Refusing to slot comfortably into any recognizable genre, “The Oregonian” teases us with horror and amnesia-mystery conventions without sealing the deal either way. From a commercial standpoint this is more than a little risky, encouraging nonplused critics to dust off the “experimental” tag that sends most moviegoers running for the hills. Yet this first feature from Calvin Lee Reeder (who also wrote the story, such as it is) doesn’t feel like an experiment; it feels like a journey whose destination was firmly predetermined.

headline: The Jets Have California on Their Minds
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Coach Rex Ryan opened his final news conference of the Jets’ voluntary workout period with an equation. Of the 2,211 possible workouts this off-season — multiplying the number of players on the team by the number of workout opportunities — the Jets players completed 2,178 of them.

headline: A Problem of Distribution
text: India holds the second-largest stockpile of surplus grain in the world, after China. Yet advocates say that more than 252 million poor Indian residents reap few benefits and often go hungry.

headline: U.S. Gymnasts in a Jam on the Road to London
text: ST. LOUIS — Martha Karolyi, the woman with the ability to make or break an American gymnast’s Olympic dream, stared stoically out onto the competition floor Wednesday on the eve of the United States gymnastics national championships.

headline: A Part of Chile About to Change Forever
text: Documentaries about the pollution, scarcity and general mismanagement of our planet’s freshwater supply have been popping up with increasing regularity. “Patagonia Rising” is the latest in this alarming subgenre, a beautifully filmed and patiently explained assessment of a proposal to build five hydroelectric dams in the Patagonia region of Chile.

headline: Error and Strikeouts Prevent Yankee Sweep
text: The Yankees started a three-game series against the Tampa Bay Rays earlier this week trailing them by one and a half games in the American League East. They gained a game on them in the series, and taking two out of three over a division rival is an achievement.

headline: Gay Black College Friends Reunite
text: Is “The Skinny” — a movie about five young, gay, black friends — likely to resonate with many viewers who are also young, gay and black? Yes. Is it a good movie? Not really.

headline: Romney Raised More Than Obama in May
text: Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign shot past President Obama’s in fund-raising in May, collecting more than $76.8 million, nearly $17 million more than his Democratic rival.

headline: Opinions of the Supreme Court
text: A New York Times/CBS News poll on Americans’ opinions of the Supreme Court.

headline: James Takes Game 6 Personally
text: BOSTON — In this house of horrors, where his championship dreams died so many times, where his career arc was indelibly dented, where he shed his Cleveland Cavaliers jersey for the final time, LeBron James stepped out, stared into the abyss and scoffed at the darkness.

headline: Corrections: June 8
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Campaigns Blitz 9 Swing States in a Battle of Ads
text: HENDERSON, Nev. — The presidential campaigns and their allies are zeroing in mainly on nine swing states, bombarding them with commercials in the earliest concentration of advertising in modern politics.

headline: Word of the Day | gaunt
text: gaunt •\ˈgȯnt, ˈgänt\• adjective

headline: Qualifying for the Cup Starts Now
text: Two years ago this month, the United States was eliminated from the World Cup in South Africa. Its road to the next tournament, which kicks off two years from Tuesday in Brazil, starts Friday.

headline: India’s Failed Food System
text: “Spurred by agricultural innovation and generous farm subsidies, India now grows so much food that it has a bigger grain stockpile than any country except China, and it exports some of it to countries like Saudi Arabia and Australia,” Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York TImes. “Yet one-fifth of its people are malnourished — double the rate of other developing countries like Vietnam and China — because of pervasive corruption, mismanagement and waste in the programs that are supposed to distribute food to the poor. ”

headline: Scientist Is Reinstated After Deceit
text: A scientist who posed as a board member of a conservative organization to gain access to its confidential information has been reinstated as president of the Pacific Institute, the environmental research organization that he founded in California. The institute said Wednesday in a statement that an independent inquiry had confirmed the account offered by the scientist, Peter Gleick, of the false pretenses under which he obtained documents of the Heartland Institute in February. The documents contained details about the budget, strategy and donors to the institute, which disputes that global warming is under way. The statement said the Pacific Institute’s board of directors had accepted Dr. Gleick’s apology. By saying that its investigation confirmed Dr. Gleick’s account, the institute implicitly backed his assertion that he was not responsible for creating a document labeled a fake by Heartland that was disseminated along with other genuine ones. Heartland, based in Chicago, assailed the announcement as a “whitewash.”

headline: Wrestle-Off in Times Square Decides Final Olympic Roster Spot
text: When Thursday began, of the three men who had a shot at the last spot on the Olympic freestyle wrestling team, Shawn Bunch was most confident in Shawn Bunch.

headline: New Clash in Congress on Gun Case Gone Wrong

headline: Florida: School President Loses Vote
text: The board of trustees of Florida A&M University voted 8 to 4 on Thursday that it did not have confidence in the leadership of the university president, James Ammons. The trustees who voted against Dr. Ammons said they did not believe he could steer them out of a crisis that followed the hazing death of a drum major, Robert Champion, in November. More than a dozen people, mostly students, have been charged in the death. The university also remains embroiled in an inquiry into financial irregularities. Dr. Ammons, whose contract runs through June 2016, vowed to do better. “You have my commitment to fix them and get this job done,” Dr. Ammons said.

headline: Bonnaroo: Getting in on the Act

And as the Cave Singers discovered before their set of bluesy, growly roots-rock, when a drummer starts steadily tapping his kit to make sure it’s coming through, a good part of the audience might start clapping along.

headline: Q. and A. with U.S. National Team Defender Oguchi Onyewu
text: Oguchi Onyewu is one of the few players on the United States national team who can say they have worked in as many countries as the squad’s coach, Jurgen Klinsmann. In a decade in Europe, Onyewu, an imposing central defender who turned 30 last month, has played for clubs in France, Belgium, England, Italy, the Netherlands and now Portugal, where he recently finished a strong first season with Sporting Club of Lisbon. He has played 65 times for the U.S., including appearances in the 2006 and 2010 World Cups, and is a member of the team that will open qualifying for the 2014 tournament this weekend. Onyewu spoke with the Goal blog on Tuesday about playing in Europe, his place on the national team, racism in the sport and why his family gets a good laugh about his soccer career.

It's difficult to document the extent of this spending because the Department of Education tracks only a small fraction of parent fund-raising and spending, leaving many groups to make potentially significant decisions with little official oversight.

headline: India, What Did You Eat Yesterday?
text: Inflation continues to soar in India as the economy cools, raising food prices faster than incomes for many working men and women. Meanwhile, the country’s food distribution system is so fundamentally broken, Vikas Bajaj writes in The New York Times, that most of the massive crops of wheat and grain grown in India never reach the people they are intended for, and tons of food is rotting away.

headline: How Twitter Changed My Life
text: I came to Twitter in the fall of 2008 after finishing my first book, “Become Your Own Boss in 12 Months.” When I tried to set up a Twitter account, I discovered that my name was taken. My book publicist, Cathy Larkin, suggested that I develop a name that would instantly convey what I stood for. We kicked around a few ideas and then she suggested @SmallBizLady, which I loved. And the name just stuck.

headline: Guitars, Groupies and Lots and Lots of Hair
text: IN the 1980s the Sunset Strip — a stretch of Sunset Boulevard in West Hollywood packed with bars and clubs — was the center of the hard-rock and hair-metal scene, spawning bands like Guns N’ Roses, Mötley Crüe and Poison. Based on the Broadway musical, the film “Rock of Ages,” which opens on Friday, starring a leather-pantsed Tom Cruise (at left and right) as the self-destructive, baboon-owning sex god Stacee Jaxx, fondly spoofs the era. It’s 1987, and the boys look like girls, the groupies look like strippers, and the hair is highly flammable. Meanwhile, as a small-town blonde named Sherrie (Julianne Hough) and her aspiring rocker boyfriend, Drew (Diego Boneta), try to succeed amid the sleaze, church-lady protesters are fighting to shut down a club called the Bourbon Room.

headline: He’s a Rainbow | Hiroshi Sugimoto for Hermès
text: “Light is my medium to be investigated,” says the Japanese artist Hiroshi Sugimoto, who spent years chasing bands of prismatic color around his studio in Tokyo and capturing them, with what was for him rapid-fire succession, using a Polaroid camera. In collaboration with Hermès, 20 of the artist’s abstract color studies have been translated into silk scarves in signed, limited editions of seven each. “Couleurs de L’Ombre” (Colors of Shadow), as the collection is called, is a moving tribute to the lowly Polaroid, which faces imminent extinction. (Sugimoto in fact exhausted his last batch of the film to make the images.) Hermès, on the other hand, developed new inkjet technology in order to faithfully recreate the subtle gradations of intense color. Where the original Polaroids are small and precious, the scarves are large — just over 55 inches square — and dynamic, playing with light in ways the artist had never anticipated. Though at around $10,000, you might think twice about actually wearing one. “It’s serious art for me,” Sugimoto says, with a nod to Hermès. “And if it’s serious art, for me, it’s also very reasonably priced.” Available at hermes-editeur.com.

headline: The Opposition in Egypt Splinters and Sputters

While journalists and NGO workers were eating in our living room, demonstrators were contesting recent election results and last week’s verdict against former President Hosni Mubarak and other top officials in his regime.

headline: Up Front
text: Near the end of “Townie,” the flinty-eyed memoir he published last year, Andre Dubus III acknowledged that it wasn’t always easy sharing a name with his father, the renowned story writer Andre Dubus. “I was treated with a vaguely disguised pity,” he writes: “How hard it must be to follow the footsteps of a real master, a writer’s writer, to share his name and probably not his gifts.” Yet the younger Dubus, who reviews Richard Ford’s novel “Canada” on this week’s cover, has been writing for more than a quarter of a century now, long enough to establish his own formidable gifts. In five books — including “Townie” and the novel “House of Sand and Fog,” both of them best sellers — Dubus has more than made a name for himself.

Jenny Craig would appear to be the Willy Wonka of weight-loss regimes, promising the magic of sweets that make you thin; the package also holds a brownie and a puff-pastry twist and a bag of chips. Finally, there are meals, packaged in sky blue: among them, French toast and an egg scramble and macaroni and cheese.

headline: Chinese Activist’s Death Called Suicide, but Supporters Are Suspicious
text: BEIJING — Li Wangyang, one of China’s longest-serving political prisoners, was not the kind of man to go down without a fight. His goal was to shame the government into providing restitution and the medical care he required after successive beatings left him nearly blind and deaf.

headline: Paperback Row
text: BLUE NIGHTS,  by Joan Didion. (Vintage International, $15.) After her husband, John Gregory Dunne, died suddenly of a heart attack in 2003, Didion made out of her bereavement a remarkable memoir, “The Year of Magical Thinking.” “Blue Nights,” a luminous companion volume, traces the author’s efforts to come to terms with a second calamity: the death of her daughter, Quintana Roo, in 2005 at age 39. Moving between recent painful memories and bright family snapshots, Didion’s elegy also becomes a meditation on the passage of time.

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Quinoa Salads With Spring Vegetables
text: I’m always tweaking the way I cook quinoa, and this week I changed my method for basic quinoa. I’d been cooking it sort of like pasta, in 3 parts water, then draining it and letting it dry out in a towel-covered pan. Ordinarily, this is a good way to obtain very fluffy grains, and you get a lot of volume too. But lately I’ve been finding that my quinoa is soggy – more waterlogged than fluffy – when I cook it this way, even after it rests under the towel. Are the grains different? I don’t know. Whatever the reason, I decided to change the grain-to-water ratio and followed the directions on my Alter Eco quinoa packages (Alter Eco is a company dedicated to fair-trade foods, and they import red, rainbow and pearl quinoas). I cooked the pearl and the red quinoas in 1 1/2 parts water and the rainbow in 2 parts water. The black quinoa in the rainbow mix takes a little longer to soften and requires a little more liquid to be properly hydrated. The grains were tighter and less moist than quinoa cooked in abundant water, and the yield was not as great because the grains don’t swell as much. But I liked the results, especially for salads, which were the destination for my quinoa experiments.

headline: How Big Can a Small Business Be? (And Why It Matters)
text: There is an age-old debate about what constitutes a small business. Most likely, we think about the question differently depending upon our vantage point in life. I’ve met corporate folks before who think a business with 500 employees or less is small. And I’ve met self-employed massage therapists who think they’re too “small” to be considered a small business.

headline: China Shows Interest in Afghan Security, Fearing Taliban Would Help Separatists

headline: A Gifted and Talented Program Grows in Carroll Gardens

This year, as its reputation spread, there were more applicants to the program than there were seats, and anxiety reigned until the Department of Education decided, at the last minute, to expand the program. A bird's-eye view of how gifted programs are formed.
