text: President Obama on Friday urged Congress to “take another look” at his proposals to spur job growth and warned that economic problems in Europe were producing “headwinds” that made Congressional action even more critical for the United States.

headline: Inside the List
text: MAN’S WORLD: The cutoff for this week’s list was June 2 — too early, you’d think, to reflect any kind of Father’s Day sales bump. Yet with subjects including the Civil War, international espionage, Navy SEALs and the most trusted man in America, the list’s new titles throw off a decidedly masculine funk. The Civil War book is Jeff Shaara’s “Blaze of Glory,” a novel about the Battle of Shiloh that hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 7 and contains one character as notable to literary historians as military ones: the Union general Lew Wallace. Blamed for the battle’s heavy casualties after he was late with reinforcements, Wallace went on to serve as governor of the New Mexico Territory before becoming, like Shaara, a wildly popular historical novelist. (His “Ben-Hur,” published in 1880, was the best-selling American novel of the 19th century, and has never gone out of print.) Shaara, a former coin dealer who started writing after the death of his novelist father, told a Florida newspaper recently that he tries to grab his audiences right away: “A very good friend of mine who is not especially a reader said to me, ‘If you expect me to read your books, you’ve gotta hook me in Chapter 1.’ ”

headline: Well-Oiled Machine
text: In the great reach for colonies that Europe began hundreds of years ago, at center stage were several curious entities that wielded more power than many governments. The United Company of Merchants of England Trading to the East Indies (commonly known as the East India Company) and its counterpart, the Dutch East India Company, fielded their own warships and armies, coined money and ruled territory eventually taken over by Britain and the Netherlands. Later, the seizure of land by Cecil Rhodes’s British South Africa Company also preceded the spread of British pink across the map.

headline: Words Per Minute
text: I share my name with an aerobatic bird that can whiz across a whole summer sky in seconds. A swift is so equipped for speed that it can scarcely cope with being stationary. I once came across an unlucky young specimen that had somehow grounded itself on a lawn and, with its minuscule legs and long encumbering wings, couldn’t regain the air. I lifted it on the perch of my finger and it was gone in a flash.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Free cupcakes, one per person in any flavor, will be handed out between 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. Friday at Georgetown Cupcake SoHo, 111 Mercer Street (between Prince and Spring Streets), for an upcoming episode of “DC Cupcakes,” a reality show that follows the two sisters behind this popular bakery.

headline: Mysterious Light Seen Over Middle East Coincides With Russian Missile Launch
text: A glowing celestial pinwheel spun in the night sky over the Middle East on Thursday night, grabbing attention across the region and fueling speculation about the possible origin of the unexplained phenomenon.

headline: Trail of Shadows
text: I opened this book as a skeptic. I am not a lover of true crime, and as a parent I recoiled from the lurid tale of a 21-year-old English bar hostess in Tokyo who was drugged and dismembered by a serial sex offender. But Richard Lloyd Parry’s remarkable examination of that crime, what it revealed about Japanese society and how it unsettled conventional notions of bereavement, elevates his book far above the genre. “People Who Eat Darkness” is a searing exploration of evil and trauma, and how both ultimately elude understanding or resolution.

headline: Becoming a Legend
text: During the great performance that was her life, Lillian Hellman always addressed the 20th century from center stage. While she defended many causes — justice, loyalty, American civil liberties, anti-fascism and Soviet-style Communism among them — what she represented most staunchly was herself, and what she believed in most fiercely was her own unassailability.

headline: Light, Truth and Whatever
text: Andrew Delbanco must be a great teacher. A longtime faculty member at Columbia, he is devoted to the development of his students as individuals, and recognizes that their time in college should be formative: “They may still be deterred from sheer self-interest toward a life of enlarged sympathy and civic responsibility.” Like most professors devoted to teaching, he has no interest in telling undergraduates what to think, but he does want to draw them toward a sense of skepticism about the status quo and to a feeling of wonder about the natural world. College, he tells us, is a time to learn to “make connections among seemingly disparate phenomena,” to see things from another’s point of view and to develop a sense of ethical responsibility. At a time when many are trying to reduce the college years to a training period for economic competition, Delbanco reminds readers of the ideal of democratic education.

headline: First Foodie
text: The richest, most influential restaurant owners lived in fear of a single critic’s word, a man whose enthusiastic home visit to an amateur’s kitchen might well inspire a lucrative career as a cookbook writer. Drawing on his limitless budget, he could roam the earth and report back on what he found.

headline: To the Bone
text: Although the 58 years between the rise of Hitler and the fall of the Soviet Union have been as well documented as any comparable historical period, there are fewer literary accounts of their most evil components than might be expected. Of course most of those who suffered directly are dead or otherwise incapacitated, and few indirect sufferers have been sufficiently talented. We do have marvelous books by Primo Levi; “Fatelessness,” by Imre Kertesz (who dismissed the film “Schindler’s List” as kitsch); Solzhenitsyn’s “Gulag Archipelago”; and perhaps Wiesel’s “Night,” but it’s a small list. Now we can add “The Hunger Angel,” by the 2009 Nobel laureate Herta Müller.

headline: City of Dreams
text: Early on in “The Chaperone,” Laura Moriarty’s fourth novel, it becomes clear that Cora Carlisle is fighting a losing battle. Her charge is Louise Brooks, soon-to-be silent-film star and something of a force of nature. As the critic Kenneth Tynan wrote, Brooks was “a creature of impulse, a creator of impulses, a temptress with no pretensions, capable of dissolving into a giggling fit at a peak of erotic ecstasy, . . . with that sleek jet cloche of hair that rings such a peal of bells in my subconscious.” Moriarty’s Louise is only 15, a Jazz Age lost girl playing uncertainty as brashness, but impulse and temptation are already in bloom.

headline: The Displaced
text: In “Against Simplification,” an essay posted on the Project Syndicate Web site last August, Norman Manea rightly pointed out that in North America literary translation is too rare a practice, arguing that “imported books are thought to be too ‘complicated,’ which is another way of saying that literature should deal with simple issues in a simple way, obeying the rules of the mass market, with its tricks of packaging, accessibility, advertisement and comfort.”

headline: Winds of Fate
text: When it was published in Britain last year, Jo Baker’s fourth novel was called “The Picture Book.” The title made some sense — it referred to both a cherished postcard album and, presumably, the snapshot structure of the narrative — but Baker’s American publishers were wise to change it. “The Picture Book” suggests something sweet and nostalgic. In its best moments, this novel, Baker’s first to be published in the United States, is gripping and ruthless.

headline: Uncertain Times
text: In his eloquent essay “The Great Christmas Killing,” the Hungarian novelist Peter Nadas describes his intense, ultimately chagrined response to a documentary about the execution of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu. Neither his opposition to capital punishment nor his belief in the importance of “just, legal procedures” keeps Nadas from feeling a surge of vengeful delight as he witnesses the final hours of the Romanian dictator. “Ceausescu just kept looking at his wife, rolling his small, shifty eyes and grinning nervously; you could tell he couldn’t grasp what was really happening or figure out how he might gain the upper hand.”

headline: Vetted, Altered, Blessed
text: When the Qaeda leader Abu Zubaydah was captured, six months after the terrorist attacks of 9/11, C.I.A. lawyers were asked to approve a battery of tough interrogation techniques hastily thrown together. They did not much fear that posterity would think them ruthless. On the contrary, the C.I.A.’s No. 2 attorney worried that “with all the restrictions and precautions and scrutiny by lawyers and doctors and psychologists,” they’d look like a bunch of wimps.

headline: From Here to Infinity
text: When Simon Norton was 3 1/2, his I.Q. was measured at 178. For three years running in high school, he was among the top scorers in the world at the International Mathematical Olympiad. At the age of 27, he and a colleague, John Conway, formulated an audacious conjecture in group theory called “monstrous moonshine,” which inspired a frenzy of mathematical work around the globe that culminated in a Fields Medal-winning proof by Richard Borcherds almost two decades later.

headline: Money Ball
text: The mantra in America is that everyone needs a dream. So why not dream that your kid will be the one to land an athletic scholarship or sign a pro contract? Because — as Mark Hyman has documented in two important but troubling books — the lengths to which many of us go in pursuit of that vision can turn it into a nightmare.

headline: Forget the Alamo
text: Texas — that vast and various landmass of nearly 26 million souls — boasts some of the most acclaimed public and private universities, a vibrant art and architecture scene, and world-class symphony orchestras and opera companies. It is one of the nation’s leaders in medical research; rightly celebrates its reputation for manned and unmanned space exploration; rejoices in its richly diverse and tasty cultural stew; and glories in its professional football teams.

headline: Triple Crown Chase Ends Day Early, in Farewell
text: There was I’ll Have Another at one end of the leather tether, looking every bit the wonder horse, with his coat combed to a chestnut glow and his mane braided and glimmering. At the other was his trainer, Doug O’Neill, leading his colt out of Barn 2 at Belmont Park for a shockingly final bow before a battery of cameras on Friday.

headline: The Return of Tirunesh Dibaba
text: One of the most anticipated entrants at this year’s Adidas Grand Prix track meet in New York on Saturday is Tirunesh Dibaba of Ethiopia, the defending women’s Olympic champion at 5,000 and 10,000 meters and quite possibly the fastest finisher in the history of women’s distance running.

headline: Wheelies: The Lone-Star Speed Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Why the Baltics Matter
text: Some readers have urged me not to spend time on Latvia, Estonia, etc., on the grounds that they are too small to matter. Sorry, but that’s not true. For one thing, every economy — even a small one — is potentially a “natural experiment” that teaches us more about how economies in general work. Beyond that, the Baltics now loom large in the imagination of austerity’s defenders, particularly since Ireland keeps refusing to play along and be a success story.

headline: DC Comics Going Even Further Back in Time
text: Last fall, DC Comics reintroduced its heroes in 52 new series, all starting with issue No. 1. This September the publisher will be going even further back in time, with plans to unveil an issue No. 0 for each of those series.

headline: Hosts of ‘Car Talk’ to Retire After 35 Years of Automotive Banter
text: 6:23 p.m. | Updated For years now, after their broadcasts, Tom and Ray Magliozzi, the hosts of the public-radio hit “Car Talk,” have been ranking the listener calls they receive on a scale from five to one, with five being the most entertaining.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/8: SeaWorld Killer Whales Ruling, and Where to Sleep Outside in New York City
text: SeaWorld and Killer Whales More than two years after a whale killed a trainer during a show at SeaWorld, a judge has ruled that the park cannot resume similar shows that allow trainers in the water to ride and kiss the animals. SeaWorld has introduced a new show that keeps trainers our of the water, which doesn’t seem to have dimmed ticket sales. (The New York Times)

headline: The Newest Rap: Intense, Authentic and Accidental
text: THREE years ago Waka Flocka Flame arrived loudly with “O Let’s Do It,” a bumpy burst of rowdy boasts and gunfire onomatopoeia. It was a rough and tumble song in a time when that style was beginning to seem extinct. Not surprisingly, when he recorded it, the goal wasn’t to fit in to the hip-hop of the day.

headline: Collaborators Dead and Very Much Alive
text: Jesse Davis

headline: Real Reporters on the Screen? Get Me Rewrite!
text: BACK when paper and ink still mattered, I fell into a job as a nightside reporter at The Providence Journal, in the habitually newsworthy state of Rhode Island. This was many years ago, before exercise, sobriety and good hygiene had ruined the misanthropic bonhomie of the typical newsroom — or so the romanticizing journalist in me likes to think.

headline: Image of the Day: June 8
text: Thousands of asthma patients throng a camp in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh to be administered a cure consisting of live sardine fish smeared with herbal paste.

headline: Fashion Web Start-Up Raises $36 Million
text: Everyone loves a bargain, but some shoppers just want access.

headline: Former UBS Trader Is Granted Bail
text: LONDON – Kweku M. Adoboli, the former UBS trader charged with false accounting related to a $2.3 billion trading loss, was granted bail by a London court on Friday.

headline: The Most Expensive Campaign Ever
text: The Romney and Obama campaigns are already spending millions of dollars to attack each other on television. It’s a bit early for that, as Jeremy Peters pointed out in The Times today, and they’re battling for the attention of an incredibly tiny slice of voters.

headline: Shareholders Rebuke Chesapeake Leadership
text: HOUSTON — Shareholders sent an angry message to the board and management of Chesapeake Energy on Friday, withholding support for the two directors up for election, rejecting the pay plan for top executives and urging the company to allow major shareholders to nominate their own board candidates.

headline: Wilson Quarterly to End Print Publication
text: The Wilson Quarterly, the 36-year-old general interest magazine published by the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, has announced that it will put out its final print issue in July.

headline: Live Sunday: Coverage of Euro 2012
text: Goal blog reporters, editors and contributors will provide coverage and live analysis of selected games during Euro 2012, starting with Sunday’s Italy-Spain game from Gdansk, Poland, and Monday’s France-England matchup in Donetsk, Ukraine. Check back next week and beyond for more matches.

headline: Nadal and Djokovic to Vie for Title and Much More
text: PARIS — By late Friday, Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic had guaranteed that history would be made at this French Open, with their latest Grand Slam final meeting now scheduled as scripted. Tennis record books will be rewritten Sunday, one way or another, by one of two players who spent the last two weeks on a clay-court collision course.

headline: Predicting the Rise and Rise of 3-D
text: Dreamworks Animation/Walt Disney PicturesDreamWorks Animation is releasing “Madagascar 3” on Friday.

headline: Real Estate Giant Domus Holdings Files for an I.P.O.
text: 1:05 p.m. | Updated

headline: Errani and Vinci Win Doubles Title
text: PARIS — Sara Errani’s streak held on Friday as she and Roberta Vinci of Italy won a rain-interrupted French Open women’s doubles final at Roland Garros against Nadia Petrova and Maria Kirilenko of Russia.

headline: A Mythical Bayou’s All-Too-Real Peril
text: MONTEGUT, La.

headline: Just One Look | Club Monaco
text: With 14 deliveries a year, Club Monaco doesn’t map out its collections season to season but rather month to month. So when you go into one of the brand’s New York City stores in December, there you will find — surprise! — not bathing suits and cover-ups but clothes that are perfect for New York City in December. In other words, festive fare that you don’t have to be floating on a sailboat in the Caribbean to pull off. Among the best looks is this sweatshirt, brilliantly gussied up with a panel of Lurex and a multibeaded skirt. Holiday party, anyone?

headline: No Charges to Be Filed in Deadly Christmas Fire, Connecticut Prosecutor Says
text: A Connecticut prosecutor said Friday that he would not file criminal charges in connection with the Christmas morning fire in Stamford that killed three girls and their grandparents.

headline: Obama Speaks About Job Growth
text: President Obama spoke on Friday about the European financial crisis and job growth in the U.S.

headline: Jamaican Drug Lord Gets Maximum Term
text: Christopher M. Coke, the Jamaican drug lord whose extradition to the United States in 2010 followed a furious manhunt in his homeland that led to the deaths of more than 70 people, was sentenced on Friday in Manhattan to 23 years in prison, the maximum he faced.

headline: Judge Allows Protesters’ Suit Against Police to Proceed
text: A federal judge indicated Thursday that the police did not adequately warn Occupy Wall Street protesters against walking on the roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge before arresting about 700 of them in October.

headline: Postcards From the Resort Collections
text: “It’s all about comfort,” Alber Elbaz said as he introduced his latest Lanvin collection to a small group of editors and retailers at Milk Studios. “To me, that’s the only definition of modernity.”

headline: Earning Less and Worth Less
text: Adjusted for inflation, per capita disposable personal income has yet to recover to the peak reached in 2008. Household net worth, also adjusted for inflation and measured on a per capita basis, is still nearly 20 percent below the high reached in 2007. The charts show four-year changes in both figures, both before and after adjusting for inflation.

headline: Scenes from Bonnaroo
text: The 2012 Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival got under way in Manchester, Tenn., on Thursday.

headline: The Rams of Memphis
text: In the annals of the Civil War, there were many unlikely heroes, but perhaps none more unusual than Charles Ellet, who built the first — and only — Union Ram Fleet. One of the most accomplished civil engineers of all time, and with no military experience, Ellet created a fleet of ramming steamships independent of the military hierarchy, stocked it with nearly a dozen of his own family members and courageously commanded it to victory in the Battle of Memphis in June 1862.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Broadway and the Tonys
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott give their regards to Broadway, still “an authentic New York experience.”

headline: The Sweet Spot: June 8
text: With the Tony Awards on Sunday, David Carr and A. O. Scott give their regards to Broadway, still “an authentic New York experience.” For live coverage of the Tonys, log on to NYTimes.com at 7 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Go West, Young Man, and Sell Out
text: Too Late Blues

headline: One Reporter’s Journey Through a Sports Day Like Few Others
text: From the French Open to an Argentina-Brazil friendly to an Oscar Pistorius 400-meter run to the Belmont Stakes to Yankees-Mets, Saturday will be a sports marathon. Having covered six sporting events in 24 hours last year, Mike Tanier is uniquely qualified to report for the fan who wants to experience championship hockey, horse racing, track and other sports in one whirlwind day.

headline: Income and Wealth Are Down in U.S.
text: AMERICANS are used to recessions, but they are also used to relatively fast recoveries.

headline: Britain Confirms Tae Kwon Do Choice Is Not No. 1 Fighter
text: The British Olympic Association ratified the nomination of Lutalo Muhammad to its tae kwon do team Friday.

headline: A Child, a Gadget, a Guest and a Question of Etiquette
text: “Yesterday,” R. wrote, “my 6-year-old child and the rest of our family visited another family with a child (also 6) who spent the whole time on an iPod touch.”

headline: The Car of Your Dreams
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about collectors of classic cars. Like any other type of collectible, some cars — often those that were widely produced — have little value as an investment. And other cars may be falling out of favor, like sedans from the 1920s and ’30s, whose biggest fans were people who remembered riding in them as youngsters. Car collecting, in other words, needs to be done with some knowledge and, often, advice from those with experience.

headline: Waiting For Non-Lefties
text: Samuel Brittain: You don’t need to be a lefty to support Krugman:

headline: Aurora Stokowski and Anthony Mazzei
text: ANTHONY MAZZEI didn’t begin his romance with Aurora Stokowski by asking her on a date. They were on the carousel at Bryant Park when, out of the blue, he confessed that he loved her — risking not only his heart, but also the business it had taken them more than a year to build.

headline: Bonnaroo: Kendrick Lamar and Rappers With Vocal Bite
text: Qualifications for rappers at Bonnaroo 2012: technique, inclusiveness, vocal bite, stage presence. Thursday night brought three in a row to the This Tent for a deluge of multiply rhymed lines and polysyllabic precision: Danny Brown, Yelawolf and Kendrick Lamar. (More are due in the next days, both well-qualified on those fronts: GZA and Ludacris.) But their shticks were different, and in my earnest way I prefer Kendrick Lamar, who equally earnestly presents pleasures–booze and sex–as ways to “ease the pain” of a deprived upbringing and a competitive adult life.

headline: Scenes from Bonnaroo
text: More Photographs

headline: Planning a Financial Tuneup
text: There comes a point in most people’s lives when the pile of undone financial tasks — the un-automated bills, the out-of-balance retirement accounts, the out-of-date budget, the under-optimized rewards programs — becomes large enough to provoke a sort of low-grade anxiety.

headline: Love Story in Residence
text: LUCAS MATTHIESSEN was born in 1950s Paris, the son of a free-spirited couple who were “looking for Hemingway,” as the title of a famous essay by Gay Talese described their generation of expatriates. His father is Peter Matthiessen, the writer, and his mother was Patsy Southgate, described in an obituary as the most beautiful woman in Paris during those years.

headline: Romney Calls Obama ‘Out of Touch’ on Jobs
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, IOWA — Mitt Romney seized on President Obama’s remark Friday that the private sector was “doing fine” by calling it an “extraordinary miscalculation and misunderstanding by a president who’s out of touch.’’

headline: Townsend and Bouchard Lose in Semifinal
text: PARIS — This wasn’t Taylor Townsend’s tournament but she wasn’t blaming anyone. “Everyone has their good days, everyone has their bad days,” she said after losing in a quarterfinal singles match on Wednesday.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Richard Ford’s New Novel
text: In The New York Times Book Review, Andre Dubus III considers Richard Ford’s new novel, “Canada,” in which a teenage boy’s life is changed forever when his parents make the unlikely decision to rob a bank. Calling the book “a masterwork by one of our finest writers working at the top of his form,” Mr. Dubus writes:

headline: Who’s Got Your Back?
text: IN a city with more than 20,000 registered real estate agents, is it any wonder that choosing one can be a difficult and sometimes fraught process?

headline: A Career Resurrected After McCain and Palin
text: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev.

headline: E-Mails Offer Look at Deal-Making Over Health Care Law
text: Emails released by the House Energy and Commerce Committee open a window into the negotiations between the White House, Senate Democrats and pharmaceutical industry in 2009 as part of President Obama’s drive to overhaul the health care system.

headline: Readers Pick Their Favorite Tony Awards Moments
text: On Thursday, The Times’s Charles Isherwood provided a “brief and highly arbitrary list” of his favorite moments from past Tony Awards shows. He called out show-stopping performances like Angela Lansbury and Bea Arthur doing “Bosom Buddies” from “Mame”; and Jennifer Holliday doing “And I’m Telling You I’m Not Going” from “Dreamgirls.”

headline: Man of The Moment | Ryan Gosling
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Obama Was Pushed by Drug Industry, E-Mails Suggest
text: WASHINGTON — After weeks of talks, drug industry lobbyists were growing nervous. To cut a deal with the White House on overhauling health care, they needed to be sure that President Obama would stop a proposal intended to bring down medicine prices.

headline: Uncle Ray’s Dystopia
text: IF you’d wanted to know which way the world was headed in the mid-20th century, you wouldn’t have found much indication in any of the day’s literary prizewinners. You’d have been better advised to consult a book from a marginal genre with a cover illustration of a stricken figure made of newsprint catching fire.

headline: Tracking Turkey’s First Starchitect
text: “The only way to arrive at Semsi Pasha Mosque is by water,” my guide said as our little boat dodged two tankers on the Bosporus. On every shore around us, the domes and minarets of some of Istanbul’s nearly 3,000 mosques delineated the skyline of a city that looks like no other.

headline: What You Did for Your Financial Tuneup
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I encourage readers to take a day to do a financial tuneup and cross off as many things as possible from their money to-do lists.

headline: The Structures of Sinan
text: He built on a monumental scale for the most powerful people on earth. Here is some of what he created.

headline: Have Elite Fliers Been Downgraded?
text: A STEADY rain was soaking the windows of La Guardia Airport when Nancy Thode, an elite frequent flier with Delta Air Lines, approached a gate agent with a pressing question: Had her request for an upgrade cleared?

headline: How to Fly V.I.P., Perk by Perk
text: Don’t fly enough to earn elite status on an airline? There are plenty of other ways to buy those perks and preferred treatment, either à la carte or through the right credit card. Here is how you can fly like an elite passenger, even for one trip a year, on several airlines. (Carriers without an elite program were not included.)

headline: No Extra Points for This Quiz
text: Not an elite flier? You’re in the vast majority. Globally, only about 4.2 million out of some 320 million frequent fliers are elite, according to Randy Petersen, founder of frequent-flier Web sites like FlyerTalk.com and MilePoint.com; most of us are just hoarding miles in hopes of one day swapping them for a coach ticket. The multibillion-dollar airline-loyalty industry has been around for more than 30 years. How much do you know about it?

headline: New Russian Law Assesses Heavy Fines on Protesters
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin signed into law on Friday a measure that will impose heavy fines on people who organize or take part in unsanctioned demonstrations, giving the Russian authorities powerful leverage to clamp down on the large antigovernment street protests that began six months ago and seemed to be re-energized after Mr. Putin’s inauguration last month.

headline: Shedding a Seedy Past in Paris
text: A sleek hotel, a natural wine shop and other businesses are giving the Bagnolet neighborhood new vitality.

headline: Bed and Breakfast, Goats and Pigs
text: I ALMOST wanted to sleep right there in the barn, snuggling with Judy and Patsy. The 700-pound pigs, sisters abandoned as piglets, were living out their days on the Woodstock Farm Animal Sanctuary with a couple of hundred other creatures.

headline: An American Safari in Montana’s Outback
text: AS we crept out of camp, the morning sky was slowly turning pink. Smoke billowed from the kitchen tent where we had just filled our mugs with wood-fired coffee. A Smith & Wesson pistol hung awkwardly on my hip. The tops of the surrounding Swan Range began to glow orange with the sunrise. Our guide, Jack Rich, scoped the grassy patches below the closest ridgeline, looking for movement. After spying a small cluster of animals from a distance, Jack led my friend Marie and me even deeper into the Bob Marshall Wilderness Complex, a tranquil pocket of Montana backcountry commonly referred to as the Bob.

headline: Rocking Summer Music Festivals
text: MADELINE FOLLIN, 23, a singer in the indie-pop duo Cults, grew up going to music festivals around San Diego, her hometown. Now she knows her way around them as a performer.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Re “36 Hours in Dresden, Germany” (May 27): We’ve been to Dresden many times and have always loved it. The collections in the Zwinger Palace can easily take a day, and the VW plant tour is fascinating. Did I miss a reference to the Green Vault? It’s an amazing collection of decorative arts, some of which were shown at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Rob HouckMount Kisco, N.Y.

headline: In South Korea, All Roads Lead to Yeosu
text: UNTIL five years ago, Yeosu was an unremarkable, out-of-the-way city on the southern coast of South Korea. Despite a temperate climate, scenic islands and a spicy local cuisine, the city was, among tourists, virtually off the map. A largely rural municipality spread out over a peninsula and 317 islands, it has three commercial and residential hubs that used to be the only places to find anything resembling bustle. Then fate smiled on the city. Yeosu (pronounced YUH-sue) was chosen to host the 2012 World Expo, the smallest city in a generation to have the honor.

headline: Briton There at Pakistan’s Birth Stays at 94, a Living Textbook
text: CHITRAL, Pakistan — During a grand gathering of tribal elders in this rugged and remote mountain district recently, one guest of honor stood out: an elderly Englishman in a suit and polished shoes, his snowy hair carefully combed, the morning newspaper folded on his lap.

headline: In Telematics Realm, Varying Approaches to Delivering a Connected Drive
text: Three deals struck this month in the arena of telematics demonstrate the speed with which connected features can migrate among platforms, as well as the influence large companies may exert over the content featured on the dashboards of the future.

headline: People, Shops and Roads Converge Here
text: NO matter which neighborhood a Bronx resident calls home, most have been to the Hub, a convergence of streets in the South Bronx that is one of the borough’s most dynamic commercial centers. For Michael Reed, it was when his parents took him shopping for Easter clothes as a boy.

headline: Name the Art That Calls Your Name
text: “There is only one valuable thing in art: the thing you cannot explain,” Georges Braque once said. It may be possible, however, to explain why you love a particular work of art, and in a column in Friday’s Times, I made a stab at doing so, writing about my repeated visits over a decade to a wonderful, deeply unsettling Caravaggio painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, “The Denial of St. Peter.” It has become like a fascinating, stubborn, moody old friend — one I admire, argue with and don’t pretend to know very well, even after so many years.

headline: Living In | The Hub, the Bronx
text: A South Bronx neighborhood where most residential property is rent-stabilized, apart from a few new two-families.

headline: Shooting at Laws in Ads (Literally)
text: Ron Gould, an Arizona state senator running for Congress, really, really doesn’t want government to mess with anybody’s health care. I noted that in a post yesterday, linking to a campaign ad that shows him blasting President Obama’s health-care reform, the Affordable Care Act, with a pump-action shotgun.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $17.25 Million
text: The apartment on Park Avenue whereLeon Hess, the oil magnate and New York Jets owner, lived until his death in 1999 sold for $17.25 million, the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: James’s Brilliance, Considered on Its Own Merits
text: The most instinctive response to the play of LeBron James is a wide-eyed stare. The relentless loathing directed toward him may provide a constant white noise, but when LeBron is LeBron, all else is mute; there’s no delight or celebration, but an awe that what we’ve witnessed should not be possible. James is often portrayed as both a hyper-flawed mortal and a peerless physical specimen, but at his most astounding, James is merely a transcendent basketball form. He doesn’t steal our attentions with some uncharacteristic seriousness. He captures us in his raw gravity.

headline: Just One Look | Derek Lam
text: There was a lot going on in the Derek Lam resort collection: leather pieces and safari/military jackets; stripes and animal spots; some swim, some chunky knits. Together it addressed every side of what is known as a rather schizophrenic season. (In November, when these clothes arrive in stores, are women shopping for the coming winter in New York or a holiday vacation in St. Barts? Or both?) The favorite, which three T editors each gravitated toward separately, was this belted handkerchief dress with buttons on the diagonal.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A four-bedroom lakefront contemporary in Wayne, N.J., and a five-bedroom colonial in Riverdale.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An East Village trilevel, a Turtle Bay duplex and a Brooklyn Heights duplex.

headline: Business Day Live: Entrepreneur Moms
text: Sallie L. Krawcheck’s proposals for bank reform. Joseph E. Stiglitz on economic inequality. Balancing entrepreneurship and motherhood.

headline: Birthday Gifts for Economists
text: Via Tyler Cowen, here’s a novel gift idea for that beloved, binge-drinking economist in your life:

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 460,000 Toyota RAV4s After Reports of Suspension Failures
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether about 460,000 Toyota RAV4s from the 2006-8 model years should be recalled because of suspension failures.

headline: Dressing for ‘Gilligan’s Island’
text: As Ginger Grant on “Gilligan’s Island,” Tina Louise had a rather remarkable wardrobe for someone who was shipwrecked while on a three-hour tour. Those marvelous beaded dresses that just matched her skin tone surely were not just lying around on the S.S. Minnow.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Batman’s Early Days
text: “Absolute Batman: Dark Victory” lands at No. 8 on the hardcover graphic books best-seller list this week. The “Absolute” hardcovers from DC tend to cost $99.99, but they present the comics in an oversized format, with better paper and rich colors, so they are often worth the price of admission. “Dark Victory,” written by Jeph Loeb and illustrated by Tim Sale, is a sequel to “The Long Halloween,” in which Batman was learning the ropes, confronting the mob, discovering a new breed of freak (the Joker, the Penguin and more) and trying to discover the identity of the Holiday killer. “Dark Victory” is still set in the earliest days of the hero’s career. It picks up some dangling threads, brings Robin into the fight for justice and introduces the Hangman, another serial killer. These early looks into the careers of heroes have become something of a trademark for Mr. Loeb and Mr. Sale. Other recommend books: “Superman For All Seasons,” “Daredevil: Yellow,” “Spider-Man: Blue” and “Hulk: Gray.”

headline: For the Patient Baseball Fan, a Beautiful Reward
text: Baseball fans are frequently asked by people who aren’t fans, How can you watch such a slow game?

headline: June 10 — 16
text: THE desire of the world’s have-nots for a more prosperous and secure life in Western Europe informs two films — Emanuele Cialese’s “Terraferma” and the twin brothers Massimiliano and Gianluca De Serio’s first feature, “Seven Acts of Mercy” — in the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s series OPEN ROADS: NEW ITALIAN CINEMA. The series, which began on Friday and continues through Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater, showcases the latest in contemporary Italian movies.

headline: Sharapova vs. Errani: Serves Will Be Crucial
text: Maria Sharapova looks to complete a career Grand Slam when she faces Sara Errani in the women’s singles final at Roland Garros on Saturday. Sharapova will be the overwhelming favorite, with her extensive experience and formidable arsenal of offensive weapons, but Errani has made an improbable run to the finals with upsets over former French Open champions Ana Ivanovic and Svetlana Kuznetsova, and Samantha Stosur, a finalist in 2010.

headline: Touring Is a Tonic for Australians
text: IT’S not every season the Lincoln Center studios ring with “G’day!” But that’s about to change, at least for a week, when the Australian Ballet visits New York for the first time since 1999.

headline: Electronic Woe: The Short Lives of Instruments
text: IN an onstage interview during an evening of music by Kaija Saariaho at Zankel Hall this spring Jeremy Geffen, Carnegie Hall’s director of artistic planning, asked Ms. Saariaho a provocative question, suggested by the nature of the music she was presenting. Though she writes prolifically for conventional ensembles, Ms. Saariaho also composes electronic music, and the works performed that evening not only combined live voices with recorded or electronically altered live sounds but also had video components, by Jean-Baptiste Barrière, that combined live and recorded elements.

headline: TV Viewers Not Enamored With ‘The Choice’
text: The series premiere of Fox’s new reality dating show “The Choice” on Thursday proved that simply putting celebrities in swivel chairs does not instantly create a ratings hit.

headline: Video Preserves Hints of Future For a Director
text: JUST out of Harvard, the director Peter Sellars made his name in the early 1980s with a series of productions of Mozart and Handel operas set in the modern world. The broad outlines of the shows could be easily summarized: “Le Nozze di Figaro” in the Trump Tower, “Così Fan Tutte” in a roadside diner in Massachusetts, “Orlando” in outer space.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: An Ugly Rash Solved
text: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to figure out the diagnosis for a 55-year-old woman with a fever, rash, bloodshot eyes and blood-filled blisters in her mouth.

headline: Europe Preparing to File Charges in Universal-E.M.I. Deal
text: PARIS — The European Commission intends to file an antitrust complaint against Universal Music Group’s proposed $1.9 billion acquisition of the E.M.I. music recording business, a top commissioner said Friday, citing concerns that the deal would reduce competition.

headline: Detail by Detail, Gupta’s Lawyer Deconstructs Goldman Testimony
text: 6:25 p.m. | Updated

headline: Reporter Accuses Syrian Rebels of Luring Him Into Death Trap
text: A British television journalist attempting to gain access to the site of a reported massacre in Syria accused rebel fighters on Friday of trying to get him and his colleagues killed by the Syrian military in an effort to draw condemnation against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Touch, Speak, Tap: Taking 5 Connected Cars for a Spin
text: IN the past, when an automaker wanted to distinguish itself, it simply had to show up its competitors: Ford had to beat Chevy, BMW had to outdo Mercedes, Morgan had to...

headline: Merging Cellphones and Dashboards
text: SEEKING to please those customers clamoring for more features in their cars, General Motors will soon make a novel offer: give them less.

headline: Rhythms for the Highway, Before the Age of the iPod
text: FROM the arrival of the earliest car radios in the 1920s to the advent of today’s colorful dashboard display screens, automakers have been playing catch-up with consumer tastes and trends. Yet the key to providing an ideal blend of in-car information and entertainment — infotainment, in the lexicon — has long been close at hand.

headline: Avedon to Warhol: Madrid Hosts Visual Arts Festival
text: PHotoEspaña is one of the world’s most wide-ranging photography festivals, encompassing the visual arts as well as photography. This year, works by more than 250 artists from 44 countries will be on view in galleries, installations, major museums and art centers through July 22. More than 700,000 people visit the festival annually, making it Spain’s most popular cultural event. Andy Warhol, Richard Avedon, Carlos Garaicoa, Santiago Sierra, Chen Chieh-jen, Alberto García-Alix and Helena Almeida are just a few of the top artists whose works will be exhibited.

headline: Physicists, Stop the Churlishness
text: A KERFUFFLE has broken out between philosophy and physics. It began earlier this spring when a philosopher (David Albert) gave a sharply negative review in this paper to a book by a physicist (Lawrence Krauss) that purported to solve, by purely scientific means, the mystery of the universe’s existence. The physicist responded to the review by calling the philosopher who wrote it “moronic” and arguing that philosophy, unlike physics, makes no progress and is rather boring, if not totally useless. And then the kerfuffle was joined on both sides.

headline: Not a Pretty Picture (Rowing = Pain)
text: When crews are seen from high overhead, as they are in our latest Look pages, they aren’t bodies pulling on oars; they’re geometries — parallels and circles and angles acute and obtuse. Seen from the shore, they typically strike viewers as all swinging gliding gracefulness.

headline: A Close Bond and the Unending Toll of 9/11
text: Eleven years ago this summer, Lt. Harry Wanamaker Jr., a 58-year-old veteran New York City firefighter assigned to Marine Company 1, posed proudly on a fireboat against the skyline of Lower Manhattan with Welles Remy Crowther, 24, an equities trader at Sandler O’Neill & Partners who worked on the 104th floor of 2 World Trade Center.

headline: Week in Culture Picture, June 8
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 8
text: Subjects include the ceremony for the new Ashanti chief, the plummeting population of red knots and the space shuttle Enterprise’s arrival at the Intrepid.

headline: Comcast Is Said to Be Mulling Bid for BSkyB
text: 5:05 p.m. | Updated Comcast is exploring whether the British Sky Broadcasting Group, Britain’s largest satellite broadcaster and a lucrative pay TV asset 39 percent owned by News Corporation, could become available for purchase, according to several people briefed on the company’s strategic thinking.

headline: Joyce Carol Oates Wants To Clear Things Up About ‘Mudwoman’
text: No, Joyce Carol Oates says forcefully: the protagonist of her new novel is not based on Harvard University President Drew Gilpin Faust.

headline: Republicans Take Aim at Obama’s ‘Doing Fine’ Comments
text: Four years ago, President Obama eagerly seized on Senator John McCain’s comment that the “fundamentals of the economy are strong” to paint his Republican rival as out of touch with a plummeting reality.

headline: Just One Look | Roksanda Ilincic
text: Roksanda Illincic has never been one to shy away from color, and resort has her seeing red — and lots of it. At the heart of the collection is a lacquered cotton that the designer cut into a simple car coat (which she showed cinched with a sliver of a white belt), a high-waisted dress and a pair of skinny trousers. The pants served as the underpinning for a series of lean, almost tuniclike dresses, whose graphic, asymmetrical color blocking, she said, was inspired by the work of Ellsworth Kelly and Kazimir Malevich.

headline: Obama Backs Away From ‘Fine’ Comment
text: President Obama on Friday afternoon backed away from his earlier comments that the “private sector is doing fine,” telling reporters that he does not believe the economy is doing fine.

headline: Now Click It, Rent It And Buy a Plane Ticket
text: The vacation rental company HomeAway joins with Priceline this week to allow customers to book plane tickets and car rentals in addition to homes.

headline: Nader Criticizes Ads on Yankees Radio Broadcasts
text: Ralph Nader, famous for his consumer crusades and presidential campaigns, has found a new target for his advocacy: ads read on WCBS-AM during Yankee games by John Sterling and Suzyn Waldman.

headline: Senator Raises Questions About Nominee for Iraq Ambassador
text: Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, is raising questions about Brett McGurk, President Obama’s nominee for ambassador to Iraq, after leaked e-mails surfaced purporting to show that Mr. McGurk had a relationship with an Iraq correspondent for The Wall Street Journal while he was the Bush White House’s top Iraq adviser.

headline: Pressed to Take Bailout, Spain Tries to Measure Its Need
text: MADRID — Spain appears poised to seek a bailout of its ailing banks, a long-anticipated acknowledgment by the government of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of the depths of Spain’s economic crisis.

headline: Sept. 11 Health Fund Given Clearance to Cover Cancer
text: A federal health official’s ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

headline: For Euro 2012, Germany Has Impressive Depth
text: Soccer, like most sports, is a team game which, in the vaguest definition, revolves around 11 players who must work together in a series of carved out positions and tactics to enable the most efficient means of obtaining and exploiting a small leather ball to allow them to win a game.

headline: Peter Gleick’s Pacific Institute Return
text: After an internal investigation, Peter Gleick has been reinstated as president of the Pacific Institute, the environmental group largely focused on water and climate that he founded in 1987. The career of this seasoned and lauded scientist and policy analyst ran off the rails when Gleick masqueraded as a member of the board of the anti-regulatory Heartland Institute to obtain internal documents on budgets and strategies. (He undertook this deception even as he was heading a task force on scientific ethics for the American Geophysical Union.)

headline: ‘Live From Lincoln Center’ Creator to Depart
text: John Goberman, who created PBS’s much-honored series “Live From Lincoln Center” more than three decades ago, is leaving as the show’s executive producer at the end of the month, Lincoln Center said Friday.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Nobody Is Happy
text: Institutional investors joined in on proxy fights, JPMorgan’s front-line regulator faced a fiery round of questioning, Nasdaq’s plan to settle Facebook claims met investor anger and the turf war between MF Global trustees grew increasingly tense. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in ferocious finance.

headline: Bonnaroo: Alabama Shakes Commands the Big Stage
text: Alabama Shakes have had a wild year: a transformation from small-town bar band to national and international exposure.

headline: Vintage M.F.K. Fisher
text: Inextricably bound up with M.F.K. Fisher’s lifelong passion for food was the pleasure she took from sipping and serving a simple house wine, a crisp aperitif or a prickly, delicious glass of Champagne. In “M.F.K. Fisher: Musings on Wine and other Libations” (Sterling Epicure; $19), Fisher’s biographer, Anne Zimmerman, gathers all of the eminent food writer’s essays on drink under one beautifully designed cover. Some of these gems have been plucked from well-known collections, like “The Art of Eating” and “Long Ago in France,” but many others — the entertaining “a Vintage Spat,” for example, and the rousing “Wine is Life” — have been out of print for decades. For Fisher fans, coming across these is like reading an as-yet-unopened letter from a dear old friend.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Bahrain, West Bank and Egypt.

headline: Badgley Mischka Previews Resort Collection via Pinterest
text: 5:15 p.m. | Updated Every day another brand tries exercising its digital muscles, from starting a Tumblr to live-streaming its runway shows. The bridal and resort seasons seem to be an opportune time for designers to experiment.

headline: As Summer Nears, Cold Noodles to Chill With
text: MAYBE cold pasta makes you think of some mediocre quasi-Italian grab-and-go deli choice in a plastic clamshell. Or perhaps that classic American picnic oddity, the macaroni salad.

headline: Even With All Those Seats, the Driver Is Left Out
text: INFINITI’S advertising tagline is “Inspired Performance.” And the mission statement of the Nissan luxury brand has long been clear: performance means taking whacks at BMW, and inspiration typically means undercutting BMW’s prices, especially with the estimable G sedan and coupe.

headline: Home 3-D Scans Made Cheap
text: This weekend, lots of people will head to theaters to see “Prometheus” and “Madagascar 3” in 3-D. A year from now, people could be seeing themselves that way, in their own homes.

headline: Under Budget Pressure, Regulator Gets Support From Former Chief
text: Republican lawmakers want Wall Street’s smallest regulator to shed some more pounds.

headline: Sure, He Can Spell ‘Opodeldoc,’ but How’s His Noo Yawk-Speak?
text: Twelve-year-old spelling whiz Arvind Mahankali of Bayside, Queens, barely bats an eyelash at words like distelfink, phrontistery, opodeldoc and uayeb, all of which he has successfully dispatched at the Scripps National Spelling Bee, where he placed third last week, the second time in two years.

headline: Has Guns, Wears Dress, Seeks Justice
text: “Revenge” is between seasons, and “Dog the Bounty Hunter” is on its last legs. What’s a fan of revenge-and-bounty-hunting-themed television to do? On Saturday night the Hallmark Movie Channel steps forward with relief: “Hannah’s Law,” a tasty western tale that seems just right for a weekend in June.

headline: At Least It Has Seven Seats...
text: The Infiniti JX35 crossover tries so hard to mimic other brands’ family values — while still being “different” — that it ties itself into a knot.

headline: Mets Selling Souvenir No-Hitter Tickets: Will You Pretend You Were There?
text: Historic events always make instant souvenirs out of the tickets that proved you were there. This was certainly the case when Johan Santana pitched the Mets’ first no-hitter last Friday and ostensibly reserved for the 27,069 officially in attendance at Citi Field.

headline: The Shepherdess in All Her Glory
text: Odd and original but not quite satisfying, “The Golden Veil,” a production of the National Theater of the United States of America at the Kitchen, is like a cabinet of curiosities, stuffed with bits and pieces of European and American culture: myths and pastoral legends; gothic don’t-go-into-the-woods stories; songs that wouldn’t be out of place on Harry Smith’s “Anthology of American Folk Music”; dances, courtly and otherwise.

headline: House Ethics Panel Won’t Release Waters Report on Misconduct Investigation
text: The House Ethics Committee refused to release on Friday the internal material it used for its decision earlier this week to move ahead with charges against Representative Maxine Waters of California.

headline: At a Concert, Even the Birds Chime In
text: OJAI, Calif. — The superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes was a natural choice to be music director of this summer’s Ojai Music Festival, which opened on Thursday evening here in California’s beautiful Ojai Valley. Mr. Andsnes has long felt strongly about the culture and environment of his homeland. For years he was a co-director of the Risor Chamber Music Festival in a small coastal town in southeastern Norway, where distinguished musicians young and old gather each summer for six busy days of concerts and camaraderie, and the music-making takes inspiration from the place itself: a charming, rustic fishing village.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Military Robots and Royal Animation
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 8
text: More Photographs

headline: Photo Replay: June 8
text: The day in sports, including French Open men’s semifinal matches and opening play of the 2012 European Championships.

headline: Hippo Playground, Riverside Park, 10:40 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Imagine the Cross-Bronx Expressway at rush hour with strollers instead of cars.

headline: Vladimir Krutov, Wing for Soviet Hockey Teams in the ’80s, Dies at 52
text: Vladimir Krutov, a husky Russian hockey player who combined speed, strength and lightning-quick wrists to become a critical component of the superb Soviet teams of the 1980s, earning the nickname the Tank, died on Wednesday in Moscow. He was 52.

headline: Cold and Warm, Chicken and Noodles
text: This week’s City Kitchen column features one of my warm-weather favorites, a rice noodle salad garnished with sweet herbs, peanuts and grilled chicken.

headline: Employment of Recent Law Grads at an Ebb
text: The share of law graduates employed a year out of school fell again last year to its lowest level since 1994, according to NALP, the Association for Legal Career Professionals.

headline: Senior Team Trial for World Mind Sports Games
text: The 90-board final of the senior team trial for the second World Mind Sports Games ended on Wednesday in Schaumburg, Ill. The winner will represent the United States in Lille, France, in August.

headline: Cocktail Basics With Jim Meehan
text: Ready for a cocktail? Jim Meehan, owner of Please Don’t Tell, shows Melissa Clark a few tips and tricks of making cocktails.

headline: A Loud Call for Cheering at Classical Concert Halls
text: It is a grim vision of the classical music concert: a sea of hollow-eyed faces in the dark, shushing the slightest peep during boring evenings stifled by ritual. The antidote? Audience members should be able to laugh, to clap in midperformance and to whoop with joy, if so moved. That would make classical music less boring and less awful, less a “musical North Korea.”

headline: Cocktails: Mixing an El Presidente
text: Ready for a cocktail? Jim Meehan, owner of Please Don't Tell, shows Melissa Clark a few tips and tricks of making cocktails.

headline: From the Union of Concerned Scientists, a Framework for Reducing Oil Consumption
text: The Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit American watchdog group, released a framework document this week for reducing the projected oil use of the United States by half over 20 years. On its Web site, the organization characterized its Half the Oil Plan as a clear, achievable road map to significantly curb the nation’s dependency on oil.

headline: Yesterday’s Latest Things
text: Over the years, automakers have overcome many technological challenges to introduce their in-car information and entertainment systems. Some proved fabulous, while others were flops.

headline: For Romance as a Game, Heart Gets in the Way
text: SAN DIEGO — The mushrooming of reality television and its lunatic subgenres might seem an unpromising subject for satire. How can you spoof a phenomenon that has metastasized so quickly that late-night comics have mostly left it behind as barren turf?

headline: Chic in Review | Miley Cyrus, Unavailable
Successes in Rhetoric: Language in the Life of Churchill
text: The orotund proclamations will be unavoidable at the new exhibition “Churchill: The Power of Words,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, because at the center of the gallery is a semi-enclosed theater. And from it, however muted, will emerge recordings of Winston Churchill’s voice, speaking to Parliament, to British radio listeners and to American audiences, breaking on the ear like waves, rising and falling with every breath, sometimes suspended unexpectedly in midair, other times rushing forward with renewed vigor.

headline: Small Fire Breaks Out in De Niro’s Apartment Building
text: A small fire broke out Friday afternoon in an apartment building on Central Park West where Robert De Niro lives, according to Fire Department officials and residents of the building.

headline: For Labor, a Fight to Lead Heats Up
text: The nation’s largest union of state and local government workers — the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees — faces another important election this month, beyond last Tuesday’s recall vote on Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, who retained his job despite the union’s all-out effort to oust him.

headline: Traveling Far From Home, but Without Adventures
text: What has the choreographer Marie-Christine Giordano received for exchanging her native Switzerland for the urban jungle of New York? In honor of her company’s 10th anniversary, she has created “In and Out,” a new work, press notes say, about trading the security of home for a life of surprises.

headline: Young Lovers Thwarted by Crime, Jail and a Mean Stepmother
text: “The Runaway,” a British mini-series being shown by the Ovation channel, is not your average tale of young lovers battling a coldhearted society. It’s bloodier, for one thing — in the first three hours, the young lovers kill three people between them, in gruesome fashion. Also, everyone thinks they’re brother and sister.

headline: Health Conditions Related to World Trade Center Attacks
text: A list of cancers now covered under the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act.

headline: Romney Buys Ads in Colorado, New Hampshire and Nevada
text: The Romney campaign, which has had a scant presence on the air in recent weeks, on Friday added Colorado, New Hampshire and Nevada to the states where it is running television commercials, according to a media buyer who monitors political spending.

headline: Allowing Cocktails to Stir the Meal
text: DRINKING seasonal cocktails used to mean manhattans in the winter and gin and tonics in the summer.
