headline: World Cup Qualifying Kicks Off: U.S. (3), Antigua and Barbuda (1)
text: The United States plays it first qualifier of the 2014 World Cup cycle on Friday night in Tampa, Fla., where it’s raining so hard that the substitutes will wait not on the bench but outside in the parking lot in an ark — just in case.

headline: Democrats Hit Romney on ‘Message of Wisconsin’ Comments
text: Democrats sought to turn the tables on Mitt Romney Friday afternoon by seizing on comments he made in Iowa that suggested the country doesn’t need more firefighters, police or teachers.

headline: Derek Jeter, Mets Killer
text: If any player deserved to be excited by the arrival of the Subway Series, Derek Jeter was a likely candidate. The slumping Jeter went into Friday’s game with the highest career batting average, .381, of any player against the Mets with a minimum of 150 plate appearances.

headline: Warm, Spicy Fare From the Himalayas
text: IT’S sometimes said that what Nepal grows best are mountains; the cold, rocky altitudes there pose significant challenges to farming. But despite the limitations of their environment, the people living in the valleys of the Himalayas have developed delicious dishes incorporating grains, nuts, and local meats and vegetables.

headline: The Hard Life on ‘The Rock’
text: There’s a scene late in “Murder in the First” in which Willie, a prisoner at Alcatraz, recalls his grim and troubled life. Why have people been so cruel to me, he wonders aloud to his lawyer.

headline: Ryan Lochte, Olympic Swimmer and Sex Symbol
text: Mr. Lochte, 27, is being groomed to be a breakout Olympic superstar, with millions in corporate sponsorships to match his athletic accomplishments.

headline: Egyptians Warned Not to Talk to Foreigners. Really.
text: Updated | Saturday, 1:42 p.m. CAIRO — An advertisement broadcast on Egyptian television this week warned a talkative public not to open up to foreign visitors, in case their new friends turn out to be spies seeking to undermine the state.

headline: A Repertory Far Beyond Italian
text: WHEN Joseph Tartaglia was searching for a name for his newest restaurant, someone suggested the fruit his family cultivated when he was growing up. That’s how he settled on Figs Wood Fired Bistro, a lively lunch and dinner spot in Sandy Hook that is much more about wood-fired than it is about figs.

headline: Formula One and Civil Unrest, Chapter IV: Montreal
text: MONTREAL — Remember Bahrain? In April, the Formula One series received near universal criticism for holding its race in a country experiencing a social uprising that brought daily demonstrations against the government, where the safety and the smooth running of the race were in doubt — to say nothing of the questionable morality of running the race in place accused of oppressing its citizens.

headline: It’s Early Pickings in the Berry Fields
text: MATTITUCK, N.Y.

headline: I’ll Have Another’s Injury Leaves Track Deflated
text: Word began to circulate just after 11 at Belmont Park on Friday morning. It almost seemed unbelievable. But it was true.

headline: Friday Night Music: More Early Music
text: There will be more indie bands, I promise. But for now a gorgeous performance suggested by reader Andre from Warsaw.

headline: U.S. Agency to Sell Off Loans to Stem Foreclosures
text: In a move intended to prevent foreclosure for thousands of homeowners and shed some seriously delinquent home loans, the Federal Housing Administration will sell off distressed mortgages in bulk, the housing secretary said Friday.

headline: Next Stop: Lattes or Gumbo
text: Two new cafes have sprung up on Walnut Street, near the New Jersey Transit rail station, close enough to serve trainbound commuters but appealing enough to tempt customers to settle in for a while.

headline: L Trains Are About to Become More Frequent
text: Claustrophobic Brooklynites rejoice: Starting on Sunday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will add 98 weekly round trips on the L line, an attempt to ease overcrowding and waiting times on one of the transit system’s most popular punching bags.

headline: Political Passions
text: AS the whirring election-year political machinery whips us into an us-versus-them frenzy, a visitor from another planet might look at it all and assume that Washington was either the entertainment capital of the country or an entirely fictional place brought to life on a Hollywood soundstage.

headline: Persian Cooking, Old-World Style
text: SUBTLETY is the hallmark of the kind of traditional Persian cooking on the menu at Ravagh Persian Grill, a nondescript-looking place flush up against a narrow strip of River Road in Edgewater. More fragrant than spicy, long on delicate, balanced flavors and short on anything startling, it’s stoutly Old Worldish fare; the focus is on pita dips, kebabs, stews and rice, with a few seafood dishes thrown in for American diners.

headline: Reviewing the Infiniti JX35
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2013 Infiniti JX35, a midlevel luxury crossover with three-row seating. Infiniti’s targets include the Acura MDX and Lexus RX, but the JX shoots wide of the mark, Mr. Ulrich writes:

headline: Week in Pictures for June 8
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the ceremony for the new Ashanti chief for metropolitan New York, the plummeting population of red knots, and the space shuttle Enterprise’s arrival at the Intrepid museum.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Frontiersmen
text: There is not a shadow of a doubt that the spotlight on dressing today is totally on men’s wear.

headline: Holder Directs U.S. Attorneys to Track Down Paths of Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday assigned two United States attorneys to lead separate criminal investigations into recent disclosures to the news media of national security secrets, saying they were authorized to “follow all appropriate investigative leads within the executive and legislative branches of government.”

headline: A Pioneer in a Mad Men’s World
text: SINCE “Mad Men” arrived five years ago, immediately ascending to the status of compulsion, we’ve been spared few reminiscences from survivors of corporate debauchery in mid-20th-century Manhattan.

headline: The Space Age Prophet
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: Exciting Firsts at Shades of Jazz
text: IN his six years as the curator of Shades of Jazz, a summer concert series at the Katonah Museum of Art, the guitarist John Scofield has built a reputation for pushing programming boundaries — a reputation that stands to grow this year with his booking of two decidedly eclectic performers, the multiethnic singer Cyrille Aimée and the “Saturday Night Live” saxophonist Lenny Pickett.

headline: The Irrepressible Auntie
text: Louise Pitre knows how to punch home a song. Starring as the irrepressible title character in “Mame” at the Goodspeed Opera House, she lends a fierce energy to the snazzy choreography by Vince Pesce and the efficient book scenes of Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee. But it’s not until everyone else departs and she’s left alone on James Youmans’s stylish set to sing the show’s rueful, climactic Jerry Herman ballad, “If He Walked Into My Life,” that this production comes fully into its own.

headline: Blowing Glass Is His Day Job, and His Other Job, Too
text: JERSEY CITY — As he wielded a hand torch in a cluttered two-car garage one recent night, Kiva Ford admitted, “I really don’t have time for a relationship because I love glass too much.”

headline: Untraded Yankee Keeps Trying to Justify Team’s Faith
text: The Yankees were playing in Detroit last Friday night, while Johan Santana was twirling the first no-hitter in Mets history back home. Phil Hughes noticed — it was all but impossible to miss — and he said he was happy for Santana. But the two have never met.

headline: Finding Humor and Pathos in Divorce
text: Angela Kennedy Lipsky was once half of the happy couple Angela and Matt. But as we meet Angela, now middle-aged, in “My Brilliant Divorce,” by Geraldine Aron, Matt has left her for a 25-year-old woman from Argentina after a long affair that Angela knew nothing about.

headline: Across Religions, Persistent Battles Over What the Faithful May Read
text: As Chris Isaak might sing, the nun did a bad, bad thing.

headline: Notions of Honor Color High-Stakes Haggling Over NATO Supply Routes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Early in the negotiations to reopen NATO supply routes through Pakistan, a senior American official suggested to his Pakistani counterparts that they should engage in “carpet haggling.”

headline: Reinforcements Are Coming
text: The Yankees’ two key injured players, Brett Gardner and Dave Robertson, are inching closer to returning, and both should be back in a week.

headline: You Gave Away Your Babies?
text: “Didn’t you just hate giving your jokes away and seeing someone else get the laughs?”

headline: A Bedtime Story for a Caribbean Night
text: Most people who have been on vacation in the Caribbean know that the premise behind “Once on This Island,” the atmospheric new production at the Paper Mill Playhouse, is based in socioeconomic reality. At many a destination, the taxi drive from the airport takes tourists through the poorer parts of the island, reminding them that the smiling people in crisp uniforms who bring them beach towels, piña coladas and room-service breakfasts in their bougainvillea-draped mini-villas lead daily lives that are a far cry from a five-star resort.

headline: Who Will Be Next to Call Nuclear Energy Indispensable?
text: Can’t live with it. Can’t live without it.

headline: A Move on Marijuana in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: James Has a Chance to Even the Score
text: BOSTON — Jerry West had the Celtics. Michael Jordan had the Pistons. Some of the great ones had to wait their turn. The process could be painful and even humiliating.

headline: Take Back the Streets
text: A FEW years ago, when my husband and I were planning our daughter’s wedding, I worried — not that the groom would vanish, the bride would trip or guests would be deluged by downpour. I worried that the bridal party would march out of Calvary Church into Street Fair Hell.

headline: Wife of Al Qaeda Leader Praises Muslim Women for Role in Uprisings
text: The wife of Al Qaeda’s leader, Ayman al-Zawahri, has made a rare online appeal to Muslim women, praising their role in the Arab Spring uprisings and urging them to raise their children “to love jihad and martyrdom.”

headline: Six Words From Obama, and a Barrage in Return From the G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — With good reason, presidents have long been said to hold the power of the bully pulpit. But when President Obama sought to wield it on Friday, by calling a White House news conference to showcase his concern for the economy and Republicans’ refusal to work with him, he was the one who ended up getting pummeled.

headline: The Euro’s 11th Hour
text: WITH each passing day, the noose around the neck of the euro zone grows tighter, with no indication that European leaders share any coherent vision for avoiding the hangman.

headline: In Era of Cheap Money, Consumers Are Shut Out
text: Michael Shreve, a 57-year-old science teacher in Marysville, Wash., has watched helplessly as mortgage rates have fallen. He said that despite his stellar credit score, no bank had been willing to let him trade in his 6.35 percent 30-year mortgage because his house was now worth less than when he bought it.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Europe’s downturn started to affect economies elsewhere — including the United States, where it threatened to undermine President Obama’s re-election chances, and China, which lowered interest rates to reinvigorate its economy.

headline: Facebook Holds a Vote and Turnout Is Low
text: It has more than 900 million people. It has its own currency. And this month, for the first time, the digital republic known as Facebook held elections of a sort: it offered users a chance to vote on the way the site is governed, including how the company deploys its users’ data.

headline: Suicides Outpacing War Deaths for Troops
text: The suicide rate among the nation’s active-duty military personnel has spiked this year, eclipsing the number of troops dying in battle and on pace to set a record annual high since the start of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan more than a decade ago, the Pentagon said Friday.

headline: Stop, Frisk, Record
text: APP Stop and Frisk Watch

headline: Majoring in Eligibility
text: The lead article in The Chronicle of Higher Education this week is about a University of Memphis football player named Dasmine Cathey. He lives not on campus but in his aunt’s home nearby, where he helps raise his siblings, who were essentially abandoned by their mother. He has two children of his own (with different mothers). He uses his Pell grant money to help pay the household bills and often skips class because he has to drive a family member somewhere. It’s a lot for a college student to shoulder, but he doesn’t shirk it.

headline: In Its Unyielding Stance on Syria, Russia Takes Substantial Risks in Middle East
text: MOSCOW — The international deadlock over Syria has, in a dreadful way, provided balm for old grievances in this city. After years of fuming about Western-led campaigns to force leaders from power, Russia has seized the opportunity to make its point heard.

headline: Twists and Turns Lead to a New Life
text: When Jared McCann was 12, he was the only kid in his Southern Baptist church in Hawaii not to be baptized. One Sunday, during the traditional altar call, his mother whispered, “Jared, don’t you feel Jesus calling at your heart?”

headline: Drug Link Is Suspected in Triple-Killing Near Columbia University
text: The streets surrounding Columbia University whirled with people as the evening rush hour gave way to happy hour on Thursday night.

headline: A Public Pension Should Be Public
text: For years, New York taxpayers have been able to find out the pension benefits for retired public employees, like state troopers, corrections officers and public schoolteachers. But New York City police pension officials have refused to disclose the names of retirees receiving pensions and the amount of the benefits. Those officials — unlike other state and local officials — decided to hide behind an ambiguity in the state’s Freedom of Information law.

headline: A Season of Open Windows, and the Second-Story Man
text: He left the apartment that Wednesday morning as he did every other day, planning on getting some work done on a book he was writing. But something strange happened.

headline: How Morning-After Pills Really Work
text: Religious conservatives are losing one of their primary arguments for trying to ban the morning-after birth control pill that can prevent pregnancy if taken within days after sexual intercourse. They and their political allies have long contended that the pills work by aborting an embryo at the earliest stages of development. But, as Pam Belluck reported in The Times on Wednesday, the latest scientific findings and expert opinion indicate that the pills work by delaying ovulation so that sperm can’t fertilize an egg to create an embryo.

headline: A Yoga Champion’s Unlikely Path
text: Jared McCann exchanged partying for practicing, sweetbreads for seaweed and his drug habit for a Vita Mix blender.

headline: Boys’ Clothes May Be Clue in Patz Case
text: Detectives who searched the New Jersey home of the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz found what “looked like young boys’ clothing” and an old toy, but were being “very cautious” about concluding they belonged to Etan, who disappeared in 1979, people with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

headline: Away From Press, Obama Meets With Star-Struck Celebrities
text: The stars came out in the morning this week for President Obama.

headline: Cross Reference
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Don’t you just hate it when you know you know an answer, you’re just positive it’s right, and yet it doesn’t seem to fit in the grid?

headline: A Day of School Revelry, Capped by Wine
text: The neighborhood restaurant plays a limited, but critical, role in New York’s culinary life: It is the place one goes not to be surprised, but satisfied. It’s always a little surprising, then, to find one that’s more than satisfactory. Saggio, a homey, full-flavored trattoria at 829 West 181st Street, is one of the newer restaurants in the micro-neighborhood that sits on the downslope between Fort Washington Avenue and the Henry Hudson Parkway in Washington Heights. On a late spring evening, you will find its front window invitingly thrown open to homebound commuters, congregating dog owners and perhaps a group of teachers from a local elementary school relaxing after a hard day with some pasta and a glass of wine.

headline: Genentech Wins Approval for New Breast Cancer Drug
text: Genentech won federal approval Friday for a new drug to treat advanced breast cancer. But the company said it was experiencing manufacturing problems that could lead to a shortage of the drug.

headline: In Latest Phase of Ground Zero Building Dispute, a New Call for Oversight
text: The financial dispute that has hobbled construction of the museum at ground zero for eight months entered a new stage this week with a struggle over who will control the overall memorial and the eight-acre site. The Sept. 11 memorial foundation, which is led by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has been responsible for the planning, development and programming of the memorial at the trade center site, as well as the visitor center and the National Sept. 11 Memorial and Museum, under a 2006 agreement.

headline: Private Florida Island Is Sold for a Mere $258,000, Piña Coladas Not Included
text: MIAMI — Ever dreamed of joining the roster of celebrities and moguls who boast of sipping piña coladas at sunset on their own private island?

headline: Commander Apologizes for Afghan Airstrike
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The NATO and United States troop commander in Afghanistan flew to the eastern part of the country on Friday to apologize personally to surviving family members for a coalition airstrike earlier this week that local officials said killed 18 civilians.

headline: Withholding Rent, a Loft Tenant Comes Out on Top
text: A sign above the entrance to Margaret Maugenest’s pale-coral Brooklyn building proclaims, “Artists in residence on 2nd-3rd-4th floors.”

headline: From a No-Hitter to No Mercy for Santana
text: Johan Santana was working in uncharted territory Friday when he became the first Mets pitcher to make a start after throwing a no-hitter. He was the toast of baseball for a week after humbling the St. Louis Cardinals on June 1, but he required 134 pitches to do it.

headline: David L. Rimoin, Geneticist and Expert on Dwarfism, Dies at 75
text: Dr. David L. Rimoin, a medical geneticist who made major discoveries in the study of dwarfism and skeletal disorders and helped develop large-scale testing for inherited diseases, died on May 27 in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: In Return to the Mets’ Lineup, Bay Picks Up Where He Left Off
text: Jason Bay made a somewhat unheralded return to the Mets’ lineup Friday night at Yankee Stadium, slipping into the eighth spot in the order and playing left field.

headline: Some Sunlight Would Be Nice
text: This has been a bad week for Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, and the way he and his staff have handled it only made it worse.

headline: Assad, the Butcher
text: In the latest horrors from Syria, United Nations monitors are investigating a massacre in the hamlet of Qubeir, where some 78 people reportedly were shot, garroted or burned alive. If formally confirmed, it would be the fourth massacre in two weeks. Activists said an assault on the town of Hiffeh that began on Monday included the first use of missiles fired from helicopter gunships since the anti-Assad protests began 16 months ago.

headline: A Sport Left at the Post
text: No more shots in the arm and no more shortcuts, more than a great day that deepens denial, horse racing needs to be shaken up, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Bargain Hunter on Two Wheels
text: Donyale Werle, a Tony Award-nominated, Obie-winning theatrical set designer and stoop-sale connoisseur, generally spends Sundays in or near her 400-square-foot co-op on the top floor of a brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn, taking a break from show business and Broadway. But she will make an exception and get dressed up on Sunday night for the 2012 Tony Awards: Her nomination for set design for “Peter and the Starcatcher” is among nine the show garnered. Ms. Werle, 41, lives with her husband, Paul Jepson, 43, a stagehand at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and their two cats, Fluffy and Kookaburra.

headline: Video: A Sport Left at the Post
text: No more shots in the arm and no more shortcuts, more than a great day that deepens denial, horse racing needs to be shaken up, says William C. Rhoden.

headline: Inflation Slows in China as the Economy Continues to Weaken
text: HONG KONG — Inflation slowed sharply in China last month as companies cut prices to cope with faltering demand, as the Chinese economy appeared to slow further, data released on Saturday morning showed.

headline: Businesses Borrowing But Not Consumers
text: Businesses are taking on new debt, while consumers are shedding it.

headline: Desperate Ugandans Seek Makeshift Healers as Mysterious Illness Strikes Young
text: OJURU, Uganda — Haunted by a merciless and debilitating disease that doctors cannot cure, villagers in this remote enclave in northern Uganda have turned to traditional healers like Alfred Ojara.

headline: Our Belmont Picks, on the Money
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome our guest picker, Melissa Francis, the host of the Fox Business Network show “MONEY with Melissa Francis.” As a childhood actress she played Cassandra Cooper Ingalls on “Little House on the Prairie” before later leaving Hollywood for Harvard, where she studied economics and was the captain of the polo team.

headline: French Connection
text: French expats living in the United States and in Canada will vote for representatives to the French National Assembly.

headline: Court Forces a Rethinking of Nuclear Fuel Storage
text: WASHINGTON — The Nuclear Regulatory Commission acted hastily in concluding that spent fuel can be stored safely at nuclear plants for the next century or so in the absence of a permanent repository, and it must consider what will happen if none are ever established, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday.

headline: In New York, French Politics Is Local
text: FLANKED by four campaign volunteers and a French television reporter, Corinne Narassiguin, a Socialist candidate in France’s coming parliamentary elections, went canvassing in her would-be district one evening in May.

headline: Obama Expresses Support for Philippines in China Rift
text: WASHINGTON — A festering quarrel that began over rare coral, giant clams and sharks in a distant sea made its way to the Oval Office on Friday, as President Benigno S. Aquino III of the Philippines sought the backing of President Obama in a maritime dispute with China.

headline: Every Night at the Opera
text: Lois Kirschenbaum, 79, has been attending opera and ballet performances in New York City for more than a half-century, and always stops at the stage door to meet the performers.

headline: Back from Injury, Se Ri Pak Leads L.P.G.A.
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — The leader of the L.P.G.A. Championship, Se Ri Pak, may not know the adage “Beware of the wounded golfer,” but she certainly has not played like a woman who has been sidelined for the last five L.P.G.A. tournaments with a shoulder injury.

headline: A Scratch Hurts NBC, Too
text: Before he was scratched from the Belmont Stakes on Friday, I’ll Have Another was NBC’s newest star, bigger than anyone playing on its air in the Stanley Cup finals. As the latest horse to seek the Triple Crown, he was NBC’s male lead in a movie-trailer-like promo, with stirring music and imagery, and excited voices.

headline: Queen of the Nosebleed Seats
text: “Any tickets for tonight, any singles?” intoned the elderly woman with the purple coat and throaty voice. “Looking for a single for tonight.”

headline: Protesters Gather in Cairo Amid Escalating Tensions
text: CAIRO — Thousands of Egyptians filled Tahrir Square on Friday with fury building amid fears that the punishment meted out to their ousted president might not stand and that the vote to choose his successor might in fact be part of a slow but unmistakable re-emergence of authoritarianism.

headline: After Edwards Trial, Much Returns to Normal, but Not All Is Set
text: The trial of former Senator John Edwards is over, and life has begun to creep back toward normal for many of the players.

headline: Greeks Rally in Opener and Spoil Poland’s Party
text: Warsaw

headline: Shh! Scholars Fight Over Library Plan
text: In the mid-1990s, when digital life had just arrived and branches of Barnes & Noble were embedding themselves in the city’s neighborhoods like moths in a coat rack, it would have been hard to foresee a time, well into the next millennium, when the matter of libraries might ignite passion and fury. And yet here we are. During recent weeks, the debate surrounding the New York Public Library’s plan to expand its central branch at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street has fiercely intensified in print, online and in public forums. Amid the heat and acrimony, few have taken the time to recognize what this might signify for the progress of civilization in a world otherwise dominated by 140-character discussions of “Mob Wives.”

headline: French Face a Battle to Control Parliament
text: PARIS — François Hollande may have been elected France’s president only a month ago, but the fate of his presidency will rest largely on the results of legislative elections that begin Sunday and conclude a week later.

headline: The Neighbors Who Don’t Knock
text: NO one on the floor can say how or why it happened, what made them different from other residents in the building. Maybe it began with a small thing: a cup of coffee brought from across the hall, a phone call at night to make sure the day’s demons were not filling up the dark.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 8, 2012

headline: Florida Halts Its Search for Violations of Voter Law
text: Florida’s attempt to purge ineligible voters from its rolls has been halted, at least for now.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: To Keep Up With Tennis’s Best, It’s All in the Wrist
text: PARIS — Linda Christensen and Julie C. Rabe spend their year around professional athletes, mostly tennis players; travel the world from tournament to tournament; adjust to the players’ personalities and tics, their speed and pace.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Making Impact in Finals After Concussions, Three Players Offer Hope
text: NEWARK — Concussions are omnipresent in hockey, even in the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,987 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Corrections: June 9
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Viola-Darling Pitching Duel in 1981 Has Not Been Forgotten
text: The game began on an afternoon in mid-May but has endured for 31 years, immortalized by a famous magazine article, viewed live by only 2,000 spectators but perpetuated, through the decades, as a moment of triumph and torment.

headline: Grappling With a New Scourge
text: For years now, New Mexico has wrestled with poverty, drunken-driving deaths and substance abuse. But recently, a new affliction has hammered the state: prescription drug overdoses.

headline: A Cup Qualifying Victory Lacks Quality
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Strange things often happen on the road to World Cup qualification, and for a few tense minutes on Friday night, it looked as if the tiny twin-island nation of Antigua and Barbuda was going to seriously challenge the United States.

headline: Spanish Banks Need $46 Billion, I.M.F. Says in Audit
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund said late Friday that Spain’s banks would need to raise at least 37 billion euros, or about $46 billion, as a buffer against a sharper economic contraction in the country. That number will guide European policy makers as they seek to stabilize the Spanish financial system and prevent contagion to the rest of the euro zone.

headline: Saints Bounty Grievance Is Denied Again
text: Four days after having one argument turned down by an arbitrator, the N.F.L. players union was denied again Friday in its quest to challenge the discipline handed out by Commissioner Roger Goodell regarding the New Orleans Saints bounty scandal.

headline: Long-Idle Defenseman Talked His Way Back on the Ice
text: NEWARK — Henrik Tallinder, the Devils’ sturdy 33-year-old defenseman, finally got to play his first hockey game in more than four months Wednesday. Tallinder passed time between periods asking Mark Fayne, another Devils defenseman, if he looked as out of rhythm as he felt.

headline: Fighting to Stay in Game While Battling Alcoholism
text: Dale Romans stood on the apron at Belmont Park on Wednesday morning and offered his assessment of Kent Desormeaux, the Hall of Fame jockey who will not be riding Romans’s horse Saturday in the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Nearly 90 percent of the infant deaths that took place at Srinagar’s G.B. Pant hospital were due to infections because of unsanitary conditions at the hospital, unnamed sources told the Kashmir Times. Ventilator tube and humidifiers were reused without being cleaned or disinfected, a “senior” source said, leading to cross-infections of pneumonia.

headline: Devils Receive Possible Cash Infusion
text: The search by Jeff Vanderbeek, the controlling owner of the Devils, for outside investment to stabilize the team’s finances has apparently ended successfully. A person briefed on the pending transaction said that Vanderbeek had found at least one investor to inject cash into the team and deal with its overdue debt. The person who described the estimated $200 million deal said it would lead to a reduction of the 47 percent stake owned by Ray Chambers and Michael Gilfillan. At the same time, part of the $77 million debt payment owed by the team and Prudential Center will be repaid as part of the complex transaction. Banks have extended the deadline for repaying the debt; if they had not, the team would have been in default. The deal was first reported by The Sports Business Journal.

headline: Reigning World Champion Is Tied at Top in U.S. Gymnastics Meet
text: The reigning world champion Jordyn Wieber closed out the first day of the United States women’s gymnastics championships in St. Louis tied for first place with Gabrielle Douglas. Wieber, who won last year’s national title by more than six points, said the tie didn’t faze her because this is just a warm-up meet for Olympic trials later this month.

headline: More Unrest Around Syria, in Hot Spots Old and New
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Activists reported new violence in southwest Syria on Saturday, saying shelling by troops and clashes between soldiers and rebel fighters in the city of Dara’a had killed 17 people, including women and children.

headline: China Plans Its First Manned Space Docking
text: HONG KONG — China’s space agency said on Saturday that it will launch astronauts later in June to perform the country’s first manned space docking, the latest step in the country’s ambitious plan for space exploration.

headline: Giants Honored at White House
text: Rex Ryan talked about it. The Giants did it. They visited the White House on Friday for the traditional salute to Super Bowl champions.

headline: Tie at Top for U.S. Women Gymnasts
text: ST. LOUIS – Reigning world champion Jordyn Wieber closed out the first day of the women’s United States gymnastics national championships on Friday tied for first place with Gabrielle Douglas, one of her teammates on last year’s world champion squad.

headline: The Making of an Olympic Sex Symbol
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.

headline: The Weekend Word: Investigation
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Bonnaroo: An Afternoon of Smart Female Singers and Songwriters
text: This one’s for the ladies. Actually that was Ludacris’s line as he introduced one of his many celebrations of lust and intoxication, setting off squeals, fist pumps and shout-alongs in a wildly appreciative arena-size crowd that swarmed well beyond This Tent. He had a backup band with him, not that I could get close enough to see it onstage.

headline: A Reporter’s Marathon Day in Sports
text: Many world-class sporting events are scheduled for today, and several of them are in the New York metropolitan area. Mike Tanier is blogging and tweeting at events and locations throughout the region, including the Mets-Yankees game in the Bronx, Game 5 of the Kings-Devils Stanley Cup finals in Newark and the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island. Follow his progress here and on Twitter @FO_MTanier with the hashtag #fanathon.

headline: Afghan Official Rebukes NATO for Civilian Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan president’s spokesman sternly rebuked American officials on Saturday, saying that the civilian casualties last week during an NATO-Afghan raid on Taliban fighters in eastern Afghanistan were unacceptable, not only because of the loss of innocent life but also because Afghan forces were not involved in the decision to call in an airstrike.

headline: Spain to Accept Rescue From Europe for Its Ailing Banks
text: MADRID — Responding to increasingly urgent calls from across Europe and the United States, Spain on Saturday agreed to accept a bailout for its cash-starved banks as European finance ministers offered an aid package of up to $125 billion.

headline: Half Photos, Striving to be More
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Anyone who has used 35-millimeter film knows that you must shoot, and advance, three frames before making any meaningful photographs. If you don’t, you are likely to get a frame that is partly fogged from daylight.

headline: Affirming Slowdown, China Reports Second Month of Scant Economic Growth
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese economy, widely seen until the last few weeks as the strongest remaining locomotive that could drag the global economy back from the brink of recession, showed a second month of anemic growth in May and performed even worse than the already lowered expectations of most economists.

headline: Urban Forager | Mulberries
text: Recently, I was walking up Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side when I felt something squishy beneath my sandals.

headline: Watching an Unsuccessful Triple Crown Bid, and Finding a Passion
text: I was an alien on foreign soil, heading directly into something I knew nothing about but with a strong desire to watch history in the making.

headline: Sharapova Wins the French Open
text: Maria Sharapova became only the 10th woman in tennis history to win all four Grand Slam titles, overcoming a spirited challenge from Sara Errani to win the 2012 French Open final, 6-3, 6-2.

headline: Nurturing a Baby and a Start-Up Business
text: FLEDGLING companies are like sticky-fingered toddlers. You’ve got to watch them every single minute.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Gay Trajectory
text: OVER the past year, the main story line in the push for marriage equality has been the ardor and success with which leading Democratic politicians have taken up the fight. The Democratic governors of New York, Maryland and Washington all promoted and signed same-sex marriage laws, for which President Obama expressed his support last month.

headline: Paul Singer’s Equality Efforts
text: In my column this weekend, I look at the efforts of Paul E. Singer, a billionaire hedge fund manager, and the way they reflect surprising and important pockets of support within the Republican Party for same-sex marriage.

headline: On Your (Last) Calendar: Mayan Sleepovers
text: Before the Mayan calendar ends in December, travelers to Belize can pay homage to the indigenous culture in overnight stays at the Caracol archaeological site.

headline: Entrepreneurship and Motherhood
text: Many women in the start-up community are balancing entrepreneurship and motherhood.

headline: Messi in Times Square, Kind Of
text: Argentina is in town to play Brazil in an international friendly Saturday afternoon at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Agüero Cools English Ire Over His Father-in-Law
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — They are fitting bookends to the long and often tortured soccer (and geopolitical) history between Argentina and England — the Hand of God and the Foot of Kun.

headline: French Open Women’s Final
text: Maria Sharapova won the first set in her French Open tennis final against Italy’s Sara Errani as the Russian tries to win her first title at Roland Garros and complete the career Grand Slam.

headline: Moving in Opposite Directions, Italy and Spain Are Set to Collide
text: On June 22, 2008, my girlfriend, now my wife, and I watched Spain defeat Italy on penalties in the quarterfinals of the European Championships at a Bavarian beer hall in the East Village with a German former decathlete.

headline: War May Be Ending, but Fight Isn’t Over for Soldiers in Remote Afghanistan
text: COMBAT OUTPOST RAHMAN KHEL, Afghanistan — Lt. Col. Shawn Daniel, standing in the middle of this dusty little outpost beneath the Afghan mountains, reassured the 70 soldiers gathered close around him that they would be going home soon.

headline: Pitchers are a Group of Winless Wonders
text: Going into last Tuesday’s games, only three pitchers had made eight starts this season without a victory. One was Chris Volstad of the Chicago Cubs, who was demoted to the minors with a 7.46 E.R.A.

headline: I’ll Have Another’s Sire: Big, Friendly and Newly Popular
text: Sandy Hatfield is the stallion manager at Three Chimneys Farm in Versailles, Ky., where I’ll Have Another’s sire, Flower Alley, stands. Hatfield is both den mother and Dr. Ruth to the farm’s nine stallions, knowing each horse and its foibles.

headline: Fighting Cyberbullies With Laws and Laughter
text: LONDON — In what is being described as a landmark case, a British woman has secured a court order obliging Facebook to reveal the identity of “cyberbullies” who targeted her with an online campaign of “vicious and depraved” abuse.

headline: Variety: A Cryptic That Cracked Me Up
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s no secret that I love me some Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon cryptic crosswords. Not only do I feel like I’m on their wavelength when it comes to solving their puzzles, but they’re just so funny. I love a puzzle that makes me laugh. I think you’ll like this one as much as I did.

headline: For Djokovic and Nadal, It’s a Chess Match
text: Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal will play in the final at Roland Garros on Sunday in a match guaranteed to make history. A Djokovic win would be his fourth straight major title. While technically not a Grand Slam (which must occur in the same calendar year), it would nonetheless be an astonishing accomplishment. For Nadal, a victory on Sunday would give him a record seventh French Open title, eclipsing Bjorn Borg’s total and further cementing his reputation as the best clay-court player ever.

headline: An Exclusive Club: Garlands and Corsages
text: Every year when a Triple Crown is on the line, three women usually gather at Belmont Park, each wearing a corsage: one blue and white, one yellow and black, one pink and black.

headline: A French Open Title and a Career Grand Slam for Sharapova
text: PARIS — Ever since shoulder surgery nearly forced Maria Sharapova into early retirement, she occupied an odd, conflicted space in both tennis and the wider world of sports. She remained among the most marketable female athletes on the planet, tall and blond and famous, a superstar in every sense except the most important one.

headline: Tale of 3 Inmates Who Vanished From Alcatraz Maintains Intrigue 50 Years Later
text: Fifty years ago, on the night of June 11, 1962, the three convicts were locked down as usual. Guards walking the tier outside their cells saw them at 9:30 and checked on them periodically all night, looking in at the sleeping faces, hearing nothing strange. But by morning, the inmates had vanished, Houdini-like.

headline: Wolkenkuckucksheim
text: Martin Wolf reports on a letter he has received from the Director General of the German Finance Ministry; taken in context with the speech just given in Riga by Germany’s man at the ECB, what we get is a terrifying picture. Basically, it seems that even as the euro approaches a critical juncture, senior German officials are living in Wolkenkuckucksheim — cloud-cuckoo land.

headline: Favorites Have Way of Fading When Open Is Played at Olympic
text: At the United States Open championship, the charm and the challenge for the world’s best golfers is coping with a course many of them have not played for more than a decade, if at all. This year’s site is the Lake Course of Olympic Club in San Francisco, a little bit of heaven with mostly sidehill fairways that drift down from the sandy cliffs above the Pacific Ocean through sentries of cypress trees and sloping target greens to the shore of Lake Merced. The club’s name calls to mind Mount Olympus, the home of the mythical Greek gods, but at its four previous Opens over more than half a century, Olympic has treated human golf gods rudely. And what glorious gods they were.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Anniversary of a Mystery at Alcatraz
text: Fifty years ago, on the night of June 11, 1962, the three convicts escaped from Alcatraz and vanished.

headline: New Generation of Ethiopians March Toward Dream of Acceptance in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Yetmwork Makurya, 35, had tears in her eyes as she spoke of her attachment to Israel. When she arrived as a teenager in 1991 on a secret overnight airlift from Ethiopia, she said, “Jerusalem and the land of Israel was my dream.”

headline: Levels, Percentages, and Structural Unemployment (Wonkish)
text: Just a quick note on a question that comes up in some comments: why do I sometimes look at percentage changes in unemployment, sometimes at changes in absolute levels? Isn’t that inconsistent?

headline: For Football’s Sake, Closely Guarding Sexual Orientation
text: David Snell knew only two other black gay people while growing up in Madison, N.J., an upper-middle-class town with white-picket fences, a mostly Irish and Italian population. One was a 13-year-old boy whom Snell encountered at his small Baptist church.

headline: Pirates Gambling on Pitchers
text: The Pittsburgh Pirates drafted aggressively again last week, grabbing the Stanford right-hander Mark Appel, a Scott Boras client, when he fell to them with the No. 8 pick. Now the Pirates must decide how much of their allotted bonus pool of $6.56 million they should give him.

headline: Standing in Djokovic’s Way: An Immovable Object
text: PARIS

headline: Health Care After the Supreme Court Ruling
text: LATER this month, the Supreme Court will rule on the Obama administration’s health care law, the Affordable Care Act, deciding whether to uphold or strike down the entire law, or to keep some provisions.

headline: A Road Trip With Lord Stanley’s Cup
text: I once traveled with the Stanley Cup in the trunk of a car.

headline: A Signature Race in a Signature Series Lacks a Signature Drink
text: Penny Chenery, who owned and bred the 1973 Triple Crown winner Secretariat, describes the Kentucky Derby as a happening “that happens to take place at a racetrack.”

headline: ‘Study Drugs’ Popular Among High School Students
text: Stimulant medications prescribed for children with A.D.H.D. are being abused by high school students wanting to study late into the night and stay focused during exams.

headline: Fewer Prescriptions for A.D.H.D., Less Drug Abuse?
text: Should doctors prescribe fewer stimulants for teenagers, to try to limit the number of young people abusing these drugs for an academic edge?

headline: Risky Rise of the Good-Grade Pill
text: He steered into the high school parking lot, clicked off the ignition and scanned the scraps of his recent weeks. Crinkled chip bags on the dashboard. Soda cups at his feet. And on the passenger seat, a rumpled SAT practice book whose owner had been told since fourth grade he was headed to the Ivy League. Pencils up in 20 minutes.

headline: Riding a Horse and Carrying a Microphone
text: When Mario Gutierrez came from virtually nowhere to ride I’ll Have Another to victory in the Kentucky Derby, Donna Barton Brothers was waiting just beyond the finish line to interview him in her role as analyst for NBC — on horseback. For Brothers, being on a horse comes more naturally than holding a microphone. Her mother, Patti Barton, was a trailblazer for women jockeys, and Brothers, her sister and her brother followed in her footsteps. When Brothers retired in 1998, she was the second-winningest female rider in the United States by money earned. But she never strayed too far away from the sport she loved. She is married to a horse trainer, Frank Brothers, and works as an analyst for NBC Sports and TVG.

headline: Breaking It Down: Djokovic vs. Federer
text: There is an intense pressure that Novak Djokovic, the world No. 1, brings to a match that you just can’t find on a stat sheet – or can you?

headline: Ex-Yankee Cabrera Whips Career Into Shape
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Several San Francisco Giants veterans, including Barry Zito, Aubrey Huff and Ryan Theriot, were sitting by their lockers at AT&T Park last weekend discussing how the team would muddle through if their closer, Santiago Casilla, could not pitch because of a knee injury.

headline: Keeping Score: Hope That Puerto Rico Can End Its Major League Slump
text: In April 1942, five years before Jackie Robinson broke baseball’s color line, Hiram Bithorn made his debut for the Chicago Cubs. By 1943, he was one of the game’s earliest Hispanic stars, winning 18 games, tossing 7 shutouts and compiling a 2.60 earned-run average.

headline: Bonnaroo: Radiohead’s Festival Evolution
text: The last time Radiohead played at Bonnaroo, in 2006, it seemed to metamorphose on the spot: from a cerebral, futuristic, anxiety-driven band playing its arcane songs to earnest theater audiences to a cerebral, futuristic band that could make tens of thousands of people dance like crazy. Friday night at Bonnaroo was the follow-through: Radiohead the rhythm band, hitting groove after groove and riding them to darkly kinetic places.

headline: A Western Outpost Shrinks on a Remote Island Now in Japanese Hands
text: CHICHI JIMA, Japan — Every morning, as the sun rises over this remote Pacific Island and its tiny port with typically Japanese low-slung concrete buildings, John Washington commits a quiet act of defiance against the famously insular Japan: he hoists an American flag over his inn.

headline: On a Japanese Island, a Community Apart
text: Tourists who travel to Chichi Jima in search of Japan’s last island paradise find a community of foreigners from the West, whose families have lived in Japan for nearly two centuries.

headline: South Carolina’s Pension Push Into High-Octane Investments
text: Columbia, S.C.

headline: Pampered Like Royalty, or Canned Like Sardines?
text: You bought a domestic coach seat on Delta* and you’re hoping to get a free upgrade at the gate, but there is only one first-class seat available. Follow the steps to find out what your chances are.

headline: It’s Time for the Fed to Lead the Fight
text: THE next meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers, on June 19 and 20, will probably be contentious. The latest employment report, showing anemic job growth for a third consecutive month and an uptick in unemployment, will surely make some Fed members want to take additional expansionary action. Others, however, appear steadfastly opposed.

headline: The Quest for Nash Could Take a Detour
text: Where will Alexander Radulov go, and will anyone want him? That is the big off-ice question of the week ahead.

headline: Facing a Challenge in Retaining Talent
text: The Oklahoma City Thunder have yet to win a championship, but the fear of breaking up a potential dynasty already has to be weighing on the minds of the team’s growing fan base.

headline: In Brazil, Battles for Ancestral Land
text: The expansion of huge cattle ranches and industrial-scale farms in remote regions has produced a land scramble, with conflicts among indigenous groups often ending in violent clashes.

headline: Violence Hits Brazil Tribes in Scramble for Land
text: ARAL MOREIRA, Brazil — The gunmen emerged from pickup trucks at dawn, their faces hidden in balaclavas, and stormed into an encampment surrounded by a field of soybean plants near this town on Brazil’s porous frontier with Paraguay.

headline: The Algorithm Didn’t Like My Essay
text: AS a professor and a parent, I have long dreamed of finding a software program that helps every student learn to write well. It would serve as a kind of tireless instructor, flagging grammatical, punctuation or word-use problems, but also showing the way to greater concision and clarity.

headline: How Banks Could Return the Favor
text: LIKE millions of homeowners, shrewd state and local governments are looking to refinance. Interest rates have hit rock bottom. So why not save some public money by replacing old debts with new ones at lower rates?

headline: The Recovery’s Fate, Back in Consumers’ Hands
text: ONE bright spot in the lusterless recovery that started in 2009 has been the performance of the private sector.

headline: When You Write a Report Card, Explain the Grades
text: This interview with  Laura Yecies, chief executive of SugarSync, an online storage service based in San Mateo, Calif., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: An Unforgettable Smile and an Unforgettable Experience
text: She did not want to root for another horse. I’ll Have Another was 12-year-old Hope Hudson’s pick, her friend and her reason for being at Belmont Park this weekend.

headline: Another Shoe Drops on Facebook
text: FACEBOOK’S initial public stock offering caused a lot of well-publicized agita. But if you think investors were the only ones fuming at the company, read on.

headline: Congressional Committees Seek Drug Information
text: Members of two Congressional committees investigating the drugging of racehorses have sent letters to racing regulators in 39 states seeking information on how trainers with multiple drug violations are disciplined and how often certain performance-enhancing treatments are used.

headline: Mirnyi and Nestor Repeat as French Open Doubles Champions
text: PARIS — The first time Max Mirnyi stepped to the line in the French Open men’s doubles final on Saturday, the Bryan twins kept him serving for nearly four minutes, holding him hostage on three break points and numerous deuces.

headline: For U.S. Inquiries on Leaks, a Difficult Road to Prosecution
text: WASHINGTON — Anger over leaks of government secrets and calls for prosecution have once again engulfed the nation’s capital. Under bipartisan pressure for a crackdown, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Friday announced the appointment of two top prosecutors to lead investigations into recent disclosures.

headline: Tenacity and Teamwork
text: I WAS born in Birmingham, England. My father was a machine tool fitter for the factory that produced the first Austin Mini car, and my mother was a seamstress at a factory. My parents worked hard to raise my older brother and me.

headline: Two Jobs, but Half a World Apart
text: YOU could say that I was raised to be a nomad. By the 10th grade, I had attended 10 schools throughout Rajasthan, my home state in northwestern India. That’s what it’s like when your dad is a civil servant for the Rajasthan Administrative Service. The experience turned out to be good training for my current working life.

headline: Padres History Missing Chapter on No-Hitters
text: Jerry Coleman has spent most of the last 70 years in professional baseball, but he has not been on the winning side of a no-hitter since Don Larsen’s perfect game in the 1956 World Series. Coleman was an infielder for the Yankees.

headline: They Got the Song Right Here
text: One of the most thrilling parts of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness pomp and circumstance comes when 100,000 voices rise for the singing of “My Old Kentucky Home” and “Maryland, My Maryland.”

headline: A Roe, by Any Other Name
text: NEW ORLEANS — The swampy Atchafalaya Basin is a far cry from the cold waters of the Caspian Sea. And its lowly native bowfin, often derided as a throwaway fish, is no prized sturgeon. Yet it is laying golden eggs.

headline: Bypassing the Grape but Enjoying Its Fruits
text: CAMERON HUGHES sees nothing romantic about being a winemaker. Having a rolling vineyard to call his own? Taking that first sip of a homegrown pinot noir? He can live without it, thanks — and he does, even as he has become a prominent name in the California wine industry.

headline: Mariners’ Scramble Yields a No-Hitter by Committee
text: SEATTLE (AP) — Mariners shortstop Brendan Ryan popped his head into the clubhouse interview room and insisted his normally stoic manager enjoyed the history that just took place.

headline: Pitching Mound Is a Work of Art Often Abused
text: DETROIT (AP) — The mound at Comerica Park sits under a protective tarp during batting practice. Once the game starts, the abuse begins.

headline: Live Analysis: Union Rags Wins the Belmont Stakes
text: Union Rags appeared to benefit from a jockey change to John Velazquez, staying out of trouble to win the Belmont Stakes on Saturday by a neck over the Bob Baffert-trained Paynter.

headline: North Korea Describes Provocation
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Saturday that although it had no current plans to conduct a nuclear test, South Korea was trying to provoke it into conducting one and taking other retaliatory actions, like an artillery attack.

headline: Russia Increases Military Flights Over Armenia
text: MOSCOW — Russian fighter jets are conducting an increasing number of training flights over Armenia, a military spokesman said Saturday, sending a clear warning that Russia could intervene at any moment should violence escalate further in the territorial dispute between Armenia and Azerbaijan.

headline: Rousing the White House on Syria and Sudan
text: My Sunday column argues that President Obama, whose foreign policy I normally admire, has been behind the curve in responding to the humanitarian crises in Syria and the Nuba Mountains of Sudan. Granted, there aren’t good options in either place, but bad options shouldn’t be an excuse for the even worse option of doing nothing.

headline: Kevin Allocca
text: Kevin Allocca is the manager of YouTube Trends, which means he spends his days tracking and analyzing viral Web videos. A former editor at MediaBistro, he’s an expert on the intersection of Web video and popular culture.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Financing Social Security
text: More income should be taxed, a writer says. Readers react.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 10
text: Since Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin survived the recall effort against him on Tuesday, both parties are trying to determine what — if anything — his victory will mean for the November election.

headline: The Biology of Bubble and Crash
text: Cambridge, England

headline: How Celebrities Come Out Now
text: INTENDED or not, President Obama’s declaration of support for gay marriage had some of the classic hallmarks of a celebrity coming out of the closet and identifying himself or herself as gay. It was a carefully orchestrated revelation, designed to try to maximize acceptance and minimize any negative consequences from, say, the Christian ministers whom Mr. Obama mollified by phone. It was not unlike how openly gay actors used to worry about the reaction within Hollywood.

headline: ‘Mary Poppins’ to Flit to New Zealand
text: Can the bottom of the world sustain one of Disney’s megamusicals? “Mary Poppins” is about to find out.

headline: Lost the Vote? Deny the Money
text: If you wanted to reproduce the conditions that led to the Great Recession in 2007, the easiest way would be the plan unveiled last week by House Republicans: gut the regulators who are supposed to keep the worst business practices in check.

headline: Getting Bigger
text: Since the 1970s, the percentage of Americans who are obese has been rising. Among children, the percentage has more than tripled.

headline: How Do You Put a Nation on a Diet?
text: The Walt Disney Company last week announced plans to restrict junk food commercials on its television programs aimed at children. A few days before, Mayor Michael Bloomberg took steps to restrict the sale of supersized sugary drinks in New York. But isolated changes may not make a substantial difference at a time when Americans are gaining weight as a nation. Reducing obesity will require a broader shift in the culture.

headline: The Trouble With Bankruptcy Lawyers
text: Bankruptcy lawyers moved to the top tier of corporate practice in 1978 when a federal statute allowed them to be paid top hourly fees, which courts had traditionally limited in bankruptcy proceedings. In recent years, legal fees in Chapter 11 reorganization cases have soared as deals have grown bigger and more complex.

headline: Natural Gas, by the Book
text: Reports from international agencies usually make for dull reading. “Golden Rules for a Golden Age of Gas,” from the Paris-based International Energy Agency, does not. It should be required reading for regulators and the industry — and for anyone who cares about energy, the environment and climate change.

headline: Eugenics, Past and Future
text: THE current issue of the Yale Alumni Magazine includes a portrait of Irving Fisher, a Yale economics professor in the 1920s and ’30s and a giant of his field. The author, Richard Conniff, takes note of Fisher’s prodigious professional accomplishments and his private decency in order to foreground the real subject of his article: the economist’s role as one of his era’s highest-wattage proponents of eugenics.

headline: Facebook Meets Brick-and-Mortar Politics
text: Istanbul

headline: Poppy Chic
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Amelia Earhart, Found and Lost
text: THERE was a picture of Amelia Earhart in the newspaper. Actually, it was in this newspaper. I read the accompanying article while riding on a train from New Haven to New York when I was in my mid-20s. Although I had graduated a few years earlier, I was still living in the town where I’d gone to college. New Haven was cheap, and book reviews paid money back then. This was in the early ’90s. The train was quiet. No one had a cellphone. The article in the newspaper said that a search party believed it had found a piece of Earhart’s plane on an atoll in the Pacific. And maybe a piece of her shoe.

headline: Our Animal Natures
text: Barbara Natterson-Horowitz is a cardiology professor at U.C.L.A. and Kathryn Bowers is a writer. This essay is adapted from their forthcoming book “Zoobiquity: What Animals Can Teach Us About Health and the Science of Healing,” which is told from the doctor’s point of view.

headline: From Peace Prize to Paralysis
text: IN THE NUBA MOUNTAINS, Sudan

headline: How Racist Are We? Ask Google
text: Barack Obama won 52.9 percent of the popular vote in 2008 and 365 electoral votes, 95 more than he needed. Many naturally concluded that prejudice was not a major factor against a black presidential candidate in modern America. My research, a comparison of Americans’ Google searches and their voting patterns, found otherwise. If my results are correct, racial animus cost Mr. Obama many more votes than we may have realized.

headline: Forced to Early Social Security, Unemployed Pay a Steep Price
text: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — This retirement oasis in the desert has long beckoned those who want to spin out their golden years playing golf and sitting by the pool in the arid sunshine.

headline: Getting Around
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Let’s take a MACRO view of this one.

headline: Messi Simply Magical
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Lionel Messi once again showed why he is the best player in the world.

headline: Stakes Winner Fractures Leg at Belmont
text: Giant Ryan, a 6-year-old Grade 1 stakes winner with career earnings of more than $600,000, fractured his left front leg Saturday at Belmont near the end of the True North Stakes, a few hours before the Belmont Stakes was run.

headline: Latino Growth Not Fully Felt at Voting Booth
text: DENVER — The nation’s rapidly growing Latino population is one of the most powerful forces working in President Obama’s favor in many of the states that will determine his contest with Mitt Romney. But Latinos are not registering or voting in numbers that fully reflect their potential strength, leaving Hispanic leaders frustrated and Democrats worried as they increase efforts to rally Latino support.

headline: The Hispanic Electorate
text: The gap between Hispanics eligible to vote and those who register and turn out to vote has continued to grow.

headline: Voter Voices: Hector Galindo Morales
text: Eighteen-year-old Hector Galindo Morales of Colorado will be voting for the first time this year. Though he is still undecided, he has identified immigration as his major issue.

headline: Firefighters Rescue 2 Children and Their Father in the Bronx
text: When firefighters got to the six-story brick building on East 191st Street in the Bronx early Saturday, they saw flames shooting from a top-floor window. Strange, sharp popping sounds filled the air and bricks flew from the facade, which meant, a fire lieutenant said later, that the heat was so intense it had swelled the air in the masonry.

headline: Day 2 at Bonnaroo
text: Radiohead lit up the stage for the first time since 2006.

headline: The Value of a Checkbook
text: Many of you were amused or baffled to read, in my post about the things I actually bought, that among the items I carry in my laptop bag is a checkbook.

headline: Exercises for Fun and Better Gamesmanship
text: Players have their own jargon and shorthand to describe what happens on the board. So when they use the word “beautiful” to talk about a move — or even a whole game — they are describing chess play that is hard to predict but afterward seems to have had an elegant logic.

headline: Dying for Land
text: Tensions run high between indigenous Guarani people and ranchers in southern Brazil after violence has flared over land rights.

headline: David M. Helpern, Chief of Joan & David Apparel Brand, Dies at 94
text: David M. Helpern, the business side of the husband-and-wife apparel design team known as Joan & David, who popularized elegant, comfortable — and non-high-heeled — shoes for working women in the 1960s before expanding their line internationally to include clothing, died on May 14 in Westwood, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Black Leaders and Gay Advocates March in Step
text: For years, gay rights organizations and major civil rights organizations viewed each other warily. African-American leaders often saw the gay rights groups as insensitive to racial concerns, and some resented the movement’s use of civil rights language to make the case for same-sex marriage. Advocates for gay rights, in turn, sometimes blamed socially conservative African-Americans for their defeat in crucial electoral battles.

headline: Anna Teresa Callen, Teacher of Italian Cooking, Dies at 86
text: Anna Teresa Callen, who learned about cooking in her family kitchen in prewar Italy before becoming a successful cookbook author and cooking teacher in New York City specializing in Italian cuisine, died on June 3 in Chieti, in central Italy. She was 86.

headline: Kuroda’s Left Foot
text: Hiroki Kuroda said his sore left foot felt better Saturday after he received treatment for a contusion he sustained during his winning start on Friday against the Mets. But the Yankees still don’t know if Kuroda will be healthy enough to make his next scheduled start against the Atlanta Braves on Wednesday.

headline: For Betting Buddies, a Belmont Stakes Reunion
text: At Belmont Park on Saturday morning, four friends met in the same spot and at the same time on Belmont Stakes day as they have for years. Over doughnuts and coffee at 9:30, near the tote board in the paddock, they talked about the races ahead and who among them would be the big winner.

headline: Firefighters Rescue Three in Bronx Apartment Blaze
text: When firefighters arrived to a six-story brick building on East 191st Street in the Bronx early Saturday, they saw flames shooting from a top-floor window. Strange, sharp popping sounds filled the air and bricks flew from the facade, which meant, a fire lieutenant said later, that the heat was so intense it had swelled the air in the masonry.

headline: Turning Saltwater From Earth and Sea Into Water Fit to Drink
text: SAN ANTONIO — Drilling rigs in the midst of cow pastures are hardly a novelty for Texans. But on a warm May day at a site about 30 miles south of San Antonio, a rig was not trying to reach oil or fresh water, but rather something unconventional: a salty aquifer. After a plant is built and begins operating in 2016, the site will become one of the state’s largest water desalination  facilities.

headline: Tight Group Near Top in Soggy L.P.G.A. Championship
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Eun-Hee Ji scrambled successfully in the third round of the L.P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, carding a three-under-par 69 on a course playing soggy and long after torrential morning rain.

headline: Getting Ahead Behind the Plate
text: Russell Martin’s string of solid work behind the plate with the starting pitchers continued Friday night with Hiroki Kuroda’s one-hit effort.

headline: Cathedral Renamed
text: There is no more Crystal Cathedral. The glass-paned church in Garden Grove, Calif., where the televangelist Rev. Robert H. Schuller, and later his children, preached for decades is now known as Christ Cathedral.

headline: A New Cast, a Winning Ride at the Belmont Stakes
text: This 144th running of the Belmont Stakes was supposed to be about history, about a gritty colt named I’ll Have Another and his determined assault on a feat achieved by only 11 horses. But the colt’s Triple Crown quest blew up on Friday when a sore tendon derailed the Kentucky Derby and Preakness champion and his connections decided I’ll Have Another would not have another chance to run. Ever again.

headline: Gardner’s Setback Leaves Yankees Bracing for Much Longer Wait
text: Brett Gardner felt more pain in his right elbow Friday during a minor league rehabilitation game in Charleston, S.C., meaning he will not be returning to the Yankees for several more weeks, and possibly longer.

headline: Mets’ Accidental Shortstop Playing Like the First Choice All Along
text: In the sixth inning of the first game of the Subway Series, and with the Yankee Stadium crowd beginning to wonder whether Hiroki Kuroda could make a second consecutive New York Friday memorable, Omar Quintanilla knocked a 93-mile-per-hour sinker to left field. Quintanilla’s double was notable for being the Mets’ first hit all evening.

headline: Surviving a Struggle With a New Sense of Hope
text: Last Tuesday, with the release of the memoir “Diamond in the Rough,” Shawn Colvin, a Grammy-winning singer-songwriter based in Austin, officially added “author” to her biography. In an ambitious bit of old-media, cross-promotional synergy, Ms. Colvin’s publisher, William Morrow/ HarperCollins, has doubled down and timed the book’s release to coincide with her first new studio album in six years.

headline: Injuries Hinder and Heal at Men’s Olympic Qualifying Track Meet
text: Oscar Pistorius’s last few chances to qualify for the 2012 London Olympics in the 400 meters, to prove that a double-amputee could sprint at the highest level of his sport, have been at the mercy of an in-flight nap.

headline: The Trouble With Finding an Extra $2 Billion
text: The Texas Department of Transportation, which often claims that it lacks the money to maintain its network of roads properly, surprised many state leaders in March when it announced it had an extra $2 billion.

headline: With Goal for Germany, Mario Gomez Vindicates Coach’s Faith
text: LVIV, Ukraine — It was the 72nd minute of a game that had grown increasingly frustrating and unproductive. Mario Gomez had labored after making an unexpected start at forward for Germany. Miroslav Klose stood at the sideline on his 34th birthday, ready to replace to him.

headline: Looking for Reasons for Dewhurst’s Failure to Secure Nomination
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Death on Virginia’s ‘Sacré’ Soil
text: Wheat fields played famous host to some of the bloodiest carnage at the landmark battles of Antietam and Gettysburg. They also marked a number of lesser-known engagements, including a forgotten battle waged in the Shenandoah Valley on June 9, 1862, when Union and Confederate forces clashed near Port Republic, a bucolic village located in the heart of the valley along the south fork of the Shenandoah River. For one Southern patriot, the battle in this wheat field was where a sentimental vow he made to leave his bones on the sacred soil of Virginia was tragically fulfilled.

headline: Germans Win and Dutch Stumble in Group of Death
text: Jeré Longman of The Times was in Lviv, Ukraine, on Saturday to see Germany’s 1-0 victory over Portugal in Euro 2012, and writes about the possibilities for the Germans with Mario Gomez scoring and Joachim Löw making all the right moves with his lineup. Things did not go nearly as well for the Netherlands in Kharkiv, where Denmark stole a goal — and a 1-0 victory — on a counterattack in a game in which they might have lost by three or four.

headline: Gymnast From Bronx, 19, Is Now a National Champ
text: ST. LOUIS — The moment John Orozco landed his final tumbling pass at the United States gymnastics national championships on Saturday, the words began ringing in his head.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 9, 2012

headline: The Sport’s Newest Twitter Star
text: PARIS — Micaela Bryan was still in the womb in January when her father, Bob, was playing in the Australian Open doubles final, which he and her uncle, Mike, lost. Bummer, she might have said.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: June 3-June 9
text: Moments from the campaign trail this week, including protests against the health care law and fund-raisers in New York and California.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: Moments from the campaign trail this week, including protests and fund-raisers in New York and California.  Go to the slide show.

headline: Romney Adviser Takes U.S. Political Debate Overseas
text: A senior economic adviser to Mitt Romney criticized President Obama and his policy toward crisis-torn Europe, and Germany in particular, in an op-ed article in a leading German newspaper on Saturday, raising the question of the propriety of taking America’s political fights into international affairs.

headline: Corrections: June 10
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Yankees’ Home Runs Help Beat the Mets
text: The Yankees have thrived on home runs this season, winning 72 percent of their games when they hit at least one, and losing all 12 of their games when they hit none. So when Mark Teixeira hit a 2-2 pitch over the wall in right in the sixth inning Saturday, the Yankees received a clear signal that a victory was in the offing.

headline: Devils Snap Kings’ Road Streak, Forcing Series Back to Los Angeles
text: NEWARK — The spell is broken. The Kings’ aura of invincibility is shattered. The Stanley Cup finals are going back to Los Angeles for Game 6.

headline: Assad’s Response to Syria Unrest Leaves His Own Sect Divided
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After Jaber Abboud, a baker from Baniyas, Syria, first lashed out publicly at President Bashar al-Assad for failing to promote real change, his neighbors ignored it.

headline: Heat Beat Celtics to Reach N.B.A. Finals
text: MIAMI — The rally was brash and ostentatious. Three towering figures rose above the fray, declaring their supremacy in bold, broad strokes. The Miami Heat were flexing and preening again, but with an authority and substance that no one, not even the Boston Celtics, could deny.

text: Sarah Ann Kotula and Christopher David Brandt were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Baltimore. Diane O. Leasure, a retired Howard County Circuit Court judge who presided in Ellicott City, Md., officiated.

text: Sarah Rose Allen and Craig Daniel Haaren were married Saturday at the Miami Marriott Dadeland in Miami. Rabbi Solomon Rothstein officiated.

Doty and George E. Doty Jr. of New York. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York.
