text: Elizabeth Clark Libert and Daniel Brent Sterner were married Saturday evening at the Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston. The Rev. Cheryl Rubin Lloyd, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Bruce Edelstein, Francesco Spinelli
text: Bruce Leon Edelstein and Dr. Francesco Luca Spinelli were married Wednesday morning at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau in New York. James Mitchell, a staff member in the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: Jocelyn White and Robin Martin
text: Jocelyn White and Robin Bradley Martin were married Saturday evening at Christ Church, Georgetown, in Washington. The Rev. Stuart Kenworthy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Crisis for Italy? Let’s Have a Look at Them First
text: In an age when the term crisis is applied to almost every degree of hardship, no matter how trivial or petty, its meaning is often lost. In soccer, a series of injuries or a streak of defeats often constitutes such a classification. Under this criteria, to label the problems faced by Cesare Prandelli’s Italy squad heading into this summer’s European Championships as a crisis seems something of an understatement.

headline: Mets Wait for Davis to Show More Power
text: The Mets’ roster is constructed differently from the Yankees’, so the fact that the Yankees have four more home runs than the Mets in the first two games of the Subway Series should not be surprising. But playing in a small ballpark, the Mets need more power in their lineup to match the Yankees. And Manager Terry Collins simply does not know where to find that power.

headline: ‘Prometheus’ Offers a Creationist Indulgence for Science Geeks
text: “Prometheus,” the new movie from the director Ridley Scott, operates on several levels. Most importantly and impressively, it is an unforgettable reminder not to open anything, ever. Doors, caves, containers — never open them!

headline: Parise Scores All-Important First Goal for Devils
text: NEWARK — The inexhaustible Zach Parise finally had one of his own goals to celebrate in the Stanley Cup finals Saturday, and, as a bonus, it came with the Devils on the power play. Parise whooped it up, slamming his right fist into the glass before his teammates swarmed him.

headline: Conflicts Endanger Reform in Myanmar
text: HONG KONG — It’s a sad and nasty problem that’s playing out in western Myanmar, a dispute that has turned violent in recent days and perhaps even threatens to derail the country’s fragile attempts at democratic reform.

headline: Pacquiao Loses to Bradley in Stunning Split Decision
text: LAS VEGAS — Timothy Bradley talked about timing.

headline: A Day With No Timeouts
text: Images from a supremely busy June day in sports, around the world and in the New York City area.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: There seems to be no escape from bad news this week, with in-depth analysis of India’s faltering growth story dominating leading publications. India’s recently announced gross domestic product growth, at 6.5 percent for the year ending March 31, 2012, was the lowest in a decade. The figures come as the rupee is plummeting, faith in the economy is waning and the criticism of the current central government rises.

headline: From Las Vegas to the Philippines, Shock Over Pacquiao Loss
text: HONG KONG — The undefeated American boxer Timothy Bradley won a controversial upset over Manny Pacquiao of the Philippines on Saturday night in Las Vegas, scoring a split decision that brought Pac-Man’s Filipino fans, celebrity supporters and even other boxers onto Twitter to express their outrage.

headline: Where Electoral Forecasts Agree and Disagree
text: FiveThirtyEight’s initial 2012 presidential forecast found President Obama as a slight favorite to win re-election. These projections are unique, both in means and ends, but the FiveThirtyEight model is operating in a crowded field.

headline: Bonnaroo: D’Angelo, Back in the U.S.A.
text: Bonnaroo’s late-night surprise was a doozy: the return of D’Angelo, the all-around soul man who has not played a concert in the United States since the end of his 2001 tour for his album “Voodoo,” a masterpiece released the year before.

headline: The EuroTARP Cometh
text: OK, so Spain gets a bank bailout. It’s basically like the TARP: a Spanish government agency will give banks cash, presumably in return for an ownership stake, with the goal of reassuring depositors and interbank lenders that their funds will remain safe even if the banks turn out to have big losses; the point is that these losses will initially come out of the new cash hoard, so that default on debts won’t happen.

headline: Latvian Competitiveness
text: As Simon Wren-Lewis says, there’s something about the Latvian experience that causes many people to leave their critical faculties at the immigration desk. I think it’s mainly the fact that austerians need a hero, and Ireland keeps failing to deliver. But whatever.

headline: Three Killed in Shooting Near Auburn University
text: AUBURN, Ala. — Three young men, two of them with ties to Auburn University’s football team, were killed and three others were wounded during a pool party on Saturday night at an apartment complex near the campus here.

headline: Men’s Final of French Open Postponed Until Monday
text: Play was halted in the 2012 French Open men’s singles final between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal with Djokovic to serve in the fourth set at 4-6, 3-6, 6-2, 2-1. It was the first men’s final at the tournament since 1973 to be postponed to another day.

headline: Uniting Through a Prayer Call
text: On a recent Tuesday at noon, a dozen live-in home health aides — all from the Bronx — dialed a conference-call number. They phoned from their elderly patients’ small apartments in Queens and from spacious houses in New Jersey and Connecticut. Within seconds, they were connected to their pastor, Benjamin Boakye, of Ebenezer Assembly of God Church on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx.

headline: Wright Gallery Opens
text: For aficionados of Frank Lloyd Wright, the new SC Johnson Gallery in Racine, Wis., offers another attraction on the fan circuit.

headline: Snorting the Good Grade Drug
text: Students feeling pressure to succeed aren’t snorting cocaine or heroin, but Adderall, an amphetamine prescribed for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. One student told a New York Times reporter that “he and his friends routinely shared to study late into the night, focus during tests and ultimately get the grades worthy of their prestigious high school in an affluent suburb of New York City. The drug did more than just jolt them awake for the 8 a.m. SAT; it gave them a tunnel focus tailor-made for the marathon of tests long known to make or break college applications.” Read the full story here, and follow more stories from high school students here—or share your own.

headline: Disruptions: For HBO, Still Beholden to a Cable Company
text: After cutting the cable TV cord two years ago, I’m often a bit late to the conversations about hot new shows. So last week, after hearing friends rave incessantly about “Game of Thrones,” I gave it a try.

headline: London Theater Journal: Another Prisoner of Noble Title
text: LONDON — What do you suppose she’s really thinking beneath the mask of majesty? All that nonstop pomp and pageantry must feel like a straitjacket. And surely she has disturbing things on her mind at the moment — worries about her husband, for one — as her reveling subjects pay such ostentatious tribute to her. Wouldn’t you just love to know what’s going on inside that serene head of hers?

headline: Euro 2012: Italy-Spain As it Happened
text: Here’s how The Times called the action from Gdansk as tournament favorites Spain battled Italy.

headline: In Europe, Banks Borrowing to Stay Ahead of the Tide
text: LONDON — As Europe works to prop up Spain’s wobbling banks, its leaders still face a problem that plagues the Continent’s increasingly vulnerable financial institutions — a longstanding addiction to the borrowed money that provides the day-to-day financing they need to survive.

headline: Crisis in Myanmar Over Buddhist-Muslim Clash
text: BANGKOK — Myanmar declared a state of emergency on Sunday in a western state where at least 17 people have been killed this month in violence between Buddhists and Muslims.

headline: Santorum Ready for Convention Battle with Paul
text: Rick Santorum plans to lead a strong pro-Romney effort at the Republican National Convention in Tampa, Fla., that can serve as a counterweight in case Representative Ron Paul and his supporters “are looking for a platform fight,” he said in an interview that was broadcast on Sunday.

headline: A Higher Calling
text: Benjamin Boakye, pastor of the Ebenezer Assembly of God Church in the Bronx, reaches out to his congregation through modern means.

headline: Watch the U.S. Open for Free Lessons
text: While the Masters in April heralds the flowering of another golf year, the United States Open lures Americans to the television for a midseason challenge more vicarious in character and charm.

headline: Kenyan Government Official Killed in Air Crash
text: LIBREVILLE, Gabon — A top Kenyan official, who grew up chasing cows in the Great Rift Valley and went on to become one of the most powerful men in the country, was killed Sunday morning when the police helicopter he was riding in plunged into a forest west of Nairobi, Kenya’s capital.

headline: ‘Madagascar 3’ and ‘Prometheus’ Lead Weekend Box Office
text: Strong turnout for the latest “Madagascar” movie gave DreamWorks Animation a shot in the arm over the weekend, while Ridley Scott’s “Prometheus” proved an R rating isn’t always a ticket-selling handicap.

headline: Pro-Obama Super PAC Up With New Bain Attack
text: Priorities USA Action, the pro-Obama “super PAC,” is up with a new anti-Mitt Romney advertisement that takes aim at Bain Capital’s stewardship of a steel mill whose closing led to the loss of hundreds of jobs.

headline: Europe Dodges a Bank Crisis in Spain, but Perils Lurk
text: FRANKFURT — With an agreement to bail out Spain’s struggling banks, Europe again avoided financial chaos in a debt crisis that is in its third year. But Europe still faces far bigger challenges that threaten the Continent and, with it, the world economy.

headline: Lax Security at LinkedIn Is Laid Bare
text: SAN FRANCISCO — LinkedIn is a data company that did not protect its data.

headline: Pentagon and Congress Argue Over Hospital for Troops
text: WASHINGTON — As the Pentagon and Congress argue over how to shrink the military to fit smaller federal budgets, no debate over matching money to mission is more heartfelt than the order to shut down the premier overseas hospital for grievously wounded troops and replace it with a new one.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Red Hot Chili Peppers Get Funky
text: With the Red Hot Chili Peppers playing the headlining set, one through-line for Bonnaroo on Saturday was funk. The festival offered up funk as motion, as repetition, as a mathematical pattern, as a process, as a communal project, as a yardstick of history and a reason to just dance.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Creator Matthew Weiner Reflects on the Season So Far
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers for the first 12 episodes of the “Mad Men” season.

headline: Used to Winning With Ease, Kings Tripped Up by Final Victory
text: NEWARK — In the end, as the minutes wound down in Game 5 on Saturday night, as they had in Game 4, the officials never had to think about pulling the Stanley Cup from its protective case. The Los Angeles Kings, who were poised to parade it around a rink in celebration, proved in two losses to the Devils that they may still be the better team, but that they are not ready to hoist the prize. They proved the theory that the final win is the hardest, and perhaps that the Stanley Cup will not be won — cannot be won? — until you have done something truly hard.

headline: ‘Once’ and ‘Clybourne Park’ Win Top 2012 Tony Awards
text: On Sunday night, The New York Times brought you live coverage of the Tony Awards with photos from the red carpet and the show, commentary from Charles Isherwood and Dave Itzkoff and behind-the-scenes reports.

headline: A Mahler That Stands or Falls on Its Finale
text: NEWARK — Mahler’s Ninth Symphony is a brave undertaking for a smallish band. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra ended its season, its second with Jacques Lacombe as music director, with performances of that work over the weekend. (Mr. Lacombe closed his first season, last year, with Mahler’s Third Symphony, also a difficult but arguably less challenging assignment.)

headline: Excavating Family Truths
text: Playwrights, be fearless about what you put into your plays. But then be ruthless about what you cut out of them. Even your best lines can be lost if they’re just tossed into an ocean of words.

headline: Movement, Interrupted and Extreme
text: When Andrea Miller began choreographing her latest dance, “Sit, Kneel, Stand,” her point of inspiration was the myth of Sisyphus and his eternal task of rolling a boulder up a hill, only to watch it roll back down. For its premiere at the Joyce Theater on Friday night, what lingered from that initial impulse were the ideas of effort and resilience, both spiritual and physical. Members of Ms. Miller’s Gallim Dance compressed or stretched their bodies to extremes, returned to form and started all over again. Presented in conjunction with the Gotham Dance Festival that concluded over the weekend, the production did offer a glimpse into a new direction for Ms. Miller, whose dances, up to this point, have been energetic but unoriginal. They take much from Gaga, a movement practice created by the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin. There are traces of Gaga in “Sit, Kneel, Stand” but, encouragingly, the performance is more than a Gaga class.

headline: Poems in Four Voices, a Concerto in Two
text: That David Robertson is a superb conductor of contemporary classical music hardly needs repeating. Evidence is everywhere in reviews worldwide and in the vivid memories of those who have heard concerts he has led. But what makes Mr. Robertson one of the most extraordinary musical advocates of our day has just as much to do with what he does off the podium.

headline: A Dancer’s Strange Route to Paradise
text: Amy Sherman-Palladino loves an idyllic hamlet. On her signature series, “Gilmore Girls,” for which she was creator and executive producer, it was Stars Hollow, with its town-square gazebo and folksy diner and ample places for unlikely intimate conversation.

headline: Festive Late Nights, Festive Mornings
text: OJAI, Calif. — As much as you love a masterpiece, as much as you think you know it well, you can still be perplexed by its hold on you. Composers experience this with particular intensity. Most spend lots of time analyzing great works of the past to uncover their inner secrets.

headline: Velvet Gloves Over Iron Fists
text: “Here we go,” Tony Soprano said in the first episode of “The Sopranos” when Dr. Melfi, his psychiatrist, reached for her prescription pad. “Here comes the Prozac.”

headline: True to Form, Mets Are Sloppy and Yankees Need a Homer
text: The baseball that leapt off Russell Martin’s bat, splashed into the left field stands and brought a sudden end to a wild contest at Yankee Stadium also reinforced two recently popular notions about the teams playing there Sunday afternoon.

headline: The Fallacy of the ‘Hijacked Brain’
text: Of all the philosophical discussions that surface in contemporary life, the question of free will — mainly, the debate over whether or not we have it — is certainly one of the most persistent.

headline: Dylan Ratigan Leaving MSNBC
text: Dylan Ratigan, the opinionated and sometimes hotheaded television host, is leaving MSNBC, the cable channel where he has worked for the last three years.

headline: Gupta Won’t Testify at His Insider Trading Trial
text: Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs accused of leaking secrets about the bank, will not testify at his insider trading trial, according to a letter from his lawyers that was filed with the court on Sunday.

headline: Expo Offers a Peek at Games of the Future
text: LOS ANGELES — You know you’re at the world’s most important video game convention when breakfast is a bacon double cheeseburger scarfed while crouched on the floor of a hallway packed full of nerds like me and young women in skimpy, corporate-branded halter tops.

headline: Mix of New and Newer for an Eclectic Festival
text: BUFFALO — June in Buffalo has a bifurcated mission that makes it an odd duck among new-music festivals. Founded in 1975 by the composer Morton Feldman and held annually on the campus of the University at Buffalo, it is partly a celebration of recent works performed by expert ensembles, both local and imported, and partly an intensive weeklong boot camp for budding young composers: 25 of them, from around the world, winnowed this year from nearly 100 applicants.

headline: Liberation as Death Sentence
text: When Civil War History published a paper this spring raising the conflict’s military death toll to 750,000 from 620,000, that journal’s editors called it one of the most important pieces of scholarship ever to appear in its pages.

headline: Festival Plans to Connect Jewish Arts
text: For almost 100 years the National Yiddish Theater-Folksbiene in New York has churned out productions in the old language of Eastern and Central European Jews, nursing and expanding a cultural connection. Theater officials are now stretching their horizons with plans for an ambitious international Jewish arts festival in New York in 2015, featuring performances and workshops in many languages exploring Jewish identity.

headline: A Backstage Pass to a High-End Food Festival
text: WHILE affluent connoisseurs sample the offerings this week at the annual Food & Wine Classic in Aspen, Colo., the public will get a look behind the scenes.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Sweet Core, Steely Edge
text: To follow Billy Joel’s sober hymn, “And So It Goes” with the frantic chromatic babble of Clifford Brown and Jon Hendricks’s “Joy Spring” is quite a leap for any singer. But Karrin Allyson made it look easy on Thursday evening at Birdland. Her show, whose selections change with every set, is a celebration of a 13-album career that is one of the most stable in jazz. She has an easy mastery of bebop, bossa nova, chanson and soft rock, to name four of the many styles in which she is comfortable.

headline: Bridging Past, Present and Future
text: This season the Brooklyn Philharmonic, revived from the dead, traveled to three of the borough’s communities with tailor-made concert series. In October the orchestra took Russian cartoon music to Brighton Beach and in March, an ambitious program full of premieres to Downtown Brooklyn, a new-music epicenter as of late.

headline: Like Buttah
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — This one left a great taste with me. Clean. Smooth. All the answers FELL into the right place at the right time. My pencil point never even broke, not once.

headline: Ensemble With Piano Wires, Off the Wall and Ceiling
text: Whenever an artist produces something so boggling and so inexplicable as to defy more than a cursory understanding at first brush, I am reminded of the science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke’s suggestion that “any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.” There was magic in the air on Thursday evening at the Eyebeam Art and Technology Center in Chelsea, when a new piece by Eli Keszler, “L-Carrier,” was introduced before a rapt audience.

headline: Newspaper as Business Pulpit
text: There is a growing worry that the falling value and failing business models of many American newspapers could lead to a situation where moneyed interests buy papers and use them to prosecute a political and commercial agenda.

headline: With Nadal Ahead but Out of Sorts, Final Is Suspended
text: PARIS — The Rafael Nadal on court late Sunday afternoon at Roland Garros seemed more like an impostor, so unlike Nadal, on his favorite surface, at his favorite tournament, getting bullied around on clay. The snarl was still there, the face all twisted and contorted; however, it came not from the usual dominance but from anger over circumstance.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be reported this week will include import prices for May (Tuesday); retail sales for May, the Producer Price Index for May and business inventories for April (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for May and the current account deficit for the first quarter (Thursday); and industrial production for May and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for June (Friday).

headline: Google Outsells, but Apple Cultivates Loyalty of App Developers
text: Smartphones running Google’s Android operating system outsell iPhones more than two to one. And yet, even as Google’s system has gobbled up market share, Apple has held onto one critical advantage — the loyalty of mobile app developers.

headline: Judi Radin at Trial for World Mind Sports Games
text: Some top players just grind out wins, playing better than their opponents. But there are a few who have an extra insight into the game, seeing possibilities that many would reject or never consider.

headline: Getting to the Heart of a Joycean Masterpiece
text: Bloomsday — June 16, the day of the events in James Joyce’s masterpiece “Ulysses” — approaches and with it the release of Alan Adelson and Kate Taverna’s documentary “In Bed With Ulysses,” a film that strips away the academic clutter surrounding that kaleidoscopic novel to reveal the vital human pulse between its lines. It does so with staged readings of the livelier passages (not, I emphasize, re-creations of them), period footage and insightful commentators (including the Irish novelists Colum McCann and Edna O’Brien), not to mention humor and a palpable enthusiasm.

headline: A Chronicle of Cairo Protests
text: Begun in January 2011 amid mass demonstrations in downtown Cairo, “Tahrir: Liberation Square” had its official premiere scarcely six months later at the Locarno Film Festival in Switzerland. That makes it a hot document as far as movies go, recording events with ramifications yet unknown to Egyptians or the rest of the world.

headline: A Conversation with Peña Nieto
text: An excerpt of an interview with Enrique Peña Nieto, the former governor of Mexico State who is the front-runner ahead of the July 1 presidential election in Mexico.

headline: Russia Arrests 5 in Inquiry on Protest
text: MOSCOW — Russian authorities said Sunday that they had arrested five more people in a continuing investigation of clashes between protesters and riot police officers at a demonstration on May 6, the day before Vladimir V. Putin’s inauguration for a third term as president.

headline: Allies Restrict Airstrikes on Taliban in Civilian Homes
text: WASHINGTON — The senior allied commander in Afghanistan has ordered new restrictions on airstrikes against Taliban fighters who hide in residential homes, coalition officials said Sunday, a move in response to a NATO attack in the eastern part of the country last week that Afghan officials say killed 18 civilians.

headline: A Fan at an Event She Once Dominated
text: ST. LOUIS — Shawn Johnson, a gold medalist at the 2008 Olympics, walked into the arena to watch the United States gymnastics national championships on Sunday and felt her stomach flutter and her body start to shake.

headline: Radio Royalty Deal Offers Hope for Industrywide Pact
text: For decades, the recording industry has lobbied Congress to change how radio stations pay royalties. The broadcasters have lobbied just as hard to preserve the status quo, making an agreement look all but impossible.

headline: Luck and Shooting Accuracy in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES — One of the great mysteries of the 2012 playoffs is how the Kings suddenly transformed from a mediocre team that barely made the playoffs to the juggernaut they have been in the postseason. Even after losing two straight games for the first time this spring, courtesy of the revivified Devils in the Stanley Cup finals, they are still 15-4 in the postseason.

headline: Spain’s Premier Steps Up, With Caveats for Europe
text: MADRID — Spain’s agreement to take a European bank bailout pushes the country into a pivotal role in determining how — and if — the euro zone can survive its debt crisis. Central to any solution will be Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, who spent his first six months in power denying that a bailout would be necessary.

headline: After Proving Doubters Wrong, Union Rags Goes Back to Being a Horse
text: The Triple Crown series is now in the books. I’ll Have Another emerged on the national stage with two brilliant stretch drives to take the first two legs, the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes. Sadly for horse racing, he was not able to compete in the final leg because of a tendon injury and is now retired.

text: MONTREAL — Lewis Hamilton drove one of the most spectacular races of the last few years, passing the leader twice to win the Canadian Grand Prix on Sunday, and become the historic seventh winner in this year’s first seven races.

text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo defended on Sunday his ties to a private lobbying group that received $2 million from the gambling industry last December as he was developing a plan to expand casino gambling in New York State.

headline: Trespassing Case Adds Strain to Trinity Church’s Ties With Occupy Protesters
text: When Occupy Wall Street protesters gathered in Zuccotti Park last fall, Trinity Church, the historic Episcopal institution just a couple of blocks south, became an ally.

headline: N.R.C. Nomination Shines Spotlight on Waste-Disposal Issue
text: WASHINGTON — When the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee meets on Wednesday to consider President Obama’s choice to head the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, three themes are likely to dominate the questioning: waste, waste and earthquakes.

headline: Banks Look to Burnish Their Images by Backing Green Technology Firms
text: Call it the greening of Wall Street.

headline: A Performance That Quelled Doubts and Tempered Sadness
text: There was no Triple Crown champion to celebrate or failed bid to lament Sunday. The Kentucky Derby and Preakness champion I’ll Have Another never got to look out of his gate and see an impressively large crowd in a mammoth Belmont Park desperate to know if the colt could run a mile and a half ahead of his rivals and pass the Test of the Champion.

headline: Are We Living in Sensory Overload or Sensory Poverty?
text: IT was a spring morning in upstate New York, one so cold the ground squeaked loudly underfoot as sharp-finned ice crystals rubbed together. The trees looked like gloved hands, fingers frozen open. A crow veered overhead, then landed. As snow flurries began, it leapt into the air, wings aslant, catching the flakes to drink. Or maybe just for fun, since crows can be mighty playful.

headline: Hundreds Protest Screening of Pro-Pinochet Film in Chile
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Hundreds of people protested Sunday near a theater where supporters of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet attended the screening of a pro-Pinochet documentary, reflecting the divisions that still exist in Chile almost 40 years after he seized power in a bloody coup.

headline: Friedrich Hirzebruch, Mathematician, Is Dead at 84
text: Friedrich Hirzebruch, who helped revive the German mathematical community after World War II and whose work in unifying disparate parts of mathematics gave birth to new tools and fields of research, died on May 27 in Bonn, Germany. He was 84.

headline: Chinatown Fair Is Back, Without Chickens Playing Tick-Tack-Toe
text: For more than five decades, the Chinatown Fair arcade attracted a steady stream of visitors, some drawn to its dim, dank and narrow battlefield of wall-to-wall Japanese street-fighter games, and others lured by a more peculiar attraction: a succession of chickens that took on all comers at tick-tack-toe, a few quarters at a time.

headline: Gathering Online, Alumni of an Elite School Share Their Accounts of Abuse
text: One said a teacher had compelled her to have sex with him if she wanted a passing grade. Another said he had been sexually assaulted by a teacher after having a private dinner at his house. Others spoke of having been groped by faculty members while they were students.

headline: Stop-and-Frisk Policy ‘Saves Lives,’ Mayor Tells Black Congregation
text: As criticism of the Police Department’s so-called stop-and-frisk policy grows louder, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took to the pulpit before a black congregation in Brooklyn on Sunday to make his most forceful and nuanced defense of the practice yet, arguing that it had helped make New York the safest big city in the country, while acknowledging that the police needed to treat those whom they stopped with greater respect.

headline: She Isn’t Sexy, She’s 7
text: I am sitting at the dinner table with my 7-year-old daughter and my 10-year-old son. Suddenly, my daughter asks: “What’s passion mean, Mama?” My son, interrupting my chance to explain, answers, “It’s when you’re really into something.”

headline: Tie Fails to Settle Anything for Spain and Italy
text: GDANSK, Poland

headline: TV Content Ratings System Set to Expand to Web

headline: Hospitals Aren’t Waiting for Verdict on Health Care Law
text: Giant aquariums now soothe pediatric patients at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. It has added welcome signs in 10 languages, a state-of-the-art cardiac operating room and programs to keep chronically ill adults safely at home. But as Pamela S. Brier, the chief executive, was walking to the main entrance last week, she spotted a rain-soaked plastic bag on the front steps.

headline: Willard Bond, Vivid Artist of Yachting, Dies at 85
text: In “First Around,” one of Willard Bond’s best-known paintings, two towering yachts are caught in a roiling sea. The one to the fore is rounding a mark, sharply heeled in the wind, its crew crammed by the upper rail to keep it from capsizing. It has not yet raised its spinnaker, the balloonlike sail toward the bow. Perilously close by, the other boat has just turned the marker, its billowing spinnaker a virtual rainbow of iridescent pink, blue, maroon and white.

headline: Swedes’ Twitter Voice: Anyone, Saying (Blush) Almost Anything
text: TROLLHATTAN, Sweden — Chances of embarrassment are unusually high when you are @Sweden, the nation’s official Twitter spokesperson.

headline: First Chinese Win on Tour Comes in L.P.G.A. Major
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Feng Shanshan of China was not the marquee player expected to emerge as this year’s L.P.G.A. Championship winner, but she was the one who showed the most resilience in the thick and punitive rough at Locust Hill Country Club.

headline: Wieber Retains Her Title in All-Around at Nationals
text: ST. LOUIS — With a packed crowd looking on and a national title on the line on Sunday, Jordyn Wieber, the reigning world champion in the all-around, did not flinch or falter.

text: Just as print publications across North America are cutting newsroom staff and daily publication schedules, Politico is expanding.

headline: Syrian Forces Shell Cities as Opposition Picks Leader
text: ISTANBUL — Syrian government forces shelled rebel strongholds across the country on Sunday, opponents of the government said, while the main opposition group in exile, the Syrian National Council, chose a new leader.

headline: Selling Abroad, China Eases Slump at Home
text: GUANGZHOU, China — With China’s domestic economy stumbling badly this spring as construction and retail sales slow, this country is unleashing a fresh surge of exports that is preserving millions of jobs in Chinese factories but could fan trade tensions with the West.

headline: Beck Renews His Radio Deal
text: Glenn Beck, who departed Fox News last year and started his own Internet television network, is sticking with his radio network partner.

headline: A National Security Blog From Wired Widens Its Reach

They are technology enthusiasts spread across military bases and mazelike corridors at the Pentagon.

headline: Backtracking on Florida Exams Flunked by Many, Even an Educator
text: SANFORD, Fla. — Bill Vogel, the superintendent of schools in this suburb of Orlando, has always been vigilant about preparing his district for the state tests.

headline: Lottery Numbers
At Meeting of Left’s Online Activists, Weighing Impact of Attack Ads
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Internet-savvy members of the political left have found the root of their problem — the “super PACs” unleashed by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United ruling. They just do not know how to solve it.

text: At the Figment public art show on Governors Island over the weekend, Nick Kenrick stood with his hands on his hips and his eyes squinted, concentrating feverishly on the classic video game Pong.

headline: Another Bank Bailout
text: Oh, wow — another bank bailout, this time in Spain. Who could have predicted that?

headline: Candidates in Mexico Signal a New Tack in the Drug War

headline: Priorities in Mexico’s Drug War
text: The following are excerpts from an interview with Enrique Peña Nieto, a former governor of Mexico State who is the front-running candidate in the July 1 presidential election in Mexico. The interview was conducted in Spanish last week and translated by The New York Times.

headline: Nuclear Time Warp
text: Did House Republicans somehow miss the end of the cold war? At a time when, for the sake of both security and fiscal responsibility, the country should be reducing its nuclear arsenal, the House has approved a defense authorization bill for 2013 that threatens to freeze the number of weapons at current levels and, over time, waste billions of dollars on unnecessary purchases and programs.

headline: Beethoven and Quasimodo Put Their Heads Together
text: Variations pose a challenge for a composer: take a theme — a melody, bass line, whatever — and progressively transform it, but never beyond recognition.

headline: The Defense of Marriage Act, Exposed
text: A federal district judge in New York ruled last week that the Defense of Marriage Act violates the Constitution by requiring the plaintiff to pay federal estate tax on her same-sex spouse’s estate, even though opposite-sex spouses are exempt. It follows a string of other rulings striking down the law in a federal appeals court, two federal district courts and a bankruptcy court.

headline: Texas Race for Senate Reveals Rift on the Right
text: FORT WORTH — At the opening ceremony of the Texas Republican Party’s convention here — typically a time for delegates to show unity for their party and principles — thousands of conservatives cheered and rose from their seats as Gov. Rick Perry took the stage on Thursday. But a few minutes into his speech at a downtown arena, many in the crowd nearly drowned him out with boos.

headline: More Debit Card Follies and Abuses
text: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau needs to bring transparency to debit card banking. The Federal Reserve made a good regulatory start in 2010, when it required banks to get account holders’ consent before enrolling them in overdraft “protection” programs that could cost them $35 each time they used a debit card and overdrew their account — the cards provide no warning of insufficient funds. Customers who did not opt in would have their purchases declined.

headline: Kings Fighting Fatigue, as Well as Devils
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — As the miles in the air and on the ice accumulate, as the hits become unrelenting, the temptation to sit on the beach and feel the soft breeze can become more pronounced.

headline: Pakalolo and the President
text: People with Hawaiian roots, like me, like to look for signs of true Hawaiianness in our president. Usually they’re subtle; these days Mr. Obama seems far more a product of the South Side of Chicago than the south shore of Oahu.

headline: Mitt Romney in Des Moines, Iowa
text: Mitt Romney spoke to supporters at a campaign event in Des Moines, Iowa.

headline: Syria’s Assads Turned to West for Glossy P.R.
text: For some journalists, Syria has been one of the least hospitable countries in the Middle East, a place where reporters — if they can get in — are routinely harassed and threatened as they try to uncover the repression that has propped up the Assad government for decades.

headline: Police Unit Draws Scrutiny for Its Handling of Crashes Involving Pedestrians
text: The crash happened before his eyes, but for Jacob Stevens all that remains is the sound: the wrenching noise of the Honda sedan as it slammed into his wife, Clara Heyworth, while she walked to meet him across a Brooklyn street last July.

headline: Grace Park Retires From L.P.G.A. Tour
text: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Grace Park could barely see through her tears to make her final putt at the end of Friday’s second round of the L.P.G.A. Championship.

headline: Final Push in Race to Serve Out Giffords’s House Term
text: TUCSON — The contest to fill the Congressional seat vacated by Gabrielle Giffords, the Democrat who survived an assassination attempt last year, has been widely referred to as the race for “Gabby’s seat.”

headline: The Rail’s Final Scoreboard, Year 5
text: With a strong showing in the Belmont, Melissa Hoppert came from behind to prevail in this season’s final standings among The Rail’s handicappers. This is her third victory in five seasons (she shared the crown with Jim Squires in 2008 and won it outright in 2010).

headline: While Seeking Support, Obama Faces a Frustrated Hispanic Electorate
text: As President Obama heads into the main stretch of his re-election campaign, his immigration policies have produced few gains for Latinos, whose votes could be crucial for him in November.

headline: Push for a Fiscal Pact Picks Up Speed, and Power
text: WASHINGTON — In an ornate room in the Capitol last Wednesday night, the Democratic senators who could hold the key to preventing a fiscal train wreck gathered for dinner and a talk with economists about their options for dealing with nearly $8 trillion in combined tax increases and spending cuts that are to be put in place automatically in January.

headline: Black and White Women Far From Equal Under Title IX
text: Last week, 20 African-American women with various connections to athletics met in Harlem at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. This was a private event — no stage, no audience — but a gathering of accomplished, like-minded women who had come to tackle the vexing issues of gender and race. The topic was “What’s Not Being Said About the Title IX Anniversary.”

headline: Tick-Tack-Toe-Playing Chicken
text: The Chinatown Fair arcade had tick-tack-toe-playing chickens for some 50 years. A decade ago they disappeared, but those nostalgic for them can visit the casino in Monticello, N.Y.

headline: Rethinking a Classic
text: “Brain Pong,” a game developed by David Reeves and a team at Hack Manhattan, allows users to move an on-screen icon using only the power of concentration.

headline: Broadcasting Kings Games in a Vacuum
text: “We’re in the third period,” the Los Angeles Kings’ longtime play-by-play man Bob Miller said into his headset Saturday as the Devils clung to a 2-1 lead in Game 5 at Newark. “If the Kings win, they win the Stanley Cup.”

headline: An Older Pettitte Settles Into a New Groove

text: On a PGA Tour overrun by perfect swings and political correctness, Bubba Watson stands out like a cowboy on Wall Street.

headline: French Vote Raises Socialists’ Hopes for Majority in Parliament

headline: Libya Postpones National Election Until July, as Preparations Lag
text: CAIRO — Libya’s transitional government on Sunday postponed the first national election since the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, changing it to July 7 from the previous date of June 19.

headline: 2 Attacks in Nigeria Target Christians
text: JOS, Nigeria (AP) — A car bomber detonated his explosives on Sunday outside a church in this central Nigerian city, and gunmen attacked another church in the nation’s northeast, killing at least four people and wounding dozens in the latest attacks against Christian worshipers, officials and witnesses said.

headline: ‘Once’ Basks in Glow of 8 Tony Awards
text: The bittersweet romantic musical “Once” was the unexpectedly dominant winner at the 66th annual Tony Awards on Sunday night, winning best musical, best actor, and six other Tonys, in a highly competitive year for Broadway honors. Many of the celebrated shows, including “Once” and the play “Peter and the Starcatcher,” were notable for their imaginative theatricality, inventive staging and ensembles of little-known theater actors, instead of the big-budget or star-driven productions that often prevail on Tony night.

headline: Health Law Ruling Won’t Alter Plans by Insurer
text: The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, announced Sunday night that it planned to continue offering some of the popular consumer protections required by the federal health care law, even if the Supreme Court declares the entire law unconstitutional later this month.

headline: Briton There at Pakistan’s Birth Stays at 94
text: “Geoffrey D. Langlands has had a front-row seat on Pakistan’s many dramas since he arrived, at the country’s chaotic birth, 65 years ago,” Declan Walsh writes in The New York Times. “He has taken tea with princesses, dined with dictators, been kidnapped by tribesmen and scraped through several wars.”

headline: Photo Replay: June 10
text: The day in sports included soccer matches at Euro 2012, N.C.A.A. baseball tournament games and baby jumping.

headline: Balotelli Continues to Amaze, and Confound

headline: 2012 Tony Awards
text: Photos of some of the winning performers and shows.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: In Season 5 Finale,  Alone Again
text: Season 5, Episode 12Season-ending cliffhangers usually involve something life threatening, but in “The Phantom,” the season finale of “Mad Men” on Sunday night, Matthew Weiner left us with a smaller, more intimate question to ponder. With Nancy Sinatra in the background singing “You Only Live Twice,” Don Draper is approached by a young woman at a bar and asked, “Are you alone?” He considers the question, gives her a sexy sideways glance and — cut.

headline: Two Jobs, but Half a World Apart
text: “You could say that I was raised to be a nomad,” Anand Chaturvedi writes in The New York Times. “By the 10th grade, I had attended 10 schools throughout Rajasthan, my home state in northwestern India.” The experience turned out to be good training for my current working life, Mr. Chaturvedi writes; who juggles his time as a senior executive with a Korean firm in Atlanta and manages a clinic for diabetes patients in Udaipur, Rajasthan.

headline: No Fanfare for China’s Female Astronauts
text: HONG KONG — Nearly half a century after the Soviet Union sent the first woman into space, China appears ready to send its first female astronaut aloft.

headline: Africa’s Second Female President Delivers
text: ACCRA, Ghana — Well, that didn’t take too long.

headline: In Mexico, a Candidate Stands Out Despite Attacks
text: MEXICO CITY — His likeness appears on a prominently displayed billboard here promoting infidelity, a reference to his affairs during his first marriage. Headlines nearly every day report on corruption allegations around former ranking officials of his party. His opponents’ television commercials warn that he will make deals with criminals to quell the bloodshed from Mexico’s drug war. University students have taken to the streets to march against him.

headline: News Quiz | June 11, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Don’t Count India Out Just Yet
text: News out of India as of late has been either bad or dreadful. Recently released statistics confirm that growth has been even lower than forecast. Most recently, poor jobs numbers confirm that the economy is in the doldrums and a report from the country’s Planning Commission shows that India is lagging in a range of social and economic indicators linked to the United Nations’ Millennium Development Goals.

headline: A Voice From the Trash
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Ex-Prime Minister Contradicts Murdoch Testimony
text: LONDON — Starting four days of testimony by political leaders about the sway of Rupert Murdoch’s newspapers over public life here, former Prime Minister Gordon Brown on Monday denied Mr. Murdoch’s depiction of some of their most contentious exchanges and accused a leading Murdoch newspaper, The Sun, of undermining Britain’s war effort in Afghanistan.

headline: In French Assembly, Socialists Appear Near Victory and Expatriates Gain a Voice
text: President François Hollande’s Socialist Party and its allies appear to be headed for a majority in the French National Assembly after Sunday’s first round of voting for the lower house, Steven Erlanger reports. The final result won’t be known until next Sunday after the second round of voting.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 11, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Pro Wrestling, Senegal Style.”

headline: Bonnaroo: Final Thoughts After the Sun Came Out
text: How long has it been since the Beach Boys played to an arena-sized audience full of young, squealing girls eager to dance and sing along? Decades? Whatever the answer, the band that summed up the myth of the California summer had something going for it on Sunday; as it played “Barbara Ann,” the sun moved out from behind the clouds for the first time all day.

headline: Raids Target Putin’s Critics Before Protest
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin raised pressure on Russia’s opposition movement on Monday, searching the homes of several of its leading figures. The coordinated early-morning raids sent a new shudder through political circles preparing for another large demonstration in central Moscow on Tuesday.

headline: Pro-Obama Ads Target Hispanics in Swing States
text: Priorities USA Action, a “super PAC” backing President Obama, is starting a $4 million ad campaign aimed at Hispanic voters in three swing states, the group plans to announce Monday morning.

headline: Documenting Death Sentences in Iran
text: When Ebrahim Noroozi attended his first hanging, he left the scene covering his ears to shield them from the roar of the crowds.

headline: Prescription Drugs and High Achievers

headline: How to Make the Most of a College Visit
text: Brennan Barnard is the director of college counseling at The Derryfield School in Manchester, N.H. He recently wrote our June college checklist for rising seniors, which details what the members of the class of 2013 should be doing as they prepare for college. In this essay, Mr. Barnard provides more in-depth advice about visiting college campuses this summer. — Tanya Caldwell

headline: Survivors
text: The other day, I came across a tin of powdered butter that I’d stored in my basement five years ago as part of an emergency cache. All I needed to do was add 27 cups of water and — voila! — I’d have a huge amount of peculiar-tasting buttery substance with which to adorn my bread and Kraft Dinner while I waited out an influenza pandemic in a pristine state of self-quarantine.

headline: America’s Hidden Austerity Program
text: Ben Polak is the chairman of the economics department at Yale University. Peter K. Schott is a professor of economics at the Yale School of Management.

headline: Telefonica to Sell Shares Back to China Unicom for $1.4 Billion
text: Telefónica, the largest European telecommunications operator by revenue, has agreed to sell back a 4.56 percent stake in China Unicom, part of an effort by Telefónica to reduce debt as the European financial crisis continues to hurt earnings in its main markets in Europe.

headline: Felda Moving Ahead With $3.2 Billion I.P.O. in Malaysia
text: HONG KONG — Facebook’s botched Nasdaq debut last month may have cast a pall over the global market for new listings, but the Malaysian palm oil producer Felda Global Venture Holdings still plans to raise up to $3.2 billion this week in the world’s second-biggest initial public offering this year, according to a person with direct knowledge of the deal.

headline: Charter vs. Charter in a Shared Harlem Building
text: In the recent past, most of the contentious battles over school space in the city have erupted when a charter school has tried to share the same floor with a traditional public school. In this case, the space crunch is between two charter schools, both of which are very different models. A Columbia journalism student reports from Harlem.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Change Your Password
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Life as a Runway: The Little Devils Wear Prada
text: “Style means pretty.” Aubrey Conlon said, summoning all the confidence a 7-year-old can. She had taken time out from a shopping adventure at the Westfield mall in Skokie, Ill., to talk about clothes, a topic close to her heart.

headline: Nadal Beats Djokovic for Record Seventh French Title
text: Rafael Nadal rarely needs help to win on clay, but in the end on Monday he got some from Novak Djokovic to win the men’s French Open final, 6-4, 6-3, 2-6, 7-5, for his seventh singles championship at Roland Garros.

headline: Tech World Double Standard for Women Entrepreneurs?
text: Perhaps it’s not surprising in the estrogen-challenged world of tech, but female entrepreneurs have a much harder time raising capital than their male counterparts, Hannah Seligson reports.

headline: Deirdre DeAngelis-D'Alessio: Leading Is an 'Us' Business
text: In the latest Principal's Office interview, the principal of New Dorp High School on Staten Island says her large high school is working for her students -- and can be a model to help preserve other large high schools in the city. "There are advantages to small schools for a certain kind of kid, but there’s something about the community of a large school that you can’t replace," she says.

headline: Should Siachen be Demilitarized?
text: The removal of Indian and Pakistani troops from the deadly, hostile Siachen Glacier is expected to dominate talks between defense officials from the two countries, which began Monday in Rawalpindi.

headline: Ravenous | Fried Baltic Herring, at Home
text: My kitchen in Helsinki is a repository for toy-size appliances: a half fridge that freezes all the vegetables that I’ve placed inside except for the palm-size, gold-flesh rutabagas that are as durable as they are delicious; two small burners that offer heat along with the unappetizing smell of an electrical fire; and a microwave that’s useless for cooking, so I’ve converted it into a storage cabinet.

headline: Q. and A.: A Panoramic View of Energy Innovation

As the founding director, voice and face of the agency, better known as ARPA-E, Dr. Majumdar has been on the front lines of the Obama administration’s investments in experimental energy projects, many of which focus on improving efficiency, reducing pollution or devising plant-based alternatives to fossil fuels.

headline: Things You Really Don’t Want To See The Morning After A Bailout
text: It’s a commonplace that the half-life of euro rescue plans has been steadily falling — that is, the time between the initial euphoria over the latest bailout loan or whatever and the realization that the fundamentals have not been addressed keeps getting shorter. Apparently that half-life is now down to a few hours.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Spinning in Syria, and a ‘No Fuss’ Coming Out for Gay Actor
text: For years, the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has used high-priced public relations advisers — veterans of the Clinton, Bush and Thatcher administrations — to portray themselves in the Western media as accessible, progressive and even glamorous, Bill Carter and Amy Chozick write. Until recently, the Assad government had a couple of obvious things working in its favor, in the words of a Middle East expert who once worked for a charity sponsored by Mr. Assad’s wife, Asma: “He speaks English, and his wife is hot.” The violent crackdown against the political opposition there has changed that friendly calculus — something the longtime ABC News correspondent Barbara Walters found out this week.

headline: Bookshelf | ‘Body Back’
text: Here’s an audacious gift idea for Father’s Day: after he’s opened those Beach Boys tickets, slip him a copy of “Body Back” (Clementine, $30), a new book by Heather Porter. Its cover is red, with a nude by Natasha Law, but it’s not exactly that kind of title. When Daddy looks a little more closely, he’ll see that he’s holding “the mother’s handbook to medical, physical and emotional well-being.” Yes, you’re bestowing upon him the gift of knowledge about everything you’ve been through after you’ve given him and nurtured the greatest gifts of all — his children. Of course, it’s really a present for you, too (payback for all those surprises that were really for him, like cooking lessons and lingerie).

headline: French Publisher Group Strikes Deal With Google Over E-Books
text: PARIS — Even as a dispute over Google’s digital book project deepens in the United States, the company said Monday that it had reached an agreement in France that could bring back to life thousands of out-of-print works.

headline: Sports Weekend Goes Into Overtime
text: As it turns out, the weekend was not big enough to contain all of the sporting events the gods — or the television executives — tried to cram in it. Something, apparently, had to give. So it rained in Paris and Rafael Nadal's victory in the men's French Open final leaked into Monday. Which means a Game 7 in the N.B.A., a Stanley Cup finals that will not die, the Belmont (deflated as it was), Euro 2012 openers, a Lionel Messi hat trick in a Brazil-Argentina friendly and a boxing match that turned into the sport's latest mess, a six-pitcher no-hitter by the Mariners, well, all of that was going to have to keep you occupied.

But it is also a position that comes with neither compensation nor thanks, and it requires sitting through hours of bickering over questions like whether the doormen ought to wear little caps. The ranks are often dominated by retirees, real estate brokers and lawyers.

The news series of ‘“Dallas” — yes, “Dallas”! — would star some of the original cast members and a new generation of characters, one of whom is an actress I’ve had the pleasure of working with on and off for quite some time, the very lovely Jordana Brewster. On the show, Brewster plays Elena, the daughter of the ranch’s cook who is involved in a scandalous love triangle. Want to know with who? Tune in to the first episode on TNT this Wednesday, June 13, at 9 p.m. Me? I’m anxious to know what Brewster has in her makeup bag and what she’s using to keep herself looking so luminous.

headline: The Two Keys to Investing: Pickiness and Persistence

headline: Monday Motorsports: Joey Logano Sets Blistering Pace at Repaved Pocono

Mark Martin, 53, seized the lead from the pole sitter Joey Logano, 22, with eight laps remaining in the Pocono 400 Sprint Cup race and appeared to have sufficient momentum to deflect a further challenge — that was, until the bump.

text: YABUCOA, P.R. — Here, on steep hills cultivated with bananas and yams, a few people had heard that a Puerto Rican man had been arrested in a 33-year-old murder of a child in New York.

text: During Memorial Day weekend, I was listening to public radio en route to my daily swim when I heard “A Child’s Reliquary,” a piano trio written by Richard Danielpour in memory of the 18-month-old son of the conductor Carl St. Clair. The child drowned in a pool in 1999 when his mother, who was in the pool with him, suffered a diabetic seizure.

headline: Incentives for Drivers Who Avoid Traffic Jams
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — London, Singapore, Stockholm and a few other cities around the world battle heavy traffic with a “congestion charge,” a stiff fee for driving in crowded areas at peak hours. But drivers generally hate the idea, and efforts to impose it in this country have failed.

headline: Sylvia Earle on Optimism and the Up and Down Sides of Fossil Fuels
text: I was listening to the deeply engaging radio program “On Being,” created and hosted by Krista Tippett, while driving to Bard College on Sunday to participate in a conference exploring paths to new economic norms. Tippett’s guest was Sylvia Earle, the underwater explorer, marine scientist and conservation campaigner. It’s well worth listening to (their entwined voices are a mellifluous duet of curiosity, passion and joy). But you can also read the conversation here.

headline: Positive Ad Push in Massachusetts Senate Race
text: BOSTON – Both candidates locked in the fierce Senate race in Massachusetts released positive, family-themed advertisements this week, with incumbent Senator Scott P. Brown looking to reach out to women voters and his Democratic challenger, Elizabeth Warren, attempting to move on from weeks of controversy over her heritage.

headline: Just One Look | The Row
text: This look from the Row is neither the collection’s most elaborate — a white-on-white coat embroidered with palms designed by the artist Whitney Bedford wins that prize — nor is it as novel as the group’s layered trousers or glossy hoods-as-rain-hats, either. What the striped, pajama-y dress does most effectively, however, is evoke fantasies of sunshine (or else why the hat?) and luxury via leisure. Buy it and you could be in a jasmine-scented canyon in Southern California drinking an Arnold Palmer with your feet in the pool, it says. Sold.

headline: Numberplay: Three-Point Turn
text: Welcome to Numberplay, the weeklong game of collaboration and discovery that also happens to be about math. If you’re new to the game, give it a try by leaving a comment at the end of this post. You don’t have to solve the problem; hunches are good. So are wild conjectures. At Numberplay, the standard answer is just the beginning.

headline: Sandusky’s Trial Begins With Graphic Testimony
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — When Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State football assistant coach, retired from Joe Paterno’s staff in 1999, he devoted himself full time to his charity, which tried to help children from disadvantaged families and broken homes.

headline: Gay Parents and the Marriage Debate
text: Slate is out with two pieces today on an attention-getting new study that looks at adult outcomes for children raised by parents in same-sex relationships — one by the study’s author, the University of Texas sociologist Mark Regnerus (who co-authored the excellent survey “Premarital Sex in America”), and a response by Will Saletan that tries to tease out some of the study’s implications for the gay marriage debate. The background to the study is the striking fact that even as traditional marriage has declined in the United States – marriage rates tumbling, out-of-wedlock childbirth climbing, and cohabitation becoming as respectable as wedlock – the evidence has mounted for the institution’s importance to the well-being of children. A happy childhood is possible in many different environments, of course. But a growing body of research indicates that no other parental arrangement, from single motherhood to cohabitation to shared custody, affords as many social, economic and emotional advantages as being raised by two biological parents joined in a lifelong commitment. (Isabel Sawhill from the Brookings Institution and Kay Hymowitz from the Manhattan Institute have both had good recent pieces elaborating on some of these themes.)

headline: Buy a Candidate
text: With Citizens United, the Supreme Court dismissed the idea that unlimited independent political expenditures from corporations or unions would lead “to corruption or the appearance of corruption” and held that “the appearance of influence or access will not cause the electorate to lose faith in this democracy.” This startlingly naïve decision, as well as lower court rulings and F.E.C. policies that rely on it, has given rise to a campaign system that’s best described as a Hobbesian state of nature.

headline: Rainbow Quinoa Salad With Fava Beans and Herbs
text: Each of the three varieties of quinoa in rainbow quinoa -- red, black and blond – has a different texture, which is one of the things I like about the blend. The black grains are the hardest and never splay, and the red grains are harder than the white grains. The mixture takes about 5 minutes longer to cook than blond quinoa alone. I like to toast the grains in a hot pan first, for a richer flavor.

For the first time, one of the creatures has been trapped on Kauai.

headline: Asked & Answered | Can Bonomo
text: Ah, to be 25, dressed like a Left Bank buccaneer and belting out irresistible Anatolian pop before a televised audience of 125 million kitsch-craving European fans. Such was Can Bonomo’s perch at the Eurovision Song Contest last month. The dashing young Turk, from a Sephardic Jewish family in Izmir, represented Turkey in Eurovision. Though he did not win — the prize went to Swedish-Moroccan singer Loreen — Bonomo was one of the more compelling singers to take the enormous and purpose-built stage in Baku, Azerbaijan. His song “Love Me Back” was performed as a jaunty set piece, variously channeling Pirates of the Caribbean (the ride), Show Boat and Ali Baba. A spicy summer mix, you might say. Bonomo stopped whirling for a moment to talk to us about “Istanbul music” and more.

headline: The Games Crows Play, and Other Winged Tales
text: The extremes of animal behavior can be a source of endless astonishment. Books have been written about insect sex. The antics of dogs and cats are sometimes hard to believe. And birds, those amazing birds: They build elaborate nests, learn lyrical songs, migrate impossibly long distances. But “Gifts of the Crow,” by John N. Marzluff and Tony Angell, includes a description of one behavior that even Aesop never imagined.

headline: ‘Girls’ and ‘Bad Sex’

headline: The Girl From Castro Convertibles’ Early Commercials Is Back
text: She did the demonstration in the front hall, where a hunter’s trophy — a large antlered head mounted on a square of dark wood — once stared down from a landing above the stairs. Surely that animal would have recognized her as the girl from the sofa bed commercials of the 1940s. And the 1950s. And the 1960s.

headline: Choosing a Sugar Substitute
text: White. Pink. Blue. Yellow.

headline: Readers React: Best Summer Olympics Movies
text: Last week, The Times’s Victor Mather presented his list of the 10 best Summer Olympics movies of all time.  Readers expressed their thoughts on this topic on Twitter.

headline: Justices Reject Detainees’ Appeal, Leaving Cloud Over Earlier Guantánamo Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to hear appeals from seven men held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, passing up an opportunity to clarify its last Guantánamo decision, in 2008. That ruling, in Boumediene v. Bush, gave prisoners at Guantánamo a “meaningful opportunity” to challenge their detentions in court.

headline: E.P.A. Soot Rules Expected This Week
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency plans to propose new air quality standards for soot by Thursday and issue final standards by Dec. 14 under a tentative agreement with 11 states that sued the agency earlier this year.

headline: Bomb Hits Ambulance in Usually Calm Afghan Area
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A roadside bomb explosion struck an ambulance in a bucolic, usually peaceful area of northern Afghanistan on Monday, killing at least three passengers and the driver, but sparing the life of the patient, a pregnant woman, who was traveling to deliver her child at a health clinic, government officials said.

headline: Virginia President to Leave After Two Years
text: Students entering the University of Virginia this fall won’t be the only new faces on campus; the university plans to have a new president, too.

headline: To Cut Blood Pressure, Nerves Get a Jolt
text: In recent decades, there have been few new treatments for people with stubbornly high blood pressure. Exercise and a low-sodium diet, along with such stalwart drugs as diuretics, ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers, have made up the standard regimens.

headline: Indian Executives Vouch for Rajat K. Gupta in Court
text: Rajat K. Gupta, the former McKinsey head and Goldman Sachs director, is relying on character witnesses from India to testify on his behalf in the Galleon Group insider trading case.

headline: Is Apple Splitting the Baby?
text: Update 3:35 p.m.: Mistakenly indentified the all-new MacBook Pro as having a 13-inch display. It has a 15.4-inch display.

headline: The Makings of Our Earliest Memories
text: Like many other pediatricians, I do not wear a white coat. Many of us believe that babies and small children suffer from a special form of “white coat syndrome,” that mix of trepidation and anxiety that some adults experience — to the point of high blood pressure — in a medical setting.

headline: France Ties England Amid Heavy Security
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — On a day of blistering heat and searing chances from France, England desperately held on for a 1-1 tie in the opening match for both teams at the European Championships.

headline: China: Survey Reveals a Growing Number of Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis Cases
text: China has a “serious epidemic of drug-resistant tuberculosis,” according to the first national survey of the disease, which was carried out by the Chinese Center for Disease Control and published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: Reagan Wouldn’t Make It
text: Jeb Bush told reporters in New York City this morning that neither his father, George H.W. Bush, nor Ronald Reagan would find purchase in today’s Republican Party.

headline: The ‘Mad Men’ Season Finale: Series Creator Matthew Weiner Discusses ‘The Phantom’
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sunday’s season finale of “Mad Men.”

headline: In Tunisia, Balancing Democracy and Religion
text: Tunisia is trying to build a new order with citizens who, having lived under repressive regimes for nearly 60 years, have little experience in accommodating their diversity.

headline: Tensions on a Campus Mirror Turbulence in a New Tunisia
text: TUNIS — The ultraconservative Islamist student announced his arrival by kicking over a large metal ashtray in the lobby.

headline: Poles Prepare for Soccer Match Against Russians With a Bitter View to History
text: WARSAW — Poland is enjoying its turn on the European stage, co-hosting the prestigious European soccer championship, which the country’s leaders hoped to use as a coming-out party for their newly confident nation. There is only one problem, and it is a familiar one: Russia.

headline: For Neil Young, a Journey Through Rock and Rust
text: In the new documentary “Neil Young Journeys,” the musician, activist and car tinkerer of the film’s title recounts how he acquired a taste for the road.

headline: Photo Replay: June 11
text: The day in sports included Rafael Nadal celebrating a seventh French Open title and a Euro 2012 match between France and England.

headline: The Reward for Donating a Kidney: No Insurance
text: When Erika Royer’s lupus led to kidney failure four years ago, her father, Radburn, was able to give her an extraordinary gift: a kidney.

headline: Joy Behar Is Reviving Her Talk Show, This Time for Current TV
text: The comedian and political commentator Joy Behar, whose HLN talk show was canceled late last year, is reprising her act for Current TV, the network announced on Monday.

headline: Schaulager Museum Sets Up Temporary Outpost at Art Basel
text: BASEL, Switzerland – As the art world arrives here for Tuesday’s opening of Art Basel – the ne plus ultra of contemporary art fairs – two things are immediately apparent. The first is the noise from the construction of a building next to the main plaza where the fair is held; the building, designed by the Swiss architects Herzog & de Meuron, will be yet another exhibition space in the complex. The second is the arrival of the “Schaulager Satellite,’’ a dramatic, all-white temporary pavilion, also designed by Herzog & de Meuron, right in the center of the main plaza.

headline: ‘Fela!’ Will Return to Broadway for a Summer Run
text: The Tony Award-winning musical “Fela!,” which ran 14 months on Broadway before closing last year, will return next month for a four-week engagement at the Al Hirschfeld Theater as part of the show’s world tour, the producers of “Fela!” confirmed on Monday.

headline: Unemployed and Forced Into Retirement
text: June 11, 2012 - When unemployment forces an early retirement.

headline: LinkedIn Hack Raises Concern
text: June 11, 2011 — Data companies and the bare-bones approach to online security.

headline: Spanish Housing Crisis Deepens
text: June 11, 2012 - Gretchen Morgenson explains the Spanish housing crisis.

headline: Drilling Down: Does the ‘Freemium’ Model Really Work?
text: This week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to an article by Dmitri Leonov that challenges the “freemium” business model. Increasingly popular on the Web, the model involves offering basic products or services free but charging a premium for advanced features or functionality (Chris Anderson famously proclaimed “free” the future of business in 2008). I decided to follow up with a few questions for Mr. Leonov, who is vice president for growth at SaneBox, a company that helps users spend less time in their in-box by filtering out and summarizing unimportant e-mails (for a fee!). The following is a condensed version of our e-mail conversation.

headline: Guest Blog | ‘Taking a Dip in the Nonfiction Pool’ With Our Summer Reading Contest
text: If you were among the thousands who posted about #summerreading on Twitter last Thursday, thank you again. The hashtag has been going strong ever since, and we expect readers to keep posting thoughts and recommendations all season long.

headline: Latvia and the Romney Record
text: OK, not a connection you expected anyone to make. But there’s something there.

headline: Bank of America’s Moszkowski to Join a Research Boutique
text: Autonomous Research, a London-based boutique research firm, has decided to expand in the United States in a big way — by hiring one of the top banking analysts around.

headline: Panel Finds U.S. and Europe Behind Schedule on Financial Rules
text: FRANKFURT — Despite fresh reminders of the fragility of the financial system, the United States, the European Union and Japan are behind schedule on implementing measures that were adopted as part of an international effort to avert future banking crises, a high-level panel said Monday.

headline: Game 6 in Los Angeles: Distractions and Motivation Galore
text: LOS ANGELES — When the Devils were down, three games to none, in the Stanley Cup finals and their team bus pulled into Staples Center before Game 4, Coach Peter DeBoer saw something that irked him.

headline: Video: LinkedIn’s Bare Bones Approach to Security
text: While it is not surprising that LinkedIn was hacked, security experts were surprised at how weak the company’s defenses against breaches were. Nicole Perlroth and David Gillen discuss.

headline: Apple Updates Laptops and Mobile Software
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple on Monday introduced a new version of its mobile operating system for iPhones and iPads that will bring a host of new features, including maps that let users soar over a three-dimensional rendering of a city.

headline: Suit Claims UConn Women’s Coach Retaliated After His Sexual Advance Was Rebuffed
text: A security director for the National Basketball Association said in a lawsuit Monday that Geno Auriemma, the coach of the United States Olympic women’s basketball team, followed, grabbed and tried to forcibly kiss her at a hotel during a basketball tournament in Russia in 2009.

headline: If Tony Broadcast Were a Broadway Show, It Might Close
text: The combined lack of blockbuster buzz and star power hurt CBS’s broadcast of the 66th-annual Tony Awards on Sunday night, as it fell to record-low television ratings. According to preliminary Nielsen estimates the telecast finished with its lowest rating ever in the 18-to-49-year-old group, the category most important to advertisers, a 17 percent drop-off from last year. It was also down in total viewers, to around 6 million from almost 7 million last year.

headline: In Las Vegas, A Dance Music Boom
text: Electronic dance music has become the sound of Las Vegas, emanating from the city’s huge “superclubs” that are attached to casinos along the Strip.

headline: Anthony Bourdain Is All Over the Media Menu
text: “I’m a big believer in forward motion,” Anthony Bourdain told me on the phone the other day. “I see lethargy and leisure time as my enemy. I’m not a guy who should have a lot of free time. It’s bad for me.”

headline: Just One Look | Nina Ricci
text: “There are slightly more casual references this season,” said Nina Ricci’s Peter Copping at this morning’s resort presentation. “This is the first time we’ve done denim.” (So easily did this denim fit into Copping’s equation for resort, one would never have known it was a novelty unless told.) Showed in the company of quintessential skirt suits, butterfly-themed pieces (a printed romper being the Parisian house’s idea of beachwear) and looks that matched dress to trench, this flirty pop-over mixes parachute silk with the blue jean basic beautifully.

headline: Diabetes Drugs Carry Vision Risks
text: A popular class of drugs used to treat Type 2 diabetes may increase the risk of vision problems, a new study suggests, underlining the importance of regular eye exams for anyone with diabetes.

headline: Where Wealth Declined Most (and an Income Riddle)
text: The bleak portrait of the financial health of American families that the Federal Reserve published Monday shows that the impact of the economic crisis has fallen with disproportionate weight on the middle class.

headline: ‘Little Dorito’ and More: Suggestions for Literary Product Placement
text: A blogger’s recent discovery that a 99-cent e-book version of “War and Peace” sold in Barnes and Noble’s Nook Store had replaced every instance of the ordinary English word “kindle” with the word “Nook” prompted much online tittering about the wisdom of outsourcing book digitization to a company named Superior Formatting Publishing as well as reminders of the deep roots of literary product placement. (When Jules Verne began serializing “Around the World in 80 Days” in 1872 shipping companies lobbied to be name-checked in the text.)

headline: Officer Faces Manslaughter Charges in a Bronx Death
text: A police officer will be prosecuted on manslaughter charges in the shooting death of Ramarley Graham, an 18-year-old who was killed by a single police bullet in his bathroom after a team of narcotics officers broke into his Bronx home, three people briefed on the charges said Monday.

headline: Not a Title That’s Meant for Mom
text: The title of the Irish novelist Colm Toibin’s nonfiction book, “New Ways to Kill Your Mother: Writers and Their Families,” is so vivid that it feels churlish to point out that a more accurate one would be something like: “Side Work: Recent Book Reviews, Essays and Odd Bits.”

headline: As Our World Shrinks, It Also Narrows
text: PARIS — Even for travelers with open tickets and time to roam, the world map is starting to look like a redacted Pentagon document: splotched with blot-out ink in so many interesting places.

headline: Regulator Releases ‘Road Map’ on Swaps Overhaul
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission detailed a plan on Monday to phase in dozens of new rules governing over-the-counter swaps.

headline: Queen’s Granddaughter, Zara Phillips, Will Compete in Olympics
text: Zara Phillips, Queen Elizabeth II’s granddaughter, has been selected to compete for Great Britain’s Olympic team at the London Games in 2012.

headline: Just One Look | Chloé
text: “So pretty,” editors gasped upon entering the penthouse at Milk Studios, where the stars of the Chloé resort collection were displayed on mannequins bathed in bright morning light. There, all-white looks like the one shown here (full, perforated skirt; peasant top — oh so pretty) segued into summery pieces like shorts and a scarf print shift (was there a designer who didn’t show a scarf print today?), and a number of even more romantic off-the-shoulder dresses. Really, really relaxed was the vibe one got from the collection and its designer, Claire Waight Keller, who seems to have settled in quite comfortably at Chloé’s helm. All those pretty — and wearable and flattering and easy-to-understand — clothes must be doing the trick.

headline: Parents Push for Faster PCB Removal
text: Parents at a Brooklyn elementary school are calling on the Department of Education to move faster to remove toxic PCBs from lighting fixtures in school buildings around the city.

headline: Tony Winners See Immediate Payoff at Box Office
text: The Broadway musicals “Once,” “Newsies” and “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” all had stronger ticket sales than usual on Monday after their wins and televised performance numbers at the Tony Awards on Sunday night, according to publicists for the productions or theater executives familiar with the sales.

headline: Defining What Qualifies as Anger in the Air
text: EVERY time I watch the television news, somebody is urgently talking about some new threat to become alarmed about. I’m thinking, in particular, about the scary report on CNN recently — widely cited in the media — that “air rage” incidents are up sharply.
