headline: Alabama: House Swarmed in Search for Suspect
text: Law officers on Monday surrounded and shot tear gas into a Montgomery house where they believe Desmonte D. Leonard, suspected of a shooting Saturday that left three people dead and three others wounded near Auburn University, may have fled. No one had emerged by late night. Two other men were arrested earlier in the case. Jeremy S. Thomas was arrested by the Auburn police on Monday and charged with hindering prosecution. Gabriel Thomas was arrested late Sunday by Montgomery police for “providing false information to law enforcement officers.”

headline: Reagan at the Wall
text: Providence, R.I.

headline: Driving Miss Siri
text: Apple announced an expansion of Siri at the opening of its developers’ conference on Monday; new devices and apps will work with the voice-command service. One of the more intriguing areas of that expansion was the addition of automakers to Siri’s roster of partners. Apple announced that Audi, BMW, Chrysler, General Motors, Honda, Land Rover/Jaguar, Mercedes-Benz and Toyota would all have “Eyes Free” buttons in their cockpits starting in the next 12 months or so.

headline: Phillip V. Tobias, Who Analyzed Apelike Fossils, Is Dead at 86
text: Phillip V. Tobias, a South African paleoanthropologist whose meticulous analyses of fossil remains helped identify extinct species of apelike creatures related to humans, and who boldly spoke out against apartheid, died on Thursday in Johannesburg. He was 86.

headline: Berkshire Offers to Buy ResCap Assets
text: Berkshire Hathaway offered on Monday to buy most of Residential Capital, the bankrupt mortgage unit of Ally Financial, trying again to acquire the business.

headline: In a Time to Shine, India Can’t Get Off the Ground
text: NEW DELHI — Like China, India has long been eager to showcase the best features of its fast-growing economy on the international stage. But whenever it gets a chance to shine, something almost invariably goes wrong.

headline: Back in Atlanta, Yanks Recalling 2009
text: ATLANTA — The last time the Yankees came to Atlanta during interleague play was in 2009, the year they went on to win their 27th World Series. But at the time of their visit here the Yankees were underachieving. They had lost four of their previous six games and two straight and General Manager Brian Cashman was concerned.

headline: Aided by Orthodox, City’s Jewish Population Is Growing Again
text: After decades of decline, the Jewish population of New York City is growing again, increasing to nearly 1.1 million, fueled by the “explosive” growth of the Hasidic and other Orthodox communities, a new study has found. It is a trend that is challenging long-held notions about the group’s cultural identity and revealing widening gaps on politics, education, wealth and religious observance.

headline: Why the Bailout in Spain Won’t Work
text: It was not enough. And it may never be enough.

headline: Shaky Battery Maker Claims an Advance
text: DETROIT — Lauded during a visit by President Obama, A123 Systems was supposed to be a centerpiece of his administration’s effort to use $2 billion in government subsidies to jump-start production of sophisticated electric batteries in the United States.

headline: Dam Removal to Help Restore Spawning Grounds
text: BRADLEY, Me. — Under a bright sky here, a convoy of heavy equipment rolled onto the bed of the Penobscot River on Monday to smash the Great Works Dam, a barrier that has blocked the river for nearly two centuries.

headline: The Follower Problem
text: If you go to the Lincoln or Jefferson memorials in Washington, you are invited to look up in admiration. Lincoln and Jefferson are presented as the embodiments of just authority. They are strong and powerful but also humanized. Jefferson is a graceful aristocratic democrat. Lincoln is sober and enduring. Both used power in the service of higher ideas, which are engraved nearby on the walls.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Principal Hits Sour Note With School's Piano
text: Five years ago, a teacher at the Bronx Adult Learning Center on East Tremont Avenue donated a Weber grand piano to the program. Two years later, the principal, Amoye Neblett, hired movers to take it to his home in Brooklyn. The city's Conflicts of Interest Board announced on Monday that Mr. Neblett has returned the piano, but it cost him his job and a $1,000 fine.

headline: Wildfires Engulf Forests and Homes in the West
text: DENVER — A fast-growing wildfire raged through dry forests and hillside subdivisions in northern Colorado on Monday, charring homes and forcing hundreds of families to evacuate in the latest out-of-control blaze to scorch the parched West.

headline: Martin Returns to Open, Where a Cart Is Waiting
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The symbolism and juxtaposition were not lost on Casey Martin on Monday when he returned to the Olympic Club for the first time in 14 years.

headline: Insider Trading Case Focuses on Defendant’s Character
text: The federal judge overseeing the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta made it clear from the outset that he would limit evidence related to the defendant’s extensive charitable works and humanitarian acts.

headline: Gov. Walker to Host Bipartisan ‘Beer and Brat Summit’
text: Gov. Scott Walker, the Wisconsin Republican who survived a recall effort last week, will meet on Tuesday with state lawmakers from both parties for a “beer and brat summit” he has orchestrated at the governor’s residence in Madison. Mr. Walker had promised a bipartisan cookout in a speech that followed his recall victory, suggesting that he was aiming to improve relations with Democrats following 16 months of tumult since he took office.

headline: Groups to Help Online Activists in Authoritarian Countries
text: WASHINGTON — From Egyptian bloggers to Russian Twitterati, activists around the world have turned the Internet into a tool for political change, even as governments have learned its usefulness for surveillance.

headline: The Sound of a Sentence
text: This is the seventh in a series of writing lessons by the author, starting with the basics and leading to more advanced techniques.

headline: Bronx Prosecutor Seeks Reports of Past Abuse at Horace Mann
text: The Bronx district attorney’s office said Monday that it was interested in hearing any reports of sexual abuse of students at the Horace Mann School, regardless of when they occurred, in an effort to address the rising concern about faculty behavior at the prestigious private school.

headline: North Dakota Considers Eliminating Property Tax
text: BISMARCK, N.D. — Since Californians shrank their property taxes more than three decades ago by passing Proposition 13, people around the nation have echoed their dismay over such levies, putting forth plans to even them, simplify them, cap them, slash them. In an election here on Tuesday, residents of North Dakota will consider a measure that reaches far beyond any of that — one that abolishes the property tax entirely.

headline: Yoga Is Not Just Posing as Sport at World Event
text: LOS ANGELES — Silence prevailed during the yoga asana routines of the ninth annual Bishnu Charan Ghosh Cup — except for one distinct sound: the low engine rumble of airplanes lifting off and landing at the Los Angeles airport.

headline: Investigation of Possible Hoax After a Report of a Yacht Explosion Off New Jersey
text: It sounded as if a disaster were unfolding in the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey, with injured pleasure-boat passengers piling into life rafts after an explosion. An emergency radio transmission said that a yacht had blown up and sunk, that 21 people aboard had made it into life rafts and that 7 were hurt.

headline: International Yoga Asana Championship
text: Images from the ninth annual Bishnu Charan Ghosh Cup, which was held at the LAX Radisson in Los Angeles, where the mirrored ballroom became a competitive yoga stadium and runway-like hallways morphed into warm-up rooms for yogis.

headline: Obesity Ills That Won’t Budge Fuel Soda Battle by Bloomberg
text: A hospital offers Zumba and cooking classes. Farmers markets dole out $2 coupons for cantaloupe and broccoli. An adopt-a-bodega program nudges store owners to stock low-fat milk. And one apartment building even slowed down its elevator, and lined its stairwells with artwork, to entice occupants into some daily exercise.

headline: The Colonel and the Governor
text: I had last seen Angus King standing on the shores of Maine’s Casco Bay, reading from the autobiography of Col. Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain. This was at a benefit for Maine writers and publishers back in 2009. Chamberlain, a revered figure in Maine, was the Bowdoin College professor who prevented the flanking of Federal lines on the second day of the Battle of Gettysburg, and who might, as a result, have single-handedly saved the Union.

headline: Chávez Forces Venezuela to Contemplate a Void
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez is the undisputed, 24-7, one-man show of Venezuelan politics, its be-all and end-all. He makes laws on his own, with the stroke of a pen. He expropriates buildings and businesses with the wave of a hand. His face smiles from billboards and posters. He posts his thoughts on Twitter. He talks on television for hours on end. He even sings and dances.

headline: How Not to Solve a Crisis
text: There is a delicious moment in the HBO film “Too Big to Fail” when Christine Lagarde, then France’s minister of finance, calls Hank Paulson, the U.S. Treasury secretary. It’s September 2008, and Lehman Brothers has just imploded after the government refused to bail it out. Panic is in the air.

headline: Casey’s Withdrawal Opens Door for 14-Year-Old Competitor
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Paul Casey’s withdrawal on Monday because of a shoulder injury paved the way for history to be made at the United States Open. The alternate taking Casey’s place is Andy Zhang, a 14-year-old Floridian of Chinese descent who will become the youngest competitor in the Open since World War II, according to the U.S.G.A.

headline: Gentle Dissent in Mormon Church on Gay Marriage
text: SALT LAKE CITY — The congregants wore church clothes to the annual gay pride parade here in the heartland of Mormonism. Waving rainbow signs and urging love and acceptance, they marched at the front of the line, vanguards of a new movement of Mormons challenging their church’s staunch opposition to homosexuality.

headline: Institute’s Gas Drilling Report Leads to Claims of Bias and Concern for a University’s Image
text: A report from a new institute at the State University at Buffalo asserting that state oversight has made natural gas drilling safer is causing tumult on campus and beyond, with critics arguing that the institute is biased toward industry and could undercut the university’s reputation.

headline: Ice Cream or Candy
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, we are just awash in water images today, aren’t we? Man your canoes and strap on those life jackets, my friends; we are riding some rapids through Peter A. Collins’s puzzle. We’ve got MOON RIVER, RED RIVER, WILD RIVER and even THE BRIDGE OVER THE RIVER KWAI running through the grid. Oh, yes, and there’s the RIO BRAVO there in the southeast.

headline: Faith and Commerce, Precariously Balanced
text: Burdens are just about equally distributed among the eclectic characters in “Storefront Church,” John Patrick Shanley’s unwieldy but affecting new play about a handful of Bronx dwellers whose lives become tangled in unexpected ways when a mortgage goes sour. With the exception of one willfully oblivious bank executive, the men and women who find themselves gathering for a church service at the play’s conclusion all feel a measure of sorrow from the hard compromises life demands — but perhaps also a sense that burdens are lightened when shared.

headline: U.S. Expects Tough Game, and Rough Reception, in Guatemala
text: Tuesday’s weather forecast in Guatemala City calls for scattered thunderstorms and a 40 percent chance of rain: pretty much what one would expect for a Central American country during its wet season.

headline: Growing Jewish Population, Especially in Brooklyn
text: After falling in the 1990s, the Jewish population of New York City and three suburban counties has rebounded.

headline: Now, Spain
text: Two weeks after Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain vowed “there will be no Spanish banking rescue,” and after days of delay in which Mr. Rajoy pressed European officials for sounder rescue terms, Spain has now joined Greece, Ireland and Portugal as the latest bailout recipient. Catastrophe averted? Hardly.

headline: Debate’s Main Quarrel: If Rangel Should Retire
text: Congressman Charles B. Rangel, participating in the first debate of his primary campaign, looked around at his four Democratic challengers on Monday and decided that none of them had made a very good case about why they should replace him.

headline: A New Outsider Arrives at the United States Open
text: SAN FRANCISCO — He is a multiple champion this year who won one of his titles in a playoff at the expense of the three-time major champion Ernie Els. And he is not Jason Dufner. The South African Branden Grace comes into this week’s United States Open — his first — with three European Tour victories in 2012, including one in sudden death against Els and Retief Goosen, a two-time United States Open champion.

headline: Giants Lineman Charged With D.W.I. After Crash in Queens
text: David Diehl, a longtime offensive lineman for the Giants, was arrested and charged with drunken driving after crashing his BMW into a row of parked cars in Astoria, Queens, on Sunday night, the police said. Diehl was alone in the car. No injuries were reported.

headline: An Election Half Empty
text: It was a statement of such unqualified certainty that Jeb Bush made it pretty much in passing, as if it required no elaboration, accommodated no dissent and was the obvious starting point from which all political discussion should flow.

headline: Ukraine: Gunpowder Accident
text: Eight people were injured in a small fire on a trolley car on Monday in the city of Dnipropetrovsk. Local prosecutors said the accidental fire occurred when a passenger dropped a bag of gunpowder, causing it to ignite. The accident renewed fears of terrorist attacks in the city, where four explosive devices detonated in late April, wounding 38. “This was not an explosion — this was an ignition of gunpowder that is not a terrorist action,” a prosecutor, Natalya Marchuk, told the Interfax news agency, adding that an investigation would be conducted.

headline: Miscues Costing a Mets Team With No Room for Them
text: First, there was the optimism engendered by the Mets’ surprising start to the season. Then came the euphoric afterglow from Johan Santana’s historic no-hitter. But now all the good feelings have been pushed aside by a week of deflating losses in which the Mets were continually victimized by their own defensive lapses.

headline: Health Reforms Consumers Want
text: UnitedHealthcare, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, announced this week that it would keep some of the popular benefits and consumer protections required by the federal health care law even if the Supreme Court strikes down all or part of it.

headline: Israel: Memorial Vandalized
text: Vandals spray-painted graffiti overnight Monday on the walls of Yad Vashem, Israel’s official Holocaust memorial, with messages attacking Zionism and blaming Zionists for the Holocaust. Nearly a dozen messages were scrawled around the Warsaw Ghetto Square monument and other parts of the campus. One said, “If Hitler hadn’t existed, the Zionists would have invented him,” and another said, “The Zionists wanted the Holocaust.” One message was signed “Global Haredi Judaism,” fueling suspicions that those behind the act were ultra-Orthodox Jewish extremists who reject the modern state of Israel.

headline: San Francisco Hotel Has Ties to Champions
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the city billed as the gateway to San Francisco there sits a hotel that can claim to being a portal to the United States Open championship. The El Camino Inn on Mission Street has ties to two of the four United States Open golf champions crowned a few miles away at the Olympic Club.

headline: Keeping the Mountains Safe
text: Members of Mountain Rescue-Aspen are responsible for saving those lost or injured in the mountainous terrain of Pitkin County.

headline: Detained in Libya
text: A Libyan militia has detained four officials of the International Criminal Court since Thursday on spurious charges. They should be released immediately.

headline: Keeping a Mountain Rescue Team on Its Game
text: ASPEN, Colo. — More than 70 people were focused on one stout rock cliff here. Forty were members of Mountain Rescue-Aspen, the team responsible for saving those lost or injured in the mountainous terrain of Pitkin County. The rest, drawn from other rescue teams in the region, were watching to see how they did.

headline: Could Reagan Lead This G.O.P.?
text: In the current Republican Party, would Ronald Reagan still be a leader, or would he be seen as too accommodating?

headline: Goldman Brings Back a Former Partner
text: Goldman Sachs has rehired Mark Schwartz to serve as the chairman of the bank’s Asia-Pacific region and as a vice chairman of the overall bank.

headline: Obama Nominates Two for Federal Appeals Court
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday nominated two lawyers to fill vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, a powerful panel to which he has so far been unable to appoint anyone.

headline: Nova’s Strong Outing Helps Yankees Vault Into First
text: ATLANTA — After an odd few weeks in the wilderness, when no one could get a clutch hit or pitch a dominant game, the Yankees finally got back to a place they always expected to be. With a 3-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves on Monday night, the Yankees were back in first place in the American League East for the first time since April 24.

headline: In Greece, Cultural Costs of Austerity
text: Greek budget cuts are affecting archaeologists, which in turn means fewer protections for antiquities.

headline: Greek Antiquities, Long Fragile, Are Endangered by Austerity
text: KYTHIRA, Greece — A jarring public-awareness ad that has appeared recently on Greek television news shows a little girl strolling with her mother through the National Archaeological Museum in Athens, one of the country’s cultural crown jewels. The girl skips off by herself, and as she stands alone before a 2,500-year-old marble statue, a hand suddenly sweeps in from behind, covering her mouth and yanking her away.

headline: Saving a River, and Its Species
text: On Monday morning, wrecking crews began demolishing the 1,000-foot-long Great Works Dam in Bradley, Me., the first step in a multiyear effort to restore ancient fish runs on the Penobscot River. This is a very welcome development for the environment and a tribute to the willing collaboration of many players, public and private.

headline: Kodak Concedes Difficulty in Drawing Lead Bidder for Patents
text: Eastman Kodak late on Monday sought to set up a confidential auction for its portfolios of over 1,100 patents, after the bankrupt film pioneer acknowledged it had encountered difficulty drawing a lead bidder.

headline: Corrections: June 12
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Cubs Outbid Rivals to Sign Cuban Slugger
text: The Chicago Cubs won the bidding for the Cuban outfielder Jorge Soler, agreeing to a nine-year, $30 million contract, according to two executives in Major League Baseball who had been apprised of the deal.

headline: Yankees Return to First Place in A.L. East
text: With a 3-0 victory over the Braves in Atlanta, the Yankees reclaimed a piece of first place in the American League East for the first time since April 24. They had fallen as far as last place on May 21. Since then, they have won 14 of 18 and climbed 10 games over .500, a season high, to catch the idle Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Vouchers Unspoken, Romney Hails School Choice
text: “Voucher” is a fighting word in education, so it may be understandable that when Mitt Romney speaks about improving the nation’s schools, he never uses that term.

headline: After 32 Years, Coroner Confirms Dingo Killed Australian Baby
text: Thirty-two years after Azaria Chamberlain, 9 weeks old, disappeared from a campsite in Australia, the coroner in the fourth inquest into her death announced on Tuesday that the baby died as a result of being taken by a dingo, an Australian wild dog.

headline: Devils’ Hopes Disappear in a Flurry of Penalties
text: LOS ANGELES — If the Stanley Cup playoffs test anything, they measure players’ ability to maintain discipline in the midst of fatigue, pressure and frustration.

headline: The Dingo Took Her Baby
text: HONG KONG — It sounded too improbable, too loony, that a dingo had made off with her baby.

headline: Frank Cady, Kept Store on ‘Green Acres,’ Dies at 96
text: Frank Cady, a character actor best known for playing the down-home shopkeeper, Sam Drucker, on the popular 1960s sitcoms “Petticoat Junction” and “Green Acres,” died on Friday at his home in Wilsonville, Ore. He was 96.

headline: Kings Capture the Cup With an Early Outburst
text: LOS ANGELES — After 62 days of playoff domination, spearheaded by sensational goaltending, the Los Angeles Kings completed their improbable Stanley Cup run Monday night in a mere five minutes.

headline: Word of the Day | diatribe
text: diatribe •\ˈdi-ə-ˌtrib\• noun

headline: James and Heat Assume New Role as Underdogs
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — In a moment of introspection and thoughtfulness, LeBron James was short-circuited by a short circuit. A slight crackle, then silence as the podium microphone sputtered in midsentence.

headline: The Hottest Spots for Their Shots
text: This year’s N.B.A. finals feature two strikingly different offenses. Over all, the Oklahoma City Thunder rely on penetration-and-pitch plays that create 3-point and close-range shots. The Miami Heat, in contrast, rely on strategic player positioning to create effective spacing for isolation plays that enable midrange and close-range scoring chances for their superstars.

headline: In a Time to Shine, India Can’t Get Off the Ground
text: “Like China, India has long been eager to showcase the best features of its fast-growing economy on the international stage,” Gardiner Harris writes in The New York Times. “But whenever it gets a chance to shine, something almost invariably goes wrong.”

headline: Where the Heat and the Thunder Hit Their Shots
text: Navigate court maps and view analysis of every shot taken over the ’11-'12 season for the Miami Heat and Oklahoma City Thunder.

headline: Campaign Season in Venezuela
text: President Hugo Chávez mobilized thousands of supporters in Caracas on Monday, the day he formally registered to run for re-election.

headline: Stanley Cup Game 6
text: A look at the Los Angeles Kings’ championship clinching victory over the Devils on Monday’s Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: News Quiz | June 12, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Disturbances Are Few in a City Prepared to Keep Title Celebration Calm
text: LOS ANGELES — Minor disturbances broke out around Staples Center on Monday night after the Los Angeles Kings beat the Devils, 6-1, in Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals to capture their first championship.

headline: Dial 108 for Ambulance in Tamil Nadu
text: The village of Kottaiyur is about a three-hour drive southeast from Bangalore, in the Krishnagiri district of Tamil Nadu. Kottaiyur is inhabited by 4,000 Irulars, who are classified by the state government as a tribal community. Although the village is connected with the nearest town, Denkanikottai, which is 30 kilometers (19 miles) away, by a concrete road, the bus service linking the village with the outside world is sporadic and unreliable.

headline: The Push and Pull of Teaching in English
text: In some Gulf states, schools have a surprising problem: To fight against the ubiquity of English while teaching Arab students high-quality Arabic, of the sort that could be used at a professional broadcaster like Al Jazeera.

headline: The Kings’ Cup Victory and the Measure of Greatness
text: LOS ANGELES – The N.H.L. released a list of notes and numbers surrounding the Kings’ Stanley Cup run. Taken together, they form an impressive portrait of just how good the Kings were this postseason. A look at some of those facts and figures:

headline: Trial of Son Taints Pakistan’s Venerated Chief Justice
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s chief justice has wielded his court as a whip against the status quo, the country’s rich and powerful, calling top government officials and military spymasters to account and asserting himself as a political force in his own right. But on Tuesday he found himself at the center of a new political firestorm when a well-connected property baron stood up in court and accused his family of corrupt dealing, detailing $3.7 million in kickbacks and cash payments.

headline: Euro 2012: A Quick Take on 4 Days, 8 Games and 16 Teams
text: Every team at Euro 2012 has played one game, so what do we know? In a tournament with some of the most expensive talent from some of the most expensive leagues in the world, Alan Dzagoev (CSKA Moscow), Mario Mandzukic (Wolfsburg) and Andriy Shevchenko (Dynamo Kyiv) are the unlikely leaders in the race for the Golden Boot; Carlos Velasco Carballo — the Spanish referee who flashed four yellow cards and the tournament’s only two reds in the event’s first game — has a future as a blackjack dealer; and the only Dutchman on track for the quarterfinals is Russia’s coach, Dick Advocaat. Let’s recap briefly the standings after the first four days:

headline: British Ex-Premier Says Murdoch Press ‘Lowered Tone’
text: LONDON — As the judicial inquiry into the British press sifts painstakingly through competing claims about the influence of Rupert Murdoch’s newspapers, former Prime Minister John Major disclosed on Tuesday, for what he said was the first time, that Mr. Murdoch withdrew his newspapers’ support for the Conservatives after Mr. Major refused a demand for changes in his policies on Europe.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 12, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “The Making of an Olympic Sex Symbol.”

headline: India Gets Waiver for Oil Trade With Iran
text: Less than three weeks before stringent American sanctions intended to reduce Iran’s oil exports take effect, “the Obama administration announced on Monday that it would exempt seven major importers of Iranian oil — but not China — from the measures because these countries had ‘significantly reduced’ their oil purchases from Iran,” Mark Landler writes in The New York Times.

headline: So You Think You Can Be a Hair Braider?
text: Jestina Clayton grew up in a village in Sierra Leone where every girl learns traditional African hair-braiding. Then, when she was 22, she moved to Centerville, Utah, a place where no one learns traditional African hair-braiding. So Clayton was pleasantly surprised to find a niche in the market among a small group of Utah parents who had adopted African children but didn’t know how to style their hair.

headline: Yes, Bob Kerrey Wants to Go Back to Washington
text: When Bob Kerrey left the Senate after two terms in 2001 — mainly, he says now, so he could remarry and start a new family away from politics — he was considered a statesmanlike and contemplative presence in a city that still valued both qualities. Kerrey had been a serious presidential candidate, a respected voice on health care and intelligence and co-chairman of one of those bipartisan commissions to reform entitlement programs. His closest friends included the small crowd of Vietnam veterans from both parties — John McCain, John Kerry, Chuck Hagel, Chuck Robb, Max Cleland — for whom party loyalty seemed well down the list of daily concerns.

headline: Africans Documenting Africa
text: Taking something as broad — and, for many, abstract — as climate change, and making it a palpable reality is the task undertaken by the Ghanaian photographers Nyani Quarmyne and Nii Obodai. Mr. Quarmyne, 39, objects to a common, Western understanding of climate change: whether to buy double-glazed windows or hybrid cars is, for many Westerners, as tangible as the situation is going to get.

headline: Heavier Weapons Push Syrian Crisis Toward Civil War
text: WASHINGTON — With evidence that powerful new weapons are flowing to both the Syrian government and opposition fighters, the bloody uprising in Syria has thrust the Obama administration into an increasingly difficult position as the conflict shows signs of mutating into a full-fledged civil war.

headline: When Kings Are Hockey Royalty
text: WHAT National Hockey League team won the Stanley Cup on Monday night?WHAT team did the champions beat?WHAT was the final score?

headline: A Primer on Greece’s Election: Niki Kitsantonis Answers Readers’ Questions
text: ATHENS — Greece is just days away from a rerun of the elections that failed to give any single party (or group of parties) enough power to form a government. How Greece, the birthplace of Western democracy, votes may have fateful consequences both for this country and for the dozens of countries who use the euro or belong to the European Union, the most ambitious project of free states and free people that this Continent has ever known.

headline: Large Anti-Putin Protest Signals Growing Resolve
text: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of protesters thronged central Moscow in a drenching rain on Tuesday, voicing renewed fury at President Vladimir V. Putin and defying recent efforts by his government to clamp down on the political opposition movement.

headline: Pakistan, India Agree to Keep Talking About Siachen
text: Two days of high-level discussions between Indian and Pakistani defense officials were “cordial and friendly,” but ended with out any progress on the demilitarization of the Siachen glacier, a dangerous, high-altitude battleground.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Sleeper Relievers
text: As someone who rarely chooses to pay the prevailing rate at auction for top-tier closers, I’m often left spending the next six months chasing anyone on my waiver wire(s) who may be even remotely in the mix for saves. This year is no exception, as we’ve seen guys like Mariano Rivera, Sergio Santos, and Andrew Bailey get hurt. Others such as Jordan Walden and Javy Guerra lost their jobs, so we’ve seen quite an influx of new closers already.

headline: The Early Word: Rifts
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: At Petersen, Cars That Cheated the Wind, if Not Always Gracefully
text: Bullet- and torpedo-shaped cars have been around almost as long as the automobile. Instinctively, early car designers gravitated toward shapes that would make their cars move more rapidly through the air.

headline: The Fiscal Legacy of George W. Bush
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: A Different Era, and a Different Animal
text: Despite Union Rags’s stirring rally in Saturday’s Belmont (for which I congratulate him and his connections heartily), I missed the hoopla and anticipation of seeing I’ll Have Another take a crack at the Triple Crown.Then again, is it that surprising that a racehorse that went all out to win the Derby and the Preakness came up injured before the last dance? Just another argument that today’s thoroughbreds are genetically engineered for speed and aggression, not the soundness and stamina it takes to win three Grade I races in five weeks.

headline: An Inspiration From Bangalore Reduces Traffic Jams
text: “London, Singapore, Stockholm and a few other cities around the world battle heavy traffic with a ‘congestion charge,’ a stiff fee for driving in crowded areas at peak hours,” John Markoff writes in The New York Times. “But drivers generally hate the idea, and efforts to impose it in this country have failed,” he wrote, referring to the United States.

headline: Axelrod Floats Amendment to Stem Campaign Spending
text: 1:09 p.m. | Updated On David Axelrod’s New York City itinerary for Monday: to meet privately with potential donors to a “super PAC” supporting President Obama’s re-election, then publicly declare that if that re-election happens, Mr. Obama will stop at almost nothing to undo the ruling that made super PACs possible.

headline: Wary of a Takeover, Qantas Hires Macquarie
text: HONG KONG — Qantas Airways of Australia has hired the investment bank Macquarie to provide advice on fending off potential hostile takeover bids after its shares plunged to their lowest levels since the company was privatized in 1995.

headline: America Movil Lifts Stake in KPN
text: Carlos Slim Helú is not taking no for an answer.

headline: India’s New Child Sexual Abuse Bill Draws Critics
text: The Protection of Children from Sexual Offenses Bill was hailed as a landmark legislation, one that will strengthen the fight against child abuse in India, when it was passed by the upper house of Parliament in May. President Pratibha Patil is expected to sign it in coming weeks.

headline: A Guide to Forecast Model Updates
text: Now that our presidential forecast model has been released, we’re looking forward to obsessing over every detail and seeing how the forecast changes as new polls and economic data are released. I hope our readers will feel the same way, so here’s a quick guide on what to look for in our model updates.

headline: Why the S.B.A.’s Partnership With I.B.M. Isn’t Enough
text: Last week, I posted about my first day at the Clinton Global Initiative in Chicago, a gathering of about 900 leaders from across the country. I participated in the small-business working group, and the team I was on focused on developing new ways for Main Street businesses to get access to capital – a topic near and dear to my heart.

headline: The Ministry of Women and Child Development on the Child Sexual Abuse Bill
text: India Ink sent questions to the Ministry of Women and Child Development about the Protection of Children Against Sexual Offenses Bill, which was made into law on May 10. Here is the ministry’s response.

headline: Containment
text: Over the weekend Spain agreed to accept as much as $125 billion in aid from euro zone partners to rescue its banks, becoming the largest European country to get financial assistance in the region’s debt crisis. Although some observers were eager to declare that the size of the bailout showed that leaders are finally coming to terms with Europe’s economic woes, most seem to believe it amounts to a preview of more trouble ahead.

headline: Campaigns Use Opponent’s Words, and Cry Foul
text: President Obama’s White House advisers have never been enamored of the press. But even by that measure, their reaction to coverage of the president’s news conference last week has been particularly testy.

headline: It Is What It Is
text: BEIRUT — On Saturday, after yet another massacre in Syria, I sat down for tea with Maan Abdul Salam, a Syrian activist decamped to Beirut. I’d hoped to lighten the mood with a game of backgammon, but we struggled through each roll of the dice. Maan’s literary cafe in Damascus, once a haven for bright minds and dissident intellectuals, shuttered months ago. Now he wore the exhaustion of a drawn-out struggle. Without adding to his anguish, I wanted his take on one question: has Syria passed a mark, into a state of civil war?

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Why the Bailout in Spain Won’t Work  |  The euro zone’s offer of $125 billion to bail out Spanish banks over the weekend was hailed by finance ministers and officials across Europe as a masterstroke. But by now, it should be apparent that the bailout has failed — or is at least on its way to failing, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column.

headline: Facebook Tries to Prove Ads Work
text: After taking a beating during its initial public offering over questions about whether its ad-focused business model is solid enough for the company to succeed on a $100 billion scale, Facebook is in a hurry to offer up new data to prove that its ads do, in fact, work.

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Words We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Toward a Greener Soda Can
text: Of all the materials that are commonly dropped in recycling bins, aluminum is by far the most valuable. New aluminum sells for almost $2,000 a metric ton, so recycling old cans would seem to be profitable. It takes about 75,000 cans to make a metric ton, so each one should be worth about 2.5 cents.

headline: Opinion Report: Serial Bailouts
text: From the editorial page

headline: Tuesday Reading: Cutting the Risk of Drowning
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Blanchard on Latvia
text: Olivier Blanchard, the IMF’s chief economist (and a former colleague of mine at MIT), has a post on Latvia’s economic experience. Given his position, and the sacred status Latvia has acquired among the austerians, he is necessarily cautious in his wording. But the substance is pretty much the same as what I said: one year of pretty good growth after an incredible decline — growth that still leaves you 15 percent below previous peak — is not exactly a proof of concept for fiscal austerity.

headline: A Regular Evening Escort
text: Dear Diary: As a very tired floor nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital in Harlem, I often took a cab home after work to my apartment in Inwood. Over the course of two years, a particular livery cab driver began to anticipate my schedule and would often wait for me outside the hospital around the end of my shift. I appreciated this, as it meant I did not have to haggle over the price of my ride with a different driver every night.

headline: More Firemen, More Policemen, More Teachers
text: First, Mitt Romney ridiculed Obama for saying that we need more public employment:

headline: Me At the LSE
text: Talk now online.

headline: Letters at Center of Sandusky Trial
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. – At the center of the first day of testimony in the government’s case against Jerry Sandusky were the letters that he wrote to one of the alleged victims of his sexual advances.

headline: United Technologies to Raise $1 Billion for Goodrich Takeover
text: United Technologies, one of the world’s largest makers of elevators and aircraft engines, announced on Tuesday that it would seek to raise $1 billion to help finance its takeover of the Goodrich Corporation.

headline: Judge in Gupta Trial Bars 2 Wiretapped Calls as Hearsay
text: Throughout the trial of Rajat K. Gupta, a former Goldman director accused of leaking secrets about the bank to Raj Rajaratnam, jurors have heard a lot about David Loeb, a Goldman Sachs executive.

headline: Prepaid iPhone Shootout: Cricket vs. Virgin
text: Just a week after writing about the prepaid no-contract iPhone deal from mobile provider Cricket, Virgin Mobile announced it would also offer the iPhone 4 and 4S on a prepaid no-contract deal.

headline: The Get | Perrin’s Attelage Minaudière
text: The specialty leather-goods brand Perrin Paris is probably foreign territory to even the most seasoned Madison Avenue shopper. But there’s nothing low profile about Perrin. After nearly 12 decades of being available exclusively in France, and more recently in Beverly Hills, Calif., the Parisian fashion house has opened shop in New York City’s Carlyle Hotel (987 Madison Avenue). The house is known for glove making, sunglasses and handbags, and is a favorite among high-profilers like Beyoncé (a fan of the Menotte Clutch), P. Diddy (Cabriolet driving gloves) and Martha Stewart (who helped design the company’s jet-set travel pouch). “Often, American women look for practicality in a bag whereas les Francaises understand it is more about the image and the completion of a look,” says Sally Perrin, the creative director of the fourth-generation-run business. “We bridge the past with the present by creating witty and unique designs.” The Attelage Minaudière is a perfect example: a classic ladylike purse by all accounts but made new in a novel itsy-bitsy size. “It’s a wrist ornament,” Perrin says, noting that the bag is available in goatskin, crocodile, lambskin, shagreen and, come fall, lacquered wood. “It’s an accessory in every sense of the word.”

headline: The White Light Festival Turns to Dark-Hued Mahler
text: White Light, Lincoln Center’s fall festival dedicated to humanity’s spiritual side, will present Esa-Pekka Salonen conducting Mahler’s Symphony No. 9 with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London next season, the center said on Tuesday. The festival will feature the jaw-harp virtuoso Wang Li; the organist Cameron Carpenter playing Bach in Alice Tully Hall; and a Stockhausen program. The announcement of the new season, to run for a month starting on Oct. 18, said the series would also include the United States debut of the Latvian Radio Choir; a Charpentier program by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants; a music-theater work by Heiner Goebbels called “I went to the house but did not enter,” with the Hilliard Ensemble; and an appearance by the singer Mary Chapin Carpenter.

headline: Churches Challenge British Government Over Same-Sex Marriage
text: LONDON — The British government was headed for a bruising showdown on Tuesday with Anglican and Roman Catholic Church leaders over Prime Minister David Cameron’s contentious plan to legalize same-sex marriage, presaging what some clerics called the most serious rift between church and state in centuries.

headline: Showtime Adds New Series: ‘Masters of Sex’ and ‘Ray Donovan’
text: Showtime’s family of original programming has grown by two, with a little help from Masters and Johnson. The cable channel, already home to series including “Homeland,” “Dexter” and “Shameless,” announced that it was picking up two new shows including “Masters of Sex,” which dramatizes the lives of the sex researchers William Masters and Virginia Johnson.

headline: A Good Day for High Jumper Nieto
text: Amid the claps, sweat and tears at the Adidas Grand Prix on Saturday in New York was a major victory for the high jumper Jamie Nieto.

headline: Daily Report: It’s Another Apple Day
text: The big news on Monday was Apple’s announcement of new products at the opening day of its developers’ conference in San Francisco. As Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report in Tuesday’s New York Times, Apple unveiled a new operating system for its iPhone and iPad, as well as an overhaul of its Mac line of laptops.

headline: Wall Street Is Lifted by Speculation That the Federal Reserve Will Act to Spur the Economy
text: Stocks advanced on Tuesday, rebounding from a decline on Monday, amid speculation the Federal Reserve will act to stimulate the economy and after the European Central Bank endorsed a plan to guarantee bank deposits.

headline: On Our Radar: A Delay in Federal Gas Leases
text: Facing threats of lawsuits, the Bureau of Land Management delays the sale of oil and natural gas leases in the Talladega National Forest in Alabama and says it will seek public comment. The sale, covering 43,000 acres, had been scheduled to begin on Thursday. [Bureau of Land Management]

headline: City Graduation Rate Barely Budges From Last Year
text: The percentage of New York City students graduating from public high schools within four years was flat in 2011 compared with the year before, marking the first time the rate has not significantly increased in the last six years. Still, the mayor and schools chancellor hailed the new numbers -- though they also expressed concerns over what will happen when higher graduation standards take effect next year.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Trader Joe’s Secrets: An advertising executive, one Mark Gardiner, was curious about how Trader Joe’s became so successful without any advertising. So he went undercover as an entry-level employee when the chain opened its first store in Kansas City. — Julia Moskin

headline: Speaking to the Haves, in a Plea to Consider All the Have-Nots
text: Rich people have more power than poor people, and they use that power to get what they want — which is, normally, more wealth and more power. Across America, politicians invariably reflect the views of their richest constituents. And the Federal Reserve, too, appears to have been captured by the rich: It seems much more worried about the specter of possible future inflation (which might be bad for the rich) than it is about the tragedy of present-day unemployment (which is calamitous for today’s jobless).

headline: Artisanal Threads | Graymarket in Williamsburg
text: Williamsburg is already recognized as a center of artisanal pickle, jam and cheese production. With the recent opening of Graymarket, a by-appointment-only boutique-cum-gallery dedicated to dead-stock clothing made by designers like Paul Harnden, Carpe Diem, Carol Christian Poell and Katie Gallagher, it’s time to add artisanal clothing to that list. The Graymarket founders, Wei Du and Alex Kasavin, met online, where artisanal clothing fans buy, trade and spend many, many characters analyzing the provenance and lineage of their limited-edition obsessions. “Buttonholes, stitching, dye lots — these kind of things are taken very seriously,” Du says. “People try to find out exactly what tannery the leather in a jacket comes from.” Many artisanal clothing designers work in black, the better to emphasize the tailoring and technique that goes into each garment, and that’s reflected in the goth cast of many of the clothes on Graymarket’s racks. But Due and Kasavin stress that they’re not purists, a stance they’ve underlined both in the tongue-in-cheek name they gave their shop — it’s a reference to goods being traded legally but not via the distribution channels intended by their manufacturers — and in the stock they carry, which includes the work of both small-scale, cult studios and boldface names like Balenciaga, Givenchy and Alaïa, designers that not all artisanal enthusiasts would accept as legit. “We don’t want to be about labels,” Kasavin says. “To us, it’s about technique and narrative, not about limiting what we can sell. We take something glam, like a jacket by Givenchy, and hang it next to something with a more street feel. We want to open up the possibilities.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Apple Ditches Google Maps, and You Really Liked ‘Cop and a Half’?
text: Apple on Monday introduced its own mapping system for iPhones and iPads, which will replace Google’s, in another sign that Apple is distancing itself from a company it once considered a close partner, Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield write. The announcement came during a developer conference, and reflects Apple’s efforts to catch up with Google on maps, including acquiring three mapping companies in three years. Also, they write,

headline: Q&A: Tracking a Missing iPhone
text: Q.

headline: Q. and A. With Mark Emmert, N.C.A.A. President
text: In the 20 months since he took over as president of the N.C.A.A., Mark Emmert has dealt with scandals, witnessed realignment, and been held powerless as the conferences negotiated their own lucrative TV deals and now work to decide how to decide a national champion in college football. All while publicly lauding an ideal that is outdated for some, a truism for others: the student-athlete.

headline: Can a Daughter With Dyslexia Learn to Love Words?
text: My heart has been heavy recently with a sense of loss. I’m grieving, but over something that hasn’t actually been taken — and perhaps won’t ever be completely lost at all.

headline: Business Day Live | June 12, 2012
text: A battery breakthrough for electric cars... perhaps. | Europe struggles to keep contagion out of Italy. | Hopes for job creation, in Ohio's pottery industry.

headline: G.M. Says It May Propose Pension Buyouts to Union
text: DETROIT — General Motors may seek a deal with the United Automobile Workers to offer pension buyouts to union retirees similar to offers made recently to 42,000 white-collar retirees.

headline: With Bosh Back, Miami Has New Punch
text: During last summer’s lockout, Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra returned to his native Pacific Northwest and, from the sidelines of a University of Oregon summer football practice, found basketball inspiration. As he watched the Ducks cut and fly about the field, their mad scientist coach – Chip Kelly – orchestrating a gridiron alchemy that helped put the struggling program back into the national spotlight, Spoelstra forged in his mind a template for what the Heat could be: fast, quick, devastating, and – perhaps most important – built around precise spacing and the peerless penetrating abilities of LeBron James and Dwyane Wade.

headline: International Yoga Asana Championship
text: Images from the ninth annual Bishnu Charan Ghosh Cup, which was held at the LAX Radisson in Los Angeles, where the mirrored ballroom became a competitive yoga stadium and runway-like hallways morphed into warm-up rooms for yogis.

headline: Leading Off: The New Kings
text: In the end, Los Angeles threw hockey a proper party Monday night. The silver streamers were a classy touc,h and the Kings fans were more than appropriately raucous for a Stanley Cup-clinching victory over the Devils. The Kings who skated with the Cup over their heads were nothing but completely deserving after a 6-1 scorching, proving all the necessary grit and resilience, proudly representing underdogs everywhere by having accomplished this as a No. 8 seed. The only glitch came when the crowd failed to follow hockey etiquette and boo Commissioner Gary Bettman, at which point you might have noticed Canada collectively rolling its eyes. Amateurs.

headline: Image of the Day: June 12
text: Children work as shoe shiners in New Delhi, as the World Day Against Child Labor is observed.

headline: Wheelies: The Eyes-Free Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A New Comedy’s Enduring Appeal
text: “Girls,” “Girls,” “Girls.” The HBO show arrived about two months ago on a wave of curiosity and anticipation and has only increased its hold on the chattering class’s attention since, providing departure points for debates about minorities on screen, about women’s body types on screen, about the disillusionments of people in their 20s, about the entitlement of people in their 20s, about urban arrogance, about urban drift.

headline: Executive Pay Rises 10% in Britain, Adding to Debate
text: LONDON – Pay for top managers in Britain rose 10 percent last year, a report released on Tuesday showed, providing fresh ammunition for critics who argue that executive pay has become excessive.

headline: Just One Look | Céline
text: There were plenty of familiar elements at Céline yesterday — wide-leg slacks, car coats, color blocking and scarves wrapped tightly around the neck, to start — but the familiar felt desirable, still. Loyalists, a k a the creatures of comfort who have the luxury of getting very comfortable with wearing Céline, appreciate designer Phoebe Philo’s consistency, and the fact that she builds collections upon collections and offers new pieces that work seamlessly into a wardrobe of old ones. Come November, you might layer in this animal spot, for example, but you need not buy a brand new white pant or scarf to achieve the look.

headline: Seagate Emphasizes Backups in New Hard Drive Line
text: Seagate, the hard drive maker, is redoing its consumer line-up with a new product that should make its mission crystal clear to shoppers. Named Backup Plus, the slim (14.5 millimeters) hard drive moves data from a computer for safe keeping. But it also will pull down photos from Facebook or Flickr too.

headline: Euro 2012: The View From Egypt
text: CAIRO — At 7 p.m. Sunday evening, an identical argument broke out in front of more than a dozen television screens in Borsa, the outdoor café-lined haven of downtown Cairo. At issue: whether to watch the second half of Spain versus Italy in the European Championship or switch to the start of Egypt’s 2014 World Cup qualifier against Guinea.

headline: London Theater Journal: Part of the Family
text: All domestic dramas more or less plop us down into other people’s homes. But watching “The Witness,” Vivienne Franzmann’s absorbing new play at the Royal Court Theater, I really felt like part of the family, as if I might be allowed to lean over and nibble off a character’s sandwich or change the television channel. And when the insults and accusations started flying, my first instinct was to run to my bedroom and slam the door.

headline: Quinoa, Spinach and Mushroom Salad
text: This is almost a classic spinach and mushroom salad, but it’s bulked up by the quinoa, which goes very well with the mix and is nicely complemented by the walnuts.

headline: 163 Questions to Write or Talk About
text: A word cloud created from all the questions compiled below.

headline: John Jay College Is Moving Up, Floor by Floor
text: As graduation neared this spring, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice had begun to move into the upper floors of its enormous new 13-story building on 11th Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets.

headline: A Possible Battery Breakthrough
text: June 12, 2012 - A battery breakthrough for electric cars... perhaps.

headline: Reimagined ‘Side Show’ Musical Has Dates on Two Coasts
text: “Side Show,” the Henry Krieger/Bill Russell musical about Siamese twins who became circus stars during the Depression, ran only 91 performances on Broadway in 1997, despite some critical acclaim. Now La Jolla Playhouse in California and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C., are producing what they call a “re-imagining” of the show that is scheduled to open on the West Coast in 2013 and on the East Coast in 2014.

headline: Egyptian Candidate Embraces Conspiracy Theory to Explain Killing of Protesters
text: CAIRO — Three weeks ago, after the first round of Egypt’s presidential election set up a final runoff between a leader of the Islamist Muslim Brotherhood and a former general who served as Hosni Mubarak’s prime minister during last year’s revolution, the activist blogger Mahmoud Salem joked that the candidate of the old regime might be forced to embrace some sort of wild conspiracy theory to deflect responsibility for the killing of hundreds of protesters during the uprising.

headline: An Eater’s Sequel to a Drinker’s Guide to Dublin, Cheese Toasties Edition
text: My latest Drink column is, essentially, an updated Dublin pub crawl, culminating at the charming L. Mulligan Grocer in Stoneybatter. My friend and I enjoyed our dinner there as much as our drinks: he had chicken stuffed with black pudding and beets, and I had one of the best steaks I’ve had in recent memory. There were no false notes: this was delicious and honest food featuring Irish ingredients, thoughtful but not overthought. (And the menus are a treat, too: beautifully written and fitted inside vintage books. It was this attention to detail that impressed us most on our visit to Mulligan’s.)

headline: Now Who’s Out of Touch? Romney Tries to Turn the Tables on Obama
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Mitt Romney understands the power of the verbal gaffe, real or perceived. During the Republican primaries, he offered up an all-you-can-eat buffet of them: his wife’s “Cadillacs,” his friends’ Nascar teams, how he liked being able to fire people.

headline: Foreign-Inspired and U.S.-Branded Snacks, Now Made in Mexico
text: In an effort to become a global player in the sale of internationally inspired dips and side dishes, Sabra dips, a joint venture of PepsiCo and the Strauss Group, officially opened a $10 million plant in Mexico on Tuesday.

headline: Daughters of Boomers Giving More Financial Help to Parents, Study Finds
text: The number of women who say they provide financial support to their baby-boomer parents is increasing, according to research from Ameriprise Financial.

headline: Once-Dueling Ad Critics Are Teaming Up at MediaPost
text: For decades, the trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek have fought as fiercely as any of the pairs of marketing rivals they cover — Coke and Pepsi, Kellogg and General Mills,  PC and Mac. Their competition was typified for many years by their dueling ad critics, Bob Garfield for Ad Age and Barbara Lippert for Adweek.

headline: Fire and Warming – Different Forecasts for Tropics and Temperate Zones
text: Researchers using a decade of satellite data on fires and a suite of climate models have produced the first thorough global estimate of changes in the frequency of fires in the world’s forests under greenhouse-driven global warming. There’s ample uncertainty but the study, published today in the peer-reviewed online journal Ecosphere, points to a variety of outcomes, with fires likely becoming more frequent in zones you might expect — like temperate North America and particularly the western United States — but rarer in the tropics.

headline: Pressures on Predators Lead to Marshland Die-Offs
text: Swaths of Cape Cod’s salt marshes are slowly disintegrating. For the human observer, the most notable sign of their decline might be the increase in night herons. They crouch like low, dark smudges on the salt marshes at dawn after feeding on the surfeit of Sesarma crabs through the night.

headline: We’re on Pinterest!
text: We’re happy to announce that the Styles desk of The New York Times is now on Pinterest, at pinterest.com/nytimes. We’ve posted our first fashion and beauty boards — Hair, Beach Bliss, Color Riot and Materials and Textures — alongside food- and interior design-themed boards created by our colleagues on the Dining and Home desks.

headline: Should Ray Allen Be a Knick?
text: Following their Eastern Conference finals loss to the Heat, the Celtics are already facing questions regarding what they’ll do next.

headline: Zingers
text: Politico collects what they say were my best.

headline: ‘Glengarry Glen Ross,’ With Al Pacino, Aiming for Broadway
text: A new Broadway revival of David Mamet’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play, “Glengarry Glen Ross,” is in the works for the 2012-13 season with Al Pacino in line to play the desperate salesman Shelly “The Machine” Levene, according to two Broadway producers with knowledge of the plans.

headline: Just One Look | Prabal Gurung
text: Prabal Gurung’s second resort collection felt like an extension of his pre-fall presentation — he showed similar silhouettes (short suit, sheath and shirt dress), all with his own quirky vision. He evolved from psychedelic pop prints to geometry this season. The dominating print is all about numbers. “It’s very mathematical,” Gurung says, “the way the pattern is fragmented.” He is referring to the looks, like this one, inspired by the 26-year-old artist Aaron Moran, whose reclaimed and rough-edged wood sculptures always have a smooth finish (sort of like Gurung’s work). Here, a cubist silk and cotton mikado blazer and tuxedo short would be fun even without the red waistband and bright blue collar.

headline: Goldman’s Muni Chief Heads to Fundamental Advisors
text: The head of municipal bond trading at Goldman Sachs, Hector E. Negroni, is leaving the firm to set up a new investment fund at Fundamental Advisors, the private equity firm said on Tuesday.

headline: The Return of Goldman’s Mark Schwartz
text: Mark Schwartz, hired this week to lead the Asia-Pacific operations at Goldman Sachs, has one of the more interesting résumés of the bank’s recent hires.

headline: Verizon Unveils Wireless Plans That Cover Several Devices
text: 4:54 p.m. | Updated Adding commentary from a consumer-rights advocacy group and an analyst.

headline: Former Coach Testifies Against Sandusky
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — On a Friday night before spring break in 2001, Mike McQueary, then a graduate assistant football coach at Penn State, was at home watching the movie “Rudy,” the heartwarming if somewhat sappy true account of a scrappy football player at Notre Dame who, against all odds, gets into a game.

headline: Women’s Eight Preparing to Defend Gold
text: A look ahead to the Women's Eight Rowing Olympic event. Marry Whipple and Caroline Lind of the United States talk about the sport and the roster selection process.

headline: A Drug Family in the Winner’s Circle
text: Newcomers rarely make it into the winner’s circle at the All American Futurity, considered the Kentucky Derby of quarter horse racing.

headline: Jeb Bush Explains His Remarks
text: After publicly questioning the Republican Party’s shift to the right and the no-compromise tactics of current conservative activists, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida took to Twitter on Tuesday to refine his remarks:

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/12: D.J.’s in Vegas and ‘Love Boat’ Ship on Sale, Again
text: Las Vegas, With a Beat D.J.’s are the new headliners featured  in Las Vegas, and they’re pulling in enough fans that casinos are now signing them to multimillion dollar contracts. (The New York Times)

headline: Video: Women’s Eight Rowing Team Preparing to Defend Gold
text: Fresh off its record-breaking performance in the women’s eight at the 2012 Samsung World Rowing Cup II in Switzerland, the United States women’s rowing team now has fewer than 10 days to complete its Olympic lineups.

headline: Test of the Thunder’s National Appeal
text: The San Antonio Spurs were ratings flops when they won the 2003, 2005 and 2007 N.B.A. titles.

headline: Burmese Democracy Leader Set for Triumphant Return to Europe
text: BANGKOK — Freedom has been a Rip Van Winkle experience for Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese democracy campaigner.

headline: Prabal Gurung
text: Prabal Gurung presented his collection on June 11.

headline: What a Devils Fan Has to Admit
text: You wake up the morning after the last game of the Stanley Cup finals, especially one in which your team has been lit up, like someone coming to after a feverish, opiate coma. You look out the window and your grass is so long it’s waving like wheat. Your car, unwashed for weeks, is splotched with branches and pollen. And there’s a stranger at the breakfast table. Oh, it’s your spouse. Sorry about that, hon. You’re looking so good I almost didn’t recognize you.

headline: Mothers’ Day in July: Frank Zappa Reissues On the Way
text: Coming soon to record stores both real-world and digital: a wave of Frank Zappa reissues.

headline: Red Quinoa, Cauliflower and Fava Bean Salad With Buttermilk Curry Dressing
text: In addition to the protein and other nutrients present in quinoa, red quinoa also has antioxidant-rich phytonutrients called anthocyanins present in the red pigment. If you want a prettier, more intensely flavored cauliflower, take the extra step of roasting it (see variation below).

headline: An Offbeat Guide to Confident Cocktails
text: They call themselves the Jellymongers, but Sam Bompas and Harry Parr, who have created models of St. Paul’s Cathedral and other landmarks in gelatin, do not include Jell-O shots in their new book, “Cocktails With Bompas & Parr.” Instead, they have written an exceptionally sensible if somewhat cheeky treatise on the cocktail, with recipes. It will make you smart, able to comprehend the cocktail long before you reach for a shaker, and primed to mix a fine drink once you do.

headline: Wines and Spirits With Provenance
text: Wines that are true to their terroir, and to the history and culture of their region, line the light wood shelves of Flatiron Wines & Spirits, a new no-frills shop. If they are natural, organic or biodynamic, so much the better. That’s the wine philosophy of its managers, Beau Rapier and Dan Weber, who worked at Uva in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Regions they like include Burgundy, the Loire Valley, Piedmont, the Rhone Valley, the Mosel, Champagne and Northern California. They also regularly curate three tables of 100 wines each (red, white and rosé), all for less than $15 a bottle, from the 1,500 or so wines in the store.

headline: Reverting to Ice to Chill the Wine
text: As the heat bears down once again, there are scores of gadgets for chilling wines. But instead of frozen gels and wraps and whatnot, these glass carafes rely on the simplest method: ice. You pour in the wine, then fill an insert with ice cubes, cooling the wine from the inside out. A bottle of room-temperature white can be a palatable 45 to 50 degrees in about 40 minutes. (You may have to refill the ice holder to maintain the chill during serving.) The insert in the Metrokane model (below, left) is metal, so the ice does not melt quite as fast as in a glass insert.

headline: Artist’s Fearless Aura, in Film, Chair or Tub
text: “The Artist Is Present,” the centerpiece of an identically named 2010 retrospective of work by the performance artist Marina Abramovic at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, was one of those rare events that breach the wall dividing the art world from popular culture. Over 90 days — from the beginning of March through the end of May — hundreds of thousands of people streamed through MoMA, lining up (sometimes after camping out on 53rd Street the night before) for the opportunity to see Ms. Abramovic face to face. She sat in a plain wooden chair, gazing straight ahead, silently, into the eyes of whichever museum patron happened to be seated across from her.

headline: World Bank Warns Euro Fears May Slow Global Growth
text: WASHINGTON — The World Bank on Tuesday warned that fears about the euro zone had reduced investors’ tolerance for risk, and it urged poorer economies to protect themselves by reducing their debts.

headline: Sweet and Spirited, Chocolates for Dad
text: Mom is the one who usually gets the fancy chocolates; for Dad, it’s a bottle. But Vosges Haut-Chocolat has come up with a gift that has both, putting the booze in the bonbons. The company has packed an assortment in a handsome vintage-style cigar box. There are two sleek dark chocolate bars with a thin filling of gooey caramel flavored with stout; a box of nine chocolate truffles with rye whiskey, Scotch, bourbon or chocolate stout ganache inside (the Scotch, a smoky Islay, is the most assertive); some nonalcoholic peanut butter bonbons; and caramels with and without bacon.

headline: Obama Stays Ahead in Pennsylvania Poll
text: President Obama is viewed more favorably in Pennsylvania than Mitt Romney, and most voters there say the president would do a better job on foreign policy.

headline: Resort Report | Stella McCartney
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Coast Guard Offers Details and Reward After Hoax
text: “We have 21 souls on board, 20 in the water,” a man can be heard saying in part of a radio call released by the Coast Guard on Tuesday. “I have three deceased on board, nine injured because of the explosion we’ve had. I’m in three feet of water on the bridge. I’m going to stay by the radio as long as I can before I have to go overboard.”

headline: U.S. Penalizes Online Company in Sale of Personal Data
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission assessed an $800,000 penalty on Tuesday against Spokeo, a data collector that the commission said violated federal law by compiling and selling people’s personal information for use by potential employers in screening job applicants.

headline: Driver Who Fatally Struck Man While Texting Avoids Jail
text: Updated, 6:45 p.m. | A driver who was typing on her cellphone when she fatally struck a man on a scooter pleaded guilty to negligent homicide Monday but was spared jail time, prosecutors in Brooklyn said.

headline: Nina Ricci
text: Nina Ricci presented her collection on June 11.

headline: Gun Ring Involving U.S. Soldier Is Broken Up, Chinese Officials Say
text: SHANGHAI — The Chinese authorities said on Tuesday that they had detained 23 suspects here and had broken up an international gun trafficking ring that conspired with a United States soldier to smuggle firearms into China.

headline: Finals Present Classic Clash of Offense vs. Defense
text: Given the participants, these N.B.A. finals will likely be remembered for something spectacular. Perhaps there will be some breathtaking dunks from Dwyane Wade and LeBron James, or late-game heroics from one of the Thunder’s young stars. Certainly the first championship for either James or Kevin Durant will be one for the history books. For statisticians, however, it will be another case of great offense versus great defense.

headline: Capturing the Glow of Old New York
text: One hundred and fourteen years ago, an experiment in a London laboratory helped shape the face of modern New York City. On June 12, 1898, two British chemists discovered neon.

headline: From That Tropical-Drink Paradise, England
text: AS summer arrives, sandwich-board signs hawking warm-weather drinks sprout on city sidewalks: sangria, margaritas, daiquiris, mojitos and other coolers born of hot-weather countries. Lately, a fancy standard from less-than-balmy Britain has joined them.

headline: Requiem for the Oddities of Isa
text: One time a food critic from another city asked me what kind of food Prune served. I had a hard time answering, because the restaurant seemed uncategorizable to me; the place looked like a bistro, but the menu didn’t look like a bistro menu, or like any other menu in town. Finally I resorted to telling him about the dishes: They serve canned sardines with Triscuits, I said. There’s bone marrow, and a dish that has an octopus tentacle next to a beef tongue.

headline: A Delicate Web of Life That Started With Lava
text: David J. Flaspohler, an avian ecologist and conservation biologist at Michigan Technological University, writes from Hawaii, where he is studying the influence of human activities on birds and the natural ecosystems that support them.

headline: Girlfriend of Crime Boss Gets 8-Year Prison Sentence
text: BOSTON — Catherine E. Greig, the longtime girlfriend of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger, was sentenced on Tuesday to eight years in prison for her role in helping him elude the authorities during the 16 years the two spent in hiding.

headline: Wayne Roberts, ‘Stay High 149’ in Graffiti Circles, Is Dead at 61
text: Wayne Roberts was a pioneering 1970s graffiti writer known as “Stay High 149” who borrowed the haloed stick figure from the title sequence of the 1960s television series “The Saint,” put a joint in its mouth and turned it around. His “Smoker” tag, or signature, turned the heads of legions of imitators and admirers, including the anonymous teenagers who slipped into train yards at night to paint whole cars, as well as Norman Mailer, who featured him in his book “The Faith of Graffiti.”

headline: TimesCast Politics: Supreme Court Docket
text: Crucial decisions from the nine justices in the weeks ahead | Bob Kerrey runs to regain his Senate seat in Nebraska | Campaigns grapple with a shortage of patriotic slogans.

headline: Stella McCartney
text: Stella McCartney presented her collection on June 11.

headline: Euro 2012: On the Bus With Fox Soccer
text: A two-story bus loaded with televisions, snacks and drinks drives through a busy urban sprawl as its occupants watch the European Championships. Only in New York, right?

headline: Arizona Race to Succeed Giffords Won by Democrat
text: TUCSON — Ron Barber, whom former Representative Gabrielle Giffords picked as her successor, defeated his Republican rival on Tuesday in a closely followed special election seen by many political strategists as testing ground for the power of national issues in deciding competitive races.

headline: For One Day, Formula One Parks at the Crossroads of the World
text: Short of strumming a guitar in one’s underwear, there are few fail-proof ways to compel passers-by to stop and gawk in Times Square. Formula One, the international open-wheel racing series, gave it a shot Monday, bringing a white and gray racecar from the Sauber team to promote coming races in the United States.

headline: European Central Bank Endorses a Banking Union
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank called on Tuesday for euro zone leaders to form a “banking union” to oversee its big banks, a move that would help shield countries and their taxpayers from the misfortunes of their troubled lenders.

headline: Book That Plagiarized From Wikipedia Is Pulled From Market
text: An Indian publisher, Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers, said on Tuesday that it had withdrawn a medical textbook after an editor of Wikipedia wrote to say that a section had been plagiarized from the Wikipedia article on H.I.V.

headline: Republican Lawmakers and Holder Spar Over Leak Investigation
text: Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday strongly criticized Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s recent decision to appoint two United States attorneys to investigate recent disclosures of classified national security information, saying the move was not enough and that he should appoint a special prosecutor.

headline: ING Bank to Pay $619 Million to Settle Inquiry Into Sanctions Violations
text: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $619 million settlement with ING Bank to settle an investigation into compliance with United States sanctions against Iran, Cuba and other countries. It is the largest fine a bank has paid to settle accusations of sanctions violations.

headline: Food Prize for Pioneer in Drip-by-Drip Farming Efficiency
text: I’ve intersected a few times with Daniel Hillel, a pioneering agricultural innovator from Israel, and each time I’ve come away with new insights, often about subjects far broader than the efficient irrigation methods he devised and refined, which have helped dry regions around the world feed themselves. It’s great to see him named this year’s recipient of the World Food Prize, an award created in 1987 by another agricultural leader, Norman Borlaug (read Justin Gillis’s fine obituary of Borlaug here).

headline: We Don’t Need No Teachers!
text: There’s a squabble in the presidential campaign over whether Mitt Romney said the country needs fewer police officers, firefighters and teachers.

headline: Mirror, Mirror | David Adjaye
text: “A mirror, to me, reflects life,” said David Adjaye of his most recent creations. “They create luminosity and brightness, and you can see the brightness more the less it acts like a mirror and the more it behaves like a reflecting plane.” The London-based architect, who was the 2011 Designer of the Year at Design Miami (and who is designing Proenza Schouler’s soon-to-open first store, on Madison Avenue) had been thinking about mirrors following a conversation he had “about a year ago” with his friend, the fashion designer Duro Olowu, about the act of gazing. “That’s what inspired the thinking, that a mirror is more than an object to look at yourself in,” Adjaye recalled. Olowu included Adjaye’s mirrors in “Material,” a group show he curated at Salon 94 Freemans earlier this year.

headline: Pottery Makes a Comeback in Ohio
text: June 12, 2012 - Hopes for job creation, in Ohio's pottery industry.

headline: Summer Drinks
text: Pair a modifier like Campari with a base spirit and a mixer, and you have a number of classic drinks at hand.

headline: Oil Slick: Serums for Sleek Summer Strands
text: Many people don’t realize that the sun can wreak as much havoc on their hair as their skin.“The UV light damages your hair,” said Dr. Debra Jaliman, a New York dermatologist and author of “Skin Rules.” “It breaks the chemical bonds, which causes split ends and makes hair more susceptible to breakage.”David Lopez, a hairstylist in New York who has worked with many celebrities, said that sun exposure can also lead to “dryness, frizz and even cause hair color to fade if you dye it.”Perhaps counterintuitively given that hot, humid weather can result in lank strands, oil-based emollients can help protect hair throughout summer, as well as facilitating the wet look that was seen on many spring runways. Here are some hair oils currently on the market.

headline: Embellish Like Bartenders
text: A COCKTAIL party shouldn’t start with the first brandish of a shaker; it should start with a menu. Curating a short list of drinks, instead of casting around for something novel to mix with that gin, allows you to serve drinks that will please even your most discerning guests, and to be a more nimble host.

headline: Fracking Research and the Money That Flows To It
text: As I report in The Times, a central question in the controversy over a new fracking study from the State University of New York at Buffalo is where the money came from to finance the report and the new institute on gas drilling that released it. The university says the money came from discretionary funds in the budget of the College of Arts and Sciences but that the new institute is seeking funds from the natural gas industry and other sources.

text: 5:53 p.m. | Updated

headline: An Open Letter to New York’s Governor
text: Dear Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo,

headline: Mitt Romney on NewsChannel5
text: Mitt Romney gave an interview to News Channel 5.

headline: An Endorsement From France’s First Lady Causes a Stir
text: PARIS — France’s new first lady, Valérie Trierweiler, created a small scandal and considerable stupefaction on Tuesday when she lent her support to a party dissident who is trying to defeat Ségolène Royal — President François Hollande’s former partner of some 30 years and the mother of his four children.

headline: On Sweden’s Democratic Twitter Account, Some Odd Questions About Jews
text: A Swedish experiment in social media democracy struck a sour note on Tuesday after the latest average citizen allowed to post a weeks’ worth of thoughts to a national Twitter account made comments about Jews that many found objectionable.

headline: How Should We Talk to Boys About Sexual Abuse?
text: Have you talked with your sons and daughters about the Jerry Sandusky case, and if you have, what did you say? Opening arguments in the trial against Mr. Sandusky, along with Amos Kamil’s New York Times Magazine story this weekend about sexual abuse at the Horace Mann School in New York City, have me revisiting what I’ve said to my children — in particular, my oldest son.
