text: Jonny Johansson presented his collection.

headline: Celine
text: Phoebe Philo presented her collection on June 11.

headline: Woods Says That Time Is on His Side
text: SAN FRANCISCO – Addressing the 2012 United States Open media Tuesday, Tiger Woods vowed that he had time to break Jack Nicklaus’s record of 18 major tournament victories.

headline: Bailout in Spain Leaves Taxpayers Liable for the Cost
text: MADRID — After clinching a $125 billion bailout for Spain’s banks, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy flew to Poland on Sunday for the Spanish team’s soccer match, declaring “this matter is now resolved.”

headline: The Soccer Chronicles: The Team Is Set, Friendlies Are Approaching
text: Heather O’Reilly, a midfielder on the U.S. women’s soccer team and a two-time gold medalist, will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. Here, her first post.

headline: Brooklyn International Theater Company Ready to Leave Nelson George’s Apartment
text: Theater is getting its due in the current Brooklyn Renaissance with the Brooklyn International Theater Company, the brainchild of Nelson George, the filmmaker and author.  Founded last summer and mostly confined to Mr. George’s Fort Greene apartment, the company’s first public venture is a reading of a play written by Mr. George called “Our BK” at the Brooklyn Museum on Thursday at 7 p.m.

headline: Live Coverage of Germany-Netherlands
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 game between Germany (1-0) and the Netherlands (0-1) on Wednesday. Duncan Irving will offer commentary and analysis of the Group B match.

headline: Deal Near for Simplified Ballots
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers on Tuesday were nearing an agreement to simplify the much-criticized ballots used in the state’s elections.

headline: Ukraine’s Poisoned Past
text: PRIPYAT, Ukraine — Nature has done its ruthless work. The main soccer stadium is now a football forest. Birches and poplars have crowded the field, pushed through the asphalt running track, blocked an entrance to the grandstand. Moss grows in clumps on concrete steps and sprouts in rotted wooden seats.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Spain, Russia and Myanmar.

headline: Gupta’s Daughter Testifies at His Insider Trading Trial
text: Geetanjali Gupta’s education at Harvard Law School may not have included a class on how to testify, but she was poised and articulate in answering questions on the witness stand on Tuesday at her father’s criminal trial.

headline: Garcia Recalls Grandfather Who Taught Him to Play
text: ATLANTA — When pitcher Freddy Garcia left the Yankees to attend the funeral of his grandfather Victor, he was doing more than paying his respects to a family member. For Garcia, his grandfather was like a second father.

headline: ‘Best Man’ Looks to TV in Electing New Cast Members
text: With four main actors scheduled to depart the show in July, the Broadway revival of “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man” is turning to some notable television stars as replacements, in hopes they will help sell tickets to the tourists who dominate New York theater audiences in summertime.

headline: After Long Resistance, Pynchon Allows Novels to Be Sold as E-Books
text: Thomas Pynchon was one of the last great holdouts: the rare writer who had refused to allow his work to be sold in e-book format.

headline: Radiation Concerns Rise With Patients’ Exposure
text: Even in health care systems in which doctors do not bill for each test they administer, the use of diagnostic imaging like CT and PET scans has soared, as has patients’ radiation exposure, a new study has found.

headline: Journal Reporter Quits Over E-Mails to Iraqi Envoy Nominee
text: A Wall Street Journal reporter who traded steamy e-mails with Brett McGurk, the Obama administration’s nominee for ambassador to Iraq, resigned on Tuesday afternoon, the newspaper announced.

headline: Bob Kerrey's Run For His Old Seat
text: On the road and in the air with the former Nebraska senator.

headline: Conjuring a Taste Filled With Tropical Wonder
text: HERE’S something we learned from years of traveling in the tropics: Big flavor doesn’t require big effort.

headline: Cyprus, Under Mounting Pressure, Explores Bailout
text: PARIS — Encouraged by the rescue of Spain’s banking sector, Cyprus has begun preparing euro zone countries and its own public for the likelihood of a bailout application before it takes over the presidency of the European Union at the start of July, European officials and bankers said Tuesday.

headline: A Time to Take Over the Streets, or Soar Above Them
text: The city’s annual Summer Streets pedestrian-fest is “taking New Yorkers to new heights” this year, Janette Sadik-Khan, the transportation commissioner, said on Tuesday. She was speaking rather literally, having moments before ridden a 30-foot-high zip line above Union Square.

headline: The Photographer Alex Webb: Live and in Color
text: The LOOK3 Festival of the Photograph, which took place this past weekend in Charlottesville, Va., featured presentations by photographers, outdoor screenings of video and photography and exhibitions and book signings around town. (Full disclosure: I am on the board of advisers of LOOK3.)

headline: Credit Union Disclosures Could Be Simpler Too, Pew Report Finds
text: Credit unions generally have shorter checking account disclosure documents and lower fees than big banks do, but they still have room for improvement, a new report finds.

text: To the Editor:

text: Pucci presented their collection.

text: Sonia Rykiel presented her collection on June 12.

headline: La Guardia’s Retail Therapy
text: Travelers who pass through La Guardia Airport’s terminal D will likely do a double take when, in place of the usual newsstand, coffee shop or kiosk selling noise-canceling headphones, they spot the new boutique Zona. The shop delivers a major upgrade to the retail offerings at the airport; it’s stocked with beauty products, jewelry and accessories for men and women, stationery and children’s toys and gifts, all by a roster of innovative designers and manufacturers. “Our first sale, at 4:30 in the morning while we were still setting up the space, was a $60 John Derian paperweight,” says Jesse James, the founder and creative director of Aesthetic Movement, the company that was hired to merchandise and brand the store. (It is run by the airport retailer A.E.I. Retail.) Prices range from $4.99 for Hurraw! Lip balms to $100 for a handmade necktie by Forage to $150 for a Thomaspaul wool shawl, and top out at $425 for a pearl and pyrite necklace by Carolina. Besides carrying items a traveler would expect, like a stylish toothbrush, James said it was important to “bring in a few things that made no sense, like a gold leather Webster’s dictionary or Harry Allen’s gold pig bank — things that are interesting and lovely, but we thought, honestly, Who will buy this in an airport?” Plenty of people, apparently. Journal sets inscribed with Oscar Wilde quotes, $109, have already sold out.

headline: A Couple of Gin Cocktails
text: What to pair with gin? Back in the day it would have been a cigarette. Instead, in place of a food pairing, here are a couple of cocktails to mix with the more flavorful American gins, provided by the drinks historian David Wondrich, one of our panelists. His cocktails are light and summery, and a refreshing change from your usual gin and tonic. The punch recipe makes 20 servings; assume that refills are likely to be in demand. The other recipe was adapted by Mr. Wondrich from one by the 19th-century bartender Jerry Thomas. The optional sparkling rosé is my own idea, a felicitously chic addition that turns the drink into something close to a French 75.

headline: A ‘Grown Up’ GoDaddy Hires an Ad Agency
text: 6:03 p.m. | Updated GoDaddy, a brand notorious for suggestive Super Bowl commercials with scantily clad women known as GoDaddy Girls, is hiring a professional advertising agency to create campaigns as the company seeks a more professional image.

headline: Malters Bring Terroir to the Beer Bottle
text: HADLEY, Mass.

headline: When the Keg Is Gone, and It’s Time to Call in a Pro
text: LAST winter, before we moved, my husband and I decided to toast our neighbors with a farewell cocktail party. We opted for a full bar, not just because we love our friends so much, but because we didn’t want to pack and move boxes of liquor. We figured we could just drink all of it in one shot.

headline: Sebastian Vettel Gets Loose on the Grand Prix Circuit in New Jersey
text: WEEHAWKEN, N.J. — The drive to my dentist’s office will never be the same. And it’s all Sebastian Vettel’s fault.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Creative Corrosion and Perfect Tweets
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. See more here.

headline: In the Studio With Hiroshi Sugimoto
text: The artist on photography, nature and spirituality. A film by Meredith Danluck.

headline: Battling a Big Hitter and an Age Gap in the U.S. Open Playoffs
text: You know what to expect when you enter the United States Open National Playoffs: big hitters who are trying to blow you off the court.

headline: ABV Wine Bar
text: Inside the scrappy restaurant that has concocted a foie gras fluffernutter.

headline: The Big Wave Will Have to Wait
text: FOUR or five guys were gathered around the counter in the back of Saturdays Surf NYC in SoHo one recent afternoon, watching surf videos on a computer monitor. They were lean, tall, sinewy. Their hair had movement, except for the one who wore a yellow Billabong cap. They were surferesque, less like surfers than like the models who are hired for GQ summer-issue shoots on the beach. They may or may not actually participate in surfing, but they certainly suggested it.

headline: On Fund-Raising Push, Obama Says Romney Lacks Solutions
text: BALTIMORE — President Obama used his first stop in a marathon day of speedy fund-raisers Tuesday to audition a new attack on the Romney campaign, hitting his opponent for what he and his surrogates described as a lack of concrete ideas to fix the economy.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Jason Wu
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Woman Said to Be a Madam Wins a Big Cut in Her Bail
text: A woman accused of running a prostitution service on the Upper East Side, which prosecutors said brought in millions of dollars in revenue by catering to a powerful clientele, may soon be leaving jail, after her bail was lowered on Tuesday.

headline: JPMorgan Chief Says Huge Trading Loss Was ‘Isolated Event’
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, plans to tell lawmakers on Wednesday that a trading blunder that could result in losses as high as $5 billion was “an isolated event.”

headline: Smith Barney Name to Join Wall Street’s Dustbin
text: It was perhaps inevitable, but worth noting all the same: Once Morgan Stanley completes its acquisition of Smith Barney, it will consign the venerable name to the financial industry’s ash heap.

headline: S.B.A. Administrator Responds
text: In a post published Tuesday morning, Ami Kassar suggested some ways that the Small Business Administration could do more to provide working capital to small businesses. Karen Mills, administrator of the S.B.A., requested an opportunity to respond, which we are happy to provide. Here is Ms. Mills’s response:

headline: Red Hook Jazz Festival
text: Now in its fifth year, the Red Hook Jazz Festival exists contentedly on the margins, like its namesake neighborhood and much of the music on its bill.

headline: A Festival of Reveling, Unhindered by Restraint
text: Hot Cup Chili Pepper 7 had just barreled through a tune called “Turkey Foot Corner” at the Red Hook Jazz Festival on Sunday afternoon when some outside noise piped up, distracting but altogether fitting. It was the rickety jingle of an ice cream truck parked next to the Urban Meadow community garden in Brooklyn, which adjoins a playground and serves as the festival site.

headline: Like Princess Grace at a Roadside Bar
text: LET it be remembered: In the year 2012, the foie gras fluffernutter entered history. There it is on your table at ABV Wine Bar, seared duck liver laid out on Wonder Bread like a sacrifice, over broad Rothko brush strokes of marshmallow fluff and peanut butter, amid drifts of hazelnut crumble and demi-orbs of sour-apple gelée ($17). It is caviar and Bud, Jane Austen and zombies, Blair Waldorf and Dan Humphrey.

headline: Ojai Savors a Scandinavian Import: Long Musical Nights
text: OJAI, Calif. — Bucolic settings have long been a major selling point of summer music festivals. There is something magical about hearing an orchestra in the outdoors, chamber music in a pavilion, or even an open-air opera. This is part of the appeal of the Ojai Music Festival, which ran from Thursday through Sunday in the lovely Ojai Valley, north of Los Angeles. Most concerts are performed in the 1,000-seat open-air Libbey Bowl, adjacent to this charming town’s park.

headline: Fossil Fuels and New Energy
text: There were brewery assembly line workers, pioneers on the prairie and plenty of detectives in the spring of 1978, but it was hard to find a rich person in prime time.

headline: The Baroness and Her Lost Mercedes
text: In 1992, when David Gooding worked in the car department at Christie’s, he received a telephone call from a lawyer charged with settling the estate of an elderly woman who had died alone in Vevey, Switzerland. For a time this woman summered at a hotel in Greenwich, Conn., and among her possessions there was a dusty old Mercedes that had been languishing in a warehouse, surrounded by old carnival equipment. “It’s black,” Gooding recalled the lawyer saying. “It’s a convertible, and it’s old.”

headline: Take On Summer With Gin From Experienced Hands
text: GROW your own, brew your own, butcher your own, ferment your own. This has been the mantra of the do-it-yourself ethos in pursuit of authentic flavors and pleasures uncorrupted by corporate or other intrusive interests. Distill your own was never far behind.

headline: A New ‘Firebird’ Takes Flight
text: Alexei Ratmansky’s new staging had its New York premiere with American Ballet Theater on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Highlights From World Cup Qualifier: Guatemala vs. U.S.
text: The United States national team is in Guatemala on Tuesday night for its second Concacaf World Cup qualifier in Group A. (The top two teams in each of the three groups advance to the final qualifying round, with games to be played between February and October 2013.)

headline: Owner of Tortilla Factory Where Worker Died Admits Payroll Violations
text: The owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where a worker died last year after falling into a mixing machine pleaded guilty on Tuesday to failing to pay adequate wages, the state attorney general’s office said.

headline: Eating Frugally in Copenhagen
text: “It’s become really hip to eat old-fashioned Danish food,” Nina A.S. Geist told me as we shared a kartoffelmad — an open-faced potato sandwich loaded with crispy fried onions — at Dyrehaven, a local cafe in the fun Vesterbro neighborhood of Copenhagen. It was great to hear this from a Dane, because from abroad what appears most hip about Danish cuisine is Noma, the world’s top-ranked restaurant for the second year running, according to Restaurant Magazine’s much-blabbed-about list.

headline: Bird of a Feather That Can Make Curses Fly Away
text: Parts of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Firebird” make me wish that I were a child again, with him as a parent or godfather telling old stories with new twists and dimensions. At its best, his “Firebird,” which had its New York premiere with American Ballet Theater on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, feels timeless and modern, an ancient myth for the children, with sexual and psychological layers that appeal to adult intelligence today.

headline: Big Staff Reductions Imposed at Papers in New Orleans and Alabama
text: NEW ORLEANS — In New Orleans and across the state of Alabama on Tuesday, scores of journalists walked into short meetings and walked out with severance packages, part of an extensive restructuring of the news business at four newspapers owned by Advance Publications.

headline: Hakkasan New York
text: Inside the multimillion-dollar exercise in Orientalism off Times Square.

headline: Google Engineers and Payload Data
text: Google has released a trove of documents related to a federal investigation into its Street View mapping project. Among the documents were sworn declarations from several employees familiar with Street View denying knowledge that the cars were collecting information traveling over personal Wi-Fi networks, also known as “payload data.”

headline: Movies That Dare to Buck a Trend
text: LOS ANGELES — Alex Kurtzman has written films about space travel (“Star Trek”), space robots (“Transformers”) and creatures who descend on the Old West from outer space (“Cowboys & Aliens”).

headline: CBS Finishes ‘Upfront’ Sales
text: CBS is finishing its sales of commercial time ahead of the 2012-13 season in what is known as the upfront market, winning rate increases that may turn out to be the largest of any of the five English-language broadcast networks.

headline: Keeping Score: Reading Statistics Like Tea Leaves
text: Carlton Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method.” They have previously written on the Stanley Cup finals, the World Series, the Super Bowl and N.C.A.A. men’s basketball final.

headline: The Army Calls In the Hoteliers
text: FORT HOOD, Tex. — The hotel here could be any Holiday Inn Express, with a green and blue sign out front, a cheery lobby and a hot breakfast bar.

headline: City Urged to Slow Down on Special Ed Plans
text: A citywide special education plan that aims to put New York City more in step with other school districts around the country by including those students in general education classrooms is causing commotion here, with a growing chorus of parents, teachers and elected officials insisting it is being too hastily implemented with too little information.

headline: A Suburban-Style Mall Is Rising in the Bronx
text: Indoor malls in New York have received a mixed reception. Outlets like Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport and the Albee Square Mall in Downtown Brooklyn have posted lackluster performances. But the shops at the Time Warner Center and the Manhattan Mall in Midtown have generally been considered successes.

headline: Huffington Post Introduces Its Online Magazine
text: The Huffington Post, which has methodically spread its wings from juicy gossip about Salma Hayek’s cleavage and pointed political commentary to a Pulitzer Prize-winning 10-part series on wounded veterans, is breaking into the magazine business.

headline: Inspired by China, but Just Barely
text: AT first, a hostile takeover did not appear to be the best solution to the problems of Hakkasan, the multimillion-dollar exercise in Orientalism one block off Times Square.

headline: Greece vs. Germany?
text: The Euro 2012 football championship — soccer to Americans — is riveting attention in Europe, perhaps more than the rescue of the Spanish banks or the Greek election on Sunday.

headline: Shrimp With Smoked Paprika
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates how to make a simple shrimp dish out of ingredients found in the pantry.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: The Pantry Made Me Do It: Shrimp, Simply Spanish
text: YOU might think, from looking at the recipe title here, that this is a story about shrimp. It’s not; rather, it’s a story about the pantry.

headline: 3 Firehouses Among 6 Buildings Now Designated City Landmarks
text: Each has a distinct architectural style. One, a narrow three-story building with a bold red door, features a recessed stone eagle overlooking an ashlar limestone entrance. The second, completed in neo-Classical style, is one of the first of its kind in the city to feature two truck-size doors instead of just one. The third, a churchlike Neo-Medieval brick fortress, has steep gables and a hose-drying tower.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Some Special Chicken Salad

headline: Days After an Order to Restrict Them, Afghanistan Calls for Airstrikes to End
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan issued an impassioned call for the end of international airstrikes in his country on Tuesday, branding them as an “illegitimate use of force” and saying that the need to protect civilian life demanded a complete halt to those operations, even in cases when troops are under attack.

headline: Maine Begins to Pick a Senate Successor to Snowe
text: Update 12:15 a.m.: Charles Summers, the Secretary of State, emerged the winner Tuesday night of the six-way primary on the Republican side for the Senate seat being vacated by Olympia J. Snowe. On the Democratic side, state Senator Cynthia Dill won the four-way primary. The two will face each other — and Angus King, the independent and former two-term governor — in November, along with some lesser known independent candidates.

headline: Capitalism, Stranger Than a Space Alien
text: Three-Headed Bird Village — the setting for Xiaolu Guo’s stingingly funny satire, “UFO in Her Eyes” — is a quiet agricultural hamlet in the Guangxi province of southern China that is uprooted by instant globalization. The catalyst is a sighting by Kwok Yun (Shi Ke), an unmarried peasant in her 30s, of what she believes is a U.F.O.

headline: Parsing Jamie Dimon’s Testimony
text: JPMorgan Chase‘s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, has said a little more about the botched derivatives trade that has led to billions of dollars of losses at the bank. The new utterances, contained in prepared testimony he will give to members of Congress on Wednesday, will likely raise more questions about the trade than they answer.

headline: Fashion News We’re Reading Now
text: Moda Operandi, a New York-based start-up, is expanding. Investors including Condé Nast, LVMH and IMG have poured $36 million into the online trunk show site.

headline: 1 World Trade Center Is a Growing Presence, and a Changed One
text: When President Obama visits 1 World Trade Center on Thursday, he will find a tower that is undeniably impressive and — even a year and a half before its scheduled completion — unquestionably a landmark of 21st-century New York.

text: PARIS

headline: Mets Ready to Try Some Bullpen Shuffling
text: ST. PETERBURG, Fla. — Manager Terry Collins and his pitching coach, Dan Warthen, spent a solid chunk of their day off on Monday in conversation about the Mets’ bullpen.

headline: Frito-Lay Takes New Tack on Snacks
text: Frito-Lay has long dominated the snack-food business by relentlessly focusing on the middle swath of America that eats chips and pretzels and party mix without regard to the effect on the waistline.

headline: Treatment for Asthma

headline: For New York Archdiocese’s One New Priest, a Lonely Distinction
text: On June 3, the Rev. Patric F. D’Arcy’s first Sunday officiating at his new parish as a newly ordained Roman Catholic priest in the Bronx, he offered Mass in crystal-clear Spanish in a packed sanctuary. Later, at a lunch celebration, his new parishioners welcomed him with trays of rice, beans and roasted chicken, and a white cake adorned with golden icing.

headline: Kings Needed 45 Years and Hot Goalie to Hoist Cup
text: It was around this time five years ago, as the Los Angeles Kings celebrated their 40th birthday by cleaving to tradition (they missed the playoffs), that the upstart Anaheim Ducks, nee Mighty Ducks, were partying with the Stanley Cup 30 miles south down the 5 freeway.

headline: Kelly Kennedy Mack
text: Ms. Mack, 38, is the president of the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which specializes in the marketing, sales and planning of luxury residential developments. Its projects include the Laurel, the Rushmore and the Riverhouse condominiums.

headline: Legal Options Limited for Alumni Who Told of Abuse at Horace Mann
text: As former students and prosecutors turn to the courts to deal with reports of widespread sexual abuse at the Horace Mann School, lawyers have begun to conclude that New York’s current restrictive statute of limitations laws are likely to block any effort to hold the prestigious private school legally accountable for the allegations, some of which are decades old.

headline: Elinor Ostrom, Winner of Nobel in Economics, Dies at 78
text: Elinor Ostrom, the only woman to win the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science — an achievement all the more remarkable because she was not actually an economist — died on Tuesday in Bloomington, Ind. She was 78.

headline: After Contrasting Closing Arguments, Clemens Jurors Are ‘Final Umpires’
text: WASHINGTON — In a final plea to jurors in the Roger Clemens perjury trial, prosecutors on Tuesday urged a conviction, saying it was obvious that Clemens had lied to Congress about his performance-enhancing drug use and concocted an elaborate cover-up to save his reputation.

headline: City Plans to Target Cabdrivers Who Join in Sex Trafficking
text: They arrange prostitutes’ schedules and ferry them to hotels for appointments, drum up clients for pimps and pocket half the proceeds.

headline: Healthy Women Advised Not to Take Calcium and Vitamin D to Prevent Fractures
text: The United States Preventive Services Task Force, an influential group that recently recommended against routine P.S.A. tests to detect prostate cancer, issued a draft statement on Tuesday recommending that healthy postmenopausal women should not take low doses of calcium or vitamin D supplements to prevent fractures.

headline: New York Seeks New Rates for Force-Placed Insurance
text: New York State is demanding that insurers that write policies to cover financially troubled homeowners submit new rate proposals after hearings last month showed companies charged too much for the coverage.

headline: At Starbucks, Uncertainty Over Impact of Bloomberg’s Drink Plan
text: Big Gulps are safe. But the fate of the Frappuccino remains unclear.

headline: Martin Has Been Key to Yankees’ Surge in June
text: ATLANTA — Shortly after the Yankees shut out the Atlanta Braves on Monday night to improve to 8-2 in June, Manager Joe Girardi said the key, as with any good streak, has been the Yankees’ terrific starting pitching.

headline: Single Women Gaining Limited Acceptance in Iran
text: TEHRAN — When Shoukoufeh, an English literature student from a backwater town, set out to rent an apartment for herself here in the capital, she first stopped at a jewelry store and picked up a $5 wedding ring.

headline: Food Stamps and the Farm Bill
text: The version of the farm bill that emerged from the Senate Agriculture Committee contains $4.5 billion in cuts to the food stamps program over 10 years.

headline: Endorsing Joe Walsh’s Opponent
text: Type the name Joe Walsh into any search engine, and two very different people pop up. The first, Representative Joe Walsh of Illinois, is a first-term Republican running for re-election. The second is a Rock and Roll Hall of Famer who endorsed the congressman’s Democratic opponent on Tuesday.

headline: Ann Rutherford, Studio Film Sweetheart, Dies at 94
text: Ann Rutherford, an actress who became famous in the late 1930s as Mickey Rooney’s sweetheart in the hugely successful Andy Hardy series and earned a role in one of the biggest movies in Hollywood history, as Scarlett O’Hara’s sister in “Gone With the Wind,” died on Monday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 94.

headline: Russia, Soviet Style
text: Vladimir Putin knows no shame. On Tuesday, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton accused Russia of supplying attack helicopters to the Syrian government. Apparently, blocking the United Nations Security Council from punishing Syria isn’t enough for the Russian president. He needs to be actively helping the Syrian dictator, Bashar al-Assad, kill his own people more efficiently and in even larger quantities.

headline: Evangelical Groups Call for New Stance on Illegal Immigration
text: Some of the nation’s most influential evangelical groups urged a solution to illegal immigration on Tuesday that defies the harsh rhetoric of the Republican primary race, which continues to undermine Mitt Romney’s appeal to Hispanic voters.

headline: JPMorgan Chief Is Expected to Play Down Trade Risks at Hearing
text: When JPMorgan’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, appears Wednesday on Capitol Hill, he plans to play down the risky trading activities that have already prompted at least $3 billion in losses.

headline: The 20 Million
text: Help wanted: Salary: $19,000 (some may be withheld or stolen). No health insurance, paid sick days or paid vacation.  Opportunity for advancement: nearly nil.

headline: Protect, Don’t Prosecute, Patriotic Leakers

headline: Republican Senators Criticize Holder Over Response to Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday strongly criticized the recent decision by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to appoint two United States attorneys to investigate recent disclosures of classified national security information, saying that the move was not enough and that he should appoint a special prosecutor.

headline: Ghassan Tueni, Top Lebanese Journalist, Dies at 86
text: Ghassan Tueni, a pre-eminent Lebanese journalist and statesman whose democratic vision for the Middle East in the 20th century prefigured the Arab Spring uprisings of the 21st, died in Beirut on Friday. He was 86.

headline: Two Worlds Cracking Up

headline: Method to Track Firearm Use Is Stalled by Foes
text: Identifying the firearm used in a crime is one of the biggest challenges for criminal investigators. But what if a shell casing picked up at a murder scene could immediately be tracked to the gun that fired it?

headline: After Eyeing Course, Watson Ready for a Challenging Open
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The fairways of the Olympic Club’s Lake Course are like Lombard Street, another of this city’s landmarks: tight and treacherous to navigate. If Bubba Watson, the reigning Masters champion, is going to add the second leg of the Grand Slam at the week’s United States Open, he is going to have to drive the ball straight. Is Watson, who is 99th on the tour in driving accuracy, up to the task?

headline: Protesting Police Tactic, in Silence
text: A fleet of portable toilets has been booked, and they will be docked along 110th Street, at the north end of Central Park, where people will be mustering on Sunday afternoon. So far, at least 35 buses are expected. The subways will most likely carry the bulk of the crowd. A group of religious leaders from all five boroughs plan to meet on Wednesday to discuss the logistics of bringing their congregations. Training will be provided Thursday night for marshals who could not make a session that was held on Tuesday.

headline: Getting Out of a Rut With Help From Schick
text: WITH branded content, videos that emphasize entertainment over a marketing message, products usually are featured but not sold overtly.

headline: At Age 14, Making History in Making the Field
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On Tuesday morning at the Olympic Club, the 14-year-old Andy Zhang joined a backup of golfers waiting to tee off on the par-3 third hole in a bottleneck that began rubbernecking.

headline: 2 Court Cases at Once for Family of Bronx Man Killed by the Police
text: For weeks, relatives of Hodean and Kadean Graham have sat in a Manhattan courtroom, listening as prosecutors described the twin brothers’ alleged role in a small gang accused of bringing guns and violence to the streets of Harlem.

headline: 2 Campaigns Chasing Funds at Frantic Pace
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama wooed campaign donors in speed-dating fashion on Tuesday, rushing through six fund-raisers in six hours in Maryland and Pennsylvania. Thursday will find him in Manhattan, where he will join Anna Wintour at the home of Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick for a $40,000-a-plate dinner, followed by another high-dollar gathering at the Plaza Hotel.

headline: A Better Way to Talk About Faith
text: Is there a way to overcome religious intolerance?

headline: The Scars of Stop-and-Frisk
text: A short documentary film on New York’s stop-and-frisk policing focuses on Tyquan Brehon, a young man in Brooklyn who says he was stopped more than 60 times before age 18.

headline: City Urges Requiring Consent for Jewish Rite
text: New York City health officials proposed on Tuesday that Orthodox Jewish parents be required to sign a consent waiver before they can take part in a circumcision ritual that is believed to have led to the deaths of at least two babies in the city over the past decade.

headline: Yemen Says Militants Are Driven From 2 Cities
text: SANA, Yemen — The Yemeni government said Tuesday that the army had driven out militants linked to Al Qaeda from two of their strongholds in southern Yemen, a region that has become a focal point of American concerns about terrorism.

headline: Motherhood Still a Cause of Pay Inequality
text: Women have made huge strides in the job market since President Kennedy signed the Equal Pay Act in 1963. Yet almost half a century after it became illegal to pay women less than men for the same job, the weekly wage of a typical woman who works full time is almost 18 percent less than that of the typical working man.

text: Bit by bit, the investors in the Mets are becoming known.

headline: A Dream Pairing of Opposite Stars at the U.S. Open
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, paired in Thursday’s first round of the United States Open, prepared Tuesday at the Olympic Club in divergent ways: Woods in the morning with an old friend, Mickelson in the afternoon with new acquaintances. Woods appeared determined, while Mickelson seemed playful.

headline: Judge Rules Restaurant Law Stifles Ohio Cities
text: A state judge in Ohio has ruled that a state law placing sweeping limitations on local government’s ability to control restaurants in the interests of public health violates the state constitution.

headline: The Case Against José Treviño
text: Court documents unsealed yesterday provide details of how the Zetas laundered drug money through the poorly regulated equine industry each month.

headline: Boy, 14, Drowns Off Beach in Far Rockaway
text: A 14-year-old boy drowned on Tuesday in the waters off a beach in Far Rockaway, Queens, after ignoring warnings not to swim in an area with no lifeguards, the authorities said.

headline: Hot, Hot, Hot
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Wednesday is better known to some as Hump Day because, while you can see the past weekend in your rear view mirror, you can’t quite see the weekend ahead just yet. So let’s see if today’s puzzle by Susan Gelfand can get us over that hump.

headline: After a Crash, New Anxiety for Travelers in Nigeria
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — The ordeal of flying in Nigeria begins with the chaotic crowds waving wads of cash who surround ticket agents in sweltering terminals lacking air-conditioning.

headline: Corrections: June 13
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Hard Choices, Same as They Ever Were
text: A good, old-fashioned consciousness-raising session flares into life in the first act of “Rapture, Blister, Burn,” the intensely smart, immensely funny new play by Gina Gionfriddo that opened Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons. Over late afternoon martinis, four women representing three generations dive into a freewheeling conversation about how women’s lives have and have not changed since the 1970s.

headline: Teófilo Stevenson, Cuban Boxing Great, Dies at 60
text: Teófilo Stevenson, one of the greatest amateurs in boxing history, the winner of three Olympic gold medals for Cuba and a national hero who shunned the prospect of turning pro, possibly fighting Muhammad Ali and becoming rich in the United States, died on Monday in Havana. He was 60.

headline: An Independent Monitor for the Police Is Proposed
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency have inspectors general who function as independent monitors. So do the police departments of major cities like Los Angeles and Chicago, as well as the nation’s capital. Even most New York City agencies, like the Education Department and the Housing Authority, have similar monitors.

headline: Group Planning Centers to Treat Combat Trauma
text: Pledging to overhaul the way the military handles the least visible wounds of war, a private foundation will unveil a $100 million plan on Wednesday to construct state-of-the-art treatment centers for brain injuries and psychological disorders at nine of the largest bases in the country.

headline: W.H.O. Declares Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer
text: Diesel fumes cause lung cancer, the World Health Organization declared Tuesday, and experts said they were more carcinogenic than secondhand cigarette smoke.

headline: Pink Slips
text: The school district in Reading, Pa. — the nation’s poorest city — laid off 110 teachers last week, along with hundreds of other employees. As elementary students watched in shock, many of their favorite teachers were pulled out of an assembly one by one and given the bad news by district officials, The Reading Eagle reported.

headline: Denials Over Google Street View
text: Google has long prided itself on not being a conventional company. But there is one characteristic it apparently shares with the most sclerotic bureaucracy: the willingness of its employees to say, “Not my job.”

headline: Wealth Erased
text: Americans know, all too well, the pain unleashed by the Great Recession of 2007-9. Still the numbers on the loss of personal wealth during those years are staggering and say a lot about why the economic recovery has been so sluggish — and why the government will need to do a lot more to turn things around.

headline: Once Illegal, Health Rumors Now Have Mubarak Die Daily
text: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak uses a wheelchair, is able to eat little more than Jell-O, and has his two grown sons by his bedside. He suffers from sore joints in his feet, high blood pressure, shortness of breath and, according to rumors widely circulated in the Egyptian and foreign press, he required artificial respiration and heart defibrillation within the space of just 24 hours last weekend. Twice, doctors could not find his pulse, the reports said.

headline: Photo Replay: June 12
text: The day in sports included Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals and Euro 2012 first round matches.

headline: Most Would-Be Successors Assail Mayor on Diversity
text: Bill de Blasio, New York City’s public advocate, called him “imperial.” William C. Thompson Jr., the former comptroller, described his record as “an embarrassment.”

headline: Santa Monica Resets Its Parking Meter System
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — It is a ritual known by tourists and residents alike: circling the blocks looking for an open parking spot and noticing that the meter still has plenty of time left on it? Why, what a lucky day.

headline: Mets Win an Easy One for a Change
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Mets’ cathartic 11-2 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays here on Tuesday seemed to unfold as one long, collective sigh of relief.

headline: Rodriguez Ties Gehrig’s Grand Slam Record in Win Over Braves
text: ATLANTA — As well as the Yankees have played this month, the one bothersome aspect of their game has been their inability to hit with the bases loaded. That even applied to Alex Rodriguez who, despite being one of the most productive hitters ever with the bases full, has struggled terribly in those situations this season.

headline: Allen Wins Republican Senate Primary in Virginia
text: George Allen, the former Virginia senator whose political career imploded after a disastrous re-election campaign in 2006, moved a step closer to redemption on Tuesday after easily defeating three conservative Republican opponents in the Virginia Senate primary.

headline: Will the Vatican’s Crackdown on Nuns Work?
text: Trying to rein in nuns has been a P.R. challenge for the church. Should it engage with the sisters in a more open dialogue instead?

headline: The Ordeal of Flying in Nigeria
text: Boarding the aging jetliner itself can seem an accomplishment, given the lack of audible announcements, working signboards or informed employees. Then the real adventure begins.

headline: McIlroy Tries His Hand as a Pitcher
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Rory McIlroy was spotted on the Olympic Club driving range throwing a golf ball at his bag. He was practicing — not for his United States Open defense, beginning Thursday, but for his appearance Tuesday night at the Giants’ home game against the Houston Astros. It was Irish Heritage Night and McIlroy, who is from Northern Ireland, was asked to throw out the first pitch.

headline: New Orleans Struggles With Latest Storm, Newspaper Layoffs
text: NEW ORLEANS — Brett Anderson kept his face out of the paper and gave fake names when making reservations, as dining critics customarily do, but in a town like New Orleans he was not fooling many people. They know Mr. Anderson by sight, just as they knew that a reporter named Katy Reckdahl had had a baby in New Orleans 24 hours before Hurricane Katrina hit — she wrote a big article about it in the paper five years later, but people knew.

headline: Stanley Cup Viewership Down From Last Year
text: The Los Angeles Kings’ 6-1 throttling of the Devils on Monday night to win the Stanley Cup was seen by an average of 4.9 million viewers, down 10 percent from the nearly 5.5 million who watched the comparable game last year between the Boston Bruins and Vancouver Canucks. NBC carried the last four games of the Stanley Cup finals, averaging 3.5 million viewers, down 34 percent from the five games the network showed last year, when the Bruins won.

headline: The Great Immigration Reform Mirage
text: In a breakfast interview with Bloomberg View on Monday, Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, expressed general disappointment with the Republican Party’s rightward drift since his brother left the White House in 2009. He also cited a specific place where his party needs to return to the center: The issue of immigration reform. According to Bush, Mitt Romney’s focus on border enforcement has placed him “in a box” and limited his appeal to Hispanic voters.

headline: Fleck Had Suggestions  for Woods, but Not a Way to Reach Him
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At the 2010 United States Open in Pebble Beach, the former Open champion Jack Fleck was among those following Tiger Woods. After watching him play early in the week, Fleck, a tireless student of the game, had some swing suggestions he wished to share with Woods. He said he sent a friend into the locker room, to ask if Woods would be amenable to meeting with him.

headline: States’ Progress on Exchanges
text: The health care law, now under review by the Supreme Court, requires states to have health insurance exchanges by January 2014. Some states have made extensive plans, while others have done little.

headline: Iran Says It Is Building a Nuclear-Powered Submarine
text: An Iranian naval commander said Tuesday that Iran had begun work on its first nuclear-powered submarine. “We have taken the first steps in the direction of building nuclear-powered submarines,” Deputy Navy Cmdr. Abbas Zamini said, according to the Fars news agency. Some analysts fear Iran could use the submarine project to justify enriching uranium to higher levels. Mark Hibbs, a nuclear proliferation expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was cited by Reuters as saying that many nuclear-powered submarines use uranium fuel enriched to levels that could also be suitable for atomic bombs. Iran is scheduled to meet next week with international negotiators over its nuclear program.

headline: Navigating the Health Care Maze
text: BOSTON — Even a self-described data nerd like Peter Kim was nearly undone by his hunt for health insurance.

headline: The Vatican: U.S. Nuns Meet With Church Officials
text: After meeting Tuesday with representatives of an association of American nuns that it had deemed to be too feminist, the Vatican reiterated that the group “remained under the supreme direction of the Holy See” and that it was bound to promote the “teachings of the church as faithfully taught through the ages.” The Leadership Conference of Women Religious, which represents 80 percent of Catholic nuns in the United States, had requested the meeting with officials in Rome to discuss a critique that led to a Vatican decision to overhaul the organization. The group’s president, Sister Pat Farrell, said in a statement that during an “open meeting” the group’s representatives “were able to directly express” their concerns. The nuns said they would report back to the group’s board in the United States and determine a course of action to respond to the Vatican.

headline: Florida’s Approach to Purging Voter Rolls of Noncitizens Prompts Federal Lawsuit
text: The Department of Justice on Tuesday followed through on warnings that it would sue Florida over the state’s plan to remove noncitizens from its voter rolls.

headline: Poland: For Russia-Poland Pre-Game, a Street Fight
text: Russian and Polish soccer fans clashed in the streets of Warsaw on Tuesday, injuring at least 15 people and leading to more than 120 arrests. Riot police used water cannons, tear-gas and rubber bullets to contain the street fighting that broke out hours before Russia and Poland played to a draw in the European soccer championship, an event that Polish officials hoped would showcase the country’s recent strides. But enmity between Russia and Poland runs centuries deep and a march by Russian fans in honor of their national holiday, Russia Day, brought out Polish fans and clashes erupted. Polish soccer hooligans chanted, “Hit the red trash with a hammer, with a sickle” and “Instead of leaves, there’ll be communists hanging from the trees.”

headline: Word of the Day | connotation
text: connotation •\ˌkä-nə-ˈta-shən\• noun

headline: New Report Says Captive U.S. Soldier Left His Post Willingly
text: HONG KONG — Two weeks from now, a young soldier from Idaho, Bowe Bergdahl, will have been in the hands of the Taliban for three years. He is America’s only prisoner of war.

headline: After Liposuction, Exercise Keeps the Fat Off
text: Liposuction, generally considered the most popular cosmetic surgical procedure in the United States and worldwide, involves suctioning out subcutaneous fat cells, those that accumulate just beneath the skin. But to gain lasting benefits, a new study suggests, people need to exercise. Otherwise they risk regaining the fat lost during surgery and redistributing that fat to their midsections, an outcome that has the potential to make them less healthy than before the operation.

headline: To Bolster Web Reach, CNBC Joins With Yahoo
text: Seeking to improve its standing among business news Web sites, CNBC will announce a new partnership on Wednesday with Yahoo Finance, the largest such Web site in the United States.

headline: North Dakota Voters Reject Effort to Abolish Property Tax
text: Voters in North Dakota on Tuesday rejected a constitutional amendment to abolish the property tax, turning aside arguments by advocates of the measure who say the tax has proved inconsistent and is in conflict with the basic concept of property ownership.

headline: After Struggling Early, Sabathia Limits Damage
text: ATLANTA — C. C. Sabathia struggled and battled over seven innings Tuesday but was lucky to get a victory as the Yankees rallied for six runs in the top of the eighth for a 6-4 win over the Atlanta Braves.

headline: With Poise and Power, Thunder Rally in Opener
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — It took patience to endure the 23-win season, the four straight lottery appearances, the long slog through a Western Conference dominated by superstars and dynasties.

headline: Airborne Tales of Fistfights, Diuretics and Crooning Pilots
text: A plane on approach to Lagos, Nigeria, crashed two weeks ago, killing all 153 passengers plus a still-uncounted number of people on the ground. Then on Friday, the runway lights failed at the airport in the Nigerian capital of Abuja.

headline: Soccer Fans from Poland and Russia Clash Ahead of Euro 2012 Match
text: Centuries of enmity between Poland and Russia manifested in bloody clashes between soccer fans on the streets of Warsaw on Tuesday hours before the two countries faced off in the European soccer championship.

headline: India, Spain and Singapore Win Awards in International Yoga Competition
text: “Silence prevailed during the yoga asana routines of the ninth annual Bishnu Charan Ghosh Cup — except for one distinct sound: the low engine rumble of airplanes lifting off and landing at the Los Angeles airport,” Sara Beck wrote in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | June 13, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: Press Inquiry Strains Britain’s Coalition Government
text: LONDON — Britain’s coalition government came under renewed strain on Wednesday after its junior partner, the Liberal Democrats, withheld parliamentary backing for Prime Minister David Cameron’s handling of events flowing from a failed bid by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation to take full control of BSkyB, the country’s biggest satellite broadcaster.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (1), Guatemala (1)
text: The United States national team has historically struggled in Central America, but Tuesday night’s 1-1 tie in Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier will still feel disappointing despite the team’s earning a point.

headline: Bomb Attacks Around Iraq Target Shiites, Killing Dozens
text: BAGHDAD — In the deadliest day in Iraq since the withdrawal of the United States military in December, a series of explosions that mostly targeted Shiite Muslims amounted to an emphatic demonstration of the still-potent capabilities of the Sunni insurgency and a reminder of the instability left behind by American forces.

headline: For Muslim Women in Delhi, a Breath of Fresh Air
text: Yasmeen Khan dons her burqa and steps out of her house in the Nizamuddin neighborhood of Delhi every evening to walk a short distance to a 10-foot-high stone wall. Behind the wall is paradise — a place where she can remove her burqa and hijab, enjoy cool fresh air in her hair, exercise and gossip with friends.

headline: Consortium to Buy Saab Automobile
text: More than a year after it last made a car, Saab Automobile of Sweden was sold on Wednesday to a group of Chinese, Japanese and Swedish investors who plan to convert the company into a manufacturer of electric vehicles.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 13, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the DealBook blog post “The Bet That Blew Up for JPMorgan Chase.”

headline: Two Decades of Prosperity Erased
text: WHEN was the net worth of the hypothetical median American family $126,400?

headline: A Rare View of Conflict in Syria
text: In one of Robert King’s photographs from Qusayr, Syria, a gray-haired man in blue scrubs holds a crying child who is tangled in IV tubes (Slide 11). Behind them, on a bed covered with disheveled blankets, three more children lie bandaged; plastic sheeting covers a window and a bookshelf, as if the room was quarantined, or as if its owner were clinging to normalcy by protecting the furniture. In another picture (Slide 13), wounded men, one in camouflage fatigues, lie cheek by jowl on floral print couches.

headline: Leaks and Press Freedoms
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Early Word: Dialing for Dollars

headline: Fantasy Focus: Buy Good Pitchers Running Bad
text: An odd thing has happened this year, though perhaps it happens every year: pitchers who were former (or prospective) aces, but recently left for dead, have recaptured their form for stretches of varying lengths. Consider Jake Peavy and Johan Santana, two former Cy Young Award winners you could have drafted in the later rounds. Santana, even after being shelled by the Yankees, has a 73:22 strikeout/walk ratio in 73 innings and an earned run average of 2.96. Peavy has fallen off of late but still has a 72:20 K/BB ratio in 82 2/3 innings, a 3.05 E.R.A. and an 0.968 WHIP.

headline: The Impending Death of the Group of Death
text: Along with predictions of German triumph, supermarket beer promotions, organized Oranje invasions and metatarsal injuries, the Group of Death has become a time-honored element of major tournament culture.

headline: U.N. Kept Out of a Town That Syria Says It ‘Cleansed’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria announced on Wednesday that the village of Al Heffa in its Mediterranean hinterland, which United Nations monitors had been physically blocked from visiting to check on fears of a massacre there, had been “cleansed” of armed terrorist gangs, the government’s blanket term for the opposition.

headline: BlackRock Hires Former Swiss Central Bank Chief
text: LONDON – The money manager BlackRock has hired Philipp M. Hildebrand, who resigned under a cloud from the Swiss National Bank in January, to oversee institutional client relationships outside the United States.

headline: The Devil in Marina Abramovic
text: Watching the new documentary about you, “The Artist Is Present,” got me curious about the economics of performance art. In 2010, you did a show at the Museum of Modern Art, where you sat for 700 hours, staring at visitors. It was seen by as many as 750,000 people, and during that time the museum collected millions in receipts. Did you get a cut of the door, like a musician? I got so little I don’t even want to tell. I was paid an honorarium of exactly $100,000. It covered one year of my work, plus how much I pay for assistants and office rent.

headline: A Bet on the Sun
text: What does a 350,000-mirror gamble on solar power look like?

headline: Aspiring Hitter Finds a Home on the Mound
text: Brandon Beachy, the Atlanta Braves right-hander who faces the Yankees on Wednesday night, did not grow up hoping to lead the National League in earned run average. He is doing that now, with a 1.98 mark, but Beachy mostly wanted to hit.

headline: Using Your 401(k) to Buy a Small Business
text: It takes a creative and determined buyer to purchase a small business in today’s lending environment. If there’s any doubt that small-business lending has yet to recover in any meaningful way, look no further than Ami Kassar’s new contribution to this blog: Searching for Capital. While frozen credit markets have made it difficult for small businesses to get loans for expansion and working capital, they have also had a major impact on the business-for-sale marketplace.

headline: Desktop Computers Look More and More Like Smartphones
text: If you’re an experienced computer user, you probably remember explaining to newbies how a desktop computer worked: Your photos should go in this folder; your documents in that one. You will need to use this application to open that image; that application to open this document.

headline: Asia-Pacific Region Is Fertile Ground for Low-Cost Airlines
text: SINGAPORE — The airline industry is suffering from global economic turmoil. But people like Kelvin Mok, who just graduated from college in Hong Kong, are helping to ensure that in Asia, at least, the sector is continuing to grow.

headline: Singer Mehdi Hassan Dies At 84
text: Mehdi Hassan, the Indian-born Pakistani singer, died on Wednesday in the Pakistani city of Karachi at the age of 84. Mr. Hassan had been suffering from multiple organ disorders for the past several years.

headline: A Plan to Regulate Gas Drilling
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is preparing a proposal that would allow hydraulic fracturing for gas only in areas where deposits are at least 2,000 feet deep.

headline: Cuomo Proposal Would Restrict Gas Drilling to a Struggling Area
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration is pursuing a plan to limit the controversial drilling method known as hydraulic fracturing to portions of several struggling New York counties along the border with Pennsylvania, and to permit it only in communities that express support for the technology.

headline: In the Wild, Seeking an Answer: What Replaces Dying Trees?
text: The coastal mountains of southeastern Alaska rise steeply from the Pacific Ocean. Fjords and channels separate over 1,000 islands from the mainland. Dressed like fishermen, we traipse through forests and crawl through brush as weather fronts whip through inlets and rumble along the outer coast.

headline: White House Rebuffs Calls for a Special Prosecutor
text: In 2007, as Democrats on Capitol Hill gleefully conducted one investigation after another into George W. Bush’s administration, Rahm Emanuel, then a Democratic congressman, quipped: “This is just the beginning.”

headline: Horace Mann Case Prompts New Look at State Sex Abuse Laws
text: In the news this Wednesday, questions about the state's laws on sexual abuse in light of the allegations surrounding Horace Mann, and stalled progress in Albany to move against public schoolteachers who abuse students. Also, does the city know enough before implementing new special education policies citywide? What about parents? And a thief takes students' cellphones.

headline: Rex Ryan, Thespian
text: Jets Coach Rex Ryan looks like a natural in Adam Sandler’s latest movie, “That’s My Boy,” playing a lawyer and Patriots fan.

headline: At Gupta Trial, a Glimpse at Goldman’s Inner Workings
text: Wall Street watchers hoped that the inner workings of Goldman Sachs would be on display during the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta, which begins closing arguments on Wednesday.

headline: Video Shows Attack on U.N. Observers in Syria
text: CAIRO — As my colleagues Mark Landler and Neil MacFarquhar report, Syrian activists said on Wednesday that rebel forces had pulled out of villages around the besieged northwestern town of Al Heffa.

headline: Trinidad Leatherbacks, Large and Small
text: Carl Safina, the peripatetic ocean conservationist and author, is in Trinidad, filming for the PBS “Saving the Ocean” program. He sent photographs of his interactions on a beach with newborn and egg-laying leatherback turtles (the species that’s the focus of his book “Voyage of the Turtle”). He included this “Postcard” (please send one yourself if you are in a place or situation that resonates with Dot Earth themes):

headline: Music for the Masses
text: Ramallah, West Bank — Monday night I attended a piano concert in Ramallah given by the internationally acclaimed Palestinian pianist Saleem Abboud Ashkar who was born in Nazareth and now lives in Berlin. Despite the hardship of the Israeli occupation, a vital classical music revival has emerged in the West Bank in the last few years.

text: Some headlines on Tuesday suggested that Barack Obama has a problem among his African-American base. The warrant for this claim is a new

headline: Wolfmania
text: Martin Wolf writes about saving the euro, citing an analysis from ING (pdf); basically Wolf argues that the only realistic hope is the strategy on the upper right of this figure from the report:

headline: Pakistan Court Initiates Contempt Charge Against Justice’s Accuser
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Supreme Court initiated contempt-of-court proceedings on Wednesday against a property baron who a day earlier accused the chief justice’s family of accepting $3.7 million in kickbacks and cash payments.

headline: For a Virginia Republican, a Comeback and a Tough Fight Ahead
text: Political redemption, it seems, is almost never completely out of reach.

headline: Grabbing a Quick, and Unpleasant, Bite
text: Dear Diary: I am walking down Lexington Avenue on the Upper East Side. I have missed lunch and am late for a meeting when I pass a store handing out free samples. I grab three pieces, say a quick thank you, thrust the nourishment into my mouth and keeping moving.

headline: Charlie Sheen Talks About ‘Anger Management’ and Anger Management
text: LOS ANGELES — Hey, remember that Charlie Sheen fellow? Used to be the star of a sitcom, “Two and a Half Men,” until he got into a war of words with its co-creator Chuck Lorre and was fired from the show? Taught us some lessons about tiger blood, warlocks and winning? Went on a cross-country live tour that didn’t get such hot reviews? What ever happened to that guy?

headline: Daily Report: Google Employees Know Nothing
text: Google has long prided itself on not being a conventional company, Edward Wyatt, a New York Times reporter notes. But he writes there is one characteristic it apparently shares with the most sclerotic bureaucracy: the willingness of its employees to say, “Not my job.”

headline: Friends Indeed | New Shows at Salon 94 Bowery and the Hole
text: “They’re like cave paintings,” Jeanne Greenberg Rohatyn said during the installation of the group show “Pothole” that opened at one of her two downtown galleries, Salon 94 Bowery, last week. “We were all inspired by Werner Herzog’s film,” she said, half joking, and adding that initially the show was to be called “Square Cave,” a reference to the both the physical space (a subterranean white box on the Bowery) and the 10 participating artists’ inclination toward gestural, expressionistic mark-making in their practices.

headline: Live Blog: Senate Banking Hearing on JPMorgan
text: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chairman and chief executive, testified before the Senate Banking Committee about the multibillion-dollar trading losses incurred at his firm’s chief investment office.

text: Q.

headline: The Breakfast Meetings: Movies for People Like Us, and Major on Murdoch
text: The Wall Street Journal is reporting that the Justice Department is investigating cable companies for using various tactics, like capping data, to quash competition from video upstarts like Hulu and Netflix. According to The Journal, investigators have already spoken to Comcast and Time Warner Cable, which have their own on-demand services that compete with the new crop of online players.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Eating Frugally in Copenhagen
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: A Chicken’s Journey From Chinatown to a Private Sanctuary
text: For those who have entered the newly reopened Chinatown Fair arcade in years past, most have distinct memories about the place: the street-fighting games, the old-school games, but more often than not, the chicken that played tick-tack-toe.

headline: The Bad News: Broadway Revival of ‘Godspell’ to Close
text: The annals of Broadway may have plenty of room for musicals with religious themes and stories inspired by the Gospels, but the summer season does not. The producers of the Broadway revival of “Godspell,” the pop musical loosely based on parables from the New Testament, said late Tuesday evening that the production will play its final performance at the Circle in the Square Theater on June 24.

headline: A State-by-State Climate Map
text: If those New England seasons feel far warmer these days than they were 20 years ago, it’s because they are. So are Florida’s, Arizona’s, and Washington State’s.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: NPR: At last, someone has the courage to come out against bananas in fruit salad. And more solid advice on composition and creativity. — Julia Moskin

headline: Just One Look | Jonathan Saunders
text: “Separates allow me to do what I love to do with color,” Jonathan Saunders said as the sun beamed down through the skylight at Industria studios, highlighting the vibrant greens, blues and reds of his resort collection. “But I’m loving a total, head-to-toe print look.” Saunders pulled out a pair of fluid palazzo pants in a bamboo print, one of several late-’70s-inspired motifs he designed for resort, including a graphic floral and a multicolored dot pattern that brought the artist Victor Vasarely to mind. The bamboo palazzo pants can be worn with a simple black top, of course, but paired with one in the matching bamboo print, the look could have easily passed for an evening dress — very chic and not in the least over the top.

headline: Apple’s Mapping Feature Wins Raves
text: I can’t possibly write today’s blog post any better than the person who submitted it — reader Adam Ornstein. Adam, take it away!

headline: Breaking It Down: Nadal vs. Djokovic
text: For world No. 1, Novak Djokovic, the best defense has proven to be more offense.

headline: Parsons Joins Lazard Board
text: One might have thought that after 16 years on the board of Citigroup — and one terrifying financial crisis — Richard D. Parsons would have had his fill of financial firms.

headline: Carven
text: Guillaume Henry presented his collection on June 12.

headline: Time to Play Outside
text: At this time of year, children need little encouragement to break out of the confines of classrooms and indoor spaces. No mittens or zippers or itchy hats — just the brief torment of sunscreen — and they’re outside and free!

headline: Subtext: Germany Threatens Europe, Again
text: LONDON — Stubborn, domineering, downright unfriendly. All the old stereotypes about the Germans are rising to the surface as frustration grows over their refusal to sign what they regard as a blank check to their less disciplined European neighbors.

headline: Driveshaft Defect Prompts Recall of 50,000 Honda Civics From 2012
text: Honda recently informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that it would recall about 50,000 of its 2012 Civics because the vehicles might suddenly lose power.

headline: On Bases, Hotels Go Civilian
text: When I completed Army basic training at Fort Leonard Wood in Missouri, I was thrilled I had made it through all six weeks and would never return.

headline: Many Young Adults Still Struggle With Health Costs, Report Finds
text: Despite recent gains in offering health coverage to young adults, many still do not have coverage and have had to make tradeoffs because of medical costs, according to a new study from the Commonwealth Fund, a nonprofit research group.

headline: Image of the Day: June 13
text: Government employees in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, demand better terms of employment.

headline: On Our Radar: Diesel Fumes Cause Cancer, W.H.O. Says
text: The World Health Organization declares that diesel fumes cause cancer, suggesting that the exhaust is a public health threat rivaling secondhand smoke. The United States rates it only as a “likely” carcinogen. [Associated Press]

headline: Soccer Officials Sentenced in China
text: SHANGHAI — The former head of the Chinese soccer association and 10 other former national team players and executives were sentenced by Chinese courts Wednesday to lengthy prison terms for accepting bribes and fixing matches, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

headline: The Business of Good Horsemanship
text: The fans of thoroughbred racing, once again, will have to go another year without a Triple Crown winner and many of them have expressed their frustration as paranoia, accusing Doug O’Neill, the trainer of I’ll Have Another, of a host of different motives: he was afraid of a drug test, he was afraid of losing, he was afraid that, like Big Brown, an abysmal showing in the Belmont would have cast doubt on his horse’s triumphs in the Preakness and the Kentucky Derby. The subsequent announcement that he was retiring the Flower Alley colt has led some to observe that I’ll Have Another’s value as a breeding animal has trumped his value as an athlete.

headline: Guess Who’s Emerging From the Crisis?
text: FT Alphaville:

headline: London Theater Journal: A Flickering ‘Torch Song’
text: Long before America cuddled up with those wholesome gay pixies on “Will and Grace” and “Modern Family,” there was “Torch Song Trilogy,” a play that scratched the surface of a fierce drag queen to discover a lovable Jewish mother with good family values beneath. Arnold was this comforting creature’s reassuringly plain name. The man who created him on the page and the stage, Harvey Fierstein, won Tony Awards for both Best Play and Best Actor in 1983, giving daring and triumphant new breadth to the notion of theater queen.

headline: Officer Had ‘No Choice’ in Bronx Man’s Shooting, His Lawyer Says in Court
text: An officer charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of an unarmed 18-year-old man who was followed by the police to his home in the Bronx and then killed by a single police bullet in his bathroom had “no choice” but to shoot him, the officer’s lawyer said at his arraignment on Wednesday.

headline: Just One Look | L’Wren Scott
text: L’Wren Scott’s first resort collection began innocently enough. “I was sitting in my office one day with all of my crayons and started coloring,” she said. Scott created nine prints, which she then produced in nine silhouettes. The collection, titled Propaganda, is inspired by poster art from World War I and World War II. The bright prints include “The Bomb” (exploding grenades), “Bromance” (American and British flags) and “Why Knot” (Chinese peace knots). Many of the looks are topped off with a cap, some done in a print, appropriately named “Hats Off,” riffed from a rendering of Queen Elizabeth by Cecil Beaton. But our favorite print spells out “L’Wren Scott don’t fake it” — in Morse code.

headline: Slight Majority of New Yorkers Oppose Soda Ban
text: A narrow majority of New York City voters oppose Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to restrict sales of big sugary beverages in city restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, according to a poll released on Wednesday. Opponents of the plan edged out supporters, 51 percent to 46 percent; opposition was strongest among older voters, white voters and voters on Staten Island.

headline: CNN Is Ending John King’s Political Show
text: 2:40 p.m. | Updated The ailing cable news channel CNN on Wednesday announced the end of “John King, USA,” its 6 p.m. political news program.

headline: Business Day Live | June 13, 2012
text: A flirting app is rocked by child rape cases. | Jamie Dimon's fall from being 'America's Banker.' | Eduardo Porter on why women still earn less than men.

headline: Big Government
text: As I wrote yesterday on this blog, and as the board wrote on the editorial page today, President Obama and Mitt Romney differ on a very basic question: Does the federal government have a duty to use its economic power in times of deep economic hardship to help states keep teachers, firefighters and policemen on the job?

headline: What Happens if India Is Downgraded to ‘Junk’?
text: Since Standard & Poor’s warned Monday that India could be the first among the BRIC nations to lose its investment grade rating, politicians in India have moved quickly to discount the report.

headline: The End of the Summer Job?
text: Summer jobs for teenagers are increasingly hard to find. Only 3 out of every 10 teenagers held a full- or part-time job in July of 2011. In 1989, that rate was nearly twice as high: nearly 6 of every 10 teenagers from 16 to 19 years old held jobs, and even in July of 2005, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that more than half of 16- to 19-year-olds were employed.

headline: WPP Chief’s Pay Package Is Rejected by Shareholders
text: LONDON — Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of the advertising giant WPP, on Wednesday became the latest British executive whose pay package was rejected by a majority of shareholders.

headline: Original Review: ‘Long Day’s Journey Into Night’
text: Brooks Atkinson’s 1956 review of Eugene O’Neill’s play on Broadway.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/13: The $96 Round-Trip Ticket, and an African EasyJet
text: Lagos-Bound Plane Crash Stokes Fears Nigerian air travel used to be so unsafe that travelers would stick to dangerous roads. It improved dramatically, and the United States gave Nigeria’s carriers the highest status — Category 1. But the plane crash on June 3 has raised new questions about the safety of air travel in the country. (The New York Times)

headline: Q. and A. With a Times Reporter About New York Hydrofracking Rules
text: 7:25 p.m. | Updated In an effort to reduce the risks associated with the controversial natural-gas drilling method known as hydrofracking, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is pursuing a plan to limit the practice to several struggling counties along the Pennsylvania border, only in towns that approve the technology, Danny Hakim reported in The New York Times on Wednesday morning.

headline: Headphones to Keep Sound Out
text: V-Moda, a headphone maker, is usually concerned with putting sound into your ears, but its Faders VIP hearing protectors are intended to keep sound out.
