text: Follow the model.

headline: Stella McCartney’s Circuslike Garden Party
text: There was fun for the whole family at Ms. McCartney’s resort presentation, as models blew bubbles and kids played ring toss.

headline: Defense Highlights Inconsistent Witness Testimony at Sandusky Trial
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — The first three days of the trial against Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach charged with being a serial pedophile, has followed a familiar pattern. Prosecutors have questioned young men who said Sandusky met them when they were children at his charity, Second Mile; showered them with gifts; and sexually abused them. The testimony has been heart-wrenching and seemingly unassailable.

headline: With New Leader, Regulator Finds a New Direction as Well
text: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency is so lenient on the banks it is supposed to regulate that it could be mistaken for a division of the United States Chamber of Commerce. Does its new head, Thomas J. Curry, have any hope of giving it a backbone?

headline: Jamie Dimon's Fall
text: June 13, 2012 - Jamie Dimon's fall from being 'America's Banker.'

headline: Resort Collections Offer Peek at September Shows
text: Looks from resort collections, including Stella McCartney, Céline, Jason Wu and Carven.

headline: 7 Tips for an Easier Family Getaway
text: WITH summer just around the bend, many families are planning getaways. But figuring out all the details — from which hotels are child-friendly to how many diapers to pack for that five-hour flight (more is better) — can be critical for a smooth trip. Here are some lessons I have learned over the years, both from other travelers and through my own experience.

headline: Russia and Iran Criticize the United States on Syria
text: TEHRAN — Russia and Iran, Syria’s staunchest allies, castigated the United States on Wednesday for its support of opposition forces battling President Bashar al-Assad and his military, and the Iranians accused the Americans and their allies of sending weapons and troops into Syria.

headline: Not Just Vacation Flings
text: THIS week in fashion, we celebrate a fairly new tradition in which dozens of designers unveil their intra-season resort collections during informal presentations by saying things like, “Color, for me, is like food,” or “I like the idea of beach to evening,” or “In the middle of this collection, I watched the movie ‘Marley,’ so there’s a bit of Rasta in there.”

headline: A Microcosm of London: John Lanchester Talks About ‘Capital’
text: In his new novel, “Capital,” John Lanchester tracks the lives of several characters living and working on one London street: a banker and his wife; a Polish house builder; a Muslim family running a shop; a teenage West African soccer star; and a political refugee who works illegally as a traffic warden, to name a few. The street’s residents have been receiving notes in the mail with pictures of their own houses and the cryptic message: “We Want What You Have.” In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Lanchester discussed fiction and nonfiction, Dickens and Tolstoy, immigration, the changing behavior of the English, and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Death Illustrates Issues With Loose Weapons Stockpiles in Libya
text: The death of an Estonian explosive ordnance disposal technician in Libya this spring illustrates the continuing problem of loose weapons stockpiles almost a year after Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was driven from power.

headline: Owners May Not Be Covered When Hackers Wipe Out A Business Bank Account
text: In May 2010, Golden State Bridge, an engineering and construction company based in Martinez, Calif., was robbed of more than $125,000 when cybercriminals hacked into its bank account.

headline: City Clings to Rays as Others Clamor for a Move
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Mayor Bill Foster scoffs at critics who accuse him of holding the Tampa Bay Rays prisoner in their stadium. Yes, attendance has generally been weak at Tropicana Field, an unattractive venue that lacks many of the amenities found at newer stadiums and, yes, people who live on the other side of the bay, in Tampa, are clamoring for the team to move there.

headline: Jeb Stuart’s Wild Ride
text: “Gentlemen, in ten minutes everyone must be in the saddle.” It was 2 a.m. on June 12, 1862, and a 29-year-old Confederate brigadier general named James Ewell Brown Stuart — Jeb to his intimates and posterity — was about to write history with his famous “Ride Around McClellan.”

headline: Just One Look | Carolina Herrera
text: “The ‘Lovers’ and the ‘Rabbits’ go very well,” Herrera said, referring to resort’s two standout prints. The “Lovers” is a watercolor with renderings of men and women in fanciful colors, applied to classic Herrera pieces: peplum blouse and cotton skirt and dress. “It’s very easy,” Herrera noted, “and feminine.” As for “Rabbit,” it’s here on a silk collared blouse and pleated skirt. Hippity hoppity.

headline: Tough Times at the Playground and the Church
text: “Rev.” is a British series about a country priest who moves to London, and “The Yard” is a Canadian mini-series about the tribal relationships among the children in a Toronto elementary school. What unites them, apart from their both making their American debuts online at Hulu, is the comedy of transgression: lasciviousness and foul language springing from what would seem to be the unlikeliest mouths.

headline: Designing a Connected Planet
text: Brown University and the Rhode Island School of Design host an annual student-organized conference called “A Better World by Design,” and each year there’s a related student design competition. This year’s design challenge, under way right now, is aimed at “connecting the disconnected,” with a focus on expanding high-speed Internet access.

headline: After Rapes, Skout App Bans Minors
text: June 13, 2012 - A flirting app is rocked by child rape cases.

headline: St. Luke’s Park, Mott Haven, the Bronx, 10:21 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Children, beware of well-dressed statues. They may be spying on you.

headline: Justice Department Is Said to Investigate Cable Companies Over Internet Video
text: 8:56 p.m. | Updated Another round is under way in the battle between established cable and Internet providers like Comcast and relative upstarts like Netflix. And the government is playing referee.

headline: If Hackers Wipe Out Your Bank Account, Will You Be Covered?
text: In 2009, hackers broke into a corporate bank account owned by Mark Patterson’s construction company, Patco, and stole $588,000. Like most small-business owners, Mr. Patterson was surprised to learn that protections on personal bank accounts do not apply to business accounts.

headline: U.S. Security Expands Presence at Foreign Airports
text: SHANNON, Ireland — An ocean away from the United States, travelers flying out of the international airport here on the west coast of Ireland are confronting one of the newest lines of defense in the war on terrorism: the United States border.

headline: Blankfein Speaks on Europe, the Financial Industry and Dimon
text: CHICAGO — Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said in a speech here on Wednesday that the European crisis was at “a very critical moment.”

headline: Economy’s Mixed Blessing: Commodity Prices Fall
text: HOUSTON — Mark Juull, a construction contractor for public and residential housing, has something to be thankful for in this sluggish economy: With global commodity prices falling, he’s saving $200 a week on fuel for his three trucks and finding deals on aluminum, lumber and roof shingles, which are typically made from petroleum.

headline: Budget Office Director Says Health Law Hasn’t Hit Economy
text: As a Supreme Court ruling on the health care law nears, theories abound as to what the economic effects of the court’s decision will be. On Wednesday, Douglas W. Elmendorf, director of the Congressional Budget Office, wasn’t eager to enter that fray – but he disputed the view pushed mostly by Republicans that the health care law has, to this point, hurt employment.

headline: Euro 2012: Germany 2, Netherlands 1
text: Germany strengthened its hold of Group B with a well-deserved 2-1 win over local rival the Netherlands in Kharkiv Wednesday night.

headline: In Good Health? Thank Your 100 Trillion Bacteria
text: For years, bacteria have had a bad name. They are the cause of infections, of diseases. They are something to be scrubbed away, things to be avoided.

text: Via Slate

headline: SUNY Downstate Medical Center’s President Suddenly Quits
text: 1:41 p.m. | Updated The president of SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Dr. John C. LaRosa, has unexpectedly stepped down, announcing his departure, effective immediately, on Tuesday afternoon in an e-mail to physicians and other staff members.

headline: Bronx Museum Gets Major Gift to Acquisitions Fund
text: The Bronx Museum, which is celebrating its 40th anniversary, announced Wednesday that it had received $500,000 from the Ford Foundation, part of a campaign to raise $1 million for a new acquisitions fund that will focus on buying the works of contemporary artists with strong connections to the Bronx.

headline: ‘Weeds,’ Long-Running Showtime Comedy, Is Canceled
text: 3:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: Scene City: Broadway Parties Til Dawn After the Tonys

headline: Elinor Ostrom Reading List
text: As noted earlier, Elinor Ostrom, the first and only woman to have won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, died on Tuesday.

headline: Aide to Giffords Is Elected to Finish Unexpired Term
text: TUCSON — Ron Barber, a survivor of the shooting rampage that brought a sudden end to Gabrielle Giffords’s Congressional career, earned the right to finish her third term on Tuesday in a closely followed special election that served as a testing ground for the power of national issues in deciding competitive local races.

headline: Barclay Street, 11:42 a.m.
text: N.Y. See: President Obama is scheduled to visit the One World Trade Center construction site on Thursday.

headline: Woody Harrelson, as Director and Co-Writer, Coming to Off Broadway
text: In the summer of 1983, when an acting career was still just a dream, Woody Harrelson worked construction in Houston and met a play’s worth of colorful characters, including an aspiring writer from Harlem named Frankie Hyman who became his best buddy on the scaffolding. That fall Mr. Harrelson headed for New York to try to break into theater, only to hit dead ends. As with many struggling actors, his thoughts turned to writing his own scripts, and he found himself thinking back to that summer in Houston – though it would take more than 25 years, and a collaboration with Mr. Hyman, to finish the play he had in mind.

headline: Cuomo’s Wise Move on New York’s Gas Resource
text: New York Governor Andrew M. Cuomo (@nygovcuomo) appears to be closing in on a plan for extracting natural gas while limiting environmental risks in the state, as reported today by Danny Hakim for The Times.

headline: Israeli Watchdog Criticizes Government Over Gaza Flotilla Raid
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s state comptroller, the government’s watchdog, issued a report on Wednesday harshly criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over his handling of a commando raid on a Gaza-bound Turkish ship in 2010. The raid, meant to halt a flotilla challenging Israel’s naval blockade of the territory, turned deadly, with severe diplomatic consequences for Israel.

headline: Young Cadets Mourn a Comrade, Felled by Gunfire in Harlem

headline: ABC Holds Steady in ‘Upfront’ Ad Sales
text: A third English-language broadcast television network, ABC, has completed its sale of commercial time before the start of the 2012-13 season as the so-called upfront market proceeds to a placid close.

headline: Driving the Audi A3 E-tron
text: Of all the Leafs, Volts, Teslas and Karmas, Audi’s E-tron moniker is most redolent of sci-fi films and the utopian promise of a brave, new, petrol-free world.

headline: Lena Dunham’s Secret Girls’ Spot
text: In last weekend’s magazine, Andrew Goldman asked Lena Dunham, who  lived with her parents while creating “Girls” for HBO, whether, now that she’s moving out, she’s moving to “cool, young Williamsburg or established, family-oriented Brooklyn Heights.” The latter, she said: “We lived there all through my high-school career, so I have an intense attachment to it.”

headline: Tyra Banks Sets an Example
text: Standing in the rain near the site of a new building on Avenue D that will eventually house the Lower Eastside Girls Club, a group of young girls on Tuesday afternoon greeted Tyra Banks by practicing one of her signature moves, the “smize.” As anyone who has watched “America’s Next Top Model” knows, that is smiling with your eyes.

headline: Impostors Post Up in N.B.A. Finals
text: Oklahoma City had scarcely gained control of the opening tip in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals Tuesday night when @NotWaltFrazier, who recently surpassed 10,000 followers on Twitter, complimented Thunder Coach Scott Brooks on his hair: “Scotty Brooks with the fresh cut for the Finals. Follicle cleanin’ and national TV preenin’! #JustForMen”

headline: Syria Crisis and Putin’s Return Chill U.S. Ties With Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Sitting beside President Obama this spring, the president of Russia gushed that “these were perhaps the best three years of relations between Russia and the United States over the last decade.” Two and a half months later, those halcyon days of friendship look like a distant memory.

headline: Just One Look | Salvatore Ferragamo
text: Salvatore Ferragamo’s creative director, Massimiliano Giornetti, presented resort at the Louvre Museum in Paris yesterday while simultaneously live streaming the show internationally. (T editors huddled together around a computer in the fashion department to watch.) The collection evoked la dolce vita in a big way with exotic skins (crocodile minidresses; python to-the-knee boots), over-the-top accessories (giant hobo bags and look-changing belts) and swinging fringe trim on skirts, tops and coats. Here, a barely there single-shoulder tunic nipped at the waist with a snakeskin belt and over-the-knee boots seems destined for a stroll along the Amalfi Coast. All that’s missing are the Jackie O. shades, maybe.

headline: Becoming a New Father, Slowly
text: When my wife was pregnant, my son would kick and cough, change her body, tastes, routines. She had a visceral, constant reminder of his presence. For me, it was completely different. My son was a notion. I looked the same, felt the same and could easily forget he was on his way. If I didn’t actively remember to think about him, I didn’t. Instead I focused on tangible things: cribs, strollers, memorizing songs to sing.

headline: Everything’s Coming Up Roses
text: FOR at least a century, the rose has been entwined in our notions of beauty and desire. A key accessory for prom queens and figure skaters (not to mention Queen Elizabeth II’s diamond jubilee), it has figured in cold cream, Chanel No. 5 and the classic Smith’s Rosebud Salve.

headline: Does Mormonism Have a Marriage Problem?
text: In a Newsweek column making the case that Mitt Romney’s Mormon faith will be a positive influence on his presidency, David Frum includes the following caveat:

headline: Romney Calls Obama Policies the Most Anti-Business in Recent History
text: On the eve of a major economic speech by President Obama, Mitt Romney told a group of business leaders in Washington on Wednesday that the Obama administration had pursued the “most anti-investment, anti-business, anti-jobs series of policies in modern American history” and was responsible for the tepid pace of the recovery.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: For Millions, a Poignant Bond
text: READERS of Time magazine might have felt something akin to déjà vu when they glanced at the cover of the June 11 issue. “How to Die,” it read. “What I Learned from the Last Days of My Mom and Dad.”

headline: A Bank’s Proper Role
text: How much protection do banks owe their older customers? Is it condescending to treat them differently from younger ones? Or, given how commonly old people are targeted by scam artists, should their actions and transactions draw additional scrutiny?

headline: The Right to Choose Your Cancer Treatment
text: Before there was Betty Ford, the outspoken first lady who brought breast cancer awareness to the wider public, there was Babette Rosmond, a diminutive New York City writer and editor who went public with her diagnosis of breast cancer 40 years ago, three and a half years before the first lady. If Mrs. Ford is remembered for her grace and honesty, we should remember Ms. Rosmond for her courage and persistence. What Ms. Rosmond demanded of her doctors — the right to choose her cancer treatment — is now the minimum that cancer patients deserve.

headline: Charlie Sheen Returns
text: Roughly a year after the actor was fired from “Two and a Half Men,” the actor is back with “Anger Management” on FX.

text: Verizon Wireless unveils a cross-platform plan for data sharing. | Apple and Google fight over maps. | An increasing number of cities adopt new parking meter technologies.

headline: Daily News Is Reviewing Restaurants Again
text: The New York Daily News has revived regular restaurant criticism in its pages, some three years after it stopped running reviews by its last critic, Danyelle Freeman, whose sobriquet was “the Restaurant Girl.”

headline: Photo Replay: June 13
text: The Olympic torch continued its trek toward London for the Summer Games, and golfers had their last full day of practice before the United States Open begins at the Olympic Club in San Francisco.

headline: Prosecutors Draw ‘Secret Pipeline’ Pattern; Defense Asks, ‘Where’s the Beef?’
text: As a director of some of America’s most well-known companies, Rajat K. Gupta was the ultimate insider, entrusted with confidential information about corporate earnings and major transactions.

headline: Hire a Vet? Forget That. Adopt One Instead.
text: Can a man who kills other men for money retain his humanity? What if his employer is the United States government?

headline: Stone Links: Addiction and Agency
text: This week The Stone featured an essay by Peg O’Connor on addiction, the brain and the will. Philosophy Now has more on the topic. Addictive actions are often thought to undermine the will. But can we think of them more simply as representing nothing more than capricious changes of mind? There is a view of temptation and the will, tracing back to Plato’s “Protagoras,” that takes them to be just that. It is an elegant theory, as it makes no use of the thorny notion of akrasia, or weakness of will. Alan Brody argues at Philosophy Now, though, that we can find another view in Plato that also refuses the concept of akrasia while still respecting the way addiction disrupts agency, in particular our capacity to regulate our actions. The view is this: when one acts on an addictive impulse, one’s will remains intact. It is, rather, the capacity to judge what is the best course of action that fails one; the addictive course momentarily appears to be the best available.What Rorty Wrought: Santiago Zabala marks the five year anniversary of Richard Rorty’s passing with this tribute in Al-Jazeera. Rorty ought to be the model for 21st century philosophy, Zabala argues, owing to his eclectic approach to philosophical method and the capacity it gave him to transcend narrow debates within Anglo-American philosophy and see the way philosophy might figure productively in the broader intellectual and political life of America and Europe. But politics should also inform philosophy: “If you take care of freedom,” Rorty says, “truth will take care of itself.” For Rorty, truth ought to be conceived not as correspondence to a mind-independent reality, but pragmatically, as consisting in those conclusions an open and free community might arrive at in the long run of inquiry.

headline: Heat-Thunder Gets a Big Number
text: Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals Tuesday night proved that a small-market team like the Oklahoma City Thunder can resonate with fans beyond its region. The Thunder’s 105-94 over the Miami Heat was seen by an average of 16.2 million viewers, the most for a Game 1 since ESPN/ABC acquired N.B.A. rights in 2002-03.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Candor
text: As you no doubt read or heard, Jeb Bush made news earlier this week, saying that neither his father nor Ronald Reagan would have found a comfortable place in the Republican Party of today. This is hardly a revelatory observation. But it’s an essential one, presented in this case by a member of one of the party’s ruling clans (at least once upon a time), as my colleague Jim Rutenberg noted in his terrific news article about Bush’s comments.

headline: Pavilion Planned for New Arts Center in Southampton Village
text: The architect David Rockwell has designed a pavilion for the Southampton Center, a new cultural and artistic organization that will occupy the Parrish Art Museum’s former site on Jobs Lane in Southampton Village, N.Y. (The Parrish is moving to a building designed by Herzog & de Meuron in Watermill that is due to open in November.)

headline: Just One Look | Altuzarra
text: For Joseph Altuzarra’s second resort collection, the CFDA winner held a seated presentation in his Tribeca studio. “I don’t really know how to do this,” he said with a laugh as models began walking in safari-inspired looks. The outerwear was Indian safari meets colonial capes and jackets; underneath were peasant tops and dresses in linen or bright ikat cotton. “I watched a Bob Marley movie while working on this collection, so the colors took on a reggae feel,” Altuzarra explained. North African bead work embellished the collars of blouses and the hems of peplum pencil skirts. Newness arrived in billowing (but belted) gypsy dresses. “Everyone in the office tried them on and they really flatter every body type,” Altuzarra said of the very un-body-con silhouette. “So that’s a new direction we’re trying.”

headline: Manchester United Said to Consider Moving Stock Sale to U.S.
text: LONDON — Manchester United may have fallen short of an English soccer championship last month, but the United States stock market is emerging as a new goal.

headline: MacBook, a Point Shy of Perfect
text: If you could design your dream laptop, how would you describe it?

headline: Uncertainty and Health Insurance Reform
text: Mitt Romney said on the campaign trail in Florida yesterday that President Obama’s health care reform law is hurting small businesses and that Mr. Obama is oblivious to the problem. “You have to scratch your head about that,” Mr. Romney said.

headline: Ask Questions of a Financial Planner, at No Charge
text: Last weekend, Ron Lieber wrote in his Your Money column about taking a day to do a financial tuneup.

headline: Maybe Just Call It the Adele Chart
text: Adele, Adele, Adele.

headline: Tonys in Hand, Celebrating Till Dawn
text: IT was 3 a.m. last Monday at the Carlyle Hotel. Amid the thwack of congratulatory back slaps, the smack of air kisses and the rustle of ball-gown trains, one man stood out in a white terry bathrobe.

headline: Just One Look | Gucci
text: When Gucci’s designer Frida Giannini presented her first cruise collection in 2005, she chose the house’s iconic flora print — originally created for one of Princess Grace’s scarves — as her focal point. Now, with nearly 30 seasons under her belt, the flora print is back. Late ’60s and early ’70s bohemian pieces, like this Capri Island-inspired day dress, set the tone. There were suede tunic dresses, denim suits and cropped leopard-patterned jumpsuits. For evening, things got a bit more mod, with diamond crystal-embroidered mini dresses with bouquet necklines made from precious stones.

headline: In Iraq, a Day of Violence
text: A series of explosions targeting Shiite Muslims in Baghdad and southern Iraq on Wednesday killed at least 90 people and wounded 260 others, officials said.

headline: In Life and Art, It’s All About Us
text: DARYL WEIN and Zoe Lister-Jones were not thinking about the most efficient way to jump-start their careers when they decided, back in 2006, to have an open relationship. Less than happy but still in love, the couple, who met as students eight years ago at the Tisch School of the Arts at N.Y.U., were merely searching for a way, in effect, to break up without fully breaking up.

headline: Powerade’s Olympics Campaign Puts Its Trust in ‘Nameonics’
text: A popular ploy in consumer marketing is using a mnemonic device in the theme, slogan or jingle of an advertising campaign, hoping to build brand awareness through repetition and being memorable.

text: MOJITOS for $14, lobster rolls for $29, rooms for $625 a night?

headline: A Deal on Lease Accounting
text: Lease accounting is one of those things that drive some analysts up a wall, and fixing it has long been on the list of things the accounting rule makers should do. But when they tried, people were furious, and the rule makers went back to the drawing board.

headline: On NBA TV, the Team Relives the Dream
text: The 1992 U.S. men’s national basketball team — a collection of players more affectionately remembered as “The Dream Team” — was American sports domination incarnate.

headline: For a New Teacher, a Soldier’s Lessons on Helping Veterans Fit In
text: The “Tower Guard” invitation arrived after Kent Dell finished up his freshman year at Michigan State University in 2011. It came with other academic junk mail he easily tossed aside — “Join this honor society, or that one. And send us $80,” Mr. Dell said. But his wife, Kolina, already an M.S.U. graduate, knew what the Tower Guard represented, even if her husband didn’t. “You should accept this invitation,” she told him.

headline: Ann Romney’s Style
text: Mrs. Romney as a standard-bearer for authenticity, a woman determined to use fashion, when the time seems right, to counter her husband’s image.

headline: Writing Her Own Dress Code
text: IN an interview on Fox News last month, Ann Romney confided that on policy issues she and her husband don’t always share the same views. “I don’t think we’re ever exactly on the same page 100 percent,” Mrs. Romney said.

headline: The Tae Kwon Do Chronicles: Working Toward Another Medal
text: Diana Lopez won a bronze medal in tae kwon do in Beijing in 2008 and will be competing again in London this year. Her reports will appear regularly on the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her first post.

text: UP five floors, past the receptionist and a row of eager job applicants, is the Chelsea office of Ricky Kenig, the founder and creative director of Ricky’s, the funky beauty-store chain known for glitter, wigs and a colossal assortment of hair products.

text: FRANKFURT — Opel, the European unit of General Motors, said on Wednesday that it was negotiating with workers to close its factory in Bochum, Germany, after 2016, in a proposed deal that might also exclude layoffs in the country until then while delaying union wage increases.

text: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Always, the Netherlands enters a tournament as a favorite, abundantly skilled and hopeful. But expectation has now left the Dutch small and fragile and nearly out of possibility.

text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Myanmar and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Myanmar, Iraq, New York and the West Bank.

headline: Seeing Reflections in John Waters and ‘Carrie’
text: It’s not surprising that John Waters, a director long celebrated and reviled for his trashy, outré, queer films, would be represented in a queer arts festival.   And there he — or, rather, an extended excerpt from his sordid, classic film “Desperate Living” — was on Saturday night at the Abrons Arts Center, when the French choreographer David Wampach performed two works as part of the Queer New York International Arts Festival.

headline: With Ballard Gone, the Giants Must Adjust
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Jake Ballard’s locker at the Giants’ training facility looked the same Wednesday morning, as if it still belonged to him. Jackets hung underneath a shelf holding his red, white and blue Giants bag, which was underneath his shoulder pads. Below that was a pile of mismatched shoes. On the wall inside the locker hung a tribute to his alma mater, Ohio State: a rag with “Ohio” scripted in scarlet and gray. Above it was a picture of the Giants tight ends from last season: Travis Beckum, Bear Pascoe and Ballard.

headline: Vision Problem Subsides, but Hitting Problem Lingers for Freeman
text: ATLANTA — A hitter is nothing without his eyes, which is why anxiety gripped Atlanta’s Freddie Freeman last month when his vision started blurring. What if his career was being sideswiped? A hitter might as well have a Wiffle ball bat in his hands if he goes to the plate and his vision is not right. Freeman, 22 and in his second season as the Braves’ regular first baseman, was scared, and rightfully so.

headline: Armstrong Faces New Doping Charges
text: The United States Anti-Doping Agency is set to bring doping charges against Lance Armstrong that could lead to his being stripped of his seven Tour de France titles.

headline: Justin Bieber Grows Up
text: The pop star turned 18 in March and his second full-length album, “Believe,” is to be released on Tuesday.

headline: A Colorful Array of Creative Furniture
text: This year’s NeoCon conference unveiled a number of eye-catching, utilitarian pieces that add bright pop to any office setting.

headline: Google Wants Love and 100 Other Things
text: Google wants love. But so do six other companies. They are after .love, actually, a new “top-level domain” that could catch on as .com, .org and .net did.

headline: Joe Average, Just Waiting for Salvation
text: The hero of Dave Eggers’s absorbing new novel “A Hologram for the King” is a penny-ante Job named Alan Clay, who finds himself in an absurd situation. Alan is deeply in debt, unable to pay his daughter’s college tuition and plagued by a scary golf-ball-size lump on the back of his neck. He’s betting everything on a last-ditch chance at a big payday, hoping he can sell the Saudi king, Abdullah, on a lucrative technology contract — a contract that depends on Alan’s going to a remote real estate development in Saudi Arabia and making an elaborate holographic presentation to the king, who may or may not even show up.

headline: Thriving With the Drug-Cartel Dead
text: When Wallace Stevens wrote, “death is the mother of beauty,” he probably wasn’t imagining anything like “El Velador” (“The Night Watchman”), Natalia Almada’s eloquent documentary portrait of a sprawling graveyard in Culiacán, Mexico, in the northwestern state of Sinaloa. The rapidly expanding cemetery has become the burial ground of choice for the country’s slain drug lords.

headline: House Hunting in ... Italy

headline: North of Rome, a Stone Villa on a Hill
text: A renovated villa in the countryside is on the market for $803,838.

headline: Jazz Acts, Blowing Superhot and Cool
text: So much about the Vision Festival communicates openness, multiplicity, fluctuation. An independent summit of experimental jazz, the festival has an aesthetic descended from the scrappy, permissive mood of downtown New York in the 1970s. Look closer, and over time you might notice that it’s a tended garden like any other. It plays favorites and exercises biases. There’s an outsider ethos at work in its presentation, but also an implicit closing of the ranks. Even the outside has an outside, for practical purposes.

headline: The Best Countries to Be a Woman — and the Worst
text: India, a country best-known for its rising economic might, is the worst place to be a woman among the world’s biggest economies, and Canada the best, according to a survey of experts published Wednesday.

headline: New Composers and New Sounds Converge in Buffalo
text: BUFFALO — In a lecture on Saturday morning for an audience of student composers at Baird Hall on the University at Buffalo campus, Robert Beaser offered a brief but detailed overview of the travails of writing his Guitar Concerto (2009). Mr. Beaser, one of four faculty members in town to preside over master classes at the June in Buffalo new-music festival, spoke of agonizing over the concerto for a decade. He still considers the work unfinished, he said, and just last week he spent four hours with the guitarist Eliot Fisk, for whom it was written, tweaking the solo guitar line.

headline: Gingrich Gone, Billionaire Now Showers Romney With Money
text: 11:15 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.

headline: A Hip-Hop Star, Pushing the Boundaries and Pleasing His Public
text: HOLMDEL, N.J. — There’s been a lot of discussion lately about boundaries in hip-hop. A couple weeks ago Hot 97’s annual Summer Jam devolved into a conflagration between Nicki Minaj, the genre-agnostic star, and the morning-radio host Peter Rosenberg, who derided her for having forgotten where the invisible lines she shouldn’t cross were. Mr. Rosenberg, a committed classicist, bad-mouthed “Starships,” one of Ms. Minaj’s big pop hits, and dismissed the young women he presumed were there to hear it; at the behest of her Young Money label’s boss, Lil Wayne, Ms. Minaj opted not to perform.

headline: Former Dewey & LeBoeuf Partner Sues Firm’s Management
text: The legal troubles continue to mount for Dewey & LeBoeuf.

text: This week on The Times’s weekly technology show, Verizon Wireless unveils a cross-platform plan for data sharing, Apple and Google fight over maps and an increasing number of cities adopt new parking meter technologies.

headline: New York City Finances Switch to Cleaner Heating Oils
text: Building owners in New York City that use the dirtiest heating oils and are now required by law to phase it out will have access to more than $100 million in special financing to help cover their upfront costs, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Wednesday.

headline: City Ballet Names New Leaders
text: The ballet brought him business, and business brought him the ballet.

headline: Step Inside a Freedom Garden
text: Some farmers in Louisiana are raising crops that would have fortified their ancestors.

headline: Invoking a Country’s Aboriginal Past and a Company’s 50 Years
text: Celebrating its 50th year, the Australian Ballet opened its week on Tuesday night at the David H. Koch Theater with the first of two performances of a triple bill with the ambiguous title “Infinity.” Its first third, “Luminous,” was a retrospective of repertory highlights and dancer showcases, interspersed with video; its centerpiece, “Dyad 1929,” choreographed by Wayne McGregor, was impeccably modern; and the finale, “Warumuk — in the dark night,” by the choreographer Stephen Page and including performers from Bangarra Dance Theater, was a mythic evocation of Australia’s aboriginal past.

headline: BAM’s New Hall Offers Flexibility
text: For years the building at 321 Ashland Place in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn was dormant, its arches filled in with bricks, a relic of the time it served as a citadel for the Salvation Army.

headline: ‘Streetcar’ Will Close on July 22
text: A multiracial production of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” which opened to lukewarm reviews and middling box office on Broadway this spring, will close on July 22 after 23 previews and 104 performances.

headline: For the Formerly Homeless, Homey Touches
text: Anyone who lives in Detroit knows how much the city’s homeless population has been suffering, particularly in the last few years. And those lucky enough to get into transitional housing after leaving the overpopulated shelters are starting from scratch — a situation that inspired Treger Strasberg and Ana Smith to start a nonprofit firm called Humble Design.

headline: For This Lobster, a Bowl, Not a Pot
text: The artist Joan Sherman works in SoHo surrounded by high-end food purveyors, but her latest inspiration was 17th-century Dutch and Flemish genre painting and those overflowing banquet tables. Ms. Sherman particularly liked the lobsters. Such delicacies were not just a merchant culture’s token of luxury, in her view, but symbols of adventure, “a kind of trophy” of sea voyages to remote corners of the earth.

headline: The Man of Kennebunkport, Sentimental Journeying
text: The documentary “41” opens with ocean spray fizzing up from the rocks around the shingled summer house of George Herbert Walker Bush in Kennebunkport, Me., and doesn’t move far from that idyllic spot.

headline: Hush, Child. Your Cradle’s Handmade.
text: What is the gestation period of a cradle? Fifty hours (not counting breaks), if you’re intent on constructing the piece using techniques associated with Windsor chairs.

headline: A Tribute to an Eames Chair, in Plastic
text: When Niels Wildenberg turned 21 and had a few dollars to spend, instead of treating himself to a used car he bought a used chair. The one he coveted was wood and leather and could be identified by almost anyone as the classic lounge chair designed in 1956 by Charles and Ray Eames.

headline: The Natural World, in Wool
text: Amy Helfand, a textile designer in Red Hook, Brooklyn, who is known for her ebullient floral patterns, has taken a tempestuous detour with Intention Is Everything, right, one of the three rugs in a new collection called This Moment.

headline: Fragrance, Linens and Housewares
text: All home fragrance is 25 percent off at Flair through June 29 (its signature candle, regularly $48, is $36); 88 Grand Street (Wooster Street), (212) 274-1750, flairhomecollection.com.

headline: A 19th-Century Town House Earned With Patience
text: With some luck and persistence, a television producer strikes real estate gold with an intricately detailed home in Chelsea.

headline: At Two City Schools, Parents' Money Leads to Two Very Different Experiences
text: Parents at P.S. 89 in Manhattan pay for laptops, a dance program, a chess club, upgrades to the gym and the library, music and art programs, and a playground assistant. They give teachers $400 each to purchase school supplies, and $200 more later in the year if needed. At P.S. 305 in Brooklyn, parents are hoping to use the $5,000 they have raised this year to send fifth graders on “a nice, end-of-year trip,” rent out a prom hall and purchase sashes for their graduation ceremony. Teachers  not only don't get money for school supplies,  they often chip in to help families and children. Another report on the impact of parent fund-raising and spending in the public schools.

headline: Old Fashioned
text: Michael Arenella tries to recreate the Jazz Age in his life.

headline: After Run to Finals, Devils and Parise Consider Their Futures
text: NEWARK — The Devils, clean-shaven, posed at center ice for a team picture Wednesday, instead of preparing for what would have been Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals. Zach Parise, their first-year captain, stayed just a minute longer to look at the shiny, silver Prince of Wales Trophy.

headline: The Law and Sex Abuse at Horace Mann
text: My colleague William Glaberson has an article in today’s New York Times about the legal implications of the abuses detailed in “Prep-School Predators,” which appeared in the magazine this past Sunday. They are few. Because of New York State’s statute of limitations — one of the most restrictive in the nation – it seems pretty clear that no one who spoke about the experiences described in the magazine has any legal recourse.

headline: Senior Trial Final for the World Mind Sports Games
text: Many players think that squeezes are executed only by experts. But some just “play themselves.”

headline: NBC Fares Well in ‘Upfront’ Market … Considering
text: NBC has finished its sales of commercial time before the start of the 2012-13 season in what is called the upfront market, achieving results that are pleasing to the executives who are trying to turn around the ailing network’s fortunes.

headline: Seniors: What Made Your New York City Education Unique?
text: Seniors, you can have the final word. SchoolBook wants to hear your anecdotes, wisdom and parting thoughts about high school life in New York City. Some of the most compelling stories may be published in The New York Times, told on WNYC and shared with SchoolBook readers at the end of the month. But first you have to submit something.

headline: The Seeds of Survival
text: DONALDSONVILLE, La.

headline: Slipping Into Something More Comfortable
text: CHICAGO

headline: Six Steps to Decluttering Your Smartphone
text: When I was a little boy, my mother used to scare me into cleaning my room with tales of the Collyer brothers. You know about the Collyers, right? Two brothers. Lived together. Hoarded everything. Everything. Like, whole rooms filled to the ceiling with stuff. One brother died when a stack of ephemera collapsed on him. The other brother, already paralyzed and blind, died of starvation days later.

headline: An Infinity of Lights: Photos From the New Yayoi Kusama Exhibit
text: The adorable, polka-dot-obsessed Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama is having her first United States retrospective at the Whitney Museum in July, but today the first part of the show opens. The installation, “Fireflies on the Water,” consists of a small room with mirrored walls, two inches of water on the floor, a raised platform for a viewer to stand on and 150 colored lights dangling from the ceiling. Only one person is allowed in the room at a time. Once the door closes behind you, it’s like you’re suspended in outer space. An infinity of lights surrounds you.

headline: Digital Notes: Plans for a New .Music Suffix, but Who Will Own It?
text: As part of changes planned by the organization that oversees Web addresses, music fans might soon be typing “JustinBieber.music” or “BruceSpringsteen.music” instead of more familiar addresses that end in .com or .net.

headline: Obama Honors Israel’s President
text: WASHINGTON —President Obama presented Israel’s president,Shimon Peres, with America’s highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, calling Mr. Peres “the essence of Israel itself — an indomitable spirit that will not be denied.”

headline: Unencumbered, Even by Regret
text: WHEN I was in sixth grade, and living in the town of Cape Coral, Fla., with my mother and stepfather, a real estate developer who was helping to turn this former Gulf Coast swampland into a planned community, our family car — a steel-gray Ford Torino I longed to drive one day — kept getting stolen.

headline: For Starters, These Are a Few of My Favorite Apps
text: Let me tell you a story. Not too many weeks ago my son was doing something adorable and I was deeply focused on filming him with my phone so I could pop it on the social media app Viddy (one of the “Instagram for video” apps that are booming right now) and share his cuteness with the world.

headline: A Chelsea Town House Worth the Wait
text: IN New York City, successful real estate outcomes are largely a result of three qualities: patience, nerve and sheer luck. George Fares, 56, a producer of television commercials, would seem to have all three.

headline: British Officials Try Again on Google Data Collection
text: British privacy officials may have finally decided to get to the bottom of how and why Google secretly collected personal data from potentially millions of the nation’s citizens. This week, the Information Commissioner’s Office reopened its investigation. There is a big problem, however; the I.C.O. permitted Google to destroy the controversial data two years ago.

headline: Suit Filed to Stop FreshDirect Plan for a South Bronx Complex
text: 11:20 p.m. | Updated  When it was announced in February that the online grocery giant FreshDirect would move from Queens to a new 500,000-square-foot facility in the South Bronx, city and state officials hailed the deal as a victory that kept FreshDirect from decamping to New Jersey.

headline: It's All Fun and Games
text: AMONG those gathered in Switzerland this week for the annual Design Miami/Basel design fair is Libby Sellers, a gallerist from London presenting “Games,” a group show with a chess theme.

headline: The Boom in Online Freelance Workers
text: Global networks make it possible to obtain work anywhere, enabling companies to hire many specialists for specific tasks at fixed amounts. Chances are this is only getting started, and there are profound implications for things as diverse as corporate structure, employment, job skills and even taxation.

text: The University of Virginia’s governing board has agreed to meet with a faculty delegation to discuss its abrupt ouster of the university president, as tension builds over a shake-up that faculty leaders have asked the board to reconsider.

text: The movement to legalize Sunday morning brunch on New York City sidewalks took a step forward on Wednesday.

headline: Henry Hill, Mobster and Movie Inspiration, Dies at 69
text: Henry Hill, an associate in the Luchese organized-crime family whose decision to turn federal informer, and subsequent itinerant life in and out of the federal witness protection program, inspired Martin Scorsese’s acclaimed film “Goodfellas,” died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 69 and had lived openly in Topanga, Calif., in recent years.

headline: For Yemen’s New President, a Battle for Control and a Tug of War With the Past
text: SANA, Yemen — A military ceremony that took place here last month seemed to indicate a smooth transition from Yemen’s former president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to its new leader, Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi.

headline: G.O.P. Senators Oppose Choice for Iraq Envoy
text: WASHINGTON — Opposition mounted in the Senate on Wednesday to the nomination of Brett McGurk as the next ambassador to Iraq, as seven Republican senators recommended that his name be withdrawn from consideration. The White House expressed support for its embattled nominee.

headline: College Postseason Will Change; the Question Is How
text: CHICAGO — The details of what a new college football postseason format would look like were still fuzzy after Bowl Championship Series officials met at a hotel here Tuesday night and Wednesday. The sense of inevitability that change was coming, though, remained.

headline: Russian Official’s Death Threat, in Bold Type
text: MOSCOW — The editor in chief of a prominent Moscow newspaper charged Wednesday that Russia’s chief federal investigator had threatened to kill the newspaper’s deputy editor over an article that documented corruption in the handling of a grisly murder case.

headline: Old-Time Texas Politician, Verbally Quick on the Draw
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Jerry Patterson is an authentic Texas politician, at a time when Texas politicians rarely act like Texas politicians. State elected officials and those trying to unseat them sue and countersue, carefully watch what they say, and are quick to apologize when they fail to do so.

headline: With Bay’s Struggles Come Tough Decisions About Playing Time
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When Jason Bay returned to the Mets on June 6 after a lengthy stint on the disabled list, he accepted that it would take him some time to become acclimated to the speed of the game.

headline: A Profitable Vestige of Cold War Precaution
text: The owner of a home in Queens has not given much thought about the origin of the concrete and steel room buried beneath his basement. “When I bought this house, nobody came to see this,” said Francisco Lago, who purchased his two-story home about 30 years ago. “It was in ruins.”

headline: Man Offers Guilty Plea, Upending Terror Case
text: A terrorism case in Manhattan that raised key questions about government interrogation tactics ended abruptly on Wednesday after the defendant pleaded guilty to conspiring to support a Somali terrorist group.

headline: A Record Worth Savoring
text: ATLANTA — Eric Chavez has played 15 seasons in Major League Baseball and says he has never seen a better player than Barry Bonds, taking into account only what was seen on the field. Bonds is the career home run king with 762 and the single season leader, too, with 73 in 2001.

headline: When Enough Is Enough
text: What to do while waiting for the health care decision. . . . Perusing one of the tiny handful of decisions the Supreme Court has issued in the past couple of weeks, an old, never-to-be-forgotten one came to mind: Bush v. Gore. Not that the new decision, Armour v. City of Indianapolis, had anything to do with presidential politics. Quite the opposite: its subject was something that happened at the most local level of government, a sewer improvement assessment in a subdivision of Indianapolis.

headline: Adding a Fresh Metaphor to a Familiar Campaign Message
text: WASHINGTON — Appearing before 500 cheering fans at a fund-raiser at the Hyatt Regency in Baltimore on Tuesday, President Obama offered up a critique of his Republican opponents certain to strike a chord with anyone who had ever gotten stuck with the bill for an expensive restaurant.

headline: Dread and Uncertainty Pervade Life in a Diminished Greece
text: ATHENS — Anyplace else, they might be signs of progress: Traffic moves faster on once clogged streets. Cigarette smoking has dropped sharply. Far less garbage heads for landfills each day.

headline: Jury Gets Insider Case of Ex-Goldman Director
text: During closing arguments in the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta on Wednesday, a prosecutor distilled a dizzying number of exhibits — phone records, board minutes, trading logs and e-mails — into a cogent narrative of the government’s case.

headline: ‘Proud’ JPMorgan Chief Apologizes
text: WASHINGTON — Jamie Dimon, the outspoken chief executive of JPMorgan Chase under scrutiny for a multibillion-dollar trading loss at his firm, apologized for the mishap on Wednesday even as he mounted a fierce defense of his bank.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For Donors, $40,000 a Plate, and Don’t Be Late

headline: Drilling in New York
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s preliminary blueprint for hydraulic fracturing in New York State strikes a sensible balance between the need for economic development and the need to protect the environment and human health. Many important issues must still be addressed — and tough, detailed regulations issued — before Mr. Cuomo can think of greenlighting drilling. But he appears to be on the right track.

headline: Mr. Dimon on the Hill
text: Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan Chase, told the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday that he had been “dead wrong” to dismiss early news reports of his bank’s reckless trading and that he was “sorry” for the resulting losses, variously estimated at $2 billion to $5 billion, and counting. He even ventured that too-big-to-fail banks have “negatives,” including “you know, greed, arrogance, hubris, lack of attention to detail.”

headline: Venture Firm Fires Back in Discrimination Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the Silicon Valley venture capital firm, filed its legal response Wednesday to the sex discrimination charges made last month by a junior partner, Ellen Pao, sweepingly and specifically denying all the claims.

headline: We Who Are Left When a Generation Passes
text: Sometime in 1931, my dad and his four siblings, farm kids all, posed for a formal photograph. The boys are wearing suits, and the girl, my aunt Janelle, is wearing an infant’s white dress. The oldest boy, Everon, is perhaps 12 years old, and my dad is 5. And now they are all gone. Everon and Janelle, the last of them, died six days apart in early June.

headline: Copters in Syria May Not Be New, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton accused Russia on Tuesday of shipping attack helicopters to Syria that would “escalate the conflict quite dramatically,” it was the Obama administration’s sharpest criticism yet of Russia’s support for the Syrian government.

headline: The Court Retreats on Habeas
text: When the Supreme Court ruled in 2008 that Congress could not strip federal courts of jurisdiction to hear habeas corpus petitions from non-American prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, the 5-to-4 majority opinion written by Justice Anthony Kennedy appeared to be a landmark victory for the rights of detainees. “The laws and Constitution are designed to survive, and remain in force, in extraordinary times,” Justice Kennedy wrote in Boumediene v. Bush, and “the framers decided that habeas corpus, a right of first importance,” must be part of the American legal framework.

headline: Michigan: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Challenging Detroit Solvency Deal
text: A judge on Wednesday threw out a legal challenge to an agreement intended to spare Detroit from financial ruin, ending a showdown that had threatened to leave the city unable to pay its bills as early as Friday. The judge, William Collette, of Ingham County Circuit Court, dismissed a suit that had been brought by Detroit’s corporation counsel, though opposed by its mayor, Dave Bing. The suit said that Detroit, which in April agreed to a deal with the state to steady its finances, could not enter into the contract because, the suit asserted, the state owes Detroit hundreds of millions of dollars from past debts. Mr. Bing said the city could now move forward in its effort to recover.

headline: Trying to Reduce Head Injuries, Youth Football Limits Practices
text: In response to growing concerns over head injuries in football, Pop Warner, the nation’s largest youth football organization, announced rule changes on Wednesday that will limit the amount of full-speed collisions and other contact allowed in practice.

headline: Energy Department Steps in to Help Uranium Enrichment Company
text: WASHINGTON — The Energy Department announced Wednesday that it was stepping in to shore up an ailing company it created in the 1990s to privatize uranium enrichment, calling the rescue vital to maintaining nuclear weapons and national security.

headline: Abuse Cases Briefly Noted at Horace Mann Graduation
text: The orchestra played “Pomp and Circumstance” as more than 170 seniors wearing black gowns and white tassels marched on a sports field beneath a big tent set up to ward off the rain.

headline: A Web Series for G.E. Tests a Refrigerator and Freshness
text: IN a telephone prank passed down by generations of children, the caller asks, “Is your refrigerator running?” and, after an affirmative response, the caller says, “Then you better go catch it.”

headline: Egypt Reimposes Martial Law, Ahead of Closely Watched Ruling
text: CAIRO — The military-led government issued a decree on Wednesday reimposing martial law ahead of an anticipated court ruling that could delay the presidential election scheduled for this weekend and the promised transition to civilian authority.

headline: Facebook Begins Ad Bidding System
text: In its quest to bolster the growth of its digital advertising, Facebook is slowly breaking down its walled garden for advertisers.

headline: Kentucky Commission to Bar Drug in Top Races
text: The Kentucky Horse Racing Commission approved a limited ban on the race-day medication furosemide Wednesday in an effort to restore public confidence that horses are running without what many veterinarians say is a performance-enhancing drug.

headline: Bury Lenin? Russian Minister Stirs Debate Over Soviet Past
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s new culture minister had already riled liberals who viewed him as the odd monarchist who is also somehow an apologist for Stalin.

headline: New Club, but a Legend’s Familiar Face
text: Descending a staircase into 54 Below, the funky-elegant new cellar cabaret on the site of the legendary disco Studio 54, I had a fantasy of visiting a speakeasy where the password for entry was a furtively whispered “verboten.” Because the star was Broadway’s tempestuous dark empress, Patti LuPone, singing an international program titled “Far Away Places,” the prospect of a globe-trotting musical journey back in time — when “verboten” conjured forbidden pleasures in exotic locales — was all the more tantalizing.

headline: Directionally Speaking
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — I grew up in and lived most of my young adult life in New York City, the only city in what seems like the entire nation without a RIGHT ON RED traffic law, so I was only vaguely aware of the advantages of this maneuver until I moved to the suburbs to raise my children.

headline: Did Any Good Come of Watergate?
text: Watergate inspired calls for regulating political fund-raising, ethical codes and aggressive journalism, as well as scorn for secrecy and surveillance. Have those notions survived?

headline: Preview of a Journey Across Iran
text: Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof gives a first look at his road trip through Iran, as he talks to ordinary Iranians about their lives, their government and the United States.

headline: Fatigue Is Not a Factor, Heat Coach Says
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The hypotheses came flying at Erik Spoelstra for 10 straight minutes, and for 10 straight minutes, Spoelstra batted them away, like an impatient college professor crossing wrong answers off the board.

headline: Ruth Sims, First Woman Elected to Lead Greenwich, Dies at 92
text: Ruth L. Sims, a Democrat who in 1977 became the first woman elected to lead historically Republican Greenwich, Conn., in a race that required two recounts and a second vote, died on June 7. She was 92.

headline: Bishops Defend Fight Against Obama’s Policy on Birth Control Coverage
text: ATLANTA — Ten years after a raging scandal forced the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops to adopt a package of policies for combating sexual abuse, the prelates on Wednesday heard a generally positive assessment of their progress at their annual meeting, and turned their attention to their newest overriding concern: their campaign to protect religious liberty.

headline: Asia Takes to the Air
text: The International Air Transport Association, an industry trade group, forecasts that two-thirds of profit this year will be made in Asia.

headline: Dickey’s Magical Year Keeps Improving
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — R. A. Dickey, who detailed his life in a memoir this past winter, added a delightful chapter on Wednesday night.

headline: Canada Seeks Alternatives to Transport Oil Reserves
text: LONDON, Ontario — As the United States continues to play political Ping-Pong with the fate of the Keystone XL pipeline, Canadian officials and companies are desperately seeking alternatives to get the country’s nearly 200 billion barrels in oil reserves — almost equal to that of Saudi Arabia — to market from landlocked Alberta.

headline: China: Actress Sues Publications Over Bo Allegations
text: One of China’s most famous actresses has filed a libel suit against two prominent Hong Kong news organizations over articles saying she was paid to have sex with Bo Xilai, the deposed Communist Party official. The actress, Zhang Ziyi, sued Apple Daily, a well-known tabloid newspaper, and Next Magazine Publishing, both of which are owned by Next Media. Executives at the companies have declined to comment. Apple Daily reported this spring that Ms. Zhang made $110 million by sleeping with Mr. Bo and other officials in recent years; the article said she was introduced to Mr. Bo by Xu Ming, a tycoon who has been detained in the Bo investigation. Mr. Bo, a former Politburo member, is being investigated for abuse of power.

headline: A Battle of Tennessee Titans
text: The fabulous pitching matchup at Tropicana Field Wednesday was special enough on its own. The Mets’ R.A. Dickey, who had nine victories, faced the Rays’ David Price, who had eight. Dickey dares hitters with a knuckleball. Price is a premier power pitcher, although the Mets figured him out.

headline: Pakistan: Supply Detour Costs $100 Million a Month
text: Pakistan’s closing of NATO’s ground supply routes to Afghanistan has added about $100 million a month to the costs of the Afghan war, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta told Congress on Wednesday. Mr. Panetta, left, said the added expenses were a result of using the longer northern route to supply the military and carry out the American drawdown in Afghanistan. Pakistan closed NATO’s supply routes across its border in November after an American airstrike mistakenly killed 24 Pakistani soldiers at a frontier outpost. Talks with Pakistan to reopen the route have stalemated. Mr. Panetta also said he would advise Congress on recommendations to deal with Pakistan in the future, including on the question of American financial assistance to Islamabad.

headline: From First Hole, Accuracy and Nerves Will Be Tested
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On the first hole, Rickie Fowler hit an errant approach from the fairway, plunked down a second ball and took another swing. On the second tee, he did the same. Multiple shots were the norm on Wednesday, the final day of practice before the 112th United States Open.

headline: How Broccoli Landed on Supreme Court Menu
text: What does broccoli have to do with health insurance?

headline: Protesters for Nuns Ask U.S. Bishops to Help Them Out
text: Protesting the Vatican’s criticism of the United States’ largest organization of Roman Catholic nuns, a group of people gathered outside the annual spring meeting of U.S. bishops in Atlanta on Wednesday and delivered a petition asking the bishops to intervene on the nuns’ behalf.

headline: South Carolina: Man Gets 50 Years for Molesting Over 20 Children
text: A graduate of The Citadel who went on to work with children there and at other schools and served as a foster parent pleaded guilty to 22 counts of child sexual abuse and was sentenced to 50 years in prison on Wednesday. The man, Louis ReVille, 32, who was arrested in October after an investigation revealed he molested more than 20 children he taught and coached in the Charleston area, apologized to his victims. Some are suing the institutions that hired him, including The Citadel, a military college. Victims have claimed that The Citadel knew Mr. ReVille molested teenagers at a camp in 2002, luring boys into his room with the promise of pizza and Chinese food and then showing them pornography and encouraging group masturbation sessions. The college, which investigated the complaint but did not report it to police, apologized.

headline: Cuba: Senators Condemn Treatment of Cuban Dissident
text: Several United States senators are condemning the arrest and abuse they say a Cuban dissident endured after he testified by video conference before a Senate subcommittee looking into repression on the island. Lawmakers said Jorge Luis García Pérez, known as Antúnez, was released Wednesday, four days after he was beaten and arrested by authorities. He had testified last Thursday from the United States Interest Section in Havana on the short-term detention of dissidents. Mr. García Pérez still faces charges, including “spreading false information,” senators Robert Menendez of New Jersey and Marco Rubio of Florida, both Cuban-Americans, said in a statement. The Cuban government has not responded, but generally treats dissidents as common criminals in the pay of the American government and exile groups.

headline: Corrections: June 14
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Equal Rights, Gay Rights and the Mormon Church
text: This month, gay and lesbian Americans celebrate gay pride. There has in fact been a lot to celebrate recently: the end of the military’s Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell policy; President Obama’s endorsement of gay marriage; and the recent ruling by a federal appeals court that declared the Defense of Marriage Act unconstitutional. For the most part, these political breakthroughs have been backed by an American public that is increasingly supportive of gay rights. Such a monumental and rapid transformation on the question of homosexuality has led many observers to deem gay rights the fastest-moving civil rights movement in our nation’s history.

headline: Campaign Aid Is Now Surging Into 8 Figures
text: Even in a political season marked by unprecedented levels of political spending, Sheldon Adelson stands alone.

headline: Three Everyman Qualifiers Offer Inspiration
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Until last week, Dennis Miller was just another guy from Ohio who liked to go to Cleveland Indians games on days when he probably should have been practicing his golf game. Until last week, Mark McCormick was another club pro from New Jersey hoping his son would become the first full-time resident of the state to play in the United States Open in 10 years. Until last week, Beau Hossler was a high school junior from Southern California, and mostly worried about final exams that would test his perfect 4.0 grade average.

headline: Summer Learning Fun, Via E-mail and Download
text: As with many things, some parents worry disproportionately about “summer slide.” Do children forget everything they’ve learned over the long summer break? It depends on how and where they spend it. If you’re reading my words, it’s likely that your children have access to reading materials at home. Children who don’t read over the summer lose two to three months of reading development while children who do gain a month — but research shows that children surrounded by reading material don’t appear to be at much risk. Summer reading is as effective as summer school, and it doesn’t matter what children read, as long as the reading is happening.

headline: Felda Raises $3.1 Billion in Asia’s Biggest I.P.O.
text: HONG KONG — Felda Global Ventures Holdings successfully raised $3.1 billion on Thursday by selling shares in Malaysia in the world’s second-largest initial public offering this year, after Facebook’s botched Nasdaq listing last month.

headline: Yankees, Playing Like a First-Place Team, Win Their Sixth Straight
text: ATLANTA — Steady rain and distant lightning accompanied the Yankees to Turner Field on Wednesday, and Curtis Granderson provided the thunder.

headline: Rare Lizard Is Protected, but Fails Endangered Test
text: HOUSTON — Depending on whom you ask, and their political affiliation, a little lizard’s long-fought battle for protection ended Wednesday either in victory or defeat, or something in between.

headline: At Stony Brook, Baseball Is Just the Latest Success Story
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — The campus sits a few miles below the rim of Long Island’s north shore, in a lush expanse of woodlands, bordering a sleepy hamlet of churches and creameries.

headline: Hearing Held on Lin’s Contract Status
text: An arbitrator will decide in the next two weeks whether to grant so-called Bird rights to Jeremy Lin and three other N.B.A. players in a case that could have a profound effect on the Knicks’ roster.

headline: Dave Boswell, Pitcher Who Fought Billy Martin, Dies at 67
text: Dave Boswell won 20 games to help take the Minnesota Twins to an American League division championship in 1969. He pitched in a World Series when he was only 20. But for many he is most remembered as a combatant on the list of Billy Martin’s greatest fights.

headline: Tennis Center Could Get New Stadiums (but No Roof)
text: The United States Tennis Association will spend an estimated $500 million through the coming decade to build a new Louis Armstrong Stadium, a new grandstand on unused land at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center, and a double-deck viewing area for fans to watch players practice during the United States Open.

headline: Time Inc. to Sell Its Magazines on Apple’s Newsstand
text: Time Inc., once the magazine industry’s most ardent opponent of selling subscriptions through Apple, will make all of its magazines available via Apple’s newsstand, the two companies said Wednesday.

headline: A Victory for Portugal, but a Disappointment for Ronaldo
text: When Joao Moutinho and his teammates ran to the corner of the field to embrace Silvestre Valera after the substitute put Portugal ahead of Denmark, 3-2, in the closing minutes of their Group B match Wednesday at Euro 2012, Cristiano Ronaldo fell to the grass and lay on the ground in the middle of the penalty box, alone, several yards away from the celebration.

headline: India the Worst Big Country to Be a Woman
text: “India, a country best-known for its rising economic might, is the worst place to be a woman among the world’s biggest economies, and Canada the best, according to a survey of experts published Wednesday,” Katrin Bennhold wrote on The Rendezvous blog.

headline: Church Battles Efforts to Ease Sex Abuse Suits
text: While the first criminal trial of a Roman Catholic church official accused of covering up child sexual abuse has drawn national attention to Philadelphia, the church has been quietly engaged in equally consequential battles over abuse, not in courtrooms but in state legislatures around the country.

headline: A Reboot for North Korea’s Annual Spectacle
text: HONG KONG — The spectacularly low-tech extravaganza staged every year by 100,000 gymnasts, dancers and flag-wavers in North Korea is apparently coming to an end — at least in the form that we’ve come to know and love.

headline: News Quiz | June 14, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: At British Inquiry, Cameron Denies ‘Deals’ With Murdoch
text: LONDON — Testifying at Britain’s long-running inquiry into media standards, Prime Minister David Cameron rejected suggestions on Thursday that he traded favored treatment for electoral support by Rupert Murdoch’s newspapers, calling talk of a conspiracy “specious” and “unjustified.”

headline: A Burmese Leader’s Triumphant Return to Europe
text: GENEVA — To rapturous applause from her audience, Myanmar’s pro-democracy leader, Daw  Aung San Suu Kyi, kicked off her first visit to Europe after nearly a quarter of a century on Thursday by appearing at the United Nations’ International Labor Organization here to appeal for investment that reinforces Myanmar’s progress toward democracy.

headline: Spanish Cost of Borrowing Soars After Rating Cut
text: PARIS — Government borrowing costs spiked to euro-era highs for Spain on Thursday, and Italy had to pay high rates again to complete a bond auction, as pressure mounted for a unified European response to the region’s financial problems.

headline: Paying Tribute at the Track
text: On Leap Day, my best friend and artist extraordinaire, Gregory Paul Frank, died after nine days in hospice. The next day, his daughter, son-in-law and I went to Fair Grounds Race Course in New Orleans and bet on horses with names that reminded us of Greg.

headline: A Conversation With: Christopher Albin-Lackey
text: In the past several years, India’s mining industry has been rocked by a series of scandals in Karnataka and Goa, among other states. The Supreme Court has banned iron ore mining in Bellary, northern Karnataka, after an ombudsman released a detailed report describing what it called the industry’s “mafia-type operations.” In the coastal state of Goa, a mining scandal helped swing an election decisively in favor of an opposition political party.

headline: Updates on Cameron Testimony to British Inquiry
text: The Lede followed developments in the daylong testimony of Prime Minister David Cameron on Thursday to a British judicial inquiry on media standards and the behavior of the press. Mr. Cameron’s appearance, which lasted about six hours and included questions about the nature of his relationship to Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, followed three days of testimony by British political leaders past and present.

headline: Singapore Zing
text: Here are a mess of lobsters for Father’s Day dinner: a pure American take on a Singaporean classic, chili crab. A fiery stew of sweet lobster and butter, hot sauce, ginger and lime, it is meant to be eaten with a fork, fingers and immense slabs of buttered toast. It tastes best when eaten outside in the throbbing heat of summer, with humidity hanging heavy in the air and the beer in the cooler so cold that it has little flecks of ice in it.

headline: A Pitch for a Pollution Solution Goes Off the Deep End
text: For our last pitch, I reviewed a Web 2.0 company that wants to help you manage your digital experience. This week, I review a pitch for a company that wants to solve our energy problems and clean up the Mississippi River at the same time.

headline: Benjamin Walker, Sexypants Vampire Hunter
text: “What I’m trying to do,” Benjamin Walker announced with mock solemnity from the stage at Joe’s Pub, the nightclub arm of the Public Theater, “is something I’ve never done before.” He made this admission on a mild evening in early April to an attentive audience of mostly young women. Walker, 29, was hosting an installment of “Find the Funny,” his charmingly slack monthly comedy show, and dressed in a fitted gray hoodie, charcoal pants and brown work boots, he surveyed the tightly packed room and ran a hand through his floppy brown hair. Then he started to play the ringing intro to Kings of Leon’s swooning hit “Use Somebody.” With his foot, he tapped a device on the floor to loop his guitar line so he could play in harmony with himself. This is not an easy trick to pull off. There’s a reason Kings of Leon has two guitar players.

headline: For the Thunder, a Coach Who Made the Pieces (and Plays) Fit
text: Since becoming the coach of the Oklahoma City Thunder in 2008, Scott Brooks has led the team to higher winning percentages, and deeper playoff runs, in each of the last three seasons. After a disappointing conference finals loss to eventual champs Dallas last spring, the Thunder dethroned the Mavericks – along with past impediments Los Angeles and San Antonio – en route to the franchise’s first- ever N.B.A. finals against the Heat and a Game 1 victory on Tuesday night.

headline: Nokia to Cut 10,000 Jobs and Close 3 Facilities
text: BERLIN — Nokia said Thursday it would slash 10,000 jobs, or 19 percent of its work force, by the end of 2013 as part of an emergency overhaul that includes closing research centers and a factory in Germany, Canada and Finland, and the departures of three senior executives.

headline: Students Report Cyberbullying Is Pervasive
text: Nearly 70 percent of some 10,000 students statewide told legislators they were victims of cyberbullying or knew someone who had been attacked on the Web. A legislator sees this as support for his bill to make cyberbullying a separate crime.

headline: Pop’s Good Boy Tries Growing Up
text: Just how fast is Justin Bieber allowed to grow up? And how much? Mr. Bieber, the defining teen star of recent years, turned 18 in March and has been in the public eye for almost four years, long enough to begin chafing. His desire to move in the world as an adult is palpable, but the very scale of his celebrity exacts its own sort of toll. Mr. Bieber can be his own man, sure, so long as he continues to belong to everyone else too.

headline: Two Nuclear Nominees Get a Hearing
text: President Obama’s nominee to lead the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said at a Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday that the nuclear industry’s share of American electricity production, steady at 20 percent for the last decade, could decline in coming years. Nonetheless, a diverse electricity supply requires continued use of nuclear power, she said.

As Greece gets perilously close to running out of cash, the results could be critical for the country’s future in the euro zone, and for the European Union as a whole.

headline: Another Installment of Civilized Conversation With Charlie Sheen
text: LOS ANGELES — In a previous polite chat with Charlie Sheen, he discussed the creation of his new FX series, “Anger Management.” In these final excerpts from that conversation, at his base camp at the studio where the show is produced, Mr. Sheen (who is the subject of an article this week) talks about his Twitter account, which he operates with the help of his social-media manager, Bob Maron; the unexpected places it has taken him; and making things right with his ex-wives and his fans.

headline: Bruce’s Bellport
text: The celebrated photographer Bruce Weber has always used his home bases — in Montana, the Adirondacks, Montauk, and Miami — as settings for his distinctly American fashion shoots. Tomorrow, the Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society on Long Island will unveil “A Bellport Tale,” a new exhibit of photos that Weber took when he resided in Bellport in the 1970s and ’80s. “Everyone knew each other,” Weber said of the quaint bayside village. “You could knock on any door and just invite a neighbor over to be part of a photography sitting. It was as easy as borrowing a cup of sugar.” The images in the exhibit come from a shoot that appeared in British Vogue in 1982 called “Under Weston Eyes.” Starring Talisa Soto and the male model of the moment, Bruce Hulse, that story was styled by Grace Coddington and inspired by the work of another photographer, Edward Weston. “He took things that were very personal to him and let us see into that world,” Weber said. “I thought it would be interesting to do a series of pictures of my own imaginary family, living together in the dysfunctional, neurotic, beautiful way that families do.” The exhibit (on view through Sept. 3) includes many memorable images, but perhaps none is more evocative of a quiet life on the bay than that of a shirtless Hulse, sitting on the stern of a boat, cigarette in hand, wearing calf-revealing baggy trousers, rumpled socks and dress shoes.

headline: Obama Says Election Offers a Clear Choice on the Economy’s Long-Term Path
text: CLEVELAND — Framing his re-election bid as a stark choice between government action to lift the middle class and a return to Republican economic policies that he said had caused a deep recession, President Obama on Thursday called the presidential decision facing Americans a clear-cut one that will determine the long-term trajectory of the economy.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Questions for Prime Minister, and Can Bieber Ever Grow Up?
text: The British prime minister, David Cameron, is spending all of Thursday testifying before the Leveson commission as it investigates the relationship between the British press and recent governments. Mr. Cameron seemed confident during the early questions, Alan Cowell and John F. Burns write, but his tone sharpened when Robert Jay, the lead counsel for inquiry, inferred that Mr. Cameron shaped Conservative Party media policy to please Rupert Murdoch and his newspapers. Those polices “weren’t dictated by anyone else,” Mr. Cameron said.

headline: Obama and Romney Campaigns Face Off in Ohio
text: The geographic terrain of the 2012 presidential campaign will narrow on Thursday to a 250-mile stretch in Ohio between Cleveland and Cincinnati, the two cities that will play host to dueling events by President Obama and Mitt Romney.

headline: Bahrain Court Upholds Convictions of 9 Doctors
text: CAIRO — An appeals court in Bahrain on Thursday upheld the convictions of nine doctors charged with crimes related to the popular uprising last year, in a case that drew international condemnation and was seen as a crucial test of the government’s commitment to political reform.

headline: What We’re Reading
