The bars pack five grams of protein, five grams of fiber and one gram of saturated fats. Not to mention coriander, ginger and white pepper. — Glenn Collins

headline: U.S. Open: Thompson Leads After First Round
text: Living up to its reputation, the Lake Course at the Olympic Club started off the first round of the United States open by extracting its toll from the field, providing a grueling venue for golf’s traditionally most taxing major. The action kicked off today and the United States Golf Association made sure the tournament captured attention quickly with the grouping of Tiger Woods, Phil Mickelson and Bubba Watson among the first to tee off.

headline: Politicking Began With India’s Very First President
text: A few weeks ago, when the names of the candidates in India’s presidential race were only just beginning to be chalked onto the tote board, I was speaking with Chintamani Mahapatra, a professor of political science at Jawaharlal Nehru University.When, I asked him, did parties start politicking so intensely over the appointment of the president – over a post that was mostly ceremonial?

headline: In Prague, Revisiting an Assassination and the Resistance Movement
text: A small-scale replica of a World War II concentration camp was erected in Prague to commemorate the assassination of the notorious Nazi general Reinhard Heydrich, 70 years ago in the Czech capital. The exhibition, “Assassination of Heydrich,”  opened last month on Karlovo namesti (Charles Square) and will run until June 18.

headline: Latest Updates on Electoral Turmoil in Egypt
text: Reporting from the Cairo bureau of The New York Times, The Lede is following the reaction in Egypt to twin rulings by the country’s highest court on Thursday, which threw the country’s post-revolutionary political transition into disarray. Two days before Egyptians go to the polls to elect a new president, the court dissolved the country’s recently elected Parliament and struck down a law passed by that body that would have barred Hosni Mubarak’s last prime minister from this weekend’s presidential election.

headline: Blow to Transition as Court Dissolves Egypt’s Parliament
text: CAIRO — A panel of judges appointed by Egypt’s ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, threw the nation’s troubled transition to democracy into grave doubt Thursday with rulings that dissolved the popularly elected Parliament and allowed the toppled government’s last prime minister to run for president, escalating a struggle by remnants of the old elite to block Islamists from coming to power.

text: Nokia said Thursday that it would slash 10,000 jobs, or 19 percent of its work force, by the end of 2013 as part of an emergency overhaul that includes closing research centers and a factory in Germany, Canada and Finland, and the departures of three senior executives, reports Kevin J. O’Brien from Berlin in The New York Times.

headline: On the 'Carousel' at Frank Sinatra High
text: The "Carousel" production brought many “firsts” to the Frank Sinatra School of the Arts in Long Island City, Queens. The arts high school with more than 700 students had staged musicals before, but this was the first one with lighting and set designers from outside the school. Somehow the show always manages to go on, a Columbia journalism student reports.

headline: Now Reading | Offbeat City Guides
text: Despite the glut of travel guides available, it’s sometimes hard to find ones that are actually instructive, that get at the heart of what’s going on in a given city and spare us the travel-writing clichés. That’s why it’s a welcome treat to discover Marc Santo and Scott Newman’s scrappy little Revel in New York series, the third edition of which went on sale last week. The pocket-size Revel isn’t a typical guidebook — half of its pages are devoted to freewheeling interviews with chefs, artists and architects about their work. But each of these subjects, New Yorkers either by birth or disposition, also shares a dozen or so deeply idiosyncratic recommendations. Taken together, their tips offer a unique way of exploring the city, even for its current residents.

headline: Living in the Past Is a Full-Time Gig
text: MICHAEL ARENELLA is at an open-air flea market in Lambertville, N.J., his fedora-topped head leaning over a gramophone. He winds the crank, lifts the arm and places the needle on a 78. Out of the old oak box comes a voice from the past: Arthur Fields singing “In My Tippy Canoe” in 1921. Mr. Arenella stands silently, hands in his pockets, taking in every crackly note.

headline: Living Retro
text: Michael Arenella, a musician from Brooklyn, escapes the reality of modern life through replicating the style of the Jazz Age. For him, living retro is a way to find happiness in ordinary things.

headline: The Balance of Power Between Bosses and Workers
text: There were lots of comments to my post on how I fire people, and I’d like to address some of the points. Commenters raised two main issues: First, that the policies I outlined in my employee manual are written for the benefit of the company as opposed to the employee and, second, that I seemed to be favoring firing people instead of training them. Both of these are complex issues that are handled differently by different companies. I can only comment on my own thoughts and experiences. Please don’t blame me for the many, many bad bosses and companies out there.

headline: F. Herbert Bormann Dies at 90; Helped Discover Acid Rain Threat
text: F. Herbert Bormann, a plant ecologist whose research with colleagues on a swath of New Hampshire forest in 1971 documented a new environmental horror in the United States — acid rain — died on June 7 at his home in North Branford, Conn. He was 90.

headline: A Parent Warns: A Focus on Fund-Raising Lets the Government Off the Hook
text: An active parent and prolific PTA fund-raiser writes: To those of us, like me, who have led the charge and devoted endless hours to school fund-raising through annual appeals, auctions, galas and other events to build the moneymaking machines some PTAs have become, I now caution: our efforts may be detrimental to systemic improvement in our public schools across the city.

text: MUMBAI, India — Men and women here in India’s largest city, a congested, humanity-soaked metropolis of roughly 20 million residents, would seem bound by at least one common misery: far too many people sharing far too few toilets.

headline: A Smell of Wine and Cheap Perfume
text: “Rock of Ages,” a jukebox musical turned junky big-screen attraction about making it in the music biz back when it still existed, is just entertaining enough to keep you from dark thoughts about the state of Hollywood. The movie is too insipid for such hand wringing, in any event, and the attention-grabbing turns by Alec Baldwin, Russell Brand and especially Tom Cruise as a rock-star crazy help enliven its overlong two hours. All singing, some dancing, the movie brings to mind “Glee,” but its truer, superior progenitor is that 1933 Cinderella story, “42nd Street,” the one in which the producer tells the chorine, “You’re going out a youngster, but you’ve got to come back a star!”

headline: The Russian Heart
text: Perhaps because I’m still in my early 30s, I tend not to fully believe that the people closest to me are vulnerable to sickness and death. But in 2008, shortly after my parents moved from Russia to Brooklyn’s Brighton Beach — a Russian neighborhood on the edge of the Atlantic — I began to have doubts that I would be celebrating Father’s Day ever again.

headline: The Get | Agatha Ruiz de la Prada’s Headbands
text: A few years ago, the designer Agatha Ruiz de la Prada was honored with an exhibition at the La Caixa Foundation in Barcelona, Spain. With approbation comes obligation; in this case, a celebratory luncheon, where the ready-to-wear and accessories designer showed up wearing a headband that sent a large, upright spiral jetting into the air. “Everyone looked shocked,” Ruiz de la Prada says. “But soon enough, the looks transformed into smiles, and the stiff formality dissipated from the room.” She credits the event’s success solely to the headband. Now, for Ruiz de la Prada’s second exclusive collection for Yoox.com, she has created 30 one-of-a-kind fascinators (priced from $90 to $105). The surreal pieces are sure to have awe-inducing effects: eggs over easy that drip down one’s head; an ace-of-hearts playing card; and a hatlike cupcake. But that’s just the tip of the capsule. Because, as Ruiz de la Prada points out, “What better than a beautiful headband to brighten up one’s day?”

headline: India’s Septic Problem
text: Some good sanitation news, discussed in a Nature commentary this week, is that some 80 percent of India’s urban residents now have access to a toilet. The bad news is that only a third of India’s urban households with a toilet have a connection to a sewage pipe network, and not all of those networks go to a sewage treatment plant. [Please read Jim Yardley’s report today from Mumbai for one consequence of the sanitation gap.]

headline: Restaurant Industry Moves Against Gas Drilling
text: Restaurant industry opposition to the controversial gas-drilling method known as hydraulic fracturing is growing as increasing numbers of high-profile New York chefs, restaurateurs, food suppliers and industry executives have joined the effort to lobby Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the State Legislature and the State Department of Environmental Conservation to ban the process.

headline: Two Journeys Into O’Neill, via E-Mail
text: IN two time zones on two continents, the actors Nathan Lane and Laurie Metcalf have been taking on formidable roles that sit at the center of the American theatrical canon. Mr. Lane, a two-time Tony winner and beloved musical-comedy star, was Theodore Hickman, known as Hickey, the hardware salesman who strips away the illusions that sustain the seedy New York bar dwellers in Eugene O’Neill’s “Iceman Cometh” at the Goodman Theater in Chicago. Ms. Metcalf, who earned some of the best reviews of her career in “The Other Place” last year Off Broadway, is the morphine-addicted matriarch Mary Tyrone in O’Neill’s “Long Day’s Journey into Night” at the Apollo Theater in London.

headline: The Best, and Worst, in Kabul Military Dining
text: I’ve risked my life in Afghanistan for a plate of French cheese. While not as arduous as serving in rural Afghanistan, the prisonlike conditions on Kabul bases — no family, long hours, repetitive food and confined spaces — often drive service members to extremes to escape the pressure and keep up their spirits.

headline: Just One Look | Peter Pilotto
text: Having found inspiration in the medieval prints of 16th-century illuminated manuscripts, designers Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vos told a strong story through embellishments (beadwork and 3-D embroidery) and exquisite fabrics (polyamide mesh, silk cloque and mikados) this season. Here, a tailored jacket with a multicolor geometric print builds upon the shapes and silhouette of the electric blue sheath dress beneath, making dressing by numbers infinitely more fun.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Loses in Court Again
text: LONDON — Britain’s Supreme Court on Thursday rejected a final move by the founder of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, to reopen his appeal of a ruling ordering him extradited to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuse and rape. In a statement, the court also ruled that he must be extradited by midnight on July 7, barring further legal intervention.

headline: In Code: Spaceships, Babies, Evil TVs
text: KEITH HARING’S ebullient, graffiti-based work epitomized an entire strain of 1980s art. His inspiration came from the street and from comic books, not from museums, and it burst onto the scene alongside that of similarly minded peers like Kenny Scharf and Jean-Michel Basquiat.

text: TNT managed to pull in a big audience by cable standards for its much-talked-about revival of the classic TV soap of the 1980s, “Dallas,” though the show was no “Hatfields & McCoys.”

headline: Ooh La La Maison | Paul & Joe Comes Home
text: Sophie Albou-Mechaly, the designer for the French clothing label Paul & Joe, doesn’t claim to be an avid chef, but delights in collecting china — from the high-end Hungarian manufacturer Herend to kitsch treasures like Ridgewood — at the Paris flea markets. “I love to dress a dinner table in colorful prints the way I dress myself,” says Albou-Mechaly, who is now expanding the brand to include home goods. “My idea of fashion is not to be only about clothes but about living well.” Paul & Joe La Maison is making its first foray into design with a three-print collection of kitchenware: cherry blossoms, kittens and Asian-inspired koi motifs. “The brand’s DNA is all about the happiness in colors and prints, so this feels like a natural extension,” she says, which is another way of saying that La Maison’s prints are derived from the current season and past collection hit makers. “As a woman and a mother, I am constantly thinking about women and the clothes and things that they need in their lives: practicality and appeal,” she adds. The collection includes everything from porcelain dinner plates and linen dishcloths to butter dishes, egg cups and even charming lunch boxes. And, with everything priced between $30 and $150 (similar to its sold-out 2006 Target collaboration), customers can afford the luxury of changing their home décor as often as they change their mood and clothes. “There’s no trend to it,” Albou-Mechaly says. “Mixing pieces and decorating your kitchen with them is fun.” The designer also suggests swapping tired hostess gifts (wine, flowers, desserts) with a La Maison item, since each piece comes beautifully packaged in a matching print box. Aren’t American kitchens’ needs different from those of French kitchens’? Albou-Mechaly begs to differ: “We are the American kitchen, English kitchen, French kitchen, Italian kitchen — it’s just the taste that is different.” Expect La Maison to take over every inch of your home, maison, flat or casa.

headline: Airports Focus on the Ground
text: At a time when federal and state public works programs are stalled, the nation’s biggest airports are in the midst of major renovations or expansions that, taken together, amount to some of the largest infrastructure projects in the country.

headline: With Science, New Portrait of the Cave Artist
text: Stone Age artists were painting red disks, handprints, clublike symbols and geometric patterns on European cave walls long before previously thought, in some cases more than 40,000 years ago, scientists reported on Thursday, after completing more reliable dating tests that raised a possibility that Neanderthals were the artists.

headline: Teacher Charged With Sexually Abusing 8-Year-Old Girl

headline: Making New York Safe for Brunch
text: An obscure 1971 restriction in the New York City code has helped put a crimp in Sunday morning brunch on city sidewalks. Now three City Council members have introduced a bill that would allow restaurants to start serving diners at sidewalk tables at 10 a.m., two hours earlier than the law permits.

headline: Pacino and a Theater Confirmed for ‘Glengarry’ Revival
text: Confirming a Times report on Tuesday, Al Pacino will star as Shelly Levene, known as “the Machine,” in a Broadway revival of David Mamet’s “Glengarry Glen Ross,” the producers of the show announced on Thursday. Mr. Mamet’s Pulitzer Prize-winning dark comedy about salesmen in a Chicago real estate office, is to begin previews on Oct. 16 at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on West 45th Street, with opening night scheduled for Nov. 11.

headline: Know That Venue: BMX Track
text: Making its second Olympic appearance, BMX biking is scheduled for the Olympic Park in August. The track was built with more than 14,000 cubic meters of soil reused from the site. Because the area previously had been highly polluted, the dirt had to be washed, sieved and then shaken free of contaminants like oil, tar, cyanide, arsenic and lead as well as some very low-level radioactive material.

headline: U.N. Monitors Find Vast Devastation in Syrian Village
text: United Nations monitors in Syria reported fiery devastation, the smell of death, vacated homes, looted stores and vestiges of heavy weapons on Thursday during a visit to what had been a Sunni-populated village besieged for days by Syrian forces and pro-government militiamen who said they had cleansed it of rebel fighters.

headline: Mets Say Wright (and Scorer) Erred
text: There was some awkwardness in the Mets’ clubhouse Thursday morning as the club followed through with its effort to have pitcher R. A. Dickey’s one-hitter against the Tampa Bay Rays on Wednesday night rescored as a no-hitter. The Mets appealed to Major League Baseball, contending that B. J. Upton’s first-inning infield single, which glanced off the bare hand of third baseman David Wright, should have been scored an error.

headline: Assuming the Doctor’s a ‘He’
text: The letter came from an English professor at a small Midwestern college. His freshman class had been assigned one of my essays, “Merced,” a story about a young woman in the I.C.U. with a mysterious diagnosis. “More than half the students,” the professor wrote, “assumed that you were a man — despite your name. When asked why, many said that your writerly voice was unmistakably masculine: logical, confident, secure, sometimes sarcastic…and, above all, that you are an M.D.”

headline: Might Celebrated ‘Iceman’ Cometh to Broadway?
text: Several Broadway producers are in talks about a Broadway transfer this fall for the Nathan Lane-Brian Dennehy revival of Eugene O’Neill’s “Iceman Cometh,” a nearly five-hour show now running the Goodman Theater in Chicago, according to theater executives with knowledge of the discussions.

text: New York’s dance music scene has thrived since well before the days of disco. Its clubs have always seemed to flourish even as the city’s fortunes — cultural, economic and otherwise — have ebbed and flowed.

headline: Despite Price Drop, Oil Cartel Keeps Production Limit
text: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries left unchanged a ceiling for oil production at a meeting in Vienna on Thursday, despite signs of a slowdown in the global economy and slumping oil prices.

headline: An Easy Commute to Stillness
text: GETTING from Point A to Point B as fast as possible in New York City is often considered a virtue. But there’s something to be said for slowing down, especially when the destination is a peaceful state of mind rather than, say, a dental appointment.

headline: Protesters Arrested in Quebec Solidarity March
text: Updated, June 15 | The police took into custody at least half a dozen people on Wednesday night as hundreds of protesters, for the third week in a row, marched from Washington Square in what they described as an expression of solidarity with striking students in Quebec.

headline: An Electric Future for Saab, but Who Provides the Power?
text: Like a punch-drunk prize fighter rising from the mat, Saab Automobile appears to have some rounds left. As The Times reported, the company was acquired on Wednesday by National Electric Vehicle Sweden, representing Chinese, Japanese and Swedish stakeholders, and could produce cars again at its base in Trollhattan, Sweden, as early as late next year, according to the new owners.

headline: Taking Off Badges and Lacing Up Gloves to Settle a Score
text: The older officer had taken a few boxing lessons at a gym not far from where his daughter went to gymnastics class. The younger officer had arms that seemed to belong to a man who weighed twice his 166 pounds.

headline: The American Symphony, at 50, Harks Back to Stokowski
text: When Leopold Stokowski formed the American Symphony Orchestra 50 years ago, he wanted to create, in part, a training ground for young musicians. Its ambition was to be second only to the New York Philharmonic in New York. Fifty years later, its ranks are dominated by veteran New York freelancers, and a claim on that No. 2 spot is unlikely. (The Met Orchestra? Orpheus? Orchestra of St. Luke’s?) But the American Symphony is still around, again playing at Carnegie Hall, with a focus on less frequently performed works and a didactic mission. It has announced an ambitious season in the fall and spring to celebrate its 50th anniversary.

headline: City Gains Jobs, but Unemployment Rises
text: What is happening in New York City’s job market is still a conundrum: The city gained more than 25,000 jobs in May but its unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent, according to the State Labor Department.

headline: Romney Assails Obama for Favoring Words Over Action
text: CINCINNATI — Mitt Romney, seeking to overshadow an appearance by the president in Ohio on Thursday, mocked President Obama as a candidate of words, not deeds, whose eloquent speechmaking abilities have not been matched by the effectiveness of his economic policies.

headline: Looking for an Error in Dickey’s One-Hitter

headline: Three City Students Win Big With Science — and a Fourth With Luck
text: Three students at city public schools won a hefty prize from the American Museum of Natural History last week: college scholarships worth $30,000. While impressive, the prize was not quite up to the winnings of Robert Salo, a James Madison High School senior who on Tuesday won the New York Lottery’s “Win $1,000 a Week for Life” game.

headline: NBC Hopes Olympics Can Help New Comedies
text: NBC will try to take advantage of the huge audience during the London Olympics by showing two of its new comedies at expected high points of the games – both without commercials.

headline: On the Trail of Oil-Munching Organisms
text: Two years ago today, BP’s Macondo well was in the midst of its 87-day spree of spewing oil into the Gulf of Mexico. Tar balls and oil slicks were showing up on beaches from Texas to Florida.

headline: Reacting to Criticism, Cuomo Adds to His Education Commission
text: Seeking to address complaints about the makeup of his new education reform commission, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has added five additional members to the panel in advance of its first meeting later this month. The commission now includes a parent advocate from Rochester, a newly elected school board member from the Adirondacks and a district superintendent from Central New York. The first meeting is scheduled for June 26.

headline: Senator Urges Bigger Cuts to Nuclear Arsenal
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee called on the Obama administration on Thursday to seek cuts in nuclear warheads far beyond the requirements of current treaties.

headline: Pondering the Rest of the Apple Announcements
text: In its keynote on Monday at the Worldwide Developers Conference in San Francisco, Apple took the wraps off enough new features and products to cover a mummy parade. I wrote about the highlights, and reviewed the new laptop — but that wasn’t the end of the food for thought. Herewith, some further reflections.

text: Dwyane Wade and LeBron James may be central to all that the Miami Heat do, but there seems to be a lingering misperception that the struggles of one superstar must in some way be connected to the the play of the other.

headline: Europe Braces for Greek Vote — and Maybe More
text: FRANKFURT — Greek elections on Sunday could bring urgency to a debate that has been largely academic: whether the euro zone can withstand the departure of one of its members.

headline: No-Foreign-Fee Cards Still Best for Overseas Spending
text: Credit cards that don’t carry foreign transaction fees are generally the best option for spending while traveling internationally. But even if you’re stuck with a card that charges the fees, you can still save more by using the card rather than by exchanging cash at banks and airport terminals.

headline: Outsiders as Trendsetters
text: The excellent collection show “Art of Another Kind” finds the Guggenheim tunneling back in time to 1959 — when its Frank Lloyd Wright building first opened — and returning with a treasure trove of postwar abstraction, much of it made by artists you have probably never heard of.

text: A scene from “Extraterrestrial,” Nacho Vigalondo’s film that blends romantic comedy with science fiction.

headline: Tomorrow’s Recriminations Today
text: If Barack Obama loses his re-election bid, there will be a host of liberals ready to argue — in a mirror-image version of the argument many conservatives made about John McCain after 2008 — that he only lost because he wasn’t liberal enough. (Mickey Kaus pre-emptively summarizes this narrative: “He’ll have lost because he wasn’t populist enough, he demoralized his base, he didn’t pursue single-payer, he foolishly tried to win over swing voters instead of registering new voters, he was too nice to the Republicans. Rachel Maddow and both her guests will nod sagely.”) There will also be a group of liberals (smaller, but perhaps more influential) who argue that Obama mostly made the right choices, but fell victim to economic forces beyond any president’s control. And then there will be the liberals (joined by some conservatives) who focus intently on monetary policy, and argue among themselves over whether the White House could have exerted more pressure on Ben Bernanke and the Federal Reserve.

headline: 36 Hours in Montreal
text: CANADA’S second-largest city may be the second-largest French-speaking metropolis on the planet (after Paris), but the attention lavished on its Frenchness — Bistros! Baguettes! People saying “Bonjour”! — tends to nudge aside the many other ethnic communities within Montreal’s remarkably diverse urban sprawl. Italians, Portuguese and Lebanese have a very visible presence, and the city hosts annual festivals dedicated to everything from Asian-American films to Caribbean food. Throw in a pulsing alternative community and creative scene (this is a place that engendered talents as diverse as Saul Bellow, Arcade Fire and the irrepressible William Shatner), and a whole new Montreal opens up. Whether your passion is Syrian cuisine, contemporary art or vintage shopping, Montreal is serving it up with aplomb. C’est vrai.

headline: Susan Stroman Will Call the Shots on ‘Bullets Over Broadway’ Musical
text: The Tony Award-winning director and choreographer Susan Stroman (“The Producers”) will perform both duties for the Woody Allen musical “Bullets Over Broadway,” an adaptation of his 1994 film that is aiming to open on Broadway during the 2013-14 theater season, the show’s producers said on Thursday.

headline: A Father, a Son and a Fighting Chance
text: WHEN my son Jeff was little, he was a pain in the neck about eating. On one drive to Huntsville, Ala., he sobbed for 70 minutes (I know because I timed it) about how we were starving him to death.

headline: As Europe’s Currency Union Frays, Conspiracy Theories Fly
text: “We need not just a currency union; we also need a so-called fiscal union, more common budget policies. And we need above all a political union. That means that we must, step by step as things go forward, give up  more powers to Europe as well and allow Europe oversight possibilities.”

headline: Greek Tourism Feeling the Strain
text: June 14, 2012 — Despite worries over the debt crisis, Greece drew a record number of tourists in 2011, but this weekend’s vital election could short circuit that growth.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Anonymous Attack and Facebook Decisions
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. See more here.

headline: Just One Look | Missoni
text: Angela Missoni looked to Chinese and British pottery for this resort season, leaving the Italian brand’s famous zigzags in the back seat (except on swimwear). Broad porcelain-blue brush strokes, ceramic-colored prints and, for diversity’s sake, polka dots — took center stage instead. Missoni also dipped its feet in more feminine silhouettes: busy printed pieces cut in A-line skirts like this one, paired with a fitted tee, got a cinch at the waistline with a wide (also printed) belt. The wedge bootie ends the sentence affirmatively.

headline: Large Works and Big Changes at Art Basel
text: BASEL, Switzerland — The day before the invitation-only opening of Art Basel, scores of collectors and dealers gathered in the cavernous building that houses Art Unlimited, the annual show of super-size artworks. Word had spread quickly about an extraordinary photo-realist painting by the Italian-born artist Rudolf Stingel. Based on a 1980s photograph of the New York dealer Paula Cooper looking glamorous with sultry eyes and a cigarette in one hand, the large canvas (it measures 11 by 15 feet) was hung dramatically in a space by itself. Its price was around $3 million, and it was bought by François Pinault, the French luxury goods magnate and owner of Christie’s, before the fair even opened.

headline: Drawing New Lines in a Romantic Triangle
text: Before gaining wider visibility as a screenwriter with “The Iron Lady,” “Shame” and the BBC series “The Hour,” Abi Morgan acquired a reputation in Britain for her formally and stylistically inventive plays, which have been compared to the work of Caryl Churchill because of their pithy language and elliptical action.

headline: Solitary Retreat to a Remote Island Leads to Many Mix-Ups
text: The three main characters in “Your Sister’s Sister,” Lynn Shelton’s new comedy of romantic confusion, are remarkably charming and pleasant company. Not always for one another, of course — hence the confusion — but certainly for all but the grouchiest moviegoer. They are articulate and funny, each one a bundle of tics, insecurities and surprising insights. The paradox is that they accomplish all of this without being especially interesting.

headline: Iran’s High Card at the Nuclear Table
text: THE rising hostilities against Iran and its atomic complex — assassinations and cyberattacks, trade bans and oil embargoes, frozen assets and banking prohibitions, among other acts open and covert — have clearly done much to bring Tehran back to negotiations, which are to resume Monday. But the drama has also tended to overshadow a central fact: the Iranians have managed to steadily increase their enrichment of uranium and are now raising their production of a concentrated form close to bomb grade.

headline: Ancient Church in Rome, Restored and Imagined
text: ROME — By the eighth century one of the earliest churches in Rome was considered quaint enough to be called Santa Maria Antiqua. The Latin name is still painted amid tiers of haloed saints in murals in the cavernous brick church, which has been largely inaccessible since 1980 on a dusty side path in the Forum.

headline: The Making of the President
text: During his 2008 campaign, Barack Obama so often stressed the improbability of his story that we have grown inured to how unlikely it really is. Everyone knows that his name, along with his inexperience, was an electoral handicap; that his mixed-race background made his victory historic; and that his transformation within five years from local Illinois politician to the most famous person on earth (and first incumbent president since Woodrow Wilson to win the Nobel Peace Prize) has no obvious parallel. The great virtue of David Maraniss’s huge and absorbing new biography is to demonstrate that Obama’s saga in its full and previously unexplored detail is more surprising and gripping than the version the world is familiar with.

headline: How James Can’t Lose
text: William C. Rhoden discusses the ability of LeBron James to be simultaneously despised and revered.

headline: Cyprus Weighs Russian Loan or a Bailout From Europe
text: Senior officials of Cyprus said Thursday that the government could seek a European Union bailout to support its struggling banks in the coming days and at the latest by the end of the month, even as they indicated the country was continuing to pursue other options, including a possible bilateral loan from Russia.

headline: When Friends Visit, the iPod Goes Off
text: Last week’s quandary: “Yesterday,” R. wrote, “my 6-year-old child and the rest of our family visited another family with a child (also 6) who spent the whole time on an iPod Touch.”

headline: Building East-West Bridges in Tune
text: Demonstrating the ways music has created connections among disparate cultures has become a minor industry within the classical concert world. Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Project has ranged freely through musical history, reviving ancient works and commissioning new ones. Early-music specialists like Joel Cohen and Jordi Savall have taken a more scholarly but equally lively approach, and Mr. Savall’s offerings have been particularly ambitious.

headline: Songs of Innocence and Aspiration
text: It always gives me pause when great expectations are heaped on a teenage performer, no matter how talented. The temptation for the singer is to swallow the hype and breathlessly await the imminent glory predicted by pundits. But it should be remembered that over the last 50 years scores of baby Barbra Streisands have been promised show business conquests that haven’t materialized. And as 18-year-old Alex Getlin, a confident, engaging young Broadway-style singer with a big voice performed her show, “You’re Gonna Hear From Me,” on Monday evening at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, I worried.

headline: Guiding a Future Star, but Finding Her Own Shine
text: When Louise Brooks, the queen of silent-movie flappers, was a wicked little minx of 15, she traveled from Wichita, Kan., to New York City to study modern dance. It was the summer of 1922, and she was accompanied by Alice Mills, who Louise would later describe as “a stocky, bespectacled housewife of 36.”

headline: A Birthday Concert in Three Parts
text: Thematic tightness is the name of the game in classical music these days. The onus is on artists to organize events that are as satisfying for the mind as for the ear.

headline: Jobs Forecast Is Steady, but Stay Tuned
text: The economic data of the past week has been close enough to expectations that Moody’s Analytics, a research firm, has not changed its forecast for job growth in coming months. As it did last week, the firm forecasts an average of 157,000 net new jobs a month in the six months leading up to Election Day. But the data has been weak enough to make the Moody’s economists nervous.

headline: A Slow Unraveling of Family Secrets
text: It would be quite possible, based on its first 10 minutes or so, to dismiss — or perhaps to celebrate — “Americano” as an exercise in cinematic nepotism. The main character, Martin, is played by Mathieu Demy, who also directed (this is his first feature) and who is the son of two great French filmmakers: Agnès Varda, the lioness of the Nouvelle Vague, and Jacques Demy, beloved by discerning romantics around the world for “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.” Martin’s girlfriend, Claire, is played by Chiara Mastroianni, daughter of the “Umbrellas” star Catherine Deneuve and Marcello Mastroianni. When a family emergency summons Martin to Los Angeles, the first person he meets is a woman named Linda, played by Geraldine Chaplin, whose pedigree hardly needs elaboration.

headline: Art Show as Unruly Organism
text: KASSEL, Germany — The longtime curator Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev has a lot on her mind, and she has managed to wedge a remarkable amount of it into Documenta 13.

headline: Margaret Dunning and Her Packard, Bound for Pebble Beach
text: Margaret Dunning, who turns 102 this month and was featured in The Times last July, was invited to show her beloved 1930 Packard in August at the Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,993 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: New Ads in Indiana Frame a Stirring Senate Race
text: Something surprising seems to be stirring in Indiana: a Senate race.

headline: Just One Look | Tory Burch
text: Tory Burch showed her resort collection in her Madison Avenue townhouse shop (near her Upper East Side home), befitting the designer’s reputation for dressing the leisure set. Burch explained that she focused on “down-to-earth fabrics, mixing brocade with a military jacket.” There were tile-print jersey dresses, traditional sun dresses in white with pintuck pleats and to-the-knee skirts (khaki with silver embellishments, brocades). “It’s how I hope I personally dress,” Burch said. Mosaic prints in sea blues were shown alongside youthful striped pencil trousers. Here, Burch pairs a brocade bandeau top in mint and gold with a military shirt and textural heavy silk skirt — the perfect look for a trip to the boulangerie in the south of France.

headline: Painting Romney With the Bush Brush
text: Mr. Obama gave a major speech in Cleveland today, by which I mean it was really long (6,607 words) and dreary. Mr. Romney spoke the day before, delivering what is now called “a prebuttal,” which is sort of like a Star Wars prequel, but just not as interesting or well-acted.

headline: Wanderer Who Still Searches for Home
text: Soothing, swaying tunes hold despair and a quest for faith in the songs of Michael Kiwanuka, who performed at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night.

headline: Songs of Love, Religious or Otherwise
text: The ancient Hebrew love poem called the “Song of Songs” has long been interpreted as a religious allegory and incorporated by Jews and Christians into scripture. In the program notes that accompanied Blue Heron’s concert on Sunday afternoon, Scott Metcalfe, the music director of this excellent Renaissance choral ensemble based in Boston, writes that for those who read the poem from a secular viewpoint, it is clearly about an amorous young couple.

headline: Syrian Liberators, Bearing Toy Guns
text: If deception has always been part of war, it has not often been as bungled as in the video announcement by Syrian opposition fighters of the formation of a special forces brigade joining the battle against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Apps I Want to Go Away
text: In my most recent Tool Kit column, I explained how to better organize the apps on your smartphone. But in the article, I wrote half a sentence that’s been bugging me:

headline: Boys Bonding and Roughhousing
text: In Larry Keigwin’s new “Contact Sport” four men dressed as schoolboys stand in front of a sparkly blue curtain. The gloriously pseudo-European voice of Eartha Kitt sings “Come on-a My House” in Japanese, and the dancers shove one another around with a combination of speed, design and play that signals choreographic wit. A good time, it seems, is in store.

headline: Gershwin Shows’ Tonys Fuel Plans for a Musical
text: Winning the Tony Award for best musical revival is great, and ’s wonderful to have two popular shows on Broadway that have potentially lucrative national tours starting next year. But for the trustees of George and Ira Gershwin’s estates the sweetest feeling this week is the satisfaction — they were loath to call it vindication — that their stewardship of the Gershwin brothers’ legacy is reaping laurels and dividends after some high-powered criticism.

headline: Heroes, Villains and the Invisible
text: It hardly needs to be said that any armed force has the potential for internal as well as external violence. But “The Invisible War,” Kirby Dick’s incendiary documentary about the epidemic of rape within the United States military, is a shocking and infuriating indictment of widespread sexual attacks on women. Such behavior, the film argues, is tacitly condoned and routinely covered up; the victims are often blamed and their reputations destroyed.

headline: Two Artists Salute a Legacy
text: POINTING her camera, the artist Carrie Mae Weems lobbed directions. “A little more smoke!” and “Women, raise your mirrors!” she instructed the performers gathered recently in a black-box theater on the Lower East Side. Geri Allen, the jazz pianist and composer, sat nearby, scribbling notes.

headline: Response to U.S.T.A. Renovations: Where’s the Roof?
text: After the United States Tennis Association revealed a renovation plan to the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center that will include a new Louis Armstrong Stadium, a new Grandstand court, improved pedestrian walkways and a two-story viewing platform that will make it easier to watch players practice, the reaction focused on what the project does not include: a roof.

headline: ‘Anything Goes’ and ‘The Lyons’ to Close
text: 6:34 p.m. | Updated  The Tony-winning revival of “Anything Goes” will close on August 5, five weeks earlier than planned but after a 565-performance run that was extended three times. And “The Lyons,” Nicky Silver’s caustic comedy of family dysfunction, will close at the Cort Theater on July 1.

headline: The Rented Guinea Pig and Other Snippets From The One-Page Magazine
text: Each week, we commission several spot illustrations for The One-Page Magazine. Because it has so much going on, the images usually end up being quite small. To commemorate the six-month anniversary of the page (which was last month), here is a belated look back at some of the more compelling illustrations, at sizes larger than you get to see in print.

headline: The First Lady’s Family
text: Twelve presidents were slaveholders, and perhaps another dozen (including the two named George Bush) came from families that once upon a time owned slaves. In common with many of our most venerable institutions, the presidency has ample connection to “slavery time”: the White House is like an Internet link that, if you click on it, bounces you to the lawn of a plantation.

headline: The Paranoid Next Door Has Guns
text: “Escape,” a new play by Susan Mosakowski, follows three eccentric pairs of neighbors, all of whom are seeking some form of liberation.

headline: New Orleans Paper Invites its Critic Back
text: 10:51 a.m. | Updated Three days after it was reported that Brett Anderson, the well-regarded restaurant critic for The Times-Picayune in New Orleans, was being laid off along with about 200 other employees, the newspaper announced on Friday that it had offered Mr. Anderson “a position writing about restaurants and dining.”

headline: Excerpt: ‘The Lathe of Heaven’
text: A scene from the Untitled Theater Company #61 production at the 3LD Art and Technology Center.

headline: Movie Listings for June 15-21
text: Movies

headline: Where Dreams of the Future Are Nightmares
text: It’s oddly encouraging that a theater only blocks away from ground zero has become a home for apocalyptic plays about damaged landscapes. New York has come a long way since Sept. 11.

headline: What He Sees May Be Closer Than He Thinks
text: Ethan Hawke, his angular features slicing across the screen, is one reason to see “The Woman in the Fifth.” Another is that this psychological thriller (or perhaps, psychothriller) about an American writer down on his luck in Paris and maybe out of his mind creates a sense of dread that builds and builds though never resolves, even in the final fade out. It doesn’t have the kind of payoff that details who did what and why, which is a problem only if you demand tidy endings. If you’re up for some narrative drift, you can just go with the ambiguous flow created by the Polish-born filmmaker Pawel Pawlikowski, who I suspect is a fan of Antonioni’s “Passenger.”

headline: Egypt’s Disarray Puts a Regional Investment Bank in Play
text: LONDON — Yasser el-Mallawany and Hassan Heikal are accustomed to turmoil. In recent years, they have steered EFG-Hermes through political upheaval, economic pain and market volatility, transforming the Egyptian financial firm into the leading investment bank in the Arab world.

headline: A Military-Style Funeral for a Young Man Killed on Harlem Streets
text: The pulpit at the Harlem church where a funeral service was held Thursday for a recent shooting victim served multiple purposes: to mourn, to pray, to preach and to advocate.

text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced on Thursday that it had been paid back for loans used to support the government bailouts of Bear Stearns and the American International Group.

headline: Mets Get Just Enough Hitting for Three-Game Sweep of Rays
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Even amid the air-conditioned confines of Tropicana Field, it was surprising how little the Mets were made to sweat this week.

headline: Let Me Get That for You
text: DOMINICK TORRES, a doorman on the Upper East Side who knows the name of almost every tenant in his 689-unit building, says he can often spot a certain something in the eye of new residents. Whether it manifests itself as unease or presumption, it is the look of someone who has never lived in a building with a doorman before, and does not know quite how to act.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 15-21
text: TEEN NIGHT

headline: Roominess Takes On New Significance
text: STEPHANIE RUDNICK never cooked. She even had the gas turned off in her Chelsea studio, though she sometimes heated frozen dumplings in the microwave.

headline: Obama in Cleveland
text: President Obama delivered a speech on the economy in Cleveland.

headline: Documenta 13
text: Scenes from the art show in Kassel, Germany.

headline: A Hospital With Fine Bones
text: CHARTERED in 1771, New York Hospital is the city’s oldest, having made peripatetic progress up Manhattan Island. In 1932 it opened a broad new campus at 68th Street and the East River, with a central tower rising in an upward cascade of almost-white masonry, Gothic arches and intricate brickwork 350 feet high. Generally, medical institutions and architectural sensibility do not coexist well, but New York Hospital, today NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, has managed, through circumstance and design, to keep much of its architectural character in good health.

headline: Taking Advantage of Low Rates
text: THE mortgage market seems to have been dancing its own version of the limbo, as interest rates headed lower and lower for six consecutive weeks.

headline: Q & A
text: Co-op Shareholder Kept in the Dark

headline: Echoes of Better Times
text: THE evidence is beginning to stack up. In Seaford, a couple selling a house listed at $369,000 received three competitive offers on the day of the first open house.

text: To the Editor:

headline: When the Appraisal Sinks the Deal
text: IN White Plains recently, 16 couples attended an open house at a wood-frame colonial with four bedrooms and two and a half baths listed for $799,000.

headline: Restructuring Nepal
text: To the Editor:

headline: Housing Funds Face a Deadline
text: PHONES in the offices of Morris Habitat for Humanity have been ringing off the hook lately as town officials throughout Morris County have been seeking its help in spending money. The same has been true for other nonprofit housing groups in New Jersey, as local governments scramble to use up affordable-housing funds before they are forfeited to the state.

headline: Sebastian Vettel in New Jersey
text: The racer Sebastian Vettel drives spirited laps on the New Jersey streets where the Grand Prix of America is expected to be run.

text: To the Editor:

headline: The Caucus Click: The Obamas Visit One World Trade Center
text: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, visited One World Trade Center on Thursday, and signed one of the final steel beams to be added to the building.

headline: Archers in Queens
text: Archers of all skill levels, from the rankest novices to competitors who might survive the “Hunger Games,” can be found at Pro Line, an indoor archery range in Queens.

headline: The Rush of Hitting the Bull’s-Eye
text: BEGINNERS on an archery range are almost as easy to spot as the targets: just look for a mean black-and-blue patch where a bowstring has sliced against an incorrectly positioned bicep. Few injuries inspire such rapid correction of form.

headline: Glass Is Pretty but, He Hopes, Troubling, Too
text: JOSIAH McELHENY’S studio is strangely unremarkable. A narrow office furnished with a desk, a drawing table and library shelves packed with books, it betrays few signs of art making, just a couple of rows of neatly pinned photocopied images and black pencil drawings on one white wall.

headline: Glass Darkly
text: A look at the work of the artist Josiah McElheny.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 15, 2012
text: The New York Times film critics on “Rock of Ages,” “The Woman in the Fifth” and “Your Sister’s Sister.”

headline: For Some Druggists, Medicaid Changes Mean Pain
text: Not long after the state rolled pharmacies into Medicaid managed care in March — an effort to save tens of millions of dollars a year — Ronald Barrett noticed something unusual at his store, Oak Cliff Pharmacy in southern Dallas. When he entered a child’s prescription into his computer to see how much he would be reimbursed by CVS Caremark, the managed care plan’s pharmacy benefit manager, he got an error message. A phone call indicated that the prescription had already been filled, at a CVS pharmacy down the road.

headline: The ‘Heady Rush’ of Freedom in College, and How to Manage It
text: Ariha Setalvad, who is studying journalism and psychology as an undergraduate at New York University, was raised in India and graduated from B.D. Somani International School in Mumbai. She is a summer intern on The Choice blog.

headline: Give Schools the Power to Punish
text: SINCE November, when the investigation into sexual abuse at Penn State University dominated the news, the nation’s attention has repeatedly turned to such abuse in schools. Similar allegations followed at Syracuse University and in many athletic programs in schools across the United States.

headline: Candidates Provide a Test for El Paso
text: Ahead of the state’s May 29 primary, Beto O’Rourke, a Democratic candidate in Congressional District 16, wanted to talk about something other than decriminalizing marijuana.

headline: Forthcoming Facebook Motion Said to Discuss Nasdaq’s Role in I.P.O.
text: Facebook is preparing for battle.

headline: The Old Neighborhood, in India
text: “Patang” (“The Kite”), Prashant Bhargava’s first feature, has a lovely, unforced quality. That’s because Mr. Bhargava lets his story, set during the annual kite festival in Ahmedabad, India, tell itself, unfolding slowly as he follows filmmaking’s most basic and most sinned-against dictum: Show, don’t tell.

headline: Redistricting for Ethnicity Isn’t Always a Sure Thing
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Jurors Begin Deliberations in Insider Trading Trial
text: As head of the elite consulting firm McKinsey & Company, Rajat K. Gupta associated with corporate chieftains and heads of state around the world.

headline: A Hip-Hop History, by Those Who Made It
text: “You write complicated rhymes,” Ice-T says to Eminem in the new film “Something From Nothing: The Art of Rap.” Do they start out that way, he continues, or do you complicate them?

headline: Mountain People With a Bad Reputation
text: A nagging junior high memory prompts a perilous trek to the back of beyond in “Ikland,” Cevin Soling and David Hilbert’s offbeat meditation on human nature and academic hubris.

headline: Ari Seth Cohen’s Portraits of Older Women
text: Discovering Mimi Weddell, the gauntly stylish actress who, at 90, was the subject of a 2009 documentary, was a turning point for Ari Seth Cohen. Mr. Cohen, a 20-something photographer living in Seattle at the time, quickly decamped for Manhattan in pursuit of his new fashion idol.

headline: How Greece Squandered Its Freedom
text: Athens

headline: Brooklyn Bridge Park Expected to Announce Developers of a New Hotel Complex
text: The Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation is expected to vote on Tuesday to select Toll Brothers and Starwood Capital Group as the development team for a new hotel and residential complex that will be built in the park next to Pier 1, just south of the Brooklyn Bridge, according to an official with knowledge of the deal.

headline: Judge Dismisses Mobley’s Lawsuit
text: A federal judge Wednesday dismissed Cuttino Mobley’s lawsuit against Madison Square Garden for forcing him to retire from the Knicks in 2008, soon after being acquired, because of a heart condition.

headline: How the Supreme Court Could Rule on the Health Care Law
text: What could happen to the health care law depending on what the Supreme Court decides on key questions.

headline: Sensible Sentences for Nonviolent Offenders
text: The enormous strain prison costs put on state budgets has led some conservatives and liberals to do something sensible together. Democrats and Republicans in several states are pushing to reform criminal justice policies based on strong evidence that imprisoning nonviolent offenders for ever longer terms adds huge costs with little benefit to public safety.

headline: Strangers, With Aliens Above
text: Alien invasion is just an excuse for romantic farce in “Extraterrestrial,” a tiresome roundelay of lies, lust and leaping paranoia.

headline: Bad Dad, With Junior’s Wedding to Spoil
text: Rejoice, fifth-grade fellas! “That’s My Boy” is a movie just for you. It has beer, hot-for-teacher sex, beer, gross-out sex, beer, strip clubs, beer, lots of bodily fluids and, mostly, a family of blue bloods gaga over an uncouth man-child.

headline: Merkel Stresses Limits to Germany’s Strength
text: BERLIN — Europe’s currency union may be inching ever closer to the brink of collapse, but Chancellor Angela Merkel has a message for those pressing her to ride to the rescue: Germany is not as strong as it looks, and certainly not strong enough to prop up the rest of Europe.

headline: Asia Is Rising When It Comes to Expatriates’ Costs, Too
text: Mercer, a human resources consultancy, has released its annual survey ranking cities according to the cost of living for expatriates. Tokyo regained its place at the top, as last year’s No. 1, Luanda, Angola, slipped a notch. Of course, this is not a list that it necessarily pays to be at the top of.

headline: President Obama in Albany
text: President Obama spoke to supporters in Albany.

headline: Behind Those Cool Squirts in Summer, Many Plumbers
text: So many fountains. So little time.

headline: Call Girl Dies, Manhunt to Follow
text: There’s a lot to like about the action film “The Girl From the Naked Eye,” especially some crisp martial arts fight sequences and the subtle sense of humor that surfaces now and then. But the filmmakers make a mistake in telling the story via flashback and a voice-over by Jason Yee, who plays Jake, the main character. As graceful as Mr. Yee is in those fights, he proves that delivering a compelling voice-over is harder than it seems.

headline: In the Facebook Era, Reminders of Loss After Families Fracture
text: Not long ago, estrangements between family members, for all the anguish they can cause, could mean a fairly clean break. People would cut off contact, never to be heard from again unless they reconciled.

headline: After Century-Long Wait, Stage Is Set for Man Daring to Cross the Falls
text: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. — The last time a man walked across the Niagara Gorge, Grover Cleveland was president. Utah had just become a state. And, that same year, the first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens.

headline: Payback From Mom and Dad
text: Murkily shot and lazily plotted, “The Tortured” is the latest bone tossed in the general direction of flayed-flesh enthusiasts. And notwithstanding a smidgen of originality in the unpleasantly familiar setup of helpless victim and instrument-wielding sadist, this wearying entry in the canon suggests only that ferreting out new ways to inflict pain requires more imagination than anyone on hand realized.

headline: Breaking Ties Is Complicated
text: So you think you know the tiebreaking procedure in the group stage of the European Championships as the third round of matches approaches?

headline: Understanding the European Crisis Now
text: Europe’s debt crisis has been caused by too much sovereign debt and growing problems in its banking system.

headline: Burnett Brings a Steady Presence to the Pirates
text: BALTIMORE — Outside it was pouring, a cold and sideways rainstorm that wiped out batting practice Tuesday at Camden Yards. Yet the pitchers still needed to throw, so A. J. Burnett dressed at his locker stall in the visitors’ clubhouse and got ready. While he did, he explained what he tells his younger teammates on the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: Libya Refuses to Release Hague Court Workers
text: PARIS — Despite pressure from international courts, NATO and rights groups, the Libyan authorities who are detaining a lawyer from the International Criminal Court and three members of the court’s staff say they will not be released until the lawyer answers questions about her dealings with Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of the former dictator, a Libyan official in Tripoli said.

headline: We Don’t Need No Education
text: Hope springs eternal. For a few hours I was ready to applaud Mitt Romney for speaking honestly about what his calls for smaller government actually mean.

headline: Dialysis Company’s Failure to Warn of Product Risk Draws Inquiry
text: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating whether the nation’s largest operator of dialysis centers violated federal regulations by failing to inform customers of a potentially lethal risk connected to one of its products, an F.D.A. official said.

headline: Sniff Test Does Not Prove Public Drinking, a Judge Rules
text: The police in New York City wrote 124,498 summonses last year for drinking in public — far more than for any other violation. After having to adjudicate so many of these public drinking cases, a Brooklyn judge has decided he has had enough.

headline: The Democratic Road Not Taken
text: For more than four decades most Americans identified the Democratic Party with a social contract and safety net, equality of justice and opportunity, and progressive — yes, even liberal — causes. Sometime in the last 30 years the party of progress and change — Emerson’s party of hope — became the party of reactionary liberalism.

headline: Gardner’s Elbow Needs More Rest
text: Outfielder Brett Gardner will get an additional three to four weeks of rest and his injured elbow will be placed in a brace during that period, the Yankees said.

headline: No Theft Charge for Chronic Fatigue Researcher
text: Nevada authorities have dropped criminal charges against a researcher who gained wide attention for scientific reports linking chronic fatigue syndrome to an obscure mouse retrovirus.

headline: Na Still Sore After Minor Fender Bender
text: Eight days before the start of the United States Open, Kevin Na was involved in a minor fender bender in Southern California while visiting his parents. The car he was driving was stopped at a light, he said, when it was rear-ended by a car that he estimated was traveling 40 miles an hour. He hasn’t felt right since the collision.

headline: A Senate Primary Stuck in the Shadows
text: ALBANY — Wendy E. Long, a Manhattan lawyer, is trumpeting endorsements from conservatives like the antitax activist Grover G. Norquist, the diplomat John R. Bolton and the former presidential candidate Steve Forbes.

headline: Survival Skill Abandoned By Schools
text: On the warm days of summer, merry pilgrims depart a city where a fair number of public school swimming pools have been dry so long that they are used to store office supplies, and where generations have grown up with no more ability to swim than a box of photocopy paper.

headline: The Clown and the Cop
text: Trapped with a Fox News big screen in my stable of trotters at the gym a few weeks ago, I took in the worldview that may give the White House to Republicans this year. After burning 400 calories, I was ready to torch the capital.

headline: Secession and Ascension in St. Louis
text: “The Unionists would all go to hell, and the secessionists to heaven.”

headline: Russian Official Apologizes for Threatening Journalist
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s chief federal investigator apologized on Thursday for an “emotional breakdown,” a day after he was publicly accused of threatening the life of a journalist.

headline: Bahrain Compounds the Injustice
text: Bahrain had a chance to correct a grave injustice and set the country on a better path by dismissing specious cases against 20 Shiite doctors convicted last year after they treated protesters injured during the popular uprising against the Sunni-led monarchy. Instead, the High Criminal Court of Appeal on Thursday upheld the convictions of nine of them and imposed sentences of up to five years in jail. And 15-year sentences against two other doctors, who have fled the country, were upheld.

headline: Armstrong Seemingly Readies for Battle
text: Earlier this spring, Lance Armstrong said he would not fight any more doping charges that cropped up against him because he was tired of it. But now that the United States Anti-Doping Agency is set to bring formal charges against him, it appears that he has changed his mind.

headline: Anything-but-Ordinary Mom Pitches for Chobani Yogurt
text: TOO bad for Greece, and perhaps the euro, that the Greek economy is in no way helped by the surging popularity of Greek yogurt among American shoppers. In another sign of that interest, Chobani, the market leader in Greek yogurt in this country, is stepping up efforts to sell its new children’s product.

headline: Smithfield Foods’ Profit Drops on Lower Margins for Pork
text: RICHMOND, Va. (AP) — Smithfield Foods, the pork producer, said Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 19 percent on lower margins on fresh pork, slow sales growth and higher selling costs.

headline: Ground Zero Cancers
text: Federal health officials took a reasonable and humane step last week when they proposed to add 50 cancers to the list of illnesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund to treat and compensate emergency workers and residents exposed to toxic fumes, dust and smoke from the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Parlors Face Age-Limit Bill Over Tanning by Teenagers
text: Under a bill working its way through Albany, teenagers under 17 would be able to get suntans only the old-fashioned way: from the sun.

headline: In a Star Pairing, Woods Is the Star
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The first tee box at the hilly Olympic Club is a tabletop plateau perched 25 feet above a winding sidewalk. The customary way to reach the tee is a 15-step staircase.

headline: The Political Contrast
text: President Obama sometimes forgets that an important speech does not have to be endless. On Thursday, appearing before supporters at a Cleveland community college, he spent 53 minutes on the stark contrast between his goals and the failed Bush-era policies that Mitt Romney is trying to resurrect. It’s hard to imagine that the speech, overgrown as it was with policy details, won the hearts of many independent voters yearning for a clear understanding of how much is at stake in November.

headline: Accused Chinese Party Members Face Harsh Discipline
text: BEIJING — Membership in the Chinese Communist Party has many advantages. Officials often enjoy government-issued cars, bottomless expense accounts and the earning potential from belonging to a club whose members control every lever of government and many of the nation’s most lucrative enterprises.

headline: Before Retrial of Lawmaker, More Discord
text: A federal judge in Manhattan raised questions on Thursday about aspects of the government’s corruption case against City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook, whose retrial is scheduled to begin on Tuesday.

headline: What Republicans Think
text: Democrats frequently ask me why the Republicans have become so extreme. As they describe the situation, they usually fall back on some sort of illness metaphor. Republicans have a mania. President Obama has said that Republicans have a “fever” that he hopes will break if he is re-elected.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Stanley Comfortable With New Caddie
text: After closing with a 69 in Memphis in his final tuneup for the Open, Kyle Stanley made a radical move. He fired his caddie, Brett Waldman, who was on his bag for his first tour victory in February in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Shot by Officer After Car Crash, Woman Dies
text: A woman was fatally shot by a plainclothes New York City police detective on Thursday after running a series of red lights in a stolen vehicle in Brooklyn, colliding head-on with a minivan, then scrambling to evade the police, the authorities said.

headline: Revolt Leaders Cite Failure to Uproot Old Order in Egypt
text: CAIRO — They toppled a pharaoh, but now the small circle of liberals, leftists and Islamists who orchestrated Egypt’s revolution say they realize they failed to uproot the networks of power that Hosni Mubarak nurtured for nearly three decades.

headline: A Police Hot Line for Abuse Claims at Horace Mann
text: The New York Police Department said Thursday that it would join the effort to identify past victims of abuse at the Horace Mann School, creating a confidential hot line for “anyone with information, regardless of how old, about inappropriate sexual contact by adults with students.”

headline: New Detroit-to-Canada Bridge to Be Unveiled
text: American and Canadian leaders are to unveil plans on Friday for a new bridge linking Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, opening a new chapter in a long and contentious debate over the future of a region that has become one of the nation’s busiest border crossings.

headline: Pressured, E.P.A. Proposes Soot Limit
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed new national air quality standards that would significantly reduce levels of fine-particle soot.

headline: What Was Yours at One Time
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — To what extent do you recognize and appreciate when an entry in a crossword puzzle is “fresh,” or is appearing for the first time (in The New York Times, anyway)?

headline: Hope Is a Thing With Long, Fuzzy Ears
text: During the heyday of Studio 54 it was probably not unusual for patrons to see visions of strange beasts roaming the dance floor. And didn’t Bianca Jagger once make an appearance on a white horse?

headline: Pop Warner Weighing Research and Risks in Concussion Prevention Efforts
text: The unremarkable football career of Dr. Julian Bailes, who is now the chairman of the Pop Warner medical advisory board, ended quietly during his college days in the 1970s. He never sustained a concussion that he knew of, but he can recall a friend in high school who did. Confused and concussed, his friend started describing a car he had just bought; there was no new car, and Bailes found it hilarious. “We didn’t know any better,” he said.

headline: ‘Caribbean: Crossroads of the World’
text: Images from the three-museum exhibition.

headline: Mayoral Hopes Seen as Muting Quinn's Voice
text: As Christine C. Quinn carefully builds her campaign for mayor, she has gone on national television to talk about the importance of honoring the nation’s veterans, issued statements about gay rights victories around the country and donned a hoodie to express her concern about the killing of a Florida teenager, Trayvon Martin.

headline: British and Iranian Officials Meet to Discuss Rift
text: The foreign ministers of Britain and Iran conferred on the sidelines of a security conference in Afghanistan on Thursday, the highest-level contact between the two nations since relations were nearly severed after protesters in Tehran overran and pillaged the British Embassy and a diplomatic residence in November.

headline: Oregon Justices Approve Release of Boy Scouts’ ‘Perversion Files’
text: SEATTLE — Oregon’s highest court cleared the way on Thursday for the release of thousands of pages of documents detailing accusations and investigations of sexual abuse or other improprieties by Boy Scout leaders around the nation from the mid-1960s into the 1980s.

headline: A Player in His Third Major Grabs the Lead and the Attention
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With its sloping fairways and slanted greens, the Olympic Club calls to mind a wood labyrinth maze game, with the golf ball replacing the steel ball as the object to be maneuvered around the pitfall-filled Lake Course.

headline: 14-Year-Old Struggles in Opening Rounds
text: Andy Zhang, a 14-year-old, got off to an inauspicious start to the United States Open with a triple bogey, a double bogey and a bogey on the first three holes. He was eight over after five before playing his final 13 holes in one over to post a 79, one stroke worse than the reigning Masters champion, Bubba Watson.

headline: Giants Add Technology to Their Training Staff
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants General Manager Jerry Reese looked out a window at the team’s training facility one day last summer and quickly became confused. He knew that Manchester United, the British soccer power, was training at the facility ahead of its match with all-stars from Major League Soccer, but he had no idea what the players were wearing.

headline: Key Events in the Egyptian Transition Imbroglio
text: The Supreme Constitutional Court’s decision to dissolve the elected Islamist-majority Parliament is the latest blow in the struggle for power in Egypt.

headline: Vast Defenses Now Shielding New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — Finally, there is a wall around this city.

headline: Shades of ’69: A Winning Team From Washington Takes on the Yankees
text: In the 1969 summer of Woodstock, something mildly hallucinogenic was going on hundreds of miles away in Washington. The Senators, a famously bad team that had finished over .500 only four times in the previous 35 seasons, had become pretty decent.

headline: City Official on Special Ed Plan: 'This Is Going Forward'
text: City officials said its new citywide special education plan, which is supposed to take effect in the fall, is moving forward. Staff training is ongoing. Better communication is on the way. And, says Corinne Rello-Anselmi, the city’s incoming deputy chancellor for special education, there will be no delays: "This reform will no longer be a reform. It will be the way we do school.”

headline: Obama Visits New York for Star-Studded Fund-Raisers
text: President Obama swept through New York on Thursday evening for a pair of high-dollar, high-wattage fund-raisers where some of the city’s top fashion luminaries lent their cash and their star power to his re-election campaign.

headline: Research in Motion Reveals Multimillion-Dollar Pay for Former Chief Executives
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion gave its former co-chief executives about $12 million in exit payments after they stepped down this year, the BlackBerry maker disclosed in a securities filing on Thursday.

headline: The Vatican: A Reconciliation Bid
text: The Vatican said Thursday that it had proposed granting the Society of St. Pius X a special legal status as part of a continued effort on the part of Pope Benedict XVI toward reconciliation with the breakaway traditionalist group. The status of “personal prelature,” similar to a diocese without specific boundaries, was introduced during the Second Vatican Council and until now has been given only to the conservative Opus Dei movement. The proposal was made during a meeting between Bishop Bernard Fellay, superior general of the Society of St. Pius X, and Cardinal William J. Levada, the Vatican’s chief doctrinal officer, to discuss elements of the “doctrinal preamble” that the group must accept before reconciliation can be reached. Bishop Fellay promised to respond in a “reasonable” amount of time. The group does not have canonical status in the church. In 1988 Pope John Paul II excommunicated Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the group’s founder, as well as four bishops he consecrated without the Vatican’s approval.

headline: Photo Replay: June 14
text: The day in sports included the European Championships, the United States Open and a Stanley Cup championship parade.

headline: Cubs, Under Epstein, Recalling Red Sox of September
text: CHICAGO — On a 90-degree Memorial Day afternoon at Wrigley Field, Theo Epstein stood outside the Cubs’ dugout, calmly faced a scrum of reporters and answered questions about his team’s 12-game losing streak.

headline: Holder to Comply in Part With Gun Inquiry Request
text: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric. H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that he was willing to partially comply with a subpoena for documents from the Justice Department about a gun-trafficking operation known as “Fast and Furious.”

headline: Word of the Day | quiescent
text: quiescent •\kwi-ˈe-sənt, kwe-\• adjective

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Finance Jobs Still Appeal to Graduates at Dartmouth
text: Wall Street’s allure may have dimmed for some of America’s sharpest young minds in recent years, but a quick look at the top of Dartmouth College’s class of 2012 shows that the appeal seems to remain strong. At its commencement on Sunday, Dartmouth recognized four valedictorians who graduated with perfect 4.0 grade-point averages. Three are headed to work on Wall Street at major investment banks, and one will go to the giant business consulting firm that advises them.

headline: James Makes a Stand, and Delivers
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — In the moment everyone waited for, the one that had filled giddy previews and stoked barroom conversations, Kevin Durant and LeBron James squared off, stared each other down and pressed against each other, fighting for just a few inches of floor space late Thursday night.

headline: Watney Records Third Double Eagle in Open History
text: Nick Watney holed out from the fairway for a double eagle at the par-5 17th. He hit a 5-iron from 190 yards to record the third double eagle in United States Open history. The other two were posted by T. C. Chen in the first round at Oakland Hills Country Club in 1985 and Shaun Micheel in the fourth round at Pebble Beach in 2010.

headline: Tribe Seeks Reopening of Inquiries in ’70s Deaths
text: PINE RIDGE INDIAN RESERVATION, S.D. — Forty years after the siege at Wounded Knee by members of the American Indian Movement, the Oglala Sioux tribe has demanded that the federal government reopen dozens of cases it says the F.B.I. may have mishandled decades ago.

headline: Suspect in ’95 Tokyo Attack Is Said to Be Caught
text: TOKYO — The man thought to be the final suspect from the doomsday cult behind the 1995 nerve-gas poisoning in a crowded subway station here that killed 13 people and sickened thousands of others was arrested on Friday, the police said.

headline: In Mumbai, a Campaign Against Restroom Injustice
text: “Men and women here in India’s largest city, a congested, humanity-soaked metropolis of roughly 20 million residents, would seem bound by at least one common misery: far too many people sharing far too few toilets,” Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times.

headline: In Return, Martin Has ‘Good Day’ With a 74
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Casey Martin admitted that he was nervous returning to the Olympic Club, 14 years after playing here in the 1998 United States Open. He hit a poor drive on the first hole and made bogey. Then he hit a worse shot from the fairway on the second hole.

headline: James Can't Lose
text: William C. Rhoden discusses LeBron James’s ability to be simultaneously despised and revered.

headline: Songwriters Hall of Fame Honors Inductees
text: Gordon Lightfoot, Bob Seger and Jim Steinman – who wrote the songs on Meatloaf’s “Bat Out of Hell” album – were among the tunesmiths inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame on Thursday at a ceremony in New York.

headline: Toilets Become a Battle Cry in India
text: You could be forgiven for thinking that safety is the top concern for travelers brave enough to venture on Indian railways.

headline: Corrections: June 15
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: To Fix Europe’s Economy, Understand One Size Does Not Fit All
text: Close families and flexible labor markets don’t go together. That’s the conclusion of a fascinating paper by a quartet of transatlantic economists, whose work I discuss in my column this week.Their research is a timely reminder that, unlike the laws of physics, to which practitioners of the dismal science yearn to be compared, economic policy is not one-size-fits-all. Something that works in one nation — flexible labor markets, for instance — may work very differently in another country, where behaviors and preferences are shaped by another culture.

headline: On Facebook? So Are Your Future In-Laws
text: You would expect Spoorthi Gadde, 25, of Bangalore, who has a master’s degree from a top-notch engineering school, to be out and about on social networks — more so since she is single, tech-savvy and employed by a leading outsourcing company.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 15, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Nik Wallenda Prepares for His Niagara Falls Stunt.”

headline: U.N. Team In Syria Is Imperiled, Leader Says
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Maj. Gen. Robert Mood, the head of the United Nations observer mission in Syria, presented a gloomy assessment of its prospects on Friday, even as the government and its opposition accused each other of fomenting bloodshed around the weekly Muslim prayer services.

headline: With ‘Safety First’ as Motto, Youth Football Changes Rules
text: WHAT youth football organization announced new rules to limit harmful contact?WHAT, exactly, are the new regulations?

headline: Central Banks Stand at Ready to Fortify Euro
text: With an election looming in Greece that could determine the future of the euro, central bankers overseas signaled Friday that they were prepared to take action to shore up nervous financial markets after Sunday’s vote.

headline: Exploring African-American Fatherhood
text: What compels you to shoot? That was the question David Alan Harvey asked his students during a workshop last year in Brooklyn. We all have our reasons — if not our obsessions — flashes of realization that come through the viewfinder and into our hearts. For Zun Lee, one of the students, the answer was uneasily evident.

headline: What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
text: Our Summer Reading Contest begins!

headline: Shifting the Paradigm for Training Racehorses
text: On Sunday afternoon of Memorial Day weekend, I stood at the outer rail along the backstretch at Saratoga Race Course watching horses and riders warming up and competing.

headline: The Early Word: ‘Make-or-Break’
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Despite Ruling by W.H.O., Advocates of Clean Diesel Stay the Course
text: This week, when the World Health Organization added diesel fumes to its list of Group 1 carcinogens — a list that includes asbestos, cigarette smoke and radiation — it put some automakers, as well as advocates of diesel vehicles, on the defensive.

headline: Hong Kong Exchange to Buy London Metal Exchange for $2.1 Billion
text: 1:57 p.m. | Updated Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing agreed on Friday to buy the London Metal Exchange for £1.38 billion, or $2.14 billion, in another sign of Asia’s importance to the world’s commodities industry.
