headline: Police Arrest Suspect in ’95 Tokyo Attack
text: TOKYO — Japanese police on Friday arrested the man thought to be the final suspect from the doomsday cult behind a 1995 deadly poison gas attack on Tokyo’s subways, at last bringing to an end a 17-year-old manhunt.

headline: Greece to Tourists: Keep Coming
text: LONDON — Taking a vacation in Greece this year may feel a bit like intruding on private grief.

headline: Cocaine Incorporated
text: One afternoon last August, at a hospital on the outskirts of Los Angeles, a former beauty queen named Emma Coronel gave birth to a pair of heiresses. The twins, who were delivered at 3:50 and 3:51, respectively, stand to inherit some share of a fortune that Forbes estimates is worth a billion dollars. Coronel’s husband, who was not present for the birth, is a legendary tycoon who overcame a penurious rural childhood to establish a wildly successful multinational business. If Coronel elected to leave the entry for “Father” on the birth certificates blank, it was not because of any dispute over patrimony. More likely, she was just skittish about the fact that her husband, Joaquín Guzmán, is the C.E.O. of Mexico’s Sinaloa cartel, a man the Treasury Department recently described as the world’s most powerful drug trafficker. Guzmán’s organization is responsible for as much as half of the illegal narcotics imported into the United States from Mexico each year; he may well be the most-wanted criminal in this post-Bin Laden world. But his bride is a U.S. citizen with no charges against her. So authorities could only watch as she bundled up her daughters and slipped back across the border to introduce them to their dad.

headline: How a Detroit Landlord Made His Properties Hot
text: As we all know, Detroit has taken some hits during the economic downturn. But residents like Eric Brown, a real estate developer, are fighting back. The president of Urbane Apartments, Mr. Brown used his social media savvy to turn his Motor City apartment complexes into attractive locations for young professionals. He has built an online community and made Urbane Apartments a hub for all things cool and fun in Detroit.

headline: Putting China’s Economic Power in Perspective
text: In January, David Leonhardt noted a finding that more Americans said China was the world’s leading superpower than said the United States was. New global survey data from Pew Research Center suggests this view is becoming more widespread around the world — although, tellingly, not in China itself.

headline: Singular Focus on the Economy Leads to One-Note Campaigns
text: NEWS FLASH! Mitt Romney thinks President Obama has failed to deliver the economic recovery Americans deserve.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: That’s Amore: Italy as Muse
text: “I WANTED nothing more than to be a foreign filmmaker,” Woody Allen said recently, “but of course I was from Brooklyn, which was not a foreign country. Through a happy accident I wound up being a foreign filmmaker because I couldn’t raise money any other way.”

headline: Walcott Pushes for Easier Firing in Sexual Misconduct Cases
text: The New York City schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, is ramping up his efforts to accelerate discipline for teachers accused of sexual misconduct, holding a rare news conference Friday morning to again make his case and writing about the issue in an Op-Ed article in The New York Times.

headline: Opinion Report: Prison Sentences
text: From the editorial page

headline: Outrage in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s revolution is back to square one. The political forces currently at play are the same ones that struggled against each other back in prerevolutionary Egypt: the conservative Islamist group and former President Hosni Mubarak’s National Democratic Party. This has been the case since the results of the first round of presidential elections were announced, but this week the country’s beleaguered transition to democracy was dealt a body blow.

headline: Can a Small Country Have a Big Heart?
text: TEL AVIV – A few dozen illegal migrants from a handful of African countries were arrested by the Israeli authorities earlier this week, just as the country was getting ready to deport several thousand other illegal migrants. Government action against illegal immigration is finally noticeable; promises made a long time ago are finally being fulfilled.  A crisis has been averted — or so the government would like Israelis to believe.

headline: Gujarat Kite Festival Inspires ‘Patang’
text: It’s fitting that the opening of a movie about a kite festival should be celebrated with a kite-flying party, but the incessant rain in New York City on Tuesday night kept the kites grounded at the event marking the U.S. release of “Patang.”

headline: The Shirt Off His Back
text: Dear Diary: Not long ago, I got off the express bus at Madison Square Park with a friend to attend a business dinner at a smart restaurant nearby. A young man holding an instrument case rushed over to my friend and asked if he would sell the black shirt that he was wearing.

headline: A Pantomime of Justice
text: MONTREAL — The right to be present at your own trial is a core civil right. Certainly, article 125 of Venezuela’s criminal procedure code bans in-absentia trials. Which is why, when faced with an attempt to sentence one of his clients who was not in the courtroom, the Venezuelan defense attorney José Amalio Graterol objected forcefully and refused to participate in an obviously illegal procedure.

headline: China to Investigate Death of Labor Activist
text: BEIJING — Chinese officials, bending to public pressure, have announced an investigation into the death of a veteran labor activist whose body was found hanging from a hospital window this month, days after he gave a series of interviews in which he vowed to continue fighting to end the Communist Party’s monopoly on power.

headline: Tip of the Week: Jumping to the Jump List
text: Jump lists — those pop-up windows that list recently used Web sites, actions, files and folders for programs in the Windows 7 Start menu and taskbar — are easy to see with a quick right-click of the mouse on a program button. For a faster and more fluid way to open the jump list from a taskbar icon, you can also press the mouse’s left button and quickly drag the cursor in an upward motion to reveal the items on that particular jump list.

headline: Daily Report: Social Networks and the Pain of Estrangement
text: In a social network world, estrangement among family members is being redefined, with new complications, Catherine Saint Louis reports in Friday’s New York Times.

headline: Jeremy Jordan Added to Cast of NBC’s ‘Smash’
text: Extra, extra! Hey, look at the headline! By night (and on matinee days), Jeremy Jordan is a Broadway star playing the leader of a feisty gang of turn-of-the-20th-century newspaper boys. Now, by day and in whatever free time he has left, he’ll be playing one of the aspiring Broadway stars hoping to hit it big in a developing musical about the life of Marilyn Monroe on “Smash.”

headline: Werk-ing Girl | Edeline Lee
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: On Eve of Vote, Egypt’s Military Extends Its Power
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers moved to consolidate power Friday on the eve of the presidential runoff election, shutting down the Islamist-led Parliament, locking out lawmakers and seizing the sole right to issue laws even after a new head of state takes office.

headline: Friday Flashback: Against East German Swimmers in ’76, a Medal and a Lot of Questions
text: Wendy Boglioli once was a kid who learned how to swim in a lake in her native Land O’Lakes, Wis., with her dad coaching her alongside while paddling a rowboat.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Painful Online Updates, and Ending a What-I-Ate-at-School Blog
text: 11:02 a.m. | Updated Facebook and other social media services have been credited with maintaining ties that would normally have faded away — grade school friends, say — but that advantage can turn cruel for families that have become estranged, Catherine Saint Louis writes. It often prevents a clean break, with parents keeping up with an estranged child from afar. She writes:

headline: Friday Reading: Facebook Complicates Family Estrangements
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Report Details History of Abuse in Australian Military
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Newly released documents detail numerous cases of physical and sexual abuse of minors in Australia’s armed forces dating back to the 1950s, prompting Prime Minister Julia Gillard on Friday to raise the possibility of a high-level public inquiry.

headline: Still A Phantom Menace
text: The policy response to financial crisis has, in effect, given us a great natural experiment in macroeconomics — an experiment that can and should be viewed as a test of two views of the economy. One view — which includes both freshwater macro and much of what Austrians say — is in effect classical macro as Keynes described it, in which the economy is always constrained by supply. The other is a more or less Keynesian view in which a depressed economy is constrained by demand, not supply.

headline: Tibetan Herder Dies After Setting Himself on Fire in Government Protest
text: BEIJING — A Tibetan herder in China’s northwest Qinghai Province died on Friday after setting himself on fire to protest government policies in the region, according to exile groups and Radio Free Asia.

headline: America Movil Increases Stake in Telekom Austria
text: BERLIN — America Movil, the Latin American phone carrier owned by billionaire Carlos Slim Helu, said on Friday that it had reached an agreement to increase its stake in Telekom Austria, the country’s leading operator, to 23 percent, advancing the Mexican investor’s push into the European telecommunications market.

headline: This Week’s Movies: June 15
text: In today’s edition of This Week’s Movies, Manohla Dargis digs into the hair band nostalgia of “Rock of Ages,” A. O. Scott unpacks Lynn Shelton’s latest indie comedy “Your Sister’s Sister” and Ms. Dargis takes a closer look at the psychological thriller “The Woman in the Fifth,” starring Ethan Hawke. Full reviews for these and all of this week’s releases can be found here.

headline: ‘Federalism by Exception’
text: My column this week has a quotation from Angela Merkel:

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New Yorker: Wines from New Jersey rival top French wines in a recent re-enactment of the 1976 Judgment of Paris tasting. Since the word is now out, I will happily accept your good Burgundies in exchange for some of New Jersey’s finest. — Eric Asimov

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Rachel Swarns talks about Michelle Obama’s family history; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Dexter Filkins discusses Syria; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: On Our Radar: A Global Wind Day
text: It’s Global Wind Day, an annual celebration coordinated by the wind industry that includes events like a photo competition, the inauguration of new wind farms and many festivals, mostly in Europe. In the United States, a group aligned with the fossil fuels industry plans counterdemonstrations to denounce the “push for expensive, inefficient and job-destroying offshore wind energy.” [Global Wind Day, Americans for Prosperity]

headline: Congress Suffers Electoral Defeat in Andhra Pradesh
text: The Indian National Congress, which leads the governing coalition in New Delhi, suffered a significant electoral setback in a large southern state, Andhra Pradesh, on Friday at the hands of a breakaway political faction.

headline: Tavern on the Green to Close Next Week
text: The Central Park Visitor Center at Tavern on the Green — which for 18 months has occupied the building that held the once-glittering landmark restaurant Tavern on the Green — will close on Wednesday afternoon for more than a year for a $9.8-million renovation project that will prepare the structure for a new restaurant tenant, as yet unnamed.

headline: Siblings, Squabbling In the Car
text: How the driving parent can ease the squabbles of siblings in the back seat.

headline: Pelvic Laparoscopy
text: A slide show depicting pelvic laparoscopy.

headline: Hi Mom, It's ...
text: "Hey!" "Hi, it's me." "Hey, it's your-name-here." Does what we say when we call our moms say anything about who we are?

headline: Who Made That Soy-Sauce Dispenser?
text: Just 16 and recently released from a naval academy, Kenji Ekuan witnessed Hiroshima’s devastation from the train taking him home. “Faced with that nothingness, I felt a great nostalgia for human culture,” he recalled from the offices of G. K. Design, the firm he co-founded in Tokyo in 1952. “I needed something to touch, to look at,” he added. “Right then I decided to be a maker of things.”

headline: Till Health Do Us Part
text: My on-again, off-again boyfriend of three years was on-again at the time he suffered a major illness. Before its onset, I was questioning our long-term potential and decided we were not meant to be. I do not have the caretaking responsibilities (his family assumed that role), and we live on oppositecoasts. I intend to see him through this illness from afar, plus occasional visits. My question: With a recovery time of four to six months, how and when can I let him go, ethically, for both our sakes? CAROLINE, FLORIDA

headline: The Jig Is On
text: Competitive Irish dancing is more than jigs and reels — you have to dress for the occasion too.

headline: How to Read a Racist Book to Your Kids
text: “Dad, why do the pirates have a gorilla?” This unexpected question intruded on a recent intergenerational cultural exchange: I was introducing my 6-year-old son to Asterix the Gaul. The pirates in the “Asterix” comics don’t travel with a gorilla, of course. One of the pirate crew is a grotesque caricature of an African who does indeed more closely resemble a gorilla than a person.

headline: The 6.3.12 Issue
text: GOD OF SMALL THINGS

headline: Our Smoking Habit
text: A few months into my fourth-grade year, in 1987, my father and I hitched a ride with a trucker in Texas, who drove us all the way north to Rochester, Minn., a small city famous for the Mayo Clinic. We were drifters. We hitchhiked even when I was very young, small enough to sleep on top of a suitcase laid on its side. I never knew exactly why we traveled so much, but Dad seemed to have his reasons, and I trusted him.

headline: Reader Idea | Personal Inquiry Projects With The Learning Network
text: Teacher: Carolyn Ross

headline: Business Day Live | June 15, 2012
text: Greek elections and the future of the euro zone. | White-collar criminals face longer sentences. | Why you should be taking a break right now.

headline: A Pragmatist In the Realm Of Perfection
text: ON Tuesday, in the middle of its nine-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater recognized its artistic director, Kevin McKenzie, for 20 years of service. Back in 1992, when Mr. McKenzie took over, not everyone would have predicted such longevity. The organization carried a deficit of more than $5.7 million, and Mr. McKenzie was its third leader in four years. A principal dancer with the company since 1980 and a member of the Joffrey Ballet before that, he had performed leading roles in many ballets, but his experience in administration was zero.

headline: Second-Round Recap: Highlights From the U.S. Open
text: Four years since capturing his last major championship, Tiger Woods will enter the weekend at the Olympic Club sharing the lead at the United States Open with two other former major winners, Jim Furyk (2003 U.S. Open) and David Toms (2001 P.G.A.). The three are the only players in the field in red numbers, each at one under.

headline: Summer’s New Destination: The Walk-Up Window
text: It’s a suburban twist in the most urban of settings: the walk-up (or drive-up) window. At Sauce, a restaurant that opened last fall on the Lower East Side, you can saunter up and order a meal in a container after midnight, or for breakfast.

headline: A Jewish-Asian Couple’s Union Leads to a Scholarly Interest in Intermarriage
text: One weekend night 15 years ago, a group of graduate students at the University of Chicago decided to interrupt their research long enough for a dinner party. Helen K. Kim made a chocolate tart with ginger cream filling. Her classmate Noah S. Leavitt regarded it and scoffed, “Nice use of your time, making a fancy dessert with all the homework we have.”

headline: Growing Up With a Fat Dad
text: I grew up with a fat dad — 450 pounds at his heaviest. Every week he would rotate to a new fad diet, and my family ended up eating whatever freeze-dried, saccharin-loaded concoction he was trying at that moment. By the time I was 9, I was an expert on Atkins, Pritikin and Weight Watchers, just to name a few. Did I mention spending four weeks at Duke University’s “fat farm” consuming only minuscule bowls of white rice, while my 10-year-old peers were home eating ice cream cones?

headline: More Goldman Partners Head for the Exit
text: Goldman Sachs employees were greeted Friday morning by a number of senior level departures.

headline: Obama to Permit Young Migrants to Remain in U.S.
text: Hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children will be allowed to remain in the country without fear of deportation and able to work, under an executive action the Obama administration announced on Friday.

headline: Over the Edge
text: The newest addition to tandem aerial sports is BASE jumping off a cliff.

headline: Coming Apart
text: Fourteen months ago, as ordinary Syrians were just beginning to gather in large numbers to call for their leaders to quit power, a cherub-faced 13-year-old named Hamza Ali al-Khateeb was taken into custody after he’d been caught scrawling an antigovernment slogan on a wall at a protest in the town of Jiza. A month later, when Hamza’s body was returned to his parents, it bore signs of the most hideous torture. His face had been beaten purple, his jaw and kneecaps pulverized, his body stabbed and torched. His penis had been chopped off.

headline: Up Front
text: As a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, Alex Witchel has profiled enough celebrities to populate a season of A-list dinner parties: from the American actress Ellen Barkin to well-connected Britons like Rupert Everett and Julian Fellowes, not to mention serious literary types like Colm Toibin. She’s spent time with Queen Latifah and Norris Church Mailer. But in “Feed Me,” the column she wrote for the Times Dining section for six years, she was more apt to celebrate kitchen-table pleasures, interviewing a homesick Texan cooking in a tiny Manhattan apartment or trying to replicate her own grandmother’s borscht.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: CANADA,  by Richard Ford. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.) A boy whose parents rob a bank in North Dakota in 1960 takes refuge across the border in this mesmerizing novel, driven by fully realized characters and an accomplished prose style.

headline: Paperback Row
text: NOTHING DAUNTED: The Unexpected Education of Two Society Girls in the West,  by Dorothy Wickenden. (Scribner, $15.) Mining a trove of letters, oral histories and period documents, Wickenden recounts how her grandmother and a friend — Smith graduates from blue-blooded East Coast families — embarked on a life-changing adventure in 1916, teaching the children of struggling homesteaders.

headline: Partisan Divide in D.C.? Not Over the S.B.A.
text: In this election season, the leitmotif to the story taking shape in Washington is that the partisan divide is vast and growing vaster — if last year it was difficult to pass bills that were once routine, now it has become impossible. But there appears to be at least one exception to the emerging rule: the Small Business Administration. Last week, the Republican-led House Appropriations Committee unveiled its bill (pdf) to finance the S.B.A. and several other government agencies, and what is most notable about the four pages dealing with the S.B.A. is the prospect for comity, not conflict.

headline: Just One Look | Valentino
text: Most great dresses have all of the following characteristics: 1. Balanced proportions on a flattering fit. 2. An element of intrigue via print or embellishment. 3. A hint of comfort, physical or emotional, but preferably both. Witness a perfect example, from Valentino. Playful jailhouse stripes on a ribbed duchesse dress draw the eye to all of the right places (and help minimize the other ones), giving a simple shape (just cap sleeves atop a flouncy skirt) equal parts structure and ease.

headline: Hints in New Scalia Book of Views on Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — With a Supreme Court decision on the fate of President Obama’s health care law expected in the next two weeks, every wisp of a hint about the justices’ thinking is getting the scrutiny usually reserved for CAT scans.

headline: Inside the List
text: SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE: “The female / Is a chaos,” Ezra Pound wrote, but if the savage women of Gillian Flynn’s critically acclaimed novels are anything to go by, chaos is only the half of it. They’re women with dark pasts and big appetites — for booze, men and mutilation. In “Gone Girl,” Flynn’s third and latest novel, which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, a happy housewife goes missing on the morning of her fifth anniversary, but naturally, nothing is what it seems. Both husband and wife are skillful liars, and the book turns out to be “a two-sided contest,” Janet Maslin wrote recently in the daily New York Times. “Each addresses the reader: Nick in the present tense, and Amy by way of an italics-filled, giddily emotional diary about the marriage. . . . They lied to each other a lot. Now they will lie to you.” Nick starts looking guilty pretty quickly, and flighty Amy turns out to be harboring some secrets of her own.

headline: By Mapping a River, Volunteers Take a Stake in Its Future
text: Dodging quicksand and rattlesnakes, Ted Mouras will spend Saturday morning walking along a five-mile stretch of a remote section of southeastern Arizona’s San Pedro River Basin in triple-digit heat for the annual wet/dry mapping of its water levels. A retired Army officer, he has volunteered annually to help the Nature Conservancy and its partners determine how the prolonged drought in the Southwest and the depletion of aquifers from local use affect the river.

headline: The Sport of Kings
text: With his graceful depictions of the embattled American West, Wallace Stegner remains unrivaled in his ability to humanize the clash between frontier beauty and “progress.” But there is always more gold in those hills, and Alyson Hagy isn’t a writer to mistake pyrite for something precious. In her third novel, “Boleto,” the alluring wilds of Wyoming and the horses wrangled there come with price tags affixed. The question is: Are we buying?

headline: Fantasy Island
text: Can the hoary trope of mistaken identity still play in the age of Google images? Especially if it’s a young, handsome womanizer with tousled blond hair being mistaken for the middle-aged, balding keynote speaker at the meticulously planned conference of a prestigious foundation?

headline: Interpreter of Maladies
text: We need to talk about Alice. ­Alice, with her black hair and big mouth. With her beautiful body and poor impulse control. Alice, criminal and savior, the victim and heroine of “Our Lady of Alice Bhatti,” a deft, evil little novel of comic genius by Mohammed Hanif, author of the prizewinning “Case of Exploding Mangoes.”

headline: The Avengers
text: “This is the hardest part,” confides one of the untrustworthy narrators in GONE GIRL (Crown, $25), “waiting for stupid people to figure things out.” There’s no need to rub it in, because Gillian Flynn’s latest novel of psychological suspense will confound anyone trying to keep up with her quicksilver mind and diabolical rules of play. Not that there’s anything underhanded about her intentions: she promises to deliver an account of the troubled marriage of Nick and Amy Dunne, who alternate as narrators, and so she does. The trickery is in the devilish way she tells their story.

headline: What Would Keynes Do?
text: Nearly four years on from the financial meltdown that plunged it into recession, the global economy remains fragile. The latest green shoots of recovery in the United States already show signs of turning brown. It is touch and go whether Barack Obama will enter the polls with unemployment above or below the 8 percent rate that usually means defeat for an incumbent president. Across the Atlantic, the euro zone stumbles from crisis to crisis; the continuing problems of the heavily indebted PIIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece and Spain) remain the basis for many a nightmare, some of the worst involving the banks around the world that own much of the debt.

headline: Changing Lanes
text: The subtitle of “Dan Gets a Minivan” — “Life at the Intersection of Dude and Dad” — nicely encapsulates a genre that has provided rich fodder for former dudes like Bill Cosby (“Fatherhood”), Robert Wilder (“Daddy Needs a Drink”) and Dave Barry (take your pick). It has also spawned a lucrative second career for the actor Paul Reiser (“Couplehood,” “Babyhood,” “Familyhood”).

headline: The Transcendentalist
text: The poet April Bernard’s latest work of fiction, “Miss Fuller,” opens in 1850, on the day the translator, literary critic, essayist, political activist and journalist Margaret Fuller died in a shipwreck off the coast of Long Island. Fuller, who had been in Italy reporting for Horace Greeley’s New-York Tribune, was returning home to the United States with her husband and young son when the ship foundered during a storm. Most of the novel is seen from the point of view of a woman named Anne, a fictitious sister of Henry David Thoreau; other parts are narrated by Fuller herself, via fabricated letters supposedly found by ­Thoreau on the day he visited the site of the wreck.

headline: Express Yourself
text: Americans love to talk about feelings. We do it almost compulsively and generally go about with the assumption that expressing emotion is a good idea. We are always articulating anger, jealousy and anxiety while people from more decorous cultures know when to keep their inner lives and dirty laundry to themselves.

headline: The Third Child
text: Adolescence is — for almost every­one, at least some of the time — excruciating. (Those few for whom this is not so, beware: there can be few things more dismaying than to find that adolescence was your zenith.)

headline: What Minty Knew
text: This is a book about secrets. What secrets do we keep? Whom do we trust? Why?

headline: Bookshelf: Dragons
text: New picture books starring the fire-breathing creatures.

headline: Bookshelf: Dragons
text: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS  By Adam Rubin.Illustrated by Daniel Salmieri.  40 pp. Dial. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 5)

headline: BASE Jumpers Double the Dare
text: MOAB, Utah — Castle Valley spread out about 1,500 feet below, and Mario Richard scooted his toes to the edge of the cliff. It can be an awkward shuffle when there is another person fastened to the front of him.

headline: Security Worker Is Sought in Shootings on Canadian Campus
text: OTTAWA — Police officers throughout Canada were searching Friday afternoon for a security company employee after three of his co-workers were fatally shot and a fourth was critically wounded during an early morning robbery attempt at a university residence and student services center in Edmonton, Alberta.

headline: German Rectitude Has Its Risks
text: As markets pummeled Spanish and Italian government bonds this week after Europe’s latest effort to contain the euro crisis, Germany seemed increasingly isolated in its demands for more austerity. The June 9 cover of The Economist portrayed the world economy as a sinking oil tanker with the caption, “Please can we start the engines now, Mrs. Merkel?”

headline: Investigation of Jeep Grand Cherokee Portends a Recall, Safety Advocate Says
text: With the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration having decided to upgrade its investigation of rear-impact fires involving Jeep Grand Cherokees, a recall of millions of those vehicles is “certain,” said Clarence Ditlow, the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, the organization whose work prompted the federal inquiry.

headline: Practical Traveler’s Tips for Summer Travel With Kids
text: If you’re planning a trip involving flights with children this summer, you’ll want to check out Practical Traveler Michelle Higgins’s advice for traveling families. “At a minimum, especially if you’re traveling with small children, take a change of clothes onboard for the child and yourself. That way, when she spills cranberry juice all over you, or her diaper leaks, you have options.” My oldest son once soaked himself at the infinity fountain in the Detroit airport …

headline: Let’s Eat!
text: I like to claim I grew up watching Julia Child on TV, though what really happened is, I watched my parents watch her. I also like to believe “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” was a huge influence on my own, though I’m not sure I’ve ever even looked at the vegetable chapter. I was there for Julia when she got all Californian. (A recipe for pita? Come on.) I’m here for her even now that she’s no longer around. We all love Julia and the stories from her wonderful life: the O.S.S., the sophisticated husband who introduced her to sole meunière, the Cordon Bleu, “The French Chef,” Paris, Provence, the fact that she was over six feet tall and was said to have dropped a chicken on live television. (Alas, it was only a potato pancake.)

headline: In Investments, as in Life, Passion Can Cloud Judgment
text: I’VE been talking to a lot of wealthy people in the last few weeks who have followed their passions into a variety of investments: vineyards, baseball teams, restaurants and racehorses. But I couldn’t help wondering what it would take for these people, who had made the money for such investments by being shrewd in other lines of work, to sell their stake in a fascinating second career.

headline: A Gleam Off the Samovar
text: Some fantasy novels deal out the tropes of the genre like cards from a dog-eared deck. Others affirm the elemental power of these tropes, reminding us not only why we read fantasy, but also why we read at all. There may be nothing new under the sun, but a good story makes you just not care. Like the expert strike of a reflex hammer, it hits precisely the right spot.

headline: Studies Find That Gossip Isn’t Just Loose Talk
text: GOSSIP. Almost all of us do it, most of us are embarrassed about it, and sometimes, to our horror, we get caught.

headline: The Gray Zone
text: Two months ago at the London Book Fair, where China was this year’s “guest of honor,” Ma Jian, the exiled author of the Tiananmen-era novel “Beijing Coma,” inked a red X across his face in an emotional protest against Chinese censorship. It may be a sign of the times that while drawing attention from the Western press, the move went almost unnoticed by other Chinese authors present, many of whom still live in China and find ways to circumvent the authorities.

headline: In Duel of Stars, Heat’s James Gains Early Edge
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Their statistics were nearly identical, mirror images of dueling superstars in search of the slightest of edges. But as LeBron James and Kevin Durant spoke late Thursday night, it was clear that the psychology of the N.B.A. finals had been flipped in favor of the Miami Heat.

headline: Kids Draw the News | Nik Wallenda’s Big Night
text: Update: This assignment is closed. The more results can be seen here.

headline: Immigration Announcement May Overshadow Romney Bus Tour
text: BOSTON — Mitt Romney begins a five-day bus tour on Friday, during which he had hoped to make his case to small-town voters that President Obama’s economic policies are failing everyday Americans. But the Romney campaign may find it more difficult to stay on message in the wake of the Obama administration’s announcement that it would stop deporting younger immigrants who came to the United States as children.

headline: Siblings, Squabbling in the Car
text: This week’s parental quandary is mine again — or rather, one I’ve solved, at least temporarily, but one on which I thought we could all use a little good crowd-sourced advice. The problem? Children squabbling madly away in the car.

headline: Prince Charles Kicks Off London Men’s Fashion Week
text: The season of international men’s-wear fashion shows kicked off in London on Thursday, which was unusual in that London, apart from its Savile Row traditions, has more recently treated men’s wear as an afterthought when it comes to the runway. London’s attempt to start a new men’s event was also unusual in that it was introduced with a party given by Prince Charles in the State Apartments of St. James’s Palace.

headline: The Well Quiz: All About Fathers
text: How much do you know about today’s fathers? And how do they compare to mothers? Take our Dad Quiz to find out.

headline: What About Dad?
text: At home, dads are more involved than ever. So why is it that all the disputes about parenting are by, for and about women?

headline: A First for the Golden Flashes
text: It’s been a dramatic and exciting season for the Kent State baseball team, and it’s not over yet. The Golden Flashes are one of this year’s Cinderella teams in the College World Series, which starts Friday in Omaha. Kent State (46-18) is scheduled to play on Saturday against Arkansas (43-20).

headline: McCain Says Adelson is Putting ‘Foreign Money’ Into Campaign
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona suggested in an interview posted online on Friday that a “super PAC” backing Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, may have provided a conduit for foreign money to enter the presidential race.

headline: In Euro Crisis, Obama Looks to Merkel
text: WASHINGTON — At the end of a summit meeting at Camp David last month, as the other world leaders were heading for their helicopters, President Obama did what has become a habit during his years in the White House: he made time for an informal but deadly serious talk with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany.

headline: Richard F. Stolz Dies at 86; Headed C.I.A. Spy Operations After Iran-Contra
text: Richard F. Stolz, a career intelligence officer who was called out of retirement in 1987 to run the Central Intelligence Agency’s spying operations and cleanse its image after the Iran-contra scandal, died on June 9 in Williamsburg, Va. He was 86.

headline: Just One Look | Rag & Bone
text: As Rag and Bone’s David Neville and Marcus Wainwright expand their line to include women’s bags, they’re stepping back and revisiting the essence of the brand with their clothing. In the designers’ resort collection you’ll find reworked favorites like silk and satin midnight-blue track pants, dark knit sweaters and leather minidresses. Pops of color came in floral printed pieces and gold sequined dresses and blouses. Their signature Newbury ankle boots came in perennial black, blue and brown. If you have the classic colors covered, check out the new shiny gold leather version.

headline: Loves DeBarge. And Fred Astaire.
text: THE fun-loving pop-rock duo LMFAO have been a major presence on the Billboard charts since last year, when they released their sophomore album, “Sorry for Party Rocking” (Interscope). Spoiler: They weren’t sorry. Their single “Party Rock Anthem” was just that: an inescapably addictive soundtrack for clubs, parties, barbecues, street fairs, anywhere people gathered to have a good time. Hits like “Sexy and I Know It” became remixed staples for nightlife-worshiping fans, not least because LMFAO created dance moves along with them.

headline: Loud Enough to Be Heard in Another Country
text: IF everything had gone according to the plan drawn up by Japandroids, they would already be long forgotten. Formed in Vancouver in 2006, this garage-rock duo had decided to call it quits in late 2008 after failing to break out of the British Columbia music scene, but not before commemorating their departure with “Post-Nothing,” a debut — and farewell — album. But after their song “Young Hearts Spark Fire” was posted by the online music publication Pitchfork in March 2009, “Post-Nothing” went from a would-be posthumous release to an industry calling card, leading to a record deal and two years of relentless touring.

headline: Exotic Creatures, Naughty and Nice
text: Gremlins 2: The New Batch

headline: Euro 2012 Highlights: Sweden (2) vs. England (3)
text: The distance between England and a European championship is vast — in real and psychic terms. But maybe, just maybe, those hurdles are not quite as high after England took the lead, lost the lead, tied the game and roared back to defeat Sweden in a Group D game in Kyiv, Ukraine, at the European Championships.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/15: Airport Makeovers and a Niagara Falls High-Wire Act
text: Bigger, Better Airports The biggest airports in the country — Los Angeles, Dallas, Atlanta, Chicago and the three that serve New York City have been undergoing major renovations and expansions. (The New York Times)

headline: Rajat Gupta Convicted of Insider Trading
text: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, was found guilty on Friday of conspiracy and securities fraud for leaking boardroom secrets to a billionaire hedge fund manager.

headline: ResCap Rejects Berkshire Bids for Assets
text: Residential Capital, the mortgage arm of Ally Financial, has rejected bids by Berkshire Hathaway to buy most of its assets out of bankruptcy, and will instead follow its original sales plans.

headline: Music Box as Muse to Puccini’s ‘Butterfly’
text: MORRISTOWN, N.J.

headline: When Slow Growth Looks Good
text: Among the Group of 7 industrialized countries, only the Canadian, United States and German economies are now larger than they were at their prerecession peaks. The top set of charts shows the seven G-7 countries, ranked by performance since each economy peaked in 2007 or 2008, with members of the euro zone in italics. The second set shows the performance of seven other euro zone countries, similarly ranked.

headline: Norway Has Noir; Just Ask Jo Nesbo
text: Jo Nesbo, the Norwegian writer of crime thrillers, is already being called the next Stieg Larsson. The comparison is a little premature: Mr. Nesbo, who has sold some 14 million books worldwide, is a household name in Europe, but in this country, even though Martin Scorsese recently announced plans to film Mr. Nesbo’s 2007 novel, “The Snowman,” his reputation is not yet Larssonesque.

headline: Keeping a Cool Head About a Passion Investment
text: Paul Sullivan has been writing for the last few weeks about various people who have followed their hearts and invested in everything from vineyards to baseball teams to racehorses. He raises the question in this week’s Wealth Matters column about whether decisions by these people on when to buy sell or how much to pay are any better than the decisions by people who put their money into stocks and bonds.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: In recognition of National Lobster Day, which is Friday, Ed’s Lobster Bar Annex, 25 Clinton Street (between East Houston and Stanton Streets), on the Lower East Side, will hold a lobster fest starting at 4:30 p.m. For $60 a person, you can taste everything from half a chilled lobster and lobster rolls to lobster-filled ravioli and tacos.

headline: Let Them Eat Cinnamon Buns
text: KELLIE CICCONI has always been a picky eater.

headline: London Theater Journal: Mary Tyrone, Deglamorized and Unforgettable
text: On the first truly sunny afternoon on offer since I arrived in London, I chose to descend into a deep American fog. Oh, I knew that light-starved, water-logged people were out there romping around Piccadilly Circus like newly escaped captives of a crypt. Yet there I was, some feet below street level in the Apollo Theater, grinning away at a fine, murky spectacle of unhappiness like a member of the Addams Family in a torture chamber.

headline: In Health Care Ruling, Vast Implications for Medicaid
text: ENGLAND, Ark. — As a construction worker and logger, Bryan L. Mashburn does what he describes as “backbreaking, muscle-pulling work,” laying concrete foundations for water towers and felling 3,000-pound trees. He has no health insurance, and he tried to avoid going to doctors when he crushed a finger on one occasion and metal shavings flew deep into his eye another time.

headline: Image of the Day: June 15
text: Anchored fishing boats at a seashore in a village in Maharashtra.

headline: Little-Known Firm to Reap Millions in Exchange’s Sale
text: LONDON – A little-known metals trading company owned by an Indian family stands to become one of the biggest winners in London Metal Exchange’s sale to Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing.

headline: A Slow Recovery in the United States, but It’s All Relative
text: THE slow pace of the American economic recovery seems likely to be a major issue in this year’s presidential election. But by the standards of other developed countries, the United States has done rather well since the credit crisis blossomed in 2008 and sent the world into recession.

headline: A Breakthrough on Immigration Policy
text: Expect Republicans and other hardliners on immigration (the few who are not Republicans) to go berserk over this one: The administration has announced that it will stop deporting many illegal immigrants who came to the United States before they turned 16.

headline: A Better Way to Prepare Quinoa
text: If you enjoy cooking with quinoa (pronounced keen-wah), then you’ll appreciate the latest preparation tips from Martha Rose Shulman. Once you perfect your prep, you’ll be rewarded with five delicious new salads made with quinoa. Ms. Shulman writes:

headline: Big Names Flock to Michael Grandage’s New Theater Company
text: Judi Dench, Jude Law and Daniel Radcliffe will play major characters in the inaugural season of London theater from a new producing company formed by the Tony Award-wining director Michael Grandage (“Red”) and his business partner, James Bierman, who together ran the Donmar Warehouse from 2006 to 2011, according to an announcement from the two men on Thursday night. The season will include a new play, “Peter and Alice” by John Logan, the Tony-winning author of “Red,” with Ms. Dench and the actor Ben Whishaw playing the two real-life figures who inspired “Alice in Wonderland” and “Peter Pan.”

headline: Just One Look | Alexander Wang
text: All you need to know about Alexander Wang’s resort collection is: mock croc (on everything from bags to puffer jackets!), transparency (in flowing paneled dresses and sturdy gossamer heeled shoes) and bras galore. This look features faux-croc track shorts and a classic knit tank, which from the front is a halter top but from the back is more of a bodysuit, with classic bra straps. Undergarments as outerwear also came in cropped corsets, spongy lime-colored compact knit tubes and new neoprene bibbed dresses. The response was supportive.

headline: An Earlier Housing Bubble
text: Bloomberg View’s excellent economic history blog tells of an earlier housing bubble, from the same country and era that brought us tulip-mania.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Setting 9/11 in Stone
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott debate the relative merits of museums and memorials and discuss how to best make sense of Sept. 11.

headline: Obama’s Decision on Immigration Is Met With Joy, Anger and Skepticism
text: Updated, 6:10 p.m. As my colleagues Julia Preston and John H. Cushman Jr. report, an Obama administration policy announced Friday morning will halt the deportation of illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children and allow them to obtain work permits.

headline: The Sweet Spot: June 15
text: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the relative merits of museums and memorials, and how to best make sense of Sept. 11.

headline: For Ann Romney, a Different Sort of Horse Race
text: The Romneys face a different sort of fierce competition this weekend: a horse co-owned by Ann Romney will compete for a berth at the London Olympic Games.

headline: Ukraine’s President Says He Has No Authority to Pardon Jailed Rival
text: MOSCOW — Ukraine’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, said in an interview published this week that he wanted to pardon Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the country’s jailed former prime minister and his main political rival, but did not have the legal authority to do so, a claim Ms. Tymoshenko’s lawyer scoffed at on Friday.

headline: Guest Column: Yes, Oil Prices Are Cyclical
text: Amy Myers Jaffe is an energy consultant and the Wallace S. Wilson Fellow for Energy Policy Studies at Rice University.

headline: Gracie Mansion Kitchen, New in Koch’s Day, Is to Be Updated
text: Any sentence that begins, “Even for a small dinner for 100 guests —” is bound to claim attention.

headline: A School With Plenty of Air-Conditioners, All Sitting in Storage
text: There are no air-conditioners in the classrooms at New Horizons Middle School in Brooklyn. Earlier this school year, workers found unused air conditioners in the basement, but the school’s wiring cannot support them.

headline: The Designs of ‘Brave’
text: A look at how the red-haired firebrand Merida of Pixar’s new movie, “Brave,” was developed.

headline: Five Small Communities Within Manhattan
text: For a few fortunate people living in Manhattan, home lies on one of a handful of short streets that run for just a block, or two or three at the most.

headline: Over a Decade Later, Still Learning the Lessons of Stop-and-Frisk
text: A former city schoolteacher writes: During the 2000-01 school year I taught a course about stop-and-frisk and the Fourth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution. With a mayoral election ahead, I stated that the days of more than 100,000 stop-and-frisks every year may be coming to an end. The students were more skeptical. Oh, how right the students were and how wrong their teacher was.

headline: Arch Basel
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Beyond-the-Grid Manhattan
text: THE vast majority of Manhattan residents live on streets that seem to run forever. Twenty-third Street clocks in at about two miles, Second Avenue at nearly seven. Thanks to Manhattan’s grid plan, which is celebrating its bicentennial with an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, the bulk of the island is laid out in rigid checkerboard fashion.

headline: Evolution of a Feisty Pixar Princess
text: IN some form or other — toys, monsters, cars, rats and even little boys — male characters have been at the center of Pixar Animation Studio’s feature films. But now for the first time in its 17-year history, Pixar has a female lead. The studio spent more than five years bringing Merida, the empowered girl at the center of “Brave” (opening Friday), to life. It took a number of designs and two directors to do it.

headline: Spotwag Helps Facebook Friends Find Pet Sitters
text: If you have a pet and you travel a lot, you know how difficult it can be to find someone to look after your furry buddy. Asking a friend, and then trying to give them money for their troubles, is often a pretty awkward affair.

headline: Movie Endings
text: Images from apocalyptic films of recent years.

headline: Walcott Seizes on Charges of Sexual Abuse in Harlem School
text: UPDATED | Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott said Friday that the arrest of a third-grade teacher at a Harlem public school, the latest in a slate of school arrests involving sexual abuse charges, is yet another reason to push forward with state legislation that would grant chancellors the power to fire offenders. His comments set off a battle with the United Federation of Teachers, which said the city should do a better job screening the people it hires -- a criticism that Mr. Walcott said on Sunday was a "disingenuous shell game" meant to draw attention away from the real problem of too-lenient arbitrators.

headline: Nancy Coffey and Timothy Nagler
text: IN August 2005, F. Timothy Nagler believed, as he put it, that he “had the happiest marriage on the planet.”

headline: TimesCast: Changes in Immigration Policy
text: Richard W. Stevenson on the political implications of President Obama’s announcement.

headline: ReRun Gastropub Theater to Close
text: The reRun Gastropub, a movie theater and bar in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, is  to close for an unspecified period of time, the site’s programmer, Aaron Hillis, announced in an email this week. With the subject line “Farewell to reRun Gastropub Theater,” Mr. Hillis wrote that he would be stepping down from curating films there and that the owner, Jason Stevens, would temporarily shut the space to revamp it for “whatever its next incarnation will be.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: The First Lady’s Family
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Edward Ball reviews Rachel Swarns’s “American Tapestry,” an intricate look into the family history of Michelle Obama. The book, which includes what Mr. Ball calls “herculean investigations,” goes back to the 1800s, following Mrs. Obama’s relatives through slavery in South Carolina, Georgia, Virginia and Kentucky. Mr. Ball writes:

headline: Glen Tonche
text: A 35-acre estate on top of Mount Tonche in the Catskill Mountains.

headline: Zeus of the Catskills
text: IT breaks Randall Wallace’s heart to have to sell Glen Tonche, the 35-acre estate he owns on top of Mount Tonche in the Catskill Mountains.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Changes in Immigration Policy
text: Richard W. Stevenson discusses the political implications of President Obama’s announcement on immigration policy.

headline: Shaw Festival Turns to a Former Leader
text: Elaine Calder, the president of the Oregon Symphony, will become the executive director of the Shaw Festival in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario, for the second time in her career, the theater’s board announced on Thursday.

headline: ‘Top Gear,’ Stig-less on Apple’s Screens
text: What is it about the “Top Gear” television series that makes otherwise upstanding companies act like used-car salesmen?

headline: This Is the Way the World Ends
text: “SOME say the world will end in fire,/Some say in ice,” Robert Frost wrote nearly a hundred years ago, but for moviegoers of the 21st century both the giant conflagration and the big freeze have become a bit “been there, done that.”

headline: Threat of Russian Hooliganism Looms Over Championships
text: Besides tossing a few firecrackers, pummeling some stadium ushers and brawling in the streets of Warsaw, Russian soccer fans, it can be said, have so far been pretty disciplined at this year’s European soccer championships.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An 1853 Greek Revival town house in Fort Greene and a one-bedroom Upper West Side condo.

headline: Stockholm, and the Strangers Who Brought Me There
text: THE view was peerless but not pierless. I was sitting on the patio of the chic Hotel Skeppsholmen, which, located on an island in the middle of Stockholm, seems to embody all that’s good about a city that is roughly one-third water and one-third green space. I could see lawn, palisades, boats and ferries, very few tourists, Northern Europe’s best-preserved medieval city, an amusement park built in 1883, important shrubbery, ducks.

headline: The Modern Pentathlon Just Got Even More … Modern
text: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — You may have missed it, but there is something big going on in the world of modern pentathlon.

headline: Palace-Hopping in Poland
text: WHEN I was a little girl living in Texas and visited my family in Poland, my grandfather would always take us to palaces. He had been an art historian and curator of a couple of the palaces around Warsaw during some of Poland’s bleakest years of Communism, and even though I was too young to understand that era, or much of Poland’s complicated history, I knew that through these palaces, something about Poland and its once-luxurious glory had been preserved. My imagination conjured images of princesses running through lavishly decorated hallways and grand, echoing rooms.

headline: Where Polish Royalty Lived
text: Travel to Warsaw for a tour of castles and palaces.

headline: Free Spirits in a Sonoma Hamlet
text: UNDER a blinding noonday sun, my boyfriend and I pulled onto the comfortably worn commercial strip of Guerneville, Calif., a former lumber town in Sonoma County. Two men, hand-in-hand, ambled past the mix of rustic, renovated and retro storefronts on Main Street, a backdrop that suggested a dash of San Francisco’s Union Street and Mayberry. A chic restaurant sat near a pawnshop that sat near the Guerneville 5 & 10, whose metal marquee and wooden sign made the place look like a relic from the 40s, which, in fact, it is.

headline: A Jersey Shore Rebound
text: WHILE towns along the Jersey Shore reinvented themselves during the boom of the aughts, sprouting boutique hotels and upscale restaurants, Asbury Park retained a refreshing, rare Americana charm. Restaurants — and boutique hotels — arrived, but they have had to share the Boardwalk with nostalgic attractions like a pinball museum and a psychic. And a majestic urban ghost presides over it all: the Boardwalk ends at the magnificent shell of a 1920s-era casino and carousel house.

headline: June 17 — 23
text: IT seems that New York City abounds with free summer outdoor movie screenings nowadays, but perhaps the daddy of them all is the HBO BRYANT PARK SUMMER FILM FESTIVAL, which celebrates its 20th anniversary this year with some of its biggest hits from the past. It starts Monday with “Psycho” and concludes Aug. 20 with “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” and on Mondays in between are heavyweights like “On the Waterfront” (July 9), “All About Eve” (Aug. 13) and “The Wizard of Oz” (July 2), which, weather permitting, may well generate the season’s biggest turnout. (I remember when “Casablanca” closed the festival a few years back. Some viewers reverently whispered famous lines a moment before they were uttered on screen.)

headline: A Czech Trove of Minimalist Design
text: FLAT-FACED, devoid of frills and anonymous, the synagogue stood at the end of a narrow street in the Czech city of Brno, not far from a railroad trestle where trains could be heard building speed for points farther east. Beyond the two slightly angled gray walls at either side of its four glass entry doors, the synagogue appeared remarkably plain, standing out among the neighboring buildings with an unwelcoming facade, and showing no sign of life.

headline: Restaurant Report: State Bird Provisions in San Francisco
text: In 2003, after dining at Tapawingo, in Ellsworth, Mich., the Times reporter R. W. Apple Jr. observed that it “may be the best restaurant anywhere in the country that’s a four-hour drive from the closest major city.” Mr. Apple took note of Tapawingo’s chef, Stuart Brioza, then 28, predicting that “he will be one of the best chefs in America, full stop, in just a few years.” He also lauded Tapawingo’s pastry chef, Nicole Krasinski, as an adroit match for Mr. Brioza’s “restless spontaneity.”

headline: ‘Mad Men’ to Turbans
text: “I’m not a big shopper,” confessed Janie Bryant, costume designer for feature films and for “Mad Men,” the AMC television series whose season finale was shown last Sunday. She finds much more inspiration in traveling to far-flung destinations and, say, riding a camel, than in riffling through clothing store racks.

headline: Hotel Review: Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel Chicago
text: UPSHOT

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $70 Million
text: A 14-room duplex penthouse apartment above the Ritz-Carlton that sold for $70 million to the casino magnate Steve Wynn was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. It was also the second-highest price ever paid for an apartment in New York City.

headline: Gracie Mansion to Get a New Kitchen
text: The kitchen at Gracie Mansion is about to be renovated for the first time in 27 years, City Room reports.

headline: Just One Look | Theyskens’ Theory
text: Come this resort season, the Theyskens’ Theory girl (who’s either a downtown model or someone working a downtown-model-off-duty look) will have to shelve her black leather motorcycle pants and tattered tees. Because the designer Olivier Theyskens is showing the softer side of cool, in the form of an all-white palette. Jumpsuits, trousers, cropped jackets — everything you already have in black, you’ll now want in white. Even those velour hot shorts now come in a white (and more covered) version. Denim vests and overall shorts are washed in light blue, and there’s an even brighter side: rainbow jeweled crop tops and threaded mini dresses.

headline: Microsoft Is Expected to Introduce a Tablet
text: For decades, Microsoft has made the software that runs a majority of the world’s personal computers, leaving a gang of outside hardware companies to design the machines. Apple, its rival, makes it all.

headline: Flights of Fancy, Indeed: French Pâtissier Onboard
text: The innovative French pastry chef Pierre Hermé, one of the world’s most famous pâtissiers, has enjoyed a long love affair with Japan. In 1998, he introduced the first outpost of his Pierre Hermé Paris pastry boutique in Tokyo, three years before opening one in Paris.

headline: Advice for the Estranged, Online and Off
text: People who are estranged from family members often don’t speak about it — out of shame, embarrassment or to avoid the judgment of acquaintances. Elizabeth Vagnoni, a documentary filmmaker, whose two sons no longer speak to her, said: “They think, ‘What did you do? What kind of mother must you be?’”

headline: Why the Thunder’s Starting Lineup Isn’t Working
text: For evidence of the power of lineup manipulation in basketball, one need look no further than the intriguing circumstances that have forced Serge Ibaka to (rather unsuccessfully) check Shane Battier. An incredibly athletic defensive player of the year candidate has been humbled in his attempts to defend an aging spot-up shooter, largely due to Scott Brooks’s reluctance to make what could be the N.B.A. finals’ most crucial adjustment.

headline: China Suspends Family Planning Workers After Forced Abortion
text: SHANGHAI — China suspended three local family planning officials in northwest China this week following a public outcry over reports that they had forced a young woman to undergo an abortion seven months into her pregnancy, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency.

headline: Movies That Flicker Only on the Page
text: Janet Maslin recently reviewed two novels that each featured fictional movies. Jess Walter’s “Beautiful Ruins” includes the idea for a movie called “Donner!” about the Donner party, which, Ms. Maslin writes, “might just be the worst screenplay idea Hollywood has ever known.” And in Alan Furst’s new novel, “Mission to Paris,” an actor stars in a movie about World War I called “Après la Guerre,” or “After the War,” which begins filming at the dawn of World War II.

headline: In Motion, Facebook Lays Out Defense and Highlights Nasdaq’s Missteps
text: Nearly one month after its bungled initial public offering, Facebook is breaking its silence.

headline: Reporter Interrupts Obama During Statement on Immigration
text: 4:40 p.m. | Updated The interruption stunned White House correspondents and television viewers. And it clearly surprised President Obama, too.

headline: Photo Replay: June 15
text: The day in sports included swimming in Rome, the European soccer championships and badminton in Jakarta, Indonesia.

headline: Good Dad, Bad Dad
text: Father’s Day is a complicated holiday for me. As an adult, my relationship with my dad is pretty good. He’s attentive and tries to be available to my brother and me. But when we were growing up, he was the worst: always focused on work or sports — anything but us. So, I’m grateful to him now, but resentful about the past. Worse, he won’t apologize. How would you handle him?Sue, New York

headline: Red Crayon, Blue Crayon
text: WHEN Really Big Coloring Books published a 32-page children’s book about the Tea Party in 2010, the book received a lot of unwanted attention. The Los Angeles Times called it “kiddie propaganda art;” its author and publisher, Wayne Bell, said he received death threats.

headline: Italy Makes Plans to Cut Debt and Revive Growth
text: ROME — The Italian government moved forward on Friday with a wide-ranging package of economic measures worth about 80 billion euros, or $101 billion, that were meant both to spur economic growth and make a dent in the country’s unsustainably large public debt.

headline: For Father’s Day, the Gift of a Fellow Fan
text: The Devils came within two games of winning the Stanley Cup, the biggest prize in hockey. As a longtime fan, I should have been bitterly disappointed. But I wasn’t, because while I followed their two-month playoff run, an unexpected hockey-watching companion developed: my six-year-old son, Nicholas. The boy who was once more interested in watching the Zamboni than the hockey game turned into a sports-page-reading fanatic.

headline: Lumière | The New Normal Chic
text: The French like their leaders to be regal, so François Hollande’s pledge to be a “normal” president will take some getting used to. Not that Hollande seems ready to surrender any of the powers of his office or abandon Charles de Gaulle’s “certain idea of France” as an exceptional nation. For now, the changes are a matter of style. Less spending, less glamour, less Versailles. More caution, more prudence, more modest living. So what is the new “normal” in Hollande’s France?

headline: London Shows Open With Up-and-Comers
text: On the first day of the inaugural edition of London Collections: Men, as this city got used to the idea of having its very own Fashion Week for men, the look for spring 2013 was black dress socks worn with shorts. Both Lou Dalton, an up-and-comer, and the designers at Topman, the premium men’s division of Topshop, styled their models in black socks, which did not exactly suggest the sort of directionality for which London designers are supposedly known. That middle-aged look for lawn-mowing has been all over Brooklyn already.

headline: Transcript of Obama’s Speech on Immigration Policy
text: The following is the full text of President Obama’s speech on Friday from the Rose Garden.

headline: Internet Unshackled, Burmese Aim Venom at Ethnic Minority
text: BANGKOK — Over the past year, Myanmar’s government has ended its heavy censorship, allowing citizens unfettered access to a wide variety of Web sites that had been banned during military rule. When the government first began dismantling its Internet controls in August, visits to sites like YouTube soared.

headline: Romney Kicks Off Bus Tour in New Hampshire
text: STRATHAM, N.H. — Mitt Romney kicked off his bus tour in the same place he kicked off his campaign a little more than a year ago, a farm here on New Hampshire’s Seacoast. But while the ambitious barnstorm through small-town America was billed as an effort to introduce Mr. Romney to a new set of voters, the first event kept him solidly in his comfort zone.

headline: The Characters Are Dead, but the Soundtrack Is Live
text: “The Black Belly of the Tarantula” is a 1971 film directed by Paolo Cavara, an over-the-top Italian giallo thriller about a murderer who slices open women, with a pop-art Roman backdrop.

headline: Russia Sending Missile Systems to Shield Syria
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s chief arms exporter said Friday that his company was shipping advanced defensive missile systems to Syria that could be used to shoot down airplanes or sink ships if the United States or other nations try to intervene to halt the country’s spiral of violence.

headline: ‘Jerry Springer Show’ Is Signed Up Through Fall 2016
text: A lot is changing in daytime television, but this is not: teenage mothers, cheating spouses and sex addicts still have a forum on “The Jerry Springer Show,” and will for years to come.

headline: President Obama on Immigration
text: President Obama spoke to reporters in the White House Rose Garden on Friday afternoon

headline: How Depressives Surf the Web
text: IN what way do you spend your time online? Do you check your e-mail compulsively? Watch lots of videos? Switch frequently among multiple Internet applications — from games to file downloads to chat rooms?

headline: Sandusky Judge Tells Jurors to Tune Out an Audiotape
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Bob Costas’s interview with Jerry Sandusky, the former assistant football coach at Penn State who is on trial on child sexual abuse charges, received considerable attention when it was broadcast on NBC last fall. And this week it received some attention in the courtroom.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 15
text: Subjects include the Puerto Rican Day Parade, the arraignment of a police officer in the killing of Ramarley Graham and a proposed new development for the Chelsea Market.

headline: 21 Years After Winning Nobel, Democracy Leader Reaches Oslo
text: OSLO — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the symbol of Burmese resistance to dictatorship, arrived in Norway on Friday to finally deliver the Nobel lecture for the peace prize she won in 1991, which she will do Saturday. But even during her years of house arrest, she said at a news conference here, she never doubted that one of her first trips abroad would be to Norway. She repeated, “I never doubted that,” then grinned and asked, “Did you?”

headline: More Pre-K Seats Open for Bid, Starting Monday
text: Parents shut out of their prekindergarten of choice will have a second chance to apply, starting Monday, when 2,000 or so available seats will become open for bids. The schools that still have open seats can be found online in a list published by the city. Parents are urged to apply at the schools of their choice.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Topman Designs
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: McConnell Accuses Obama and Aides of Schemes to Curtail Free Speech
text: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Friday accused President Obama, his campaign and his administration of engaging in Nixonian dirty tricks, including keeping an enemies list, inciting “mob” attacks on its critics and leaking confidential tax information, in a concerted effort to curtail the free speech of his opponents.

headline: The Thurmond Rule
text: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell announced this week that he is imposing a blockade on President Obama’s nominations to the circuit courts. The G.O.P. will likely hold off on blocking district court judges until early September.

headline: In Tokyo, Grown-Up Utility From Toyota Toys
text: Toyota is showing off two diminutive concept cars at the Tokyo Toy Fair, running through June 17. The vehicles together are called Camatte, an adaptation of a Japanese word intended to signify “caring for others,” Toyota said, and are aimed at “bringing delight to parents and children alike.”

headline: Pizza to Go
text: Jonathan Darsky couldn’t find a suitable site to open a pizza restaurant, so he installed an oven in a truck and hit the road.

headline: For Gupta, What Lies Ahead
text: Rajat K. Gupta’s conviction on four of six counts shows that federal prosecutors can still win an insider trading case based largely on circumstantial evidence. In the end, it appears that the jury was quite persuaded by wiretaps. For the two charges that he was acquitted on, the government did not present overheard conversations of Raj Rajaratnam describing his source of inside information.

headline: Still a One-Hitter, Baseball Says
text: 5:34 p.m. | Updated R.A. Dickey will have to keep working to get a no-hitter. As expected, Major League Baseball on Friday upheld the ruling made Wednesday, when the official scorer decided that B. J. Upton’s chopper to third base in the first inning was indeed a hit and not an error by David Wright, who grabbed at the ball with his bare hand but never gained control.

headline: New Energy in Palm Springs
text: Lively hotels, restaurants and boutiques are lending vitality to this part of Southern California.

headline: A Second Life for Discarded Fishing Nets
text: Abandoned and lost fishing gear makes up about 10 percent of the trash that collects in the world’s oceans, according to a report from the United Nations. Much of this debris is lost in storms, vandalized or simply discarded. It piles up on beaches, creates a navigational hazard for boats or settles to the bottom, where it can damage sensitive ecosystems. Discarded nets can cause a particular problem as they continue to “ghost fish,” trapping fish and other sea animals like turtles, seabirds and dolphins.

headline: Putting the Whole Beet to Work, Including the Tops
text: I SPEND a lot of time meandering through the greenmarkets. When planning my pedestrian itinerary, I always make a deliberate detour, and not just for research, but also to pick up something for dinner.

headline: It Took a Village for a Play (7 Writers and 4 Directors)
text: The title of “We Play for the Gods,” a slight production from the Women’s Theater Project, comes from Ellen Stewart, the founder of La MaMa, who died last year. “We play for the Gods,” Ms. Stewart said, “and in return, they play for us.”

headline: Daredevil Takes a Successful Walk Across a Popular Void
text: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario — Nik Wallenda became the first man to walk over the Niagara Gorge in 116 years Friday night — and the first ever to walk right over the falls.

headline: Soft-Shell Crabs
text: If you love soft-shell crabs, why not try cooking them at home? Melissa Clark shows how.

headline: Beet Salad for Summer
text: At the outdoor markets in France, most vegetable merchants customarily sell beets already cooked, as a convenience to shoppers. The beets sit in a bowl along with a big fork. Generally there are two kinds, both red, one large and round and the other more elongated. You ask for the type you want and it gets forked into a paper wrapper, ready to slice for a beet salad when you get home.

headline: Digital Notes: ‘Call Me Maybe’ Is an East Coast Hit, Spotify Says, but Gotye Is Tops
text: Who streams what, and where?

headline: Breaking All the Rules
text: IF you’re worried all this Emily Post-style rule-mongering will squeeze the life out of your wedding toast, consider jettisoning the rules entirely to follow the example of Selma and Kenny Furst. The couple, who this year will celebrate their 72nd anniversary, became YouTube sensations this spring when a spirited toast they made for their grandson’s wedding was posted on awkwardfamilyphotos.com.

headline: The Art of the Wedding Toast
text: MY friend was distressed. His brother was getting married this summer, and he knew he would be expected to give a toast. Not just any toast, but one that would be funny, heartfelt and memorable.

headline: Just One Look | Louis Vuitton
text: Louis Vuitton was on fire for resort, playing with the notions of heat and shine. Sinewy separates in warming tones of cream and brown pleasantly melded with pops of blue and pink on dresses and jackets. Returning in less exaggerated forms from fall were oversize buttons and bell skirts, all of which paid homage to the film “Indochine” with Catherine Deneuve. The film, set in the the French colonial era of the 1930s to 1950s, inspired the tribal yet grand nature of the collection, which featured cutoff trousers, romantic lace blouses and waistcoats, some embellished for extra sizzle. Here, a visor secured with a silk tie rises to the occasion of a single-sleeve sequin and lace dress.

headline: Soft-Shell Crabs in Balance
text: TWO things happen when you bite into a perfectly cooked soft-shell crab.

headline: Herb Butter: Spread It Around
text: Herb butters are excellent, instant meal enhancers, worthwhile to have on hand.

headline: Seeing an Omen on a Faded Newspaper Page
text: THIRTY years ago, Nancy LeSage and Fleur Marks were strangers with something in common. Miss LeSage, of Madison, Conn., and Miss Marks, of Princeton, N.J., saw their photos side by side on a Society News page of The New York Times on Sunday, May 2, 1982.

headline: From Pie-in-the-Sky Dream to Hottest Truck in Town
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: The crisis in Europe took new turns; Jamie Dimon testified about JPMorgan Chase’s trading loss; R. Allen Stanford was sentenced to 110 years on his Ponzi scheme conviction; and Rajat K. Gupta was found guilty in his insider trading trial.

headline: 35 Years Ago, the Mets Traded Tom Seaver
text: In their 51-year existence, the Mets have had their share of happy “where were you when” moments: the 1969 World Series win, Robin Ventura’s game-ending “grand slam” single in 1999 and, of course, Mookie Wilson’s famous dribbler up the first-base line in Game 6 of the 1986 World Series.

headline: A Classic From Loewy’s Portfolio
text: THE Studebaker Avanti was one of those rare cars whose design seemed to arrive fully formed — and without precedent. But it arrived as the company was on its last legs.

headline: From Savior to Orphan
text: A BREAKTHROUGH design introduced 50 years ago in a last-ditch attempt to salvage a gasping automaker, the Studebaker Avanti has been called the car that never dies.

headline: Chic in Review | Lady Gaga Reeks of Fame
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Sports Illustrated to Cut Editorial Staff
text: Weeks before the Summer Olympics in London and the start of the National Football League’s training camps, Sports Illustrated is cutting editorial staff through buyouts and possible layoffs.

headline: Momentary Minglings, Like Encounters on La Rambla
text: The Barcelona collective known as por instantesisn’t as exotic as it sounds. Led by the German-born choreographer Julia Koch and the American director Daniel Zippi, the group named itself after the phrase “by moments,” which seems to mirror the way its collaborators bring pedestrian encounters to fleeting life. A woman sways seductively while caressing her shoulder. A couple’s lips brush slowly for a kiss, then draw apart. Another woman speaks incessantly to anyone who will listen.

headline: The Car That Never Dies
text: The Avanti began as a rakish grand touring car, the result of a whirlwind design program in 1961.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Superhero Story With Humor
text: The seventh volume of “Empowered” hits No. 3 on our paperback graphic books best-seller list this week. Created by Adam Warren and published by Dark Horse, this manga-influenced black-and-white series follows Elissa Megan Powers (a k a Empowered) as she attempts to navigate a life filled with superheroes, ninjas and self-esteem issues.

headline: A Maker’s Beloved Designs
text: STUDEBAKER hired Raymond Loewy in 1936, who then brought in top talent like Virgil Exner from Pontiac and later, Gordon Buehrig, a designer for Auburn, Cord and Duesenburg, and the promising Robert Bourke. He established a studio in South Bend that he visited from New York every few weeks, traveling on a Pennsylvania Railroad train that his firm designed.

headline: An Affordable Icon
text: IN all its forms, the Avanti still turns heads, but its value as a collectible has never equaled its stature as a design icon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Myanmar, Malaysia and Egypt.

headline: Week in Culture Pictures, June 15
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Fight Over Post Tests India Party’s Mettle
text: NEW DELHI — Ordinarily, Pranab Mukherjee might be considered a shoo-in for the largely ceremonial position of president of India. The job usually goes to someone of stature, or at least someone with good political connections, and Mr. Mukherjee has both. At 76, he has spent a half century in Indian politics, often appearing on the global stage, and he is well prepared for the elder statesman role.

headline: City Ballet: Vivacity Breaks Up Doldrums
text: It’s fair to say that New York City Ballet has begun a renaissance. The recent season at the David H. Koch Theater kept supplying evidence of this, not least at Sunday’s closing performance of George Balanchine’s two-act “Midsummer Night’s Dream,” led by Teresa Reichlen as Titania and, even better, with Tiler Peck in the Act II divertissement.

headline: Judge Seems Reluctant to Follow CBS and Block ‘Glass House’ on ABC
text: The latest effort to stop what appears to be a copycat version of a hit reality show is heading in the same direction all the others have traveled: nowhere.

headline: Troubled Greek Economy Is Being Left to Fend for Itself
text: ATHENS — No matter what happens in this weekend’s elections, Greece is rapidly becoming an isolated economy.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: “Wi-Fi and Amtrak: Missed Connections (June 3): Beside issues with Internet connection, there’s no corporate accountability at Amtrak. I’m on Amtrak regularly and often find the Wi-Fi is entirely shut off, not just spotty. When asked to fix it, conductors invariably say, “Service needs to be switched on from a central office.”

headline: E.P.A. Casts New Soot Standard as Easily Met
text: As anticipated, the Environmental Protection Agency announced on Friday that it was proposing to update and tighten national air quality standards for fine-particle soot.Somewhat surprisingly, however, the agency said that by the time these new standards were fully in force in 2020, all but six counties in the United States would be in compliance with them as a result of steps taken to abide by other tightened rules.

headline: Another Little VW
text: The Up, a cute-as-a-Bug Volkswagen, is perfect for the parking-starved city, but won’t be trolling for spaces in America. It’s not coming here.

headline: Just Passing Through, Impressively
text: YOU might assume, on the petite heels of the Mini Cooper, that car companies would be amassing an army of Lilliputian cars to sell here. But consider the Volkswagen Up, AWOL from our shores.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 15
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Puerto Rican Day Parade, the arraignment of a police officer in the killing of Ramarley Graham and a proposed development for the Chelsea Market.

headline: A Conflicted Jury Finds Rajat Gupta Guilty
