text: The jury for the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta took only two days to reach its verdict. But the process was not easy, with several jurors saying they felt conflicted.

headline: Picking The Best Target-Date Mutual Fund
text: Before we get to the business of target-date fund selection, which is the subject of this weekend’s Your Money column, a quick word on the basic merits of target-date mutual funds.

headline: Celebrating Bloomsday, With James Joyce (and Other Irish Writers)
text: Readers picked up on the not-so-subtle nod to James Joyce’s “Ulysses” at the end of my June “Drink” column. Hey, it was hard to resist: for those who love the book, any walk around Dublin in some way evokes the company of Leopold Bloom, Stephen Dedalus and others. It seems you can never get far without passing a landmark that appears in the novel.

headline: Players Who Are a Study in Contrasts
text: It was an Elliott Carter kind of week in New York, and few would complain. On June 8 Mr. Carter, still astonishingly productive at 103, was present for the premiere of his latest work, “Two Controversies and a Conversation,” in Contact!, the New York Philharmonic’s new-music series.

headline: The Midwife as Status Symbol
text: BESIDES being impossibly gorgeous mothers, what else do Christy Turlington, Karolina Kurkova and Gisele Bündchen have in common?

headline: Revisiting a Passion of the Past
text: If briefly during the late 1960s the symphonies of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen seemed to be catching on with American audiences, this was almost entirely because of the advocacy of Leonard Bernstein. In addition to conducting the works prominently, Bernstein recorded three of Nielsen’s six symphonies, as well as the flute and clarinet concertos, with the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Wealth Destruction
text: I haven’t weighed in on the Survey of Consumer Finances, which shows a sharp decline in net worth and real income between 2007 and 2010. I guess the basic response should be “Well, duh” — that’s what happens when you have a massive housing bust and a severe economic slump.

headline: Fête Accompli | WCS Gala in Central Park
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 15
text: More Photographs

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Great Beards and Russian Robots
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: Crony Keynesianism
text: George Osborne, the architect of Britain’s austerity policies, has just done an about face (without, of course, admitting it). Jonathan Portes has the goods: he points out that the assumptions under which the UK government’s new policy of subsidizing private investment — including infrastructure investment! — through loan guarantees makes sense are exactly the same assumptions under which debt-financed government spending on, say, infrastructure makes sense.

headline: Target-Date Funds Not Equally Safe
text: Let’s say you’re 63 years old and trying to figure out how to invest the money you’ve managed to put aside over the years.

headline: This Romeo Doesn’t Fall Short at Love
text: It’s hard to believe now, but there was a time, 5 to 10 years ago, when one of the most serious questions in the ballet world was whether Herman Cornejo could play Romeo.

headline: Smith Street, Brooklyn
text: Scenes from Smith Street, including a birthday party at Carroll Park, a sidewalk sale, Momofuku Milk Bar and the Gowanus Yacht Club.

headline: Formerly Captive Israeli Soldier Now a Sports Columnist
text: JERUSALEM — In his most expansive public comments since he was released eight months ago, Gilad Shalit revealed how his love for sports had kept him going through five years of captivity in Gaza, while providing some personal connection with his captors from the Islamic militant group Hamas.

headline: What Do DNA, Insects and Bullets Have in Common?
text: The phrase “DNA evidence” is so common in real-life cases and on police procedurals these days that it’s easy to forget how relatively new it is to the lexicon. The premiere of “Forensic Firsts,” Sunday on the Smithsonian Channel, takes us back to that eureka moment in the 1980s when genetic science met police work.

headline: Friday Night Music: Save Yourself
text: Some people have recommended for months that I listen to Sharon Van Etten, and I’ve resisted — basically, did I want to listen to another confessional singer-songwriter?

headline: Power Is Always in Vogue
text: WHEN Anna Wintour was in Paris for Fashion Week in March, there was one topic the Vogue editor couldn’t stop talking about. And it had nothing to do with the winter collections.

headline: Block by Block | Smith Street, Carroll Gardens
text: Carroll Gardens is the quiet Brooklyn neighborhood that lies between Red Hook and Gowanus and is known for its Italianate brownstones with spacious front yards.

headline: A Garden? Chess? PTAs Face Choices About How to Spend Parent Money
text: As coffers swell -- or as schools in low-income communities try to figure out how to stretch their budgets -- PTA officers and other parents are prioritizing the use of parents' money, and it's not as easy as it might seem.  “Sometimes, it’s hard to judge what’s the right thing to do,” said Sue Dietrich, the PTA treasurer for Staten Island Technical High School, one of the city’s nine selective high schools, which raises about $60,000 annually. “It’s hard to know what’s really necessary.”

headline: Declaration of Independence
text: LAST January, Amy Chua got an unexpected e-mail just before an excerpt from her provocative child-rearing manual, “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,” appeared in The Wall Street Journal. It was from Wendi Murdoch, the wife of Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns The Journal.

headline: Smile! It’s Time for a Guilty Plunge Into Summer TV
text: There’s a surprising amount of television this summer that threatens to be good for you: “The Newsroom” on HBO. “Michael Wood’s Story of England” on PBS. “N.Y. Med” on ABC. “Political Animals” on USA. You might as well still be in school.

headline: The Costs of Pre-K
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Cunningham | Impressions
text: One of the prettiest sights is the New York Botanical Garden dinner dance in the Bronx.

headline: A Leader in Saving Rivers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Group of 20 to Urge Quicker Action in Europe
text: WASHINGTON — The rest of the world has a message for Europe, whose intensifying debt crisis will dominate the agenda at the Group of 20 summit meeting next week in Mexico: Tell us how you will end this.

headline: Remembering a Dad, and the Little Things
text: My friend Barry just lost a three-year battle with a rare form of lung cancer, the kind you can get even if you’ve never smoked. My grandmother used to say that every person’s life is a novel waiting to be written. In their eulogies, Barry’s children told his story, and the beauty of it was in all the things I didn’t know about Barry, the little things.

headline: Reviewing the Volkswagen Up
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Up, an impressive supermini that began colonizing the urban cores of Europe this year.

headline: The Flowers of Carroll Gardens
text: The neighborhood is known for its Italianate brownstones with spacious front yards, a civilized buffer between home and sidewalk. These are planted in various styles — from garden-club meticulous to near-jungle — but there are recurring plants and flowers, creating a floral theme.

headline: The Health Care and Broccoli Analogy
text: To the Editor:

headline: First Major Talent Exit After Facebook I.P.O.
text: Bret Taylor, Facebook’s chief technology officer, announced Friday afternoon he was leaving the company to start his own. It was the first major exit of a Facebook executive since its public offering nearly a month ago and signals a recurrent challenge in Silicon Valley: How to retain talent after the company goes public and employee shareholders make their millions.

headline: Turn Left at the Roses
text: ON a recent Sunday morning, at the Carroll Gardens Greenmarket in Brooklyn, the pickle guy from Divine Brine in Suffolk County was cutting up some samples, and the bird man from Dipaola Turkeys, out of New Jersey, was grilling bite-size pieces of turkey burger. More than a few fathers with infants strapped to their chests had wandered over from Carroll Park, just across the street, while groups of friends in knee-skimming skirts bought peonies and baby bok choy from the stalls that start at the corner of Smith Street.

headline: For Sale: Avantis and Studebakers. Must Have Good References.
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, I write about the enduring appeal of the Avanti, created by Studebaker 50 years ago. I also offer an update on the most recent Avanti maker, who is serving time for timeshare fraud and whose cars are being offered in a court-ordered sale.

headline: At Camp Sweden, the Party Goes On Even After England Ends the Dream
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The Caravan of Love had traveled more than 800 miles, hoping not to get sideswiped so soon by heartbreak.

headline: The Founding Myth of a Master Pizzaiolo’s Food Truck
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In Sunday’s Automobiles section, I write about the Del Popolo pizza truck and how it came to be a foodie phenomenon in the Bay Area. From the beginning, the truck project was in seasoned hands.

headline: Microsoft and Samsung Try Out Apple’s Secret Sauce
text: There is something different about Microsoft’s event scheduled for Monday in Los Angeles, but also something very familiar. The secrecy surrounding this particular product introduction feels a lot like Apple’s.

headline: A History of Making Protest Messages Heard, Silently
text: They marched down Fifth Avenue on that summer Saturday without saying a word. They chanted no chants, sang no protest songs. The only sounds were the disconcertingly mournful thuds of muffled drums — and, of course, the marchers’ footsteps on the hot pavement.

headline: Prescription for Kids in Trouble
text: From the first moments of “Recall,” as a parent drones on about reality TV while an adolescent scrubs ineffectually at a giant bloodstain on the carpet, we are firmly in the realm of arched-eyebrow mayhem that has proved rewarding for the likes of Quentin Tarantino and Martin McDonagh.

headline: Ratings for Finals Remain High
text: The Oklahoma City Thunder and Miami Heat have split the first two games of the N.B.A. finals — exciting matchups that have so far attracted more viewers than any finals since ESPN and ABC’s current deal with the league began in 2002-03, according to Nielsen.

headline: Creating Rules for Natural Gas Drilling
text: To the Editor:

headline: V-Green, an Online Bridge Magazine
text: Didier Lévy, a Frenchman who has retired to Guadeloupe, has developed some terrific software that easily puts bridge articles into an interactive form. You can play numerous deals at vubridge.com in a more realistic way than when reading about bridge in a newspaper, magazine or book.

headline: Egyptian Activists Debate How Not to Vote
text: CAIRO — As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, many of the Internet activists who helped drive Egypt’s 2011 revolution are dismayed about the choice offered by this weekend’s presidential runoff between two conservatives. In meetings with bloggers in Cairo all this week, conversations returned again and again to how best to respond to a deeply unpalatable choice: voting for Ahmed Shafik, Hosni Mubarak’s last prime minister, or Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that was Mr. Mubarak’s main opposition but has managed to alienate many former allies from last year’s protest movement.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: An Amityville modern, a Fairfield colonial and West Windsor retreat.

headline: Lockheed Is Replacing Strikers at Fighter Plane Plant
text: Lockheed Martin said Friday that it had hired 300 temporary workers to replace striking union employees at its fighter plane plant in Fort Worth and could hire hundreds more.

headline: Obama Acknowledges U.S. Is Fighting Groups Tied to Al Qaeda in Somalia and Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — Opening the window just a little further into his secret war on terrorists, President Obama publicly acknowledged for the first time on Friday that United States military forces had taken “direct action” against groups affiliated with Al Qaeda in Somalia and Yemen.

headline: Dance Position No. 6: Rest
text: For the choreographer Mark Morris, 55, artistic director of the Mark Morris Dance Group, Sunday is often a day of homecoming, when he returns to his apartment in the Kips Bay section of Manhattan after a far-off performance. (The troupe, based in Brooklyn, just got back from its first visit to China.) The peripatetic life sets limits: Mr. Morris has no pets or house plants — “I would have to have a python and a cactus,” he said — and he has trained himself to drink his coffee black so he does not have to go out for milk after a long trip.  JOHN LELAND

headline: Epstein’s New Team Beats His Old One
text: CHICAGO — On a day of divided emotions at Wrigley Field, Theo Epstein’s present got the better of his past as his new team, the Cubs, beat his old one, the Red Sox, 3-0.

headline: The Past Has a Presence Here
text: OAXACA, Mexico — The past casts a sharp shadow here, wherever you look. You see it on mountaintop plateaus, where the ruins of ancient pyramidal staircases and capital-I-shaped ball fields hint at mysterious rituals that disappeared over a millennium ago.

headline: She’s Innocent. We’re Guilty.
text: Sydney, Australia

headline: William Knowles, Nobel Winner in Chemistry, Dies at 95
text: William S. Knowles, who was 84 and in retirement when he shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2001 for improving ways to manufacture drugs, including L-dopa for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease, died on Wednesday at his home in Chesterfield, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis. He was 95.

headline: Refugees Plant Roots in a New Land With a New Garden
text: Angele Nogue grew up on her grandmother’s farm in Cameroon, and growing vegetables has always been part of her life. In 2008, though, she had to flee her country, and was granted asylum in the United States.

headline: Hopes for Diversity at a Brooklyn School
text: A visit to P.S. 257, federally funded to help with its integration, struggles to attract students from outside its attendance zone.

headline: Reggie Pearman, Postwar Middle-Distance Runner, Dies at 89
text: Reggie Pearman, who was one of America’s outstanding middle-distance runners in the post-World War II era, winning multiple titles for New York University, died on Monday near his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 89.

headline: Integrating a School, One Child at a Time
text: HER bow flopping on her head, Kylie Cao pirouetted alongside her fellow kindergartners in pink tutus and black leotards.

headline: Your Guide to a Tour of Decay
text: STAND on the pedestrian walkway of the Greenpoint Avenue Bridge, and you might notice a vaguely ominous red brick tower on the Queens side of the Newtown Creek, looming over the railroad tracks and asphalt plants.

headline: Newtown’s Champion
text: Several years ago, Mitch Waxman stumbled upon Newtown Creek, the heavily polluted Superfund site that forms part of the border between Brooklyn and Queens. Now he’s an expert.

headline: China: Tibetan Dies in Protest Fire
text: A Tibetan herder in China’s northwest Qinghai Province died Friday after setting himself on fire to protest government policies in the region, according to exile groups and Radio Free Asia. The herder, Tamdin Thar, thought to be in his early 60s, set himself on fire in Markethang, in the Huangnan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, said the group Free Tibet. Since 2009, at least 39 Tibetans have set themselves on fire. Of those, 30 have died, according to the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group in Washington. “If the human rights situation doesn’t improve, such tragic incidents will keep happening,” said Tsering Woeser, a Tibetan writer in Beijing. “Many Tibetans think the pain of self-immolation is nothing compared to the pain of living without religious freedom.”

headline: Louisiana: Dining Critic Has a Job, Paper Says
text: Three days after it was reported that Brett Anderson, the well-regarded restaurant critic for The Times-Picayune in New Orleans, was among about 200 employees being laid off, the paper said Friday that it had offered Mr. Anderson “a position writing about restaurants and dining.” Mr. Anderson, 41, is headed to Harvard University in the fall on a journalism fellowship that he landed before the layoffs took place. “We told Brett then that he would have a job with us when the fellowship ended,” Jim Amoss, the paper’s editor, said in a report on the newspaper’s Web site. “We should have communicated that this week when we announced the changes.” Mr. Anderson had said earlier that he was told the fellowship was the reason for his dismissal. Mr. Anderson said that he did not have to make a decision about the job until his fellowship nears its end in 2013. “I don’t know yet,” he said. “I’m going to kick that can down the road a ways as to whether or not I’ll take it.”

headline: Running on Empty
text: Our biggest political division is the war between the empty places and the crowded places.

headline: Attacking the Basket and a Perception
text: OKLAHOMA CITY

headline: The Hague: New Prosecutor Sworn In
text: A former justice minister from Gambia, Fatou Bensouda, became the new prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Friday, replacing Luis Moreno-Ocampo. The court’s mandate is to investigate large-scale and systematic atrocities. It is recognized by 121 countries. Ms. Bensouda, left, who has been deputy prosecutor for the past eight years, said that she intended to expand investigations of large-scale sexual abuse and crimes involving children in conflicts.

headline: Powers, U-2 Pilot Captured by Soviets, Awarded Silver Star
text: WASHINGTON — More than 50 years after his plane was downed in the Soviet Union, Francis Gary Powers was posthumously awarded the military’s third-highest decoration on Friday.

headline: Go, Fight, but Don’t Win!
text: Berlin

headline: Perfect Together
text: Every player knows that there are accomplishments in baseball that might seem personal, yet in fact they belong not to the individual but to the history and legacy of the game itself. Twirling a no-hitter, hitting for the cycle, the grand slam, the perfect game. None of these is meant to be just another tick on a résumé; they’re for the game to own. These markers are much bigger than the players who, technically, accomplished them.

headline: Principal Is Trampled in a Rush to Vilify
text: Anyone who has ever considered a career in school administration, and paid attention to the recent experiences of Greta Hawkins, must surely be wondering whether tending a tollbooth on the George Washington Bridge would secure greater karmic rewards. Since September 2009, Ms. Hawkins, a former French teacher who worked in the New York City school system for 18 years, has served as the principal of Public School 90, an elementary school in Coney Island, Brooklyn, where attacks against her have had an eerie constancy.

headline: Judge Is Taken Off Murder Case for Bias Toward the Defendant
text: NEWARK (AP) — An appeals court on Friday removed the trial judge from the case of a prominent defense lawyer accused of orchestrating the murder of a government informant. The court cited questions about the judge’s impartiality.

headline: For @NewYork, 8 Million Characters
text: WHAT would you do if the city handed you a megaphone and told its people to listen?

headline: The Last-Minute Photographer by City Hall
text: Braulio Cuenca, 46, has hawked his photography services outside the Manhattan Marriage Bureau for nearly 20 years.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Provocateur Surges in a Primary Race for Congress
text: Suddenly, Charles Barron has regained the ability to shock.

headline: Something Borrowed, Something Last-Minute
text: THE couples who marry at Manhattan’s Marriage Bureau, at 141 Worth Street, by City Hall, sometimes forget something — like a bouquet of roses, which they can buy at the store inside for $35, or a photographer, whom they can find outside on the sidewalk. Since 1994, Braulio Cuenca has offered his services as a speedy, last-minute photographer for those taking a step that might be quick, but that they hope will endure.

headline: A Candidate Known for His Unconventional Views
text: New York City Councilman Charles Barron has won prominent political endorsements in his race for Congress this year, but he has a history of attracting attention with fiery speeches and unconventional political views. Some examples:

headline: Educator’s Recipe for School Success
text: PARENTS and principals trying to understand what makes successful New York City schools work ought to read Deborah Kenny’s “Born to Rise: A Story of Children and Teachers Reaching Their Highest Potential” (Harper, $25.99). Teachers don’t need to. They already know.

headline: Michigan’s Attack on Women’s Rights
text: Even at a time when extreme attacks on women’s reproductive rights and freedom are nothing unusual, a sweeping measure on a fast track in Michigan’s Republican-led State Legislature stands out.

headline: Revamped Disney Park Tries Again
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Thousands of people camped on the street overnight waiting to get in. Media coverage by more than 400 print, online and broadcast outlets. Dozens of costumed characters foxtrotting to “Ain’t We Got Fun.” Fireworks at 8 a.m.

headline: Pettitte Turns 40 and Turns His Attention to Facing the Nationals
text: WASHINGTON — A third member of the Yankees turned 40 on Friday as Andy Pettitte joined Raul Ibanez and Mariano Rivera in their fifth decades. Manager Joe Girardi played with Pettitte on the Yankees from 1996 to 1999, and is only seven years his senior.

headline: A Dead Father Remembered by Many, and a Stabbing Suspect Known to Few
text: A woman named Amy, 37, stood with her 3-year-old daughter parked on her hip on East Fifth Street in Alphabet City. “I was his fiancée,” she said. “We had wedding bands already.” And plans for Father’s Day. “We were all going to dress the same. Red shorts and striped, red-and-white polo shirts. From T. J. Maxx.”

headline: Answering a Question About an Airport Bathroom
text: Q. On returning to Kennedy Airport from a trip abroad, I went through Terminal 4. There is something strange about the men’s rooms in that building. At the center of each urinal, toward the bottom, there is an image of a large black housefly. Is this someone’s idea of a joke? Please explain.

headline: In Celebrity Brawl at Club, a Scene of Flying Bottles and Ice Cubes
text: The melee bore the marks of storied New York nightclub brawls of yore: star rappers were involved, egos were bruised and revelers got bloodied. But this week’s altercation involving the R&B crooner Chris Brown and the rap artist Drake stands apart in the weapons of choice: it did not, by most accounts, involve guns or knives, but rather airborne cubes of ice, cocktail glasses and high-priced bottles of liquor.

headline: Mickelson Makes Progress, if Not a Charge, and Survives the Cut
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With a clutch birdie on the last hole of his second round, Phil Mickelson gave himself some much-needed breathing room. Not at the top of the leader board, mind you, but at the bottom, near the cut line. After opening with a 76, Mickelson knew he had to go much lower on Friday to keep alive his dreams of winning his first United States Open.

headline: Romney’s Bus Tour of New Hampshire Lets In a Bit of the Outside World
text: MILFORD, N.H. — Mitt Romney was supposed to depart from his usual campaign approach on Friday, and he did — though not the way his strategists had envisioned.

headline: Banks’ Fire Drill for Greece Election
text: The banks are on high alert.

headline: Excitement for the Wallenda Walk
text: Tightrope walkers, clowns, and other circus performers entertained the people of Niagara Falls, N. Y., before Nik Wallenda’s high wire act Friday night.

headline: T.V. Ratings for Finals Up Seven Percent From Last Year
text: The Oklahoma City Thunder and Miami Heat have split the first two games of the N.B.A. finals — exciting contests that have so far attracted more viewers than any finals since ESPN and ABC’s current deal with the league began in 2002-03, according to Nielsen. Game 2, won by the Heat, 100-96, was seen by an average of 16.7 million viewers on ABC, 7 percent better than the comparable broadcast last year between the Heat and the Dallas Mavericks. Through two games, the average viewership of 16.4 million is also up 7 percent. ¶ Tina Charles had 20 points and 8 rebounds to lead the host Connecticut Sun to a 97-55 victory over the Liberty. Connecticut led by 61-27 at halftime, setting the league record for the largest lead at the break. Essence Carson scored 14 points for New York (3-7). (AP)

headline: The Safest Bank
text: We’re counterprogramming today.

headline: A Step Toward a Dream
text: The Obama administration’s decision to allow as many as 800,000 young immigrants avoid deportation and apply for work permits makes perfect sense. It wisely rescues blameless young people from legal limbo in an immigration system marked by dysfunction and toxic politics.

headline: City Divides and Unites for a Dog Called Blue
text: ELEPHANT BUTTE, N.M. — This is the story of a leash, a law and a city’s dueling definitions of compassion. It is a story of limits tested and stretched; of strife, threats and, possibly, compromise.

headline: The Man Who Punches Steel
text: ON Wednesday morning, a short man walked up to a huge steel light pole in Riverbank State Park in Harlem and began punching away at it.

headline: Taking On a Leash Law
text: A leash, a law and dueling definitions of compassion form a story of a dog who drew both complaints and support from residents of a small desert city.

headline: Jackson Says He Would Not Have Wanted to Coach Flawed Knicks
text: Phil Jackson views the Knicks as a flawed team and says he would have turned down the franchise had it offered him the head coaching job, according to a transcript of a coming segment of “Real Sports” on HBO.

headline: A Final Newscast for Sue Simmons on WNBC
text: 11:51 p.m. | Updated Sue Simmons, a television institution in New York City, anchored her final newscast on WNBC on Friday night, months after reports of her forced retirement startled longtime fans, colleagues and competitors.

headline: Primary Day Is June 26
text: Instead of the usual fall Congressional primary, the vote in New York this year will be on June 26 — days away. These are also newly drawn districts. What hasn’t changed is that New York needs strong representatives in Washington, and voters need to go to the polls and make their voices heard. Here are our endorsements in five Democratic primaries:

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Yale and U.S. Resolve Sexual Harassment Claim
text: NEW HAVEN (AP) — Yale University and the federal Education Department have reached an agreement to resolve a complaint about sexual harassment on the university’s campus, the department said on Friday.

headline: Voices: An Immigration Policy Hits Home
text: Three young people who will be affected by President Obama’s new immigration policy received the news with happiness and trepidation.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Obama’s Announcement Seizes Initiative and Puts Pressure on Romney
text: WASHINGTON — In many ways, President Obama’s unilateral shift in immigration policy was a bluntly political move, a play for a key voting bloc in the states that will decide whether he gets another term. But as political moves go, it held the potential for considerable payoff.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Bay, Just Off Disabled List, May Have Concussion
text: Jason Bay, the Mets’ left fielder who spent several weeks on the disabled list earlier this season with a fractured rib, sustained a possible concussion Friday when he crashed into an outfield wall at Citi Field.

headline: Girl, 9, Gives School Lunch Failing Grade
text: LONDON — On the first day Martha Payne, 9, reviewed her school lunch online, she also posted a picture of a small pizza, a cupcake, a smattering of sweet corn and a solitary reconstituted potato croquette. “I’m a growing kid and I need to concentrate all afternoon and I can’t do it on 1 croquette,” she wrote. “Do any of you think you could?”

headline: Won’t Shut Up
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I came to a dead stop right out of the gate, if that’s even possible, because I made the mistake of trying to start at 1 Across. This was a thorny, tricky puzzle by Barry C. Silk, yet I liked it.

headline: A Cellphone for Every Woman
text: AS world leaders gather next week in Brazil for the Rio+20 summit meeting on sustainable development, poverty fighting will be high on the agenda. Gender inequity should be, as well. In a world where women hold less than 20 percent of all legislative seats, 70 percent of the poorest people — those who live on less than $1.25 a day — are women, and 4 million more women die each year than men, a result of poor families’ preferences for male infants and underinvestment in women’s and girls’ health.

headline: Solo Climber Reaches New Heights
text: As a professional rock climber who often scales cliffs with nothing to save him should he fall, Alex Honnold has encountered plenty of harrowing moments. But early this month Honnold, a 26-year-old from Sacramento, found himself high on a face in Yosemite National Park in a creepy situation.

headline: Boutique Treatment for the Lowly Frank
text: WHAT’S in a hot dog? Just about anything these days. Westchester County is enjoying a boom in boutique hot-dog joints run by young entrepreneurs with a taste for good mustard and an eye on the bottom line. Dobbs Dawg House in Dobbs Ferry, and Doc Ice Southern Snow in Elmsford — two relative newcomers — have opened to noisy acclaim on Web sites like Yelp and Urbanspoon. Kindred spirits include So Dam Hot in Valhalla, and Lubins-n-Links in Tarrytown.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Victory Spurs Talk on Bharara’s Next Move
text: With the conviction of Rajat K. Gupta, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, has now secured the biggest scalp yet in the government’s broad campaign against insider trading on Wall Street.

headline: Presidential Geography: New Mexico
text: This is the inaugural post in our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of all 50 states and the District of Columbia. In each state, we’ll explore the economic and demographic peculiarities that combine to make one state lean toward President Obama and another go solidly to Mitt Romney. We’ll also highlight a bellwether county in each state to watch for clues on election night as to where the statewide vote will end up.

headline: Record of Detective in Fatal Shooting Is Defended
text: The woman was known to the authorities, with prior arrests on charges that included kidnapping, burglary and attempted murder.

headline: U.C.L.A. Trounces Stony Brook in Series Opener
text: OMAHA — After arriving in Omaha as the toast of the town, the Stony Brook Seawolves were routed by U.C.L.A. on Friday in the team’s inaugural appearance at the College World Series. The Bruins, the tournament’s No. 2 overall seed, beat the Seawolves, 9-1, at TD Ameritrade Park.

headline: In New Hampshire, a Coveted Chance to Hunt a Moose
text: CONCORD, N.H. — “Oh my God,” cried Alice Jenness, fanning her overheated face with both hands. She had just won the lottery.

headline: Answering Questions After Exiting the U.S. Open
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For a couple of years now, as each major golf championship concludes, Luke Donald can predict the immediate future. He knows that within 10 minutes he will face one specific question — and it will not be how it feels to be the world’s No. 1-ranked ranked golfer.

headline: Greek Mayor Aims to Show Athens How It’s Done
text: Thessaloniki, Greece

headline: Woods Tied With Two at the Top in the Open
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At most tour stops, par is the loneliest number. Like the interstate speed limit, it’s a signpost to be routinely ignored by golfers in a rush to reach the winner’s circle. Not this week. Not at the Olympic Club, a 7,170-yard speed trap set up to ensnare competitors at the 112th United States Open.

headline: Traditional Flavors, With a Cuban Kick
text: A CUBAN restaurant opening on Long Island is news; in the case of the delightful Cuban Crocodile in Long Beach, it’s great news. This pretty place, which made its debut in February, is the only Cuban restaurant I know of on the Island.

headline: Experimenting Pays Off
text: Experimentation is slowly expanding the versatility of North Fork winemaking. Three offbeat dry whites and an unusual light-colored sparkling red illustrate these successful innovations.

headline: A Taste of the Veneto, a Reminder of Home
text: DOES Fairfield County need another Italian restaurant? The answer is a resounding “Yes” when it is as distinctive as Cesco’s Trattoria, an eight-month-old spot in Darien named for chef-owner Aldo Chiamulera’s father, who did the same work in the Veneto region of Italy, where Aldo grew up.

headline: Vegetarian Woos a Ribs Place
text: Credit for attracting the first New Jersey outpost of Dinosaur Bar-B-Que to Newark goes partly to the city’s mayor, Cory A. Booker.

headline: At Romney’s Side, a Determined Running Mate
text: WASHINGTON — Years before Mitt Romney ever ran in his first political race, his wife, Ann, beat him to public office.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Ann Romney's Role
text: A Conversation With Ashley Parker.

headline: Russian and Uzbek: A Venturesome Menu
text: THE delicious Russian/Uzbek food I found on my first visit to the Shirin Cafe competed for attention with images of barely clad women gyrating in foreign-language music videos on two inescapably big screens. (On my second visit, the monitors displayed only talking heads.)

headline: Caramoor Festival Marked by a Director’s Imprint
text: WHEN Michael Barrett took over as chief executive and general director of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah in 2003, he was brimming with ideas for broadening the center’s programming beyond the standard presentations of core European repertory that had prevailed for much of Caramoor’s 56 years.

headline: Ann Romney Steps Into the Spotlight
text: As the presidential election heats up, Mrs. Romney has become her husband’s chief promoter.

headline: From Flower Girl to Loverly Lady, Accent and All
text: It is not uncommon for theatrical costumes to be too tight, too baggy, too long or too short. But sometimes stage sets can be ill-fitting, too.

headline: Jason Bay Hurt as Mets Fall to Reds
text: It was happening so fast. Josh Thole, the catcher, focused on the Reds’ bruising outfielder, Jay Bruce, lumbering around the bases, but the ball had not come in from left field yet. He saw Jason Bay was down. He thought it was his leg. Then Bruce scored. And Thole saw Bay stand up and sway, and he figured Bay must have hit his head.

headline: Dissecting the Future of Landmarks Preservation
text: “THE Future of the Past” seems an appropriate title for a panel discussion moderated by Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel, who is passionate about the concept of preservation as more forward-thinking than a mere clinging to days gone by.

headline: Disasters in Dating, With a Side of Charm
text: Drama is supposed to feed the soul, but TheaterWorks in Hartford is serving up a meal for the body along with its newest production, “I Loved, I Lost, I Made Spaghetti.”

headline: Prince Hal, You’re Keeping Bad Company
text: Some 400 years before television audiences were riveted by the medieval struggles in “Game of Thrones,” William Shakespeare entertained Elizabethans with his Wars of the Roses cycle. These eight history plays imaginatively dramatize troubled English kings and their heirs during the 15th century, when the Plantagenet dynasty degenerated into the clashing houses of Lancaster and York.

headline: Mayors See Slight Gains, No Thanks to Congress
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Three years after their cities were battered by recession, America’s mayors are exhaling — collectively — and saying the worst may be over.

headline: After Death, Manslaughter Charge for Cyclist
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Despite its hilly topography and hairpin curves, San Francisco has embraced the bicycle. In the last five years, the number of bikes here has jumped 71 percent. The city now ranks fourth (behind Portland, Ore., Minneapolis and Seattle) in the number of people who bike to work, according to the United States Census Bureau.

headline: Obama and Merkel: Politically at Odds, Personal Pals
text: President Obama’s relationship with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is perhaps the best he has had with any foreign leader, but he has yet to convince her how to handle the debt crisis in Europe.

headline: Workers Point Finger at Their Own Agency Amid a Backlog in Veterans’ Benefits
text: To hear wounded veterans tell it, there are few things more daunting, infuriating or soul-crushing than dealing with the Veterans Benefits Administration, the agency that decides whether they will receive disability benefits for injuries and illnesses incurred during war.

headline: Winning Streak Ends, but First-Place Yankees Make Sure It Isn’t Theirs
text: WASHINGTON — The Yankees are expected to be in first place. But the Nationals, who have never finished above .500 since moving from Montreal in 2005, have seized the imagination of baseball with their young stars.

headline: Japan Reaches Tax Deal That Could Help Shrink Debt
text: TOKYO — In a deal that could lead to Japan’s first substantial steps toward reducing its burgeoning debt burden, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda agreed with the country’s two largest opposition parties Friday on legislation to double the country’s consumption tax.

headline: Americans’ Views on Illegal Immigrants
text: American’s views on whether illegal immigrants should be allowed to apply for citizenship, stay as guest workers or be required to leave the United States.

headline: Devilish Olympic Tests McDowell’s Sunny Nature
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Graeme McDowell is a merry man, equally at ease lifting a trophy or a pint. He bounded up the steps from the eighth green to the clubhouse — after shooting a second-round 72 at the United States Open on Friday — like a child who had been let out for recess.

headline: On the Wire Over Niagara Falls
text: Nik Wallenda, whose acrobatic lineage stretches back seven generations, becomes the first person since 1896 to walk from one side of the Niagara to the other on a wire.

headline: Investment Returns as You Age
text: When you start with a lump sum of money at or near retirement, your balance 15 years later depends on how you divide the money among various investments.

headline: Judy Freudberg, a Writer for ‘Sesame Street’ for 35 Years, Dies at 62
text: Judy Freudberg, who entertained millions of children as a writer for Elmo, Big Bird, Oscar the Grouch and other residents of “Sesame Street” for 35 years and shared more than 15 daytime Emmys, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 62.

headline: Russia Solid on the Field, Troublesome Off It
text: With Russia poised to advance to the quarterfinals of Euro 2012 with a win or a tie against Greece on Saturday, Michael Schwirtz writes in Saturday’s editions of The Times about the trouble its fans have caused during the tournament.

headline: 'Abraham Lincoln, Vampire Hunter'
text: A preview of the 3-D action-horror film starring Benjamin Walker, produced by Tim Burton, directed by Timur Bekmambetov and based on the novel by Seth Grahame-Smith.

headline: Egypt’s Military Power Play on the Eve of an Election
text: Egypt’s military rulers shut down the country’s Islamist-led Parliament as voting was about to begin. Protesters continued to gather in Tahrir Square in Cairo.

headline: Fight Over Post Tests Congress Party’s Mettle
text: “Ordinarily, Pranab Mukherjee might be considered a shoo-in for the largely ceremonial position of president of India,” Jim Yardley wrote in The New York Times. “The job usually goes to someone of stature, or at least someone with good political connections, and Mr. Mukherjee has both.”

headline: Corrections: June 16
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Rajat Gupta Convicted of Insider Trading
text: Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, “was found guilty on Friday of conspiracy and securities fraud,” Peter Lattman and Azam Ahmed wrote for DealBook in The New York Times.

headline: Nik Wallenda Walks Across Niagara Falls
text: Nik Wallenda, a seventh-generation stunt performer, became the first man to walk over the Niagara Gorge in 116 years Friday night — and the first ever to walk right over the falls.

headline: With Revolution’s Fate at Stake, Egypt Votes on President
text: CAIRO — Voters cast ballots on Saturday for the first competitively elected leader in Egypt’s history, even as a last-minute grab for power by its ruling generals raised questions about whether the election would be a milestone in the transition to democracy or a facade obscuring the re-emergence of the old order.

headline: The Weekend Word: Executive Action
text: Today’s Times

headline: Japan Public Still Divided as 2 Reactors to Be Opened
text: TOKYO — Brushing aside widespread public opposition to avoid feared electric power shortages, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda ordered the reactivation of two nuclear reactors at a plant in western Japan on Saturday, making it the nation’s first plant to go back online since the crisis last year in Fukushima.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The state police arrested five men in Kashmir on Thursday, accused of being operatives in the terror group Lashkar-e-Taiba, in connection with planting an explosive device on the outskirts of Srinagar last month, Hindustan Times reported. The police had foiled the bid, which they claim was aimed at security personnel, after receiving a tip off from a local, the newspaper reported.

headline: N.F.L. Fans Will Have Access to Coaches’ Film
text: The N.F.L. is giving fans the chance to pay to see the same game film that players and coaches review. That should lead to better analysis, despite what critics like Charley Casserly said last year.

headline: A Suitcase Packed With Expectations, Stowed Away Until Next Year
text: When one packs a suitcase for a trip, it is filled with things to accommodate your travel needs. One packs what he or she hopes is the appropriate clothing, hats, medicines and those special comfort items needed when traveling away from home. But there is something else intangible that also goes into the suitcase, and that is personal expectations.

headline: First Female Astronaut From China Blasts Into Space
text: SHANGHAI — China sent a crew of three, including the country’s first female astronaut, into space on Saturday to carry out its first manned docking mission, an important step in an ambitious plan to build a Chinese space station by 2020.

headline: Live Coverage Sunday of Netherlands-Portugal
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 game between Portugal and the Netherlands on Sunday. Jack Bell will offer commentary and analysis of the Group B match.

headline: Nayef bin Abdul Aziz, Saudi Crown Prince Who Led Crackdown on Al Qaeda, Dies at 78
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Crown Prince Nayef bin Abdul Aziz al-Saud, the hard-line Saudi interior minister who was a late if zealous convert to the fight against Al Qaeda and who took a dim view of democratic change, died in Geneva on Saturday. He was 78.

headline: Happy Bloomsday! The World Celebrates James Joyce
text: LONDON — The Irish, at least, were taking a break from the pervasive euro-gloom on Saturday to mark Bloomsday, an annual celebration of the life and work of James Joyce and of his most famous fictional character, Leopold Bloom.

headline: U.N. Suspends Syria Mission, Citing Increase in Violence
text: CAIRO — The United Nations said Saturday that it was suspending its observer mission in Syria because of the escalating violence, the most severe blow yet to months of international efforts to negotiate a peace plan and prevent Syria’s descent into civil war.

headline: On the Wire Over Niagara Falls
text: Nik Wallenda became the first man to walk over the Niagara Gorge in 116 years Friday night — and the first ever to walk right over the falls.

headline: A Firsthand Look At the Gun That Shot J. R.
text: In advance of TNT’s reboot of the television series “Dallas,” Southfork Ranch, a private home turned conference and event center used as the exterior for the Ewings’ mansion, has been welcoming more visitors than ever.

headline: As the Netherlands Stumbles, Cruyff Imparts Wisdom in Mexico
text: As the Netherlands was getting knocked down — and maybe out — in the European Championships in Ukraine, the former star of Dutch soccer Johan Cruyff was stepping in the door and widening his influence at Chivas of Guadalajara in Mexico.

headline: After Niagara Falls Tightrope Walk, Hope for a Boost in Tourism
text: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario — After 116 years, a man on a wire conquered the Niagara Gorge again.

headline: Bombs in Pakistan Kill at Least 32
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Two bombings killed at least 32 people on Saturday in the Khyber tribal region, according to a senior regional administration official and The Associated Press.

headline: Death Throes
text: My colleague David Brooks tells us that Republicans see the economic crisis as showing that the welfare state is in its “death throes”. And it’s true — that is what they think, or claim to think.

headline: Romney Accidentally Puts Obama in Governor’s Office, but Goes With the Idea
text: WEATHERLY, Pa. — At an early morning stop on Saturday here in Weatherly — a town in a county in which President Obama barely eked out a victory four years ago — Mitt Romney had some backhanded advice for the president.

headline: Goodbye, Bell Bottoms
text: I GREW up in West Palm Beach, Fla. My dad took me hunting, trapping and fishing when I was a kid. Years later, when I was working for I.B.M. in the Midwest, a customer invited me to go pheasant hunting in South Dakota. I haven’t missed a season there in 20 years.

headline: Disputing Whether a Treasure Needs a Name Upgrade
text: GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. — In 1906, a vagabond with an eye for beauty named John Otto fell in love with the unscarred land out here. After seeing the sandstone spires and hypnotic canyons that rise above this town, he made a decision: “I’m going to stay and build trails and promote this place,” he wrote, “because it should be a national park.”

headline: For Palmer, One That Got Away
text: Arnold Palmer couldn’t miss winning the 1962 United States Open. Two months earlier he had won the Masters for the third time in five years. He had won the 1960 Open with a final-round 65 and also the 1961 British Open. More popular than ever at age 32, the charismatic commander of Arnie’s Army made the cover of Newsweek with the caption “Arnold Palmer: Perfection Under Pressure.” In the cherrywood-paneled basement of his Latrobe, Pa., home a coffee table was inlaid with 24 gold medals, each representing a tournament he had won. But one space was empty.

headline: Game Loses One of Its Voices
text: Last Sunday morning, at the Phoenix Communications office in South Hackensack, N.J., Steve Insler spotted Warner Fusselle with a stack of newspapers, pens and a pair of scissors.

headline: One Night Only: Syria in Revolt, on a Beirut Stage
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian playwright Mohammad al-Attar considers the common wisdom about the uprising in his country — “the fear is gone” — somewhat overstated.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Photos of the Moment | Oliver Spencer
