headline: Amid Tight Security and Low Expectations, Egypt Votes Again
text: CAIRO — As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, voters went to the polls in Egypt on Saturday, starting two days of voting in the country’s presidential runoff election, which pits ousted President Hosni Mubarak’s former prime minister against an Islamist candidate from the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Journalist Is Killed in Bangladesh
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh (AP) — A journalist hacked to death by unidentified assailants was probably killed because of his reporting on the illegal drug trade in southwestern Bangladesh, the police said Saturday.

headline: Best Seats in the House? Any Place With Dad
text: When you’re a dad, life sometimes tosses miracles. You have to be enough of a child to catch them.

headline: In Long-Overdue Speech, Dissident Says Nobel Opened Her Heart
text: OSLO — When she was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, while under house arrest in Myanmar, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi said Saturday, she realized that the Burmese “were not going to be forgotten.”

headline: Why You Should Take More Breaks at Work
text: June 15, 2012 - Why you should be taking a break right now.

headline: To Stay on Schedule, Take a Break
text: Editors’ note: Here’s one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

headline: When Software Grades Your Essay
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Singapore Loosens Its Grip, Residents Lose Fear to Challenge Authority
text: SINGAPORE — Those accustomed to thinking of this booming city-state as a bastion of apolitical strivers and shopaholics might be stunned by the burst of civic activism sweeping this crowded flyspeck of an island.

headline: Variety: A Visual Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I must confess that I found today’s acrostic fairly easy because I had already read the book from which today’s quote was taken. That didn’t make the puzzle any less entertaining; on the contrary, one of the reasons I had read the book is because the author, Dr. Temple Grandin, is someone I greatly admire.

headline: Otherworldly Pitch Meets Its Jedi Master
text: In the far corner of the Mets’ clubhouse at Citi Field, propped against the wall near the showers, is a fan’s painting of R. A. Dickey as an alien. On the shelf in Dickey’s locker, next to his usual passel of hardbacks, is a stuffed Yoda, from “Star Wars,” knitted for him by a fan.

headline: Why Punish the Savers?
text: To the Editor:

headline: 2 Car Bombs Target Shiites in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — A security clampdown aimed at protecting Shiite pilgrims failed to prevent a new round of carnage on Saturday as two car bombings in Baghdad killed more than 30 at the end of a weeklong celebration.

headline: In Moscow, Iran to Face Critical Choice in the Latest Round of Nuclear Talks
text: WASHINGTON — The calendar will loom large over the next round of Iran nuclear talks.

headline: Caution, Please: The Boss’s Office Is a No-Spin Zone
text: This interview with  Shawn H. Wilson, president of Usher’s New Look Foundation, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: One Crowd Rumbles; the Other Slumbers
text: A few short years ago, Oklahoma City was primarily known in basketball circles as the place where the former Knicks player John Starks had bagged groceries on his way to the N.B.A. Now, the city has a new calling card: an aural mayhem that its Thunder fans unleash on a nightly basis.

headline: Whatever Greek Voters Decide, the Euro Looks Likely to Suffer
text: IT will be a late Sunday night for financial pros like Markus Krygier. In New York, London, Tokyo and beyond, nearly everyone is focused on one thing right now: Greece. To be precise, they are focused on a “Grexit” — the possibility of the country’s eventual exit from the euro. For many, the prospect has moved from “if” to “when.”

headline: As Greeks Head to Polls Again, a Fear That No One Will Win
text: ATHENS — Greeks head to the polls on Sunday for the second time in two months with a pervasive sense of dread that any government that comes to power will fail to resolve the political and economic turmoil that threatens the country’s future — and the financial stability of Europe itself.

headline: Photos of the Moment | E. Tautz
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: A Contrarian Case for Investing in Europe
text: BANK bailouts, political upheavals, spiking bond yields and falling stock markets: the troubling headlines from Europe just keep on coming.

headline: Lynn Having a Breakout Year for the Cardinals
text: In all the pitching excitement last Wednesday, when the Giants’ Matt Cain fired a perfect game and the Mets’ R. A. Dickey tossed a one-hitter, it was easy to miss Lance Lynn of the St. Louis Cardinals. Lynn struck out 12 White Sox while allowing three hits in seven and a third shutout innings, matching Dickey for the National League lead in victories, with 10.

headline: European Leaders to Present Plan to Quell the Crisis Quickly
text: The head of the European Central Bank and other euro zone leaders worked on Saturday on a grand vision for the euro zone meant to reassure investors and allies that flaws in the currency union will be addressed quickly.

headline: Broken Trust Takes Time to Mend
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA caused a stir recently when he said that “the private sector is doing fine” and pinned many of the nation’s economic troubles on a decline in public-sector employment. He cited some interesting numbers, but he didn’t draw the right lesson — namely, that America is witnessing a collapse of trust in politics, including the shaping of its broad economic policy.

headline: With Every Shot, Olympic Club Tests the Best
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is all Rory’s fault.

headline: The Surprising Mr. Smith, and Other Party Notes
text: One of the obvious names missing from the men’s catwalking calendar in London this weekend is Paul Smith, one of the most recognizable names in British fashion for more than 40 years. The reason he is not showing his collection here, however, is simple. Since 1977, he has presented his men’s wear in Paris, where he has a showroom with hundreds of employees, so it was too big a job to move it all back to London.

headline: Meet Your Cousin, the First Lady: A Family Story, Long Hidden
text: REX, Ga. — Joan Tribble held tightly to her cane as she ventured into the overgrown cemetery where her people were buried. There lay the pioneers who once populated north Georgia’s rugged frontier, where striving white men planted corn and cotton, fought for the Confederacy and owned slaves.

headline: ‘Miracles Happening’
text: In a video posted on Community Education Center’s Web site, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey praises the work of one of the company’s halfway houses at its tenth anniversary celebration.

headline: A Source of Laughter
text: Viviana Tulli dives into a bush in front of her home in Garfield, N.J., as her sister records it. The video was posted on YouTube.

headline: Governor Christie and John J. Clancy
text: Governor Christie praises John J. Clancy, the founder of Community Education Centers. Mr. Clancy was one of the first entrepreneurs to realize that halfway houses could be big business.

headline: Halfway House Alumni
text: Former inmates of Delaney Hall share their experiences. “It’s just been an amazing journey,” one man said.

headline: Tracking Down Halfway House Fugitives
text: Thaddeus B. Caldwell spent four years hunting escapees. He retired from state corrections in 2009 and worked for Community Education, but resigned after less than a year.

headline: Unlocked: Coming Monday
text: Reports of gangs flourishing inside a halfway house.

headline: Honey, the Baby Is Coming; Quick, Call the Photographer
text: Lynsey Stone does not set foot in the shower without placing her cellphone on a nearby ledge, lest she miss an urgent text from a woman in labor. She schedules vacations 10 months in advance to ensure they do not conflict with due dates, and on family outings she and her husband leave their Granbury, Tex., home in separate cars, in case she needs to race to the hospital.

headline: Unlocked: Coming Tuesday
text: A murder inside a halfway house.

headline: Formula One Track, Nearing First Race, Gets Wary Embrace From Austin
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Less than 15 miles from the state capitol, and just down the road from Wild Bubba’s Wild Game Grill, Austin’s next big thing is rising from a sprawling patch of rock, clay and shrubs.

headline: Jonathan Saunders: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: London

headline: Jonathan Saunders Men’s
text: London

headline: 30 Seconds With Johnny Bench
text: Johnny Bench played his way into the Hall of Fame with power hitting and defense during a 17-year-career as a catcher with the Cincinnati Reds. In addition to his 389 home runs and 1,376 runs batted in, Bench won 10 Gold Glove awards and led the National League three times in percentage of runners caught stealing. He had a .990 fielding percentage as a catcher.

headline: With Casino Revenues, Tribes Push to Preserve Languages, and Cultures
text: COARSEGOLD, Calif. — Inside a classroom of some 20 adults and children studying the language of their tribe, a university linguist pointed out that Chukchansi has no “r” sound and that two consonants never follow each other. The comments seemed to stir forgotten childhood memories in Holly Wyatt, 69, the only fluent speaker present, who was serving as a living reference book.

headline: Two Fathers, Two Sons, Two Ball Games
text: When New Yort Times writer (and Motherlode contributor) Matt Richtel was 10, his father took him to the watch the Yankees in the World Series. It was an impulsive trip, one they extended to watch a rained-out game play the next day.

headline: Unlocked, Part 1
text: A 10-month investigation reveals that New Jersey’s privatized halfway houses have become a largely unregulated shadow correction system.

headline: China Closes Window on Economic Debate, Protecting Dominance of State
text: BEIJING — As China heads toward a once-a-decade change of its top leadership, its vaunted embrace a generation ago of markets and economic openness — which catapulted the country from isolated poverty to its place as a global export powerhouse — is also at a turning point.

headline: As Escapees Stream Out, a Penal Business Thrives
text: After serving more than a year behind bars in New Jersey for assaulting a former girlfriend, David Goodell was transferred in 2010 to a sprawling halfway house in Newark. One night, Mr. Goodell escaped, but no one in authority paid much notice. He headed straight for the suburbs, for another young woman who had spurned him, and he killed her, the police said.

headline: Be Prepared for an Extra-Long Off-Season in the N.H.L.
text: The Stanley Cup playoffs and the coronation of the Los Angeles Kings may well be the last N.H.L. action hockey fans will see for some time — perhaps until Christmas.

headline: South Africa Debates Law to Support Tribal Courts
text: CANDU, South Africa — The court’s verdict was swift and sure: Nomvulo Ludonga was guilty as charged. To atone for her offense, Ms. Ludonga, a widowed schoolteacher, had to give the court a live sheep, 50 liters of maize beer, two cases of regular beer, two bottles of brandy and two bottles of juice.

headline: The Catcher: Toughest Job on the Diamond
text: The rigors of being a catcher in the major leagues.

headline: Behind the Plate
text: Russell Martin on the demands of being a catcher for the New York Yankees.

headline: Yes, Wall Street Can Reach Out
text: WITH unemployment just above 8 percent, it’s clear that finding a job is tough for many Americans. But for war veterans, particularly disabled ones, it’s even tougher. Nearly one of every three young male veterans was out of work last year.

headline: Defamation Suit Puts New Law to the Test
text: In September 2010, two Democratic candidates for the State Board of Education posted a YouTube video satirizing the work of the board’s “right-wing extremist” members in revising Texas’ curriculum.

headline: C.E.O. Pay Is Rising Despite the Din
text: YOU call this a revolution?

headline: Two Different Parties, Two Very Different Moods
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Mapping, and Sharing, the Consumer Genome
text: IT knows who you are. It knows where you live. It knows what you do.

headline: ‘Band of Brothers’ Pulls Strings for Cruz Campaign
text: The establishment nearly always wins in Texas politics, so Jason Johnson, a longtime Republican consultant, said he thought it would be next to impossible to stop a powerful and wealthy lieutenant governor who would never run out of money or friends.

headline: Iranian Nuclear Progress …
text: The uranium enrichment process seeks to raise levels of U-235, a rare isotope used to fuel bombs and reactors.

headline: One Hard Way to Play Ball
text: It was a typical moment in an ordinary game on an average day for a major league catcher. This one happened to be May 30 in Anaheim, but it could have been August in Kansas City or March in Tampa.

headline: Plumbers in the Outfield: Meet the All-Watergate Team
text: Richard M. Nixon was a baseball fan whose presidency was wrecked by the Watergate break-in, which happened 40 years ago Sunday. How do you properly commemorate the seismic political scandal of the 1970s while recognizing Nixon for rooting for the Washington Senators and witnessing Dave Righetti’s no-hitter from George Steinbrenner’s private box at Yankee Stadium? With an All-Watergate team.

headline: Romney Paints Himself as the Anti-Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Speaking by video from Pennsylvania to a crowd gathered at the Faith and Freedom Coalition conference here on Saturday, Mitt Romney presented himself as the antithesis of President Obama and his policies.

headline: Niagara Falls Tightrope Walk Is a Ratings Bonanza for ABC
text: The live telecast of a tightrope walk over Niagara Falls on Friday night did exactly what ABC hoped: it lifted the network to a first-place finish for the night and provided evidence that there’s an audience out there hungry for big television stunts.

headline: Changing Locations for Lunch
text: QUAKERTOWN, Pa. — It was hoagie interruptus for Mitt Romney on Saturday afternoon in this small town north of Philadelphia.

headline: It’s Not the Years, It’s the Miles
text: The first two games of the 2012 N.B.A. finals played out like repeats of the same horse race. The Miami Heat ran to an early lead, looking nearly invincible, then the Oklahoma City Thunder stormed from behind.

headline: Reagan and Inflation
text: Hmm. I thought I might respond to something that has been coming up in comments and emails recently. I’ve been writing about how macroeconomic reality under Ronald Reagan didn’t actually match the myth, and many people are inevitably upset. And one of the things they tend to bring up is the hoary old myth that the 80s success in taming inflation was somehow a terrible shock and surprise to Keynesians, who had no explanation.

headline: Egyptians Head to the Polls
text: Egyptians lined up Saturday to pick the first president since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak, choosing between a stalwart of the old secular autocracy and a veteran of its Islamist opposition.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Ancestors
text: The first lady’s family tree includes pioneers who once populated north Georgia’s rugged frontier, fought for the Confederacy and owned slaves.

headline: The First Family, Redefined
text: Michelle Obama’s ancestry links her to a white woman named Sherry George through the painful legacy of slavery.

headline: Romney Horse Wins Spot on Olympic Dressage Team
text: GLADSTONE, N.J. — Mitt Romney and his wife, Ann, who plan to attend the opening of the Olympic Games in London this summer, now have a personal rooting interest in the event.

headline: Too Small? An Astro Responds to Doubts in a Big Way
text: The first time he saw Jose Altuve, in the summer of 2006, Omar Lopez liked almost everything. Altuve was 16 years old and ripped line drives from gap to gap. He showed good range and hands at second base. He always hustled. To Lopez, a scout and minor league manager for the Houston Astros, there was only one problem: Altuve was very, very small.

headline: Journey to the Center of the Video Game Universe
text: The annual Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, attracted tens of thousands of video game aficionados at the Los Angeles Convention Center this month.

headline: Before and After Title IX: Women in Sports
text: It’s hard to exaggerate the far-reaching effect of Title IX on American society. Here are a few of the landmarks along the timeline of women in sports, before and after the passage of the law.

headline: F1 on Pause for 24 Hours … of Le Mans
text: It is rare for the world’s greatest endurance automobile race to not take place during a Formula One Grand Prix weekend. But that is what is happening this weekend, as the 24 Hours of Le Mans starts at 3 p.m. in France Saturday and ends at 3 p.m. Sunday. A lot of Formula One media, fans and other people within the series will be watching the race closely in a way they usually cannot do. And it will be a race very much worth watching, from many points of view — some even relevant to Formula One.

headline: This Week at Film Forum
text: “The Terrible Elbows” (1965, Georges Millefeux) Determined to improve his station, Claude LeFevre — a heavy-lidded pickpocket from the wrong side of the tracks — hatches a reckless plot to seize the tracks and move them 200 yards to the right. While hurrying across the Pont Neuf, he meets Lulu, an enchanting schoolgirl of 37, when her head gets stuck between the spokes of his bicycle wheel. They quickly become lovers — then rivals, then acquaintances, then paramedics, then lovers once again — in this New Wave romance that dispenses with traditional notions of theme and structure in order to set the world record for jump-cuts.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Schools for Rich and Poor
text: Readers discuss how to reduce educational inequities.

headline: First Theater, Then Facebook
text: THE 300th birthday of Jean-Jacques Rousseau falls next week, and it is only proper to wish him a happy one. He had a few choice words to offer on the theme of happiness — the sort associated not with fleeting social pleasures but with “nothing external to ourselves, nothing if not ourselves and our own existence.”

headline: National Secrets and National Security
text: ON May 29, a New York Times article depicted President Obama as deciding case by case on secret drone-strike assassinations, personally poring over photos of prospective targets.

headline: Capt. Mike Carriker
text: Capt. Mike Carriker, a chief test pilot for Boeing, was involved in ensuring the safety of the most commonly used commercial airplanes that will carry travelers this summer. A former Navy pilot who flew A-7E and F-18 combat jets, Captain Carriker has logged more than 8,000 flight hours in more than 130 airplanes.

headline: The Strange Career of Juan Crow
text: THE depth of my alienation from home hit me last January, when Alabama shut out Louisiana State for the college football championship. Even in the familiar afterglow of ’Bama’s second title in three years, I had to ask myself, what right did my state have to brag, about anything?

headline: Thoughts on Fathers and Families
text: A FEW years ago, while I was preparing to write a memoir about my father, I spent time looking through old photographs. One in particular, which I hadn’t seen in years, caught my attention. It’s not a typical family portrait. But by mid-20th-century America’s stingy definition, we weren’t a typical family.

headline: Reform, in the Name of the Father
text: Abuja, Nigeria

headline: Summonses Often Issued, Mostly Tossed
text: Of New York City’s summonses in 2011, most were dismissed or thrown out.

headline: Inside the Warped World of Summons Court
text: Step into the dingy hallways of New York City summons court in Lower Manhattan and you are instantly struck by the racialized nature of this system. New York is a multiracial city, but judging from the faces in cramped courtrooms, one would think that whites scarcely ever commit the petty offenses that lead to the more than 500,000 summonses issued in the city every year.

headline: Stronger Medicine for What Ails Horse Racing
text: Regulators in Kentucky, the heart of the horse breeding industry, have taken a significant step against the widespread doping that is putting horses’ lives and the sport’s credibility at risk at racetracks across the nation. A diuretic drug routinely used on race days to shed water weight and boost horses’ performance will be banned under an overdue regulation adopted last week by the Kentucky Horse Racing Commission.

headline: The Children Deserve Justice
text: There has been no shortage of child sex abuse scandals during the legislative session that is going into its final week in Albany — the Penn State case and the cover-up trial of Msgr. William Lynn in Pennsylvania and, closer to home, the abuse allegations at Syracuse University and the private Horace Mann School in New York. That makes it all the worse that lawmakers have done little to fix New York’s weak laws for protecting children from sexual predators and providing victims with justice.

headline: Energy Etch A Sketch
text: As governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney endorsed an aggressive program to reduce the state’s greenhouse gas emissions, pushed to close old coal-fired power plants and embraced wind and solar power. Then came his bids for the Republican presidential nomination, first in 2008 and now in 2012. On climate change as on other issues, he has transformed himself, bit by reactionary bit.

headline: Fair Use, Art, Swiss Cheese and Me
text: NONE of the thoughts that occurred to me on that tranquil afternoon when a slice of Swiss cheese was deposited on my face were so exotic as to include the notion that, 15 years later, I would listen to judges debate whether I should be allowed to remove the cheese and set it on fire.

headline: First Tahrir Square, Then the Classroom
text: Istanbul

headline: Moral Dystopia
text: EVERYONE is good, until we’re tested.

headline: Buddhists’ Delight
text: WHY was I in a tent in northern Vermont? Much less a tent in the woods at a Buddhist meditation center, reading Sakyong Mipham’s “Turning the Mind Into an Ally” by the light from my smartphone?

headline: Sympathy for the Radical Left
text: IT is difficult to envision an American parallel to Syriza, the far-left political coalition that has a chance to throw Europe into further turmoil with a victory in this weekend’s Greek elections. But imagine a movement that combines elements from Occupy Wall Street and Ralph Nader’s 2000 presidential campaign, and you have a sense of where Greece’s leading opposition party would fit in the American political spectrum.

headline: 2012’s Financial Free-for-All
text: FRIENDSHIP brings such blessings. And such bargains! Only because of our closeness was President Obama willing to drop his asking price and offer me a picture and a moment with him on the cheap. At least that’s what my invitation to a fund-raiser last Thursday night said.

headline: Pinched and Griping in Iran
text: TEHRAN

headline: تنگدستی و تقلا در ایران
text: This is the Persian-language translation of a New York Times Op-Ed column by Nicholas D. Kristof. If you cannot view the Persian, you might need to adjust the settings on your Web browser or on your computer’s operating system.

headline: Female Athletes, Thank Nixon
text: POOR Richard Milhous Nixon. Loathed by the left and having left no estate for the right, Nixon’s stock sells cheap these days and still finds no takers.

headline: Readers Comment on Iran Sanctions
text: My Sunday column, based on my road trip across Iran, looks at economic sanctions there. Bottom line is that they are working pretty much as Washington wants them to: they are inflicting real pain, often on ordinary citizens, in ways that inflame discontent with the system.

headline: Playable
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There will be a Notepad that is worth reading in tomorrow’s (Monday’s) puzzle that says: “When this puzzle is done, the circled letters, reading from left to right and top to bottom, will reveal who wrote the seven songs in the theme.”

headline: Pettitte Goes 7, but the Yankees Take Twice That to Win
text: WASHINGTON — Oh, the lengths the Yankees must go just to win a game without a home run.

headline: Stage Collapses Before Toronto Radiohead Concert
text: A massive rooflike structure collapsed onto a temporary stage for a Radiohead concert in Toronto on Saturday afternoon, hours before the band was supposed to go on, killing a stagehand and injuring at least three other workers, CNN and the CBC reported.

headline: Wambach Stunner Helps U.S. Women Beat Sweden
text: The United States women’s national team began a two-game trip to Sweden on Saturday with a 3-1 victory over the host country. Alex Morgan scored in the first half and Tobin Heath in the second, but the goal of the day — and that includes the Euro 2012 action — was the 35-yard, first-touch half-volley scored by Abby Wambach in the eighth minute.

headline: How to Beat the Heat Without Having to Go Too Far
text: This time last year was the beginning of a record-busting heat wave that gripped Texas, with several cities experiencing 50-plus consecutive days of 100-degree-plus temperatures and an average 2011 summer temperature of 86.7 degrees. The rains this spring have cooled things off, but the first day of summer is approaching, and with it expect above-average temperatures, says John Nielsen-Gammon, the state’s climatologist. While some people flee the oppressive heat and vacation in cooler climates in the North, there are ways to stay in state and keep cool.

headline: Eugene Selznick, Beach Volleyball Pioneer, Dies at 82
text: Eugene Selznick, a celebrated volleyball innovator who helped raise American players’ game to international caliber in the 1960s, and whose shrewdness in drafting Wilt Chamberlain for a 1970s exhibition of beach volleyball helped make Californians’ beach-party game an Olympic sport, died on June 11 in Los Angeles. He was 82.

headline: 4 Climbers Presumed Dead in Mt. McKinley Avalanche
text: Four Japanese climbers are presumed dead days after an avalanche consumed a stretch of Mount McKinley where they had begun their descent.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 17
text: As the presidential race heats up, Mitt Romney will appear on his first Sunday show — other than Fox News — to discuss the things both he and President Obama said last week on the campaign trail. David Plouffe, Mr. Obama’s senior adviser, will make the network rounds as well, defending the president’s words on the economy and promoting his new policy shift to cease deportations for some young illegal immigrants.

headline: Mickelson, With Plenty to Celebrate, Is Hoping for One More Reason
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The United States Open falls on Father’s Day weekend, a quirk in the calendar that’s seen as serendipitous since fathers and sons often treat golf as a bonding exercise. A dozen times in Phil Mickelson’s playing career the tournament has fallen on his birthday, a scheduling oddity that is beginning to feel more like a barb than a bonus for Mickelson, whose struggles continued on Saturday at the event he most wants to win.

headline: Schwartzel Pushes Through Pain
text: The South African Charl Schwartzel grimaced after almost every swing on the practice range on Saturday at the United States Open. A few times, he clutched his stomach. Somehow, he kept going. Schwartzel, the 2011 Masters champion, was three over par in the first 36 holes of the United State Open despite playing with an abdominal tear.

headline: Woman, 88, Is Killed in Bronx Apartment
text: Neighbors at the Pelham Parkway Houses in the Bronx knew Evelyn Shapiro as a well-dressed, agreeable woman who, even well into her 80s, remained independent and active, still driving and doing her own grocery shopping.

headline: Greens Slow as Tournament Goes On
text: Several players early in Saturday’s third round remarked how much slower the greens at the Olympic Club were compared to the first two rounds. Customarily, the greens at the United States Open get quicker as they dry out.

headline: For Many Immigrants, Policy Offers Joy and Relief
text: LOS ANGELES — Ana Sochitl graduated from the University of California, Los Angeles, on Saturday, with a degree in sociology. But until Friday, she had worried that even after she threw her cap into the air, she would be stuck at her job at a taco shop, the price of having immigrated here illegally at age 4.

headline: Bay Enters Disabled List With Another Concussion
text: Call it bad luck. Call it a bad break. Call Jason Bay injury prone. Whatever it is called, it had Mets Manager Terry Collins fidgeting Saturday, clearly worried after Bay’s latest stroke of bad luck, his latest bad break, his latest injury.

headline: Under Fire, Westbrook Will Keep Shooting
text: MIAMI — Two games into the N.B.A. finals, Oklahoma City point guard Russell Westbrook is averaging nearly a triple double against the Miami Heat, but do not confuse him with the next Magic Johnson.

headline: The Pitfalls of a Counterattack
text: Levon Aronian’s two losses in the early rounds of the Tal Memorial tournament in Moscow last week — games in which he was quite soundly beaten — illustrate one of his tactics that his opponents may be able to exploit.

headline: On Going Forth in the World
text: At colleges and universities across the country, many notable names have sent the Class of 2012 on its way with words of wisdom, doses of reality and touches of comedy.

headline: Familiar Faces Offering Advice, Idealism and Humor
text: Alongside the statesmen, tycoons and artists who addressed the class of 2012 at commencement exercises this spring, a popular choice of speakers seemed to be “people we’re used to seeing on television,” offering a dose of comforting familiarity to young people headed into a parlous world.

headline: Cuomo and Christie Request Federal Financing for Sept. 11 Museum
text: Amid the seemingly interminable wrangling over financing for the National September 11 Memorial Museum, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey sent a letter to the National Park Service on Saturday seeking federal money for the project.

headline: At Open, Counting the Damage on the First Six Holes
text: The first six holes at the Olympic Club have lived up to their billing as a daunting test for the world’s best players at the United States Open.

headline: Two Women and Two Trajectories in China
text: BANGKOK — When the photograph was posted online, the reaction inside China was immediate, massive and angry. In no time, there were more than a million page views.

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: Sheldon Adelson, a wealthy casino owner, is committing to give at least an additional $10 million to conservative groups expected to play a major role in this year’s presidential and Congressional elections, cementing his growing role as one of the country’s leading political financiers.

headline: Steve Ben Israel, a Living Theater Performance Artist, Dies at 74
text: The young Steve Ben Israel was a longhaired, card-carrying pacifist, anarchist, comedian and performance artist who toured during the 1960s and ’70s with the Living Theater, an avant-garde repertory group. He had leading roles in many of the company’s cheerfully seditious productions, including “Paradise Now,” in which the cast, naked, exhorted audience members to seize the theater, form anarchist cells and overthrow the government.

headline: Birdies Finally Arrive, but Woods Falls From Lead
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The scoreboard at the 112th United States Open broke into a rash of red numbers Saturday. After a two-day quarantine imposed by the United States Golf Association to prevent a spread of birdies, rounds below par suddenly became contagious at the Olympic Club. The infected included everyone from the United States Open winners Graeme McDowell, Ernie Els and Retief Goosen to Lee Westwood, a veteran desperate to join their exalted ranks.

headline: Forget Feel-Good Story: 17-Year-Old Aims to Win
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Standing by the practice putting green Wednesday, 17-year-old Beau Hossler said he had simple goals for the 112th United States Open.

headline: Early Curveball Proves Costly, and the Mets Cannot Recover
text: Jon Niese dawdled as he left the mound, with one pitch to blame. He walked slowly toward the dugout, glancing briefly toward the sky, slapping the air halfheartedly, boiling in a kind of quiet rage undoubtedly.

headline: Punching Steel With Johnny Knuckles
text: Johnny DeVincenzo, known as Johnny Knuckles, began punching steel poles while in prison, to win bets and respect. The thick calluses on his fists attest to his ability to punch through his pain.

headline: Decision Day for Greece and the Euro
text: Decision day dawned for the Greeks on Sunday as they headed out to vote in an election that they were being told would determine the economic future of their country, Europe and even the wider world.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: The cover story in Tehelka magazine, entitled “Jailhouse Rock,” uncovers the continuing “goonda raj” — or thugs’ reign — in the state of Uttar Pradesh despite assurances from the newly elected chief minister, Akhilesh Yadav, of stringent action against criminals in the state. The author, Ashish Khaitan, cites several examples of convicted gangsters, incarcerated for a broad range of crimes including murder, extortion, abduction, assault and others. Abhay Singh, a notorious don, is “back in business” under the new administration in the state, the article notes. “On 24 May, the Samajwadi government…took the decision to withdraw a case registered in Faizabad district court under the U.P. Gangster Act – the only case out of 18 pending cases in which [Abhay] Singh had not got a bail,” thus allowing Mr. Singh to go free. The district police signed off on this. Incidentally, “exactly two years ago, the same district police had booked Mr. Singh under the U.P. Gangster Act,” Mr. Khaitan reported.

headline: The Gift of Being Gay and a Dad
text: I’m in my mid-40s. Growing up, there was no such thing as gay parenting. I had a vague notion, I think, probably from television or a movie, that some kids’ fathers or mothers could end up running off with someone of the same sex. So, technically, they were a parent and they were gay – but it was a roundabout, devastating way to do it, kind of like demolishing a building by using a hurricane. It gets the job done but you wouldn’t want to see it.

headline: Egypt’s Military Cements Its Powers as Voting Ends
text: CAIRO — The Muslim Brotherhood early Monday projected its candidate, an Islamist, as the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, hours after the ruling military council issued an interim constitution granting itself broad power over the future government, all but eliminating the president’s authority in an apparent effort to guard against just such a victory.

headline: Supporters of Bailout Claim Victory in Greek Election
text: ATHENS — Greek voters on Sunday gave a narrow victory in parliamentary elections to a party that had supported a bailout for the country’s failed economy. The vote was widely seen as a last chance for Greece to remain in the euro zone, and the results had an early rallying effect on world markets.

headline: Canyon Ranch Opens Its Doors to Teenagers
text: Canyon Ranch, the upscale spa that usually caters to adults, is dedicating two weeks this summer to a weight-loss program for parents and teenagers 14 to 17 years old. The seven-night program, held at the Tucson spa on July 8 and again starting Aug. 12, offers participants group and individual sessions with a nutritionist who instructs them on how to prepare healthy meals together, and with an exercise physiologist who gives guidance on incorporating fitness into their lives. The program also offers exercise classes and a meeting with a life coach. Every participant goes home with a customized plan and receives nine 50-minute follow-up sessions with his or her choice of specialist.

headline: Disruptions: Wearable Gadgets Upset  F.A.A. Curbs on Devices
text: Pity the poor flight attendant. They didn’t sign up for this: millions of petulant airline passengers surreptitiously reading digital books and magazines on their iPads or Kindles during takeoff and landing.

headline: Paul Jenkins, Painter of Abstract Artwork, Dies at 88
text: Paul Jenkins, a colorful Abstract Expressionist who came of age during the heyday of the New York School and for several decades carried on its highly physical tradition of manipulating paint and canvas, died on June 9 in Manhattan, where he lived and had continued to paint until recently. He was 88.

headline: Mitt Romney, Weather Man
text: BRUNSWICK, Ohio — As the rain slowed to a light spit, the bloated periwinkle clouds faded to white and the sun crested, Mitt Romney showered the crowd at a Father’s Day pancake breakfast here with a hail of weather metaphors.

headline: In Chapman the Reds Have a Lights-Out Closer, for Now
text: If it were four months ago, or perhaps next season — if the Reds had their way, Aroldis Chapman would be a starter. Or so was the plan.

headline: Rodney King Dies at 47; Police Beating Victim Who Asked ‘Can We All Get Along?’
text: LOS ANGELES — Rodney G. King, whose 1991 videotaped beating by the Los Angeles police became a symbol of the nation’s continuing racial tensions and subsequently led to a week of deadly race riots after the officers were acquitted, was found dead Sunday in a swimming pool at the home he shared with his fiancée in Rialto, Calif. He was 47.

headline: Romney Doesn’t Say Whether He Would Overturn Obama Immigration Order
Traditional Tailoring Meets the Younger Pack
text: After the E. Tautz show, in a wharf building on the east side of London, I stopped with Jonathan Player, who is shooting the men’s collections for The Times this weekend, for a coffee at an Italian place nearby. The clearly fashionable couple at the next table struck up a conversation, and, as it turned out, they were Alex and Zofia Torun-Shaw, the founders of Laird & Co., a young company making gentlemen’s hats here in London’s grand millinery tradition. They made the hats for some of the cool shows this weekend, including a pastel pink crusher for E. Tautz, which is a recently revitalized, more contemporary division of the Savile Row tailor Norton & Sons.

headline: Box Office Busts for Sandler and Cruise Movies
text: LOS ANGELES — The weekend’s two new wide-release movies — “Rock of Ages” and Adam Sandler’s ultracrude “That’s My Boy” — both flopped, continuing Hollywood’s boom-or-bust summer.

headline: Long Run Greek Competitiveness
text: One of the things you keep hearing about Greece is that if it exits the euro one way or another there will be no gains, because Greece basically can’t export — so structural reform is the only way forward.

headline: Revisiting the Era of Automatic Dining
text: Audrey Meadows worked there in “That Touch of Mink.” Marlo Thomas met a photographer there in an episode of “That Girl.” Joan Crawford longs for a fellow patron’s pie in “Sadie McKee.” In “Easy Living,” Jean Arthur calmly digests her beef potpie while cafeteria chaos ensues. Neeley ate there in “A Tree Grows in Brooklyn.” An Irving Berlin ditty evokes the place (“let’s have another cup of coffee”) as do the lyrics of “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.” The advertising slogan “Less work for mother” became a middle-class mantra.

headline: Police Close SoHo Club After a Celebrity Brawl
text: The police have shut down a nightclub where the R&B singer Chris Brown and people associated with the rapper Drake were involved in a brawl early Thursday morning, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Tribute: Thierry Roland, the Legendary Voice of Soccer in France

headline: Euro 2012 Highlights: Portugal (2), Netherlands (1)
text: The myriad permutations in Euro 2012’s Group B for bedlam played out Sunday with Germany and Portugal advancing to the quarterfinals: Portugal squashed the Netherlands, 2-1, while Germany defeated and eliminated Denmark by the same score.

headline: Victim of Radiohead Stage Collapse Identified as Drum Technician
text: The man killed when a stage roof collapsed Saturday afternoon just before a Radiohead concert in Toronto has been identified as Scott Johnson, 33, from South Yorkshire, England. He was a drum technician for the band, the BBC and The Globe and Mail reported. Mr. Johnson also worked for Keane, another British band.

headline: In Brooklyn, Another Church Receives the Mayor’s Gospel on Stop and Frisk
text: Updated 4:20 p.m. | For the second consecutive Sunday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took to the pulpit at a large, predominantly African-American church and defended the Police Department’s controversial stop-and-frisk program, saying it needed to be “mended, not ended.”

headline: And Then What?
text: So it appears that the governing coalition in Greece has pulled out a narrow victory — winning only a minority of votes, but getting a narrow majority in the parliament thanks to the 50-seat bonus New Democracy gets for coming in first.

headline: A ‘Ulysses’ for Those Unable to Make ‘Bloomsday on Broadway’
text: Fans of James Joyce who were unable to attend the annual “Bloomsday on Broadway” readings at Symphony Space on Saturday – along with anyone who appreciates the sound of famous literature read aloud by trained actors – will want to sample the BBC Radio 4 production “James Joyce’s Ulysses,” currently accessible to American listeners on the BBC Web site. Broadcast on Saturday – June 16 being the day when the action of “Ulysses” takes place – this new radio adaptation consisted of segments scattered across the day’s schedule, at times roughly corresponding to the movements of Leopold Bloom and Stephen Dedalus across Dublin in the novel.

headline: Sexy Drug Dealers Have Parents, Too
text: It was not possible to finish Don Winslow’s lean, mean, piercingly funny 2010 “Savages” without wanting more. But there was a problem. By the time Mr. Winslow finished his tale about three dope-dealing Laguna Beach hipsters — two guys and a girl: Ben, Chon and O — they were floating out to sea on God’s great cosmic surfboard. None of them was available for an encore.

headline: Rodney G. King, Symbol of Police Brutality, Dies at 47
text: The acquittal of the police officers accused of beating him during a traffic stop led to six days of rioting in South Los Angeles in 1992.

headline: Protecting the Key, if Not Their Bodies, the Heat Try to Draw Charges
text: MIAMI — While Oklahoma City has the shot-blocker extraordinaire Serge Ibaka to clean up defensive mistakes near the basket, the Miami Heat have their own plan to protect the paint against the Thunder.

headline: Aftermath of the Greek Vote
text: With the Greek election results now in, the impact is being weighed in the zone of 17 countries using the euro currency – not to mention giant economies like the United States and China whose precarious health depends in part on Europe’s success. The Lede blog has been following the reaction as reported by correspondents from The New York Times and The International Herald Tribune based around the world.

headline: I.O.C. Investigating Olympic Ticket Sales
text: International Olympic Committee officials have opened an investigation in response to allegations that officials violated the committee’s rules about ticket sales to the London Games.

headline: A Sibling Odyssey, in Space
text: For most of its deliriously odd 75 minutes “Space//Space,” a mythic and slyly theatrical production by the experimental company Banana Bag & Bodice, seems like some kind of cosmic joke. It’s about brothers in space, bored out of their minds.

headline: A Tea Party of a Circus: No Mad Hatter Here
text: In calling her company Wind-Up Dances, Emily Faulkner has hit upon an accurate label. In the two dances she presented at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Friday, her default way of moving is toylike. The body twists in segments, softly but mechanically, all elbows and knees. Occasionally one part of the toy helps another part along. A less flattering label might be Chiropractic Choreography.

headline: Euro Fears Are Eased — for Now
text: ATHENS — Greek voters narrowly favored a pro-Europe party in Parliamentary elections on Sunday, a result that is likely to calm world markets and ease fears that the country will leave the euro zone, our colleague Rachel Donadio reports from Athens.

headline: Music, Meeting at the Crossroads
text: Most summer music festivals find their artistic definition through an overall theme. The Chelsea Music Festival, which opened its third season with a rewarding concert on Friday night at the trendy Eyebeam Art + Technology Center, is juggling, by my count, at least six themes that mostly overlap, though not without some stretching.

headline: Thousands March Silently to Protest Stop-and-Frisk Policies
text: In a slow, somber procession, several thousand demonstrators conducted a silent march on Sunday down Fifth Avenue to protest the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policies, which the organizers say single out minority groups and create an atmosphere of martial law for the city’s black and Latino residents.

headline: Young Has Solid Outing, but Reds Hang On for Sweep
text: It has been all or nothing these days for the Mets, who were swept a week ago by the Yankees, before winning all three of their games last week against the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Think Before You Breed
text: As a young woman in my 20s I pondered whether or not to have children. Is there a way, I wondered, to decide thoughtfully rather than carelessly about this most momentous of human choices?

headline: Yankees Turn Showdown Into Showcase in Sweep
text: WASHINGTON — It was supposed to be an interleague showdown between the Yankees and the Nationals, the two hottest teams in baseball riding six-game winning streaks and leading their divisions.

headline: Web Sites Illuminate Unknown Artists
text: At twilight on Monday, something new will light up a Times Square billboard. An original work of art, 23 stories high, will replace a bright yellow ad for Sprint.

headline: A Fresh Breeze in Pastoral Russia
text: Experiencing a little discomfort is probably an appropriate way to immerse yourself in the world of Chekhov. It’s not the thunderclap of tragedy that plagues his characters, after all, but nagging, incurable heart cramps. The funky, fresh new production of “Uncle Vanya” that opened on Sunday night at Soho Rep  brings this point home to the audience with unusual immediacy.

headline: A Special Milestone
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There is a Notepad that is worth reading on today’s puzzle that says: “When this puzzle is done, the circled letters, reading from left to right and top to bottom, will reveal who wrote the seven songs in the theme.”

headline: Romantic Mishaps in Web-Size Bites
text: When you’re No. 2, you have to try harder. When you’re No. 2 in unique viewers of online video by a score of 157 million to 53 million, you have to try a lot harder.

text: The fourth-floor space on East 126th Street does not look anything like a museum.

headline: Southern Baptists Set for a Notable First
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Southern Baptist Convention, a denomination born in 1845 in defense of slavery and a spiritual home to white supremacists for much of the 20th century, is poised to elect its first African-American president.

headline: Relationships, Flawed and Fragile, in an Updated Classic
text: It’s best to get disappointments over with before a show starts. As my companion to watch the Australian Ballet’s “Swan Lake” I invited an old friend who has known “Swan Lake” for decades. Two hours before Saturday’s performance at the David H. Koch Theater she e-mailed me to say that she was looking forward to it because Australia has real black swans, and she was eager to see the connection onstage. I informed her hurriedly that this “Swan Lake” was the one about Diana, Charles and Camilla, and that Australian black swans were not on offer.

headline: Revisiting Jazz Repertory, With Speedy Scat
text: The guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel played on Saturday night at the Jazz Standard with a consistent tone and sound, dry and slightly reverbed, chords harmonically colored or extended, or replaced altogether by quick and startling runs that rippled the surface. It was sturdy, organized, meticulous, but still basically inward; he’s evolved within the academy-oriented air of jazz-guitar playing over the last 20 years.

headline: Blacklists and Shadows Looming Over Composers
text: The young company Opera Moderne wants to be the go-to source of programs for sophisticated listeners, featuring music a little off the beaten path. This season it has put on varied song programs, Wolf-Ferrari’s charming opera “Le Donne Curiose” and an acclaimed production of Britten’s “Turn of the Screw.”

headline: Like a Sampling D.J., John Cage Weaves a Piece From the Works of Others
text: One reason “Credo in Us,” a 1942 composition by John Cage, never grows old is that, by design, it never fails to surprise. The piece, played at the start of a concert by the Glass Farm Ensemble in the Leonard Nimoy Thalia at Symphony Space on Friday evening, incorporates bursts of other composers’ music produced with a radio, a phonograph or both, amid a frolicsome tumult of lively rhythms played on piano, tin cans and muted gongs. An electric buzzer keeps the piece from getting too cozy.

headline: Cyberfraud and Businesses

headline: A Baldwin Play Reading Will Benefit Theaters
text: To raise money and awareness for African-American theater and playwrights, Project1Voice, a nonprofit organization, will stage a one-night-only benefit reading of James Baldwin’s 1954 play, “The Amen Corner,” in 18 cities and 28 theaters across the country. Part of Project1Voice’s second annual event 1 Voice, 1 Play, 1 Day, the reading was chosen to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Baldwin’s death. Set in Harlem in the 1950s, “The Amen Corner,” like Baldwin’s first novel, “Go Tell It on the Mountain,” explores the role Christianity plays in the lives of African-Americans. The New York reading, which will be performed on Monday at 7 p.m at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, is to be hosted by Norm Lewis (below, of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess”) and directed by Walter Dallas with Lillias White, Chuck Cooper and Adriane Lenox starring. Speaking in a telephone interview, the Project1Voice founder Erich McMillan-McCall said that the goal of the annual reading was to help “preserve the legacy and tradition of black theaters for future generations,” adding, “By creating awareness and reigniting what I call lesser-known classics by African-American playwrights we can get people to realize that there is a voice that is missing, and that is the voice of many minority professionals.” Tickets are available through (631) 464-7421 or project1voice.org.

headline: Baruch College Finds Problems in a Business Program
text: An internal investigation at the Zicklin School of Business at Baruch College has uncovered “irregularities” in its executive master’s degree programs, and the college has taken disciplinary measures against faculty and staff members involved, Baruch officials said on Sunday.

headline: Senior Teams Trial for World Mind Sports Games

headline: Socialists’ Victory in France Buttresses Hollande’s Power
text: PARIS — President François Hollande’s Socialists and their allies won an absolute majority in runoff parliamentary elections on Sunday, strengthening the hand of Mr. Hollande both at home and in Europe, where he is pressing for less austerity and more growth in the face of a deepening recession.

headline: Index Ventures Raises $442 Million in New Fund
text: LONDON – The European venture capital firm Index Ventures has raised 350 million euros ($442 million) to invest in early stage start-ups in both Europe and the United States.

headline: Jehovah’s Witnesses Told to Pay in Abuse Case

headline: 3 Church Attacks and Retaliation Rock Nigeria
text: ZARIA, Nigeria (Reuters) — Suicide car bombers attacked three churches in a northern Nigerian state on Sunday, killing at least 19 people and wounding dozens, and setting off retaliatory attacks by Christian youths who dragged Muslims from cars and killed them, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Search Ends for Japanese Climbers on Mount McKinley
text: ANCHORAGE (AP) — The National Park Service said on Sunday that a search for four Japanese climbers who were swept by an avalanche from Mount McKinley had been permanently suspended after a mountaineering ranger found their climbing rope in debris at the bottom of a crevasse.

text: After more than a decade, the royalties for Internet radio and other digital music streams are finally starting to add up.

headline: Suspect in Shooting in Canada Is Arrested

headline: Saudis Seek a Crown Prince and Talk of Other Successors

headline: Digital Media’s Ever-Swifter Incursion
text: Last Wednesday night on the rooftop of the Gramercy Park Hotel, all the signs of the classic magazine launch party were on display: an open bar ringed by thirsty media reporters, groaning trays of shrimp, a D.J. playing music just soft enough that it didn’t drown out the chatter. The proud editor showed off his new product, the woman who is its namesake held court a few feet away, and the Pulitzer Prize-winning contributor was surrounded by a cluster of partygoers.

headline: World Leaders Meet in a Mexico Now Giving Brazil a Run for Its Money

headline: New Online Partnership Aims for Cheaper Political Ads

headline: The Linda Lingle Channel
text: Starting last week, channel surfers in Hawaii found something new tucked between the Fox News Channel and CNN Headline News. headline: Newspaper Work, With Warren Buffett as Boss

At the headquarters of The Buffalo News here, a sand-colored office building across the river from a fragrant Cheerios factory, the only visible sign of the owner is a small photograph hanging in the office of the publisher, Stanford Lipsey, signed, “To the best in the business, Warren.”

headline: A Refocused Colsaerts Makes an Inspired Run
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Fresh from taking his first bow on the big stage, Nicolas Colsaerts sent the sports psychologist Bob Rotella a text message. “Man, what a day,” he wrote on Saturday night after moving into a tie for fourth at the United States Open. “It’s so much fun when you play good in an atmosphere like this.”

headline: A Test of Racial Justice
text: North Carolina’s Legislature is moving shamefully to gut the state’s 2009 Racial Justice Act. The statute is the first in the nation to allow death row inmates to have their sentence reduced to life without parole if they show that the sentence was tainted by racial bias.

headline: Greece as Victim
text: Ever since Greece hit the skids, we’ve heard a lot about what’s wrong with everything Greek. Some of the accusations are true, some are false — but all of them are beside the point. Yes, there are big failings in Greece’s economy, its politics and no doubt its society. But those failings aren’t what caused the crisis that is tearing Greece apart, and threatens to spread across Europe.

headline: Extending the Drama of Track and Field Year Round

headline: In Village Steeped in Past, Voters Feel Bound by It

Like many people in this angst-ridden country on Sunday, he had waited until the last moment to cast his vote in Greece’s most pivotal election in recent memory.

headline: Ghost Goal: Fire (3) vs. Red Bulls (1)

headline: Bob Chappuis, Halfback Rescued in World War II, Dies at 89

headline: Canaries in the Coal Mine
text: Over the past few decades, working class whites – loosely defined as those without college degrees – have been a strikingly reliable indicator of the strength of the two main political parties. These voters are highly volatile and their shifting loyalties are a powerful factor in determining control of Congress and of the White House, according to recently re-analyzed exit poll data provided to the Times by Alan Abramowitz, a political scientist at Emory, and Sam Best, a political scientist at the University of Connecticut.

headline: In Its First Life, an Oil Platform; in Its Next, a Reef?

Below the surface, corals, sea fans and sponges cover its maze of pipes. Schools of jack and snapper, solitary grouper and barracuda circle in its shadows. Dive boats periodically stop at the enormous structure, where dolphins, sea turtles and sharks are often spotted.

headline: Coverage of Scandal Dents Credibility of Pakistani TV News

headline: An Immigration Order in June, With an Eye to November

headline: Films, Literature Devote Little Attention to Female Feticide

headline: Militants Attack Israelis Across Egyptian Border, Renewing Concerns on Sinai

headline: No Relief Rally on Greek Vote

But the reaction was short-lived as borrowing costs in Spain and Italy reminded investors that the troubles facing the euro zone were far from resolved.

headline: Reserve Bank Holds Interest Rates Steady to Fight Inflation
text: In spite of growing calls for it to support India’s slowing economy, the Reserve Bank of India said on Monday it would not cut interest rates or lower banking reserve requirements because inflation was still too high for it to act.

headline: No One Budges in Tense Iran Nuclear Talks in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — A tense first day of talks between Iran and six world powers broke no new ground on Monday evening, offering little hope that the negotiations would defuse the standoff over Tehran’s nuclear ambitions.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 18, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “Forced to Early Social Security, Unemployed Pay a Steep Price.”

headline: Cooperation Replaces a Lone Wolf Approach to Photography
text: After shooting their assignments for The Naples Daily News, Lexey Swall, Greg Kahn and Tristan Spinski would unwind together at night, playing dice and talking about photography. Mr. Spinski, 33, says rolling dice is “a nice conduit to conversation.”

headline: Yemeni Commander Killed in Suicide Bombing
text: LONDON — An important military commander in Yemen was assassinated on Monday in the southern port city of Aden just days after the Yemeni government announced a major military victory over Qaeda militants in the region.

headline: First Relief, Then Skepticism After Greece Votes
text: LONDON — European leaders might have given the impression in recent weeks that the Greeks were feckless, tax-cheating ingrates, incapable of distinguishing between a bailout and a handout, and prepared to turn their backs on Europe rather than accept just a bit more economic pain.

headline: A New Government for Greece
text: WHAT political party won the parliamentary election in Greece?WHAT does this party want to do fix the country’s failed economy?WHAT other parties ran in the election?

headline: University Sends ‘Fear of God’ Letter to Students With Senioritis
text: College-bound seniors beware: If you slept through your classes this semester and have the failing grades to prove it, your university may soon threaten to rescind your admission this fall.

headline: The Early Word: Processing
text: Today’s Times

headline: After Victory, Egypt Islamists Seek to Challenge Military
text: CAIRO — Having won the presidential vote, Egypt’s main Islamist group, the Muslim Brotherhood, squared off on Monday against the nation’s military rulers, who showed few signs of ceding ultimate authority to the longtime outlaw group.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Working Without Pay
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Toasted
text: When I leave our apartment, I can’t remember if I’ve turned off the toaster oven. The appliance doesn’t go off automatically. If it is on, you have to turn the knob to the left or unplug the whole gadget. I have a picture in my mind of the heating elements glowing red and the food crumbs catching fire inside. I know this can happen because I’ve seen it. I’ll be toasting something, and I’ll see a flickering yellow light through the oven’s small window. If I do nothing, the fire will continue unabated. If I open the oven door, the inflow of air will feed the flames.

headline: Tomlinson’s Legacy, Real and Fantasy
text: Links for your consideration:

headline: Taliban Block Vaccinations in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani Taliban commander has banned polio vaccinations in North Waziristan, in the tribal belt, days before 161,000 children were to be inoculated. He linked the ban to American drone strikes and fears that the C.I.A. could use the polio campaign as cover for espionage, much as it did with Shakil Afridi, the Pakistani doctor who helped track Osama bin Laden.

headline: Lakshmi Mittal’s Million Dollar Tribute to London
text: “Steel. Art. Sport. A bold combination.” This is the tagline at the top of the invitation to a Champagne reception hosted by the steel magnate Lakshmi Niwas Mittal, and his wife Usha on Friday night to celebrate the newly opened ArcelorMittal Orbit at Olympic Park in London.

headline: Melrose in Talks to Buy German Manufacturer for $2.3 Billion
text: LONDON – The British private equity firm Melrose said on Monday that it was in talks to buy the Elster Group, a German utility meter manufacturer, for $2.3 billion.

headline: Opinion Report: The Fiscal Cliff
text: From the editorial page

headline: Deutsche Borse Asks Court to Overturn Decision to Block NYSE Deal
text: LONDON — Deutsche Börse has asked a European court to overturn a decision by antitrust regulators that blocked its planned merger with NYSE Euronext.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: When Buffett Is Your Boss
text: What’s it like when Warren Buffett is your boss? That’s the question on the mind of hundreds of journalists at the newspapers the Berkshire Hathaway legend has recently bought. The best answer, writes Christine Haughney, may be at The Buffalo News, the daily Mr. Buffett bought in 1977 and has run ever since. The verdict: Mr. Buffett is a hands-off boss who invests in local journalism and provides a great pension plan, but The News hasn’t been immune from the downturn facing the rest of the business.

headline: In Defense of Parasites
text: Would you purposely allow Schistosoma worms to burrow into your body and take up residence in your bloodstream, lungs and liver? Or perhaps allow writhing botfly larvae to feast upon your juices before popping out of your skin as a hairy fly?

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Victory Spurs Speculation on Bharara’s Next Move  |  With the conviction of Rajat K. Gupta, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, has now secured the biggest scalp yet in the government’s broad campaign against insider trading on Wall Street.

headline: Man Group Appoints New Finance Director
text: The Man Group, the world’s largest public hedge fund, has a new finance director.

headline: Russian Warships Said to Be Going to Naval Base in Syria
text: MOSCOW — A tiny, frayed Russian military base on Syria’s Mediterranean coast has jumped into international focus amid concern over how far Russia might go to bolster the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Philippines and China Ease Tensions in Rift at Sea
text: BEIJING — Chinese fishing boats near the disputed Scarborough Shoal off the Philippine coast were heading back to port on Monday after Philippine vessels withdrew from the same area in an easing of tensions in the South China Sea, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said.

headline: Aiming for School Diversity in Williamsburg, With Little Progress
text: How difficult is it to integrate a city school? Pretty tough, according to the latest article in The New York Times's "A System Divided" series, which has been examining the issue of segregation in the New York City public school system. Also in the news this Monday morning: a principal under fire, sexual misconduct, teacher evaluations and Pearson.

headline: Monday Reading: Tips for an Easier Family Getaway
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Takes On Google in Maps
text: Last week, Apple announced that its phones would no longer come with maps from Google built in, but instead would feature Apple’s own map service, part of its new mobile operating system. In Monday’s New York Times, Quentin Hardy looks into whether Apple can build a map service that does as good a job as Google’s — or a better one.

headline: Can’t Get No Satisfaction
text: Busy morning, so just a brief post now.

headline: Arrested Development
text: Don’t expect too many developments on development at the Rio+20 summit this week. Touted as an opportunity for developing countries to show their new strength in the global economy, the meeting is shaping up to be an exercise in putting off important decisions.
