text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Investor Backs Vodafone’s $1.6 Billion Bid for Cable & Wireless
text: LONDON — The Vodafone Group moved a step closer on Monday to its £1.04 billion ($1.63 billion) takeover of Cable & Wireless Worldwide, after the largest investor in the British telecommunications company backed Vodafone’s bid.

headline: Stopping to Question the Numbers
text: If there is wisdom to be gleaned from the torrent of emotions over the police practice commonly known as stop-and-frisk, it is that City Hall’s worship of statistics has distinct limitations. And if there is anyone who you’d think would have understood that point instinctively, it is the police commissioner,  Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: Don’t Look Now
text: Championships do not come with a guarantee that they'll be worthy of framing. Often, in the slog of a drive for a title, many of a sport's fine artistic points are lost, their beauty obscured in the sheer effort it takes to win. Or, in the case of the United States Open golf championship or the N.B.A. finals, it gets buried in a cloud of fog and unrepentant fairways or drowned out by referees' whistles and bodies hitting the floor.

headline: Sweden 1912: Thorpe’s Olympic Moment
text: One hundred years ago the Summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

headline: Pearl Buck Novels to Be Published as E-Books
text: Thirteen novels by Pearl S. Buck will be released in e-book form for the first time, her publisher said on Monday, the latest works by an acclaimed author to be published digitally after being available only in print.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Richard James
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Dealing With the Facebook Lawsuits
text: The campy 1980s hit “It’s Raining Men” could well be translated into a new song called “It’s Raining Lawsuits” to describe the deluge of cases triggered by Facebook’s botched initial public offering on May 18.

headline: Basu Says Crucial Reforms Coming Soon
text: Acknowledging recent missteps by the government, India’s chief economic adviser said Monday that he was confident that economic reforms like increased foreign investment in the retail sector and reduced fuel subsidies would soon be enacted.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Telegraph: The 9-year-old Scottish school-lunch blogger Martha Payne (right), whose blog, Neverseconds, has received more than five million hits in the last month, was ordered to stop by local authorities last week. You can guess how that turned out. — Julia Moskin

headline: In London, the Ones That Stand Out
text: One peculiar thing about the London men’s collections taking place this weekend is that the coolest young designers, or at least the ones with the most buzz here, tend to show in what would seem to be the worst time slots. Jonathan Anderson, whose label J. W. Anderson has been on the hot list for men’s and women’s wear in recent seasons, showed at 9 a.m. on Sunday, on the last day of the men’s shows.

headline: Winslet and Branagh Among Those Honored by Queen
text: The film stars Kate Winslet and Kenneth Branagh and the architect Zaha Hadid were among the Britons honored for their contributions to the arts this weekend by Queen Elizabeth II. They were named to the Order of the British Empire in the Queen’s birthday honors list along with hundreds of others who received a variety of awards for their work.

headline: Bank of America Hires Senior Oppenheimer Health Care Banker
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired Brian McCarthy as a vice chairman of health care investment banking, the firm announced on Monday in an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook. Mr. McCarthy came over from Oppenheimer & Company, where he was the head of the health care investment banking team, and previously worked at JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers.

headline: British Prosecutor Drops Suspect in Kaupthing Investigation
text: LONDON – Britain’s Serious Fraud Office on Monday dropped the property tycoon Vincent Tchenguiz as a suspect in its investigation into the collapse of Icelandic bank Kaupthing, less than a month after it admitted mistakes in the inquiry.

headline: Business Day Live | June 18, 2012
text: After the Greek election defuses one crisis, looking for the next. | Bayer's chief executive on Europe's economic outlook.

headline: Professional Photographers in the Delivery Room
text: “I want to see that moment when I’m in labor,” said Rhisie Hentges of Long Beach, Calif., who paid $1,895 to have Briana Kalajian, a co-owner of Shoots and Giggles Photography, document the birth of her first child. “That moment when both my husband and I look to see what the sex is? That’s something that I want to see happen.” For “Honey, the Baby Is Coming; Quick, Call the Photographer,” Elissa Gootman spoke to parents, photographers and doctors about the new “front lines” of documenting childhood: birth photographers.

headline: Really? Ginseng Can Help Relieve Fatigue
text: THE FACTS

headline: On Our Radar: The Negotiating Text in Rio
text: Environmentalists complain that the negotiating text being readied for the Rio+20 environmental conference this week in Brazil is riddled with words like “support” and encourage” rather than “must” or “will,” the language of commitment; a coalition, meanwhile, organizes a “Twitterstorm” calling for an end to fossil-fuel subsidies. The conference opens on Wednesday. [W.W.F., endfossilfuelsubsidies.org]

headline: 70 Major Art Dealers  at Kensington Gardens Show
text: Though it was just established two years ago, Art Antiques London has already become an important nexus for international dealers, collectors, museum curators and academics. This year’s fair, in a handsome pavilion in Kensington Gardens through June 20, brings together more than  70 major art dealers, including specialists in modern British art, 20th-century design, tapestry and antique textiles and European jewelry.

headline: Get the Speculators
text: The Greeks got all the attention, but the more important election Sunday may have been in France, where the Socialists and their allies won a clear majority in Parliament.

headline: Soups That Taste Like Spring
text: I wanted comforting food this week that would showcase the wonderful late spring/early summer vegetables that are appearing in markets all over the country right now – great big bunches of chard with wide stems and lush leaves, tender leeks, the last of the fava beans, first of the green beans and the first of the summer squash, still small and delicate. I didn’t have a lot of time, and I wanted to make dishes that I could serve as the main dish for dinners throughout the week, so I did what the French do: I made soup.

headline: Russian Arms Dealer Was Classified as a Small Business, Briefly
text: Here’s a new topic for You’re The Boss: Russian arms for Syria. Russian-made helicopters are en route to Syria, sold to the Assad regime by Rosoboronexport, the Russian state-owned arms exporter. Since 2007, Rosoboronexport, the sole Russian arms exporter, has supplied Syria with 78 percent of its arms imports, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. (The New York Times has reported that the copters heading to Syria were most likely already part of that country’s fleet, returning after routine maintenance in Russia.)

headline: His Domain Transformed, Parks Chief Is Leaving
text: He got his start as a teenager cleaning locker rooms at a city pool in the East Village and picking up litter in East River Park, and ended up overseeing the most ambitious program of building and refurbishing New York City’s parks since the era of Robert Moses. Now, after a decade on the job, the parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, 55, is stepping down to take a position with a national conservation group.

headline: Monday Motorsports: After Four-Year Absence, Dale Earnhardt Jr. Visits Victory Lane
text: It was described by various motorsports media as a pinch-me moment. Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, had won a Sprint Cup race for the first time in four years.

headline: The Musicians’ Words: Interviews With Stars Donated to Library of Congress
text: A trove of interviews with more than 200 giants of the music industry including Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Charles, Barbra Streisand, Little Richard, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Elton John, Paul Simon, David Bowie, Billy Joel, Tony Bennett, Joan Baez and Tina Turner has been donated to the Library of Congress by Joe Smith, the former president of Capitol Records/EMI.

headline: Some Humility Looks Good on the Heat
text: MIAMI — With three simple words that were more playful than derisive, Kevin Durant helped along the continuing reputation reset of a team that for much of its two seasons in present form has been the essence of entitlement and presumption. Dwyane Wade didn’t initially hear the remark after Durant effortlessly canned a second-quarter jump shot over Wade, though from Durant’s lips to television viewers’ eyes, the message was perfectly clear.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/18: Couch Seats on Planes and Greece Beckons Tourists
text: RT@Greece: It’s Still Nice Here Greece’s national tourism agency has started a social media initiative to promote travel to the economically challenged country and to counter “inaccuracies or speculations” that have caused a dip in tourism there. (The International Herald Tribune)

headline: First Defense Witnesses Called in Sandusky Case
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Jerry Sandusky, the former assistant coach at Penn State accused of sexually abusing 10 boys, regularly took boys into locker-room showers reserved for coaches, according to two longtime colleagues who testified on Sandusky’s behalf Monday.

headline: Vain Glorious | You Can Rest Easy at Mohonk Mountain House
text: Who: Mohonk Mountain House Spa. For a 143-year-old mansion, which still offers horse-and-buggy rides in and around its cavernous quarters, it’s refreshing — oh, so very refreshing — to see how its eco-friendly spa continues to adapt to frenetic modern lives.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Patrick Radden Keefe on the Sinaloa Drug Cartel
text: Patrick Radden Keefe wrote this week’s cover story on Mexican drug cartels. A fellow at the Century Foundation, Keefe is the author of “The Snakehead: An Epic Tale of the Chinatown Underworld and the American Dream” and “Chatter: Uncovering the Echelon Surveillance Network and the Secret World of Global Eavesdropping.”

headline: Many Americans Struggle to Pay for Health Care, Survey Finds
text: As the nation awaits the Supreme Court’s ruling on challenges to the health care law, Americans continue to report that they struggle to pay for medical care.

headline: Street Style: Summer Nail Designs
text: The best summer nail designs for the week of June 11.

headline: Numberplay: Mixed-Up Wires
text: Welcome to Numberplay, the week-long game of collaboration and discovery that also happens to be about math. If you’re new to the game, give it a try by leaving a comment at the end of this post. You don’t have to solve the problem; hunches are good. So are wild conjectures. At Numberplay, the standard answer is just the beginning.

headline: New Efforts Begin to Form a Government in Greece
text: ATHENS — Antonis Samaras, the leader of the center-right party that placed first in Greek parliamentary elections, began talks on Monday to form a coalition government aimed at keeping Greece in the euro zone and renegotiating its loan agreement with the foreign creditors keeping the country afloat.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: June 10-June 17
text: Moments from the campaign trail last week, including the launch of a bus tour, fund-raising and a dressage championship.

headline: Even the Chinese Muse About Hillary Clinton’s Future
text: Who thinks Hillary Rodham Clinton might run for president in 2016? Democrats? Republicans? Her husband? The vice president?

headline: ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,’ With ‘Hairspray’ Song Team, Plans London Opening
text: A new musical version of Roald Dahl’s beloved children’s book “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” directed by Sam Mendes, will open at the London Palladium in June 2013, according to a news release. The ubiquitous Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman, who co-wrote the lyrics for the Tony-winning musical “Hairspray” (Mr. Shaiman wrote the music) and created the music for the NBC series about Broadway, “Smash,” will be writing songs for the show.

headline: What Rodney King Said During One of His Final Interviews
text: Since last November, when we introduced the The One-Page Magazine, I’ve interviewed more than 30 celebrities and cultural luminaries for a mini how-to column. (It’s our version of what would be the back page of a “multipage” magazine.) Dr. Phil told me how to break off an engagement nicely; Diahann Carroll divulged how to look great in your 70s; Fran Drescher spoke about how to stay friends with your ex.

headline: Image of the Day: June 18
text: Acute water shortage has plagued several parts of Delhi.

headline: Putting Obama’s Jobs Proposal in Context
text: With federal borrowing costs virtually at zero, President Obama has been pressing Congress for months to pass a major infrastructure program aimed at putting Americans to work and rebuilding the country’s creaking roads, bridges, rails and tunnels.

headline: Premier League 2012-13 Schedule
text: Manchester City will open defense of its Premier League title at newly promoted Southampton on Aug. 18 in the schedule released Monday by the league and its title sponsor, Barclays.

headline: With Each Passing Memorial Day, What Changes?
text: Another Memorial Day has come and gone. We had our barbeques and enjoyed the day off, and some of us paid respects to the fallen. Now we’re back to the routine of doing what it is that Americans do. As for the war? Out of sight, out of mind.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Mary Cadwallader joined the Washington office of TPM Media, the publisher of Talking Points Memo, as vice president for advertising sales. She succeeds Waldo Tibbets, who left, the company said, to pursue other professional interests. Ms. Cadwallader had most recently been national sales manager at The Hill, Washington, part of News Communications.

headline: How Global Companies Take Aim at China
text: In the book “All Business Is Local: Why Place Matters More Than Ever in a Global, Virtual World,” John A. Quelch makes the case that the push for globalization is obscuring the significance of local tastes, preferences and ways of life.

headline: The ‘Heady Rush’ of Freedom in College, and How to Manage It
text: For many graduating seniors, going to college this fall means that “they will no longer need to devise ways to sneak out of the house at 2 a.m.,” writes Ariha Setalvad, a student at New York University.

headline: Rodney King’s Starring Role in Citizen Journalism
text: Rodney King, who died on Sunday at age 47, came to represent many things during his life — the brutality of the Los Angeles Police Department, the explosion of the city’s long-simmering racial tensions and the simple wish that we could all, as he pleaded, get along.

headline: TimesCast | June 18, 2012
text: Greek voters give a victory to a pro-euro party that supports the economic bailout. | Egyptians elect an Islamist in their first competitive presidential election.

headline: For Weddings and a Funeral
text: TBILISI, Georgia — It’s a modern marriage. A puppet show tells the couple’s love story in verse: while a young man narrates, five custom-made marionettes — the bride, the groom and their three children — bob about. The two people we’ve come to honor have to pick each other out of two line-ups of a dozen potential grooms and brides draped in bed sheets. Then emerges a young bearded man wearing a red cloak and a TV remote control around his neck. Placing battery-operated Christmas-tree lights on the couple’s heads, he pronounces them husband and wife to the applause of the 60 or so guests in attendance.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Christopher Raeburn
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: John McCain’s Three Little Words
text: In his 2010 State of the Union address, President Obama roundly criticized the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision, arguing that it had “reversed a century of law.” That practically sounds like a hymn of praise compared to what Senator John McCain had to say on “Meet the Press” this weekend. He called Citizens United: “arrogant, uninformed, naïve.”

headline: Bieber Fever Comes to Macy’s
text: For hard-core Justin Bieber fans it was an opportunity not to be missed. The pop star put out the word over Twitter on Sunday that there were 500 tickets available for an unannounced show Monday night at the Apollo Theater. All one had to do to get two of them was to buy $168 (plus tax) worth of his new fragrance at Macy’s in Herald Square.

headline: In House Testimony, Dimon Sticks to Script
text: Anyone hoping that Jamie Dimon‘s second round of prepared Congressional testimony will reveal the full story behind his bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss — or any fresh details for that matter — is in for a disappointing read.

headline: Fires Prompt Intensified Investigations of 1.4 Million Toyotas and 342,000 Chevy TrailBlazers
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified investigations into whether 1.4 million Toyotas and almost 342,000 General Motors sport utility vehicles may have defective power-window switches that could lead to smoke and fire conditions.

headline: Heart Trouble Early and Often in H.I.V. Patients
text: Mike Godfrey was 19 when he found out he had H.I.V.

headline: The trillions of germs living in and around your body; the mysterious third voyage of a 15th-century explorer; and new findings on cardiac deaths among patients with H.I.V.
text: The trillions of germs living in and around your body; the mysterious third voyage of a 15th-century explorer; and new findings on cardiac deaths among patients with H.I.V.

headline: A Bet on the Sun
text: Out in the Mojave Desert in California, a power plant that could eventually generate enough electricity for 140,000 homes hopes to get its moment in the sun soon. When the $2.2 billion solar thermal plant known as Ivanpah is completed — sometime next year, if all goes according to plan — nearly 350,000 mirrors on 3,600 acres will reflect light onto boilers. Steam will power turbines, which will generate electricity that flows to California homes. It will be the largest such plant in the world. These “solar workhorses of the desert,” says V. John White, an analyst in Sacramento and an advocate for renewable energy, “can produce a lot of high-quality energy in the way that other renewable energies can’t do. And there are only a handful of places on the planet that have solar radiation that good.” But some opponents have criticized the Obama administration for pushing solar projects that don’t pan out. The solar-panel maker Solyndra declared bankruptcy last year despite receiving $528 million in federally guaranteed loans, while BrightSource Energy, one of Ivanpah’s developers, has benefited from a similar $1.6 billion government loan. It’s expensive harnessing the sun. And the costs go beyond construction. BrightSource says that it has spent more than $56 million relocating desert tortoises. JULIE BOSMAN

headline: The Look of a Longhorn Dynasty at the U.S. Open
text: The University of Texas is becoming known for more than its football and basketball prowess, thanks to the recent success of its men’s golf team. The Longhorns just won the N.C.A.A. title, and can count on having two up-and-coming talents as part of their team for the next few years.

headline: Too Poor for Their Own Graduation
text: A Bronx middle-school teacher who blogs about her experiences writes: "My students don’t have it easy. But every year I go to prom, and I see them at graduation.  They are happy, looking their best, feeling successful, cheering for themselves and for one another.  I see their parents snapping pictures of them, and hugging them, and smiling proudly.  And I realize that for many kids, that is a rare occasion." When some of the children can't afford prom and graduation, some people are happy to help, because  "feeling for one day that they have done something worth celebrating is a cause worth investing in.

headline: Statin Drugs Cause Fatigue in Some People
text: Many observational reports have suggested that statin drugs cause fatigue in some people, and now a randomized trial has found further evidence for the effect.

headline: Job May Affect Fertility, but a Beer May Not
text: Drinking, smoking and using recreational drugs probably will not reduce a man’s fertility, a new study suggests — but working on a road crew might.

headline: Do Magnet Schools Still Matter?
text: As detailed in Sunday’s Metropolitan cover story, “Integrating a School, One Child at a Time,” four elementary schools in Brooklyn’s District 14 won a federal magnet grant in 2010 for approximately $1.5 million over three years to desegregate.

headline: Facebook Acquires Israeli Facial Recognition Company
text: Facebook, the largest repository of pictures anywhere and at any time in history, has acquired an Israeli company, called face.com, that makes facial recognition technology. Neither company disclosed the sale price nor the other terms of the deal.

headline: Women Are Still a Rarity in Building Service Jobs
text: Monique Catus stood at the entrance of an elegant Art Deco apartment building on East 51st Street one day this spring, with a smile on her face and pristine white gloves on her hands. A little girl trotted by, she later recounted, looked up at her, and then looked at her mother. She was confused.

headline: Morgan Stanley Declares Victory
text: Morgan Stanley, with Facebook egg all over its face, has adopted the strategy memorably advocated by Senator George Aiken in 1966: Declare victory, and get out.

headline: Defense Minister New Heir to Throne in Saudi Arabia
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia’s Prince Salman bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, who was governor of Riyadh for nearly 50 years until his recent promotion to Saudi Arabia’s defense minister, was officially named crown prince on Monday, making him the heir apparent to the 88-year-old King Abdullah.

headline: An Agency Division Chronicles Its Own I.T. Overhaul
text: A division of a giant agency holding group that usually produces campaigns for clients is, in a change of pace, undertaking a campaign with itself as the subject.

headline: The Body’s Protein Cleaning Machine
text: When Dr. Avram Hershko, 74, a biochemist at the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa and a winner of the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, was recently asked to name the most important fact of his life, he answered: “That I love my six grandchildren. For two, three days every week, I take them to dance class, sport and school. I am completely in their lives.”

headline: TimesCast | Egyptian Election Analysis
text: In Tahrir Square, celebrations began Monday after Egyptians elected an Islamist in their first competitive presidential election.

headline: Omega-3s Don’t Cut Diabetics’ Heart Risks
text: A large trial has found that supplements of omega-3 fatty acid do nothing to prevent cardiovascular problems or death in people with Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Looking for the Next Crisis In Europe
text: June 18, 2011 - After the Greek election defuses one crisis, looking for the next.

headline: One Bounce, You’re Out, at the Old Ball Game
text: In the third inning of the New York Gothams’ first game on Governors Island on Saturday, a batter hit a towering fly ball to shallow left field.

headline: Sonos Gets Boost From Former Apple Executives and Other Investors
text: Sonos is a company that sometimes gets compared to Apple because it designs the hardware and software for its products, a line of home audio equipment for listening to digital music. Now the company is raising money from a group of investors that includes a couple of former Apple executives.

headline: Predators, Prey and Lyme Disease
text: Deer ticks are aptly named, in a sense; a Northeastern deer can carry over 1,000 of these ticks on its body. But as far as humans are concerned, the ticks might be more relevantly called mouse ticks. That’s because white-footed mice and other small mammals, not deer, are now known by scientists to be major carriers of Lyme disease.

headline: Man of The Moment | Jay-Z
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: At Party, Bloomberg Tips Hand on Endorsement
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York has remained coy about whether he plans to endorse a presidential candidate this year, even as Mitt Romney and President Obama aggressively court the billionaire media mogul.

headline: Fraud Charges Threaten Burgundy's Vaunted Reputation
text: PARIS — Accusations of wine fraud, which have been swirling around the international trade in rare vintages, have now struck home at the source of some of the world’s most prized bottles, the cellars of Burgundy.

headline: To Advance, Search for a Black Cat in a Dark Room
text: Many people think of science as a deliberate process that is driven by the gradual accumulation of facts. Legions of smart scientists labor to piece together the evidence supporting their discoveries, hypotheses, inventions and progress itself.

headline: TimesCast | Greek Election Analysis
text: On Sunday, Greece’s New Democracy party narrowly defeated the leftist Syriza party, which had surged on a wave of anti-austerity sentiment.

headline: Klein Returns Full Time to Education Work at News Corp., Leaving Investigative Role
text: Joel I. Klein, who had been heading up the committee at News Corporation charged with investigating its role in the phone-hacking scandal in Britain, is leaving that position to concentrate full time on the company’s education division.

headline: Battersby
text: Inside the Cobble Hill restaurant, where the quarters are tight but the food is earnest.

headline: Obama’s Iraq Envoy Nominee Steps Aside
text: President Obama’s nominee for ambassador to Iraq withdrew from consideration on Monday after a series of racy e-mails fueled Republican resistance to his confirmation in the Senate.

headline: Apple’s Maps Don’t Look So Bad
text: Apple has a lot more on maps than it is showing, and that is sowing confusion in the online and mobile maps industry.

headline: Did Etiquette End Dickey’s Scoreless Streak?
text: With R. A. Dickey back on the mound Monday night, it seems like the right time to revisit Mets Manager Terry Collins’s thought processes last Wednesday night when he watched his knuckleball pitcher throw a one-hit masterpiece against the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Cold There Tonight
text: Or at least that’s what the speech recognition software on my voice mail says.

headline: Can You Contract Plague From a Corpse?
text: Q. If long-ago victims of the bubonic plague are dug up, could the germs infect someone?

headline: Consumer Agency Seeks Details on Financial Abuse of Elderly
text: The next target for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is financial abuse of the elderly.

headline: A Hormonal Remedy for Brain Injuries Is Explored
text: Late one evening last December, 18-year-old Michelle Vaquero was crossing a busy street in San Jose, Calif., when a car slammed into her. She landed more than 30 feet away. An ambulance rushed her to Santa Clara Valley Medical Center, where doctors diagnosed traumatic brain injury.

headline: A Mythical Anniversary
text: We’re coming up on the second anniversary of my piece “Myths of Austerity“, in which I tried to knock down the simply insane conventional wisdom then gelling among Very Serious People. Intellectually it was, I think I can say without false modesty, a huge win; I (and those of like mind) have been right about everything.

headline: Transcripts of Conversations Between Zimmermans Are Released
text: In recorded conversations from jail, George Zimmerman and his wife, Shellie, discussed how to move tens of thousands of dollars from the money that flowed into an online defense fund he set up to credit union accounts under her name and into his sister’s account, according to audio recordings of their conversations and court documents released in Florida on Monday.

headline: London Theater Journal: Imagination From Despair in Edinburgh and Minsk
text: Don’t bother telling the title characters of “Boys,” Ella Hickson’s play at the Soho Theater, to clean up their room. They’re beyond hope, in every sense of the phrase. In addition to the usual clutter of bottles, boxes and stolen street signs that passes for interior decoration among university students, fat bags of trash occupy a wall by the stove. In the tenants’ defense, allow me to note that they’re not just making excuses when they say they can’t do a thing about it.

headline: Battersby Is Poised, for the New Brooklyn
text: IT is elbow to elbow at Battersby on a Saturday night, at tables barely wide enough for a game of checkers. “How am I supposed to talk to you?” a flummoxed swain whispers. Couples cleave to a wall; latecomers hunch at the bar. Outside it is Smith Street in Cobble Hill, a formerly insalubrious strip (weren’t they all?) that is now just a Marc Jacobs away from becoming Brooklyn’s Bleecker.

headline: Environmental Protest Becomes Rallying Point in Malaysia
text: KUALA LUMPUR — When a planned 24-hour environmental protest gets under way this Saturday on the outskirts of the coastal Malaysian town of Kuantan, the roll call will include speakers from across the country.

headline: Nelson Peltz Takes 5.1% Stake in Lazard
text: Nelson Peltz‘s Trian Fund Management said on Monday that it now owns a 5.1 percent stake in Lazard, stressing that it believes the investment bank is undervalued but on the right track with its strategic plan.

headline: Normalcy Grinds to a Halt
text: In the 1954 Ray Bradbury story “All Summer in a Day,” Earthlings who have colonized Venus see the Sun shine only once every seven years, and then only for a couple of hours: The rest of the time it rains, and a little girl, who has recently arrived from Earth, is mocked by her schoolmates for describing her memories of what the Sun looked like from home.

headline: Justices Back Drug Industry on Overtime
text: WASHINGTON — Representatives of pharmaceutical companies who visit doctors’ offices to promote their companies’ products are not entitled to overtime pay, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision that broke along ideological lines. A contrary decision would have exposed the pharmaceutical industry to billions of dollars in potential liability.

headline: School Bus Overturns in Queens; Matron Badly Hurt
text: A school bus carrying school five special-education students overturned early Monday morning after being struck by a taxi in Queens.

headline: Romney’s Sons to Make a Joint Appearance on ‘Conan’
text: 5:25 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney might not yet feel completely comfortable making the rounds of late-night television, but he is sending in the next generation.

headline: The High Price of Loneliness
text: Loneliness stings at any age. But in older people, it can have serious health consequences, raising the risks of an earlier-than-expected death and the loss of physical functioning, according to a study published on Monday.

headline: For Rescue Line, Cyprus Prefers a Russian Loan
text: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — Caviar and pelmeni line the supermarket shelves in this picturesque seaside Cypriot city, so pervasively Russian that it has been dubbed “Limassolgrad.”

headline: Fast Access to Records Helps Fight Epidemics
text: Public health departments around the country have long scrutinized data from local hospitals for indications that diseases like influenza, tuberculosis, AIDS, syphilis and asthma might be on the rise, and to monitor the health consequences of heat waves, frigid weather or other natural phenomena. In the years since 9/11, this scrutiny has come to include signs of possible bioterrorism.

headline: Kenya: Study Finds Parental Factors Crucial in Choosing Circumcision for a Baby
text: The crucial factors in choosing circumcision for a baby in western Kenya are whether the father is circumcised and whether both parents agree to the procedure, a new study has found.

headline: An E-Book Fan, Missing the Smell of Paper and Glue
text: This past weekend, while visiting New York on a short work-related trip, I was reminded of how much I miss printed books.

headline: Factory Five Gen 2 GTM: Wringing Small Miracles From the Corvette Parts Bin
text: The cranberry bogs of southeastern Massachusetts are normally quite serene. But this area also happens to be the headquarters of Factory Five Racing, where I recently made a pilgrimage to drive the company’s second-generation GTM supercar. And once I was behind the wheel of the midengine, 420-horsepower GTM, the two-lane roads wending past the cranberry bogs were no longer quite so peaceful.

headline: Charting Traxman
text: In the world of dance music, Traxman is known as a longtime Chicago ghetto-house and juke D.J. who also helped develop the stripped-down, kick-drum-heavy footwork genre. His recent album, “Da Mind of Traxman,” out now on Planet Mu, is fast, playful, sample-heavy and chaotic. Traxman is playing June 23 at the Knitting Factory. The artist Andrew Kuo breaks it down, track by track.

headline: Publicis Makes Advertising's First Foray Into Palestinian Territories
text: PARIS — Publicis Groupe of France said Monday that it had acquired a stake in an advertising agency based in Ramallah, on the West Bank, in what it described as the first equity investment by any of the big Western marketing companies in the Palestinian territories.

headline: General Butler and the Women
text: On June 11, 1862, this newspaper addressed the widespread controversy that had erupted in response to Gen. Benjamin Butler’s General Order No. 28, commonly known as “The Woman Order.” On May 26 The Times quoted the New Orleans native and Confederate General P.G.T. Beauregard, who opined that the order, announced on May 15, gave occupying Union troops “the right to treat at their pleasure the ladies of the South as common harlots.”

headline: PBS and More
text: PBS filmed a profile of yours truly a few weeks back, which should be appearing on the Newshour tonight. They promise web links later tonight too.

headline: Photo Replay: June 18
text: The day in sports included the European fencing championships in Legnano, Italy, and the European soccer championships in Poland and Ukraine.

headline: Christie Orders Stepped-Up Inspections by State of Halfway Houses
text: Gov. Chris Christie ordered new inspections on Monday of New Jersey’s large, privately run halfway houses, saying his administration would ensure that the system operated “effectively and safely.”

headline: Prone to Lend a Hand, Even When It Doesn’t Pay
text: BEING in the hotel business, I need to travel, and travel often. As a marketing guy with Hilton, I’m always looking for ways to improve customer service. Airports are great places to see how people interact with one another, and how well staff members treat people.

headline: Dispatches from Rio – The Legal Environment
text: Through most of this month and the next few days, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is hosting an enormous gathering of environmentalists, diplomats, scientists, indigenous leaders and others trying to break new ground in international efforts to fit human activities and aspirations within the constraints that come with life on a finite planet. This is “Rio Plus 20” — the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, which marks the 20th anniversary of the 1992 meeting known as the Earth Summit.

headline: How to Make Animations With the Jittergram App
text: Jittergram is a nifty free app that helps you make and share simple stop-motion animations using an iPhone. It’s pretty easy to use, but not so easy that it couldn’t benefit from some instructions.

headline: Shiba Russell Succeeds Sue Simmons on WNBC
text: Shiba Russell, who joined WNBC in early 2011 and faced speculation right away that she was in line to succeed Sue Simmons, will in fact succeed Ms. Simmons on Monday night.

headline: Tending the Body’s Microbial Garden
text: For a century, doctors have waged war against bacteria, using antibiotics as their weapons. But that relationship is changing as scientists become more familiar with the 100 trillion microbes that call us home — collectively known as the microbiome.

headline: ‘Once,’ ‘One Man, Two Guvnors’ Enjoy Tony Awards Bump at Box Office
text: The fallout from this month’s Tony Awards at the Broadway box office – good and bad – came into sharper relief last week, with the musicals “Once,” “Newsies,” and “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” and the plays “One Man, Two Guvnors” and “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man” in the strongest shape among new productions as the summer tourist season begins, according to the weekly ticket sales data compiled by the Broadway League.

headline: Clemens Found Not Guilty of Lying About Drug Use
text: WASHINGTON — Roger Clemens, who intimidated even the toughest batters while becoming one of the best pitchers in baseball history, was acquitted Monday of all charges that he lied to Congress in 2008 when he insisted he never used steroids or human growth hormone during his long career.

headline: Face to Face, Obama Tries to Persuade Putin on Syria
text: SAN JOSÉ DEL CABO, Mexico — President Obama and his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, finally had their face-to-face meeting on Monday, as Mr. Obama pressed Mr. Putin to work with him to ease President Bashar al-Assad of Syria out of power, a move increasingly viewed by the West as the only way to end the bloodshed that has been under way there for more than a year.

headline: And in the Role of Mitt Romney . . . John Kerry
text: As he approaches his three critical face-offs with Mitt Romney this fall, President Obama needed to find the perfect person to stand in as his Republican rival during mock debates.

headline: Brown Tentatively Accepts a Kennedy Debate Invitation
text: BOSTON – Senator Scott P. Brown has tentatively accepted a debate invitation from the widow of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, whose death in 2009 opened up the seat Mr. Brown is now defending. But his campaign says he will attend only if the debate meets certain “neutrality conditions.”

headline: Vain Glorious | New York Gets a Rudy’s
text: Who: Rudy’s Barbershops

headline: An Anomaly in Mating: Self-Castration Raises Reproductive Success
text: Males of a tropical species of orb-web spider castrate themselves, either partly or fully, after mating.

headline: Sold on the Feeling, if Not the Benefits to Health
text: Almost everyone has gotten the message that exercise is important for health. Yet most who start exercise programs stop. Perhaps, researchers say, the way to persuade more people to exercise is to study those rare individuals who love it.

headline: Invisible Residents
text: The Human Microbiome Project has spent two years surveying bacteria and other microbes at different sites on 242 healthy people.

headline: Young, Social and Paperless
text: The children of the baby-boom generation are the first generation that never knew life before the Internet. And because they are a growing portion of the work force, the companies that employ them, as well as the hotels, airlines and other travel-related businesses that serve them, are having to change the way they talk to them, work with them and sell to them.

headline: Five-Four
text: The Supreme Court today withheld its ruling on the Affordable Care Act, issuing instead four opinions insufficiently flashy for widespread coverage in the press. There’s something newsworthy about the decisions, though, at least in the aggregate: Three of four were decided with a five-four split, which will surely add to the impression that the court, like the country, is bitterly divided.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Greece, Bangladesh and Nepal.

headline: Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2013 Accessories
text: Accessories highlights from the London men’s collections.

headline: Rubio Is Likely to Shelve Efforts on Bipartisan Immigration Bill
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said on Monday that President Obama’s executive action to suspend deportation of illegal immigrants brought to the country as children will likely put his search for bipartisan legislation on ice for now.

headline: Q&A: Adding Radio Stations to iTunes
text: Q.

headline: Underwood Gains Berth for Olympics
text: Quanitta Underwood, considered a contender to win a medal for the United States in women’s boxing, was awarded a berth in the London Olympics on Monday.

headline: Egypt’s Generals Hollow Out Its Presidency
text: CAIRO — As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, the apparent victory of Mohamed Morsi, the Muslim Brotherhood’s candidate, in Egypt’s presidential election was complicated on Monday by legal maneuvers from the ruling military council which cast doubt on what power the office now holds.

headline: He Says a Lot, for a Norwegian
text: Until the recent publication of “My Struggle,” a 3,600-page work in six volumes, the career of the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard had followed a fairly conventional trajectory: A young man besotted by the beauty of words, nature, music and painting writes a coming-of-age novel that earns him prizes and praise and then tries something more ambitious, which becomes an international best seller and wins more prizes.

headline: Small Telescope Helps Make Big Discovery
text: A small telescope, no bigger nor more powerful than a high-end digital camera, has helped researchers discover two new planets, both similar in makeup to the gas giant Jupiter.

headline: Trust in Government, Declining With Cuts
text: Tyler Cowen’s Economic View column on Sunday argued that the government’s economic tool kit was less effective because Americans lacked trust in the government:

headline: Trappings of Art, From Tank to Coffin
text: A central goal of the inaugural Queer New York International Arts Festival was to posit a more expansive notion of queerness. Yet in several solo performances offered last week at Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side, one of the most striking through-lines was the way these works dealt with various ideas of confinement and were themselves confined.

headline: Step Into My Parlor, Coaxes This Pitcher Plant
text: Pitcher plants are carnivores that rely on insects for nourishment. One species of the plant, found in Southeast Asia, uses raindrops to trap prey in its fluid-filled pitcher, a new study reports. Writing in the journal PLoS One, researchers describe how the species Nepenthes gracilis has a springboardlike mechanism built into its lid.

headline: New Hits Needed; Apply to NPR
text: On an unseasonably warm spring night at the Bell House, a hip club in Brooklyn, a new NPR quiz show was taking shape. Like its hit older sibling “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!,” the new show, “Ask Me Another,” is taped before a live audience. But “Wait Wait ...” tapes at the likes of the august Carnegie Hall when it is in New York; this audience was sitting on metal folding chairs and drinking beer from plastic cups as contestants filed onstage to compete over obscure trivia like Weird Al Yankovic lyrics.

headline: How’s That Mom Stuff Working for You?
text: The why is obvious.

headline: Hour by Hour, Celebrating an Eclectic Festival
text: However quixotic the notion of mounting a 12-hour concert is, and however impractical it can be to attend one in its entirety, I feel guilty when I am unable to be at the annual Bang on a Can Marathon from start to finish. I feel obliged to meet a challenge on its own terms, as I did when Bang on a Can celebrated its 20th anniversary with a 27-hour event in 2007.

headline: A Career Waiting for E.T. to Phone
text: Jill Tarter once complained to me that she had no poetry in her soul.

headline: Penney’s No. 2 Executive Is Departing After 8 Months as President of Struggling Retailer
text: The No. 2 executive at J. C. Penney is out after only eight months on the job.

headline: The Media and Obama’s Immigration Gambit
text: A month ago, I wrote a Campaign Stops column laying out the political risks associated with a presidential “evolution” on gay marriage. That same afternoon, President Obama formally endorsed same-sex marriage. Last week, I wrote a Campaign Stops piece explaining why the politics of immigration aren’t as favorable to various forms of legalization as many elites in both parties tend to assume. Three days later, President Obama unilaterally ordered a kind of provisional legalization (an end to deportation, and with it the possibility of work permits) for under-30 illegal immigrants who were brought to America as children.

headline: East Nashville’s Flowering Food Scene
text: A neighborhood thick with hipsters, like East Nashville, is an indicator that good food is not far away.

headline: Discovery of a £16 Advance Sheds Light on John Cabot’s Adventures
text: In early 1496, a Venetian sea captain named Giovanni Caboto appeared in the southern English port city of Bristol. He had no money, but carried a warrant from King Henry VII to obtain a ship and sail on a voyage of trade and discovery.

headline: New Albums from Patti Smith, Ravi Coltrane and Neneh Cherry
text: PATTI SMITH

headline: Nashville’s Rising Stars: The Kitchen Is Their Studio

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Swarms of Farmbots and E-Book Growth
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. See more here.

headline: Footnote
text: Patti LuPone’s cabaret show “Far Away Places” at 54 Below in Manhattan has added seven performances through Saturday. Andrea Martin, who was supposed to take the stage this week, was said to be suffering from “a stubborn bronchial infection.” Her show will be rescheduled.

headline: Nature Follows a Path of Pixels Into Children’s Hearts
text: Middle age, I’ve discovered, brings with it an almost irresistible urge to slip into the comfortable skin of the curmudgeon and gripe, especially about things teenagers do, especially if they are popular and fun.

headline: The Delicate Art of Naming Campaign Bus Tours
text: On Tuesday, Mitt Romney will wrap up his “Every Town Counts” bus tour through small towns in six states. The thematic barnstormer-via-motorcoach might be quaint in the days of Twitter and microtargeting, but such bus tours are actually a somewhat recent phenomenon.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Italy Advances to Knockout Round With a Tense Victory

headline: Shot Fired at Duane Reade Cashier in Robbery Attempt
text: A surveillance camera recorded the scene: On Friday, around 11 p.m., two men stood at the counter of a Duane Reade at 100 Delancey Street on the Lower East Side. One man, wearing a blue baseball cap, drew a gun from inside his jacket and fired a single bullet at a cashier, who was standing outside the camera’s field of vision. The two men fled.

headline: A Public Service Ad About Air, and an App
text: “I MEAN, yeah, you can say it’s an unusual hobby,” says a man in his 20s wearing oversize glasses in a quirky new public service announcement from the American Lung Association. “I’ve had people laugh at me, but I don’t care. I just love collecting air.”

headline: Using Risk Estimates to Guide Nuclear Safety
text: Since the inception of civilian nuclear power, critics have argued that the regulators do not draft or apply rules in a way that is appropriate to the risks. Oddly, the regulators sometimes agree; the rules and practices governing reactor safety, they say, are a patchwork.

headline: A Conversation with Ambassador Rice
text: A Google+ Hangout features the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kritsof, Ambassador Susan E. Rice and a selection of reader participants in a discussion of United States foreign policy.

headline: Google Getting More Requests From Democracies to Censor
text: Government censorship is on the rise — and not just in the countries you would expect, according to Google.

headline: Flier Satisfaction Suffers as More Seats Squeeze In
text: LET me spill a secret here. The truth is, I really do not like to travel, even though I have to.

headline: Groups Urge Facebook Not to Aim Ads at Children Under 13
text: An alliance of consumer rights groups on Monday pressed Facebook not to aim advertisements at preteen children or track their activities online if it formally opens its site to them.

headline: Much-Debated Scholarship Program for D.C. Students Is Renewed
text: The D.C. Opportunity Scholarship Program will at least live on another year.

headline: Microsoft Introduces a Challenger to the iPad
text: LOS ANGELES — In its most strategically significant push yet into the hardware business, Microsoft on Monday unveiled a tablet computer called Surface that is intended to challenge Apple’s iPad.

headline: French Elect New Yorker to National Assembly
text: Updated, 10:40 p.m., June 22 | WHEN France’s National Assembly reconvenes on Tuesday, its new Socialist majority will include a longtime New Yorker.

headline: Rio Isn’t All Lost
text: IN June 1992, world leaders, including President George Bush, agreed to combat climate change at the Earth Summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro. This week, at “Rio+20,” leaders, experts and activists will once more gather to ponder the fate of the planet.

headline: Even in New York, China Casts a Shadow
text: One month after their flight from China to New York, the dissident lawyer Chen Guangcheng and his family have settled into comfortable, busy lives in Greenwich Village.

headline: Nearly 20 Years Later, Arsenio Hall Is Returning to Late-Night TV
text: After an absence longer than many careers in show business, Arsenio Hall will be attempting a comeback in late-night television when a new syndicated show begins in over a year.

headline: Barton Lidice Benes, Provocative Artist, Dies at 69
text: Barton Lidice Benes, a New York sculptor who worked in materials that he called artifacts of everyday life, expanded his definition of “everyday” as he went. He used the everyday mementos of childhood in his early work, and later made sculptures from chopped up, everyday American cash (purchased pre-shredded from the Federal Reserve).

headline: U.S. Accuses Colombian in Drug Bribes
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Mauricio Santoyo led an elite antiterrorism squad in Colombia’s National Police force and then became chief of presidential security when Álvaro Uribe took office as the country’s tough-on-crime president. Once there, he worked closely with United States officials to beef up Mr. Uribe’s safety arrangements.

headline: With Risks for Growth Still Hazy, Fed to Weigh New Aid
text: WASHINGTON — In retrospect, this might not have been the best week for a long-scheduled meeting of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee.

headline: Erica Kennedy, a Music Writer Who Satirized the Hip-Hop World, Dies at 42
text: Erica Kennedy, a music writer turned novelist who came to wide attention in 2004 with the publication of her first novel, “Bling,” a satirical roman à clef about the world of hip-hop, was found dead last week at her home in Miami Beach. She was 42.

headline: Microsoft’s Not Competing With the iPad — Not Entirely
text: Microsoft’s new Surface tablet computer is not an iPad competitor. It’s an ultrabook competitor.

headline: Mets Keep a Cautious Approach With Injured Players
text: As the Mets on Monday continued to navigate delicate injury situations on multiple fronts, the overarching message has become one of caution.

headline: City Moves Ahead to Replace Staff at 24 Failing Schools
text: As the city prepares to shut down 24 failing schools and reopen them in the fall as newly imagined institutions, close to 3,000 New York City public school teachers received letters Monday informing them that their jobs would soon be terminated and they would be put in a special pool of teachers without full-time posts.

headline: The American Dream: Phase II
text: “Sprawl … It’s the American dream unfolding before your eyes.”

headline: Loopholes Abound Despite New Rules
text: Bank regulators are casting new nets to catch excessive risk-taking in the financial system. But future London Whales may find plenty of ways to slip right through them.

headline: Goldman Stuck With a Defense Tab, and Awaiting a Payback
text: For Goldman Sachs, the insider trading case against a former board member, Rajat K. Gupta, which ended in a conviction on Friday, was distracting and discomforting.

headline: Road Trip Helps Romney Brush Up on Banter
text: JANESVILLE, Wis. — Mitt Romney’s English is direct and to the point, useful for attacking President Obama on the stump or dismantling his Republican opponents in primary debates. He is even fluent in French. But the one language Mr. Romney doesn’t seem to speak is small talk.

headline: Hall of Fame Voters to Judge Stars Marred by Steroid Scandals
text: When the 2013 Baseball Hall of Fame ballot is distributed in November, it will be a who’s who of baseball’s steroids era. Appearing for the first time will be the names of Roger Clemens, Barry Bonds and Sammy Sosa, all of whom had sparkling careers that were tarnished by their highly publicized links to performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Regulators Join Dimon at House Panel Hearing
text: Jamie Dimon, the outspoken chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, is returning to Washington to face another round of questions about his bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.

headline: Taming Sentences
text: Diagramming sentences: what, after all, is it good for?

text: If you want to be scared, truly terrified, listen to Mark J. Grant. He might be right.

headline: Global Economy Limits Expectations at Earth Summit in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Global leaders, development experts, bankers, academics and activists are gathering here this week to celebrate the anniversary of the landmark Earth Summit of 1992 and to try to address the linked problems of poverty, hunger, energy shortages and environmental degradation.

headline: No Majority Rationale in Crime Lab Testimony Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — In a badly fractured 5-to-4 decision in which no rationale commanded a majority, the Supreme Court on Monday seemed to retreat from a groundbreaking decision in 2009 that said crime lab reports may not be used in criminal trials unless the analysts responsible for creating them provide live testimony.

headline: Investors in Search of Bigger Fix to Euro Crisis
text: The latest relief rally in European financial markets was over almost before it began.

headline: Council Aide Seeks a Slot on Ballot in Sierra Leone
text: By around midnight at a fund-raiser last month for Al-Hassan Kanu, a City Council aide making a run for public office, only about a dozen supporters had shown up at an African restaurant in Jamaica, Queens.

headline: Greek Voting Past, Europe Returns to Fiscal Rescue
text: BERLIN — After Greek elections eased fears that the country’s exit from the euro zone was imminent, attention turned Monday to an even bigger challenge: restoring the economic body to health with Greece still in it.

headline: An Ex-President Who Won’t Keep Away
text: Medellín, Colombia

headline: 2 Legislators on Tough Turf Try Delicate Run Down the Middle
text: GRAYSLAKE, Ill. — He had to know it would be unpleasant, interrupting eight unsmiling men of a certain age who were polishing off their morning coffee. But Representative Robert Dold, his face locked in a smile so bright it could be studied by astronomers, moved in.

headline: For Tyson, a ‘Vulnerable’ Performance Outside the Ring
text: There are not an awful lot of firsts left for Mike Tyson. Fights, world records, championships, prison, prostitutes, drugs, Hollywood blockbusters, pigeons: all checked off. But a little before 3 p.m. on Monday, on a spotlighted West 48th Street stage, Mr. Tyson marked one more milestone, as he answered a question from a reporter from Playbill magazine.

headline: Hollywood to Black Mothers: Stay Home
text: The movie “What To Expect When You’re Expecting” was, sadly, exactly what I expected: devoid of any real representation of African-American motherhood. Whenever Hollywood sets out to portray the joys and trials of modern motherhood on the big screen, black mothers are blatantly and consistently missing from the mix.

headline: Oracle’s Results Surpass Analysts’ Expectations
text: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) — Oracle reported financial results late Monday that exceeded Wall Street’s expectations and said it would buy back up to $10 billion of its shares. But the bigger surprise was the timing of the company’s announcement; the numbers were not expected to be released until Thursday.

headline: The Betrayal of Egypt’s Revolution
text: CairoPreliminary election results show that the Muslim Brotherhood’s Mohamed Morsi is likely to become Egypt’s next president. But even if Mr. Morsi is declared the official winner later this week, Egypt’s first popular presidential election will not have been a democratic milestone.

headline: Electronics Retailers Scramble to Adapt to Changing Market
text: Even as Best Buy insists it can get out of its current predicament, competitors are circling, as everyone tries to prove one point: that electronics stores can thrive.

headline: And Now for Something Completely Different
text: Greece and Germany will face off Friday with a berth in the semifinals of Euro 2012 at stake. The two teams met in an even more momentous game back in 1972.

headline: Hate Speech and Free Speech, Part Two
text: Readers of my column about Jeremy Waldron’s new book, “The Harm in Hate Speech,” wondered how the hate speech regulations Waldron calls for could be implemented, and wondered, too, whether key terms like “dignity” and “harm” could be defined in ways that would avoid the dangers of imprecision and the slippery slope. The editors and I have invited Professor Waldron to respond to these and other questions. One poster asked if I was reporting on Waldron’s arguments or endorsing them. I was endorsing them, as I have already (implicitly) done in “There’s No Such Thing as Free Speech … And It’s a Good Thing, Too” and other publications. — S.F.

headline: Rutgers Case Will Not Spur Deportation, Officials Say
text: Immigration officials said Monday that they would not try to deport Dharun Ravi, the Indian-born 20-year-old convicted in March of using a webcam to spy on his roommate having sex with another man in their dormitory at Rutgers University.

headline: Jail for Ex-Westchester Legislator in Tax Case
text: WHITE PLAINS — Nicholas A. Spano, who spent nearly three decades representing Westchester County as a state senator and assemblyman, was sentenced on Monday to a year and a day in jail for tax evasion.

headline: Ex-Prosecutor Presents N.F.L.’s Findings in Bounty Case
text: The four New Orleans Saints players suspended for what the N.F.L. says was their roles in a bounty system met with Commissioner Roger Goodell on Monday in Manhattan and were given the opportunity to respond to the league’s evidence against them.

headline: Facing Confirmation Fight, Nominee as Ambassador to Iraq Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s nominee for ambassador to Iraq withdrew from consideration on Monday after a series of racy e-mails fueled Republican opposition and eroded Democratic support for his confirmation in the Senate.

headline: When ALEC Takes Over Your Town
text: The Rhode Island State Legislature finally adjourned its 2012 session around 3:30 a.m. on Wednesday morning. It had been a brutal last few days.

headline: Microsoft’s Surface Pro: Sorry, H.P.
text: MicrosoftMicrosoft’s Surface tablet has a keyboard and a kickstand.

headline: Coach of the Thunder Keeps Grinding It Out
text: MIAMI — In the cursory review of Scott Brooks’s winding N.B.A. career, it is the names, not the numbers, that stand out. If there were such a thing as greatness by association, Brooks might have become an All-Star through osmosis.

headline: Egypt’s Democracy Interrupted
text: The once-promising democratic transition in Egypt is in peril after a power grab by the generals and the courts — holdovers from Hosni Mubarak’s repressive regime. This is not what Egyptians rallied and died for in Tahrir Square. It guarantees more turmoil. Given Egypt’s importance in the Arab world, it sets a terrible example for other societies trying to get beyond autocratic rule.

headline: Running for the House on Pride in His Roots, and Pure Energy
text: Adriano Espaillat strode across the light blue linoleum floor of his campaign office with a FedEx box tucked under his arm, his tie as neat and step as perky as they were when his day began 15 hours earlier.

headline: Dickey Pitches Another One-Hitter
text: R. A. Dickey has tried to play down the dominance of his knuckleball, the enchanting novelty of his remarkable performance this season.

headline: Marijuana Plan Appears Doomed in Albany
text: ALBANY — Facing resistance from the Republican-controlled Senate, a proposal by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana in public view appeared near defeat on Monday as lawmakers approached the end of this year’s legislative session.

headline: Can Stop-and-Frisk Be ‘Mended’?
text: As marchers in Manhattan protested the Police Department’s increasingly unpopular stop-and-frisk program on Sunday, Mayor Michael Bloomberg took to the pulpit at a predominantly black church in Brooklyn and said the policy must be “mended, not ended.”

headline: With Three Spirited Primaries, Competitive Democracy Is Breaking Out
text: Vito J. Lopez, assemblyman and chairman of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, is trying to help me understand why he longs to electorally decapitate his borough’s senior Democratic congresswoman, Nydia M. Velázquez.

headline: Lost in Recession, Toll on Underemployed and Underpaid
text: Throughout the Great Recession and the not-so-great recovery, the most commonly discussed measure of misery has been unemployment. But many middle-class and working-class people who are fortunate enough to have work are struggling as well, which is why Sherry Woods, a 59-year-old van driver from Atlanta, found herself standing in line at a jobs fair this month, with her résumé tucked inside a Bible.

headline: The Confrontation Clause, Confused
text: The Supreme Court ruled in 2009 that crime lab reports cannot be used against criminal defendants unless the analysts responsible for them are subject to cross-examination. On Monday, the court’s 5-to-4 majority sharply departed from that clear precedent, without overruling it, in a fractured decision that will sow confusion about how such reports can be used in criminal trials.

headline: We’ll Take Summer
text: It’s easy to forget that we live in a world of temporal abstractions. The sun reaches its zenith — local noon — a little earlier in New York City than it does in Buffalo, but, according to the clocks, “noon” comes at exactly the same moment in both places. The world has been organized and synchronized for very good reasons, but it’s worth remembering that, only a couple of centuries ago, time was utterly local. Noon here — wherever you happened to be — was never the same as noon farther east or west.

headline: Don’t Look Down
text: Somewhere between Nik Wallenda’s first step onto a tightrope over Niagara Falls and Greece’s most recent retreat from the brink, it hit me: teetering needlessly on the precipice of disaster wasn’t just the story of the weekend. It’s the story of our days.

headline: Filling the Silence With the Voice of Youth
text: The scrabbling of iguanas across a metal roof, the squawk of a parrot and other colorful noises are resounding throughout the Claire Tow Theater, the handsome new auditorium built atop Lincoln Center Theater’s Broadway home, the Vivian Beaumont Theater. But the truly exotic note in the jungle symphony of Greg Pierce’s play “Slowgirl” is the adrenaline chatter of the 17-year-old American girl who finds herself in the alien environment of rural Costa Rica. Her anxious, endless nattering reverberates like a constant klaxon horn amid the silence inhabited by her uncle, who has retreated from the world to live in solitude with nature.

headline: Uncertainties Underlie the Celebrations in Cairo
text: CAIRO — The first celebrations for the new president were joyous but spare, a party overwhelmed by traffic and heat. In Tahrir Square, flags waved and boys set off fireworks that disappeared in the midday sun.

headline: ‘Allo, ‘Allo!
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If the Monday through Saturday New York Times crossword puzzles ran with a title, today’s would have to be something along the lines of “‘Allo, ‘Allo!” because, and I’m sure you’ve sussed this out already, the grid contains all O’s. Sixty nine of them. That’s the only vowel in the whole puzzle. O is a very common letter, but it’s still quite a feat to pull this off. Steven Riley has done it, and with the exception of some less than stellar areas, he’s done it well.

headline: Corrections: June 19
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Dropping Helmet Laws to Reduce a Town’s Risk
text: MILTON, Wash. — Will the nanny state take away our right to drink too much soda? Will the police rob us of privacy in the name of fighting terrorism? In an era of polarized politics, the fear of government encroachment is one thing that unifies Americans from the left and the right.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Lower East Side Roots in Full Bloom
text: Wearing a floral print Suno dress, Esther Weisbrod explains her style.

headline: The Middle School Conundrum
text: Do preteens and young teenagers fare better in K-8 schools or sectioned off in separate middle schools?

headline: As Swarms Startle New York, Officer on Bee Beat Stays Busy
text: One swarm covered the side-view mirror of a Volvo station wagon in a lot by the Hudson River, trapping a family of three inside. Another humming cluster the size of a watermelon bent a tree branch in front of a Chase Bank on the Lower East Side, attracting a crowd of gasping onlookers. And for several hours, thousands of bees carpeted a two-foot-tall red standpipe on the patio of a South Street Seaport restaurant, sending would-be outdoor diners elsewhere.

headline: Finding Work From Fly-Fishing’s Popularity
text: PUNTA ALLEN, Mexico — For nearly two millennia, the Mayan people along the Yucatán Peninsula’s Caribbean coast have relied on fishing for sustenance and trade. The tradition continues, though today many Mayan fishermen are as likely to be throwing a 10-weight graphite fly rod as a net.

headline: In Spirit and in Form, Ousted Titan Keeps a Hold Over Senegal
text: DAKAR, Senegal — He suffered a crushing electoral defeat less than three months ago, rejected by nearly two-thirds of the electorate. Some of his top political lieutenants have abandoned him. And he recently turned 86 — at least according to him — after a lifetime in Senegalese politics.

headline: Lobbying Effort Is Said to Sink New Controls on Painkillers
text: WASHINGTON — Efforts to impose stricter controls on prescription drugs that are subject to rampant abuse have apparently failed after a groundswell of lobbying by pharmacists and drugstores, members of Congress said on Monday.

headline: Bone Bruise Keeps Swisher Out
text: Nick Swisher missed his second consecutive start Monday because of a bone bruise in his quad, although Manager Joe Girardi said there was progress.

text: Community Education’s founder and chief executive said Delaney Hall offered innovative services that help prisoners and save tax dollars.

text: Gov. Chris Christie speaking at Delaney Hall’s 10th-anniversary celebration, in a company promotional video.

headline: Anger Builds Over Dismissal of University of Virginia President
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — More than a week after the University of Virginia suddenly ousted its president, the furor over the move continued to mount on Monday, as thousands of students and faculty members gathered to support her, even as the governing board met to consider an interim replacement.

headline: New Yorkers, Show Us Your Beehives
text: Update  We are no longer accepting submissions for this feature, but we thank all of the beekeepers who shared photographs with us. Below, we present  a slide show of the best entries.

headline: Jeter Drives Yankees’ 10th Straight Win
text: Derek Jeter has been the Yankees’ everyday shortstop since 1996, a stretch in which Jeter has played in 2,476 regular-season games. During that time, the longest winning streaks Jeter has experienced have been 10 games.

headline: Jeffrey’s Difficult Move
text: Jeffrey Isidoro, 10, moved to Mexico after his father was deported from the United States. He is part of a new generation of young immigrants blurring the line between Mexican and American.

headline: Teachers’ Union to Open Lesson-Sharing Web Site
text: Teachers seeking lesson plans on anything from fractions and multiplication tables to Shakespeare or the Civil War can take to the Internet for a boundless array of work sheets, reading lists and classroom tips, available free or for a fee.

headline: Life After the Games for Five Former Olympians
text: They may be Olympians, but no one is ever going to mistake Tara Lipinski, Sasha Cohen, Sarah Hughes, Jeremy Bloom or Joey Cheek for beach volleyball champions.

headline: Witness to a Murder
text: Derek West Harris was killed in a robbery at Delaney Hall. Another inmate witnessed the attack.

headline: Chinese Activist, Now in New York, Takes a Harder Look at Beijing
text: BANGKOK — Even after years of detention, rough treatment and harassment in his rural village in China, Chen Guangcheng seemed to hold tight to the belief that Beijing was a shining city on a hill, a place where officials in the central government — if they only knew — would look favorably on his efforts to win legal rights for beleaguered plaintiffs over illegal land grabs and forced abortions.

headline: In a Shift, Biggest Wave of Migrants Is Now Asian
text: Asians have surpassed Hispanics as the largest wave of new immigrants to the United States, pushing the population of Asian descent to a record 18.2 million and helping to make Asians the fastest-growing racial group in the country, according to a study released Tuesday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Asians Are Immigrations New Face
text: Asians have overtaken Hispanics as the largest stream of new immigrants.

headline: Southern Baptist Convergence
text: The secular media usually ignores the thousands of pastors, missionaries and church volunteers who gather every summer for the annual meeting of the Southern Baptist Convention. This year is different. Everyone from PBS to the Huffington Post is buzzing with anticipation — and not because they are awaiting the tedious discussion of committee reports and budgets necessary to manage the country’s largest evangelical denomination. The reason for all the excitement is this: the 2012 convention, which opens Tuesday in New Orleans, will elect a black man as president for the first time in Southern Baptist history. This is no small thing for a denomination that separated in 1845 from its northern brethren in order to defend the right of Southern slaveholders to serve as missionaries.

headline: American Children, Now Struggling to Adjust to Life in Mexico
text: IZÚCAR DE MATAMOROS, Mexico — Jeffrey Isidoro sat near the door of his fifth-grade classroom here in central Mexico, staring outside through designer glasses that, like his Nike sneakers and Nike backpack, signaled a life lived almost entirely in the United States. His parents are at home in Mexico. Jeffrey is lost.

headline: At Penal Unit, a Volatile Mix Fuels a Murder
text: NEWARK — Derek West Harris wore tailored pants, soft sweaters and shiny shoes. People called him D-Nice. His easygoing manner drew customers to his barber’s chair at Million Dollar Kutz in Newark, a shop where he was known as much for his conversation as for his trims. He chatted about religion, relationships and cars, which he loved.

headline: Rhode Island: Death Penalty Sought, as State Feared
text: The federal government will seek the death penalty in the case of Jason W. Pleau, the man at the center of a legal custody battle between the State of Rhode Island and federal prosecutors. Gov. Lincoln Chafee had initially refused to hand over Mr. Pleau, who is accused of killing a gas station attendant during a robbery in 2010 in Woonsocket, R.I., to federal authorities, arguing that doing so could expose him to the death penalty, which Rhode Island does not have. A federal appeals court ordered the transfer last month. On Monday, federal prosecutors filed a notice of intent to seek a death sentence.

headline: R.A. Dickey’s Second Consecutive One-Hitter
text: The Mets knuckleballer manhandled the Orioles and became the first pitcher to record back-to-back one-hitters since Dave Stieb in 1988.
