text: forgo •\fȯr-ˈgo\• verb

headline: Connecting to Lower East Side Roots in Style
text: Esther Weisbrod’s connection to the Lower East Side runs deeper than her appreciation for the neighborhood’s mom-and-pops stores, live music venues and leather and tattoo-clad residents. We spotted her at Ludlow and Rivington Streets, just blocks away from where she said her great-grandfather used to live and sell stockings out of pushcart on Pitt Street.

headline: Competitors Form Partnership to Develop Autism Drugs
text: Two of the front-runners in the race to develop drugs to treat mental retardation and autism are joining forces, hoping to save money and get to the market sooner.

headline: St. John’s Dunlap to Be Coach of Charlotte Bobcats
text: After a season highlighted by turnover, St. John’s lost another key piece Monday night. The assistant Mike Dunlap, the Red Storm’s key strategist, is leaving to become the coach of the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: Which Wayne Rooney Will Return for England?
text: Wayne Rooney’s relationship with international tournaments has been a complicated one. It’s almost eight years since Rooney consummated that relationship in the purest way a soccer player can, with goals. It could be said that the same time has elapsed since a relationship was evident at all.

headline: Armenia and Azerbaijan Blame Each Other for Protracted War
text: MOSCOW — A day after the presidents of the United States, Russia and France issued a joint statement calling for a peaceful settlement to the more than 20-year war between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the two enemies publicly blamed each other Tuesday for failing to resolve the conflict.

headline: New Worries About Women’s Rights and Ethnic Tensions Emerge in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Events this week that raised questions on women’s rights and ethnic tensions have added to long-term concerns about Afghanistan after American-led forces withdraw in 2014 and new elections are held.

headline: 800,000 People Forced to Flee Across Borders in 2011, Report Says
text: Upheavals in Ivory Coast, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and elsewhere drove 800,000 people to flee their countries and become refugees in 2011, the highest number in 11 years, the United Nations said Monday in its annual report on the forcibly displaced. The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said that 4.3 million people in all were newly displaced last year, which includes those who stayed in their countries and those who fled. At the end of 2011, the report said, 42.5 million people were either refugees (15.2 million), internally displaced (26.4 million) or in the process of seeking asylum (895,000). The overall total was lower than the 2010 total of 43.7 million mainly because 3.2 million internally displaced people returned home, the report said. The number of people who fled their countries and became refugees last year was the highest in that category since 822,000 in 2000.

headline: Iraq: Bomber Attacks Funeral
text: A man wearing an explosives belt detonated it amid a group of Shiite mourners at a funeral in Diyala Province on Monday, killing at least 15 people and wounding more than 40, according to security officials. The attack came after days of strikes against mostly Shiite targets in a stepped-up campaign of sectarian violence carried out by the Sunni insurgent group Al Qaeda in Iraq. Over the past week nearly 150 Iraqis have been killed in attacks. Violence, largely sectarian in nature, has substantially increased after a period of relative calm following the withdrawal of the American military in December. The rising violence coincides with a political struggle involving Iraq’s three main factions — the Shiite majority, which controls the government, and the minority Kurds and Sunnis, who have called for a vote of no confidence against Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: China: Spacecraft Docks With Orbiting Module
text: A Chinese spacecraft carrying three astronauts docked with an orbiting module on Monday, another first for the country as it strives to match American and Russian exploits in space. The Shenzhou 9 capsule completed the maneuver with the Tiangong 1 module 213 miles above Earth. The astronauts will live and work in the module for several days as part of preparations for a permanent space station. The crew includes 33-year-old Liu Yang, an air force pilot and the first Chinese woman in space. The docking was a first for Chinese astronauts. In November 2011, the unmanned Shenzhou 8 successfully docked twice with Tiangong 1 by remote control. Monday’s docking also was completed by remote control from a ground base in China. A manual docking, to be carried out by one of the crew members, is scheduled for later in the mission. (AP)

headline: News Quiz | June 19, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: An Insider’s View of the Film Censor Board
text: A housewife rolls in bed, mysteriously moaning all alone at night, unable to sleep. Her husband, an officer with the merchant navy, is always traveling for work. Her gawky young brother-in-law watches her every night from the bedroom door left open. In the morning, the housewife serves breakfast to her shy brother-in-law while they exchange uncomfortable glances. The same scenes get repeated for hours, only the moans keep getting louder.

headline: A Conversation With: Film Censor Board Chief Executive, Pankaja Thakur
text: Pankaja Thakur is the chief executive of the Central Board of Film Certification, commonly known as the Censor Board of India. The post of chief executive, who administers the board, has been vacant for more than a decade until Ms.Thakur was appointed in 2010.

headline: Setback in Talks on Iran’s Nuclear Program in a ‘Gulf of Mistrust’
text: MOSCOW — Talks on Iran’s disputed nuclear program descended into mistrust and frustration in Moscow on Tuesday, casting doubt on whether the two sides can negotiate a way out of the escalating crisis.

headline: A New Policy for Illegal Immigrants
text: Please note: Today’s edition of 6 Q’s focuses on the complex issue of immigration policy, and our questions are drawn from several sources. Those answers not found in the related article linked above can be found by clicking the link in the question.

headline: How to Make Jobs Disappear
text: At precisely 8:30 a.m. on the first Friday of the month, thousands of people (including me) stare at a dull government Web site and hit refresh until they see the number: how many jobs were created or lost during the previous month. Then, with amazing speed, reports and analysis of the number are disseminated by newspapers, bank economists, independent analysts, investment newsletters and countless TV pundits. Within minutes, the national narrative is set. Either the economy is doing far worse (like last month) or far better (as in January) than anyone realized.

text: A clip from Kenneth Lonergan's new film, starring Anna Paquin, Matt Damon and Mark Ruffalo.

headline: In Post-Colonial Hong Kong, Finding Whimsy and Menace
text: HONG KONG – During the months he spent trekking through this city for National Geographic magazine, Mark Leong was on a hunt for glimpses of its underground. Years of Hong Kong cinema had colored his view of the place, rendering it a seedy scene beneath a vibrant subtropical metropolis.

headline: Kenneth Lonergan’s Thwarted Masterpiece
text: Think back on the last time you saw Kenneth Lonergan’s 2000 film, “You Can Count On Me.” Do you remember how good it was? The intellectual and emotional complexity of the script? Those remarkable performances by Mark Ruffalo and Laura Linney? That scene — to choose one among many — between Terry (Ruffalo) and his 8-year-old nephew, Rudy (Rory Culkin), in which the drunk Terry sits next to Rudy’s bed late at night, smoking a cigarette and telling Rudy why his dad is such a jerk and why the town he lives in sucks so much? (“Fortunately for you, though, your mom is like, the greatest. So you had some bad luck, and you had some good luck.”) It was a modest story of a brother and sister whose parents die when they’re kids and whose lives are blown in different directions and who, years later, come to some almost-peace about what they can and can’t be for each other. But there was such intense realness about it, the way people really talk, the way lives are actually lived, that was unlike anything else on screen, radical almost, in its attention to the genuine messiness of human lives.

headline: Before Greek Coalition Forms, Questions About Its Resolve
text: ATHENS — Antonis Samaras, the leader of the center-right New Democracy party that finished first in the Greek parliamentary elections, was poised on Tuesday to form a coalition government with the Socialists and a smaller left-wing party.

headline: Lingering Fears Push Spanish Short-Term Borrowing Costs Up
text: LONDON — Spain’s cost of borrowing continued its rise into unsustainable territory Tuesday, reflecting heightened fears that the country would eventually need a bailout that Europe might not be able to afford.

headline: West Bank Mosque Is Set Ablaze and Vandalized
text: JERUSALEM — A West Bank mosque was burned and vandalized early on Tuesday, with graffiti warning in Hebrew of a “war” over the impending evacuation of the small, disputed Jewish settlement of Ulpana.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Doldrums Behind the Plate
text: The value of the catcher position varies depending on format, as it increases if your league uses two spots in the starting lineup. However, even in two-catcher formats, few catchers are drafted highly for two reasons. First, the position’s taxing physical demand limits their plate appearances, reducing their upside simply through lack of volume. Second, during the past 10 seasons, just eight catchers have finished with more than 10 steals, making it a position that inherently helps you in four categories at best.

headline: The Case of the Screen’s Green Blob
text: You think you’re good at technology? O.K., let’s see you troubleshoot this one.

headline: With Parents' Support, a Chelsea School Goes Healthy
text: Adrian Allannic, a third grader, has learned the lessons of healthy eating at home, but at his school, Public School 11 William T. Harris, he gets to live his healthy habits all day. A growing number of more affluent parents and a motivated principal have brought a new emphasis on fresh foods to the school of almost 700 students in Chelsea, Manhattan. Many schools in New York City have taken steps to provide healthier foods for students in their cafeterias, but P.S. 11 has gone further than most. Elbert Chu's multimedia report shows another way in which New York City's parents are Paying for Public School.

headline: The Surface: Celebrate the Competition, Question the Premise
text: On Monday at a Los Angeles media event that had been veiled in secrecy, Microsoft announced that it was going to make a gorgeous touchscreen tablet like the iPad. It’s called the Surface tablet. Its main differentiators from the iPad: It has a kickstand, it has real PC ports and it will run Windows 8.

headline: The Three Biggest Myths About the S.B.A.
text: I want to share with you what I consider to be the three biggest myths about the Small Business Administration. But let me be clear: I am a big supporter of the S.B.A. My company, MultiFunding, brokers loans, and we put about 25 percent of our clients into S.B.A. loans. I think it’s a good program with a lot of economic benefits. It’s also terribly misunderstood by many of the small-business owners we talk to.

headline: Consumer Bureau Says It Resolved 4 of Every 5 Complaints
text: In its first 10 months on the job, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been able to resolve roughly four out of every five consumer complaints to the apparent satisfaction of the consumer involved, according to statistics released by the bureau on Tuesday.

text: Corporate espionage is a booming industry in India, according to a recent report. And it’s being fueled by executives spying on their rivals as well as their own employees.

headline: The Writing on the Walls

headline: What Obama’s Immigration Decision Might Mean for 2012
text: Even in an era where partisanship is on the rise, demographic changes exert a gravitational pull on policy and politics and are occasionally enough to overcome political divisions. What is more remarkable than President Obama’s decision on Friday to suspend deportations of some illegal immigrants is Republicans’ relatively passive reaction to it.

headline: Making the Most of a Year in the Woods
text: Moving our family from the New Jersey suburbs to the woods of Maine for a year was a big step. It took planning, perseverance and a willingness to deal with biting insects, no dishwasher, no coffeemaker, no microwave and doing laundry at the laundromat. (Thankfully, the laundromat doubles as the pub.)

headline: Charter Schools Face Opposition to Plan for Special Needs Children
text: Charter schools are under increasing pressure to admit and provide more services for children with special needs. This spring, they have been asking the Legislature for the authority to form coalitions, so they can pool resources that will help them fulfill their mandate. The bill seemed to be cruising along, but now the state teachers' union has thrown up a roadblock.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Many Workers Remain Underpaid and Underemployed
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Interest Rates: Varieties of Error
text: I wrote recently about how the failure of inflation to soar was one of the three key tests that classical economics, in all its forms, failed in this depression, while Keynesian economics succeeded. A second was the effect of austerity; Jared Bernstein points us to one of the many charts, this time from Jay Shambaugh, showing that euro experience looks awfully Keynesian:

headline: Square Introduces a Digital Loyalty Card
text: Square, the mobile payments start-up, thinks it has come up with another good reason to buy things with a smartphone instead of cash or a credit card. Its apps now allow shoppers to carry around a digital loyalty card, a replacement for the cards that get punched — buy 10 coffees and get the next one free.

headline: Edible Selby | Ignacio’s Mostly Latin Lunch
text: In a film by The Selby, the chef Ignacio Mattos (formerly of Isa and Il Buco) prepares a richly flavored (mostly) Latin lunch at his home in Brooklyn with his wife, Gabi Plater; their son, Paco Plater Noya; and their friends David Tanis (a New York Times contributor and the author, most recently, of “A Platter of Figs“), Fernando Aciar (owner of O Café) and Pam Yung (a former pastry chef at Isa). Click here to see what’s on the menu.

headline: Whips, Scourges, and Cats
text: So I didn’t realize that this was going to be a whole week of me me me on PBS; nobody tells me anything.

headline: A Refreshing Gulp From the Well of Tainted Politics
text: Just when things were starting to look somewhat bleak for trackers of wayward New York politicians, a federal trial begins on Tuesday for Larry B. Seabrook, a city councilman accused of indulging in various forms of corruption.

headline: Rio +20 Summit
text: World leaders will gather in Rio on Wednesday, 20 years after the original earth summit took place there.

headline: New Book Raises Questions About Obama’s Memoir
text: At Harvard Law School in 1990, President Obama found himself lovingly mocked by his peers for relentlessly promoting the exotic story of a search for racial identity that later became the theme of his best-selling book, “Dreams From My Father.”

headline: For R. A. Dickey, the Ascent Continues
text: It might be possible to imagine two more divergent story lines in one sport than baseball managed Monday, but it would take some heavy-duty creative thinking. Because after baseball followed the Roger Clemens verdict with a second straight one-hitter by Mets pitcher R. A. Dickey, you get the feeling there are some science-fiction writers out there muttering, "I couldn't have thought that up."

headline: Facebook Focuses on the Olympics
text: We’ve mused here before whether this summer’s Olympic Games could be the Twitter Olympics, but let us not forget Olympic athletes on Facebook, which has played a large role in helping some athletes stay connected to fans while far from home.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Gilt Taste: The lobster roll, perfected at home with help from Ruth Reichl: homemade mayo, toasted and buttered bun, potato chips on the side and — who knew? — female lobster. Besides giving you roe to help flavor the spread, they have sweeter meat. — Patrick Farrell

headline: Myanmar President Announces Economic Reforms
text: President Thein Sein of Myanmar announced a “second wave of reforms” on Tuesday aimed at rolling back decades of state control over the country’s sheltered and dysfunctional economy. The changes seek to improve public welfare, he said in a nationally televised address.

headline: A Start-Up Bets on Human Translators Over Machines
text: Language does not come naturally to machines. Unlike humans, computers cannot easily distinguish between, say, a river bank and a savings bank. Satire and jokes? Algorithms have great trouble with that. Irony? Wordplay? Cultural context? Forget it.

headline: The Animated Life of Seth MacFarlane, From ‘Family Guy’ to ‘Ted’
text: When Seth MacFarlane calls to talk about his directorial debut, “Ted,” he’s multitasking, of course. He’s just finished another day of work overseeing the three Fox animated comedies he produces – “Family Guy,” “The Cleveland Show” and “American Dad” – and is preparing to attend a benefit that night. “It’s a little crazy,” Mr. MacFarlane said. “But I can shower and get dressed while we’re on the phone.”

headline: Efforts to Resurrect Kashmir’s Dal Lake Push Forward
text: As the shikara moved silently through Dal Lake on a recent early morning, Lassa Dar, the boatman, quietly spoke of his love for the place and his fears for its future.

headline: Jefferies Profit Falls 22%
text: The Jefferies Group‘s second-quarter profit tumbled 22 percent from the same time last year, the investment bank said on Tuesday, with only debt-trading posting a rise in revenue.

headline: Edible Selby | Ignacio’s Latin Lunch
text: Ignacio Mattos prepares a fish stew with bananas. A film by Todd Selby.

headline: He Has Seen the Internet, and It Is Us
text: The title of Andrew Blum’s first book, “Tubes,” is a tacit and playful acknowledgment of something the world’s digerati have long known: Ted Stevens was right.

headline: Business Day Live | June 19, 2012
text: Microsoft's new tablet hopes to challenge the iPad. | How electronics retailers like Best Buy must change, or die. | Getting the legal bill after an insider trading conviction.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: New Entry in the Tablet Landscape, and a More Hip NPR
text: Taking on Apple’s iPad would seem to be a tough task, but Microsoft on Monday took up the challenge, introducing a new tablet computer called Surface. The new product marks a foray into making hardware for a company known mostly for its software, but it is an acknowledgement, writes Nick Wingfield, that the company needed to depart from its regular way of doing business to maintain its dominance in computing.

headline: Amid Protest, University of Virginia Picks Interim President
text: The University of Virginia on Tuesday selected the dean of its undergraduate business school as its interim president, just hours after about 2,000 students, staff and faculty members held a campus demonstration to support Teresa Sullivan, the departing president.

headline: Good Things Happening for Hard-Luck Cain
text: Anaheim, Calif.

headline: Bangladesh’s Right of Refusal
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The Rohingyas of Myanmar would seem to be a most impolite people. They refuse to die.

headline: It’s V.P. Mentioning Season for the G.O.P.
text: Who will be Mitt Romney’s running mate? I can hardly wait to find out, and I’m sure you can’t, either. Lots of names are getting tossed around, with the background encouragement of Mr. Romney’s aides, who are trying hard to show that they’re doing a better job of vetting candidates than Republican nominees generally do.

headline: As PCB Issue Lingers, Removal Will Be Expedited at a Brooklyn School
text: A Brooklyn public school that had leaking light fixtures will be moved to the top of the list of schools with PCB problems, and the city will replace its lighting very soon, city officials said last week. But some health and environmental experts say the timeline for light fixture removal from schools should be expedited citywide.

headline: Wheelies: The Trading Places Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Cybercriminals Getting Quicker and Craftier, Google Says
text: Five years ago, Google started a “Safe Browsing” initiative to track down malicious content across the Web. On Tuesday, the company shared some of the insights it gleaned during the cleanup job.

headline: Just One Look | Narciso Rodriguez
text: “The whole thing is about mixing tailoring and bias cutting into one piece, so that the clothes would be languid and easy,” said the designer Narciso Rodriguez about his resort collection. The theme came across in a white sheath dress featuring a color-blocked bondage bodice (“Classic me,” Rodriguez said), sleek crepe trousers and an even sleeker black coat (“At-night me,” he said), and a bias-cut, bra-equipped buff-colored strap dress (“Day me.” We should have known). This pantsuit and striped top combo sums it up for the designer, because: “It’s my favorite.”

headline: 10 Lessons From the Food & Wine Classic
text: We sat in on some seminars at Food & Wine magazine’s annual festival in Aspen, Colo., last weekend. Our takeaways:

headline: Americans Polarized on Climate, Tuned Out on ‘Fracking’
text: At a young age, Sheril Kirshenbaum has already excelled at many things — authorship in books on kissing and scientific illiteracy, blogging at “Culture of Science,” and more.

headline: Doubt Is Cast on Mission by Monitors Inside Syria
text: The commander of the 300 unarmed United Nations observers assigned to monitor Syria, in his first direct report to the Security Council, cast doubts on Tuesday on the survival of their mission, telling diplomats that he had decided to suspend their work this past weekend because of repeated exposure to close-range gunfire and hostility, some aimed directly at them, by the antagonists there.

headline: Business Day Live | Electronics Retail
text: June 19, 2012 - Best Buy's troubles signal changes in the retail electronics market.

headline: A View From Homs
text: A resident of Ghouta, a neighborhood of Homs, Syria, recorded video of a tank passing by a store.

headline: Tough Times, Even for Those With Jobs
text: Benefits are shrinking and fewer workers are leaving their jobs voluntarily.

headline: Live Blog: House Panel Hearing on JPMorgan
text: Jamie Dimon was back in the hot seat on Tuesday.

headline: Shapeways, Having Printed 1 Million Objects, Secures More Financing
text: screenshot via ShapewaysShapeways allows people to 3-D objects which are then mailed to them.

headline: Microsoft Surface Allows People to Create
text: Did Microsoft just pull off the impossible? Creating a beautifully designed tablet computer that might compete with the Apple iPad?

headline: Alliance Boots Taps Longtime Adviser Centerview in Walgreens Deal
text: LONDON – Centerview Partners, the American investment banking boutique, was named Tuesday as the sole adviser to Alliance Boots in its $6.7 billion deal with Walgreens.

headline: Activist Artist vs. Pipeline
text: An illustrated article that takes a leaf from “Alice in Wonderland” has gained something of an online following, prompting thousands of people to urge the Canadian government to halt development of the Northern Gateway oil pipeline.

headline: Lil Wayne Defends Pulling Nicki Minaj From Hot 97’s Summer Jam
text: Who knew Lil Wayne was a feminist?  That New Orleans rapper said he asked Nicki Minaj, who is signed to his Young Money label, to sit out Hot 97’s Summer Jam concert on June 3 because she was a woman and deserved more respect than she received when one of the radio station’s D.J.’s mocked her recent pop single “Starships.”

headline: Off to Prom, With or Without Date
text: A senior at the Life Academy for Film and Music was not deterred from going to her prom when she and her boyfriend broke up weeks before the big day. Check out the WNYC video of one high school student prepping for her prom -- and share your own prom thoughts.

headline: Business Day Live | Microsoft's Tablet
text: June 19, 2012 — Microsoft’s new tablet hopes to challenge the iPad.

headline: The Perks of a Certain Address
text: In my Sunday column I talked about the frenzied money race in this year’s election, distinguished by the presence of “super PACs” and of billionaires willing to pour millions upon millions into those groups.

headline: Where the Linens Are Laundered
text: W. H. Linen Rental has been washing the linens of some of New York’s finest restaurants for 75 years.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Popular-Vote Option
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Linen Suppliers, the Suds Have Stories to Tell
text: IN 75 years of laundering restaurant napkins, tablecloths and aprons, W. H. Linen Rental has watched the fortunes of its industry rise and fall. But at least one thing has remained constant: the haul of items that come out in the wash, like fish pulled in by a net.

headline: French Architect Arrested in Chinese Inquiry
text: HONG KONG — A French architect who worked closely with a disgraced Chinese official and his wife has been arrested in Cambodia, the French government said late Tuesday, in a development that could trigger further diplomatic friction in a domestic Chinese political dispute that has already embroiled the United States and Britain.

headline: For the Thunder, Slow Starts Could Mean a Quick Exit
text: After managing to claw back from a number of early deficits during their impressive playoff run, the Thunder’s propensity for first-quarter malaise appears to have caught up with them. After Miami jumped out to an 18-2 first quarter lead during Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals, the Heat withstood wave after wave of Thunder runs on the way to securing a series-tying 100-96 victory in Oklahoma City Thursday night.

headline: Looks Like a Taco, Tastes Like a Chip
text: THERE is a compelling logic behind the Doritos Locos Taco, the wildly successful newcomer to the Taco Bell menu. Americans love tacos. They love Doritos Nacho Cheese Flavored Tortilla Chips. So why not combine the two in one fast-food product?

headline: Business Day Live | Insider Trading
text: June 19, 2012 - Getting the legal bill after an insider trading conviction.

headline: Diabetes Linked to Memory Problems in Older Adults
text: A new study adds to growing evidence that the complications of diabetes may extend to the brain, causing declines in memory, attention and other cognitive skills.

headline: 3 Basics of a College Financial Plan
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published earlier this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

text: Badminton player Saina Nehwal displays the medals she won at the Indonesia Open and the Thailand Open.

headline: I’ll Have Hot Toddy Hair and Tyra Brows
text: MANY women go to a salon to relax, but I find the experience exhausting. It’s not just the time-consuming appointments. It’s the vast array of products and services available and the decisions to be made about them, usually while I’m frantically tapping out office e-mails or on a cellphone conference call, pretending to be at my desk.

headline: After Prevailing in Court, ‘The Glass House’ Falters With Viewers
text: A court said last week that viewers should be given a chance to tune in to ABC’s new summer series “The Glass House.” Viewers said, essentially, that’s O.K.

headline: Before Birth, Dad’s ID
text: It is an uncomfortable question that, in today’s world, is often asked by expectant mothers who had more than one male partner at the time they became pregnant. Who is the father?

headline: Tactical Adaptability: The Key to Germany’s Success
text: As the only remaining team in Euro 2012 with a perfect record, you would reckon Germany would be regarded as the favorite. Yet, the manner in which the team has reached these goals has seemingly undermined the achievements, to the point that most neutrals would consider Germany to have underachieved, despite topping the heralded Group of Death.

headline: Lawmakers Clash on Regulation at JPMorgan Hearing
text: Jamie Dimon and his regulators visited Capitol Hill on Tuesday for another round of scrutiny for a recent multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Considering Microsoft’s Surface Tablet
text: Microsoft unveiled its Surface tablet at a news event in Los Angeles on Monday night. On the Bits blog, tech reporters of The New York Times weigh in on the various features of the new device.

headline: Stack of Farm Proposals Is Coming Up for Votes
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate began voting Tuesday on a slimmed-down list of amendments to a farm bill that would set the nation’s food and agriculture policy for the next five years.

headline: A Track Favorite Who Can’t Get Enough Soccer
text: This summer’s Euro 2012 has had no shortage of stories about soccer fandom. Some of them have been good natured, others less so, but they’ve all given credence to the argument that more than any other sport soccer seems to bring out the fanatic in its supporters. As images from the fan zone in Warsaw, Poland, make clear, soccer fans are plentiful. And they can be found anywhere — even among Olympic hopefuls, such as Mo Farah, track and field’s world champion in the 5,000 meters and this year’s favorite to win the gold medal in both the 5,000 and the 10,000 meters.

headline: President of Dow Jones Is Stepping Down
text: 3:34 p.m. | Updated Todd H. Larsen, president of Dow Jones & Co. and a 13-year veteran of the company, which publishes The Wall Street Journal and Barron’s and MarketWatch, is stepping down, Dow Jones said on Tuesday.

headline: Amazonia or Bust!
text: Babylon may well be glorified for its walls, Nineveh for its grandeur, Athens for its letters, and Constantinople for its empire, but Quito trumps them all: as the key of Christianity, and for having conquered a world; for to this city belongs the discovery of the great River of the Amazon.

headline: At Trial, Sandusky’s Wife Comes to His Defense
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — For more than a week, prosecutors and the witnesses they called depicted life inside the Sanduskys’ house at 130 Grandview Road in State College, Pa., not as the warm refuge for a stream of children that the outside world saw, but as a place of horrors where Jerry Sandusky sexually abused one young boy after another.

headline: Subaru BRZ: Slow to the Dealer, Fast Off the Lot
text: Buoyed by positive press and tight supplies, the rear-wheel-drive Subaru BRZ spent the least time in American showrooms than any car in May, according to Edmunds.

headline: With Speed-Camera Bill, More Writing of Tickets May Be Going Hands-Free
text: For many New York City drivers, the cadences of the common speeding ticket can be unfamiliar. Rare is the need to haggle with a police officer, pleading to be let off with a warning, or presenting the pregnant wife as Exhibit A in a bid for leniency. Rarer is the stretch of urban streetscape where an officer might safely approach an offending vehicle, as he would on a highway shoulder.

headline: London Theater Journal: Seeing Patterns in a Nuclear Cloud
text: After more than a week of wall-to-wall theatergoing here, strange patterns are taking shape in my crowded, sleep-starved mind, the sort of coincidences that a cultural kabbalist might make much of.

headline: Mark Ruffalo Joins Call for a Tax on Wall Street
text: The push to tax Wall Street is getting some star power.

headline: Delicate Pastas, Barely Dressed
text: As packaged dried egg pastas go, the pappardelle, tagliolini and others bearing the Cipriani label are fashioned with great finesse. Now there are two new varieties, made only with the egg whites, so they are cholesterol free. The very thin pappardelle noodles and tagliardi squares cook in less than five minutes, with silken yet al dente results. Serve them lightly dressed for summer with chopped fresh tomatoes or coins of sautéed zucchini, strewn with herbs and perhaps some nuggets of crab meat.

headline: A New Stache for ‘Peter and the Starcatcher’
text: Christian Borle, who won a Tony Award earlier this month for playing Black Stache in “Peter and the Starcatcher,” will be leaving the show on June 30 to start production on the second season of NBC’s Broadway-themed series “Smash.” Matthew Saldívar, now in the Broadway revival of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” will take over the role.

headline: Sophisticated Flavors for Summer Heat
text: Ice cream and summer are a predictable pair, but this year brings a few surprises.

headline: A Day at the Beach? Suit Yourself
text: THERE are few expeditions that strike as much terror in women’s hearts as shopping for a bathing suit — or so one of the biggest clichés of retail holds. Ohmygod, those fluorescent lights, highlighting our every dimple and wrinkle! Another round of cosmopolitans, sister girlfriends!

headline: In Protest, Walker Won’t Allow Hebrew Translation of ‘The Color Purple’
text: 3:42 p.m. | Updated

headline: Obama’s Lawyer Demands Information on Group’s Donors
text: 6:29 p.m. | Updated  The lawyer for President Obama demanded on Tuesday that Crossroads GPS disclose its donors, saying in a complaint to the Federal Election Commission that the group is plainly a “political committee” subject to federal reporting requirements.

headline: Q&A: Checking Up on Windows Security
text: Q.

headline: Jamie Dimon on Gambling
text: Jamie Dimon, the head of JPMorgan Chase, testified before the House Committee on Financial Services today. This was my favorite exchange:

headline: Despite Nook, Barnes & Noble Sales Miss Expectations
text: Barnes & Noble reported a fourth-quarter loss of $57.7 million on Tuesday, falling short of market expectations, even though sales of the popular “The Hunger Games” and “Fifty Shades of Grey” and the liquidation of Borders lifted same-store sales by 4.5 percent in the period.

headline: Perfumes to Sip as Well as Sniff
text: IF you think perfume’s only place is behind the wrist or ear, take another sniff at that drink you just ordered. Scents are starting to show up in martinis, margaritas and much fancier concoctions, thanks in large part to Mandy Aftel, a former psychotherapist who now makes edible and potable perfumes.

headline: Self-Interest Meets Mandate
text: Within the next few days, the Supreme Court may strike down the provision in the Affordable Care Act requiring every American to buy health insurance. Odds that the justices will reject this measure, the so-called individual mandate, are approaching 80 percent on Intrade, a market where investors can bet on the outcome of pretty much everything.

headline: From the Restaurant Kitchen Straight to the Sidewalk
text: In the hot weather you want ease, and the walk-up window lets you order food without waiting to be seated. At Sauce, a restaurant that opened last fall on the Lower East Side, you can saunter up and order a meal in a container after midnight, or for breakfast. For Frank Prisinzano (in photo), the chef, who also has restaurants in the East Village, and his partner, Rob DeFlorio, the window, which opened last week, is a way to sell food when the restaurant is not open for table service. “There are not a lot of options when you’re hungry in this neighborhood, especially late at night,” Mr. DeFlorio said. The menu includes five dishes, like spaghetti with various toppings, as well as French toast, eggs and a kale salad.

headline: Ryanair Offers $883 Million for Aer Lingus
text: 05:07 a.m. | Updated

headline: On Our Radar: Fake Clean Energy Credits
text: A lawyer for a Maryland man accused of selling $9.1 million in fraudulent renewable energy credits says his client isn’t guilty because buyers knew they were fake. The defendant. Rodney Hailey, is accused of using the proceeds to buy cars, homes and jewelry. [Associated Press]

headline: Mike Dunlap Is Not a Big Name, but He Has Big-Name Fans
text: Imagine the standard pre-game introductions for the Charlotte Bobcats: “And now coaching your Bobcats…Mike Dunlap!”

headline: David Roberts on the Simple Climate Problem
text: David Roberts of Grist.org has posted his presentation at an Evergreen State College  TEDx event, “Hello Climate Change: Rethinking the Unthinkable.” The conference was organized “to encourage thinking about the role of liberal arts education in an era of climate change.”

headline: In Romney and Obama Speeches, Selective Truths
text: To listen to Mitt Romney tell it, President Obama is a job-killing, free-spending, big-government liberal who made the recession worse with his policies and endangered free-market capitalism. The president has spent tax dollars “at a pace without precedent in recent history,” Mr. Romney says, and “added almost as much debt as all the prior presidents combined.”

headline: Selective Storytelling From the Stump
text: An interactive comparison provides analysis and context to some of the candidates’ truths, half-truths and exaggerations.

headline: The Dickey Streak, Updated
text: Not to belabor the point, but R. A. Dickey’s scoreless innings streak would be in the low 40s and almost in hailing distance of Orel Hershiser’s major league record if he had not surrendered that ninth-inning run on a ground ball to short last Wednesday night.

headline: Underwood’s Olympic Dream Was Delayed but Is Still Cherished
text: The movie of boxer Quanitta Underwood’s life — and there are documentary filmmakers following her around to capture every detail — gained a poignant moment on Monday after Underwood found out she had been granted an Olympic berth. She wanted to surprise her sister Hazzauna with the news, so she drove to the hospital where Hazzauna works and the two broke out in spontaneous celebration.

headline: Restaurateurs and Others Form New Lobbying Group
text: A well-connected group of restaurateurs, bar and lounge owners, hotel executives and liquor distributors with deep pockets on Tuesday announced the creation of an upstart trade group, the New York City Hospitality Alliance, to lobby legislators and city regulatory agencies in the five boroughs.

headline: Wiggle Room Emerges in Greece’s Bailout Deal
text: BRUSSELS — As Greece’s political parties maneuvered to form a new government Tuesday, the country’s creditors were signaling a willingness to discuss revised terms for Greece’s bailout package to reflect its rapidly deteriorating economy.

headline: Video: Microsoft’s New Tablet
text: Microsoft’s new tablet hopes to challenge the iPad. Nick Wingfield and Catherine Rampell discuss.

headline: Teacher’s Aide Accused of Sexual Misconduct Is Cleared by Grand Jury
text: A teacher’s aide in New York City is caught between the justice system and the New York City Department of Education since a grand jury on Monday declined to indict him on child sexual abuse charges.

headline: Diane Paulus ‘Pippin’ May Get Broadway Backers
text: The next major theater project by Diane Paulus, the director of the Tony Award-winning musical “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” is already attracting Broadway attention. Barry and Fran Weissler, veteran Broadway producers, are considering signing on as backers of Ms. Paulus’s revival of the 1972 musical “Pippin” that is scheduled to run this winter at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., a spokesman for Mr. Weissler confirmed on Tuesday. While the spokesman, Clint Bond Jr., said any talk of a Broadway move for “Pippin” was premature, such a transfer would become a possibility if the Weisslers, who have produced musical revivals like the long-running “Chicago,” come on board and the show draws strong reviews in Cambridge, where it is scheduled to run Dec. 5-Jan. 20, 2013.

headline: The Blessing of the Bees
text: On Tuesday morning, witnesses to a ceremony at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine were encouraged to wear long sleeves, long pants and socks. The subjects of this holy event were about 15,000 honeybees that live on the church’s campus in Morningside Heights.

headline: Andy Statman, a Brooklyn Virtuoso, Receives Heritage Award
text: Andy Statman, the virtuoso clarinetist and mandolin player from Brooklyn, was awarded the National Endowment for the Arts Heritage Fellowship on Monday for his contributions to bluegrass and klezmer music, the organization announced on Tuesday.

headline: Fate of Charter School in Brooklyn Is Unclear
text: New York City officials announced in January that they were shutting Williamsburg Charter High School in Brooklyn because of concerns about its management, but court proceedings have stalled the efforts.

headline: That Bon Iver Singer-Songwriter Dude Releases . . . a Shoe?
text: I just found out that Justin Vernon has “released” a shoe. There’s something fussy about caring about shoes, let alone designing one for sale when your living is made making music, so I went back to look at last year’s profile of Vernon in the magazine to see if there were any hints that he might be the fussy shoemaking type. Some of Vernon’s attributes: Songwriter since age 12. Religion major in college. Women’s studies minor. Tattoo on his chest of Wisconsin, where he grew up. Didn’t go hunting till he was 23. Maker of an album that “sounds like crying, deep primal purging.” Where he recorded that album: in his father’s hunting cabin in the woods. And so on.

headline: Turning to Frogs for Illegal Aid in Horse Races
text: Racing regulators kept hearing the reports: trainers were giving their horses a powerful performance-enhancing potion drawn from the backs of a type of South American frog.

headline: Tanglewood Revisits Its Past, for All to Hear

headline: Should Bryce Harper Be in the All-Star Game, or Run for President?

headline: Indiana Governor Said to Be In Running for Purdue Post
text: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana is a candidate again. Not for president of the United States — he declined to run for that post last year. And not for governor — term limits prevent him from seeking re-election.

headline: Life After ‘Dead': Jon Bernthal Joins MCC Theater Play and Scorsese Movie
text: When a man has lost the woman he loved, seen the near-annihilation of the human race, been stabbed to death, resurrected as a lumbering corpse and shot and killed again, where does he go next? To the stage, of course.

headline: Kindly Pausing for Mortality
text: John Jesurun, Julie Atlas Muz, Taylor Mac, Penny Arcade: these are names that draw me into a theater with high hopes that something interesting will happen. They are also names attached to “The Etiquette of Death,” where hope, among other things, meets a long and painful end.

headline: Miró Painting Sets Record on Otherwise Lackluster Opening Night of London Auctions
text: The London auction season kicked off on Tuesday night at Sotheby’s, where a 1927 painting by Joan Miró, “Blue Star,” brought nearly $37 million, more than twice what it had sold for at a Paris auction in 2007 and a record price for the artist at auction.

headline: Feathering the Nest With a Mask and a Plan
text: “Inside Men” is a British heist drama that goes on for too long (four hours) and, perhaps as a result, keeps wandering away from the story of the prodigious armed robbery — a haul of more than $250 million — at its core. It’s held together by a couple of things: its icy tone, which it maintains even as it detours needlessly into the personal lives of the robbers, and a twitchy, absorbing performance by Steven Mackintosh as the ringleader, a milquetoast who blossoms in the role of criminal mastermind.

headline: Repelling Alien Conquerors Is Easy; It’s Ruling That’s Hard
text: A blazing meteorite has hit the Florida town that is the central battlefield in the war between humans and aliens. Her name is Hanna Cheek.

headline: Castle Ruins and Smoked Herring: Touring a Danish Island on Two Wheels
text: Oluf Host? The Oluf Host, the Danish contemporary painter famed for his scenes of Bornholm, on the very island I was visiting? It was indeed him – or more accurately, it was the stone that had marked his grave since 1966 – right in front of me in the churchyard in Gudhjem, the cozy coastal village where I had just stopped on my bike.

headline: Hispanic Voters Less Plentiful in Swing States
text: As I wrote on Tuesday morning, President Obama’s decision to suspend deportations of some young illegal immigrants should entail mostly upside for him from a political standpoint. Based on polls about his decision and the way that Republicans are reacting to it, the evidence that public opinion is on Mr. Obama’s side is reasonably clear.

headline: Plans for Massachusetts Debate Seem to Collapse
text: Plans for a debate in the Massachusetts Senate race — to be held in Boston at the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate, named for the Democrat who held the seat for nearly half a century — seemed to collapse Tuesday under the weight of partisanship.

headline: Fennel, Garlic and Potato Soup
text: This anise-scentedsoup is reminiscent of the classic potato and leek soup known as vichyssoise,but it’s lighter and contains no dairy. It’s good hot or cold.

headline: Puréed Zucchini Soup With Curry
text: Just the right amount of basmati rice contributes just the right amount of substance to this beautiful, light spring soup.

headline: Coin Collection Is Partly Saved by a Loan
text: When the financially struggling Hispanic Society of America decided to sell its collection of nearly 38,000 rare coins last year, that Upper Manhattan museum sought to allay fears that its cultural treasure would become inaccessible to scholars and the public by striving to find a public institution to buy it. None, however, was found to purchase the collection, valued at more than $25 million; the coins landed in private hands; and some of those scholars’ concerns are now being realized.

headline: NPR Intern Gets an Earful After Blogging About 11,000 Songs, Almost None Paid For
text: When it comes to digital music, can the audience be shamed into doing the right thing? That is, even if we all agreed that it was the “right thing” for musicians to be paid each time someone listened to their music, would it make any difference?

headline: Queens Teacher Cleared by Grand Jury of Abuse Allegations
text: A teacher’s aide in New York City is caught between the justice system and the New York City Department of Education since a grand jury on Monday declined to indict him on child sexual abuse charges.

headline: Finding Some Principles by Telling Some Lies
text: “Faith begins as an experiment and ends as an experience.” That quotation from the Anglican priest William Ralph Inge, which begins the documentary “Kumaré: The True Story of a False Prophet,” evokes the film’s ambiguous exploration of religion, teaching and spiritual leadership.

headline: Braving Broadway in Summer
text: The height of summer and the dead of winter are the worst times to open a Broadway show, since too many theatergoers are distracted by vacations and weather. But the lure of empty New York theaters has led the producers of two multimillion-dollar touring musicals to bring them to town for limited engagements, starting in July, in hopes of earning short-term profits and adding Broadway cachet before sending the shows back on the road.

headline: One Dish at The NoMad
text: Yes, just one. But it’s not just any dish — it’s Daniel Humm’s roast chicken for two at The NoMad, talked about more avidly and incessantly than any other new restaurant offering in town, going back perhaps as far as the introduction of the Bo Ssam around the beginning of 2007.

headline: Only the Budgets Are Small
text: Movies are simultaneously getting bigger and smaller, more aggressively global and more stubbornly local. The season of “bigger” is certainly upon us now, as “The Avengers” and “Prometheus” prepare to make way for “Brave” and Spidey and Batman. But luckily, BAMcinemaFest opens its annual showcase of smaller movies on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Working-Class Men, Longing for Change in a Restless Land
text: There’s palpable verisimilitude in Asli Ozge’s “Koprudekiler” (“Men on the Bridge”), a powerful portrait of working-class Istanbul that artfully suggests a wellspring of found moments. Quietly, steadily, it gathers a resonance belying its slice-of-life scale.

text: At an online auction on Tuesday, a lot of green, or unroasted, coffee beans from Finca El Injerto in Guatemala sold for $500.50 a pound, one of the highest prices ever paid for coffee.

text: On Tuesday, Aston Martin released images and details of the AM 310 Vanquish, a V-12-powered supercar to sit atop the company’s range when it goes on sale next year at a projected price of $280,000.

headline: After Sweeps, San Jose Stores Property of Homeless
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — For years, the authorities periodically swept the banks of San Jose’s waterways, dismantling and discarding the elaborate, makeshift homes built by hundreds of homeless people. Tons of debris cleared, the homeless returned within days or hours.

headline: Israel Weighs Response After Attacks by Hamas
text: GAZA — The armed wing of Hamas, the Islamic militant group that governs here, fired barrages of rockets into southern Israel on Tuesday after a break of more than a year during which the group largely adhered to an informal cease-fire.

headline: After 39 Years, Secretariat Is Awarded Preakness Record
text: Not that his résumé as one of the greatest racehorses of all time needed any more burnishing, but Secretariat had some gold dust added to his legend Tuesday when the Maryland Racing Commission decided he ran a lot faster than he was credited for in the 1973 Preakness Stakes.

text: Like many other places in Silicon Valley and in the Bay Area just north, San Jose, Calif., is struggling to cope with entrenched homeless encampments that proliferated during the financial crisis.

text: Social media are often seen as part of a long-term shift in how people interact, like the telephone. But Facebook’s troubled I.P.O. and other growing pains might make you wonder.

headline: Robert A.M. Stern
text: Mr. Stern, 73, a modern traditionalist architect, is the founder of Robert A. M. Stern Architects, the dean of the Yale School of Architecture and the author of several architecture books.

headline: Divide in Albany Kills Proposal on Marijuana
text: ALBANY — The Democrats who control the State Assembly, many of them black or Latino residents of New York City, saw a proposal to decriminalize the open possession of small amounts of marijuana as a simple matter of justice: too many black and Latino men were being arrested because, after being stopped by the police, they were forced to empty their pockets.

headline: New Inquiry of Deaths on Reservation in the 1970s

headline: Pineda, Injured Arm Out of a Sling, Visits the Yankees
text: Michael Pineda was smiling during Yankees batting practice Tuesday, his right arm by his side instead of in a sling. It was about the best news possible for a player who has produced bad news since joining the Yankees in the off-season.

headline: Split by Rivalry, United in Bid for a Ring

Though it did come up that Battier, the erstwhile Blue Devil who grew up in a Detroit suburb, once accepted a pair of autographed sneakers from Howard when the latter was playing for the Wolverines as a member of the Fab Five.

headline: Florida: State Is Sued Again Over Voter Purge
text: A second lawsuit was filed in federal court in Miami on Tuesday against the State of Florida over its search of voter rolls for noncitizens. Several civil and voters’ rights groups joined in the suit, which says the search violates the National Voting Rights Act and the National Voter Registration Act. The groups said the review discriminates against minorities and is prohibited within 90 days of an election. Florida has a primary in August. The state is also being sued by the Department of Justice. Earlier this year, the state sent names of 2,700 possible noncitizens to county election supervisors, who were advised to write those people, asking them to offer proof of citizenship or risk being dropped from the rolls. But the list, compiled by comparing voter rolls to a driver’s license databank and overwhelmingly singled out minorities, was found to be flawed. The state has asked the Department of Homeland Security to allow it to use an immigration database to verify the list, but the federal government has not done so. As a result, Florida is suing Homeland Security over access to the database. The civil rights groups say they hope their suit deters other states from conducting similar searches.

headline: Putin Rules Out Intervention to Stop the Syrian Rebellion
text: SAN JOSÉ DEL CABO, Mexico — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Tuesday that the fate of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria should be left to the hands of the Syrians, saying that no one country has the right to tell another people whom their leader should be.

headline: Don’t Shut the Golden Door
text: IMMIGRATION is in the headlines again, with President Obama’s decision last week to stop deporting young illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children, and the Supreme Court’s approaching decision on the constitutionality of Arizona’s crackdown on undocumented migrants.

headline: Wasting Warren Buffett
text: Watching this campaign unfold reaffirms how much it would have benefitted from a serious, centrist third-party challenger. It would have been so clarifying to have an independent voice calling out Mitt Romney for running a campaign that consists of decrying the last three and a half years of the Obama presidency, while offering to reinstate the very same failed policies that made the eight years of George W. Bush a disaster that President Obama has spent most of his time cleaning up. And it would have been equally clarifying to have an independent challenger calling out Obama for failing to put a credible, specific economic plan on the table — at the scale of our problem — but relying instead on a campaign that amounts to a series of discrete appeals to each of the Democratic Party constituencies. It feels like a ground war with no air cover.

headline: Before Standardized Tests, Teaching Children Not to Drown
text: At the first swim lessons, no one could pry Amahri’s arms from the neck of the instructor trying to coax her into the pool. It turns out that an 8-year-old girl, determined to keep her face dry, has the strength of a sumo wrestler. Perched near the instructor’s head, she could not complete the Blowing Bubbles in the Water portion of the curriculum, which followed Introductory Toe Wiggling.

headline: An Emphasis on Fun for Language Learners
text: ROSETTA STONE, the 20-year-old language instruction company, has taken a fairly straightforward approach to advertising with commercials that promote a software-based method as an effective alternative to classroom learning.

headline: When ‘Self-Defense’ Violates Civil Rights
text: The United States Commission on Civil Rights is right to order an investigation into whether racial bias might be a factor in the rise in homicides connected to notorious Stand Your Ground laws. The shooting death of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, in Florida has put into question how police enforce this kind of statute.

headline: Deadly Particles
text: In a welcome move that will make the air that Americans breathe cleaner, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed on Friday to tighten standards governing fine particles, commonly known as soot. Released by sources like diesel trucks and power plants, these microscopic specks can lodge in the lungs and bloodstream and cause respiratory and heart ailments.

headline: Debit Cards on Campus
text: Given the history of shady dealings between banks and colleges, Congress needs to take a hard look at the increasingly common practice of schools contracting with banks to disburse financial aid dollars to students.

headline: Forced Move Raises Anger in West Bank Villages

headline: Jail Term Ends After 20 Days for Ex-Rutgers Student
text: Dharun Ravi, the former Rutgers University student convicted of using a webcam to spy on his roommate having sex with another man, left jail on Tuesday, 20 days after beginning a 30-day jail sentence, having earned early release for his work and good behavior behind bars.

headline: Inmate Charged With Murder in 2006 Brooklyn Fire
text: More than six years after a fire in a Brooklyn apartment building killed four people, including two children and their mother, a man with a long history of drug and burglary convictions was accused of igniting the blaze and was charged with murder on Tuesday.

headline: Progress Is Our Most Important Product
text: Certainly there is plenty wrong with our food “system,” and it’s easy to point that out week after week. Every day there’s more bad news, and when credible people say that 900 million Indians are hungry — really hungry, not “dying” for a Snickers — the tendency is to get so depressed that one overlooks progress. (Perhaps, too, New Yorkers are born to kvetch.)

headline: Environmental Groups Say They Will Fight Cuomo’s Gas Drilling Plan

headline: The Trouble With Ms. Merkel
text: After their two-day meeting ended on Tuesday, leaders of the Group of 20 top economies managed to say some of the right things. Focusing on the euro-zone debt crisis — clearly, the largest threat to the global economy — they pledged to do more to spur growth, ensure financial stability and support a stronger European fiscal union.

headline: Senators Start a Review of Solitary Confinement
text: WASHINGTON — Solitary confinement “is inhumane and by its design it is driving men insane,” a former inmate who spent 18 years in prison in Texas, a decade of that time in isolation on death row before being exonerated, told a Senate panel in a hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Huge Crowds in Tahrir Square Protest Military Rule

headline: ‘Summer Sketches’
text: I made “Summer Sketches” so I could keep some summer in my pocket. Come the dead of winter, when I play the film back on my phone, it will warm by sparking memories of bare feet in sand, warm breezes off bays, the smell of sun-tan lotion and chlorine, the kids turning amphibian for a day, and secret tan lines. The film is about water, too — being in it, on it, under it and next to it. Water is the most animated substance on the planet, and when I’m not drawing it or painting with it (watercolor) I often find myself photographing it.

headline: Public Workers Face New Rash of Layoffs, Hurting Recovery
text: Companies have been slowly adding workers for more than two years. But pink slips are still going out in a crucial area: government.

headline: World Leaders Make Little Headway in Solving Debt Crisis

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: The goal was in, and Ukraine is out. But as usual, it’s not that simple.

headline: Corrections: June 20

headline: Romney the Cautious
text: Mitt Romney’s vigorous denial notwithstanding, yesterday’s report that his campaign isn’t even planning to vet Florida Senator Marco Rubio as a potential vice presidential pick was entirely consistent with the kind of campaign that Team Romney appears intent on running. Rubio has long been cited as one of the most exciting running mates available – someone who would add youth, charisma and diversity to a ticket lacking all three. But with youth comes inexperience and with excitement comes risk, and lately the Romney campaign seems to have decided that they can win this election without taking any substantial risks at all.

headline: News Corp. Makes $2 Billion Deal to Acquire Australian Pay TV Company
text: In a move that would give News Corporation a larger foothold in the lucrative pay TV business in Australia, Rupert Murdoch’s media conglomerate said it has agreed to pay roughly $2.2 billion to acquire Consolidated Media Holdings.

headline: In Art, Freedom of Expression Doesn’t Extend to ‘Is It Real?’
text: John Elderfield, former chief curator of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, remembers the days when scholars spoke freely about whether a particular work was genuine.

headline: Santana Returns to Form of an Ace
text: The questions about whether Johan Santana could return to form after his June 1 no-hitter were lingering, generating anxiety for his manager perhaps more than anyone.

headline: Suddenly, Michigan Looks Like More Fertile Ground to Romney Campaign
text: DeWITT, Mich. — Mitt Romney spent Tuesday baking pies here in this city just north of Lansing, but his campaign also sent a message to President Obama: Mr. Romney says he believes that Michigan is up for grabs in November, and if nothing else, his campaign plans to force Mr. Obama and the Democrats to spend time and money defending turf that, until recently, seemed safely in the blue.

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Turns to Ecuador for Asylum

headline: Administration Took Accidental Path to Setting Record for Leak Cases

headline: The Olympians’ Housemother

The best biomechanists in the world watch runners jog on gravity-defying $25,000 treadmills, and chefs prepare fresh, wholesome meals every day for some 170 resident athletes and coaches who train here.

headline: Japanese Officials Failed to Use U.S. Data Tracking Radiation After Tsunami
text: TOKYO — The United States shared detailed radiation measurements with Japan in the early days of the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster that the Japanese government did not make public or use in conducting evacuations, officials acknowledged on Tuesday.

headline: Braves Rally Last, Ending Yankees Winning Streak at 10
text: Confidence swirled in the home dugout at Yankee Stadium in the late innings Tuesday, and with good reason. The Yankees had won 10 consecutive games, and the small breaks that often balance during 162 games seemed to tilt consistently in the Yankees’ favor. Derek Jeter had referred to a wave the team was riding, with the unstated implication that all waves will eventually crash.

headline: Mitt Romney’s Bus Tour

headline: Olympic Trials in Black and White

headline: Olympic Trials in Black and White
text: In 1972, I was in Eugene, Ore., photographing my first United States Olympic track and field trials. I was 23.

headline: News Corp. Offers $2 Billion in Australian TV Takeover
text: HONG KONG–Rupert Murdoch’s Australian unit, News Limited, said on Wednesday it had offered $2 billion cash in a takeover bid for the Sydney-listed Consolidated Media Holdings, controlled by the Australian casino and media magnate James Packer.

headline: Venice Beach or Silicon Beach?
text: According to real estate agents, Google is negotiating a lease on the 31,000-square-foot expanse that is Gold’s Gym, the bodybuilding symbol of the Venice section of Los Angeles.

headline: Venice Beach Bodybuilders Fear Google Is Kicking Sand at Them
text: LOS ANGELES — This city’s boardwalk community of Venice has long celebrated its seediness, accepting — embracing, really — the kind of sensory assaults that would faze more conventional places: beachfront bodybuilders, ragamuffin street vendors, tattoo artists, Hare Krishna chanters, skateboarders, drug dealers, gangs, homeless encampments, rowdy tourists, film crews and, more recently, a colony of medical marijuana dispensaries.

headline: Dan Dorfman, 82, Dies; His Tips Moved Markets
text: Dan Dorfman, a highly visible financial journalist whose televised market reports could send a stock soaring — or plummeting — but whose career was tarnished by accusations of insider trading, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Victor Spinetti, Favorite in Beatles Films, Dies at 82
text: Victor Spinetti, who was an established British film star in 1963 when he agreed to make a movie with a pop group called the Beatles and who became famous ever after as the only person besides the four Beatles to appear in “A Hard Day’s Night,” “Help!” and “Magical Mystery Tour,” died on Tuesday in London. He was 82.

headline: Two One-Hitters With a Twist of Relief
text: On Sept. 7, 1955, Whitey Ford went to the mound at Yankee Stadium and pitched a one-hitter against the Kansas City Athletics, matching what he had done five days earlier against the Washington Senators.

headline: Charter Schools Still Enroll Fewer Disabled Students
text: Charter schools in most states continue to enroll proportionately fewer students with disabilities than traditional public schools, a new government report shows.

headline: ‘Kidnapped’ TV Crew Apparently Wasn’t
text: BANGKOK — It was eight days ago that a prominent TV reporter and his film crew disappeared into a jungle on the island of Jolo in the southern Philippines. They didn’t call their bosses or their families, and they missed their return flight to Manila. For a week, not a word.

headline: Norman Lent, Moderate Congressman Who Served 11 Terms, Dies at 81
text: Norman F. Lent, who in his 11 terms in Congress representing a large swath of Long Island’s South Shore was a significant voice in shaping environmental legislation, despite always being in the minority, died on June 11 at his home in Arlington, Va. Mr. Lent, a Republican, was 81.

headline: Can Athletes Perform Well on a Vegan Diet?

But is going totally meatless and, as in Mr. Jurek’s case, dairy-free advisable for other serious athletes, or for the rest of us who just want to be healthy and fit?

headline: Colloquial Music Reflects Changes in Rural Indian Romance
text: As the nation’s 919 million mobile connections grow by nearly 1 percent a month, scores of songs in the Bhojpuri language, commonly used in north India, have come to celebrate the mobile phone both as a fashion statement and a handy tool for romance. Their lyrics – and the cheaply shot videos that illustrate them, like the one above – demonstrate how the tiny digital device is cutting through the thicket of rural conventions that can make liaisons difficult and often dangerous in their rigidly conservative societies. (The lyrics of this song roughly translate to: “The fancy madam has got a mobile and started going on dates.”)

headline: Goa Points the Way for Women
text: “After you have spent some time in relatively conservative northern India, the state of Goa can give the impression of a feminist paradise — especially this year, when women have been unusually successful in running for key posts in the powerful local village councils, ” Nilanjana S. Roy wrote for The International Herald Tribune.

headline: Wedding Cakes in NYC With an Indian Touch
text: One of the highlights of planning my wedding a decade ago was choosing the cake. I had attended countless weddings where I felt that this standard dessert was an afterthought in both design and taste: the inside was usually a dry yellow while the exterior was a coat of sickly sweet buttercream with an uninspired design. I was determined to have a decadent sweet ending that would be memorable in taste and presentation and would indulge my love for chocolate.

headline: Ivan Lendl Gets Back to Tennis
text: On New Year’s Eve, Andy Murray, a 25-year-old Scot and professional tennis player who has lost in the finals of three major championships and is currently on pace to end his fifth year in a row ranked No. 4 in the world, announced that he had hired Ivan Lendl as his new coach. His decision to offer employment to the mostly unloved, all-time-great Lendl made Murray’s desperate unhappiness with his also-ran status achingly public and set the tennis world abuzz, particularly in Britain, where Wimbledon starts next week and there hasn’t been a native-born male champion since 1936.

headline: Apps That Eke Better Sound From Old Earphones
text: People are forever buying new headphones in an attempt to eke a little more enjoyment out of music on pads, pods and phones. It can be an expensive habit.

headline: Pakistan Arrests Frenchman Suspected of Qaeda Links
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani intelligence officials have detained a Frenchman of Algerian origin who is suspected of having links to a cell of Al Qaeda that carried out the attacks of Sept. 11, a senior Pakistani official said Wednesday.

headline: On Our Radar: Back in Rio, 20 Years Later
text: More than 50,000 people and representatives of more than 120 countries gather in Rio de Janeiro for the opening of the Rio+20 conference on sustainable development. Topics include the destruction of the rain forest, vanishing coral reefs, land grabs, the need for food security, clean water, the role of women in food production, safe drinking water, energy access, clogged transit systems, jobs and sustainable development as a way of fighting poverty. The conference marks the 20th anniversary of the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio. [The Miami Herald]

headline: Egypt Intrigue Rises as Lawyer Says Mubarak Merely Fell
text: CAIRO — A new sense of political intrigue compounded the confusion over the health of Hosni Mubarak on Wednesday when one of his lawyers contradicted what he called false reports in Egypt’s state-run media that the imprisoned former president had nearly died, insisting that Mr. Mubarak simply fell down in the prison bathroom.

headline: Dispatches From Rio (and Beyond): Young People Reflect on What’s Missing
text: Here’s two fresh dispatches from young people reflecting on Rio+20, the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, which is approaching its conclusion in Rio de Janeiro in the next few days. You can best track developments via the #rioplus20 tag on Twitter. Here’s the final draft of “The Future We Want,” the conference declaration heading to heads of state for signature and upsetting environmental campaigners. The fight over the formal proceedings, which were bound to be underwhelming, distracts from some significant developments that I’ll be covering in subsequent posts.

headline: Asylum for Assange: What’s in It for Ecuador?
text: LONDON — A decision by Ecuador to grant political asylum to Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder facing extradition to Sweden, was almost a done deal, one Quito newspaper said on Wednesday. “It is a matter of hours,” El Comercio said.

headline: Morning TV’s Stepsister Feels the Ratings Heat
text: IT’S a windy May morning on the Rockefeller Center plaza where the stars of NBC’s “Today” periodically gather to perform in the open air, and for some reason Kathie Lee Gifford and Hoda Kotb are wearing hospital gowns, like a latter-day Lucy and Ethel embarked on some crazy scheme. Ms. Gifford’s explanation — it has something to do with a segment on plastic surgery — requires dramatic gestures, and with one of them she knocks a batch of notecards out of the hands of the show’s co-host Ann Curry.

headline: Supreme Court Could Pose New Challenge for Romney on Immigration
text: As Mitt Romney sought support among conservatives in his party’s primary races this year, he pledged to back an immigration law in Arizona that has drawn a fierce legal challenge from President Obama and the federal government.

text: This month, as Bernard L. Madoff completes the third year of a 150-year sentence for masterminding his global Ponzi scheme, the top courts in the United States and Britain are tackling issues that could have a multibillion-dollar impact on thousands of his victims.

text: JERUSALEM — The military wing of Hamas, the Islamic group that governs Gaza, announced late Wednesday that it was committed to an Egyptian-brokered cease-fire to end three days of fighting with Israel.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Prize for the Eyes
text: The Samurai Shopper is particularly delighted this week with eye primers. What a difference they make in the general scheme of looking good. Eye primers are not pudding-y and slick like eye creams, nor are they powdery, dry, greasy or thick like concealers: they’re the intermediate step between those two. Some are tinted to match your skin color, some have a nacreous luster, one or two terrible ones are pasty and glittery. The better primers disappear but leave a film that acts like a two-sided piece of tape: the primer adheres to eyelids while keeping eye makeup on top from huddling in a corner or forming a wobbly line on your eyelid crease. A good eye primer can replace concealers entirely over the lid, evening out skin tone. The very, very good ones can even be swept under the eye, where the bags might be.

headline: Trouble in Sinai
text: JERUSALEM — It was in ancient Kadesh Barnea that after the Jews’ exodus from Egypt spies sent out by Moses reported back that the land of Canaan would not easily be conquered. And it was from near modern-day Kadesh Barnea, a small village by Israel’s southern border with Egypt, that on Monday another event proved the enduring difficulty of ruling this land.

headline: Wall Street Dips Slightly on Fed Decision
text: Wall Street gave a tepid response on Wednesday to the Federal Reserve’s decision to extend a program intended to drive down long-term interest rates, as analysts questioned just how far the measure would go in bolstering economic growth.

headline: Confusion Over Diplomatic Immunity Delays Arrest in Rape Case
text: The boundaries of diplomatic immunity were brought into sharp relief this past week with news that a French diplomat had been accused by his wife of raping their 3-year-old daughter. Despite the wife’s testimony and some corroborating medical evidence, Bangalore police took five days to arrest the diplomat because of worries over his diplomatic status.

headline: Q.&A.: The Underside of ‘Green’ Transactions
text: At Rio+20, the global conference on sustainable development that got under way Wednesday morning in Brazil, discussions abound on advancing environmental goals in a way that will benefit local and national economies. But development experts say there is a dark side to some ostensibly “green” market initiatives: the appropriation of resources for biofuels production, carbon offsets, ecotourism and so on can have devastating consequences for local people.

headline: China, Citing Errors, Vows to Overhaul Rare Earth Industry
text: HONG KONG — China’s cabinet issued on Wednesday its first white paper on rare earth industry policies, acknowledging that poorly regulated mining of rare earth metals had caused widespread environmental damage and promising an extensive cleanup and a crackdown on illegal mines.

headline: Matt Groening Ends His ‘Life in Hell’ (The Comic Strip, That Is)
text: While his animated comedy “The Simpsons” has been on the air a mere 22 seasons and counting, series creator Matt Groening has spent those years – and then some – drawing his syndicated comic strip “Life in Hell.” But soon that streak and the comic itself, which ran more than 30 years and played a crucial role in the creation of “The Simpsons,” will be no more: Mr. Groening has said he is ending the strip.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Gray Report: Noilly Prat is bringing back the dry vermouth it used to market just in the United States but discontinued in 2009. The lighter, simpler vermouth, which was sold from 1979 to 2009, was replaced by the straw-colored, spicier Noilly Prat vermouth that is the norm in the rest of the world. But American sales dipped, so the company reversed itself, and will sell the product under a different name: Noilly Prat Extra Dry. — Robert Simonson

headline: Reports of Mubarak’s Death Clinically Exaggerated, Egyptian Bloggers Say
text: Last Updated, 12:13 p.m. CAIRO — The exact condition of former President Hosni Mubarak’s health remains a mystery, as government officials variously described him to the media as comatose, on life support, and much improved, just hours after Egypt’s state news agency pronounced him “clinically dead,” in a report on his late-night transfer from prison to a hospital in an upscale district of the capital.

headline: Amid Debt Crisis, Overseas Buyers Seek European Companies
text: LONDON – Europe’s capital markets are in the doldrums. Uncertainty caused by the Continent’s financial crisis has led to a big fall in initial public offerings, while investors remain wary of buying sovereign and company debt.

headline: Up Close, but Doing No Harm
text: WHITE-WATER rafting in Costa Rica. Riding an elephant in Thailand. Communing with indigenous people in Ecuador. Tour operators are marketing activities like these to travelers in search of “authentic” experiences, often using buzzwords like “eco-friendly” or “sustainable.” But how do you know which tour operators are truly responsible or simply exploitive?

headline: Chinese Artist Is Barred From His Own Hearing
text: BEIJING — If the Chinese authorities thought that barring the artist Ai Weiwei from the courtroom where his lawsuit against tax officials is being heard might tamp down public interest in the matter, they must be sorely disappointed.

headline: Waiting for the King: Dave Eggers Talks About His New Novel
text: In Dave Eggers’s new novel, “A Hologram for the King” (McSweeney’s Books), a 54-year-old American businessman named Alan Clay travels to Saudi Arabia in hopes of selling holographic technology to the country. This depends on making a presentation to the king, who may or may not show up. In her review, Michiko Kakutani wrote: “Thanks to Mr. Eggers’s uncommon ability to access his characters’ emotions and channel their every mood, we are instantly immersed in Alan’s story, rooting for him somehow to win an audience with the king and turn his life around.” In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Eggers discussed his inspiration for the novel, his editing process, the people he met in Saudi Arabia and more. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Galileo Galilei, Observed
text: Following up on her illustrated biographies for older readers (“Woody Guthrie,” “The Daring Nellie Bly,” “Django”), Bonnie Christensen dials back several centuries in “I, Galileo,” demonstrating once again how a well-conceived and executed picture book can deliver a serious story — in this case, of one of history’s great independent thinkers — in a beautiful, enriching way for those readers who’ve supposedly “moved on” to chapter books.

text: 4:26 p.m. | Updated  This seems like a good day for a reminder that asset purchases work. The Federal Reserve really can lower interest rates by purchasing large quantities of Treasury securities, mortgage-backed securities, or other kinds of securities.
