text: Have you followed the recent tussle between J. C. Penney and anti-gay groups? It’s pretty interesting. And it’s pretty suggestive of changed attitudes in this country toward gay men and lesbians.

headline: An African Answer to African Problems
text: JOHANNESBURG — If only I could be a Malawian citizen for a day. Then I could brag that my country’s new leader, President Joyce Banda, is doing the right thing by warning Sudanese leader Omar al-Bashir that he’ll be arrested if he sets foot in Malawi. In honoring the arrest warrant that the International Criminal Court has issued against Bashir for crimes against humanity — and showing basic respect for human rights and international law — she stands virtually alone among African leaders.

headline: For Probationers, Moving Offices Closer to Improve Results
text: One recent hot Friday evening, 15 young men and women on probation filed into an unfurnished room in a former school in central Harlem, awaiting some kind of news. Probation officers set up fans and passed out drinks and chips.

headline: Making Sense of New E.E.O.C. Rules on Hiring
text: Second chances come up often when you talk to business owners on the record about hiring people who have served time — the subject, indirectly, of a just-published Times story about the new rules from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that may limit using criminal records in hiring decisions. Joseph Dutra, who employs 23 people at Kimmie Candy Company in Reno, Nev., is willing to give somebody with a criminal history a second chance, provided the crime didn’t include violence or a sexual advance on a child. “We don’t have a blanket policy here, but we need to have people with good morals, who are compatible with the public that we bring in,” said Mr. Dutra, who added that groups of schoolchildren often tour the factory. “We’re trying to make this a fun little place where people can come and feel safe.”

headline: When a Daughter Marries (Very) Young
text: Admitted: This is among my personal fears as a parent. On Tablet, Evelyn Krieger, who describes herself as a “Modern Orthodox Jew,” writes about her daughter’s decision to marry very young, at 20, as part of her choice to follow a more rigorous religious path.

headline: In Britain, a Plan to Give Shareholders More Say on Pay

headline: Jackson Brothers Start a Tour
text: The four remaining members of the Jackson Five are starting a tour on Wednesday, just days before the third anniversary of their brother Michael’s death, The Associated Press reported.  The “Unity” tour will begin at Casino Rama in Ontario and will finish up on July 29 at a casino in Snoqualmie, Wash., hitting 14 other cities along the way. They will play the Apollo Theater in Harlem on June 28.

Holder Jr. for contempt and President Obama asserted executive privilege to shield Justice Department documents from disclosure.

But he’ll have to fit them all into one, for now: a book that Mr. Nash will write about his life and rock-music career has been acquired by Crown Archetype, an imprint of Random House’s Crown Publishing Group, the publisher is expected to announce on Wednesday.

With his current partners, Luke Ostrom and Josh Pickard, who run the Italian restaurant Locanda Verde, in TriBeCa, and the American restaurant The Dutch, in SoHo, he plans to open a French restaurant in NoHo by the end of the year.

headline: Imprisoned Serial Killer Flown to New York to Face Murder Charges

headline: The Opening of the American Frontier
text: Wartime emancipation was a tangled story of incremental steps by Congress, the president, and the Union Army and acts of supreme bravery of the part of slaves. In August 1861, just three months after the onset of hostilities, Congress granted federal authorities the right to confiscate slaves used to aid the rebellion, yet the act did not guarantee these slaves permanent freedom, and in fact the Fugitive Slave Law was still in place. The following March, Congress barred the military from returning fugitive slaves to their masters, and began to pressure Lincoln to take more drastic action.

headline: Anti-Abortion Grandstanding
text: Republican lawmakers are tireless in their protection of gun ownership. Their argument is that states and localities have no right to play around with Americans’ constitutional rights and, anyway, the Supreme Court has spoken on this.

headline: Dispatches from Rio: Keeping Crowding Cities Moving
text: While the world’s wealthy countries appear to be inching toward “peak travel,” a decoupling of wealth and miles traveled, that is far from what’s going on in the world’s fast-growing cities in developing countries.

headline: With Output Stumbling, Fed Takes a Modest Step
text: WASHINGTON — In a pattern that has become familiar, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that the economy was growing more slowly than it had forecast, in part because its efforts to hasten recovery had proved insufficient.

headline: Business Day Live | Health Care Mandate
text: June 20, 2012 - What a verdict on the Affordable Care Act will mean for health insurance.

headline: Business Day Live | Layoffs
text: June 20, 2012 — In the public sector, the pink slips keep coming.

headline: Andrew Sarris, Village Voice Film Critic, Dies at 83
text: Andrew Sarris, one of the nation’s most influential film critics and a champion of auteur theory, which holds that a director’s voice is central to great filmmaking, died on Wednesday at St. Luke’s Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Video: Romney’s Horse Gets the Colbert Bump
text: Rafalca, a horse co-owned by Ann Romney, earned a berth on the United States Olympic dressage team on Saturday and Stephen Colbert wants some credit for that.

headline: Bedeviled by Telematics Woes, Ford Falls Further in J.D. Power Quality Study
text: The J.D. Power & Associates Initial Quality Study released on Wednesday shows that automakers continue to make gains in vehicle quality, but the black art of telematics design poses a growing liability, especially for Ford.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Lands a New Leading Couple
text: Two theater actors who know their way around moody, macabre musicals have been cast as the main characters in another one: the Broadway musical “Rebecca,” which lost its original leading lady and man this winter when producers were unable to raise the show’s $12 million budget to open as initially planned in April.

headline: Scouting Report
text: POP-UPS

headline: Countdown to a Coronation
text: For a while — for almost the entire game Tuesday night, in fact — it looked as if Heat-Thunder was going to be a real series. But then LeBron James channeled Willis Reed, or a flu-stricken Michael Jordan, and now Miami is up, three games to one, and pretty much everyone is conceding the N.B.A. title to the talents in South Beach.

headline: Beurre & Sel Cookies Coming to Two Markets
text: Dorie Greenspan (right) who has written a shelf load of baking books, and has been running occasional pop-up cookie bakeries with her son, Joshua Greenspan, plan to open cookie shops called Beurre & Sel (butter and salt) in the Essex Street Market and in La Marqueta by late summer. The two will also have bakery space at La Marqueta, in East Harlem.

headline: Deutsche Bank Ends Deal Talks With Guggenheim Partners
text: LONDON — Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday that it had failed to reach an agreement to sell part of its asset management business to Guggenheim Partners.

headline: Jurors Report Split Over Church Abuse Charges
text: PHILADELPHIA — In its 12th day of deliberations, the jury in the landmark trial of a Roman Catholic Church official accused of covering up sexual abuses by other priests said Wednesday that it was deadlocked on four of the five charges in the trial.

headline: Transgender Athlete Looks to Qualify in Hammer
text: Keelin Godsey is one of 24 athletes scheduled to participate Thursday in the women’s hammer throw at the United States Olympic trials, but for Godsey, 28, of North Adams, Mass., there is much more than a spot in London at stake.

headline: Coast Guard Investigating if Hoaxes in New Jersey and Texas Are Linked
text: The vessel-in-distress calls, placed to the Coast Guard three weeks and half a continent apart, were strangely similar.

headline: Speaking of the Economy, Let’s Talk About Immigration
text: What’s on the mind of a campaign’s message machine may not be the burning issue in journalists’ minds. When Mitt Romney’s campaign held a conference call with reporters on Wednesday morning to discuss what it called President Obama’s “record of failure on the economy,” the first three questions from reporters were about Mr. Romney’s views on immigration. Campaign press aides abruptly ended the conversation.

headline: Iran Officials Assert Defiance of West in Aftermath of Nuclear Talks
text: TEHRAN — Iranian politicians and military commanders said Wednesday that their country would never relinquish what they called its nuclear rights, a day after talks between Iran and world powers in Moscow failed to make substantive progress in the dispute over Iran’s uranium enrichment.

headline: The Pawlenty Possibility
text: Hard on the heels of the (swiftly denied, but totally plausible) report that Team Romney isn’t even vetting Marco Rubio as a potential running mate comes a Wall Street Journal report that Tim Pawlenty’s star is rising in Romneyland:

headline: Burger King Rejoins the Public Markets
text: Burger King completed its latest flip on Wednesday, rejoining the public markets after closing a deal to merge with an investment vehicle whose backers include the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman.

headline: Speaking of City School Graduations . . .
text: A handful of New York City public schools have netted some famous keynote speakers for their graduation ceremonies, including Steve Madden, the shoe designer, and Lin-Manuel Miranda, who wrote the Tony Award-winning musical “In the Heights,” the Department of Education announced Wednesday. Here's the list.

headline: The Last Day of Spring
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week’s image.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Selective Truths
text: Fact-checking the candidates' speeches.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Gun Control and Genocide
text: Via The New York Observer

headline: Ancient Dairy Farmers Of the Green Sahara
text: Prehistoric people in Saharan Africa had dairy farming operations 7,000 years ago, a new study reports — an insight revealed by their pottery. Researchers performed isotope analysis on samples drawn from excavated pottery, and were able to identify organic residues that originated from dairy fat.

headline: New Ads Trade Shots on the Economy
text: President Obama and several conservative groups are going head-to-head in a flurry of new attack ads, trading accusations over mishandled economic policies and inattention to the plight of struggling Americans.

headline: The Lowdown | Kembra Pfahler
text: The artist Kembra Pfahler is best known for getting completely naked and then covering her svelte body in red paint, donning a three-tiered black wig, and speak-singing (sometimes roaring) along to the music of her band the Voluptuous Horror of Karen Black. It should be mentioned that despite what her penchant for public full-frontal might lead you to think, Pfahler is 50. She has been a star on the scene since the 1980s, mishmashing her own brand of punk, haute glam and horror. It is always a great thrill to find her and her band of body-painted troublemakers shaking up the status quo at self-important art events, as she straps bowling balls to her feet or stands on her head while a cohort cracks paint-filled eggs between her legs.

headline: Photo Replay: June 20
text: The European soccer championships had a rare off day in Poland and Ukraine, and tennis players tuned up for Wimbledon in Eastbourne, England.

headline: Turning Androgyny Into Art
text: “I WAS having lunch with Rufus Wainwright,” said Justin Vivian Bond, arriving home a few minutes behind schedule. “I’m going to be officiating at his wedding. I was just confirmed. I’m now officially a reverend!”

headline: Sanity Hearing Is Postponed for Man Who Said He Killed Etan Patz
text: A hearing to determine whether the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz is mentally fit to stand trial will be pushed back until Oct. 1, people briefed on the case said on Wednesday.

headline: London Theater Journal: Body Counts
text: When the cannibal pie-maker Mrs. Lovett sings “times is hard” in the popular new revival of “Sweeney Todd” at the Adelphi Theater, the words reverberate more than usual. Played by a smashing Imelda Staunton as the ultimate avatar of British can-do resourcefulness, Mrs. Lovett inhabits a visual landscape guaranteed sure to set off alarm bells in London audiences. That’s in addition to the usual tensions that come from knowing that many throats will be cut before the evening’s end.

headline: Chase to Drop Overdraft Fees for Purchases of $5 or Less
text: As of July 22, JPMorgan Chase will no longer charge its checking account customers overdraft fees for any purchase of $5 or less.

headline: A Big Push to Get Going
text: SHANNON WHITEHEAD and Kristin Glenn became fast friends working in bars in Manly Beach, Australia, a post-college ramble, before eventually returning home to the United States to buckle down in the reality of the bad economy. “What are we going to do?” recalled Ms. Glenn, 26, with a playful bored-child’s plaintive emphasis on do.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Facebook’s Payment Plan
text: TimesCast Tech: Facebook accepts payments in global currencies. | A start-up connects local investors with struggling small businesses. | Sam Grobart tests kitchen tech.

headline: Scene City: Shakespeare in the Park Turns 50
text: Dinner and theater with Meryl Streep as Juliet and Kevin Kline as Romeo.

headline: Is This the Seminoles’ Year in the Series?
text: Florida State’s baseball team is looking sharp so far in the College World Series in Omaha, defeating U.C.L.A. on Tuesday evening, 4-1, to take the elimination game. The Seminoles (50-16) have never won the championship in 21 trips to the College World Series. But they are now one step away from the final, needing two wins over their next opponent, Arizona, in their series that starts Thursday at TD Ameritrade Park.

headline: A Bronx Guy Talks Trippingly
text: SHAKESPEARE called aging “sapless,” “clawing” and a “sullen sorrow.”

headline: Microsoft Shows Off Payment Technology in New Phone Software
text: Microsoft’s mobile operating system, Windows Phone, hasn’t made much of an impact on the phone market. But the company is far from giving up. It is investing even more in the software with a major upgrade set for release this fall. What’s it got that the iPhone doesn’t? A complete mobile payment system.

headline: A Senator’s Sometimes Lonely Fight Against Waste
text: There are things in the United States Senate that are regular and expected: steamed fish served on Tuesdays for partisan lunches; fulminating conference calls hosted by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York; and amendments to bills that point out embarrassing government expenditures, offered by Senator Tom Coburn, often bound for failure.

headline: N.H.L. Announces Award Winners
text: The N.H.L. held its annual award ceremony in Las Vegas on Wednesday night. Among the winners was Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist, who received his first Vezina Trophy. Click here for the article on the award winners.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Facebook Currency
text: This week on The Times’s weekly tech show: Facebook drops its Credits program in favor of payments in global currencies; a start-up connects local investors with struggling small businesses; and Sam Grobart tests kitchen tech.

headline: For Spain, Accusations of Lagging on Reforms
text: MADRID — Spain plans to release on Thursday two independent reports on the condition of the country’s banks, which the government has said it is awaiting to help determine how much of its bailout offer of 100 billion euros it actually needs.

headline: WPP Acquires AKQA to Beef Up Digital Marketing
text: PARIS — WPP Group, the world’s largest advertising company, escalated the industry’s digital arms race on Wednesday, saying it had reached an agreement to buy AKQA, one of the biggest independent agencies specializing in new forms of marketing.

headline: Putting Westbrook’s Mistake in Context
text: With just 13.8 seconds remaining in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals, Russell Westbrook’s mind seemed to leave him when he intentionally fouled Mario Chalmers at a time when it was embarrassingly imprudent to do so. It was a mistake that, in an obtuse way, cost the Thunder the chance to win the game.

headline: Ryanair Approaches Aer Lingus for a Third Time
text: Will Michael O’Leary get lucky on his third try?

headline: Egypt Delays Declaring Winner of Presidential Election
text: CAIRO — Egyptian election officials said Wednesday that they were postponing the announcement of a winner in last week’s presidential runoff, saying they needed more time to evaluate charges of electoral abuse that could affect who becomes the country’s next leader.

headline: Lehrer Apologizes for Recycling Work, While New Yorker Says It Won’t Happen Again
text: The science writer Jonah Lehrer, author of the runaway bestseller “Imagine: How Creativity Works,” has become the latest high-profile journalist to be caught up in a plagiarism scandal, with a counterintuitive twist that could come right out of his own books: The journalist he has been accused of borrowing from is himself.

headline: As War of Words Continues, Change Not Likely in Teacher Discipline
text: In all the sound and fury over Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott's demand for more power to fire teachers for sexual misconduct, there is little likelihood that Albany will be addressing the matter any time soon -- or that the matter will be resolved without legislative intervention, given the heated tension between the city and the union, according to people familiar with the issue.

headline: Caught Amid Life’s Own Sly Tricks
text: In 2005 Alex Stone joined the Society of American Magicians. He swore an oath, learned a secret handshake and seldom left home without a deck of cards and three Kennedy half dollars. He tried hard to make the group’s bimonthly meetings a big part of his social life. “ I thought magic would actually make me less nerdy,” he recalls.

headline: The New Princes of the City (There’s Even a Harry)
text: ON a Thursday evening last month, Harry Brant and Peter Brant II sat on the stoop outside the Jitrois boutique in SoHo. In a cross-platform coup, they were hosting an Interview magazine fete for the clothing label, a new advertiser.

headline: Three Small Steps for Kitchen Technology
text: Three gadgets represent small steps by technology into the kitchen: a rice cooker, a kitchen thermometer and an espresso coffee maker.

headline: Digital Wizardry Meant to Impress the Cook
text: We expect technology in certain places. We even welcome it. Technology in the workplace? A given. At home in the living room? Awesome — more movies to watch, more music to listen to, more games to play. When we’re traveling? Also a boon. We gain a wealth of information, and therefore power, as we compare fares, rebook canceled flights and find taxis in strange cities at odd hours.

headline: Senate Move to Reverse Mercury Rule Fails
text: A Senate resolution seeking to reverse federal regulations limiting emissions of mercury and other toxic substances from coal-burning power plants failed to win passage on Wednesday. The resolution, introduced by Senator James M. Inhofe, an Oklahoma Republican, won support from 46 senators; 53 voted against it.

headline: The Campster | Outdoorsy Web Sites
text: If camping didn’t take planning, more city dwellers would do it. (How much easier to book that hotel room in the Hamptons.) But even the plushest of hotels can’t supply the recharging that comes from a night spent outdoors. The following Web sites will take the headache out of the planning and point the way to some of the best open-air spots near you.

headline: Beyond the Four-Stroke
text: A conventional piston-driven internal-combustion engine functions by performing a cycle with four main steps: Air intake, air compression, combustion and exhaust. An engine is referred to as a “four-" or “two-stroke” model according to the number of movements the piston makes to perform one cycle. The Scuderi split-cycle engine and EcoMotor OPOC engine are both departures from the four-stroke engine most commonly found in automobiles. By revisiting and perfecting existing technologies, the companies say their motors provide more power, lower emissions and significantly better fuel efficiency.

headline: Usher Scores His Fourth No.1
text: A wave of new releases took over the top rungs of the Billboard chart this week, with Usher reaching No. 1 for the fourth time and new albums by Rush, the country singer Josh Turner and the British singer Ed Sheeran also scoring high.

headline: At Men’s Fashion Week in London, Newcomers Shine
text: There was much to discover, and just enough to provoke, in London’s first fashion event for men, which kicked off the spring season and will be followed by collections shown in Florence, Milan and Paris.

headline: A Changing of the Guard
text: LONDON

headline: They Still Don’t Want to Live With You
text: Looking over the results of a national survey on attitudes about aging, released on Monday, I groaned over some of the dopier questions. (At what age did people experience their first kiss? Not quite 15, on average. Who cares?)

headline: The French Still Flock to Bookstores
text: PARIS — The French, as usual, insist on being different. As independent bookstores crash and burn in the United States and Britain, the book market in France is doing just fine. France boasts 2,500 bookstores, and for every neighborhood bookstore that closes, another seems to open. From 2003 to 2011 book sales in France increased by 6.5 percent.

headline: Apps That Present Highlights of the World in Front of You
text: A relaxed late evening stroll along the esplanade in my seaside hometown may not seem like the ideal opportunity to test out what may be the cutting edge of mobile app technology, but it was this week. On the walk I’d noticed an enormously large cargo ship, with giant cranes on its deck, floating in the sunset haze a few miles out at sea, and I was curious what the ship was named and where she was from. Fortunately there was an app for that. An augmented reality app.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Noisy Creativity, and Drunken Texts
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: Filling a Spotlight Beyond Broadway
text: What is the career path of a modern-day Cinderella? For Laura Osnes, who will portray that ultimate fairy-tale golden girl next season on Broadway in a theatrical revival of the Rodgers and Hammerstein television musical “Cinderella,” it involves winning a national talent competition to star in a Broadway revival of “Grease.”

headline: When Sneakers and Race Collide
text: TO Jeremy Scott, the rebel designer from Los Angeles, the plastic shackles that he designed for a pair of orange-and-purple Adidas sneakers were inspired by a toy monster from the 1980s.

headline: ‘Sister Act’ Set to Close on Broadway
text: June hasn’t been kind to Broadway shows with religious themes. The producers of the musical “Sister Act,” about a singer-on-the-lam who finds happiness hiding in a convent of nuns, announced on Wednesday that it will close Aug. 26 after a 16-month run, having played 28 previews and 561 performances.

headline: Heart Attack Survivors May Develop P.T.S.D.
text: The emotional toll of a heart attack can be so severe that an estimated 1 in 8 patients who survive the experience develop post-traumatic stress disorder, a condition that doubles the risk of dying of a second heart attack, according to new research.

headline: Enemies and Allies for ‘Friends’
text: When it comes to sitting for interviews Mitt Romney is not usually a willing and eager subject. But there is one invitation he rarely turns down.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Bad and the Better'
text: William Apps and Sarah Lemp in a scene from the new show from the Amoralists.

headline: Going, Going, Gone Times Nine
text: Summer officially arrived in the Bronx on Wednesday, bringing with it sizzling temperatures and an afternoon fireworks display not previously listed on the Yankees’ schedule.

headline: Live Coverage Thursday of Portugal-Czech Republic
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 game between Portugal and the Czech Republic on Thursday at 2:45 PM ET. Duncan Irving will offer commentary and analysis of the quarterfinal match.

headline: Coney Island, 11:33 A.M.
text: Warm weather drew crowds to the beach on the first day of summer.

headline: For Chalmers, Echoes of a Championship Performance
text: Since the start of the N.B.A. playoffs there have been few sideshows more interesting than the Heat’s tough-love approach to the third-year guard Mario Chalmers. Four years after he led the 2008 Kansas team past Derrick Rose’s Memphis Tigers for the Jayhawks’s fifth national championship, the memory of Chalmers’s overtime-forcing 3-pointer had faded, replaced by images of LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and the rest of the Heat elder statesmen berating him.

headline: NBC Prepares to Replace Ann Curry on ‘Today’
text: NBC executives are making a plan to replace Ann Curry on the “Today” show, only a year after she became the co-host of the newly vulnerable morning television franchise.

headline: Peltz Turned Down Seat at Ingersoll-Rand
text: 6:58 p.m. | Updated with filing Nelson Peltz‘s Trian Group disclosed on Wednesday that it turned down a board seat at Ingersoll-Rand, after the company sought to impose further restrictions on the hedge fund.

headline: Open Series at European Championships in Dublin
text: The European Championships are taking place in Dublin and will end on Saturday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Spain, Iraq, Gaza Strip and China.

headline: Looking for a Job? Chances Are, the PTA Is Hiring
text: There is no centralized accounting of how many New Yorkers owe their livelihood to public school PTAs. But parent association Web sites -- which often include lists of the activities parent dollars are now responsible for -- suggest that if you are an actress with an appetite for history, an entrepreneurial bongo drummer, a yoga instructor O.K. with teaching downward dog to 6-year-olds, even a skateboard champion looking to earn some extra cash, currying favor with the city’s better-off PTAs is just good business.

headline: An Early Death but Perhaps Not a Surprise
text: THE bereaved reactions on Twitter came from all over: Kim Hastreiter, the editor of Paper Magazine; Bruce LaBruce, the independent film director; and Jake Shears of the Scissor Sisters, who called his recently departed friend “brave” and “honest.”

headline: Long Live the Kitsch
text: DURING Queen Elizabeth II’s Diamond Jubilee celebration this month, many BBC viewers were offended by its coverage of some of the tackier souvenirs and royal memorabilia available in London. There were temporary tattoos of corgis, a solar-powered waving doll of Elizabeth and a gelatin mold in the shape of her face. What really seemed to upset people was a Jubilee “sick bag,” for those who overindulged in the festivities.

headline: International House Hunting
text: Near Lyon, a 13th-century castle is frequently called the “Castle of Sleeping Beauty.”

headline: House Hunting in ... France
text: A NEOGOTHIC “SLEEPING BEAUTY” CASTLE IN BURGUNDY

headline: The Pleasure of Performers Transcending Their Material
text: The most welcome element of the program that the Limón Dance Company is presenting this week at the Joyce Theater is the way the group dances are performed. The dancers neither condescend to the old works by José Limón, who founded the troupe in 1946, nor present them as if they were the Holy Grail. They perform with a mixture of honest-to-goodness objectivity and what seems like a certain private pleasure. Two of the four pieces in the quadruple bill are by Limón, one is a work by another choreographer since his death in 1972, and one is a world premiere.

headline: Homes for $750,000
text: Properties in New Orleans, Maine and North Carolina.

headline: What You Get for ... $750,000
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Council Members Urge Expansion of Classroom Breakfasts
text: City Council members pressed the city to move its breakfast programs from the cafeteria to the classroom. New York lags behind other large urban areas in school breakfast participation and some studies support the theory that offering the meal in the classroom encourages enrollment.

headline: Parents With Limited English Skills Say City Fails to Help Them
text: Several dozen parents gathered on the steps of the Tweed Courthouse on a sweltering Wednesday afternoon, at a news conference to announce a complaint against the Department of Education. The complaint accuses the Education Department of discriminating against parents who have limited English proficiency, and whose children require special education services.

headline: City Is Backing Widow’s Suit Over U.S. Law on Gay Marriage
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, announced on Wednesday that they intended to file a legal brief arguing that the federal government’s Defense of Marriage Act is unconstitutional.

headline: The Montana G.O.P.’s New Platform
text: You’ve got to feel bad for the Montana Republican Party. It’s just gotten so hard to take a clear stand in favor of making homosexuality illegal.

headline: Putting the Squeeze on a Family Ritual
text: AT mealtime, I turn into a vaudevillian. The Contortionist. Dr. Airplane. Maestro the Great.

headline: Sounds Out of Several Worlds Converge in a Harlem Supper Club
text: The pianist Arturo O’Farrill was introducing a fresh composition on Tuesday night at Ginny’s Supper Club, the new room underneath the Red Rooster restaurant in Harlem, and it was hard to find the patrons’ attention, much less keep it. The club’s a beautiful basement space with serious food and infused bourbons. The owners are only getting started with music this summer; for a while a certain percentage of people will likely come to please their eyes and stomachs and treat the music as something to be endured.

headline: Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra at Ginny’s Supper Club
text: The ensemble led by the pianist Arturo O’Farrill performed in the new space underneath the Red Rooster restaurant in Harlem.

headline: The D.N.C.’s Hollywood Donors
text: What do you call a list of Hollywood’s glitterati that includes Will.I.Am, Kirk Douglas, Billy Crystal, Robert Downey Jr., Jack Black, Tom Hanks, Meryl Streep, Salma Hayek and Burt Bacharach?

headline: In Defense of the Decorator
text: DONNA MAY WOODS is trying to explain the complexities of a hot-pink and turquoise silk brocatelle.

headline: ‘Like’ My Room
text: WITH booming e-commerce and the proliferation of showrooms that encourage anyone to wander in off the street, design is so closely within reach that the average shopper doesn’t have to extend an arm. But just because consumers have grown more autonomous doesn’t mean they have the experience and taste to dispense with advisers and friends. And where’s the fun in filling a digital shopping cart all by yourself?

headline: Two Times Ad Executives Named Group Vice Presidents
text: The New York Times Company announced on Wednesday that two main members of its advertising department would take on expanded responsibilities as group vice presidents.

headline: Mr. Apartment Therapy’s East Hampton Home
text: Maxwell Gillingham-Ryan has added something extra to his property with a barn and six yurts.

headline: Pregnancy Rates Rise for Women Over 40
text: Women in their early 40s are getting pregnant more often.

headline: Tree by Tree, Yurt by Yurt
text: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our window air-conditioners partly block a desirable view. Would it be worth getting through-the-wall units installed in our apartment before trying to sell it?

headline: Using Untested Skills to Fix a Home With a Dubious History
text: In “Sugarhouse,” Matthew Batt’s memoir about buying and renovating a reputed former crack house in Salt Lake City, the author delights in describing his olfactory experience upon entering the home for the first time. He compares the odor, variously, to “a derelict litter box,” “muddy diapers,” “a state fair Porta-Potty during a heat spell and a sanitation strike,” and “rubber cement and burning fiberglass.”

headline: With a Moo-Moo Here and a Buzz-Buzz There
text: Looking at a farm scene imagined by Studio Job, you might well expect a slaughterhouse somewhere in the picture. The partnership of the Belgian and Dutch designers Job Smeets and Nynke Tynagel is notorious for richly executed dark visions, like harlequin-patterned stained glass windows depicting smoking industrial chimneys.

headline: Circular Logic
text: Two years ago, Connie Lam introduced her design for a metal lounge chair at a Brooklyn furniture show. The lounger provoked a fair amount of interest, but nothing like its bright orange cushion, which Ms. Lam had made by bundling together different sizes of rolled-up felt. People asked if the cover could be made into coasters or placemats. And though Ms. Lam described the work of sewing the felt rolls as “super-tedious,” she took the hint.

headline: Designing a Laid-Back Classic
text: In 1958, the furniture maker Plycraft introduced a plywood armchair designed by Norman Cherner with slim legs, a fan-shaped back and a nipped-in waist, proportions not dissimilar to those of Barbie, who reached the market a year later.

headline: Moss Goods for a Whisper
text: After closing its SoHo storefront earlier this year, the design shop Moss established itself in a smaller space in the garment district, trendsetting goods and all. “We have no way to display some of this stuff,” said Franklin Getchell, president and an owner of the entity now called Moss Bureau, which offers consulting services along with stylish tabletop objects, furniture and jewelry. “I’m trying to get us out of the inventory business.”

headline: Sales at Sur La Table and Others
text: Beds, bed frames and mattresses are up to 15 percent off at Scott Jordan Furniture, through June 30 (the Willoughby queen-size platform bed in solid cherry, originally $1,875, is $1,593); 137 Varick Street (Spring Street), (212) 620-4682, scottjordan.com.

headline: Wary of Plastic, and Waste, Some Consumers Turn to Glass
text: Glass water bottles, so yesterday. Plastic, so convenient; metal, so hip.

headline: Skipping the Architect: Wise or Otherwise?
text: UNDERTAKING a major renovation or new construction without an architect to provide design know-how or detailed plans would seem to be the realm of either the foolish or the very handy. Even the most gung-ho D.I.Y.ers have reason to fear blowing out a load-bearing wall.

headline: Picasso and Magritte Among the Top Sellers at Christie’s London Auction
text: LONDON — Depictions of two women — one, by Picasso, seated and pregnant, and another, by Magritte, of a woman being raped — were the top two sellers at Christie’s auction of Impressionist and Modern art here on Wednesday night.

headline: Worries About a Dolphin in the Hudson
text: What was an offshore bottlenose dolphin doing in Harlem?

text: On Wednesday morning, Bloomberg released a poll that showed President Obama 13 points ahead of Mitt Romney among likely voters.

headline: Audra McDonald Will Be Out of ‘Porgy and Bess’ Until July 3
text: On doctor’s orders, Tony-winning actress Audra McDonald will be out of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” until July 3.

headline: Sherry Pairings and Science
text: I recently took a trip to Andalucía, Spain, to spend four days exploring the sherry region. My column this week, the first of two on sherry, focuses on a hopeful sign for this region, which has been hard hit by a changing market for fortified wines over the last few decades.

headline: A Human Tower Needs a Foundation as Well as a Pinnacle
text: Updated | I went in wanting to be an I-beam. I settled for being a brick in the foundation, way down at the base: solid, sturdy, dependable. And oblivious to what was going on above me, which was a “human tower” seven levels high, being assembled on a rooftop near Madison Square Park, with two people on each level, standing on the shoulders of the people below.

headline: Noir Shadows, Shady Characters and Pulpy Plot Twists
text: By the end of “The Bad and the Better,” Derek Ahonen’s red-herring-stuffed panorama of dime-store pulp, nearly every one of the 26 cast members gets to do at least one of the following:

headline: A Family’s Sad Truth as a Subject for a Novel
text: Writing what you know, as aspiring authors are often advised to do, almost inevitably requires hurting those you love. Theatergoers learned this from the acclaimed Broadway production of “Other Desert Cities,” and will have the lesson drilled into their heads again in “This Is Fiction,” a new play in which yet another literary daughter purges a family secret through publishing.

headline: Excerpts: 'Love Goes to Press'
text: Scenes from the Mint Theater's revival of "Love Goes to Press."

headline: Dispatches, Lighthearted but Exacting, From the Front Lines
text: The war correspondent heroines of the 1946 play “Love Goes to Press” have smarts and bravado and glamour. They also have an impeccable pedigree: They’re creations of Martha Gellhorn and Virginia Cowles, journalists who covered the Spanish Civil War and World War II, which gave them intense, firsthand experience of the topic.

headline: Euro 2012: A Day Off … and More Views From the Goal Line
text: You really know you have a problem when the prime minister of Ukraine chimes in in favor of more transparency … on the soccer field.

headline: How America Can Help Its Friends Make Nice
text: Washington

headline: An Equity Share in a Graduate’s Income?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Driving the 2013 Lexus ES 300h
text: SHORT HILLS, N.J. — There have been five generations of the ES sedan since its introduction in 1989, and more than one million remain on the world’s roads. But the model never was available with a hybrid powertrain until this, the ES 300h, was introduced at the New York auto show in April.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,998 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: The Federal Reserve’s Interest Rate Statement
text: The following is the full text of the statement released on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve:

headline: With Power and Energy, Valdespin Takes Cues From Reyes
text: Jordany Valdespin, the Mets’ offensive spark du jour, nodded vigorously when asked if he still communicated with the former Mets star Jose Reyes.

headline: Romney’s Super Fan Loses His Truck in a Fire
text: Jim Wilson, whose cross-country travels in a GM pickup festooned with giant Romney for President signs and stickers earned the admiration and enmity of strangers, reported that his truck was badly burned on Interstate 70 in Pennsylvania on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Relief in Every Window, but Global Worry Too
text: In the ramshackle apartment blocks and sooty concrete homes that line the dusty roads of urban India, there is a new status symbol on proud display. An air-conditioner has become a sign of middle-class status in developing nations, a must-have dowry item.

headline: At Century-Old Club, Money Woes Sour the Mood
text: They were supposed to be the grown-up club on the block. As crisis after crisis hit the National Arts Club, the 124-year-old Players, which stands next door on Gramercy Park, seemed to hum above the fray.

headline: Breakfast, Bombing, Then Lunch: A Return to Grim Rhythms
text: BAGHDAD — On Saturday, a young Shiite man, bloodied from bombing wounds to his arms and head, was lying on a hospital bed when his cellphone rang.

headline: EBay Plans Data Center That Will Run on Alternative Energy Fuel Cells
text: EBay plans to build a data center to handle its billions of dollars in retail transactions that will draw its power from alternative energy fuel cells rather than the national power grid, which is heavily dependent on coal plants.

headline: Ads For and Against the Health Care Law
text: Since President Obama signed the health care law, hundreds of groups and candidates have run television advertisements critical of the law.

headline: Dirtying Up Our Diets
text: OVER 7,000 strong and growing, community farmers’ markets are being heralded as a panacea for what ails our sick nation. The smell of fresh, earthy goodness is the reason environmentalists approve of them, locavores can’t live without them, and the first lady has hitched her vegetable cart crusade to them. As health-giving as those bundles of mouthwatering leafy greens and crates of plump tomatoes are, the greatest social contribution of the farmers’ market may be its role as a delivery vehicle for putting dirt back into the American diet and in the process, reacquainting the human immune system with some “old friends.”

headline: Nuclear Operator in Japan Exonerates Itself in Report
text: TOKYO — The much vilified operator of the tsunami-hit nuclear power plant at Fukushima released a report on Wednesday that said the company never hid information, never underplayed the extent of fuel meltdown and certainly never considered abandoning the ravaged site. It asserts that government interference in the disaster response created confusion and delays.

headline: Florida Republican Drops Bid to Return to U.S. Senate
text: Former Senator George LeMieux of Florida will end his bid to return to the United States Senate, clearing the way for Representative Connie Mack to run as the Republican nominee.

headline: Aiming for the Time and Place Right Before That Queasy Feeling
text: FOR a product that treats motion sickness, Dramamine has itself barely moved in terms of marketing in recent years, with no national advertising campaigns since at least 2005, according to Prestige Brands, which purchased Dramamine from Johnson & Johnson last year.

headline: Europe Needs a Federal Reserve
text: AS the world economy teeters again, pressure is mounting on central banks to reopen their spigots, make it even cheaper for companies and households to borrow money, and prop up commercial banks to prevent another financial crisis. On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve, which had already promised to keep short-term interest rates near zero until the end of 2014, extended its latest, modest strategy to keep long-term rates down, too.

headline: One Last Lesson
text: In early May, my neighbor and I moved my three horses across the gravel road to her summer pasture. Last year, it took a while before her animals — a thoroughbred and a mule — herded up with mine, but eventually they settled down into a single unit. This year, they did something unexpected. They ejected Remedy, my old quarter horse, from the herd. My neighbor put salve on his bites. And, when I went to check on him the next morning, I found him standing alone in the shallow creek, as if his feet were hot. His head was to the fence, and his tail to all the rest of the world.

headline: Where Are the Clean Water Rules?
text: In April last year, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed badly needed policy “guidance” reminding the staff of the Army Corps of Engineers of their duty under the Clean Water Act to protect all bodies of water, large and small, from harmful development. The guidance was sent to the White House in February for final approval. There it has languished — another prisoner of election-year politics.

headline: B.C.S. Commissioners Reach Consensus on 4-Team Playoff
text: The expected became a reality Wednesday as college football’s leaders announced that they will move forward with a four-team seeded playoff to decide the sport’s champion starting in 2014.

headline: Jail for Library Employee Who Embezzled Fines
text: The lore of American thrift and personal finance going back to Benjamin Franklin is full of admirable tales of disciplined savers and investors who, over many years, turn pocket change and small bills into a comfortable nest egg.

headline: Tragedy for All Syrians
text: Father Paolo Dall'Oglio, an Italian Jesuit, recently left Syria and the monastery he spend three decades turning into a center for interfaith dialogue.

headline: Car Survey Shows Fewer Complaints but More With Personal Electronics
text: DETROIT — Carmakers are doing a better job than ever eliminating nagging problems like wind noise, paint chips and balky engines.

headline: Syria Expels Jesuit Priest Who Spoke for Change
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thick wooden beams barred the doors of St. Cyril’s Church in Damascus when friends of Bassel Shahade, a young opposition filmmaker killed in Homs in late May, arrived for a memorial prayer service. Government thugs dragged some mourners off to jail and chased away the rest, according to activists.

headline: UConn Is Among Those Barred From Postseason Basketball
text: In March, one year after Kemba Walker led the Connecticut men’s basketball team to its third national championship, the Huskies were ousted in their first game of the N.C.A.A. tournament, an early end to a disappointing season. But Connecticut will be unable to redeem itself next season because the N.C.A.A. on Wednesday imposed a one-year postseason ban as a result of the program’s low Academic Progress Rate scores.

headline: Black New Yorkers Not Keeping Pace
text: An analysis of employment data compiled by the federal Labor Department found that African-Americans and other non-Hispanic blacks in New York City were faring worse than residents of other races.

headline: Along the Hudson, a Rare Fallen Slab Jolts a Landscape of Towering Cliffs
text: ALPINE, N.J. — Last month, passengers on the Metro-North Railroad trains that run along the Hudson River looked up from their tepid coffee and their iPads to find the familiar view transformed. Just south of Hastings-on-Hudson, it looked as if a giant hand had carved a gash in the umber face of the Palisades, the wall of jagged cliffs that towers over the west bank of the river, depositing a huge mound of boulders below.

headline: A President Speeds Past, Casualties in His Wake
text: JOHANNESBURG — In Zimbabwe, President Robert G. Mugabe’s motorcade, with its phalanx of motorcycles and sport utility vehicles escorting the heavily armored presidential limousine, has a nickname: Bob and the Wailers.

headline: Political Private Practice
text: Let’s talk privatization.

headline: Lawyers Say Rape Case in Brooklyn Won’t Go On
text: In a startling reversal in a case that raised questions about misconduct in the Brooklyn district attorney’s office, defense lawyers for two of the four men from Crown Heights, indicted last year on charges of raping and forcibly prostituting a neighborhood woman for nearly a decade, said that prosecutors notified them on Wednesday that they were planning to drop all charges in the case.

headline: Bosses Rein In Banker Who Golfs With Obama
text: One of the biggest banks in the world wants the president’s favorite banker muzzled.

headline: U.S. Urged to Confront Iran on Nuclear Work
text: WASHINGTON — With high-stakes negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program at an impasse, the Obama administration is under mounting pressure to rethink a diplomatic exercise that many argue is simply stringing along the rest of the world.

headline: James Lives, Learns and Just Might Win
text: MIAMI — Nearly every detail in the portrait looks the same now as it did then: in the foreground, a microphone wrapped in a red-white-blue N.B.A. logo; in the background, a bright blue banner reading, “The Finals.” In between, LeBron James.

headline: Pakistani President Chooses Party Stalwart as New Premier
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Asif Ali Zardari has chosen a party stalwart, Makhdoom Shahabuddin, to replace the ousted prime minister, Pakistani news media reported late Wednesday.

headline: Blacks Miss Out as Jobs Rebound in New York City
text: For months now, New York officials have been highlighting how the city has regained all the jobs lost during the long recession and then some. But by several measures, the city’s recovery has left black New Yorkers behind.

headline: Trapping Heat
text: Many of the gases that run air-conditioners are powerful agents of global warming.

headline: An Amplifier to Enrich Digital Music, Heard on the Go
text: As audiophiles go mobile and take their music with them on their travels, device makers are trying to keep up by offering headphones and portable speakers to enhance the sound during playback on the go. Unfortunately, the music stored on a portable device is compressed, making it sound flat and dull.

headline: Money Market Funds Still at Risk, S.E.C. Chief Says
text: WASHINGTON — Despite changes made in the wake of the financial crisis, money market funds remain vulnerable to runs by panicked investors seeking to withdraw their money, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to tell a Senate committee Thursday.

headline: Frances W. Preston, Defender of Songwriters’ Copyright, Dies at 83
text: Frances W. Preston, who worked her way up from a radio-station mailroom to become one of the most influential figures in the music business, died on June 13 at her home in Nashville. She was 83.

headline: Football Faces ‘Turning Point’ on Safety Risk
text: Bart Scott, an unapologetically violent Jets linebacker known as the Mad Backer, will not let his 7-year-old son play football.

headline: Pandora Faces Rivals for Ears and Ads
text: Pandora Media, with more than 150 million users, is perhaps the biggest name in digital music, apart from Apple’s iTunes. The question, as a clutch of new competitors arrives, is whether it can hold on to that dominance.

headline: Albany Bill on Organ Donation Urges License Applicants to Act
text: The New York State Legislature passed a measure on Wednesday aimed at increasing the low number of organ donors in the state by encouraging driver’s license applicants to make an active choice about their donation status. If the bill is signed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, New York will become the second state, along with California, to make such a change in its donor registration process.

headline: Upstate Legislators Aid Caterer in Its Bid for Liquor License on Park Ave.
text: ALBANY — What interest do lawmakers from Binghamton and Buffalo have in a Manhattan catering hall? Plenty, apparently.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Biggest Rival for a Congresswoman From Brooklyn Isn’t Even on the Ballot
text: Councilman Erik M. Dilan may be the best-known candidate seeking to oust Nydia M. Velázquez, a 10-term Democratic congresswoman from Brooklyn, in next week’s primary. But to hear her talk about the race, it sounds as though her opponent is Vito J. Lopez, the head of the Brooklyn Democratic Party.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 16
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: In Iran, They Want Fun, Fun, Fun
text: ALONG THE CASPIAN SEA, Iran

headline: Home Prices in the West Are Rebounding as Inventory Shrinks
text: PHOENIX — Prices for existing homes here and in surrounding areas climbed by 25 percent during the 12-month period that ended in April, pointing to a decisive shift in the market realities of a place where foreclosed signs, abandoned properties and deserted neighborhoods became one of the most enduring symbols of the nation’s crippling real estate bust.

headline: LeRoy Neiman Dies at 91; Artist of Bold Life and Bright Canvases
text: LeRoy Neiman, whose brilliantly colored, impressionistic sketches of sporting events and the international high life made him one of the most popular artists in the United States, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: The Travelers Remains the Tour’s Proving Ground
text: CROMWELL, Conn. — Webb Simpson, the newly crowned United States Open champion, has not forgotten the tournaments that gave him his start. In 2008, shortly after he turned pro following the N.C.A.A.’s golf championship, opportunity presented itself when he was given a sponsor’s exemption from the Travelers Championship here. Simpson made his second professional start — one of five he made as a pro that year — and tied for 37th, earning $25,800.

headline: Payments for Victims of Eugenics Are Shelved
text: North Carolina’s novel effort to compensate people who were sterilized under a widespread and decades-long eugenics program that stretched into the 1970s all but died in the State Senate on Wednesday.

headline: Health Groups Criticize Allergy Drug Promotion
text: Public health advocates on Wednesday accused the drug company Merck of improperly marketing an over-the-counter allergy medicine directly to children using animated characters from the movie “Madagascar 3: Europe’s Most Wanted.”

headline: City Issues Warnings as It Prepares for Second Day of Heat
text: It was the longest day of the year Wednesday, and with temperatures in New York hitting the mid-90s, the hottest one, too.

headline: The Abuse of Solitary Confinement
text: Solitary confinement in this country has devolved from a short-term punishment imposed infrequently for violating prison rules into a routine form of prison management. Today, tens of thousands of local, state and federal prisoners are held in prolonged abusive isolation — in tiny, windowless cells for up to 23 hours a day.

headline: What Is Not Really There
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There is a Notepad in today’s (Thursday’s) puzzle which reads: “Parts of six answers have been entered in the grid for you.”

headline: Retrial Begins for City Councilman in Corruption Case
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have again asked a jury to convict City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook on corruption charges, accusing him on Wednesday of having abused his office “to enrich himself, members of his family and a woman he was having an intimate relationship with.”

headline: Once Again, the Cry May Be ‘Matteau’
text: Stefan Matteau was three months old on May 27, 1994, when his father, Stephane, scored his most famous goal: the overtime winner for the Rangers in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals against the Devils at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Pointless Partisan Fight
text: The political feud between the White House and Congressional Republicans has now culminated in a House oversight committee vote to cite Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. for criminal contempt. His supposed crime is failing to hand over some documents in an investigation of a botched gunrunning sting operation known as “Fast and Furious.”

headline: Donations to Democratic ‘Super PAC’ Rise Just as Campaign Steps Up Spending
text: Three $1 million contributions in May sharply increased the fortunes of the Democratic “super PAC” backing President Obama even as his campaign stepped up spending amid concerns expressed by top advisers about being wildly outspent this fall.

headline: China: 2 Tibetans Set Themselves on Fire to Protest Beijing’s Rule
text: Two Tibetans set themselves on fire on Wednesday to protest Chinese rule and to call for the return of the exiled Dalai Lama, according to a report by Radio Free Asia. The Tibetans were identified as Tenzin Khedup, 24, a former monk, and Ngawang Norphel, 22. The self-immolations occurred in the Yushu Prefecture of Qinghai, a Chinese province that is traditionally the northeastern Tibetan area of Amdo. The burnings occurred in the town of Dzatoe, known in Chinese as Zaduo. The report, which cited a monk in India who came from the Yushu area, said that Tenzin Khedup died at the scene and that Ngawang Norphel was badly burned.

headline: Vendors Arrested for Sale of Counterfeit T-Shirts
text: A disabled 67-year-old Vietnam veteran who sells “I ♥ NY” merchandise from a table near Battery Park said on Wednesday that he and two other street vendors had been arrested for selling counterfeit versions of the ubiquitous white T-shirts.

headline: In Western Pennsylvania, an Energy Boom Not Visibly Stifled
text: SMITHFIELD, Pa. — From his farm nestled far from the big cities, in the wooded hills above the Monongahela and Cheat Rivers, David Headley has not heard much about the battles in Washington over regulations that Republicans say are stifling a domestic energy revolution.

headline: Ordered to Prison, Former Romanian Prime Minister Shoots and Wounds Himself
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Former Prime Minister Adrian Nastase of Romania shot and wounded himself on Wednesday, apparently in a suicide attempt, hours after the country’s Supreme Court ruled he must serve a two-year sentence for corruption.

headline: A Dream on Two Wheels
text: ITEN, Kenya — Five years ago, Sammy Ekiru was negotiating traffic on his bicycle taxi for roughly three dollars a day in Kitale, a remote Kenyan town 20 miles from the Ugandan border. Today, he and his bike remain inseparable. His labor and his livelihood, however, have taken a substantially different course.

headline: Distaste for Health Care Law Reflects Spending on Ads
text: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — Erika Losse is precisely the kind of person President Obama’s signature health care law is intended to help. She has no health insurance. She relies on her mother to buy her a yearly checkup as a Christmas gift, and she pays out of her own pocket for the rest of her medical care, including $1,250 for a recent ultrasound.

headline: Gee Does His Part as Mets Complete a Sweep
text: Dillon Gee, a 13-game winner in 2011 whose current campaign has yet to gather momentum, responded to Manager Terry Collins’s challenge Wednesday night.

headline: Lin Adds Agent to Handle His Growing Marketing Demands
text: Jeremy Lin is preparing to capitalize on his meteoric rise to fame, and he has hired a new agent to help him take that step.

headline: Corrections: June 21
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Romney’s Personal Touch Pays Off With Campaign Donors
text: Mitt Romney’s biggest donors and fund-raisers are descending on Utah’s exclusive Deer Valley resort this weekend for what invitees are calling Republicanpalooza: a two-day retreat featuring Karl Rove, Condoleezza Rice, Jeb Bush and John McCain.

headline: در ایران مردم می خواهند خوش باشند و خوش باشند و خوش باشند
text: This is the Persian-language translation of a New York Times Op-Ed column by Nicholas D. Kristof. If you cannot view the Persian, you might need to adjust the settings on your Web browser or on your computer’s operating system.

headline: Campaigns and Crankiness
text: Have I ever told you that I get a bit curmudgeonly when I grow weary? No? Well, sit a spell. Take your shoes off.

headline: 2 New Resignations Rock the University of Virginia
text: In the continuing turmoil after the abrupt ouster of University of Virginia’s president, Teresa Sullivan, on June 10, the university’s vice rector, Mark Kington, and a prominent computer science professor have resigned — and some faculty members say there may soon be enough turnover on the 16-member Board of Visitors that Dr. Sullivan could be reinstated.

headline: Devils Could Be Nearing Deal With New Investors
text: Jeff Vanderbeek, the controlling owner of the Devils, could complete a deal by the end of next month to erase most of the team’s debt and bring in new minority owners, according to two people with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Senate Weighs Bill Overhauling Agriculture Programs
text: WASHINGTON — The farm bill under debate in the Senate would be the nation’s first major overhaul of federal agriculture programs in decades, including an end to the policy of paying farmers whether they grow crops or not.

headline: Judith S. Wallerstein, Psychologist Who Analyzed Divorce, Dies at 90
text: Judith S. Wallerstein, a psychologist who touched off a national debate about the consequences of divorce by reporting that it hurt children more than previously thought, with the pain continuing well into adulthood, died on Monday in Piedmont, Calif. She was 90.

headline: What Happened to the Tea Party?
text: In 2010, the movement and its supporters filled the airwaves. Where are they now? Did they simply get absorbed by the G.O.P.?

headline: Those 857 Desks? A Message for the Candidates
text: WASHINGTON — Tourists trying to figure out how to reach the capital’s monuments and museums on Wednesday found something on the National Mall that was not on their maps: 857 student desks arrayed near the Washington Monument.

headline: In Audio of Police Call, Trayvon Martin’s Father Is Heard Looking for Son
text: The morning after his 17-year-old son was fatally shot by a neighborhood watch volunteer in Sanford, Fla., Tracy Martin called a dispatcher about filing a missing person report, described his son’s now-famous attire and insisted the teenager did not know anyone in the neighborhood, according to recordings obtained by NBC News.

headline: From Penguin, a Plan to Make Its E-Books Available in New York City Libraries
text: In the past year, Penguin Group USA has slowly pulled away from the library e-book market. Now it is tiptoeing back in.

headline: Life, Interrupted: Fighting Cancer, and Myself
text: There is a dreadful routine to chemotherapy. My life has been synched to a chemotherapy calendar ever since my leukemia diagnosis last year. I have become an expert at predicting when side effects and symptoms will set in. It’s a ghoulish monthly party, and the guests always arrive on time: nausea, vomiting, chills, exhaustion, fever, mouth sores, pain, infections and emergency hospitalizations.

headline: Susan Tyrrell, Oscar Nominee, Dies at 67
text: Susan Tyrrell, a whiskey-voiced character actress whose talent for playing the downtrodden, outré and grotesque led to an Oscar nomination for best supporting actress in the 1972 John Huston film “Fat City,” died on Saturday at her home in Austin, Tex. She was 67.

headline: Word of the Day | muggy
text: muggy •\ˈmə-ge\• adjective

headline: A Late-Night Appearance for the Romney Brothers
text: Mitt Romney’s five sons — Tagg, Matt, Josh, Ben and Craig — appeared on “Conan” Wednesday night to answer the trenchant political questions that have perplexed and puzzled the nation. Or, at least, the comedian Conan O’Brien.

headline: Florida: Sanford’s Embattled Police Chief Loses His Job
text: Police Chief Bill R. Lee Jr. of Sanford, who drew criticism for his department’s handling of Trayvon Martin’s killing, lost his job on Wednesday. In a news release, City Manager Norton N. Bonaparte Jr. announced that Mr. Lee was immediately relieved of his duties. “We need to move forward with a police chief that all the citizens of Sanford can support,” Mr. Bonaparte said. In April, he announced that the chief had agreed to resign, but the City Commission rejected the resignation. Mr. Lee has been on administrative leave.

headline: Hawaii: Island of Lanai Sold to Chief Executive of Oracle
text: Lanai, the smallest publicly accessible inhabited island in Hawaii, has been sold, the governor’s office announced Wednesday. Castle & Cooke, the company that owned 98 percent of the 141-square-mile island, agreed to sell that land to Lawrence J. Ellison, chief executive of Oracle, the software giant. The price was not known, and neither Castle & Cooke nor Oracle responded to a request for comment.

headline: Minnesota: Zoo Animals Drown in Flooding in Duluth
text: At least 11 animals at the Lake Superior Zoo in Duluth drowned when severe storms caused major flooding in northeastern Minnesota on Wednesday. Much of the zoo was under water, and firefighters and police officers were dispatched to help round up a polar bear and two seals that escaped from their exhibits.

headline: From Milk to Peas, a Chinese Food-Safety Mess
text: HONG KONG — There’s mercury in the baby formula. Cabbages are sprayed with formaldehyde. Gelatin capsules for pills, tens of millions of them, are laced with chromium. Used cooking oil is scooped out of gutters for recycling, right along with the sewage.

headline: Young Photographer’s Death Has Some Worried
text: Tarun Sehrawat was a 22-year-old photographer for Tehelka magazine who returned after an assignment deep in the heart of India’s forests where Maoists battle security forces and indigenous groups often get caught in the crossfire. He had gone with a reporter, Tusha Mittal, into the forest-dense state of Chhattisgarh in central India in May. He had been unwell during the trip and felt uneasy upon his return but continued to work. (The pictures that he took during the trip appeared in the magazine’s May 12 issue.)

headline: C.I.A. Said to Aid in Steering Arms to Syrian Opposition
text: WASHINGTON — A small number of C.I.A. officers are operating secretly in southern Turkey, helping allies decide which Syrian opposition fighters across the border will receive arms to fight the Syrian government, according to American officials and Arab intelligence officers.

headline: News Quiz | June 21, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: A Primer on Best Practices for Journalistic Safety
text: Most international newspapers have strict rules and policies that require correspondents going on hazardous assignments to be trained adequately to face risks. It is unclear if any Indian news organization appears to be providing similar training; of the six news organizations in India that India Ink approached, two responded, and neither provides such training.

headline: Report on Its Banks’ Needs Raises Spain’s Borrowing Costs
text: MADRID — Spain’s increasingly fragile finances were on full display Thursday, with the government again having to pay high interest rates to sell its bonds, and audit reports indicating that the country will need as much as 62 billion euros, or $79 billion, to shore up its banking system.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 21, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Ed “Power With Purpose.”

headline: For Justin Bieber, Growing Up Is Tricky
text: WHO released his second full-length album on Tuesday?WHO are some of the artists that Justin Bieber is compared to in this piece?

headline: Prairie, Poetry and Loss
text: Rebecca Norris Webb’s book “My Dakota” is a personal meditation on the land where she came of age and an elegy for her brother who died in the middle of her project. James Estrin interviewed Ms. Norris Webb via e-mail.

headline: The End of the Euro Is Not About Austerity
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: A Generation Gap Cleaved Apart With Hockey Sticks
text: “The field hockey stick is not among the weapons that the Mumbai police force issues its officers,” Manu Joseph wrote in The International Herald Tribune. But that is the “implement” an assistant commissioner of police, Vasant Dhoble, “carried with him at least once this month as he and his team raided Mumbai’s pubs and nightclubs, making boys with gelled hair and girls in high heels flee inelegantly into the night,” Mr.Joseph wrote.

headline: 7 Things Graduating Seniors Should Know About College
text: As graduating seniors prepare for their freshman year in college, we’ve asked Lynn F. Jacobs and Jeremy S. Hyman, authors of “The Secrets of College Success,” to provide tips for incoming college freshmen. What follows are excerpts. — Tanya Caldwell

headline: The Early Word: Cited
text: Today’s Times

headline: Talking About Why Women Can’t Have It All
text: The cover story for the July/August issue of The Atlantic is one bound to stir conversation — as it was meant to. In “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” Anne-Marie Slaughter, the director of policy planning at the State Department under Hillary Rodham Clinton from 2009 to 2011, writes from personal experience about the reasons women can’t juggle both the demands of a high-powered job and being fully present as parents — at least not with the way America’s economy and society are structured today. After two years in Washington doing work she loved, she returned to academia at Princeton University, not because she didn’t want to stay in public service, but because “juggling high-level government work with the needs of two teenage boys was not possible.”

headline: Relief in Every Window, but Global Worry, Too
text: “In the ramshackle apartment blocks and sooty concrete homes that line the dusty roads of urban India, there is a new status symbol on proud display,” Elisabeth Rosenthal and Andrew W. Lehren wrote in The New York Times. “An air-conditioner has become a sign of middle-class status in developing nations, a must-have dowry item.”

headline: Syrian Pilot Granted Asylum in Jordan
text: Syria’s government was jolted Thursday by the first defection from its elite air force in the 16-month-old uprising, when a colonel commandeered a Soviet-era MIG warplane and flew to neighboring Jordan, where he sought and received political asylum.

headline: Twelve Stone Fruit Recipes
text: Peaches, cherries, plums — poached, stewed, sautéed.

headline: Stone Links: The Ethics of Ignorance (and Humor)
text: What do Jenny McCarthy and Socrates have in common? According to a post by Massimo Pigliucci at his blog Rationally Speaking, they each exemplifie a certain understanding of ignorance. Inspired by Katja Vogt, Pigliucci uses the Platonic concept of “transferred ignorance,” to distinguish between a healthy Socratic, “self-aware” kind of ignorance, and the kind of “willful ignorance” that allows “feelings” to “somehow trump actual scientific evidence,” as in the case of McCarthy’s campaign against childhood vaccination. Pigliucci argues, after Plato, that this latter type of ignorance can be “morally problematic,” and that its recent prevelance has led our political discourse into “never before achieved peaks (or, rather, valleys).”

headline: She’s 350 Pounds and Olympics-Bound
text: When you’re a big, strong girl — a really big, strong girl — it’s easier to pull the table to your chair than to scoot your chair toward the table. Doorknobs need to be tightened, or you might pull them off. Holley Mangold, 22 and a superheavyweight Olympic weight lifter, is 5-foot-8 and weighs 350 pounds. When she squats, which she can do with 525 pounds on her shoulders, she looks almost wholly like an egg. “I get a lot of Creepy McCreepersons interested in me because I’m so big it’s not normal, it’s like a fetish,” she told me one day in the gym. “And I don’t like to sit outside. Not because I don’t like to be outside, but usually there are plastic chairs. Once you break a couple plastic chairs, you’re afraid of them all.”

headline: In Detroit, the Green Garage Is a Different Kind of Incubator
text: Built in 1920, the brick warehouse at 4444 Second Avenue in Detroit used to be a showroom for the city’s pride: Model T-based automobiles. Now it’s a metaphor for urban reinvention. Last fall, the building reopened as the Green Garage, a living laboratory and co-working space for the what its owners, Tom and Peggy Brennan, see as the future of Motown — triple-bottom-line sustainable enterprises that define success by social and environmental measures as well as by financial profit.

headline: A Dozen Ways to Serve Stone Fruit
text: Stone fruit is summer in your hand. To me, there isn’t a better unmessed-with food than a good, ripe peach. Still, stone fruit can be fun to play around with, and a recipe for one kind is a recipe for almost all. Peaches, nectarines, apricots, plums, mangoes and cherries all respond similarly to sautéing, poaching, macerating, grilling, roasting and drying. And once cooked, stone fruit goes with just about everything.

headline: West Floats Clemency Offer if Assad Goes Quietly
text: LONDON – Will Bashar al-Assad be offered the chance of a peaceful retirement in exile? And would he agree to go to Switzerland to discuss the idea?

headline: Q&A: Playing Music on a Kindle Reader
text: Q.

headline: The Running Mate Guessing Game
text: The silly season has officially begun.

headline: As Unwanted Suitor Looms, KPN Struggles to Find Buyer for German Unit
text: KPN’s last-ditch efforts to forestall a hostile bid by América Móvil, Latin America’s largest mobile operator, may have ended after it broke off talks to sell its German business.

headline: Presidential Geography: Montana
text: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the economic and demographic peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Today’s stop: Montana, the Treasure State.

headline: H.D.R. Photography for the Realist
text: A technique called “High Dynamic Range,” or H.D.R. for short, has gotten a bad rap for its ability to make photos surreal-looking.

headline: An ‘Exorcist’ Turns Heads to the Stage
text: LOS ANGELES A DESECRATED statue of the Virgin Mary. A forebodingly steep outdoor staircase. A girl whose head twists all the way around her body and emits something thick, green and unpleasant from her mouth.

headline: When in Rome, Still an Anxious New York Intellectual
text: “Don’t psychoanalyze me! Many have tried. All have failed.”

headline: Opinion Report: Solitary Confinement
text: From the editorial page

headline: A Desk for Every Dropout, Every Hour, Every School Day
text: Regents, heat, finals, heat, graduation, heat, and confusing end-of-year schedules are on the minds of city school parents, students and teachers this Thursday in June. So as a diversion, let's go to Washington, where a visual stunt on the National Mall tried to focus attention on the state of the nation's schools.

headline: On Our Radar: A Drone for Tracking Poachers
text: Conservationists in Nepal will soon start using special drones as part of an effort to protect endangered species like rhinos and tigers. The pilotless aircraft can alert enforcement teams to the presence of poachers. [BBC]

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Bosses Rein In Banker Who Golfs With Obama  |  One of the biggest banks in the world wants the president’s favorite banker muzzled. The banker, Robert Wolf, a top UBS executive in New York, is among President Obama’s leading fund-raisers, building more than $500,000 for his re-election so far this year.

headline: Poem for a Summer Sunset
text: Read all recent entries and our updated submissions guidelines. Reach us via e-mail: diary@nytimes.com or telephone: (212) 556-1333. Follow @NYTMetro on Twitter using the hashtag #MetDiary.

headline: Pakistan Court Orders Arrest of Presidential Ally in a Drug Inquiry
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s judiciary stepped up its assault on government authority on Thursday when a court, prompted by a military-run antidrug agency, issued an arrest warrant for a close ally of President Asif Ali Zardari, effectively blocking his nomination as the country’s next prime minister.

headline: Assange, the Drama King
text: WikiLeaks’ founder still has it. Julian Assange made headlines again this week by walking into the Ecuadorean Embassy in London requesting asylum. He is hoping to avoid extradition to Sweden (for questioning over alleged sexual abuse and rape) and perhaps ultimately the United States (where Assange believes he could face charges of treason and espionage).

headline: Documents Tell Zimmerman’s Side in Martin Case
text: MIAMI — George Zimmerman was in a panic. A “suspicious” man he had been watching had jumped him in the rain. The man was pummeling him, slamming his head repeatedly into the pavement so it “felt like my head was going to explode,” Mr. Zimmerman told the police in newly released tapes.

headline: Thursday Reading: Heart Attack Survivors May Develop P.T.S.D.
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: NBC Contingency Plans Are Not Needed as Ann Curry Reports to Work at ‘Today’
text: For a couple of hours on Wednesday, as Ann Curry’s negotiations to leave the “Today” show were first reported publicly, NBC News officials believed that she would not be coming into work Thursday morning, according to people at the network who were not authorized to speak on the record.

headline: Vietnam Law on Contested Islands Draws China’s Ire
text: BEIJING — In a show of its resolve in a dispute over the South China Sea, China sharply criticized Vietnam on Thursday for passing a law that claims sovereignty over the Paracel and Spratly Islands, saying they are the “indisputable” territory of China.

headline: Enjoying Air-Conditioned Sidewalks?  Thank the Lawbreakers
text: Summer officially arrived on Wednesday at 7:09 p.m. Hours earlier, on a day so hot that the only things half-baked were the usual weather clichés, many shopkeepers in New York welcomed the season in traditional fashion:

headline: Play About ‘Checkers’ Speech to Kick Off Vineyard Theater Season
text: New plays about Richard and Pat Nixon, a high school confrontation and older women looking at their futures will make up the Vineyard Theater’s 30th season, the Off Broadway company announced on Thursday. The Vineyard also announced that the new musical “The Landing,” with music by the Tony Award winner John Kander (“Cabaret,” “Chicago”) and lyrics and book by Greg Pierce (“Slowgirl”), will be produced in the fall of 2013.

headline: Summer Reading in Style
text: Here are 20 of summer’s must-reads to pack in your beach tote:
