headline: Year-End Roundup | Language Arts, Journalism, the Arts and Academic Skills
text: This week, we’re looking back at all the lesson plans we published during the 2011-12 school year.

headline: Daily Report: EBay to Power a Data Center With Fuel Cells
text: EBay plans to build a data center that will draw its power from fuel cells rather than the national power grid, which is heavily dependent on coal plants, James Glanz reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Preview: Portugal-Czech Republic
text: While Karel Poborsky was ever-so-deftly scooping the ball up and over Portugal goalkeeper Vitor Baia in the quarterfinals of Euro 96 in Birmingham, England, I was leaning ever-so-precariously against the bar at Scarlett O’Hara’s in Prague, Czech Republic.

headline: Whose Jersey Is No. 1? Kobe Bryant’s
text: Kobe Bryant may be at home watching the N.B.A. finals on television, but he’s better than LeBron James: he has the top-selling N.B.A. jersey in the world.

headline: Maharashtra State Headquarters Evacuated After Fire
text: A big fire on Thursday afternoon ravaged the six-story headquarters of the state government of Maharashtra, the home of India’s financial capital Mumbai.

headline: Cabot to Buy Norit for $1.1 Billion
text: The Cabot Corporation agreed on Thursday to buy Norit, a Dutch manufacturer of activated carbon that is used in chemical reactions, for $1.1 billion.

headline: Richard Ford: By the Book
text: What book is on your night stand now?

headline: Disclosure Would Be Great. Then What?
text: President Obama’s lawyers have sent a letter to the Federal Election Commission complaining that Crossroads GPS, a partisan campaign committee that pretends to be a “social welfare” organization, is really a partisan campaign committee that pretends to be a “social welfare” organization.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Fox & Friends’ and the Campaign, and a New iPhone Rival
text: The morning show “Fox & Friends” has become the home of some of the most strident attacks on President Obama at Fox News, Jeremy W. Peters reports. It is also a reliably friendly landing spot for Mitt Romney, who has appeared as a guest 21 times in the last year. Fox News officials stress that the show falls under the network’s entertainment umbrella and does not pretend to be straight news, but, even so, Mr. Peters writes that “Fox & Friends” offers a test for the network and Mr. Obama’s reelection campaign:

headline: The Possum Ate My Cable
text: Venezuelans are pretty jaded about the news these days, and for good reason. Newspapers often read like a magic-realist novel: the president’s daughter redesigns national symbols on a whim; the government might mess with the time on your watch and the remains of independence-era heroes. But the bizarreness reached a new height this week when the Venezuelan government announced that the major blackout Ciudad Guayana had suffered the day before was to be blamed, not on years of mismanagement and underinvestment, but on a wily possum that had chewed through cables at a local substation.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Serious Eats: “Great bartenders are born, not made.” Do you have what it takes? Michael Neff (above) offers 20 rules for bartenders. See where you fit in, even if you weren’t born with a vest and sleeve garters. — Eric Asimov

headline: ESPN Will Emphasize Live Coverage of Wimbledon
text: The ESPN networks take over full coverage of Wimbledon for the first time next week, ending NBC’s 43-year partnership with the tournament, a switch that was motivated in part by the All-England Club’s frustration with NBC’s inability to consistently show live tennis.

headline: Football and Basketball Prepare for Changeup
text: It seemed as if Wednesday existed in sports as a day to contemplate the future and how everything is going to change. It appears we are about to exit a world in which LeBron James has become the most vaunted athlete who has not won anything and enter one in which he has. College football moved with more finality out of the hated Bowl Championship Series era and into one with something resembling a playoff. That this all happened on the summer solstice might either prove to you that higher powers are fiddling with our fun and games, or prompt you to say, "It's summer for goodness' sake, why is the N.B.A. still playing basketball?!"

headline: Markets Down Sharply on Economic News
text: Major stock indexes fell to their lowest levels of the week on Thursday, driven down by worries about global economic growth, troubled banks and falling oil prices.

headline: On Children and Digital Depictions of Nature
text: Carol Kaesuk Yoon, who writes frequently for Science Times and in 2002 collaborated with me on a story about the growing human influence on that thing called “nature,” had a thought-provoking essay in the paper this week titled “Nature Follows a Path of Pixels Into Children’s Hearts.”

headline: How Hot Is It?
text: Updated, 5:33 p.m. | Day 2 of Summer 2012’s opening blast brought more blistering heat and record-setting or record-breaking temperatures, though not in Central Park, weather forecasters said. Power consumption, although high, was short of record levels, utility officials said.

headline: Sandusky’s Adopted Son, Claiming Abuse, Offered to Testify at Trial
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Hours after a jury began deliberating the child sexual abuse charges against Jerry Sandusky, lawyers for one of his adopted children said Thursday that he had been abused by Sandusky and had offered to testify in the case.

headline: Business Day Live | June 21, 2012
text: UBS muzzles President Obama's favorite banker. | Beating the heat while battering the environment. | Ann Curry navigates the turbulence of morning television.

headline: House of Cards
text: “THIS won’t be a big part of my story,” I assured Lauren Greenfield. “But can you tell me a little bit about the lawsuit?”

headline: Opposition Divided Over Presidential Nominee
text: India’s main political opposition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, extended its support to Purno Agitok Sangma as an independent candidate for India’s presidency on Thursday, although two parties allied with the opposition said they would not back Mr. Sangma. Until Wednesday, Mr. Sangma was a member of a governing coalition party.

headline: Visiting Artists | Peter Sutherland
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Militant Gets 20 Years in Prison for Bali Bombing
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An Indonesian court on Thursday sentenced a militant to 20 years in prison for his role in several terrorist acts, including the twin nightclub bombings on the resort island of Bali in 2002 that killed 202 people, mostly foreigners.

headline: Talks May Test Partnership Between a Weak France and a Strong Germany
text: PARIS — Armed with a new mandate and a solid legislative majority, France’s François Hollande is off to do battle with Germany’s Iron Chancellor in the name of growth, prosperity and human decency. Or that’s the popular image, at least, of what is in fact a more delicate and nuanced relationship between the new French president and the German chancellor, Angela Merkel.

headline: The Tae Kwon Do Chronicles: Workouts Await
text: Diana Lopez won a bronze medal in tae kwon do in Beijing in 2008 and will be competing again in London this year. Her reports will appear regularly on the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her second post.

headline: Commerce Secretary Resigns
text: 8:54 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON — John E. Bryson announced his resignation as President Obama’s commerce secretary on Thursday, citing medical reasons after an episode in which he had a seizure and was involved in a sequence of car crashes.

headline: Wheelies: The Corner-Office Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Audiences Can Now Analyze Dr. Ruth
text: WHEN Dr. Ruth Westheimer, the sex therapist, met Sigmund Freud on a fateful night in midtown Manhattan, she probably should have known what might happen nine months later. The encounter took place last fall at the New World Stages theater complex, where Dr. Westheimer had just seen “Freud’s Last Session,” the word-of-mouth Off Broadway hit by Mark St. Germain. Afterward she found herself chatting with Martin Rayner, the actor who plays Freud.

headline: Many Borrowers Fall Behind Again After Mortgage Modifications
text: More than half of delinquent borrowers who received mortgage modifications were behind on payments again 18 months later, according to a new analysis from the credit reporting company TransUnion.

headline: The South From Many Angles
text: HOW can a museum promote new photography while also building its own holdings? With an initiative like “Picturing the South,” run by the High Museum of Art in Atlanta since 1996. Over the years the museum has asked nine photographers to create pictures inspired by the modern American South “without any strings attached,” said Brett Abbott, the curator of photography there. And it has included nearly 200 of the works into its collection.

headline: Pentagon Gets Attention, but Planned Spending Cuts Range Far and Wide
text: WASHINGTON — It is no secret here that come January, barring Congressional action, huge spending cuts will hit the Pentagon. Congressional Republicans, President Obama’s secretary of defense and military contractors have taken pains to denounce the planned reductions, which were scheduled as part of the resolution to the debt-ceiling crisis of last year.

headline: My Air-Conditioner Envy
text: With scorching heat enveloping New York City this week, I’m suffering from air-conditioner envy. I want a model like the one I saw in April at the Terre Policy Center in Pune, India. But I can’t buy it.

headline: Dead Dolphin Found at Chelsea Piers
text: Updated, 6:40 p.m. | A dead dolphin was found Thursday morning in the Hudson River at Chelsea Piers. It was a common dolphin, said Kimberly Durham, a biologist with the Riverhead Foundation, the organization that removed the animal’s body from the marina.

headline: In Need, in New York
text: A native of Chicago’s South Side, I was raised in poverty. Several times my mother and I had to take refuge in other people’s homes, and sometimes in shelters. I thought that by joining the Navy at 18, I would get the training and education I needed to improve my life and help my family.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/21: Flight Diversions and Superfund Tours
text: Touring a Different New York Mitch Waxman, who earns his living retouching photos, leads tours of Newton Creek, on the Brooklyn-Queens border, which was designated a Superfund site in 2010. (The New York Times)

headline: Supreme Court Rejects F.C.C. Fines for Indecency
text: WASHINGTON —   The Supreme Court on Thursday declined to address whether the government still has the authority to regulate indecency on broadcast television, but it ruled in favor of two broadcasters who had faced potential fines for programs featuring cursing and nudity on narrow grounds.

headline: Now Screening | Warby Parker’s ‘Le Chat Cambrioleur’
text: Last night at the Payne Whitney Mansion at the French Embassy in New York, the SoHo-based sunglasses company Warby Parker celebrated Les Auteurs, its new collection, with cocktails and a screening of the film “Le Chat Cambrioleur” (“The Cat Burglar”). Inspired by midcentury French cinema and shot true-to-form on 16 millimeter film, the silent short stars Martine Langatta (wearing the line’s Filmore frames) and Diego Ongaro (in the Winston style). “A lot of what made French films from this period stand out was that the plot was secondary to the attitudes of the characters and the style of the times,” said the brand’s co-founder Neil Blumenthal. “That’s very much the case with our piece.” Watch it here.

headline: The Cat Burglar
text: Inspired by midcentury French cinema and shot true-to-form on 16 millimeter film, the silent short stars Martine Langatta and Diego Ongaro sporting frames by Warby Parker.

headline: The Debt Ceiling Escape Hatch
text: Last year, when House Republicans pushed the government to the point of default by threatening not to raise the debt limit, there was a lot of frantic talk about using the Constitution as an escape hatch. Because the 14th Amendment prohibits any action that raises doubt about the public debt, the theory went, President Obama could declare the ceiling unconstitutional and simply ignore the House’s threat.

headline: Washington Mutual’s Former Chief Takes Issue With Book’s Portrayal
text: A new book about Washington Mutual, “The Lost Bank” by Kirsten Grind, has been praised for its in-depth account of biggest bank failure in the nation’s history.

headline: Orbitz Releases New Travel App
text: Orbitz released a new version of its iPhone app today that allows users to book flights, hotel rooms and car rentals in one seamless session. The upgrade is a departure from other travel apps that handle multiple reservations, like Kayak’s, which sends users to browser screens within the app, and Expedia’s, which requires users to enter their data repeatedly.

headline: In Speech, Romney Takes Softer Tone on Immigration
text: 1:33 a.m. | Updated A revised version of this post is available here.

headline: A Black Spy in the Confederate White House
text: Mary Bowser, born into slavery in Virginia sometime around 1840, was, alternately, a missionary to Liberia, a Freedmen’s school teacher — and, most amazingly, a Union spy in the Confederate White House.

headline: Image of the Day: June 21
text: The “Rath Yatra” or chariot procession festival in Puri, Orissa.

headline: California Academic Named Director of MacArthur Fellowship Program
text: Cecilia Conrad, vice president for academic affairs and dean of Pomona College in Claremont, Calif., has been named the next director of the MacArthur Foundation fellowship program known as the “genius” awards, foundation officials said Thursday.

headline: Indiana Governor to Be President of Purdue
text: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana was unanimously voted the next president of Purdue University by the board of trustees on Thursday, making official what had been reported by a number of local and national news outlets this week.

headline: Hate Mail and the New Religious Wars in Tech
text: A note from a reader:

headline: Role of Digital Music Underpins Senate Hearings on Universal-EMI Deal
text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated The Internet has changed almost everything about the music business, of course, from introducing a vast piracy threat to opening up avenues of distribution that allow musicians everywhere to instantly make their work available online. But when it comes to the big record companies, could the digital revolution actually have made the strong even stronger?

headline: Summer, and the Devil Is in the Scheduling
text: “How,” a friend asked via email, “is June going for you? Hate the transition from the school schedule devil-we-know to camp and the devil-we-don’t.”

headline: Washington Law Firm Finds Niche in Sports and Entertainment
text: What do Ann Curry, the “Today” show co-host, and Jeremy Lin, the New York Knicks point guard, have in common?

headline: Shading the Gray
text: Those who cover their gray hair with dye often experience regrowth within three weeks, making it a time-consuming and expensive chore (especially if performed at the salon). But in recent years several easy-to-use products that temporarily cover roots have arrived on the market, extending the time between single-process jobs. We tried some of the newest.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Anna Schwartz, Economist Who Collaborated With Friedman, Dies at 96
text: Anna J. Schwartz, a research economist who wrote monumental works on American financial history in collaboration with the Nobel laureate Milton Friedman while remaining largely in his shadow, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96.

headline: Bobby Cannavale to Play Ricky Roma in ‘Glengarry Glen Ross’ Revival
text: Coffee’s for closers only, as a great man once said. So hoist a mug of joe for Bobby Cannavale, who has closed on a role in the coming Broadway revival of “Glengarry Glen Ross,” its producers said on Thursday, and will join Al Pacino in that David Mamet play.

headline: Air-Conditioners Cause Global Worry
text: As air-conditioners sprout across the world, scientists are becoming increasingly alarmed about the impact of the gases on which they run. Elizabeth Rosenthal reports.

headline: Business Day Live | UBS Banker
text: June 21, 2012 - UBS muzzles President Obama's favorite banker.

headline: Who Needs a Prince When Fun’s Afoot?
text: The riotous mass of bouncy curls that crowns Merida, the free-to-be-me heroine of the new Pixar movie, “Brave,” is a marvel of computer imagineering. A rich orange-red the color of ripe persimmon, Merida’s hair doesn’t so much frame her pale, creamy face as incessantly threaten to engulf it, the thick tendrils and fuzzy whorls radiating outward like a sunburst. There’s so much beauty, so much untamed animation in this hair that it makes Merida look like a hothead, a rebel, the little princess who wouldn’t and didn’t. Then again, Rapunzel has a supernice head of hair too.

headline: For Convicted Financier, a Farewell to Bugatti and Other Baubles
text: Timothy S. Durham once presided over an investment portfolio that included restaurants, bars and the National Lampoon constellation of media properties, as well as a dream garage of contemporary and classic sports cars. On Wednesday in Indianapolis, a jury found the financier guilty on 12 felony charges relating to fraud.

headline: Euro 2012 Highlights: Portugal (1), Czech Republic (0)
text: Portugal became the first team to reach the semifinals of Euro 2012 with a well-deserved 1-0 win over the Czech Republic in Warsaw Thursday night.

headline: Twitter’s Site Suffers Some Downtime
text: 5:21 p.m. | Updated Further explanation of the company, added at the bottom of the post.

headline: The Field Hockey Chronicles: Strength in Numbers
text: Michelle Kasold, a striker, has been a member of the U.S. field hockey team since 2006 and will compete in her first Olympics in London this summer. She will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her first post.The 2012 Olympic Field Hockey Team by the Numbers

headline: Photoville Comes to Brooklyn Bridge Park
text: When the Miser was younger and needed the money, guarding one of the world’s greatest art collections in a majestic Fifth Avenue fortress didn’t seem like such a horrible prospect, even if the uniform sure wasn’t anyone’s idea of sexy. Summer weekends were tough, though. Long stretches were spent gazing out of available windows, neglecting priceless artifacts. Our holdings of works from Africa, Oceania and the Americas, for example, could have been greatly reduced thanks to the more prosaic distractions of Central Park in summer. Think about that next time you read of some daring art heist somewhere.

headline: A Jilted City Finds Itself Enjoying the Heat
text: SEATTLE – It was Wednesday, the day after the Miami Heat went up, three games to one, against the Oklahoma City Thunder in the N.B.A. finals. And all around this city, there was a good deal of satisfaction that the Thunder, the team that used to be known as the Seattle SuperSonics, was probably going to come up short in their quest to win a championship.

headline: Sonny Rollins Is Big Winner at Jazz Awards
text: Sonny Rollins, the veteran saxophonist, was the big winner on Wednesday night at the annual Jazz Awards in New York, taking home three trophies. He was named musician of the year for the second year in a row and won for best record and best tenor saxophonist to boot.

headline: Losing Faith in American Institutions
text: As Tyler Cowen (and then I) wrote about earlier this week, trust in government is declining.

headline: Theater Talkback: Boxers on Broadway
text: ArtsBeat once again is inviting members of the theater world to contribute over the summer to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. For the first guest post, Trav S. D., a historian of vaudeville, talks about the long bare-knuckles history shared between the boxing  ring and the stage.

headline: A Strong Finish Makes Up for a Strange Ride
text: While the Oklahoma City Thunder await their formal elimination from the postseason, the rest of us can only enjoy – and dread – the waning moments of another brilliant N.B.A. campaign. What began in a Christmas Day fervor has ended with a gift; an exhausting regular-season schedule was upstaged by riveting playoff theater, and has culminated in an unforgettable display of artistry and grandeur in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Immigration
text: Romney shifts on immigration. | The showdown over “Fast and Furious” poses political risks | Connecticut Republicans face off in a Senate race | Romney thanks donors with a personal touch.

headline: Stolen Cultural Treasures on Display in Paris
text: PARIS — It is a most unusual and diverse art exhibition for Unesco, the United Nations arm dedicated to preserving and promoting the world’s culture. On Wednesday, 31 rare artifacts and works of art – all of them stolen or illegally exported, mostly in or from Italy – went on display at UNESCO’s Paris headquarters, in an exhibition called “Recovered Treasures.”

headline: Natural Gas for Vehicles Could Use U.S. Support
text: The fuel is cheap and plentiful. But there is little infrastructure to deliver it to users, and so there is little demand for equipment to use it.

headline: An Earth Summit Draws on Oil, Mining and Utility Largess
text: RIO DE JANEIRO – The cups at the water coolers here at Rio+20, the global sustainability conference taking place Wednesday through Friday, are made of rough biodegradable corn fiber rather than plastic. Vans running on second-generation ethanol made from sugar cane bagasse take conference members, free of charge, from the hotels on the Copacabana beach to the conference center an hour away.

headline: Prosecutors in Norway Seek Hospital for Gunman
text: OSLO — Norwegian prosecutors asked a trial court here on Thursday to order Anders Behring Breivik, who has admitted killing 77 people, confined for compulsory psychiatric treatment instead of sentencing him to prison.

headline: Bird Flu Paper Is Published After Debate
text: The more controversial of two papers describing how the lethal H5N1 bird flu could be made easier to spread was published Thursday, six months after a scientific advisory board suggested that the papers’ most potentially dangerous data be censored.

headline: Novel Maneuvers in Battle for Quest Software
text: The battle for Quest Software highlights a board’s quandary when a chief executive makes a play for the company. Not only that, it’s also a fun takeover battle in the midst of a slow summer deal market featuring some novel deal-making.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Immigration
text: Michael D. Shear discusses Mitt Romney’s shifts on immigration and the showdown over ‘Fast and Furious.’ Peter Applebome looks at Connecticut Republicans facing off in a Senate race, and Michael Barbaro explains Mr. Romney’s technique with donors.

headline: Zimmerman Re-enactment
text: The day after George Zimmerman killed Trayvon Martin, police accompanied Mr. Zimmerman to the scene.

headline: Mitt Romney Speaks at NALEO Conference
text: Mitt Romney spoke to the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials conference on Thursday in Orlando.

headline: Air France Plans to Cut 10 Percent of Its Work Force
text: PARIS — Air France said Thursday that it would eliminate more than 5,100 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, by the end of next year, part of its efforts to return the company to profitability at a time of deepening economic gloom across Europe.

headline: Crystal Clear | Eyal Burstein for Swarovski
text: It’s hard to believe that Swarovski’s Crystal Palace program, in which contemporary designers imagine ever-newer uses for Swarovski crystals, is 10 years old. The years — and crystals, as interpreted by people like Toord Boontje, Zaha Hadid, Ron Arad and John Pawson — have flown by. But last week, Swarovski celebrated the program’s anniversary at Design Miami/Basel with Beta, an installation by the designer Eyal Burstein, of the Berlin studio Beta Tank, in which the crystals were conceptual rather than literal. Beta featured three concrete and metal chairs and a plexiglass bench, all of which were influenced by the shape of Swarovski’s classic Chaton-cut crystals.

headline: Refuse Thy Neighbor
text: I recently resigned from my job as an engineer to be at home more with my young children. When news got around, I started receiving requests for favors from neighbors (for baby-sitting, dealing with garbage bins, walking dogs). I didn’t mind at first, but now I’m being asked several times a week, often at the last minute and for much longer than originally requested (one hour turns to five). I feel like a lousy neighbor when I refuse, but even that hasn’t deterred the guilt-trippers. Any advice?J. C., Baltimore

headline: White House Dismisses House ‘Fast and Furious’ Investigation
text: The White House on Thursday dismissed the House Republican investigation that has led to a showdown over executive privilege and contempt of Congress as a “politically motivated, taxpayer-funded, election-year fishing expedition.”

headline: Refining Web Recommendations Through Friends
text: On the Internet, everyone is a critic.

headline: Laurie Metcalf Coming to Broadway in ‘The Other Place’
text: The 2013 Tony Awards race for best actress in a play has begun. Starting in December the Emmy-winning actress Laurie Metcalf (“Roseanne”) will reprise her acclaimed performance as a drug-industry businesswoman who unravels emotionally in “The Other Place,” a psychological drama by Sharr White that ran off Broadway in 2011 and will be remounted on Broadway by Manhattan Theater Club, the organization confirmed on Thursday. Ms. Metcalf, who is currently drawing rave reviews in London playing Mary Tyrone in “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” won an Obie Award and a Lucille Lortel Award last year for “The Other Place”; hers was the sort of performance that often draws Tony Awards attention but “The Other Place” wasn’t eligible because only Broadway productions are considered for Tonys.

headline: Business Day Live | Ann Curry
text: June 21, 2012 - Ann Curry navigates the turbulence of morning television.

headline: Discovering a New Land, in Middle and High School
text: There are an estimated 1.3 million people immigrating to the United States each year. Many are children, and most are poor. In Queens,  almost half the residents were born outside the U.S. A Columbia journalism school student provides a multimedia report on how one middle school student is making the transition.

headline: U.S. and Switzerland Reach Deal on Sharing of Financial Account Data
text: PARIS — Washington gained another victory on Thursday in its push to extend surveillance over Americans’ financial dealings when Switzerland joined the list of countries that have agreed to cooperate in an initiative to track down tax cheats overseas.

headline: Good Features Demand Good Design
text: This week, I took up an invitation from Samsung to go to its United States headquarters in New Jersey and check out a bunch of products.

headline: I.M.F. Urges Europe’s Strongest to Shoulder Burdens of Currency Bloc
text: LUXEMBOURG — Euro area countries must share debt and use rescue funds to recapitalize troubled banks directly to ensure the survival of the currency union, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said late Thursday.

headline: Those Already Ill Have High Stake in Health Ruling
text: BATAVIA, Ohio — The tumor grew like a thick vine up the back of Eric Richter’s leg, reminding him every time he sat down that he was a man without insurance. In April, when it was close to bursting through his skin, he went to the emergency room. Doctors told him it was malignant and urged surgery.

headline: Albany to Limit the Disclosure of Teacher Evaluations
text: ALBANY — Siding with teachers’ unions over the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the New York State Legislature on Thursday approved a plan to limit the public disclosure of teacher evaluations.

headline: Can Doctors Learn Empathy?
text: My colleague loved performing surgery as much as anyone I had ever met. Every morning he bounded into the hospital, full of energy and cheerful anticipation of the day’s surgical schedule, his prominent mouth stretched into a broad grin.

headline: Health Care Confusion
text: The Times’s Abby Goodnough reported today that right-wing groups have spent $235 million on ads attacking President Obama’s health-care law — and seem to have gotten their money’s worth. People hate the law, they don’t understand it, they think it’s something that will hurt, oppress and bankrupt them — even when it won’t.

headline: Laughs From the Comic’s Perspective
text: While “Seinfeld” was famously about nothing, last season “Louie” often seemed to be about everything, whether it was grappling with our country’s history of racism or the inexplicable torture of unrequited love. Yet what makes this FX show the best comedy on television — and its third season, which has its premiere on Thursday, the cultural event I am most excited about this summer — is how it manages to tackle big, complicated issues through a very small prism. The specificity of the New York stand-up comedy world that Louis C. K. presents on this show lets him explore universal themes without becoming abstract, overly cerebral or ever less than intensely funny.

headline: Big Banks Brace for Credit Rating Downgrades
text: Moody’s Investors Service has begun notifying some big banks that their credit ratings may get cut as early as this afternoon.

headline: Blunt Memories of Celluloid Life
text: The energy source for Laura Moriarty’s new novel, “The Chaperone,” is its secondary character: Louise Brooks, at the age of 15. This book is really about the older woman enlisted to accompany Louise to New York from Wichita, Kan., during the summer of 1922. Louise was going to study dance. The woman’s job was to keep Louise on the path of virtue. As if.

headline: 36 Hours in Kiev, Ukraine
text: AFTER seven decades of Soviet dominance, Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, has emerged as one of Europe’s most vibrant 21st-century cities. With a thriving contemporary art scene, a new generation of chefs taking innovative approaches to Ukrainian cuisine, and a delirious dance-til-dawn night life, Kiev — currently a co-host of the 2012 European Soccer Championship — is a weekend magnet for European and Russian fashionistas. But new cuisine and clubs are only the latest cultural attributes of a city that has more than its share of ancient catacombs, churches and monuments. Don’t let Kiev’s reputation as “the birthplace of the Slavs” conjure up stereotypes of Slavic dourness. For starters, the city looks as if it was painted like a Ukrainian Easter egg, with brightly colored buildings and gold domes glittering on the hills above the Dnieper River. And then there are the Kievans themselves — a resilient lot whose hearty sense of humor and a seemingly boundless hunger for fun are reflected in the city’s bustling cafes, thronged beaches and bars that never close.

headline: Lively Kiev, Ukraine
text: Discover the city’s pulsing clubs, arresting architecture, skimpy urban beachwear and more.

headline: Inspired Creation, Found in a Desert
text: If I had a camper, I would load it up with big bottles of water at the end of this summer and head to the Black Rock Desert in Nevada for the annual Burning Man festival, which runs from Aug. 27 through Sept. 3 — that is, had I been smart enough to secure a ticket long ago. Attendance is capped at 60,900, and the event is sold out.

headline: Fund-Raising Fairness Is Being Tested in Oregon, With Mixed Results
text: With parent fund-raising machines kicking into high gear – in New York City, collections by some schools' groups are in the million-dollar range – school districts are starting to develop policies to address the resulting issue of fairness. One model can be found in Portland, Ore., a progressive district that shares a portion of the money raised in wealthy schools with schools that serve poor families.

headline: Vintage Pynchon Goes Electronic
text: Fifteen years after it was first published, Thomas Pynchon’s “Mason & Dixon” remains his most emotionally affecting novel and a dazzling, encyclopedic showcase for his talents: his ability to mix the philosophical with the slapstick, the playfully postmodern with the old-fashioned picaresque; his delight in language and narrative sleight of hand; his Swiftian knack for satire; and his storyteller’s ability to fuse history and science and fable with ardor and panache.

headline: Dreaming Up Whole New Carbon Markets
text: Normally, when supporters of renewable energy talk about carbon markets, they’re referring to a system of traded credits that industries buy to compensate for their emissions of greenhouse gases, like the ones already sold in Europe and under development in California and Canada. But at the Renewable Energy Finance Forum-Wall Street, an annual conference organized by the American Council on Renewable Energy, the talk on Wednesday was of developing a different kind of carbon market where the gas would be bought and sold like a commodity to encourage carbon capture.

headline: Dispatches from Rio: None from Obama?
text: I understand why President Obama is not going to the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development in Rio, which is a reprise of the 1992 Earth Summit there at which President George H. W. Bush and nearly all the world’s leaders appeared. (He’s skipping the conference despite taking direct heat in a YouTube message to Rio from Senator James Inhofe, the Republican of Oklahoma and steadfast ally of big coal, and indirect heat from Senator John Kerry, the Democrat of Massachusetts who gave a long floor speech on global warming and the Rio meeting yesterday, decrying “the conspiracy of silence that now characterizes Washington’s handling of the climate issue.”)

headline: Radiohead Postpones European Shows
text: The stage collapse that killed a Radiohead crew member last Saturday in Toronto also destroyed the band’s sophisticated light show, forcing the British group to postpone seven concerts in Europe over the next two weeks while repairs are made, the band said on Thursday in a statement. That means Radiohead will skip a swing through the Italian cities of Rome, Florence, Bologna and Codroipo, a two-night stand in Berlin and a stop at Canton de Vaud in Switzerland. It will resume the tour in Nimes, France, on July 10.

headline: Smartphones: The New Post-Coital Cigarette?
text: Jonathan Evans/ReutersJerry Hall in a stage performance of ‘The Graduate,’ demonstrating a more traditional addiction.

headline: Exploring the Pine Barrens on a Literary Tour of New Jersey
text: I grew up in West Virginia and Florida, and since I was young I’ve been drawn to Southern lit like a bug to light — to William Faulkner and Eudora Welty, Harry Crews and Flannery O’Connor, Zora Neale Hurston and Cormac McCarthy.

headline: Burundi Sentences Journalist to Life in Prison for Terrorism
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — A journalist from Burundi has been sentenced to life in prison as a terrorist for what the government has called his involvement in a deadly gun attack there last year.

headline: Maddon and Johnson Feuding Over Pine Tar Drama
text: 7:12 p.m. | Updated Can we maybe get Managers Joe Maddon of the Rays and Davey Johnson of the Nationals to agree that they totally disagree right now?

headline: Albany Deal: Teacher Evaluations Will Be Public Only to Parents
text: UPDATED | In a deal reached in the final days of the session in Albany, legislators agreed to a system that will allow parents to see the evaluations of their children's current teachers, but the public will be allowed to see only evaluation information with teachers' names redacted.

headline: Obama Calls Passage of Student Loan Legislation a ‘No-Brainer’
text: President Obama on Thursday again called on Congress to pass legislation avoiding a hefty increase in student loan interest rates that takes effect in 10 days, but Republicans said the president had refused to work with them to find a compromise.

headline: Romney on Rubio's DREAM Act
text: Mitt Romney answered questions from reporters while campaigning with Marco Rubio.

headline: Senate Passes Farm Bill With Bipartisan Support
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved a sweeping new farm bill on Thursday that would cost nearly $1 trillion over the next 10 years, financing dozens of price support and crop insurance programs for farmers and food assistance for low-income families.

headline: Banner Days
text: His dashing ascot billowing, his flat cap perched just so (to hide his bald spot), the cleft-chinned Harry Hay had some impressive head shots. As a student at Stanford in the early 1930s, he had come out to his classmates as “temperamental,” code for “homosexual.” In 1934, having dropped out of Stanford and moved to Los Angeles to try a career in pictures — and having already begun to hone his identity as sensualist and agitator — he joined the Communist Party. Around 1936, he turned up at a Halloween party dressed as “the demise of fascism.” The other homosexual bons vivants were stumped: none were terribly turned on to politics, so none knew what Harry’s costume meant. These men, and others like them across America, had no core ideology, no political groups to join, no leaders. Hay changed that. In 1950, he helped create the Mattachine Society, the country’s first gay rights organization, and demanded that the people it represented “be respected for our differences, not for our sameness to heterosexuals.”

headline: Mitt Romney on 'Face the Nation'
text: Mitt Romney spoke on President Obama's most recent changes to immigration policy in an interview with Bob Schieffer.

headline: Norman Foster to Design Ballet School in Cuba
text: The British architect Norman Foster has been selected to design a new arts complex on the outskirts of Havana for the Cuban ballet star Carlos Acosta.

headline: Brief Notes From Hiding
text: I am, as I warned readers, in an undisclosed location actually being a human being for a few days. So blogging has suffered and will continue to suffer. But a couple of quick reactions to events transpiring these past couple of days:

headline: How Can a Big Gulp Look So Small?
text: This column appears in the June 24 issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: Preview: Germany vs. Greece
text: One of the most famous Monty Python sketches, featured on the Goal blog earlier this week is a simple soccer match between Germany and Greece entitled “International Philosophy.” The twist in this timeless gag is that the two squads are built with classical thinkers from both nations’ illustrious cultural past, as they do their best to not only beat each other in the game, but to outwit and out think their opponents.

headline: The Well Quiz: Supersize Soft Drinks
text: How skilled are you at judging serving sizes? Take this soda quiz, based on a test developed by marketing professor Pierre Chandon, to find out. Related Article »

headline: Ultra-Orthodox Men Charged With Trying to Silence Accuser
text: The Brooklyn district attorney, facing a wave of public criticism about his handling of sexual abuse allegations in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community, on Thursday charged four men with attempting to silence an accuser by offering her and her boyfriend a $500,000 bribe, and threatening her boyfriend’s business.

headline: A Darkening Jobs Picture
text: The jobs picture is darkening. The latest batch of economic data has been fairly weak, especially surveys from the manufacturing sector. As a result, The Times’s weekly jobs tracker, based on forecasts from Moody’s Analytics, now shows a projected employment gain of only 125,000 in June, down from a projection of 150,000 last week.

headline: New Faces for a Familiar Festival
text: My last visit to the Newport Folk Festival was 10 years ago, when Bob Dylan made his long-awaited return, bringing a heavy dose of mystique and a fainter trace of closure. He hadn’t played Newport since 1965 — the year Dylan Went Electric, as lore would have it, raising the stakes for rock ’n’ roll artistry and planting a stake in the heart of the folk revival. Of course the rift was never really that simple, and the reunion was no act of penitence. In 2002 Mr. Dylan showed up in a fake beard and a cowboy suit and, backed by his whip-smart band, played a proud, locomotive set.

headline: Google Aims to Smooth the Path for Android Developers
text: Android is the top operating system in mobile, but Android app developers don’t seem to be making much money compared to Apple iOS developers. New statistics reinforce this trend.

headline: New York Hot Spell
text: High temperatures marked the second day of summer in New York City.

headline: Yopparai
text: Inside the modest sake bar located in a repurposed Lower East Side railroad apartment.

headline: Sizzling Hybrid of Rhythms
text: Arty and wild-eyed impulses are both part of any bohemia worth its creative juice, and in Brooklyn they regularly connect in music. The Afro-Punk Festival, which reaches its 10th year this summer (after Tropical Storm Irene canceled what would have been a ninth appearance last year), loudly celebrates both sides of its hyphen, among other subcultural hybrids. Along with music, there are skateboarding and BMX biking competitions.

headline: Portrait of Bacon-Freud Back Up for Auction
text: LONDON — The e-mail blast was sent late last month. “An exciting new discovery at Christie’s,” read a statement from Francis Outred, the head of the postwar and contemporary art department in Europe for Christie’s. Mr. Outred was describing a 1964 painting by Francis Bacon, “Study for Self-Portrait,” which he said was the only full-length self-portrait to combine Bacon’s face with the body of his friend the painter Lucian Freud.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Gaza, Indonesia and Greece.

headline: A Sake Bar Best Taken in Small Sips
text: IT feels illicit, to be hovering here on the crumbly stoop of a Lower East Side tenement. Press the buzzer, and a voice, garbled, exacts your name. The doorknob clicks, and you blink a moment in the bright foyer, until a pocket door skids open and a figure in black, behind a curtain of ropes, beckons.

headline: In Magazine Interview, Curry Talks of Future on ‘Today’
text: Little more than a month ago, Ann Curry told a magazine interviewer that she saw herself spending the next five years on the “Today” show, where she was a news anchor for 14 years before becoming a co-host last year.

headline: The Truth Is Out There, but Maybe Not in Here
text: The novelist Edmund White has called biography “the most middle class of all forms, the judgment of little people avenging themselves on the great.”

headline: Cures for Blockbusteritis, Even in the Land of Hollywood
text: Each summer Hollywood swamps the country’s movie theaters with its biggest, often most blockheaded blockbusters, flooding thousands of screens with the usual loud bangs, broad laughs, high concepts, low returns, remakes, reboots and foolishly resurrected bad ideas. The summer can feel especially endless in Los Angeles, where I live, because the entire city and its environs — from car-clogged street to street, from looming billboard to billboard — transform into one continuous advertisement for new releases that you’re not sure you want to see but probably will (even if you don’t make a living watching them).

headline: Can Come Back
text: The German experimental-rock group Can has never been obscure. Though not quite a household name here in the States, Can recorded several European hits in the years they were together, 1968 to 1979. They have also had an impact on a diverse group of musicians, from David Bowie to Brian Eno to Radiohead, and pioneered whole styles of music that their followers later expanded upon. This week, Mute Records releases “The Lost Tapes,” a three-CD box set containing over 180 minutes of previously unissued material. More than a great listen, the set solidifies both Can’s oeuvre and their approach to music making as far-reaching influences.

headline: Romeos and Juliets
text: Three ballerinas are playing Juliet in Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet”.

headline: Street Hustlers, in All Their Glamour and Grit
text: In Paris in the mid-1950s the Swedish photographer Christer Strömholm (1918-2002) gravitated to the red-light district around the Place Blanche, where he was drawn to a subculture of cross-dressing young men, many of whom worked as prostitutes to earn enough money for sex-change operations. The stocky, middle-aged photographer with a beard and military haircut hung out with them for more than a decade and photographed them on the street at night and in bars and hotel rooms with a coolly affectionate eye.

headline: A Tool for Selecting the Best Cash-Back Credit Card
text: There are lots of cash-back credit cards out there, but it’s often difficult to know which one may work best for you, based on your personal spending patterns. Some cards offer initial bonuses, as well as rotating categories of purchases that can earn more cash back. So it’s hard to compare them without doing a lot of number-crunching.

headline: Chinese Dissident Artist Ends Yearlong Probation
text: BEIJING — Ai Weiwei, the Chinese rebel artist, said Thursday that his one-year probation had ended but that the police had told him he could not leave China because of continuing investigations.

headline: Leaving the Figure Behind
text: “Approaching Abstraction,” at the Rubin Museum, tries to put an Eastern phenomenon in a Western box. It doesn’t always work, but there’s much to be learned from the effort. It helps to let go of the Euro-American idea that abstraction is purely a formal phenomenon; in Indian modernism it can also be a rupture in narrative.

headline: Long-Missing Proposal Found Close to Home
text: A 1940s proposal for a children’s picture book turned up a few months ago in forgotten files in London, after scholars had spent decades hunting for it as far away as Iceland. The illustrator Eric Ravilious was finishing the images when he was killed in a Royal Air Force plane crash in 1942, at 39.

headline: The Times Co. Names 2 Directors, Including Joi Ito, Internet Entrepreneur
text: The New York Times Company, continuing its efforts to move forward in a more digitally focused news media industry, has added two members with extensive technology backgrounds to its board.

headline: The Shard and the NYT Tower
text: When the Olympic Games are off and running on TV next month, viewers are sure to see lots of shots of the Shard, which topped out recently. That’s the new London tower above, in a picture taken by the photographer Chris Levine for the magazine earlier this year. (In that same “London” issue the novelist China Miéville provided a word-picture equivalent: “The spine of the Shard soars over South London accumulating glass as if it’s in solution, growing crystals.”) When, as the BBC notes, you’ve got the tallest building in Western Europe — somewhere in Eastern Europe something looms taller, I guess — you can expect it to be the focus of much attention.

headline: At Season’s End, a Flourish and a Glimpse of What’s to Come
text: The last subscription program of the New York Philharmonic’s current season began Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, but it would be understandable if you had failed to notice it. Not to sell the program short — Alan Gilbert led as majestic a Mozart performance as anyone might want, with the kind of guests that would make cognoscenti sit up and take notice.

headline: Cellulite and 2nd Chances as the Stuff of a Revue
text: Step aside, all you apple-cheeked newspaper boys and American idiots, you little mermaids and littler orphans. The grown-ups have something to say. You may want to take some notes — and not just because you’ll be one of them soon enough.

headline: In ‘Men in Black 3,’ Court Street Is Dismissed
text: In May of last year, Court Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was transported back in time for a few days.

headline: So Sayeth the Anchorman
text: It’s not enough to be right; everyone else must be wrong.

headline: Look Up to the Heavens and Listen
text: As throngs of musicians and listeners, professional and amateur, looked forward to Make Music New York — an annual daylong, citywide celebration of the summer solstice on Thursday — the Hayden Planetarium, with its proprietary interest in the phenomenon, stole a march on Wednesday evening. Part of the American Museum of Natural History, the planetarium presented “Summer Solstice,” a collaboration between the Cassatt String Quartet and Carter Emmart, the museum’s director of astrovisualization and the wizard behind the curtain of the Digital Universe, the museum’s compilation of data gathered from astronomical catalogs and other sources.

headline: Kimmel Is Lifted to Late-Night Victory by N.B.A. Tie-Ins
text: ABC’s all-out commitment to pushing Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show during its coverage of the N.B.A. finals paid off last week with the best ratings for the show in five years, and a first: Mr. Kimmel topped both Jay Leno and David Letterman in the most important late-night ratings category.

headline: On Vacation and Sick? A Court Says Take Another
text: BRUSSELS — For most Europeans, almost nothing is more prized than their four to six weeks of guaranteed annual vacation leave. But it was not clear just how sacrosanct that time off was until Thursday, when Europe’s highest court ruled that workers who happened to get sick on vacation were legally entitled to take another vacation.

headline: Late-Night Drinks With a Pianist
text: A Little Night Music is the apt title for the Mostly Mozart Festival’s popular series of late-night programs in the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center. The success of this seemingly modest venture shows that it does not take much to freshen up the protocols of classical music and entice audiences. People sit at small round tables with complimentary wine, taking in starry views of the city. The programs begin at 10:30 and last about an hour. Audiences have relished the chance to hear a string quartet or a singer, a Baroque vocal group or a contemporary music ensemble, in this intimate, relaxed setting.

headline: Submerging in an Ocean of Sound
text: In a way, the New York Philharmonic’s “Philharmonic 360” program at the Park Avenue Armory is a classical music critic’s summer escapist fantasy: The orchestra, freed from the formal atmosphere and mediocre acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall, moves across town to the cavernous armory to present a program far quirkier and more adventurous than anything it does during the regular season.

headline: Song and Dance, and Gender, in ‘Dido’
text: The revival of Henry Purcell’s opera “Dido and Aeneas” at the Mostly Mozart Festival promises to be an arresting event, even for the blind: While the Mark Morris production occurs onstage, the extraordinary mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe, placed with the musicians, will sing the Sorceress, as well as Dido, with her large, dramatic, dark but mobile voice, which can sound like molten lava.

headline: Respectful Heirs Together Invoking Playful Spirits
text: When K T Sullivan swept onto the stage of the Laurie Beechman Theater on Wednesday evening with mischief in her eyes and a swivel in her hips, the image of Mae West flashed in my mind. Like West, Ms. Sullivan is voluptuous, blond and funny — and ageless. But Ms. Sullivan has a softer edge. Overt carnality is smothered in soap bubbles. Widening her saucer eyes and wearing a half-smile, a zany hat tilted just so, she projected an ebullient va-va-voom that camouflaged the vigilance of a performer on whom nothing is lost.

headline: Slaying With Silver in 19th-Century South
text: “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter” is such a smashing title it’s too bad someone had to spoil things by making a movie to go with it. Then again, a big-screen version of Seth Grahame-Smith’s comic novel was doubtless inevitable, given the delectable absurdity of the 16th president of the United States’ going all Buffy on a vamp army, splitting heads like rails. That sounds funny, and for a while it plays like head-exploding gangbusters on screen, particularly when the young Mr. Lincoln (a solid Benjamin Walker), in his grasshopper stage, begins learning how to swing a silver-tipped ax like a kung fu master. (As the great man said: “Whatever you are, be a good one.”)

headline: In Kampala, Classics Have Their Day in the Sun
text: Julia Mayersohn bravely and graciously attended numerous collector-car shows with Norman Mayersohn, her father and the deputy editor of the Automobiles section, while growing up in New Jersey. She lives and works in Kampala, Uganda.

headline: A Team’s Never-Ending Olympic Trials
text: Roman Catholics are supposed to hate the sin but love the sinner. Viewers can love sports and still hate the Olympics.

headline: Visions of the ’80s Storming Back
text: Nostalgia for the 1990s supplanted nostalgia for the ’80s a couple of years ago, but lately the tide’s been shifting back: Reagan in political discourse, shimmery dance music on the radio, the crack plotline on “Girls.”

headline: Q & A
text: Sponsor Withholds Maintenance

headline: Romney on Immigration at NALEO
text: Mitt Romney spoke on immigration at the NALEO conference in Florida.

headline: Increased Interest in Expanded HARP
text: MORE homeowners who are “underwater,” or owe more on their homes than they are worth, have been taking advantage of an expanded Home Affordable Refinance Program to refinance their loans and obtain lower interest rates, according to a recent government report.

headline: Krzyzewski Wouldn’t Mind if Finals Ended Tonight
text: DURHAM, N.C. – Count Mike Krzyzewski among the more interested observers in the remainder of the N.B.A. finals, which could end Thursday night, which would be just fine with Krzyzewski, the Duke coach. His rooting interest lies with neither Miami nor Oklahoma City, but more with time – time off, time to heal and time to prepare.

headline: Mitt Romney’s Positions on Immigration
text: A video feature examines how Mitt Romney has had to finesse his position on illegal immigration as he pivots towards the general election.

headline: Spare Times — For Children for June 22-29
text: FAMILY DAY

headline: For Teenage Heroes, Morphin’ Time Again
text: Every five years or so, a fad comes along that separates parents from their children but that, a decade or two later, those parents come to understand. “What is a Monkee, and why are you and your friends endlessly debating which one is coolest?” mothers and fathers all over the land were asking back in 1966. Yet before long, Monkees songs were turning up as elevator music.

headline: Excerpt: ‘As You Like It’
text: Lily Rabe and David Furr in a scene from the Shakespeare in the Park production at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: Moody’s Cuts Credit Ratings of 15 Big Banks
text: 10:33 p.m. | Updated Already grappling with weak profits and global economic turmoil, 15 major banks were hit with credit downgrades on Thursday that could do more damage to their bottom lines and further unsettle equity markets.

headline: Whisk Opens Another Cookware Shop
text: When creativity hits, cooking often provides release. Take Natasha Amott, who decided four years ago that working with finance in the nonprofit sector did not inspire her. So she opened Whisk, a cookware store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. On Friday, she’ll add a larger outlet in the Flatiron district that goes somewhat beyond the offerings in Brooklyn.

headline: Back Onstage, and Showing No Mercy
text: Hamminess, sloppiness, fatuity, inanity and, if we’re lucky, all-out insanity: such are the attributes that make a bad Broadway show so satisfying for people with a taste for turkey. In recent years mainstream New York theater certainly hasn’t been lacking in productions that embody those essential traits. And disaster cultists who train their sights on Broadway thank the New York theater for continuing to deliver such abundance.

headline: Time Machines, Always Cool
text: Fans of the modern “Doctor Who” — the fast-paced, high-tech, hyper-verbal science-fiction series that will begin its seventh season later this year — most likely know that the show has a long, storied and intensely codified history, stretching back 49 years and nearly 800 episodes. But if they’re American, the odds are good that they’ve never seen the show’s earlier incarnation, which ran on the BBC from 1963 to 1989.

headline: From 20 Critics, a Ticket to Summer
text: SUMMER sauntered in this week and it wants to play. What will make its desultory heart race, its toes tap, its synapses fire in the steamy idle hours that stretch ahead? What movie, what concert, what play, what book, what TV show, what dance, what high art or low comedy? We asked 20 arts critics for The New York Times to share the one thing on, or inspired by, the cultural calendar that they most looked forward to. Their answers — your guide to a summer of entertainment — are below.

headline: Lincoln Center Turns Dramatically Irish
text: The Lincoln Center Festival’s rich roster of theater offerings this year includes a couple of promising star turns: a one-man “Macbeth” starring Alan Cumming, and Cate Blanchett portraying the languid, dissatisfied Yelena in “Uncle Vanya.” But the production I’m most looking forward to is “DruidMurphy,” a cycle of three plays by the contemporary Irish writer Tom Murphy, presented by the Druid Theater Company of Galway.

headline: It’s Secretariat, Faster Today Than in 1973
text: Secretariat, the racehorse synonymous in most people’s minds with thoroughbred greatness, broke many records in his career. The latest fell only this week.

headline: 33 Acres of Privacy for $65 Million
text: WHAT could be better than a sprawling home in one of the Hamptons’ most exclusive enclaves on the banks of the tranquil Sagg Pond, with sweeping views of the ocean? What if that home sat on one of the largest parcels of privately owned land in the area — 33 acres to be exact — and was bordered by dozens of acres of protected land, ensuring privacy and pristine conditions in perpetuity?

headline: Artwork That Runs Like Clockwork
text: This summer the city that never sleeps will have another glimpse of an artwork that doesn’t relent much either: “The Clock,” a spellbinding, time-telling 24-hour wonder of film and sound montage by Christian Marclay, the polymath composer, collagist, video artist and pioneer turntablist.

headline: A Tenuous Coalition Government Takes Reins in Greece
text: ATHENS — Greece’s new coalition government, sworn in on Thursday, declared that its chief goals were “to tackle the crisis, pave the way for growth and revise the terms of the loan agreement without endangering the country’s European course and its position in the euro zone.”

headline: Online Sale Picks for June 21
text: Give your wallet a break this week and get ready to beat the Web shopping sharks for some great markdowns. Review our online and sample sale picks of the week.

headline: Politics as Performance, an Evolving Art
text: Artists have always blurred the lines among art, life and politics. Joseph Beuys planted thousands of trees as ecological sculpture. Gordon Matta-Clark stockpiled useless slivers of Manhattan real estate to illustrate the absurdity of property ownership. The tradition continues in the work of the Cuban-born artist Tania Bruguera, who has created the equivalent of a full-time performance piece called the Immigrant Movement International in Corona, Queens.

headline: Where Holograms Are Hopping Again
text: Holograms haven’t been cool for a long time. I’m old enough to remember when they were, at least to a 1980s kid raised on “Star Wars” and “Jem and the Holograms.” Somehow they’ve been left out of the great 3-D revival, confined to credit cards, scanners and other useful but dull items.

headline: Spare Times for June 22-29
text: LUMEN 2012 (Saturday) It wasn’t until February that Christopher Eamon, the curator of Lumen festival on Staten Island, knew that the mountains of salt weren’t going anywhere. This free festival, dedicated to video, interactive and performance art, is being held from 6 p.m. until midnight at the Atlantic Salt Company, which provides New York with road salt. This year’s mild winter meant the mounds didn’t budge. So Mr. Eamon and Melanie Cohn, executive director of the Council on the Arts and Humanities for Staten Island, the festival’s sponsor, decided to use the 150,000 tons of salt as a canvas. The biggest mound will serve as a screen for projections — Marco Brambilla’s re-creation of the lunar landing, and a neon salt digger courtesy of a Brooklyn artist, Jeanne Verdoux, who made the cut in a local open call. The others will be surrounded by performances and site-specific installations. “We’re going to shape the salt in various formations and do something like a salt Zen garden,” Mr. Eamon said via Skype on Tuesday.

headline: When Graphic Novelists Go Where Photographers Can’t
text: Sometimes circumstance dictates how we treat our articles visually. Often, for example, photography is not practicable for reasons of danger or an inability to capture past events. We’re then forced to find a solution that not only depicts a sense of place but also helps tell the story.

headline: Five Romeos and Five Juliets: Sweet Sorrow and Star Turns
text: “Star quality: I don’t know what it is, but I’ve got it.” The words are Noël Coward’s and “Star Quality” is the title of the marvelous Coward show at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. It is also epitomized by three international ballerinas performing next door at Lincoln Center as part of American Ballet Theater’s current season.

headline: Michelle Segre: ‘Lost Songs of the Filament’
text: Derek Eller Gallery

headline: Mark Boulos: ‘Projects 97’
text: Museum of Modern Art

text: Art
