text: Higher Pictures

headline: Dance Listings for June 22-29
text: Dance

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Twitter Vending Machine and Beyond Google Glasses
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. See more here.

headline: ‘From an Object’s Point of View’
text: Murray Guy

headline: ‘Animated by Spirits: Shields of New Guinea’
text: Cavin-Morris

headline: Zimmerman Interview With Detective
text: A day after George Zimmerman killed Trayvon Martin, he was interviewed on video by a detective.

headline: Classical Music and Opera Listings for June 22-29
text: Classical

headline: N.F.L. Retirees Ask A.F.L.-C.I.O. to Expel Players Union for ‘Moral Failures’
text: A group of retired N.F.L. players has asked that the players association be expelled from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for failing to represent the retirees’ interests.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 22-29
text: Jazz

headline: Pop Music Listings for June 22-29
text: Pop

headline: Developer to Revive a Project in Brooklyn
text: A planned $1.4 billion residential development at the Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn that was given up for dead last year took on new life on Thursday when a new developer signed a contract to buy the property.

headline: Movie Listings for June 22-29
text: Movies

headline: Putin Seeks to Reassure Foreign Investors
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — After a series of hard-line moves and statements after his re-election this spring, President Vladimir V. Putin softened his approach during a speech to foreign investors on Thursday.

headline: Theater Listings for June 22-29
text: Theater

headline: U.S. to Play at Mexico in August
text: It is called a friendly, but usually it is everything but when the United States and Mexico take up occupancy on the same soccer field.

headline: For Some Who Served, an Awful Betrayal of Trust
text: The documentary filmmaker Kirby Dick has become one of the indispensable muckrakers of American cinema, zeroing in on frequently painful stories about how power functions in the absence or failure of accountability. “Twist of Faith” (2004) was about a young man seeking some measure of justice after being sexually abused, as a child, by a priest. “This Film Is Not Yet Rated” (2006) focused on the secretive, often inexplicable workings of the Motion Picture Association of America’s ratings board. “Outrage” (2009) pointed a finger at the sexual hypocrisy of the political class.

headline: Designing a Synagogue for a Gay Congregation, With Acoustics in Mind
text: Since 1973, Congregation Beit Simchat Torah has tried to reconcile traditions transmitted across the millenniums with traditions that its members — gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Jews — have often had to make up on the fly, battling hostility, indifference and the AIDS epidemic at the same time.

headline: Romney’s Immigration Speech
text: Mitt Romney gave his big speech on immigration policy today and announced his big idea: He said the U.S. should offer a path to legal status for undocumented immigrants who were brought here as children by their parents.

headline: Different Ways of Looking at Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Steak and Pie From the Automat, Back Then
text: To the Editor:

headline: 47 Pit Bulls, Bred for Fighting, Are Rescued in the Bronx
text: Forty-seven pit bulls, bred for fighting, lived crammed in a basement-level apartment in the Bronx, the police said. They stayed in cages, some two to a cage, and, the police said, some of them might never have seen the sun before Thursday afternoon.

headline: Reading and Guilty Pleasure
text: As we move into the summer season of beach and hammock reading, many of us reach for books that we describe as “guilty pleasures.”  This notion has become an important category in our thinking about literature.  Two prominent examples are NPR’s regular feature “My Guilty Pleasure” and Arthur Krystal’s recent New Yorker essay, “Easy Writers: Guilty pleasures without guilt.”

headline: What Kind of Church?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stop-and-Frisk, Through the Prisms of Race and Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Risk of Concussions in Young Football Players
text: To the Editor:

headline: This Neck of the Woods, Please
text: FOR Nelson Aspen, only one neighborhood would do. His new place had to lie within a certain chunk of the Upper West Side — the West 60s or the low West 70s.

headline: Apocalypse? Road Trip!
text: If you are seeking a movie about the end of the world, you have a lot of choices. There are the sturdy, old, large-scale disaster epics, of course, but lately the trend has been toward more intimate studies of apocalypse, Lars von Trier’s “Melancholia” and Abel Ferrara’s “4:44 Last Day on Earth” being two notable recent examples.

headline: A Battle Over Faculty Housing
text: Princeton

headline: Deed Mutes Protest in Ridgefield
text: RIDGEFIELD

headline: Old Neighborhood, New Life
text: EMILY De NICOLO has lived in Manhattan for the last 14 years. But as she and her husband, Jay Della Monica, prepare for the arrival of their first child, in August, city life is looking more and more like a thing of the past. In fact, the couple are anticipating a future in Port Washington, Ms. De Nicolo’s childhood home.

headline: As Roomy as a Town House
text: ABOVE a side entrance to the Abingdon, a newly converted condominium building at 320 West 12th Street in the West Village, are carved the words “Laura Spelman Hall,” a reminder of the 1905 structure’s early life as a home for working women. It was later a nursing home, with beds for 200 residents.

headline: Changing the World, a Picture at a Time
text: A great passion fired up the Photo League, a group of mostly young New York photographers who, beginning in the 1930s and right up until the group’s abrupt end in 1951, believed that they could change the world with their cameras and the righteousness of their own beliefs. The group’s story — shaped by art and politics, some unexpected heroes and the period’s usual lineup of red-baiting villains — is the subject of “Ordinary Miracles: The Photo League’s New York,” an alternately stirring and stolid documentary directed by Daniel Allentuck and Nina Rosenblum, and narrated by Campbell Scott.

headline: ‘As You Like It’
text: Scenes from the Shakespeare in the Park production.

headline: A Delightfully Oddball Block
text: NOT all great New York blocks are end-to-end mansions. A case in point is the short stretch of West 75th between Broadway and West End Avenue, a curious mix of bedraggled row houses and spiffed-up town houses, of Tudor prewars and white brick apartment houses. If you need a big, fancy street, this isn’t it; in fact, it’s just the opposite.

headline: ‘Les Amies de Place Blanche’
text: Christer Strömholm’s photographs are the subject of a new show at the International Center of Photography.

headline: Ronaldo’s Latest Masterpiece Puts Portugal in Semifinals
text: WARSAW

headline: Hank Williams’s Swan Song
text: The urge to romanticize popular artists who die young is a powerful one, and movies about their all-too-brief lives are often buffered by their subjects’ lingering charisma and ardent fan bases. Such is the case with “The Last Ride,” Harry Thomason’s dreary imagining of the final days in the troubled life of Hank Williams, the music legend whose death on New Year’s Day 1953, at 29, has reverberated for more than half a century.

headline: New MSNBC Show Will Feature a Panel of Political Pundits
text: MSNBC’s plan for a new 3 p.m. program is illustrative of a cable news trend. It’s an ensemble show with a cast of four fresh-faced political pundits.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | The Seafood Shop
text: For 40 years, this Wainscott standby has offered some of the freshest fish on the East End. The Hamptons have changed — fewer fishing boats, more yachts — but the shop hasn’t much.

headline: Transgender Athlete Fails to Qualify
text: BEAVERTON, Ore. — Keelin Godsey, a 28-year-old from Massachusetts who was seeking to become the first openly transgender athlete to represent the United States at the Olympics, failed to qualify for the London Games in the women’s hammer throw competition held here Thursday.

headline: Taliban Attack Lakeside Resort Hotel Near Kabul, Taking Families Hostage
text: QARGHA LAKE, Afghanistan — As families ate a late dinner at a popular lakeside resort hotel here on a warm summer night, at least three Taliban shot their way into the compound, entered the dining room and took an unknown number of hostages, Afghan officials said early Friday.

headline: She’s Not His Mother
text: A damaged loner and a romantically hopeful virgin enjoy an unlikely bond in “Nate & Margaret,” Nathan Adloff’s tart-sweet tale of cross-generational friendship.

headline: The First Picture Show in a Tipperary Town
text: “Stella Days” opens with the last rites and closes with a first for a tiny rural parish in Tipperary, Ireland: a movie theater. In between boil all sorts of shenanigans, most of them in the vicinity of Father Daniel Barry (Martin Sheen), a well-traveled priest on loan from the Vatican. More progressive than his bishop or parishioners would like, the good father soon learns that electricity and enlightenment are to be equally distrusted.

headline: Should Air-Conditioning Go Global, or Be Rationed Away?
text: Is air-conditioning a modern-day right like clean water or the Internet, or an unsustainable luxury that we should give up or ration?

headline: Where Fishermen See Stars
text: WHERE, on the endless drive from New York City to the Hamptons, does the weekend really begin?

headline: Can You Say That on TV? Broadcasters Aren’t Sure
text: WASHINGTON — Imagine a world where it would be O.K. to use particularly foul language in an e-mail sent from your smartphone, but where you would be fined if you uttered the same words during a phone call.

headline: A.I.G. Installs New Chairman at Plane-Leasing Unit
text: The American International Group said on Thursday that it had named a new executive chairman of its plane-leasing unit, the International Lease Finance Corporation, following an investigation into a relationship between the division’s chief executive and another employee.

headline: Good News From Down Under
text: It will soon be much safer to be a fish in Australia, now that the country is planning to turn nearly one-third of its coastal waters into the world’s largest network of marine preserves. The plan would restrict fishing and oil and gas drilling in a patchwork totaling 1.2 million square miles, including the Coral Sea and the Great Barrier Reef.

headline: Spain’s Chief Justice Quits Over Claims of Misusing Public Money
text: MADRID — Spain’s image suffered another blow on Thursday when the chief justice of the Supreme Court resigned after being accused by a fellow judge of claiming vacations as business expenses.

headline: Imprisoned Over 20 Years, Brooklyn Man Gets Retrial
text: After spending more than two decades in prison saying he was not guilty of murder, a Brooklyn man won a new trial this week after an appellate court vacated his conviction based on evidence that another man might have committed the crime and that a key trial witness had recanted her testimony.

headline: Ex-Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Rape Charges
text: A former New York City police officer who was convicted in March of sexually attacking a schoolteacher at gunpoint in Upper Manhattan pleaded guilty on Thursday to rape counts that were left unresolved by a jury.

headline: To Settle Lawsuit, Facebook Alters Policy for Its Like Button
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Complicating its efforts to accelerate advertising revenue, Facebook has agreed to make it clear to users that when they click to like a product on Facebook, their names and photos can be used to plug the product. They will also be given a chance to decline the opportunity to be unpaid endorsers.

headline: Drug Kingpin’s Son Is Arrested in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — A man believed to be the son of Mexico’s most-wanted drug trafficker has been detained by the Mexican Navy, one of a series of recent moves aimed at toppling the elusive kingpin, Mexican officials said Thursday.

headline: A Walking Course in Tel Aviv’s Graffiti
text: Guy Sharett teaches Hebrew on the streets and alleys of the Florentin neighborhood of Tel Aviv, along the way deciphering a new vocabulary of politics, art and subculture scrawled on the walls.

headline: As Growth Ebbs, Brazil Powers Up Its Bulldozers
text: IPOJUCA, Brazil — More than 40,000 laborers swarm the port complex here in northeast Brazil, building a refinery for the state oil company. Five thousand others toil at a shipyard, another government-led project. Real estate prices are soaring and unemployment is falling in this region along the Atlantic coast, once known for its festering poverty.

headline: Learning Hebrew on the Streets, With Walls as Assigned Reading
text: TEL AVIV — The texts, written on metal grates, stone walls and neon signs, sometimes disappear from one class to the next. The themes are pluralism, economic justice and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict — and grammar, always a little grammar thrown in.

headline: Chief Justice Offers Hint at New Timing for Health Care Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday indicated that it is likely to go into overtime next week, as the nation awaits its decisions in challenges to President Obama’s health care law and a tough Arizona immigration law.

headline: Google Maps Where Your Workers Are
text: Workplace hooky, a hallowed tradition that put so many salesmen into movie matinees between customer calls, is so Web 1.0.

headline: Britain: A Historic Address
text: Myanmar’s opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, urged British leaders to support moves toward openness in her country as she became the first person who was not a head of state to address Parliament on Thursday. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi’s visit to Britain, where she once lived with her husband and children, was her first in more than two decades. She endured long periods of house arrest in Myanmar, or Burma, but refused to leave when she had the chance, fearing that she would be denied re-entry. “I am here in part to ask for practical help,” she said, addressing a hall packed with Britain’s political elite, “in support of the reforms which can bring better lives, greater opportunities, to the people of Burma who have been for so long deprived of their rights and their place in the world.” Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel laureate and now a lawmaker, also met with Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: With a Four-Under 66, Simpson Keeps Smiling
text: CROMWELL, Conn. — The sound of cheers reverberated Thursday from the first tee at T.P.C. River Highlands, where they greeted the marquee group of Keegan Bradley, Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson as they began the first round of the Travelers Championship.

headline: Billions of Dollars Are in Play Over Health Care Law
text: PEEKSKILL, N.Y. — In this small city about an hour from Manhattan, pregnant teenagers, laid-off professionals and day laborers without insurance receive care at a community health center that has been part of the social fabric here for nearly four decades.

headline: At Google’s Annual Meeting, Silence From Larry Page
text: Larry Page was missing in action Thursday at Google’s annual meeting because he had lost his voice. Eric Schmidt, the company’s former chief executive and now executive chairman, pinch-hit. Mr. Schmidt did not explain what happened but made clear it was serious enough that Mr. Page had already canceled his appearance at a major Google event for developers next week as well as on the company’s quarterly earnings conference call next month.

headline: Rangel Seeks to Minimize Any Concern About Age
text: Congressman Charles B. Rangel was celebrating his 82nd birthday, but he appeared eager not to look like an old man.

headline: Call Me, Pay Fee
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Sanctions Against Iran
text: It is disappointing but not surprising that two days of negotiations this week failed to produce any real progress toward curbing Iran’s nuclear program. Iran, always playing the angles, is still trying to figure out how much economic pain it is willing to accept to maintain its nuclear ambitions and what, if anything, it is willing to give up.

headline: Normal as Folk
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Customers Do the Selling for Travel Firms
text: PERHAPS not coincidentally in an era of interpersonal, often electronic communication, three travel brands have introduced campaigns based on the concept of a travel diary.

headline: Times Names 2 With Broad Technology Experience to Its Board
text: The New York Times Company, continuing its efforts to move forward in a more digitally focused news media industry, has added two members with extensive technology backgrounds to its board.

headline: Ratings Downgrade Cuts Deeply at Morgan Stanley
text: As Moody’s Investors Service prepared to cut the ratings of some of the world’s biggest financial firms on Thursday, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, was in St. Petersburg, Russia. He spoke to a group of business and economic leaders about how banks would have rethink their roles in an environment characterized by more regulation and falling profits.

headline: The Schadenfreude Sports Fan
text: Tough week. Blistering heat. Europe on the brink. The activist Supreme Court just days from possibly taking health care away from millions. And then, those diversions of lasting consequence on the court and on the pitch.

headline: Level of Music Label Power Is Debated in Senate Hearing
text: Is the music industry like other businesses, and thus subject to concerns about market concentration, or is it an anomaly in which nothing matters but hits?

headline: Death in the Desert
text: Watertown, Mass.

headline: California’s Trust Act
text: A bill moving through the California Legislature, aptly named the Trust Act, seeks to counter the damage done to community policing and public safety by the Obama administration’s Secure Communities program. The program conducts mandatory immigration checks of everyone booked into local jails and has led to the deportations of many thousands of people with no criminal records, while impeding law enforcement.

headline: Lottery Numbers
20 Years Later, a New World for the N.B.A.
text: MIAMI

headline: For Gatlin, Brash Talk and Renewed Confidence
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Much was made of the recent back-and-forth between the United States sprinter Justin Gatlin and the Jamaican star Usain Bolt. Their brief exchange of trash talk essentially boiled down to Gatlin saying he would happily “take charge” of bringing a challenge to Bolt, and Bolt saying: “I don’t want to sound rude or anything, but I think Gatlin had his chance. That’s a funny thing he said.” Bolt added that Gatlin “has a few guys to get past before he worries about me.”

headline: As Facebook Seeks Answers, S.E.C. Investigates Exchanges
text: Nasdaq has blamed Facebook’s botched debut last month on flawed computers and “technical errors.”

headline: Six-Year Sentence in Theft of Millions in Union Funds
text: By any measure, Melissa G. King lived an extraordinary life, one that far eclipsed her position administering benefit funds for the sandhogs’ union. She spent millions of dollars on herself, hiring a personal staff, buying expensive clothes and jewelry, and running up about $5 million in equestrian-related expenses, prosecutors have said.

headline: Fire Threat Up as Vintage Air Arsenal Shrinks
text: BROOMFIELD, Colo. — With a low roar, the 1954-vintage warplane barreled down the runway and heaved itself into the air, wobbling for a moment as its engines toiled to pull skyward. “They’re not exactly leaping off the runway,” said Paul Buxton-Carr, a Canadian pilot, as he watched the potbellied plane, designed to hunt submarines, climb toward its latest mission: dousing wildfires in the American West.

headline: Online Outrage Over Bullying of School Bus Monitor
text: Update | 11:55 a.m. Friday, June 22 More than $500,000 has now been raised online for a 68-year-old school bus monitor from Rochester, N.Y., after a cellphone video went viral this week, showing a group of seventh-grade boys on the school bus brutally mocking and taunting her.

headline: Democrats Seek New Reports on New Jersey Halfway Houses
text: Democrats in New Jersey’s Legislature called for stricter oversight of the state’s troubled system of halfway houses on Thursday, saying new disclosure requirements would lead to “better safety for our communities and the halfway house residents.”

headline: Union, on Heels of Wisconsin Recall Vote, Selects a New President
text: LOS ANGELES — Nearly 3,000 delegates from the nation’s largest union of state and local government employees gathered here this week. Judging from the talk on the convention floor, one would hardly know that they had experienced a huge defeat this month in their effort to recall Wisconsin’s governor, or that they faced lawmakers and voters across the country who have grown increasingly unsympathetic to public sector workers.

headline: U.S.O.C. Knits a Controversy
text: The United States Olympic Committee unintentionally offended thousands, if not millions, of people this week – and potentially dangerous people, too, considering they wield long, sharp sticks — when it sent a letter to a knitting Web site asking that it stop using the term ‘Ravelympics’ for a contest it planned to hold in conjunction with the London Olympics.

headline: NBC News Faces Shift in Television Dominance
text: NBC News has long been a dominant presence on network television, regularly winning the ratings competition against its evening news and Sunday morning political show competitors, and reveling in the “Today” show’s 16-year winning streak in morning television, a record not broken until April.

headline: Void for Vagueness
text: It is not so common these days to see a near-unanimous Supreme Court ruling on an issue like regulation of the airwaves, but the justices issued such an opinion on Thursday that sensibly said federal authorities were wrong to conclude that Fox Television and ABC had violated indecency standards for a couple of fleeting expletives and seven seconds of partial nudity.

headline: To Tackle an Invasive Weed, Bringing In the Hooved Pros
text: On a sweltering afternoon on Staten Island, the New York City parks department unveiled its latest weapon in the war on phragmites, an invasive weed that chokes the shoreline: goats. Twenty Anglo-Nubians, to be exact. With names like Mozart, Haydn and Van Goat, and with floppy ears and plaintive bleats, they did not seem fearsome. But on Thursday they were already munching inexorably through the long pale leaves in the first phase of a wetland restoration at what will soon be Freshkills Park.

headline: New Mexico Commission Limits Drug Use in Horse Racing
text: The New Mexico Racing Commission voted unanimously Thursday to limit the use of drugs in the state’s horse racing industry and to impose tougher penalties on those who run afoul of its drug rules.

headline: Romney Exhibits a Change in Tone on Immigration
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Mitt Romney struck a more conciliatory tone toward illegal immigrants on Thursday than he took during the Republican primary season, but he backed only limited steps to address the concerns of many Hispanic voters as he confronted one of the trickiest issues in his efforts to build a broad general election coalition.

headline: Four Seniors Look Beyond an Unlikely Run
text: With their underdog College World Series run over, their improbable dash to prominence completed, Stony Brook University’s baseball team came together one last time for the sake of a game.

headline: Prisons, Privatization, Patronage
text: Over the past few days, The New York Times has published several terrifying reports about New Jersey’s system of halfway houses — privately run adjuncts to the regular system of prisons. The series is a model of investigative reporting, which everyone should read. But it should also be seen in context. The horrors described are part of a broader pattern in which essential functions of government are being both privatized and degraded.

headline: Racial Tensions Flare Anew in a Texas Town
text: JASPER, Tex. — For more than 100 years, a rickety iron fence separated the black graves from the white ones at a cemetery in this East Texas town. Months after the brutal murder here of James Byrd Jr., a black man chained to a pickup truck and dragged to death by three white men on June 7, 1998, the fence was torn down by residents as a sign of unity and reconciliation.

headline: Central Park, a Forest of Ardor
text: The Public Theater celebrates 50 years of Shakespeare in the Park at the Delacorte Theater this summer. By all rights the city’s theater lovers should be showering the company with bouquets, and in a sense they do, day after day, summer after summer, snapping up the free tickets to this cherished New York institution whether the clouds threaten rain or the mosquitoes swarm.

headline: Gridded Display
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — The last time we encountered a puzzle by Josh Knapp he was lecturing us on all of the things we should not do (Across Lite, Solution, blog). As someone who runs with scissors on a regular basis, I enjoyed that one a lot. Today, we get to enjoy Mr. Knapp’s fourth outing as a constructor.

headline: Worker in Trench Dies in a Collapse
text: A 29-year-old worker was killed Thursday after being buried when a trench collapsed at a construction site on Staten Island, the authorities said.

headline: Insurers Seek to Soften Their Image, No Matter How Court Rules on Health Act
text: As the country waits to see how the Supreme Court will rule on the Affordable Care Act, health insurance companies are taking matters into their own hands.

headline: An Unlikely Incubator of Olympic Talent
text: MILPITAS, Calif. — The table tennis club was built by Indian immigrants who made their fortunes in Silicon Valley. Its coaches were imported from around the world. And its star players were born to immigrant parents from China and Taiwan.

headline: Yankees-Mets Tickets Available, Some at a Discount
text: The Mets have had a surprisingly good run so far this season. Despite a wave of injuries and some notable misadventures by their relievers, they are six games over .500 as the midway point of the season approaches and in second place in the National League East.

headline: Hospital Systems’ Merger Talks Collapse as New Suitor, Mount Sinai, Steps In
text: Merger talks between two of New York City’s biggest hospital systems — NYU Langone Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners — broke down abruptly on Thursday after Continuum got a competing offer, officials said.

headline: Commentary: Too Many Applications May Be a Crapshoot
text: For this week’s installment of The Choice on India Ink, we have an essay that sheds some light on the college admissions process in the United States. The author, Jordanna Suriani, is an admissions counselor at Ramapo College of New Jersey. — Tanya Caldwell

headline: New Meeting Is Set on Fate of President of University
text: The campaign for the reinstatement of Teresa Sullivan as the University of Virginia’s president took a giant step forward on Thursday as the governing Board of Visitors scheduled a special meeting for Tuesday to consider “possible changes in the terms of employment of the president,” the university announced.

headline: Wilhelm, Grandfather of Dickey’s Knuckleball, Once No-Hit Yankees
text: R. A. Dickey has been pitching with such profound dominance lately that when he digs his fingernails into the ball at Citi Field on Sunday night and stares in at Derek Jeter, it will be hard not to think back to what a predecessor of Dickey’s did 54 seasons ago.

headline: For the Ron Paul Wing, Now What?
text: Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul has admitted that he won’t have enough delegates at the Republican National Convention in Tampa in August to win the nomination.

headline: Elite Women Put a New Spin on an Old Debate
text: If a woman has a sterling résumé, a supportive husband who speaks fluent car pool and a nurturing boss who just happens to be one of the most powerful women in the world herself, who or what is to blame if Ms. Supposed-to-Have-It-All still cannot balance work and family?

headline: Jack Caulfield, Bearer of a Watergate Message, Dies at 83
text: Jack Caulfield, a former New York City police detective who died on Sunday in Vero Beach, Fla., at 83, was once a master of dirty tricks for the Nixon White House who had his biggest brush with history in the role of a messenger.

headline: Thoughts From New York on Rio+20
text: What do people in New York City have to say about the Rio+20 Earth Summit? We went to Midtown Manhattan to find out.

headline: Veterans Providing Intrigue at Draft
text: PITTSBURGH — Prospects and their families arrived here Thursday for the N.H.L. entry draft, but the league’s future stars are almost a sideshow. The real interest is in the 30 general managers, who are poised to make trades.

headline: Georgia: Satellite Dishes Seized
text: The authorities on Thursday raided companies connected to a billionaire opposition leader, Bidzina Ivanishvili, seizing a large number of satellite dishes being distributed at negligible cost to provide access to an opposition station just months before Mr. Ivanishvili’s party competes in parliamentary elections. The prosecutor general announced that the satellites were being seized temporarily as part of an investigation into Global Contact Consulting Ltd., a satellite television company in which Mr. Ivanishvili’s brother holds a majority stake. The dishes, the statement said, were being handed out to bribe voters; their seizure was approved by the Tbilisi City Court. Mr. Ivanishvili, whose net worth Forbes estimated at $6.2 billion, announced last October that he would finance an opposition movement against President Mikheil Saakashvili.

headline: Where the Money Has Gone
text: The federal government has distributed at least $13.7 billion to date to various government and private groups as part of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, the federal health care law passed in 2010.

headline: With Few Real Choices, Some Just Sit Out Vote
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: For Recent Attorneys General, Crisis Is the Norm
text: WASHINGTON — In the increasingly polarized world of brass-knuckle Washington politics, virtually every attorney general for the past generation has been swept up in a crisis that proved a major distraction and often a threat to their leadership.

headline: For State Senator From San Antonio, an Unexpected Rival in a Republican Runoff
text: Sleep is a precious commodity for Donna Campbell these days. Even as she seeks to unseat longtime State Senator Jeff Wentworth, Republican of San Antonio, much of her time is still devoted to her work as an emergency room physician. It is not unheard-of for Dr. Campbell to plow through a series of campaign events after finishing a shift at 6 a.m.

headline: Partisan Confrontation That Not All Wanted
text: WASHINGTON — For weeks, Republican leaders in and out of Washington adopted a go-slow approach to the brewing confrontation between the House and Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., worried that a blowup over the “Fast and Furious” scandal would detract from their central message of the 2012 campaign: jobs.

headline: Board Authorizes Rent Increases for Rent-Stabilized Apartments
text: The Rent Guidelines Board voted on Thursday to approve a rise in rents on rent-stabilized apartments in New York City, authorizing increases of up to 2 percent on one-year leases and 4 percent on two-year leases.

headline: Approving Billions in Cuts to Social Services, California Reaches a Budget Deal
text: LOS ANGELES — Just 10 days before the start of the new fiscal year, Gov. Jerry Brown and the Democratic-controlled Legislature reached a budget deal on Thursday to close a nearly $16 billion budget gap. The agreement came after days of negotiations, with legislative leaders reluctant to make the cuts that Governor Brown said were urgently needed.

headline: Fired Jasper Police Chief Is at Center of Divide
text: JASPER, Tex. — Three weeks after Rodney Pearson became Jasper County’s first black state highway patrolman, he responded to a call from the Jasper Country Club. As he pulled up to the clubhouse, his partner told him to wait.

headline: Louisiana Illegally Fired 7,500 Teachers, Judge Says
text: NEW ORLEANS — As much as some may wish otherwise, there is no starting from scratch when rebuilding a city, or a school system.

headline: Flipboard, Another Apple Darling, Expands to Android
text: Yet another app that was exclusive to Apple’s mobile devices is expanding to Google’s Android platform and elsewhere. What’s unusual in particular about this app, Flipboard, is that the company behind it was co-founded by a former Apple employee who worked on the iPhone.

headline: Texas Man Is Accused of Threatening Tennessee Mosque
text: A Texas man was indicted Thursday, accused of threatening to use violence to stop construction of a mosque that for two years has divided the community of Murfreesboro, Tenn., and has become a national barometer of anti-Muslim sentiment.

headline: LeBron James Leads Heat Past Thunder for N.B.A. Title
text: MIAMI — In one swift motion, packed with power, grace and symmetry, LeBron James grabbed a title and released his burdens, enjoying a coronation and liberation all at once. The audacious star with the “Chosen One” tattoo now has a trophy to validate the claim.

headline: Dalí Painting Stolen From Manhattan Gallery
text: The police are searching for a man who they say entered an art gallery on the Upper East Side on Tuesday, plucked a Salvador Dalí painting from one of its walls, stuffed it in a shopping bag and strolled out without anyone noticing.

headline: Indiana: Governor Will Lead Purdue
text: Gov. Mitch Daniels will be the next president of Purdue University, starting in January, when his term as governor ends, the university announced Thursday. The school’s trustees unanimously approved the appointment. Mr. Daniels, a Republican fiscal conservative who cannot run for a third term because of term limits, declined to run for president last year, and had been considered a possible running mate for Mitt Romney. But in a statement after the formal announcement of the Purdue job on Thursday, Mr. Daniels said that effective immediately, he would recuse himself from any partisan political activity. Purdue, a public university whose main campus is about an hour northwest of Indianapolis, enrolls about 75,000 students.

text: Action from the Heat-Thunder championship series, which Miami won with a 121-106 victory over Oklahoma City in Game 5 .

headline: When the President Comes to New York
text: President Obama has visited New York City 23 times since the start of his term. When he arrives, many New Yorkers’ plans are upended.

headline: UPDATE: Maharashtra Secretariat Fire
text: The big fire on Thursday afternoon that ravaged the six-story headquarters of the state government of Maharashtra in Mumbai has left four people dead and a dozen injured, according to a police official. The injured are being treated at Sir J.J. Hospital in southern Mumbai.

headline: Search Resumes for Survivors After Boat Capsizes Off Java
text: SYDNEY, Australia — An international search effort was under way on Friday to locate possible survivors from a fishing vessel carrying some 200 people believed to be seeking asylum in Australia after the boat capsized in rough seas south of the main Indonesian island of Java.

headline: Witnesses Describe Brazen Attack on Resort Hotel Near Kabul
text: QARGHA LAKE, Afghanistan — A minivan pulled up to the entryway of the Spozhmai Hotel just before midnight on Thursday, and what appeared to be seven Afghan women in characteristic head-to-toe blue burqas piled out.

text: 6:48 a.m. | Updated

headline: Food Pouches: Healthy Solution, or Convenient Cop-Out?
text: WHAT relatively new innovation is eliminating some challenges that arise when parents try to feed their babies or toddlers?WHAT are the writer’s specific concerns about his children’s use of this innovation?

headline: Bringing Photographs of War to the Brooklyn Waterfront
text: Tyler Hicks traveled with Northern Alliance troops as they captured Kabul, Afghanistan, from the Taliban, in November 2001. Joao Silva photographed the Mahdi Army in Najaf, in 2004, as they fought street by street against the United States military. Michael Kamber returned to Iraq in December 2011 as the United States began removing its last combat troops.

headline: Pakistani Parliament Elects New Prime Minister
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Parliament elected a new prime minister on Friday in a dignified ceremony that contrasted with the back-room intrigue of the preceding days and that offered at least a brief interlude in the wider struggle between President Asif Ali Zardari and the senior judiciary.

headline: At Trial’s End, Lawyers Say Norway Killer Is Not Insane
text: OSLO — The trial of Anders Behring Breivik ended on Friday with an unusual reversal of roles, as defense lawyers insisted that he was sane when he killed 77 people last year and should be sentenced to prison, and prosecutors arguing that he was mentally ill and thus not criminally responsible, and should be hospitalized instead.

headline: What the Most Successful Parents Do Before Breakfast
text: Years ago, when I was writing a book on time management, a first year legal associate who was the mother of a 2-year-old asked me to look at her schedule. She wanted to spend more time with her daughter during the week. The problem? She frequently had to work into the evening. She pushed back when she could, but as a new hire, she didn’t have much control over her hours, and she seldom got home long before her daughter went to bed.

headline: An Unlikely Incubator of Olympic Talent
text: “The table tennis club was built by Indian immigrants who made their fortunes in Silicon Valley,” Somini Sengupta wrote in The New York Times. “Its coaches were imported from around the world.” And its star players were born to “immigrant parents from China and Taiwan,” Ms. Sengupta wrote.

headline: Checkpoint Jitters
text: Jabaa Checkpoint, West Bank — Every day, at hundreds of checkpoints throughout the West Bank, Palestinians are stopped and made to wait, often for a long while, before they are let through. Last week I was halted at the Jabaa checkpoint on my way from my home in Ramallah to dinner at a friend’s house in Bethlehem.

headline: How to Help Aparna and Girls Like Her
text: The India Ink article, “Meet Aparna, Mumbai’s Teenage Sex Educator,” inspired many among our readers to write and leave comments on the piece, asking how they could help Aparna to fulfill her dream of becoming a gynecologist.

headline: In the Hospital, but Not Really a Patient
text: On Labor Day weekend in 2009, Miriam Nyman, 83, arrived by ambulance at Rhode Island Hospital. She’d fallen, a result of a degenerative brain disorder, and broken her neck. She and her daughter, Tamar Lasky, waited in the emergency room for eight hours until finally, close to midnight, Dr. Lasky needed to go home to sleep.

headline: Awaiting the Supreme Court’s Health Care Ruling
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: U.P.S. Is to Put 150 Plastic-Body Trucks Into Service
text: After a yearlong field test in five regions, United Parcel Service has ordered the production of 150 delivery trucks with bodies built of composite plastic panels. The company said that relative to the aluminum-bodied P70 package car, as the company’s equivalent vehicle is known, each plastic-body truck would lower fuel consumption by 40 percent.

headline: 20 Years Later, Agassi Recalls Ecstasy and Agony of Victory
text: Has it really been 20 years since Andre Agassi won Wimbledon, since he rose above the external critics and internal monologue with his long, faux-blond hair streaming out of the back of his cap?

headline: Cambodia Ambiguous on Plans for French Architect
text: HONG KONG — Cambodia’s Foreign Ministry said Friday that the country had no plans to extradite to China or France a detained French architect with links to a disgraced Chinese politician and his wife, but that the architect was not yet being set free, either.

headline: When My Crazy Father Actually Lost His Mind
text: We were on something like the 15th round of rummy, and my father was winning decisively. He cracked a wide, toothy grin as he laid his cards on the table. “That’s 321 for BaBa, and 227 for String Bean,” he said, tallying the ledger we were keeping on a piece of scrap paper.

headline: The Best and Brightest
text: IT’S the fashion equivalent of a Lotto hit. A single item from a designer’s collection catches the public’s fancy and blows up. There is a sound of rejoicing along Seventh Avenue as cash registers go ka-ching. (Well, cash registers are now mainly digital and hushed, but you get the idea.)

headline: Rio+20: The View from Manhattan
text: This week we hit the streets of Manhattan to talk to the public about Rio+20, the three-day environmental conference that opened on Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro. We wanted to gauge public awareness of the event and solicit views on whether developing nations should pursue economic growth in an environmentally sustainable way.

headline: Devil’s Advocate: Breivik Lawyer Defends Rule of Law
text: LONDON — Geir Lippestad, the Norwegian defense lawyer in the Anders Breivik trial ending on Friday, feels his soul has been on loan in the almost year-long case but he hopes to get it back intact.

headline: America Movil Spends $1.59 Billion to Lift Stake in KPN
text: América Móvil, the Mexican mobile operator owned by the billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, extended its foothold in Europe after paying 1.27 billion euros, or $1.59 billion, to increase its stake in the Dutch telecommunications company KPN to 20.9 percent.

headline: Dueling Economic Messages From Romney and Republican Governors
text: Mitt Romney is on a collision course — not just with President Obama, but also with Republican governors in several important swing states.

headline: Daily Report: To Settle Lawsuit, Facebook Changes Policy for Its Like Button
text: Facebook has agreed to make it clear to users that when they click to like a product on Facebook, their names and photos can be used to plug the product, reports Somini Sengupta in Friday’s New York Times. They will also be given a chance to decline the opportunity to be unpaid endorsers.
