headline: Seven Tips for Better Fireworks Photos
text: Part of the beauty of fireworks is their impermanence. They are a momentary flash of beauty that fades to a memory. Unless, perhaps, you know the tricks of photographing fireworks.

headline: Calculating ‘House Effects’ of Polling Firms
text: One of the ways that our forecast model seeks to make polling data more robust is by calculating and adjusting for “house effects,” which are systematic tendencies for polling firms to favor either the Democratic or Republican candidate.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Gentle Introduction to Augmented Reality
text: This week’s column was about augmented reality apps and their powers of helping you find your way around, or even to learn odd or fascinating data about the world nearby. The many A.R. apps out there are powerful, possibly a bit daunting, and they require you to spin on the spot with your smartphone outstretched.

headline: Leaving the Figure Behind
text: “‘Approaching Abstraction,’ at the Rubin Museum, tries to put an Eastern phenomenon in a Western box,” Karen Rosenberg wrote in The New York Times. “It doesn’t always work, but there’s much to be learned from the effort.”

headline: For Top Athletes, the Side Order They Can’t Give Up
text: EUGENE, Ore. – Forget quinoa or lentils: Is it possible that bacon is the secret super food for the top United States athletes?

headline: Politico Suspends Reporter Over Romney Comments
text: Politico, the Web site devoted to covering all facets of the political news cycle, said late on Thursday that it had suspended one of its White House reporters for making numerous disparaging and vulgar comments about Mitt Romney.

headline: Paris Does Brooklyn
text: Growing up in the Paris suburbs, David Obadia, 23, was obsessed with Nike Air Jordans and the American street-wear brands Supreme and Stussy. Meanwhile, his best friend, Nelson Hassan, 22, was more drawn to the avant-garde looks of Comme des Garçons and Raf Simons. No wonder, then, that upon graduation from business school and fashion school, respectively, the duo started their own label, Brooklyn We Go Hard, named for the Jay-Z song. “We like everything about Brooklyn, including Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Dr. Brown’s soda and the Nets,” Obadia explains. (He assures that they’ve both been there several times.) “Brooklyn brings together the mainstream and the underground, which is what we want to do with the clothes.” They started in 2010 selling simple white T-shirts embossed with gritty images of New York taken by a handful of Paris photographers, but they gained steam last year when they introduced an elbow-padded sweatshirt (about $140), soft cotton on the inside and nubby wool on the outside, with the motto “Brooklyn Parle Français” embroidered across the chest. The sweatshirt got picked up by Colette in Paris, Antonioli in Milan, Urban Research in Tokyo and Opening Ceremony in the United States, and has been worn by the likes of Kid Cudi, who sported it at the “Hunger Games” premiere, as well as Olivier Nakache, the director of the recent French box-office record-breaker “Les Intouchables.” (“Can you help us get the sweatshirt on Jay-Z or anyone from the Nets?” Hassan asks.) Later this month, they’ll show their first full collection at the Paris men’s Capsule show; the collection includes pieces that would look right at home on the lazily fashionable young men of Bedford Avenue, including chambray shirts with baseball stripes ($100) and reversible cotton knit sweaters that droop on a skinny torso as raffishly as a cigarette from the lips of a Marais bobo ($164). The guys are making the clothes in conjunction with a magazine they publish that, in charmingly bad English, helps foreigners understand such Brooklyn characters as boricuas and Lubavitchers. “People in Paris want to be in New York and Tokyo, and vice versa and vice versa,” Obadia says. “Everybody doesn’t want to be where they are.”

headline: Having It All
text: Anne-Marie Slaughter’s long Atlantic essay on work-life balance, “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” is a striking mix of important truth and wishful thinking. The important truth is that there really is more than our society could do to help women (and men) balance their careers and their family lives. Both our workplaces and our public policy arrangements have not kept up with the decline of the single-breadwinner household, and an era of massive female labor force participation requires greater accommodations and adjustments to the reality of childbearing than American society has yet made.

headline: Listmania: Top 10 U.S. (Small- to Midsize) Soccer Cities
text: If there were ever doubts that soccer in the United States has found a home far beyond the big urban centers, a new survey released by Livability.com seems to put them to rest.

headline: Artist Not Happy After Jewish Museum Takes Down His Work
text: A decision by the Jewish Museum to remove a photographic installation from an exhibition about the politics of sex and desire has drawn criticism from the artist who created the work.

headline: Now That a Disclosure Bill Is Passed, What's Next?
text: Now that the legislative battle over disclosure of teacher evaluation data is over, what does the future look like? Some of the coverage of Albany's vote on the controversial bill, which would allow only parents to see the data related to their children's teachers, speculated that a fair amount of chaos lies ahead.

headline: Showdown in Egypt Escalates in Fight for Power
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers and the Muslim Brotherhood escalated their confrontation on Friday as the generals threatened to use “the utmost firmness” to preserve their authority and the Islamists presented a reunited front with some of their former allies from the revolt against Hosni Mubarak.

headline: DuPont Facing 30,000 Claims for Tree Deaths
text: A year after it became clear that a new and highly touted lawn herbicide called Imprelis was killing and damaging many thousands of trees around the country, the manufacturer, DuPont, is busy processing claims for compensation.

headline: Rangers Could Pursue Jordan Staal
text: PITTSBURGH–Add a new name to the Rangers’ wish list: Pittsburgh center Jordan Staal.

headline: Tata Wins Land Appeal, Deals Blow to Mamata Banerjee
Savoring Human Nature in Random Flux
text: ANDRÉ TÉCHINÉ, who turns 70 next year, makes impossibly elegant movies about very messy lives. All the people in his films are in one way or another wanderers, existential transients drifting from relationship to relationship, identity to identity, unable somehow to settle into themselves, and that’s just the way Mr. Téchiné likes them. Movies like “Wild Reeds” (1994), “Thieves” (1996), “The Girl on the Train” (2009) and the new “Unforgivable” — his 19th feature, opening Friday — are filled with characters who seem not to have been created but simply found, strays picked up off the street. He offers them a place to rest while they, and he, try to figure out who they are and where they’re going: the house is rambling but beautifully appointed, and the host is gracious, tolerant, tactful. At this point Mr. Téchiné has been putting up lost souls for nearly 40 years; he knows what he’s doing.

headline: How to Escape a Lowly Socioeconomic Class: Go to College
text: The latest installment in our Is College Worth It? series comes courtesy of the Treasury Department, which on Thursday released a report titled “The Economic Case for Higher Education.”

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Esquire: Apparently canned beer is gearing up for a comeback …

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: On ‘Having It All’ (or Some), and Cracks at NBC News
text: 11:38 a.m. | Updated An article in The Atlantic just posted online has renewed an intense discussion among women about how best – and whether – to balance family and career, Jodi Kantor writes. It is a discussion, admittedly, among elite women who are at the top of their fields, including the comedian Tina Fey, the Facebook executive Sheryl Sandberg and the author of the Atlantic article, Anne-Marie Slaughter, a Princeton professor who recently left a job at the State Department. The pace of the arguments about the article, “Why Women Still Can’t Have It All,” reflects the Internet age, Ms. Kantor writes:

headline: Live Coverage Friday of Germany vs. Greece
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 game between Germany and Greece on Friday at 2:45 PM ET. Jack Bell will offer commentary and analysis of the quarterfinal match.

headline: Take One Critic, Add Mud, Mix
text: When TNT announced that it would be rolling out its first attempt at reality television, a competition show called “The Great Escape,” starting Sunday, it seemed as if it might be an opportunity to explore two long-standing questions I’ve had about the genre: Are these competitions real, and, more important, could I do this stuff? My editor felt the same way, especially about Question 2, since she’s a bit of an “Amazing Race” addict. So the two of us asked TNT and the creators of the show, Elise Doganieri and Bertram van Munster (who are also behind “The Amazing Race”), if we might come to a shooting location for “The Great Escape” and try out the course.

headline: Innocent Abroad
text: Alan Furst’s Web site lists his current residence as Sag Harbor, Long Island. But, as legions of readers know, Furst obviously dwells in another time and place, somewhere between Paris and the Carpathian Mountains, sometime between the blindly tragic years of 1933 and 1941, when the world, as he says in an earlier book, “drifted idly toward blood and fire.”

headline: New York Mandates Alerts on Sewage Discharges
text: People in New York State will be notified within hours if sewage has been discharged into a waterway under a bill approved on Thursday that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to sign into law.

headline: Traitor, Martyr, Liberator
text: Joseph Conrad wasn’t the only literary European who traveled through the Congo basin during the 19th-century rush to harvest the region’s ivory, animal hides, minerals and especially its “black gold” — the liquid latex that welled in its rubber trees. While journeying by caravan to Léopoldville in 1890 to take charge of the merchant ship Le Roi des Belges, Conrad met Roger Casement, a handsome 25-year-old Irish do-­gooder who had lived and worked in the Congo Free State for the past few years. Like Conrad, Casement had come to Africa buoyed by the conviction that European colonization would bring moral and social progress to the continent and free its inhabitants “from slavery, paganism and other barbarities.” Each man would soon learn the gravity of his error.

headline: Members of the Wedding
text: “Seating Arrangements,” Maggie Shipstead’s smart and frothy debut novel, is set on a perfect John Cheever island — the kind where old-money families gather to drink gin and nurture loyalties. Beneath the surface of this summery romp, however, lie animosities, well-paced sexual suspense and a clash between appearances and authenticity.

headline: Seeking Susan
text: When she was 13, Susan Sontag “made a rule”: “No daydreaming.” The habit of idle reflection, to most writers part of the job, seemed to her not so much a waste of time as a threat to stability: “Being intelligent isn’t, for me, like doing something ‘better,’ ” she confided to her journal in 1973. “It’s the only way I exist. If I’m not [being] intelligent, I hover near being catatonic.”

headline: You Can’t Say That
text: The United States is almost alone among Western liberal democracies in not punishing what is called hate speech — oral or written messages that “incite hatred” against a person or group on the basis of their race, religion, sex, ethnicity or sexual orientation. Canada, Britain, Denmark, Germany and New Zealand have such laws, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights purports to require signatory nations to pass them. In the American constitutional tradition, by contrast, even detestable speech is permitted so long as the speaker does not threaten violence or incite others to it. The Supreme Court’s recent decision upholding the right of the Westboro Baptist Church to engage in hateful picketing of military funerals in opposition to toleration of homosexuality (“God Hates Fags,” one sign said) is a ready example. That case would almost certainly have come out differently in other liberal democracies.

headline: Boiler Rooms
text: Robert J. Shiller made his name in 2000 with “Irrational Exuberance,” a book that drew on behavioral economics to explain why financial markets overshoot. Shiller concentrated on the boom-bust cycle in technology stocks, but a later edition published while real estate was taking off correctly anticipated the popping of that bubble, too. With his latest volume, “Finance and the Good Society,” Shiller is coming at us from the opposite direction. Quoting Walt Whitman, who found “the eternal meanings” in muscular commerce, he celebrates finance’s “genuine beauty” and exhorts idealistic young students to pursue careers in derivatives, insurance and related fields.

headline: ‘Were We All People?’
text: One man volunteered for Ausch­witz, and now we have his story. In September 1940 the 39-year-old Polish cavalry officer Witold Pilecki deliberately walked into a German roundup in Warsaw, and was sent by train to the new German camp. His astounding choice was made within, and for, Poland’s anti-Nazi underground.

headline: Talking Head
text: “How to Build an Android” is the honest title of an earnest book, the first by David F. Dufty, a senior research officer at the Australian Bureau of Statistics. It explains how a team of researchers at the University of Memphis collaborated in 2005 with an artist and robotics expert, David Hanson, to create what was then the most sophisticated android anywhere, a replica of the science-fiction writer Philip K. Dick.

headline: Egypt’s Quantum Entanglement
text: CAIRO — In the famous thought experiment by the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrodinger, a cat that is placed in a box, alongside a radioactive element whose decay will trigger the release of a deadly poison, is said to be at once alive and dead. According to the laws of quantum physics there is an equal chance that the radioactive element will decay and that it won’t. Thus Schrodinger posited that until the box is opened and the cat’s state observed, the animal is theoretically in a state where both possibilities co-exist.

headline: The Great Mediocrity
text: Slender volumes on hefty topics have a natural appeal. Who would not like to master a complex subject in the space of a single afternoon? Yet small books on big things can also have their built-in hazards, as they run the risks of neglecting nuance and precision and ignoring valuable details. While it certainly offers numerous insights into Adolf Hitler and the wider context that made his monstrous career possible, A. N. Wilson’s “Hitler” ultimately falls short as a satisfactory substitute for something more substantial.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: WHEN CAPTAIN FLINT WAS STILL A GOOD MAN  By Nick Dybek.  Riverhead, $26.95.

headline: The Dependents
text: While visiting the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, England, two Pakistani immigrants happen upon the Meridian Line. Harris, the central character in Rosie Dastgir’s first novel, points it out excitedly to his date. “Look!” he exclaims. “I have one foot in the Eastern Hemisphere and one in the West — at the same time. This is us, Farrah, isn’t it? Eastern Westerners.”

headline: Child of God
text: “There is a world in my room,” says Judith McPherson, the mother­less 10-year-old narrator of Grace McCleen’s first novel, “The Land of Decoration.” “It is made from things no one else wanted and it is made with things that were my mother’s, that she left to me.” The world is Judith’s miniature re‑creation of the land of milk and honey that she believes will come after Armageddon. Touchingly, it is just a cleaned-up version of her working-class neighborhood, comprising tiny gardens and snowmen and clay model figures on which she eventually enacts a shameful voodoo. It’s no wonder Judith spends all day in her room. She is abnormally isolated — constrained by her father’s religious fundamentalism, which dictates that she sit out school assemblies and accept as her social circle the motley members of her church group, with whom she wanders through town trying to evangelize. Judith considers all of this within the range of normal. Only when she becomes the target of the class bully does the imminence of the End seem personal, and acute.

headline: Up Front
text: “My relationship to the gay rights movement has been decidedly mixed,” said Rich Benjamin, who this week reviews Linda Hirshman’s “Victory,” a history of the movement. “I’m not an activist by nature. I’ve never been totally in the closet, but until recently I’d never been ‘out.’ I’m a fan of secrets. The less people know about me the better I can maneuver. There’s a beauty to mystery, to conversation, to discovery, to the exquisite pastimes through which people do a tango of distance and intimacy. And secrets are power.

headline: Inside the List
text: GUEST BOOK: Dorothea Benton Frank’s homey novels about family life in South Carolina’s Lowcountry — her latest, “Porch Lights,” hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 5 — are the kind you’re apt to discover on the bookshelf of a rented beach house, their swollen pages foxed and mildewed and maybe marked with a ring of vegetable oil, since Frank’s Web site provides recipes for her characters’ meals. (Grilled chicken, fried bananas, lots of seafood.)

headline: A French Jester Who Trades in Hate
text: PARIS

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BARACK OBAMA: The Story,  by David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $32.50.) This huge and absorbing new biography, full of previously unexplored detail, shows that Obama’s saga is more surprising and gripping than the version we’re familiar with.

headline: Paperback Row
text: TRAIN DREAMS,  by Denis Johnson. (Picador, $12.) The taming of the American West is encompassed in Johnson’s novella. Sent by train into the woods of the Idaho panhandle in the 1890s, his orphaned hero, Robert Grainier, works on logging gangs, falls in love and loses his wife and daughter to a devastating wildfire. “What Johnson builds from the ashes of Grainier’s life is a tender, lonesome and riveting story,” Anthony Doerr wrote here.

headline: From This Day Forward
text: “When gay people everywhere can marry, will that mean the end of gay literature?” I was regularly asked this question last spring while on tour for my most recent book, an account of how novels and plays in the years after World War II shook up sexual attitudes. This was months before President Obama announced his support for gay marriage; the subject was already very much out there.

headline: Polls Shift Into the Swings of Summer
text: With summer here, accompanied by the heat, fireflies and the aromas of food on the grill, we can also expect volatility in the polls.

headline: The Scarlet Diary
text: On Nov. 15, 1850, 37-year-old Isabella Robinson went to a party in Edinburgh where she was introduced to Edward Lane. Later she noted in her diary that he was “handsome” and “fascinating,” the first of many entries describing her feelings for Lane, a married medical student 10 years her junior.

headline: Business Day Live | June 22, 2012
text: Ratings agency deals a blow to 15 major banks. | The Georgia town that took its public services private. | Colorado's governor on the economic toll of battling wildfires.

headline: Mike Trout, the Angels’ Prodigy, Is Enjoying the Ride
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Mike Trout is a humble, clean-shaven baseball prodigy from a small town in southern New Jersey. He works at Angel Stadium, three and a half miles from places called Fantasyland, Tomorrowland and Main Street, U.S.A. His story springs from all of them.

headline: 50 Shades of Mad Men
text: “You can have one girlfriend or three,” my divorced father once told me, offering advice, as usual, that only applied to him. “But never two. When two girlfriends find out about each other, you’ve got trouble.” Presumably two girlfriends would gouge each other’s eyes out, whereas three girlfriends might unpack a picnic lunch of tea sandwiches and cherry wine, lovingly braid one another’s hair and then fall asleep in the sun.

headline: To Tell or Not to Tell
text: My mother has been having memory issues for a number of years. Her neurologist has been telling her it is “mild dementia.” Her cognitive impairment and memory loss have worsened, and I recently met the neurologist without her. He told me that she has Alzheimer’s. He felt we should not yet tell my mother, as that diagnosis has been her greatest fear and it would be too devastating. He felt we could not tell my father unless we told my mother. I am uncomfortable keeping this terrible secret. Is it better to tell a loved one of the prognosis they fear, or is it more ethical to let them live in hopes that they have escaped it? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Who Made That Cubicle?
text: Imagine yourself in a typing pool in the early 1960s, amid the clack-clack-clack-PING of dozens of Smith-Coronas. You’re out in the open, like a factory worker, with nowhere to hide from the raking gaze of the boss.

headline: The 6.10.12 Issue
text: PREP-SCHOOL PREDATORS

headline: Our Lady of Contraception
text: After you testified before House Democrats in February about the limited contraceptive coverage in Georgetown University’s insurance plan, Rush Limbaugh referred to you as a “slut” on his radio show. He said you were “having so much sex” that you couldn’t afford all the birth-control pills you needed. Do you suppose he doesn’t understand how the pill works?  It does seem to make a case for comprehensive sex education, doesn’t it? Actually, what I’ve learned has less to do with Mr. Limbaugh specifically and more to do with a part of our population that has this view. Because frankly, you don’t go on national radio and talk for several days about something that no one wants to hear. There’s an audience for this type of sexist vitriol. There is real hate and sexism within our society that we have to do something about.

headline: Looted for Love
text: I grew up in the East Village, in New York City, surrounded by art. Most of it was contemporary, but there was one piece that was old — really old. It was a fragment of an ancient marble column, and we used it as a doorstop. I’d never seen marble like that outside of the Metropolitan Museum — marble that changed color with the time of day, almost as if it were blushing. After looking at the marble for 30 years, I finally asked where it was from.

headline: Sweets and Studios in Kyoto
text: Artists and artisans are spurring a revival in a neighborhood that’s fallen off the tourist maps.

headline: Horace Mann Abuse Article Plays Loose
text: The New York Times Sunday Magazine article on abuse by teachers at Horace Mann School (“Prep-School Predators,” June 10, 2012) was a highly unusual artifact of journalism, a journey into a black hole of a kind.

headline: France, and the World, Drinks More Pink
text: PARIS–High-end Bordeaux and Burgundy may be all the rage in the new wine-drinking markets of Asia, especially China. Back home in France, the star of the wine scene is rosé.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Linda Hirshman talks about “Victory,” her history of the gay rights movement; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Lawrence Downes discusses the android Philip K. Dick; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: 3 Orchestras With a Sound To Fit the Space
text: FOR the planners and builders of the Park Avenue Armory, the landmark structure that consumes a city block, bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues and 66th and 67th Streets, music was surely not among the chief concerns. Completed in 1881, the armory was intended to serve as a military installation and social club for the Seventh Regiment of the New York National Guard.

headline: Cuteness: Another Word for Evil
text: With “Ted” coming to theaters, a look at some other twisted walking, talking plushies on the screen.

headline: It’s All Over Now. Or Is It?
text: Perhaps, in the end, the Heat's N.B.A. championship will bring greater relief to everyone else than even to LeBron James himself. Because while yes, even James's superteam shortcut of sorts to the championship that would make his nickname sound fitting instead of ridiculous was harder than he expected, it was taxing for all sides. For the anti-James camp, it took energy to maintain a proper level of antipathy, when every missed fourth-quarter free throw or highlight-quality dunk qualifies as news in the James-obsessed N.B.A. Meanwhile, his defenders shouted themselves hoarse trying to drown out the detractors, especially with the Heat's tendency -- until the finals at least -- to make everything more difficult than it probably needed to be. And even those who sat back and considered "As LeBron Turns" to be a mostly fascinating nightly pschyodrama, it got rather exhausting. We worked overtime playing the role of his therapist and now we need a vacation.

headline: Dispatches from Rio and Nepal: Knife Fights Over Firewood
text: In the final hours of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development in Rio de Janeiro, a reverberating theme has been “sustainable energy for all” — a push catalyzed by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon in a stump speech on energy poverty that he has delivered many times over the past year. The most effective lines in these speeches draw on his personal experience growing up with no electricity in post-war South Korea:

headline: Weekend Fare: Mermaids and Gay Pride
text: In conjunction with the 30th annual Mermaid Parade, the Coney Island Brewing Company, 12th Street and Surf Avenue, in Coney Island, Brooklyn, will offer tastings on Saturday starting at 2 p.m. of four new beers. One is Shmaltz Brewing’s Mermaid Pilsner.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Trixie Whitley
text: I had been warned to brace myself for the power of Trixie Whitley’s voice, but nothing could have prepared me for what came spilling out of the mouth of this diminutive blonde. Whitley’s vocals are nothing less than soaring, and the soul that pours forth from her is heart wrenching. Even in the stuffy reality that is an Art Forum/D.A.P. cocktail party at the top of the Standard Hotel, Whitley’s boot stamping, guitar strumming and deep wails brought the schmoozing to a grinding, and welcome, halt.

headline: How My View on Gay Marriage Changed
text: IN my 2007 book, “The Future of Marriage,” and in my 2010 court testimony concerning Proposition 8, the California ballot initiative that defined marriage as between a man and a woman, I took a stand against gay marriage. But as a marriage advocate, the time has come for me to accept gay marriage and emphasize the good that it can do. I’d like to explain why.

headline: Hearing the World, While Staying At Home
text: Honolulu

headline: Hugh Bonneville, Star of the Olympics Comedy ‘Twenty Twelve’
text: TWO years ago Hugh Bonneville was just another hard-working British actor whose plummy vowels and cherubic cheeks lent themselves to characters good (Bernie, the stockbroker who never gets the girl in “Notting Hill”) and not so good (Henleigh Grandcourt, the aristocrat who sends the girl fleeing in “Daniel Deronda”).

headline: Taliban Attack a Resort Hotel
text: Taliban militants shot their way into a lakeside resort near Kabul, killing 20 and taking scores of hostages during an 11-hour siege.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: Regarding “The Upgrade Maze” (June 10), I read that at the beginning of the fare games one of the major airlines believed its loyal customers would appreciate better service and amenities, even if they came at slightly higher fares. It lost customers in droves. As a traveler on a budget, I almost always choose the lowest fare, so I recognize that I’ve helped create this mess today.

headline: Going to the Fat Farm With Dad
text: My dad was a brilliant ad man in the “Mad Men” era, responsible for such iconic slogans as “Coke Is It,” “Leggo My Eggo,” and “Fly the Friendly Skies of United.” He also was extremely overweight.

headline: Putting a Spin on Touring
text: ANDY HAMPSTEN, 50, may be best remembered by cycling fans for overcoming a blizzard on a steep climb in the 1988 Giro d’Italia.

headline: Restaurant Report: Restaurante da Dona Liceia in Arapeí, Brazil
text: The wealthiest guests travel to Liceia Franklin de Oliveira’s farmhouse restaurant by helicopter, landing amid the green hills outside Arapeí, Brazil, about 20 miles as the chopper flies from the resort town of Angra dos Reis. But you don’t need to be rich to afford the 70-real prix fixe lunch: that’s only $35 at 1.98 reais to the dollar. Plebeians will, however, need some time. By car it’s a two-hour, 110-mile drive from Rio de Janeiro, the last three miles of which are down a dirt road barely wide enough for a compact rental. (Ask for directions if you don’t see signs in town for the restaurant.)

headline: Hotel Review: Brick in Mexico City
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: An Old Mexico City Colonia on an Upswing
text: BESIDE the small, open courtyard on the roof of a former mansion, Anuar Maauad had a cigarette in one hand, a beer in the other and a ringing — constantly ringing — cellphone in front of him on his long kitchen table. He sat, flanked by friends, as the Mexico City sky exploded with thunder so powerful it shook the 123-year-old building.

headline: Seeking Japanese Calm, Closer to Home
text: YEARS ago, while traveling through Japan, I booked a last-minute room through the tourist office at Kyoto’s train station and ended up at a traditional guesthouse without knowing what I was getting into.

headline: Tracking the Bieb and the Bard in Stratford
text: ON a sweltering afternoon recently I stood in a dusty skateboard park in Stratford, Ontario, surrounded by about a dozen sullen-looking boys, all around 17. I mentioned someone they might know, someone who a few years ago used to hang out there, too, and a couple of them said he was a jerk. They could have been jealous, of course: We were discussing Justin Bieber, who not long ago was a local kid busking on the street a few blocks from this park and is now a pop star estimated by Forbes magazine to have earned $55 million, even before last week’s release of his third full-length album, “Believe.”

headline: Hiking Through Biblical Backcountry
text: AROUND the corner from Nazareth’s Old City market, in the shadow of 200-year-old Ottoman mansions, there’s a cobblestone street so narrow you can almost touch the houses on either side. An arrow pointing up some stairs is painted on one rough wall, along with the words “Jesus Trail.” It’s the de facto trailhead for a 40-mile hike through the Galilee region of Israel in the footsteps, more or less, of the man who made Galilee famous.

headline: Wall-Breaking Moves, Fit for a Screen
text: IN a new dance the choreographer Jonah Bokaer, dressed in black, moves inside of a sleek box that stands an arm’s reach taller than his six-foot frame. Transferring his body weight with exacting control, he maintains a profile stance as his arms and legs — extending straight like rods — create a world of lines within lines.

headline: Chasing a Prairie Tale
text: One of the most adrenaline-fueled vacations in American history took place in August 1872, when a young New Yorker named George Bird Grinnell boarded a train at Grand Central Depot for the era’s hot new travel destination — Nebraska.

headline: A Hybrid Approach to Solar Power
text: When photovoltaic cells make electricity from sunlight, they collect a lot of heat along the way. And they don’t work as well warm as they do cold.

headline: Crisscrossing the Plains
text: Violent history, modern rebirth and an occasional curiosity on a trip through Kansas and Nebraska.

headline: Image of the Day: June 22
text: German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle on a two-day visit to India.

headline: Friday Flashback: For Federer, the Olympics Have Been About Family
text: Most athletes come away from the Olympics with a cherished lifetime memory of representing their country. A select few will get to be flagbearers for the opening ceremony. The really lucky and talented ones return home with a medal or two.

headline: Blogging to Build Your Business
text: Blogging for business is not a new concept, but for many small businesses, especially service businesses, it can be an extremely effective tool to build your social media footprint, establish your brand, or position yourself in your area of expertise. The ultimate benefit of blogging is the opportunity to communicate your expertise and establish your business as a resource.

headline: June 24 — 30
text: AN early oratorio version of Paola Prestini’s multimedia opera, “OCEANIC VERSES,” was performed at New York City Opera’s Vox readings in 2011, and it left a mixed impression. But since then Ms. Prestini — an inventive composer whose style mixes the ancient and the up-to-date, the folk inspired and the artfully polished — has revamped the work, expanding it into a full opera, with a libretto by Donna Di Novelli and film by Ali Hossaini. The nonlinear story follows four characters — the Sailor, the Soldier, the Scholar and the Peasant — whose individual quests are linked by a search for a common past in the disappearing traditions of southern Italy. The characters have alter egos of sorts, film versions meant to represent their inner selves. The expanded work is having its New York premiere as part of the River to River Festival. The production is directed by Kevin Newbury, and Claudio Prima, Christopher Burchett, Helga Davis and Nancy Allen Lundy sing the principal roles, with Julian Wachner conducting Novus NY (the contemporary music ensemble of Trinity Wall Street), the Washington Chorus and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus. 7:30 p.m. Monday, Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts, 3 Spruce Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 219-9401, rivertorivernyc.com; free.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Triumphs of the Gay Rights Movement
text: In the New York Times Book Review, Rich Benjamin reviews Linda Hirshman’s “Victory,” a history of the gay rights movement. Mr. Benjamin writes:

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Opens Investigations Into the Chrysler 200 and Ford Explorer
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened investigations into possible stalling problems on 87,000 Chrysler 200 sedans and a loss of power-steering assist on 83,000 Ford Explorers.

headline: To Give or Not to Give, Up to $5.12 Million
text: TIME may — or may not — be running out for one of the biggest tax breaks for wealthy Americans: the chance to give up to $5.12 million to heirs tax-free and then pay a comparatively low 35 percent rate on any gift above that. The break is scheduled to expire in six months, but no one will hazard a guess about its fate because it is just one of many tax and spending measures expiring at the same time.

headline: Braving the Klondike on a Shoe Diet
text: AS “The Artist” arrives on home video this week with its five Oscars in tow, perhaps this mock-silent movie from Michel Hazanavicius will motivate viewers to check out some of the many authentic examples of silent-film art that are currently available on DVD and Blu-ray. The air of amused condescension that Mr. Hazanavicius’s film expresses toward an imaginary era of “lost innocence” quickly dissipates when exposed to the emotional complexities and stylistic refinements of a film like Charles Chaplin’s 1925 classic “The Gold Rush,” recently issued by the Criterion Collection in a digitally restored version that puts all previous editions of this great film to shame.

headline: Sanding Down the Grit on Rap and Metal
text: SpaceGhostPurrp

headline: Former Busker Is Now Back as a Solo
text: THE audience at Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in SoHo might well have expected Glen Hansard to open his recent show there with a song from “Once,” the Broadway show built around his songs that had won eight Tonys just two days earlier. Or maybe something from his first solo album, “Rhythm and Repose,” which was about to be released.

headline: Man Is Sentenced for Threats Against Creators of ‘South Park’
text: A man involved with a Web site that posted threatening messages about the creators of the Comedy Central series “South Park” was sentenced to 11½ years in prison on Friday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 22, 2012
text: The New York Times film critics on “Brave,” “To Rome With Love,” and “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter.”

headline: Look of The Moment | The Angelina Effect
text: When Angelina Jolie’s leg stole the Academy Awards show this past February, the fashion police raged. Shocked and bemused, no one would have predicted at the time that the thigh-high slit in that Atelier Versace dress combined with Jolie’s deliberate, look-at-my-leg pose would start a red-carpet trend. But alas, the Angelina Effect has taken hold of red carpets everywhere, from New York to Hollywood and Antibes. A repeat offender, the model Anja Rubik took the look to new heights in an Anthony Vaccarello dress slit on the right for the Met Ball, and then in Roberto Cavalli at the Cannes Film Festival. “There is something so seductive about the movement of a dress with a high slit,” said Jason Wu, who designed the racy lace dress worn by the model Jessica Stam to the CFDA Awards earlier this month. “It definitely makes you look twice.” Also spotted at the CFDA Awards was the model Hilary Rhoda, in modernist Rebecca Minkoff. “Adding a slit to a long dress makes it feel less formal,” Minkoff said. “It’s a modern bombshell look.” That’s got legs, no doubt.

headline: Morning Walkabout — 6/22: Techie-Friendly Ads and a T.S.A. Gadget That Doesn’t Work
text: Ads and Apps Two techie-friendly ad campaigns: Crystal Cruises will let owners of iPhones with the Aurasma-augmented reality app use it to view videos that use the print ads as a jumping-off point. Air France has introduced a free iPhone app that lets passengers create personalized, location-based photo albums on their trips that can be shared on Facebook with friends and also with a network of Air France’s “Travel Bookers.”  (The New York Times)

headline: Pakistan’s Ménage à Trois
text: London — For as long as I can remember, the politics of Pakistan  have been discussed in binary terms: civil vs. military, democracy vs. dictatorship, good vs. evil. The ouster this week of Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on an order of the Supreme Court changes all that. Thanks to this “judicial coup,” as many in Pakistan are calling the move, the country is now in effect being run by a ménage-à-trois.

headline: Whatever Happens, I Will Have Reacted Already
text: When a politician responds to something another politician has not yet said, we call that a “prebuttal.” It’s a variant is the “presponse,” in which networks air the opposition party’s “response” to a State of the Union Address that was taped prior to delivery.

headline: This Week’s Movies: June 22
text: In today’s edition of This Week’s Movies, Manhola Dargis reviews the horror fantasy “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter” — a film with “such smashing title, it’s too bad someone had to spoil things by making a movie to go with it” — and “Brave,” the animated fairy tale that features Pixar’s first female protagonist. A. O. Scott weighs in on Woody Allen’s latest, “To Rome With Love.” Full reviews can be found here.

text: Alessandra Stanley, the Times’s chief television critic, looks at several cultures from around the world through the prism of their television programming.

headline: A Loophole Big Enough to Lose a Billion
text: If nothing else, the collapse of MF Global has made one thing clear: The notion that customer assets were safe was a sham.

headline: New York Wrecks Inspire Aquarium Design
text: Scientists from the Wildlife Conservation Society are exploring shipwrecks off the coast of New York to help architects accurately design a new facility at the New York Aquarium.

headline: Switzerland’s Battle to Suppress the Franc Exacts a Price
text: IN the middle of the chaos and fear that is Europe today sits a country seemingly apart from it all.

headline: The Swiss Dilemma
text: Switzerland is trying to keep its currency from becoming too strong, which is causing problems.

headline: Syria Shoots Down Turkish Warplane, Fraying Ties Further
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkey announced Friday that Syrian forces had shot down a Turkish warplane with two crew members over the Mediterranean, a potentially ominous turn for the worse in relations already frayed because of Turkey’s support for Syrian rebels fighting to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: As Sandusky Jurors Deliberate, Lawyer Acknowledges His Doubts
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — With the jury in the Jerry Sandusky sex-abuse case deep into its second day of deliberation, Sandusky’s lawyer said Friday evening he would be shocked if his client was acquitted on all of the nearly 50 counts of abusing young boys he faced.

headline: Business Day Live | Wildfire's Toll
text: June 22, 2012 — Colorado’s governor talks about the economic impact of battling wildfires.

headline: Should You Bribe Children to Behave in the Car?
text: Last week’s parental quandary was mine, or, at least, mine and a whole lot of other people’s. The problem? Children squabbling madly away in the car. I offered my solution in the video when I first posted it last week: I will give a Tic Tac to any child who can get through a car ride without poking, prodding or otherwise antagonizing a sibling.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Dancing the Night Away
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about summer rock festivals and “The Electric Daisy Carnival.”

headline: The Sweet Spot: June 22
text: In this week’s episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss the increasing number of electronic dance music festivals and talk with Ben Sisario and Jon Pareles about the trend.

headline: The First Family: A New Glimpse of Michelle Obama’s White Ancestors
text: When we invited readers to pose questions about an article on Mrs. Obama’s white ancestors, we never imagined that one would provide us with the first glimpse of two key figures in the first lady’s family tree.

headline: In Effort to Remove Tarnish, a Heat Title Helps
text: MIAMI — When the party crashed the locker room, made the floor a sticky mess and packed it with revelers wall to wall, Micky Arison stood in the middle and referenced the last time he picked up the check for a wild Miami Heat bash.

headline: The Euro Is Flat
text: Still limited blogging. But I thought I’d post about something that sort of surprised me.

headline: Downsized, With Penthouse
text: JAMES FREUND grew up in a two-bedroom apartment on East 72nd Street, where his mother, Marcy Freund, a fiercely independent 104, still lives. But in many respects his heart was on the West Side.

headline: The Soccer Chronicles: Inspiration in Sweden
text: Heather O’Reilly, a midfielder on the U.S. women’s soccer team and a two-time gold medalist, will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her second post.

headline: On Our Radar: Limping Toward the End in Rio
text: Although serious policy discussions have unfolded at the Rio+20 environmental conference in Brazil — along with plenty of theatrics — it will wrap up today without committing nations to any binding targets on sustainability. [The Washington Post]

headline: Iceland Plans to Join European Bloc Despite Economic Turmoil
text: BRUSSELS — Despite a sovereign debt crisis that threatens to tear the European Union apart, Iceland is speeding ahead on its bid to join the bloc and even delivered a pep talk Friday to those struggling to hold it together.

headline: Tip of the Week: Texting a Caller Back
text: Ever been in a meeting or other quiet occasion where answering an incoming phone call is not an option? Smartphones running the Android 4.0 software (also known as Ice Cream Sandwich in Google’s dessert-themed nickname scheme) offer a convenient feature that lets you respond to the caller with a text message.

headline: Condo Boards Take a Stand on Delinquencies
text: A SUCCESSFUL condominium depends, in large part, on owners’ paying their monthly fees promptly and in full. Delinquencies can mean less money for maintenance and amenities — and draw the ill will of fellow residents. While the sheer size of larger buildings can often blunt their impact on the budget, small buildings with a high number of delinquencies can be toxic for buyers and a millstone for sellers.

headline: Souped-Up Summer Vegetables
text: For a light, healthful meal, nothing beats soup, even in the summertime. This week Martha Rose Shulman offers soup recipes that put the spotlight on summer vegetables. She writes:

headline: A Bicycle Headset Doubles as a Walkie-Talkie
text: If you like talking, bicycling and a project, then you’ll like the Cardo BK-1, a walkie-talkie, Bluetooth music player and hands-free phone headset in one.

headline: Making Sense With Me Me Me
text: OK, actually it’s Making Sense With Paul Solman, but currently it’s a lot of me me me; videos galore. Also some of Robin.

headline: Down Memory Lane With the National Book Awards (and Not Just the Winners)
text: The National Book Foundation has created an online exhibit to highlight notable American authors like Cynthia Propper Seton, Earl Thompson and Alan Saperstein. Oh, and Hemingway, Faulkner and Flannery O’Connor, too. They’re all among the 373 finalists for the National Book Award for Fiction since the honor was first issued in 1950.

headline: Letty Brown and Jan Novak
text: WHEN Letty Brown and Jan Novak were introduced by a mutual friend at a Japanese restaurant in Sacramento in 2008, her course seemed set. Dr. Brown, a botanist, was planning to depart for eastern Brazil, where she was to map an uncharted corner of the Atlantic Forest on a Fulbright scholarship.

headline: A Shipwreck as a Portal for an Aquarium Exhibit
text: On the evening of Feb. 10, 1939, the oil tanker Lightburne ran aground in dense fog on a shoal off Block Island, R.I. In lashing winds and pounding surf, the Coast Guard raced to the site and performed what The New York Times called “one of the most spectacular ship rescues in recent years,” saving all 35 crew members.

headline: Euro 2012 Highlights: Germany (4) vs. Greece (2)
text: Germany Coach Joachim Löw made a number of changes to his starting lineup. Lukas Podolski, Lars Bender, Thomas Müller and Mario Gomez were out; Miroslav Klose, Marko Reus and Mesut Özil are in. Boateng returned to the defense, And there’s more. Perhaps only a team with the depth, and confidence of Germany could and would dare to make such wholesale changes.

headline: Chris Bosh, the Second-Most Maligned N.B.A. Champion
text: This N.B.A. title — and all that comes with it — belongs to LeBron James, the player of unspeakable talent, unbelievable growth and the target of unprecedented criticism. But while his personal journey has become the narrative of an entire league, he shares the Heat’s scene with so many others. Dwyane Wade tabled injury and personal trial to compete for another title. Erik Spoelstra pushed the Heat into the future with his adaptive rotation. And Chris Bosh — the unbelievably strange target of a raging public’s remaining bile — thrived for Miami in a more crucial capacity than ever.

headline: Leaders Vow to Defend Euro, but Hint at Rifts on How
text: ROME — The leaders of the euro zone’s four largest economies vowed Friday to defend the common currency with all means necessary, trying to reassure jittery financial markets before yet another summit meeting of the European Union next week in Brussels. But clear disagreements remained on what those mechanisms ought to be.

headline: Living With P.T.S.D. and Allowing Myself to Get Help
text: An alarm clock chimes across a pitch-black room. I slowly rise. Standing in my bathroom, I brush my teeth and shave away yesterday’s stubble – part of every Marine’s mandatory morning routine. The person in the mirror seems somehow unfamiliar. Downstairs, the morning pot of coffee brews. I finally begin to wake. Leaving home, the roads are lined with beautiful farmland, backlit by a rising sun. Morning dew glinting off the fields gives way to a kaleidoscope of neon signs as I reach town. Pulling into the parking lot, I take a deep breath and step out of my truck.

headline: Bain Capital Buys Half of TV Shopping Company in Japan
text: Bain Capital agreed on Friday to buy 50 percent of one of Japan’s biggest television shopping companies, in the latest move by the private equity firm in that country.

headline: Shelf Life | Summer at Karma
text: From its seashell-encrusted vessels and faux aged terra cotta flower pots to the hand-painted driftwood key chains and dip dyed towels, Summer is exactly the kind of home décor shop that you might expect to find on main street Sag Harbor or Amagansett. Only this three-week retail operation is in the West Village, in the storefront of Karma, Brendan Dugan’s design office/gallery/bookstore, and its proprietors, Aaron Aujla and Dylan Bailey, are not out-of-work Domino editors but the gainfully employed assistants to the artists Nate Lowman and Dan Colen, respectively. Aujla and Bailey, whose personal studio practices trade in mimicry and appropriation, spent untold hours studying and documenting virtually every home décor shop within about 100 miles, meticulously cataloging the tropes and tricks of visual branding and retail display — “Have you ever noticed that the dog bowl outside of the Thom Browne store up the street has a lemon wedge in it?” Aujla asks — and then set out to set up a shop of their own.

headline: When Zealots Attack
text: So far this year I’ve only been called an “idiot” on two occasions.

headline: Ex-Officer Gets 9-Month Term in Racially Tainted False Arrest
text: A former New York police officer who used a racial slur while bragging about falsely arresting a black man last year was sentenced on Friday to nine months in prison for violating the man’s civil rights.

headline: On Radio, Mayor Signs Taxi Sex-Trafficking Bill
text: For the New York City government, it was almost certainly a first: a sitting mayor signing a bill into law in the midst of a live radio interview, applying his signature from the unglamorous confines of a Lower Manhattan studio.

headline: Lin Granted Early-Bird Rights
text: A dispute between the N.B.A. and the players union over Jeremy Lin’s so-called Bird rights could spill into July, clouding the Knicks’ free-agency agenda and creating potential chaos for all parties.

headline: Rubio Denounces Partisanship on Immigration
text: An hour before President Obama was to speak to Latino officials on Friday, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida lamented how the immigration issue has become hostage to politics — on both the left and right.

headline: After 62-Year Absence, Le Monstre Will Stalk Le Mans Again
text: Briggs Swift Cunningham, a wealthy sportsman who raced yachts as well as cars, never achieved his dream of winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans in France. But he came fairly close, placing as high as third over all and first in class in both 1953 and 1954, with C4R and C5R cars of his own company’s design.

headline: Conventions, or Hallelujah Parties?
text: The quadrennial Republican and Democratic nominating conventions stopped being actual parts of the nominating process in the 1970s.  But they retained aspects of their original purpose – the ritual vote and the speeches by each party’s big shots and nominees. A convention can set the tone for the fall campaign – for good (Barack Obama’s wildly successful convention in Denver in 2008) or ill (John Kerry’s cringe-inducing convention in Boston in 2004.)

headline: Cardinal’s Aide Is Found Guilty in Abuse Case
text: PHILADELPHIA — Msgr. William J. Lynn, a former cardinal’s aide, was found guilty Friday of endangering children, becoming the first senior official of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States convicted of covering up sexual abuses by priests under his supervision.

headline: U.S. Military Hunts for Safe Smartphones for Soldiers
text: The military has long needed computers that are tough enough on the outside to withstand the rough and tumble of the battlefield. Now, with the proliferation of smartphones and tablets in the hands of soldiers, those devices also have to be strong on the inside. They are loaded with contacts, location information and all kinds of military-grade applications, so it can be deadly for a soldier to lose a mobile device or have its data leak out unwittingly.

headline: How Is the Monthly Jobs Report Actually Calculated?
text: In this week’s magazine, Adam Davidson writes about the jobs report, the government’s monthly estimate of the employment situation in the United States. The Bureau of Labor Statistics releases the report on the first Friday of every month, at exactly 8:30 in the morning. In an instant, reporters and analysts decide whether it spells doom or salvation for the economy. But how are the numbers calculated in the first place?

headline: A Practiced Nonchalance
text: Sean MacPherson, 47, proprietor of the Bowery, Jane and Maritime hotels and an owner of the Waverly Inn restaurant, is revamping the Crow’s Nest Inn in Montauk, N.Y. His wife is Rachelle Hruska, a founder of the night-life blog GuestofaGuest.com. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Oregon Study Shows Benefits, and Price, for Newly Insured
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — When Wendy Parris shattered her ankle, the emergency room put it in an air cast and sent her on her way. Because she had no insurance, doctors did not operate to fix it. A mother of six, Ms. Parris hobbled around for four years, pained by the foot, becoming less mobile and gaining weight.

headline: A Look at the Top N.H.L. Draft Prospects
text: The folks at Bleacher Report have produced a series of videos about a dozen of the prospects likely to be among the top selections in the N.H.L. draft on Friday night. Above, the video about probable No. 1 pick Nail Yakupov. The other videos can be found here.

headline: Living In | Goshen, N.Y.
text: Like the Biblical place that inspired its name, Goshen is the proverbial land of plenty, at least to many of those who live here.

headline: Biblical Name, ‘Utopian’ Quality
text: LIKE the biblical place that inspired its name, Goshen is the proverbial land of plenty, at least to many of those who live here: 5,500 people in the historic 3.2-square-mile village center, the Orange County seat; and 8,200, many of them farmers, in the countryside that makes up the surrounding town, renowned for its exceptionally fertile black soil.

headline: Exploring Bioluminescence
text: David Gruber and Vincent Pieribone make their first dive at the Solomon Islands site.

headline: Another Injury Puts Clijsters’s Summer in Doubt
text: Hours before she was to play in a semifinal match at the Unicef Open in the Netherlands on Friday, Kim Clijsters of Belgium withdrew from the tournament with a new injury, a stomach muscle strain.

headline: An App That Can Predict Sunny or Stormy Drives
text: Though the weather may not affect your road trip as dramatically as it would have in tornado-ravaged Hampton, Va., this month, it still can dramatically alter your drive.

headline: Stars of the Earth Summit
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — If the Rio+20 conference on sustainable development has been criticized for being short on results, the mega-event has at least made the city a stage for a colorful cast of political and environmental personalities.

headline: American and Pilots Near Accord on Contract
text: American Airlines and the union representing its pilots are close to reaching a deal on a new contract, a significant milestone in the ailing carrier’s seven-month-old bankruptcy, although one that still leaves the door open for a possible merger with US Airways.

headline: Gazprom Reaches Deal With EDF to Invest in European Power Plants
text: ST. PETERSBURG — Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, reached a deal Friday with EDF of France to jointly invest in gas-fired power plants in Europe, gaining an important toehold for its exports at a time when competition from shale gas and liquefied natural gas is disrupting its main business.

headline: The Ascent
text: Part art installation, part adventure ride, part spiritual journey, “The Ascent” claims to let users harness their brain’s own electrical impulses to levitate themselves.

headline: Ensemble Intercontemporain Names Music Director
text: The graying but still spry grandfather of new-music groups, the Ensemble Intercontemporain, said on Friday that the composer and conductor Matthias Pintscher would become its next music director, starting in 2013. Mr. Pintscher, 41, who has an increasingly busy conducting career along with his work as a composer, will succeed Susanna Mälkki.

headline: Artifacts | Chris Crocker’s Zoo Story
text: It’s Pride week in New York, when gay, lesbian and transgendered people can celebrate themselves in the streets. In Bristol, Tenn., however, the flamboyant Chis Crocker will have to parade at home on his computer screen. Not that he’ll be alone, exactly.

headline: Brain Waves Lift Me Higher
text: YOU could drive past the hulking warehouse on the rough patch of waterfront in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, several times without ever figuring it for the latest frontier of neurological thrill-seeking. But that’s where Yehuda Duenyas, 38, who calls himself “a creator of innovative experiences,” was camped out last week, along with his team of scrappy young technical wizards and a quarter-million dollars’ worth of circuitry, theatrical lighting and optimism called The Ascent.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A two-bedroom one-bath renovated farmhouse on one acre in Stamford, Conn.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: An Upper East Side co-op, a Greenwich Village co-op, an Astoria co-op and a Windsor Terrace house.

headline: Hyatt’s Free Time Puzzle
With Elections Awash in Cash, There’s Plenty of Blame to Go Around
text: WASHINGTON — David Axelrod, President Obama’s political strategist, recently invoked a common perception about the 2012 campaign by blaming the Supreme Court for empowering 21st-century “robber barons trying to take over the government.”

headline: In Florida, Obama Assails Republicans Over Immigration Policy
text: 9:14 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.

headline: The Science of Illusion
text: PINCH a coin at its edge between the thumb and first fingers of your right hand and begin to place it in your left palm, without letting go. Begin to close the fingers of the left hand. The instant the coin is out of sight, extend the last three digits of your right hand and secretly retract the coin. Make a fist with your left — as if holding the coin — as your right hand palms the coin and drops to the side.

headline: Digital Notes: @KimDotcom Jokes of Money ‘Laundering’ and Tennis ‘Racketeering’
text: For Hollywood and the music industry, the criminal case against Megaupload is critical in their fight against piracy, and the scale of it is the stuff of symbolism: A federal indictment accuses the file-sharing site and seven of its operators, including the founder, Kim Dotcom, of abetting $500 million in damages.

headline: Consider the Heirs
text: Once again, Congress and the president are at loggerheads about tax policies, and one tax break that benefits the wealthy is among them. The fate of those policies may not be determined until after the November election.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $40,064,000
text: A duplex penthouse co-op at 70th Street and Fifth Avenue that sold for just over $40 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Getting Lost in the Labyrinth of Medical Bills
text: Ask Jean Poole, a medical billing advocate, about her work helping people navigate the bewildering world of medical bills and insurance claims, and the stories pour out. There’s the client who was billed almost $11,000 for an 11-minute hand surgery.  The cancer patient who was charged $9,550.40 for a round of chemotherapy he never received.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 24
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Sweet Almond Tart Crust
text: Want the perfect vehicle for summer fruit? Try making a sweet almond tart crust. Melissa Clark shows how.

headline: Setting Aside That British Reserve and Acting the Hooligan
text: Cold Spring, N.Y.

headline: Jaguar Puts On Its Game Face
text: The XKR-S, the fastest series production car in Jaguar’s history, has a grace and grit that’s rare in a luxury sports car.

headline: A Fresh Fruit Tart, Perfumed With Roses
text: A CLASSIC berry tart, crumbly crust brimming with pastry cream and lined with neat rows of fresh fruit, is a refined and utterly traditional way to take advantage of summer’s bounty.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Uncanny X-Force’ Does Double Duty
text: The writer Rick Remender is a double threat this week, appearing on our hardcover and paperback graphic books best-seller lists with “Uncanny X-Force.” Volume 5 of the series is on the hardcover list at No. 8, while Volume 3 is at No. 10 on the paperback list.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Israel, Egypt and West Bank.

headline: When Is a Child Old Enough to Stay Home Alone?
text: This week’s quandary fits right into the conversation about the challenges of summer scheduling: when, and under what circumstances, is a child old enough to stay home alone?

headline: Chris Hayes Has Arrived With ‘Up’
text: AROUND 11 p.m. on a Friday this past spring, Ted Leo, a singer and songwriter considered something of a legend in New York punk and indie-rock, opened a raucous late set at the Black Cat club in Washington with a curious greeting to his followers.

headline: How an Australian Company Won the Top Spot in Teacher Training
text: A decade ago, Australia nearly topped the charts when it came to teaching children to read. Although Australia has fallen in more recent international rankings, its reputation has helped one company dominate the New York City market in on-the-job teacher training. The company, known as AUSSIE, is a leading example of how the push to provide improved training for teachers has turned into a multimillion dollar enterprise.

headline: It’s as Easy as 123!@S
text: WITH numbers. Without. One capital letter. None. More than eight characters. Fewer than 16.

headline: Decoding Your Medical Bill
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at how difficult it’s become for consumers to figure out how much they actually owe on their medical bills, and what the charges are based on to begin with.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 24
text: More Photographs

headline: A Summer Salad the French Might Recognize
text: FRESHLY dug potatoes are at the market and the weather is warm, so it’s a good time for potato salad. I don’t mean a pale scoop next to a grilled sausage. I want more of a meal: savory, garlicky, shot through with anchovy and capers and herbs, and topped with skinny green beans and hard-cooked eggs.

headline: Buying Anchovies and Capers
text: This week’s City Kitchen column features a potato and green bean salad with inspiration from the south of France. Whether or not it qualifies as a true salade Niçoise, or a simplified version of the real thing, is debatable.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 22
text: Subjects include Nik Wallenda’s tightrope walk across Niagara Falls, the first hot spell of summer and a rock slide in the Palisades.

headline: Richards-Ross Aims for Her Olympic Moment (or Two)
text: EUGENE, Ore. – It’s overcast and drizzly on the campus of the University of Oregon, as the United States track and field Olympic trials prepare to begin in earnest at Hayward Field at 1 p.m. Pacific time. Friday’s program features, among other events, half of the decathlon as well as preliminary rounds in several of the sprints. The only finals contested Friday will come in the evening, when the men’s 10,000 meters starts at 6:45 p.m. and the women’s 10,000 follows at 7:20 p.m.

headline: Missing the Boat: A Case for Marriage
text: HE proposed a year after we started dating. I was 24, naïve and ambitious. I had been plotting my career since I was 13, never giving much thought to marriage.

headline: A Split Decision Over the ’63 Sting Ray
text: THE 1963 Corvette Sting Ray coupe, with its sharklike styling details and boattail roofline, is acknowledged as one of the most desirable of all Corvettes. Its defining feature is a two-piece fastback rear window, the stylish conclusion of a windsplit that runs unbroken from the nose of the car to its tail.

headline: Ralph Wenzel, Whose Dementia Helped Start a Debate, Dies at 69
text: Ralph Wenzel, a former National Football League lineman whose early-onset dementia helped draw attention to recent debates about the safety of football, died on June 18 in Annapolis, Md. He was 69.

headline: The Mixed Bag of Driver Education
text: THERE is no debate about this fact: The first year that American teenagers have their driver’s licenses will be among the most dangerous of their lives. Nothing kills more of them than car crashes.

headline: Literary Brooklyn Gets Its Leading Man
text: ON a late afternoon in May, Martin Amis gestured toward the tall, sun-filled parlor windows of his Brooklyn brownstone.

headline: Resources for Parents
text: COST, duration and convenience are typical concerns when selecting a driver education program, “but those are distant seconds to the main issue of quality,” said William E. Van Tassel, manager of driver training programs at AAA.

headline: Kevin Tucker Is Dead at 71; Led Philadelphia Police
text: Kevin M. Tucker, a former Philadelphia police commissioner who was credited with turning around a department riddled with corruption and beset by criticism over its bombing of a radical group called Move in 1985, died on Tuesday at a hospice in Mount Holly, N.J. He would have turned 72 on June 21.

headline: Champion of the Corvette, Feted in the Land He Left
text: Moscow

headline: Worlds Within Worlds, Both Real and Imagined
text: Just what exactly is a hungry kite? Which way does it blow? Deganit Shemy, the choreographer of “Hungry Kite,” a new dance that opened at the Chocolate Factory on Wednesday night, likes to keep things ambiguous. Her choreographic strokes leave behind blurry lines, so that linear meaning is cast aside for an atmosphere better suited to dreams.

headline: President Obama at NALEO
text: President Obama spoke at the National Assocation of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials.

headline: Gifts for Couples for the Great Outdoors
text: Gifts for those couple who find themselves in remote locations, including a solar charger that can keep phones ready, whether to report a bear sighting or just to call home.

headline: Play Together, Stay Together
text: IF lolling around the beach or yard isn’t a newly married couple’s idea of fun, consider a gift with get-up-and-go: a colorful stunt kite, a soft leather golf bag, a camping lantern or a snorkeling mask with built-in camera. And for those who find themselves in remote locations, a solar charger can keep phones ready, whether to report a bear sighting or just to call home.

headline: In the Air and on the Ground, a Force of Nature in Ashton’s Fairyland
text: With its production of “The Dream,” American Ballet Theater has reached the peak of its current season. No other production looks more beautiful on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House. The set and costumes, designed by David Walker, create a completely satisfying world, with space, air and depth around the dancing.

headline: Stripping the Big Top to Sublime, Nail-Biting Essentials
text: BECKET, Mass. — Contemporary circus shows are often dissatisfying affairs. Having stripped out many of the traditional elements that make a trip to the big top so pleasurable, they suffer from something of an identity crisis, padding their offerings instead with tedious emotional clichés and boilerplate design elements. Spectacle becomes schmaltz.

headline: Scouting Out the ‘Girls’ Hotspots
text: TO date, no tour buses have been sighted outside Café Grumpy, the real-life coffee shop at 193 Meserole Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, where the fictional Hannah serves up lattes and attitude on the HBO series “Girls,” which concluded its first season last Sunday. But give it time.

headline: A Nonvote in Albany: Tough Luck, Sharks
text: California’s done it. Oregon’s done it. Illinois is expected to do it this summer. But New York State won’t be banning the trade in shark fins – at least not this year. On Thursday, the New York State Senate did not act on a bill that would have banned the distribution, sales and possession of the fins before it adjourned.

headline: Bloomberg Suggests Shame as a Punishment for Speeding
text: In a setback to traffic safety advocates, the State Legislature this week again failed to vote on a bill that would allow the Bloomberg administration to use so-called speed cameras at dangerous intersections to enforce the city’s 30-mile-per-hour speed limit.

headline: A High-Heeled Stroll Through History
text: “Women From the Ankle Down: The Story of Shoes and How They Define Us.” By Rachelle Bergstein. 304 pages. Harper. $24.99.

headline: A Star Athlete Makes a Big Move Off the Field
text: WHEN the noted British athlete Ben Cohen — the David Beckham of rugby — walked down the runway this month for an AmFAR benefit at the New York Public Library, odds were that many in this audience thought he was just another handsome, muscular model. With his easy smile, buzz cut and 6-foot-3 frame, Mr. Cohen fit the mold and the clothes.

headline: Google Cuts Prices for Map Use by Site Owners
text: 5:07 p.m. | Updated  Adding comments.

headline: The Man Who Saved the ’Vette
text: Zora Arkus-Duntov made the Corvette an enthusiast’s touchstone and kept it there through constant engineering improvements, the development of a racing program and the introduction of daring midengine prototypes.

headline: Republican Budget Plan Comes Under Fire From Unlikely Source: G.O.P. Candidates
text: Republican leaders in Congress had hoped to lay out big plans for 2013, then run for election in November united around that vision. But the vision itself is coming under attack from an unlikely and possibly potent source: Republican candidates.

headline: Chic in Review | Hedi Slimane for SLP
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Video: Three Small Steps for Kitchen Technology
text: Three gadgets represent small steps by technology into the kitchen: a rice cooker, a kitchen thermometer and an espresso coffee maker. Read more about kitchen tech in this week’s Tool Kit column.

headline: Obama Calls Romney ‘an Outsourcing Pioneer’
text: 6:02 p.m. | Updated  LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. – President Obama and his team gleefully went after Mitt Romney on Friday for helping companies move jobs overseas, declaring that “we do not need an outsourcing pioneer in the Oval Office.”

headline: ‘Devious Maids,’ Rejected by ABC, Ends Up on Lifetime
text: The path from rejected network pilot to cable network series has begun to be more traveled, and the most prominent example so far was introduced on Friday by the Lifetime channel, which ordered the series “Devious Maids.”

headline: President Obama at NALEO
text: President Obama spoke at the NALEO conference on Friday.

headline: A Celebrity Push on Pancreatic Cancer
text: Next week, as Washington braces for the Supreme Court health care ruling, Lisa Niemi Swayze, the widow of the actor Patrick Swayze, will hit Capitol Hill to advocate for a bill that seeks more federal attention – and presumably money – to combat pancreatic cancer, which killed her husband in 2009.

headline: Photo Replay: June 22
text: The day in sports included the Euro 2012 soccer championships in Poland, cliff diving in Corsica and tennis in Singapore.

headline: Greek-German Tensions Over Finances Spill Into Another Arena
text: GDANSK, Poland — The giant blue-and-white flag blotted out the overcast Baltic sky on Friday as the Greek fans pounded their drums and cheered at the foot of the centuries-old City Hall here. The Germans took up a chant in honor of their chancellor, Angela Merkel.

headline: Live Coverage Saturday of Spain vs. France
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 game between Spain and France on Saturday at 2:45 PM ET. Andrew Das will offer commentary and analysis of the quarterfinal match.

headline: Performing With Men’s Hands Gripping Their Throats
text: BECKET, Mass. — Not to steal the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival’s thunder on the opening night of its 80th-anniversary season, but as the Pillow presented its first concert, by Mimulus Dance Company of Brazil, on Wednesday, I kept thinking of its slightly younger counterpart, the American Dance Festival in North Carolina. Specifically, I was reminded of a destined-to-become-infamous incident from 1984, when the choreographer Mark Morris rose from the audience during a performance of Twyla Tharp’s “Nine Sinatra Songs,” yelled “No more rape!” and exited the theater.

headline: One Summer, Many Tarts
text: In this week’s video, I demonstrate how to make an almond crust for a fruit tart. And in my Good Appetite column, I fill the crust with rose-scented pastry cream and fresh berries. But don’t stop there. This crust recipe, which tastes like an almond shortbread cookie, can be used for any kind of sweet tart. Here are some more ideas for tarting up summer fruit:

headline: England Wins the European Women’s Bridge Championship
text: The new European Women’s Teams champion is England, represented by Sally Brock, Nicola Smith, Fiona Brown, Susan Stockdale, Heather Dhondy and Nevena Senior.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses Police of Ignoring Directive on Marijuana Arrests
text: Nine months ago, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly issued a memorandum directing police officers not to make misdemeanor arrests for possession of small quantities of marijuana discovered when suspects are ordered to empty their pockets in stop, question and frisk encounters.

headline: Obama and Romney’s Speeches at the NALEO Conference
text: In what amounted to the general election campaign’s first debate on immigration, President Obama and Mitt Romney spoke on back-to-back days at the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials.

headline: Filling Up on a Midday Bite of New York History
text: The evening restaurant meal is an elaborate ritual in which exquisitely prepared foods are eaten in a particular order, using fine utensils in select company.

text: Kyrie Irving shows off his dance moves as Uncle Drew in a Pepsi commercial.

headline: Ray Bradbury’s ‘451’ Coming to a New Screen Near You?
text: Ray Bradbury, who died earlier this month at 91, will live on in his books. He might also echo in a message to frustrated Internet users.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: A Swiping App and Black Market Apple
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: Democrats Mock Scott Brown’s Claim of Secret Meetings with Royalty
text: That Senate campaign in Massachusetts that is supposed to be the premier Senate race in the country? Its highlight this week was a gaffe by Senator Scott P. Brown in which he said he had been busy holding secret meetings with kings and queens.

headline: Reviewing the Jaguar XKR-S
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2012 Jaguar XKR-S, a limited-edition, range-topping coupe and convertible from an automaker that currently forgoes the entry-level luxury buyer.

headline: On Egyptian News Sites, ‘Shocking, Breaking News’ That Might Not Be True
text: Updated, Saturday 6:56 a.m. CAIRO — As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, tensions escalated in Egypt on Friday as the country’s presidential election commission continued to delay the publication of official results, five days after the polls closed and the votes were counted in public.

headline: The Black Keys Sue Home Depot and Pizza Hut
text: The Black Keys have sued both the Home Depot and Pizza Hut for copyright infringement, saying that the companies used musical elements from the band’s recent hits without permission in commercials, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Response from Bain Capital
text: Bain Capital does not make money on investments when our investors lose money. Any suggestion to the contrary is based on a misleading analysis that examines the income of a business without taking account of expenses. This selective accounting excludes the clawback of profits from other investments, and large expenses associated with running the business and exploring the hundreds of transactions we review and choose not to do every year.

headline: Walcott: Don't Penalize Parents Who Raise Money for Their Schools
text: In an interview in April to mark his first anniversary as chancellor, Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott said the Fund for Public Schools can be an equalizer when it comes to disparities in parent fund-raising. Meanwhile, he said, one thing he is not going to do is discourage parents from raising money for their children's schools.

headline: Devils to Host Next Year’s Draft
text: PITTSBURGH — The Devils will host to the 2013 entry draft, the N.H.L. announced Friday. It will be the first time the league has held the draft in the New York area.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Sizzle
text: With exquisite timing, a heat wave arrived on the first day of summer, and stylish New Yorkers didn’t miss a beat.

headline: Achieving Fame Without a Legacy
text: When I was in graduate school in the mid-’70s, trying to learn how to paint, a useful, shorthand criticism for a certain kind of creation was, “It looks like a LeRoy Neiman.” A reasonably sophisticated art student knew what that meant, and it was not a compliment. It referred to the splashy, garish, instantly recognizable style of illustration, a formulaic mix of impressionism, expressionism and realism, that Mr. Neiman used to make himself one of the most famous artists in America.

headline: Robert J. Kelleher, Judge and Tennis Official, Dies at 99
text: Robert J. Kelleher, a federal judge and former tennis champion who helped transform tennis in the United States by spearheading an effort to admit professionals into major tournaments, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 99.

headline: Greek Tragedy at the Soccer Bar
text: The winds whipped up, the thunder cracked and lightning bolts slashed the sky as I walked in the rain to my local soccer bar Friday afternoon to watch the match between Germany and Greece in the European Cup quarterfinals. A friend texted me, implying that Zeus had orchestrated the weather, suggesting that Greece — the underdog — would prevail.
