headline: Chevrolet Recalls 413,000 Cruzes for Engine-Fire Hazard
text: General Motors is recalling every Chevrolet Cruze it has produced at its plant in Lordstown, Ohio.

headline: Innovations, Both Raw and Cooked
text: JUST when I thought I had experienced almost everything the restaurant scene had to offer, I walked into a renovated pizzeria in Jersey City and ordered a spicy barbecued squid salad. The pickled pearl onions, jalapeño peppers and fresh, bright cilantro seemed to pop in my mouth, to set off intensifying waves of flavor. Here was a kind of cuisine I had never tasted in New Jersey.

headline: Korean Fare, on Tables Made by the Owners
text: KOREAN barbecue is a refreshing change of pace from the big slabs of smoked or slow-cooked meat featured in American styles. At Ssambap Korean B.B.Q. in Stony Brook, for instance, diners cook thin slices of raw meat on gas grills at their tables, then take the cooked morsels of meat and enfold them in a romaine leaf, possibly adding some bean paste, scallions and sliced radishes from among the condiments on the table. The resulting lettuce-wrapped package is a ssam; add rice to the mix and you have a ssambap.

text: About $600,000 has been raised online this week for a 68-year-old school bus monitor from upstate New York after a cellphone video showing a group of boys on the bus brutally taunting her spread quickly on the Internet.

headline: Man Sentenced for Punching Woman in Fight for Parking Space
text: It began as the sort of tense dispute that is a regular part of Manhattan’s rattle and hum: two people, a man and a woman, arguing over who had the rightful claim to a parking space.

headline: Even a Martini Has Prosciutto in It
text: My first pilgrimage to West Hartford’s newest gastronomic shrine came one Tuesday evening when a friend and I managed to snag the last two seats at the bar. Across the marble counter, we found ourselves facing hanging cured meats and a gleaming Berkel slicer. All around, patrons enjoying cocktails and prosecco were dangling bits of prosciutto into their mouths.

headline: Flower Power Sags in London
text: LONDON — The calendar kept by the theater here is as unforgiving as time itself. This season it is confirming, with withering wit and sociological specificity, that youth is never evergreen. Winter, you see, has finally arrived for the flower children of the 1960s.

headline: G.M. Recalls 475,000 Chevy Cruzes to Fix a Potential Engine Fire Hazard
text: DETROIT — General Motors said on Friday that it was recalling 475,000 of its popular Chevrolet Cruze compact cars in the United States and Canada to modify parts that could cause fires in the engine compartment.

headline: Blues and Soul, Vintage Blend
text: Bonnie Raitt began her show at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night the same way she begins her new album, “Slipstream”: with a brittle funk tune called “Used to Rule the World.” Written by Randall Bramblett, it rolls out a catalog of comeuppance, its point aimed at anyone who ever claimed immunity against the passage of time.

headline: Family-Owned, and Perfect for Families
text: It wasn’t clear, at first, what the relationships were. Three handsome guys in their 20s were sitting at one of Cedar Street Grill’s prime window tables, talking and trading hats and goofing around. Friends? Roommates? But as the meal proceeded, it was revealed by the diners’ body language: The middle-age man and woman sitting with them were their parents, and the three were brothers, probably just back from college.

headline: Far From a Shooting in Florida, an Increase in Block Watchers
text: Walking home in Astoria, Queens, one night this month, Daniel Rutkowski, 52, noticed a darkened stretch of sidewalk and looked up to see that the streetlight was out. He pulled out his cellphone and dialed, and said to the person on the other end, by way of introduction, “Here is my number,” rattling off a confidential identification code.

headline: So Articulate, Yet Crazed by Loss
text: When I first read Joan Didion’s book “The Year of Magical Thinking,” in 2005, the observation I remembered best was about shoes. Ms. Didion, newly widowed, reasoned that she could not give away her husband’s shoes because he would need them when he came back. After seeing the Westport Country Playhouse’s moving, elegiac production of the play that Ms. Didion adapted from that book, the line that echoes in my head is “You’re safe. I’m here.”

headline: We Have Met the Solution and It Is Us
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Showdown at the Trailer Park
text: The New Jersey Repertory Company valiantly strains its modest stage capabilities to present the world premiere of “American Stare,” a new play by Tony Glazer that demands six actors and a realistic setting for a contemporary story that takes place in a trailer park in South Florida.

headline: Something We Can All Agree On
text: BIRMINGHAM, England — From the start, the organizers of the London 2012 Festival wanted this celebration to take place all over Britain. As if to emphasize that goal, none of the major events that officially opened the festival on Thursday night took place in London.

headline: In Banks’ Downgrade, Not Much to Worry Consumers
text: Now that several of the big banks’ credit ratings have been downgraded, they may have to pay more to borrow money. And while the banks are hardly shy about passing higher costs on to their customers, many experts said they expected that the downgrade would have little effect — at least in the near term — on consumers.

headline: Hairston Embraces His Bigger, If Still Limited, Role
text: Ronny Cedeno, in his first game since May 26 after going on the diabled list with a strained left calf, was starting and batting second Friday night aganst the Yankees. Kirk Nieuwenhuis, the starting center fielder and usual leadoff man, was on the bench, as was the regular starting catcher, Josh Thole, and second baseman Daniel Murphy, who badly needed at-bats to shake a 2-for-21 slump. Manager Terry Collins felt he had no choice. A left-handed pitcher was on the mound.

headline: For Pole-Vaulters, Clearing the Bar Is the Easy Part
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Mark Hollis often finds it hard not to scoff at vacation travelers who complain about having to fit sandals, bathing suits and tanning oil into a suitcase while still keeping its weight less than 50 pounds.

headline: Light-Rock Concerts With a Cause
text: THE Two River Theater in Red Bank, best known for its dramatic offerings, is the setting for an “Intimate Evening” series of concerts this summer featuring artists like Rickie Lee Jones and Pure Prairie League. The shows will appeal to light-rock listeners, the organizers said.

headline: Giants and Jets Sue to Block Mall in Meadowlands
text: The Giants and the Jets filed a lawsuit on Friday to block the proposed American Dream shopping and entertainment mall in the Meadowlands, which they contend will threaten their ability to successfully hold games at the nearby MetLife Stadium.

headline: An Increase in Barriers to Trade Is Reported
text: WASHINGTON — Argentina tweaked import regulations on bottle caps and water balloons. India banned exports of cotton. South Africa instituted a tariff on artificial turf. Those recent policy changes sound minute. But they, and scores more like them, have stoked fears about trade protectionism rising as the global economy cools.

headline: A Sober New Reality in Credit Downgrades for Banks
text: When a consumer’s credit score drops, it is hard to recover financially. Wall Street firms could face the same fate.

headline: ‘Maritime Rites’
text: Central Park Lake

headline: Cuomo Backs Rangel’s Re-election Bid
text: Four days before the state’s Congressional primary elections, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Friday endorsed Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and two other Democrats who are in tight races in New York City.

headline: ‘Vexations’
text: Wall and Broad Streets

headline: ‘Musik im Bauch’
text: Naumburg Bandshell

headline: A Daylight Theft of a Drawing by Dalí, Incongruous in Simplicity and Ease
text: He did not wear gloves, nor did he don a ski mask. He staged no elaborate diversion. He did not even hide under the cover of night.

headline: ‘The New Rule’
text: Father Duffy Square

headline: Arkansas Court Upends Death Penalty
text: The Arkansas Supreme Court struck down the state’s death penalty law on Friday, faulting a provision that permitted the Corrections Department to select the fatal drugs used in an execution.

headline: Germany Progresses, Greece is Out. A Metaphor? An Omen?
text: In the end, the Germans won.

headline: For Young Olympic Hopefuls, Table Tennis Is All Business
text: In Friday’s editions of The New York Times, Somini Sengupta told the story of an unlikely incubator of Olympic talent: a nondescript warehouse in Milpitas, Calif., known as the India Community Center Table Tennis Center.

headline: Basketball Star Sues Club Over Brawl; Liquor Agency Files Charges
text: Tony Parker, a point guard for the San Antonio Spurs, has filed a $20 million lawsuit against the W.i.P. nightclub in New York and its operators, saying his left eye was damaged during a brawl at the club last week involving the R&B singer Chris Brown, the rapper Drake and their entourages.

headline: In Karaoke, Lawmakers Find a Catalyst for Collegiality
text: ALBANY — After several minutes of swaying side-to-side and fiddling with the microphone’s cord in his left hand, Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol stiffened his body. His torso inflated.

headline: Snapshots of a Presidential Tour: Seized Silverware and a Stumble
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – It was a quirky day on the road for President Obama. He headed to Florida for a couple of events: a speech to a Latino group in Lake Buena Vista outside Orlando, then a campaign rally in Tampa.

headline: Game 5 Receives High TV Ratings
text: The Miami Heat won the N.B.A. title Thursday but even after being blown out in Game 5, the Oklahoma City Thunder proved emphatically that their small-market status did not hurt viewership.

headline: Killings Curb Reporting of Mexican Crime Wave
text: XALAPA, Mexico — Throwing his burly frame to the ground, the photojournalist Alberto Morales click, click, clicked away on Tuesday as police officers and soldiers in body armor barked into radios, hoisted their rifles and crouched into position on word of a suspicious vehicle moving in.

headline: In Valencia, Another Spin of the Wheel
text: VALENCIA, Spain — There have been seven different winners in the first seven races this season, and we may find it impossible to know who will win next; but these days it is even more difficult to figure out from the series’ practice sessions on Fridays who is most likely to take the pole position on Saturday.

headline: New Union Leader Vows Tougher Fight for Rights
text: LOS ANGELES — For Lee Saunders, the newly elected president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, defeat does not mean retreat.

headline: Companies’ Ills Did Not Harm Romney’s Firm
text: Cambridge Industries, an automotive plastics supplier whose losses had been building for three consecutive years, finally filed for bankruptcy in May 2000 under a mountain of debt that had ballooned to more than $300 million.

headline: Gay Marriage Gains Backer as Major Foe Revises Views
text: David Blankenhorn, a national figure in the movement against same-sex marriage, has recanted his opposition, saying “the time has come for me to accept gay marriage and emphasize the good that it can do.”

headline: Chinese Data Mask Depth of Slowdown, Executives Say
text: HONG KONG — As the Chinese economy continues to sputter, prominent corporate executives in China and Western economists say there is evidence that local and provincial officials are falsifying economic statistics to disguise the true depth of the troubles.

headline: Obama Draws Contrast With Romney in His Turn Before Hispanics
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — President Obama on Friday sought to capitalize on his newly announced reprieve for young illegal immigrants with a broad attack on Mitt Romney and Congressional Republicans as obstacles to a comprehensive overhaul of the nation’s immigration system.

headline: Bill Is Passed to Make Kindergarten Mandatory for 5-Year-Olds
text: State lawmakers in Albany voted this week to make kindergarten mandatory for all 5-year-olds in New York City, lowering the required age for schooling by one year.

headline: Why Vincent Chin Matters
text: San Francisco

headline: Shaken by Sandusky Scandal, a Changed Penn State Is Moving On
text: With Penn State’s campus tucked away in a remote section of central Pennsylvania, one of its charms has always been its isolation and simplicity. The destination restaurant is The Tavern. The most popular hotel is still called an inn. And the primary administration building is simply known as Old Main.

headline: The (Sort of) New Mitt
text: Today: Mitt Romney and immigration.

headline: Bike-Share Program May Mean More Accident Suits Against the City, Liu Warns
text: The New York City comptroller, John C. Liu, is warning that the city’s ambitious bike-share program, which is to begin next month, could face lawsuits from accidents involving those bikes.

headline: Dolan Begins Religious Freedom Campaign
text: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan on Friday helped kick off a national campaign opposing President Obama’s health care mandates and other government policies that Roman Catholic leaders say threaten their religious freedom.

headline: Senate’s Vote Ousts Leader of Paraguay After a Clash
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Paraguay’s Senate voted on Friday to remove President Fernando Lugo from office, plunging the country into a political crisis. Mr. Lugo said he accepted the results of the hastily arranged vote, despite describing the efforts to remove him as an “express coup d’état.”

headline: 6 Charged in Murder of Rapper 50 Cent’s Associate
text: They called him Jimmy Henchman — the man with the Teflon reputation, tied for years to the feud that led to the murders of two legends of the hip-hop world.

headline: Velázquez and Opponents in House Race Debate Influences
text: During the only debate of the campaign, Representative Nydia M. Velázquez and her best-known opponent, Councilman Erik M. Dilan, fought back on Friday against accusations that they were controlled by others, describing themselves as “unbossed and unbought.”

headline: Finding in Sunlight a Sound and a Taste
text: Mountainville, N.Y. — A sparkling melody dances through the air on a hilltop in the south fields of Storm King Art Center, a sculpture park that spans 500 verdant acres here. Emanating from four bullhorn speakers mounted on a lone pole, the jazzy keyboard notes fill what is normally a silence broken only by birdsong and the occasional whoosh of the wind. Peter Coffin, the artist who created this sound installation, called it “a soundtrack to the sunshine,” an answer to the question: What does sunlight sound like?

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Buys a Newspaper in Texas
text: Berkshire Hathaway said on Friday that it had agreed to buy The Waco Tribune-Herald to expand in Texas. Berkshire is buying the newspaper, which has a daily circulation of 34,000, from the Robinson family, the company said. Terms were not disclosed. Warren E. Buffett, Berkshire’s chief, has said that newspapers must rethink whether to offer free content on the Internet, and that publications with a community focus can thrive where there is little competition.

headline: Runaway Masters
text: The Arago, a mail steamer, was scheduled to head north at dawn from the Union outpost on South Carolina’s Sea Islands. Any letters that missed the outgoing ship’s departure would wait for another 10 days. So it was that Maj. Gen. David Hunter stayed up all night on June 22, 1862, amid a violent thunderstorm, writing incessantly, assisted by his young aide, Maj. Charles Graham Halpine. Hunter, a West Pointer from the class of 1822, commanded “The Department of the South” — in Halpine’s words the “tortuous and broken sea-coast of Georgia, South Carolina, and Florida” that had proven vulnerable to Union naval probes.

headline: Where Was Stonewall?
text: In the early spring of 1862, the Confederate general Thomas J. “Stonewall” Jackson won dazzling victories in Virginia’s Shenandoah Valley that made him “the hero of the South.” Combining incredible energy and audacity with a mastery of terrain and tactics, Jackson’s Valley Campaign is internationally famous and still studied today.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mississippi’s Only Abortion Clinic at Risk as Law Nears
text: JACKSON, Miss. — It was only recently that Dr. Willie Parker began flying down here from Washington, heading to work at a vaultlike building that sits unassumingly on a busy thoroughfare. On his way in, he may pass Prof. Matt Friedeman, standing on the sidewalk with a Bible and a handful of pamphlets, having made the four-minute drive from his home as he has done once a week for years.

headline: Burger King, the Cash Cow
text: Earlier this week, a well-known company went public in a complicated transaction that involved a handful of Wall Street sharpies and a mysterious investment vehicle called a SPAC. The company was Burger King.

headline: Armstrong Could Lose More Than Titles if Guilty of Doping
text: Lance Armstrong should be ready to repay a $5 million performance bonus he earned by winning the 2004 Tour de France if the latest doping accusations against him lead to his losing that title, a lawyer for the company that paid that bonus said Friday.

headline: The Anti-Union Roberts Court
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling this week in Knox v. Service Employees International Union is one of the most brazen of the Roberts court. It shows how defiantly the five justices act in advancing the aggressive conservatism of their majority on the court.

headline: A Skewed Take on Love in the ’60s
text: Soon after “Luv” became a huge hit on Broadway in 1964, Murray Schisgal, its author, was asked in an interview to explain the title. The “emotion of love has been perverted and misused to such an extent that it can only be defined by using another word,” he answered in part. “L-u-v is the perversion of l-o-v-e.”

headline: Video Adds to Honduran Drug Raid Mystery
text: WASHINGTON — Aerial surveillance video of a fatal shootout during a counternarcotics mission in Honduras last month shows a long, dugout-style boat ramming a smaller canoe carrying Honduran and American agents — and a seized cocaine shipment — followed by a brief but furious round of gunfire.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 22
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Nik Wallenda’s tightrope walk across Niagara Falls, the first hot spell of summer and a rock slide in the Palisades.

headline: A Small Stimulus for Europe
text: At the conclusion of the meeting of leaders from the Group of 20 largest economies early this week, participants said they were united in their efforts to promote growth and jobs. But no one was sure whether Angela Merkel, Germany’s chancellor and a champion of budget austerity, was ready to drop her opposition to more government spending to ease Europe’s debt crisis. Her agreement on Friday to a stimulus package worth up to 130 billion euros is a welcome sign that she might come around after all.

headline: For Duquesne Professors, a Union Fight That Transcends Religion
text: “Union busting is a mortal sin,” the Catholic Scholars for Worker Justice said in a 2010 statement on the indispensable role of unions. And while the church hierarchy has never quite put it that way, workers’ right to unionize is an issue on which church teachings are pretty clear.

headline: A New Generation Keeps Up With Bruce Jenner
text: EUGENE, Ore. – For the first time since the 1976 Olympic trials, Bruce Jenner returned to Hayward Field on Friday as almost surely a bigger star now than he was then.

headline: What’s Missing From This Picture?
text: New York lawmakers had little reason to celebrate the conclusion of this year’s legislative session on Thursday. Gov. Andrew Cuomo praised the Legislature effusively for its work, but he failed to mention how he and lawmakers created corrupt legislative districts that will remain for a decade — the worst political act of the session.

headline: Realized in the End
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle almost made me weep with frustration, but I loved it. It’s the same as all the Saturday puzzles you’ve done, yet it’s not.

headline: Alan Turing’s Legacy
text: Alan Turing, born a century ago Saturday, was only 41 when he committed suicide. But into that short life, he crowded several lives. His essential insights into mathematics and the nature of computability dealt with the limits of what can be calculated by machines. One way to describe his achievement is to say that he was a genius of coded-ness, whether the code was mathematical, cryptological or biological.

headline: A Debate Goes Behind Closed Doors
text: In the long war over Wall Street regulation, a little-noticed clash erupted this week over a plan to rein in risky trading overseas.

headline: Sandusky Guilty of Sexual Abuse of 10 Young Boys
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Jerry Sandusky, a former Penn State assistant football coach, was convicted Friday of sexually abusing young boys, completing the downfall of a onetime local hero in a scandal that shook a proud Pennsylvania community, a prominent American university and the world of major college football.

headline: Seeking Some Revenge, Greece Comes Up Empty
text: RETHYMNO, Greece — Poor Greece. Condemned in the court of world opinion after an economic crisis spread around Europe, Greek fans had to swallow a humiliating 4-2 thrashing on Friday night in Gdansk, Poland, at the hands of Germany as the delighted German chancellor, Angela Merkel, looked on in the stands.

headline: Rodriguez, Having Been Down Similar Path, Is Happy to See James Win a Title
text: Alex Rodriguez watched his hometown Miami Heat win the N.B.A. championship on Thursday night, and immediately knew the exhilaration and relief that LeBron James was experiencing. Rodriguez said he felt the same way three years ago when he won his first World Series and eliminated one source of ammunition from his critics.

headline: Florida Struggles to Overcome Threats to Freshwater Springs
text: SILVER SPRINGS, Fla. — Of Florida’s 700 artesian springs, Silver Springs shimmered the brightest. Its fresh water was so translucent that the white sand and tiny shells at the bottom glistened, giving the river and springs a beautiful blue tint from above.

headline: Bullies on the Bus
text: “Making the Bus Monitor Cry.”

headline: A Digital Art Space
text: APP MoMA Art Lab

headline: Cost of Minnesota Flood Estimated at $100 Million
text: The waters in Duluth are receding, but the damage is done: the northeastern Minnesota city estimates more than $100 million will be required to repair utilities, streets, parks and trails in the city and surrounding county of St. Louis, said Pakou Ly, a spokeswoman for Duluth. The State Department of Transportation estimates its roads have sustained $20 million worth of damage.

headline: Searching for a New Economy
text: Given persistent debt troubles, the deep divisions between haves and have nots, and wear and tear on the planet’s living systems, there’s much talk these days of new ways to define, gauge and nurture economic progress.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Jamie Dimon testified again about JPMorgan Chase’s huge trading loss, the Federal Reserve outlined more steps to help the economy and Ann Curry’s negotiations to leave the “Today” show signaled greater problems at NBC.

headline: Mike Miller Shows How Heat’s System Can Work
text: In 12 N.B.A. seasons, Mike Miller earned a reputation as a reliable sharpshooting veteran. Though he’s received accolades like Rookie of the Year (2001) and Sixth Man of the Year (2006), an N.B.A. championship eluded him.

headline: Delighting in Sea Mail
text: HARVEY BENNETT, 61, has lived his entire life in Amagansett, on the East End of Long Island, but every few months since childhood, he has cast his fortunes out on the high seas by putting a note in a bottle and throwing it into the ocean.

headline: The Third Intifada Is Inevitable
text: Jerusalem

headline: Friends, Nostalgia and a Mountain of Seafood
text: Summer on the shore evokes soft breezes, cold beer, mini-golf, fried clams and lobsters the color of sunset. This year, that vision becomes reality amid the warehouses and cobblestone streets of Red Hook, Brooklyn, right across the street from the Fairway parking lot. In just two weeks, Brooklyn Crab has become the hot new vacation spot — for an evening. It’s beach-town kitsch a long block from the New York Harbor.

headline: Mets Closer Stirs Pot, Then Shuts Door
text: Hours before thousands of fans watched Frank Francisco dance around the Yankees in the rain, the Mets’ closer walked into the clubhouse Friday either unaware or ambivalent about the weight of his words, serenaded by the “Chicken Dance” song and surprised with a copy of The New York Post at his locker.

headline: The Pepsi Septuagenarian
text: The breakout star of this year’s N.B.A. finals was not a member of the Miami Heat or the Oklahoma City Thunder, but instead a man appearing to be well into his 70s who had supernatural basketball gifts and referred to himself simply as Uncle Drew.

headline: Emerson College Makes Splash in N.B.A.
text: BOSTON – Situated in the heart of the city’s theater district, Emerson College boasts a list of notable alumni that includes the longtime Hollywood figures Jay Leno, Norman Lear and Henry Winkler.

headline: Game 5 Draws Highest Average Audience of Series
text: The Miami Heat won the N.B.A. title Thursday night, but even after being blown out in Game 5, the Oklahoma City Thunder proved emphatically that their small-market status did not hurt viewership.

headline: Pittsburgh-Carolina Trade Reunites Staal Brothers
text: PITTSBURGH — On Tuesday, Stefan Matteau, son of the former Ranger Stephane Matteau, whose famous overtime goal beat the Devils in Game 7 of the 1994 Eastern Conference finals, said it would be “a bit ironic” if he wound up being drafted by the Devils rather than the Rangers later in the week.

headline: California: Cigarette Tax Defeated
text: Voters narrowly rejected a proposed $1-a-pack tax increase on cigarettes. On Friday, trailing by about 28,000 votes with just over 100,000 ballots left to count, proponents of the statewide tax conceded defeat. The vote had remained too close to call since polls closed on June 5. California has not raised the tax since 1998, and proceeds from the tax would have financed cancer research. Opponents of the tax spent nearly $50 million, largely from the tobacco industry, to defeat the measure.

headline: I.R.A. Ex-Commander to Shake Hands With Queen
text: DUBLIN — In one of the most anticipated gestures in recent Irish history, a former commander of the Irish Republican Army will shake hands next week in Belfast with Queen Elizabeth II, once a prime target of I.R.A. attacks, the group’s onetime political wing announced Friday.

headline: 10K Runners Are First to Make Olympic Team
text: EUGENE, Ore. – Running through rain that was at times torrential, Galen Rupp, Matt Tegenkamp and Dathan Ritzenhein became the first runners to officially make the United States Olympic team Friday night when they qualified in the 10,000 meters.

headline: Virginia: Governor Threatens University Board With Removal
text: The University of Virginia must decide on Tuesday whether to keep its president, Gov. Robert F. McDonnell said Friday, or he will ask the entire governing board to step down. The president, Teresa Sullivan, resigned two weeks ago after being told the Board of Visitors wanted her out. But protests from faculty members and students prompted the board to call next Tuesday’s meeting on her status. “I want final action by the board on Tuesday,” Governor McDonnell wrote in a letter to the board. “If you fail to do so, I will call for the resignation of the entire board on Wednesday.”

headline: For 40-Year-Old Rookie, Leader Board Is Long Way From Selling Knives
text: CROMWELL, Conn. — Kimberly Christian could not help but chuckle earlier this week when she noticed that the PGA Tour Web site had divided the Travelers Championship field by age and listed her husband, Gary, under the category of grizzled veterans.

headline: Hiding Out, With Books and Food
text: As an editor at Simon & Schuster, Karen Thompson Walker used to spend her days polishing the prose of her roster of authors. But nearly every morning for more than three years, she was also rising at 7 to squeeze in an hour or two of writing before going to her day job in Midtown Manhattan. The product of that quiet endeavor is her debut novel, an apocalyptic tale titled “The Age of Miracles,” which will be published by Random House on Tuesday. Now a full-time writer, Ms. Walker, 32, lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with her husband, Casey, 32, who recently earned a Ph.D. in English literature from Princeton and has enrolled in the Iowa Writers’ Workshop in the fall. Until the couple pick up and move to Iowa City in August, they can be found wandering Brooklyn on Sundays.

headline: Mets Make Opening Statement Hold Up
text: Because of an ill-considered comment by Frank Francisco, the Mets’ shaky closer, there was a heightened sense of drama in the ninth inning at Citi Field on Friday. Would the Yankees make Francisco pay for his remark, or would he back up his brash statement?

headline: Oars Fly in Rumble on the River
text: AMANDA KRAUS stood in her favorite spot on the second-floor deck of the Peter Jay Sharp Boathouse, which floats in a cove on the Harlem River where Dyckman Street meets the Harlem River Drive. She watched as a pair of $45,000 shells, each propelled by a gaggle of high school students, eight to a squad, rushed past. “When done right, it’s poetry in motion,” she said of rowing crew.

headline: Lee Is Doing Everything for Phillies but Winning
text: PHILADELPHIA — Cliff Lee was scheduled to start Friday night’s game for the Phillies before it was rained out, and his basic season statistics read this way: 0-3, 3.48. That record would generate scrutiny for a past Cy Young Award winner in the season’s first month. But the season is in its third month, and Lee is still winless.

headline: The Road to the Ironman
text: GUY ADAMI has experienced the thrill of trading millions of dollars in precious metals in a matter of seconds on Wall Street in the 1990s, and analyzing the financial crisis each afternoon as a panelist on the live CNBC program “Fast Money.”

headline: I’ll Have Another Will Stand Stud in Japan
text: I’ll Have Another, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes last month, will head to Japan to stand at stud.

headline: Offspring Who Cling to the Nest
text: Not too long ago, I asked a friend, the mother of two daughters who are 9 and 13, whether she had ever taken her children to Disney World — a contractual obligation of parenthood, I assumed. The girls attend a progressive school in New York, and their tastes and proclivities run accordingly. The older might be found on a Saturday cooking ground ostrich in spices, in deference to ancient Roman cuisine. The younger can solve elaborate cubic puzzles in the time it takes to turn on a faucet.

headline: Working Russia’s Streets, and Its Halls of Power
text: MOSCOW

headline: The Classes of P.S. 99
text: Queens is the most diverse county in the country, and its evolution is visible in these class photographs from P.S. 99 in the Kew Gardens neighborhood.

headline: In Class Photos, Faces of Change
text: QUEENS is the most diverse county in the country, and one way to see that is to view a historical panorama of students from Public School 99 in Kew Gardens. A series of class photographs, beginning in 1929 and continuing through June 2012, puts faces on the decennial census results, which quantify the neighborhood’s evolution. Joseph De May Jr., 62, who has lived in Kew Gardens since 1974, has collected 313 of the pictures on a Web site, A Picture History of Kew Gardens, NY, dedicated to depicting the metamorphosis in the faces of the community’s students.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Silver Springs in Florida Threatened
text: Silver Springs in Florida has experienced a sharp drop-off in flows and a steady rise in algae.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Poland: Radio Hosts Apologize
text: Derogatory remarks by a pair of Polish radio hosts about their Ukrainian housekeepers escalated into an international incident this week, forcing them to issue an on-air apology. On Friday, the hosts, Michal Figurski and Kuba Wojewodzki of Radio Eska, expressed “deep regret about our comments concerning Ukrainian women,” adding, “We personally believe that Ukrainian women possess exceptional beauty, which elicits both our admiration and respect,” according to the Unian news agency. The hosts’ offensive remarks last week prompted the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry to protest to the Polish National Council of Television and Radio. The ministry criticized the comments as “offending the honor and dignity of Ukrainians” and demanded a public apology.

headline: Richard Adler, ‘Pajama Game’ Collaborator, Dies at 90
text: Richard Adler, a composer and lyricist whose towering early successes on Broadway in the 1950s — the smash hits “The Pajama Game” and “Damn Yankees” — were followed abruptly by the death of his creative collaborator, died on Thursday at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Edward N. Costikyan, Adviser to New York Politicians, Is Dead at 87
text: Edward N. Costikyan, a former adviser to New York governors and mayors who as a Democratic Party insurgent in the early 1960s took over the leadership of the party as it rooted out a century of Tammany Hall bossism, died on Friday at his home in Mount Pleasant, S.C. He was 87.

headline: Corrections: June 23
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Could a Falling Out Bring France Together?
text: France and Holland were never pitted directly against each other at this summer’s European Championships, but they continue to compete for the title of European soccer’s perennial subversives.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: In northern Kashmir, near the Line of Control that divides the Indian and Pakistan-controlled territories in the region, security personnel recovered a huge cache of arms and ammunition, Kashmir live reported. The supplies were “apparently dumped by arms smugglers for use of militants operating in the Valley,” the newspaper wrote.

headline: The Early Word: Guinea Pig
text: Today’s Times

headline: Father of Modern Computing, Nazi Code Breaker, Homosexual
text: LONDON — The centenary of the birth of Alan Turing, the World War II code-breaker and father of modern computing, was marked on Saturday with memorials, exhibitions and academic gatherings in his native Britain and beyond.

text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Do Democrats Have a Shot at the House?
text: So far this election season we have written very little about the race for the House of Representatives. In part this is because this looks to be less dramatic than the presidential race — where Barack Obama has only a slight edge, in my view — or the race for the Senate, which looks increasingly like a tossup.

headline: British Airways Menu Designed to Retain Flavor in Flight
text: A golden beet root starter, a rillette of mackerel and a chocolate fondant are the latest creations of the Michelin-starred chef Heston Blumenthal. To sample them, you’ll have to be 30,000 feet in the air.

headline: Ermenegildo Zegna Men’s
text: Milan

headline: Progress on the Sidelines as Rio Conference Ends
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Burdened by low expectations, snarled by endless traffic congestion and shunned by President Obama, the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development ended here as it began, under a shroud of withering criticism.

headline: Now Streaming | Burberry Prorsum Spring 2013 Men’s Collection Show
text: The Spring 2013 men’s collection from Burberry at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: At Sander’s Show, Watching a Master’s Work
text: MILAN — Rust never sleeps, as Neil Young once famously noted. Yet, after years spent tending her gardens outside Hamburg, Germany, in what can only be called semi-voluntary retirement Jil Sander returned Saturday to the label that bears her name and the city where she made her reputation to prove that, if you are sufficiently gifted, you can outrun it.

headline: Leaving Baggage On the Dock, a Flagship Departs From California
text: FREMONT, Calif. — On a Friday filled with press conferences, roundtable discussions, production-line walk-throughs and chaperoned test drives, it was only at a concluding pep rally, held on the Tesla Motors factory floor here, that the mood became palpable. As executives for the electric-vehicle start-up handed keys to the first Model S sedans to retail customers, the sense of a victory, to some an improbable one, came across as loud and giddy as any celebration of a basketball championship.

headline: Rangers’ Closer Nathan Passes Rivera
text: June has been very good for Texas Rangers closer Joe Nathan. He is the only player from Stony Brook University to reach the major leagues, and four years ago he donated $500,000 to help the university build a baseball field, which bears his name. The Seawolves reached their first College World Series this month, and Nathan has thrived along with his alma mater.

headline: 60 Years Ago, an Olympic Trifecta of Endurance
text: I have been fortunate to attend many big international track meets. Each one brought memorable moments, including record performances and crowds of spectators that intermingled in appreciation of the sport.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Turkey Vows Action After Downing of Jet by Syria
text: CAIRO — Turkey’s president said Saturday that his country would do “whatever is necessary” in response to the downing of a Turkish military jet by Syria, adding a new complication to the tense relationship between the former allies split by Turkey’s support for Syrian rebels trying to overthrow the government.

headline: Not So Easy on the Eyes
text: Greg Maddux won 355 games as a starting pitcher based largely on his ability to vary the speed between his fastball and changeup by as little as five to six miles per hour, which was enough to throw hitters off balance.

headline: Playing Like Bombers, but Power Has Its Limits
text: There was something poetic and appropriate about Alex Rodriguez’s home run in the sixth inning Friday night. It traced an arching path back over the pitcher’s head, cleared the 408-foot marker on the center-field wall and landed right in the well of the Mets’ home run apple.

headline: Variety: Spiral
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — You don’t need me for this. Honestly.

headline: Wave of Violence Swallows More Women in Juárez
text: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — First, there were just a few bones and body parts, found in a valley beyond the sprawl of this wild city. At least four women had been killed and dumped, the authorities said. Then, in the same area, investigators made another discovery early this year: a dozen more dead women and girls.

headline: Knicks’ Lin Is Guarding a Word That Defined a Craze
text: By Feb. 13, Jeremy Lin was five games into transforming the Knicks. He was the point guard they craved, the player whose court vision, zippy passing and double-figure scoring brought unexpected joy to Madison Square Garden. From Seventh Avenue to Taiwan, he became a phenomenon: Linsanity.

headline: Sandusky Son With Troubled Past Went From Ally to Accuser
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Matt Sandusky appeared in the Centre County Courthouse ostensibly as a loyal if silent supporter of his adoptive father, Jerry Sandusky.

headline: Wearing Brave Face, Obama Braces for Health Care Ruling
text: Late on Tuesday, March 27, halfway around the world, President Obama began one of the most suspenseful waits in recent presidential history.

headline: In College Ball, Northern Teams Look for Help
text: OMAHA — Any college baseball player or coach from the northern part of the country can identify with Kent State’s path to the College World Series.

headline: In Egypt, Declaration of Winner in Presidential Contest Is Said to Be Near
text: CAIRO — The commission overseeing Egypt’s first competitive presidential election will declare an official winner on Sunday, the panel said Saturday, amid growing conviction that the announcement has become a bargaining chip in a negotiation for power between the ruling generals and the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Greek Coalition Outlines Plan to Renegotiate Loan Deal
text: ATHENS — Two days before Greece’s international creditors return to Athens to begin talks on keeping the nearly bankrupt country solvent, the new coalition government on Saturday highlighted the main points it plans to renegotiate with lenders, aiming to revoke certain taxes, suspend planned layoffs in the bloated public sector and extend by two years the deadline for imposing additional austerity measures.

headline: Decathlon Champion Stumbles at U.S. Trials
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Twenty years and some 2,000 miles removed from the most memorable duel (and startling stumble) in United States decathlon history, a serendipitous twist of timing appeared to have left the sport on the cusp of another American renaissance. The Olympic trials here were supposed to be the send-off. There was the veteran Bryan Clay, 32, hoping to defend his gold medal from Beijing; there was the defending world champion, Trey Hardee, 28, squarely in his prime; and there was the phenom Ashton Eaton, who at 24 may already be the best of the group. American dominance in London seemed almost assured.

headline: Euro 2012 Quarterfinals: Spain 2, France 0
text: Midfielder Xabi Alonso scored two goals in his 100th appearance for Spain, giving the defending World Cup and European champions a 2-0 victory over France on Saturday in a Euro 2012 quarterfinal in Donetsk, Ukraine.

headline: Apple’s Retail Army, Long on Loyalty but Short on Pay
text: Last year, during his best three-month stretch, Jordan Golson sold about $750,000 worth of computers and gadgets at the Apple Store in Salem, N.H. It was a performance that might have called for a bottle of Champagne — if that were a luxury Mr. Golson could have afforded.

headline: From Colombia to Los Angeles, Angels’ Frieri Surpasses Expectations
text: Ernesto Frieri was 12 years old when his countryman Edgar Renteria lined a single up the middle to win Game 7 of the 1997 World Series for the Florida Marlins. Frieri was a soccer player, like most boys in Colombia, he said, but he was captivated by Renteria.

headline: With Wild West Spirit, Tombstone Fights for Its Water
text: TOMBSTONE, Ariz. — The rules were clear: no vehicles and no heavy machinery on the mountainside spot ravaged by fire and rain. Fixing the PVC pipe that carries water from a spring in the Coronado National Forest to this old frontier boomtown, the United States Forest Service decreed, would have to be done by hand.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Dolce&Gabbana Men’s
text: Milan

headline: World War II Soccer Match Echoes Through Time
text: KIEV, Ukraine — There are few striking features about Start Stadium except its disrepair. Wooden planks in the grandstand, like neglected teeth, are mostly loose or missing. Behind the tiny seating area, though, a sturdy column rises and supports a statue. It depicts a muscular, naked man heroically kicking a soccer ball into the beak of a trampled eagle.

headline: Violence Escalates on Gaza Border
text: TEL AVIV — Despite a pledged cease-fire agreement between Hamas and Israel, strikes resumed on both sides of the Gaza border on Saturday, killing at least two Palestinian men and a 6-year-old boy in Gaza, and wounding an Israeli man in Sderot, officials said.

headline: More Stringent Requirements Send Nurses Back to School
text: ABINGTON, Pa. — Jennifer Matton is going to college for the third time, no easy thing with a job, church groups and four children with activities from lacrosse to Boy Scouts. She always planned to return to school, but as it turned out, she had little choice: her career depended on it.

headline: A Knuckleball Fraternity of One
text: R. A. Dickey has an energetic mind, an expansive imagination. So, sure, he will not rule out a future in which more pitchers embrace his chosen weapon, the knuckleball, and give it equal billing alongside baseball’s 100-mile-per-hour fastballs and 12-to-6 curves.

headline: Political Scientists Are Lousy Forecasters
text: DESPERATE “Action Alerts” land in my in-box. They’re from the American Political Science Association and colleagues, many of whom fear grave “threats” to our discipline. As a defense, they’ve supplied “talking points” we can use to tell Congressional representatives that political science is a “critical part of our national science agenda.”

headline: As Hopes for Reform Fade in Bahrain, Protesters Turn Anger on United States
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — In a dark alleyway of a low-slung suburb here, two dozen protesters gathered quietly and prepared to march toward a United States naval base. A teenager wrapped his scarf close to his mouth, bracing for tear gas. A man peeked out of his doorway, holding his infant daughter above his head, to show her a ritual of defiance that has become a grinding way of life.

headline: A Georgia Town Takes the People’s Business Private
text: SANDY SPRINGS, Ga.

headline: Serena Williams Feeling Confident Ahead of Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The turnaround from the red clay of Roland Garros to the pristine lawns of the All England Club is perhaps the most challenging in tennis, akin to plunging into a cold tub right after a soothing dip in the whirlpool — a shock to the system without the chattering teeth. Patience may be a virtue at the French Open, which rewards consistent baseliners, but it is a vice at Wimbledon, where, Maria Sharapova said, anything longer than a five-ball rally means “you’re probably doing something wrong.”

headline: Police Make an Arrest in 3 Killings Near Columbia University
text: Detectives on Saturday arrested a 30-year-old man suspected of fatally shooting three men as all four were sitting in a BMW parked across the street from a Columbia University building this month.

headline: Malaysia Haze Points to a Regional Problem
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — For much of the year, the Petronas Towers, the world’s tallest twin buildings, are gleaming landmarks visible far from the city center here. But last weekend, the 88-story structures were shrouded in a smoky haze that prompted doctors to warn people with respiratory problems to wear masks.

headline: Rangers Keeping Core Intact
text: PITTSBURGH — The Rangers will try to improve via free agency rather than by a trade that will cost them key young players, General Manager Glen Sather said at the conclusion of the N.H.L. entry draft Saturday afternoon.

headline: Nature: Now Showing on TV
text: ONE morning some birder pals and I spend an hour at Sapsucker Woods in Ithaca, N.Y., watching two great blue herons feed their five rowdy chicks. It’s a perfect setting for nesting herons, with an oak-snag overhanging a plush green pond, shallows to hunt in and a living larder of small fish and frogs. Only weeks old, the chicks are mainly fluff and appetite.

headline: As Wimbledon Approaches, Crime Novelists Hover
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Alan Chalmers stood like a sentry at Gangway 210 leading to Centre Court at the All England Club.

headline: Share the Wealth
text: Philadelphia

headline: Money or Your Life
text: This is the first article in Bedside, a new series about nursing and health care.

headline: ‘We’re Not Coming Home This Time Without a Gold Medal’
text: Matt Scott, who played wheelchair basketball for the United States in the 2004 and 2008 Paralympic Games, is preparing for the 2012 Games in London. He also plays professionally in Turkey with Galatasaray.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Electing a President
text: Readers offer opinions on the national popular vote plan.

headline: Joshua Bell
text: Joshua Bell is a Grammy Award-winning violinist. He is the music director of the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields, a London-based chamber orchestra, but lives in New York.

headline: The New Busking
text: THREE months ago I had never heard of Kickstarter, the Web site where you can raise funds for a creative project. Today I stand exposed as someone who miserably failed to raise a budget of $21,000 to make a CD with my band, Afro-Jersey. A once celebrated contributor to my profession, I am the artist formerly known as “one of The Roches.”

headline: Farewell to Chocolate City
text: “NOW, I’m not proud of what I did,” my friend Donna said the other day, her voice dropping to a low, confessional register.

headline: High School Student Starts Summer Vacation by Running in Olympic Trials
text: Most athletes currently competing at the United States Olympic trials in Eugene, Ore., at least entertain the possibility that they might qualify for team that will travel to London next month. Mary Cain was just happy to be there.

headline: Mexican Democracy’s Lost Years
text: Mexico City

headline: Former Russian Minister Warns of Economic Ebb
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — President Vladimir V. Putin was all swagger last week at the annual economic forum here, effectively wagging a finger at Europe over its fiscal problems and keeping the chief executives of some of the world’s most powerful oil companies waiting for hours in a hallway until he finally met with them. In the forum’s keynote address, Mr. Putin boasted of Russia’s relatively low debt burden, balanced budget and “fiscal discipline.”

headline: Planned Parenthood’s Self-Destructive Behavior
text: PLANNED PARENTHOOD has a large target on its back. At no time in the organization’s history has it faced such a concerted Congressional challenge to its agenda. But most worrisome is the organization’s shrinking number of defenders, and Planned Parenthood has only itself to blame. It has adopted a strategy driven by blind partisanship, electing to burn bridges instead of building them. That strategy is damaging, and possibly imperiling, its mission.

headline: Some Books Are More Equal Than Others
text: BECAUSE I am a middle school reading enrichment teacher, parents and colleagues often ask my advice about summer assignments. My automatic reply echoes a hit song from the ’70s, “any love is good lovin’.” I tell them blithely that any reading is good reading, while I think to myself, we’ll take whatever we can get.

headline: A Few Who Could Surprise at Wimbledon
text: MEN

headline: End of a Career Echoed the Beginning
text: In the end, Kerry Wood took control. His career had sent him down so many twisting paths and challenged him with 15 trips to the disabled list. But when Wood sensed the end last month, he went out on his terms.

headline: Information for Us, or for the Enemy?
text: Re “National Secrets and National Security” (June 17):

headline: Still Depressed, After All These Years
text: With Europe suffering under self-destructive austerity and the United States facing its own prospect of punishing budget cuts, it is easy to forget that the housing bust has been the biggest drag on the economy over the past five years. Even with recent housing market improvements, sales and construction are still at very low levels, while prices are still falling in most areas.

headline: What Sheldon Adelson Wants
text: No American is dedicating as much of his money to defeat President Obama as Sheldon Adelson, the casino magnate who also happens to have made more money in the last three years than any other American. He is the perfect illustration of the squalid state of political money, spending sums greater than any political donation in history to advance his personal, ideological and financial agenda, which is wildly at odds with the nation’s needs.

headline: Alabama’s White Elephant
text: Federal taxpayers have spent almost $250 million on a new federal prison for women in Aliceville, Ala., that should never have been built. The prison is almost completed and, within a year or so, is scheduled to house around 1,500 secure prisoners as well as 250 minimum-security inmates — or about one of every eight women in federal prison.

headline: Outsourcing City Hall
text: Since the day Sandy Springs, Ga., incorporated, it has handed off to private enterprise just about every public service. Leaders call the system “the model.”

headline: Retired Horace Mann Teacher Admits to Sex With Students
text: Tek Young Lin was revered at the Horace Mann School. He was different from other teachers — a Buddhist who carefully tended to his elaborate gardens, a chaplain and a cross-country coach. He was so beloved that the English department chairmanship was named in his honor.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: June 24
text: At the end of a week that saw tensions mount between the Obama administration and House Republicans, Representative Darrell Issa of California will appear on three shows to offer his perspective.

headline: Foie Gras a Faux Pas?
text: This is the last week for legal foie gras in California. A law to shut down the making, cooking and selling of super-fatty goose or duck liver takes effect July 1. Chowhounds from Chico to Chula Vista have been opening their wallets for restaurants’ foie gras menus, gorging themselves like birds before the winter migration. The law’s purpose is to end gavage, the ancient practice of forcing grain down the throat of a goose or duck until its liver is grossly enlarged. The law’s critics say gavage is hardly more stress-inducing than the many other things humans do to the animals they eat. The corporate operations that grow and slaughter pigs, poultry and cattle represent animal cruelty on an immense scale, they say, about which the foie gras ban does nothing.

headline: The Court’s Moment
text: The challenge to the Affordable Care Act  tops the list of Supreme Court rulings expected this week. The big question is whether Congress has the power to require that individuals buy or obtain health insurance as part of a comprehensive reform. Other issues are whether Congress can broaden Medicaid coverage of the poor and taxpayers can even challenge the individual mandate before it takes effect in 2014. The outcome — aside from determining whether millions of Americans will get health coverage — will show whether the Roberts court recognizes that constitutional law requires that it defer to Congress on matters affecting the national economy.

headline: Live Coverage Sunday of England vs. Italy
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 game between England and Italy on Sunday at 2:45 p.m. ET. Jeffrey Marcus will offer commentary and analysis of the quarterfinal match.

headline: Last Lap for Transportation Bill
text: Congressional negotiators are racing to agree on a transportation bill before the current law expires on June 30. The choices before them are wildly different: a Senate bill that would invest $109 billion over two years on critical road, bridge and mass transit projects, and an ideologically driven, short-term House bill that is loaded with anti-environmental riders and would extend current financing for only three months, leaving future financing up in the air.

headline: Suggested Safeguards Irk Fund Industry
text: FOR a moment last week, watching the Senate Banking Committee hearings on money market mutual fund reforms, I thought I had fallen into a time warp. As Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, outlined proposals meant to ensure that taxpayers would never need to bail out a money fund, some of the sharp questioning she received had a depressingly familiar ring.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 17
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Let Everyone Swim, but Make Sure You’re in the Pool
text: This interview with  Angie Hicks, co-founder and chief marketing officer of Angie’s List, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: All the President’s Privileges
text: WHEN George W. Bush was president of the United States, it was an article of faith among liberals that many of his policies were not just misguided but unconstitutional as well. On issues large and small, from the conduct of foreign policy to the firing of United States attorneys, the Bush White House pushed an expansive view of executive authority, and Democrats pushed right back — accusing it of shredding the constitution, claiming near-imperial powers and even corrupting the lawyers working in its service.

headline: The Rise of Popularism
text: TRAVELING in Europe last week, it seemed as if every other conversation ended with some form of this question: Why does it feel like so few leaders are capable of inspiring their people to meet the challenges of our day? There are many explanations for this global leadership deficit, but I’d focus on two: one generational, one technological.

headline: Three Months in Customer Service Limbo
text: THE Haggler’s column about a man whose Facebook account was hijacked by a sneaker-selling spammer provoked a lot of been-there e-mails, and some of them were kind of amusing. One, from Bryan Dale of Toronto, is destined to become a plot point in a Channing Tatum rom-com:

headline: نه چندان احمقانه در تهران
text: This is the Persian-language translation of a New York Times Op-Ed column by Nicholas D. Kristof. If you cannot view the Persian, you might need to adjust the settings on your Web browser or on your computer’s operating system.

headline: Not-So-Crazy in Tehran
text: To watch the video, press the play button in the bottom-left corner of the image.

headline: ‘Exergames’ Don’t Cure Young Couch Potatoes
text: GETTING our sedentary, overweight children off the couch is a challenge. That’s why the Nintendo Wii game console, which arrived in the United States six years ago, was such an exciting prospect. It offered the chance for children to get exercise without even leaving the house.

headline: Burberry Prorsum: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Burberry Prorsum Men’s
text: Milan

headline: E-Tailer Customization: Convenient or Creepy?
text: DMITRI SIEGEL, until last year a marketing executive at Urban Outfitters, thought he had hit on a novel idea to personalize the company’s Web site for frequent customers. He would make it easier for female shoppers to peruse women’s apparel and for men to concentrate on men’s clothing by altering the site’s product displays to match a user’s gender.

headline: A Happy Ending for the Matteaus
text: PITTSBURGH — The biggest eyebrow-raiser of the N.H.L. entry draft here this weekend was the Devils choosing Stefan Matteau with the 29th pick Friday night after the Rangers had passed on him at No. 28. Matteau was amusing in his comments to reporters, wryly asserting that “I’m in shock myself” about going to the Devils, the team his father beat with a Game 7 overtime goal at Madison Square Garden in 1994.

headline: Colors of Confinement
text: Newly discovered Kodachrome color photographs from a Japanese American Internment Camp in Wyoming, 1943-44.

headline: Injustice, in Kodachrome
text: On Feb. 19, 1942, two months after Japan’s attack on Pearl Harbor, President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed an executive order that the United States military used to remove every person of Japanese ancestry from the West Coast. Among the 120,000 people rounded up — two-thirds of them citizens — was Bill Manbo, an auto mechanic from Riverside, Calif., who dabbled in photography and model airplanes. He and his wife, Mary; their baby son, Billy; and her mother and younger siblings were detained at a racetrack near Los Angeles. (Mary’s father, who had been interned as an “enemy alien,” soon joined them after he was determined not to be a threat.)

headline: Investors Muddle Through Mire of Uncertainty
text: IN Europe, the obsessive concern of policy makers shifted from Greece to Spain, with its ailing banks and brutally high bond yields. In China and in the United States, there were signs of economic slowdowns. And for investors nearly everywhere, it was difficult to muster much confidence.

headline: Reviving Real Estate Requires Collective Action
text: IMAGINE that you are watching an outdoor theater production while sitting on the grass. You have difficulty seeing, so you prop yourself up on your knees. Soon everyone behind you does the same. Eventually, most people are kneeling or standing, yet they are less comfortable than they were before and have no better view. Everyone should sit down, and everyone knows it, but no one does.

headline: Lesley Brown, Mother of World’s First ‘Test-Tube Baby,’ Dies at 64
text: Lesley Brown, the mother of the world’s first “test-tube baby” — Louise Brown, born July 25, 1978 — died on June 6 in Bristol, England. She was 64.

headline: Letting the Mission Govern a Company
text: THREE years ago, in front of my 300 colleagues at LRN, I ripped up our organizational chart and proclaimed that none of us would report to a boss anymore. From that point on, we would all “report” to our company mission. Literally. No one would experience life at LRN as someone else’s subordinate. In short, we would strive to become a self-governing company.

headline: Element of Surprise
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh my. I’m blushing right now because I did not get this theme at first, and now that I’ve figured it out (with some help from a friend) I’m in awe. All I needed was a smack upside the back of the head, which loosened up the brain bits that still remember my high school chemistry. Element of surprise, indeed.

headline: Lessons of Early Hardship
text: I WAS born in Hattiesburg, Miss. When I was 5 years old my parents moved to Georgia, to begin new teaching jobs.

headline: Gitta Sereny, Author Who Focused on Evildoers, Dies at 91
text: Gitta Sereny, an Austrian-born English journalist whose work, which included portraits of Nazi war criminals and studies of youthful murderers, repeatedly and sometimes controversially sought to illuminate the wellsprings of evil, died on June 14 in Cambridge, England. She was 91.

headline: Letters: How to Mend Trust in the U.S. Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Getting Personal With Marketing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bringing Water to Tombstone
text: Volunteers hiked into the Coronado National Forest in Arizona, and moved by hand boulders that disrupted the water supply lines funneling water from mountain springs into Tombstone.

headline: In Paraguay, Democracy’s All-Too-Speedy Trial
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the span of a few hours on Friday, Paraguay’s Senate convened its members, read a list of accusations and put President Fernando Lugo on trial. Dismissing his request for more time to mount his defense, the senators abruptly voted to oust him from office, spurring a fierce debate across Latin America over the fragility of democratic institutions in a region with a long history of dictatorships.

headline: Segregated Funerals in the South
text: Charles Menendez runs a funeral home about an hour’s drive east of Atlanta. All of his cases are black.

headline: Helpful Hands on Life’s Last Segregated Journey
text: MADISON, Ga. — When a black person dies in one of the rural counties around here, chances are the body will end up in the hands of Charles Menendez.

headline: A Law That Lets the State Decide Who Can File Suit Against It
text: After December 2009, you have to assume that lawyers for every coach thinking about taking a job at a Texas college — or anyone looking at any contract with the state — would have boned up on sovereign immunity law.

headline: Crackdown Intensifies on Barratry
text: Joined by lawyers who are tired of competitors illegally soliciting business after accidents, prosecutors are cracking down on a lesser-known, multimillion-dollar criminal enterprise in Texas: barratry.

headline: Versace: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Versace Men’s
text: Milan

headline: State Spending for Weight-Loss Surgery Increases
text: As the numbers of obese in Texas have swelled, so has the comfort of state and federal lawmakers with spending taxpayer dollars on weight-loss surgery for the elderly and the poor.

headline: A Chance to Challenge Phelps, Maybe
text: OMAHA — In the individual medley events, the swimmer Tyler Clary has spent the past four years playing Andy Murray to Michael Phelps’s Rafael Nadal and Ryan Lochte’s Novak Djokovic.

headline: Reader Comments on Iran
text: My Sunday column is my last from my Iran road trip, and it’s accompanied by a terrific video made by a Times video journalist, Adam Ellick, who accompanied me. I am still somewhat surprised and awed that Iran not only gave us visas but also allowed us to travel across the country unescorted. After all, Bahrain — our ally! — doesn’t even give me a visa, because of my human rights reporting.

headline: Supporters Slow to Grasp Health Law’s Legal Risks
text: WASHINGTON — With the Supreme Court likely to render judgment on President Obama’s health care law this week, the White House and Congress find themselves in a position that many advocates of the legislation once considered almost unimaginable.

headline: My Iranian Road Trip
text: A short documentary follows the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof as he travels across the country talking to ordinary citizens about their lives and the effectiveness of American sanctions.

headline: Juror Says Panel Had Little Doubt on Sandusky’s Guilt
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Joshua Harper watched Jerry Sandusky listen to one guilty verdict after another — 45 in all — and was more certain than ever that Sandusky, the former Penn State football assistant, had sexually abused those young boys. Sandusky never flinched. No sign of regret creased his face.

headline: In a Secret Ballot, Pole-Vaulters Have Their Say
text: EUGENE, Ore. — How is it determined that an Olympic trials competition should be postponed because of weather? Sometimes, apparently, the process resembles a student council election.

headline: Critics See Flaws in Spain’s Art
text: KIEV, Ukraine — A consensus has formed at Euro 2012. Germany is the team to beat. Spain cannot decide on a lineup. It seems unsettled, if hardly unnerved. This is what happens when people are no longer content with beauty and now expect perfection.

headline: For Wealthy Romney Donors, Up Close and Personal Access
text: PARK CITY, Utah —They schmoozed with Mitt Romney at a barbecue cookout at the Olympic Park, pressing him on labor regulations and the threat of a nuclear Iran as downhill skiers performed midair flips behind them.

headline: Mets Try to See Win Column as Half Full
text: Terry Collins and Miguel Batista started their major league careers in the same week, with the same team, in the same bullpen. Collins was a rookie bullpen coach for the 1992 Pittsburgh Pirates. Batista was a Rule 5 draft pick who made the team as a reliever. On the first Saturday of the regular season, he logged two innings at the end of a loss in Philadelphia. He did not resurface in the majors for more than four years.

headline: Despite Slam Dearth, Federer Looms as a Wimbledon Favorite
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Grand Slam drought grows longer for Roger Federer. He has remained a serial winner elsewhere, but he has not won one of the four titles that matter most since January 2010 and has not reached a final at a Grand Slam event for more than a year.

headline: The Sandusky Verdict: Who Would Believe a Kid?
text: The former assistant Penn State football coach Jerry Sandusky was convicted late Friday of sexually abusing 10 boys, the verdict coming after two days of deliberation by a jury of seven women and five men, more than half with ties to Penn State.

headline: In Omaha, a Hotel’s Guest List Will Include a Baseball Champion
text: OMAHA — Next year, every team that qualifies for the College World Series will demand to stay at the Hilton Omaha, one block south of TD Ameritrade Park.

headline: Ex-Governor of New York Reluctantly Accepts Portrait
text: For years, former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has refused to sit for his official portrait, leaving a void in the likenesses of former governors that line a corridor in the New York State Capitol.

headline: I.O.C. Adopts Policy for Deciding Whether an Athlete Can Compete as a Woman
text: Three years after international sports officials drew widespread criticism over the handling of the case of a female athlete who was accused of being unfairly masculine, the International Olympic Committee has adopted new regulations for determining whether someone should not be allowed to compete as a woman if her gender is questioned under those rules.

headline: Mets’ Bay Feeling Much Better
text: The Mets’ clubhouse was all laughs before Saturday’s game against the Yankees. That was chiefly because of Little Jerry Seinfeld, a chicken that Tim Byrdak let loose inside as a gag a day earlier, which players say has brought good luck and humor to Citi Field. Left out of the shenanigans was Jason Bay, who addressed the serious subject matter of the concussion that  landed him on the disabled list.

headline: After Bad Start, N.B.A. Season Finishes with Inspiring Vision
text: As the music blared and the confetti spilled Thursday night in Miami, two transcendent figures met at midcourt, shared an embrace and some parting words — a poetic coda to a season that almost wasn’t, an inspiring vision for the future.

headline: Move to a New (Old) Park Helped Arizona on Road to College World Series
text: OMAHA — Baseball fans in Tucson revere Hi Corbett Field nearly as much as Bostonians do Fenway Park. The memories transcend generations. The Hall of Famers Bob Feller, Willie Mays and Ted Williams played at Hi Corbett during its 46 years as the spring training home of the Cleveland Indians, and part of the 1989 film “Major League” was filmed there.

headline: World’s No. 1 Needs Help to Prevail in Moscow
text: The Tal Memorial tournament in Moscow was a nail-biter: five of the 10 players were tied for the lead with two rounds to go.

headline: Libya Democracy Clashes With Fervor for Jihad
text: DARNAH, Libya — Abdul-Hakim al-Hasadi first took up arms nearly 20 years ago to try to bring Islamic law to Libya. He studied under the Taliban in Afghanistan, and during last year’s uprising he led a local militia council here in a city famous as a cradle of Islamic jihad.

headline: Flyers Acquire Defenseman Schenn From the Maple Leafs
text: The Philadelphia Flyers acquired defenseman Luke Schenn from the Toronto Maple Leafs for forward James van Riemsdyk. Schenn, 22, who has 14 goals and 61 assists in four seasons, should help replace the void created by the loss of Chris Pronger, who is unlikely to return because of postconcussion symptoms. Van Riemsdyk, also 22, has 47 goals and 52 assists for 99 points in three seasons.

headline: Staying Patient, Yankees Bash Two Homers to Top Mets
text: Eric Chavez knew only that something good had happened for his team Saturday when he heard a roar from the Yankees fans at Citi Field. Chavez was pacing in the tunnel between the dugout and the visiting clubhouse, keeping his surgically repaired back loose, when Raul Ibanez hit a three-run homer in the seventh, tying the game, 3-3.

headline: A Mets Mascot and Good Luck Charm, for a Day
text: Reliever Tim Byrdak said he knew the Mets would beat the Yankees on Friday for their fourth straight win. But his reasoning could be seen as questionable.

headline: For Masters of Monday Qualifiers, a Paycheck Is a Victory
text: CROMWELL, Conn. — Patrick Reed is hungry to make cuts on the PGA Tour.

headline: Corrections: June 24
text: SPORTS

headline: For Purveyor of Heartache and Cruelty, It’s All Fiction
text: To judge by her fiction writing, the retired schoolteacher turned best-selling writer Leila Meacham would seem to be personally acquainted with outsize heartbreak, betrayal and the cruelties one generation commits unto the next.

headline: Dead Heat in Women’s 100 Leaves Four Runners for Three Spots
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Moments after the women’s 100 meter final concluded Saturday, Carmelita Jeter, Tianna Madison and Jeneba Tarmoh came through the media mixed zone as the presumed top finishers. The three runners talked excitedly about having made the United States Olympic team, with Tarmoh saying, “I’m so thankful for everything.” Allyson Felix, who was said to have finished fourth, was despondent. “Fourth is the worst,” she said.

headline: U.N. Report from Rio on Environment a ‘Suicide Note’
text: The United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development has wrapped up in Rio de Janeiro — contentiously so — marking two decades since the first Earth Summit was held, also in Rio, in 1992.

headline: In a Few Quick Missteps, the Mets Watch a Win Slip Away
text: It only takes a few misplays to squander a sizable lead in baseball. That was all it took Saturday as a walk here, a single and a fielding mishap there, a pitch up in the zone sent over the fence — all in a few minutes — spoiled what had been a big week for the Mets.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Outlook magazine in its recent issue weighs in on the debate about having a single entrance examination for all engineering colleges in India. The federal minister for human resource development, Kapil Sibal, is of the opinion that a single entrance examination will aid in creating uniformity in the system and reduce the applicants’ burden of stress, preparation time and money spent on examination fees. However, this proposal has not been well received. The piece delves into the negative reactions this announcement has engendered among the management of the prestigious Indian Institute of Technology (I.I.T.), which has several campuses in India, alumni of the institution and students aspiring to seek admission in the premier engineering institution.

headline: Turkey to Consult NATO Over Downing of Jet by Syria
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s foreign minister said Sunday that his country would hold emergency talks with NATO in the next few days over the downing of one of its jet fighters by Syria, asserting that the plane was shot down in international airspace.

text: Hotels with spas that offer treatments for teenagers are nothing new, but some properties have aimed at a younger audience: the under-13 set.

headline: Surveying the Terrain, After Rio+20
text: Our colleagues at the I.H.T. Rendezvous blog are inviting comments today on the just-ended Rio+20 environmental conference. “Are large-scale gatherings like Rio worth the time, the cost and the carbon footprint?” they ask. “Is sustainable development even possible, given the current state of the world economy? Should developing countries be held to less stringent rules on greenhouse emissions, for example, than developed economies?”

text: The Governors Ball, which started Saturday on (not Governors but) Randall’s Island, is a manageable music festival: just two days long and just two stages running in alternation, not far apart, which means zero tough choices about missing anything on the lineup.

headline: Named Egypt’s Winner, Islamist Makes History
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers on Sunday officially recognized Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood as the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election, handing the Islamists both a symbolic triumph and a potent weapon in their struggle for power against the country’s top generals.

headline: Bankers Call for Wider Measures to Stem Crisis
text: FRANKFURT — An organization that serves as an umbrella institution for the world’s largest central banks on Sunday joined a growing list of institutions and leaders pushing euro zone countries to insure bank deposits and take other steps to prevent the European debt crisis from further undermining the global economy.

headline: Pixar’s ‘Brave’ Leads Weekend Box Office
text: Pixar’s first female protagonist didn’t hit a box office bull’s-eye, but she was no slouch, either: “Brave,” a fairy tale about an archery-loving Scottish princess, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, taking in about $66.7 million — a better-than-anticipated total albeit one that ranks on the low end of Pixar’s track record after adjusting for inflation.

headline: Amid Debt Crisis, Banks Confronted by Familiar Problems
text: Despite efforts to strengthen the international banking industry, many of the world’s largest financial institutions still face the same pressures that confronted the sector after the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008, according to the Bank for International Settlements.

headline: Officer and 2 Others Are Shot in Bronx
text: An off-duty police officer was in stable condition on Sunday after a shootout near his home in the Bronx in which he and two other men were wounded, the authorities said.

headline: Getting Away With It
text: Robin Wells and I publish our latest in the NYRB.

headline: Rubio Calls Obama’s Dream Act Move a ‘Short-Term Fix’
text: Senator Marco Rubio had been trying to put together his own version of a Dream Act bill that would pass muster in Congress, but President Obama‘s executive order effectively derailed that effort. And on Sunday, Mr. Rubio took issue with the president’s actions, calling it “a short-term fix to a long-term problem.”

headline: Hedge Fund Manager to Pay $405 Million in Madoff Settlement
text: Clients of J. Ezra Merkin, a prominent Wall Street hedge fund manager who invested his clients’ money in Bernard L. Madoff’s epic Ponzi scheme, will recover more than $400 million under a civil settlement negotiated by the New York State attorney general’s office.
