text: Zeljko Ivanek and Sarah Steele in a scene from Greg Pierce's play at the Claire Tow Theater.

headline: Magic Aside, Even Genies and Demons Need Wi-Fi
text: In an unnamed emirate in the Persian Gulf there lives a young man with Harry Potter potential. He calls himself Alif, for the letter in the Arabic alphabet, but that’s not his real name. It’s the Internet moniker he uses for his work as a hacker, protecting his clients from censors and the secret police. Alif is uncannily good at this. He’s not a boy wizard like Harry, but he works magic just the same.

headline: With Opposition to Runoff, Decision on Final Olympic Spot Could Be Delayed
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The United States Track and Field Association does not have a procedure in place to handle a tie between runners for the final spot on a given Olympic team so officials met late into Saturday night discussing how to resolve the dead-heat finish between Allyson Felix and Jeneba Tarmoh in the 100 meters. As it turns out, the discussions may drag on even longer.

headline: With Tablet, Microsoft Takes Aim at Hardware Missteps
text: SEATTLE — Around the time the iPad came out more than two years ago, Microsoft executives got an eye-opening jolt about how far Apple would go to gain an edge for its products.

headline: In Sleazy Era, Writer Found His Subjects
text: Don Winslow, whose book “The Kings of Cool” just came out, is a rarity among writers of crime fiction: He doesn’t just make it up. For years he was a private investigator, and he used to read writers like Chandler, Hammett and Elmore Leonard while sitting in his car on stakeouts. Eventually he worked his way up to high-profile arson cases in California (the background for his 1999 novel “California Fire and Life”), but he got his start in Times Square in the late ’70s, when, he likes to say, “the whole place was a glittering river of theft.”

headline: Winner of Most Improved: The Ball
text: Of all the golf equipment advancements in the last 15 years, nothing compares to the improvements made to the once simple, flawed golf ball. The most expensive golf balls are technological marvels, and the best values are probably one step below the highest end of the market.

headline: Tips for Chipping: Listen to the Grass
text: Craig Harmon has been the head pro at the Oak Hill Country Club near Rochester for parts of five decades. In that time, Oak Hill has hosted a United States Open and two Ryder Cup matches; it will be the site of a third P.G.A. Championship next year.

headline: Sober and Serene, a Champ Is Still Swinging
text: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif. — The ball was nowhere to be found when he reached the green, and Oscar De La Hoya assumed it must have spun back into the rough. Too bad. He had nailed a gorgeous 9-iron approach from 135 yards right at the flag on Trump National Golf Club’s opening hole, an uphill par 4. He deserved better. One of his playing partners, who knew the course well, then offered a possibility De La Hoya had yet to consider: “It’s in the hole.”

headline: Chinese Astronauts Make Their First Manual Docking With Orbiting Module
text: BEIJING — A Chinese spacecraft with three astronauts on board docked manually with an orbiting module on Sunday, an important step toward China’s goal of building a space station by 2020.

headline: Presidential Geography: New Hampshire
text: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the political peculiarities in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Today’s stop: New Hampshire, the Granite State.

headline: Euro 2012 Live: Italy Defeats England in Penalty Shootout
text: Italy dominated play in the quarterfinal of Euro 2012 in Kiev, Ukraine, and sends England crashing out of another major tournament in a penalty shootout. The New York Times provided live commentary as the two teams vied for the final spot in the semifinal. Italy will play Germany on Thursday.

headline: Man Is Killed by U.S. Agent in Drug Raid in Honduras
text: WASHINGTON — A United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent shot a man to death in Honduras during a raid on a smuggling operation early Saturday, a spokesman for the American Embassy in Honduras said Sunday. The man who was killed had been reaching for his weapon, the official said, and the agent fired in self-defense.

headline: A Festival With Classical Roots and Fanciful Surroundings
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — The Caramoor International Music Festival has a stranger back story than most summer music destinations, and its quirkiness remains a strong draw. It takes place on a 90-acre estate of Italianate gardens, picnic grounds, winding paths, outdoor theaters and an architecturally disparate country villa. The villa, cobbled together by Lucie and Walter Rosen, includes rooms from European palaces that they shipped over from Europe in the 1930s and filled with artifacts they had collected, among them a 14th-century Florentine tapestry and a bed that belonged to Pope Urban VIII.

headline: Franklin Projected as an Olympics Star, but First She Has to Make the Team
text: OMAHA — This week has been in Missy Franklin’s sights for four years, since she left here with her parents after competing in the United States Olympic trials as a 13-year-old. During the drive home to Colorado, Franklin said, she was focused on a distant horizon.

headline: Machinists at Lockheed to Vote On Agreement to End a Strike
text: Lockheed Martin said it had reached a tentative agreement Saturday night with the machinists union to end a nine-week strike at its fighter jet plant in Fort Worth and two other sites.

headline: Amateurs Take the Stage, Many Bringing Shy Smiles
text: The River to River Festival Web site makes a point of linking its free events to its city. Its tag line says: “Made in New York. Inspired by New York.” And this week there will be several works by New York choreographers that promise to offer intriguing responses to that statement.

headline: A 977-Foot Tower You May Not See, Assuming You’ve Even Heard of It
text: A steel beam is to be hoisted 977 feet to the top of 4 World Trade Center on Monday, ceremonially signifying the completion of its structural framework.

headline: Philippines Says Reporter From Jordan Held Hostage
text: MANILA — A veteran Jordanian journalist who has been missing in the southern Philippines for nearly two weeks is now considered a captive, a senior Philippine government official said Sunday.

headline: European Team Championships in Dublin
text: The European Team Championships finished in Dublin on Saturday.

headline: Evolution and Our Inner Conflict
text: The human species’ vexing combination of “sin” and “virtue” may be better explained by the two extreme evolutionary forces that created us.

headline: Repeating a Repetition Repeatedly Once Again
text: It all started at a party when the comedian Tig Notaro approached Taylor Dayne, a singer whose star has faded since the early 1990s, and said, “Excuse me, I’m sorry to bother you, but I just have to tell you: I love your voice.”

headline: Daytime Emmy for ‘Regis and Kelly’
text: Recognizing Regis Philbin’s final season as co-host, “Live With Regis and Kelly” picked up its first Emmy Award for outstanding entertainment talk show on Saturday when the daytime entertainment Emmy Awards for 2011 were presented by the National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. Mr. Philbin, who departed the talk show last November, and Kelly Ripa were also awarded an Emmy in the talk show host category. Ms. Ripa has been joined by guest hosts for the first half of this year; a permanent replacement for Mr. Philbin is to be named by September. “The Dr. Oz Show” won the Emmy for informative talk show for the second year. At the awards show in Los Angeles, televised live by the cable channel HLN, the last soap opera standing on ABC, “General Hospital,” was named outstanding drama series and was also awarded an Emmy for directing. Bill Geddie, the executive producer of “The View” on ABC, received a lifetime achievement award. But ABC didn’t come out on top in the morning show category: NBC’s “Today” show bested “Good Morning America” for the fourth year in a row.

headline: Jennifer Hudson to Appear on ‘Smash’
text: Jennifer Hudson is set to join a fellow “American Idol” runner-up, Katharine McPhee, for a guest stint on NBC’s musical drama “Smash,” the network has announced. Ms. Hudson, left, who has won an Academy Award, a Golden Globe and a Grammy, will portray a Tony-winning Broadway star for a multi-episode arc, starting with the Season 2 premiere. The second season is expected to begin early next year, though no date has been set. The premiere of “Smash” drew 11.4 million viewers in February, but the show attracted just 6 million for its season finale in May.

headline: Moncler: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Milan

headline: Moncler Gamme Bleu Men’s
text: Milan

headline: When Sacred Themes Arrive Wrapped in Unlikely Packages
text: NEW HAVEN — Titters spread through the Shubert Theater here on Friday, when the Mark Morris Dance Group performed as part of the International Festival of Arts & Ideas. Mr. Morris has created many comic works, but none of those were on this program. Of the three dances presented, all set to live Baroque or classical music, two were overtly and sincerely religious. The laughter was the uncomfortable kind.

headline: As Clouds Roll By, Sheep Roll In
text: HIGH WYCOMBE, England — It is hard to imagine a more idyllic outdoor setting for an opera production than Wormsley, the splendid country estate in the Chiltern Hills northwest of London. For the second summer this is the home of Garsington Opera, founded in 1989. Productions are presented in a commodious, airy and well-equipped open-air pavilion seating 600 comfortably, with a large stage, a sizable orchestra pit and see-through soft plastic walls offering views of the bucolic surroundings. It is equally hard to imagine a more appropriate work for Garsington to be presenting right now than Vivaldi’s musically rich and charming opera “L’Olimpiade,” set in ancient Olympia.

headline: Technology Identifies Lost Color at Roman Forum
text: ROME — Historical sources describe the menorah looted by the Romans when they destroyed the Second Temple in Jerusalem in A.D. 70 as made of gold, as God instructed Moses in Exodus.

headline: A Smooth-Jazz Standard-Bearer Offers Soft Exclamations
text: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. — At the precise midpoint of his concert at the Bergen Performing Arts Center here on Saturday night the saxophonist Dave Koz paused for an important announcement. It pertained to Dave Koz & Friends at Sea, the luxury cruise he has headlined every year for the last seven, and he framed it as an enticing question: Who wanted to win a cabin for the 2013 edition, which would tool around the Mediterranean next fall?

headline: A Photo Finish Too Close to Call, Even by Camera
text: EUGENE, Ore. — It was track’s version of Bush v. Gore. Potential fame and fortune were on the line for the winner, if those in charge could only figure out who had won.

headline: Watching Others Watching Me, or Reflection in the YouTube Age
text: When Chris Crocker screamed “Leave Britney alone!” into a camcorder in 2007 and posted the clip online, it seemed less like a rallying cry and more like a cry for help. A transgendered gay man from Bristol, Tenn., Mr. Crocker had already made a small name for himself in Internet-video circles with sassy, humorous, catchphrase-filled clips of himself. This was the most outrageous of those videos, the most timely, the most cut-and-paste-able.

headline: A Medical Guessing Game, With Life as the Ultimate Prize
text: The central gimmick of Discovery Fit & Health’s latest series is fairly distasteful, but the real-life medical cases the episodes describe certainly make you feel the frustration and terror of an attack by an unknown enemy. The program, “Diagnosis: Dead or Alive,” which has its premiere Monday night, explores medical mysteries through re-enactments and commentaries from the families and doctors who experienced them.

headline: Too Fast, Too Furious
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — True story: When I was pregnant with The Boy, there was a point where the pregnancy hormones and resulting brain fog turned me into the worst driver in the history of driving.

headline: With Grown Children, What Am I Besides ‘Mom’?
text: As I was driving down the Long Island Expressway, my friend, an aspiring cinematographer, was filming me from the passenger seat. She asked me to give her one word that best identified me. I fought like crazy to stop myself from saying it. I spewed forth lawyerly equivocation, harking back to my days as a litigator, but out it came: “Mom.”

headline: Pressure for Action at Brussels Meeting

text: Victoria Cohen, 9, of Brooklyn, was cheered during the Achilles Hope and Possibility 5-Mile Run in Central Park.

headline: Phelps Will Compete in 400 I.M.
text: OMAHA — Around midday Sunday, Michael Phelps posted a photo on his Twitter account — @MichaelPhelps — of his non-mustachioed mug. On the face of it, it looked as if Phelps had decided to try to defend his Olympic 400-meter individual medley title despite not having raced in the event in a major meet since the summer of 2010.

headline: HBO’s ‘Newsroom’ as a Map for CNN
text: CNN, which has long struggled to locate an anchor for its 8 p.m. hour, may have finally found him.

headline: When a Dead Heat Is More Than a Photo Finish
text: EUGENE, Ore. — For casual sports fans, the term “photo finish” conjures images of a close race that is too close to call. But the reality is that, technically, every race at a major track meet is a photo finish.

headline: Streamlined Suits Seen as One Reason for Increase in Competitors
text: OMAHA — There are over 1,800 swimmers competing for roughly 50 berths on the United States team bound for the London Games, a vast departure from 20 years ago when the qualifying standards for the selection meet was set so that ideally there were no more than four or five heats in each event.

headline: North Korea Tests the Patience of Its Closest Ally
text: BEIJING — As Kim Jong-un, the young leader of North Korea, consolidates his grip on power, China is showing signs of increasing frustration at the bellicose behavior of its longtime ally.

headline: Church and School Cuts Anger Catholics in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — “It’s been a rough week” is how the Rev. Charles Zlock, pastor of the St. Mary of the Assumption Parish, started his 10 a.m. homily on Sunday.

headline: A Governor Trying to Elude the Sophomore Slump
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, the consummate strategist, ran out of leverage this spring.

headline: Fox News Reporter Hired as Vatican Media Adviser
text: ROME — In an effort to shore up its communications strategy amid a widening leaks scandal in a troubled papacy, the Vatican has hired the Fox News correspondent in Rome as a senior communications adviser.

headline: GQ Throws a Party, American Style
text: MILAN — It may shock a reader to learn that fashion is not one big happy family. Outside of the surreal award shows that seem to abound in the business, where people receive plaudits and strange statuettes for having created a handbag or shoe, designers seldom fraternize.

headline: 11,000 Evacuated as Colorado Fire Grows
text: A rapidly expanding wildfire in Colorado forced the evacuation of more than 11,000 people in communities near Pikes Peak on Sunday, as crews struggled to contain several large blazes around the state amid 100-degree temperatures and strong winds.

headline: A Cruel and Unusual Record

headline: Companies Shortchanged Preschool Special Education Program, State Audits Find
text: The owners of a Bronx company that employs teachers for disabled toddlers used thousands of dollars in government funds to fix up a weekend getaway in the Poconos, state auditors found. A Brooklyn company in the same program, which provides treatment for prekindergarten special education students, billed taxpayers for his wife’s $150,000 salary as his assistant director when she was a full-time professor at the City University of New York, the auditors said.

headline: Preparing to Respond to Landmark Decisions
text: Rarely have the black-robed justices at the Supreme Court held so much potential for dominating the political conversation.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Is Said to Be Near a Deal for Grupo Modelo
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev is nearing a deal to buy the half of Grupo Modelo it does not already own, according to people briefed on the matter, giving the global brewing giant control over the maker of Corona Extra beer.

headline: Egypt Results Leave White House Relieved but Watchful
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, expressing relief on Sunday that the Muslim Brotherhood’s candidate will be Egypt’s next president, voiced cautious optimism that the choice could keep the country’s rocky transition to democracy on track.

headline: Gerhard Kallmann, Architect, Is Dead at 97
text: Gerhard Kallmann, the architect who, with Michael McKinnell, designed Boston City Hall, a hulking, asymmetrical, Modernist building that has been widely acclaimed by architects for half a century though disparaged by many Bostonians, died on Tuesday in Boston. He was 97.

headline: Lucrative Afghan Oil Deal Was Awarded Properly, Karzai Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai, responding to recent allegations that insiders close to him are plundering the nation’s mineral wealth, said Sunday that the United States and British governments had given their imprimatur as to how a lucrative oil contract was awarded.

headline: Programs Most Watched Using DVRs

headline: NBC Series Saved by Delayed Viewership
text: The narrative about the new NBC drama “Smash” this spring, promulgated largely by critics and bloggers, centered on the show’s serial failings: it did not live up to its pilot; it alienated viewers with sappy writing and acting; and the only reason NBC ordered a second season was because Bob Greenblatt, the top NBC entertainment executive, decided its fate based on his heart, not his head.

headline: Outsourcing Sandy Springs
text: Wealthy communities are finding a way to insulate their tax dollars from the poorer, surrounding communities. Editor David Gillen takes a closer look at one Georgia town that redefines private.

headline: At Travelers, Leishman Gets First PGA Tour Win
text: CROMWELL, Conn. — Ever since the Australian golfer Marc Leishman won the Warrnambool Club championship at age 13, he had dreamed of victory on the PGA Tour. But not even Leishman could have imagined he would shoot an eight-under-par 62 to rally from a six-shot deficit at the start of the final round and then wait more than two hours to earn his first tour title, by one stroke.

headline: The Great Abdication
text: Among economists who know their history, the mere mention of certain years evokes shivers. For example, three years ago Christina Romer, then the head of President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, warned politicians not to re-enact 1937 — the year F.D.R. shifted, far too soon, from fiscal stimulus to austerity, plunging the recovering economy back into recession. Unfortunately, this advice was ignored.

headline: Video of Joy and Despair in Cairo
text: CAIRO — As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the Islamist candidate who was declared the winner of Egypt’s first competitive presidential election on Sunday, erupted with joy in Tahrir Square the moment the result was announced.

headline: Would Russia Help Oust Assad?
text: Can Syria’s strongest ally be persuaded to play a crucial role in ending the bloodshed there?

headline: Hayward Field and Its Big Screen Moment
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Hayward Field, home of this year’s United States Olympic track and field trials, will be seen countless times on TVs and in YouTube clips as careers are made or ended.

headline: Benefactor Fills a Hole in the City’s Effort to Enforce a Taxi Law
text: In sleek black sedans and unmarked blue vans, stretch limousines and family-friendly S.U.V.’s, the city’s unlicensed taxi drivers have long thrived on a simple fact: Officials often could not seize their cars because there was no place to put them.

headline: Gatlin, Continuing Comeback from Ban, Earns Return to the Olympics
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Justin Gatlin moved one step closer to completing his long comeback, leading the men’s 100-meter dash at the United States Olympic trials from start to finish and earning a ticket to the London Games next month.

headline: New Rules on Public Pension Funds Seek Better Disclosure
text: Cities, states and the millions of Americans who work for them will soon face new accounting rules that will require many local governments to disclose pension obligations that were hidden until now, stepping up the pressure to rein in public workers’ benefits.

headline: Officers, Exhorted to Report Corruption, Still Fear Retaliation
text: In the hallways of Police Headquarters and precinct station houses, posters exhort officers to call the Internal Affairs Bureau if they observe corruption.

headline: Small Fire at La Guardia Prompts Evacuation
text: Hundreds of people were briefly evacuated from a Delta terminal at La Guardia Airport on Sunday evening as firefighters responded to a small electrical fire at one of the security stations.

headline: Yankees Have Feasted on National League Foes
text: When interleague play began in May, the Yankees were only two games over .500 and were in fourth place, four and a half games out of the American League East lead. Since then they have fattened up on the National League, winning 12 of their 17 interleague games going into Sunday’s finale against the Mets, and have used the N.L. to greatly improve their outlook.

headline: Lift the Veil on the Spending Cuts
text: The Pentagon’s powerful Republican friends in Congress are griping about a required $500 billion cut to the military budget over nine years beginning in January. It would “hollow our military,” said Speaker John Boehner. It’s a “national disgrace,” said Representative Howard McKeon, chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Anthony Schulte, Publisher and Early Audiobook Proponent, Dies at 82
text: Anthony M. Schulte, a publishing executive who was an early proponent of audiobooks and among the first to tap the ready-made audience for books written by trusted television personalities like Alistair Cooke, Carl Sagan and Walter Cronkite, died on June 17 in a swimming accident in Maine. He was 82.

headline: A Mediocre Farm Bill
text: The farm bill approved by the Senate last week makes significant changes in existing farm programs, some for the better. But it takes a disproportionate whack from environmental programs, needlessly trims food stamps and does not fundamentally alter the program’s bias toward relatively well-off growers of big crops like corn, wheat and soybeans.

headline: Gay Marriage Again on Ballot in Maine
text: AUGUSTA, Me. — Three years after voters in Maine rejected same-sex marriage, they will consider the matter again in November. This time, advocates say they have reason for optimism.

headline: Seeing an Obama Army in Gay Pride Legions
text: To most passers-by, the tens of thousands of people who jammed the sidewalks of Greenwich Village on Sunday were just the typical tank-top-clad revelers of a gay pride weekend.

headline: Halfway Houses in New Jersey
text: The term “halfway house” suggests a small, closely supervised residential program where people making the transition from prison to the outside world get drug treatment, job placement and other services.

headline: Challenges Multiply for Presidential Winner in Egypt
text: CAIRO — As his supporters in Tahrir Square were chanting on Sunday for the end of military rule in Egypt, the country’s president-elect, Mohamed Morsi, had glowing words for none other than the army, saying he regarded it with a “love in my heart that only God knows.”

headline: Block in East Harlem Celebrates Defeat of Drug Gang
text: The block party outside an East Harlem housing complex could easily have seemed like an ordinary celebration on a bright summer weekend day. But to residents and others who knew of the complex’s menacing recent past, the party was sprinkled with triumphant symbolism.

headline: Try Finding a Job Without a G.E.D.
text: The General Educational Development test, which provides the equivalent of a high school diploma, is being revised to conform with the rigorous new standards proposed by the National Governors Association, along with state school superintendents. New York State and New York City will have to do more to prepare people for an exam that could help them get a leg up in the job market.

headline: Fandango Adds MSN to Its Ticket-Sales Portals
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s starting to look as if the movie ticketing war in the United States has been won, with MSN’s switch to Fandango as the latest evidence.

headline: Manhattan, 1:38 P.M.
text: Chad Gilkison, 41, and Scott Parrish, who were married in 2004, with their twins Lukas and Olivia, 3, in the 43rd Annual Gay Pride March.

headline: Advertisers Urged to Use More Black Media
text: Note to marketers: Television advertising is not postracial.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS New home sales for May (Monday); the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index for April and consumer confidence for June (Tuesday); durable goods for May and pending home sales for May (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and first-quarter gross domestic product (final) (Thursday); personal income and spending for May, the Chicago purchasing managers’ index for June and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for June (Friday).

headline: Polarized Over Health Care, United on Drama of Ruling
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers are not usually eager to get back to Washington after a weekend in their districts, especially during campaign season. But Representative Michele Bachmann boarded a flight from Minnesota on Sunday night — even though the House will not meet until Tuesday — to make sure she would not miss the Washington moment she has been excitedly anticipating, the Supreme Court ruling on President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Sony Puts Spotlight on Its New Smartphone
text: LIKE many cellphone vendors, Sony is marketing its latest phone with an emphasis on everything but its original purpose: talking.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Federal Funds Called Vital for Many Public Stations
text: When Congress approved a $445 million advance appropriation for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in December, the corporation, which administers funds given to public broadcasters, was directed to investigate an important question: Could public television and radio survive without federal funds?

headline: Your Ad Here, on a Fire Truck? Broke Cities Sell Naming Rights
text: BALTIMORE — Should this city’s red fire trucks be transformed into rolling billboards?

headline: In Documents on Pain Drug, Signs of Doubt and Deception
text: A research director for Pfizer was positively buoyant after reading that an important medical conference had just featured a study claiming that the new arthritis drug Celebrex was safer on the stomach than more established drugs.

headline: Healthy and Happy, Richards-Ross Ties Trials Record in 400
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Sanya Richards-Ross is back with a vengeance.

headline: Knuckleball Is Unfamiliar, but Yankees Keep Routine
text: The first thing Nick Swisher saw Sunday morning when he woke up and turned on the television, he said, was Mets starter R. A. Dickey giving an interview about the pitch that has transformed him into a sensation.

headline: Folger Shakespeares in E-Book Format
text: The Folger Shakespeare Library editions will be available in e-book format for the first time beginning Monday. Known as one of the most popular and accessible editions of Shakespeare’s works, they feature scene summaries and notes and are frequently used in schools. Simon & Schuster said it collaborated with the Folger Shakespeare Library to create the e-books. The e-books, including “Hamlet,” “Julius Caesar” and “The Merchant of Venice,” will be sold for $5.99 each. “Shakespeare’s plays are one of the true landmarks in English writing, and the Folger editions have always served to make accessible, authoritative editions of the plays available to a broad sweep of the reading and playgoing public,” Michael Witmore, the director of the Folger Shakespeare Library, said in a statement. “The arrival of Folger Editions as e-books extends the reach of this invaluable series even further.”

headline: Names Have Been Changed to Protect the Innuendoes
text: Just about everyone who grew up with a rabbit-eared television set in the 1970s harbors an abiding, possibly mortifying affection for one of the era’s signature sitcoms. On a down day I might even be persuaded to spend an hour with “Laverne & Shirley.” But I never thought I’d feel any residual nostalgia for “Three’s Company,” the fluff-brained sitcom that kick-started the careers of John Ritter, Suzanne Somers and Joyce DeWitt.

headline: Francisco Is Sidelined, Unsettling Mets’ Bullpen
text: Frank Francisco provided an entertaining subplot to the Subway Series when he entered the weekend by calling the Yankees chickens. Francisco exited the weekend on the disabled list, a sour ending to a series in which he remained in the spotlight.

headline: Advice for Rookies From a Survivor
text: Rod Strickland remembers his walk across the grand stage of the N.B.A. draft in June 1988. He had left DePaul after three years and was looking forward to a long-awaited career as an N.B.A. player.

headline: No Evidence White House Covered Up Guns Case
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Darrell Issa, the Republican leading the investigation into the Obama administration’s handling of the botched gun-smuggling investigation known as Operation Fast and Furious, appeared to contradict Speaker John A. Boehner on Sunday, saying there was no evidence that White House officials were involved in a cover-up.

headline: Combating Doubts About Celebrex
text: Recently unsealed internal documents and depositions provide a window into the calculation made by Pfizer and its efforts to overcome doubts about its arthritis drug Celebrex.

headline: Clijsters Summons Last Push, Comfortably on the Way Out
text: WIMBLEDON, England — No, no, no, Kim Clijsters was saying. This time, there is no doubt. None at all. Not a trace. At the end of her last match here — be it Monday against the former No. 1 Jelena Jankovic, or on July 7 in what would be an improbable appearance in the women’s singles final, or at any stage between — Clijsters will bid farewell to Wimbledon, a tournament that has given her a stable of fond memories but no championship.

headline: In a Troubled Country, Still Time for High Society
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — Can celebrity and fashion save Pakistan from its dark image? That’s the proposition of Hello! Pakistan, a glossy new magazine that has opened a new window into the lives of the country’s gilded elite, and rekindled an old debate about their role in a troubled society.

headline: Ways of Picking and Choosing Olympic Teams
text: There is no set method to determine Olympic teams in various sports, with various governing bodies and countries left to decide their own selection rules.

headline: The New Islamists
text: Articles here explore the rise of political Islam in the Middle East, as Islamic movements struggle to remake the Arab world.

headline: Pain of Swim Trials in ’08 Rekindles Love of Sport
text: OMAHA — The name on the building has changed since she last stepped foot inside it, but CenturyLink Center otherwise was exactly how Dana Vollmer remembered it. It was cold comfort. Entering the multisport arena Friday night, Vollmer said, was “like hitting a brick wall.”

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: June 17-June 24
text: Moments from the campaign trail this week, including the end of a bus tour and appearances at the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials.

headline: For Candidates in Primary, a Frenzied Day of Campaigning as Voting Nears
text: Late Sunday afternoon, an exhausted-looking Hakeem S. Jeffries, his forehead shiny with sweat, walked into his fifth church of the day to make yet another plea for support in the Congressional primary on Tuesday.

headline: With Cuomo, a New Group Will Push for Publicly Financed Elections
text: Frustrated with Albany’s tepid reaction to the idea of publicly financed elections, the Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes and his fiancé are financing a new campaign to press the issue in coordination with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Remarkable Seniors Recognized
text: Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott is honoring nearly 200 graduating seniors Monday night who have overcome what he calls "remarkable obstacles" to earn their diplomas. One of those students is Daniel Gillen of Beacon High School.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: Moments from the campaign trail this week, including the end of a bus tour and appearances at the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials.  Go to the slide show.

headline: Another Complete Game Gives Arizona an Edge
text: OMAHA — The last time Arizona Coach Andy Lopez thought he had a team with a shot at the national championship, in 2008, he fashioned his pitching staff the way he prefers — in reverse. He stuck his power arms, the major league first-round draft picks Ryan Perry and Daniel Schlereth, in the bullpen. Then he told his starters to give him five innings and go wave towels in the dugout while the relievers finished up.

headline: What? No Rock, Paper, Scissors?
text: EUGENE, Ore. — What’s a gold medal worth? Potentially 25 cents.

headline: Flipboard in Content Deal With New York Times
text: The New York Times said on Monday that it would make its articles available through Flipboard, a popular app for browsing news and social media on phones and tablets. It will be the first time that the newspaper has allowed subscribers to get full access to its Web content through a third party.

headline: Word of the Day | legerdemain
text: legerdemain •\ˌle-jər-də-ˈman\• noun

headline: Having Your Coffee and Enjoying It Too
text: A disclaimer: I do not own stock in Starbucks nor, to my knowledge, in any other company that sells coffee or its accouterments. I last wrote about America’s most popular beverage four years ago, and the latest and largest study to date supports that earlier assessment of coffee’s health effects.

headline: Pitching Duel Fizzles; Yankees’ Power Does Not
text: By the time Robinson Cano came to the plate with the score tied in the eighth inning Sunday night, the two men that most fans thought would provide the narrative for the game were long gone.

headline: White Working Chaos
text: Political analysts, journalists and academics are fighting over white working-class voters – over how to define them and what their political significance is. Part of the reason for the furious tone of the argument is that this is an issue of central importance in American politics. And it’s not just crucial for the presidential election: understanding what the white working class is and where it is going is fundamental if we want to understand where the country is going.

headline: Women Facing Harsh New Pressures in North Korea
text: HONG KONG — As the world’s youngest dictator, Kim Jong-un has gotten off to a remarkable start in North Korea.

headline: Euro 2012 Semifinals: And Then There Were Four
text: Italy’s win over England on penalty kicks Sunday — deserved, if an hour overdue — completed the semifinal matchups for the European Championships.

headline: Sports Replay: June 24
text: Images from soccer’s European Championships, the United States Olympic track and field trials and Nascar’s California stop.

headline: Multiple Choices for What Makes Up the Last Week of School
text: It's an odd end to the school year for many students. Since there were no snow days this year, the Education Department is allowing more than 650 schools to cancel classes Monday and Tuesday to allow for professional development for teachers. But students need to show up for a half day on Wednesday to pick up their report cards.

headline: When Knuckler Doesn’t Behave, Dickey Lowers His Shoulder
text: The throw was coming from left field, and R. A. Dickey was determined to beat it to the plate. Never mind that Dickey was pitching his poorest outing in two months. If there was any way of salvaging a win, then Dickey, now a base runner, needed to take a chance sliding into home.

headline: Survival Without Adult Supervision, Stark Reality in Rural Bihar
text: Meena Devi is unlike any little girl you will ever meet. In many ways, she isn’t even a child. The afternoon we met, she’d cooked lunch for herself and her older brother. “I made dal bhat tarkari,” she said proudly, referring to a local dish of rice, lentils and seasonal vegetables. “But we are out of dal, so really, it was just bhat tarkari.” Meena also washes her family’s dirty clothes and drags her brother off to school every morning.

headline: Hazel Hankin’s Mambo Madness
text: Against a shimmering sonic backdrop of brassy horns and percussive beats, mambo masters know it is a dancer’s dream to lose themselves in each other and the music. This is not some quick one-two, but a complex symphony of steps that test the hardiest hoofer.

headline: Latest Syrian Defectors Are From Higher Ranks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s armed forces have been slowly bleeding defectors and deserters since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad began 16 months ago. But now the military arrivals reaching Syria’s neighbors are more likely than ever to have stars on their epaulets.

headline: Haunted Heart
text: I grew up in a house that shook with rage a couple of times a week. Maybe it was the frays, genes or both, but I have always been haunted by the sense that something terrible was just about to happen. Of course there were times when I was dead right, like when my warring parents turned the house upside down in the middle of the night, or more recently, when a doctor left a message on the phone that I needed to call back — as soon as possible.

headline: This Week in Small Business: 10 Billion Video Ads

headline: Cooking the Planet or the Self, an Uneasy Choice
text: In  a recent article in The New York Times, Elisabeth Rosenthal and Andrew W. Lehren warned of the role of air-conditioning gases in worsening global warming. The story described the increased sales of air-conditioners in countries like India and China, which it said are rising 20 percent a year “as middle classes grow, units become more affordable and temperatures rise with climate change.” It added that “the potential cooling demands of upwardly mobile Mumbai, India, alone  have been estimated to be a quarter of those of the United States.”

headline: Monday Reading: Up Close, But Doing No Harm, While Traveling

headline: Conditional 'Yes' on Money for 24 City Schools
text: Last week ended with a flurry of news, in part because of the conclusion of the legislative session in Albany. But before departing for the weekend, the state Education Department slipped in a decision on providing $60 million in aid to 24 "turnaround schools" in the city. And this week -- the last week of public school -- starts with news of audits of an expensive kindergarten program for special-needs children, and more on the Horace Mann School sexual misconduct allegations. Oh, yes, and there are a few graduations.

headline: Amid Uncertainties on Role, Egypt’s President-Elect Begins Rituals of Office
text: CAIRO — President-elect Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood on Monday toured his new office in a presidential palace once occupied by Hosni Mubarak, taking a break from the power struggle with Egypt’s ruling generals to savor, for a moment at least, his electoral victory.

headline: Daily Report: For Tablet, Microsoft Breaks Away From Partners

headline: A Look Back at Court’s Arguments on Health Care, Laugh Count Included
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s momentous decision on the fate of President Obama’s health care law is expected Thursday, and it is likely to be dry, sober, weighty and self-conscious about its place in constitutional history.

headline: Police Arrest Key Suspect in the Mumbai Terror Attack
text: The police in New Delhi have arrested a man suspected of being one of the planners of the 2008 militant attacks in Mumbai that killed more than 160 people, the government said Monday.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Ads, Ads Everywhere, and What Ratings Are Best?
text: Local governments, transit systems and school districts have been offering up advertising and sponsorship deals that encroach on basic services and equipment, including ads on school buses, sponsorship of subway stations, or (temporary) ads on fire hydrants and manhole covers, Michael Cooper writes. The deals — like one being considered in Baltimore to allow advertisements on fire trucks — seemingly serve a need for each side. Cash-strapped cities averse to raising taxes can help pay the bills with the revenue from sponsorship deals. (By renaming its Bus Rapid Transit system the HealthLine, Cleveland received $6.25 million over 25 years.) And, Mr. Cooper writes, advertisers can “try to reach consumers who have grown more adept at tuning out commercials, whether with remote controls or digital video recorders.”

headline: Taking a Second Look at an Ex-Officer’s 75-Year Sentence
text: If a contest were held for the most despised man in New York, Michael Pena would be a strong contender. “Despicable” doesn’t begin to describe what he did.

headline: Swedish House Mafia’s Pulsating Tour to Come to an End
text: The glowsticks are dimming and the beat will be slowing for Swedish House Mafia. The trio, whose thumping house tracks quickly entranced millions of neon-clad, pulsing fans of electronic dance music, announced on Saturday that it will stop touring.

Cue the Congressional delegations from three states that trend red (as in cranberry-producing and Democratic): Massachusetts, Oregon and Wisconsin. (Via Gawker.) — Patrick Farrell

headline: A Tragicomic Take on Cape Wind
text: WASHINGTON — When the energy entrepreneur Jim Gordon first proposed building the Cape Wind project in Nantucket Sound, he assumed the project would be a slam dunk. Liberal Massachusetts communities would surely embrace a clean energy initiative, he figured.

text: Even as technology blows companies apart, can the people in them work better together?

headline: Alex Trebek Suffers Mild Heart Attack
text: Alex Trebek, the “Jeopardy!” host and burglar-foiler, had a mild heart attack on Saturday. He was admitted to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, according to Paula Askanas, a spokeswoman for Sony Television, which distributes the game show. “Trebek is in good spirits and is currently under observation and undergoing further testing,” Sony said in a statement on Sunday. “He is expected to fully recover and be back at Jeopardy! when production begins taping in July for the new season, the show’s 29th.”

headline: Memorable Mess in Argentina
text: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina — Like the ending to a Jorge Luis Borges story, the final weekend in Argentina’s Clausura championship entertained those who enjoy dipping their toes in the surreal.

headline: Even Video Pros Make Mistakes
text: During a drive back from a shoot last week for the PBS series I’m hosting, “NOVA ScienceNow,” I was telling the story of one cameraman I worked with, earlier in my career, who found himself in that classic nightmare: He discovered that he hadn’t been filming when he thought he was, and was filming when he thought he wasn’t. He’d somehow gotten out of cycle with his Record button. (The new season of the show will have six episodes, one hour each; they begin in October.)

headline: Governors Ball Day 2: Turning Back the Clock
text: The top of Sunday’s lineup at the Governors Ball — the rock festival that commandeered Randalls (not Governors) Island on the weekend — could have been booked a decade ago. The headliner was Beck, leading the band that made his album “Sea Change” with him in 2002, in a set full of songs from “Sea Change” and his 1990s albums.  Preceding him were Modest Mouse, which had its biggest hit in 2004 and hasn’t released a new album since 2007 (though it did have new material); the instrumental rock band Explosions in the Sky, formed in 2000; and Fiona Apple, who has just released a superb new album but who made her multimillion-selling debut in 1996. Earlier there was a set by Built to Spill, formed by the songwriter and guitarist Doug Martsch in 1992.

headline: Linn Energy to Buy BP Property in Wyoming for $1 Billion
text: Linn Energy said on Monday that it had agreed to buy property in Wyoming from BP for more than $1 billion, in its second deal with the British oil giant this year.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Madoff Dispute
text: 8:25 p.m. | Updated The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not hear a dispute over how the claims of investors in Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme should be calculated, a decision that could speed up payouts to the victims of the fraud.

headline: Indian Police Arrest Suspect in 2008 Mumbai Attack
text: NEW DELHI — The police in New Delhi have arrested a man suspected of being one of the planners of the 2008 attacks in Mumbai that killed more than 160 people, the government said Monday. The police did not provide the suspect’s name, referring to him only by the alias Abu Jindal. Indian news media reports have identified him as Sayeed Zabiudeen Ansari.

headline: Aging: A Collective Response
text: One of the things I appreciate about the new book “Independent for Life: Homes and Neighborhoods for an Aging America” is the sheer amount of information it collects in one handsomely designed paperback.

headline: In Europe, It’s a Jeff Koons Summer
text: Yes, a room full of Hoover vacuum cleaners and shampoo polishers can be beautiful! The curators at Fondation Beyeler in Basel, Switzerland, have used tricks of light and space to stage its first exhibition of the American artist Jeff Koons’s work, writes Elisabeth Hopkins in the IHT’s Global Arts Guide. A riot of colors, ideas and symbols, the work is are arranged in three sections: the Hoovers (‘The New’’), the ‘‘Banality’’ sculptures, each of them according to Mr. Koons, a ‘‘metaphor for the viewer’s cultural guilt and shame,’’ and ‘‘Celebration,’’ a mix of paintings and balloon sculptures (dog, tulips, a heart). “Split-rocker,” a massive floral sculpture first assembled in Avignon in 2000 and, notoriously, at Versailles in 2008, is blooming now in the foundation’s park. www.fondationbeyeler.ch

headline: Chef Departs Demi Monde
text: Phillip Kirschen-Clark, above, the chef who attracted attention at Vandaag, which he left last summer and which recently closed, has now left Demi Monde, a bar and lounge with a chef’s table in the Financial District that opened in mid-May.

headline: No Way to Run an Olympic Trial
text: The easiest old joke among the five-ring set is that the only amateurs left in the Olympics are the people running them. This theme pops up reliably at every Games, so we have to hand it to USA Track and Field for getting a jump on things and accomplishing this a month before the Olympics even start. In the first weekend of its Olympic trials, a dead heat for third place in the women's 100 means one of the marquee spots in the Olympics might be decided by a coin flip, or Allyson Felix or Jeneba Tarmoh could gracefully bow out for the good of making this seeming like less of a circus. The fact that those are two of the top three options hanging over the scenario two days after the race tells you pretty much everything you need to know about this enterprise. And these options were stumbled upon by USA Track and Field about a day and a half ago.

headline: Image of the Day: June 25
text: Fire at a revered shrine sparked off anti-India protests in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Master of the Shot Put, and the Cube
text: EUGENE, Ore. — On Sunday, after fending off a number of competitors, shot-putter Reese Hoffa made the U.S. Olympic team for a third time.

headline: Toy, a New Diversion in the Gansevoort Hotel
text: Toy, an ambitious, multifaceted restaurant, opens on Monday, replacing Tanuki Tavern and Carte Blanche in the Gansevoort chain’s hotel in the meatpacking district.

headline: London Theater Journal: ‘Sunshine’ in Different Sizes
text: Willie Clark, the great vaudeville comedian, has a carved-in-stone list of things that are funny. Words that have “k” sounds, for instance, like pickle and cake and cucumber. Might I add to that list the image of a tufted Danny DeVito in striped pajamas and a sports jacket?

headline: Stolen Bust of Rodin by Camille Claudel Recovered in France
text: A rare bronze bust of Auguste Rodin, made by his disciple and lover Camille Claudel, has been recovered by French police more than a decade after it was stolen from a museum, The Telegraph reported. The bust, which was taken from the Museum of Art and Archeology in Guéret in central France in 1999, was discovered in the van of an antiques dealer who had been under surveillance in connection with recent thefts in the Lyon region, and who was arrested on Tuesday with another man. The bust, one of about 50 sculptures made by Claudel, is estimated to be worth between about $600,000 and $1.2 million, according to Agence France-Presse.

headline: ‘Exergames’ Don’t Make Children Fitter
text: Thinking of a Wii or an Xbox with Kinect to get your children off the couch? Think again: new research reported in The New York Times’s Business section shows that even children who have access to only the most active games aren’t more active over all. The kids may get off the couch at first, but once their initial interest in the games wanes, they seem to go back to more sedentary pursuits.

headline: Court Declines to Revisit Its Citizens United Decision
text: WASHINGTON — In a brief unsigned decision, the Supreme Court on Monday declined to have another look at its blockbuster 2010 campaign finance decision, Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission.

headline: Goldman Executive to Join Bank of America
text: LONDON — Diego de Giorgi, a senior Goldman Sachs executive, is leaving the firm to take a top position at Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Deleveraging and the Depression Gang
text: The Bank for International Settlements has just come out with a report emphasizing the “limits to monetary policy”, which is apparently being taken seriously. I guess I’d start from the observation that the BIS has already embraced liquidationism, the idea that all this suffering is good for us and that trying to mitigate the pain would somehow be a bad thing. Now they’re just trying to come up with additional arguments for doing nothing.

headline: At Gucci, Assuredly ‘Made in Italy’
text: Inevitably all conversation here these days turns to the floundering Euro zone economy. Even fans rooting for the underdog in the European cup match pitting Germany against Greece over the weekend were secretly relieved when the German team won. Everyone knows that in the larger sense Germany controls the ball.

headline: Business Day Live | Apple Stores
text: June 25, 2012 - David Segal on Apple's retail army.

headline: Numberplay: se5en
text: Welcome to Numberplay, the weeklong game of collaboration and discovery that also happens to be about math. If you’re new to the game, give it a try by leaving a comment at the end of this post. You don’t have to solve the problem; hunches are good. So are wild conjectures. At Numberplay, the standard answer is just the beginning.

headline: Sweet and Savory Bread Puddings
text: I used to bake bread every week, but in recent years I’ve gotten out of the habit. The main reason is that I don’t eat as much as I used to, and I kept finding myself with stale bread on my hands. But I reminded myself this week how much I like bread puddings, both savory and sweet, so I may get back into the habit, as they’re such an easy and delicious destination for stale bread.

text: LONDON — Even for a music critic eager to hear as much as possible while here, a day off is a good idea. Mine came on Sunday, a lovely day, with mild temperatures and only intermittent showers.

headline: Away from Rio, a Big Victory for a Small Conservation Group
text: While world leaders in Rio were casting adrift an imperiled planet, an impassioned young Frenchwoman forced a giant supermarket chain to stop pretending that its bottom-fishing trawler fleet was safeguarding the future of fish.

headline: Women May Compete for Saudi Arabia
text: Saudi Arabia, a monarchy with severe restrictions on women in daily life, will allow female athletes to compete in the Olympics for the first time this summer if they qualify, according to a statement by the country’s embassy in London.

headline: Justices Bar Mandatory Life Terms for Juveniles
text: WASHINGTON — Some 2,000 juvenile offenders serving life sentences without parole were given hope of eventual release by the Supreme Court on Monday. The court ruled that laws requiring youths convicted of murder to be sentenced to die in prison violate the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: Military Expedition Into the Heart of Darkness
text: Most military shooters — a subgenre of video games with conventions so rigid as to seem ritualistic — try to have it both ways when it comes to their relationship with actual warfare. Players are clearly supposed to find the combat, and the real-world settings, a viscerally exciting way to connect to current events. At the same time, far-fetched plotlines reassure us that this is all just a game; have fun and don’t think too much about what you’re doing.

headline: Beyond Rio: Pursuing ‘Ecological Citizenship’
text: I’m posting a few final reflections related to the “Rio+20” United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, which marked the 20th anniversary of the first “Earth Summit” and concluded ingloriously in Rio de Janeiro on Friday. If there is to be a 40th anniversary, what approaches or initiatives would you want to see there that weren’t in play this time around?

headline: Just Passing Through, Putin Consults With Israeli Leaders on Syria and Iran
text: JERUSALEM — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia conferred with Israeli leaders on Monday during a 24-hour visit that juxtaposed the much improved ties between the countries with their sharp differences, chief among them the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: Arizona’s Immigration Law and Mandatory Life Terms
text: Still no ruling on health care, but the Supreme Court did hand down two important decisions this morning. The justices struck down most of Arizona’s immigration law , with the backing of Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., and prohibited mandatory life terms without parole for juvenile offenders.

headline: The Litigation That Haunts Goldman Sachs
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, may well be thinking of Michael Corleone’s famous line in the otherwise forgettable “The Godfather: Part III”: “Just when I thought I was out … they pull me back in.”

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Jeneen Interlandi on Dealing With Her Father’s Mental Illness
text: Jeneen Interlandi, who wrote this week’s cover story about hospitalizing her father because of his struggle with bipolar disorder, is a science and health reporter and 2013 Nieman fellow at Harvard University. Her last article for the magazine was about patients waking from states of minimal consciousness.

headline: Artnet Chief Steps Down and Artnet Magazine is Closed
text: Hans Neuendorf, the chief executive of Artnet, an art-market information company that has helped to transform the way art is bought and sold, has stepped down, handing the reins of the company to his son, the New York Observer reported. In addition, the company is ceasing publication of its online magazine and on Monday closed its magazine offices in New York, Berlin and Paris, according to the Observer.

headline: The Evolution of the Summer Olympics Video Game
text: Are we forgetting the best Summer Olympics video game of all time and you just can’t believe it? Tell us about it on Twitter @LondonLive with the hashtag #summervideogames. We will publish selected Twitter responses on this blog later in the week.

headline: Scalia Cites Obama Immigration Policy in Dissent on Arizona Law
text: 3:32 p.m. | Updated Justice Antonin Scalia made a foray into the realm of political combat on Monday, citing President Obama’s recent decision to stop enforcement of deportation against some illegal immigrants in a biting statement of dissent (a summary of which can be found here) from his colleagues who struck down parts of Arizona’s immigration law.

headline: Zimbabwe: Seeking to Set an Example, Legislators Are Circumcised in Parliament Building
text: A group of legislators in Zimbabwe had themselves circumcised last week to set a good example for the country, most in an impromptu surgical theater in a tent in Parliament House.

headline: Boston Rock Radio Voices Plan to Move Online
text: Fans of the Boston alternative-rock station WFNX, which is being sold to Clear Channel Communications, will soon be hearing some familiar voices online.

headline: A ‘Real’ Video Helps Fight Against Premature Births
text: The March of Dimes has gone to YouTube to find a video to illustrate its latest public service advertising campaign, part of an initiative by the United States Department of Health and Human Services to prevent preterm birth.

headline: After Costly Delays, Boston Tea Party Museum Set to Reopen
text: The Boston Tea Party Museum is set to reopen on Tuesday after a stalled and costly renovation, The Boston Globe reports. The floating museum, on the historic industrial Fort Point Channel, includes replicas of three ships and a recreation of the events of the night of Dec. 16, 1773, that helped foment the American Revolution (and, a few centuries later, birth a political movement).

headline: Pondering a Breakup of the BlackBerry Maker

headline: Keeping Bees in the City
text: Reader-submitted photographs show the work of urban beekeepers.

headline: A Firm Diagnosis of Frailty
text: Quick, define frailty. Infirmity? Disability? Weakness? Shakiness?

headline: On City’s Stoops, a Familiar Shelter Is Losing Its Appeal
text: When Joseph Vance closed on his mid-19th-century wood-frame house in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, two summers ago, he knew exactly how he wanted to celebrate. But he did not reach for a bottle of Champagne or saunter off to a fancy restaurant. Instead, he got his toolbox and spent the rest of the day attacking a dreary, brown accessory that hung over his new front door:

headline: Linda P. Fried
text: An interview with the geriatrician and dean of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University on preventing frailty and the transition to an aging society.

headline: Blake Exits Wimbledon First Round, Falling to Becker
text: WIMBLEDON, England — James Blake fell to Benjamin Becker of Germany, 6-7 (4), 7-5, 6-0, 6-4, in the first round at Wimbledon on Monday, his first loss ever to Becker and a disappointing early exit from the tournament.

headline: Unafraid of Aging
text: The signal public health achievement of the 20th century was the increase of the average human life span. Now, as that achievement helps raise the proportion of the aged around the world, what once seemed an unalloyed blessing is too often regarded as a burden — a financial burden, a health care burden, even a social burden.

headline: Adding a French Accent to the New York Market Scene
text: Bensidoun USA, the American branch of the company that runs all the public food markets in Paris — 26 outdoors under canopies and six indoors — will open its first market in New York on Friday, at the invitation of and in partnership with the Chelsea Improvement Company.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Justices Rule on Immigration
text: A look at the decision, the politics and the impact on the border as the Supreme Court blocks parts of Arizona’s immigration law.

headline: Former Obama Aide Joins Re-election Campaign in Press Post
text: Jennifer Psaki, one of the best-known and most well liked aides in President Obama’s long 2008 campaign and then in his White House, is joining his re-election effort after less than a year as a private-sector consultant.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Yammer for $1.2 Billion
text: Microsoft announced on Monday that it would buy Yammer, a social network service for businesses, for $1.2 billion in cash, as it seeks to strengthen its enterprise software business and compete more directly with Salesforce.com.

headline: Savory Bread Pudding With Grated Squash and Feta
text: This savory whole-wheat bread pudding has Greek overtones, with the dill or mint and feta cheese. Make sure to squeeze as much water as you can out of the grated squash, or the dish will be too watery.

headline: Designated Finance Minister Drops Out of Greek Cabinet, Citing Health Problems
text: ATHENS — Greece’s designated finance minister resigned on Monday after being hospitalized, an unexpected blow to the new government of Prime Minister Antonis Samaras as it struggles to manage the country’s financial crisis.

headline: Must We Worry About the Boys of ‘Brave’?
text: Pixar’s “Brave,” which opened this weekend, offers a first among Disney “princess” movies: the princess who neither wants nor needs a prince. The princess who isn’t ready for a prince. The perfect princess for the little girls, in fact: a young princess, whose “happily ever after” remains, at the end of the movie, happily in question.

headline: A New Satellite Tool Tracks Deforestation
text: An international team of researchers presented a new tool at the Rio+20 sustainability conference last week: the first satellite system for monitoring deforestation across Latin America in nearly real time. While such programs have existed in Brazil for several years, the program, called Terra-I, fills a much-needed gap for some smaller Latin countries that are losing forests at an equal or higher rate.

headline: Consumer Group Questions ‘High’ Auto Insurance Rates
text: Safe drivers who live in moderate-income areas are being told they have to pay what consumer advocates say are “high” and widely variable rates for minimum auto insurance coverage.

headline: Pressure Grows on Congress for Immigration Overhaul
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on Monday on the Arizona immigration law – and President Obama’s reaction to it – appeared to put the onus on Congress to act on what Republicans and Democrats agree is a broken immigration system.

headline: U.S. Men’s Basketball Team, Taking Stock of Injuries, Might Lose Wade
text: The N.B.A finals are concluded, which means it’s time for Mike Krzyzewski, the Olympic men’s basketball coach, to check on the health of his players for London.

headline: Dressing for Music at the Governors Ball
text: Looks for Governors Ball, a summer music festival held on Randalls Island, N.Y.

headline: In the 400, Good Heats for Phelps and Lochte
text: OMAHA – From his thousand-meter stare before the race’s start to his seemingly effortless finish, Michael Phelps looked like his old self on Monday in the preliminaries of the 400-meter individual medley at the United States Olympic Trials.

headline: Play Trumps Politics as U.S. and Afghanistan Meet in New York Tournament
text: The Cosmos Copa isn’t your average amateur tournament. The former France international Youri Djorkaeff decided to play once more, taking the field with his countrymen in the inaugural competition. Pele handed out awards in 2009 and 2010. Combine this sprinkling of stardust with the inevitable drama when national teams drawn from the New York City area are matched up and you have a distinctive tournament. And, in this year’s qualifying round, the Copa set up an unusual encounter when teams representing the United States and Afghanistan were paired.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Moncler Gamme Bleu

headline: A Glimpse of the Coming ‘Downton Abbey’ Catfight
text: Cue the sharp gasps and the “Oh no she DIDN’T” drumroll on Twitter: judging from a clip from the upcoming season of “Downton Abbey,” fans will get the period catfight they were hoping for when it was announced that Shirley MacLaine would be joining the cast to play the mother of Elizabeth McGovern’s Lady Cora.

headline: On Roofs and in Gardens, the Beehives of New York
text: It’s been a busy spring for the hardworking honeybee and the keepers tending to hives in New York City and the region.

headline: Twitter Transformed Into a Barometer of Anxiety as Egypt Waited for Election Results
text: CAIRO — Since The Lede used Twitter on Sunday to report from Tahrir Square live as Mohamed Morsi was declared the winner of Egypt’s presidential election, readers might be unaware of just how tense the atmosphere was in the country’s capital before the dramatic announcement.

headline: Really? The Claim: Eating Soy Increases the Risk of Breast Cancer
text: THE FACTS

headline: Senator Assails Court’s Decision on Montana Campaign Contributions
text: Jon Tester, Montana’s buzz-cut farmer-senator, reacted angrily on Monday to the Supreme Court’s summary dismissal of his state’s 100-year-old ban on corporate campaign contributions, calling it another blow to democracy.

headline: As You Were
text: The justices of the Supreme Court follow the news, and must be aware of the transformation of American politics that followed their Citizens United decision in 2010. They have watched as hundreds of millions of special-interest dollars flowed into super PACs, and into secretive advocacy groups that violate the court’s own preference for disclosure.

headline: In Kashmir, Killing Ebbs, but Killers Roam Free
text: BONIYAR, India — After decades of war, Kashmir is blooming again. Hotels are bursting, roads are being fixed and offices rebuilt. But with the guns silenced, India must soon decide whether justice will be as welcome as the tourists.

headline: Street Style: Ripped Jeans and Cut Off Shorts
text: The best of readers’ looks incorporating ripped jeans or cut-off shorts for the week of June 18.

headline: Romney Stresses States’ Rights in Response to Court’s Immigration Ruling
text: 7:01 p.m. | Updated

headline: Italy Is Poised to Pass Labor Laws Most View as Flawed
text: ROME — Prime Minister Mario Monti is hoping to arrive at the summit meeting of the European Union in Brussels on Thursday with a freshly passed package of labor laws for Italy, in what would be a symbolic token of the nation’s ability to change amid the region’s upheaval.

headline: In Student Awards Season, Thinking About the Ones We Don't Give
text: A  middle school teacher in the Bronx writes: What about the awards we don't hand out to students? "How about an award for my student who isn’t the best or the fastest, but who always helps her peers, and is kind when they don’t understand something?  Or for the student who brightens everyone’s days with his sense of humor, and his perfect comedic timing in a tense moment?  Where do I find the award for the child who has overcome the most this year -- who has been heroic in his or her personal survival?"

headline: Cells Most Vulnerable to HPV Are Identified
text: Scientists have located the cells in the cervix that give rise to cancer when attacked by the human papillomavirus, a discovery that may lead to new methods of preventing and treating the disease.

headline: Vollmer’s Fast Early Swim Has Her Thinking Higher
text: OMAHA – Dana Vollmer pulled off her goggles and read her time on the overhead scoreboard Monday morning with a mix of surprise and relief. Surprise, in that she nearly broke her American record in 100-meter butterfly in a preliminary at the Olympic swimming trials. And relief, in that a swim that fast felt so smooth and easy.

headline: With No Vote, Taxpayers Stuck With Tab on Bonds
text: Surprised local taxpayers from Stockton, Calif., to Scranton, Pa., are finding themselves obligated for parking garages, hockey arenas and other enterprises that can no longer pay their debts.

headline: Tesla Model S Offers a Lesson in Electric-Vehicle Economics
text: A handful of fully electric Tesla Model S Signature Performance sedans were presented to their owners at the company’s factory on June 22, each priced around $100,000. The luxury sedans were fitted with the most powerful battery pack available from the start-up automaker, rated at 85 kilowatt-hours. In combination with the vehicles’ electric motor and other running gear, those reserves of energy are capable of generating 416 horsepower, Tesla claims.

headline: Shades of Psychopathy and Ambition Run Amok
text: Here’s a medical riddle: When is just a touch of a disease worse than the full-blown thing?

headline: Photo Replay: June 25
text: A view of the day in sports, with play at Wimbledon, the United States Olympic swimming trials in Omaha and a celebration of the Heat’s N.B.A. championship.

headline: Goodbye to Mountain Forests?
text: When the smoke finally clears and new plant life pokes up from the scorched earth after the wildfires raging in the southern Rockies, what emerges will look radically different than what was there just a few weeks ago. According to Craig Allen, a research ecologist with the United States Geological Survey in Los Alamos, N.M., forests in the region have not been regenerating after the vast wildfires that have been raging for the last decade and a half.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Calvin Klein Collection
