headline: Traveling With Circus Props That Delight the T.S.A.
text: I OWN Aerial Angels, a small circus company. We do everything from lavish corporate events to theater shows to street performing all over the world. We don’t ride on a train with elephants. We sit in the airport lounge, hoping our plane is on time. And like everyone else, we hope we get an upgrade.

headline: Trade You an Azevedo for a Petri (Bubblegum Not Included)
text: While a Tony Azevedo 2012 card probably isn’t going to rival say, a 1909 Honus Wagner for value, USA Water Polo is commemorating the London Games with a set of trading cards featuring the full rosters of both the men’s and women’s teams.

headline: Harrison Survives, Gets Djokovic Next
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Ryan Harrison rallied from a first-set lapse to defeat Lu Yen-Hsun of Taiwan, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2, in the first round of Wimbledon Monday.

headline: ‘Casablanca’ Director’s Oscar Goes on the Block
text: Round up the usual entertainment memorabilia collectors: The 1943 best director Oscar for “Casablanca” is on the auction block, the latest in a slew of little gold men from Hollywood’s Golden Age to come up for sale.

headline: Jill Hoder: Take Public Education Personally
text: In the final Principal's Office interview of the 2011-12 school year, Jill Hoder, principal of P.S. 161 Arthur Ashe School in Queens, said data helps the school personalize the learning experience for its diverse student body and in inclusion classes that accommodate a special-needs population of 13 percent. "The mission and the motto in this building is that we take public education personally. What you do or what you need to learn is gravely different from what the person next to you needs to learn."

headline: Downgraded in the Sky, Too
text: As a credit union chief executive, James L. Van Arsdale used to travel frequently to big conferences and to meetings with clients. Now, more than four years after he led the acquisition of the credit union, he is an insurance agent with Mass Mutual, offering people financial advice and dealing with a life of fewer perks.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Instagram Fatigue and iPhone Prototypes
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Monday. See more here.

headline: How Natural is Too Natural?
text: When Patrice Grell Yursik began wearing her hair in a wash-and-go style, she got lots of praise. “Women would tell me they wish their hair looked like mine,” said Ms. Yursik, 33, the creator of the blog Afrobella.

headline: At New York’s Auction Houses, Food Finds a New Stage
text: Christie’s and Sotheby’s have been increasingly using cuisine as a vital component of marketing in the secretive auction house world.

headline: Casual, With a Spanish Touch, at the Standard
text: This new seasonal restaurant in front of the Standard New York (where one can ice skate in winter), will be equipped with a wood-fired grill and an oven where the chef, Seamus Mullen, will cook an array of casual, summery dishes, often with the Spanish touches for which he has become known.

headline: Facebook Adds Sandberg to Board
text: Facebook, the world’s largest social network, has wrestled with a peculiar conundrum when it comes to female representation.

headline: Health Care Ruling Expected Thursday
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would issue the rest of its decisions for its current term on Thursday, making it very likely that a decision on the comprehensive law overhauling health care will come that day.

headline: Powerhouse Fare for High-Powered Bidders
text: BEFORE an auction of rare Italian masterworks by Fra Bartolommeo and Simone Martini, Sotheby’s rolled out some rarefied Italian treats, including imported guanciale in vinaigrette. For an offering of Japanese contemporary art, potential bidders were plied with freshly sliced sushi. And for a preview before the sale of “The Scream” by Edvard Munch, who grew up in Oslo, there was a lavish smorgasbord of Norwegian specialties.

headline: How Wider Coverage Affects Health Spending
text: In an article over the weekend, I took a close look at a continuing health study relevant to the Supreme Court ruling due Thursday on the federal health care law, the Affordable Care Act.

headline: A Tale of Post-Traumatic Success Disorder
text: Halfway through this intense but ungainly memoir Anthony Swofford describes being enraged at his father and taking his fury out in his driving, as he guns his BMW M3 down an upstate New York highway, ripping through its gears, “an angry man in a sick-fast car,” doing twice the 45 m.p.h. speed limit. “In front of me was about two miles of mostly straight road,” he writes, “and I killed it, I chewed it up, the speedo climbed to 90, and then 105, and then 120, and then 130, and then it hovered and ticked at 133; the world flew by, seasons changed, my heart hung at the edge of the world. I could die, I could kill myself with a flick of my wrist and it would look like a mistake, a daredevil young writer, war veteran, pushing all the limits at once and doing a header into a tree with his $65,000 car.”

headline: Traffic Noise May Raise Heart Attack Risk
text: A new study published in PLoS One suggests that traffic noise may be more than just a nuisance. It may increase the risk for heart attack.

headline: Obama Challenges Romney on His Home Turf
text: DURHAM, N.H. — President Obama traveled to Mitt Romney’s home territory on Monday to challenge his Republican rival on what he described as a long record of shipping American jobs overseas.

headline: A Town That Backed a Failed Project Refuses to Pay
text: Residents of Moberly, Mo., got a shock last year when they discovered that their city had guaranteed $39 million in bonds, sold by an independent authority, to help a Chinese company build a plant to make sucralose, an artificial sweetener.

headline: Weight-Loss Surgery and Alcohol Abuse
text: The most common type of weight-loss surgery may increase the risk for alcohol abuse, a new study says.

headline: The Vatican Takes on ‘Pettiness and Lies’
text: The Roman Catholic Church has been getting a lot of press lately, much of it negative: The priest sex abuse scandal won’t go away (on Friday, a former cardinal’s aide was convicted of covering up sexual abuse by priests under his supervision); the pope’s butler leaked private documents alleging corruption in Vatican finances (he was then arrested); and church leaders are cracking down on nuns for daring to buck doctrine.

headline: Combating Acid Reflux May Bring Host of Ills
text: The first time Jolene Rudell fainted, she assumed that the stress of being in medical school had gotten to her. Then, two weeks later, she lost consciousness again.

headline: ‘Newsroom’ Debut Draws Audience of 2.1 Million
text: HBO generated a huge amount of talk — positive and negative — about its new Aaron Sorkin drama, “The Newsroom,” and it managed some better-than-average audience totals for its premiere Sunday night.

headline: Smith Declines Option Year, Could Re-Sign with Knicks
text: J.R. Smith will decline his Knicks contract option Tuesday, but with the intent of re-signing under more lucrative terms, according to a person with knowledge of the situation.

headline: Pediatric Prescriptions Down for Allergies, Up for A.D.H.D.
text: The number of prescriptions dispensed to children under 18 declined by 7 percent from 2002 to 2010, a new study reports.

headline: Sandberg Joins Facebook’s Board
text: Facebook said on Monday that its chief operating officer, Sheryl K. Sandberg, had joined the social network’s board, becoming the first woman to serve as a director for the company.

headline: A Legacy Far Beyond the National Anthem
text: WASHINGTON — Noah Webster’s American Dictionary. The Erie Canal. Uncle Sam. Andrew Jackson’s presidency. “The Star-Spangled Banner.” The beginning of the end for American Indians. “Don’t give up the ship!”

headline: Immigrant Rights Groups Unhappy With Supreme Court’s Mixed Decision
text: Immigrant rights groups said they worried that the Supreme Court’s decision on Monday allowing a key provision in Arizona’s tough immigration law to stand would lead to racial profiling, as Gov. Jan Brewer described the decision as “a victory for the rule of law.”

headline: In Breaststroke Preliminaries, Two Notable Comebacks
text: OMAHA – The breaststroker’s comeback got off to a promising start on Monday.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Prada
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Governor Says He Believes Property Tax Abatement Will Be Preserved
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Friday that he believed a property tax abatement for hundreds of thousands of condominium and co-op owners in New York City would be preserved, despite his rejection of a renewal of the abatement as part of a package of housing legislation on the final day of the legislative session last week.

headline: Brain Banks for Autism Face Dearth
text: Clare True had autism and periodic seizures, but nothing prepared her family for Christmas Eve in 2006, when the 26-year-old went to bed after watching a movie and stopped breathing.

headline: Test Expert: State Exam Problem Is Worse than Reported
text: A retired senior analyst in city government who is a testing expert has questions for the state and Pearson about this spring's tests — and preparedness for next year's. Among the questions: How many operational questions were left on the state English and math exams, upon which important decisions affecting students, teachers and schools will be made? Will there be enough field-tested questions to make next year's testing more reliable? The expert, Fred Smith, explains why he sees more trouble ahead.

headline: Like It or Not, Facebook Changes E-Mail Settings
text: 10:55 a.m. | Updated Clarifying the language between Facebook and the F.T.C.

headline: New Troupe Chooses Bronx Zoo for a Debut
text: Now and then you witness a debut so happy and so rich with potential that you can’t wait to share the news. In the case of On Site Opera, a fledgling company that mounted its inaugural production on Saturday afternoon, it seems especially vital to spread the word, since few cognoscenti were on hand to witness its opening splash. True to the troupe’s mission of presenting operas in unconventional settings, the performance took place on the Asia Plaza Stage at the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Wandering and Waiting for the Unknown
text: In the two works presented by Dagmar Spain and her company, Dance Imprints, at Danspace Project from Thursday through Saturday, the best performance was given by Alec Dana. For the first few minutes of the first piece, Mr. Dana, an elegant older gentleman, sat silent and dignified as he was berated by the actor Iorgo Papoutsas. After that Mr. Dana left, never to appear again.

headline: Rooms Where Norman Bates Would Feel at Home
text: “Functional is all I’m looking for.” So announces the hustling copier salesman, Mark (Mike Shapiro), about his modest expectations for overnight accommodations. It’s a low bar, but sorry, mister, you’ve checked into the wrong establishment.

headline: How Gulbis Defeated Berdych: His Second Serve
text: Ernests Gulbis edged sixth-seeded Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic in three straight tiebreakers at Wimbledon on Monday, in a clash of two of the biggest hitters on the tour. Gulbis played boldly, hitting an astonishing 62 winners while committing only 33 unforced errors. The talented Latvian kept Berdych off balance with big serving and returning. Berdych, normally a power player who dominates points with his serve and forehand, was in the unusual position of having to react to Gulbis throughout the match. He managed only 30 winners (13 of which were aces) and had 27 unforced errors.

headline: Math Prodigy, Too Smart by Half, Stuck in High-Strung Adolescence
text: Scott C. Embler’s production of “7th Monarch,” playing at the Acorn Theater, is directed with skill and capably acted by a smart if not always ideally cast ensemble. But while the story is absorbing, this odd mystery by Jim Henry has a whiff of stale psychodrama that overloads on sorrowful revelations with inadequate foreshadowing.

headline: Union Panel Urges Approval of Lockheed Contract
text: A bargaining committee for the union machinists on strike at Lockheed Martin’s fighter jet plant in Fort Worth has recommended that members vote for a new contract that would eliminate traditional pensions for newly hired employees, according to a summary posted Monday on the union’s Web site.

headline: Computer Scientists Break Security Token Key in Record Time
text: For years private companies and government agencies have given their employees a card or token that produces a constantly changing set of numbers. Those devices became the preferred method of securing confidential communications online. No one could have access to the data without a secret key generated by the device.

headline: Court Won’t Rule on San Diego Cross
text: The Supreme Court on Monday announced that it would not decide whether a cross at a veterans memorial in San Diego can be allowed to remain on public land.

headline: Finding a Sustainable Running Stride
text: Have you managed to sustain your running routine?

headline: 4 World Trade Center, 9:40 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Construction workers signed the last steel beam before it was raised into place.

headline: Pittsburgh, After the Steel Mills
text: Within days of wrapping up his picture taking for “Here is London,” a photo essay the magazine published in March, Mark Neville had moved on to another city, Pittsburgh. He was one of 14 artists invited by the Andy Warhol Museum to examine various local industrial legacies.

headline: Google Brings Free Wi-Fi to Some New York Subway Stations
text: This summer, New York subway riders might be able to actually get some work done on the train (rather than just beating their high scores in Temple Run). Beginning Monday, free Wi-Fi will be available at a number of stations courtesy of Google.

headline: Scientists and the animals they love; tweaking the bird flu; and the emotional toll of heart attacks.
text: Scientists and the animals they love; tweaking the bird flu; and the emotional toll of heart attacks.

headline: The Leaders of the Egyptian Military Council
text: Egypt’s ruling military council is made of up 23 senior officers. Six of them dominate the decision making in the council.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
text: Photos from India, Israel, Syria and Spain.

headline: Before ‘The Newsroom,’ There Was ‘The Newsroom’
text: Last night was the debut of “The Newsroom,” the anticipated and by-now widely dissected new HBO series from Aaron Sorkin. It’s intended, in large part, as a critique of the news industry — its venality, its superficiality and its overall intellectual laziness. All of which is exposed by Will McAvoy (played by Jeff Daniels), a mad-as-hell-and-not-taking-it-anymore news anchor who decides he can do better — and an example of a stock Sorkin character type that The New Yorker’s TV critic Emily Nussbaum calls “The Great Man,” a character “who is theoretically flawed, but really a primal truth-teller whom everyone should follow (or date).”

headline: Summer Essential: Jelly Sandals
text: Don’t be a victim to unpredictable summer weather. Here’s an alternative to chunky rain boots.

headline: Intelligence Chief Announces New Rules to Curb Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officials will face the possibility of additional scrutiny by lie detector tests and a recently established inspector general under new rules intended to deter and detect leaking to news organizations, James R. Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence, announced Monday.

headline: The Evolution of Bird Flu, and the Race to Keep Up
text: On May 20, a 10-year-old girl in rural Cambodia got a fever. Five days later, she was admitted to a hospital, and after two days of intensive care she was dead.

headline: Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island
text: The Governors Ball Music Festival brought 22 and a half hours of music to Randalls Island on Saturday and Sunday.

headline: Two Days Contain a Multitude of Mood Swings
text: The Governors Ball Music Festival, which brought 22 ½ hours of music to Randalls Island on Saturday and Sunday, was relatively modest as festivals go: about 21,000 people each day, only two stages and no overlapping sets to demand tough decisions on which act to see. It was also divided by style. Saturday was devoted to electronics-loving, D.J.-rooted, dance-centered pop, headlined by the band Passion Pit and the rapper Kid Cudi. Sunday featured hand-played, guitar-centered rock from seasoned performers, headlined by Beck, Modest Mouse and Fiona Apple. But the festival’s two-day passes were sold out; marketers and radio stations notwithstanding, concertgoers don’t confine themselves to categories.

headline: Rule Those Bloody Waves
text: LONDON — There were ardent ovations for the impressive cast of the English National Opera’s new production of “Billy Budd” on Saturday night in the second performance of this grimly atmospheric staging by the director David Alden. But the biggest cheers rang out for the conductor Edward Gardner and the orchestra, a response that matched mine.

headline: Seeking a Profitable Place to Put Captured Carbon
text: Two major oil companies joined by a chemical company and an investment group have invested $9 million in a commercial carbon capture project in Texas that will treat the flue gases from a coal-fired cement kiln and turn them into marketable chemicals.

headline: Falling in Love May Take a Lifetime of Research
text: ALBUQUERQUE — Glauco Machado’s plans for his future were not working out the way he had hoped.

headline: Ready or Not
text: Q. The packets for annual seeds say to plant them after any danger of frost. How do so many annuals seem to survive the winter?

headline: Rodriguez Given Day of Rest
text: The Yankees’ lineup card on Monday did not include Alex Rodriguez and placed Curtis Granderson at designated hitter for the first time this season.

headline: In a Chorus of Bleats, One That Sounds Familiar
text: If you’ve heard one pygmy goat kid bleating, you’ve heard them all — unless, that is, you’re a mother goat.

headline: Gait Helps Geckos Stay on Their Sticky Toes
text: Geckos have adhesive toe pads that allow them to cling to almost any surface with ease. Researchers now report that the mechanics of the geckos’ stride help keep these pads clean, preserving their stickiness.

headline: Fare-Beating Arrests on City Buses Double
text: The police have arrested more than 1,200 people for fare evasion on city buses in 2012, officials said Monday, more than double the number at this point last year.

headline: Albums From Rick Ross, Cassandra Wilson and Ralph Peterson
text: MAYBACH MUSIC GROUP

headline: New Jersey Senate Bans Treatment of Fracking Waste
text: New Jersey legislators approved legislation on Monday banning the treatment or storage of fracking waste in the state.

headline: Apple Tweaks Its ‘We’re Safe’ Message and Antivirus Makers Take Notice
text: It was a subtle tweak, but it didn’t go unnoticed by antivirus software makers for long.

headline: ‘Nature’s Masons’ Do Double Duty as Storytellers
text: GUBBIO, Italy — North of Rome, in Umbria, a series of picturesque, ancient towns perch on the tops or sides of the foothills of the Apennine Mountains. Their placement here was a defensive imperative for successive Umbrian, Etruscan, Roman and Christian occupants over the millenniums. But these hillside locations were also of great advantage for constructing massive buildings, fortified walls and aqueducts, because of to unlimited local supplies of limestone.

headline: Herd in Iceland
text: Lindsay Blatt and Paul Taggart joined forces to shoot a documentary about Iceland's unique horse breed and its independent people.

headline: Cato Institute and Koch Brothers Reach Agreement
text: A rift between the Cato Institute and two of its leaders, the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, ended Monday with an agreement to revamp the research group’s leadership in a way that Cato officials said should maintain its political independence.

headline: Oudin Out in First Round, but Not Without a Fight
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For Melanie Oudin, not all first-round losses at the All England Club are created equal.

headline: Can Women ‘Have It All’? Let’s Talk
text: To the Editor:

headline: Digging Deeper, Red Bulls Return to First Place
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Just as the Miami Heat needed Shane Battier, Mike Miller and Mario Chalmers to win an N.B.A. title, Thierry Henry said his Red Bulls would need an equally contributive supporting cast to do the same in the M.L.S.

headline: Campaign Spending
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prospect Park Lake, 10:53 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: a trio of cygnets celebrated their one-month birthday in the rain.

headline: Regulator Proposes New Rule for Large Derivatives Trades
text: Wall Street traders making big bets on derivatives would receive relief from regulation only if they met certain standards under a rule proposed on Monday.

headline: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Inside Google’s secretive X laboratory, known for inventing self-driving cars and augmented reality glasses, a small group of researchers began working several years ago on a simulation of the human brain.

headline: A Fresh Look at Oil’s Long Goodbye
text: [Please be sure to read this followup post, as well: “Oil’s Long Goodbye and a Species’ Quest for Self Control.“]

headline: Federal Prosecutor Nominated for District Court Bench
text: President Obama on Monday nominated Katherine Polk Failla, the chief of the criminal appeals unit in the United States attorney’s office for the Southern District of New York, to the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Nasty Elmo Is Gone, and the Other Ones Are Just Tickled
text: The pedestrian plazas of Times Square are prime territory for the Elmo impersonators of New York, who, dressed as the familiar, cuddly Sesame Street character, compete for tourists’ camera lenses and cash. But there was one Elmo who not only drove tourists off, but made his fellow Elmos back nervously away.

headline: Zimmerman Seeks Another Chance at Freedom on Bond
text: The lawyer for George Zimmerman argued on Monday that his client should be granted bond for a second time as he awaits trial on murder charges in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.

headline: Fake Parking Pass Costs City Planner $6,500 and Her Job
text: A former urban planner for the city was fined $6,500 by New York City’s Conflicts of Interest Board for creating a fake parking placard, which she used to park in prohibited spaces, and to bail herself out of several parking tickets.

headline: Israeli Soldier, Once Held by Hamas, Visits the Mayor
text: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg marched arm in arm with Gilad Shalit’s parents in the 2009 Salute to Israel parade in New York, he sported a button demanding freedom for Mr. Shalit, the young Israeli soldier who had been captured by Hamas in June 2006.

headline: Protecting New Orleans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turkish Border Is Crucial Link in Syrian Conflict
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The onetime ragtag militias of the Syrian opposition are developing into a more effective fighting force with the help of an increasingly sophisticated network of activists here in southern Turkey that is smuggling crucial supplies across the border, including weapons, communications gear, field hospitals and even salaries for soldiers who defect.

headline: In Turkey, a Staging Ground for Syrian Rebels
text: A crossroads in southern Turkey has turned into a staging area for the Syrian opposition to smuggle supplies ranging from weapons to operating tables across the border.

headline: Being Gay Today
text: To the Editor:

headline: Romney and Energy
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Problems With Forecasting and How to Get Better at It
text: Are political scientists any good at making predictions? Jacqueline Stevens, a professor of political science at Northwestern University, argued in an Op-Ed last Sunday that political scientists make for lousy forecasters. Ms. Stevens suggested that National Science Foundation grants to political scientists should be awarded by lottery instead of toward “research aimed at political prediction,” which she said is “doomed to fail.”

headline: Heat Fans Hail a Championship
text: MIAMI — While confetti fell and horns blared downtown, Dwyane Wade held the Larry O’Brien trophy in his arms and a smiling LeBron James assumed his place as conquering hero.

headline: Free Subway and Bus Rides Proposed for Some Disabled Users
text: In the annals of cost-cutting at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, officials have asked themselves many questions. How long will people wait for a bus? Are so many subway announcers needed? How much platform grime will a city tolerate?

headline: Heat-Driven Wildfires Continue to Consume the West
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — Already choking through one of the worst wildfire seasons in recent memory, Colorado found itself dealing with a new series of blazes this week, driven by a relentless heat wave that has threatened to further fan the flames.

headline: Smugglers in Support of Syria
text: As the conflict over control of Syria continues, smugglers based in Turkey bring supplies over the border while bringing the wounded and information back out.

headline: A Palestinian Village Tries to Protect a Terraced Ancient Wonder of Agriculture
text: BATTIR, West Bank — In this scenic Palestinian village in the West Bank hills near Bethlehem, just south of Jerusalem, a week is said to last eight days, not seven. That is because Battir’s eight extended families take daily turns watering their crops from the natural springs that feed their ancient agricultural terraces, a practice they say has worked for centuries.

headline: Left-Hander Comes Up in Latest Bullpen Juggling
text: CHICAGO — The Mets’ bullpen, a source of so much consternation during the team’s otherwise solid start to the season, was making the transition into yet another phase Monday afternoon.

headline: Public Universities See Familiar Fight at Virginia
text: The tumult at the University of Virginia — with the sudden ouster of President Teresa Sullivan on June 10, and the widespread anticipation that she will be reinstated on Tuesday — reflects a low-grade panic now spreading through much of public higher education.

headline: Fixing College
text: Washington

headline: Colorado Wildfire
text: The Waldo Canyon Fire threatens homes near Colorado Springs.

headline: Captain America?
text: The most powerful office on earth?

headline: Immigrants Are Crucial to Innovation, Study Says
text: Arguing against immigration policies that force foreign-born innovators to leave the United States, a new study to be released on Tuesday shows that immigrants played a role in more than three out of four patents at the nation’s top research universities.

headline: Spain and Cyprus Seek Rescue for Ailing Banks
text: MADRID — On the eve of a crucial summit meeting of European leaders in Brussels, Spain on Monday formally requested billions of euros in aid for a banking sector battered by the country’s real estate collapse and Cyprus announced that it would apply for a bailout.

headline: List of Unexploded Arms in Libya Is Seen as Limited
text: The release by NATO of a list of unexploded munitions from the alliance’s military action in Libya has been both welcomed as a step toward postconflict accountability and criticized as a half-measure that falls short of protecting civilians and specialists trying to rid the country of its hazards.

headline: A Coin Flip? A Runoff? Talk About Amateur
text: So let’s get this straight. The women’s 100 meters took about 11 seconds Saturday at the Olympic track and field trials. But it may take the rest of the week or longer to decide who competes in London.

headline: No Drama for Jeter, Just Victory
text: EUGENE, Ore. — All Carmelita Jeter has done is win, win, win — including in the 100-meter finals at the United States Olympic track and field trials on Saturday. Yet all anyone wants to talk about is how Allyson Felix and Jeneba Tarmoh will break their third-place tie in the event.

headline: For New York’s Early Congressional Primaries, a Desperate Push for Turnout
text: Campaign volunteers fueled their cars to ferry voters to the polls. Labor unions deployed teachers, tradesmen and firefighters to make phone calls. Candidates buttonholed prospective voters at subway stops.

headline: Taliban Kill 13 Soldiers in Pakistan Raid
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A relatively rare cross-border raid into Pakistan by Afghan-based Taliban militants killed at least 13 Pakistani soldiers, the military said Monday.

headline: Voting Tuesday
text: Congressional primary elections will be held across New York State on Tuesday.

headline: With Tiebreak Rules Clear, Sprinters Now Have Days to Decide
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Track officials hastily convened a meeting at the Hilton Hotel here Saturday night to determine how to deal with a seemingly unprecedented problem. Two sprinters vying for an Olympic berth had finished in a dead heat, and the high-tech cameras and timing system had been unable to discern who crossed the line first.

headline: F.D.A. Unexpectedly Delays Move on Anticlotting Drug
text: In a move that came as a surprise to researchers and analysts, the Food and Drug Administration has decided not to approve — for now — the anticlotting drug Eliquis, viewed as the next blockbuster for its makers, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pfizer.

headline: Paula Hays Harper, Art Historian, Is Dead at 81
text: Paula Hays Harper, one of the first art historians to bring a feminist perspective to the study of painting and sculpture, and the co-author of a major biography of Camille Pissarro, died on June 3 in Miami. She was 81.

headline: The Patriotic Pull of the Railroad
text: TRAINS may not figure as prominently in the popular imagination as they did in the 1950s, when every American boy seemed to have an electric train set, but the railroad industry is, to be sure, still chugging along.

headline: Matches to Watch: Day 2
text: A look at five matches to watch on Day 2 of Wimbledon. Players seeds are in parentheses.

headline: First Class as Ransom to Escape the Sardine Can
text: BILL CATLETTE gave himself a treat on his last birthday. No more flying in coach.

headline: Microsoft Enters Office Socializing in $1.2 Billion Deal
text: Plenty of people goof off at the office by checking their Facebook accounts. Now Microsoft is paying $1.2 billion for a company that has made Facebook-style social networking just another tool for getting work done.

headline: An Upstairs-Downstairs Divide at a Public School Building in East Harlem
text: Karen Melendez-Hutt once presided over a fine success story. Early last decade, she became principal of Public School 30 in East Harlem, a school on the critical care list.

headline: Zynga Pursues New Hits for a Fickle Market
text: The social game company Zynga hit it big in 2009 with FarmVille, a phenomenon on Facebook that had millions of people watering virtual corn.

headline: In Reversal, Ex-President of Paraguay Seeks Power
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Paraguay’s ousted president, Fernando Lugo, lashed out on Monday at the political establishment that removed him from office after a hastily arranged trial, saying he would forge a popular movement aimed at regaining power.

headline: Fears Accompany Fishermen in Japanese Disaster Region
text: SOMA, Japan — The catch from six small fishing boats, the first to resume commercial fishing in the waters off Fukushima since last year’s nuclear catastrophe, went on sale at local supermarkets on Monday, raising hopes and concerns in a region struggling to return to something like normal.

headline: Tennis Potential Replaced by Potential for Disaster
text: WIMBLEDON, England — After losing his 12th consecutive match, after crumbling from self-doubt and somehow making an opponent who screamed at the heavens and thumped his sternum with his racket appear as serene as a Japanese teahouse, Donald Young sat in an interview room with a towel draped over his head. His shoulders slumped, his eyes drawn to the floor. His voice was at a volume far lower than his appeals to the line judge or desperate pleas to himself.

headline: Arizona Ruling Only a Narrow Opening for Other States
text: While the Supreme Court’s mixed decision on Monday on Arizona’s immigration enforcement law gave a big political boost to officials there who supported it, the ruling does not seem likely to unleash a new wave of legislation by other states to crack down on illegal immigration.

headline: Another Chance for Egypt
text: Now that Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood has been declared its first freely elected president, Egypt has another chance to steer onto a more democratic course. It will require a much greater willingness to work for the common good than the country’s polarized political groups have shown so far.

headline: Gunmen Kill 3 Officers at Airport in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Three federal police officers were shot to death on Monday in a busy passenger terminal at the Mexico City airport as they prepared to arrest two fellow officers in a drug-trafficking investigation, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Big Brother’? No, It’s Parents
text: When her children were ready to have laptops of their own, Jill Ross bought software that would keep an eye on where they went online. One day it offered her a real surprise. She discovered that her 16-year-old daughter had set up her own video channel.

headline: Tools to Control a Child’s Technology
text: How you handle technology in a child’s life depends entirely on how you parent.

headline: Jesse Jackson Jr. Takes Medical Leave for Exhaustion
text: CHICAGO – Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., a Democrat from Illinois and the son of the civil rights leader, is on a medical leave of absence, being treated for exhaustion, his office announced on Monday.

headline: A Con Man Who Lives Between Truth and Fiction
text: BUTNER, N.C. — “I’m a proven liar. Don’t believe anything I say.”

headline: Vote Tuesday in New York
text: New York’s earlier-than-usual Congressional primary elections are on Tuesday. The primaries were moved to June from September to comply with a 2009 federal law that requires military personnel overseas to get ballots at least 45 days before the November election. The date change and the newly drawn districts could add to voter confusion. A low turnout is expected, which means every vote has more weight in contested races. Polls are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m., except in Dutchess County where they are open from noon to 9 p.m.

headline: The Voice of the Storyteller
text: This is the eighth and last in a series of writing lessons by the author, starting with the basics and leading to more advanced techniques.

headline: Men’s and Women’s 800-Meter Teams Are Settled
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Under another day with a gray sky and continual drizzle, thousands of fans packed into Hayward Field, many wearing bright yellow windbreakers and sitting in the rain for hours.

headline: As Bloomberg’s Third Term Winds Down, Unusually Loyal Aides Begin to Eye Exits
text: As New York City mayors go, Michael R. Bloomberg has enjoyed an unusual degree of fidelity among the ranks. His inner circle, mostly unchanged after a decade in office, has avoided the churning disputes and abrupt exits that typically plague political administrations.

headline: For City Parents, Frustration Over Rising Cost of Public School
text: Despite the long-held ideal that public education should be free, parents in New York City are finding themselves paying for an increasing number of things, like class trips and basic supplies.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Jets Defensive Tackle Is O.K. After Flipping His Car
text: Jets defensive tackle Muhammad Wilkerson was examined by doctors at the team’s facility Monday after being involved in a car accident over the weekend in which the vehicle he was driving flipped on the Garden State Parkway.

headline: Middle School Is Basketball’s Fiercest Recruiting Battleground
text: CHANTILLY, Va. — Coaches sat scattered across the bleachers at a basketball tournament here this month, interested observers determined to find the next big star.

headline: Education Dept. Retracts School Coach’s Suspension
text: The New York City Education Department has dropped its disciplinary case against one of the city’s most successful high school baseball coaches, who was forced to sit out a year after he was accused of improperly recruiting a player.

headline: Immigration Law
text: The Supreme Court rejected the foundation of Arizona’s cold-blooded immigration law and the indefensible notion the state can have its own foreign policy. In a 5-to-3 decision, the court blocked three of four provisions in the statute and gave a significant, though incomplete, victory to the federal government.

headline: Letter From Turkey to U.N. on Plane Shot Down by Syria
text: On June 24, 2012, Turkey sent a letter to the Security Council about a Syrian attack that destroyed a Turkish warplane, calling the action “a serious threat to peace and security in the region.”

headline: In Arizona, Confusion on Ruling on Migrants
text: PHOENIX — In the place where it all began, there was confusion and consternation on Monday at the United States Supreme Court’s unanimous decision to uphold the most controversial portion of Arizona’s contentious immigration law, the part that requires law enforcement officers to check the immigration status of people in custody who they suspect are in the country illegally.

headline: Sex-Verification Policy Is Criticized as a Failure
text: The International Olympic Committee’s new policy regarding who is eligible to compete as a female athlete is a veiled sex-verification test that fails in its objective to protect the integrity of women’s events at the Games, critics of the regulations said Monday.

headline: You Feel Lucky Today?
text: Administrivial Blog Maintenance Alert! As I mentioned last week, there is some maintenance that will be conducted on the New York Times blogs tomorrow night, so the Wordplay blog for the Wednesday, June 27 puzzle will be delayed. The puzzle will be available at the regular time (10:00 p.m. Eastern), but the blog will go live at 11:59 p.m. The emus appreciate your patience.

headline: Corrections: June 26
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: On the Campaign Trail, Obama and Romney React to the Justices’ Decision
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on Arizona’s strict immigration law gave President Obama another shot at energizing Latino voters, while Mitt Romney defended states’ aggressive efforts to fight illegal immigration.

headline: Citizens United
text: The Supreme Court examined the Arizona immigration law in minute detail, but when it came to revisiting the damage caused by its own handiwork in the 2010 Citizens United case, it couldn’t be bothered. In a single dismissive paragraph on Monday, the court’s conservative majority refused to allow Montana or any other state to impose limits on corporate election spending and wouldn’t even entertain arguments on the subject.

headline: Britain: Security Chief Offers Assessment About Olympics
text: A month before the start of the Olympic Games, the chief of Britain’s domestic security service, MI5, offered a guarded reassurance on Monday about the risk of terrorist attacks during the 17-day spectacle in Britain. “No doubt some terrorists have thought about whether they could pull off an attack,” Jonathan Evans, MI5’s director general, told an audience in London. “But the Games are not an easy target, and the fact that we have disrupted multiple terrorist plots here and abroad in recent years demonstrates that the United Kingdom as a whole is not an easy target.” British officials will deploy a security force of more than 25,000 for the Games, and Mr. Evans cited the “extremely generous” security assistance given by “friendly countries,” an allusion to an Olympic security unit run by F.B.I. and C.I.A. officials. He said security officials had assessed the current threat of a terrorist strike in Britain as substantial, meaning that an attack is “a strong possibility.” But he noted that the threat assessment was “one notch lower” than it had been for most of the period since the 2001 attacks in the United States. “There is no such thing as guaranteed security,” he said. “But I think we shall see a successful and memorable Games.”

headline: Often Outscored and Unsupported, but Over .500
text: The Cleveland Indians have lost their last three games by a collective score of 22-3. The most recent, a 7-1 defeat on Monday at Yankee Stadium, was over early. The Yankees scored two runs in each of the first three innings, and the Indians do not win slugfests.

headline: The Power of the Particular
text: They say you’ve never really seen a Bruce Springsteen concert until you’ve seen one in Europe, so some friends and I threw financial sanity to the winds and went to follow him around Spain and France. In Madrid, for example, we were rewarded with a show that lasted 3 hours and 48 minutes, possibly the longest Springsteen concert on record and one of the best. But what really fascinated me were the crowds.

headline: Suspense Is Over in Madoff Case
text: On Monday morning, as the Supreme Court was issuing its big ruling on the Arizona immigration law — and prolonging the suspense on its Affordable Care Act decision — it also quietly decided to end the suspense for the victims of the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scheme. Without comment, the court declined to hear a case about which Madoff victims should be compensated and which should not.

headline: Justices Define Narrow Opening on Immigration
text: The legal opening the Supreme Court defined for action by states on immigration is relatively narrow, constitutional lawyers said.

headline: Supreme Court Decision on Arizona Immigration Law
text: Text of the Supreme Court’s decision on Monday on Arizona’s immigration law, with analysis by The New York Times.

headline: Given Rare Start, a Yankees Outfielder Makes the Most of It
text: Dewayne Wise learned that he was starting his first game since May 22 when he arrived at Yankee Stadium on Monday, viewed the lineup card placed by his locker stall and saw his name in the No. 8 spot. Opportunities are rare for Wise, a 34-year-old journeyman who has played with six teams in parts of 10 seasons.

headline: A Short History of Presidential Politicking
text: In running for re-election, Barack Obama commands the most powerful democratic platform in world history and the greatest backdrop, the White House. A seemingly casual announcement in a TV interview can trigger a political earthquake, as Obama did when he endorsed gay marriage. But the president’s magnificent residence can also be what Harry Truman called the Great White Jail.

headline: Can the Muslim Brotherhood Unite Egypt?
text: Will Mohamed Morsi, a former member of the once-banned Muslim Brotherhood organization, be able to unite Egypt?

headline: Lochte Works His Way to Win Over Phelps
text: OMAHA — If Ryan Lochte was going to dethrone Superman, he had to become a Strongman. And so it was, heading into his showdown with Michael Phelps at this week’s United States Olympic trials, Lochte worked on his butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke and freestyle, but also on his pony keg heave, his 400-pound chain drag, his 650-pound tire flip and his heavy bar lift.

headline: Homicides in Selected Large Cities
text: Homicides in selected large cities

headline: City Hall Budget Deal, for Now, Includes Few Layoffs and No Tax Increases
text: Despite uncertainty over hundreds of millions of dollars in anticipated revenue, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council agreed Monday on a $68.5 billion budget for the coming fiscal year that would avoid tax increases, firehouse closings and widespread layoffs.

headline: Coffee Nerves New York
text: The animator Gary Leib’s short film noir portrays the city as observed by a well-caffeinated mind.

headline: Rate of Killings Rises 38 Percent in Chicago in 2012
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s first reading material each morning, at 5:30, is not a budget update, a legislative proposal or a packet of headlines. It is an e-mail from the Chicago Police Department listing the crimes that were committed during the night that just ended. By 7 a.m., he is calling Garry F. McCarthy, the police superintendent. That is unlikely to be their final conversation of the day, or even of the morning.

headline: Fish, With Emotional Loss in 2004, Will Remain Away From the Olympics
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The lure of the Olympics is particularly powerful at Wimbledon this year. Three weeks after the tournament ends, the predominantly all-white clothing rule will be waived and most of the world’s best tennis players will return for the Olympic tournament on the grass they know so well.

headline: Hatch Is Tested in Utah, but Tea Party Anger Cools
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Utah is where the Tea Party slew one of its first giants, toppling a three-term Republican senator in a 2010 electoral coup that scrambled party politics and heralded a litany of fierce contests between establishment Republicans and conservative upstarts.

headline: Motivated by the Two Stars He Helps Push
text: OMAHA — In the years leading up to the 2008 Olympics, Peter Vanderkaay trained alongside Michael Phelps, who went on to win a record eight gold medals at the Beijing Games. Last year, he began training in Gainesville, Fla., alongside Ryan Lochte, who went on to win five gold medals at the World Championships in Shanghai and is poised to compete for more medals at the London Games.

headline: Drained From Series Against Yankees, Mets Look Lifeless Against the Cubs
text: CHICAGO — The Mets players wandered ghostlike around the antique grounds.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Voter ID Law Spurs Debate
text: A top Pennsylvania Republican’s remark this weekend that the state’s new voter ID law would help Mitt Romney win the state has reignited a debate over whether the law is intended to curb fraud, as Republicans say, or to depress Democratic turnout, as Democrats charge.

headline: Pennsylvania’s Voter ID Law Spurs Debate
text: A top Pennsylvania Republican’s remark this weekend that the state’s new voter ID law would help Mitt Romney win the state has reignited a debate over whether the law is intended to curb fraud, as Republicans say, or to depress Democratic turnout, as Democrats charge.

headline: Word of the Day | infernal
text: infernal •\in-ˈfər-nəl\• adjective

headline: With F-150 Limited, Ford Raises the Ceiling, Again, on Premium Pickups
text: Ford introduced its refreshed F-150 pickup truck for the 2013 model year earlier this month but withheld information about its range-topping variant until Tuesday.

headline: Little Rattles Vollmer as She Cruises Into 100 Fly Finals
text: OMAHA — A mid-afternoon fire alarm at the Hilton Omaha rattled a number of swimmers from their Olympic trials between-sessions naps Monday, but not butterfly specialist Dana Vollmer. “I wasn’t able to sleep in between,” she said.

headline: Father in Chinese Forced-Abortion Scandal Is Said to Be Missing
text: Update, 3:58 p.m. Tuesday, E.S.T.: Deng Jiyuan called his sister, Deng Jicai, on Tuesday afternoon to report that he was safe, Ms. Deng told Edward Wong of The Times.

headline: California: Bankruptcy Looms for City at End of Mediation
text: State-mandated mediation between the City of Stockton and its creditors was set to expire at midnight on Monday, moving the Central Valley community one step closer to becoming the largest city in the country to go bankrupt. If the 90-day mediation fails, the City Council is set to vote Tuesday evening on a new budget to cover a $26 million deficit in case of bankruptcy. City officials would then have until July 1 to officially file for bankruptcy protection. Once a booming bedroom community for San Francisco Bay Area commuters, the city was hard hit by falling housing prices, enduring one of the highest foreclosure rates in the country. Since 2009, the city has cut some $90 million from its budget, including deep cutbacks to municipal staff, police and fire departments.

headline: Massachusetts: Bulger Trial Delayed
text: Lawyers for James (Whitey) Bulger on Monday won a four-month delay in his trial and told a judge that a deal between their client and the government renders him immune from prosecution, and that they will seek to have charges against Mr. Bulger dropped. Mr. Bulger, who prosecutors said acted as an F.B.I. informer while playing a leading role in Boston’s crime underworld, faces charges including 19 murders at a trial now scheduled to begin March 4, 2013. His lawyers said they need more time to prepare his defense. Mr. Bulger was captured last summer in Santa Monica, Calif., after spending 16 years in hiding with his girlfriend, Catherine Greig, who was recently sentenced to eight years in prison on charges of harboring a fugitive.

headline: Florida: Zimmerman Seeks Another Chance at Freedom on Bond
text: The lawyer for George Zimmerman argued on Monday that his client should be granted bond for a second time as he awaits trial on murder charges in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin. In a motion filed with the Seminole County Circuit Court, the lawyer, Mark O’Mara, said his client is not a flight risk and takes responsibility for his role in not alerting the judge about tens of thousands of dollars in donations made to an online fund that he had set up before his first bond hearing in April. Bail was revoked for Mr. Zimmerman on June 1 after prosecutors told the court that he and his wife, Shellie Zimmerman, 25, had misled the court about their finances and had spoken to each other in code about the estimated $125,000 in donations. The second bond hearing is scheduled for Friday.

headline: After a Victory, Lochte Steps Out in Style
text: OMAHA — After winning the 400-meter individual medley at the Olympic trials Monday night, Ryan Lochte broke out a pair of Adidas high-top “star-spangled” sneakers that he helped design. The right shoe is blue with white stars. The left one is white with red horizontal stripe. Both have wings, as if he is an All-American Hermes.

headline: 5 Percent of Job Programs Fail Test on Graduates’ Success
text: The Department of Education is issuing data on Tuesday showing that 5 percent of career-training programs — all of them at for-profit institutions — failed all three requirements of the department’s new gainful-employment regulations. Under the new rules, intended to protect students from taking on high debt for worthless job credentials, at least 35 percent of graduates must be repaying their loans, and the typical graduate’s estimated annual loan payments must not exceed 12 percent of earnings, or 30 percent of discretionary income. Starting next fall, schools that fail all three tests for three of four consecutive years will lose their access to federal aid.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Rips Into Romney at Obama Fund-Raiser in Boston
text: BOSTON – Elizabeth Warren opened for President Obama at his Boston fund-raiser on Monday, ripping into his rival, Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, using themes from her own campaign.

headline: News Corp. Considers Dividing Itself in Two
text: 1:29 a.m. | Updated News Corporation is considering dividing itself in two, cleaving its publishing arm from its far larger entertainment division, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook early on Tuesday.

headline: Frisbee Gains Popularity in India
text: The Frisbee is not native to India. It does not engender the obsession of cricket or beckon the roaring fans of soccer. It is not steeped in the culture like kabaddi or popularized in social clubs like squash.

headline: News Quiz | June 26, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: In Kashmir, Killing Ebbs, but Killers Roam Free
text: “After decades of war, Kashmir is blooming again,” Gardiner Harris wrote in The New York Times. “Hotels are bursting, roads are being fixed and offices rebuilt.”

headline: Test Yourself | June 26, 2012
text: This question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “A Georgia Town Takes the People’s Business Private.”

headline: Backed by NATO, Turkey Steps Up Warning to Syria
text: WASHINGTON — Buoyed by support from its NATO allies, Turkey escalated its warnings against Syria on Tuesday, even as some American and allied officials privately raised questions about whether the Turkish warplane shot down by Syrian air defenses — provoking the denunciation — had been on a spy mission.

headline: What It Takes to Be an Ironman
text: WHO is Guy Adami?WHO is Mike Reilly?

headline: Australian Billionaire Threatens to Dump Fairfax Media Stake
text: HONG KONG — The Australian mining billionaire Georgina Rinehart has threatened to sell her recently acquired 19 percent stake in Fairfax Media, sending shares in the Australian publisher tumbling on Tuesday.

headline: How Does the Film Industry Actually Make Money?
text: I’ve been trying to come to terms with two seemingly irreconcilable facts. First, “Men in Black 3” has made more than $550 million worldwide. Second, while a representative from the parent company of Columbia Pictures told me that the movie is now “in the win column,” it seemed until recently as if Columbia might actually lose money on it. How could that be? It’s not so complicated. Its production costs were close to $250 million; worldwide marketing most likely added at least that much; and a big chunk of the ticket sales go to theaters and distributors.

headline: Rounding Up Iceland’s Horses
text: Lindsay Blatt and Paul Taggart did not know much about Iceland beyond the headlines in the news — its recent bankruptcy, the eruption of Eyjafjallajokull, the volcano that ruined many travel plans (and confused many more  with its pronunciation), and its most famous native, Bjork.

headline: Settlers Begin Evacuation of a West Bank Outpost
text: BEIT EL, West Bank — The rooms are much smaller, with kitchens running along a wall of the salon rather than in a separate space. But freshly potted flowers and trees awaited the new residents on each doorstep. There are no hilltop views, no grassy yards, though neighbors share courtyard patios of the same red brick that formed a path behind the old place.

headline: Economics, Good and Bad
text: Jonathan Portes pursues a debate with Diane Coyle over the state of economics; since my name comes up both in his piece and in Coyle’s, I think I should weigh in and add some further points.

headline: Japan Reactor Building Is Tilting but Not a Risk, Operator Says
text: TOKYO — A heavily damaged reactor building at the tsunami-stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has a slight tilt, but the tilt does not pose a risk to the integrity of the building, according to the plant’s operator.

headline: Stimulus Even Republicans Can Support
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: U.S. Soccer Check-In: 10 Things We Know
text: Jurgen Klinsmann has two World Cup qualifiers under his belt as coach of the United States national team, and two-plus months to consider his options before the team travels to Jamaica for its next match in the semifinal round.

headline: Assad Supporters Suspected in New Beirut Incidents
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Gunmen erected roadblocks, burned tires and fired into the air in downtown Beirut in the predawn hours of Tuesday, while in the suburb of Jounieh to the east, at least two land mines were found on the grounds of a hospital.

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Find Good Job Candidates?
text: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the members followed up on issues raised in previous posts. The conversation then turned to the challenges of hiring, including where to find the best candidates: LinkedIn? Craigslist? Dog parks?

headline: Saudi End to Olympics Women Ban Will Have No Practical Effect
text: LONDON — Saudi Arabia’s decision to allow women to compete at the Olympics for the first time is being greeted with more cynicism than celebration.

headline: Credit Suisse Said to Plan New Round of Layoffs in Europe
text: LONDON – The Swiss bank Credit Suisse is planning to further reduce the size of its European investment banking department, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: With Mukherjee’s Departure, Who Will Run the Show?
text: Filling Pranab Mukherjee’s shoes won’t be easy following his retirement Tuesday to run for  President of India. In addition to heading the Finance Ministry, the 76 year-old runs a staggering 13 of India’s 27 Groups of Ministers, special decision-making groups set up to consider policy on difficult issues, and all 12 of the Empowered Groups of Ministers, which are additional ministerial working groups.

headline: On Our Radar: Water Pollution and Logging
text: The Supreme Court agrees to decide whether federal regulators should treat storm water on industrial timberlands the same way they do pollution discharged from a factory rather than as they do water from farm fields. [Associated Press]

headline: Political Pitfalls in a Hasty Reaction to the Health Care Ruling
text: Shortly after 10 a.m. on Thursday, the world will get its first reports from the United States Supreme Court about the fate of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: New City Budget Restores Money for Day Care and After-School Programs
text: The annual city budget dance has ended, and the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have waltzed to a deal for $68.5 billion that includes no tax increases, no firehouse closings, no widespread layoffs of teachers or others — and, in fact, slight increases to some services for children and families.

headline: A Life Spent in Sugar and Spice
text: The universal rule of kitchen work, Marcus Samuelsson says in his crisp new memoir, “Yes, Chef,” goes as follows: “Stay invisible unless you’re going to shine.” That rule applies to writers too, especially to those who would write food memoirs. Because you like to put things in your mouth does not mean you have a story to tell.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Dividing News Corp.? And Quoting Men About Women
text: News Corporation is considering splitting itself in two, DealBook reported early Tuesday morning, with the publishing businesses — including The Wall Street Journal, The Times of London, The New York Post and the HarperCollins book business — separated from its entertainment assets like the Fox movie studio and TV networks. The change, which was long opposed by Rupert Murdoch, wouldn’t be expected to affect the Murdoch family’s control of both sets of assets, DealBook reported, but would please investors who are looking for a clean break from the phone-hacking scandals related to the News Corporation newspapers in Britain.

headline: A New Ride-Sharing Service Turns Private Cars Into Taxis
text: Technology start-ups continue to chip away at the idea that everyone should own a car or two.

headline: The Get | Louis Vuitton’s Orangerie des Tuileries Brooch
text: Louis Vuitton is celebrating all things French just before Bastille Day (July 14), opening its first fine jewelry and watchmaking boutique on July 3 on the renowned Place Vendôme in Paris. To mark the occasion, Lorenz Bäumer, the artistic director of haute joaillerie for Vuitton, has designed three new collections inspired by three of the City of Light’s most iconic locations: the Place de la Concorde, the Champs Élysées and the Tuileries. Here, the Orangerie des Tuileries brooch features two flowers lifted from LV’s near-synonymous logo, one made of tsavorite and diamonds, and a larger one with a blue tanzanite gemstone in the center.

headline: Can Gadgets Bring You Closer to Your Children?
text: Can you know your children as well as your parents knew you? Or in the digital age, can you know them better?

headline: In a Draft Lacking Drama, Sullinger’s Stock Plummets
text: Jared Sullinger insists he is not injured. He participated in the pre-draft combine and worked out for various teams in the leadup to Thursday’s N.B.A. draft. Yet the player who was projected as a top-five pick out of Ohio State just a year ago was red-flagged as a future injury concern by doctors who have examined his back, leading to a precipitous fall in his draft ranking.

headline: For Hispanics, A Court Decision Won’t Root Out Profiling
text: NEW YORK — For millions of Latinos who sought to get rid of Arizona’s infamous and draconian immigration law, the U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling on Monday brought some relief — but not a full reprieve.

headline: Russians Join Israel to Start Jewish Prize of $1 Million
text: MOSCOW — A charity founded by Russian Jewish billionaires is establishing a $1 million annual award for excellence in virtually any field, to honor those people who attribute their success to Jewish values. The prize will be administered in partnership with the Israeli government, highlighting the strong ties between Israel and Russia.

headline: At Wimbledon, Disappointing Results for U.S. Olympians
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The United States Tennis Association must be hoping that its squad announced Tuesday for the London Olympics will fare better at the All England Club next month than it has so far at Wimbledon. Representing the men in singles will be John Isner, Andy Roddick, Donald Young and Ryan Harrison. Roddick is scheduled to play later Tuesday, but of the other three Americans only Harrison won his first-round match. Isner and Roddick will team in doubles, as will Bob and Mike Bryan.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Fighting Acid Reflux May Bring Other Risks
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: On Primary Day, Closely Watching Two Races
text: By the hundreds of thousands, New Yorkers will not vote in primaries being held on Tuesday in Congressional districts. We’re very good at not voting in this city. Our approach to polling stations is similar to what Lawrence Peter Berra, the catcher in the wry, once said about ballparks, something to the effect that if people don’t want to go, nothing can stop them.

headline: Engaging Nonfiction: The Times, the Common Core and a Question for You

headline: Daily Report: Google Brain Teaches Itself to Recognize — What Else? — Cats
text: Google scientists created one of the largest neural networks for machine learning by connecting 16,000 computer processors, which they turned loose on the Internet to learn on its own. Presented with 10 million digital images found in YouTube videos, what did Google’s brain do? What millions of humans do with YouTube: looked for cats.

headline: News Corp. Shares Leap on Potential Split
text: Shares in News Corporation rose more than 6 percent in morning trading on Tuesday, on reports of a potential plan to split the media empire in two.

headline: Panderer’s Box
text: TBILISI, Georgia — Tucked away in what used to be a water-filtering plant on the banks of the Mtkvari River, a few miles from Tbilisi’s city center, is Georgia’s newest television station, Channel 9, and the epicenter of the curious saga of media freedom in Georgia.

headline: Before Talks With Lenders, Greece Appoints Finance Minister
text: ATHENS — The Greek government moved swiftly Tuesday to shore up its unraveling cabinet ahead of crucial talks with its international lenders, appointing a new finance minister with vast economic experience whose main aim is to keep Greece within the euro zone.

headline: A First Look at the Revamped Aakash Tablet
text: The Aakash-2, or the new and improved version of Aakash, India’s super-cheap tablet computer, was introduced in Mumbai on Monday.

headline: Coney Island Kernels
text: Dear Diary: Summer means corn on the cob. Back in the 1940s, when I was a kid, the best place to bite into an ear was at Coney Island.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Ham Independence: An Iowa-based maker of excellent prosciutto, La Quercia, wants Americans to declare independence from foreign hams. Herb Eckhouse is on tour, promoting “Life, Liberty, and the Prosciutto of Happiness.” — Julia Moskin

headline: A Swimming Rivalry Intensifies; a Tennis Career in Doubt
text: Swimming threw its first splash of pool water into the Olympic season Monday with the first day of the United States Olympic trials, which means from now until the last wall is touched in August, it is officially Ryan Lochte vs. Michael Phelps season. If this is not a season you are ready for, NBC's brain programmers will be at your door shortly. This is the great rivalry of the coming Games, an epic clash of titans, the tale of the superstar coming into his own (Lochte) trying to unseat swimming's Superman (Phelps). Knowing that, you can now put NBC on mute for two months, because it will do little but fill your head with that theme. Dramatic overkill, after all, is that fourth Olympic principle after higher, faster, stronger.

headline: Clay Won’t Compete, but He’ll Be in London
text: Bryan Clay has been a fixture in the Olympic track and field community since 2004, so it was not surprising that almost as soon as Clay stumbled out of this year’s trials, a public movement began calling for United States Track and Field to find a way to get Clay to London anyway.

headline: Sex in This City
text: NAIROBI — Kenya’s cosmopolitan capital barely sleeps. Not only are most workers up before the sun, for many young men and women, the predawn hour is when the real fun starts.

headline: Markets Gain on a Positive Housing Report
text: Major stock indexes in the United States rebounded from Monday’s sell-off, as optimism about the housing market tempered concern about a worsening of Europe’s debt crisis.

headline: Business Day Live | June 26, 2012
text: Why News Corporation may divide itself in two. | The anxiety of being a digital parent. | Google's artificial brain scours the Internet in search of ... cats.

headline: Olive Oil From a California Tribe
text: A number of American Indian tribes produce food products, usually items like wild rice, pemmican and fry-bread mixes. The Yocha Dehe Wintun Nation, of the Capay Valley in Northern California, has gone farther. Last year, the tribe — which has a casino and grows various crops, like wine grapes — harvested and pressed enough arbequina olives to bottle and sell the oil, which the state has certified as extra virgin. Chartreuse and medium-bodied, it is on the mellow side, hinting of herbs, and in the back of the palate, pepper.

headline: For a Fresh Burst of Citrus
text: Love the convenience of those citrus-shaped spray bottles of lemon and lime juice, but also want the juice to be fresh? Both are possible with Stem, a spray nozzle that you insert into the fruit. Press the plunger to spritz fresh juice (even orange or grapefruit) onto fish, into a cocktail or over a salad. Stem is the latest product from Quirky, a collaborative New York company that specializes in developing “Why didn’t I think of that?” gadgets. Would-be inventors who join the Quirky community (easily done online at quirky.com) can submit ideas, and if they win the approval of other members, the company’s design and production team takes over. Quirky also handles distribution and shares profits with the inventor.

headline: The Case for Spending a Little More Sometimes
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at BAM Advisor Services. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog.

headline: Pick Your Race and Train With Run Well
text: Today Well reintroduces its popular fitness training tool, Run Well, which allows readers to choose among several free running plans for long and short distances from some of the country’s top running coaches.

headline: U.S. Grants a Keystone Pipeline Permit
text: The Obama administration, moving swiftly on the president’s promise to expedite the southernmost portion of the disputed Keystone XL pipeline, has granted construction permits for part of the route passing through Texas, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Claude Lemieux and Shanahan Among Candidates for Hall
text: On Tuesday at 3 p.m. the Hockey Hall of Fame will announce its 2012 inductees. The announcement will be shown live on the NHL Network in the United States and on TSN2 in Canada.

headline: Driving the 2013 Ford Focus ST
text: Holdouts certainly remain, but the lament that presumes well-engineered, sporty compact cars bypass the American driver is playing more softly of late.

headline: Weight Gains
text: Gretchen Reynolds, the Phys Ed columnist, explores the new science of weight lifting, why runners might lift and why the squat may be the most effective weight-lifting exercise.

headline: Federal Appeals Court Upholds CO2 Rules
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has bluntly rejected challenges to the Obama Administration’s rules restricting carbon dioxide emissions as a pollutant under the Clean Air Act. Here’s the core conclusion of the panel and the full ruling:

headline: Shopping Snapshots: June 28
text: Charlotte Olympia designs patriotic pumps just in time for July 4; ways to work the sun visor look; and Everlane opening a pop-up in Soho.

headline: London Theater Journal: Shock Value
text: Rarely does a play leave me shaking these days. But Philip Ridley’s “Mercury Fur,” which ended its limited run at Trafalgar Studios last weekend, offers the most merciless vision of a self-devouring Britain since Sarah Kane’s “Blasted” rattled audiences here in 1995. This savage and utterly gripping drama imagines a lawless London in what – if you’re in the right (or wrong) mood – feels like the all-too-foreseeable future.

headline: Brooklyn District Attorney Drops Sexual Abuse Case
text: An explosive sex-crime case in Brooklyn that centered on allegations that a group of men had abused a young Orthodox Jewish woman from Crown Heights over nearly a decade ended on Tuesday, as a judge granted the prosecutors’ request to dismiss the indictment against four defendants.

headline: Corruption Allegations Prompt Slew of Political Resignations in India
text: Tuesday’s resignation of the Congress Party leader Virbhadra Singh as minister of micro, small and medium enterprises, after a court brought charges of corruption against him, is the latest Indian government official to depart under a cloud.

headline: Al Mancini, Las Vegas Restaurant Critic, Is Answering Questions
text: Al Mancini is a conspicuous character in a city full of them — Las Vegas, where he is a restaurant critic and journalist. From graduating from Brooklyn Law School, to tending bar at CBGB’s Pizza in the East Village, to writing reviews of strip clubs, he has followed an unorthodox path to the luxurious dining rooms he now frequents.

headline: Spice Girls Reunite to Announce a Musical
text: Twenty years ago they were mere wannabes, but now there is going to be a stage musical based on their music and their careers. The Spice Girls, symbols of bubbly mid-’90s dance pop, reunited briefly in London on Tuesday for the announcement of “Viva Forever!,” which is scheduled to open there at the end of the year; according to its creators, it will address the “bitter reality of fame.”

headline: Obama Ad Attacks Romney as ‘Outsourcer in Chief’

headline: Hawk Cam Has Gone Dark
text: The 2012 season of the Hawk Cam has come to a close.

headline: Grazing in the Stacks of Academe
text: In Still Life, a series of articles beginning this week, writers for The Times sketch their favorite summer images.

headline: Simple Advice for Better Weight Training
text: For many of us, weight training is a mysterious and intimidating activity. People often ask me if they really need to lift weights. And if so, do they need to lift heavy weights? What is a heavy weight? People also ask if weight lifting will make them bulky — and often wonder whether, if they already regularly run, walk, swim or cycle, they need to lift weights at all?

headline: Major Work by Pollock Slated for Getty Center Conservation
text: One of Jackson Pollock’s most important pre-drip paintings, “Mural,” from 1943 – the subject of political skirmishes in the last few years over whether its owner, the University of Iowa, should sell it to raise money for the school – will travel to Los Angeles to undergo extensive study and conservation by scientists at the Getty Conservation Institute and conservators at the J. Paul Getty Museum.

headline: For Australian Men, the First Round Is the Only One
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Australian grass-court dynasty was broken up years ago. But despite all the changes in Australia and its tennis players, there is still something in the collective consciousness that associates the sunburned land down under with the rain-threatened lawns of Wimbledon.

headline: We All Start Small
text: Perhaps housing prices have finally hit bottom and even begun to recover. That is certainly the view of a growing number of experts of various kinds, including the very rarest kind – the experts who have avoided such declarations until now.

headline: Bird Set to Leave Pacers, Despite Turnaround
text: A month ago, Larry Bird was basking in the league-wise praise of his in-progress rebuilding of the Indiana Pacers. And he won kudos from his peers too, as he was recently named the N.B.A.’s executive of the year.

headline: Formula One Boss Questions Likelihood of 2013 Grand Prix in New Jersey
text: Bernie Ecclestone, the 81-year-old head of the Formula One race series, said recently in an interview with the BBC that the Grand Prix of America, scheduled to be run in New Jersey next summer, may not happen.

headline: F.T.C. Charges Hotel Group Over Data Breaches
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission charged Wyndham Worldwide and three hotel and resort affiliates on Tuesday with allowing three breaches of its corporate data files in two years, resulting in the electronic theft of the credit card data of hundreds of thousands of the hotel chain’s customers.

headline: For Olympic Trials, an Ad That’s Personal
text: EUGENE, Ore. – Perhaps the best story out of the Olympic trials this week wasn’t on the track or field at Hayward Field, but in the stands.

headline: As Rebels Attack Elite Guards, Assad Talks of ‘State of War’
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A surprise assault by Syrian insurgents on a Republican Guard base in Damascus, just a few miles from the presidential palace, elicited a furious military response on Tuesday, with government forces shelling surrounding neighborhoods in an escalation that brought combat in the Syrian conflict close to the heart of the capital.

headline: 50 Cent Injured in Car Accident
text: The rapper 50 Cent was hospitalized briefly Tuesday morning after a truck hit his car from behind on the Long Island Expressway, according to his Web site, ThisIs50. His publicist said that the 36-year-old rapper, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, had been treated for minor injuries to his neck and back at New York Hospital Queens and then released. According to Mr. Jackson’s Web site, the accident occurred when the driver of a Mack truck lost control after the load he was carrying shifted, causing the truck to hit the rear of the SUV with Mr. Jackson and his driver.

headline: A Pioneer in Aging
text: Today’s Science Times continues its Profiles in Science series with an article on the pioneering geriatrics researcher Linda P. Fried, now dean of the Mailman School of Public Health at Columbia University. Dr. Fried, who has spent years developing measures of frailty that allow for more targeted health care and prevention, talks about reframing the way our culture views aging.

headline: Making Commanders Accountable for Soldiers’ Suicides
text: Suicide remains an alarming and growing problem throughout the Army, with the annual number of suicides now greater than the number of deaths resulting from combat.

headline: ‘The Nance’ Looking Likely as Nathan Lane’s Return to Broadway
text: It looks as if the 2012-13 Broadway season will include Nathan Lane in one play at least.

headline: Craving Carbs on an Empty Stomach
text: Have a habit of skipping meals? A new study shows that people who sit down to eat after an overnight fast are more likely to ignore protein, fats and vegetables and head straight for high-calorie carbohydrates and starches first.

headline: Food Trucks to Take Turns at the Library
text: Call it the lunch exhibition that escaped into the park.
