headline: ‘Glass House’ Ratings Sink; CW Ratings Approach Rock Bottom
text: “The Glass House,” the reality show that was the subject of a bitter legal dispute between ABC and CBS — which went in ABC’s favor — has quickly earned mostly disfavor with viewers.

headline: A Small Restaurant Gets a Big Increase in Health Premiums — and Misses the Tax Credit
text: With this post, The Agenda returns to our occasional series on how small companies are coping with providing health insurance. We’re going to Woodinville, Wash., about a half hour north of Seattle, and The Herbfarm Restaurant. The Herbfarm, which grows many of its own ingredients in its garden and nearby fields, has also cultivated a distinguished national reputation since it opened more than two decades ago. The travel guide Frommer’s once declared that the restaurant is “so famous and serves such unforgettable meals that people plan Seattle vacations around dinner here,” but that hasn’t made it any easier for its proprietors to provide affordable insurance to their employees.

headline: Image of the Day: June 26
text: School children in Assam wade through flood water to attend school.

headline: Goffin Hopes to Be This Year’s Wimbledon Surprise
text: WIMBLEDON, England — David Goffin of Belgium was the luckiest loser at the French Open this year, a qualifier who gained last-minute entry to the main draw when another player withdrew. He then proceeded to win three rounds and even took a set off Roger Federer before falling in four respectable sets.

headline: A Novel About Wall Street Borrows From Life
text: The new book by John Gapper, “A Fatal Debt,” is a work of fiction. But buried in the story are some not-so-subtle allusions to Wall Street.

headline: Republican Reactions to the Arizona Decision
text: If you found the Supreme Court’s ruling on Arizona’s anti-immigration law confusing – the justices rejected three parts of the statute and sort of punted on the fourth – then you should read the reactions from some Republican politicians. At least the court’s decision had internal logic.

headline: Turnout Mixed in Early Voting in City’s Congressional Primaries
text: With several hotly contested Democratic Congressional primaries being held months earlier than usual, fears of light turnout on Tuesday appeared justified in some districts but not in others in the opening hours of voting.

headline: Sweeping Effects as Broadband Moves to Meters
text: SAN ANTONIO — The broadband era began with the expectation that Internet connections were like buffets — all you can eat, 24 hours a day. But users are now being prodded to think about how much they’re consuming.

headline: Forced to Abort, Chinese Woman Under Pressure
text: BEIJING — A woman who was forced by local officials to abort a seven-month-old fetus this month and whose case has spurred a national discussion about China’s one-child policy said on Tuesday that she was “under a lot of pressure” and was being watched by guards in a hospital, who do not allow her to leave.

headline: Top Executives Weigh Breakup of News Corp.
text: Top executives at News Corporation met on Tuesday to discuss a potential breakup that would sever the media company’s underperforming newspapers from its lucrative entertainment assets.

headline: Romney Previews His Response to the Supreme Court’s Health Care Ruling
text: SALEM, Va. — Mitt Romney‘s campaign is eagerly awaiting the Supreme Court’s decision on President Obama’s health care law, which is expected on Thursday morning.

headline: Motown and Berry Gordy Jr. to Get the Broadway Treatment
text: Berry Gordy Jr. is bringing his life story to Broadway next year.

headline: Obama Campaign Banks on High-Tech Ground Game to Reach Voters
text: CHILLICOTHE, Ohio — A cheer erupted at about 8 on a June evening as a woman scrawled with red marker on paper taped to the wall: the small group in a storefront Obama campaign office in this Mayberry-like southern Ohio town had exceeded the night’s goal of calling 700 voters with an hour to go, despite time out for a pep talk from a surprise visitor, former Gov. Ted Strickland.

headline: Breaking It Down: Federer vs. Ramos
text: The lost art of serving and volleying has been found again by Roger Federer.

headline: Hoyer Challenges Issa to Show E-Mails
text: WASHINGTON — With the House just days away from a vote on holding Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in contempt, Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California, appeared on national television on Sunday to say he had e-mails showing that the architects of a federal gun-smuggling investigation intended to use the operation to build a case for reinstating the lapsed ban on assault-weapons sales.

headline: F.B.I. Says 24 Are Arrested in Credit Card Theft Plan
text: For hackers in search of information like credit card numbers and software to spy on computers, the site called Carder Profit appeared to be a veritable eBay for thieves.

headline: The Caucus Click: Serving the President
text: Cashiers jockeyed for position behind the counter as they tried to get President Obama’s attention during a campaign stop on Tuesday at The Varsity restaurant in Atlanta.

headline: In Tough Times, Private Equity Saves Jobs
text: Richard Farley is a partner in the corporate practice of Paul Hastings and is based in the firm’s New York office. His practice centers on representing some of the world’s leading commercial and investment banks in leveraged buyout financing, recapitalization and refinancing.

headline: Louis C.K. Gets Into the Ticket-Selling Business
text: At this point in his booming career, Louis C.K. could fill theaters by charging Broadway-style prices, and blame the high cost on scalpers and ticketing services. Instead, he has decided to try to reinvent another comedy business model.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week Spring 2013 Accessories
text: Cloth neck pieces at Armani; gladiator nods at Versace; neon soles at Salvatore Ferragamo, all from the Milan men’s collections.

headline: A $100 Weekend in Oslo
text: Tell people you’re off to spend the weekend in Oslo with $100 in your pocket, and the warnings start flowing. Some came in the form of legitimate research like the UBS report that has ranked Oslo the world’s most expensive city for the last three years; others were shock-and-awe anecdotes, like “Food in Oslo is so expensive you can actually buy half a cucumber.”

headline: Franklin Breaks One-Minute Barrier
text: OMAHA – At 17, Missy Franklin is one of the younger participants in the United States Olympic trials, but she can be forgiven for feeling as if the wait to swim her first race here took forever. For the past several months Franklin has been portrayed as the fresh face of the 2012 U.S. Olympic team despite not having yet made the squad.

headline: Wild Card Tennis Entries Are Announced
text: The International Tennis Federation announced the acceptance list for the 2012 Olympic Games on Tuesday afternoon, finally ending months of speculation and calculations.

headline: Court Backs E.P.A. Over Emissions Limits Intended to Reduce Global Warming
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld a finding by the Environmental Protection Agency that heat-trapping gases from industry and vehicles endanger public health, dealing a decisive blow to companies and states that had sued to block agency rules.

headline: The Best Cars for a Teenage Driver
text: Just what every newly licensed, teenage driver wants: a safe, reliable midsize sedan.

headline: Good Day for Oates: Coaching Job and Hall of Fame Election
text: Tuesday was a great day to be Adam Oates. In the morning, he was named to his first head coaching job, by the Washington Capitals. In the afternoon, he was elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

headline: Tech Companies Announce ‘Girls Who Code’ Initiative
text: It’s no secret that programmers who work at start-ups are predominantly men. This is evident on all corners of the Internet: from the naming of some products — which can sometimes “make women cringe” — to the endless stream of “top 100″ lists that are often 95 percent men.

headline: The Wisdom of a Moral Panic
text: In a piece pegged to the death of the first woman to conceive through in vitro fertilization, the Atlantic’s Megan Garber looks back on what she calls “the IVF panic” that accompanied the technology’s 1970s emergence:

headline: Waverly Inn Is Closed After Fire
text: The Waverly Inn and Garden is closed, after a fire in the basement early Monday evening. The clubby restaurant in Greenwich Village is likely to reopen within a week, said Emil Varda, the managing partner in the restaurant, which is also owned by Graydon Carter, the editor-in-chief of Vanity Fair.

headline: Following Your Children Online: How Much Is Too Much?
text: I get a pitch from a P.R. person to cover some form of child-monitoring/Internet safety app, tool or device almost every day. Internet safety, however you define it, is both big business and a huge parental concern — and judging from the 230-plus comments so far on “Big Brother? No, It’s Parents” in The Times today, we’re not nearly done with  talking about how software can, and whether it should, help us monitor our children’s lives online.

headline: Tiptoeing Past the Deaf
text: There are world premieres by famous playwrights in “More of Our Parts” at the Clurman Theater, among them works by the lord of the WASPs, A. R. Gurney, and the king of emotional brutality, Neil LaBute. Yet the wittiest script among these six short one-act plays about life with disabilities comes from a relative unknown, Bruce Graham, the Philadelphia playwright who did “Any Given Monday.”

headline: Without News, CNN Is Without Viewers
text: The news for CNN has been bad for a long time, but it got especially bad in the second quarter of this year. Ratings for the network’s prime-time shows plunged by 40 percent from a year ago, and the network’s performance was its worst ever for a second quarter.

headline: Why Germany Will Pay Up to Save the Euro
text: To go by the pronouncements coming out of Germany over the last couple of weeks, you might naturally conclude that the euro is toast. Speaking before Parliament, Chancellor Angela Merkel broadly rejected “counterproductive” proposals to pool Europe’s resources to help floundering Mediterranean nations. Germany’s “strength is not infinite,” she stressed.

headline: No Income Tax? No Boost.
text: This past February, Oklahoma Governor Mary Fallin announced a plan to phase out her state’s income tax over ten years. “We’re going to have the most pro-growth tax system in the region,” she said, according to The Wall Street Journal.  Lawmakers in Kansas and Missouri have also pushed to eliminate their state income taxes this year—convinced, like Ms. Fallin and like the majority of the Republican Party since the 1980s, that the best way to grow is to cut.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Play in a Digital Age
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parker’s Injury Leaves Olympic Fate in Hands of Spurs
text: The N.B.A.’s current relationship with international basketball competition is, in a word, complex.

headline: Catholics, Continued
text: My last column discussed an exit strategy for disaffected Catholics. The proposition was that Catholics who want a church more bighearted on issues like the role of women and the acceptance of gay love should consider looking elsewhere, because today’s Catholic hierarchy is stuck in a deep rut. The reaction was unusually plentiful and heartfelt, but it rolled in while I was on vacation with my family, mostly unplugged. This is an attempt to reckon with some of the feelings I seem to have aroused.

headline: Valuing a News Corp. Breakup
text: On Wall Street, it’s called the “Murdoch discount.”

headline: A Novel Way to Clean Wastewater
text: Seven years ago, Paul Edmiston was working in his laboratory on a potential way to detect the presence of explosives. By accident, he created a material that acted as a powerful sponge that could absorb small organic compounds like gasoline, motor oil, and pesticides  dissolved in water.

headline: Pok Pok Ny
text: Inside Andy Ricker’s first sit-down restaurant in New York City.

headline: Digital Notes: Clear Channel Signs Rivals’ Stations to Its App
text: How does the biggest radio company in the country become bigger online? By inviting hundreds of competitors to join its aggregator app.

headline: Iran’s Vice President Makes Anti-Semitic Speech at Forum
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s vice president delivered a baldly anti-Semitic speech on Tuesday at an international antidrug conference here, saying that the Talmud, a central text of Judaism, was responsible for the spread of illegal drugs around the world.

headline: Roche to Shut Former U.S. Headquarters
text: Roche, the Swiss pharmaceutical company, said Tuesday that it would shut down its site in Nutley, N.J., which served as its American headquarters for 80 years, in an effort to cut costs. About 1,000 jobs would be lost, the company said.

headline: Thailand Extends to Brooklyn
text: AT first I didn’t notice the green chile paste at the center of the plate. I was in the backyard of a new Thai restaurant in Brooklyn called Pok Pok Ny (rhymes with “rock rock fly”), enjoying a deep communion with a grilled sausage that seemed to be everything anyone could want on a summer night. The sausage was rough-hewed and reddish, with little studs of melting pork fat and traces of galangal and white pepper that were flowery and spicy at the same time.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Dsquared2

headline: Wheelies: The Double-Image Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Even Baseball Becomes Entangled in Politics
text: BOSTON – A joke by President Obama in the heart of Red Sox Nation provoked punditry on Tuesday, as campaign aides and journalists took to Twitter to debate whether Mr. Obama had been booed by guests at a fund-raiser here on Monday night.

headline: Photo Replay: June 26
text: A view of the day in sports, with berths on the Olympic swimming team at stake in Omaha and Wimbledon hopes alive in England.

headline: A Mock Trial Over Genocide, Meant to Help Students Face History
text: On a recent Wednesday morning, at the Bronx Hall of Justice, Augustin Bizimungu, the former Rwandan army chief, was being grilled by a prosecutor over his role in the Rwandan genocide. Luckily for him, the stakes at this second trial were much lower than at his first. In fact, all that really hung in the balance was a grade, since the trial was being conducted by a class of sophomores from the Facing History School, a small high school in Manhattan that set up the mock trial to help students learn the importance of ethical decision-making.

headline: More Than 200 Buildings Gain Landmark Protection
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission closed its last meeting of the 2012 fiscal year with the addition of 190 buildings to the Riverside-West End Historic District on the Upper West Side, the designation of a new historic district in Crown Heights and the naming of three buildings in Lower Manhattan as landmarks.

headline: Ousted Head of University Is Reinstated in Virginia
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Facing a torrent of criticism, the University of Virginia trustees made a stunning turnabout on Tuesday, voting unanimously to reinstate the president they had forced to resign over concerns that the university was not adapting fast enough to financial and technological pressures.

headline: Lochte Won’t Compete in 100-Meter Backstroke at Olympics
text: OMAHA – Ryan Lochte finished third in the 100-meter backstroke at the 2008 United States Olympic trials, missing a berth on the Beijing-bound team by one place.

headline: She’s the Man of This Swamp
text: Hushpuppy, the 6-year-old heroine of “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” has a smile to charm fish out of the water and a scowl so fierce it can stop monsters in their tracks. The movie, a passionate and unruly explosion of Americana, directed by Benh Zeitlin, winks at skepticism, laughs at sober analysis and stares down criticism. Made on a shoestring by a resourceful New Orleans-based collective, it is animated by the same spirit of freedom it sets out to celebrate. If, as the Fourth of July approaches, you find yourself craving an antidote to anger and cynicism, a bracing reminder of the meaning of independence, and a helping of homegrown art to go with your hamburgers and watermelon, then this may be just what you need.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,007 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: The Hart of the Matter
text: And now for something completely different: I haven’t seen anyone point this out, but the very interesting Times story on why Microsoft is building its own tablet was a perfect illustration of Oliver Hart’s theory of the firm.

headline: Deleveraging, Monetary Policy, and Fiscal Policy: A Further Note
text: I wrote the other day about the nature of our depression, and how Very Serious People seem determined to block all useful responses — all in the name of sound policy, of course. While I’m at it, however, I realized that thinking about the depression this way may offer a better, or at least different, answer to the question that originally inspired both my Sam and Janet post and my work with Gauti Eggertsson: How can the answer to a crisis brought on by too much debt be more debt?

headline: Romanian Cultural Institute’s New Mandate Draws Protests in Europe and United States
text: Over the past five years or so, the Romanian Cultural Institute has become an important force in global cultural exchanges, promoting writers, artists and especially the critically acclaimed cinema movement known as the Romanian New Wave. But the coalition government that recently came to power in Romania has ordered an end to that international focus as it tightens its political control over the institute, actions that have set off protests among arts groups throughout Europe and the United States.

headline: On Facebook, the Semantics of Visibility vs. Privacy
text: When I called Facebook on Monday to ask why the company had changed the settings  for the display of people’s e-mail addresses without their permission, potentially violating users’ privacy, I was told that the swap was not a “privacy” change, but rather a “visibility setting” change.

headline: Love Lies in Carthage, but Duty Calls in Rome in Berlioz’s 5-Act Epic
text: LONDON — A lot was riding on the new production of Berlioz’s epic opera “Les Troyens” that opened at the Royal Opera, Covent Garden, on Monday night. This staging by the director David McVicar is a co-production with the Vienna State Opera, Teatro Alla Scala in Milan and the San Francisco Opera. The Royal Opera’s “Troyens” is also a major event in the London 2012 Festival, and it will be shown in movie theaters worldwide in November.

headline: She’s Caught Between a Hapless Prince and a Virile Sorcerer
text: “Swan Lake” is about transformations. The prologue of Kevin McKenzie’s version for American Ballet Theater that began a week of performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, has several. To enchant the princess Odette and change her into a swan, the evil sorcerer von Rothbart, who looks like Swamp Thing, takes on a more seductive, human form. Mr. McKenzie manages this transformation by casting two von Rothbarts.

headline: Impeccably Dressed, With His Violin at the Ready
text: The British violinist Charlie Siem, 25, has courted attention far beyond the standard classical music circles.

headline: A Filmmaker’s Life, Part 2, or Maybe One and a Half
text: From Cannes to sundancenow.com: Jonathan Caouette’s new documentary, “Walk Away Renee,” is following the still lightly traveled digital path to distribution.  First shown at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival, “Walk Away Renee” will be available beginning Wednesday at SundanceNOW, the independent film site, as a $6.99 rental (but free to the site’s subscribers). The online release coincides with the film’s North American theatrical premiere at the BAMcinemaFest at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: How a Cheetah Runs
text: Slow-motion video of a cheetah running.

headline: The Components of News Corp.
text: News Corp.’s publishing business is about 25 percent of its revenue

headline: Creating a ‘Hamlet,’ of Sorts, in Eastern Slovakia
text: “Gypsy,” a fictional portrait of an impoverished Roma settlement in eastern Slovakia, offers a mostly depressing picture of a marginalized Middle European culture living in squalor. The villagers dwell in filthy huts planted on a muddy hillside; their roofs are assemblages of junk, and there is no electricity, heat or running water.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Umit Benan
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Stoudemire Fined for Using Slur on Twitter
text: Amar’e Stoudemire was fined $50,000 by the N.B.A. on Tuesday for using a homophobic slur in response to a fan’s taunt on Twitter.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Florida and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Florida, Spain, Uganda and West Bank.

headline: The Mediterranean Sea, Singing Along in Italy
text: Paola Prestini has been at work on “Oceanic Verses,” a multimedia folk opera, since Carnegie Hall commissioned part of it for a composers’ and singers’ workshop in 2009. She presented a section of it at New York City Opera’s Vox readings last year, and offered the New York premiere of the finished piece on Monday evening at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University, as part of the adventurous River to River Festival.

headline: Three Dishes at Pok Pok Ny
text: Andy Ricker has been traveling to Thailand since 1987, and at some point he started to fall for the cuisine of the country’s north in a way that knocked his life and his career in new directions. Back home in Portland, Ore., he began grilling chickens stuffed with lemon grass in his driveway; customers would carry it over to his picnic table and sit down. This unconventional set-up evolved into Pok Pok, Mr. Ricker’s acclaimed Thai restaurant, which he has attempted to recreate on Columbia Street in south Brooklyn. That restaurant, Pok Pok Ny, is the subject of my restaurant review this week; a few days ago, I interviewed Mr. Ricker by phone to get some background on three of the restaurant’s best dishes.

headline: In Dimitrov, Winning Echoes of Federer
text: The rapidly improving Bulgarian Grigor Dimitrov, nicknamed Baby Fed by tennis observers, made a telling comment in his news conference after his upset win over 32nd-seeded Kevin Anderson. When asked about comparisons between his game and Roger Federer’s, Dimitrov, while acknowledging the “great compliment,” gave an honest assessment of his game: “I’ve not got to the second week of a Grand Slam yet and have not won an ATP event or reached the top 20 … I need to progress a lot and can’t cut any corners.”

headline: Euro 2012: ESPN Scores Big Ratings
text: Nearly three million people hunkered down last Sunday to watch on ESPN as Italy eliminated England in a penalty-kick shootout in a quarterfinal match in Kiev, Ukraine.

headline: Sotheby’s Contemporary Sale Makes $108 Million
text: LONDON — In a little over two hours on Tuesday night, Sotheby’s managed to sell $108 million worth of contemporary art, another testament to the breadth and depth of interest in works by well-known names like Basquiat, Bacon, Twombly and Warhol. The auction house had packed the sale with 79 paintings, sculptures, drawings and prints, mostly by artists who have brought top prices in recent seasons. But while the salesroom was filled with an international crowd of dealers and collectors, the evening could best be described as more solid than exciting.

headline: The Journal Fires an Intern Who It Says Made Up Quotes and Sources
text: The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday said it had fired an intern who it says fabricated sources and quotes just three weeks into the job.

headline: Looking Anew at the Business of Sherry
text: The depressed sherry industry needs to do a lot of things to help itself, as I’ve reported in my columns this week and last.

headline: Sherry Sidles Out of the Drawing Room
text: SANLÚCAR DE BARRAMEDA, Spain

headline: Live Nation Acquires Electronic Music Promoter
text: Big money is flowing into electronic dance music. In the latest example of corporate interest in this once-ignored market, Live Nation Entertainment said on Tuesday that it had acquired Hard Events, a Los Angeles company that has put on popular festivals and concerts across North America.

headline: A Quixotic Solution: The Test-Tube Burger
text: Four months ago, Mark Post, a professor of physiology at Maastricht University in the Netherlands, drew broad attention when he announced that he was close to producing a hamburger without a cow at his laboratory at a cost of about $330,000.

headline: The Old and Uneducated Watch the Most TV
text: Older Americans and high school dropouts spend the most time watching TV, according to new Labor Department data.

headline: Senator McCaskill to Skip Democratic Convention
text: One would think that a nominating convention is a command performance for prominent members of a president’s party.

headline: Money Market Industry’s Resistance May Hurt Companies
text: Money market funds are what investors use to earn a few tenths of a percentage point of interest.

headline: Representative Rangel Votes
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel spoke to reporters Tuesday after he voted at Public School 175 in Harlem.

headline: Boston Properties Sticks to Its Formula
text: When Boston Properties, a real estate investment trust that focuses on prime office buildings in five markets in the United States, said recently that it had abandoned efforts — at least for now — to make its first foray into the London market, many Wall Street analysts were relieved.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ and ‘Memphis’ Closing
text: Another major Broadway musical is closing in what is shaping up to be a summer of housecleaning at New York theaters. “Memphis,” which won the Tony Award for best musical in 2010, will close at the Shubert Theater on Aug. 5 after 30 previews and 1,166 performances, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday. The musical will have had a fairly long run by today’s standards, but ticket sales have been uneven, with the show grossing a relatively modest $541,602 last week (or 44 percent of the maximum possible amount). Separately on Tuesday, a spokeswoman for the Broadway revival of “Jesus Christ Superstar” confirmed that that show would close on Sunday after a run of 24 previews and 116 performances. The musical opened in March to mixed reviews and never caught on at the box office.

headline: Columbia Unveils Med School Building
text: The architecture firm Diller Scofidio & Renfro has designed a 14-story tower of study and social spaces that will be Columbia University Medical Center’s new medical and graduate education building in Washington Heights. The design, to be released on Wednesday, is unorthodox for a medical school not only in its verticality and sculptural treatment of exposed interiors but also, according to the architects, in its reflection of a more collaborative, team-based mode of teaching. Gensler is the architectural firm of record for the building, working with the Diller team on technical aspects of the project, including construction documents. Construction — to begin in early 2013 and take about three and a half years — will be supported by a previously announced lead gift of $50 million from Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, an alumnus of Columbia’s medical school, and his wife, Diana Vagelos. The design incorporates an auditorium; event areas; student lounges; cafes; and outdoor spaces, including a terrace with views of the Hudson River. The building is to be the central hub for the students pursuing medical and doctoral degrees at Columbia’s College of Physicians and Surgeons and will also serve Columbia’s three other medical schools and the biomedical departments of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

headline: In Mongolia, a New, Penned-In Wealth
text: TAVAN TOLGOI, Mongolia — “All you need to mine here is a shovel,” said an awe-struck Indian investment manager as he stood behind a barrier, along with dozens of international mining industry executives and other eager investors, gazing at the immense coal pit gouged out of the rust-colored earth below.

headline: Developer in Chelsea Honors a Great Architect While Redesigning His Work
text: The legacy of Ralph Walker, the great 20th-century architect whose Art Deco towers brought muscle to the New York skyline, is having a very mixed year.

headline: In Mongolia, Mineral Wealth and a Geopolitical Quandary
text: Mongolia’s mineral deposits should make it rich, but the landlocked country knows that prosperity depends on its neighbors.

headline: Reconciling History and Hope at 3M’s Old Home
text: ST. PAUL — The squat, unassuming building at 900 Bush Avenue here seems an unlikely centerpiece for a battle between the St. Paul Port Authority and neighborhood preservationists. The two-story structure is dwarfed by a former factory across the street, and the only hints of its significance are brass letters above the door that proclaim Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, today known as 3M.

headline: Tara I. Stacom
text: Ms. Stacom, 53, is a vice chairwoman of the commercial real estate brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield, providing both tenant representation and landlord leasing services to a wide array of prominent clients.

headline: ‘Memphis’ and ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Announce Broadway Closing Dates
text: Another major Broadway musical is closing in what is shaping up to be a summer of house-cleaning at New York theaters. “Memphis,” which won the Tony Award for best musical in 2010, will close at the Shubert Theater on Aug. 5 after 30 previews and 1,166 performances, the show’s producers announced on Tuesday.

headline: Across the Country, the Menu Expands
text: THERE are times it seems as if progress in America’s food landscape is measured in the tiniest increments and among the tiniest part of the population. But after a recent cross-country trip, I can share three encouraging observations.

headline: Immigration Policy Offers Relief for Students Facing Deportation
text: Monday’s Supreme Court ruling on Arizona’s immigration law reminded us of President Obama’s recent executive action that allowed hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants to remain in the United States if they came as children. Many of these young men and women are currently attending college in the country.

headline: Live Coverage Wednesday of Spain-Portugal
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 semifinal game between Portugal and Spain on Wednesday at 2:30 p.m. ET. Duncan Irving will offer commentary and analysis of the match.

text: Benefits

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Apple Stores and Smartphone Stupidity
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Tuesday. See more here.

headline: College Football Playoff Approved for 2014 Season
text: WASHINGTON — The university presidents stood on a stage in a hotel ballroom Tuesday, smiling and satisfied that the college football playoff system the nation had clamored for had been agreed upon in three hours.

headline: On 38th Birthday, Jeter Prepares for Just Another Day at the Park
text: Around 3:30 p.m. Tuesday, two Yankee Stadium kitchen employees walked through the tunnel pushing a cart with a birthday cake on it almost the size of the jersey it was designed to replicate.

text: Opening

headline: What Would Get More New Yorkers to Vote?
text: Can anything be done to raise voter interest in elections and get more New Yorkers to the polls?

headline: Senate Panel Backs Punishing Russians on Human Rights Violations
text: Senators of both parties rebuffed President Obama and advanced legislation on Tuesday intended to punish Russian human rights violators despite concern by the White House that it would further complicate already souring relations with Moscow.

headline: Sudan Deports Egyptian Journalist and Detains Bloggers as Protests Continue
text: Updated | Wednesday, 7:18 a.m. CAIRO — Sudan deported an Egyptian journalist and briefly detained another prominent blogger on Tuesday, as the authorities attempted to stifle a protest movement that started last week. The demonstration came after President Omar Hassan al-Bashir announced spending cuts and austerity measures, like reducing fuel subsidies and raising taxes.

headline: An iPhone Case Fit for a Flounder
text: While quite a few cases protect an iPhone from the elements, and some are even submersible, DriSuit Technologies claims that its Endurance case is the only one that lets you use the phone’s touch screen underwater.

headline: Q&A: Using Dropbox to Move E-Books Between Computer and iPad
text: Q.

headline: Learning About Life on Mars, via a Detour to Mexico
text: CUATRO CIÉNEGAS, Mexico — Studying Mars usually involves tilting one’s head up toward the heavens, but not here in the Chihuahuan Desert, where the vast, scorching plain is so inhospitable — and so Mars-like — that scientists seeking insight into that distant planet look down at their feet.

headline: Spain’s Midfield Enchanter Stands Out by Fitting In
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Euro 2012 has reached the semifinals, and few would be surprised Wednesday if the Spain-Portugal match was decided by a pass or a goal from Andrés Iniesta, the little man of big moments.

headline: There’s Less of Anthony
text: A motivated, sleeker Carmelo Anthony said Tuesday that he had lost 12 pounds since the end of the Knicks’ season.

headline: A Graduation and a Dream for Young Illegal Immigrants
text: With caps, gowns and a message for lawmakers, more than 350 young illegal immigrants from 13 states gathered in a District of Columbia church Tuesday for a “graduation ceremony,” to urge the passing of the Dream Act and to recognize young people whose prospects were stunted because their families entered this country illegally.

headline: Lineup Heavy on Lefties Searches for Its Swing Against Left-Handed Pitchers
text: CHICAGO — Manager Terry Collins has shown supreme patience with his group of young and inexperienced players, coaxing from them a surprisingly successful campaign during the first half of the season.

headline: Galleon Official Is Spared Prison
text: Adam Smith, a former portfolio manager at the Galleon Group hedge fund who provided the government with crucial assistance in prosecuting his onetime boss, Raj Rajaratnam, avoided prison on Tuesday when a judge sentenced him to two years’ probation.

headline: F.D.A. Hearing to Focus on Replacement Hips
text: The Food and Drug Administration will start a two-day hearing on Wednesday meant to help doctors find ways to better monitor the risks posed by all-metal replacement hips.

headline: Church Abuse Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: Madison Square Garden Buys the Forum in Los Angeles
text: Madison Square Garden now has a cousin in Los Angeles.

headline: Teacher Layoffs
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Wimbledon, Serena Upholds Williams Brand
text: WIMBLEDON, England — All the emotions produced by her shocking defeat in Paris four weeks ago — disappointment, stress, motivation — were released by Serena Williams in one cathartic outburst Tuesday afternoon, after a first-round victory that stemmed the tide of on-court misfortune plaguing her and her sister.

headline: Court Rulings on Hot-Button Issues
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nora Ephron Dies at 71; Writer and Filmmaker With a Genius for Humor
text: Nora Ephron, an essayist and humorist in the Dorothy Parker mold (only smarter and funnier, some said) who became one of her era’s most successful screenwriters and filmmakers, making romantic comedy hits like “Sleepless in Seattle” and “When Harry Met Sally...,” died on Tuesday night in Manhattan. She was 71.

headline: George R. Hearst Jr., Leader of Publishing Giant, Dies at 84
text: George R. Hearst Jr., chairman of the Hearst Corporation and the oldest grandson of the media titan William Randolph Hearst, died on Monday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84.

headline: A Pinup Who Eats His Vegetables
text: VEGETARIANS and gay men come in all sizes and types. Zachary Koval, who happens to be both, comes in what you would call the chiseled gladiator package.

headline: Which Diet Works?
text: One of the challenges of arguing that hyperprocessed carbohydrates are largely responsible for the obesity pandemic (“epidemic” is no longer a strong enough word, say many experts) is the notion that “a calorie is a calorie.”

headline: The World Koran-Reciting Competition in Tehran
text: What one participant called the “Olympic Games of Koran recital,” the Iran International Koran competition, took place in Tehran last week.

headline: Before a Full House in Iran, Koran Reciters Vie for Top Honors
text: TEHRAN — On the long journey from Kampala to Tehran, 15-year-old Hamissi Mawejje had plenty of time to spend with his iPod. The plugs pushed into his ears, which emerged from under his red fez, Mr. Mawejje whispered along with his favorites. Rather than rap or dubstep, however, his interest ran more to the star chanters — some long dead — of the Koran.

headline: Rethinking Gay Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Faulting a Plan to Replace the Scorned Tappan Zee
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — It was unloved from the start, built on the cheap, located improbably at the broadest stretch of the Hudson River, its improvised design derided by its own engineers as “one of the ugliest bridges in the East.”

headline: Public Exchanges Duel With Newcomers Over Trade Transparency
text: While most people trading stocks at home imagine their orders zipping from their brokers onto one of the nation’s stock exchanges, almost none of the trades go anywhere near those public markets.

headline: At Fireworks, Not All Seats Are Created Equal
text: They are an expression of democracy, liberty and equality, a pyrotechnic celebration of the ideals on which the United States was founded. But this year’s Fourth of July fireworks on the Hudson River will offer a new tier of premier viewing — a V.I.P. section in Hudson River Park where spaces will go for $200 a pop.

headline: In Iowa, Biden Assails Romney for Swiss Bank Account
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday joined President Obama in decrying Mitt Romney’s investment record at Bain Capital, but Mr. Romney’s past Swiss bank account seems to be gaining favor as Democrats’ metaphor for depicting the Republican candidate as out of touch with average Americans.

headline: From Sharp Edges to Sugary Success and Back
text: When Nora Ephron wrote about her early aspiration to be the only lady at the table, the sharpest wit in the room, she called this her “Dorothy Parker problem.” The problem was that many other young writers saw Dorothy Parker as their role model, too.

headline: Two Lawsuits Challenge the Lack of Air-Conditioning in Texas Prisons
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In the brutal heat of summer, many Texans flee to shopping malls, movie theaters and other air-conditioned havens to keep cool. But for one segment of the population, there is literally no escape from triple-digit temperatures: state prison inmates.

headline: Nora Ephron
text: Ms. Ephron, an essayist and humorist, told love stories to generations of moviegoers with hit films such as “Sleepless in Seattle” and “When Harry Met Sally...”

headline: Live-Blogging the Primary: In the End, No Upsets
text: Check out our New York primary page for complete results from Tuesday’s contests. And read the overview of all of the day’s developments that ran in Wednesday’s paper.

headline: To Save the Euro, Leave It
text: Chicago

headline: Michael J. Dontzin, Counsel to New York Mayor in ’70s, Dies at 89
text: Michael J. Dontzin, who as counsel to Mayor John V. Lindsay in the early 1970s helped deal with uprisings in New York City’s jails and who later served as a State Supreme Court justice, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Columbia University Unveils an Unorthodox Med School Building
text: The architecture firm Diller Scofidio + Renfro has designed a 14-story tower of study and social spaces for Columbia University Medical Center’s new medical and graduate education building in Washington Heights.

headline: Swedes Find Stolen Atlas in New York
text: He was entrusted to guard Sweden’s cultural heritage, but instead this senior librarian spent years surreptitiously stealing and selling scores of its rare and precious books. When the thief, Anders Burius, was finally caught in 2004, the media called him the “Royal Library Man,” and his sensational crime and subsequent suicide became the subjects of a government inquiry, a radio documentary and, last year, a television mini-series.

headline: Help for the Gooey-Fingered
text: SINCE tablet computers came on the market, there has been the kitchen equivalent of the space race: competition to develop technology that can keep a cook’s sticky, floury hands off the touch-screen. With its new app, the e-commerce site Gilt Groupe appears to have combined appealing recipes with a touchless interface that really works.

headline: How to Stop Traffic
text: THE dream of bringing Manhattan traffic flow to a total standstill draws nearer every day, and if everybody does his part, these new regulations will speed its realization.

headline: Democrats Feel Pressure From Gun Lobby on Contempt Vote
text: WASHINGTON — The National Rifle Association has joined a Republican push to make Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. the first sitting cabinet member to be held in contempt of Congress, turning a once obscure fight over a gun-smuggling investigation into a proxy war over gun control.

headline: Vollmer Leaves Disappointment and Rivals Behind in the 100 Butterfly
text: OMAHA — The United States Olympic swimming trials are like a Fiona Apple album: an emotional roller coaster with soaring arrangements that drown out the melancholic stories. Few swimmers are more conversant with the meet’s range of highs and lows than Dana Vollmer, a preteen prodigy in 2000, a surprise Olympian in 2004, a washout in 2008 and a star in 2012.

headline: Savannah Guthrie Is Said to Be Offered Role as Co-Host of ‘Today’
text: NBC News officials are in negotiations to have Savannah Guthrie, a relatively new face at the “Today” show, replace Ann Curry as the show’s co-host.

headline: Children in Prison for Life
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling this week prohibiting mandatory sentences of life without parole for juveniles convicted of murder is a measured and important step in a trend in juvenile justice begun more than two decades ago. The court left open the possibility that minors under age 18 could be sentenced to life without parole — but only if the sentencing judge has made an individualized finding that such a penalty is appropriate, weighing the defendant’s characteristics and the details of the crime.

headline: Rude or Polite, City’s Officers Leave Raw Feelings in Stops
text: Most of the time, the officers swoop in, hornetlike, with a command to stop: “Yo! You, come here. Get against the wall.”

headline: Time for Bankers to Intervene
text: Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, have both argued correctly that the slowing global economy requires decisive action by political leaders.

headline: The Old Neighborhood
text: If you’ve lived for long in New York City, chances are you’ve lived in several different places. On the map of where we dwell now is also where we used to dwell, just across the park, a borough away, a few subway stops farther north or south. That is one of the peculiarities of this city — the proximity of our geographical past. Some people move from Ohio to Oregon. We move from 93rd to 13th, from Alphabet City to Carroll Gardens, all over town.

headline: Best Buy Founder Is Said to Consider a Takeover Bid
text: Richard Schulze, the founder of Best Buy, is exploring putting together a bid to take the struggling electronics retailer private, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Spanish Officials Hailed Banks as Crisis Built
text: As Spain edged closer to a real estate and banking crisis that led to its recent bank bailout, Spanish financial leaders in influential positions mostly played down concerns that something might go terribly wrong.

headline: Obama Calls Romney Possible ‘Outsourcer in Chief’
text: ATLANTA — President Obama escalated his campaign’s latest line of attack on Mitt Romney’s business career on Tuesday, telling audiences at a series of fund-raising events that when it came to job creation, the former Massachusetts governor excelled more at creating them overseas than in America.

headline: At News Corp., a Plan to Sever Publishing Arm
text: After years of defending its financially underperforming newspapers, News Corporation is now in talks to break up the company and sever its publishing assets, like The Wall Street Journal, The Times of London and The New York Post, from its lucrative entertainment units.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Teenage Prospect Goes From Big Sky to Big Skyline
text: Once, Brandon Nimmo would have been content riding bulls for the rest of his days, up on a 6,000-foot plateau where the wind rarely died and the Rocky Mountains are always visible. Under a clear sky so big that on some days Nimmo could see across the plains for 40 miles in any direction from his home outside Cheyenne, Wyo.

headline: German Ruling Against Circumcising Boys Draws Criticism
text: BERLIN — A German court in Cologne ruled on Tuesday that circumcising young boys represents grievous bodily harm, a decision that could have significant repercussions for religious groups.

headline: At Stuyvesant, Allegations of Widespread Cheating
text: Administrators at Stuyvesant High School, in Lower Manhattan, are investigating an apparent case of cheating that may have involved more than 80 students communicating about exams via text message, students said, offering a glimpse of what some called a pervasive cheating problem at one of New York City’s most prestigious public schools.

headline: Immigration Ruling Leaves Issues Unresolved
text: The Supreme Court’s mixed decision on Arizona’s tough immigration enforcement law has laid the ground for years of legal and political wrangling in many states over racial profiling and civil rights, making it likely that the court will be asked to revisit immigration.

headline: The Fear Factor
text: If there is one thought that summarizes the strength and weakness of the Arab awakenings, it’s the one offered by Daniel Brumberg, a co-director of the democracy and governance studies program at Georgetown University, who observed that the Arab awakenings happened because the Arab peoples stopped fearing their leaders — but they stalled because the Arab peoples have not stopped fearing each other.

headline: Tropical Storm Debby Makes Landfall, Then Weakens
text: After four days of drenching rain, causing historic flooding in parts of Florida, Tropical Storm Debby made landfall near Steinhatchee along the northwest coast about 5 p.m., according to the National Hurricane Center.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Be Poised to Sue Fund Manager
text: His wireless dreams all but dashed, billions of dollars lost and investors swearing him off, Philip A. Falcone has been a colorful exhibit of how quickly fortunes can turn in the hedge fund world.

headline: Off-Exchange Stock Trades Are Rising
text: More stock trades are being executed away from regulated exchanges.

headline: Cyprus to Take Over European Presidency
text: NICOSIA, Cyprus — When the Republic of Cyprus takes over the European Union’s rotating presidency on Sunday, it will have one qualification that could help endear it to the crisis-weary bloc and its 495 million citizens: it, too, is nearly broke.

headline: Appeals Court Calls a Stop-and-Frisk Illegal
text: A state appellate court ruled on Tuesday that a New York City police officer who found a concealed handgun on a 14-year-old in the Bronx during a stop-and-frisk encounter in 2010 did not have sufficient cause to search him, and reversed his conviction.

headline: Nordstrom Said to Sign Deal for Site in Manhattan
text: After spending the past two decades scouring Manhattan for the right location and the right deal, Nordstrom, the upscale department store, has finally found a home.

headline: A Flashpoint on Turkey’s Border
text: Turkey showed prudent restraint after one of its fighter jets was shot down by Syria on Friday. But the incident is a reminder of how easily Syria’s bloody civil war could spill over their common border, and it lends greater urgency to United Nations and Western efforts to end that conflict.

headline: Sentencing Ruling Reflects Rethinking on Juvenile Justice
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling on Monday barring mandatory life sentences for juveniles convicted of murder was the sharpest indication to date of a shift in how the American judicial system views young felons — from irredeemable predators to victims of circumstance with a potential for rehabilitation.

headline: Latest Poll Shows Obama and Romney in Dead Heat
text: The contest between President Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, remains close according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll.

headline: European Union Prods Germany With Fiscal Plan
text: PARIS — European leaders increased the pressure on Germany to move more aggressively to defend the euro on Tuesday by publishing proposals for a more tightly knit European Union, with phased-in moves toward central banking supervision, unified deposit insurance and more sharing of the region’s debt burden.

headline: Cargo, the Terrorists’ Trojan Horse

headline: Egypt Court Strikes a Decree Reimposing Martial Law
text: CAIRO — An administrative court on Tuesday suspended a decree by the military-led government that authorized soldiers to arrest civilians. The court’s action raised the possibility that the judges may also try to roll back other aspects of the generals’ recent expansion of their powers.

text: As the pop fly faded into foul territory, Dewayne Wise braced himself for a leap of faith. He stuck his black Rawlings 12 ¾-inch glove into the air and plunged over the left-field railing into Section 129. He closed his eyes.

headline: A.N.C., Admitting Failures, Weighs How to Lift South Africans
text: JOHANNESBURG — During apartheid, in the coastal municipality of Overstrand, just east of Cape Town, whites lived in plush, seaside enclaves whereas blacks and mixed race people lived in ugly townships and shacks. Whites owned almost all the businesses, and had access to the best jobs, health care and schools.

headline: In Rizzo, Cubs Hope They Have a Player to Build Around

The Cubs are a major league-worst 25-48, taking their lumps as Theo Epstein’s new regime promises a future of “sustained success.” Tuesday, though, the cloud of despair was lifted — at least for one day — to reveal, perhaps, a hint of that future.

headline: DuPont Says Claims Over Herbicide Are Rising
text: DuPont, which introduced a herbicide last year that was later linked to the deaths of  thousands of trees, has begun processing claims for compensation that are running into the hundreds of millions of dollars, company officials said.

headline: In the Women’s 100 Backstroke, a Record Is Set and Quickly Eclipsed
text: OMAHA — In the first semifinal heat of the women’s 100-meter backstroke, Rachel Bootsma, 18, set a girls’ 17-18 national age-group record of 59.10 seconds. It lasted less than five minutes. In the next heat, the 17-year-old Missy Franklin swam a 59.06.

headline: Inquiry Looks Into a Shield for Donors in Elections
text: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York has begun investigating contributions to tax-exempt groups that are heavily involved in political campaigns, focusing on a case involving the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, which has been one of the largest outside groups seeking to influence recent elections but is not required to disclose its donors.

headline: Investigation Finds No Violations by Nuclear Head
text: A report by the inspector general of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, released Tuesday, has found that the commission’s chairman did not exceed his authority in directing his agency’s response to the Fukushima Daiichi meltdown last year in Japan, despite his colleagues’ complaints over his management. The chairman, Gregory B. Jaczko, has said he will resign as soon as a successor is sworn in, probably next week. The inspector general has investigated a variety of actions, but the new report does not find any clear violations. It said Dr. Jaczko had broken with past practice by seeking to change the recommendations of the commission staff, and that he limited staff communications with the other four commissioners in a way that “was inconsistent with the commissioners’ expectations.” His behavior was “not supportive of an open and collaborative work environment,” the report said. Dr. Jaczko denied any wrongdoing.

headline: Rangel Fends Off Challengers to Win a Congressional Primary
text: Surviving one of the toughest re-election fights of his career, Representative Charles B. Rangel fended off four challengers on Tuesday to win the Democratic nomination for a 22nd term in Congress.

headline: Following Her Fiancé’s Lead

headline: The Liberal Embrace of Judicial Restraint
text: It’s a great pleasure, in this week when the entire political world is hanging on the Supreme Court’s health care ruling, to welcome so many liberals to a cause dear to my heart: The crusade for judicial restraint.

headline: What Fresh Puzzle is This?

headline: What Runners Can Learn From Cheetahs
text: Back in the 1960s, researchers in Africa clocked the wild cheetah as it ran and determined that at full gallop, a cheetah reached a top speed of about 65 miles per hour, making it easily the world’s fastest land mammal. No other quadruped or biped comes close. Galloping quarter horses top out around 47 miles per hour, while sluggish humans, in the person of the world record 100-meter sprinter Usain Bolt, have attained a top speed of less than 28 miles per hour. Even the bullet-trainlike greyhound, similar in build and running style to the cheetah, doesn’t surpass 40 miles per hour.

headline: 130 Rescued After Shipwreck South of Indonesia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australian officials said Wednesday that 130 survivors, most of them reported to be women and children, had been rescued after a ship apparently full of asylum seekers trying to reach Australia capsized in the Indian Ocean.

headline: In London, Dance, Collaboration and Public Art in One
text: The Dance We Made brings dance to the public in wonderful, new ways. This interactive pop-up dance project invites people to choreograph for the professional dancer Tim Casson, a member of the Jasmin Vardimon Company who teaches regularly at Sadler’s Wells and other major companies. His performances of their dances are filmed and posted online and on mobile for sharing. Part of London 2012 Cultural Olympiad’s Big Dance program, the event allows anyone to get involved – no dance or choreographic experience required.

text: If the euro were to dissolve, Germany’s exchange rate would most likely increase, lessening its relative advantage for exports.

headline: New Survey Finds U.S. Concerns Over a Rising China

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Last Tour as a Rock-Star Diplomat
text: On May 3, the day after an artful deal to end the diplomatic crisis over Chen Guangcheng, China’s now-famous dissident, unraveled spectacularly, Hillary Rodham Clinton followed a scrum of Chinese ministers around an exhibition of clean cookstoves. These are safer, portable alternatives to the crude stoves used by hundreds of millions of women in the developing world — at grave risk to themselves, their children and the planet. Not long after becoming secretary of state in 2009, Clinton took up the cookstove cause, one of what she describes as “smart power” issues — though skeptical veterans of American foreign policy tend to deride them as soft more than smart.

headline: Piling in a Flatbed to Get By in the Suburbs
text: A bridge is situated on a highway that goes from the Mexican city of Nuevo Laredo — across the United States border in Laredo, Tex. — due south to Monterrey. headline: Clasping Hands, Ex-Guerrilla and Queen Briefly Bridge a Divide
text: LONDON — She wore bright green; he was somber-suited. Between them lay a gulf of history that had been beyond bridging, defined by faith and nation, hatred and loss, war and, only more recently, redemption.

headline: Grading Banks on Their Small-Business Lending
text: On any given day at MultiFunding, I talk with a dozen or so bankers. As we work together to close loans, they demand precise information as they try to reach lending decisions. After all, precise information is what banking is all about.

headline: Stone Links: A Constellation of Philosophers
text: Here is an intriguing map of philosophical space at the statistics blog Drunks and Lampposts, drawn in terms of the field’s leading lights. The map looks much like a chart of the heavens, but lines of influence are what define the size and position of each node. The raw data was culled from the “influenced by” section for the pages of all the philosophers listed in Wikipedia — using an algorithm. The images are startling, and the map does seem to give many of the big thinkers what seems to be intuitively the right size and location (though one does notice Descartes’ “star” must be too small relative to his influence). But it is unclear how effective the algorithm is at saying something meaningful about the history of philosophy and, correlatively, the history of ideas. One also wonders what a similar map drawing on the data in, say, The Stanford Encylopedia of Philosophy, would look like.

headline: Glencore’s $24 Billion Deal for Xstrata Under Threat
text: LONDON – Glencore International’s $24 billion deal with Xstrata is under threat after Qatar Holding asked Glencore to increase its bid amid mounting opposition to executive pay arrangements.

headline: Wednesday Reading: A $100 Weekend in Oslo, Norway
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: The Trouble With Limits on Broadband
text: The broadband era began with the expectation that Internet connections were like all-you-can-eat buffets. But as Brian Stelter reports in Wednesday’s New York Times, people are now being prodded to think about how much they’re consuming. In South Texas, Time Warner Cable customers have been given the online equivalent of a scale in the bathroom: a “usage tracker.” Customers who sign up for a light plan of 5 gigabytes of broadband are rewarded with a $5 discount each month if they don’t go over. If they do, they pay $1 for every additional gigabyte.

headline: Airbnb ‘Wish Lists’ Are a Highlight of New Site Design
text: If you have ever tried to look at multiple listings on Airbnb, the short-term rental Web site, the confusing site design likely forced you to open a dozen or so tabs in your browser.

text: A new Quinnipiac University Swing State Poll of three battleground states shows President Obama ahead of Mitt Romney by nine points in Ohio and six points in Pennsylvania, while his four-point edge in Florida is within the survey’s margin of sampling error.

text: If you think about it in a certain light – although you probably try not to – the ocean is gross. It has the unfortunate role of being at the end of most of our drains for all kinds of waste washed from the land.

text: To the agony of scheduling activities for your children this summer, add the cost: according to a survey of American families from the American Express Spending and Saving Tracker, the average per-child cost of summer fun (which can also mean child care) is $601. Affluent families (defined as those with a minimum household income of $100,000) will spend nearly double that: $1,116.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Serious Eats: A tribute to the late Nora Ephron (right), both a greatly gifted storyteller and a lover of food. — Jeff GordinierThe New York Times: Marcus Samuelsson recounts his astonishing rise, from poverty in Ethiopia to an orphanage in Sweden to international acclaim in Manhattan — grappling with racism all along the way. “A hundred years ago,” he writes in “Yes, Chef,” his new memoir, “black men and women had to fight to get out of the kitchen. These days, we have to fight to get in.” …

Because really: for all the courage and daring and confidence it took for Andrea Pirlo to pull one off against England’s Joe Hart on Sunday, it would take twice as much — five times, 10 times as much — for a player to try another less than a week later.

headline: Werewolves, Vampires, Shrinks and Other Terrors: Glen Duncan Talks About ‘Talulla Rising’
text: Glen Duncan’s novel “The Last Werewolf” was narrated by a 200-year-old man/wolf named Jake Marlowe. Jake’s creepy condition forced him to eat a human being every month or perish, but otherwise he was a charming fellow. In The New York Times Book Review, Justin Cronin said the book “plays out in splendid good fun, bouncing from one James Bondian locale to another, bon mot to bon mot, the text saturated with literary and cultural references.” Mr. Duncan’s new book is a sequel, “Talulla Rising,” about a female werewolf desperate to rescue her newborn son from a pack of vampires. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Duncan discussed his relationship to the paranormal, the appeal of unsympathetic characters and why psychotherapy is not for him. Below are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: London Theater Journal: A ‘Henry V’ That Doesn’t Take Sides
text: The skies opened over Agincourt on Sunday, just as the British were declaring their miraculous victory over the French. It had rained during the siege of Harfleur, too. The sun showed up now and then, to smile upon tavern-crawling lowlifes like Pistol and Nym, and on a French princess’s English lesson and on a few random executions of traitors. But for the final peace treaty, which you would have thought would have glowed with celestial gold, it was cloudy again and threatening to spit.

headline: India Says Pakistan Supported Planner of Mumbai Attacks
text: India’s home minister on Wednesday accused Pakistan of supporting the masterminds of the 2008 Mumbai attacks, citing information provided by Abu Jindal, an Indian national who is suspected of being one of the planners.

headline: Eve Ensler’s ‘Emotional Creature’ To Open Off-Broadway
text: “Emotional Creature,” a new play by Eve Ensler (“The Vagina Monologues”) about the inner lives of girls across the world, will have its Off Broadway premiere this fall at Signature Center, the show’s producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Facebook Plans to Speed Up its iPhone App
text: Facebook’s iPhone app is slow. Often painfully slow.

headline: Alternatives to the Mandate
text: The Supreme Court is expected to decide imminently on the constitutionality of the health care act. Many people, ordinary citizens and legal experts, think it will strike down the mandate that all Americans buy health insurance.

headline: Ancient Marble-Paved Road Discovered in Greece
text: A 230-foot section of a road built by the Romans nearly 2,000 years ago has been discovered by archaeologists in Thessaloniki, Greece’s second-largest city, during excavations for a new subway system, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Buffett Joins Bon Jovi in a Song for Charity
text: Warren E. Buffett appears to be building a side career as a musician.

headline: The Things Traders Say
text: How do traders talk?

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Picks Design Team to Help With Its Expansion
text: Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the architectural firm responsible for the redevelopment of Lincoln Center and the city’s High Line, has been chosen to design the gallery and visitor experience at the remodeled Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum on the Upper East Side. Local Projects, a design firm, will also be part of the team and responsible for the museum’s digital offerings. The renovations of the museum’s Carnegie Mansion are part of a $64-million capital campaign. “This project gives Cooper-Hewitt the opportunity to re-invent itself, to rethink museum conventions and the entire museum ‘visit,’” said Caroline Baumann, associate director of the museum. “We’re delighted to be working with DS+R and Local Projects in creating a distinctly contemporary vision that will serve as a model for a new type of museum.” While the renovations are underway, Cooper-Hewitt, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution, is offering exhibitions and educational programs at the Cooper-Hewitt Design Center in Harlem, the Enid and Lester Morse Historic Design Lecture Series at the University Club, and elsewhere. The museum on East 91st Street at Fifth Avenue is scheduled to re-open in 2014.

headline: Challenging the Long-Held Belief in ‘Shareholder Value’
text: It’s a bedrock principle of our era: Companies should be run for the sole purpose of increasing their stock prices, or returning “value” to shareholders, the ultimate “owners.”

headline: Details of Health Care Ruling Could Be Lost on Public
text: As The New Republic’s Jonathan Cohn notes, the Supreme Court has a wide menu of options for what it might do with President Obama’s health care bill, upon which it is expected to rule on Thursday.

headline: Image of the Day: June 27
text: A newlywed’s protest against the lack of toilets in her marital home in Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Super-Dreams of an Alternate World Order
text: EVILDOERS, beware! You cannot hide from the modern-day superhero! And neither can anyone else heading to the movies this summer. “Marvel’s The Avengers” which opened on May 4, reached $300 million in domestic ticket revenue faster than any other movie in history and tied the record for fastest $1 billion worldwide gross. On Tuesday, Sony will unleash the newest version of another venerable Marvel property, “The Amazing Spider-Man,” followed later in the month by “The Dark Knight Rises,” a Warner Brothers release and the third (and possibly the last) of Christopher Nolan’s Batman movies. The summer of 2012 is hardly unusual. The current superhero boom dates to the dawn of the century — Bryan Singer’s “X-Men” came out in 2000, Sam Raimi’s “Spider-Man” in 2002 — and shows no sign of abating. The New York Times’s chief movie critics, A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, ponder the meaning of an apparently invincible genre.

headline: University of Virginia President Is Reinstated After Unanimous Vote
text: The University of Virginia’s board of trustees voted unanimously on Tuesday to reinstate president Teresa A. Sullivan, whom they had forced to resign 16 days earlier. The board had originally charged that Ms. Sullivan was not handling the escalating financial and technological pressures facing colleges rapidly enough.

headline: Sabathia Is on Disabled List
text: If it were September or October, C.C. Sabathia might make his next two starts, but it was a Wednesday in June, the All-Star break less than two weeks away, so the Yankees practiced restraint and precaution and placed their ace on the 15-day disabled list.

headline: Fighting for Nightfall
text: On the morning of June 27, 1862, the Union’s Fifth Army Corps retreated south from the hamlet of Mechanicsville, Va., and set up defensive positions near a mill owned by a local planter named Gaines. Rather than securing the rest they badly needed, the exhausted soldiers of Col. Elisha G. Marshall’s 13th New York Infantry began building breastworks. An overwhelming Confederate force was in pursuit, and Marshall’s troops steeled themselves for a delaying action that would allow the rest of the Army of the Potomac to escape.

headline: Thousands Flee Colorado Springs Area as Winds Fuel Wildfire
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — With wind and heat giving it new strength, the furious wildfire that has been burning in the foothills around Colorado’s second-largest city doubled in size by Wednesday, first roaring past containment lines and forcing tens of thousands of residents to flee, chased by billowing smoke, blowing ash and the fear that their homes might be burned to the ground.

headline: Nora Ephron Never Forgot the Food
text: The writer Nora Ephron, who died Tuesday night, wore many hats, all of them jauntily. She was a screenwriter, feminist, journalist, humorist and passionate (but absolutely unsnobbish) foodie, long before the term existed. Even when she wore those other hats and became a Big Hollywood Screenwriter, for food lovers, she was always one of us, endlessly entertained by restaurants, cooking, cookbooks, the whole crazy salad of foodie life.

headline: Head of T-Mobile USA Resigns
text: Philipp Humm, chief executive of T-Mobile USA, has resigned from his position, Deutsche Telekom, the company that owns the carrier, said on Wednesday. The company said he planned to pursue a new career and spend more time with his family in Europe.

headline: Syria Talks Won’t Include the Saudis or Iranians
text: GENEVA — Kofi Annan, the special Syria representative from the United Nations and the Arab League whose paralyzed peace plan is in danger of collapse, announced in a statement on Wednesday that he was convening an “action group” meeting of influential countries here on Saturday in an effort to revive the plan.

headline: Diving With a Blue Light
text: Vincent Pieribone of the John B. Pierce Laboratory/Yale School of Medicine discusses the use of blue light in searching for biofluorescent molecules.

headline: Google Tries Something Retro: Made in the U.S.A.
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Etched into the base of Google’s new wireless home media player that was introduced on Wednesday is its most intriguing feature. On the underside of the Nexus Q is a simple inscription: “Designed and Manufactured in the U.S.A.”

headline: Google’s American Factory
text: Google is making its new media player in San Jose, as an experiment to see whether domestic manufacturing can work.

headline: Promoter Offers Drake and Chris Brown $1 Million Each to Meet in the Ring
text: By all accounts, there was nothing gentlemanly about the recent bar brawl involving Chris Brown and Drake. The combatants lobbed champagne bottles and glasses at one another and trashed a classy Soho nightclub.

text: Spain defeated Portugal, 4-2, in a penalty shootout in Donetsk, Ukraine, Wednesday, after a nervy 120 minutes of scoreless soccer failed to produce a winner.

headline: Shopping for London Theater Tickets? Read This.

headline: Afghan Rape Case Turns Focus on Local Police
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — The policeman spoke with calm and assurance as he insisted that he could not have raped the teenage daughter of a local shepherd, because a mullah had married them just before intercourse.

headline: 501(c) Mischief
text: It seemed like no one in a position of authority was going to do anything about the rampant abuse of federal laws governing 501(c) organizations – the practice of funneling money through charities, foundations or “social welfare” groups to flood political campaigns with baldly partisan advertising. Donors find these particular avenues of influence appealing because tax-exempt groups, unlike super PACs, need not disclose their names to the public.

headline: On Our Radar: An Ivory Bonfire
text: With its president doing the honors, Gabon burns its government-held stockpile of ivory to emphasize its commitment to fighting elephant poaching and the illegal wildlife trade. [The Guardian]

headline: Senseless or Sensible?
text: David Brooks: Gail, let’s praise the Supreme Court! I find it an endlessly impressive institution. Here are people who disagree on large issues with large consequences, and as far as I can tell they preserve an attitude of friendship and generosity toward one another.

headline: For Graduates of City's New Schools, Tradition Is What They Say It Is
text: For students, being part of a new school meant designing the student council, instituting annual traditions during the school year, deciding on school colors, school cheers and events. It also meant major preparations for the first graduation, with the added responsibility of setting the tone for younger classmates by coming up with specific ideas that could set their school's event apart from others. And of course there were a few pitfalls -- like, in the case of Pan American International High School, discovering that if you order the yearbook in May, it won't be there on time for graduation day.

headline: Most Americans Support Plan to Suspend Saturday Mail Delivery, Poll Finds
text: An overwhelming majority of Americans support the Postal Service’s plan to end Saturday mail delivery, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times/CBS News.

headline: Attack Raises Fears of a New Gang War in Macau
text: MACAU — A senior figure in Macau’s gambling industry was severely beaten by six men in a restaurant at his own casino, the highest-profile case of violence in the city’s booming gambling business since Portugal handed control of the former colony back to China in 1999.

headline: A Sea of Job-Seekers, but Some Companies Aren’t Getting Any Bites
text: After the latest, disappointing unemployment figures, policy makers and economists continue to debate how American companies might create more jobs. But business owners and recruiters say thousands of jobs around the country are sitting vacant, particularly at small and midsize companies.

headline: Budget Woes Prompt Cuts at Seattle Opera
text: The Seattle Opera says an anticipated $1 million budget shortfall this season will mean cuts in salaries and staff and a reshaping of its programming, with a four-opera season instead of five beginning in 2014. Opera company officials said in a press release issued Tuesday night after a board meeting that a difficult economy, along with a drop in subscription sales and major donations, have contributed to its fiscal woes.

headline: Some Prehumans Feasted on Bark Instead of Grasses
text: Almost two million years after their last meals, two members of a prehuman species in southern Africa left traces in their teeth of what they had eaten then, as well as over a lifetime of foraging. Scientists were surprised to find that these hominins apparently lived almost exclusively on a diet of leaves, fruits, wood and bark.

headline: Big City Book Club, Baseball Edition: Discuss ‘Bang the Drum Slowly’

headline: Tip of the Week: Caret Browsing
text: Need to frequently copy and paste text from Web pages? If so, the “caret browsing” feature in some browsers can make text selection more precise. It lets you use the keyboard to grab the text instead of swiping across it with the mouse — and possibly getting text you do not want in the selection.

headline: Prescription Drug to Aid Weight Loss Wins F.D.A. Backing
text: The first new prescription diet pill in 13 years won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, providing a new option for the roughly one-third of American adults considered obese.

headline: Finding Childhood Independence in the Sabbath
text: Wherever I move, I always know which neighborhood I want to live in. I don’t aim for proximity to organic freshly roasted coffee, a Whole Foods or Trader Joe’s, or even a park and green space, but to a synagogue. One day a week my family forgoes modern methods of transit and reverts to the primal ways of our ancestors by walking wherever it is we want to go, which makes it necessary for us to live in walking distance to our place of worship.

headline: After a Hall of Fame Snub for Shanahan, Plenty of Questions

The Hall released its list of 2012 honorees on Tuesday, with Joe Sakic, Adam Oates, Pavel Bure and Mats Sundin to be enshrined on Nov. 12.

headline: Andy Murray’s Osmolarity Is Looking Good So Far
text: Andy Murray’s demeanor has been dogging him lately. Yesterday, before Nikolay Davydenko took the court for his first-round match at Wimbledon against Murray, the British press was full of Davydenko’s comments about Murray’s on-court affect and his tendency to put his hurt on display. “We just laugh sometimes,” The Sun (among others) quoted Davydenko as saying. “Sometimes he walks on court, he looks tired, like he doesn’t want to run anymore, and then he runs like an animal. He has done that all his career. He just walks and he’s like, ‘Ah, I don’t want to play any more.’ Then he starts returning and running, and you see his condition is very good. Maybe it is a special Scottish thing.”

headline: S.E.C. Files Civil Charges Against Falcone

headline: Future of an Aging Court Raises Stakes of Presidential Vote

But she drew chuckles from a group of liberal lawyers not long ago while recalling how Justice Elena Kagan, 52, had suggested during an oral argument before the Supreme Court that people born before 1948 were old.
