headline: Site to Be Seen | Everlane.com
text: Michael Preysman wants you to know that if you are buying such basics as T-shirts, belts or tote bags at traditional retailers, you’re probably paying too much. Just how much is a matter of debate, but Preysman, a co-founder and the C.E.O. of the e-commerce site Everlane.com, contends that when designer labels are stitched into these typical items, the price can be eight times higher than what it costs to make them.

headline: Manhattan Theater Club Unveils New Play Initiative
text: The Manhattan Theater Club on Wednesday announced a new initiative at City Center to support the creation of new plays. The Studio at Stage II, as the initiative is called, will host two new productions in its first season beginning this fall, with all seats $30. The theater also announced a new partnership between and Ars Nova, called The Writer’s Room, that will commission work to be shown at the studio.

headline: Europe’s Mightiest Banks Still Grapple With Crisis
text: FRANKFURT — Five years after the financial crisis began, many banks throughout the euro zone are still in a weakened state, cut off from money markets because investors do not trust them, and effectively on life support from the European Central Bank.

headline: Injured Pettitte Will Be Out at Least Six Weeks
text: 3:40 p.m. | Updated Andy Pettitte, who at 40 has been as dependable as any Yankees starter this season, fractured his left ankle in a game against the Cleveland Indians on Wednesday and will be out for at least six weeks, the Yankees said.

headline: Alec Baldwin Returning to Broadway in Spring 2013
text: After seven seasons playing the charismatic, controlling network executive  Jack Donaghy on the NBC comedy “30 Rock,” Alec Baldwin will return to Broadway in spring 2013 in a much darker show – but in a role that is no less charismatic or controlling. Mr. Baldwin will portray Harold, a mobster who is kidnapped and held by two troubled brothers in Lyle Kessler’s 1983 drama “Orphans,” the show’s producers said on Wednesday. The play will be directed by the Tony Award winner Daniel Sullivan (“The Columnist,” “Proof”), who is also staging a Broadway revival of “Glengarry Glen Ross” this fall.

headline: For Spectacular Serves, Numbers Don’t Add Up

headline: Destination America Channel (Formerly Planet Green) Has Big Plans for Fourth of July

headline: For a Blonde Like That, Why Not Be Someone Else?
text: As his uproarious 1983 play “Noises Off” so nimbly demonstrated, Michael Frayn is a master of that most frantic of genres: the door-slamming, coincidence-splattered, slapstick-studded genre of farce. With his latest novel, “Skios,” Mr. Frayn tries to translate farce from the theater to the page — with somewhat mixed results. The novel is immensely entertaining, sometimes laugh-out-loud funny, but it’s also a pretty flimsy production, with an unsatisfying and jerry-built conclusion.

headline: D-Day
text: The most useful way to read a Supreme Court decision, I figured out years ago, is to start with the dissents. That way, you can proceed to the majority opinion as a better informed reader, with the full range of possibilities in view: What arguments did the majority reject? Which did it respond to, and which did it not even bother to acknowledge? Most important, what was the disagreement really about?

headline: Cutting the Electric Bill with a Giant Battery

headline: Obama to Tour Colorado Fire Areas
text: President Obama plans to travel to Colorado on Friday to tour areas devastated by raging wildfires, the White House said on Wednesday. One of the fires, in the foothills near Colorado Springs, has burned 24 square miles, destroyed an unknown number of homes and forced some 26,000 people to evacuate.

headline: Trading Brand Names for Homemade
text: Compared to a new dress or handbag, most beauty products are modest indulgences. Still, these are recessionary times. With that in mind, here’s a guide to achieving brand-name results at wallet-friendly prices, so you can look great this summer even if you’re feeling pinched.

headline: Yankees Lose Sabathia, Then Pettitte to Injuries

He was fitted for a black boot that went up to his knee, given crutches and told to elevate his leg for a few days — maybe he could move better by Friday.

headline: Rubenstein Buys a Copy of the Emancipation Proclamation for $2 Million

headline: For Designers of Tata Emo, No Glitz, but Plenty of Promise

headline: Creator of ‘Family Guy’ Donates Carl Sagan Papers to Library of Congress
text: It seems like an improbable connection, but Seth MacFarlane, creator of “Family Guy,” ”American Dad!” and “The Cleveland Show,” all animated TV shows that are not shy about crude humor, has donated funds to the Library of Congress so it can acquire the personal papers of Carl Sagan, the scientist and astronomer, library officials announced Wednesday.

headline: Attack on Pro-Assad Television Studio Raises Questions on Rules of War
text: CAIRO — As my colleagues Rod Nordland, Nick Cumming-Bruce and Alan Cowell report, Syria said Wednesday that rebels stormed a pro-government television station in a Damascus suburb, killing journalists and blowing up the station, in a predawn raid.

headline: A Night of Jazz Is Rooted in the Moment While Reaching to the Past
text: A charged and tingly curiosity preceded the guitarist Marc Ribot’s opening set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night. The room was packed tight, and the air thick with anticipation: this would be Mr. Ribot’s first engagement as a leader at the Vanguard, which is still a coveted milestone for almost any jazz musician. And his trio, with the bassist Henry Grimes and the drummer Chad Taylor, suggested both a convulsive departure from the club’s center-lane programming and the reverent ennobling of a chapter in its history.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Beasts of the Southern Wild’

Scott calling it “a blast of sheer, improbable joy” and Manohla Dargis calling it “among the best films to play at the festival in two decades.”

headline: In a Retrospective Evening, a Celebration, Too
text: The New York Philharmonic devotes relatively little of its stage time to contemporary works, but things may be looking up. Last year the orchestra established the Marie-Josée Kravis Prize for New Music, a $200,000 award for a composer selected every two years by a committee of musicians. And if you award a prize, you might as well perform the recipient’s work.

headline: Teachers Starting to Hear if They Are Part of Turnaround Plan
text: Thousands of teachers at 24 "turnaround" schools are learning whether they have been selected to come back in the fall, but hiring decisions are still subject to an arbitrator's decision later this week.

headline: Browsing Rights | Ommu in Athens
text: “It’s difficult,” says Marina Legaki, summing up the current climate in Athens where she and her partner, Tasos Gaintatzis, run Ommu, a bookstore and arts space. Established in 2009 as a temporary shop in the corner of the Athens gallery AMP, Ommu now operates out of a newly renovated 1950s-era building all its own, specializing in hard-to-find (in Athens) international magazines like Kaleidoscope and Apartamento; monographs on artists like Dan Colen, Esther Tielemans and Fia Backstrom; and lesser-known publications like “Movie List,” a black and white facsimile of an original maquette by the late artist Dash Snow, released in zine form by Snow’s estate. Legaki, who studied psychology before moving into publishing, and Gaintitzis, a former photographer, first worked together in 2002, on the now-defunct Dynasty zine. Ommu also trades in limited-edition artworks and contemporary furniture — surrounding piles of books are psychedelic sculptures by the Greek artist Antonis Vathis and clever, modular benches by the German designer Manuel Raeder, all of which are for sale. Quick-fire exhibitions, the most recent of which featured works by the London design office Zak Group, take over any remaining white space on the walls.

headline: Fairway Market Plans a Kips Bay Store
text: Fairway Market, which has stores in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens as well as upstate New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, will open a 42,000-square-foot store in late fall in the Kips Bay section of Manhattan.

headline: For Arts Institutions, Thinking Big Can Be Suicidal

headline: As Obama Buys Up Time, NBC Executive Says Positive Ads Do Better at Olympics
text: With the news that the Obama campaign has purchased $5.5 million in commercial time during the coverage of the London Olympics, an NBC executive had advice for both presidential candidates: Don’t go negative during the three weeks’ worth of thrills of victory and agonies of defeat.

headline: Colorado Wildfires Force Thousands to Evacuate
text: A raging wildfire in the hills overlooking Colorado Springs doubled in size overnight, as my colleague Dan Frosch reports, destroying dozens of homes and forcing the evacuation of tens of thousands of people, including the Air Force Academy.

headline: The Financial Costs of War, Beyond the Battlefield
text: Of all the issues surrounding the military today — repealing Don’t Ask Don’t Tell, whether to plan for intervention in Iran and or Syria, what form our role in the Pacific should take, the disturbing questions over torture and the use of drones against humans — none has more immediate and long-lasting potential for good or bad than educating our society about post-traumatic stress disorder. As evidenced by the still-growing number of suicides within and outside the military as well as violent crime by veterans, how we define and treat P.T.S.D. is an issue likely to affect generations of taxpayers to come.

headline: Conjuring Youth by Way of Billy Joel
text: Inside many male Broadway singers is a barely suppressed rock ’n’ roll wild man who dreams of exploding before thousands of screaming fans.

headline: Milan Men’s Wear for Spring 2013
text: Looks from spring 2013 collections including Prada, Jil Sander, Calvin Klein and Gucci,

headline: To Go Forward, Go Back
text: MILAN

headline: A House Facing a Canal in the Dutch Capital
text: A five-bedroom house in Amsterdam’s trendy Nine Streets neighborhood is on the market for $1.9 million.

headline: House Hunting ... in the Netherlands
text: A FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE IN CENTRAL AMSTERDAM

headline: Tweets We Loved From #MFW
text: As the fashion flock heads to Paris, we review some of our favorite tweets from the Milan men’s shows.

headline: Liz Smith Recalls Nora Ephron, Whose Death She Reported Prematurely
text: As she sat at a luncheon on Wednesday celebrating a film series on groundbreaking women, Liz Smith, the celebrity columnist, fondly remembered getting to know Nora Ephron in a gossipy women’s group dubbed “the Harpies.”

headline: Sony RX100 Field Test
text: The huge sensor in Sony’s new pocket camera allows it to do things generally reserved for S.L.R.’s.

headline: India Says Pakistan Aided Planner of Mumbai Attacks
text: NEW DELHI — India’s home minister on Wednesday said there was new evidence of Pakistani state support for the 2008 Mumbai attacks, citing information provided by Abu Jindal, an Indian man suspected of being one of the planners.

headline: Tiny Camera to Rival the Pros
text: This is a review of the best pocket camera ever made.

headline: A Dark Irish Voice Revisits His Rage
text: THROUGH her unflinching productions of plays by Martin McDonagh and others, the director Garry Hynes bears as much responsibility as anyone for resetting the popular conception of Irish theater. The county names are just as mellifluous as before, but the plays now contain torturers and sociopaths.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Wild Fires and Abstinence
text: Via Right Wing Watch

headline: Who Are These Guys? Slumping Mets Thrash the Cubs
text: CHICAGO — Under slightly different circumstances, the Mets’ 17-1 victory against the Chicago Cubs, as impressive as it was, would not have carried such importance.

headline: Live Coverage Thursday of Germany-Italy Match
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 semifinal game between Germany and Italy on Thursday at 2:45 p.m. ET. Duncan Irving will offer commentary and analysis of the match.

headline: TimesCast Tech: Google Developers’ Conference
text: Electronic Arts develops an HTML5-based video game, competitive sailing adapts new technology to attract television views and Reading Rainbow takes young readers on a new adventure. Plus, a big step forward for iPad apps in the kitchen.

headline: Beyond the Magazine
text: Working at The New Yorker has inspired its fair share of memoirs over the years. Here are some noteworthy titles:

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: BURLINGTON, N.J.

headline: Homes for $500,000
text: Properties in New Jersey, Chicago and New Mexico.

headline: Overconfidence Suggested in Supreme Court Predictions
text: Bettors at the prediction market Intrade are quite confident that the Supreme Court will declare the individual mandate unconstitutional when it rules on the government’s health care bill. (The decision is expected to come on Thursday.) At this writing, the consensus prediction of the market is that there is a 74 percent chance that the court will vote to overturn the mandate.

headline: Washington Post Rebuffs Romney on Retraction
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign demanded — but did not receive — a retraction on Wednesday from The Washington Post for an article alleging that during Mr. Romney’s tenure, Bain Capital invested in companies that pioneered the practice of sending jobs out of the country.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Skydiving Glasses and Sympathy for a Twitter Bot
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Wednesday. See more here.

headline: City and Union Collaborate on New Community Hubs
text: The teachers' union and the Education Department are joining forces to provide more social and medical services to students and their families at six schools, which will serve as community hubs.

headline: The New Yorker, From a Seat on the 18th Floor
text: ONE night a few weeks ago, a large crowd packed into the National Arts Club in Manhattan to witness a literary debut 55 years in the making. The author, a witty, 75-year-old college professor named Janet Groth, told stories of working at The New Yorker during the magazine’s heyday in the 1950s and ’60s: her weekly lunches with the revered reporter Joseph Mitchell; her affair with a cartoonist she nicknamed “the great deceiver”; her fleeting interactions with the longtime editor William Shawn, who, despite his shyness, was “gallant enough to present me with a rose when I left the magazine.”

headline: Maybe Petzschner Can’t Deal With Success
text: Men’s tennis is experiencing an age of unprecedented record-setting and players who are able to play equally well on all surfaces, making the present into what some are calling a golden age for the sport. While the surefire Hall of Famers Rafael Nadal, Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic contend for a Grand Slam, Philipp Petzschner of Germany made his own sort of history at Wimbledon on Wednesday.

headline: N.H. Approves Voter ID Law
text: The New Hampshire legislature on Wednesday overrode Gov. John Lynch’s veto of a voter ID bill, making it the latest state to require that voters present photo identification at the polls.

headline: A Soaring Requiem to Fill St. Paul’s
text: LONDON — A cathedral can be a terribly reverberant place to hear music, especially symphonic works. But there is a rich heritage of pieces that were conceived for the resonant acoustics and spatial dimensions of a large church, like the sacred music Monteverdi and Gabrieli wrote for St. Mark’s Basilica in Venice, music that gloried in placing groups of singers, strings and brasses in lofts and alcoves to produce exhilarating antiphonal effects.

headline: Filling a Room With Wireless Sound
text: About a year ago, I wrote about the best way to set up wireless audio — how to get the music that lives on your computer onto speakers scattered throughout your home.

headline: Nora Ephron’s Hollywood Ending
text: IN “You’ve Got Mail,” Meg Ryan asks Tom Hanks why it is that men quote “The Godfather” all the time. Tom Hanks explains that “The Godfather” is the I Ching. “ ‘The Godfather’ is the sum of all wisdom,” he says. “ ‘The Godfather’ is the answer to any question. What should I pack for my summer vacation? ‘Leave the gun, take the cannoli.’ ”

headline: Unnerved but Not Undone, Spain Advances to Final
text: DONETSK, Ukraine — Spain has been criticized as boring at the European Championships, admonished as too defensive. But these are only opinions. Nothing really counts but the objective measure of the final score. While Spain became unnerved by Portugal’s pressure in the semifinals on Wednesday, it never came unraveled or undone.

headline: Half the Man He Used to Be, Fighting Rage
text: Charlie Sheen did not go unpunished.

headline: Records Set at Christie’s Contemporary Sale in London
text: LONDON – At Christie’s post-war and contemporary art auction here on Wednesday evening – an event aptly described by the super dealer Larry Gagosian as “Masterpiece Theatre’’ – collectors from around the world dropped millions of dollars on works by many of the major names of the 20th century, and record prices were set for two of them: Yves Klein and Jean-Michel Basquiat.

headline: Curry Set to Announce Departure From ‘Today’
text: 1:13 a.m. | Updated Ann Curry will step down on Thursday morning from her co-host chair on NBC’s “Today” show, capping weeks of private negotiations with the network officials who have been trying to ease her out of the job that she has held for just over a year.

headline: A Vocal Reaction to an Article on Stop-and-Frisk Experiences
text: The stop-and-frisk has emerged as one of the New York Police Department’s favored tactics for fighting crime in troubled neighborhoods, but based on reader comments submitted to nytimes.com, the policy is wildly unpopular with readers of The New York Times.

headline: Custom Doghouses, Fit for a King
text: The only superfluous accessory in the modern doghouse may be the dog.

headline: Luxury Doghouses and the Dogs That Couldn’t Care Less
text: MANY of them have carpeting, heating and air-conditioning, indoor and outdoor lighting, elaborate music and entertainment systems. Some are even eco-friendly, with solar panels or planted green roofs.

headline: M.L.S. Readjusts Its Focus to Site of World’s Fairs
text: Major League Soccer dipped its figurative toes in the Hudson River, downtown along Manhattan’s West Side, as it considered building a new stadium at Pier 40. The league, which seems committed to placing its 20th team in New York City, also scoped out more than a dozen other possible locations — including the West Side Yards; Greenpoint, Brooklyn;  Willets Point; and the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx.

headline: The Bully on the Night Stand
text: I USED to be a sleep bragger. You probably know the type. I was the guy in college who felt energized after getting just three hours of shut-eye before the midterm. I was your smug colleague who sermonized about the productivity gains achieved by waking before dawn. Sleeping, I’ve been known to argue, is an enormous waste of time, a scourge to be tamped down in favor of more work, or at least more time goofing off on the Web.

headline: A Treasure in the Historic Core of Spain
text: An ancient building meets minimalist style in this renovated Spanish home.

headline: Somewhere in Time
text: Girona, Spain

headline: Shopping for Grills
text: Dan Kluger, the executive chef of ABC Kitchen in Manhattan, embarks on a quest to uncover the perfect grill for a summer of outdoor cooking.

headline: Grills
text: FOR Dan Kluger, executive chef of ABC Kitchen in Manhattan, summer conjures up visions of grilling outdoors.

headline: Date Blamed for Low Vote in Primaries
text: Several unusually competitive Congressional primaries excited New York City’s political class on Tuesday, but they did not have such an effect on voters. As campaign officials had predicted, turnout was very low in the city and across the state.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our two children share a bedroom, and it looks cramped. What can we do to make the room appear larger?

headline: Fight Over a Potential Rolling Stones Tour Reveals Promoters’ Backbiting Ways
text: At the very top of the music industry, everybody seems to be friends. And also enemies. Oh, and then friends again.

headline: Citing Discrimination in Stop-and-Frisk Practice, Coalition Calls for Reforms
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has recently adopted a somewhat conciliatory tone with critics of the police department’s stop-and-frisk practice, pledging that police officers will be trained to behave more courteously and promising that the number of stops will decline.

headline: The Way We Live: Drowning in Stuff
text: From 2001 to 2005, a team of social scientists studied 32 middle-class families in Los Angeles, a project documenting every wiggle of life at home. The study was generated by the U.C.L.A. Center on the Everyday Lives of Families to understand how people handled what anthropologists call material culture — what we call stuff. These were dual-earner households in a range of ethnic groups, neighborhoods, incomes and occupations, with at least two children between the ages of 7 and 12 — in other words, households smack in the weeds of family life.

headline: Whirl Crazy
text: When the Pakistani designer Tahir Mahmood, 43, moved to Toronto five years ago, he vowed to give his son, Efan, who was 4 at the time, the pleasure of two pastimes Mr. Mahmood had enjoyed growing up in Lahore. Kite flying was easy, but playing with spinning tops proved trickier. Mr. Mahmood had trouble finding wooden tops. “So I designed this set for my kids,” he said.

headline: A Shiny New Home for Christofle
text: After 25 years in cramped quarters on Madison Avenue, the French silver company Christofle has a new home several blocks north. Its 1,400-square-foot boutique is “a series of contradictions — intimate and open, soft and hard, light and dark,” said its designer, Stéphane Parmentier, who worked for Lanvin, Karl Lagerfeld and Givenchy before founding his own firm in Paris more than a decade ago.

headline: Have a Seat on a Catwalk
text: Since 1986, the artist Ruben Toledo has collaborated with Ralph Pucci on chic mannequins for the fashion world. Now Mr. Toledo has crossed into Mr. Pucci’s other business area: furniture. Their latest project is a group of tables, chairs and a bench (shown).

headline: Barbie, Not Ken, Does Repairs Here
text: For years, educators have debated how to get more women into math and science careers. Alice Brooks, Bettina Chen and Jennifer Kessler, who met as master’s students at Stanford, have come up with a novel solution: a dollhouse with circuit boards. The women were frustrated by the gender imbalance in their classes, Ms. Brooks said, and realized “we could trace the initial spark for our interest in math and science to the toys that we played with.” (Her dad gave her a saw instead of a Barbie.)

headline: At One Brooklyn School, a Lesson in the Danger of Success
text: If you believe the research, statistics and experts, it appears that my son’s elementary school, Public School 9 in Brooklyn’s Prospect Heights neighborhood, has been doing everything right. Middle-class, college-educated people are increasingly sending their children there because of its academic excellence, its emphasis on individualized instruction, its commitment to arts education and its progressive, inquiry-based approach.

headline: Sales at Garnet Hill, Jayson Home and Others
text: Summer sheets from Eileen Fisher and Lilly Pulitzer are 20 percent off at Garnet Hill through July 10, or while supplies last (Eileen Fisher Lustrous cotton sateen bedding, left, originally $50 to $250, is now $40 to $200; Lilly Pulitzer Bella coverlet and sham, originally $48 to $228, is now $38 to $182); (800) 622-6216, garnethill.com.

headline: No Matter What Court Decides, Health Care Law Has ‘Got to Go,’ Romney Says
text: STERLING, Va. — Mitt Romney may not know how the Supreme Court is going to rule on President Obama’s health care plan on Thursday, but he did have one prediction at a campaign rally here on the eve of the decision: “My guess is they’re not sleeping real well at the White House tonight.”

headline: The Roberts Court’s Liberal Turn on Juvenile Justice
text: Las Vegas

headline: What’s Up With Samantha Stosur?
text: One of the anomalies of the tennis scoring system is that a player can win more points over all but still lose the match. Such was the case in Samantha Stosur’s three-set loss to Arantxa Rus on Wednesday at Wimbledon. Stosur won 86 points to Rus’s 77, and each player won 12 games. But Rus won the match, breaking Stosur right back after Stosur rallied to tie the score late in the third set.

headline: You Can Track Your Kids. But Should You?
text: When does monitoring your children through technology cross the line into invasion of privacy?

headline: A Dissent by Scalia Is Criticized as Political
text: When Justice Antonin Scalia read aloud from his dissent in the Arizona immigration case on Monday, including an attack on President Obama’s recent decision not to deport many illegal immigrants who arrived here as children, it raised some eyebrows. Mr. Obama’s policy was announced two months after the case had been heard.

headline: As His Optimistic Budget Falters, Christie Comes Out Swinging
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey promised a have-your-cake-and-eat-it-too budget for next year, one that would make the state’s pension payments, increase money for schools, provide drug treatment for nonviolent criminals, restore tax credits for the working poor and give every taxpayer a 10 percent income tax cut.

headline: As Retail Hub, Manhattan Tops National Average and Outstrips Other Boroughs
text: The retail success story in Manhattan is well known: a steadily growing influx of tourists has pushed per capita retail sales in the borough far higher than in the rest of the country.

headline: For Kleenex, a Song and Dance to Sneeze To
text: ADVERTISING for Kleenex, the brand that invented the facial tissue category 88 years ago, has had little need to provide tips on how to use the product.

headline: Awaiting Ruling on Fairly Simple Questions About a Complex Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is expected to announce on Thursday morning its decision on the health care overhaul that President Obama signed into law in 2010 — an act of Congress thousands of pages long, containing hundreds of changes costing hundreds of billions of dollars and affecting nearly every American from cradle to grave.

headline: Beneath a Ranting Elmo’s Mask, a Man With a Disturbing Past
text: The man in the red Elmo costume was back to work in Central Park on Tuesday, but under the mask, he was not smiling. He was behind in tips he earns by posing for photographs with tourists. He said he had gotten a late start because he was not released from a psychiatric evaluation at a nearby hospital until midmorning.

headline: Tropical Storm Debby Exits a Rain-Soaked Florida
text: MIAMI — After pounding Florida with relentless rain for four days, slow-moving Tropical Storm Debby traveled out of the state near Jacksonville on Wednesday morning, leaving behind a soggy trail of damaged homes, beaches and roads.

headline: A Note to Readers
text: On June 28, 2012, The New York Times introduced a beta version of a new online Chinese-language edition designed to bring New York Times journalism to China.  The Web site, http://cn.nytimes.com, continues to  grow in scope and functionality.

headline: Google Sees the Promise in Hardware
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It was an event that included sky divers, stunt bikers and people rappelling down the side of a building. Then came another spectacle: watching Google, the Web search giant, reimagine itself as a hardware maker.

headline: The Best Mailgirl Ever
text: When Nora Ephron graduated from college in 1962, she applied for a job as a writer at Newsweek, was told women weren’t allowed to be writers there, and settled for mailgirl. I used that story as a kind of centerpiece in a book I wrote about American women because it reminded me of one of those old movies about a Broadway musical with pompous stars played by actors you’ve never heard of, plus Judy Garland in the back of the chorus.

headline: Ex-Students Acquitted of Hazing in Cornell Death
text: Three former Cornell University undergraduates have been found not guilty of hazing a sophomore who died during a fraternity ritual last year, in a case that drew attention to dangerous behavior among American college students.

headline: Harry Levinson, Psychologist for the Workplace, Dies at 90
text: Harry Levinson, a psychologist who helped change corporate America’s thinking about the workplace by demonstrating a link between job conditions and emotional health — a progressive notion when he began developing his ideas in the 1950s — died on Tuesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 90.

headline: Remembering Nora Ephron
text: Outside the luncheon for the AOL/PBS digital project “Makers: Women Who Make America,” some influential women spoke about Nora Ephron’s legacy.

headline: A Breakthrough Candidate and Potential Star
text: Grace Meng had just left a senior center in Forest Hills, Queens, on Wednesday, thanking the lunchtime crowd for contributing to her victory in the previous day’s Congressional primary, when she ran into a group of two dozen boys from the Acheinu Day Camp.

headline: On the Farms of France, the Death of a Pixelated Workhorse
text: PAIMPONT, France — A faint trail of mud and manure leads from the door of Yves Denais’s barn-floor office, overlooking the pens for his Holstein calves, to a cluttered desk atop which sits a compact beige plastic box that once placed Mr. Denais at the cutting edge of information technology.

headline: After Years of False Hopes, Signs of a Turn in Housing
text: WASHINGTON — Announcements of a housing recovery have become a wrongheaded rite of summer, but after several years of false hopes, evidence is accumulating that the optimists may finally be right.

headline: ‘Not My Fault’ That Ump Didn’t Catch It Either, Wise Says
text: Don’t blame me, Dewayne Wise said, “It’s not my fault.”

headline: South Carolina House Panel to Hear Ethics Complaints Against Governor
text: Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina has drawn political fire from both major political parties since the moment she took office in 2011.

headline: Election 2012 Pop Quiz!
text: Now that it’s clear that the presidential election will be between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, let’s see how much you know of the candidates. Take my presidential quiz, and if you get them all right, I nominate you to be a White House aide.

headline: A Rate-Setting Mechanism of Far-Reaching Effects
text: A multiyear, global investigation into the setting of interest rates has focused on often complex trades in the financial centers of New York, London and Tokyo. But the accusations in the case have real-life consequences for consumers and businesses in the United States.

headline: The Deal on Student Loans
text: At the last minute, like everything else in Congress, a bipartisan Senate deal fell into place on Tuesday to prevent interest rates on student loans from doubling on July 1. Now it is up to the House to quickly approve the measure and ensure that students struggling with the economy will not incur extra debt.

headline: Judy Agnew, Wife of Vice President, Dies at 91
text: Judy Agnew, who went to Washington after Richard M. Nixon plucked her husband, Spiro, from relative political obscurity to make him vice president and who later stood by him when he resigned in 1973 because of criminal charges, died on June 20 in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Finish of 200 Freestyle May Be Surprise, but Not to Phelps
text: OMAHA — To Michael Phelps, all the talk that he was chasing Ryan Lochte was frustrating, to use one of his favorite post-2008 adjectives.

headline: The Spread of Wildfires in Colorado
text: Animated maps showing how the Waldo Canyon wildfire spread near Colorado Springs, Colo.

headline: Leaving Alabama Behind
text: Mobile, Ala.

headline: Amid Gloom, Job Hopes Rest Heavily on New Arena
text: Atiya Cheatham woke up two hours earlier than usual, murmured her daily prayers, brushed and curled her long ebony hair and put on her best interview outfit, a cream-colored, three-quarter-sleeved blouse and khaki slacks.

headline: Deadly Day for Afghan Police
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ten police officers died in violence across Afghanistan on Wednesday, including the district chief of a counterterrorism unit in Herat Province in the west of the country, officials said.

headline: To Lure ‘Twilight’ Teenagers, Classic Books Get Bold Looks
text: Teenagers are still reading the classics. They just don’t want them to look so, well, classic.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 18
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: California: Stockton Readies for Bankruptcy
text: Stockton officials have approved a new budget that will guide city operations during bankruptcy. When officials file for Chapter 9 bankruptcy, which could happen this week, Stockton will be country’s largest city to go bankrupt. The budget, approved Tuesday night, will suspend debt payments, cut employee pay and reduce retiree benefits, allowing the city of about 292,000 residents to continue providing essential services through the bankruptcy process. After nearby Vallejo, Calif., filed for bankruptcy in 2008, state lawmakers passed legislation requiring cities to hire a third-party mediator to negotiate with creditors before filing for bankruptcy. Stockton officials had hoped to avoid bankruptcy when the city entered into 90 days of mediation in March. But on Monday, the city and its creditors failed to meet a deadline for a deal.

headline: Beijing, a Boon for Africa
text: IN June 2011, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a speech in Zambia warning of a “new colonialism” threatening the African continent. “We saw that during colonial times, it is easy to come in, take out natural resources, pay off leaders and leave,” she said, in a thinly veiled swipe at China.

headline: News Corp. Announces Spinoff of Newspapers
text: Rupert Murdoch was getting cold feet. For months, his top lieutenants at News Corporation had been prodding him to spin off the newspaper unit, which was underperforming but had long been close to his heart.

headline: You Can’t Win if You Don’t Pay
text: Give a few dollars to President Obama or Mitt Romney, the e-mail messages say, and you have a shot at sitting next to them for dinner. You could shake hands with George Clooney at a presidential fund-raiser. You might win a lunch with Mr. Romney and Donald Trump and a tour of “The Celebrity Apprentice” boardroom.

headline: A Court Rules for the Planet
text: A federal court decision on Tuesday upholding the Environmental Protection Agency’s landmark rulings to control greenhouse gases was a decisive victory for the Obama administration and a devastating blow to polluters. It vindicated the administration’s strategy of controlling emissions through regulation and showed good sense at a time when both the agency and the science of global warming are under relentless Congressional attack.

headline: At Outset of Brussels Summit Meeting, the One Thing Missing Is Confidence
text: BERLIN — With its democratically elected president and powerful finance minister, the European Union of the future will be more adept not only at fighting crises but at preventing them in the first place. Its bicameral legislature, with an empowered Parliament and an upper house like the United States Senate, will ensure greater legitimacy among the Continent’s polyglot people.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Police Had Unusual Access to Nightclub Data, Suit Says
text: For more than a year, the New York Police Department had ready access to a database that held the scanned identification document of every person who entered a large SoHo nightclub, whether those people were engaged in criminal activity or simply socializing with friends, according to a lawsuit.

headline: NBC Goes Digital for Olympics, but Tape Will Still Roll in Prime Time
text: I have, for 20 years, written copiously about NBC’s use of tape-delay during the Olympics. I bore witness to the pre-1992 Summer Games vow of Terry O’Neil, then the executive producer of NBC Sports, that the events from Barcelona, Spain, would be shown “plausibly live” — on tape but delivered as if live.

headline: Sharp Rise in New York Beach Closings Is Found
text: A report on water quality at the nation’s beaches has found that the number of closings and advisories from contamination concerns at New York State beaches rose sharply last year. It also warns that a new standard proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency could inadequately protect beachgoers.

headline: How the Number of Uninsured May Change With and Without the Health Care Law
text: Estimates from the Congressional Budget Office show how health insurance coverage may change for non-elderly Americans in the next decade. The Supreme Court decision and possible action by Congress will determine whether the 2010 federal health care law will continue to go into effect.

headline: Diplomatic Crisis Gives Romney Campaign a Chance to Work Out Its Policy
text: It seemed a ripe opportunity for Mitt Romney: The crisis that unfolded last month over the Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng was a way to hammer President Obama as weak on human rights and unwilling to be assertive with China.

headline: Window, of Sorts
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — How much of a TIME FRAME do you have to discuss today’s puzzle?

headline: New York City’s Balanced Budget, for Now
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg and New York City Council members have proudly announced an agreement on a $68.5 billion budget that they expect to approve on Thursday. The proposed 2012-13 budget, which is due by July 1, is full of good news. Taxes won’t go up. Teachers won’t be fired. Libraries and firehouses will stay open. And child care services for poor families will be expanded.

headline: Candidate Blank
text: I’m not sure I’ve ever seen anything like this.

headline: Some Leave for Trials, but Others Face Fires
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — John Orozco, the reigning national gymnastics champion in the all-around event, is known for his ability to stay even-keeled, even in the most adverse situations. But recently in Colorado Springs, where he trains at the United States Olympic Training Center, there has been a distraction that he could not ignore.

headline: Syrian Arrests Are Said to Have Snared Tens of Thousands
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — After Syrian secret police officers spotted Azam at a peaceful demonstration in the heart of this city, he said, they chased him down and dragged him off to prison, where he was tortured during his 40 days in confinement.

headline: Recycling Revolutionized
text: Cities in the Pacific Northwest are moving to biweekly garbage pickup in an effort to reduce landfill and increase composting and recycling.

headline: Which Direction for the Mideast?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Judge Sides With Florida on Purging Voter Rolls
text: MIAMI — A federal judge on Wednesday rebuffed the Department of Justice’s emergency request to stop Florida’s attempt to remove people who are not American citizens from its voter registration rolls.

headline: The Times’s Chinese-Language Web Site Goes Live
text: HONG KONG — The New York Times launched a Chinese-language Web site on Thursday morning.

headline: A Light in Captivity, and a Subject for Writing
text: Gilad Shalit watched the Spanish goalkeeper and the Portuguese goalkeeper stand guard on the television screen. He did not volunteer that, before he was taken hostage, he also was a goalkeeper.

headline: Stop and Frisk
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Positive Housing News
text: Many housing figures released this week indicated improvement.

headline: Rebranded and Relocated, the Nets Are Desperate to Re-Sign Williams
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The road leading toward the Nets’ training center ends abruptly, and a huge football stadium rises to fill the eastern horizon. You cannot see Brooklyn from here, but the Nets’ future is out there, somewhere.

headline: Summer Reading List
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tourists Seek Medical Care in Mexico
text: Medical care has become the primary tourist lure in some Mexican border towns.

headline: Solitary Confinement
text: To the Editor:

headline: Egypt’s Everywoman Finds Her Place Is in the Presidential Palace
text: CAIRO — Naglaa Ali Mahmoud wears an Islamic head covering that drapes down to her knees, did not attend college and never took her husband’s last name, because that is a Western convention that few Egyptians follow. She also refuses the title of first lady, in favor of simply Um Ahmed, a traditional nickname that identifies her as the mother of Ahmed, her eldest son.

headline: Corrections: June 28
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Italy Passes Labor Laws Before Talks
text: ROME — The Italian Parliament on Wednesday gave its final approval to a package of labor laws aimed at making it easier for businesses to hire and fire workers, arming Prime Minister Mario Monti with a victory as he arrived in Brussels for a critical summit meeting of European leaders.

headline: Nash to the Knicks? Not So Fast
text: “Nash to the Knicks! Nash to the Knicks!”

headline: Raf Simons: Spring 2013 Menswear

headline: For Franklin, No Rest Till After London
text: OMAHA — Eighteen minutes. That’s how much time 17-year-old Missy Franklin had between finishing her 200-meter freestyle semifinal and firing off the start in the 100 backstroke final Wednesday night at the United States Olympic swimming trials.

headline: A Pariah Returns, to His Peers’ Chagrin
text: WIMBLEDON, England — At 1:49 p.m. Wednesday, perhaps the most polarizing figure on the ATP Tour walked onto Court 9 at the All England Club, and no one seemed to notice. There were no hoots or catcalls for Wayne Odesnik, no cheers or applause, either, for the man Andy Roddick once suggested should be barred from the sport.

headline: Cities Get So Close to Recycling Ideal, They Can Smell It
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Stephanie and Matt Murphy plan on using cloth diapers instead of disposable ones once their first baby arrives next month. They want to be good environmental citizens and reduce what they send to landfills, but there is another incentive, too.

headline: Raf Simons Men’s
text: Paris

headline: Big, Athletic and at 18 Something of a Draft-Day Gamble
text: One of the tallest players who will be selected Thursday in the N.B.A. draft is Andre Drummond. A 7-foot center, Drummond is also one of the most intriguing prospects.

headline: Matches to Watch: Day 4
text: Again, the uncooperative skies above the All England Club led to a “match to watch” being postponed. Maria Sharapova had saved five set points in the first set and led Tsvetana Pironkova, 7-6 (3), 3-1, when their match was postponed due to darkness. They will be back on court Thursday, as will these five matches to watch on Day 4 of Wimbledon 2012. Players’ seeds are in parentheses.

headline: N.H.L. Players Join Forces Before Labor Talks Begin
text: CHICAGO — Less than three weeks after the Los Angeles Kings raised the Stanley Cup, the N.H.L.’s marquee summer showdown will begin Friday in New York when representatives for owners and players meet for the first time to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement.

headline: Ethiopia: Journalist Found Guilty
text: An Ethiopian court on Wednesday convicted a prominent journalist along with 23 others on terrorism charges in a trial that had been criticized by international rights groups. The case of the journalist, Eskinder Nega, attracted attention in the United States in the spring after he was given a prestigious press freedom award by PEN America. The charges stemmed from writings last fall that questioned the arrests of other journalists as the authorities clamped down on dissent out of fear that the Arab Spring revolts would be emulated in Ethiopia.

headline: Mexicali Tour, From Tummy Tuck to Root Canal
text: MEXICALI, Mexico — Tourists often come to border towns looking for some kind of illicit adventure, trotting among the bars, strip joints and seedy motels that dot the streets. Here, though, the visitors are searching for something more basic: a root canal they can afford or surgery they have been putting off for months.

headline: Craig Ferguson’s On, but the Lights Are Out
text: The CBS late-night host Craig Ferguson likes to have fun with the bare-bones nature of his show, but on Thursday it was no joking matter. Or actually, the only thing he could do was make jokes when a power failure at his Los Angeles studio meant he had to tape the show without the usual stage lighting. The production relied instead on flashlights, a hand-held floor stand and some house lights above the audience, a network spokeswoman said by e-mail.

headline: Tentative Deal Reached on 2-Year Transportation Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans and Democrats reached a tentative agreement on Wednesday on a two-year bill to finance highways, ending a partisan stalemate that had left transit projects under a cloud of uncertainty.

headline: China: Migrant Unrest Flares
text: A fight between a teenager from a migrant worker family and a local boy in southern China escalated into rioting and protests this week. The unrest, which followed the teenagers’ fight on Monday and the subsequent beating of the migrant boy by local villagers, occurred in the area of Shaxi in Guangdong Province. Migrant protesters smashed storefront windows and overturned cars, including police vehicles and ambulances, according to photographs of the rioting posted on the Internet. Caijing, a Chinese news organization, also reported that hundreds of riot police officers clashed with villagers in the Foshan area of Guangdong on Tuesday after the villagers protested illegal land seizures.

headline: Coach’s New Germany Is the Perfect Solution to an Old Azzurri Problem
text: “We don’t care who we play” was the statement with suitable intent that Joachim Löw boldly announced at a news conference before Sunday night’s decisive Euro 2012 quarterfinal match between Italy and England.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Too Sick to Smoke
text: The Challenge: Can you solve a medical mystery involving a previously healthy 48-year-old man who for three months has suffered a cough, shortness of breath, fatigue and weight loss?

headline: In 2006 Video, Romney Calls Health Care Mandate ‘Essential’
text: On the eve of the Supreme Court’s health care ruling Thursday morning, a Democratic group has uncovered what it said was fresh evidence of Mitt Romney’s one-time embrace of the individual insurance mandate that he now scorns.

headline: Word of the Day | marshal
text: marshal •\ˈmär-shəl\• noun and verb

headline: Outsourcing Becomes Toxic in U.S. Presidential Campaign
text: Outsourcing has never been a popular term in the Western countries that lose jobs to emerging markets, but it has become positively toxic in the current United States presidential campaign.

headline: Report Highlights a Rise in Reverse Mortgages
text: WASHINGTON — As baby boomers edge toward retirement, they are beginning to transform yet another slice of the financial industry: the market for reverse mortgages, a type of loan in which older homeowners borrow against the value of their house.

headline: Ephron’s Leukemia Was Uncommon and Complicated
text: The illness that claimed the life of Nora Ephron is an uncommon type of leukemia for which there are few treatments, medical experts said.

headline: For a Swim Couple, One Stays, One Goes
text: OMAHA — Ten minutes before Annie Chandler was due on the blocks for the 100-meter breaststroke final, she interrupted her prerace reverie to watch her fiancé, Matt Grevers, race for an Olympic berth in the 100-meter backstroke.

headline: Kentucky: Settlement Is Reached Over Site That Focused on Veterans’ College Benefits
text: Under a consumer protection settlement with 20 state attorneys general filed Wednesday in Frankfort, QuinStreet Inc. will turn over its GIBill.com Web site to the Department of Veterans Affairs and pay $2.5 million to the states involved. Attorney General Jack Conway of Kentucky, who announced the settlement, led a multistate investigation into the Web site, which was aimed at veterans for their education benefits, falsely giving the appearance that it was operated or endorsed by the government. Veterans have been the targets of aggressive recruiting by for-profit colleges, which are required to get at least 10 percent of their revenues from sources other than federal student loan or Pell grants. A loophole provides that veterans’ benefits count toward that 10 percent.

headline: A Newcomer Is Making Her Own Waves
text: OMAHA — As a first-time competitor at the Olympic trials, Breeja Larson faced a quandary. Should she act as if she had been here before or go ahead and try to get the autographs of all her favorite swimming stars?

headline: New Hampshire: Lawmakers Override Vetoes on Voting and Abortion Bills
text: The State Legislature on Wednesday overrode a veto by Gov. John Lynch of a bill requiring that individuals present a valid form of identification or sign an affidavit in order to vote. The list of acceptable forms of identifications will be narrowed in September 2013 to exclude student identification cards, and those who sign affidavits will be required to be photographed. The Legislature also overrode Mr. Lynch’s veto of a ban on the procedure known as partial-birth abortion. Overall, the state’s House and Senate overrode 6 of 13 vetoes on Wednesday; a veto on the House’s redistricting plan was overridden in March.

headline: After a Swimmer’s Disappointment Comes Hope
text: OMAHA — They were supposed to be the 55 minutes that validated Davis Tarwater’s decision to come out of retirement after failing to make the 2008 United States Olympic team.

headline: Activist Says Chinese Officials ‘Terribly Afraid’ of Rural Unrest
text: HONG KONG — Chen Guangcheng seems to be settling in nicely as a visiting scholar at New York University’s law school — a faculty apartment in Greenwich Village for him and his family, and courses in English, American history and law.

headline: Tata’s ‘Emo’ Offers No Glitz, but Plenty of Promise
text: A Tata Technologies electric vehicle called the “Emo,” showcased at a demonstration in a parking lot in Detroit, “symbolizes a philosophy of designing and marketing electric cars that is very different from that employed by Tesla, or for that matter Nissan or Ford,” Phil Patton writes for the Wheels blog.

headline: News Quiz | June 28, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: JPMorgan Trading Loss May Reach $9 Billion
text: Losses on JPMorgan Chase’s bungled trade could total as much as $9 billion, far exceeding earlier public estimates, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.

headline: Felda Shares Soar 20% on the Heels of $3.1 Billion I.P.O.
text: HONG KONG — Shares in Felda Global Ventures rose as much as 20 percent in their trading debut in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Thursday following the palm oil producer’s successful $3.1 billion initial public offering earlier this month.

headline: Just Bury Some Bodies
text: BONIYAR, Kashmir — Atta Mohamad Raja Khan said the officers promised him many things if he would just bury some bodies.

text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian insurgents fighting to topple President Bashar al-Assad struck at high-profile targets in the capital region on Thursday for the third time this week, demonstrating their increasing effectiveness and reach.

headline: A Manifesto for Economic Sense
text: As regular readers know, I’ve been arguing for a long time that policy makers have misunderstood the nature of our economic crisis, mistaking symptoms for causes, and responding in ways that make the situation worse. Richard Layard and I now have a manifesto laying out the essence of this case, and are asking other economists to sign on.

text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

text: Chris Gregory grew up in Puerto Rico and left to attend George Washington University. He started covering politics as an intern for The Hill newspaper and The Washington Post. Mr. Gregory, 22, is now a photography intern at The New York Times.

headline: South Korea to Sign Military Pact With Japan
text: SEOUL, South Korea — In a significant step toward overcoming lingering historical animosities with its former colonial master, the South Korean government has unexpectedly announced that it will sign a treaty with Japan on Friday to increase the sharing of classified military data on what analysts cite as two major common concerns: North Korea’s nuclear and missile threats and China’s growing military might.

headline: With Jews Like Us
text: HAIFA, Israel — A reporter friend calls me a “conference diva”: in the last seven days alone I have participated in three panels, all about American Jews’ relations with Israel.

headline: In New Jersey, Brewing an Alternative to Petroleum
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.J. — Walking into the research facility of Primus Green Energy is not unlike wandering onto the set of “Dr. Who.” Everywhere you look, there is plumbing, usually covered in multiple layers of shiny aluminum foil. The foil is hot, it’s festooned with hundreds of wires and it reeks of solvents.

headline: Russia Says Transition Is Needed in Syria but Cannot Be Imposed
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said on Thursday that Syria needed a period of political transition but reiterated Moscow’s resistance to any plan being imposed by the international community.

headline: How William Faulkner Tackled Race — and Freed the South From Itself
text: A poll of well over a hundred writers and critics, taken a few years back by Oxford American magazine, named William Faulkner’s “Absalom, Absalom!” the “greatest Southern novel ever written,” by a decisive margin — and the poll was conducted while looking back on a century in which a disproportionate number of the best American books were Southern — so to say that this novel requires no introduction is just to speak plainly.

headline: Get Him to the Fenugreek
text: No matter how accomplished you are in the kitchen, you always learn something when you cook with someone else — at least I always have. But it’s worth remembering that what you learn may be something other than what you thought you would.

headline: Building a Brand When You Can’t Afford an Ad Agency
text: I met Tito Beveridge, the man behind Tito’s Handmade Vodka, about 15 years ago when he first started making vodka in Austin, Tex. Thinking it would be great to do advertising work for an adult beverage company, I called him. He told me he couldn’t afford advertising, but he invited me out to his still — and I couldn’t resist visiting a maker of spirits during business hours.

headline: New Congressional Nominee Favors Subsidizing Private Schools
text: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, hot off primary night where he won the Democratic nomination for Congress, set off a controversy when he came out in favor of support for private and religious schools -- but not for vouchers.

headline: Petronas to Buy Progress Energy for $5.35 Billion
text: Petronas, the Malaysian state-owned oil and gas company, agreed on Thursday to buy Progress Energy Resources of Canada, the latest in a wave of energy deals.

headline: News Corporation’s Big Move: Murdoch Informs the Staff
text: News Corporation announced Thursday morning that it would spin off its publishing division from its entertainment unit and create two separate, publicly traded companies. Here is the memo Rupert Murdoch, News Corporation’s chairman and chief executive, sent to the company’s employees.

headline: Seeking, and Resisting, Vaccines
text: It’s hard to argue with the premise that in the United States, some parents take lightly their ability to vaccinate children against childhood diseases. Recent studies suggest that as many as 21 percent of parents in the U.S. are delaying or refusing some or all of the recommended early childhood vaccines. Schools in some areas — educated, upper-middle-class regions — have startlingly low vaccination rates: in one Washington State county, 72 percent of kindergartners and 89 percent of sixth graders are either not compliant with or exempt from vaccination requirements for school entry, and at a Bay Area Waldorf school I wrote about last year, only 23 percent of the incoming kindergarten class had been fully vaccinated.

headline: The Lady or the Teddy?
text: There is really only one joke in “Ted” — a toy bear comes to life and turns out to have a filthy mouth and a taste for weed — but the movie’s attempts at humor can nonetheless be sorted into a few distinct categories. There are jokes that are funny only because a stuffed bear says them, jokes that are not funny even though a stuffed bear says them and jokes that may or may not be funny because of Mark Wahlberg. Mila Kunis is also in the movie, but she can’t be funny because she’s a girl, and her job is to be amused, tolerant and pretty.

text: 11:39 a.m. | Updated Rupert Murdoch confirmed Thursday morning that News Corporation, his $54 billion media conglomerate, will proceed with a plan to divide the company in two — separating newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, The New York Post and The Times of London from the fast-growing entertainment unit.

text: Dear Diary: My father and I recently spent a lovely day in Manhattan. We saw a matinee performance by the New York City Ballet and met good friends for an early dinner on the Upper West Side.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: ‘Wow the World as Two,’ and Romeo in Stubble
text: With a memo to the staff Thursday morning, Rupert Murdoch confirmed that News Corporation, the company he built from a single Australian newspaper, would split into two — as a publishing company and an entertainment company. In his memo he was seemingly ecstatic — “we will wow the world as two, as opposed to merely one.” Yet Mr. Murdoch was reluctant to make the move, Amy Chozick writes, and needed much persuasion. She writes about the logic that carried the day:

headline: Remembering Nora Ephron, a Reporter at Heart
text: It was hard to resist a smile — a very slight smile, while keeping tears in check — on hearing Tuesday night that Nora Ephron had died, of an illness she hid from almost everyone.

headline: A Phone With Google Wallet and $25 Cash
text: The announcement that Virgin Mobile would carry the iPhone on a no-contract plan overshadowed another nifty bit of technology the carrier was offering.

headline: Thursday Reading: How Foul Is Your Favorite Beach?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Supreme Court Health Care Decision Live Updates
text: The Supreme Court is expected to announce on Thursday morning its decision on the health care overhaul that President Obama signed into law in 2010. The Times is covering the decision and providing live updates, analysis and reaction from around the country. Follow along on the live dashboard and on Twitter (@nytlive).

headline: Larry King Takes His Star Power to Comic-Con
text: The Hub TV Network may not have huge ratings, but it certainly has a sense of humor: Larry King will be one of the children’s cable channel’s star attractions this year at the pop culture convention known as Comic-Con.

headline: Errani Keeps Winning
text: WIMBLEDON, England — As she prepared to serve, Sara Errani of Italy looked skyward on Thursday morning and squinted at an unexpected sight, sunshine, at the All England Lawn Tennis Club.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: It’s all about quality, not quantity: Mark Bittman explains a new Harvard University study suggesting that the kind of calories consumed is more significant than the sheer number, in losing weight — because the body handles highly processed carbohydrates less efficiently. So low-calorie diets (whole grains, fruits and veggies) are less effective than a low-glycemic-index diet (blood-sugar-regulation plans like the Zone diet and Nutrisystem). – Glenn Collins

headline: Barclays Chief Faces Political Firestorm
text: The Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., faced a political backlash on Thursday, a day after the British bank agreed to pay more than $450 million to settle accusations that it had attempted to manipulate key interest rates.

headline: Goffin Advances to Third Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — David Goffin of Belgium, who gained special acclaim at the French Open for his unexpected run of victories, defeated Jesse Levine of the United States on Thursday to advance to the third round at the All England Lawn Tennis Club.

headline: A Low-Key Transition for ‘Today’ Hosts
text: 11:54 p.m. | Updated On Friday morning, Savannah Guthrie is scheduled to be sitting beside Matt Lauer on the “Today” show — and once again, NBC’s ability to pull off talent transitions will be put to the test.

headline: Will Manmohan Singh Shake Up the Finance Ministry Again?
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, who took charge of the Ministry of Finance earlier this week, delivered a call to arms of sorts to the mandarins at the ministry, telling them that they needed to “restart the Indian growth story” and revive the economy’s “animal spirit.”

headline: Image of the Day: June 28
text: Indian prisoner released by Pakistan returns to India after 31 years.

headline: An Armchair Revolution, and Barbie, Too
text: IT was the video that went viral before there was such a thing as viral video. Todd Haynes’s “Superstar,” released in 1987, was a darkly campy and experimental biopic about Karen Carpenter, who rose to fame with her brother, Richard, in the ’70s pop group the Carpenters, and who fought a protracted battle with anorexia nervosa before her death at 32 in 1983. In the film characters were portrayed by plastic dolls, including Barbies, that looked as if they’d been plucked from a garage-sale free bin. Running 43 minutes, “Superstar” was a phenomenon, but not at the multiplex. It was shown primarily in galleries, museums and clubs, though it had a theatrical life at some repertory houses. Eventually it was copied and widely traded on bootleg VHS tapes, available for rent at alternative video stores across the country.

headline: Tanglewood’s Archival Magic Still Casts a Spell
text: THE magic of Tanglewood, the summer festival in western Massachusetts, has many parts. There is the music of course, this being the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. There is the beauty of the surroundings, both on the meticulously maintained campus in the quaint town of Lenox and all around in the Berkshire Hills.

headline: ‘Gasland’ Filmmaker Takes on Cuomo and ‘Dot.FlatEarth’
text: Josh Fox, the filmmaker whose “Gasland” documentary powerfully influenced debates about gas extraction from shale deposits, has started a conversation with me related to his new short video, “The Sky is Pink,” and my post supporting New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s signaled plans for the state’s gas resource.

headline: Mercury Sickens Adirondacks Loons
text: Many see New York State’s six-million-acre Adirondack Park as a place of respite where you go to gulp down the cool air and hear loon calls echoing through the hills. The landscape is unmarred, wild.

headline: Most Borrowers Still Wary of Reverse Mortgages
text: As my colleague Edward Wyatt wrote Thursday, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is looking into whether more regulation is needed of reverse mortgages — special loans that allow homeowners 62 or older to borrow against the equity in their houses, without making monthly payments.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Health Care Law, 5-4, in Victory for Obama
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld President Obama’s health care overhaul law, saying its requirement that most Americans obtain insurance or pay a penalty was authorized by Congress’s power to levy taxes. The vote was 5 to 4, with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. joining the court’s four more liberal members.

headline: Lying About Earning War Medals Is Protected Speech, Justices Rule
text: A divided Supreme Court on Thursday overturned a law that made it a crime to lie about having earned a military decoration, saying that the act was an unconstitutional infringement on free speech.

headline: London Theater Journal: Going in Circles
text: Whoosh. There’s nothing like an actor’s pumping legs to stir up a breeze on a summer night. Make that legions of actors’ legs, running and running and running in circles through (and at eye level with) much of the audience at the Gielgud Theater, where “Chariots of Fire” is now in residence.

headline: Chief of Vivendi Resigns After Strategy Dispute
text: PARIS — Jean-Bernard Lévy stepped down as chief executive of Vivendi, the French media and telecommunications conglomerate, on Thursday after losing a boardroom battle over strategy. The move prompted speculation about a possible breakup of the company.

headline: Sistine Chapel Choir to Sing With Westminster Abbey Choir
text: For the first time since its founding more than 500 years ago, the Sistine Chapel Choir will sing as a single chorus with another choir. But not just any group of voices: the Westminster Abbey Choir, a much older body that, at least since the16th century, has been a symbol of the Church of England’s separation from the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: The Supreme Court Decision on Obama’s Health Care Law
text: The Supreme Court largely let stand President Obama’s health care overhaul, affirming the central legislative pillar of his term.

headline: Inspectors Find No Stowaways on Cargo Vessel
text: A day after the Department of Homeland Security examined a cargo vessel at Port Newark in New Jersey on the suspicion that it contained stowaways, federal officials said on Thursday that no one had been found.

text: David Beckham revealed Thursday that he would not be picked for Britain’s soccer team for this summer’s London Olympics.

headline: Business Day Live: Google’s Route to ‘Made in the U.S.’

headline: Too Important to Be Left to the Generals
text: ISTANBUL – Having been introduced to international diplomacy by the Marx Brothers in “Duck Soup,” I cannot but view Turkey’s current crisis with Syria with unease. In that 1933 film, Groucho (aka Rufus T. Firefly) swaps finely tuned insults with the ambassador of Sylvania until he famously cries: “This means war!” When the ambassador pleads that he will do anything to avoid conflict, Firefly replies: “I’ve already paid a month’s rent on the battlefield.”

headline: How Might the Health Ruling Play in November?

headline: Soho Rep Extends Production of ‘Uncle Vanya’
text: Not one but two productions of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya” are among the hottest theater tickets of the summer in New York.

headline: Tides Canada Stands Up to Government Critics
text: A charitable foundation devoted to environmental causes that has been vilified by politicians in Canada’s governing Conservative Party has struck back, outlining its finances and accusing the politicians of trying to silence dissent.

headline: On the Hill, Relief for Democrats and Repeal Pledges From Republicans
text: 12:04 p.m. | Updated Republicans reacting to the Supreme Court’s decision on the health care law Thursday were quick to seize on two themes: that they have the legislative prowess to undo the law themselves, and that the court had revealed that the individual mandate at the center of the law was the tax that Democrats insisted all long it was not.

headline: David Beckham Will Not Be on British Olympic Team
text: David Beckham revealed Wednesday that he would not be picked for Britain’s soccer team for this summer’s London Olympics, Andrew Das reports on the 2012 London Olympics blog. “Everyone knows how much playing for my country has always meant to me, so I would have been honored to have been part of this unique Team GB squad,” Beckham said in a statement to Britain’s Press Association. Read the full story here.
