headline: Despite End-of-Year Confusion, Attendance Was on Par With Last Year
text: According to Department of Education officials, attendance on Wednesday was at 79.4 percent, a mere .2 percentage points lower than the rate for the last day of school in 2011 -- despite the fact that many schools had canceled classes on Monday and Tuesday because the city had clocked none of its allotted snow days this year.

headline: Spreading Joy of Swimming, Ex-Olympian Finds It Again
text: OMAHA — The black Imagine Swimming jacket, worn over a gold California swimming and diving T-shirt, covered Anthony Ervin’s heavily tattooed arms. The glasses and the wispy facial stubble gave Ervin more the look of a graduate student, which he is, than of the other facets of his personality — guitarist, swimming instructor, thoughtful individualist who, to his own surprise and wonder, finds himself back in the pool after years away.

headline: Ruling Likely to Prompt Re-evaluation of Roberts
text: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. surprised many on Thursday by providing the crucial fifth vote for upholding President Obama’s health care law. To those on the left who viewed him as an ideologue eager to pull the court to the right, the ruling will begin a re-examination of Chief Justice Roberts’s style and legacy, as it will for those on the right who considered the law unconstitutional and relied on him to make that point.

headline: Life, Interrupted: My Incanceration
text: The first time I was hospitalized after my cancer diagnosis — one year ago this month — I was placed in isolation in a drab room where the windows didn’t open. An electronic bracelet was strapped to my wrist, and I was issued a backless hospital gown. A triple-lumen catheter was surgically implanted in my chest to create a central line through which chemotherapy and fluids would be administered. I was all tied up, with both limbs connected to a monitor holding a ring of hanging IV bags.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names New Director
text: Morgan Stanley said on Thursday that Robert H. Herz, a former chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, has been elected to its board of directors.

headline: Health Care Ruling: The Wordle
text: For readers who want to get a flavor of the language and themes in today’s Supreme Court ruling without reading all 193 pages, here’s a word cloud showing the most commonly used terms:

headline: Who Should the Knicks Pick?
text: Having dealt away their first-round draft pick in the 2010 Tracy McGrady trade, the Knicks’ hopes for adding depth will now have to be realized in the second round. But while rotation-ready players are seldom found outside the top 30, the past two drafts have seen the Knicks walk away with a pair of finds – Landry Fields (2010) and Josh Harrellson (2011) – who both ended up making rookie year contributions.

headline: Supreme Court Rules on Health Care
text: We present this special edition of 6 Q’s About the News in the wake of Thursday’s Supreme Court ruling.

headline: Roberts Hits the Reset Button
text: The Supreme Court’s decision upholding virtually all of the health care reform law (with the exception of a provision on Medicaid that does not really have much practical impact) is a great development, first of all, for Americans. The Affordable Care Act will provide insurance for tens of millions of working people and it will eventually help rationalize and bring down the costs of health care for everyone. This is a huge victory for President Obama at a critical time and a big loss for the right.

headline: Romney Says He Will ‘Repeal Obamacare’ if Elected
text: 12:31 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney declared Thursday that he would “act to repeal Obamacare” if he was elected president, saying that he agreed with the dissenting justices in the Supreme Court ruling on Thursday.

headline: Snoop Dogg Is Said to Be Detained by Norwegian Customs Officials
text: The Norwegian press is reporting that Snoop Dogg was briefly detained when he entered Norway on Thursday for carrying marijuana and a large amount of cash, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Britain, Amid Austerity, Turns Rather Cutthroat
text: LONDON

headline: Catching Running Partner, With a Chance to Pass
text: EUGENE, Ore. — About a year ago, as Jeneba Tarmoh was wrapping up her running career at Texas A&M, she conferred with her coaches and family about where she should continue her training. Then her phone rang.

headline: My Vegan Marathon
text: Nine years ago, when I trained for my first marathon, I did everything by the book. I built my mileage over the course of 18 weeks; I stretched, I rested on the days I was supposed to rest, and I ate everything the running books told me to eat: yogurt smoothies in the mornings, lunches of fruit, cheese and crackers; dinners of whole grains and vegetables, along with turkey, skinless chicken and fish.

headline: The Future, in a Past Life
text: Back in 1989, the publishing company then known as E.P. Dutton was an old-fashioned kind of place. Wide-sashed windows opened to the weather; an orange carpet was duct-taped together where it had frayed; the telex machine buzzed and spit out missives from abroad. I was a young editor, newly enough promoted to still be dazzled by lunches with agents who drank me under the table and left me with the check.

headline: Left for Dead in Virginia
text: George T. Perkins and his Union comrades breathed a collective sigh of relief on the afternoon of June 27, 1862. Positioned behind breastworks along a stretch of pinewoods on the battlefield of Gaines’s Mill, they listened as the pounding of artillery and rattling of musketry on their left rose and faded. Then another din on their right, followed by three Yankee huzzahs.

headline: The Remarkable Comeback of Brian Baker
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Jarkko Nieminen called it “a great story” and “one of the most impressive comebacks, for sure.” And then he was forced to witness the Brian Baker phenomenon from up close – or rather unfortunately for him, from the other side of the net. Nieminen lingered on Court 9 for all of 80 minutes Thursday, becoming the latest victim vanquished by Baker on his improbable ascent.

headline: Private Equity Firms See a Brighter 2012
text: Private equity firms are more bullish about investment opportunities in 2012 than they were in 2011, but they don’t expect a surge in capital raising this year.

headline: Biofluorescence Under Blue Lights
text: Vincent Pieribone is a neuroscientist at the John B. Pierce Laboratory/Yale School of Medicine studying biofluorescent molecules in the Solomon Islands. In his laboratory, he uses these molecules in biomedical research.

headline: John Roberts’s Political Decision
text: During the run-up to this morning’s Supreme Court health care ruling, liberals insisted over and over again that a decision overturning Obamacare would represently a nakedly “political” move by the court’s conservatives, rather than a decision motivated by an honest, principled interpretation of the Constitution and the law. Which makes it ironic that — upon first reading, at least — Obamacare seems to have been saved by Chief Justice Roberts’s decision to put political considerations ahead of a straightforward reading of the health care bill.

headline: In Health Care Ruling, Investors See a Mixed Blessing
text: Hospitals will gain millions of paying customers. Insurers, by contrast, could face crimped profits from restrictive rules. Medical device and pharmaceutical companies will bear new taxes and other higher payouts, but they were already expecting such costs.

headline: Obama Praises Court’s Decision
text: President Obama hailed the Supreme Court’s decision on the Affordable Care Act, saying the politically divisive measure will improve health care for millions of Americans who have insurance and expand coverage to millions who do not.

headline: Business Day Live | Building in America
text: June 28, 2012 — John Markoff reports on the manufacturing of the Google Nexus Q in the United States.

headline: Video: Building in America
text: John Markoff reports on the manufacturing of the Google Nexus Q in the United States.

headline: Brazil’s Start-Up Baby Boom
text: SAO PAULO — There is something of a baby boom going on in Brazil’s burgeoning e-commerce sector.

headline: G.O.P. Vowing to Take Battle Over Health Care Law Into November
text: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney and other Republicans who oppose the health care law are looking ahead to one remaining avenue of appeal: the ballot box in November.

headline: Conditions Improve Slightly in Fighting Colorado Wildfires
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — Helped by cooler temperatures and lighter winds, fire officials said Thursday morning that they hoped to gain more control over the Waldo Canyon Fire burning around Colorado Springs. Wind and heat had earlier fueled the furious wildfire burning in the foothills around Colorado’s second-largest city, first roaring past containment lines and forcing tens of thousands of residents to flee, chased by billowing smoke, blowing ash and fear that their homes might burn to the ground. At a news conference Thursday morning, officials said 5 percent of the fire was contained, though they expected that number to grow significantly by the end of the day.

headline: In Health Ruling, Relief for Obama but a Blow to Conventional Wisdom
text: The Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 decision on Thursday to uphold most of President Obama’s health care law represents a hurdle cleared for Mr. Obama. He had been at risk of seeing his most ambitious policy initiative — and most expensive, in terms of the political capital it required — neutered oroverturned by the court.

headline: In a Morning Media Blitz, Murdoch Defends His Newspaper Assets
text: Rupert Murdoch went on a rare publicity blitz on Thursday to defend News Corporation’s decision to split the company’s newspapers from its entertainment assets.

headline: Springsteen Agrees to Be 2013 MusiCare Person of the Year
text: Bruce Springsteen has agreed to be the 2013 MusiCares Person of the Year and will be honored at an award ceremony and concert to be held in Los Angeles on Feb. 8, two days before the Grammy Awards. Mr. Springsteen is being recognized not just for his career as one of rock’s most electric performers and songwriters, but also for his philanthropy, said Neil Portnow, the president of the Recording Academy, who called the New Jersey rocker a “Renaissance artist of our time, a national treasure and an exemplary humanitarian.”

text: Paris

headline: Gentlemen Racers’ 1939 Lagonda Visits Goodwood Before Auction
text: Barring access to the resources of the big factory teams, it is all but unimaginable to field a racecar, let alone have it qualify, for the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

headline: Reaction to Stolen Valor Ruling
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday overturned a federal law that made it illegal to lie about being a decorated war veteran, saying that the law was an unconstitutional infringement on free speech.

headline: Paulson Talks Returns, Regret and Retirement in New Profile
text: Appearing on the forthcoming cover of Bloomberg Businessweek is a close-up of the hedge fund titan John A. Paulson. Plastered over his face is a sticky note with the words “The Big Loser.”

headline: As Top Players Advance, Equal Pay Discussion Remains
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Andy Murray's obstacle course at the All England Club began in earnest on Thursday as he managed to solve the enormous riddle of Ivo Karlovic on Centre Court.

text: What book is on your night stand now?

text: Duncan Irving of The Goal blog provided live coverage of today’s Euro 2012 semifinal game between Germany and Italy. Continue reading to see how the match unfolded.

headline: Stephanie J. Block, Will Chase Join the Revival of ‘Edwin Drood’
text: In addition to the previously announced Chita Rivera, the Roundabout Theater Company’s coming Broadway revival of Rupert Holmes’s musical “The Mystery of Edwin Drood” will also star Stephanie J. Block (“Anything Goes”), Will Chase (NBC’s “Smash”), and Tony winner Jim Norton (“The Seafarer,” “Finian’s Rainbow”), the theater announced on Thursday.

headline: Let the Memes Begin …
text: Gary He’s take on CNN’s initial wrong call on the Supreme Court ruling on the health care law.

headline: House Finds Holder in Contempt Over Inquiry on Guns
text: WASHINGTON — The Republican-led House of Representatives on Thursday voted to hold Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in contempt for failing to disclose internal Justice Department documents in response to a subpoena. It was the first time in American history that Congress has imposed the sanction on a sitting member of a president’s cabinet.

headline: Car Rentals for the ‘Eco-Curious’
text: Electric car sales have so far ranged from disappointing to dismal. But Lee Broughton, head of corporate sustainability for Enterprise Holdings, the parent of Enterprise, National and Alamo, has an idea about how they might be improved: by enlisting an American demographic he calls the “urban eco-curious.”

headline: TimesCast Politics: Health Care Decision
text: The details, the politics and reaction from social media as the Supreme Court allows the health care law to largely stand.

headline: Flavor Is Price of Scarlet Hue of Tomatoes, Study Finds
text: Plant geneticists say they have discovered an answer to a near-universal question: Why are tomatoes usually so tasteless?

headline: Health Spending Stopped Growing — in Other Rich Countries
text: In 2010, health care spending stopped growing altogether across the member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, according to a report released Thursday.

headline: Former Knicks Big Man Cummings Dead at 55
text: 10:21 p.m. | Updated  Read Cummings’s obituary here.

headline: Good News, Bad News
text: News Corporation confirmed today that it would split in two, with newspapers (the part hated by Wall Street) in one company and television (the part Wall Street loves) in the other.

headline: Despite Change in Oscar Rules, DocuWeeks Program Is Set
text: LOS ANGELES — While the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science tries out new rules for its documentary Oscars, DocuWeeks — a showcase that helps documentarians without commercial distribution qualify for the awards — is forging ahead. The International Documentary Association, which sponsors DocuWeeks, said this year’s program would include 17 feature films and 11 shorts.

headline: An Important New Limit on the Commerce Clause
text: Broccoli carried the day.

headline: Let Them Climb Trees (and Fall)
text: Recently, my son surprised me when he came shuffling into our house mumbling about life being unfair. When I asked him what was going on, he responded: “It’s not fair! I climb those trees all the time. Now she’s mad at me and I can’t climb anymore!”

headline: Ruling Brings Relief at a Virginia Clinic
text: LEESBURG, Va. — There were no shouts, no whoops of joy. But the fortunes of the patients at the Loudoun Community Health Center quietly changed on Thursday morning when the Supreme Court ruled to uphold the Affordable Care Act.

headline: London Theater Journal: Meeting the Faces in the Crowd
text: Be careful of what you say to strangers on the streets. Your words may well come back to haunt you some day. Or, really, any minute now.

headline: There’s No Crying in Media-League Softball
text: Our story begins one steamy evening last August, on the fertile lowlands of Central Park’s public fields, as dusk settled and the promise of the Tap a Keg summoned, and The New York Times Magazine’s ragtag softball team’s once-commanding lead against its archrival, The New Yorker, evaporated in the game’s final inning. As the sun set, what once appeared a sure win ended in a tie.

headline: Chasing the Sockeye Salmon Migration
text: In early summer, the biggest run of wild salmon left in the world reaches its peak. The sockeye salmon migration of Bristol Bay, Alaska, can number more than 40 million fish; the resulting fishing industry is worth more than $400 million. The award-winning author (and Times contributor) Paul Greenberg, author of the New York Times bestseller “Four Fish,” is blogging via satellite as he travels down the Stuyahok River with the Alaska guide and longtime outdoorsman Mark Rutherford.

headline: With Feed-In Financing, Modest Solar Projects  for Long Island
text: The Long Island Power Authority approved a new program on Thursday to encourage developers to build medium-scale solar projects using a financing mechanism, the feed-in tariff, that has resulted in both booms and busts overseas.

headline: Brown Finishes 12th, and Couldn’t Be Happier
text: OMAHA — Jack Brown tied for 12th in the preliminaries of the 200-meter breaststroke on Thursday. Never mind the chance to make his first United States Olympic team, Brown had much to be proud about in advancing to the semifinals.

headline: 36 Hours in Turin, Italy
text: WHEN it comes to urban reputations, being home to the Shroud of Turin and the headquarters of Fiat isn’t a lot to coast on. But Turin, Italy’s fourth-largest city, also has the elegant cafe culture of Trieste by day and the vibrant aperitivo scene of Milan by night, all while being nestled in Piedmont, arguably the finest food and wine region in Italy. Recently, the city inaugurated a stadium for the popular Juventus soccer club and reopened a pair of stellar museums highlighting the city’s multifaceted importance throughout Italy’s history. Turin, it seems, is revving its engine.

headline: Touring Turin, Italy
text: Where Italy stretches toward France, walk among palaces and visit a giant temple to food.

headline: Chief Curator to Leave Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles
text: Paul Schimmel, the chief curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, and one of the most respected authorities on postwar Los Angeles art, is leaving the museum, according to its board.

headline: Ex-Leader of Bosnian Serbs Fails to Get War Crimes Trial Halted
text: PARIS — Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb psychiatrist who became a nationalist wartime leader, has failed in his bid to get his war crimes trial in The Hague halted and have all charges thrown out for lack of sufficient evidence. But the United Nations judges hearing his case have dropped one of the two counts of genocide against him, the court announced Thursday.

headline: A Free Checking Account Pioneer Brings It Back
text: Now that regulations have crimped the fees that banks can earn from debit card purchases, “free” checking accounts are a thing of the past — right?

headline: This Could Be the Foodiest School in New York
text: Many public schools incorporate food — its production, nutritional value and place in the larger culture — into their curriculums, And at certain private schools lunchtime can include braised meats and Korean meatloaf. But at P.S. 150, a school of fewer than 200 students in TriBeCa, an appreciation for food is an integral part of student life, interwoven into the culture of the school and shared by the families who send their children there, many of whom have sophisticated palettes themselves.

text: President Obama initially heard that the Supreme Court had overturned a crucial plank of his landmark health care act before the White House counsel, Kathy Ruemmler, flashed the president a two-thumbs-up sign to indicate it had actually been upheld.

headline: New York Led Country in Population Growth Since 2010 Census
text: New York began the second decade of the 21st century with a growth spurt, adding more people than any other city in the country in the 15 months ending July 1, 2011, and outpacing population gains in its neighboring suburbs, the Census Bureau estimated on Thursday.

headline: Cravath Names a New Leader
text: The New York law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore announced on Thursday that it had elected C. Allen Parker as its next chief, succeeding Evan R. Chesler, who will become chairman.

headline: New Ratmansky Work to Have Debut at American Ballet Theater’s Fall City Center Season
text: American Ballet Theater’s 2012 fall season at New York City Center, which runs from Oct. 16 to 20, will include the premiere of a new work by Alexei Ratmansky, the company’s artist in residence, Ballet Theater said.

headline: Getting Names Right? Harder Than It Sounds
text: WIMBLEDON, England — If there are times when tennis officials and announcers warrant some sympathy, then the first few days of a major tournament like Wimbledon would be one of them. Hundreds of matches in singles and doubles featuring players from Argentina to Uzbekistan are a linguistic gantlet of the highest order. On the women’s side alone, there were first-round contests between Scheepers and Shvedova, Gajdosova and Zaniewska, and Foretz Gacon and Niculescu.

headline: Uncertainty Over States and Medicaid Expansion
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Thursday that a huge expansion of Medicaid envisioned in the 2010 health care law was an option, not a mandate, for states. Experts disagreed on whether states would take the option, one of the most important questions created by the court’s decision.

headline: Lincoln Center Pledges to Make Avery Fisher Hall More Accessible
text: Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center will become more accessible to people with disabilities under a court settlement reached Wednesday between the performing arts center and the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan.

headline: Among Doctors, Too, Women Are Paid Less
text: Brilliant and hard-working, my younger colleague had just returned from delivering one of the main talks at a national medical meeting. All of us viewed the invitation to speak as an acknowledgment of her great potential, so when I asked her about the conference, I expected her to bubble over about the accolades she’d heard and the plum job offers she’d received from competing medical centers.

headline: Republicans Wage Repeal Campaign on Social Media
text: Soon after the Supreme Court ruling on President Obama’s health care law was announced, Republican leaders took to Twitter with a new hashtag, #fullrepeal, aimed at helping to focus the conversation on ousting Mr. Obama in November and reversing the law.

headline: Lichtenstein’s Gatekeeper Uses Her Key
text: SOME time in the mid 1970s Dorothy Lichtenstein stopped by her husband’s studio on the Bowery one day after lunch, expecting to find him at work on a new painting.

headline: ‘Roy Lichtenstein: A Retrospective’
text: A look at works on view at the Art Institute of Chicago.

headline: A Few Good Ideas for Products
text: A pitch is a news item, new product announcement or something else a corporate public relations person hopes to see covered in the media. Like all columnists, I get bombarded by them every week.

headline: Q&A: Keeping the PC Safe on the Cheap
text: Q.

headline: Health Care Fight Moves to Senate Races
text: Much of the political chatter of the day has been about the impact of the Supreme Court’s ruling on the presidential campaign. But the court’s decision to let stand President Obama’s health care plan may hold even more import in the battle for control of the Senate.

headline: The Whole World, Stitched and Patched
text: There’s a bittersweet addition to the Museum of Modern Art’s sculpture garden this summer. Half hidden in the shade of a tree, it’s a life-size bronze statue of a gaunt-looking guy holding a fountainlike hose in one hand. When water spraying from it hits his head, steam rises, as if his brain were sizzling.

headline: Just One Look | Akris
text: The men’s shows may be raging in Paris, but in New York it’s still about women’s resort. Akris’s creative director Albert Kriemler chartered a nautical escape with tailored separates in double-faced cashmeres, cotton maxiskirts and slouchy, cocoonlike slickers leading the way. The inspiration behind the collection: Prince Albert I of Monaco’s oceanic explorations aboard his yacht, Princesse Alice. Moonlight reflections and swimmers find their way onto dresses and separates as prints. Here, the out-at-sea scene on an elegant long-sleeve top meets its matching shorts without missing a beat.

headline: How the Justices Ruled on the Health Care Law
text: The Supreme Court largely let the health care overhaul stand, upholding the individual mandate and limiting the Medicaid provision.

headline: Political Cartoon Taking Aim at Pipeline Company Is Pulled
Ford Motor, Citing Europe’s Woes, Says Foreign Losses to Triple in Quarter
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Europe’s economic woes are taking a much bigger bite out of the profits of Ford Motor, which until now has largely avoided the hefty losses that have dragged down the profits of many of its rivals.

headline: In Case Against Philip Falcone, a Warning to Others
text: Hedge fund managers have long flown underneath the radar, doing pretty much as they pleased with little oversight from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Securities fraud charges filed against Philip Falcone and his firm, Harbinger Capital Partners, are a warning that funds can now expect the same scrutiny that Wall Street banks and brokerage firms receive.

headline: Double Scotch Time
text: Yes, I’m on vacation. And I’ve tried not to think about Scotus, even though I was campaigning for universal health care long before it was fashionable. But I did have a feeling of dread in the pit of my stomach this morning, all the same.

headline: Romney’s Call to Arms
text: Mitt Romney looked a little shaken when he faced the cameras this morning to comment on the Supreme Court’s decision upholding the Affordable Care Act. Having thrown out his preferred speech thanking the court for rejecting the law, he didn’t seem to have much of a backup other than a call to arms for conservative voters.

headline: Village Roadshow, Supplier of Movies to Warner Brothers, Gets New Financing
text: LOS ANGELES — Village Roadshow Entertainment, one of the primary suppliers of movies to Warner Brothers, on Thursday said it had raised $380 million in new capital — a modest deal as Hollywood money goes, but one that has important implications.

headline: Court Denies City's Revocation of Williamsburg School's Charter
text: UPDATED | In a ruling announced on Thursday, Judge Ellen M. Spodek of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn wrote that the city's decision this year to revoke Williamsburg Charter High School's charter, despite having renewed it in 2009, was "arbitrary and capricious" and "not corroborated by any policy, regulation or protocol established by the D.O.E."

headline: HIV in the Mountain Kingdom
text: Jordan Schermerhorn, a recent graduate of Rice University, is the 2012 “Win A Trip” winner. She is currently traveling with Nick through parts of southern Africa. In her first post, she writes about HIV treatment in Lesotho.

headline: Readers React to Surveillance Software for Parents
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Somini Sengupta wrote about software and services that let parents keep tabs on their children’s activities online. The article sparked a spirited conversation among Times readers, who were largely split into two camps: those who think monitoring will damage the trust between parents and their children, and those who feel that the Internet raises new challenges that require new tools. Here is a sampling of what people are saying. (Some of these comments are excerpts from longer passages.)

headline: Funds and Allies Defend the Buck
text: Here’s a clever idea.

headline: Caitlin & Robert
text: Caitlin Kelly and Robert Marcoux met Shanghai, China but they both returned to the United States to receive MBA degrees. Their relationship deepened at school and they decided to marry.

headline: Again, Numbers Are Down in Annual Goose Roundup
text: Updated, 4:56 p.m. | The government’s annual roundup and slaughter of Canada geese from city parks is under way, and once again, the numbers are down this year, indicating the success of past years’ efforts to control the goose population.

headline: What the Health Care Ruling Means for You
text: Now that the Supreme Court has upheld most of President Obama’s  health care law, you may be looking for a little refresher on what it all means for you and your wallet.

headline: Lifetime Achievement Award for a Throwback Coach
text: EUGENE, Ore. — In the stands here is Al Buehler, a retired Olympic and Duke University track coach known for his wide-brimmed hat and long career. On Wednesday night, Buehler took center stage and received a lifetime achievement award from USA Track and Field, the national governing body for the sport. He is also the subject of a documentary film and a book coming out this summer.

headline: Producer Says He Still Intends to Bring Ephron Play to Broadway
text: One of the theater producers aiming Nora Ephron’s new play “Lucky Guy” for Broadway confirmed on Thursday that he is going forward with the show, a bio-drama about the New York newspaper columnist Mike McAlary. Ms. Ephron, a celebrated humorist and Oscar-nominated screenwriter, died on Tuesday at the age of 71 from pneumonia brought on by acute myeloid leukemia.

headline: How to be a YouTube Celebrity
text: A mash-up of advice from the people who know YouTube best: the amateurs.

headline: On YouTube, Amateur Is the New Pro
text: A kid from Nebraska shows up in New York City to make it big. This kid was Bryan Odell, a 21-year-old college dropout who lived with his parents. Gangly, with curly blond hair, he looked and talked­ as if he arrived straight from central casting. (“I was just a kid from Nebraska,” he says.) But central casting had nothing to do with it. As an aspiring YouTuber, he cast himself.

headline: Hot Kitchen
text: Inside the unpretentious Sichuanese restaurant in the East Village.

headline: Digital Notes: Another Jolt to U.S. Case Against Megaupload
text: A New Zealand judge has dealt yet another setback to the United States in its case against the file-sharing site Megaupload, and this time it’s a big one: the search warrants used to carry out a raid on the service were found to be illegal.

headline: Second Thoughts on a Hookup
text: I am a single gay man in a city full of gay men, and I’m not having enough sex. So I downloaded the Grindr app to find guys near me who are looking for quick sex. The problem is, after I find a promising guy and we meet for a date, I feel awkward launching right into sex. So I beg off, and the other guy tends to get angry. Any ideas about what to say to end things on a nicer note? Anonymous, New York

headline: Knicks’ Pick Is Likely to Stay Overseas
text: The Knicks looked to the future Thursday on draft night, selecting Kostas Papanikolaou of Greece with the 48th overall pick. It was a decision that disappointed many fans because Papanikolaou, a 6-foot-8 forward, will probably play overseas for at least two years.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Washington, Syria, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

headline: Puccini’s Spending His Summer in the Park
text: Opera isn’t cheap to produce, so it’s not easy to present free. A couple of years ago the Metropolitan Opera ended its longstanding tradition of offering, gratis, live performances of full operas in concert in city parks; it replaced them with recitals featuring rising singers.

headline: Rushing to Report the Health Ruling, and Getting It Wrong
text: The national news media mostly got it right on Thursday in reporting the Supreme Court’s decision to uphold President Obama’s health care overhaul law. But the cable news channels CNN and Fox News initially got it wrong, causing a day’s worth of consternation and second-guessing.

headline: Burmese Opposition Leader Finds Support as Her European Tour Ends
text: PARIS — The Burmese opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi ended a triumphant two-week European tour on Thursday evening after lining up assurances of support for a democratic transition in Myanmar and receiving honors and accolades usually reserved for heads of state.

headline: In a New Locale, He Has the Same Familiar Croon
text: “Show rooms keep closing behind me, but I just keep moving,” the singer Jack Jones remarked near the end of his show at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening, naming two fabled but vanished Las Vegas lounges. In New York City, Mr. Jones, until this year, had made an annual appearance at the now closed Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel. He has since moved 17 blocks uptown, and from the West Side to the East, for a too-short run at Feinstein’s.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Health Care Decision
text: David Leonhardt discusses the details of the Supreme Court’s ruling on President Obama’s health care law, Jim Rutenberg analyzes the political implications of the rulings and BuzzFeed’s Ben Smith recaps the social media’s discussion.

headline: Less May Be More for 3-D TV
text: StreamTV NetworksThis is precisely what is wrong with the marketing of 3-D TV.

headline: Stylish Deconstruction, in a Flow of Movement and Stillness
text: At several points in her hourlong solo recital at the Joyce Theater this week, Shantala Shivalingappa keeps her back to the audience while continuing to dance. One such sequence occurs in the third of her four dances, “Shift,” which she choreographed. Those in the audience who are acquainted with Indian dance may recognize some gestures and phrases: the hand, held out with fingers splayed like an open fan, is moved in an arc sideways, and the eyes, torso and legs all follow it.

headline: Bankruptcy Court Gives Blessing to Philadelphia Orchestra Reorganization
text: The Philadelphia Orchestra, which filed for bankruptcy last year, jolting the classical music world, announced on Thursday that its reorganization plan had been approved by a federal bankruptcy court and that it expects to emerge from Chapter 11 by the end of July.

headline: 20th-Century Flashbacks: Barrelhouse and a Conn-O-Sax
text: Richard Auldon Clark’s Manhattan Chamber Orchestra can be counted on to present entertaining programs of accessible contemporary works, with occasional glances at the repertory’s quirky mavericks to keep the programs fresh, and an emphasis on American composers. But you never know quite what form the ensemble will take until its players file out on stage.

headline: Military Contractors Are Fined Over Aid to China
text: WASHINGTON — A Canadian subsidiary of the Connecticut-based military contractor the United Technologies Corporation pleaded guilty on Thursday to federal charges that it had illegally helped the Chinese government develop an attack helicopter now in service there.

headline: P.J. Clarke’s Drops a Top Bartender
text: 8:44 a.m. | Updated We reached the bartender Doug Quinn late Thursday evening. “The phone has been…,” he said in a hoarse voice, trailing off. “You can’t even imagine. People calling me, e-mailing me, texting me.”

headline: The Lowdown | Bianca Casady
text: This is a big summer for Bianca Casady, half of the musical duo CocoRosie, who just released a new single and video for their song “We Are On Fire.” In late April, she wrapped up her first experimental dance piece, “Nightshift,” which she performed at the Donaufestival in Krems, Austria. And this evening she will unveil her first solo show of artwork (drawings, collages, photographs and audio and video pieces) in New York City since her debut at Deitch Projects in 2007. Even as she spreads herself across numerous formats, Casady is a prolific artist, consistent in her voice.

headline: Wheelies: The Cellular-Wall Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: As Regulator Scores Record Fine, Support Emerges for Bigger Budget
text: A tiny Wall Street regulator had a big money day.

headline: A Skyrush Point of View
text: A point-of-view angle of the Skyrush roller coaster at Hersheypark in Hershey, Pa.

headline: Hitting the Sweat Spot, Straight From Sichuan
text: THE Eskimos may not have a hundred words for snow, but surely the Sichuanese have words for the seemingly infinite shades of heat that ripple through a single meal.

headline: The War Photographer, Way Back in 1666
text: LONDON — For decades now we have relied on news photography to capture the horrors of war. But some 350 years ago there were artists risking their lives, sketching away as soldiers and sailors fell and guns blazed.

headline: A Justice in Chief
text: The title “chief justice of the United States” is not in the Constitution, and neither was it in the first Judiciary Act by which Congress organized the federal courts. It came into use only casually and gradually, by the late 19th century replacing the favored “chief justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.” Even today, people often mangle the title as “chief justice of the Supreme Court.”

headline: School Districts Team Up to Demand Better Textbooks
text: New York City's Department of Education is joining forces with 30 other school districts to demand textbooks that are in sync with the new Common Core standards. At a panel on Thursday, some school officials said companies were trying to slip materials by them, with stickers that say things like, "Common Core Ready."

headline: The Two Big Questions on Health Care
text: THERE are two great mysteries about the Supreme Court’s ruling on the Affordable Care Act that befuddle commentators. First, why was Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. the crucial fifth vote upholding the requirement that individuals buy health insurance? And what will be the impact of declaring unconstitutional the penalty for states that decide not to expand their Medicaid programs to everyone who earns less than 133 percent of the income defined as the poverty level?

headline: Stitching Together Civil War History
text: Fabric supplies were crucial for both sides in the Civil War, so the Northern soldiers invading the South would expressly set out to trash cotton fields and burn textile factories.

headline: Bunny Yeager, the Pinup’s Pinup Maker
text: Photographs by Bunny Yeager

headline: Siding With the Liberal Wing
text: How often Supreme Court justices sided with the court’s liberal wing in 5-to-4 decisions.

text: Paris

headline: Farewell, Without a Parachute
text: To her credit Ann Curry didn’t pretend on Thursday that she was leaving “Today” on NBC voluntarily or happily.

headline: Corporate Profits Fall for First Time Since Recession
text: unemployed Americans have complained that even as companies have done so well, workers’ own fortunes have stagnated.

headline: A Step to Lose Face Over
text: Artists have done it. Athletes have done it.

headline: Military Rulers Fixed Presidential Vote to Install Islamist, ‘Egypt’s Glenn Beck’ Says
text: CAIRO — Two members of the military council that has ruled Egypt since Hosni Mubarak was forced from power last year took to the airwaves Wednesday night to reject claims by a television host that they had conspired with the United States to rig this month’s presidential election in favor of the Islamist candidate.

headline: In Setback, RIM Delays BlackBerry’s Next Version
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion unexpectedly announced on Thursday that a new line of phones that it still hopes will revive its BlackBerry brand will be delayed until next year.

headline: Remnants of an Ancient Kitchen Are Found in China
text: Fragments of ancient pottery found in southern China turn out to date back 20,000 years, making them the world’s oldest known pottery — 2,000 to 3,000 years older than examples found in East Asia and elsewhere.

headline: Rolls-Royce Appoints Giles Taylor to Lead Design Department
text: Rolls-Royce has named Giles Taylor its new design director, succeeding Ian Cameron, who supervised the rebirth of the company under the BMW Group beginning in 1999.

headline: The Body Politic
text: The hip-pumping studs who work at the Xquisite dance club know a thing or two about making the ladies scream in delight. But nobody works the crowd like Magic Mike (a terrific Channing Tatum), the gyrating main attraction in Steven Soderbergh’s funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream. Then again, few directors can sell the goods — whether it’s Che in Cuba or Mike in a thong — as shrewdly as Mr. Soderbergh. A restive talent who toggles between big-studio and low-budget work, he has a genius for wrapping tricky ideas, like capitalism and its discontents, into commercial packages. Never before has he put them into cheek-baring chaps.

headline: Nadal Stunned in Second-Round Knockout
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Lukas Rosol was keeping it simple against Rafael Nadal, crushing serves and ground strokes at every reasonable and sometimes unreasonable opportunity.

headline: A Measure of Desire
text: WE moved from Los Angeles to Maine with four years of sobriety under our belts, a 2-year-old daughter and another baby on the way.

headline: Life, Interrupted
text: Suleika Jaouad, a 23-year-old writer from Saratoga Springs, N.Y., is chronicling her experiences as a young adult with cancer.

headline: Home Alone? Don’t Tell the Neighbors
text: Wow.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Raf Simons
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Like Watching Paint Thrive
text: Painting is a lot of things: resilient, vampiric, perverse, increasingly elastic, infinitely absorptive and, in one form or another, nearly as old as humankind. One thing it is not, it still seems necessary to say, is dead.

headline: What the Health Care Ruling Means for Medicare
text: “This is great news for seniors on Medicare,” Paul Nathanson, executive director of the National Senior Citizens Law Center, a nonprofit advocacy group, said in a conference call on Thursday after the Supreme Court issued its ruling upholding the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Let No Bus Separate Us
text: AMIT KALRA grew up, with his parents and his sister, in a brick row house in East Elmhurst, Queens, not far from La Guardia Airport. While an undergraduate at Baruch College 10 years ago, he bought a three-bedroom co-op at Berkeley Towers in Woodside, Queens.

headline: London, an Olympian Among Cities
text: WASHINGTON — The attention London receives this summer is sure to include the kind of glossy public relations usually associated with hosts of the Olympic Games. Surely the script is already written. Here is a modern metropolis with deep roots in the past, a city that eagerly embraces all the earth’s diversity, that operates with magical efficiency, that brings to bear the most advanced technologies, that celebrates with all its might the world’s elite athletic competitors.

text: Classical

headline: Speeding Up Refinances
text: MANY large financial institutions are facing backlogs of mortgage applications as more homeowners take advantage of low interest rates and the government-sponsored Home Affordable Refinance Program, or HARP.

text: Sarah Polley, the writer and director of "Take This Waltz," narrates a scene from the film.

text: Mitt Romney spoke briefly to reporters in Washington on Thursday.

headline: Homages and Soapboxes Mix and Mash It Up
text: We’ll be hearing a lot more from Sharon Hayes. That much is clear from “Sharon Hayes: There’s so much I want to say to you,” her promising, stimulating but uneven solo show at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

text: Art

headline: Q & A
text: Does the Landlord Do Windows?

headline: Roddick Roars Into Third Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — There is a little dip that can snare players’ shoes as they walk onto Court 1, and Andy Roddick estimated that he has tripped on it “about 66 times” over the years. He cherishes the walk to Aorangi Park, the 22-court practice site on the northern fringe of the All England Club, and the crowds here cherish him, exhorting, “Come on Andy!” between points, between games, between sets.

headline: Afghan Officials Hail Talks With Insurgents
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A flurry of informal contacts between the Afghan government and insurgent representatives over the past week suggests that long-stalled peace negotiation efforts may be inching forward, Afghan officials say, though American officials played down the significance of the meetings.

headline: Poultry Proximity: Plus or Minus?
text: IN Westchester and surrounding counties, raising chickens in the backyard has evolved into quite the rage, with homeowners touting the advantages of eggs laid by hens that dine on the finest available hormone-free feed and are allowed to range at will.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 29-July 5
text: NORTH RIVER HISTORIC SHIP FESTIVAL

headline: Paris Men’s: The New Austerity
text: I got into town early and, of course, had to dog-trot to Rick Owens’s show at 12:30 p.m. The Paris traffic soaks up your time in a way that feels different and, alas, permanent. Still, the Paris spring men’s collections provide the nearest thing to a vacation at work; they’re always relaxed and friendly (Dries Van Noten served gin and tonics before his show Thursday night), and the fashion is plentiful.

headline: Built Green, or Red-White-and-Blue
text: Amagansett

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google Wars and iTunes Sharing
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Thursday. See more here.

headline: Au Naturel
text: A roundup of new books featuring work by van Gogh, Ryan McGinley and others.

headline: Theater Listings for June 29-July 6
text: Theater

headline: That Riveting Co-op Financial Statement
text: WHEN you own an apartment in a co-op and the annual board meeting rolls around, the building’s financial statement arrives in the mail.

headline: A Bounty of Asian Movies
text: “The King of Pigs,” an animated feature by the South Korean director Yeun Sang-ho, is a poisoned-memory play: two men who appear to be in their 30s meet for the first time in years and spend the rest of the film reminiscing about their youth. One is miserable over his stalled career as a writer, the other has failed in business and, in rage and despair, murdered his wife. The root of their malaise, they agree, is no mystery: it’s middle school.

headline: Role After Role, She Cuts Years Off Her Age
text: AS Becky, the 17-year-old motormouth in the new Off Broadway play “Slowgirl,” Sarah Steele rips through dialogue with such scatterbrained delight — “Stuff comes into my head, and I just say it, you know? I don’t, like, check where it fits on the Appropriate Topics Scale or whatever.” — that this actress’s own poise at a recent interview was startling at first. But at 23, Ms. Steele is an old pro at exploring how troubled teenagers resort to exhibitionism to bury their vulnerabilities.

headline: For Career Women, a Hassle-Free Haven
text: AT the turn of the last century, single professional women had a difficult time finding places to live in which they were free from the suspicion of immoral behavior. A group of reformers responded in 1903 by building a hotel exclusively for women, the Martha Washington, at 30 East 30th Street through the block to 29 East 29th. Though quite average architecturally, it is one of New York’s newest landmarks.

headline: Au Naturel
text: The savviest piece of advice I got as a rookie reporter-photographer came my first week on the job at The Exeter News-Letter in New Hampshire. The picture editor told me, “If you think you’re close, get closer.” Words to brand on your brain, maybe even your retinas, if you’re being paid to see, especially when laying bare the natural world.

headline: Gems From the Sea
text: The Snug Harbor Cultural Center, a bucolic spread of historic architecture on the north shore of Staten Island that includes a botanical garden and children’s museum, began life in the early 19th century as a retirement home for sailors. Tucked in Building D, one of the glorious Greek Revival structures on the grounds, is the Noble Maritime Collection, among the city’s distinctive and relatively unsung cultural institutions. On Sunday afternoon it will host a free reception for its exhibition “Treasures of Sailors’ Snug Harbor.”

headline: Booby-Trapped Flashlights Rattle Arizona and Baffle Authorities
text: PHOENIX — It is a law-enforcement mystery with bizarre overtones: flashlights dropped in seemingly random places that explode whenever someone tries to turn one on.

headline: Living In | Dongan Hills, S.I.
text: A two-and-a-half-square-mile enclave (population about 25,000) that sweeps from Lower New York Bay to the base of Todt Hill.

headline: A Layer Cake, Topographically and Otherwise
text: THE idea that there could be mean streets on the Upper East Side may seem, to some New Yorkers, akin to the suggestion that alligators swim in the sewers. But crime was in fact a problem on the streets of Yorkville in the early 1960s, according to Steven Zboinski, whose parents would whisk him away each summer to the sparsely settled and comparatively wholesome East Shore of Staten Island.

headline: Celebrity Luxe, Then and Now
text: IN eastern Monmouth County, the name Hartshorne has plenty of resonance. In addition to Hartshorne Road and Hartshorne Woods Park, there’s the Hartshorne mansion, a brick Tudor-style home on the banks of the Shrewsbury River in Little Silver. It was built in 1929 by the Olympic figure skater Harold Hartshorne.

headline: A 2nd U.S.-Supported Maker of Solar Panels Will Close
text: WASHINGTON — Abound Solar, a solar panel maker that received a $400 million loan guarantee from the federal government, announced on Thursday that it would file for bankruptcy amid plummeting prices and intense competition from Chinese manufacturers in the solar equipment market.

headline: Dark Chords and Celestial Grooves
text: Terje Rypdal began his third piece at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday night with a solo fanfare on his electric guitar, bracing and imperious. Playing in a brusque but gleaming tone, he parceled out phrases of irregular shape, sidestepping expectation.

headline: Sometimes Attraction Becomes a Slow Dance Around the Subject
text: Margot (Michelle Williams) and Daniel (Luke Kirby) meet on a trip to Louisbourg, Nova Scotia, site of an 18th-century French fort and a present-day National Historic Park. They sit together on the flight home to Toronto, and the attraction between them is obvious and mutual. This makes it a bit awkward when they discover, sharing a cab from the airport, that Daniel lives across the street from the charming, cozy row house where Margot lives with her husband, Lou (Seth Rogen).

headline: The Supreme Court Decision on the 2010 Health Care Law
text: The New York Times analyzes the Supreme Court’s decision to uphold the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

headline: ‘Game Plan’
text: A look at the Alighiero Boetti survey at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: A Duel Before Darkness
text: WIMBLEDON, England — This was a battle — and it’s not over.

headline: Where Making Summer Fun Is a Family Matter
text: EGG HARBOR TOWNSHIP, N.J. — At the beginning, you meet Mother Goose. She is a 25-foot tower of concrete, rheumy-eyed but smiling, standing beside a goose almost as gargantuan as a giraffe.

headline: Paint City
text: Images from Chelsea shows of contemporary painting.

headline: Fourth of July Celebrations From June 29-July 4
text: The Fourth

headline: Folk Art and Hope in Phrases of Music
text: “Glee” without the contrivance, the tokenism or the choreographed karaoke: that’s one way of looking at “Mariachi High,” which leads off the PBS Arts summer documentary series on Friday night. Any suspicion that the film’s creators were hoping we might see it that way doesn’t lessen its charm or relevance.

headline: The Best of All Possible Worlds
text: The French are wittier than the Spanish, and the English know more than the Danes. The ancient Athenians were ingenious and polite, but modern Greeks are stupid and indolent. Jews are noted for fraud, of course, and Armenians for probity. Or so it seemed in 1742 to David Hume when he wrote an essay, not his best, on national characters.

headline: Pondering a Link Between Forest Fires and Climate Change
text: This week, record temperatures and wildfires have scorched the western United States. The National Climate Data Center reports that 41 heat records (6,027 weather stations take measurements around the country) have been broken or tied since Sunday, mostly in Colorado, Kansas and Nebraska, which is quite unusual for this time of year.

headline: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Gets a Transformative Gift for Its African Collection
text: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, has received a major donation of Benin bronzes and ivories, a gift that promises to transform its African collection.

headline: Your Winged Chariot Is Ready. A Seat on the Edge?
text: HERSHEY, Pa. — Each season in the theme park world brings a spirit of roller coaster one-upmanship. Which park will build the fastest, tallest, scariest, weirdest or most-talked-about coaster of the summer? Park officials plug away at research, and engineers tinker with formulas to come up with rides they hope will turn heads and raise arms.

headline: Romney Campaign Unleashes Coordinated Response to Court Ruling
text: Moments after the Supreme Court ruled on President Obama’s health care law, Lanhee Chen, the policy director for Mitt Romney, sent an e-mail to about three dozen senior Republicans on Capitol Hill and in state attorneys general’s offices.

headline: Aid Workers Detained in Myanmar
text: GENEVA — The United Nations and several humanitarian agencies that operate in Myanmar said Thursday that a number of their staff members had been detained by the government in a part of the country where sectarian violence erupted this month, and that they were trying to secure their release.

headline: A Vindication, With a Legacy Still Unwritten
text: WASHINGTON — For Barack Obama, who staked his presidency on a once-in-a-generation reshaping of the social welfare system, the Supreme Court’s health care ruling is not just political vindication. It is a personal reprieve, leaving intact his hopes of joining the ranks of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Lyndon B. Johnson and Ronald Reagan as presidents who fundamentally altered the course of the country.

headline: Two Couples Collide, With a Roman Beauty as Muse and Catalyst
text: Not long after Philippe Garrel’s languid, emotionally raw film “A Burning Hot Summer” opens, its lonely beauty, Frédéric (Louis Garrel, the director’s son), dies. He’s first seen standing next to his BMW at a gas station, taking pulls from a flask, his hair and clothes disheveled. He looks more distracted than disturbed, but a few beats later, when he’s speeding behind the wheel down a dark highway, you see that his eyes are glassy.

headline: With Style, Balotelli Sends Italy to Final
text: WARSAW — The Germans have never beaten the Italians in a major soccer tournament, and after what happened here in Poland’s new National Stadium on Thursday night, they must wonder whether they ever will.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
