text: To the Editor:

headline: European Leaders Agree to Use Bailout Fund to Aid Banks
text: BRUSSELS — Working through the night in the face of pressure from the embattled euro zone countries Italy and Spain, European leaders agreed early Friday to use the Continent’s bailout funds to recapitalize struggling banks directly, according to the European Council president, Herman Van Rompuy.

headline: Old Man of Rock Takes a Road Trip
Picking the Right College, Even if You’ve Never Heard of It
text: Ariha Setalvad, who is studying journalism and psychology as an undergraduate at New York University, was raised in India and graduated from B.D. Somani International School in Mumbai. She is a summer intern on The Choice blog.

headline: Business Day Live | Angela Merkel
text: June 27, 2012 - European leaders put pressure on Angela Merkel over debt.

headline: Business Day Live | Metered Broadband
text: June 27, 2012 - The cable industry's efforts to put a meter on your broadband bill.

headline: Spying on a Half-Sister Right Under Her Nose
text: The jittery opening scenes of “People Like Us” capture the high anxiety that is epidemic in the modern workplace with the clattering velocity of an action film. Sam Harper (Chris Pine), a motormouthed New York salesman of remaindered merchandise, is called on the carpet for a costly mistake in the transportation of a shipment of canned soup. Amid the brouhaha, a bigger screw-up comes to light, and for the rest of the movie he is hounded by telephone threats from the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Photo Replay: June 28
text: A view of the day in sports, with track-and-field action in Helsinki and tennis in England.

headline: With Venice as Backdrop, Players Glide Among Their Relationships
text: The characters on the constant move in “Unforgivable,” the latest from the French director André Téchiné, often seem to be heading toward one another, yet for all their movement forward, it can be hard for them to connect. They go in and out of homes, boats and beds, a rhythmic to-ing and fro-ing matched by the ebbing and flowing of the surrounding water. Set in a less touristy if still impressively lovely Venice than often appears onscreen, the film can seem as if it’s as unmoored as with all these people coming and going, as if Mr. Téchiné had no particular destination in mind for these restless souls.

headline: American Wrestler Kicked Off Team
text: The American wrestler Stephany Lee, who celebrated her Olympic trials victory in Iowa two months ago by marrying her longtime girlfriend, has been bumped from the team for testing positive for marijuana.

headline: Where They Can Handle the Hot Sauce
text: Singh’s Roti Shop and Bar offers the food and atmosphere of the Caribbean.

headline: Black House Democrats Lead Walkout During Holder Contempt Vote
text: Black lawmakers led a throng of House Democrats in a walkout Thursday during the vote to hold Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in contempt of Congress.

headline: 10-Year Sentence for Lawyer in Terrorism Case Is Upheld
text: A panel of federal judges in Manhattan upheld the 10-year prison sentence imposed on Lynne F. Stewart, the disbarred lawyer convicted in a terrorism case who had been resentenced to that term after boasting that she could do a much shorter sentence “standing on my head.”

headline: Assad, in Taped TV Interview, Calls Iran a Wise Friend
text: TEHRAN — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria thanked Iran as one of the “wise governments” seeking to protect Syrian stability in the face of the uprising against him, he said in a taped interview broadcast Thursday on Iranian state television.

headline: Roberts Shows Deft Hand as Swing Vote on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. has a favorite quotation from one of the giants who preceded him on the Supreme Court. Assessing the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. once wrote, “is the gravest and most delicate duty that this court is called on to perform.”

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor’s Role in Abuse Case Is Examined
text: For years, Avrohom Mondrowitz counseled children out of his home in the Borough Park neighborhood of Brooklyn. He was host of a call-in radio show popular among ultra-Orthodox Jewish listeners, claiming to be a rabbi and psychologist. But law enforcement officials say Mr. Mondrowitz, who fled to Israel in 1984 to avoid arrest, was also something else: “a compulsive pedophile.”

headline: Seven Consequences of the Health Care Ruling
text: “I have had some bitter disappointments as president,”Harry S. Truman wrote in his memoirs, “but the one that has troubled me most, in a personal way, has been the failure to defeat the organized opposition to a national compulsory health insurance program.” He was just the first in a long line of presidents stymied by health reform. NowBarack Obama has succeeded where his predecessors failed. Or has he?

headline: A Growing Black Market for Body Parts
text: With Europe roiled by financial upheaval, experts say the black market for selling human organs is expanding as vulnerable, desperately poor people seek to sell their body parts.

headline: Black Market for Body Parts Spreads Among the Poor in Europe
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — Pavle Mircov and his partner, Daniella, nervously scan their e-mail in-box every 15 minutes, desperate for economic salvation: a buyer willing to pay nearly $40,000 for one of their kidneys.

headline: Will Google’s Personal Assistant Be Creepy or Cool?
text: One day, people won’t have to type queries into a box to search for information. It’ll be delivered to them, via their various screens, based on where they are, who is nearby and what they might like and need to know.

headline: Live Music, Hot Food, Hot Sauce
text: IT’S a warm June night on Liberty Avenue in Richmond Hill, Queens, a flat half-mile past the last stop on the A train. Inside what looks like a low, neon-lighted diner, a West Indian band has just taken its set break, and a tassa drum ensemble assembles in an alcove, four men loosely circled, between mirrored walls and beneath pinpoints of green and red light.

headline: To Expand Its Brand, a Sponsor Goes Golfing
text: WEB.COM, which provides Internet services to small and medium-size businesses, is switching up its low-key profile by signing on to sponsor the golf circuit for promising players seeking to qualify for the elite PGA Tour.

headline: Crime Report Manipulation Is Common Among New York Police, Study Finds
text: An anonymous survey of nearly 2,000 retired officers found that the manipulation of crime reports — downgrading crimes to lesser offenses and discouraging victims from filing complaints to make crime statistics look better — has long been part of the culture of the New York Police Department.

headline: Online Sale Picks for June 28
text: Barneys.com Acne’s colored jeans, VPL lingerie and other designer goodies all up to 60 percent off.When: Ongoing

headline: Pettitte’s Earliest Return Is Aug. 28
text: Placed on the 60-day disabled list Thursday with a fractured left fibula, Andy Pettitte won’t be eligible to return until Aug. 28. He hadn’t expected to miss the rest of his summer when a sharp grounder struck him on Wednesday. His shins had taken plenty of hits before, and he told himself that the pain seemed tolerable.

headline: Man and Mustache Advance at Trials
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Is facial hair making a comeback in track?

headline: A Confused Opinion
text: THE stunner yesterday was that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., joined by the Supreme Court’s four most liberal justices, wrote the majority opinion that upheld the individual mandate in President Obama’s signature Affordable Care Act, which requires Americans to obtain health insurance or pay a penalty. In an ironic twist, the chief justice simultaneously accepted the conservative argument that Congress’s power to regulate interstate commerce did not include the power to regulate economic inactivity, like a decision not to purchase health care. The court ruled 5 to 4 on that point, with the chief justice joined by the court’s four other conservative justices.

headline: U.S. Exempts Singapore and China on Iran Oil
text: Acting at the last minute, the Obama administration on Thursday spared China and Singapore from potentially onerous financial penalties required under a strict American law on Iran sanctions, saying that both countries had earned an exemption by significantly reducing their purchases of Iranian crude oil.

headline: Don Grady, Robbie on ‘My Three Sons,’ Is Dead at 68
text: Don Grady, who played Chip and Ernie’s wholesome, heartthrob big brother Robbie on the long-running television sitcom “My Three Sons,” died on Wednesday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 68.

headline: North Carolina: Soldier Kills Officer and Turns Gun on Self at Fort Bragg
text: An Army officer was shot and killed by another soldier Thursday afternoon at the Fort Bragg military base in North Carolina, military officials said. The soldier who killed the officer immediately turned the gun on himself and suffered a wound but was not killed and is in custody, said Col. Kevin Arata, a spokesman for the base. Another soldier was also injured from a ricocheting bullet. All three are members of the 525 Battlefield Surveillance Brigade. The identities of the dead officer and the wounded soldiers were not released. Military officials said they did not yet know the motive for the shootings and did not release details about the kind of weapon that was used. Colonel Arata said security forces arrived at the scene minutes after shots were fired around 3:30 p.m. He said the base remains open. Fort Bragg, in Fayetteville, is one of the nation’s largest military bases, home to both the Army airborne forces and Special Forces.

headline: Gymnastic Team Contender Stays Calm and Solid
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Four years before Aly Raisman was considered a lock for the United States Olympic gymnastics team, she was in the stands at the national championships when the M.C. asked her a question she will not soon forget: where are the Beijing Olympics going to be?

headline: Angry British Leaders Take Barclays’ Chief Executive to Task
text: LONDON — Robert E. Diamond Jr., the chief executive of Barclays, is again in the cross hairs of angry politicians and dissatisfied shareholders.

headline: Modesty and Audacity
text: Washington is full of arrogant people who grab power whenever they get the chance. But there is at least one modest minimalist in town, and that’s John Roberts Jr.

headline: Martin Out of Lineup Again
text: Russell Martin’s sore back acted up again on Thursday and he was left out of the starting lineup for the Yankees game against the Chicago White Sox. Chris Stewart returned behind the plate.

headline: Romney’s Supreme Burden
text: Congratulations to Mitt Romney! His signature contribution to American life, devising a health plan that became a model for the only major Western democracy without medical care for nearly all of its citizens, has been upheld. If Romney accomplishes nothing else in life, he will go down in history as the man who first proved, in the laboratory of Massachusetts, where he once governed, that an individual mandate could work.

headline: Pat Cummings, Rugged N.B.A. Forward, Dies at 55
text: Pat Cummings, who played 12 seasons in the N.B.A., including four seasons at power forward with the Knicks in the 1980s, was found dead on Tuesday at an apartment in Greenwich Village. He was 55.

headline: Kentucky Reigns Again on N.B.A.’s Draft Night
text: NEWARK — Despite playing only one season for Kentucky, a university that has become nearly synonymous with the one-and-done era of the N.B.A. draft, Anthony Davis is a bit of a throwback when it comes to top draft picks.

headline: Justices Allow the Term ‘Tax’ to Embrace ‘Penalty’
text: There are lots of taxes that people pay only if they buy something — sales taxes, taxes on cigarettes and taxes on airline tickets among them.

headline: Another Food Company Deepens Roots in the Bronx, but Reception Is Mixed
text: Even as FreshDirect’s planned move to the Bronx faces opposition from residents, city officials are forging ahead with plans to transform the borough into a destination site for the food industry.

headline: Empty About 3 Decades, Pool From the Depression Era Reopens to Cool Off Brooklyn
text: For 28 years, McCarren Pool sat empty on the Williamsburg-Greenpoint border in Brooklyn, its enormous basin growing cracks and sprouting weeds. One by one, the 10 other public pools that opened in New York City during the scorching summer of 1936 were revamped, but not McCarren. A generation of Brooklyn children learned of its invigorating charms only from their parents who had swum there when they were children.

headline: In Albany and at Polls, Conservative Party’s Sway Rises
text: The chances that Wendy E. Long might beat Kirsten E. Gillibrand, the Democratic incumbent, in the Senate election this fall are decidedly slim. Still, Ms. Long’s victory this week in the Republican primary provided New York State’s Conservative Party with one more reason to celebrate its muscular sway within the Republican Party.

headline: Looking for Cash, Congress Finds Some in a Corporate Pension Rule Tweak
text: Lawmakers looking for money to finance low-cost student loans and fix aging highways have found about $20 billion in an unlikely place: company pension funds.

headline: Western Colorado Struggles as Energy Jobs Fade
text: MEEKER, Colo. — The news of a nationwide energy boom is almost too much for people in this town built atop a sea of oil shale and natural gas, where rusting tanks line the highways and ExxonMobil helped to finance the 4-H club’s new community center.

headline: Database of Veterans’ Medals Cited as Alternative to ‘Stolen Valor’
text: In his opinion striking down the Stolen Valor Act on Thursday, United States Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy offered an alternative solution for defending the military’s award system against fakers, one he said would not infringe on First Amendment rights.

headline: Murdoch Sees Strengths in New Print Division
text: Rupert Murdoch played offense on Thursday, embarking on a rare publicity campaign to extol the economic prospects of News Corporation’s newspapers after announcing earlier that they would be spun off into a separate company.

headline: Bending Toward Universal Health Care
text: IN finding the Affordable Care Act constitutional, a narrow majority on the Supreme Court, led by Chief JusticeJohn G. Roberts Jr., has surprised almost everyone. The decision is a victory for the century-long struggle to ensure basic health coverage for virtually all Americans, and it sets the nation on a path toward more rational, cost-effective ways of delivering care. These will be the eventual outcomes — but months and years of fierce political battles lie ahead.

headline: After Rangel Victory, Uncounted Votes Prompt Questions
text: Two days after Congressional primary elections in New York State, supporters of the top challenger to Representative Charles B. Rangel voiced concerns on Thursday that some votes still had not been counted.

headline: Finally, That First Splash
text: New York City’s 55 public outdoor pools require weeks and months of preparation by the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation.

headline: Researchers See Decline in Child Sexual Abuse Rate
text: Anyone reading the headlines in recent weeks has come away with an unsettling message: Sexual predators seem to lurk everywhere.

headline: Phelps Stays Driven in Event That Propelled Him to Top
text: OMAHA — A swimming career is like a chocolate sundae, Michael Phelps said the other day.

headline: Dressing With Faith, Not Heat, in Mind
text: When the mercury passes 90, most New Yorkers start to wilt. Many resort to shorts and tank tops, even in the office. More than a few bankers and lawyers reach for their seersuckers.

headline: British Memorial Honors World War II Bomber Crews
text: LONDON — Just once, in a raid over Düsseldorf in 1944, Jack Watson said on Thursday, he had a momentary misgiving about the carpet bombing of German cities that became, after World War II, one of the most controversial aspects of the Allied operations that won the war.

headline: Holocaust Survivors Take the Runway
text: HAIFA, Israel — Estee Lieber was in a bit of a tizzy as she emerged from under the blow-dryer for the final walk-through on Thursday evening. “I don’t like it straight,” she complained, wearing a triple strand of pearls and her sash, while waiting to put on her velvety black dress slit up the side. “I’m not modern. In my eyes it’s not beautiful.”

headline: States Face a Challenge to Meet Health Law’s Deadline
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act shifts the focus from whether sweeping changes to the health insurance market should take place to a scramble to meet the law’s rapidly approaching deadlines.

headline: Court Says Taxi System Complies With Disabilities Law
text: A federal appeals court panel ruled on Thursday that New York City’s taxi system complied with federal disabilities law, rebuffing a class-action suit brought by advocates for disabled passengers that had threatened to jumble an already uncertain future for the city’s taxicabs.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Man Faces Prison for Selling Glove With Babe Ruth Lie
text: The offer was extraordinary: A baseball mitt once owned by Babe Ruth was being offered by a memorabilia broker in Nevada. But the mitt had an even richer history, its owner wrote; in 1944, the Babe had given the glove to his close friend Robert Young, the Hollywood star, who had kept it in his private collection for more than 68 years.

headline: A Pyrrhic Victory
text: Washington

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Health Care Law
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld most of President Obama’s health care overhaul law, saying it was authorized by Congress’s power to levy taxes.

headline: Greece: Man Dies After Fall From Acropolis
text: A Greek man died on Thursday after falling from the Acropolis, the capital’s most prominent landmark, in what appeared to be the latest suicide linked to Greece’s economic hardship. A police spokeswoman confirmed that a man in his 40s jumped from the slopes of the hill at about 9 a.m. He was taken to a hospital but died of head injuries a few hours later. The man, who according to Greek media was a bank worker, reportedly fell on the marble bleachers of the ancient Theater of Dionysus, on the southern slopes of the Acropolis Hill, the site of the ancient Parthenon monument. Visitors and guards at the site, Greece’s foremost tourist attraction, said they heard a cry before seeing the man fall into the theater. Local media said the man had reported for work on Thursday at a branch of ATEbank, a state-owned agricultural lender with serious liquidity problems, but left for a break soon after. Suicides have sharply risen in recent months, most of them attributed to financial problems stemming from Greece’s economic crisis.

headline: Something to Chew On
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Not bad for a Patrick Berry outing. Not his best, and I will admit that I cringed when I filled in the DESEX/SEXTET crossing. Sure, etymologically the two words are very different so it’s allowable, but it’s just not what I would expect from a Berry byline. There was no heart-grabbing, “Oh, my goodness, I can’t believe he pulled that off!” moment. Maybe I’ve become spoiled.

headline: China: Tainted Milk Recalled
text: A Shanghai dairy company announced Thursday that it was recalling a batch of milk that had been contaminated with lye, a chemical used to clean pipes, according to a message posted on the company’s Web site and a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The company, Guangming Dairy Group, said it was recalling 300 cartons of tainted milk produced Monday. The Web site said that the milk had been tainted during routine maintenance, and that the company would compensate customers. Contaminated food is a constant issue in China, and many Chinese have been especially vigilant about tainted milk since a 2008 scandal that exposed a common practice in which a toxic chemical, melamine, was added to milk.

headline: CNN and Fox Trip Up in Rush to Get the News on the Air
text: The national news media mostly got it right on Thursday in reporting the Supreme Court’s decision to uphold President Obama’s health care overhaul. But the cable news networks CNN and Fox News Channel initially got it wrong, causing consternation behind the scenes.

headline: Syria: Hamas Member Killed
text: The Palestinian Islamic group Hamas said Thursday that one of its members had been killed in Damascus, Syria. The group did not immediately blame Israel for the death of the man, Kamal Husni Ghanaja, saying it was still investigating. Israel has long fought a shadow war with Hamas, which runs Gaza and advocates armed resistance against Israel. But some Israelis and Palestinians have noted that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, who is trying to crush an armed uprising, also had a score to settle with Hamas. Hamas has refused to back Mr. Assad and abandoned its longtime base in Damascus a few months ago. Israel Hasson, an Israeli lawmaker and former security official, said that Mr. Ghanaja was responsible for supplying weapons to Hamas.

headline: The Real Winners
text: So the Supreme Court — defying many expectations — upheld the Affordable Care Act, a k a Obamacare. There will, no doubt, be many headlines declaring this a big victory for President Obama, which it is. But the real winners are ordinary Americans — people like you.

headline: Egypt: Ex-Official Sentenced
text: A court on Thursday sentenced a former oil minister and a business associate of former President Hosni Mubarak to 15 years in prison for corruption and squandering public funds in the sale of natural gas to Israel. In addition to the former oil minister, Sameh Fahmy, above, five other officials of the ministry and the state-run natural gas company were also sentenced to prison for 3 to 10 years. The businessman, Hussein Salem, was tried in absentia; he is awaiting extradition from Spain. He was among the founders of a company that won a lucrative no-bid contract to act as a middleman in the gas deal. The state news agency said the group was fined a total of $2.3 billion.

headline: South Carolina Governor Criticizes Accuser
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Gov. Nikki Haley lashed out Thursday night against a fellow Republican who has accused her of ethics violations.

headline: Iran: Diplomatic Deal With Britain
text: Iran said it had agreed with Britain to establish diplomatic interests sections in each other’s capitals, seven months after Britain nearly broke off relations with Iran, withdrew its diplomatic staff and expelled all Iranian diplomats in response to the pillaging of the British Embassy in Tehran by Iranians protesting British economic sanctions. Iran’s foreign minister, Ali Akbar Salehi, was quoted by Press TV, a state-run Iranian broadcaster, as saying that Iran had agreed to establish an interests section at Oman’s embassy in London, and that Britain had agreed to establish an interests section at Sweden’s embassy in Tehran. A spokesman for Britain’s Foreign Office said he could not immediately confirm Mr. Salehi’s announcement.

headline: Reaction to the Court
text: Charts of daily stock closes for some major health care businesses.

headline: Vietnam: China’s Claims Disputed
text: The Foreign Ministry has protested a Chinese state-owned oil company’s move to offer for exploration nine blocks in a disputed area of the South China Sea. Vietnamese officials say the area is inside Vietnam’s exclusive economic zone and is not part of China. The Chinese government has laid claim to much of the South China Sea, areas of which are believed to be rich in oil, gas and fish. The blocks were put up for bids from foreign companies last week by China National Offshore Oil Corporation, or Cnooc. Some of the blocks overlap with ones that PetroVietnam, a state-owned enterprise, has already delineated as areas under contract for exploration by foreign companies. An executive at PetroVietnam has said it will proceed with the contracts. China said this week that Cnooc had the right to offer the blocks.

headline: Israel: Settlers Evacuated
text: Israel on Thursday completed the evacuation of 30 families from five buildings in the disputed Ulpana section of Beit El, a settlement in the West Bank. About 15 right-wing activists barricaded themselves inside an apartment for several hours. The police removed them, arresting six, a police spokesman said. The families left peacefully after the government promised to build 300 more homes in Beit El and 500 in other West Bank settlements. The Supreme Court had ordered the buildings to be demolished by July 1 because they sit on private Palestinian land. The state has requested an extension of several months.

headline: Will Time Heal Health Care Wounds?
text: When the Supreme Court declared the Affordable Care Act’s provision for an individual mandate to buy medical insurance constitutional, the majority did so by placing the mandate within Congress’s power to tax rather than under the Commerce clause. While the decision keeps most of the law intact, what does it mean politically? And how will the characterization of the mandate as a tax play among supporters and opponents of the legislation?

headline: Hossler Draws a Crowd at AT&T National
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Morning rush-hour traffic clogged the Capital Beltway as temperatures rose when Beau Hossler teed off shortly before 9 o’clock Thursday at the AT&T National. But a large crowd was on hand to follow the 17-year-old Hossler, who was a sensation at the United States Open.

headline: How Will the Health Care Law  Unfold?
text: What will be the economic implications of President Obama's signature legislation? How well will it expand coverage?

headline: Two Sprinters Who Tied in 100 Advance in the 200
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Allyson Felix and Jeneba Tarmoh qualified for the semifinals in the 200 meters on Thursday, moving one step closer to resolving their dead heat for third place in the 100 meters.

headline: An Ode to Palawan
text: Mysticism infuses Auraeus Solito’s “Busong,” a quiet, lyrical ode to Palawan, a tropical island paradise in the Philippines whose inhabitants go by the same name. The film, based on folk tales passed to the director from his mother, comprises four loosely linked narratives. Punay (Alessandra de Rossi) is a woman covered in sores who must be carried by her brother, Angkadang (Rodrigo Santikan), to find a tribal healer. They encounter Ninita (Bonivie Budao), who searches for her missing husband; Lulong (Dax Alejandro), a fisherman deprived of his boat; and Aris (Clifford Banagale), a son of Palawan returning to reclaim his shamanic birthright.

headline: A Moderate Ruling With Risks Ahead
text: There is no underestimating the importance of the Supreme Court decision upholding most of the health reform law — politically, constitutionally and in terms of its practical effects on the nation and the economy.

headline: Swim Veteran Lezak Still Has a Chance
text: 5:48 p.m. | Updated OMAHA — Outside of Michael Phelps and Ryan Lochte, arguably the most recognizable swimmer at this week’s United States Olympic trials is Jason Lezak, who snatched a victory from apparent defeat in the 400-meter freestyle relay at the 2008 Olympics with a sizzling anchor leg.

headline: A Muddled Political Response From the Right
text: The future of the health care system is now back where it should be, out of the hands of judges and into those of voters. With the constitutional question about President Obama’s health care law now settled, the public will have a chance to examine Mitt Romney’s claims that it is terrible for the country. Based on his remarks on Thursday, they will not have much to go on.

headline: Yankees Look Within to Patch Rotation
text: During Freddy Garcia’s exile to the bullpen, an agonizing eight weeks that included 14 days of inactivity, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman had several conversations with Garcia and Garcia’s agent, Peter Greenberg.

headline: Fighting With Homeland Security
text: If the astonishing events laid out in “Top Priority: The Terror Within” are to be understood at all, they will require a more coolheaded documentary than this one. Detailing the lengthy and convoluted conflict between Julia Davis, a former Customs and Border Protection officer, and the Homeland Security Department, this screeching exposé from Asif Akbar serves neither the viewer nor its embattled subject.

headline: City Council Changes Zoning to Limit Sprawl of Big Banks on Upper West Side
text: The City Council approved a zoning change on Thursday that is meant to stop the proliferation of impersonal bank branches and other large storefronts along the major commercial avenues of the Upper West Side.

headline: Yankees’ Bullpen Falters in the Ninth
text: Clay Rapada made the pitch he wanted to make. He got the result he wanted, too, when A. J. Pierzynski hit a slow tapper back to the mound. Rapada had only to turn and make a routine throw to second base to initiate an easy double play, and the Yankees would be on their way to another victory.

headline: Ivan Karp, Pop Art Dealer, Dies at 86
text: Ivan Karp, a cigar-chomping, fast-talking New York gallery owner who helped find, popularize and market the Pop artists of the 1960s, including Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein and Robert Rauschenberg, died on Thursday at his home in Charlotteville, N.Y. He was 86.

text: OMAHA — After finishing fourth in 2004 and third in 2008, Davis Tarwater was back in the final of the 200-meter butterfly on Thursday. That was the good news.

headline: A Victim of Abuse Follows Sandusky Trial Closely
text: OMAHA – With a stable of aspiring Olympians to tend to, Kristen Lewis Cunnane, the associate women’s head coach at California Berkeley, tried to shut out all distractions in the lead-up to this week’s United States Olympic trials. The child sexual abuse trial of Jerry Sandusky, a former defensive coordinator at Penn State, made that impossible.

headline: The Nets Acquire a Kansas Star
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Nets are bound for Brooklyn, but they are taking a piece of New Jersey with them.

headline: Postcard from Kashmir
text: Nelson Guda, a world-wandering photographer, artist and writer (with a doctorate in biology), sent me a note early this week from Kashmir, the beautiful and turbulent patch of territory caught for decades in a border dispute between India and Pakistan. Tensions were heightened when a revered Muslim shrine was destroyed in a fire on Monday. (The cause is still in dispute.) Guda is there for his Enemies Project, in which he is photographing people on opposite sides of conflicts around the world. I invited him to send a Dot Earth “Postcard,” which is posted below with more background and news links:

headline: Seeking, and Resisting, Vaccines
text: “It’s hard to argue with the premise that in the United States, some parents take lightly their ability to vaccinate children against childhood diseases,” KJ Dell’antonia wrote in the Motherlode blog of The New York Times.

headline: The Voice of Track and Field
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Since the early 1990s, Paul Swangard has been known as the “Voice of Hayward Field,” announcing a medley of University of Oregon track meets and championships. He is wielding the microphone during the United States Olympic trials here this week. When he is not tucked away in his booth in the back of Hayward’s stands, Swangard works as managing director of Oregon’s Warsaw Sports Marketing Center. He discussed the often-overlooked world of track and field announcing.

text: “No matter how accomplished you are in the kitchen, you always learn something when you cook with someone else — at least I always have,” Mark Bittman wrote in The New York Times. “But it’s worth remembering that what you learn may be something other than what you thought you would.”

headline: Sister to Sister: Celebrities and Aid
text: “As more women acquire the financial muscle to support a cause, they seem to feel a special pull to help other women — and get actively involved in the process,” Katrin Bennhold reports. “Their empathy with less fortunate sisters, often rooted in shared female experiences like motherhood or the stubborn barriers to gender equality that persist from Pakistan to the United States, is quietly blurring the traditional line between donors and activists.”

headline: Memories Bought and Sold
text: When Gloria Baker Feinstein held an estate sale, before a move made necessary by health issues her husband was experiencing, it was an emotional event. The items on sale offered a record of a lifetime’s travels and the raising of two children. But it felt as though she was selling more than children’s toys or serving bowls. It was like giving away the actual memories associated with them.

headline: In Bangalore, Even a New Smile Can Be Bought on Credit
text: Binodini Mohapatra, 28, an engineer with a large multinational, gleefully recounted how she got a new smile on E.M.I., or equated monthly installments, as they are known here.

headline: South Korea Postpones Military Pact With Japan
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Faced with mounting political pressure at home, the South Korean government on Friday abruptly postponed the signing of its first military cooperation pact with Japan since World War II.

headline: Annan ‘Optimistic’ Over Geneva Talks on Syria
text: MOSCOW — As global powers prepared for an 11th-hour effort to revive the stalled peace effort in Syria, Kofi Annan, the special envoy and mediator who called the meeting, said on Friday he was optimistic that the talks in Geneva would yield an acceptable result despite Russian calls for changes in his settlement ideas.

headline: Brewer to Buy Remaining Stake in Grupo Modelo
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev agreed on Friday to buy the half of the Mexican brewer Grupo Modelo it does not already own for $20.1 billion, the latest deal in the fast-consolidating global brewing industry.

headline: A Snitch’s Dilemma
text: Kathryn Johnston was doing pretty well until the night the police showed up. Ever since her sister died, Johnston, 92, had lived alone in a rough part of Atlanta called the Bluff. A niece checked in often. One of the gifts she left was a pistol, so that her aunt might protect herself.

headline: Syrian Groups Say Violent Day Left High Civilian Toll
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s opposition on Friday reported the deadliest 24-hour period so far in the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad and said rebel fighters had seized two Syrian generals, including the highest-ranking officer to fall into insurgent hands.

headline: Coty Files to Go Public
text: Coty filed to go public on Friday, revisiting a strategic plan it had formed before trying to buy Avon Products for $10.7 billion this year.

headline: Pitched to Perfection: Pop Star’s Silent Partner
text: LOS ANGELES — Two days before Justin Bieber’s 18th birthday he was, as usual, working. He walked into the main control room at Record Plant, a recording studio here, his blue-and-pink high-top Balenciaga sneakers unlaced, nodding his head to a sinuous beat blaring over the speakers.

headline: Daily Report: Another Setback for RIM
text: Research in Motion announced it was further delaying the introduction of its new line of BlackBerry smartphones until 2013, a setback that has further eroded confidence in the company that had once established its phone as the standard issue of corporations across the globe.

headline: Friday Reading: What the Health Care Ruling Means for Medicare
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Announcing … the Winner of India Ink’s Finance Minister Contest
text: On Wednesday, India Ink invited you to submit your “application” to be the next finance minister of India. Well, the entries are in, and we at India Ink have been sifting through what you sent us. You may read all of them in the “Comments” section at the end of the original article.

headline: What’s in a Coup?
text: MONTREAL — Judging a change in government in Latin America used to be simple: either tanks were rolling down the street it was a coup and that was bad, or there’d been an election and it was democracy and that was good. No more. These days, the lines between a coup and a legitimate transfer of power are getting a lot blurrier.

headline: Matches to Watch: Day 5
text: For the fourth straight day, there are leftover matches from the previous day. One of Tuesday’s matches to watch, the second-round encounter between Sam Querrey and Milos Raonic, was halted because of darkness with the two knotted at one-set all and 3-3 in the third. They have just resumed on No. 1 Court. Here’s a fresh slate of five new matches to watch on Friday. Players’ seeds are in parentheses.

headline: An App That Prompts Children to Do Their Chores
text: As a preteen I was fascinated with a neighbor’s chore board. I recall a rotating wheel, color coding and a list of household assignments. It showed who was to do what task that week, and it had a points system that led to rewards.

headline: Gilt Groupe’s Recipe for Success in Mobile
text: Companies that aren’t successful yet in mobile (like Facebook) could take some tips from Gilt Groupe. The New York-based start-up, best known for selling designer clothing, expects 40 percent of its revenue on the July 4th holiday to come from its iPhone and iPad apps, says the company’s chief executive.

headline: Questions on Special Ed? There's a Hot Line for That
text: One of the many big changes coming to the city schools next year is the revamping of the special education program, which calls for more inclusion classrooms, with special education classes reserved for only the most severely disabled students. Now comes word that the city is creating a hot line so that parents can easily reach education officials if they have questions or problems with their child's placement or services that can't be addressed by the school.

headline: Ristretto | The Old Guard Is New Again
text: Sometimes the old guard is also the avant-garde. Richard Serra still has his edge, ditto Patti Smith — the two artists surfaced in the 1970s, flirted with mainstream success and seem more comfortable hanging out at the fringe of the establishment than taking a seat at the table.

headline: Credit Suisse Expects Profit in Second Quarter

text: 7:38 p.m. | Updated An investor group led by Sony closed its $2.2 billion acquisition of EMI Music Publishing on Friday, creating a giant force in music publishing, the unglamorous but lucrative side of the music business that deals with songwriting rights.

headline: Afghanistan Woos Foreign Investors in New Delhi
text: It was a standing-room-only crowd Thursday at the Taj Palace Hotel’s Shahjehan Hall, as Afghan government officials and business executives wooed foreign investors at an all-day conference in New Delhi.

headline: Second Bail Hearing for Zimmerman
text: Updated | 2:25 p.m. A Florida judge heard more than two hours of arguments and testimony on Friday at the second bond hearing for George Zimmerman, who is awaiting trial in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Rush to Report Health Care Ruling, and ‘As the Anchor Turns’
text: On the day of a historic Supreme Court ruling on the health care law, two cable news outlets — CNN and Fox News Channel — briefly made themselves the story, Brian Stelter writes. In trying to synthesize a complicated ruling, both reported that the court had struck down the law’s individual mandate, when in fact, in a 5-to-4 vote, the court had upheld the mandate as a tax; at CNN, the mistake lingered for six minutes.

headline: Markets Cheer Europe’s Bailout Plan
text: It was the relief rally that beleaguered investors were waiting for as a new plan to tackle the European banking crisis sent stock markets in many countries to their best day of the year on Friday.

headline: University Will Not Investigate Fracking Institute
text: The State University of New York at Buffalo has rebuffed calls for an investigation of the work of a new institute it founded that is devoted to the study of shale gas drilling, saying it is defending the freedom of faculty members to conduct research.

headline: Digital Diary: Talking About Death Online
text: Here’s a shortlist of the things I post about on the Internet on any given day of the week: the latest Rihanna remix, excerpts from interesting bits of writing around the Web, GIFs that made me crack up at my desk.

headline: When the Lights Go Out
text: KARACHI — For the first time in his 25 years of cleaning homes in Karachi’s posh residential neighborhoods, Ijaz Bashir has to break his own rules: he asks his employers for an advance on his salary. Owing to prolonged power outages, food supplies are rotting in his warm fridge. Pakistan faces a shortfall of 5,733 megawatts — out of a nationwide requirement of approximately 19,000 megawatts — and power cuts for up to 20 hours a day are common. “It’s my own fault,” Ijaz says. “I should have remembered not to buy perishable items in bulk.”

headline: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Junya Watanabe Men’s
text: Paris

headline: Champions of Verse
text: Sports fans are not necessarily renowned for their literary tastes — their passions oft running less to soulful ruminations than to beer-fueled stadium chants — so Olympics observers may be flummoxed by the sudden proliferation of poetry related to the 2012 Games. This weekend, international poets have converged on London to orate in 50 languages at a festival called Poetry Parnassus, with 100,000 copies of their collected work to be dropped by helicopter on the venue by the Thames. Another poetic project, “The Written World,” will feature a poem from each of the 204 competing Olympic countries read live and broadcast daily by the BBC. And verse has been engraved on plaques of stone, metal and wood emblazoned at strategic points throughout the Olympic Park, for the edification of athlete and spectator alike.

headline: Up Front
text: With two novels published and a third arriving next month, Jonathan Evison — who reviews Anna Keesey’s “Little Century” this week — has already made big noise as a writer. Before he turned to books, though, he made a different sort of big noise: as the lead singer of a 1980s Seattle punk band called March of Crimes. “My life as a rock ’n’ roller was dead sexy,” he said in a recent e-mail: “Four sweaty teenage dudes in a run-down van. A lot of sleeping on questionable sofas. A lot of doing other stuff on questionable sofas. Getting paid in pot. All in all, a lot like my first book tour.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: VICTORY: The Triumphant Gay Revolution,  by Linda Hirshman. (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) Written with knowing finesse, this expansive history of gay rights from the early 20th century to the present draws on archival records and interviews.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Times: Oh, so that’s why tomatoes are often so shiny and flavorless! — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Paperback Row
text: ONCE UPON A RIVER,  by Bonnie Jo Campbell. (Norton, $15.95.) Campbell’s first novel, “Q Road” (2002), told the story of Rachel Crane, an isolated and determined young woman in Kalamazoo County, Mich. This follow-up is the story of her mother, Margo, herself a difficult and willful young woman, in rural Michigan in the late 1970s. Raped by an uncle at 15, Margo develops a taste for hunting that turns her small world upside down and leaves her adrift as she evades both her relatives and the authorities.

headline: America’s Portraitist
text: In 1934, Thomas Hart Benton, purveyor of muscular scenes of American life, was the country’s most famous painter and one of the very few ever to have his picture on the cover of Time. In 1949, Jackson Pollock, painter of abstract drips and swirls, appeared in a four-page spread in Life teasingly headlined “Is He the Greatest Living Painter in the United States?” Yes or no didn’t really matter: he was the nation’s new art star.

headline: Grevers Will Swim the 100-Meter Freestyle
text: OMAHA – Matt Grevers was surprised to hear that he had been scratched from the final of the 100-meter freestyle. As it turns out, he wasn’t.

headline: Man Behind the Music
text: Kuk Harrell, a vocal producer for singers like Justin Bieber and Rihanna, reveals his process for coaxing superstar performances out of his clients.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Kolor
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: I Refuse to Let Child Abuse Define Me
text: I was booked solid from 8:30 a.m.  to 2:16 p.m., so as I trekked down the hallway to the next room where I’d be speaking, I ate a few bites of my apple. The health classes were 43 minutes long, 41 after a few kids wandered in late and the teacher reminded everyone to hand in their nutrition projects by Friday. This was the second year I’d volunteered as a guest speaker at this high school, and today they were making sure I reached every last senior.

headline: The Upstarts’ Empire
text: LONDON

headline: Cooking for My Fat Dad
text: Two days before my 13th birthday, my younger sister, April, was cast as an orphan in the national touring production of “Annie,” the Broadway musical. My sister was going on the road with my mother for a year. I was to stay home with my father.

headline: Anatomy of an Olympic Gold Medal Race
text: The American men’s eight rowing team ended a 40-year gold-medal drought in 2004. That team’s coxswain, Peter Cipollone, revisits the historic win in Athens.

headline: Friday Flashback: A Missed Call, a Silver Medal
text: It was about as close to a Dream Team as you can get in women’s soccer. Mia Hamm. Brandi Chastain. Julie Foudy. Carla Overbeck. Kristine Lilly. Joy Fawcett.

headline: Business Day Live | June 29, 2012
text: European leaders reach an agreement on bailouts. | Winning the battle, but losing the war with health care ruling. | Is the hype over cloud computing justified?

headline: You Like Me. You Really, Really Like Me.
text: Mark Zuckerberg has come a long way since 1998.

headline: Painting by Numbers
text: I am an artist, and a colleague recently asked me to make her a painting. It will be an arduous process, and I’m charging her my usual freelance rate. In the next few months I must give a wedding gift to the same colleague, who is not a close friend. Am I right to charge her for this painting and subsequently buy a wedding gift of lesser value? I feel that the value of the painting is too high for me to give away to someone I am not close with. S.L., CHICAGO

headline: The 6.17.12 Issue
text: COCAINE INC.

headline: My Home in Africa
text: In fourth grade, my best friend and I made a papier-mâché map of Africa for Sister Ernestine. Our bumpy, still-wet continent was so unwieldy that we had to carry it to school like a plank of Sheetrock, one of us at each end. The map assignment, messy and time-consuming, bolstered our teacher’s campaign to turn us into travelers: Be brave, children! The world is an amazement!

headline: Who Made That Baby Bjorn?
text: Bjorn Jakobson — himself a father of young children — went into the baby-equipment business after returning to Stockholm from a 1961 trip to America with a “baby sitter” bouncer chair. At first, the fledgling entrepreneur was unable to persuade any Stockholm department store to take a chance on the contraption. After finally selling two to one department store, he was reduced to sending in his mother to buy them (the store then ordered more). It was only then that Jakobson thought to appeal to pediatricians — and struck upon the formula that would guarantee his success: clean-lined design, with a progressive medical seal of approval. Ultimately the chair would become a hit worldwide and a standard item on baby registries. But it was the Hjartenara (Close to the Heart) baby carrier, introduced in 1973 and later known as the Baby Bjorn, that made him a household name.

headline: The Taming of the Stooge
text: I saw you perform in Portland, Me., back in the ’80s when you opened for the Pretenders. I had never experienced anything like it. You actually licked my hand.  I was just really happy to be in Maine — I’m a travel enthusiast. And I’m glad I got away with a lick. But those were pretty mainstream shows. It was an introduction to another part of the American public. I remember there was one gig on that tour at Penn State, and it looked just like “Children of the Corn” — these penetrating blue Anglo-Saxon eyes staring at me from beneath identical corncob-colored crew cuts.

headline: Bunny Yeager, the Pinup’s Pinup Maker
text: Tall ladders and long legs.

headline: Business Day Live: The Health Care Ruling and Commerce
text: European leaders reach an agreement on bailouts. Also, winning the battle, but losing the war with the health care ruling; and, is the hype over cloud computing justified?

headline: Government Considers Investigating G.M. Crossovers for Headlight Failures
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is considering whether to investigate hundreds of complaints about low-beam headlight failures on almost 250,000 Saturn Outlooks and GMC Acadias from the 2007-9 model years.

headline: Fjord Hopping in Norway
text: Encounters with plunging rock, glassy water and a rumored ghost on a trip through fjord country.

headline: Driven to a Fjord Lately?
text: WE were in a motorized rubber boat on the edge of Sognefjord, the longest fjord in Norway, slicing through water that resembled dark green glass. The sky yawned ever wider as the docks of the small town of Balestrand fell behind. All five passengers were wearing puffy, black full-body suits that worked as life jackets and, the captain assured us, would sustain us for two days if the untoward occurred.

headline: Tim Burton’s ‘Frankenweenie’ to Open Fantastic Fest
text: Fantastic Fest, a film festival in Austin, Tex., known for its genre films and attention-getting stunts, will have Disney joining its party this year. That studio’s film “Frankenweenie,” directed by  Tim Burton, will have its world premiere as the opening-night film.

headline: Tour Is Shaping Up as a Bicycle Race That Is Built for Two
text: LIÈGE, Belgium — The Tour de France has every reason to be lackluster this year. Alberto Contador, professional cycling’s best rider, is serving a doping ban. Andy Schleck, a perennial contender, is sidelined with an injury. And the Olympic road race in late July, just days after the Tour’s end, has some competitors thinking about saving themselves for the one-day event.

headline: This Week’s Movies | June 29, 2012
text: The New York Times film critics on “People Like Us,” “Ted,” and “Magic Mike.”

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buys Rest of Grupo Modelo, Maker of Corona Beer
text: 11:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: Vacation Sabotage: Don’t Let It Happen to You!
text: I’M heading into another vacation, and I’m nervous. I don’t want to kill again.

headline: A Rape Survivor Now Ministers Body and Soul
text: RALEIGH, N.C. — On the Sunday after she was attacked, Marcia Mount Shoop went to church. The descendant of three generations of ministers, she knew of few more familiar and reassuring places. The Presbyterian Church of Danville, Ky., was the congregation in her hometown, where just about everybody recognized her as the daughter of two college professors, a star miler on the high school track team.

headline: From Woman to Girl, an Introduction to Finance
text: A FEW weeks before the school year ended, I visited Westover School in western Connecticut to sit in on a class aimed at encouraging teenage girls to consider careers in finance.

headline: ‘Star Trek’ Shuttle Brings $70,000 at Auction
text: The “Star Trek” shuttle craft from the U.S.S. Enterprise sold Thursday at auction for more than $70,000 after a bidding war, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Indie Shops Land on Chicago’s Gold Coast
text: Several homegrown stores have taken root recently in the glossy downtown district.

headline: Buy on the News
text: There is an impressive rally around the world, after Europe again came up with a solution that will prevent immediate disaster.

headline: Interest in European River Cruises Soars
text: IN Europe, where waterways were the roadways of the pre-automobile past, major cities from Amsterdam to Vienna reside on rivers. Centuries after those rivers were supplanted by railways and highways as main thoroughfares, there is renewed interest in traveling on them: at least 11 new river cruise ships are launching this year, and a similar number is expected next year. Over the last five years, many lines have doubled their capacity.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Editor: “Tips for an Easier Family Getaway” (June 17): Years ago, when our children were young, we used to travel to Europe for my husband’s work. In preparation for the overnight flight, we would dress our kids in their pajamas at the airport and then let them run around the unoccupied parts of the waiting area. Our fellow travelers thought we were horrible parents, I am sure, and dreaded being seated anywhere near our children, who were acting like maniacs. The payoff? By the time we boarded, the kids were so tired they fell asleep right away — and stayed that way throughout the entire flight.

headline: Hotel Review: Inn at the Presidio in San Francisco
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: In Singapore, Taking Butter With Your Coffee
text: WADING through the plume of smoke from a thicket of men puffing away outside, my father and I made our way to the only available table in sight.

headline: A Princess Has to Eat
text: AS soon as Kelly Macdonald, 36, the voice of the Scottish princess Merida in Pixar and Disney’s new animated feature “Brave,” finishes filming a season of the HBO television series “Boardwalk Empire” in New York, she returns to her home city, Glasgow. There, she loves to scout out new restaurants and visit old haunts.

headline: Restaurant Report: Café Florie in Savannah
text: Café Florie is a soul-food shack that has captivated Savannah’s foodies since opening in December in a blue-collar midtown neighborhood on the edge of the historic district.

headline: Video: Anatomy of a U.S. Olympic Gold Medal Race
text: “A lifetime dream realized” is how Peter Cipollone, the coxswain for the men’s eight team that won the gold medal at the 2004 Olympics, describes the historic victory that ended a 40-year Olympic medal drought for the United States men’s rowing team.

headline: Image of the Day: June 29
text: A crane removes the carcass of an elephant after it was hit by a truck on the outskirts of Delhi.

headline: London Underground | An Architectural Summer

headline: Redefining Success and Celebrating the Ordinary
text: I’VE been thinking a lot about the ordinary and extraordinary lately. All year, my sons’ school newsletters were filled with stories about students winning prizes for university-level scientific research, stellar musical accomplishments and statewide athletic laurels.

headline: Presidential Geography: Georgia
text: Today we continue our Presidential Geography series, a one-by-one examination of the economic and demographic peculiarities that drive the politics in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. Today’s stop: Georgia, the Peach State. FiveThirtyEight spoke with Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University, and Charles S. Bullock III, a professor of political science at the University of Georgia.

headline: Mets’ Murphy Finds Peace Amid Setbacks
text: LOS ANGELES — There is an image of Daniel Murphy, shaped slowly over the length of his professional baseball career, as a man unsettled.

headline: Live Coverage Sunday of Italy-Spain Title Game
text: The Goal blog will provide live coverage of the Euro 2012 championship game between Spain and Italy on Sunday at 2:45 p.m. ET. Jack Bell will offer commentary and analysis of the match.

headline: In the Light of Day, Querrey Defeats Raonic
text: WIMBLEDON, England — In a hard-serving battle stalled by darkness, Sam Querrey of the United States surged back from a first-set stumble and defeated Milos Raonic of Canada, 6-7 (3), 7-6 (7), 7-6 (8), 6-4, on Friday in the second round of the 2012 Wimbledon Championships.

headline: Italians, Their Confidence at a Record Low, Sharply Cut Their Spending
text: AS their recession deepens, Italians appear to be more worried about the future than they have been in decades, and they are responding by closing their purses and wallets.

headline: An Early Education in Finance
text: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week is about a program, Investing in Girls, that aims to open up finance as a possible career path for teenage girls. The program, run by a nonprofit group, pairs girls in the program with woman who are working in finance.

headline: Fear Rises in Italy
text: Economic conditions are weakening across the board in Italy

headline: Know That Venue: Beach Volleyball at the Horse Guards Parade
text: Those at a beach volleyball match at the London Olympics this summer will find themselves seated smack dab in the middle of history.

headline: And the Oscar Goes to…the Bouffant!
text: It gives Hollywood hairstylists only a whisker of added industry respect, but there is celebrating nonetheless in the celebrity blow-out and bun-knotting world: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences this week decreed that the Oscar for makeup will henceforth be called the “makeup and hairstyling award.”

headline: Dreams of Prosperity
text: Millions of Americans loved Ulysses S. Grant, but, as so often with love, the relationship can be hard to understand from the outside. Grant did not woo the public. A rumpled man, he seemed shorter than he was. When he opened his mouth, cigars and whiskey went in, but few words came out. His critics, then and now, have disagreed over whether he should be condemned primarily as a brute of a general or a dupe of a president.

headline: After Shutdown, Tour Buses Vie For Local Riders
text: Six large, white tour buses rolled up last Sunday morning looking as if they were bound for a casino, and, in fact, some of them bore the faded logos of Atlantic City casinos. But the buses that appeared on this particular block in Queens for the first time were not picking up gamblers. They were loading passengers in Chinatown in Flushing who were traveling to Chinatown in Manhattan.

headline: Strauss-Kahn and Wife Separate, Tabloid Reports
text: PARIS — She has been more than the faithful wife. She has been the fiercest of defenders.

headline: Human Bonds
text: “Who are your people?” It’s a question exchanged often by black Southerners to identify kith and kin. But few remember that its roots can be traced to the after­math of the Civil War. Once emancipated, former slaves desperately searched for family members who had been sold away from them. Their plaintive entreaty — “Help me to find my people” — provides the title and the subject of Heather Andrea Williams’s latest book.

headline: Against the Grain
text: “And the house of Israel called its name Manna: and it was like coriander seed, white; and the taste of it like wafers made with honey.”

headline: Little Estate on the Prairie
text: It is in names like Victoria, Rugby and Runnymede (a dinky little community long since buried beneath a sea of Kansas wheat) that modern travelers across the great plains of the Midwest can still catch a glimpse of the lost — and deeply weird — world that has been lovingly excavated and brought back to life in “Prairie Fever,” by Peter Pagnamenta, a writer and documentary producer for the BBC.

headline: Ex and the City
text: One of the pleasures of Christopher R. Beha’s 2009 memoir, “The Whole Five Feet: What the Great Books Taught Me About Life, Death, and Pretty Much Everything Else,” in which he sets out to spend a year reading the Harvard Classics, is being diverted, along with him, into another, much more personal project. “The book I intended to write,” he tells us, “was essentially a comedy, about a feckless, somewhat lost young man who shuts himself away from the modern world.” But when he learned that his adored aunt had terminal cancer, his reaction to her suffering created a very different book: his love for her became both his subject and his inspiration. On the way to a radiation treatment, when he asked permission to write about her, she gave her approval. “Hearing the pleasure in her voice,” Beha confesses, “was one of my happiest moments. . . . I allowed myself to think that, no matter what happened . . . I could save her in some way if I got everything down just right on the page.”

headline: Pioneer Woman
text: There are staples we’ve come to expect in the American frontier novel: unlikely homesteaders, stoic farmhands and scheming railroad men; unchecked ambitions, mysterious pasts and vigilante justice. Winter always seems to be looming. Or summer. Somebody will probably divulge a secret to a horse or a child. Mishandled, these western standbys can seem like threadbare, dime-­novel clichés. Handled deftly, these conventions are the stuff of American myth. The line is finer than one might think. While Anna Keesey’s first novel, “Little Century,” may walk a well-worn path, the familiar is rendered vividly through fluid and restrained prose, solid plotting and a keen eye for detail.

headline: In Obama’s Victory, a Loss for Congress
text: With the landmark Supreme Court ruling on Thursday, conservatives and libertarians lost their legal battle to overturn the Obama administration’s signature health care legislation. But they may have won a bigger war.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: THE SEA IS MY BROTHER  By Jack Kerouac.  Da Capo, $23.

headline: Hopelessly Devoted
text: Jeffery Deaver is a man of many skills. And XO (Simon & Schuster, $26.99), a heart-in-mouth thriller about a country-pop star being stalked by an obsessive fan, owes a great deal to one of them — his previous career as a folk musician, a vocation Deaver hasn’t entirely given up. He wrote the lyrics to the country-­western songs that figure in the story, and he’s given his informed passion for country music to many of his characters.

headline: Defending the Union
text: Fergus M. Bordewich has written a lively, attractive book about a fearsome and almost intractable crisis: the tangle of issues involving expansion and slavery that confronted the political class of the United States in 1850. Sectional passions ran so high then that there was a real danger of secession, perhaps even civil war. But thanks to two senators — Henry Clay and Stephen Douglas — and numerous bit players, Congress adopted a package of compromises that allowed the country to stumble along in one piece for 11 more years.

headline: Destroying the Union
text: Civil War fever is raging. Last year, the 150th anniversary of the outbreak of the war, brought a number of war-related books, ranging from microstudies of a specific time or theme (including Adam Goodheart’s “1861: The Civil War Awakening,” and Amanda Foreman’s “World on Fire: Britain’s Crucial Role in the American Civil War”) to macro-­overviews of the whole era, most notably David Goldfield’s “America Aflame: How the Civil War Created a Nation.” The micro/­macro phenomenon continues this year, with the appearance of a single-theme book like Fergus M. Bordewich’s “America’s Great Debate” (see the opposite page) and, from the macro perspective, Allen C. Guelzo’s sweeping “Fateful Lightning: A New History of the Civil War and Reconstruction.”

headline: Inside the List
text: MADE IN AMERICA: Dave Eggers’s new novel, “A Hologram for the King,” cracks the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 16. The book (our review is coming soon) is about an American businessman hoping to land a big deal in Saudi Arabia, and one of its recurring themes is the decline of American manufacturing. So it’s noteworthy that Eggers — who publishes his own books, through his McSweeney’s publishing house — devotes a paragraph of his acknowledgments to the staff of Thomson-Shore printers in Dexter, Mich., where the novel was produced.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Geoffrey Ward talks about his new book, “A Disposition to Be Rich”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Holland Cotter discusses the artist Thomas Hart Benton; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: As I.P.O. Shows Life, ServiceNow Jumps on First Day
text: If ServiceNow is any indication, the market for initial public offerings isn’t entirely moribund.

headline: Photos of The Moment | Dries Van Noten
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: WikiLeaks Enters the Music Business
text: In its never-ending quest to find ways to circumvent corporate and governmental power, WikiLeaks has announced that it is getting into the music business, releasing a CD called “Beat the Blockade” that is chock-full of songs about this whistle-blowing Web site’s struggles with Washington and American banks.

headline: Romney Ad Shows Hillary Clinton Attacking Obama
text: President Obama and his Democratic allies love to tweak Mitt Romney with unflattering quotations from his rivals in the primaries.

headline: The Perfect Hamburger
text: You don’t have to fire up the outdoor grill to make a great hamburger. Melissa Clark shows how to make a perfect hamburger indoors.

headline: This Week’s Movies: June 29
text: In today’s edition of This Week’s Movies, our critics look at three Hollywood movies that are neither sequels nor based on a comic book. Stephen Holden offers his thoughts on the drama “People Like Us,” starring Chris Pine and Elizabeth Banks. A. O. Scott weighs in on “Seth MacFarlane’s comedy “Ted,”, about a toy bear who comes to life and turns out to have a filthy mouth. And Manohla Dargis offers a revealing and positive review of “Magic Mike,” Steven Soderbergh’s film starring Channing Tatum as a male stripper. Full reviews for these and all of this week’s movies can be found here.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A rotating cast of food trucks will be parked each day from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. through Labor Day at the New York Public Library, West 40th Street at Fifth Avenue, as part of the exhibition “Lunch Hour NYC.” ’Wichcraft, which has two carts at the library, will promote the exhibit Friday by offering free samples of its peanut butter and jelly sandwiches in the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building on the first floor in Astor Court. The triple-decker sandwiches will be sold for $3 while the exhibition is on display.

headline: After Years of Injury, a Strong Character Emerges
text: On Thursday morning I ran into Alex Zotov, a former Davis Cup player for Belarus. He played college tennis at Vanderbilt University, where I coach the women’s team, and we started talking about Brian Baker. A year ago Zotov and Baker were playing in the Middle Tennessee Tennis League.

headline: BMW and Toyota Sign Agreement to Collaborate on New Products and Technologies
text: As vehicle manufacturers seek less expensive ways to produce desirable products and meet ever more stringent corporate fuel economy standards, teamwork is a recurring theme. On Friday, BMW Group and the Toyota Motor Corporation announced a collaborative effort aimed at developing new products and advanced-powertrain technologies.

headline: 18 Moments: Elite Gymnasts, Behind the Scenes
text: Sometimes social media can feel like a giant, all-encompassing scrapbook your great aunt is forcing you to flip through — again. But if that book were pared down, there would be be some real gems. If you take away the noise of a thousand hash tags and the cacophony of fans, you’re left with a glimmer of what it is like for elite gymnasts competing for a spot on the Olympic team.

headline: At the Apollo, the Jacksons Pay Homage to Their Roots and Their Brother
text: There was no avoiding thoughts of Michael Jackson when the Jacksons — his four older brothers, Jermaine, Marlon, Tito and Jackie — brought their Unity Tour to the Apollo Theater on Thursday night. Just over three years after Michael Jackson’s death, it was a show that treaded carefully between respect and exploitation.

headline: Health Care: Solidarity vs. Rugged Individualism
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Oscar Pistorius Fails to Meet Qualifying Time for Olympics
text: Oscar Pistorius, trying to become the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, failed to meet the qualifying time for the 400 meters and now must hope to be selected for South Africa’s 4x400 relay team.

headline: From Uruguay, a Sandwich to Rival the Reuben
text: AS the story goes, an Argentine lady on vacation walked into a beach-side restaurant in Punta del Este, Uruguay, and requested a sandwich, specifying it be made with chivito, grilled baby goat, the kind she could get back home.

headline: Yo-Yo Ma and Alvin Ailey Part of Dartmouth’s Culture Celebration
text: Yo-Yo Ma, John Lithgow, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra are among the artists to be featured in Dartmouth College’s special celebration of culture for the 2012-13 academic year, the New Hampshire college announced Friday.

headline: It’s Like a Burger, but Perhaps (Gasp!) Even Better
text: If you’re in the mood to grill, why not make a chivito, the summery steak sandwich featured in this week’s City Kitchen column? Just as easy to make as a hamburger, but arguably better, it’s the iconic national snack of Uruguay. Essentially a chivito is a somewhat overstuffed affair with a thin slice of grilled beef on a roll, layered with burger-type accompaniments, and extras, like cheese, roasted peppers, grilled onions, egg, ham or bacon. But the best versions are small and restrained, or at least that’s the way I like them. (There are gargantuan chivitos as well, but I’d rather eat two little ones.)

headline: Business Day Live | Health Care Ruling
text: June 29, 2012 - Winning the battle, but losing the war with health care ruling.

headline: What a Pile of Star Wars Figurines Has to Do With Smart Movie-Making
text: This week in the magazine, Adam Davidson ponders how the film industry actually makes money. In their perfect world, studios could predict what moviegoers want. In reality, they’re stumped. A vast majority of movies fail to break even. So how have studios managed to make a steady profit, even as they churn out a steady stream of flops? Davidson writes that “they have found ways to, as they say, monetize the ancillary stream by selling pay-TV and overseas rights, creating tie-in video games, amusement-park rides and so forth.” Forget the art of making movies. The true artistry is in promotion, distribution and merchandise. Here are a few blockbusters that changed the way studios make money.

headline: Phelps Gives a Tip of the Golf Cap to Watson
text: OMAHA – Through the magic of Twitter’s direct messaging, Michael Phelps has traded cellphone numbers with the golfer Bubba Watson. If he could, he’d happily trade sports. Phelps, who took up golf after his record eight-gold-medal performance at the 2008 Olympics, said: “I love watching him. I try to hit the ball really far, but he just crushes it.”

headline: Ethics Inquiry Exonerates Governor In Lobbying
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Gov. Nikki R. Haley was cleared of wrongdoing on Friday by state lawmakers who investigated assertions that she had violated ethics rules when she was a state representative by lobbying on behalf of two businesses she worked for.

headline: One Woman No One Wants to Tangle With
text: Tyler Perry has his Madea character on a leash in the latest movie in that franchise, “Tyler Perry’s Madea’s Witness Protection,” a comedy that’s too late to the Ponzi-scheme party to be topical, and not outrageous enough to take advantage of its own setups.

headline: Superdupermarket, a Pop-Up in Chelsea
text: An unusual pop-up indoor market, called the Superdupermarket, will open in Chelsea for three days, July 13 through 15, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Friday and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturday, with a great gaggle of high-profile vendors, many of them first-timers in New York.

headline: Q. and A.: What Does the Health Care Ruling Mean for You?
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on the health care law has raised many questions for consumers about what it means for their coverage.

headline: Sweden 1912: Now That’s Fencing!
text: One hundred years ago the Summer Olympics were held in Stockholm. As we count down the days to London 2012, we’ll take a look back at what was happening at the Games a century ago.

text: WIMBLEDON, England — Sloane Stephens of the United States stepped to the service line with her back against the wall, trailing by 5-2 in the final set on Thursday at the All England Lawn Tennis Club.

text: The Look: French Twist. A white dress with ornate appliqués and a period bustle at the hips is prepped for Versailles.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects F.C.C. Appeal in Janet Jackson Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday refused to consider an appeal by the Federal Communications Commission of an appeals court ruling that overturned the agency’s fine against CBS for its broadcasting a fleeting image of Janet Jackson’s breast during the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show.

headline: Populence Has Popcorn for All Seasons
text: Maggie Paulus, who plans to open Populence, a sophisticated popcorn store, on Wednesday in Greenwich Village, said she might actually have popcorn in her genes.

headline: Book Review Podcast: An Early Practitioner of the Ponzi Scheme
text: In the New York Times Book Review, T. J. Stiles reviews “A Disposition to Be Rich,” by the historian Geoffrey Ward, which tells the story of Ferdinand Ward — the author’s great-grandfather. Ferdinand Ward was the Bernie Madoff of his day, practicing the Ponzi scheme in the late 1800s, before the crime had that name. His exploits bankrupted many, including Ulysses S. Grant, who was persuaded to become a partner in Grant & Ward, a Wall Street brokerage house, only to see it collapse in 1884. Mr. Stiles writes:
