headline: Think Like a Doctor: Too Sick to Smoke Solved!
text: On Thursday I challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 48-year-old man with shortness of breath, fatigue and lesions on his shoulder and thigh bones. Nearly 200 people wrote in, and nearly one in six, or 34, people figured it out.

headline: United States Ambassador to Kenya Quits Before Audit Release
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The American ambassador to Kenya, once a confidant of President Obama, abruptly announced on Friday — days before the release of a stinging internal audit — that he was resigning, citing “differences with Washington.” His departure will leave the top embassy post vacant at a time when Kenya is increasingly being drawn into a battle with militant Islam.

headline: Bread Pudding for Dinner or Dessert
text: I still remember the first time I tasted bread pudding — a heavenly concoction conjured up at Commander’s Palace in New Orleans. But it was only recently that I learned how easy it is to make bread pudding at home after trying a chocolate-pumpkin bread pudding recipe from the vegan chef Chloe Coscarelli. (Coconut milk makes it irresistible.)

headline: CUNY Building at Ground Zero Nears Completion After 11 Years
text: It took much less time to build the second Fiterman Hall than it took to tear down the first one.

headline: Settlement in Gulf Spill Cleanup Dispute
text: During the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, I walked along mucky beaches in Louisiana watching cleanup and rescue crews scrape down the sand and hunt for oil-soaked wildlife. The crews’ effectiveness was questioned at the time, but from a logistical standpoint the vast deployment seemed impressive.

headline: Singer in U.S. Metal Band Arrested in Fan’s Death in Czech Republic
text: The lead singer with the metal band Lamb of God has been arrested on manslaughter charges in the Czech Republic in connection with the death of a fan who jumped onstage two years ago during a concert, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Rousseaumania Runs Rampant in France
text: ERMENONVILLE, France—– Jean-Jacques Rousseau may have been born in Switzerland (Geneva in fact, in 1712) and not in France. But that tiny geographic detail has not kept the citizens of the Oise, the region north of Paris where Rousseau lived briefly and died, from celebrating the philosopher all year as a national hero.

headline: Second Shocker Lurks, but Federer Slips By
text: WIMBLEDON, England — On the eve of his match against Roger Federer, Julien Benneteau tuned into the biggest upset at Wimbledon in 25 years and thought to himself, “Why not me?” Why couldn’t he knock the tennis world off its axis, as Lukas Rosol did on Thursday with a stunning victory against Rafael Nadal? Why couldn’t Benneteau topple Federer, as he did the last time they played, two and a half years ago in a hardcourt tournament in Paris?

headline: Yes, Liberals Won
text: There was a widespread and bipartisan impulse, in the wake of yesterday’s health care ruling, to cast John Roberts’ exercise in political finesse as a potentially significant long-term win for conservatism. Variants of this case were made by George Will and Jay Cost on the right, Jonathan Chait and Tom Scocca on the liberal side of things, and many others besides. By affirming a limited and limiting reading of the Congress’s Commerce Clause powers even as he upheld the individual mandate for other reasons, Will wrote, the Chief Justice “rejected a constitutional rationale for the mandate … that was pregnant with rampant statism,” and laid the groundwork for a future in which the judiciary returns to its pre-New Deal habit of “viewing congressional actions with a skeptical constitutional squint, searching for congruence with the Constitution’s architecture of enumerated powers.” From the left, Chait made a version of the same point, worrying that a Roberts-led Court would now be able to advance a much more limited understanding of federal power by “a process of slow constriction,” rather than “one suddenly and transparently partisan attack.” The right lost the battle, these and other writers agreed, but thanks to Roberts’ savvy it could well be on its way to winning the larger size-of-government war.

headline: The Field Hockey Chronicles: A Warm-Up With Some Fire
text: Michelle Kasold, a striker, has been a member of the United States field hockey team since 2006 and will compete in her first Olympics in London this summer. She will be writing regularly for the 2012 London Olympics blog. This is her second post.

headline: New Media’s Old Problem
text: Women dominate social media. They’re the biggest and most engaged users of social networking sites in America, according to the Pew Research Center.

headline: Will the Whale Swallow JPMorgan’s 2nd-Quarter Earnings?
text: JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, has given many assurances that, despite suffering big losses on botched derivatives trades, the bank will report solid second-quarter profits.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Batwoman’ Ascends to the Top
text: At No. 1 on our hardcover list this week is Vol. 1 of “Batwoman,” which reprints the first six issues of the continuing series. Like every other mainstream title from DC, “Batwoman” was part of the “New 52,” an overhaul of the company’s characters to spruce them up for a new generation. In September, my colleague Adam Kepler and I reviewed the first issue. Having read the first arc, my impression of the book is very much the same: The artwork by J.H. Williams III, who writes the series with W. Haden Blackman, is simply stunning. The richly detailed drawings and exciting page designs cause my eyes to linger far longer than they do on most comics.

headline: Even if News Corp. Divides, the Murdochs’ Control Is Undiluted
text: Wall Street has cheered Rupert Murdoch’s decision to separate News Corporation’s underperforming newspapers from its lucrative entertainment assets.

headline: When Staying in School Is a Bad Move
text: Last night’s N.B.A. draft showed that it is probably not a good idea for players with lottery-pick potential to stay in school. The traditional argument for turning pro as soon as possible has long been: What if a significant injury occurs while a player is (ostensibly) competing for free in in the N.C.A.A., and he never gets the big N.B.A. payday? But the case of Perry Jones III, the Baylor star and subject of my cover article in the magazine on March 8, 2011, raises another question: What if the nagging doubts raised by a promising player in Year 1 of college solidify, in Year 2, into conventional wisdom?

headline: Disney Media Unit to Distribute Oscar Telecast Abroad Through 2020
text: LOS ANGELES—The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences shored up the future of the Oscars with another long-term agreement: This one, announced by the Academy on Friday, extends through 2020 a deal under which Walt Disney’s media unit distributes the Academy Awards telecast abroad.

text: Heard the one about the pregnant man? Yes, you probably have. But what if the joke turns out to be that he’s basically the same as a pregnant woman? Oh, you’ve heard that one, too?

headline: Vindication for Maligned Lawyer in Justices’ Decision

headline: Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, Republicans Stay on Message
text: Whatever you think about the House Republicans, you have to admit they stay focused. Yesterday, while the rest of the country was distracted by the Supreme Court decision on the most important piece of social legislation in generations, the House Republicans were concentrating on the big picture – the personal and political destruction of President Obama.

headline: Lauryn Hill Pleads Guilty in Income Tax Case
text: Lauryn Hill, the Grammy-winning singer, has pleaded guilty in New Jersey to charges that she did not pay income taxes for three years running, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Hill, whose solo debut album in 1998 established her as a major figure in hip-hop and R&B, admitted in federal court in Newark on Friday that she had not filed tax returns from 2005 to 2007, a period during which she earned more than $1.5 million. She faces a maximum of one year in prison on each count. Ms. Hill, 37, of South Orange, N.J., has kept a low profile since she put out the critically acclaimed “Miseducation of Lauryn Hill” in 1998, focusing instead on raising her six children. She did make an appearance at Hot 97’s Summer Jam concert this year.

Bandier, the chairman of Sony’s current publishing arm, Sony/ATV. The deal reunites Mr. Bandier — a veteran of music publishing and one of the music industry’s great characters — with the EMI catalog, which he ran for 17 years before going to Sony/ATV in 2007.

The unit, No. 70B, has views of Central Park, the Hudson River and virtually the entire Manhattan skyline.

But he watched it somewhere almost as good: “It was compelling viewing at the center-of-the-Italian universe, Mama’s of Corona, Queens, surrounded by antipasto and cannolis and friends.” Read his full report here.

headline: Allies With an Eye on Each Other
text: THE history of French-American relations is a tale of an old alliance that bends with shifting cultural and political winds but never breaks, and whose mutual fascination, shared interests and ideological divides have created a host of competing narratives about how one side views the other.

headline: Sifting Through Songs for the Man Underneath
text: IT’S there, fat and juicy, right on the track listing of the new Chris Brown album, “Fortune” — a song called “Don’t Judge Me.” Since pleading guilty in 2009 to assaulting Rihanna, his girlfriend at the time, Mr. Brown has released three good to very good albums, each an opportunity for listeners to scavenge closely for hints about his inner life. A song called “Don’t Judge Me” screams out for deeper consideration. Maybe Mr. Brown is finally ready to share.

headline: Is the Family Dinner Overrated?
text: DOZENS of studies in the past decade have found that teenagers who regularly eat dinner with their families are healthier, happier, do better in school and engage in fewer risky behaviors than teenagers who don’t regularly eat family dinners. These findings have helped give dinnertime an almost magical aura and have led to no small amount of stress and guilt among busy moms and dads.

headline: E.P.A. Official Who Resigned Over ‘Crucify’ Comment Joins Sierra Club
text: Al Armendariz, who resigned from the Environmental Protection Agency at the end of April after it came to light that he had suggested that the agency “crucify” polluters to deter others, is joining the Sierra Club to work on its campaign to end the use of coal.

headline: With Two Retirements, a Ballet Era Ends
text: THEY have been the Apollo and Dionysus of American Ballet Theater. Ethan Stiefel is fair, elegant, a superbly refined classicist whose dancing retains an innate purity and clarity of line even in virtuoso display. Angel Corella is Latin, full of fire and bravura, a dancer whose technical feats and intense presence can make audiences leap to their feet with delight.

headline: Adele Says She Is Pregnant
text: Adele, the 24-year-old British singer who swept the Grammys this year, announced on Friday she is pregnant with her first child. She wrote on her Web site that she and her boyfriend, Simon Konecki, 36, a former financier and a co-founder of Life Water, “are expecting our first child together.”

headline: Rainbow Trout, Both Rare and Ubiquitous
text: Late June and early July mark the peak of the biggest run of wild salmon left in the world. The sockeye salmon migration of Bristol Bay, Alaska, can number more than 40 million fish, and the commercial fishing industry in the region is worth more than $400 million. During this peak salmon period, Paul Greenberg, author of the New York Times bestseller “Four Fish,” will be blogging remotely via satellite as he travels down the Stuyahok River with the Alaska outfitter Mark Rutherford. This year’s fishing trip is particularly relevant. At present the Environmental Protection Agency is weighing whether to prevent the permitting of a 10 billion-ton copper and gold mine in this remote sensitive area, something many fishermen fear could spell the end of this magnificent run. —Mark Bittman

She filled me in on her future movie projects: “Big Sur” (about Jack Kerouac) and “CBGB” (about the rock club), and revealed how she keeps her skin glowing and her figure fit.

headline: An Audience for Free Spirits in a Closed Society

International acclaim followed, including two Oscar victories.

headline: Following Bliss With Beethoven
text: JUST as actors traditionally portray King Lear later in their careers, pianists usually wait to record Beethoven’s complete piano sonatas. Offering the 32 works at 24 is a bold move, but the Korean pianist H J Lim, who performed the complete cycle in Paris in 2010, felt ready. She demonstrates her mettle with a set of distinctive, passionate interpretations, which landed at No. 1 on Billboard’s classical chart shortly after EMI Classics released them on iTunes in May.

headline: Your Burger Will Thank You
text: I’M no slouch when it comes to D.I.Y.-ing it. I confit my own tomatoes every August. I make ricotta, batch up habanero sauce, simmer jams and marmalades and put up homemade maraschino cherries. Once I even churned butter, though that was really an accident involving overbeaten whipped cream.

headline: How to Pan-Grill a Burger
text: This week’s video about pan-grilling the perfect burger (though there are tips that apply to burgers on the regular grill, too) is a companion to my column about DIY condiments. Basically it’s my week to revel in burgers, toppings and all.

headline: A Mortgage Rate Beginning With a 3
text: Mortgage rates have never looked this good. They are at about 3.81 percent for a second week, a record low. But who gets that rate? What does it actually take to secure a mortgage rate that begins with the enviable number 3?

headline: On Celebrities Good and Bad, or Alec Baldwin
text: SOME years ago, I was standing behind Alec Baldwin at a party while talking with another writer, when the actor turned around and offered us a cigar with the most postmodern smile I have ever seen. “Have a petit robusto,” he said. He exaggerated the “eet” in “petit” ever so slightly, a delicate emphasis that had the effect of making comically explicit the absurdity of applying “petit” to “robusto.” When he got to the latter word, he pronounced “robusto” one syllable at a time — “Ro. Bus. Toe.” — with such ironic vigor that cigar, celebrity and offer collapsed into layers of self-parody. He was a famous actor playing a regular guy who was acknowledging the fatuity of being a celebrity even as he was savoring its every moment. You felt he really, genuinely, wanted to be liked, at the same time as he couldn’t have cared less whether you liked him or not.

headline: Grevers Passes on Shot at 200 Backstroke Medal
text: OMAHA – Matt Grevers, who nearly set a world record in the 100-meter backstroke earlier this week, is capable of winning an Olympic medal in the 200-meter backstroke at next month’s London Games. That’s not the issue. He knows it. His coach knows it. No doubt Ryosuke Irie of Japan, another strong medal contender, knows it.

headline: ‘Soft Patch’ on Jobs, With Election on Horizon
text: With the unemployment report for June due in one week, and the general election a bit more than four months away, the job indicators for the pre-election season remain fragile, according to the latest weekly analysis from Moody’s Analytics.

headline: In Traffic? Next Time, Use an App
text: EVERYBODY complains about the traffic, like the weather, but no one does anything about it. That may finally be changing as new technology to track cars becomes more widely used.

headline: Can Balotelli Make Italy Less Racist?
text: “After two goals Thursday that catapulted Italy to the Euro 2012 final, Italians immediately anointed a new national hero,” writes Elisabetta Povoledo, “Mario Balotelli, whose biography neatly encapsulates the changes that have swept Italian society in the past 20 years —as well as its contradictions.”

headline: Comme des Garçons: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Comme des Garçons Men’s
text: Paris

headline: The iPhone Turns 5. Here’s What It Wrought.
text: Friday is the fifth anniversary of the sales debut of the iPhone, the phone that changed everything. Love it or hate it, Apple’s touch screen handset has made an impact on some aspect of your life — whether it’s how you work, communicate with friends, plan your day or read the news.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Hong Kong, Spain and the West Bank.

headline: Strong Ratings for Debut of Sheen’s ‘Anger Management’ on FX
text: Charlie Sheen is still “winning.” The debut of his new series, “Anger Management,” was the most-watched series premiere in FX history in total viewers.

headline: Katie Holmes Files for Divorce From Tom Cruise
text: Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, whose high-profile marriage has been tasty fodder for the Hollywood celebrity media, are getting divorced.

headline: Layers of Mediums, and Movements and Stories
text: BECKET, Mass. — No one can accuse Morphoses of false advertising. Founded in 2007 by Lourdes Lopez and Christopher Wheeldon, this contemporary ballet company reinvented itself following Mr. Wheeldon’s departure in 2010, shifting from a structure with a permanent artistic director to a rotating system. Ms. Lopez stayed, but choreographers and dancers came in, project by project.

headline: Egyptian President-Elect Addresses Nation From Tahrir Square
text: On the eve of his official inauguration as Egypt’s first Islamist and civilian president, Mohamed Morsi read a symbolic oath of office in front of tens of thousands of supporters at Tahrir Square.

headline: Nations United in Song
text: The Friendship Ambassadors Foundation, based in Greenwich, Conn., has promoted cultural exchanges between American and international arts groups since its founding in 1973. This year the group, which often focuses on youth initiatives, has produced the inaugural Rhythms of One World festival, a series of choral performances featuring adult and children’s choirs from Trinidad and Tobago, South Africa, Luxembourg, Canada, Australia, Norway and the United States.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 29
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Qualifying for Mortgage Rates That Start With a 3
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses what it actually takes to qualify for the current incredibly low mortgage rates. This week, the 30-year rate stood at about 3.81 percent (with no upfront fees, known as points).

headline: Chic in Review | Make That Hedi Slimane for YSLA?
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Reviewing the Coda
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Bradley Berman reviews the 2012 Coda, a purely electric, no-frills compact sedan that is priced within range of the more luxurious Ford Focus Electric and Nissan Leaf.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 29
text: More Photographs

headline: A Prince Siegfried Ready to Move On
text: When Angel Corella first joined American Ballet Theater in 1995, his charms were impossible to deny: He was as ebullient as a puppy. His smile could melt an iceberg. And Mr. Corella, born in Madrid, could dash off pirouettes as easily as others breathe.

headline: With Chilled Mâconnais Wines, Seafood Is in Order
text: The best of the Mâconnais wines expressed citrus and minerals balanced by a touch of grapy richness. They can handle many dishes, especially in warm weather.

headline: Trying to Take D.C. United Back to the Top
text: 9:37 p.m. |Update

headline: Givenchy: Spring 2013 Menswear
text: Paris

headline: Confidence Fell in June, but Business Picked Up
text: Reports released Friday showed a mixed picture of the economy, with consumers still feeling pinched but business activity picking up.

headline: Givenchy Men’s
text: Paris

headline: The Well, a Pioneering Online Community, Is for Sale Again
text: Before Facebook, Twitter, Google — even before the Web — there was The Well, an online discussion community founded in Northern California in 1985 that became home to the early denizens of what used to be called cyberspace.

headline: Germany Cedes Some Ground in Steps to Bolster Euro
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders went a surprising distance on Friday toward restoring confidence in the euro, taking a significant step toward economic integration and easing market pressure on Spain and Italy, as what appeared to be a new coalition of forces pushed Germany to bend.

headline: In Europe, Looking for Patient Bond Buyers
text: LONDON — As Europe slouches toward a monetary union that aims to force euro area governments to cede control over their banks and budgets, a crucial question remains unanswered: how to persuade investors to buy, and hold for the long term, the bonds of at-risk economies like Italy and Spain.

headline: Israeli Coalition Divided on Military Conscription for Ultra-Orthodox Jews and Arabs
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s supersize coalition was showing its first serious signs of stress on Friday in its quest for a more universal draft system in Israel.

headline: Two Cities on the Verge of Devouring Themselves
text: LONDON — Words don’t come easily in the opening moments of “Minsk, 2011: A Reply to Kathy Acker,” the lacerating new work from the Belarus Free Theater. The latest offering from this astonishing troupe in exile, which recently closed at the Young Vic Theater, begins with individual performers walking up to a microphone. Each pauses, hesitates, starts to unfold a flag, play a flute or merely glance at a wristwatch. Then, before any of them utters a sound, they are dragged out of sight by a troop of stocking-capped men.

headline: Dawn Powell’s Diaries for Sale on the Internet
text: If it weren’t for Tim Page, the diaries of Dawn Powell wouldn’t be worth much. Mr. Page, a Pulitzer Prize-winning former music critic at The Washington Post (and before that a frequent contributor to The New York Times), has pretty much single-handedly engineered a revival of interest in Powell, a New York novelist greatly admired by critics like Gore Vidal and Edmund Wilson, but whose career, even during her lifetime, was always in need of a jump start. When she died in 1965, most of her 15 novels were out of print. She was buried in a potter’s field.

headline: After Delay and Debate, Regulators Support New Rule
text: Regulators agreed to support a draft proposal to regulate overseas derivatives trading, a move that comes just days after internal wrangling delayed the plan and prompted several last-minute changes.

headline: Paris Men’s: Gingham and Roses
text: Day 3 of the Paris men’s shows saw pick stitching and country club colors at Junya Watanabe, Holy Communion at Givenchy and visions of The Dude at Comme des Garçons.

headline: Profiles of Mexico’s Presidential Candidates
text: Voters in Mexico thought they had a good take on the presidential candidates going into Sunday’s elections, but each candidate has confounded expectations.

headline: Sophisticated Touches at a Family Place
text: DON’T let the uninspired name for this restaurant fool you. Entering its sixth month, King Street Restaurant and Bar does have a few issues to address — like a high noise level and its policy of only accepting reservations for groups of six or more. Apart from these, however, there is much to like about this restaurant: its food and décor, both considerably less boring than the name would suggest.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review: Calls for Regulations and Resignations
text: A Madoff brother pleaded guilty, and the British took Barclays to task. JPMorgan’s trade loss could reach $9 billion. News Corporation planned a split, and Microsoft acquired a social network. A look back on our reporting of last week’s news in finance.

headline: Yahoo’s General Counsel Resigns
text: Yahoo said on Friday that its general counsel, Michael J. Callahan, had resigned,  the latest executive change under the Internet company’s interim chief executive, Ross Levinsohn.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 29
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include karaoke among Albany legislators, the primary races in New York and the long-awaited reopening of McCarren Park pool.

headline: The Mâconnais, Poised for Rediscovery
text: THE wines of the Mâconnais region of France are nobody’s idea of a new discovery. Back in the 1980s, when I began drinking a lot of wine, they were a reliable source for fresh, crisp, inexpensive whites, and they have remained so.

headline: Restrained in Décor, Distinctive in Flavor
text: AT first glance, there was nothing on the menu at New Haven’s Miso Japanese Restaurant to distinguish it from other sushi menus in the area. Open since 2002, the Ninth Square establishment offers an assortment of traditional Japanese and fusion appetizers, and the usual list of sushi and sashimi entrees, and cooked dishes. The selection of special rolls is smallish and the seafood variety is not unusual.

headline: Finally, Somewhere to Wear Lederhosen
text: A GERMAN restaurant is not the most likely newcomer to the East End: dumplings and sauerbraten do not seem to go with beaches and bikini-clad bodies. But Montauk, that bastion of fishermen and families, is not the Hamptons, and Zum Schneider Montauk, which opened in May, fits right in.

headline: Expressive Pinks Flourish
text: Rosés are blossoming throughout Long Island wine country. At least 32 of the region’s more than 50 producers make them, and Channing Daughters, with eight, is in the vanguard.

headline: Unesco Adds Nativity Church in Bethlehem to Heritage List
text: JERUSALEM — The Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, along with the Pilgrimage Route, was added on Friday to Unesco’s World Heritage List, a move that was celebrated by Palestinians who hailed it as a significant political and diplomatic achievement as much as a cultural one.

headline: After Dead Heat in 100, Felix and Tarmoh Nearly Tie in 200 Semifinals
text: EUGENE, Ore. — History repeated itself at the Olympic trials on Friday. Sort of.

headline: Soccer’s Lost Boys, Stranded in Istanbul
text: The light was dim, and the room dank. The photographer Jason Andrew descended the basement steps. A single television displayed the English Premier League match between Chelsea and Tottenham, as flickering light of the television illuminated nearly a dozen dark faces in the room.

headline: Fire Up the Pit: My Brisket Can Burn Yours
text: Vernon, N.J. — The doubters are out there, and Scott Reid has heard them.

headline: Students Are Suspended for Verbally Abusing School Bus Monitor
text: The four boys who taunted a 68-year-old school bus monitor from Rochester, N.Y., prompting outcry over bullying when a video of their insults went viral, have been suspended from their middle school for one year, school officials said on Friday.

headline: June 29: Obama Rises to 67.8 Percent
text: President Obama, who got good news in Thursday’s health care ruling, received more overnight on Friday when European leaders agreed to terms on a bank bailout. That sent the S.&P. 500 up by 2.5 percent on the hopes that this will reduce some of the downside risk in the economy.

headline: Deal Gives Knicks Lift in Effort to Re-Sign Lin
text: Jeremy Lin and Steve Novak will keep their so-called early Bird rights under a settlement reached Friday afternoon, giving the Knicks a huge boost on the eve of free agency.

headline: Finding Inspiration in a Borrowed Past
text: An update might be in order for the term “new media,” which was invented a few decades ago to describe video and other forms of digital art. It is not imperative, however, that this be done for “New Media: New Forms” at the Montclair Art Museum, since most of the works by the 13 artists in the show employ familiar technology and strategies endemic to contemporary art, like sampling, appropriating and remaking older artworks.

headline: A Round Robin of Partners and Movement
text: Cherylyn Lavagnino’s new “Triptych” has many fine ingredients. For the dance’s outer segments, American Virtuosi, an ensemble of Baroque specialists (including two countertenors) led by Kenneth Hamrick at the harpsichord, plays Couperin and Biber. In between, taped music by the composer Scott Killian provides both contrast and continuity. And throughout, 11 skilled dancers keep the stage aswirl with elegant, complex patterns.

headline: White House Releases Staff Salary Report
text: The White House submitted to Congress a list  of its staff members and their salaries on Friday, giving people in Washington their annual opportunity to marvel that some of the nation’s most powerful government officials are paid roughly the same as first-year associates at big New York law firms.

headline: European Team Championships in Dublin
text: Surely the most imaginative bidding decision made at the European Team Championships in Dublin occurred in the diagramed deal.

headline: Lance Armstrong Charged With Doping by U.S. Agency
text: The United States Anti-Doping Agency has officially charged Lance Armstrong with a violation, accusing him of doping during most of his cycling career and participating in a doping conspiracy.

headline: George Clooney Will Attend Swiss Fund-Raiser for Obama
text: The actor George Clooney will headline a sequel to the blockbuster fund-raiser he hosted this year to benefit President Obama’s campaign.

headline: 5 More States Get Waivers From Education Law Rules
text: The Obama administration granted waivers to five more states seeking relief from key conditions of the No Child Left Behind education law on Friday. In exchange, the states agreed to enact new standards and evaluate schools and teachers based on students’ academic progress.

headline: A Symbiotic Relationship of Art and Conservation
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — One afternoon last month, Susan D’Alessio, a landscape painter, stood at her easel on a sandy spit of land overlooking Scallop Pond, in the Southampton hamlet of North Sea. “There’s two big babies in there,” she said, pointing to an osprey nest atop a tall pole in a salt marsh nearby. A couple of minutes later, as if on cue, a pair of swans glided by in the pond.

headline: How Egypt’s Army Won
text: Cairo

headline: No Zombies, Just a Pint and an Aria
text: The dead walk the earth this Sunday night — and on PBS, no less.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Paint-On Batteries and Facebook’s ‘Want’
text: Some interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web on Friday. See more here.

headline: 2 Women Found Shot to Death in Burning Apartment
text: Firefighters called to a fire in a building in Manhattan’s Chinatown on Friday found two women lying in a smoke-filled ground-floor apartment. After carrying them outside, the firefighters determined that both women were dead. But they had not been killed by the fire; they had been shot before it started, the authorities said.

headline: Consumer Questions on Health Care Act, and the Answers
text: Q. Now what? The law is upheld, so where does it go from here?

headline: In Guilty Plea, Peter Madoff Says He Didn’t Know About the Fraud
text: Peter B. Madoff, the former No. 2 executive at Bernard L. Madoff Securities, stood before a judge on Friday and admitted to committing numerous crimes.

headline: Obama Visits Colorado as Firefighting Progresses
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — As President Obama arrived here on Friday to tour the aftermath of the most destructive wildfire in Colorado history, fire crews said they were slowly hemming in the blaze and beginning to reopen a few neighborhoods where residents had fled gales of ash and smoke.

headline: Mexico Seems Poised to Embrace Party It Ousted in 2000
text: MONTERREY, Mexico — Vicente Fox exulted in victory 12 years ago over the autocratic, often corrupt party that ruled Mexico for 71 years, sipping Champagne from a balcony overlooking supporters euphoric over the arrival, finally, of true democracy.

headline: Governor Reappoints Trustee Who Ousted University President
text: The governor of Virginia on Friday reappointed the University of Virginia trustee who played the lead role in ousting the university president, a move that was reversed this week.

headline: Enforcement a Little Fuzzy on Elmos
text: In 2010, a man dressed as Elmo materialized in Times Square, posing for pictures with children before rudely shaking down the parents for $5, $2, or whatever. Passers-by said he smelled bad.

headline: Florida Judge to Rule Next Week on Zimmerman’s Bid for Release
text: MIAMI — A month after he ordered George Zimmerman back to jail for misleading the court about his finances, a Florida judge heard arguments on Friday on whether Mr. Zimmerman, Trayvon Martin’s killer, should be freed again.

headline: Christie Limits Legislature’s Scrutiny of Halfway Houses
text: Gov. Chris Christie on Friday curbed an effort by the New Jersey Legislature to improve oversight of the state’s system of large, privately run halfway houses.

headline: After Genocide, Stifled Dissent
text: Antwerp, Belgium

headline: A Mexican Showman Trots Toward the Exit
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — El Padrino, a 21-year-old horse with a white mane befitting a rock star, seemed tired and mad, but his owner understood.

headline: Fortune’s Wheel Casts Mismatched Friends Together
text: Pat Sajak is always so nice to the contestants on “Wheel of Fortune.” And you have to believe that he’s at least partly sincere, because you can tell when he thinks someone is an idiot. Considering that Mr. Sajak has become America’s sweetheart (not to mention rich and famous) mostly by telling strangers whether they have correctly guessed a letter of the alphabet, he is a strong candidate for most likable human being on earth.

headline: U.S. Reaches Out to China, but Not for Naval Maneuvers
text: BEIJING — As the United States’ top military commander for Asia and the Pacific wrapped up a four-day tour of China on Friday, a large multinational maritime war exercise hosted by the United States was getting under way in the waters off Hawaii. China was not invited.

headline: Wal-Mart Suspends Supplier of Seafood
text: Wal-Mart Stores has suspended one of its seafood suppliers in the South as an advocacy group for foreign workers pressed the retailer to improve working conditions there and at a dozen other suppliers cited for hundreds of federal labor violations.

headline: Italy’s Prime Minister Nudges German Chancellor Toward Growth
text: ROME — At the summit meeting of European Union leaders in Brussels early Friday morning, Germany’s leader, Angela Merkel, found herself facing a tenacious opponent, one who in the course of an exhausting night of bargaining finally forced the Iron Chancellor to blink. Even more surprising than that was the identity of her antagonist: Mario Monti, the soft-spoken technocratic prime minister of Italy whom Ms. Merkel had helped to install in office.

headline: Vamping With Nora
text: So frequently the wrong people die.

headline: N.Y.U. Plan to Expand Has Critic in Neighborhood Star
text: They were called to testify in small groups, given about two minutes each to say their piece about New York University’s expansion plan.

headline: Life and Death of the Beach
text: MANY of us have childhood memories of the beach. For members of the baby boom generation, who grew up in the golden age of American beach culture, those images are typically idyllic: pure, clean sands, peaceful, paradisiacal. I myself was born a bit earlier, and my own recollections of the beach — at Atlantic City on the Jersey Shore during World War II — are quite different. I remember a wreck-littered, oil-stained strand that bore witness to the dangers lurking just offshore.

headline: Matches to Watch: Day 6
text: For the first time since we started spotlighting matches, we have no carryovers into the next day of play. Here are five fresh picks for Saturday to refill your clean plate. Players’ seeds are in parentheses.

headline: French Masters in a Sylvan Setting
text: AS its name suggests, Maverick Concerts does not offer a conventionally grand stage. Set in a romantic, barnlike theater amid 100 acres of tall trees and farmland in Woodstock, its charm is largely rustic, and the theater, while lovingly restored, is lacking in some state-of-the-art technology and space — it seats just 230 people indoors and, weather permitting, another 150 on benches outside. In fact, to hear Alexander Platt, the concerts’ music director, tell it, the summer festival is a modest affair. As he prepared recently for Maverick’s 97th season, on the theme of a “Tour de France,” Mr. Platt sought to play down any suggestion that he would offer an extensive survey of the French musical literature.

headline: Iranian Says Nuclear Talks Have Reached ‘Critical Point’
text: Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations said Friday that negotiations with the big powers over the disputed Iranian nuclear program had reached a “critical point,” implicitly raising the possibility of failure, because of the new regimen of harsh economic sanctions that have just been imposed on his country by the United States and European Union.

headline: Rooting Out Police Corruption
text: IN 1970, Mayor John V. Lindsay appointed Whitman Knapp to lead an investigation into the Police Department. Prompted by articles in The New York Times about the whistle-blower Frank Serpico, the commission set out to uncover proof not only of serious crimes committed by an “incorrigible few” (the so-called meat eaters) but also of a widespread culture of bribery among “grass eaters” who indulged in “everyday graft.”

headline: Dream to Nightmare
text: The College World Series wrapped up on Monday and the Arizona Wildcats were crowned college baseball’s national champions. Despite the elite talent of the participants in the series, many of the graduating seniors will move on to new lives without baseball. Only a select few can make a profession out of the game, and they will have a new set of expectations for themselves — and from their future baseball employers — once they sign on that dotted line.

headline: Corrections: June 30
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Google unveiled a new wireless home media player, Ann Curry announced her exit as a co-host of the “Today” show and News Corporation announced that the company would be split.

headline: On the Road, Cheers for a Kenyan and His Cause
text: Kajiado, Kenya

headline: Merkel Gets Parliament to Approve Euro Deals
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany rushed back to Berlin and secured the necessary majority to pass the European Union fiscal pact and the permanent European bailout fund on Friday, despite what was viewed at home as a stinging defeat in the previous night’s negotiations in Brussels.

headline: White House on the Pamunkey
text: On June 28, 1862, in the midst of the Seven Days battles outside Richmond, smoke billowed in the distance as Confederate cavalrymen advanced toward the Union’s main supply base at a plantation called the White House, located on the Pamunkey River. Robert E. Lee’s daring decision to seize the offensive against his enemy’s right flank had exposed the Union supply lines and forced George McClellan to make a fateful decision of his own: to abandon the White House and burn whatever his troops could not take with them.

headline: For Opponents of Health Care Law, No Easy Road to Repeal
text: WASHINGTON — Minutes after the Supreme Court ruled to uphold most of the health care law, Congressional Republicans vowed to use every ounce of their legislative muscle to repeal it on their own.

headline: Christie Signs Budget, but Also Vetoes Pieces
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey used his line-item veto power on Friday to prune the budget passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature.

headline: First, Oatmeal. Later, a Massage.
text: When Ina Garten left her job as a nuclear energy budget analyst for the Carter administration to open her tiny specialty food shop, the Barefoot Contessa, in Westhampton, N.Y., in 1978, she began a domestic-arts empire that is still evolving. Ms. Garten, 64, has been the star of the Emmy-winning “Barefoot Contessa” on the Food Network since 2002; in 2006 she formulated a line of designer edibles, known as Barefoot Contessa Pantry, with her business partner, Frank Newbold. Ms. Garten, the author of many cookbooks, lives in East Hampton with her husband, Jeffrey Garten, 65, a professor of business at Yale; the couple also have apartments in New York and Paris.

headline: Lottery Numbers
After a Bizarre Journey, a Stolen Dalí Is Returned
text: The way it was stolen was unusual. So was the way it was returned.

headline: For a 1950s TV Evangelist, a Step Toward Sainthood
text: Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, who died in 1979, does not fit the stereotype of a Roman Catholic saint. Famous for his evangelizing television program in the post-World War II era, he was dramatic and humorous, not humble and retiring. He even won an Emmy.

headline: Obama, for the Win!
text: Republicans are apoplectic. They’ve lost again.

headline: Coughlin Has One Last Chance
text: OMAHA — One more race. One more chance.

headline: A Truck Is No Match for His Teeth
text: MIKE GREENSTEIN, 91, strode through the lobby of his apartment building in Rockaway, Queens, where the usual afternoon gang was gabbing away.

headline: KB Home Cuts Loss; Its Shares Rise 12.6%
text: Shares of KB Home, the Los Angeles-based home builder that caters to first-time buyers, rose the most in three years Friday after the company reported a narrower quarterly loss as it sold more houses at higher prices.

headline: It’s Time to Set Up Exchanges
text: Now that the health care reform law has been ruled constitutional, it is imperative that as many states as possible move aggressively to establish a centerpiece of the reform structure: new insurance policy exchanges for people who lack affordable coverage through an employer. Federal subsidies will be available for those with low or moderate incomes.

headline: Mourning the Wit and the Woman
text: SHE could have mastered the medium if she had chosen to, tailored as it is to pithy turns of phrase and incisive observations.

headline: Pressure Rises With Heat in Con Ed Negotiations
text: While New Yorkers try to keep their heads cool during this weekend’s heat wave, they may also want to hope that those running the final negotiations between Consolidated Edison and its biggest union do the same.

headline: Track Town USA and the Meet It Loves Most
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Minutes after Ashton Eaton set a world record in the decathlon at the Olympic track and field trials last Saturday, he paid homage to the sellout crowd at Hayward Field, the storied track at the University of Oregon where the 10-day meet is being held.

headline: U.S. Court Ruling Allows Religious Groups to Use Schools for Services
text: A federal judge ruled on Friday that religious groups cannot be prohibited from using public schools to hold services, rejecting the argument that such use violates the Constitution’s requirement to keep church and state strictly separate.

headline: Very Unfriendly Way to Respond
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh, dear. Things may get a bit dicey with today’s puzzle, so if nobody minds, I’m going to set down a couple of ground rules for the discussion:

headline: Afghanistan: Insurgents Kill 10 in Attacks on Villages
text: Insurgents attacked three villages in the Kamdesh district of Nuristan Province near the Pakistan border on Friday, killing six Afghan security officials and four civilians, Afghan officials said. The fighting lasted for more than 12 hours, and more than 50 houses were destroyed, said Shams Rahman, a border police battalion commander in Nuristan. He said more than a hundred insurgents had stormed the area. A large explosion set off by insurgents outside the district governor’s house killed the district governor’s wife, he said. NATO said that it provided some air support for Afghan security forces involved in the fighting. Coalition ground forces, led by the United States, have withdrawn from the remote province in eastern Afghanistan. In 2009, insurgents attacked two American bases in the Kamdesh district, killing eight Americans.

headline: Voices of the Struggling in Texas
text: Three Texans expressed cautious hope that the health care overhaul upheld by the Supreme Court would bring them much needed help.

headline: Coney Island’s Big Hit
text: Q. I’d like some information about the killing of Joe Masseria, the mob leader also known as the Boss, in 1931. All I’ve heard is that the shooting took place in Scarpato’s Coney Island Restaurant and that Lucky Luciano was supposed to have been there.

headline: From an Operating Table to a Promotion Ceremony
text: Just five months ago, Officer Kevin Brennan lay on an operating table in a Manhattan hospital. He had been shot, point-blank, in the head. Trauma surgeons carefully removed a bullet from the base of his skull. Pumped with morphine, he later drifted in and out of consciousness, as his family maintained a vigil, not knowing if he would live to see his 6-week-old baby grow up.

headline: For Uninsured in Texas, Supreme Court Ruling Adds to Uncertainty
text: PASADENA, Tex. — In an ordinary world, Josh Hebert would have accepted the raises his employer offered.

headline: The Muddled Way
text: Judging from the strong rally in global financial markets, European leaders meeting this week in Brussels managed once again to say and do enough to quell the euro-zone debt crisis. For a day, anyway.

headline: A Handshake in Belfast
text: When Queen Elizabeth II, Britain’s head of state, shook the hand of Martin McGuinness, the former commander of the Irish Republican Army, on Wednesday, it was so simple a gesture. Yet, in the context of the Northern Ireland peace process, it was necessary, even courageous.

headline: Score One for the Gun Lobby
text: The House’s 255-to-67 vote on Thursday to hold Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. in contempt of Congress said more about how far lawmakers will go to pander to the gun lobby in an election year than about any improper conduct by Mr. Holder.

headline: Mom, Dad, This Playground’s for You
text: IT was a classic father-son moment, reversed: The 2-year-old sat and watched patiently as his parent hung upside down from the monkey bars. A few feet away, a white-haired man skipped across an S-shaped metal beam. Another man squeezed his six-foot frame onto a metal rack for situps, and two others hoisted themselves up chin-up bars.

headline: Revisionist History in Abuse Cases
text: Institutional history — who gets to define it, promote it, exploit it, obscure it, distort it — sits at the heart of child sexual abuse charges like those currently unfolding at two of the city’s private schools: Horace Mann, in the Bronx, and Poly Prep, in Brooklyn. And so, too, in a broader sense, does the matter of cultural history itself. A consistent theme in the defensive narrative in these cases — which involve stories of abuse that surface decades after it happened — is that the world then bore little resemblance to the one we occupy now, boundaries were unclearly delineated, and a certain kind of ignorance reigned.

headline: Reluctance in Some States Over Medicaid Expansion
text: WASHINGTON — Millions of poor people could still be left without medical insurance under the national health care law if states take an option granted by the Supreme Court and decide not to expand their Medicaid programs, state officials and health policy experts said Friday.

headline: U.S. Indicts Man Accused of Aiding Al Qaeda in Yemen
text: A man being held in Britain has been indicted in Manhattan on charges that he helped to develop online propaganda for Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen, federal prosecutors said Friday. He is expected to be sent soon to New York. The defendant, Minh Quang Pham, 29, traveled to Yemen and took an oath of allegiance to the affiliate, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, received training from the group and provided it with expert advice and assistance in photography and graphic design, an indictment says. It also says that in April 2011, he worked with an American citizen in Yemen on the propaganda effort, and met with another American as well. The indictment does not identify the Americans, but their descriptions suggest they might be Anwar al-Awlaki, the American-born radical Muslim cleric, and Samir Khan, who helped to produce Inspire, an English-language online magazine published by the group in Yemen. Both men were killed in a drone strike last September.

headline: Dr. Richard Isay, Who Fought Illness Tag for Gays, Dies at 77
text: Dr. Richard A. Isay, a psychiatrist, psychoanalyst and gay-rights advocate who did not admit to himself that he was gay until he was 40, married and a father, and who won a pitched battle to persuade his own profession to stop treating homosexuality as a disease, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: For Obama, a Signature Issue That the Public Never Embraced Looms Large
text: WASHINGTON — On the day President Obama took the final step in turning the Affordable Care Act into law, his senior adviser, David Axelrod, predicted the public would eventually embrace his ambitious effort at health care reform.

headline: Lifeguards Attacked at McCarren Pool
text: An unruly crowd at McCarren Pool in Brooklyn attacked the lifeguards Friday evening, leading the city’s parks department to close the pool early just one day after its reopening.

text: New York Times readers submitted their photos of wildfires that have devastated parts of the western states.

headline: Brigitte Engerer, Pianist With Singular Style, Dies at 59
text: Brigitte Engerer, a Russian-trained French pianist known for her immense sound, prodigious technique and probing musicality, died on June 23 in Paris. She was 59.

headline: Rosol Brought Warrior’s Spirit Into Fifth Set vs. Nadal
text: Lukas Rosol looked out of sorts at the end of the fourth set, as Rafael Nadal clearly had the momentum after breaking Rosol’s serve to even the match at two sets all. Securing the all-important second break meant that Nadal would serve to start the fifth set, which gave him the advantage of serving to go ahead in the score rather than serving to tie the score.

headline: 100 Freestyle Wraps Up, but Relay Isn’t Settled
text: OMAHA — As exciting as the 100-meter freestyle finish was at the Olympic trials on Friday night, it was only the start. Now it could get really interesting.

headline: Six Stages to Watch at the Tour de France
text: Avid Tour de France fans may be disappointed: this year’s race will not feature famed mountain climbs like L’Alpe d’Huez or Mont Ventoux. Tour organizers have said they want to highlight the intermediary mountain stages this year, not just the spectacular summits in the Alps and the French Pyrénées. For the first time since 2007, there are also three individual time trials — totaling more than 100 kilometers, or 62 miles, of solo racing — which will serve to heighten the yellow jersey drama as well.

headline: In Difficult Double, Lochte Bests All Comers
text: OMAHA — Michael Phelps’s birthday is Saturday, and Ryan Lochte was asked what he planned to give him for a gift. He smiled and said, “I’ll have to think about it.”

headline: Wieber Leads at Olympic Gymnastics Trials
text: Jordyn Wieber, the reigning world champion in the all-around, came one step closer to clinching a spot on the United States Olympic gymnastics team on Friday, finishing first in the all-around of the first day of Olympic Trials in San Jose, Calif. With 61.70 points, she leads the second-place Gabby Douglas by 0.30 points.

headline: Would You Watch a Third-Place Game?
text: The first two weeks of a major soccer tournament can be two of the best weeks of a fan’s year. (Wives of those fans, like mine, not so much, but I digress.) Two games a day are a great way to spend an evening, or a lunch hour, or an early morning — depending where you or the games happen to be.

headline: Olympic Trials: June 29
text: Scenes from the Olympic swimming trials in Omaha, Neb., track and field trials in Eugene, Ore. and gymnastics in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Rough Night for Veterans of ’08 at U.S. Gymnastics Trials

headline: Dickey Earns 12th Win as Mets Top Dodgers
text: LOS ANGELES — R. A. Dickey on Friday returned some normalcy to his season. Though, of course, what has been normal for him this year has been anything but routine.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The army will court-martial five of its officers who are accused of involvement in the killing of five civilians in a fake encounter in Anantnag district of Kashmir in 2000, The Indian Express reported. The killings followed the massacre of 35 Sikhs in a village in Anantnag, and the army had labeled the five civilians as militants.

headline: The ‘Busy’ Trap
text: If you live in America in the 21st century you’ve probably had to listen to a lot of people tell you how busy they are. It’s become the default response when you ask anyone how they’re doing: “Busy!” “So busy.” “Crazy busy.” It is, pretty obviously, a boast disguised as a complaint. And the stock response is a kind of congratulation: “That’s a good problem to have,” or “Better than the opposite.”

headline: Talks Come Up With Plan for Syria, but Not for Assad’s Exit
text: GENEVA — Major world powers on Saturday failed to reach a consensus on calling for the removal of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria from power, agreeing instead on a plan for a political transition that seemed to have little chance of implementation.

headline: Macroeconomics and the Centrist Dodge
text: Simon Wren-Lewis says something quite similar to my own view about the trouble with macroeconomics: it’s mostly political. And although Wren-Lewis bends over backwards to avoid saying it too bluntly, most – not all, but most – of the problem comes from the right.

headline: After Storms in Mid-Atlantic, Stifling Heat and Power Loss
text: WASHINGTON —  With temperatures expected to soar on Sunday, about two million customers remained without electricity after a deadly string of thunderstorms whipped through the mid-Atlantic region, downing trees and power lines, and killing at least 12 people, including a 90-year-old woman who died when a tree fell on her house as she slept.

headline: Who’s Running the Ads, and Where

headline: At U.S. Trials, There’s No Swimsuit Issue
text: OMAHA — The waves of technology lapping the Olympic pool this year are ferrying space-age goggles and contoured caps that will never be confused with couture. It is fitting that the head and the eyes are the focal points. With the era of polyurethane racing suits receding, people can once again look at swimmers’ times and rationally assume that they are unaided.

headline: The Perfect Set Is No Myth in the Women’s Third Round at Wimbledon

That is what happened Saturday to Yaroslava Shvedova, who played a flawless set of tennis, the best by a woman in at least 44 years, and did not even realize it.

headline: Syrian Video Activists Plan News Broadcasts to Offer an Alternative to State Media
text: CAIRO — In an interview this week at his home here in the Egyptian capital, the British-Syrian activist Rami Jarrah described ambitious plans to create an Internet news network, with radio broadcasts and live video streams of daily life inside rebel-held territory, to offer an alternative to Syria’s state-controlled media.

headline: 6 Years Later, Still Striving to Get Back to the Majors
text: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — The last time Mark Prior pitched in the major leagues, for the Chicago Cubs on Aug. 10, 2006, he had no children. Now he has three. They have some grasp of what their father does for a living, which has never changed. Prior was a ballplayer then, and he has never stopped thinking of himself that way.

headline: U.S. Bets New Oil Sanctions Will Change Iran’s Tune
text: WASHINGTON — After three and a half years of attempting to halt Iran’s nuclear program with diplomacy, sanctions and sabotage, the Obama administration and its allies are imposing sweeping new sanctions that are meant to cut the country off from the global oil market. Many experts regard it as the best hope for forcing Iran to change its course.

They are good places to escape the desert heat, and in a conservative Islamic culture, they are one of the few places where young couples openly flirt or women smoke cigarettes in public.

text: BEIJING — Millions of high school graduates across China have been furiously dialing telephone hot lines or gathering with family members around the home computer in recent days in a nail-biter of a ritual not unlike that of waiting for a winning lottery number.

headline: Amazon Web Services Knocked Offline by Storms
text: People who tried to watch Netflix on Friday evening saw nothing but red. Instagram users couldn’t upload or view photos. And a number of other Web sites and services were knocked offline. Storms had disrupted Amazon Web Services, which stores vast amounts of data for companies worldwide.

text: BRUNSWICK, Me. — Angus King is the prohibitive favorite to win the open Senate seat in Maine this year, and it is easy to see why.

headline: Horacio Coppola, Evocative Argentine Photographer, Dies at 105
text: Horacio Coppola, whose black-and-white photographs of the cafes, side streets and neon-lit boulevards of Buenos Aires in the 1930s, and of ordinary objects like a typewriter and a doll, introduced avant-garde photography to Argentina, died on June 18 in Buenos Aires. He was 105.

headline: Barry Becher, a Creator of Ginsu Knife Commercials, Dies at 71

headline: For Attorneys General, Long Shot Brings Payoffs
text: WASHINGTON — Few handicappers gave a band of Republican attorneys general much chance of success when they filed a constitutional challenge to President Obama’s health care law just minutes after it was signed on March 23, 2010. Some mocked them, while others largely ignored them.

He was 96.

text: Violent storms engulfed the eastern United States, killing at least 10 people and knocking out power to millions while temperatures across the region reached triple-digits.

headline: No Respite for Liberals
text: ANTON CHEKHOV once remarked that “one must not put a loaded rifle on the stage if no one is thinking of firing it.” In the term that ended last week, the Supreme Court reached a liberal outcome in cases involving President Obama’s health care law, Arizona’s draconian immigration statute and mandatory life sentences for juveniles. But the conservative majority also laid down a cache of weapons that future courts can use to attack many of the legislative achievements of the New Deal and the Great Society — including labor, environmental, civil rights and consumer protection laws — and to prevent new progressive legislation. Far from being a source of jubilation, the term may come back to haunt liberals.

text: There is so much to celebrate about the All-Star Game. From the relay of dominant pitchers to the kaleidoscope of uniforms to the wonderfully inclusive rule that every team must be represented, baseball should be proud of its summer showcase.

headline: I Took a Web Detour, and Now I Feel Better
text: THE Internet is a rabbit hole of distraction. It’s easy to wind up knee-deep in paparazzi photos of Beyonce’s new baby when you intended only to answer a few e-mails.

headline: With Spot in 100 Secure, Jones Turns Attention to Relay

The race is only one lap, but it was not a snap for Jones, who pushed himself beyond exhaustion in finishing second to Nathan Adrian in the 100-meter freestyle Friday night.

headline: In Return to Normalcy, the Free-Agent Market Is Set to Roll
text: Midnight madness returned to the N.B.A. at 12:01 Eastern on Sunday morning — an exhilarating burst of phone calls, texts and multimillion-dollar offers, a jolt of normalcy to end a most abnormal year.

headline: A Trader Who Swerved, and Crashed
text: THE first third of “Octopus,” Guy Lawson’s new book on the 2005 collapse of the Bayou Group hedge fund, is what you might expect: an engrossing tale of the rise of Samuel Israel III, a cocaine-snorting crook who started his firm in the basement of his Westchester County home. If the rest were simply the story of Mr. Israel’s inevitable fall, it would still be a darn good read.

headline: From Dot-Com to Dot-Co
text: I WAS born and raised in Bogotá, Colombia. We fled when I was 15 after my cousin was kidnapped during turmoil in Colombia in the early 1990s. I came home from school one day, and my parents said we had to pack our bags and leave home the next morning.

headline: What Did the EU Summit Accomplish?
text: OK, the summit was clearly an upside surprise: in effect, the Latin bloc forced Merkel to bend, at least slightly. But was it good enough?

headline: Short-Fused and Explosive
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The long diagonal pass floated across midfield, its accuracy all the more remarkable for its distance. Waiting with impeccable timing was Mario Balotelli of Italy, one of soccer’s most gifted and eccentric players. He sprinted past the German defense and turned to meet the ball, nimbly switching directions, backpedaling with the gliding agility of a man on skates.

headline: After Turns on Mound and in Stands, Wise Stars at Plate for Yanks
text: Nine days ago, a struggling Dewayne Wise retrieved the film from his best spring training game in late March. He felt vaguely disjointed and amiss, and he watched the footage of his two home runs that day closely.

headline: Where’s Charlemagne When We Need Him?
text: WRITING some 50 years ago, Archduke Otto Hapsburg, the last pretender to the crowns of Austria and Hungary, warned that economic cooperation alone would not satisfy the peoples of Europe and that European unification could not succeed unless it was imbued with an abstract principle. Only something as mystical, he wrote, as the Holy Roman Empire could give people hope, a sense of religious renewal and combat the pernicious effects of local interest, chauvinism, xenophobia and racism.

headline: To Have (It All) and Have Not
text: FOR years the debate about working motherhood has swung between two poles — the sunny optimism of having it all and the judgmental gloom of the finger-waggers. Now we are in another paroxysm of angst, prompted by a provocative article by Anne-Marie Slaughter in The Atlantic about the impossibility of combining working motherhood with jobs at the pinnacle of power. Yes, her article focuses on the elite. But she raises troubling questions about whether mothers with children at home can wield sustained power in American society — power that some might use to improve the lot of less privileged women.

headline: Joan Dunlop, Advocate for Women’s Health Rights, Dies at 78
text: Joan Dunlop, a global leader in addressing women’s issues who helped prod the United Nations to define a woman’s right to say no to sex as an essential human right, died on Friday at her home in Lakeville, Conn. She was 78.

headline: Showcasing Your Work, in an Online Portfolio
text: Q. Some of your colleagues and friends have created Web sites listing their professional experience, credentials and samples of their work. Should you have some sort of online portfolio, too?

headline: What Really Makes Us Fat
text: A CALORIE is a calorie. This truism has been the foundation of nutritional wisdom and our beliefs about obesity since the 1960s.

headline: The Kindest Cut of Meat Is Ground
text: AS Americans plan their Independence Day barbecues, they should skip the tony sirloins and chops, and opt for what can be the most sustainable, economical, gastronomically flexible and morally responsible cut of meat: ground.

headline: Loneliness of the Long-Distance Walker
text: EUGENE, Ore. — Rarely have so many done so much in front of so few. That is the dynamic that racewalkers face at the Olympic track and field trials.

headline: A Devil for 20 Years, Brodeur Is Expected to Test the Market
text: Zach Parise and Ryan Suter have long been expected to be the top prizes in the N.H.L. free-agent market that opens at noon Eastern on Sunday. But a surprising new name has been added to the mix: that of Martin Brodeur.

headline: A Jobs Boom Built on Sweat in an Age of Belt-Tightening
text: Want to know what the job of the future looks like? Go to the gym.

headline: Reader Comments on my Africa Rising Column
text: My Sunday column is the first from my Win-a-Trip journey 2012, and I wanted it to be an antidote to much of my usual coverage from Africa – wars, famine, genocide, AIDS, and so on. I think those topics are truly important and deserve more coverage, but I believe in periodically reminding everyone that the larger context is a rising Africa that some think is going to be the next Asia.

headline: The World’s Large Dams: Almost 7,000 and Counting
text: Dams can provide hydroelectric power, control floods and direct water for irrigation, but can also create havoc on the local environment.

headline: Despite High Hopes, Match Races Rarely Meet Expectations
text: Near the end of the 1730 edition of John Cheny’s “Historical List of Horse-Matches Run” was a schedule of the next year’s races in England and Wales.

headline: The Dam Boom in the Amazon
text: Rio De Janeiro

headline: The Week in Political Pictures: June 24-June 30
text: Moments from the campaign trail last week, including rulings by the Supreme Court, campaign stops in the South and recovery from fire.

headline: In Chile, Rodeo Rules the Land
text: COLCHAGUA VALLEY, Chile — Up norte, the N.B.A. playoffs are over. The Stanley Cup has been passed around. Baseball is at midseason. And here, as usual, it’s rodeo time.

headline: How Liberals Win
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA has endured much criticism of his legislative skills from his fellow progressives. His conciliatory approach has been compared unfavorably with Franklin D. Roosevelt’s gleeful pugnacity and Lyndon B. Johnson’s relentless arm-twisting. His willingness to strike deals with corporations has been tagged “business as usual.” Many progressives, frustrated over the past three years, have concluded that the political system is fundamentally broken because corporate power has been allowed to suffocate popular liberal policies.

headline: Insider’s View of Changes, From Outside
text: THE NEW YORK TIMES is the closest thing we have in this country to a “newspaper of record.” A year ago I suggested that the paper should do a better job, therefore, of maintaining a record of the articles it publishes. Because of the swift changes wrought by the Internet, I observed, Times articles drift out into digital space in multiple versions. Some articles disappear altogether.

headline: The Price of Health Care
text: “IT is not our job,” Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. wrote in Thursday’s health care ruling, “to protect the people from the consequences of their political choices.” He might just as easily have written, “to protect politicians from the consequences of their political choices.” And now, with the Supreme Court parenthesis out of the way, we can get back to finding out exactly what those consequences will be.

headline: The Radical Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court’s landmark decision upholding the Affordable Care Act was a deft turn by Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., who voted with the court’s four moderate liberals for the first time in a 5-to-4 ruling. Yet, while they upheld the law’s mandate for individuals to buy insurance under Congress’s taxing power, the chief justice joined the four other conservatives to reject that provision under the Constitution’s commerce clause.

headline: A Window on Campaign Abuse
text: The secret world of undisclosed political contributions is in desperate need of sunlight. Public corporations are giving money in support of political candidates without any accountability to shareholders or consumers. Charities are taking tax-deductible contributions and improperly funneling them to strident advocacy groups. All the while, government watchdogs are dozing.

headline: Washington Is Stuck but He’s Getting Out
text: Washington

headline: Yankee Doodle Dandies
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I know what you’re thinking. Here we are with a patriotic puzzle and it’s not even the Fourth of July yet.

headline: Immigrants and Small Business
text: Immigrants are known as entrepreneurial people, for obvious reasons: those with the ambition and energy to uproot themselves and build new lives in a distant land are well equipped to build businesses and the economy, too. That is the common wisdom, anyway, which a new study from the Fiscal Policy Institute strikingly confirms. The study, based on census data, looks at owners of small businesses across the country and paints a broad and detailed picture of immigrant entrepreneurship.

headline: The Wearing of the Green
text: GALWAY, Ireland

headline: A Former Israeli Leader Who Clung to Territories
text: Former Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who clung throughout his life to the belief that Israel should hang on to territory and never trust an Arab government, has died. He was 96 years old.

headline: Taking One for the Country
text: IN my mind, there are two lessons from the Supreme Court’s 5-to-4 decision to support President Obama’s health care plan: 1) how starved the country is for leadership that puts the nation’s interest before partisan politics, which is exactly what Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. did; and 2) the virtue of audacity in politics and thinking big. Let’s look at both.

headline: Action Group for Syria Final Communique
text: Global powers agreed on Saturday to back a plan for political transition in Syria that did not include a specific call for President Bashar al-Assad to step down.

headline: Africa on the Rise
text: MASERU, Lesotho

headline: With Prosperity Elusive, Mexican Voters Focus on the Economy
text: While a minority of educated, skilled workers benefit from the dynamics of global trade, many more Mexicans work long hours, often at several jobs, without progressing.

headline: Pocketbook Issues Weigh Heavily as Mexicans Vote
text: CIUDAD NEZAHUALCÓYOTL, Mexico — Fernando García fondly recalls the late 1990s, when all three floors of his factory in a green row house here held employees sewing and tagging the women’s slacks that his family has been selling for decades.

headline: Sudanese Children in Exile
text: Fleeing the war in Sudan’s Nuba Mountains, a new generation of Lost Boys, and some girls too, is being born.

headline: New Wave of ‘Lost Boys’ Flee Sudan’s Lingering War
text: YIDA, South Sudan — Thousands of unaccompanied children are streaming out of an isolated, rebellious region of Sudan, fleeing a relentless aerial assault and the prospect of famine.

headline: A Day After Violence, Crowds Jam McCarren Pool
text: A day after McCarren Pool in Brooklyn shut down when lifeguards were attacked by unruly teenagers, hundreds of people lined up outside the pool on Saturday, determined to cool off from the blistering heat that again descended on the city.

headline: In Supreme Court Term, Striking Unity on Major Cases
text: WASHINGTON — The last week of the Supreme Court’s term told one kind of story, of a deeply divided court delivering historic victories to the Obama administration in immigration and health care cases. Those decisions, however, obscured a different story about the work of the court, one that unfolded over the last nine months.

headline: U.S. Women Edge Canada in Olympic Farewell Game
text: The United States women’s national team beat Canada, 2-1, on Saturday in Sandy Utah, in its final exhibition game before this summer’s London Olympics.

headline: Few Expect a Positive Change in Drug Violence After Mexico’s Election
text: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — As traffic hums along in this border city, car radios blare the optimistic promises of Mexico’s presidential hopefuls, all of whom say that if they are elected on Sunday, a new country will emerge.

headline: U.S. Women Beat Canada in Final Olympic Tuneup
text: The United States women’s soccer beat Canada, 2-1, on Saturday in Sandy, Utah, in its final exhibition game before this summer’s Olympics, but Coach Pia Sundhage got a scare in the second half when her star striker Alex Morgan limped off with a knee injury. Read more on the Goal blog.

headline: A Century Later, Galveston’s Nod to Jack Johnson
text: GALVESTON — Jack Johnson stood on a pedestal behind Old Central Cultural Center, ready to throw a left hook and then come back with a right.

headline: Texas Lawmakers Warily Watch Mexico’s Election
text: With a mix of trepidation and optimism, Texas lawmakers are closely watching Mexico’s election on Sunday. The expected outcome would return the Institutional Revolutionary Party to power.

headline: Olympic Trials: June 30
text: Scenes from the Olympic swimming trials in Omaha, Neb., track and field trials in Eugene, Ore., and gymnastics in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Learning the Game From Two of the Best
text: After the fall of the Soviet bloc, many Eastern European players settled in the United States and carved out careers as coaches. But none of them were world-championship-caliber players.
